title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Before his New Year's Eve recital at Carnegie Hall, Itzhak Perlman held a sort of preview yesterday afternoon to salute the start of the United Nations International Year of the Disabled. The violinist is a member of the United States committee.

title: Brzezinski's Plans
description: In an appointment to take effect the day after the Reagan inaugural, Zbigniew Brzezinski will join Georgetown University's Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington.

title: No Headline
description: Resumes Talks With Guild Over a New Contract

title: FLOAT MAKERS' ART PARADED AT FAIRS
description: Behind the lavish displays of spectacular blossoms and ingeniously designed floats in the 1981 Rose Parade is a risky and competitive business involving six companies that compete to build the floats that appear in the traditional New Year's Day parade.

title: A Top Executive Elected At Microsonics Corp.
description: Robert F. Bennett, 47, has been elected president of the Microsonics Corporation, which licenses and produces miniature phonographs and records, effective Jan. 5. He will succeed Sam Schulman, 70, who will remain chairman and chief executive officer of the Century City, Calif., company.

title: A Promise to the Neediest
description: ''Poverty may be reduced, but it is still much too prevalent,'' says a note accompanying a generous check to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Its 69-year-old author has now contributed to the fund for 50 years in a row.

title: Large Block of Stock In Alexander's Sold
description: Sol Goldman, a New York real estate investor, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had sold nearly all of his Alexander's Inc. common stock, or 334,800 shares, at prices ranging from $13.09 to $14.75 a share. The block represented 7.4 percent of Alexander's outstanding common.

title: REAGAN'S DESCENDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 20.50-21.50 ** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A Glimpse Of Haig En Route
description: When Colonel Alexander Haig became commander of the Third Regiment at West Point in 1967, his first order was about marching. Every cadet in the regiment, he said, would march with his fingers cocked squarely at the second knuckle, thumb running stiffly along the index finger and pointing ''like an arrow'' to the ground, elbows rigidly locked.

title: IRAN ISSUES NEW THREAT
description: The Algerian intermediaries in the hostage crisis flew home today to discuss with their leaders the latest American proposal before going on to Iran for what could be a decisive round of talks.

title: WNCN-FM IS PUT UP FOR SALE BY GAF
description: The company that saved WNCN-FM five years ago from the fate of a rock-music format is divesting itself of the station, but classicalmusic listeners apparently have no cause for alarm.

title: City Stores Files Repayment Plan
description: The City Stores Company, operator of the W.&J. Sloane furniture stores, said it had filed its proposed plan of rearrangement with the bankruptcy court.

title: I.R.S. Seeking $16.6 Million In Back Taxes From Welch
description: The Internal Revenue Service is seeking $16.6 million in back taxes, penalties and interest from Bernard C. Welch, an alleged thief and the accused killer of Dr. Michael L. Halberstam, a prominent physician and author.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
HAPPY NEW YEAR
description: Ring out the old! Ring in the new! The year of 1980 is through But there are games to be played and races run In the year of 1981. So rally 'round with goblets high, Chanting prosit! Skaal! And mud in your eye! For the mob in sports, every gal and guy In the passing show as it capers by.Ring out wild bells! Sing hey, nonny nonny For the ice queen, Linda Fratianne, For the pig-tailed princess, Tracy Austin, For all the embattled fans of Boston. May another sweetheart like Genuine Risk Come along to charm us; may Carlton Fisk Find there's life after Burleson, perhaps after Lynn. Where the Red Sox are out, are the Yankees in? George Steinbrenner's checkbook has charms for Dave

title: Greschner on Injury List
description: Ron Greschner, the Rangers' high-scoring defenseman, has been added to the injury list.

title: U.S. Says Recall of Fords Still Remains a Possibility
description: Government officials, after announcing a compromise with the Ford Motor Company in a safety case involving transmissions on 20 million Ford cars and light trucks, said today that a recall had not been completely ruled out.

title: MASTECTOMY PATIENTS ARE SAID TO BE AIDED BY TRIPLE-DRUG DOSES
description: Treating women with a combination of drugs after mastectomy to curtail the spread of breast cancer greatly increases their chance of survival, but the medicine must be given in high doses, a study concludes.

title: 1981:A YEAR FOR ARTISTS' CENTENARIES
description: Though not yet a centenarian, I count myself as a longtime centenarist: a collector and celebrator of centenaries, that is to say. And for the centenarist, Jan. 1 is the crown of the year: the moment at which one set of anniversaries goes into the shredder and a whole slew of new ones comes into view.

title: Arizona State On Probation
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association placed the Arizona State football program on probation today for two years. The school had already been penalized by the Pacific-10 Conference for academic violations involving its football program.

title: CYSTIC FIBROSIS STUDY SEES PROMISE IN TEST TO IDENTIFY THE DISEASE
description: The development of a promising screening test for carriers of cystic fibrosis, the most common lethal inherited disease of white Americans, was reported yesterday by medical scientists in Boston.

title: Justice Dept. Seeks Airline Merger Bar
description: The Justice Department urged the Civil Aeronautics Board to reject a proposed merger of Continental Air Lines Inc. and Western Airlines Inc. on the ground that the proposed merger would have an ''unacceptable'' anticompetitive effect on Western airline markets served through Denver and Salt Lake City.

title: CHOMSKY STIRS FRENCH STORM IN A DEMITASSE
description: ''I am not really familiar with what Professor Faurisson says, but I will defend to the death his right to say it'': this, approximately, is the line that the American linguist Noam Chomsky is sticking to in his slanging match with a clutch of French intellectuals, academics and journalists.

title: POSSIBILITY OF BOMBING IS REPORTED
description: An explosion that Kenyan officials said might have been caused by a bomb killed at least five people at the Norfolk Hotel last night and injured a hundred, some seriously.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Citibank N.A. has named William T. Comfort Jr. and Gerard B. Finneran senior vice presidents.

title: Rail Link Decision Delayed
description: The Justice Department said today that it would reserve its decision on whether to oppose the proposed mergers of the Union Pacific, Western Pacific and Missouri Pacific Railroads until after Interstate Commerce Commission hearings on the plan. The department's antitrust division said it would participate in the commission's fact-finding hearings on the proposed merger beginning in January because it was concerned about the possible effects on competition.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JANUARY 1, 1981
description: International The intermediaries in the hostage talks flew home to Algiers to discuss with their leaders the latest American plan to free the 52 Americans in Iran. They will then go on to Teheran for what may be a decisive round of talks. With three weeks remaining in their term, Carter Administration officials again contended that their reformulation of previous proposals offered Iran a way to resolve the 14-month dispute if Iran wanted to do so. (Page 1, Column 1.) An explosion in Nairobi, Kenya, killed at least five people and injured 100, some seriously. The blast, which Kenyan officials said might have been caused by a bomb, destroyed the main part of the Norfolk Hotel, a favorite gathering place for thousands of tourists in East Africa. (4:1-2.)

title: NEW YEAR'S DAY
description: Parking - Sunday regulations in effect; alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - No collections, no street cleaning.

title: INTERNATIONAL KING'S TABLE INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Dec 13
DELTAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Sanders Leaves $1.5 Million
description: The late Harland Sanders, the founder of Kentucky Fried Chicken who donated millions to charity, left an estate of less than $1.5 million, according to his will. Most of the estate will go into a trust, according to documents filed in Shelby County District Court. The beneficiaries were not named in papers filed, a spokesman said.

title: Rates End Year on Upswing; Federal Funds Still Above 20%
description: Short-and long-term interest rates rose modestly yesterday, as prices declined on trading volume that was suprisingly heavy for a holiday-shortened workday.

title: Two of Studio 54 Get Reduced Terms
description: The former owners of Studio 54, Steven Rubell and Ian Schrager, yesterday won a reduction of the prison sentences that they received for evading $400,000 in income taxes on cash skimmed from their popular Manhattan discotheque.

title: Kennedy Son Arrested in Jersey
description: The 19-year-old son of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, was arrested for possession of a small amount of marijuana as he drove to his home in McLean, Va., on Christmas vacation from Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., the state police said yesteray. Edward M. Kennedy Jr. was given a summons charging him with possession of less than 25 grams of marijuana. Under state law, the violation is less serious than a misdemeanor.

title: 16 PRISONERS' SENTENCES ARE COMMUTED BY CAREY
description: Governor Carey yesterday commuted the minimum sentences of 16 state prisoners, including Dollree Mapp, whose 1961 conviction in Ohio on obscenity charges had been overturned by the United States Supreme Court.

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times Those Little Magazines By JAMES ATLAS THE PUSHCART PRIZE, V: Best of the Small Presses. Edited by Bill Hender- son. 608 pages. Pushcart. $17.95.

title: 2 Accused of a Plot To Murder Witness
description: Two reputed organized-crime figures, Russell Bufalino and Michael Rizzitello, were indicted in Manhattan on a Federal charge of conspiracy to murder a witness in the Federal Witness Protection Program.

title: SOME TOP NEW YEAR'S WISHES FOR A BETTER NEW YORK IN 1981
description: At the beginning of a new year and a new decade, some of New York's famous and learned and powerful were asked to imagine themselves responsible for New York City and New York State, which they presumably know better than most and love as well as anyone.

title: TV: 'INVASION, ' RUSSIANS IN CZECHOSLOVAKIA
description: ''Invasion,'' a 90-minute program on ABC-TV tonight at 9:30, is a British ''docudrama,'' which is not the same thing as an American ''docudrama.'' The product in this country is frequently presented with qualifications, usually to the effect that composite characters and time compressions had been employed in the interest of dramatic structure. The British tend to be more concerned with pure fact.

title: Israel's Police Chief Ousted For Using Illegal Methods
description: Minister of Interior Yosef Burg today ousted the national police chief, Inspector General Herzl Shafir, on grounds of showing disregard for the rights of the individual.

title: COURT HALTS PAY-TV NEWWORK
description: The Getty Oil Company and four of the nation's largest film companies were enjoined yesterday by a Federal court judge from going ahead with plans tomorrow to begin a new pay-television network called Premiere. The new network would have limited the availability of the partners' feature films to other pay-TV networks.

title: THE WASTED POTENTIAL OF AN EX-PRESIDENT
description: To the Editor:

title: DECEMBER FARM PRICES OFF 1.1% FOR FIRST DECLINE IN 8 MONTHS
description: Prices that farmers get for raw products dropped 1.1 percent in December, the first price decline in eight months, the Agriculture Department said today. Despite the one-month drop, farm prices were 9.2 percent higher than at the end of 1979.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 20.50-21.50 ** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: by Maggie Scarf; - ''HOW'S your wife been since the operation?'' asked our family doctor, in the course of a routine physical. My husband looked at him in surprise: ''My wife hasn't had an operation,'' he replied.
description: Later, we laughed about this incident. ''Maybe,'' I proposed, ''when a man is in his early 40's, that's just a conversation starter. Instead of asking 'What do you think of this crazy weather we're having?' he asks how your wife is doing since her operation.''

title: TO MANY CHINESE, COMMUNISM IS A SECURITY BLANKET
description: Just after noon each day in offices around Peking, many employees carefully clear off their desks and spread bedrolls over them. They are preparing for one of the most important and satisfying rituals of Chinese life, the long midday nap, or xiuxi.

title: MICHIGAN COLLEGE SETTLES WITH EX-PRESIDENT
description: Seven months ago the trustees of Wayne County Community College dismissed the college president, saying that he had misspent money, ignored their directives and presided over a decline of quality at the 27,000-student school.

title:
TOWARD A DECISION IN THE WESTWAY CONTROVERSY;
* To the Editor:$
description: Please, enough of the jockeying, hedging, fencing and fencesitting. Let's get on with the building of Westway! Now that Westway has its air-quality permit and now that the ''trade-in'' has been shown to be an unreliable source of funds for the subways, there is simply no excuse for further delay.

title: N. CAROLINA DEFEATS TEXAS, 16-7
description: Amos Lawrence and Kelvin Bryant each scored touchdowns to lead North Carolina over Texas, 16-7, tonight in the 22d Bluebonnet Bowl.

title: BLACK IS STABBED BY A WHITE MAN IN BUFFALO STREET
description: Authorities in Buffalo say they believe the same white man who killed two black men with a knife in Buffalo and Rochester earlier this week critically wounded a third in Buffalo yesterday afternoon.

title: OFFICER IN KILLING OF BRONX YOUTH RELIEVED OF DUTY
description: A police officer who shot and killed an unarmed 19-year-old youth Tuesday evening was suspended early yesterday, the police said, and the incident is under investigation by the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

title: SALVADORAN VILLAGE GETS A TASTE OF WAR
description: Wearing aviator sunglasses, black hair curling from under his green baseball-style cap and a black collapsible-stock automatic rifle hanging from a strap around his neck, the short rotund man began by justifying his authority with a quotation from the Letter of St. Paul to the Romans.

title: CHINA'S DAMAGED YOUTH
description: The nine-year-old twins who lived across the lane from us in the Zhong Shan University compound in Canton, China, were carrying between them a basket made heavy (for them) by a large head of cabbage and two sweet potatoes: lunch and dinner for themselves and their parents.

title: I.B.M. Plans Issue Of Treasury Stock
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it expected to generate $500 million a year in new capital by issuing treasury stock for its employee stock purchase plan instead of purchasing I.B.M. shares on the open market.

title: 100 Inmates Riot and Set Fires At Corrections Center on Coast
description: At least 100 inmates at the state Corrections Center destroyed a guard shack, broke windows and set fire to their library tonight after their evening meal, a state spokesman said.

title: A DESIGN PROGRAMMED FOR EFFICIENCY
description: The first impression made by Jane Victor's apartment is that it is a parody of the overdesigned interior - flashing lights, moving partitions, sculptured surfaces, lots of dimmers and control panels that would look more at home in a 747 cockpit than by the bed, where, in fact, they are situated.

title: 1980 CENSUS FIGURES REPORTED TO CARTER NEAR THE DEADLINE
description: After the most tortured census in American history, plagued by bitter lawsuits, the Census Bureau officially certified the 1980 population count of the states today and reported it to President Carter only hours before the legal deadline.

title: MRS. THATCHER WARNS BL STRIKERS ON AID LOSS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher appealed today to striking British Leyland workers to return to their jobs, and hinted that continuation of their two-week-old walkout might cost the auto company $2.5 billion in Government aid.

title: MASSACHUSETTS TOLD OF WIDE CORRUPTION
description: Corruption in state and local government in Massachusetts was so pervasive in the 1960's and 1970's that it became ''a way of life,'' a special state investigating commission concluded today after two and a half years of study.

title: Kings 5, Sabres 2
description: Doug Keans, a rookie goaltender, stopped 32 shots tonight to lead the Los Angeles Kings to a 5-2 victory over the Buffalo Sabres.

title: 3 Milers Set for Milrose
description: Eamonn Coghlan of Ireland, the former Villanova star who has run the fastest indoor mile in the world, will face stern challenges from Steve Scott, the American record-holder, and Craig Masback in the Wanamaker Mile, feature of the 74th Wanamaker Millrose Games Feb. 6. Coghlan, whose record is 3 minutes 52.6 seconds, will be seeking his second straight triumph in the event. Last year, he ran 3:52.8 to beat Villanova's Don Paige by a tenth of a second.

title: DOW ADVANCES 1.96, TO END 1980 at 963.99
description: The stock market closed out the year on a quiet note yesterday, belying the tumultuous activity that marked most of 1980. Both prices and volume managed only slim gains on the New York Stock Exchange as the Iran crisis, the uncertain economy and the approaching change of Presidents appeared to keep many investors on the sidelines.

title: TIMES NAMES 2 OFFICERS
description: APPOINT/ Names 2 Officers Lance Primis, advertising director of The New York Times, and John M. O'Brien, the newspaper's controller, have been elected vice presidents of The Times, it was announced yesterday.

title: Haley Associates Names President
description: James K. Makrianes Jr., a 55-year-old advertising executive turned head-hunter, has been named president and chief operating officer of Haley Associates, an executive recruiting firm in New York. He succeeds George Haley, 63, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: WHERE IS ALL THAT AMERICAN COAL?
description: To the Editor:

title: RISE IS 6TH IN ROW
description: The Government index designed to forecast future economic trends rose significantly in November, the Commerce Department reported today, indicating that the weakness forecast by many economists is still not in sight.

title: MUSIC: LEINSDORF AND PHILHARMONIC RING OUT THE OLD
description: It was a timely program that Erich Leinsdorf offered on Tuesday night, when he conducted the New York Philharmonic in Avery Fisher Hall. It opened with Haydn's ''Clock'' Symphony (No. 101 in D) and, for the New Year, a festive second half was devoted to the Johann Strausses - senior and junior.

title: CONVICTION UPHELD IN PROVENZANO CASE
description: The conviction of Anthony Provenzano in the murder of a teamster union rival in Ulster County, N.Y., in 1961 was upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Albany, but a new trial was ordered for a co-defendent. Mr. Provenzano, who received a sentence of 25 years to life following his conviction in 1978 is serving a 20-year sentence in a Federal prison in Lompoc, Calif., on a racketeering conviction in New Jersey. Mr. Provenzano and the co-defendant, Harold Konigsberg, were convicted of murdering Anthony Castellito in a struggle for control of Local 560 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in Union City, N.J. The appellate court ordered a new trial for Mr. Konigsberg after finding that the judge had placed limitations on the cross-examination of a witness. PF3 PF1 PF4 PF4 dis doc 74878

title: UNDERSTATED WESTERN MILITARY MIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: Good Old Reliable Nathan
description: There is a day toward the close of summer when the light is suddenly autumnal. September 21 may be weeks away, but that bluing of the air tells us, more surely than any calendar, that fall has come.

title:
TOWARD A DECISION IN THE WESTWAY CONTROVERSY;
* To the Editor:$
description: In an Op-Ed piece on Nov. 8, Marcy Benstock of the New York Clean Air Campaign asserted that Westway might not be built because the Interstate Highway Trust Fund is in danger of running out of money. This is not so. As long as New York State wishes to build Westway, there will be funds available to build it.

title: New Bond Issues WEDNESDAY, DEC. 31, 1980 UTILITY BONDS Moo dy's rrent IssuesRat ing d&Asked Chng Yield So Wst Bell Tl 14 1/4s20 Aaa 102 1/2 + 1/4 13.90Sthrn Bell Tel 12 7/8s20 Aaa -95 7/8 5/8 13.43Sthrn Calif Ed 13 1/2s10 Aa -96 1/2 ...  14.00; CORPORATE BONDS Fed. Dept. Strs. 10 1/4s10 Aaa -83 1/2 1/4 12.35 J.C. Penney 12s10 A -88 3/4 3/8 13.55 Revlon 10 7/8s10 Aa -87 3/8 3/8 12.50; INTERMEDIATE NOTES R.J.Reynolds 10.45s90 Aa -88 7/8 1/4 12.50 GMAC Vrn 13.45s90 Aaa -97 1/4 + 1/2 15.18; INTERNATIONAL ISSUES
description: Source: First Boston Corp.

title: The Economy
description: A key Commerce Department economic index rose 1.2 percent in November, the sixth consecutive monthly gain, indicating that the weakness expected by economists was not yet in sight. President-elect Ronald Reagan said he would not change his economic program because of the rise, but Carter Administration officials said it would propose a delay in the effective date of tax cuts for individuals. (Page 1.) The prices that farmers get for raw products dropped 1.1 percent during December, but still closed the year 9.2 percent higher than in December 1979, the Agriculture Department said. (28.)

title: Back in the Running at St. Bartholomew's
description: His opposition to the proposed selling of part of the landmark Park Avenue property of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church led J. Sinclair Armstrong to enter the election for vestrymen scheduled for January. But his name was not on the ballots mailed out in November - church officials had disqualified his candidacy on the ground that he had not contributed financially during 1980 - so the investment banker went to court.

title: 12 Persons Are Killed In House Fires in 5 States
description: By The Associated Press At least 12 persons in five states died in fires yesterday, including a five-alarm apartment building blaze in Cleveland, where the authorities said eight other persons were missing.

title: President and President-elect On the Move
description: Associated Press and United Press International

title: Bus Fares Rise 10 In Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS (AP) - Fares on Westchester County buses go up from 50 to 60 cents today, but monthly passport commutation tickets remain at $20.

title: A SECOND DRY CLEANER FOUND SHOT TO DEATH IN YORKVILLE IN A WEEK
description: A dry cleaner was found shot to death in his store in the Yorkville section of Manhattan last night, just one block from the store in which another dry cleaner was killed a week ago, the police said.

title: Aetna Real Estate
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company announced that it had sold for $58 million virtually all of the assets of Aetna Diversified Properties Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary, to the Botaba Realty Company of Texas.

title: Technology; Continuous Casting in Steel
description: ALTHOUGH the technology of continuous casting has been around for two decades, most domestic steel producers had found it uneconomical and impractical until recently.

title: ROCKIES SET BACK RANGERS, 6-4
description: Ulf Nilsson says he is glad to be back, but not when the Rangers lose. Nilsson, who had been sidelined two months by an arm injury, scored a goal against the Colorado Rockies last night on his return to Madison Square Garden. But the Rangers spotted the Rockies a 5-2 lead and lost, 6-4.

title: AMID THE GAIETY OF TIMES SQUARE, A BRIEF TRIBUTE TO THE HOSTAGES
description: As the traditionally raucous, horn-blowing crowd of thousands gathered in Times Square last night to cheer in the New Year, the lighted globe atop No. 1 Times Square was darkenend for a minute in a tribute to the American hostages in Iran.

title: KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN'S GROWTH PLAN
description: As the railroad deregulation bill moved through Congress this year, there was no more active opponent than Irvine O. Hockaday Jr., then the president of the small but profitable Kansas City Southern Industries. Mr. Hockaday contended that his little railroad was likely to be crushed as four or five giant systems emerged from the national rush to rail consolidation.

title: SOFT SHOTS AND LOBS BRING TENNIS UPSET
description: - A half-hour into the final set of her second-round match at the Rolex international junior tennis tournament today, top-seeded Kate Gompert threw down her racquet in disgust and kicked it twice. She was losing.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Argo Petroleum Corporation executed a letter of intent with Lucky Chance Mining Company and Great Northern Resources Inc. to develop jointly the Sunnyside Gold Placer Property in California.

title: HEATING OIL PRICE RISES SPREADING
description: The Curtiss-Wright Corporation, which owns a 14.3 percent block of stock in the Kennecott Corporation, yesterday appeared to reject an offer by Kennecott to buy back the block for $150 million.

title: KOCH TRANSPORT
description: To the Editor:

title: No Strong Leads In Rockland Killings
description: The police investigating the killing of Arnold and Elaine Sohn said they had no strong leads in the case and discounted optimistic reports by the Rockland County District Attorney that an arrest might be made soon.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: PITTSBURGH (NL) - Agreed to con- t ract terms with Ben Wiltbank, picher, and H ediberto Vargas, first baseman. FOOTBALL HOUSTON (AFC) - Dismissed Bum P hillips, coach and general manager.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This afternoon your time of challenge and promise begins.'' - Ella T. Grasso to William A. O'Neill, her successor as Governor of Connecticut. (22:3.)

title: NEW ACCOUNTING RULES DUE FOR NONPROFIT GROUPS
description: Nonprofit organizations, such as museums, foundations and charities, should be required to follow uniform rules in reporting their financial results, just as businesses are, the private sector's top rule-making body on accounting matters has decided.

title: Bridge: Listening Is Recommended Before Deciding on a Lead
description: If there were an award for the best opening lead of 1980, West's effort on the diagramed deal would surely be a strong candidate. It occurred in playoffs to determine the Canadian world championship team, and the hero was Joe Silver of Montreal.

title: PRIME MINISTER IS BEING SWORN IN
description: Leopold S. Senghor, the poetstatesman who has led Senegal since its independence from France 20 years ago and helped preserve African cultural traditions, announced his resignation today as President.

title: VESCO VANISHES AT THE DEADLINE FOR DEPORTATION
description: Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive American financier, has left his home here and his whereabouts is unknown, officials of the Ministry of Home Affairs said today.

title: Index; International
description: Noam Chomsky stirs furor in France 2 Salvadoran village gets a taste of war 3 Around the World 4 Israel reports downing two Syrian jet fighters 4 Senegal's President resigns after 20 years in office 4 General Around the Nation 5 Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, vanishes in Nassau 5 New Year's wishes by notables in New York City 21 Westchester gets evacuation plan for nuclear emergencies 22 Black man stabbed by a white on street in Buffalo 22 Studio 54's former owners win prison term reduction 23 Officer suspended in killing of un- armed Bronx man 23 NEW YEAR'S DAY Parking - Sunday regulations in effect; alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - No collections, no street cleaning. Federal, state and municipal offices -Closed. Post offices - Closed; only special delivery and express mail delivered. Banks - Closed. Stock and commodity markets -Closed. Transportation - Subways and buses on holiday schedule; handicapped and senior-citizen fares in effect; Long Island Railroad and Conrail on holiday schedule; PATH trains and Suburban Bus Authority on Sunday schedule. Libraries - Closed. Public schools - Most closed until Jan. 5.

title: Pastor Says He's in Hiding After Ku Klux Klan Threats
description: A West Virginia minister said that he has gone into hiding because he had been terrorized by the Ku Klux Klan.

title: A Post-Wedding Party and a Pre-Wedding Rush
description: China Machado will give a postwedding party at her Central Park West apartment this evening for Elaine Kaufman, the restaurateur, and Henry Ball. Mr. Ball, a wine connoisseur, is manager of restaurants at the new Helmsley Palace Hotel. Until fairly recently he was a Boston resident.

title: O'NEILL SWORN IN AT HARTFORD, SUCCEEDING GOV. GRASSO Gov. William A. O'Neill and wife Natalie O'Neill (p.22)
description: Lieut. Gov. William Atchison O'Neill was sworn in today as Connecticut's 84th Governor in a brief and somber ceremony at the State Capitol, a few blocks from the hospital where Ella T. Grasso is fighting the cancer that forced her to resign as Governor.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TICKETS IN DUFFY SQUARE

title: Backup Quarterback Lonesome Cowboy
description: Glenn Carano is a quarterback for the Dallas Cowboys who seldom plays and never complains. He is the No. 2 quarterback behind Danny White, who has been doing so well that there has been no reason to turn to No. 2. But both players know that circumstances could change.

title: DECLARED 'MEDIUM IS THE MESSAGE'
description: Marshall McLuhan, the communications theorist who taught that ''the medium is the message,'' died yesterday in his sleep at his Toronto home, his family reported. He was 69 years old.

title: BASQUE REGION WINS RIGHT TO LEVY TAXES
description: The Government of Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez appeared today to have made a major breakthrough in the tortuous negotiations to confer real governing powers on the fledgling homerule authority in the Basque region.

title: Body Snatchers
description: Unable to possess the spirit of Nadezhda Mandelstam, Soviet authorities snatched her body. This grisly episode could well have been taken from her own memoirs, ''Hope Against Hope'' and ''Hope Abandoned.''

title: 2 Coast Utilities Cut Liquefied Gas Plans
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company said it planned to reduce substantially its investment in a long-delayed $3.2 billion liquefied natural gas project.

title: INDUSTRY BAIL-OUTS IN NEED OF A FEDERAL PRICE TAG
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Plead Guilty to Fixing Lottery
description: Two brothers pleaded guilty today to participating in the rigging of the Pennsylvania lottery on April 24 and received five years' probation. The plea arrangement required Jack and Peter Maragos to make complete restitution to the state of any money that they or friends had gained as a result of the conspiracy.

title: SADRI WINS
description: Top-seeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina continued toward his third straight Australian open tennis championship today, but he stumbled slightly.

title: I.R.S. SOFTENS ITS RULING ON BANKS' TAX LIABILITY
description: The Internal Revenue Service, bowing to strong pressure from the banking industry, retreated today on a key point of a revenue procedure that would have subjected financial institutions to hundreds of millions of dollars in back taxes.

title: Chain Letter for the Welfare State
description: Most wage earners are in for an unpleasant surprise when they receive their first paychecks of the new year. Social Security taxes are going up about $6 a month for the typical worker, and by nearly $400 a year for someone with a $30,000 income.

title: WESTCHESTER GIVEN 2 UTILITIES' PLAN ON NUCLEAR EMERGENCY EVACUATION
description: A plan developed by the two utilities operating nuclear plants at Indian Point for dealing with a public emergency created by a nuclear accident was disclosed today by Westchester County, whose officials said they were not happy with the plan as drafted.

title: 1980 A VERY GOOD WALL ST. YEAR
description: With confetti flying and champagne corks popping, Wall Street yesterday closed out its most lucrative year ever. For traders and dealers, 1980 was also a year that required quick reactions, steady nerves and strong stomachs. Extreme volatility and high volume were the hallmarks of the financial markets and, judged in those terms, it was a year unlike any other.

title: A CHECKLIST FOR INSPECTING AND REPAIRING; by Berbard Gladstone
description: Just as most people who are shopping for a house will hire a home inspector to inspect the premises and list all problems and need ed repairs, so too can the average homeowner save time, money and aggravation by doing an annual inspection of his own hous e - and what better time to do this than at the beginning of a new year?

title: FLA. STATE MEETS AN OLD FOE
description: A minister's son who ran away from the University of Oklahoma one night because he was only the third-string quarterback could help decide tomorrow night whether his team or Florida State becomes the nation's No. 1 college football team. Either would need the cooperation of Notre Dame, which would have to beat undefeated Georgia six hours earlier in the Sugar Bowl game for anyone else to have a shot at No. 1.

title: 45-Year Terms Given 2 in Bank Robberies
description: Two men convicted of armed bank robbery have received 45-year sentences in Manhattan from a Federal judge who said ''the public is fed up'' with guns and violence.

title: The Mayor and the Major
description: A vacationing Mayor Koch has now met with Major Saad Haddad, Christian warlord of a strip of Lebanon just north of the Israeli border. Israel supports Major Haddad.

title: No Headline
description: FLXIBLE BUSES IDLED IN CHICAGO: Rows of buses await inspection and repair at a garage near Chicago. Some 205 Grumman Flxible buses, operated by the Chicago Area Regional Transportation Authority, were recalled by the manufacturer after frame and structural defects were found.

title: STATE OPPOSING A RULE TO CURB PAROLE OFFICERS
description: Asserting that the public's safety is at stake, New York State officials have asked a Federal appeals court to stay a judge's order that would prevent parole officers from searching the homes of paroled convicts without a court warrant. Such searches are now conducted routinely during supervisory visits by the state's 650 parole officers.

title: RULING IS SAID TO ALTER BILINGUAL EDUCATION POLICY
description: A decision yesterday by the Department of Education allowing a Virginia school district to provide instruction solely in English is viewed by education officials and organizations as significantly softening the department's proposed requirements on bilingual education.

title: Q. I am putting ceiling tile up in one of my bedrooms, using a mastic cement recommended by the manufacturer. In order to prepare the ceiling for the cement and tile I started to scrape off some of the loose paint that had been starting to chip. Most of this is coming off without too much difficulty, but it is a slow process. Can you tell me if I have to remove all of the old paint, or is there some kind of size or sealer I can apply that will insure that I am cementing to a solid surface? -J.K., Philadelphia
description: A. Cement or mastic can be used to put ceiling tile up over a painted surface, but only if the old paint is adhering firmly. If the paint has started to let loose, or if it lets loose later on, it will simply take the cement and tile off with it. That is why you must scrape off paint that is loose or peeling or both. But you do not have to remove old paint that is adhering firmly. If in doubt, however, get the paint off.

title: Stallions Name Klivecka
description: Ray Klivecka, former coach of the Cosmos and the Rochester Lancers, has been named coach of the Major Indoor Soccer League's Buffalo Stallions. Klivecka succeeds Sal DeRosa, who resigned yesterday with the team in last place in the Central Division with a 5-10 record.

title: WHEN 'ON LOCATION' MEANS IN YOUR HOME
All the Kitchen's a Stage In 'Letters From Bernice'
description: THE names were changed, but many of the details stayed the same when Jeanne Michels and Phyllis Murphy decided to write a play based on their own lives. Planned as a benefit for A New Space, a nonprofit theatrical production company, the play was staged in Miss Michels's tiny SoHo apartment for two weeks in December and there are tentative plans to restage it. Folding chairs and mismatched stools were set up and the audience sat within arm's length of the stage action, which took place for the most part in Miss Michels's kitchen and around her dining table. ''We sat in the kitchen to write the play and we used what we had in the apartment to put it on,'' Miss Michels said.

title: IT'S THURSDAY: MUST BE THE 12TH
description: December derives me crazy: Its etymology indicates that it is the ''10th'' month, but the calendar designates it the 12th. It is enough to provoke a suit for breach of roots from the firm of Simon, Newman, Ciardi, and Espy.

title: Thermostatic Legacy
description: The Department of Energy has asked President Carter to extend the order that thermostats be set no higher than 65 in winter, no lower than 78 in summer. If Mr. Carter does nothing, the rule will expire Jan. 16, four days before Ronald Reagan becomes President. Mr. Carter would do the nation a service by sticking to his principles and extending the rule.

title: 7Koch box; A Caution From Koch On Investing in Camels
description: Mayor Koch, who returned from a trip to China last year with visions of what would prove to be ill-fated bicycle lanes, told New Yorkers yesterday that ''nobody should go out and buy a camel in anticipation of camel lanes'' when he returns from the Middle East.

title: ISUZU TO MAKE 'J' CAR AND SELL IT IN JAPAN
description: The General Motors Corporation's Japanese partner, Isuzu Motors Ltd., will begin production in late 1981 of G.M.'s new subcompact ''J'' car for sale in the Japanese market, it was reported today.

title: KANSAS STATE WINS, 47-39, HALTS FRESNO STATE STREAK
description: Tyrone Adams led a second-half rally that helped Kansas State beat Fresno State, 47-39, tonight and end the nation's longest major-college winning streak at 13 games.

title: Now It Can Be Told
description: Sidney (Lethargic) Lazarre, the sleepy literary superagent, is trying to start a row along Publishers Row by leaking to the press his list of potential best sellers drawn from the memoirs of the members of the Carter Administration.

title: An Appreciation
description: In his long critical essay in the Modern Masters series, Jonathan Miller wrote of Marshall McLuhan's peculiar style. McLuhan, according to Dr. Miller, offered his dictums ''not as his privately owned opinions, but as orphan data sent back to earth, as it were, from an unmanned space probe.'' ''He likes to see himself, not as an author, but as a publicly subsidized payload of sensitive instruments that records information irrespective of personal values.''

title: Friends Get Permit to Bury Russian Poet's Widow
description: Friends of Nadezhda Mandelstam, widow of the Russian poet Osip Mandelstam, said today that they had obtained permission to give her a Russian Orthodox funeral.

title: WHITE HOUSE GUN SUSPECT HELD
description: A 29-year-old woman was arrested at the White House, accused of pulling a .32-caliber handgun from her purse while on a public tour and demanding to see President Carter, who was at Camp David, officials said today. Paulette Hutcherson of Pittsburgh was arrested last night and was being held in the District of Columbia jail pending arraignment.

title: IRVIN F. WESTHEIMER, 101, FOUNDER OF BIG BROTHERS AT START OF CENTURY
description: Irvin F. Westheimer, who was inspired to form the Big Brothers organization when he saw a ragged boy and his dog rummaging through trash for food 77 years ago, died yesterday at the age of 101 years.

title: Body of a Nigerian Rebel Moslem Reported Found in Shallow Grave
description: The police discovered the body of the reputed leader of Moslem riots in northern Nigeria in a shallow grave outside the provincial capital of Kano, the official News Agency of Nigeria reported today.

title: THE STRUCTURED LIFE: RIGID OR CREATIVE?
description: Structure returns to life in January, after the welcome disruption of winter holidays or the unwelcome but pervasive Christmas blues. People are generally of two minds about structure. Some tell you enthusiastically how they organize their homes and lives so they can discharge dizzying numbers of responsibilities and still find time to be spontaneous and creative. Others are frankly disgusted by the concept, preferring to float on impulse from one pursuit to another in the belief that chaos fosters spontaneity and creativity.

title: ITALIAN ANTITERRORIST GENERAL IS SHOT AND KILLED IN ROME
description: Two terrorists masquerading as delivery boys shot and killed a general in the Carabinieri paramilitary police today as the general and his wife returned home from mass in Rome, the police reported.

title: TOWARD A DECISION IN THE WESTWAY CONTROVERSY
description: To the Editor:

title: Mitsubishi Cuts Cars Planned for Chrysler
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation in January will cut temporarily its monthly vehicle shipments to the Chrysler Corporation to between 8,000 and 10,000 vehicles from about 15,000, a Mitsubishi spokesman said.

title: Kennedy-Carter Seeks Salant Control
description: An investor group said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it intended to seek control of the Salant Group, a diversified New York apparel concern, to increase its profitability by disposing of inefficient facilities and other steps.

title: COCKTAIL PARTIES COMBATING ALCOHOLISM
description: In the view of officials at the Johnson County Mental Health Center, a good way to help prevent alcoholism is to teach people how to drink.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Snubs Five Who Defied Olympic Ban
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today snubbed five Olympic gold-medal winners who defied her request to boycott the Moscow Games by deciding not to recommend that they be given awards in Queen Elizabeth's New Year's Honors List.

title: No Headline
description: Governor Carey plans to recommend that New York State take over the two airports operated by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and use them as the centerpieces of economic development programs, government and transportation officials said yesterday.

title: URANIUM CONCERN INQUIRY HEARS TOP LILCO OFFICIALS
description: 8 By FRANCES CERRA

title: HARDWICKE COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 28
description: B-Including $557,000 tax credit; the fiscal 1980 shr earnings figure is after payment of a 50 cents a shr preferred stock div there was no such payment in fiscal 1979; the company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange

title: GROUPS HELPING NEEDIEST CASES INCLUDE SOME THAT GAVE EARLIER
description: Gifts from corporations, foundations and employee groups continue to be an important share of the contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, now in its 69th year.

title: NOTRE DAME OUT TO BLOCK GEORGIA'S DRIVE FOR NO. 1
description: The undefeated and untied Georgia football team will try to earn its first No. 1 ranking tomorrow in the 47th annual Sugar Bowl game when the Bulldogs meet Notre Dame, a team used to that honor.

title: PHILLIPS IS DISCHARGED BY OILERS AFTER CONTROVERSY OVER OFFENSE
description: Oail Andrew (Bum) Phillips, the coach and general manager who came equipped with cowboy boots and down-home colloquialisms, was dismissed by the Houston Oilers yesterday, three days after the team's loss to the Oakland Raiders in the American Conference wildcard playoff game.

title: Foster Snell, Chemical Engineer And Head of Consulting Concern
description: Dr. Foster D. Snell, a chemical engineer and consulting chemist, died Sunday at his home at 860 United Nations Plaza in Manhattan at the age of 82.

title: 2 SYRIAN JET FIGHTERS SHOT DOWN BY ISRAELIS OVER SOUTH LEBANON
description: Israeli fighter planes shot down two Syrian MIG-21 jet fighters over southern Lebanon today, a military spokesman announced.

title: ROPER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
Oil Production Down in China
description: China's production of oil and natural gas declined in 1980, the official New China News Agency said yesterday. Government sources in Japan, meanwhile, said China had raised its crude oil price by 85 cents a barrel, retroactive to Dec. 1.

title: Thomson Reported Ready To Buy 2 Med Publications
description: Unconfirmed reports have the International Thomson Business Press ready to purchase Practical Cardiology and Internal Medicine, two magazines put out by Med Publishing. International Thomson, an American arm of the International Thomson Organization, of Toronto, was set up in Philadelphia to acquire or start business publications.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JANUARY 2, 1981
description: International An expected leadership shift in China was signaled officially. Hua Guofeng did not appear at a New Year's reception given by the Communist leadership and attended by about 100 top officials, strengthening a belief that he has been forced to resign as chairman of the party. Instead, the host was Hu Yaobang, who is believed likely to replace Mr. Hua as the party's senior official. (Page A1, Column 6.) Pleas by Iranians for spy trials for the American hostages reportedly increased. Ayatollah Alemeh Nouri, a respected revolutionary clergyman, was quoted as saying that the 52 Americans were espionage agents and should be tried. Ayatollah Nouri holds no official post, but the statement reflected a problem that Iran's Parliament must overcome to resolve the issue. (A1:5.)

title: Bess Myerson's Injury
description: Although Bess Myerson has been in Lenox Hill Hospital in New York since Tuesday night, she still doesn't know exactly how serious was an injury she sustained when she fell from a ladder in her home, a close friend said yesterday.

title: New Air Safety Record Set; Only 13 Persons Killed in '80
description: Flag, trunk and local-service airlines in the United States set a new safety record in 1980 with only one fatal crash, in which 13 persons were killed, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: 'LET GRUMMAN GET CRACKING!'
description: To the Editor:

title: SECRETARIES SEE PARALLELS IN 'NINE TO FIVE'
description: Jennifer Robinson, a 27-year-old secretary in an advertising agency, was taken to lunch over the holidays by her boss. She, in turn, invited him to the movies. They could see ''Nine to Five,'' she suggested devilishly, the new comedy about three oppressed clerical workers who get even with their macho boss. Wouldn't that be great fun?

title: MUSIC: SONGS OPEN A WORLD FOR THE RETARDED BLIND
description: THE 20 to 30 retarded ''young adults'' of the Jewish Guild for the Blind, who ranged in age from 21 to 35, sat in front of the auditorium three years ago, rocking back and forth, being led to and from the microphone, haltingly reciting their memorized lines and nervously singing Broadway tunes, radio hit songs and holiday melodies. But the sound - which was all they could be aware of - was less distressing than the sight - which became so affecting it was easier to look down rather than watch. Pain, isolation, and incapacity were visibly thrown into relief by the awkward attempts at song.

title: Greece Is 10th Member Of the Common Market
description: Greece joined the Common Market today in a move that is expected to be an important turning point for the country and the 10-member organization.

title: U.S. GIVES OWNERS OF WASTE DUMPS 6 MONTHS TO INSURE AGAINST HAZARDS
description: The Government has announced financial requirements for those companies engaged in disposal of hazardous wastes, giving owners of chemical dumps six months to provide financial protection against hazards.

title: EX-RESIDENTS OF NEW YORK CITY AIDING THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: New York City is still where the heart is for many former residents, and each year they express their loyalty in contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Jack Steele, a Journalist For 40 Years, Dies at 66
description: Jack Steele, an award-winning journalist for Scripps-Howard Newspapers who has been called ''the father of modern investigative reporting,'' died late Wednesday of cancer in a hospital in Bennington, Vt. He was 66 years old.

title: Old masters for a new year
description: SELDOM have the January sales at New York's top auction houses begun with more strength in old-master paintings and drawings than this year. Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, and Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, will each auction an exceptional collection next week, along with notable works from a scattering of other owners. Seventeen Dutch and Flemish paintings assembled over the last decade by Mr. and Mrs. John Seward Johnson - he is heir to the Johnson & Johnson pharmaceutical company - will be up for bids at Sotheby's next Thursday at 2 P.M. Most of these paintings are landscapes, including two by Salomon van Ruysdael - ''Alkmaar seen from the River'' (expected to sell for as much as $250,000) and ''A Dune Landscape With Fisherman by a River'' (up to $90,000). Two others are Jan van Goyen works -''A Beach Scene,'' painted in 1634 (up to $200,000), and ''Peasants by a Footbridge'' (up to $100,000).

title: Sailors Brave Icy Waters In 50th Frostbite Regatta
description: Nearly 100 sailors braved frigid temperatures today to launch the 50th Frostbite Regatta on Long Island's Manhasset Bay amid ice floes and an occasional dusting of snow.

title: Pope Bids Nations Spend More on the Handicapped
description: Pope John Paul II, in a New Year's Day mass for 20,000 people at St. Peter's Basilica, urged nations to spend more money on the handicapped and less on arms.

title: Forgotten Americans
description: More than five million Americans make up our nation's military family, serving around the country and abroad.

title: Blazers 122, Nuggets 119
description: Kelvin Ransey scored a career-high 29 points, including Portland's last 8, to lead the streaking Trail Blazers past Denver.

title: Death Toll Rises to 16 In Nairobi Hotel Explosion
description: The death toll in the explosion and fire at the landmark Norfolk Hotel here climbed to 16 today as Kenyan policemen sifted through the debris searching for evidence.

title: Tests to Continue In S.I. Train Crash
description: An examination of three of four brake systems on the Staten Island commuter train that crashed into a wall at the St. George terminal on Monday indicated that the brakes were working, according to an investigator for the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: 4 Arrested on Charges Of Sugar Bowl Scalping
description: The police said today they had arrested four men on charges of scalping Sugar Bowl tickets for as much as $50 each.

title: No Headline
description: Books: British Photo Art By Jack Manning The Linked Ring. By Margaret E. Harker. Focal Press/William Heinemann. 196 Pages. $65.

title:
TV WEEKEND;
BRITAIN IN THE BLITZ ERA; MONTH OF HEALTH SPECIALS
description: THE new Masterpiece Theater series beginning on WNET, Channel 13, on Sunday night at 9, is ''Danger UXB,'' the letters representing unexploded bomb. The Nazi blitz of Britain in World War II included bombs that, usually intentionally, would not immediately explode. A ''bomb disposal unit'' was assigned the harrowing job of defusing the monsters.

title: Company Adds Oilfield Interest
description: Combustion Engineering Inc., a major energy-equipment manufacturer, said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase the assets of HubnerVamag. of Vienna, which manufactures oilfield wellheads and valves and industrial valves.

title: North Sea Pipeline Cost
description: The British Gas Corporation has raised its construction-cost estimate of a proposed pipeline for gathering North Sea natural gas to about $4.7 billion, up from an earlier estimate of $2.6 billion, according to a company spokesman.

title: WOMAN HELD IN SLAYING OF STEPSON
description: A 14-year-old boy was shot to death by his stepmother last night in their Brooklyn apartment, apparently because he had misbehaved, the police said.

title: TIME STILL IN THE BLACK IN CANADA
description: Four years after the passage of legislation here intended to stimulate the Canadian magazine industry, Time magazine continues to publish profitably in this country, with an advertising base that is about 80 percent Canadian. Reader's Digest, the other American publication affected by the bill, chose to develop what is in effect a separate Canadian operation.

title: No Headline
description: PLANE CRASH KILLS FIVE: Officials remove the bodies from the wreckage of a twin-engine airplane that crashed yesterday into an empty warehouse shortly after taking off from Gillespie Airfield in El Cajon, Calif. A spokesman for School of Missionary Aviation, which owned the plane, said ''none of the people authorized to fly it was aboard.'' The severely burned bodies of four men and a woman were found in the wreckage.

title: TO COPE WITH AMERICA'S VERY REAL TRADE PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN KAUFMAN TALKS, FINANCIAL MARKETS LISTEN
description: Henry Kaufman, the Salomon Brothers chief economist and general partner who has been called the ''wizard of Wall Street,'' has no peer in the ability to send the stock or bond markets into a tailspin with a few appropriately gloomy words. Just last month, his prediction that interest rates in 1981 would be ''extremely volatile'' helped push short-term and long-term bond prices down sharply.

title: Arrests of 350 Precede Pasadena's Rose Parade
description: More than 1.5 million people today watched the 92d annual Tournament of Roses parade of flowered floats, marching bands and equestrian units.

title: Ceferino Garcia, Former Boxer; Won Middleweight Crown in '39
description: Ceferino Garcia, a former world middleweight boxing champion, died yesterday at the age of 77. Mr. Garcia became renowned for his ''bolo'' punch, which he wound up like an uppercut.

title: The Economy
description: Modest import protection for makers of specialty steel is expected to be introduced by President Carter before he leaves office. The socalled antisurge mechanism for specialty steel imports would mainly affect Japan and the European Economic Community. An investigation of possible unfair trade practices would begin each time imports reached certain levels. (Page A1.)

title: Braniff Ratings Are Downgraded
description: The financial problems at Braniff Airways have prompted the Standard & Poor's Corporation to reduce ratings on the airline's debt issues. Before the downgrading the airline's debt had been classified by the rating agency as ''predominantly speculative.''

title: OPERA 'HOFFMAN' A TV DAZZLER
description: LONDON OPERA as show biz, for movies and television, is now a reality, transporting improbable plots and hefty singers from stage to screen with varying results. As show biz, the Royal Opera's dazzling new ''Les Contes d'Hoffmann'' at Covent Garden, staged by the film director John Schlesinger in his opera debut, is being praised by London critics as an eye-filling if controversial triumph.

title: RANDY STEVENS, GLITTERY SATIRIST
description: AS of tomorrow, you can start the New Year in style by going to see an exhibition of paintings and drawings by Randy Stevens at the Kornblee Gallery, 20 West 57th Street. It's a fun show, and at first glance it might seem to relate to the esthetic of bad taste that is now doing its best to rough us up, but in point of fact it has quite other claims upon our attention.

title: Peter Saul, wild and funny
description: PETER SAUL has been called the Mel Brooks of art, and not without reason. Taste and subtlety are not the prime ingredients of his wild, funny and often raunchy paintings, done in raucous Day-Glo colors, a rubbery comic-strip style and pegged to topical events. Take ''Subway,'' for example, a very large canvas on view in the Saul show that opens tomorrow (through Jan. 30) at the Allan Frumkin Gallery, 50 West 57th Street. Its theme is crime underground, and it shows a manic mass of policemen, victims, muggers, thieves and rapists around a crashed subway train, all depicted in clinical detail. The heavily armed police are giving more than they get.

title: A DRAFT SOLUTION
description: One of the first decisions that Ronald Reagan will face as President will be whether to continue draft registration. It will be a tough choice. Will he listen to defense advisers who counsel him to retain the present system, or fulfill his campaign pledge to end peacetime registration? Is there a way out of this seeming dilemma?

title: Clearing The Record
description: As relentlessly as 1980 turned to 1981, inflation still races along. Nevertheless, on New Year's Day, these additional inflationary steps were taken:

title: Famed Ranger in Texas
description: As a member of the Texas Rangers, E. J. Flournoy first won attention in 1932, when he brought in a couple of tough-guy members of the notorious ''Bonnie and Clyde'' bank-robbing gang.

title: ABC TIES CBS INWEEK'S NIELSEN POLL
description: Helped by the final week of Monday night football and an unusually strong showing for a documentary, ''The Shattered Badge,'' about violence against the police, ABC-TV finished in a dead heat with CBS for first place in the week's Nielsen audience-popularity ratings. NBC again trailed its rivals.

title: SOVIET FEARS POLISH TRADE UNIONS MAY BECOME A POLITICAL OPPOSITION
description: Tass, the Soviet Government's press agency, said today that ''antisocialist forces'' in Poland were trying to make the new trade unions into a political opposition and lead the country into economic chaos.

title: SINATRA, LONG A FRIEND OF POLITICIANS, HAS AGAIN ESTABLISHED WHITE HOUSE TIES
description: Frank Sinatra, who has had an off-and-on role as friend to Presidents for 20 years, is re-establishing a relationship with the White House after Ronald Reagan's election as President.

title: Jersey Hiker, 23, Dies After Trek in Maine
description: A young New Jersey hiker found unconscious in the snow after being lost for more than two days in the mountains of western Maine died early yesterday at Maine Medical Center.

title: STAGE: 'AMERICAN DAYS,' A BRITISH COMEDY
description: THE Manhattan Theater Club may have gotten off to a slow start earlier this season, but it is quickly making up for lost time. Last week, in its small Upstage theater, this company introduced New Yorkers to a fresh young playwright named Beth Henley, whose ''Crimes of the Heart'' is one of the funniest shows in town. Last night, Stephen Poliakoff's ''American Days'' arrived on the main stage, and it, too, is a provocative comedy that has been directed and acted to the hilt. As both these plays have limited runs, let me recommend that you take in a double bill at your earliest possible convenience.

title: Pro Hockey Notebook Rookie Fills a Void In Canadiens' Goal By PARTON KEESE
description: Rick Wamsley, a 21-year-old rookie, has become the newest of the Montreal Canadiens' goaltenders, replacing more familiar ones like Michel Larocque, Denis Herron, Richard Sevigny and even Mark Holden.

title: Accent's On Youth In Winter At Big A
description: Their bright, young faces are filled with hope, and even when they aren't riding they pass up the pinball machines and the Ping-Pong action to watch others race on the closed-circuit screen in the jockeys' quarters. They are horse racing's freshman class, the dozen or so apprentices who rush to pick up the loose change left by varsity riders who have followed the birds to Florida or the 747's to California.

title: Heating Oil Is Abundant, But Price Continues Rise
description: There will be more than enough oil to heat houses in the Northeast, even through the toughest winter, if homeowners can afford the higher prices, state and business officials agree.

title: HUNTER COLLEGE PARADOX
description: To the Editor:

title: MARY TYLER MOORE AND LINDA LAVIN SEEK DIVORCES
description: In court papers filed this week in Los Angeles, two actresses known chiefly for their television appearances asked for divorces. Mary Tyler Moore seeks to divorce Grant Tinker, with whom she founded the MTM Enterprises television production company several years ago.

title: OKLAHOMA WINS
description: Georgia had to drive only 23 yards for two first-half touchdowns after Notre Dame mistakes in the Sugar Bowl game today, and the Bulldogs held off the Irish for a 17-10 victory.

title: SHEARSON'S MILLARD: PREMIER NEGOTIATOR
description: The sweetest deal of 1980, many on Wall Street say, was the $2.3 billion sale last April of the extensive United States oil and gas properties of the Seagram Company Ltd. to the Sun Company, the nation's 10th-largest oil company. It was the largest deal ever negotiated in this country and the second biggest sale, after the Shell Oil Company's successful $3.65 billion bid at auction for the Belridge Oil Company.

title: LLOYD W. SVEEN
description: Lloyd W. Sveen, executive editor of The Fargo Forum, died last night at a hospital here. Mr. Sveen, who was 63 years old, entered the hospital earlier in the day after becoming ill at home.

title: 10 Die as Pakistani Train Derails
description: A passenger train derailed today, killing 10 people and injuring more than 150, the authorities reported. The accident took place about 170 miles north of here.

title: INDUSTRY COMPETITION ANALYZED
description: His white shirtsleeves rolled to the elbows, the wiry impresario hammers home another lesson after 80 minutes of Socratic dialogue with his class about Japan's rise to dominance in worldwide motorcycle production.

title: MEXICO'S FOOD NEEDS
description: ''Food for crude,'' the food warriors' favorite slogan, may be about to enter the arena of United States-Mexican relations. This year, Mexico has become a net importer of food from the United States.

title: Linda Greenhouse Bride of Eugene R. Fidell
description: Linda Greenhouse, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, and Eugene R. Fidell, a partner in the Washington office of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae, New York law firm, were married in Washington last evening. Rabbi Philip L. Rabinowitz performed the ceremony at the Georgetown Synagogue-Kesher Israel Congregation.

title: DANISH BOYS AND PASOLINI BITS
description: THE film is called ''You Are Not Alone,'' and in it, no one ever is. The setting is a Danish school for young boys, and the students practice a brand of togetherness that is the film's major selling point. They hug. They shower. They romp in their skivvies, and go for long, romantic idylls in the nearby woods. Whenever characters in ''You Are Not Alone'' appear to be in danger of finding something new to think about, the conversation turns to masturbation, or whether sex is nicer with boys or with girls, or whether the school officials are wrong in banning pornography in the students' rooms.

title: Romero Barcelo Takes Oath For a Second Term Today
description: Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo, who is to be sworn in tomorrow for a second four-year term, has been forced to abandon plans for a statehood plebiscite this year because of the narrow margin of his election victory.

title: RECITAL TEAM OFFERS ALL-SCHUMANN NIGHT
description: Musicians constantly look for new programming ideas that will stimulate both performers and audience to hear the masters in a fresh light. Bethany Beardslee, the soprano especially noted for her extensive repertory of contemporary music, and Richard Goode, the pianist who won the 1980 Avery Fisher Award, have hit upon an interesting twist. A little over a month ago, the two presented an all-Brahms program divided between his songs and piano music, and Sunday night at the Abraham Goodman House they will do the same for Schumann, followed by a third recital, on March 2, devoted to Schubert.

title: MICHIGAN ENDS SLIDE BY BEATING HUSKIES IN ROSE BOWL, 23-6
description: Power running by Butch Woolfolk and timely passing by John Wangler ended Michigan's postseason drought today as the Wolverines defeated Washington, 23-6, in the 67th Rose Bowl game.

title: The Mystery Wrapper
description: China has long evoked a sense of awe, of fascination in the West, as the place where everything seems to be different. There is a holdover from the childhood memory of being told that if you keep digging your sand tunnel deep enough, you'll come out in China on the other, upside-down side of the world.

title: Italian Editor Seized on Vacation After Interviewing Red Brigades
description: An editor of a weekly magazine that plans to publish an interview with fugitive urban guerrillas of the Red Brigades was arrested and charged with aiding and abetting terrorists, the police said today.

title: Koch Returns Today From Mideast Visit
description: Mayor Koch completed his visit to the Middle East yesterday with tours of Israel's military bases in the Sinai Peninsula, and he was expected to arrive in New York this morning at 6:30.

title: Diana Rigg to play title role in musical 'Madame Colette.'
description: AFTER flirting for several years with the idea of doing a Broadway musical, Diana Rigg has just said yes. She will star in the title role of ''Madame Colette,'' a new show that has music by Harvey Schmidt and a book and lyrics by Tom Jones, the team that wrote ''The Fantasticks.'' Miss Rigg, a leading lady of the British stage, is best known to American audiences as the sexy heroine of the television series ''The Avengers,'' although New York theatergoers are familiar with her excellent stage work on Broadway and at Lincoln Center. She is going to do the role in ''Madame Colette'' that was announced not long ago as belonging to Debbie Reynolds.

title: PAUL MORRISON, 74, SET DESIGNER FOR 60 PRODUCTIONS ON BROADWAY
description: Paul Morrison, a designer of sets, lighting and costumes for more than 60 Broadway productions and for 17 years a director of the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theater, died at New York Hospital on Monday. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Ali Backs $1 Million Bond For Employe in Drug Case
description: Muhammad Ali, the former world heavyweight champion, says he will guarantee a $1 million bond set for a former employe accused of conspiracy to smuggle 37,000 pounds of marijuana into Charleston County.

title: Policeman Kills Woman Outside a Bar in Harlem
description: A 40-year-old woman was fatally shot by a policeman early yesterday after she brandished a gun in a Harlem bar, the police said. According to the police, the woman, Ruth Olstran of 2043 Valentine Avenue, the Bronx, was shot once in the chest at 5:30 A.M. on Seventh Avenue at 132d Street.

title: Police See No Link In Yorkville Slayings
description: The New Year's Eve murder of a dry cleaner at 88th street and First Avenue in Manhattan's Yorkville section appeared to be unrelated to the Christmas Eve murder of another dry cleaner one block away on York Avenue, the police said.

title: Film Series on American Art in Queens; Queens Museum Showing Films on American Art
description: ''American Art Now,'' a five-week series of films about artists and their work, begins tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. at the Queens Museum in Flushing Meadow-Corona Park. On the bill are ''Mindscape,'' an animated film by Jacques Drouin; ''Christo's Valley Curtain,'' a documentary about the land sculpture by Christo, and ''Alex Katz Painting,'' a portrait of the artist.

title: CHICAGO THRIFT UNIT LURING BORROWERS WITH INNOVATIVE MORTGAGE PROGRAM
description: With interest rates on home mortgages ranging between 15 and 18 percent in many parts of the country, the Talman Home Federal Savings and Loan Association here is offering some mortgages that are four to six percentage points below the market. An innovative plan called the preferred interest rate program allows a buyer of a home on which Talman already holds the mortgage to take over the home loan of the previous owner at two percentage points above the original mortgage rate. The assumed loan and any new loan required are weighed and averaged to determine the interest rate charged on the new financial package. One couple saved almost $2,000 in yearly mortgage payments on a cozy brick home they purchased for $44,000, minus a 20 percent down payment, when they assumed the old $31,000 mortgage, which had a 6.5 percent rate. Talman charged the couple 10.8 percent to wrap up their 30-year deal. While some states insist that home purchasers be allowed to assume an existing mortgage at the original interest rate, others permit lenders to set the terms. Given that freedom, most lenders bar the assumption of mortgages so they are free to raise the interest rate to prevailing market levels. 'Due on Sale' In Illinois, under the "due on sale" clause in mortgage contracts, the lending bank has the right to call in the mortgage loan if the owner subsequently wants to transfer ownership. While the plan lures potential buyers with lower-than-usual mortgage rates, it is designed to undercut under-the-table transactions between buyers and sellers that have been costing thrift institutions millions in lost interest payments.

title: HEPHZIBAH MENUIN, SISTER OF VIOLINIST
description: Hephzibah Menuhin Hauser, pianist-sister of the violinist Yehudi Menuhin and his early partner in their international musical careers, died today after a long illness. She was 60 years old and was the wife of Richard Hauser, a sociologist.

title: by Tom Buckley; A favorite of a 'pom' named Prince Charles.
description: ''IT gives the poms hell right enough, but that didn't stop Prince Charles from loving it and having it shown at Buckingham Palace for his mother.'' The speaker was Jack Thompson, ''poms'' or ''pommies'' are what Australians call their English cousins, and ''it'' is ''Breaker Morant,'' the film in which Mr. Thompson plays a starring role. He and Bruce Beresford, the director and co-author, made the long slog from Down Under to be present at its generally wellreceived New York opening last week.

title: REP. ASPIN STILL FEELS SOVIET MAY SEND ARMY INTO POLAND
description: The chairman of the House intelligence oversight subcommittee said today that the odds favored Soviet military intervention in Poland after the middle of this month.

title: YEAR-END LARGESSE ON WALL STREET
description: ''Our partners have never received so many hugs and kisses from the staff,'' said Howard Silverman of Gruntal & Company, a New York Stock Exchange member firm that has been selling stocks and bonds for 100 years.

title: OHIO RULING BUOYS HOUSING BIAS FOES
description: Advocates of open housing, defeated in a recent Senate fight for tougher laws against discrimination, have been buoyed by a Federal District Court's order that Parma, Ohio, an all-white Cleveland suburb, open its doors to blacks.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS 'BAN' TWO LEADERS OF A BLACK UNION
description: The Government showed its concern this week over the tendency of black trade unions to take strong political stands by placing strict ''banning'' orders on two leaders of a journalists' union that had just resolved a two-month dispute with the major English-language newspaper groups.

title: IRON HORSE AND SHANK'S MARE
description: To the Editor:

title: A paradox in the Reich- Glass mode
description: LA MONTE YOUNG is a paradox, an influential American composer and musician whose work has been infrequently heard. His Trio for Strings, composed in 1958, predated and helped inspire the Minimalist movement that has produced popular, important composers like Philip Glass and Steve Reich, but it's performed very rarely and has never been made available on records. His 1960's performing groups included a future Minimalist trailblazer, Terry Riley, and a future rock-and-roll prophet, John Cale, but made no commercial recordings. His ''Dream House'' music, a thunderously amplified droning, is preserved only on a dauntingly rare French album. Directly or indirectly, Mr. Young's work has had a great deal to do with the shape and substance of concert music and avant-garde rock today. But where can one hear it?

title: NEXT BUS: DEC. 31, 1988
description: I should not have been surprised. (By now, everyone knows that the Grumman Corporation's new Flxible buses with cracking A-frame undercarriages have been yanked out of service - those sleek modern vehicles with their digital messages and futuristic interior that have been both condemned and praised.) Yet, I was still not prepared for the old green bus that came lumbering toward my stop.

title: HUA GUOFENG ABSENT FROM A PEKING FETE, POINTING TO OUSTER
description: The first official indication of the downfall of Hua Guofeng, the party chairman, came today when he did not appear at a New Year's reception given by the Central Committee.

title: ALTHEA T. HENRICH IS MARRIED TO GEORGE CLEAVLAND PALMER
description: Mrs. Althea Trochelman Henrich, widow of George N. Henrich, was married yesterday to George Cleaveland Palmer, a vice president of E.F. Hutton & Company Inc. The Rev. Frederick Savage performed the ceremony at the Bayport (L.I.) Methodist Church.

title: Ruling Is in Favor Of Gus Williams
description: Telford Taylor, the court-appointed arbitrator, has ruled in favor of Gus Williams in Williams's salary and compensation dispute with the Seattle SuperSonics.

title: Mrs. Carter Off the List
description: How quickly they forget. Every year, like clockwork, Rosalynn Carter has been named ''political style maker'' by the National Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Association.

title: Advertising; Monitoring A Media Revolution
description: AS THEIR titles suggest, agency media directors are at the center of the storm caused by the introduction of new electronic media. These are the people who must evaluate the advertising potential of the new satellite and cable networks and the new devices, such as videodisks and tapes. One expert in the field is Jules P. Fine, Ogilvy & Mather's executive vice president of marketing services, who was recently named Mediaperson of the Year by Marketing and Media Decisions magazine.

title: The 500-Year Paving Job
description: We've noticed an increase in the use of a certain metaphor for the troubles of old cities and, grim as it is, we like it. The image comes from the language of maintenance and capital replacement and seems to have first gone public in 1978.

title: No Headline
description: CASPER DEAL IS CITED IN PHILLIPS DISMISSAL

title: LINDSAY CROUSE KEEPS UP A FAMILY STAGE TRADITION
description: Lindsay Crouse took a cup of tea to ''the troll who lives upstairs''- her husband, David Mamet, the playwright - and settled back the other day in her old-timey Chelsea apartment to tell the story of her magical childhood. As she spoke, there was the muffled pounding of Mr. Mamet's typewriter, a sound that is part of the texture of her life.

title: IMPERIAL CHINA VISITS TULLY HALL TONIGHT
description: After invading Bloomingdale's and conquering the New York Coliseum, the long march of Chinese culture is moving uptown tonight to Lincoln Center.

title: REMARKS BY WEST VIRGINIA JUDGE SHOCK MAGISTRATE
description: In a videotaped talk intended as a course on judicial ethics, West Virginia's Chief Justice advised magistrates to steer clear of moonshine and 13-year-old girls and stay out of ''the whorehouse business.''

title: Tower of Pisa Reported To Endure a Major Jolt
description: The Leaning Tower of Pisa vibrated for 22 minutes after a powerful earthquake in Italy on Nov. 23 but returned to normal, according to the tower's caretaker.

title: CARTER IS EXPECTED TO GIVE IMPORT AID TO SPECIALTY STEEL
description: Before he leaves office, President Carter is expected to introduce some modest import protection for the makers of specialty steel, according to Administration aides.

title: No New Trumpets; No New Economics?
description: The new Reagan Administration won't issue a stirring declaration of economic emergency, and in a way it's a shame. We like the idea, put forth by Congressmen Jack Kemp and David Stockman, the budget director-designate. Loud, certain trumpets would be a sure way to attract the nation's attention and help the new President win economic credibility. But if they are to call the public to battle, trumpets must have music to play.

title: Sports of The Times; Glory, Glory, Herschel Walker
description: UP in a private box in the Superdome, the second most important citizen in Georgia peered down yesterday at the most important. President Carter was watching Herschel Walker run with a football. And when the Sugar Bowl game was over, when the University of Georgia had outlasted Notre Dame, 17-10, for its claim to the No. 1 ranking among college teams, after he had galloped for 150 yards and two touchdowns in 36 carries, Herschel Walker, the 18-year-old freshman, was asked what it had been like to perform for the President.

title: photo of food preparation at Kennedy Airport facility; INFLIGHT FOOD SALES AT $1 BILLION RECORD
description: A bumper crop of salads and fruit plates, a torrent of diet soda and wine, and two million kosher snacks and meals helped set a record of $1 billion in sales in 1980 by inflight catering companies and wholesalers supplying food and drink served on airline flights originating from United States airports.

title: 4 HOME TEAMS GET EDGE IN PLAYOFF GAMES
description: Will the muddy field be frozen in Cleveland? Will Tom Landry's play selections befuddle the young Atlanta linebackers? Can Dan Fouts avoid being a greedy quarterback? Do the Vikings stand a chance?

title: HUNT PRESSED FOR LINKS IN UPSTATE AND CITY STABBINGS
description: Law enforcement authorities continued their search today for a white man who they believe wounded a black man here on Wednesday and stabbed to death two others earlier this week in Buffalo and Rochester.

title: NICHOLAS W. DANTON
description: Nicholas W. Danton, Chief Judge of the Maine District Court, died of a heart attack yesterday at the age of 62 years.

title: by Mimi Sheraton; From Afghanistan and south of border.
