description: ''DO you realize we are eating in the only Afghan restaurant in New York?'' a man asked his friend at the two-month-old Pamir. ''I doubt that,'' the other man said. ''I can't believe there is only one of anything in this city.''

title: LOW WAGES PERSIST IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: Low-wage industries, such as textiles, apparel and furniture, help keep North Carolina at or near the bottom of a variety of statistical measures of economic health, including the Labor Department's monthly rankings of state manufacturing wages.

title: MUSIC:PERLMAN'S PARTY
description: ITZHAK PERLMAN'S New Year's Eve violin recital at Carnegie Hall began on a serious and high-minded note and then gradually relaxed into a celebration appropriate to the hour.

title: FOR AFGHANS, ABSENCES INSPIRE RUMORS OF PURGE, SHOOTOUT AND BETRAYAL
description: As President Babrak Karmal of Afghanistan made public his plans for widening the governing coalition, staff members of Western embassies in Kabul wondered whether the recent disappearance from public view of high Afghan officials signified yet another round of factional warfare and purges.

title: ALUMNI CONTROL ISSUE STIRS RIFT AT MICHIGAN STATE U.
description: Michigan State University's Alumni Association is in a fight with Dr. Cecil Mackey, the university president, that Dr. Mackey may settle by establishing his own group to deal with old graduates and their checkbooks.

title: MCHENRY ASSERTS BRZEZINSKI SENT 'MIXED SIGNALS'
description: Donald F. McHenry, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, has criticized Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser, for speaking out when he ''should@n't have'' and sending ''mixed signals'' about the Administration's foreign policy goals.

title: Whitney Museum to Open Branch in Stamford in May
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art will open a branch museum at the new headquarters of Champion International Corporation in Stamford, Conn., in May. In a two-story high gallery, the Whitney will stage at least six exhibitions annually.

title: Vandanya, 13-1, Is Winner In Rosetown at Aqueduct
description: Vandanya, a 13-1 shot, scored a front-running victory in the $56,400 Rosetown Stakes yesterday as Aqueduct opened the 313-day 1981 New York thoroughbred racing Season.

title: HIS ACTION FILMS REFLECTEDHIS LIFE
description: Raoul Walsh, a dynamic movie pioneer and a major director for nearly half a century, died Wednesday night, apparently of a heart attack, at the Simi Valley Adventist Hospital near Los Angeles. He was 93 years old.

title: NEW-OWNERSHIP DEADLINE PASSES FOR LONDON TIMES
description: An end-of-the-year deadline has passed with no firm prospect for a new owner for The Times of London, which is under the threat of closing by spring.

title: Jersey Man Indicted For Firing at Thieves
description: A 41-year-old Vineland man has been indicted for endangering the lives of two alleged burglars he shot at while chasing them from his home.

title: RESTORING FAITH IN LLOYDS
description: Peter Green took over as chairman of Lloyd's of London in 1980, just as a storm broke. Both international re-insurers and private investors were refusing to pay up for suspect North American claims; the classic motto Uberrima Fides (''the utmost good faith'') was fraying at the edges, and the Government's Fisher Committee was about to deliver proposals for wide-ranging reforms.

title: Theater at La Mama
description: ''Nuit Blanche,'' an experimental theater work that incorporates film and slides, will be presented by the Fiji Company for the next four weekends at the La Mama E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street.

title: Mozambique to Free 600 Rebels
description: A parliamentary commission has pardoned more than 600 soldiers jailed for taking part in an uprising six months after independence in 1975. Fifteen men accused of organizing the rebellion, which left five people dead, still face possible death sentences.

title: Economic Scene; The Cost in Jobs Of Low Inflation
description: THE toughest problem the Reagan administration will face in the year ahead is how to stop inflation without worsening unemployment at the same time. The question, however, is whether this is an impossible mission.

title: Real Estate; West Street Lofts Made Into Co-ops
description: ''T HERE are people who come to New York City with one thing in mind for a profession,'' said John Waggaman, an established fine-arts photographer, ''but end up doing something entirely different. That's what makes it so interesting.''

title: SANTUCCI SEEKS DEATH PENALTY IN MURDER OF POLICEMAN
description: District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens is seeking the death penalty for the suspect in the city's most recent killing of a police officer, and says he will press a death-sentence case against five men in another police killing.

title: FIRST CHICAGO'S REVIVAL PLANNED BY SULLIVAN
description: Barry F. Sullivan does not expect 1981 to be easy. Last June, the 49-year-old banker resigned as executive vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank to become chairman of the First Chicago Corporation and its primary subsidiary, the First National Bank of Chicago.

title: RALPH ELLISON IN MIXED-MEDIA SETTING
description: The prose of the novelist Ralph Ellison and the music of the saxophonist and composer Julius Hemphill have a great deal in common. Both men have created works that celebrate and explore the meaning of life in black America. Both men are familiar with the blues, the bedrock of black American musical expression, but they have distanced themselves from it, too.

title: Jewelry Trade Magazine Planned by Talcott Group
description: Talcott Communications, Chicago, which already publishes Giftware News, has brought out Executive Jeweler, an expensively made, controlled-circulation trade publication.

title: Herschel F. Clesner Dead at 57; Former Counsel to House Panel
description: Herschel F. Clesner, former chief counsel to the Subcommittee on Commerce, Consumer and Monetary Affairs of the House Government Operations Committee, died today of a heart attack at his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 57 years old.

title: ENERGY WATCH DELAYED
description: Energy Watch, which normally appears on Fridays, will be printed tomorrow because of a delay in compiling the statistics caused by the holiday.

title: Khomeini Calls for End To Armed Forces Rivalry
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini called today for cooperation between Iran's armed forces after Ayatollah Hussein Ali Montazeri, Iran's second most powerful religious leader, took President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr's Supreme Defense Council to task over its conduct of the war with Iraq, the Iranian press agency Pars said.

title: CHINA, FOR A FORTUNATE FEW AT THE TOP, IS PARADISE OF PRIVILEGE AND
description: PERQUISITES By FOX BUTTERFIELD

title: J. HILBERT JOHNSON
description: J. Hilbert Johnson, president of the Hickory Furniture Company, died at his home of cancer yesterday.

title: 7, INCLUDING 4 CHILDREN, DIE IN HOUSE FIRE IN JERSEY
description: A fire that quickly engulfed a small frame house here early today killed seven persons, including four small children found huddled only a few feet from a first-floor window.

title: BRINGING IN THE NEW YEAR
description: A T the stroke of midnight it wasn't ''Auld Lang Syne'' or even ''Oo-La-La-Sasson'' that was sung at the New York Rangers New Year's Eve party. Instead, the team members, their wives, sweethearts, parents and friends at the East Side restaurant, Oren & Aretsky, gave a rousing version of ''Happy Birthday to You.''

title: MT. SINAI DOCTORS STUDY A DISEASE AFFLICTING JEWS
description: Doctors at Mount Sinai Medical Center are making a major effort to control Gaucher's disease, an incurable and inherited affliction that strikes approximately one of every 2,500 Jews born in the United States.

title: IF U.S. BONDS HAD STABLE PURCHASING POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: ADOPTION RATES FOUND TOO LOW BY MISS BELLAMY
description: Less than 20 percent of the 6,424 children available for legal adoption in New York City in 1979 through publicly assisted agencies were placed, although child-care agencies had enough applications to more than double that rate, according to a study made by the office of the City Council President, Carol Bellamy.

title: THE DAY AFTER: HANGOVERS, HOPES AND THE USUAL NEW YEAR'S 'FIRSTS'
description: New Year's Day is the ultimate morning after. On Jan. 1 the world is divided into two kinds of people: those who celebrated injudiciously the night before and are paying for it, and those who did not and are pleased with their own temperance; that is, those who are facing a brand-new year with bright eyes and high hopes and those who are facing it with a growl of discomfort and a hangover.

title: TRIBULATIONS ARE AHEAD, POLES ARE WARNED
description: Poles were told last night that they had successfully weathered a difficult year and were warned to brace themselves for further trials and tribulations in 1981.

title: FOREIGN POLICY CLUE
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * William W. Galvin 3d has been appointed executive vice president of Newsome & Company, Boston.

title: Money Funds Off By $673 Million
description: The total assets of the nation's 95 money market funds fell by $673 million, to $74.7 billion, in the week ended Tuesday because many investors apparently preferred the high interest rates paid on sixmonth money market certificates, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report.

title: ROLLICKING TEXAS HONKY-TONK HEARS ITS LAST CORD
description: Armadillo World Headquarters, the Texas honky-tonk that served up Lone Star beer and progressive country music for a decade, went out of business New Year's Eve with a party attended by nearly 2,000 people.

title: Friday; THE RENAISSANCE ON S.I.
description: The Collegium Musicum, the Wagner College ensemble that brought you music from the court of Vlad the Impaler last November, is going all out for the New Year with a Renaissance feast tonight at 7. Such fare as ''wossele coppes,'' ''sucklyng pigges'' and ''flamyng plum puddyng'' will be on hand, as well as 16th-century dance, theater and, of course, music, with recorders, krummhorns, lute and other instruments of the period. Prof. Ronald Cross, founder of the group, will perform on the English virginal. There will also be a costumed procession and some commedia dell'arte. The site is St. Paul-St. Luke's Lutheran Church of Port Richmond, S.I. Reserved tickets are $20 ($38 for two), and Renaissance attire is encouraged. Information: 442-7224.

title: Man Kills Himself After Slaying Market Manager in Los Angeles
description: A man committed suicide after fatally shooting a supermarket manager whom he took hostage in a New Year's Day robbery attempt, the police said.

title: Bachelorettes, Jobettes
description: For a long time we thought depression over the economy and the divorce rate was pretty general -until, that is, we read a report in The Times about some people oblivious to both. They are the 77 percent of women in a recent Brown University study of 3,000 Ivy League students who say mothers should not work at all or only part time until their children are 5. Their cheerful assumption is that they will always be free to work out of choice, not necessity.

title: Index; International
description: Uruguay's proud past lives on in abundant old cars A2 Tass sees threat of an opposition developing in Poland A3 Czech officials compare Polish crisis to 1968 liberalization A3 Poles are told to brace for new tribulations in New Year A3 Chief U.N. delegate assails Brze- zinski A4 Around the World A5 Terror, but not inflation, is under control in Turkey A6 China, for a lucky few, is a para- dise of privilege A6 Government/Politics Remarks by West Virginia's Chief Justice shocks magistrates A9 General ''Deplane'' makes the 7th annual Dishonor List of Words A9 Around the Nation A10 Rollicking honky-tonk goes out of business in Austin, Tex. A12 Obituaries Paul Morrison, stage designer D7 Hephzibah Menuhin Hauser, pian- ist-sister of Yehudi Menuhin D7 Weekend Weekender Guide C1

title: ATTIRE OF PRESIDENTS PAST
description: The history of Inauguration Day dress is filled with all sorts of sartorial trivia. And a good place to find it is in ''Facts About the Presidents'' by Joseph Nathan Kane.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard ANGELS. By Peter Lamborn Wilson. Illus- trated. 200 pages. Pantheon Books. $29.95.

title: EFFACING A PRESIDENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Lee Sparks's Laryngitis Puts Off 'Joan Crawford'
description: Because Lee Sparks, the leading player, has laryngitis, producers of ''An Evening With Joan Crawford'' have postponed its opening at the Orpheum Theater, 126 Second Avenue, at Eighth Street.

title: Market Place; Ways to Fight 'Bracket Creep'
description: WHEN taxpayers receive raises to offset the ravages of inflation, they often experience so-called bracket creep. That is, they are taxed more heavily on some or all of their added income under a system that levies at a progressively higher rate. More and more individuals who have encountered this frustration are investing in tax-exempt municipal bonds, and they do so mostly through unit investment trusts.

title: DR. KIRKPATRICK'S VIEW OF NATIONAL INTEREST
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER JUDGE PURSUING STEADY COURSE IN THE SWIRL OF THE HARRIS MURDER CASE
description: Judge Russell R. Leggett presides over the Jean S. Harris murder trial like the father of a large family. He has managed to keep squabbling lawyers apart, explain legal procedures to recess-weary jurors, comfort nervous witnesses and even chat with the neighbors when court is not in session.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He didn't help us win the game. He was just watchin'.''

title: No Headline
description: Alabama Batters Baylor

title: STAGE: 'SOLOMON'S CHILD,' CULT PLAY, AT LONG WHARF
description: ''Solomon's Child,'' a new play by Tom Dulack at Long Wharf's Stage Two, deals with a timely, explosive subject, one that has been treated extensively by the press and on television: the seduction of young people by radical religious sects and their deprogramming by hired ''kidnappers.'' The play has moments that seem simplistic, there are gaps in the dramaturgy, and there is an epilogue that vitiates the work's climax and lodges it tentatively in ''Equus'' country. However, Mr. Dulack explores the issue with an inquisitive mind, intelligently sifting the various responses to an unnerving dilemma. This is a provocative play that makes a serious attempt to understand an urgent parental concern - a conflict between responsibility and freedom.

title: 100 Blind Are Held Briefly in India For Disorder During Job Protest
description: Indian policemen briefly arrested about 100 blind demonstrators today when they tried to push through a cordon near Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's official residence.

title: DRIVE ON SOCIAL SECURITY DEFICITS BEING MOUNTED BY CONGRESSMEN
description: A few members of Congress and a handful of Congressional aides have begun to discuss ways to scale back the Social Security benefits to be paid in the future to people who are now working.

title: Sinatra Among Stars Set For Jan. 10 Cancer Benefit
description: In a one-night stand at Radio City Music Hall on Jan. 10, Frank Sinatra, Sarah Vaughan, the Count Basie orchestra and Rich Little, the comedian, will perform for the benefit of the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center.

title: DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM OPENS SEASON TOMORROW
description: ''DO your own thing. But have the technique to compete.'' Those words might be carved over the doorway of the Dance Theater of Harlem's headquarters on West 152d Street, for that philosophy is, essentially, the heart of the ballet company's success. The words were spoken by Arthur Mitchell on an April afternoon in 1974, just before the company's Broadway debut and just six years after the former New York City Ballet star, stunned by the assassination of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., decided to share with other blacks his art of ballet and its nourishing discipline. Now, Dance Theater, which opens its winter season at City Center tomorrow, is considered one of New York's major dance companies .

title: IRANIAN CLERIC ASKS TRIALS FOR CAPTIVES
description: An Iranian clergyman was quoted today as saying that the 52 Americans held here were spies, not hostages, and should be put on trial.

title: Transactions; BASKETBALL
description: DETROIT (NBA) - Activated John L ong, guard, who had been out with injured k nee.

title: Vesco Son Says His Father Will Return Home Sunday
description: A son of Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive American financier who disappeared from his home in Nassau before Bahamian authorities could serve him with a deportation order, said today that his father would return Sunday.

title: International Bidding Accord
description: Starting today, the governments of 19 countries, including the United States, will be able to make purchases from foreign companies.

title: MRS. TEETERS STILL WAGES HER LONELY FED FIGHT
description: The conduct of monetary policy is often more art than science, so it is not surprising that the record high interest rates of 1980 have prompted debate among economists and politicians.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY: UELSMANN'S SURREAL WORLD
description: ''THE irrational,'' wrote Wallace Stevens, ''bears the same relation to the rational that the unknown bears to the known.'' This is an observation worth remembering in approaching the photography of Jerry N. Uelsmann -the subject of a beguiling exhibition at the Witkin Gallery, 41 East 57th Street (through Jan. 24). As a photographer, Mr. Uelsmann is a virtuoso of the irrational image. His is a pictorial world in which the laws of gravity are frequently suspended and the unexpected is more or less the norm. We are in the realm of multiple images and photomontage, where, though the isolated details may be familiar, or at least recognizable, their often bizarre juxtaposition carries us into the dream world of the irrational.

title: INAUGURATION DAY '81: A SARTORIAL CONTROVERSY
description: Through the years, Presidential inaugurations have always been the scene for one kind of drama or another, and, judging from the response of many on Capitol Hill to the ''suggestion'' that semiformal attire would be appropriate on the morning of Jan. 20, the coming inauguration promises to be no different. The advice from the Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies has, in fact, caused a minor storm of indignation and incredulity.

title: Abdou Diouf Is Sworn In As President of Senegal
description: Prime Minister Abdou Diouf was sworn in today as the second President since Senegal gained independence from France 20 years ago.

title: LAST YEAR'S DRACULA IS THIS YEAR'S FRANKENSTEIN
description: David Dukes is fairly used to changing theatrical identities on short notice. For instance, he rehearsed only a couple of days before replacing an ailing Jean LeClerc in the title role in ''Dracula'' on Broadway last season, just before Mr. Dukes's taking on the role of a homosexual persecuted by the Nazis in ''Bent,'' for which he won high praise.

title: Bridge: Becker and Rubin Triumph In '80 Trophy Computation
description: Two trophies, each commemorating a leading New York bridge personality, are awarded annually by the Greater New York Bridge Association for individual performance during a calendar year. One is the Spero Trophy for team play, and the other is the Lipton Trophy for overall achievement.

title: PUBLISHING: ISMS IN CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MUCH attention has been paid in recent times to representing modern themes and problems in children's books, especially the young-adult category. Divorce, remarriage, adjustments to new families, teen-age pregnancy, drug abuse and growing up with physical and mental handicaps have all been the themes of contemporary children's books.

title: Park Tour Sunday
description: How the designers of Central Park, Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, handled the problem of traffic through the park will be explored in a walking tour and slide show presented by the Urban Park Rangers on Sunday at 2 P.M., beginning at the Dairy, 65th Street, north of Wollman Memorial Rink. The 90-minute tour, which is free and goes on rain or shine, will cover bridle paths, transverse roads, carriage roads and footpaths. Information: 397-3156.

title: BOWDEN'S DREAMS SHATTERED
description: By halftime of today's Sugar Bowl game in New Orleans, with Georgia apparently holding its national ranking as the No. 1 college football team, Bobby Bowden's good ol' boy joking had stopped.

title: Block Plans Budget Cuts In Food Stamp Program
description: John R. Block, who has been designated by President-elect Ronald Reagan as Secretary of Agriculture, says the food stamp program will be the primary target for budget cuts in his department.

title: CZECHOSLOVAKS CONTRAST POLISH CRISIS TO THEIRS IN '68
description: Czechoslovak officials acknowledge that their Government's reaction to developments in neighboring Poland has been conditioned in part by the crisis of 1968, when the wavering leadership of Alexander Dubcek created a situation that finally led to invasion by Soviet-bloc forces.

title: REASSESSING LOAN AID FOR STEEL
description: At a time when many companies and entire industries are under financial strain, the Economic Development Administration, the key Federal agency to help communities and companies cope with economic decline, is re-examining a policy of providing hundreds of millions of dollars in loan guarantees to revitalize the steel industry.

title: New Year Reunites, More or Less, Feuding TV Stars
description: The new year was only a few hours old yesterday, when NBC-TV announced that an old feud between its stars of the late-night ''Tomorrow'' show, Tom Snyder and Rona Barrett, had been patched over, sort of.

title: MCNAMARA GAINS IN OPEN
description: He needed five sets, four hours and a little help from a friend, but Peter McNamara of Australia reached the semifinals of the $350,000 Australian open tennis tournament today, defeating Peter Rennert, 7-6, 5-7, 6-2, 6-7, 6-3.

title: URUGUAY'S PROUD PAST LIVES ON IN COPIOUS OLD CARS
description: The streets of Montevideo are filled with them - 1925 Packard roadsters for the the fun lovers of the flapper era, the utilitarian 1928 Model A's that Grandfather supposedly drove and those curvaceous 1938 Art Deco Chryslers, dripping with images of Raft and Bogart.

title: A West Point for the Indian Points
description: About a year ago, as part of the ''lessons learned'' from Three Mile Island, every nuclear plant in the country was required to hire a cadre of ''shift technical advisers.'' These technically trained individuals were intended to help operating personnel diagnose troubles more precisely. They were to stand aloof from the turmoil of reactor trouble in order to offer calm, reasoned advice on how to solve the crisis. Such advice could have headed off the misjudgments that nearly turned Three Mile Island into a disaster.

title: News Analysis
description: The Presidential commission that has recommended a fundamental ''reorientation of Federal urban policy'' to spur the migration of people toward jobs in the Sun Belt readily acknowledges the unorthodox nature of its prescription.

title: TURKISH ARMY TAMES TERRORISM, BUT INFLATION'S STILL RUNNING WILD
description: Turkey welcomed the new year with general satisfaction that the armed forces seem to have brought political terror under control but concern that inflation continues to soar, now topping the 100 percent level.

title: NOW LET'S GIVE A BIG WELCOME TO THE NEWEST COMICS IN TOWN
description: WHY do they do it? Why do they stand alone in a spotlight behind a microphone, shrouded in cigarette smoke late at night in clubs that are anything but luxurious? To New York's latest crop of young comics, the answer is really simple. Somewhere out there is the big break, the television series, the movie role that will make one rich and celebrated.

title: NEW CONNECTICUT GOVERNOR FACING TESTT; News Analysis
description: Yesterday, as he became the 84th Governor of Connecticut, William A. O'Neill was thrust from the comfortable obscurity of the Lieutenant Governor's office into a sudden test of his ability to govern the state and to build a record on which to run for Governor himself in two years.

title: Rockets 117, Jazz 103
description: The Rockets had four players score 20 points or more, led by Rudy Tomjanovich, with 25, in the victory over Utah. In addition to Tomjanovich, Moses Malone and Robert Reid each scored 22 points and Calvin Murphy tossed in 20, including 10 in the final quarter, for Houston (17-22). Utah, which fell to 16-24, was led by Adrian Dantley, who had 27 points.

title: Incinerator Closing In South Brooklyn
description: The 18-year-old Hamilton Avenue incinerator in South Brooklyn will be shut down by the City Department of Sanitation today, the third of six city incinerators to be closed in the last 18 months for failing to meet air standards.

title: Ceferino Garcia, Former Boxing Champion, 77
description: Ceferino Garcia, a former middleweight boxing champion who fought Fred Apostoli and Henry Armstrong in the most famous of his 116 professional bouts, died yesterday in a San Diego hospital at the age of 77.

title: Biles, Phillips Aide, Named to Oiler Post
description: Ed Biles, the Houston Oilers' defensive coordinator, was named head coach to replace Bum Phillips today, and he immediately announced that changes would be made in the team's sagging offense.

title: David Lynch, Sang With Platters
description: David Lynch, one of the original members of the Platters singing group formed in the 1950's, died today of cancer at the Veterans Administration Hospital here.

title: Brooklyn Recluse Leaves $430,148
description: A 79-year-old recluse who died Monday left $430,147.95, much of it cash strewn around his Brooklyn apartment, according to the Housing Authority Police.

title: THE SOVIET FIEF CALLED EAST GERMANY
description: To the Editor:

title: Suns 133, Nuggets 132
description: Len Robinson scored 32 points - 19 in the first quarter - to lead Phoenix over the Nuggets. It was a goaltending call against Denver's David Thompson with 38 seconds to go that enabled the Suns to win. With the score tied at 131-131, Thompson missed a long outside shot and Alvin Scott of the Suns came in for a layup, which Thompson pinned against the backboard.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AZL Resources Inc. acquired 90.6 percent of Solar Petroleum Inc. and agreed to buy its remaining shares early in 1981 in a transaction valued at about $15.7 million.

title: INDUSTRY AND WOMEN CLASH OVER HAZARDS IN WORKPLACE
description: A little over two years ago, four women workers startled the country by disclosing that they had voluntarily undergone sterilization to keep their high-paying jobs at a lead pigment plant run by the American Cyanamid Company in West Virginia. Because the lead was potentially harmful to fetuses, the company would not permit fertile women to work in some areas of the plant.

title: Brooks Quits Post but Not for Rangers
description: Herb Brooks, who coached the United States team to an Olympic gold medal in hockey last winter, resigned today as coach of the Davos hockey club of Switzerland.

title: UNIVERSITY PREPARES TO GROW OIL
description: Within five years, the University of Arizona will be turning tons of desert plants into oil, gasoline and petrochemicals, preparing for the day when plant-produced oil will supply 5 to 10 percent of the nation's energy needs, a researcher at the school says.

title: THE BATTLE FOR AN INMATE'S MIND
description: ''To get you to confess they don't use physical torture, I could have stood it better that way,'' said a former Red Guard of his experiences in a labor reform camp. ''It was all mental pressure.''

title: CANDYMAN-DESIGNATE FOR PRESIDENT-ELECT'S SWEET TOOTH; Candyman-Designate for President-Elect's Sweet Tooth
description: Whatever else you may have heard about how things will be run in the Reagan White House, you may be sure of one thing: ''There will be jelly beans in the White House, that's all I can say about it.''

title: Israel Inflation Rate 135%
description: Israel's inflation rate for 1980 reached a record 135 percent, according to an estimate issued today by the Central Bureau of Statistics. The bureau said the value of the Israeli currency, the shekel, fell by 114 percent against the dollar over the year. The International Monetary Fund said this week that Israel's inflation rate was the world's highest, ahead of Turkey and Argentina.

title: SURVEY OF 'SAFE' ADDITIVES COMPLETE
description: THREE years ago Congress enacted a law regulating food additives, which stipulated, among other things, that each ingredient had to be shown to be safe in order to remain on the market. But the law contained a loophole: Generally Regarded As Safe (GRAS) materials were exempted.

title: Index; International
description: Widow of Osip Mandelstam, the Soviet poet, buried at Moscow 3 Israel reports victims of terror- ism down by half 3 Begin ordered to rest with cold, but to attend Sunday meetings 3 Around the World 4 Ex-Red Guard tells of experience in a reform camp in China 4 Government/Politics Novel legal concept: Justice Dept. vs. regulatory units 7 New rules are issued to protect journalists from searches 7 Carter and Georgia friends at football game 9 Suffolk Legislature ousts Noto, its Presiding Officer 24 General Around the Nation 6 Japanese investment is swelling in Hawaii's tourist trade 6 Frozen teen-ager's recovery called ''a miracle'' 6 Tenants at 345 East 56th Street are looking at the dark side 23 Talk of Buffalo: tense and worried over slayings 23 The Region 24 New suspect arrested in slaying of Port Authority officer 24 The City 25 Some city bus drivers are paid just to wait for buses 25 Arts/Entertainment Papp hopes ''Pirates'' will be an- other ''Chorus Line'' 12 Zwi Kanar presents 11 mime solos 12 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of predictions of unusually cold weather, alternate-side parking is suspended today in Queens, Brooklyn,- the Bronx and Staten Island. All other parking rules remain in effect. CityJulie Harris ill; ''Mixed Cou- ples'' is closing 12 ''Play of St. Nicholas'' at Cathe- dral of St. John the Divine 13 ''City People,'' a history by Gun- ther Barth, reviewed 19 British students seem to prefer classics to best-sellers 19 Fire breaks out in La Scala Opera House; causes little damage 43 Royal Opera House plans to video- tape operas and ballets 43 Style Consumer Saturday: Survey of safe additives complete 44 Fashion buys all over town 44 De Gustibus: To readers' dismay, a supermarket classic changes 44 Sports Miami downs Virginia Tech, 20-10, in Peach Bowl 14 College football's year of the Bull- dog has perfect windup 14 Florida State coach sees bright spot in Orange Bowl loss 14 Rangers beat Islanders, 3-1, at Garden 15 Nets drop 7th straight as Cava- liers win, 111-105 15 Vilas, extended to 5 sets by Sadri, gains Australian semifinals 15 Coaching vital in high-stakes N.F.L. playoffs 15 Ed Biles, Oilers' defensive coordi- nator, replaces Phillips 15 Musselman, Cavaliers' coach, used to riding out storms 16 Pistons beat Knicks 102-100 17 George Vecsey on Butch Goring and his venerable helmet 18 Obituaries The Rev. Ernest Ryden, Lutheran minister and hymnologist 26 Features/Notes Issue and debate: Excluding women from hazardous jobs 9 Saturday News Quiz 19 About New York 25 Notes on People 43 News Analysis John Vinocur views French-Ger- man ties 2 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 20

title: RICHARD WATTS, DRAMA CRITIC AT TRIBUNE AND POST
description: Richard Watts, drama critic for The New York Herald Tribune and The New York Post between 1936 and 1976 who was also a foreign correspondent and World War II civilian aide, died of cardiac arrest yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He had suffered a stroke recently and had been in a coma for several weeks. He was 82 years old, and lived in Manhattan.

title: U.S. MAY APPEAL RULING FORBIDDING INDEFINITE DETENTION OF REFUGEE
description: Federal officials said today that the Government would probably appeal a Federal judge's ruling that the detention of a Cuban refugee was unlawful. But they said they would also have to consider other alternatives, such as the conditional release of some of the Cubans being held in prison for eventual return to Cuba.

title: DECONGESTING TRAFFIC
description: Despite worsening traffic congestion in New York City's central business district, there has been no concerted effort to apply engineering techniques that could substantially improve the movement of traffic.

title:
PATENTS;
Color Calculator For Use in Photo Labs
description: A color calculator invented by Thomas E. Norton of Cambridge, Mass., is regarded as useful for photo laboratories, commercial art departments and printers.

title: Fire Fatal to 7 Linked to Wiring
description: A fire that roared through a frame house and killed seven members of a family on New Year's Day may have been caused by too-heavy fuses and overheated wiring, authorities said.

title: The Back-Door Physicians
description: Thousands of students rejected by American medical schools are attending second-rate schools abroad and then returning for further clinical training and eventually a license to practice medicine in the United States. The situation has stirred bitter controversy. Parents of the overseas students are pressing to facilitate their return while American medical schools are resisting.

title: Old Dominion Trounces Columbia Five, 92 to 58
description: Ronnie McAdoo passed the 1,000-point career scoring mark as Old Dominion rolled to a 51-18 halftime lead and routed Columbia, 92-58, tonight in the opening game of the Old Dominion Classic.

title: The Economy
description: The prime rate was cut a full percentage point, to 20 1/2 percent from 21 1/2 percent, by major banks across the country. It was the first major retreat for the key bank lending rate in a six-week surge that carried it to record levels. Analysts, while cautious, expect the decline to continue at a gradual pace. (Page 1.)

title: No Headline
description: With new and younger management taking over at most levels, Sears, Roebuck and Company, the nation's largest retailer, is looking forward to regaining its former luster with the financial community and its own customers, despite the problems posed by a less-than-vigorous economy.

title:
Patents;
Process Cuts Solar Power Cost
description: WASHINGTON APROCESS designed to reduce the cost of drawing power from the sun was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The process involves the heating of silicon to form ribbon-shaped crystals for use in solar cells.

title: DAKOTA TEEN-AGER RECOVERS AFTER BEING 'FROZEN STIFF'
description: Jean Hilliard was literally frozen stiff, ''like a piece of meat out of a deep freeze,'' when a friend found her in the snow after a night of 22-below-zero temperatures. But the 19-year-old has made an unusual recovery.

title: Exhibition on Art of Benin At N.Y.U.'s Grey Gallery
description: Cast bronzes, carved ivories and terra cotta figures will be on display at the Grey Gallery and Study Center of New York University, 33 Washington Place, in ''Images of Power: The Royal Court of Benin'' from Jan. 23 to Feb. 21.

title: Two Judges Clash Again In Louisiana School Dispute
description: A state judge ordered the police today to accompany three white girls to an all-white school when classes resume Monday. The directive was aimed at thwarting a Federal judge's efforts to send them to an integrated school as part of his desegregation order.

title: U.S. TAKES 5 OF 10 SWIM EVENTS
description: Tracy Caulkins, Mary T. Meagher, Craig Beardsley and Rick Carey led the way with world-best times as United States swimmers won five of 10 individual events tonight in an international swim meet, beating Olympic gold medalists each time.

title: JACQUES L. BRIL
description: Jacques L. Bril, a consulting criminologist who was an expert on and innovator of lie-detector techniques, died last Sunday on a cruise ship in the Caribbean.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Snow - snow, it's terrific!'' -Elmer Bartek at Mount Mansfield near Stowe, Vt. (6:2.)

title: DISASTROUS CON ED SURRENDER
description: To the Editor:

title: LOUISANA GENERAL SERVICES INC.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Olivetti Typewriters
description: The Olivetti Corporation will introduce two portable electronic typewriters next week that are designed for personal use. The company said that the machines, called the Praxis 35 and Praxis 30, would be marketed to doctors, dentists, pharmacists and private users who require high-quality print.

title: TRAINING MACHINISTS
description: It's we-hate-CETA time again on the small-business front. This time, the challenge is taking the form of crisis warnings. The National Tooling and Machining Association has told Congress that if it wants to step up production of military hardware, the machining industry may not be able to handle the work, at least not without cutting back severely on civilian production, because the machinists it needs don't exist. What the association wants to do is start a ''massive training effort.'' This translates into breaking Federal training dollars free from CETA.

title: DONATIONS SENT BY YOUNGSTERS TO HELP NEEDY
description: Children are often among contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund during the holiday season, with many continuing a tradition established by their parents,

title: G.M. PRICES UP AVERAGE $149, OR 1.5%
description: The General Motors Corporation today announced its third price rise on its 1981 models, this time raising average list prices by $149, or 1.5 percent.

title: Fourth Suspect Identified In Slaying of Iranian
description: Federal prosecutors said today that they believed a Washington cabdriver, identified as Musa Abdul Majid, supplied the ammunition and possibly the weapon used in the slaying last July of the Iranian exile Ali Akbar Tabatabai by a man posing as a mailman.

title: YOU CAN'T LOSE 'EM ALL
description: Now that it's over I have to admit it was a pretty good holiday around our place. Our son Duke and his wife Louise came and spent several days and brought their dog Biff.

title: Kenya Hunts for Suspect In Fatal Hotel Bombing
description: The Kenyan police said today that they were now convinced that a bomb had caused the explosion that destroyed Nairobi's landmark Norfolk Hotel, killing 13 New Year's Eve revelers, and that they were searching for a male guest traveling with a Maltese passport in connection with the incident.

title: U.S. Steel Sees Rise In '81 Shipments
description: The United States Steel Corporation said it expects domestic steel industry shipments of at least 90 million tons in 1981, compared with 84 million in 1980.

title: Start on 9-Digit ZIP Code Off From February to June
description: The Postal Service said today that it would delay until June plans to begin switching to a controversial nine-digit ZIP code.

title: 'COUPLES' CLOSING
description: Because of the illness of Julie Harris, James Prideaux's comedy ''Mixed Couples,'' which opened last Sunday, will close after tonight's performance at the Brooks Atkinson Theater. Geraldine Page, Rip Torn and Michael Higgins are also starred.

title: Carter Plans To; Wear Formal Attire Jan. 20
description: President Carter will wear a black club coat and striped pants at the inauguration of Ronald Reagan on Jan. 20, the President's press secretary said today.

title: U.S. ASKS SHARP CUT IN WATER POLLUTION BY STEEL PRODUCERS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed stringent new rules requiring producers of iron and steel to cut down substantially on the toxic substances and other pollutants that they discharge into the nation's water supply.

title: INQUIRY BEGUN IN REPORT OF FLORIDA PRISON BEATINGS
description: The United States Attorney's office here is investigating charges by a state prison inmate that he routinely administered beatings to fellow prisoners with the approval of guards and that one beating resulted in the death of a fellow inmate at the Union Correctional Institution.

title: SNOWFALL AND RECORD COLD BRING AID TO SKIING INDUSTRY IN THE EAST
description: The ski industry in the eastern half of the country has roared back to life this winter as record cold temperatures and small but regular snowstorms combined to bring skiers streaming back to the slopes.

title: 843 Couples Say They Will at Engagement Ceremony
description: Whatever the Rev. Sun Myung Moon does, he likes to do in a big way. Like matchmaking, for example. Yesterday and on New Year's Day, the leader of the Unification Church performed mass engagement ceremonies in New York for 843 couples.

title: Ampco-Pittsburgh's Buffalo Forge Bid
description: The Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation said that its wholly owned subsidiary, the Ampco-Pittsburgh Securities Corporation, intended to make a tender offer for all the outstanding shares of the Buffalo Forge Company's outstanding stock at $25 a share.

title: Choir and Organ Concert
description: Paul-Martin Maki will direct the choir and William Entriken will be the organist in a performance of music for choir and organ tomorrow at 4 P.M. in St. Michael's Church, 225 West 99th Street.

title: WHAT PRICE THE LIFE OF A HOSTAGE?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Not to Believe Your Partner Is Occasionally a Good Idea
description: It often happens that a player must choose between believing his partner and believing an opponent. In general, it is right to believe one's partner, but there are exceptions. If the bidding seems to indicate that the total number of points around the table greatly exceeds the standard 40, it is wise to examine the vulnerability. The vulnerable partnership is usually honest, while a nonvulnerable player may be drawing the longbow.

title: LENOX INC.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Trials of the Dead
description: Historical revisionism is nothing new, but there's a novel twist. More and more historical figures and ideas are being hauled up for retrial before actual tribunals.

title: ALGERIAN ENVOYS RETURN TO TEHERAN WITH NEW U.S. OFFERS ON HOSTAGES
description: The Algerian intermediaries returned here today with the latest United States proposals and terms for the release of the 52 American hostages.

title: Oil Acreage Picked For Alaska Search
description: The Interior Department today selected 3.4 million acres of land north of Alaska's Aleutian Islands for possible oil and gas exploration.

title: Ruling Is Issued in Favor Of Ship Pilot in Fatal Crash
description: A state hearing officer ruled today that a harbor pilot acted reasonably and prudently in guiding the ship that struck the Sunshine Skyway Bridge in an accident that killed 35 persons.

title: LEAR FLIES ITS NEW LIGHTWEIGHT
description: The Lear Fan, the first of a new breed of planes built entirely of lightweight nonmetallic materials that promise big fuel economies, has made its first test flight.

title: RULES ISSUED TO PROTECT JOURNALISTS FROM SEARCHES
description: The Justice Department published guidelines today restricting the use of search warrants by Federal investigators seeking documents, tape recordings or similar materials from journalists, lawyers, physicians and clergymen who are not suspected of any crime.

title: BRITAIN'S STUDENTS FAVOR CLASSICS, NOT BEST-SELLERS
description: British students seem to favor the classics over today's best-sellers in what The Times of London calls a reassuring development - but a surprise.

title: Zlotkin in Cello Recital
description: Frederick Zlotkin, cellist, will give a recital with Margo Garett, pianist, tonight at 8 o'clock in the 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue. On the program are Bach's Suite No. 3 in C for unaccompanied cello, Schumann's Fantasiestucke for cello and piano (Op. 73), Shostakovich's Sonata in D minor (Op. 40), Chopin's Polonaise Brilliante (Op. 3) and Francoeur's Sonata in E. Tickets are $6, $7 and $8.50. For information, call 427-6000.

title: Algeria Storm Cuts Oil Flow
description: A storm that closed the Algerian oil port of Arzew has stopped about half of the country's oil and gas exports from reaching the world market and it might take at least 10 days to restore output, according to oil industry sources.

title: Christian de Juniac Weds Miss Holland
description: Kristine Holland and Christian de Juniac, who received M.B.A. degrees last year from Harvard University and are management consultants with the Boston Consulting Group, were married in Wellesley, Mass., yesterday. The Rev. Richard Holloway performed the Episcopal ceremony in the chapel at Wellesley College, from which the bride was graduated as a Durant Scholar.

title: Spurs 118, Lakers 112
description: James Silas scored 10 points in the last four a half minutes to help San Antonio defeat Los Angeles.

title: 8 EAST SIDE TENANTS LOOK AT THE DARK SIDE
description: There was a time when Patricia Matthews could look down from the window of her 11th-floor apartment's small bedroom to the corner of East 57th Street and First Avenue.

title: THE GREEN HOUSE
description: In the late 1880's, Escanaba, then a city of 10,000, in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan, had more than 100 saloons and two city blocks of brothels. It was the largest iron-ore shipping port in the country, but it was most famed as a fun center.

title: West German Sentenced in East On Charge of Smuggling People
description: A court in Potsdam today sentenced a West German to six years in prison for allegedly working for a gang that smuggled East Germans to the West, the official East German press agency said.

title: Inquiry Continues In Teacher's Slaying
description: Detectives continued their investigation yesterday into the fatal stabbing of a 23-year-old Brooklyn schoolteacher whose body was found Thursday morning in the back seat of her car.

title: Cities Service Raising Prices
description: The Cities Service Company will raise wholesale gasoline and home heating oil prices 5 cents a gallon on Monday, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: ROYAL OPERA AND BBC TO VIDEOTAPE PRODUCTIONS
description: Britain's Royal Opera House at Covent Garden announced today that it would make opera and ballet more accessible by means of video cassette and videodisk recordings.

title: Train Kills Mount Kisco Woman
description: Helen Johnson, 51 years old, of Mount Kisco was killed when she was hit by a Conrail train today as she was crossing the tracks here, the police said.

title: Strike Threatened, Conrail Talks Are Set
description: NEW HAVEN (UPI) - Union and Conrail officials agreed to meet over the weekend in an effort to head off a strike scheduled for midnight Sunday that could affect 85,000 commuters in southern New England and New York.

title: energywatch
description: Dec. 26, 1980, Crude oil supplies rose slightly to 374.6 million barrels.

title: BUSINESS LOANS DROP $1.2 BILLION
description: Commercial and industrial loans made by major New York City banks fell by $1.2 billion in the week ended Dec. 24, the first such drop in recent weeks, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: PRIME RATE TRIMMED ON POINT, TO 20 1 2%, BY BANKS ACROSS U.S.
description: Banks across the country, reversing a pattern of rapid increases in their loan charges since mid-November, dropped their prime lending rates yesterday to 20 1/2 percent from a record 21 1/2 percent.

title: CONFIDENT KODAK LIFTS PRICES
description: In a move that stock analysts said demonstrated unusual confidence in its hold on consumers, Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it would raise prices an average of 8 percent on a wide variety of photographic products.

title: Chrysler Loan Board to Meet
description: The Chrysler Corporation Loan Guarantee Board said today that it will meet next Tuesday to resume consideration of Chrysler's request for another $400 million in Federal loan guarantees.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 20.50-21.50 ** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Coaches Vital in High-Stakes Pro Playoffs
description: As the Houston Oilers' Bum Phillips was reminded once again when he was discharged on Wednesday after losing on Sunday, the importance of coaches can never be underestimated in playoff games. The stakes are high; the ultimate goal, the Super Bowl, is near, and the occasion is one for bold coaching direction.

title: Geneen Group Bids for Cannon Mills
description: The Cannon Mills Company, the largest manufacturer of cotton towels in the nation, disclosed yesterday that a small group of investors headed by Harold S. Geneen, the retired board chairman of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, had offered to buy the company for $376 million in cash.

title: SALVADORAN REBELS STILL PREDICT AN OFFENSIVE
description: For the second time in a week, a top guerrilla commander has said that leftist insurgents will soon open a military offensive to overthrow the Government.

title: 'Live From Lincoln Center' Plans 2 February Shows
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, with Itzhak Perlman, violinist, and the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, with Vladimir Ashkenazy, pianist, will be featured in two ''Live From Lincoln Center'' shows next month on PBS.

title: Palau Islands in Pacific Become Republic of Belau
description: The Palau Islands in the western Pacific have become the world's newest independent nation, the Republic of Belau.

title: st
description: Sadr of Iran in a photo made available by the Iranian press agency.

title: Bus Breaks Queens Water Main
description: A street collapsed yesterday under a private bus driving through Queens, the police said, and as the vehicle fell into the hole it ruptured a water main, flooding the area. There were no immediate reports of injuries. The cave-in was at Queens and Woodhaven Boulevards.

title: ERNEST E. RYDEN, 94, HYMNOLOGIST
description: The Rev. Ernest Edwin Ryden, a Lutheran minister, journalist and hymnologist who helped unify four denominations to form the Lutheran Church in America, died Thursday in Providence, R.I. He was 94 years old.

title: A Perfect Year of the Bulldog
description: Pondering the kind of events that had befallen Georgia's undefeated and untied football team all season long, John Scully, Notre Dame's all-America center, paused after yesterday's Sugar Bowl game and said:

title: RANGERS DEFEAT ISLANDERS BY 3-1
description: In a contest reminiscent of the Rangers' stirring semifinal conquest of the Islanders in the 1979 playoffs, the Rangers played 60 inspired minutes against the defending Stanley Cup champions and earned a 3-1 victory last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Ashland Offer Filled For Integon Shares
description: Ashland Oil Inc. said about 3.14 million shares of the Integon Corporation's stock were tendered as of midnight Dec. 31 in response to its offer for up to 2.84 million shares at $40 cash a share.

title: A TOUCH OF ROMAN
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. IS ARMING FOR REDISTRICTING, ARMED WITH CENSUS AND COMPUTER
description: Using campaign contributions, computer programs and careful planning, the Republican Party has positioned itself to take advantage of the 1980 census figures when the Congressional and state legislative redistricting battles are fought in the 50 state capitals this year.

title: TO READERS' DISMAY, A SUPERMARKET CLASSIC CHANGES
description: Now that reading the fine print on the labels of food packages has become a national pastime, even the smallest changes in contents are rapidly noticed, to say nothing of a change as major as new ownership. And consumers persist, no matter how difficult manufacturers make it to read those labels. A case in point is what might be called the Sacramento Tomato Juice Caper. A few weeks ago that product was included in a list of supermarket classics that appeared here.

title: ANSWERS OF QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 19. 1. Marinus van der Lubbe was found guilty of setting fire to the Reichstag, the seat of the German Parliament; he was put to death in 1934.

title: Arrows Down Avalanche As Zungul Scores 4 Goals
description: Steve Zungul scored four goals and made two assists as he led the New York Arrows to an 8-3 victory over the Detroit Avalanche tonight in a Major Indoor Soccer League game before 6,893 at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: PORTLAND (PCL) - Signed Earl Wil- l iams, catcher, the National League rookie o f the year with Atlanta Braves in 1971. BASKETBALL DALLAS (NBA) - Signed Monti Davis as f ree agent and placed Ralph Drollinger, a c enter who has tendinitis, on injured-re- s erve list.

title: OFFICER IS BADLY HURT IN BROOKLYN SHOOTOUT
description: A plainclothes police officer lying on a sidewalk was shot and critically wounded with his own gun yesterday in a shootout involving his partner and a suspect who had wrested his weapon away in a struggle outside a Brooklyn housing project.

title: APPLICATION ENGINEERING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MIME: ZWI KANAR'S SOLOS
description: Zwi Kanar is a tiny, baldish man with an impish face and neatly turned-out legs. His presence alone lends itself to funny and touching characterization.

title: El Al to Purchase Four Boeing 767's
description: The Israeli Government has signed a $200 million contract with the Boeing Company to buy four Boeing 767's for El Al, sources at the national airline said.

title: Musselman of Cavaliers Used to Riding Out Storms
description: In one way, at least, Bill Musselman is the perfect coach for the Cleveland Cavaliers, because in a career at the high school, college, minor league and major league levels he has often been at the center of controversy.

title: Sharon Walsted Packey Is Bride of Barnet Phillips 4th
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More yesterday, Sharon Walsted Packey, a financial analyst with the Union Carbide Corporation, was married to Barnet Phillips 4th, a partner in the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. Msgr. James G. Wilders performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: RUSSIANS BURY NADEZHDA MANDELSTAM
description: Nadezhda Mandelstam, widow of Osip Mandelstam, the poet who died in a Stalinist purge, was buried today on the outskirts of Moscow.

title: ISRAEL SAYS CASUALTIES FROM TERRORISM ARE CUT BY HALF
description: Israeli casualties from terrorist incidents dropped by more than half in 1980, according to an army report made public yesterday. The report said that Israel's policy of preventive strikes at Palestinian bases had ''paralyzed'' terrorist activity.

title: France Urges An 'Oil Bank'
description: France has proposed that industrialized nations form an ''oil bank'' to which they will contribute a share of their oil to be used by any member suddenly suffering from an oil shortage, according to officials of the French ministry of industry.

title: FLORIDA STATE LOOKS AT THE BRIGHT SIDE
description: The morning after a spectacular Orange Bowl game that Oklahoma did not clinch until the final play, the losing coach, Bobby Bowden, was feeling pretty good about his Florida State team, and the winning coach, Barry Switzer, was saying, ''We're not a very good football team.''

title: Panel to Weigh Rules In Subway Dispute
description: The Transit Authority set up a committee to determine who has the authority to shut off power in the subways during an emergency. The decision was made after a transit police officer and a trainmaster argued about who had the right to turn off power at a station where a woman had jumped in front of a train.

title: Lisa Minnelli Suffers Another Miscarriage
description: Lisa Minnelli has lost the baby she was expecting in May. It would have been the first child for the 34-year-old entertainer, who suffered the miscarriage at the Washoe Medical Center in Reno late New Year's Day.

title: SWELLING JAPANESE INVESTMENT IS PLAYING A KEY ROLE IN HAWAII'S TOURIST TRADE
description: Japanese investors have now bought almost every resort hotel on Waikiki Beach, the keystone of Hawaii's economy. It was the destination of most of about four million tourists who visited the state in 1980 and provided its greatest source of revenue.

title: Chinese Buy Austen, Bronte
description: Jane Austen's ''Pride and Prejudice,'' Charlotte Bronte's ''Jane Eyre'' and Romain Rolland's ''Jean Christophe'' were among the most popular translations sold in China's state-run bookshops last year, the New China News Agency reported today. It said that books on economics had also become more popular, but gave no figures.

title: Rockets 124, Mavericks 120
description: Houston's Calvin Murphy hit a 3-point field goal with four seconds to play, sending the game into overtime, and the Rockets never trailed thereafter. Moses Malone had 40 points and Murphy 38 for the Rockets. Geoff Huston scored 29 points and Jim Spanarkel had 26 for Dallas.

title: SOCIAL-INSURANCE CRISES
description: The safest economic prediction of the season is that the new Congress will cut personal and business income taxes. The size and shape of the cut remains uncertain, for President-elect Ronald Reagan still supports the Kemp-Roth bill, which would reduce taxes by about $192 billion per year by 1985. But while we contemplate huge income-tax cuts, quiet crises in our two most important social-insurance systems create the likelihood of substantial increases in payroll taxes soon.

title: BIPARTISAN GROUP IN SUFFOLK LEGISLATURE OUSTS NOTO
description: An unusual coalition of Republicans and Democrats yesterday ousted Anthony Noto as Presiding Officer of the Suffolk County Legislature and elected William Richards to succeed him.

title: Swap for Power Is Victor By Nose in Montauk Dash
description: Swap for Power won by a nose and a decision yesterday in the $54,400 Montauk Stakes for New York breds at Aqueduct.

title: CROWNAMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
VILAS GAINS SEMIFINALS
description: Guillermo Vilas of Argentina survived a severe challenge today from last year's runner-up, John Sadri, and kept alive his quest for a third straight Australian open tennis title.

title: MANY NEW YORK CLUBS AND OFFICE BUILDINGS VIOLATE THE FIRE LAWS
description: More than two-thirds of the nightclubs, discotheques and social clubs in New York City are in violation of a law requiring them to install improved fire safety devices, according to officials of the Department of Buildings.

title: TURKEY SAID TO SEIZE 10 ACADEMICS, STIRRING FEARS AMONG INTELLECTUALS
description: Turkish martial law authorities have detained the president and nine professors of the Academy of Economic and Commercial Sciences in Adana, according to authoritative sources in that southern industrial center.

title: Gas Supplies Held Adequate
description: Natural gas supplies, which ran out in the rugged winter of 1976-77, will just about cover this season's heating and fuel demands even if the weather is unusually cold, the Energy Department said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PROLONGING THE SEASON

title: Charles F. H. Johnson Jr. Is Dead; Former President of Botany Mills
description: Charles F. H. Johnson Jr., former president of Botany Mills Inc., a textile concern, and a well-known horse breeder and owner of the Bernadotte Farm in Colts Neck, N.J., died Saturday at his home in Colts Neck. He was 74 years old.

title: THE $30-PER-WEEK FOOD BUDGET PUZZLE
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: 'ST. NICHOLAS PLAY'
description: For thoughtful celebrators of Christmas, ''The Play of St. Nicholas'' may well become a seasonal tradition, perhaps never rivaling the mass appeal of ''Messiah'' but still offering a chaste and quiet reflection on the giving of gifts and the miracles of Christianity's past.

title: Earl Williams Is Signed By Minor League Team
description: Earl Williams, the National League's 1971 rookie of the year, has signed a one-year contract with the Portland Beavers of the Pacific Coast League.

title: NETS' LOSING STREAK HITS 7 AS CAVS WIN
description: The New Jersey Nets revived briefly in the third quarter tonight, turning a 13-point deficit into a 9-point lead against the Cleveland Cavaliers. But the Nets were outscored, 37-22, in the final quarter and lost for the seventh straight time, 111-105, before a crowd of 7,147 at the Rutgers Athletic Center.

title: Deere Stock Offering
description: Deere & Company said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of 4 million shares, underwritten by the Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group.

title: PREMIER RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $147,000 for the qr and $187,000 for

title: BRONSTON GETS 4 MONTHS IN BUS-STOP FRAUD CASE
description: Jack E. Bronston, a former State Senator from Queens, was sentenced to serve four months in prison yesterday on fraud charges that grew out of a controversial franchise for bus-stop shelters in New York City.

title: HIS CAREER SPANNED 4 DECADES
description: Today's credit markets, characterized by double-digit interest rates and bond prices that routinely change a point or more in a day, might seem to have little in common with the market of 1951 when Treasury bonds yielded less than 3 percent and a 1/4-point price change was a big move.

title: Brzezinski Defends Role After McHenry's Attack
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser, issued a statement today concerning criticism of him by Donald F. McHenry, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations.

title: Silver Objects Stolen From Jewish Center
description: A Brooklyn Jewish Center was broken into yesterday evening and $10,000 worth of silver objects were stolen, the police said. The thief or thieves shattered the front window of the building, the Remsen Heights Jewish Center, at 8700 Avenue K, between 5:30 P.M. and 7:30 P.M., according to a police spokesman.

title: Begin Is Told to Rest With a Cold But Plans for Meeting of Cabinet
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin, suffering from a cold, has been ordered to stay at home for several days but expects to attend important meetings on Sunday, his spokesman said today.

title: Sweden Downs Soviet Six
description: Sweden defeated the Soviet Union, the defending champion, 3-2, today to win ice hockey's world junior championship.

title: BUFFALO BLACKS ARE ANGERED OVER SLAYINGS; The Talk of Buffalo
description: Clenching the remnant of a cigar between his teeth, Nathaniel Hall took short, careful steps along the snowblanketed street on his way to the Main and Utica Tobacco Stand. He paused briefly in the stinging cold to articulate a concern of black citizens of this industrial city on Lake Erie.

title: Coach Considers Quitting After Striking a Referee
description: Mickey Wells's future as women's basketball coach at Morehead State University was in doubt today after he struck a referee in a game at the University of Kentucky last night.

title: Your Money; Moving to Gas From Oil Heat
description: WASHINGTON WITH those big winter heating bills once again landing in the mailbox, perhaps in the company of Christmas bills and tax forms, many homeowners with oil furnaces will be prompted to take a new look at the economics of converting to natural gas. Now is a good time to do this since the natural seasons for actually performing such work are spring and summer.

title: REAGAN TO RESTUDY GRAIN CURB
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan declined today to commit himself to lifting the curtailment on grain sales and shipments to the Soviet Union, a pledge he had made during last year's campaign.

title:
PATENTS;
Honey Bee Colonies Have Two Separate Queens
description: An engineer employed by the Army has, in his spare time, devised an approved method of creating large honey bee colonies with two queen bees, which are isolated to prevent one from killing the other. Otis R. Pannell of Alexandria, Va., has been awarded patent 4,241,467 for a hive arrangement with four chambers, between which only the honey bees can pass.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JANUARY 3, 1981
description: International The latest American proposals for freeing the hostages were brought to Teheran by the Algerian intermediaries after four days of talks in Washington. The United States and Iran appear to have reached general agreement on the conditions for the hostages' freedom. The American terms reportedly call for the deposit of $5 billion to $6 billion in Iranian frozen assets - the amount relatively unencumbered by lawsuits in the United States - in the Algerian Central Bank. (Page 1, Columns 4-5.) China maintains prison labor camps in which hundreds of thousands of people have been detained, according to reports from several dozen former inmates. (1:2-4.)

title: Con Ed to Get a Refund Of $16.9 Million for Oil
description: An oil company has been ordered to pay the Consolidated Edison Company $16.9 million for overcharges, and a Con Edison spokesman said its customers would receive rebates as a result.

title: CAR EXHAUST TEST BEGINS FOR NEW YORK CITY AREA
description: A computerized analysis of exhaust emissions became part of the state automobile-inspection procedures for the 3.9 million cars in the New York City metropolitan area on New Year's Day.

title: SEOUL'S DISMAL RECORD ON HUMAN RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: MR. PAPP'S TREASURE CHEST MOVES TO THE GREAT INDOORS
description: When Joseph Papp's musically updated version of Gilbert and Sullivan's ''The Pirates of Penzance'' opens at the Uris Theater on Broadway next Thursday, the producer is hoping that it will become what ''A Chorus Line'' became five years ago - a seemingly limitless source of funds to subsidize his Off Broadway experiments.

title: HUNDREDS OF THOUSANDS TOIL IN CHINESE LABOR CAMPS
description: Despite a recent effort to create a fair legal system and prevent a renewal of the arbitrary persecutions of the Cultural Revolution era, China still operates a vast network of labor reform camps populated by hundreds of thousands of prisoners.

title: F.T.C. Asks Delay In LTV Acquisition
description: The Federal Trade Commission asked a Federal court in Dallas to delay the proposed acquisition of the Wilson Oil Rig Manufacturing Company by the LTV Corporation.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Red Brigades Reports Killing Antiterrorist Police General

title: Daon to Acquire 50% of Omni Project
description: The Daon Development Corporation said it would acquire a 50 percent interest in the Omni International Atlanta project, a major hotel, office and retail complex in Atlanta, for $47 million.

title: Flames 7, Kings 6
description: Eric Vail scored a power-play goal with 25 seconds to play to give Calgary the victory over Los Angeles. Vail's goal came only five seconds after Marcel Dionne of the Kings scored a short-handed goal on a breakaway for a 6-6 tie.

title: FED-MART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 23
SOME CITY BUS DRIVERS BEING PAID TO WAIT
description: For the 20th day since the city's fleet of Grumman Flxible buses was pulled out of service, scores of bus drivers earned their regular wages yesterday even when there were no buses to drive - between $11,000 and $12,000 worth of nondriving, based on figures for the early part of the week.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Polish Newspaper Appeals For an Open Government
description: Poland's leaders considered a new warning from the Soviet Union today as a leading Polish newspaper appealed for a more open Government.

title: FACTORY ORDERS AND BUILDING UP
description: Factory orders and new construction increased modestly in November, the Commerce Department said today, offering evidence that the economy is holding up despite record-high interest rates.

title: No Headline
description: Los Angeles police officers moving into the market where a gunman held an assistant manager hostage for several hours. According to the police, 29-year-old Claudio Santi, the assistant manager, was shot by a man they identified as Ronald Berryman, who then turned the gun on himself.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 26. 1. A West Berlin court overturned a 1933 verdict and declared the defendant not guilty. Who was the defendant and why was he convicted? 2. After a monthlong investigation the United States Drug Enforcement Administration has identified a new narcotic that had proved fatal in several cases. What is the street name of the drug?

title: GLADDING CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-After a $14,735,000 gain on restructuring of debt under the Dec 11, 1978 court approved plan of bankruptcy, a tax benefit of $103,000 and income from discontinued operations of $112,000

title: HI-SHEAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $520,000 or 13 cents a shr gain on the sale of investment securities

title: FASHION BUYS ALL OVER TOWN
description: If you've been yearning for a Calvin Klein jacket or a Ralph Lauren skirt or a Perry Ellis sweater that was priced slightly out of your reach, you may now be able to afford it. Department stores are having their end-of-season sales -and to one shopper they seem to be more extensive in scope and more dramatic in markdowns than in recent years. While most reductions are between 30 and 50 percent, some items can be found at one-third original price.

title: Fire Set by Arsonists Damages Martinique Government Building
description: DE-FRANCE, Martinique, Jan. 2 (AP) - A fire set by arsonists severely damaged the Justice Building in the capital of this French island in the Caribbean, the police said today. A separatist group took responsibility for the blaze.

title: News Analysis
description: The friendship between West Germany and France, a basic element in Western Europe's relationship with both the United States and the Soviet Union, is losing some of its warmth. There have been no open clashes or publicly argued differences of opinion because they would serve little purpose, but officials in both capitals are acknowledging that the need the two countries felt to view world events with the same European outlook has diminished.

title: CURTISS RAISES OFFER FOR ITS SHARES TO $46
description: The Curtiss-Wright Corporation, in an effort to outmaneuver the Kennecott Corporation, said yesterday that it was increasing its offering price to buy 1 million shares of its own stock to $46 a share from $44.

title: GAMBLING'S BRIGHT PROMISE
description: To the Editor:

title: A More Perfect Union, in Europe
description: The new year has brought the admission of Greece to the Common Market - and with it, a welcome sign that northern Europe is beginning to take seriously its responsibilities to its southern neighbors. Like Portugal and Spain, which are negotiating for entry now, Greece is once again a thriving democracy after years of stifling right-wing dictatorship. The stability and development of the poorer democracies are in the urgent interest of a strong, united Europe - and the United States.

title: A MARKET FOR HOPE AMID EAST HARLEM RUINS
description: Across the street from the Park Avenue Banana Company in East Harlem, an old man in a fancy overcoat is peddling hope. He makes his way through the early morning scene in La Marqueta shouting in Spanish: ''Lottery, lottery - the first of the New Year.'' A few merchants take time out from opening their stalls in a heated enclosure under the rumbling elevated commuter trains. They greet the long-shot vendor and take another chance on a windfall.

title: Oil Shortage Doubted in '81
description: Barring an unforeseen upheaval in a major oil-producing nation, the United States probably will not face any serious oil shortages this year, but Americans will be paying up to $1.60 for a gallon of gas in 1981, a Cornell University economist says.

title: Rally Gives Market A Headstart for 1981
description: A late-blooming rally in blue chips provided a hearty send-off for the stock market yesterday in 1981's opening session. Several takeover bids also provided some of the day's excitement.

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times Gallant Hearts in the City By ANATOLE BROYARD CITY PEOPLE: The Rise of Modern City Culture in 19th-Century America. By Gunther Barth. Illustrated. 289 pages. Oxford University Press. $19.95.

title:
PATENTS;
Oral Hygiene Composition Designed to Fight Plaque
description: A New York dentist, Dr. David G. Vlock, has been granted a patent for an oral hygiene composition to inhibit plaque accumulation on teeth.

title: CHICAGO BOARD IS SET TO OFFER SCHOOL JOB
description: One year after it was rescued from the brink of bankruptcy, the Chicago school board is still trying to balance the school system's budget and to desegregate the city's schools and is facing another controversy as it tries to select a new school superintendent.

title:
PATENTS;
Bronx Builder Converts Waste Nuclear Energy
description: A real estate manager and contractor in the Bronx has patented an apparatus for converting waste nuclear energy to electricity.

title: Swiss Concerns Buy Fidelity and Deposit
description: The American General Corporation said its Maryland Casualty Company subsidiary had sold the Fidelity and Deposit Company of Maryland to a concern jointly owned by the Swiss Reinsurance Company and the Zurich Insurance Company for $135 million of adjustable rate notes.

title: Fire at La Scala Opera; Sprinklers Help Contain It
description: Fire broke out in La Scala opera house last night, but automatic sprinklers kept the damage to a minimum, fire officials reported.

title: Carter Moves to Improve; Fair Housing Program
description: President Carter issued an executive order today in a move designed to strengthen the Government's ability to administer its fair housing programs.

title: NEW SUSPECT SEIZED IN SLAYING OF PORT AUTHORITY OFFICER
description: Hudson County authorities said today that another suspect had been arrested in the slaying of a police officer for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and that they were sure they had the right man this time.

title: Mrs. Chennault, Backer Of Taiwan, Visits China
description: Anna Chennault, a member of the Republican Party's finance committee and long a staunch backer of the Nationalist Chinese Government on Taiwan, arrived in Peking today.

title: Ex-Premier of Portugal Stricken
description: A former Prime Minister of Portugal, Alfredo Nobre da Costa, is in stable condition after a heart attack during the night, medical sources said today. They added that Mr. da Costa, who was here on vacation, showed no complications. Mr. da Costa, who is 57 years old, became Portugal's first presidentially appointed Prime Minister in 1978. He served four months.

title: Sports of The Times; Venerable Helmet
description: THERE was one winter in the early 60's when every young hockey player in Winnipeg had to have a Tumba helmet. To play an amateur game with any other model would have been hopelessly out of style, like playing basketball in the wrong brand of sneakers.

title: Praise for a 'Good Guy'
description: He won't be giving up the anchorman position on the CBS Evening News until March, but already Walter Cronkite has received some generous praise from a couple of his chief competitors.

title: Miami Tops Va. Tech in Peach Bowl
description: Jim Kelly, a sophomore quarterback, threw for one touchdown and set up another with his passing in the opening half today to lead the Miami Hurricanes to a 20-10 Peach Bowl victory over Virginia Tech.

title: U.S.O. in Times Square
description: Since World War II, the U.S.O. has maintained its busiest and most famous facility in the heart of New York, just off Times Square.

title: The Washington Star
description: After a three-day Christmas vacation in Georgia, and a brief stop there to pick up friends on the way to help cheer the Georgia Bulldogs to victory in the Sugar Bowl, President Carter is planning another long weekend in his home state beginning next Thursday.

title: WASHINGTON, PEKING AND THE TAIWAN ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Peter Pan,' 'Nutcracker' Shown at Museum Today
description: Film versions of ''The Nutcracker'' and ''Peter Pan'' will be shown today at the Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street. The 1977 American Ballet Theater production of ''The Nutcracker,'' choreographed by and starring Mikhail Baryshnikov, can be seen at 12:30 and 2:30 P.M.

title: Justice Confirms Offer of State Dept. Post
description: Justice William Clark of the California Supreme Court confirmed today that he had been asked to become Deputy Secretary of State in the Reagan administration. Justice Clark, who was appointed by Gov. Ronald Reagan, said in a telephone interview that he had not decided whether to accept the post as top aide to Secretary of State-designate Alexander M. Haig Jr. He said that published reports of the offer had in general been correct.

title: FEDERAL COURTS SAY U.S. CAN SUE ITSELF
description: Two recent decisions by a Federal appeals court here have upheld the novel principle that the Justice Department may appeal to the courts to resolve its legal disputes with Federal regulatory agencies.

title: Pacers 109, Hawks 106
description: Louis Orr, a reserve forward, scored 21 points to help Indiana beat the Hawks and end a three-game losing streak.

title: EARLY DIRECTOR OF MOVIES
description: Raoul Walsh, a dynamic movie pioneer and a major director for nearly half a century, died of a heart attack Wednesday night at Simi Valley (Calif.) Adventist Hospital near Los Angeles. He was 93 years old.

title: Sale of Joslyn Unit
description: The Joslyn Manufacturing and Supply Company of Chicago said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the assets of its stainless steel division to a unit of Slater Steel Industries Ltd. of Hamilton, Ontario. Joslyn noted that the purchase price was subject to certain adjustments and would not exceed $30 million.

title:
JUNIOR GREAT BOOKS WRITE A NEW CHAPTER;
NORTH CALDWELL, N.J.
description: AN ogre is reading a book in the mural above them as Nancy Hampson and Joanne Sylva, two parent volunteers, greet 14 fifth-graders in the Gould School library here. They have come to talk about ''Charles,'' a story by Shirley Jackson.

title: No Headline
description: No, Mr. Eder. Anti-Semitism is not unique to postrevolutionary France. Indeed, Jews already flourished in France during the first century, 400 years before the advent of Frankish Christendom. If French ''xenophobia'' is to be legitimized, logic would have it expressed by those who were ''there first,'' the Jews! STEPHEN A. BERGER, M.D., Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: Dynanite Scores on Coast; Bold 'n Determined Second
