description: Bill Shoemaker drove Dynanite to an upset victory over Bold 'n Determined by a nose today in the $54,250 La Brea Stakes for 4-year-old fillies at Santa Anita.

title: DRAFT REGISTRATION TO BEGIN NEW ROUND
description: The second round of draft registration is scheduled to begin Monday under several handicaps but with at least one gold star for the Selective Service System's report card for the first round.

title: Lydia Gray Hobart Is Bride
description: Lydia Gray Hobart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Hobart Jr. of Troy, Ohio, was married there yesterday at the Trinity Episcopal Church to John Duncan Mason, son of Mrs. Lilla D. Goggin and John D. Mason, both of El Paso, Tex. The Rev. Pierce Klemmt and the Rev. Gordon Price ofoficiated. The couple graduated from Yale University.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
EVEN WITHOUT WATER RATIONING, THE OUTHOUSE IS FAR FROM IN
description: HERE in Bergen County, we now have water rationing: 50 gallons a day per person. There is no allowance for pets, no increase for house guests, no liberality even for house plants.

title: Michigan 92, No. Michigan 56
description: Mike McGee scored 27 points in leading unbeaten Michigan to a 92-56 victory over Northern Michigan tonight.

title: Kansas State 64, Louisville 47
description: Kansas State scored a 64-47 victory over Louisville, the national champion, tonight and gave the Wildcat coach, Jack Hartman, his 200th career victory.

title: Dispute Over Rules and a Tire Shortage Stall Grand Prix Season
description: The Argentine Grand Prix, which was to open the Formula One racing season two weeks from today, has been postponed because officials could only guarantee the entry of nine cars, including three without tires.

title:
TELEVISION;
DAVID BRINKLEY AND HIS 'NBC MAGAZINE'
description: The prime-time news magazine is proving that journalism, too, can be profitable for the television industry. With the aggressive personality of Mike Wallace dominating its on-air style, ''60 Minutes'' continues to maintain its top-10 ratings for CBS. Over at ABC, ''20/20'' has parlayed superstar biographies and Geraldo Rivera flashiness into consistently strong audience numbers. Only NBC has failed to get a firm foothold in the area. ''NBC Magazine,'' overseen by David Brinkley and producer Paul Friedman, has languished at or near the bottom of the weekly ratings lists since its debut last September. Part of the problem may be that the program has not yet settled into a comfortable format. Far more obvious, there is the competition. On Fridays at 10, ''NBC Magazine'' has had the misfortune to run up against CBS's ''Dallas,'' the most popular of weekly series for the past several months. Fred Silverman, president of NBC, has promised ''Magazine'' a new time slot in a couple of months or so.

title: With Its Independence Established Brasilia Reacts With Caution to Signals From Reagan
description: Brazilian leaders are treating with great wariness indications that the Reagan administration is looking to a closer association with Brazil in developing its strategy for this region.

title: Clock's Running On Carter Solution To Hostage Dispute
description: An old Navy man as well as a veteran of negotiations to free the 52 Americans in Iran, Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher voiced hope last week that ''this tragic event (which) happened on our watch'' could be brought ''to a successful conclusion on our watch.''

title: Carol Jennings Wed To John Merrill Jr.
description: Carol Jennings, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Jennings of Bucyrus, Ohio, was married yesterday in New York to John P. Merrill Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. John P. Merrill of Boston and Squirrel Island, Me. The Rev. Ralph Woodworth Jr. of St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Weston, Mass., performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home.

title:
The Education Consumer;
HELPING YOUR CHILD GET A START IN SCHOOL
description: IF you have a 4-year-old who will begin school in September, what can you do now - every day - to help the child get a good start? You can do what the kindergarten teachers do - recognize that learning comes through experience and that all experiences come through the senses. Kindergarten teachers work to give their pupils learning experiences that are sensory.

title: Speed-Skate Mark Set
description: Natalya Petruseva, a gold-medal winner in the 1980 Winter Olympics, broke the world record in the 1,500-meter speed-skating event Saturday in Alma-Ata, Tass, the Soviet news agency, reported. Miss Petruseva skated the distance in 2:06.01, 1.17 seconds faster than the previous record.

title: MOB FUNDS TRACED IN TOXIC WASTE PLANT'S TAKEOVER
description: Financing of an alleged mob takeover of the Chemical Control Corporation of Elizabeth, N.J., has been traced in part to a wholesale fish dealer at the Fulton Fish Market in lower Manhattan, according to material recently presented to a Congressional subcommittee.

title: O'Neill Takes Over In Connecticut
description: By Don Wycliff and Alvin Davis In one of her last official acts as Governor of Connecticut before her resignation took effect on Wednesday, Ella T. Grasso wrote a letter to her successor, Lieut. Gov. William A. O'Neill, which said in part: ''This afternoon, your time of challenge and promise begins.''

title: Iowa 86, Eau Claire 62
description: Vince Brookins scored 17 points to lead seven Iowa players in double figures today as the Hawkeyes defeated the Univeristy of Wisconsin-Eau Claire, 86-62.

title: AGAINST GUN CONTROL
description: By Mark K. Benenson

title: 'THE COMPETITION' STIRS MEMORIES OF MUSIC IN MOVIES
description: Ever since Harry Baur appeared as Beethoven in a movie of the 1920's there have been films about classical musicians, most of them so bad as to enter some kind of unprintable category of their own; and ''The Competition,'' which opened last month, is merely the latest in an ineffable line. Collectors dote on them, alternating between tears and hysterical laughter. Fortunately, it should be said at the outset, ''The Competition'' is better musically than most, and in the piano competition part of the film really tries hard to come to grips with the phenomenon.

title: WASHINGTON'S ALTERNATE CURRENT CRACKLES IN THE 'D.C. CIRCUIT'
description: Ronald Reagan and his conservative supporters in Congress say they will give a high priority to eliminating burdensome Federal environmental and worker-safety regulations. But after Inauguration Day, defenders of those and many other Government rules may still have an influential friend in Washington: the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

title: A ROMANCE FOR HIGHBROWS
description: NUNS AND SOLDIERS By Iris Murdoch. 505 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $14.95.

title: NATURAL WORDS AND PICTURES
description: A VISION OF EDEN The Life and Work of Marianne North. Illustrated. 240 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $22.95.

title: HOW TO GET A PROFESSIONALLYF SMOOTH PLASTER FINISH
description: ALTHOUGH it is not especially difficult for any reasonably handy man or woman to patch holes and cracks in plaster, many do have trouble getting a really smooth finish and wind up doing a lot of unnecessary sanding after the patch has dried.

title: WASHINGTON
description: AMONG all the interest groups anxiously awaiting the formulation of Federal policies once President-elect Reagan takes office, none are so filled with anticipation - or trepidation - as those concerned about education.

title: Falcons Get Big Chance to Achieve Status
description: The founding of the Atlanta Falcons football team 15 years ago was followed by few successes and many disappointments. Tomorrow, however, will bring a great opportunity to the current team, which will face the Dallas Cowboys in a division playoff game.

title: OSHA, E.P.A.: THE HEYDAY IS OVER
description: ''Of all the Washington acronyms, OSHA is the worst four-letter swear word in small business's vocabulary.'' - Mike McKevitt, director of Federal legislation for the National Federation of Independent Business.

title: Flores: Quiet Leader Of Rowdy Raiders
description: Typically, Coach Tom Flores passed virtually unnoticed in a crowd of Oakland Raiders last night when the team arrived for its American Conference playoff game against the Cleveland Browns tomorrow.

title: HOW TO GET A PROFESSIONALLY SMOOTH PLASTER FINISH
description: ALTHOUGH it is not especially difficult for any reasonably handy man or woman to patch holes and cracks in plaster, many do have trouble getting a really smooth finish and wind up doing a lot of unnecessary sanding after the patch has dried.

title: CHANGES AT THE TOP
description: HARTFORD ASUBDUED ceremony in the Hall of Flags at the Capitol on New Year's Eve underscored the rapid changes in Connecticut politics during 1980.

title: GLOSSARY GIGGLES
description: To The Living Section: What a lovely way to start the morning; smiles and even a couple of giggles. Thank you for David Diefendorf's "Glossary of Unfamiliar Terms" (Jan.&). It even makes the crosstown bus crossable. Diana Cecil Manhattan

title: WHAT'S DOING IN NEW ORLEANS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- NIKKI STILLER, who until recently taught English at the University of New Orleans, now teaches at Baruch College in New York. By NIKKI STILLER

title: No Headline
description: Modern professional football players enter the field bedecked for battle in a manner redolent of the era of jousting knights, with helmets, shoulder shields and forearm guards converting them into enormous hurtling forces. And while these pieces of equipment are described as protective in the defensive sense, in reality they are used and intended equally as offensive weapons.

title: CITICORP PLANS NEW OFFICE TOWER ON LEXINGTON, SOUTH OF CENTER
description: Citicorp has bought land and commissioned plans for a new office tower on 53d Street and Lexington Avenue, just south of the Citicorp Center, which it built four years ago, and cater-corner to the rear of the bank's headquarters at 399 Park Avenue.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: GREENBURGH THE pigeons were cooing, making the wild, fluttery sound of wind blowing through the trees. It was a sound that evoked the outdoors, but these birds were caged, surrounded by a bluejay and two squirrels that were similarly confined and by a red-tailed hawk tethered to a perch.

title: The Petty Politics of Federal Pay
description: Congress has always been shy about raising its own pay. And so it has adopted a petty, damaging attitude toward raises throughout the Government. It has by law linked top salaries in the judicial and executive branches to its own scale, allowing almost no official to make more money than a Congressman. Yet while Congressional standards of living remain high, inflation has degraded the pay of several thousand important judges and civil servants.

title: CRIME
description: Tony Hillerman is not a prolific writer. He takes his time, and his books show a good deal of thought, research and authentic background material. The Indian reservations of New Mexico serve as his background. Mr. Hillerman, a journalist, has worked in that area and seems to have the knack of putting himself into an Indian's mind. His ''Dance Hall of the Dead'' of 1973 won the 1974 Edgar of the Mystery Writers of America. It is conceivable that his latest book, PEOPLE OF DARKNESS (Harper & Row, $9.95), will be under consideration when the 1981 awards come around.

title: COACHES POLL The United Press International Board of Coaches Top 20 college football ratings, with first-place votes in parentheses, season records and total points.  1 Georgia (36)
description: 12-0-0 596 2 Pittsburgh (3) 11-1-0 543 3 Oklahoma 10-2-0 495 4 Michigan (1) 10-2-0 430 5 Florida State 10-2-0 423 6 Alabama 10-2-0 419 7 Nebraska 10-2-0 354 8 Penn State 10-2-0 328 9 North Carolina 11-1-0 232 10 Notre Dame 9-2-1 211 11 Brigham Young 12-1-0 167 12 Southern California 8-2-1 136 13 Baylor 10-2-0 116 14 U. C. L. A. 9-2-0 114 15 Ohio State 9-3-0 70 16 Purdue 9-3-0 62 17 Washington 9-3-0 50 18 Miami, Fla. 9-3-0 14 19 Florida 8-4-0 13 20 S. M. U. 8-4-0 8 Note: By agreement with the American Football Coaches Association, teams on probation by the N.C.A.A. are ineligible for the top 20 and national championship consideration by the UPI Board of Coaches. The only team currently on probation is Auburn.

title: PEDESTRIANSL FIND 'NEW' SIDEWALKS ARE OFTEN SLIPPERY
description: Jane Ann Cohen, a former account coordinator with Ted Bates & Company, used to walk past 1166 Avenue of the Americas on her way to work from her East Side apartment. But when the streets were wet or icy, she changed her route to avoid that sidewalk. "I find it slick and if there's ice, forget it - it just doesn't grip," she said. Israel Iveson, a 75-year old part-time messenger, walked in front of 1 Times Square while on the job last winter. It had snowed that morning and the terazzo sidewalk was icy and slippery. Mr. Iveson fell and fractured his hip. His lawyer has filed a claim against the city for a million dollars, charging that Mr. Iveson was disabled for life. In a pending case, Mohamed Ahmed, an accounting clerk, seeks $2 million in damages for injuries that he says resulted from a fall in 1974, when he was 52, on a terrazzo sidewalk outside 522 Fifth Avenue on a rainy day. Mr. Ahmed says he was permanently disabled, with a loss of sight in one eye and the use of an arm seriously impaired. Both the property owner - then the First National City Bank - and the city were sued for $2 million on the claim that terrazzo is dangerous when wet and needs to be covered, at the very least, by a rubber mat. According to lawyers in negligence suits, such cases are on the rise as a result of the wider use of a variety of materials for sidewalks to obtain a more esthetic effect than concrete provides.

title: Pitt 65, St. Bonaventure 61
description: Sam Clancy scored 13 of his 19 points in the second half to help Pittsburgh withstand a St. Bonaventure rally and earn a 65-61 victory today in an Eastern Eight game.

title: PROFILE OF A REAGAN MANAGER
description: The likely appointee is in his 50's and a senior executive at a major company.

title: Goddard Is Off Accrediting List
description: By Margot Slade and Eva Hoffman In a hard fall from a vanguard place, Goddard College in Plainfield, Vt., known since its inception as a pioneer in experimental education, lost its accreditation last week.

title: A 9,331-MILE TRAIN TRIP BECKONS THOSE WITH SIX WEEKS TO SPARE
description: Among people who made New Year's resolutions there must be many who resolved that 1981 would be the year they took the Big Trip. A long cruise, a grand European tour and a visit to China are among the ideas on the minds of ambitious travelers. For tourists with the time (and several thousand dollars) to invest on such a major journey, a trip called the Central Kingdom Express also fits the bill.

title: THE SIREN SONG OF OLD INSTRUMENTS
description: Collectors of musical instruments and music lovers with a taste for history will be heading for Vancouver, B.C., during the next three months to see ''The Look of Music,'' an exhibition of rare musical instruments dating from 1500 to 1900. The show, which is at the Vancouver Centennial Museum through April 5, is described as ''unprecedented'' by Professor Philip T. Young of the University of Victoria, who assisted in the planning of the exhibition and wrote the impressive catalogue ($16.95 soft cover; $29.95 hard cover), which is published in association with the museum by the University of Washington Press.

title:
DINING OUT;
ORDINARY BY DAY, HAUTE BY NIGHT
description: BY day, Fritz's in Somers is a white-walled luncheonette as plain as a shower room, serving up bacon-lettuce-and-tomato sandwiches, eggs-any-style, pastry and ''a cuppa'' to those in the neighborhood of the miniature shopping mall that surrounds it. But Thursday, Friday and Saturday evenings, on the stroke of 6:30, Fritz's dims the lights, spreads its table linens, lines up its ice buckets and chalks up a menu for two to attract one of Northern Westchester's most knowing clienteles. What they come for is ambitious cooking, full of haute cuisine touches - feuilletes, compound sauces and all.

title: ISRAELI EMIGRATION INSPIRES ANGER AND FEAR
description: With ''descents'' rising and ''ascents'' declining, each to record levels, 1980 was a bitter year for Israel. The mystical character of the words Zionists use to describe, respectively, emigration of a Jew from Israel or his immigration to the Jewish state shows the high degree of emotion contained in demographic statistics in this country and explains the bitterness.

title: Royals to Tour Japan
description: The Yomiuri Shimbun-Sha Corporation of Tokyo has invited the Kansas City Royals to play a series of exhibition games in Japan next fall. The tour is scheduled Oct. 28 through Nov. 24 and will include 17 games against Japanese professional clubs and all-star teams in 14 cities. The first game will be played in Tokyo on Oct. 31.

title: MERRYMAKING IN MERSAULT
description: Meursault is a tiny hillside hamlet in the Burgundy country of France, a village whose lifeblood is wine, a place where nearly all of the 1,831 inhabitants work in the vineyards or in the cellars beneath the whitewashed houses, turning the juice of grapes into some of the finest white wines made anywhere in the world. The pace of life is sleepy here, except for one day each year, when Meursault becomes the social hub of all of Burgundy, the Monday when the Paulee is held, when more Burgundy wine is consumed per person per hour than anywhere else at any other time.

title: Nonsupport Offender Is Jailed
description: A man convicted of failing to pay more than $17,000 in child support to seven women has been sentenced to prison. ''This is the most shameful situation I've seen in all my years on the bench,'' Judge Chester J. Byrns said as he imposed the maximum, one-year sentence on Sammy Bl anks, 30 years old, who owed the payments for the support of nine children.

title: Anti-Semitism In France
description: Richard Eder's article on the bombing of the Paris synagogue looks in vain for specific organized French anti-Semitism but actually suggests a far more serious cause: xenophobia (''The Jewish Question in France,'' by Richard Eder, Nov. 30).

title: LIQUOR: SOON, THE SOUTH WILL BE ALL WET
description: GREENVILLE,N.C. I N Bob Sauter's downtown restaurant, the Pipeline, a customer who wants a drink must employ an old Southern custom: he pours it from a bottle wrapped in a brown paper bag.

title: NEW OLD TOWN HALL
description: Wilton's Old Town Hall will mark the completion of its 2 1/2-year restoration with an open house at 2:30 this afternoon. Situated in a historic district of Wilton opposite the Congregational Church on Ridgefield Road, the Old Town Hall has been described by a local resident as ''a beautiful, pristine building, typical of the first public structures in Connecticut.''

title: OCEAN DUMPING: PROBLEM WORSENING, EXPERTS CONTEND
description: CLINGING to the outline of a sunken ship 30 miles off the coast of Long Beach Island, several inches of black sludge have smothered the last signs of marine life where abundant algae and blue mussels once grew as forage for larger species.

title: HER SO-SO CAREER
description: MY BRILLIANT CAREER By Miles Franklin. 232 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $9.95.

title: Water Cleanup Rules Proposed For Steel Industry
description: By Michael Wright and Caroline Rand Herron The Environmental Protection Agency issued clean water proposals last week that seemed likely to force an early test of Presidentelect Reagan's campaign pledge to declare a moratorium on all new Federal regulations. Acting under pressure of a court order, the agency proposed stringent new rules that would sharply reduce the discharge of pollutants into the nation's water supply by the iron, steel and coal-mining industries.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: FOR Jonathan Friedman, chief of the frauds bureau of the District Attorney's office, the results of the nation's second consecutive year of double-digit inflation are disturbingly clear.

title: No Headline
description: True, football is often a malevolent game - much like life itself. Or perhaps less, for how often does life afford the opportunity to wreak one's vengeance? And thanks for disproving Mr. Greene's troglodytic reputation. Seems he's shown us that violence on the football field can be ethical, moral and downright effective. VINCENT BORGESE, New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: FINK URGES LONG-TERM SPENDING TO WOO BUSINESS
description: Public spending for roads, bridges and mass transit may be even more useful than new tax cuts in attracting business to New York, Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink said yesterday.

title: Narcissa Vanderlip Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kelvin C. Vanderlip Jr. of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mr. Vanderlip's sister, Narcissa Cox Vanderlip of Los Angeles, to Parmer Fuller, also of Los Angeles. He is the son of Mrs. Edgar D. Osgood of Woodside, Calif., and George W. Fuller of Mill Valley, Calif.

title: Chachaji
description: To the Editor:

title: D.S. Hessney, Bank Officer, Marries Sharon Ann Cohen
description: Sharon Ann Cohen and David Samuel Hessney, who received M.B.A. degrees in 1978 from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, were married yesterday. Rabbi Gerald Weider performed the ceremony at the couple's house in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
A Talbots Sale On Clothing
description: The Talbots traditionally marks down some of its first quality current women's clothing, and some men's wear by 50 percent on the first Monday of each January and July. This year the sale will run tomorrow from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M., and will continue Tuesday from 9 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.

title: Military Analysis
description: The possibility of a diplomatic stalemate over the status of the 52 American hostages in Iran and the advent on Jan. 20 of a new American administration have reawakened interest among military planners in another attempt to rescue the hostages.

title: No Headline
description: The feminist health movement, with its unrelenting emphasis on gynecology, gives women the misleading impression that feminine health concerns begin and end with their reproductive apparatus. As a woman who has had the usual complaints about the medical establishment, I have had my flirtations with trendy alternatives to establishment health care.

title: UPROOTING THE FAILING TEACHER
description: THE vigilance of teachers' unions, protective state laws and changing views on what constitutes immorality and its effect on teaching ability are making the discharge of incompetent teachers increasingly difficult, according to school officials across the country.But after losing hundreds of cases on technicalities each year in attempts to dismiss alleged incompetents, schools are beginning to watch teachers more carefully, seeking better and more objective ways to judge teaching ability. And as a result more charges are being brought by school systems long frustrated by their inability to rid themselves of unqualified teachers.

title: THE 'REDISCOVERY' OF C.P.E. BACH
description: One wonders what papa Johann Sebastian felt toward the end of his life, in 1747, when he visited his son Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach and his son's employer, King Frederick of Prussia. The king gave Sebastian a chromatic theme to improvise upon. Intrigued by its difficulty, Bach made it the foundation for ''The Musical Offering,'' which, with the ''The Art of the Fugue,'' was his summing up of a career devoted to the glories of architectural counterpoint.

title: COMPOSITE PHOTOS OF SUSPECTS NOW DOUBTED BY SOME POLICE
description: Some police departments in the New York City area that bought machines to make composite photographs of suspects, including the identification section at Police Headquarters in Manhattan, are abandoning them in favor of conventional artists' drawings.

title: Energy Policy
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Tammy D. Sand Is Engaged To David Melech Friedman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Julius Sand of Miami Beach have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tammy Deborah Sand, to David Melech Friedman, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Morris S. Friedman of North Woodmere, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

title: NEW MUSIC SERIES STIRRING DISCORD
description: WESTBURY THERE will be a new outlet for serious music and dance on the Island two weeks from tomorrow, when the Music Fair here opens the Fortunoff Classic Series with the Vienna Choir Boys. Four more concerts, featuring the violinist Yehudi Menuhin, the trumpet virtuoso Maurice Andre, the pianist Byron Janis and the Ballet Folklorico Nacional de Mexico, will follow through March 30.

title: Molloy Takes Two Relays, Lincoln Scores at Meet
description: Archbishop Molloy won two open relay events yesterday at the novice indoor championships of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: Miss Freund, T.J. Kniesner Are Married
description: Deborah Anne Freund, a health economist, and Thomas John Kniesner, a labor economist, both faculty members at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, were married last evening in New York. State Supreme Court Justice William Kapelman performed the ceremony at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Seelig Freund, the bride's parents.

title: SITKA, Alaska
description: PITKAS POINT, an Eskimo village with a population of 80, sits on the Yukon River not far from the Bering Sea and only 200 miles south of the permafrost of the Arctic Circle.

title: BLACKOUTS ARE PART OF LIFE IN FLORIDA
description: About 12 times a year Florida utilities run out of options and their customers run out of power. That means, for varying numbers of customers at any given time, that their television sets suddenly flicker out and their airconditioners shut down.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: Pops and Sons By William Safire

title: FIVE WOMEN AT THE COUNTRY CROSSROADS
description: For the past few years, many country artists have tried to ''cross over'' into the lucrative pop charts. They have done so by altering their music to conform to some already commercial mainstream style, be it middle-of-the-road or pop or rock. But at the same time country music itself has become mainstream - so much so that jazz (WRVR in New York) and rock (KHJ in Los Angeles) stations all over the nation have switched to a country format, country nightclubs are blossoming in the North, and Kenny Rogers, a former slick folkie turned country/ middle-of-the-roader, is now the most popular singer in the land.

title: Daytona a $750,000 Race
description: The 23d annual Daytona 500 stock car race Feb. 15 will be worth a record $750,000. Last year's purse was $100,000 less, with Buddy Baker taking home $102,175 for winning. This year, victory could be worth more than $150,000.

title: Elizabeth Marran, Artist, Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William R. Marran of Cold Spring Harbor and Amagansett, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ann Marran, to Kimball Erskine Clement Hull. He is a son of Rear Adm.

title: Miss Edmunds Is the Fiancee Of Peter Smith
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Edmunds of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Priscilla Edmunds, to Peter Burr Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Hawley Smith of Tucson, Ariz.

title:
NEW JERSEY HOUSING;
CONFESSIONS OF A CONDOMINIUM SELLER
description: EXPERIENCE, they say, is the greatest teacher, and I have learned many things since my husband and I put our condominium up for sale a couple of months ago. In fact, I would like to share with you what I have come to think of as ''Great Moments in Real Estate.''

title: ORGANIZING YOUR HOME FILES
description: I F there ever were a right time of year to review and organize personal financial records, it is now. The number of people whose files include everything from mortgage payment receipts to expired toaster warranties is probably far greater than the those whose files are as neat as a bookkeeper's ledger. The problem is how to reform a haphazard filing system without throwing away everything but your passport and birth certificate.

title: CLEMSON 76, NORTH CAROLINA STATE 68
description: Clemson's point guard, Chris Dodds, had 25 points, and its freshman guard, Vince Hamilton, scored 15 as the Tigers downed North Carolina State, 76-68, in an Atlantic Coast Conference game tonight.

title: LABOR WORRIES OVER DECLINE IN ITS INFLUENCE
description: Lane Kirkland, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., is given to understated irony, and his comment when Raymond J. Donovan was nominated by President-elect Reagan to be Secretary of Labor was characteristically restrained but mordant. ''I look forward to meeting Mr. Donovan,'' Mr. Kirkland declared.

title: NUCLEAR POWER: STILL MORE OPTIONS
description: Miriam Goodman (in ''Nuclear Power and the Need for Energy: More Opinions'') has taken the nuclear energy debate out of the realm of electric power and into a truly perilous area. She demands that her own personal opinion be declared a human right superior to the rights of others and in defiance of all of the deliberations of our elected representatives.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 11 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $15.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history. 2 2 15 THE KEY TO REBECCA, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $12.95.) German espionage in Cairo during the desert campaigns of 1942. 3 4 20 FIRESTARTER, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) E ightyear-old Charlie can look at anything and turn it into flames. 4 6 14 LOON LAKE, by E.L. Doctorow. (Random House, $11.95.) The strange, lyrical adventures of a young man during the Depression. 5 3 7 UNFINISHED TALES, by J.R.R. Tolkien. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.) Hitherto unpublished fragments of writing about Middle-earth. 6 1 MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $9.95.) A fantastic tale about the Sun, the Moon and a lost treasure. 7 8 2 ANSWER AS A MAN, by Taylor Caldwell. (Putnam's, $12.95.) A man who has made it big in early 20th-century America struggles against the corruption that engulfs his life.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE Army Corps of Engineers plans to begin a $42 million beach repair project in Westhampton in the spring. According to the plans, the erosion-prevention project will use eight million cubic yards of sand dredged from the ocean to fill in and bury 15 rock groins that were originally constructed in the 1960's.

title: 'WINTERFEST' OF NEW PLAYS TO OPEN AT YALE
description: FOR the last 12 years, Lloyd Richards has served as artistic director of the 16-year-old National Playwrights Conference at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford. During his years with them the conference has presented 214 new plays by 156 playwrights. In going to Yale last year as artistic director of the Yale Rep and dean of the Drama School, it was expected that Mr. Richards's interest in new plays and playwrights would continue. It has. The ''Winterfest of New American Plays'' that begins on Saturday and runs through Feb. 21 at the Yale Rep is the proof of it.

title: BOGUS SOCIAL SECURITY CARDS FOUND INCREASING BY G.A.O.
description: The General Accounting Office says there appears to be a growing traffic in fraudulent Social Security documents, especially among illegal aliens who use the cards to obtain jobs and unauthorized Government benefits. But the agency, an investigative arm of Congress, says that issuing new cards would not significantly reduce the amount of fraud.

title: 2 CHAMBER GROUPS OPEN NEW YEAR
description: THE Madison Trio and the Emerson Quartet have the honor of giving the first Westchester chamber concerts of the year. Because both groups, which have two players in common, happen to be first-rate, it safe to say that the year is off to a great musical start.

title: Tennessee 70, Alabama 69
description: Michael Brooks, a freshman guard, sank eight consecutive free throws in overtime that gave Tennessee a 70-69 victory over Alabama in a Southeastern Conference game tonight.

title: The New Grove Dictionary
description: In the Dec. 21 issue of the Book Review the publisher of ''The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians'' was incorrectly identified as St. Martin's Press. The actual publisher is Grove's Dictionaries of Music, Inc., located at 1283 National Press Building, Washington, D.C. St. Martin's Press does some distribution for ''The New Grove,'' but that is their only connection. STEPHANIE R. COOPER New York City

title: Airport Parking
description: To the Editor:

title: Cynthia Anderson Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roy Anderson of Wethersfield, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Veronica Anderson, to Herbert Borenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Borenstein of Brooklyn.

title: ANSWERING ANTI-SEMITISM WITH A LESSON
description: As the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith reported last week, anti-Semitic incidents involving assaults and vandalism are on the rise. But in this Long Island community, the principal of the high school where vandals spray-painted anti-Semitic slurs and obscenities now says that what happened was the basis for a ''positive learning experience.''

title: Army LSD Case
description: Sensitive documents about atomic missiles had disappeared from a United States Army center in Orleans, France. Suspicion fell on Pfc. James R. Thornwell.

title: THE FORGOTTEN PEASANT IS VERY MUCH ON POLAND'S MIND
description: He is a stereotype recognizable in countrysides the world over - the hardworking, God-fearing man of the earth who resents government orders and clings to the land with a ferocious sense of ownership. But in the rest of Europe, the small farmer has succumbed to 20th century agribusiness and in most of the Communist East, he is an ''agricultural worker,'' a wage-earner on a vast state farm. Only in Poland is the stereotype still a reality.

title: BROOKLYN OFFICE DECIDES THE TREATMENT OF CASES THAT INVOLVE A FELONY
description: CHARGE In a drab, green-tiled room on the fringe of downtown Brooklyn, the first important decisions are made on how people arrested for felony crimes allegedly committed in Brooklyn will be handled by the criminal-justice system.

title: ON THE WAY TO RICHMOND
description: THECRATER By Richard Slotkin. 559 pp. New York: Atheneum. $17.95. By GEOFFREY C. WARD

title: THE '81 ART PICTURE: REALISM MAY PREVAIL
description: WHAT can the New Jersey art world expect in 1981? If 1980 can be used as a touchstone and anticipation of what is to come, some solid predictions can be made.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: Moon of Cualadora By Russell Baker

title: OVERHAULING AMERICA'S BUSINESS MANAGEMENT
description: The French journalist Jean-Jacques Servan-Schreiber warned his readers in the late 1960's that Europe was in grave danger of economic invasion by the United States. The Old World, he said, might soon become a subsidiary of the American multinational companies and vanish as an autonomous civilization. These American invaders were superior, in Servan-Schreiber's view, not because of their money, resources or technology but because of their corporate organizational ability - and the genius behind it all was the American corporate manager. He was the real key to American power.

title: Critics' Choices
description: When a great many new films open simultaneously, the best can get lost in the shuffle. Roman Polanski's beautiful, gentle ''Tess'' runs an especially good chance of being overlooked, in view of the unusual schedule that had the film opening early in December for a one-week run, closing, and then re-opening recently at the Little Carnegie.

title: NEW LEADERS TAKING CONTROL
description: HARTFORD CHANGES that were set in motion in last fall's election campaigns and accelerated by Governor Grasso's resignation have brought increased prominence to three politicians who share a small-town background and are widely perceived as more conservative in their approach to government policies than some of the elected officials whom they replaced.

title: LIFE IN DETROIT: COUNTING ON NEW YEAR
description: Every year about this time, the billboards sprinkled along the spaghetti mass of highways ring in the new year with zeros, seven of them - 0,000,000 - in a row.

title: ON A HOLIDAY WEIGHT-LOSING SPREE
description: While members of the outside world were eating, drinking, being merry - and gaining weight - over the holidays, 28 persons inside a walled compound here were busy taking it off.

title: Alan Eugene Hall And Beth Raebeck To Marry in June
description: Elizabeth Peters Raebeck of Nashville, a writer for The Vanderbilt Register, Vanderbilt University's weekly newspaper, plans to be married in June to Alan Eugene Hall, a reporter for The Tennessean in Nashville.

title: Gangster-Kids
description: To the Editor:

title: DAVE ANDERSONSports of The Times; Eagles' Secret Weapon - Sid Gillman
description: HE sat in a booth on the press-box level, a green windbreaker over the green shirt and green slacks worn by all those on the Philadelphia Eagles coaching staff. During yesterday's National Football League playoff game, 69-year-old Sid Gillman kept staring at the Minnesota Vikings' defensive alignments for only one reason -how to complete another pass, preferably how to complete another pass that would produce a big play that is usually so necessary in the playoffs leading to the Super Bowl.

title: Conrail Strike Is Averted By Tentative Agreement
description: Members of the United Transporation Union and Conrail negotiators reached a tentative agreement today, temporarily averting a walkout that could have crippled rail service between New York and Boston, including trains carrying more than 20,000 commuters a day.

title: FASHION
description: DIPPING INTO SPRINGTIME The soft curve of a shoulder, the subtle allure of a bare back, the daring of a plunging neckline - these are some of the traditional elements of evening clothes. For spring, many important American designers have combined these ideas for up-to-date decolletages.

title: No Headline
description: William Barry Furlong's article further obscures an already clouded issue when, by implication, he substitutes ''violence'' for existing, legitimate terms like ''unnecessary roughness'' and ''unsportsmanlike conduct.''

title: COURTER OPTIMISTIC ON REPUBLICAN ROLE IN DEMOCRATIC HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON JUST two and a half years ago, in what was his first race for Congress, he won the Republican primary by only 134 votes before upsetting the Democratic incumbent, Helen S. Meyner, in the general election with 52 percent of the vote.

title: THE MENSHIVIK, BOLSHEVIK, STALINIST FEMINIST
description: BOLSHEVIK FEMINIST The Life of Aleksandra Kollontai. By Barbara Evans Clements. Illustrated. 352 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. $15.

title: Artificial Aids, Natural Enemies
description: By Margot Slade and Eva Hoffman For the heart, human and of related varieties, there were hopeful developments last week and distressing news. At the University of Utah, a calf named Tennyson reached a record 32 weeks of survival with an artificial heart driven by compressed air from an attached source.

title: Football Violence OR Those Football Knights of Violence
description: William Barry Furlong's insights into the violence of pro football were quite sobering (''Football Violence,'' by William Barry Furlong, Nov. 30). My love for the game is tarnished now,knowing the players are trained to react violently for the purpose of maiming and injuring. What kind of mentality would participate under these guidelines? Has Vince Lombardi's philosophy of winning via good blocking, tackling and running succumbed to the performance standards of Conrad Do- bler? JAY TOBIN DAVIS, Charlottesville, Va.

title: TAX FRAUD BY MICHIGAN GAS WHOLESALERS IS ALLEGED
description: Fraud by Michigan gasoline wholesalers may be depriving the Federal Government of millions of dollars in excise taxes annually, Representative William M. Brodhead, Democrat of Michigan, said yesterday.

title: SNOW FALLS, AS DOES THE MERCURY
description: A sudden winter storm, driven by blustery winds, passed across the New York metropolitan area yesterday, driving temperatures sharply lower and leaving as much as four inches of snow on the ground.

title: LONG BEACH GETTING A NEW LOOK
description: LONG BEACH ''IF I had one million dollars to spend in Long Beach, I would fix up all the broken-down buildings,'' wrote Michael Ward, an 11-yearold sixth grader in an essay he sent to City Hall, where planners are spending more than $8 million in Federal funds to rebuild the boardwalk, construct two new neighborhood centers and revitalize the downtown area, among other projects.

title: COUNTY SKEPTICAL ON BID TO MAKE YONKERS JAIL A VALHALL 'ANNEX'
description: MAYOR Gerald E. Loehr of Yonkers, in an attempt to reorganize the city's jail to save money and solve what he sees as several problems with the current system, has met with skepticism at the county level.

title: Article 208852 -- No Title
description: An award of $1.2 million to support the basic biological research of two American scientists has been announced by an unusual foundation set up by a businessman concerned about a shortage of funds for exploring the most fundamental biology of cancer.

title: Denver Newspaper to Be Sold
description: The Times-Mirror Company, owner of the Los Angeles Times, Newsday, the Dallas Times Herald and the Hartford Courant, has completed a $95 million deal to purchase the Denver Post. The newspaper's employees have agreed to sell their 10 percent interest for $101 per share. The boards of the Helen G. Bonfils and Frederick Bonfils Foundations, which own the other 90 percent, approved the sale earlier.

title: Syrian Wounded in Cyprus Blast
description: Hani al-Hindi, a Syrian journalist, was seriously injured today when a bomb exploded as he opened the door of his car, a police statement said.

title: THE DANGERS OF SUPPRESSED RESEARCH
description: ON May 17, 1979, Jimmy Carter presided over a White House celebration marking the 25th anniversary of the 1954 Supreme Court decision on school desegregation. A few miles away, at the United States Office of Education, 2,000 copies of an official report on the decision languished in Government Printing Office cartons because the Administration did not like what it said.

title: EDUCATORS FIND BOTH SEXES CHANGING CAREER ATTITUDES
description: HIGH school guidance counselors, teachers and family relations experts on the Island report that they are seeing appreciable changes today in the career aspirations of young people, who are increasingly viewing their education and careers along nonsexist lines. With sexual stereotyping breaking down, priorities for this generation's students appear to revolve around a perception that they are free to be whatever they want.

title: Sharon Anne O'Neal Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Patrick William O'Neal of Hingham, Mass., formerly of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sharon Anne O'Neal, to Bruce Monroe Walgren Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce M. Walgren of West Hartford, Conn. The future bride is a senior at the University of Massachusetts, of which her fiance is an alumnus.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
HOUSE AND GARDEN: NOT FOR EVERYONE
description: WHY is it that one reads too much about the wealth, homes, gardens and almost inescapable anesthetic beauty of the Westchester suburbs? Popular local publications are forever overflowing with the most tedious news on such vital topics as repairing a loose gutter, the proper food for parties and what happens when Johnny or Lisa is sick and the lawn needs a facelift.

title: Court Denies Students' Bid To Block Faculty Dismissals
description: A District Court judge has refused to block a plan by officials of financially troubled Colorado Women's College to reduce the number of full-time faculty members from 35 to 10. Students had sought a restraining order from Judge Clifton Flowers to block the reduction.

title: Miss Shidler Bride Of David Burkhart
description: The marriage of Deborah Ann Shidler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Shidler of Wilton, Conn., to David Aaron Burkhart, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. John Burkhart of Chicago, took place yesterday afternoon in Zion's Hill United Methodist Church in Wilton, Conn. The bridegroom's father, a Presbyterian minister and a professor of theology at the McCormick Theological Seminary in Chicago, and the Rev. Dr. Carl Kohn, pastor of the Zion's Hill church, officiated.

title: ETHEL MCCULLY, SAVED VIRGIN ISLANDS HOME FROM CONDEMNATION
description: Ethel Walbridge McCully, the grandmother who went to Washington to ''raise a little hell'' on Capitol Hill in 1962, died Dec. 21 on St. John in the Virgin Islands in the home she successfully defended against condemnation by the National Park Service. She was 94 years old.

title: The Ford Solution: Warning Stickers Instead of Recall
description: By Margot Slade and Eva Hoffman The National Highway Safety Administration announced last week it would not order a recall of 16 million Ford Motor Company cars and trucks for repairs - at least, not yet.

title:
ANTIQUES;
PARAMUS: THE ACCENT IS ON PORCELAIN
description: PARAMUS ONE OF the newer additions to the 40 assorted stores in Village Square at Bergen Mall is Ann and Roy Wintrob's shop, which features fine china (both European and Oriental), bronzes, lamps and finely carved ivories, among other antiques.

title: 'WAITING FOR AN INGENIOUS TWIST THAT NEVER COMES'
description: The clue to my own in-and-out admiration for, and ultimate dissatisfaction with, Peter Shaffer's ''Amadeus'' lies in a brilliantly performed passage that appears quite early in the new importation at the Broadhurst. We have already met actor Ian McKellen, met him as the dying 18th-century Viennese court composer Salieri, a crumpled ghost in a wheelchair looking as though his shawling and tight gray nightcap had already provided him with a shroud.

title: FIVE WOMEN SINGERS AT THE COUNTRY CROSSROADS
description: For the past few years, many country artists have tried to ''cross over'' into the lucrative pop charts. They have done so by altering their music to conform to some already commercial mainstream style, be it middle-of-the-road or pop or rock. But at the same time country music itself has become mainstream - so much so that jazz (WRVR in New York) and rock (KHJ in Los Angeles) stations all over the nation have switched to a country format, country nightclubs are blossoming in the North, and Kenny Rogers, a former slick folkie turned country/ middle-of-the-roader, is now the most popular singer in the land.

title: A Zermatt Ski Holiday, With an Infant Daughter in Tow; Ominous warnings from the baby's grandparents proved to be unwarranted.
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- ROBERT WOOL is an independent book packager in New York and co-author of ''All You Need to Know About the I.R.S.'' By ROBERT WOOL

title: Wake Forest 87, Ga. Tech 61
description: SALEM, N.C., Jan. 3 (AP) - Guy Morgan had a game-high 20 points as he lead undefeated Wake Forest to its 10th victory, an 87-61 decision over Georgia Tech, which has a 3-8 record.

title: 'A Man'
description: To the Editor:

title: Bob Shawkey, Pitcher for Yankees And Later Manager, Is Dead at 90
description: Bob Shawkey, a star pitcher for the New York Yankees when they began to dominate baseball in the 1920's, died New Year's Eve at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Syracuse after a long illness. He was 90 years old.

title: Hillary Blumenthal, Banker, Is Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Blumenthal of Yonkers have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hillary Iris Blumenthal, to Dr. Marc Holman Alpert, son of Mrs. Tobe Alpert of Westfield, N.J., and Dr. Joseph Alpert of Springfield, N.J. A May 3 wedding is planned.

title: Robyn Douglas Fiancee Of Robert Edward List 2d
description: The engagement of Robyn Ann Douglas to Robert Edward List 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. List of Westfield and Cape May, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Douglas of Westfield, and New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: No Headline
description: In Richard Eder's portrayal of benign anti-Semitism in France, he wanders far afield. We are told that France, unlike Russia, had no pogroms: Irrelevant - neither did 19th-century Germany. Mr. Eder points to Mayor Koch's ''fulminations against the French'' and Menachem Begin's lack of tact - but what has either man to do with the social fabric within France? Yet the anti-Semitic remarks of key French officials such as Charles de Gaulle and Raymond Barre are excused as utterances which do not mean what they would appear to mean.

title: NEGLECTED TREASURES OF THE LOWER
description: NILE By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN

title: More on Mexico's Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMER RATES
PRODUCTIVITY DEAL RAISES THE ISSUE OF PAY PARITY
description: Almost before the ink was dry on the arbitrator's award that gave New York City the right to use two-man rather than three-man sanitation trucks (as long as it paid an $11 shift differential to each worker), officials who worked on negotiations had to start thinking about a painful consequence. Pay levels of uniformed employees have since the 1930's been intertwined, or perhaps entangled, in a web of vertical and horizontal relationships called parity. What would an $11 differential do to such relationships?

title: Cecily Hamel Plans Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. W. Rogers Hamel of Francestown, N.H., and Key West, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cecily Charlyn Hamel, to Kenneth Mapes Houston, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Mapes Houston of Schenectady, N.Y. An October wedding is planned.

title: The Magic Lens of George Tice
description: MORRISTOWN APHOTOGRAPHER since he was 14 years old, George Tice of Iselin has had numerous exhibitions in the United States and abroad, has produced five limited-edition portfolios and is currently at work on his eighth book. This will be published next fall, probably under the title, ''Urban Romantic.''

title: 37 FOOD PLACES FAIL HEALTH CHECK
description: The New York City Department of Health has cited 37 food establishments for Health Code violations. The department also listed two restaurants that reopened after correcting violations and one that was closed for failing to do so.

title: WINTER: COLD CARS, WARM PARTS
description: This new year, like last, has started out chilly for the automobile companies, whatever the weather. But for many of the folks who make automobile parts, a cold winter is a good thing.

title: KNICKS APPLY PRESSURE QUICKLY AND OVERWHELM HAWKS, 131-95
description: Applying full-court defensive pressure for much of the game, the Knicks enjoyed their most one-sided victory of the season last night as they routed the Atlanta Hawks, 131-95, at Madison Square Garden.

title: NOTES: THE PEABODY PHILOSOPHY
description: When Elliott Galkin was appointed head of the Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore in 1977, it was expected that there would be some changes. He was a musician with an impressively varied background who knew the musical scene as a performer, administrator, educator and critic. He has a doctorate from Cornell University and took additional studies at the Paris Conservatory and Vienna's University and Music Academy. He studied the violin with his uncle, Ruvin Heifetz, who was Jascha's father. He has played in a hillbilly band, where he was known as ''Deacon Jones, the Fiddlin' Fool.'' He has run the music department at Goucher College. He was music critic of the Baltimre Sun from 1962 to 1978. So much knowledge as he acquired could be put to good use at Peabody, and recently he spoke of his aims in connection with the school.

title: Football; N.F.L. ALL-PRO TEAM; PRO FOOTBALL WRITERS OFFENSE
description: Wide Receivers - John Jefferson, San Diego; James Lofton, Green Bay. Tight End - Kellen Winslow, San Diego. Tackles - Mike Kenn, Atlanta; Leon Gray, Houston.

title: LYNN ZANOWSKI IS PLANNING TO BE WED TO DONALD PENTZ
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Zanowski of Lancaster, Pa., announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynn Marie Zanowski, to Donald Hayes Pentz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hayes Ellsworth Pentz of Leola, Pa.

title: U.S. AGENCY WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: CHRISTINA PASZTOR was unemployed two years ago with an ailing, jobless husband and two small children in her Jamaica Plain, Mass., home. Although in desperate need of income, she lacked the skills to get a job.

title: A QUIZ DESIGNED TO CHALLENGE THE REAL MOVIE MANIACS
description: his is it: the first movie quiz of 1981, 21 questions designed to separate the seriously lunatic moviegoer from the reasonable fringe, those people who don't feel compelled to see absolutely everything. The questions are suggested by films released in the 1980 calendar year. Anything less than a perfect score is failure. The answers will be found at the bitter end.

title: PIECES OF PRIVATE FEELING
description: JOURNEYAROUNDMYROOM The Autobiography of Louise Bogan. A Mosaic by Ruth Limmer. 197 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95. By WILLIAM PRITCHARD OR years the name Louise Bogan meant for me an accomplished minor poet who did lots of reviewing for The New Yorker; then in 1973, three years after her death, her literary executor and friend, Ruth Limmer, brought out a volume of her letters, sensitively edited and introduced. No one could read these through without realizing that Bogan was an extraordinary person, altogether larger in wit, anger, passion, contempt for stupidities and proud reticence than one had gathered from the poems alone. This is exactly how she insisted that it be, for as she remarks here, ''open confession for certain temperaments (certainly for my own), is not good for the soul, in any direct way.'' She was also suspicious of journal-keeping, in which the tendency toward ''self-regarding emotion ... can become overwhelming.'' It was her belief that ''the poet represses the outgoing narrative of his life,'' and that this repressed material becomes the poem.

title: PIPELINE OF CO-OPS EXPANDS IN CITY
description: The movement toward conversion of rental buildings into cooperatives continued to accelerate last year in the boroughs outside Manhattan as part of what two government economists have called ''an extension of the real-estate frenzy that has been sweeping the nation.''

title: QUOTATIONS
description: ''We continue to invest heavily in the dollar, but we would like to have a stake in every major currency. The Germans and Japanese finally decided to open the door, and we went in.'' - A Saudi banker explaining Saudi Arabia's quiet move to put more funds into marks and yen.

title:
CURLING: A SPORTING WAY TO PASS WINTER;
NORFOLK
description: WHEN the temperature dips to the freezing mark, dozens of Connecticut residents flock to the former Norfolk Downs Golf Course. Carrying brooms, they square off as ''terrible but friendly rivals'' in the sport of curling, according to Edward C. Childs, a founder of the 25-year-old Norfolk Curling Club.

title: Miss Armstrong, Is Wed to Student
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Campbell Armstrong, daughter of Col. Peter - Forbes Campbell Armstrong, U.S.M.- C., retired, and Mrs. Armstrong of Honolulu, formerly of Washington, to James Bedford Downing 3d, son of Mrs. Edmund R. Beckwith Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Mr. Downing Jr. of Trappe, Md., took place yesterday afternoon. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesey performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan.; The bride, a sales representative for - Brunschwig & Fils, a wholesale fabric -

title: PURCELL AND COHALAN FOCUS ON MONEY AS TOP PROBLEM
description: NASSAU County Executive Francis T. Purcell and Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan emphasized fiscal restraint and reduced governmental expectations last week as they looked to the new year and their plans for 1981.

title: Jacqueline Dietz Is Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Dietz of Mountainside, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Jacqueline Dietz, to William A. Koenigsberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Koenigsberg of Lido Beach, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Ohio State 88 Bowling Green 70
description: Jim Smith scored 12 points in the first half tonight, helping Ohio State to move to a 88-70 rout of Bowling Green.

title: No Headline
description: This Week:

title: Reagan Prepares To Go to Work
description: With Inauguration Day no longer just a speck on the horizon, President-elect Ronald Reagan is due to leave the Pacific Palisades at a full gallop this week.

title: Warren Avis Marries Yanna Elbim in Mexico
description: The marriage of Yanna Elbim to Warren Avis, founder of Avis Rent A Car, took place in Acapulco, Mexico, yesterday. Msgr. Angel performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Casa La Barranca, the Avis home.

title: o The Living Section:
description: After reading the praiseworthy and banal thoughts from those secretaries about TomMargittai's comments concerning them and down coats, I've decided that secretaries have a lot in common - typing, steno and a complete lack of proportion about what was probably an offhanded remark. If it was an attempt at wit, I hope Mr. Margittai's souffles rise to the occasion better than his sense of humor.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have nothing to hide, but at the same time we are not going to be partners to some indiscriminate witch hunt.'' - Zbigniew Brzezinski, saying he had declined to supply Senate Democrats with files on Alexander M. Haig Jr. (1:6.)

title:
RED SMITH;
The Bowl and a Pension Plan
description: ANIGHT'S sleep, a few drops of Visine in red and swollen eyes, and television's unseen millions emerge from the college football season practically as good as new. New Year's Day is always The Longest Day for them and, praise be, the last one demanding undivided attention. Still to be played are the East-West Shrine game and the Hula Bowl, but these are all-star exhibitions. Intercollegiate competition, meaning one college against another college, ended with the Peach Bowl Friday. For the first time since man came down out of the trees and began kicking around the skull of an obsolete neighbor, it ended with Georgia on top of the national heap.

title: THE COSTS OF A RUNOFF IN THE PRIMARY
description: TITLE 19, the law governing the conduct of New Jersey elections, is a hodgepodge of ambiguous regulations and differing interpretations. It has evolved over the years largely as a result of piecemeal legislative tinkering aimed at satisfying the demands of one group or another.

title: CRAFTS
description: ''INTERTWINING,'' the title of an exhibition at the Summit Art Center, refers not only to the structures and visual impressions of the fiber works and sculptures on view, but also to the wealth of conceptual connections that they suggest in relationship to one another.

title: Future Events On Three Odd Days
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:A Russian BallJan. 9 - Because Le Bal Blanc means just that, everything in the decor of the Plaza's Grand Ballroom will be white - tablecloths, candles, flowers - so that nothing will take away from the vivid colors of gowns worn by women and the black-or white-tie attire of their escorts. The ball, held since 1948 by the American-Russian Aid Association to bring in the Russian New Year, gives guests their annual chance to shine up tiaras and titles, some inherited or earned by marriage. Join princesses, countesses, baronesses and the untitled with just as solid roots in Czarist Russia for cocktails at 8, dinner at 9 and dancing to past midnight to a Meyer Davis orchestra, alternating with the Balalaika Russe, a trio of young women of Russian ancestry. Mrs. Ivan Obolensky, whose father-in-law, the late Col. Serge Obolensky, established the ball as a social event of the New York season, is this year's chairman. Proceeds will help support its four homes in Glen Cove, L.I., for 30 elderly residents chosen through their applications because of need and not nationality. Some even get pocket money to spend. Tickets are $80, from 787-0206 weekdays from noon to 5 P.M.

title: Skelly Takes Ski Jumping To Win Eisenhower Cup
description: Rick Skelly of the University of New Hampshire ski team won the New Jersey ski-jumping championship and the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Jumpoff Trophy as the 1981 season got under way today on the 50-meter hill.

title: Demand for Action On Jailed Refugee
description: By Michael Wright and Caroline Rand Herron Until last week, Pedro Rodriguez must have wondered whether his boat took a wrong turn during last April's Cuban refugee ''boatlift.'' Shortly after he arrived in the United States, he was trundled off to the Federal penitentiary in Leavenworth, Kan.

title: THE NEW STATUS IN DINING
description: 8,35,14,10JACK LENOR LARSEN has applied his talent for fabric design to motifs for the table. Left: Bamboo in porcelain for Dansk.

title:
ART;
COMPLEX WORKS SHOWN AT ATHENEUM
description: HARTFORD DOTTY ATTIE, whose drawings are being exhibited at the Matrix Gallery of the Wadsworth Atheneum until Jan. 25, is a complex and even rather distressing artist. Her drawings, which were recently shown at the A.I.R. Gallery in New York City, are very small and extraordinarily delicate in coloring, but they have an intensity and strangeness all their own.

title: SWEDISH CUISINE: BORN OF WINTER
description: LAKE RONKONKAMA BY now most people are beginning to remove the Christmas decorations and giving thought to the inevitable stack of bills that follows the holidays. Not Carl Stroem. ''I like to keep the Christmas spirit going until March, until the spring,'' he said.

title: Prison Revolt in Louisiana Laid to Neglect by Officials
description: A reform leader said today that a prison uprising in Lafayette on New Year's Day was the result of failure by officials to bring the jail up to the standards ordered by a Federal court.

title: Veterans to Get Record Dividend From G.I. Life Insurance Policies
description: Nearly four million veterans whose G.I. life insurance policies are still in force will share in a record $619.7 million dividend in 1981, according to the Veterans Administration.

title: Transactions; FRIDAY BASEBALL
description: PORTLAND (PCL) - Signed Earl Wil- l iams, catcher, the National League rookie o f the year with Atlanta Braves in 1971. BASKETBALL DALLAS (NBA) - Signed Monti Davis as f ree agent and placed Ralph Drollinger, a c enter who has tendinitis, on injured-re- s erve list.

title: San Francisco Board Approves Waterfront Rejuvenation Project
description: A $100 million plan to rejuvenate San Francisco's decaying southern waterfront with housing, parks and a new marina has won its first vote of approval.

title: BOSSY REACHES 40 GOALS
description: In their last meeting of the regular season, the Islanders trounced the Hartford Whalers, 8-1, tonight at Nassau Coliseum. New York's 44-shot attack featured two short-handed scores and a pair of goals by Mike Bossy, who took over the National Hockey League lead with 40.

title: ON GRAND CONCOURSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Zimbabwe Moves to Gain Control of Newspapers
description: The Zimbabwe Government announced today that it had moved to tighten control over the country's main newspapers, but it pledged that press freedom would not be impaired.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Unemployment on the Rise

title: THE U.S. AND MEXICO
description: By Richard S. Fagen

title: Some Coast Prisoners Must Pay for Jail Cells
description: Petty thieves, intoxicated drivers and other people who commit misdemeanors will have to start paying for their cells as well as their crimes if they choose an optional weekend jail sentence offered in some Orange County cases.

title: Remy Joseph to Be Wed In March to Mark Steele
description: Mr. and Mrs. Allan B. Joseph of Pound Ridge, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Remy Joseph, to Mark W. Steele, son of Col. Eugene W. Steele, U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Steele of Fort Walton Beach, Fla. A March wedding is planned.

title: AILING BUSES, AGING SUBWAYS: THE PRICE A CITY PAYS
description: The Fantus Company is a consulting firm that advises big-time clients on moving from one location to another, sometimes thousands of miles away. Its guidance is often asked these days by companies that have begun to chafe in their big-city locations - in no small part because of the deterioration of the aging subways, commuter trains and other mass-transit systems that take employees to work.

title:
GARDENING;
HERBS FOR YEAR-ROUND ENJOYMENT
description: HERBS are plants with many uses. They lend their fragrances to perfumes, their distinctive flavors to foods, their repelling qualities to ridding the home and garden of insect pests and their healing properties to medicines. Herbs may also be planted for the beauty they contribute to the garden.

title: State Is Urged to Act On Succeeding Governor
description: The sad news of the resignation of Gov. Ella T. Grasso of Connecticut because of serious illness underscores the urgent necessity for New Jersey to change the method by which a successor to our Governor is chosen.

title: EAGLES AND PUFFINS IN RESURGENCE
description: The populations of the bald eagle, the symbol of the nation, and the puffin, the comical little seabird with an outsized red, yellow and blue beak, appear to be growing in Maine.

title: MONEY PROBLEM NO. 1 AT CAPITOL
description: HARTFORD THE 1981 General Assembly will convene Wednesday with a new Governor, many new leaders and new members but with an old problem - money - that promises to pervade the Capitol like the soot and smoke from a basement fire last Saturday night.

title: Carl Albert Is Heart Patient
description: McALESTER, Okla., Jan. 3 (UPI) -Carl Albert, former Speaker of the United States House of Representatives, is suffering from a heart condition and is under intensive care, a nurse at McAlester Regional Hospital said today.

title: IDEOLOGY ASIDE, NEW CONGRESS IS LIKELY TO STAY NEAR THE CENTER
description: ''Things are going to be different around here,'' Democratic Representative Morris K. Udall mused recently. ''I don't think the country wants us to turn back the clock, but they want us to slow down, to digest what we've swallowed.''

title: PARLEZ VOUS FRAN,CAIS?
description: Although English may have overtaken French as the generally accepted ''world language,'' French remains the language of the cosmopolite, and an opportunity to learn it painlessly is being offered by the Westchester County chapter of the Alliance Fran,caise, 9 Antony Road, White Plains.

title: GAINS IN SAVING OIL CHANGE U.S. OUTLOOK
description: As Americans respond to soaring oil prices by reducing their use of energy, Government and industry analysts are cutting their forecasts of demand for the rest of the century. They suggest that the gain in conservation represents a fundamental shift in the nation's energy picture.

title: Attribution
description: To the Editor:

title: Syria Strikes Out Hither and Yon
description: By Barbara Slavin and Milt Freudenheim In the political jargon of the Middle East, Syria ''steadfastly confronted'' its enemies last week, apparently also seeking to prop up the sagging prestige of President Hafez al-Assad.

title: THE PRIME SLIDES
description: The prime rate was cut to 20 1/2 percent, from 21 1/2 percent, led by Citibank and then followed by Bank of America, Manufacturers Hanover, Bankers Trust and other major banks. Four other big banks had already lowered their prime, but Citibank's move marked the first industry-wide retrenchment for the prime since it began to rise sharply in mid-November.

title: Swedish Youth on Upset Streak
description: Joakim Nystrom, a 17-year-old who came to the United States three weeks ago as an unheralded member of the Swedish squad, continued his series of surprises today at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: Missouri 83, Oral Roberts 74
description: Paced by Steve Stipanovich, the center who had not been expected to play, the Missouri Tigers got doublefigure scoring from five players and swept to an 83-74 victory over Oral Roberts tonight.

title: ECONOMIC DIFFICULTIES CONFRONTING CONGRESS ON RETURN TOMORROW
description: Congress returns to Washington Monday, with Republicans sharing power with the Democrats for the first time in nearly a generation and with all the lawmakers facing an economy that continues to produce high interest rates, inflation and unemployment.

title: NO MANDATE TO RENEW THE COLD WAR
description: By Javan Kienzle

title: Gordon Mott, Reporter, Weds Donna Belle Lilly
description: Donna Belle Lilly, a resident vice president in the financialinstitutions division of Citibank in Mexico City, was married at noon yesterday in Tepoztlan, Mexico, to Gordon Dennis Mott, a correspondent in Mexico City for The Associated Press. Vice Mayor Miguel Angel Robles of Tepoztlan performed the ceremony at a villa.

title: The Deeper Problems
description: It is the turn of the year and of a political generation. In the American tradition it should be a time of hope. But my sense is that most Americans, including those who voted for Ronald Reagan, have very limited hopes for transforming change in the years ahead. We doubt that life will improve.

title: Colombians Say Aide Died In Blast at Kenyan Hotel
description: A Colombian official and his son are missing and presumed dead in the Norfolk Hotel bombing that killed at least 13 people and injured 87 on New Year's Eve, the Colombian Embassy said here today. The dead included an American, identified only as Kenneth Moyer.

title: THE ANGUISH OF AN INJURED BALLERINA
description: For a just a few moments, it was possible to forget that Merrill Ashley hadn't performed before an audience in half a year. It was 6:30 P.M. on a Saturday night in December, and she was the sole dancer backstage in an empty New York State Theater. She was stretching, bending and reaching at the battered iron barre at stage left, a tiny figure in a dusty immensity. The only sound was the squeak of her pink toe shoes and the muffled flex of joints and muscles pushed to the limit. And the sight was so thoroughly familiar - the sleek Ashley carriage, the elegant neck, the long, quick legs, the huge hazel eyes staring levelly into that immeasurable space that is the realm of ballerinas only.

title: Coming Up Short On Fire Safety
description: By Don Wycliff and Alvin Davis After the fatal fires late last year in the MGM Grand Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev., and last month at Stouffer's Inn in Harrison, N.Y., New York City's Mayor Koch ordered a review of the city's fire and building codes. Plainclothes inspectors have issued summonses against 1,000 buildings, ordering the owners or managers to appear in Criminal Court.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: TIES THAT BIND EAST EUROPE SEEM TO BE GETTING LOOSER
description: The Communist countries of Eastern Europe appear to be going their separate ways to a degree unthinkable a decade ago. Their diversity in attitudes and policies has been spotlighted lately in their responses to the political and economic crisis in Poland, the chill of which the nearest Communist countries feel deeply, but which is looked upon by the more distant Communist nations with indifference bordering in some cases on contempt.

title: THE TOP 30 AUTOMEN
description: General Motors has made more money, but Ford has made more history, according to the Society of Automotive Historians, which placed three generations of Ford's on its list of the industry's most significant figures.

title: BOOK REVIEW
description: January 4, 1981 NONFICTION ALEKSANDRA KOLLONTAI: Socialism, Feminism, and the Bolshevik Revolution. By Beatrice Farnsworth. 3 ALEXANDRA KOLLONTAI: The Lonely Struggle of the Woman Who Defied Lenin. By Cathy Porter. 3 THE BACKYARD REVOLUTION: Understanding the New Citizen Movement. By Harry C. Boyte. 6 BOLSHEVIK FEMINIST: The Life of Aleksandra Kollontai. By Barbara Evans Clements. 3 CALIFORNIA RICH. By Stephen Birmingham. 10 JOURNEY AROUND MY ROOM: The Autobiography of Louise Bogan. A Mosaic by Ruth Limmer. 4 REVITALIZING AMERICA: Politics for Prosperity. By Ronald E. Muller. 10 ST. PAUL'S: The Life of a New England School.
