title: IF IT'S TUESDAY, IT MUST BE
description: THE first thing I do with the first new calendar I get is to see what day of the week my birthday falls on in the new year. Next year it will be a Saturday, which I find sort of nice.

title: Show Bettors Collect Bonanza at Aqueduct
description: Dr. Blum finished first in the $54,300 Paumonok Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday, but it was the fourth-place finish by Clever Trick that attracted the most attention.

title: HUNTINGTON OFFICIALS RESISTING CHALLENGE TO ONE-FAMILY ZONING
description: to moderate-income people, isn't getting any help from Town Board members of either party. The politicians are taking a united stand against the proposal.

title: CIVIC GROUP ACTING TO FIGHT CRIME AND JOBLESSNESS
description: The two biggest threats to New York City as a place to live or work are crime and unemployed youth, a coalition of the city's business and civic leaders has decided.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Fire and Water
description: Fire and water: bitter foes, yet capable of fruitful collaboration; each perilous to survival, yet each essential to life; each noticed in New York in 1980 as rarely before.

title:
GARDENING;
HERBS FOR YEAR-ROUND ENJOYMENT
description: HERBS are plants with many uses. They lend their fragrances to perfumes, their distinctive flavors to foods, their repelling qualities to ridding the home and garden of insect pests and their healing properties to medicines. Herbs may also be planted for the beauty they contribute to the garden.

title: Sarah Docter Beats Sister In U.S. Speed-Skating
description: Sarah Docter edged her sister Mary in the women's 1,000 meters at the United States speed-skating championships today.

title: WOULD REAGAN PLEAD FOR THE 'GANG OF FOUR'?
description: By Steven I. Levine

title: 2d Journalist Is Arrested For Red Brigades Interview
description: A second journalist from the weekly magazine L'Espresso was arrested today in connection with its publication of an interview with the Red Brigades.

title: Why Did Legislators Raise Salaries After Hearings?
description: On Jan. 5 the members of the Westchester County Board of Legislators will consider raising their base salaries from $15,255 to $16,550 in 1981 and to $17,956 in 1982. The County Executive's salary will go from $64,990 to $70,515 in 1981 and to $76,510 in 1982.

title: NEW YORKERS ABROAD PASS EXAM
description: All 38 New Yorkers in the first graduating class of Tel Aviv University's Sackler School of Medicine passed exams qualifying them for residency training in American hospitals, the students learned last week.

title: Transactions; BASKETBALL
description: SAN FRANCISCO (WBL) - Named Dean M eminger coach to succeed Frank LaPorte.

title: Recordings; THE 'REDISCOVERY' OF THE 'GREAT' (C.P.E.) BACH
description: One wonders what papa Johann Sebastian felt toward the end of his life, in 1747, when he visited his son Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach and his son's employer, King Frederick of Prussia. The king gave Sebastian a chromatic theme to improvise upon. Intrigued by its difficulty, Bach made it the foundation for ''The Musical Offering,'' which, with the ''The Art of the Fugue,'' was his summing up of a career devoted to the glories of architectural counterpoint.

title: CORRECTION
description: In last Sunday's list of 1980 champions, the winner of golf's Vardon Trophy, given to the PGA Tour player with the lowest stroke average, was incorrect.

title: A 'HORIZON' CREATED OF WOOD
description: ROSLYN HARBOR THERE is nothing shrinkingly timid or demurely unobtrusive about the wooden construction that Robert Stackhouse has built on the grounds of the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art. Not only does it dominate the landscape; it becomes the landscape. With its leviathan length of 220 feet and its towering height of 25 feet, it cuts an imperious profile over the lawn on which it stands. It is Mr. Stackhouse's own horizon line.

title: No Headline
description: Ski Check To the Editor: In the Special Ski Report (Travel Section, Nov. 16), an item on Cannon Mountain stated that skiing in the United States began there a half century ago. I question the validity of the statement.

title: INDIAN VILLAGE PLIGHT DEFIES REFORMERS, REVOLUTIONARIES
description: On the outskirts of this bustling commercial center in the state of Bihar, where dusty city lanes give way to quilts of tiny fields and densely packed village settlements, there is a large shed where 50 teen-age boys are being taught to weave rugs by hand. The workshop is one of 10 in the district, sponsored by a voluntary social agency and the Government handicraft board. At another training center, 25 older men are being taught to make chairs and baskets from bamboo strips. There is also a factory that manufactures diesel generators.

title:
ART;
SEEKING AND CAPTURING GHE SCENIC
description: EAST HAMPTON FIFTY years ago, when the artist Childe Hassam spoke at the opening ceremonies of Guild Hall, he dedicated the largest gallery to the memory of Thomas Moran (1837-1926). As the first painter to build a home and studio in East Hampton, Moran set a precedent that has since been emulated by hundreds in the visual, literary and performing arts, so that today the village is celebrated for its roster of distinguished artist-residents.

title: UConn 74, Rhode Island 69
description: Corny Thompson scored 22 points and Chuck Aleksinas 21 today as Connecticut remained undefeated with a 74-69 victory over Rhode Island.

title: VESCO ASSERTS HE ISN'T IN HIDING
description: Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive American financier, said in a statement released by his attorney today that he had not ''disappeared, vanished or absconded'' and that he would be back in Nassau Monday to fight Bahamian efforts to deport him.

title: Rams Owner Reportedly Recorded Telephone Calls
description: A former employee of the Los Angeles Rams has said in a sworn deposition that the club's owner, Georgia Frontiere, secretly recorded telephone calls and conversations in her home.

title: ANNA CHENNAULT SEES DENG
description: Anna Chennault, a Chinese-American who has high-level ties with both the Republican Party and the Chinese Nationalist Government on Taiwan, met today with Deng Xiaoping, China's paramount leader.

title: AIR FORCE ACADEMY SUED OVER SICKLE CELL POLICY
description: A former cadet from Minneapolis has filed a class action suit against the Air Force Academy, charging that the academy discriminates against blacks by a refusing to enroll those who carry a genetic anomaly called sickle cell trait.

title: Facilities
description: A gentleman of our acquaintance was looking out the window of his brownstone the other day when a mail truck drove up, the mailman jumped out and the space between two building across the street was turned into an instant comfort station.

title: ALGERIAN TEAM DISCUSSES U.S. REPLY WITH IRANIANS
description: The Algerian diplomatic intermediaries met this morning with Iranian officials to discuss the latest United States proposal for freeing the 52 American Embassy hostages, but throughout the day and evening there was no indication of what the Iranian reponse would be.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
AGEISM IS CITED IN FAMILY CARE FOR THE ELDERLY
description: MOST people believe that the elderly have no families - or have only infrequent contact with family members - or that adult children don't care about their aging parents and abandon them or put them in institutions.

title: A WALK IN WINTER TELLS NATURES SECRETS
YALE TO SELL BRASHER DOUBLOON TO HELP FINANCE UNIVERSITY'S NEW LIBRARY
description: One of the world's most famous, valuable and storied coins - Yale University's Brasher Doubloon - has been put up for sale for $650,000 to help underwrite a new library for the New Haven campus, Yale's president, A. Bartlett Giamatti, announced yesterday.

title: Bob Shawkey Dead at 90
description: Bob Shawkey, a star pitcher for the Yankees during the 1920's and their manager for one year, died at the age of 90. An obituary appears in Section I page 26.

title: Penn 60, Georgetown 58
description: The University of Pennsylvania broke Georgetown's 11-game home winning streak tonight with a 60-58 victory at McDonough Arena.

title: THE PROFESSOR-STUDENT BARRIER TO GROWTH
description: She sat down in the chair I indicated, unwound her scarf and unbuttoned her jacket. "I don't know if you remeber me," she began. "Of course I remember you!" I was astounded. Linda Harrison had been one of 15 students in a discussion section that had met weekly, just the previous semester, my first as a philosophy professor at Smith College. How could she suppose I wouldn't remember her? When I thought about it later, my astonishment was tempered by the reflection that when I was an undergraduate I imagined myself part of a fog of names, faces and personalities to my professors, a fog that might clear when I spoke up in class or besieged them during office hours, but would quickly and inexorably descend again. After all, they had so very many other students and such other important things to think about. But later that week I heard my colleagues reminisce about students who had graduated five years previously. So it wasn't true! That was the first of several startling comparisons I made between the views from the students' and the professors' sides of the desk. Another occurred after having brooded about what seemed to me an epidemic of absences from class. It had to mean that they thought me boring or incompetent. I confessed to a senior in my other class my anxiety over the number of students who skipped my intro course. "Hmmm," she said, "does it meet early in the morning? Or right after lunch? Or in the evening?" My worry dissipated.

title: STAMFORD, CONN.
description: Continental Baking Company has leased 17,000 square feet of office space at 1275 Summer Street in Stamford, Conn., a newly constructed building developed by Louis Evangelista. The 5-year lease has an aggregate rent of $1,445,000. Broker: Michael H. Godt, vice president, William Pitt Inc., of Stamford.

title: College Football's Final Top 20
Feminist Health Clinics
description: Allow me to share some of the insights I have had while working at several women's health clinics, including the first legal abortion clinic in the United States, the Women's Medical Center in New York City (''A New Era for Feminist Health Clinics,'' by Paula Span, Nov. 23). Things have changed incredibly during the last 10 years.

title: NOW, WHAT WAS YOUR ZIP CODE?
description: The nine-digit ZIP code the Postal Service intends to introduce next June 1 is two numbers too long to fit in most people's shortterm memory, claim researchers who study memory processes. This means that looking up a new ZIP code in a directory, closing the book, walking to a desk and writing the number down on an envelope is beyond the mental capacity of most people.

title: Lois E. Dehls Plans Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Allan W. Dehls of Bridgewater, N.H., formerly of Mountainside, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lois Elizabeth Dehls, to Paul Lincoln Cornell 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornell Jr. of Washington, Conn., A June wedding is planned.

title: Back to the Old Teeming Shore
description: By Michael Wright and Caroline Rand Herron The acting commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service last week proposed adding one more wrinkle to a system that, in the last decade, has been bent, folded and spindled into all but complete disarray.

title: Headliners Senghor Says Goodbye
description: ''He is an intelligent man, competent and humble,'' Leopold Sedar Senghor said last week, describing Abdou Diouf, his chosen successor as president of Senegal. Mr. Senghor, chief of state of the West African nation since it became independent of France 20 years ago, took his leave on New Year's Day, handing over power to Mr. Diouf, the Prime Minister, in a peaceful transfer. Mr. Senghor, who is as well-known for his French poetry as for his statecraft, told his nation of 5 million that, at age 74, he could no longer work the 10 hours a day that the Presidency required.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Thanks to the child psychologist Bruno Bettelheim's book-length benediction to fairy tales, ''The Uses of Enchantment,'' many of the darker stories in the repertory have been restored to respectability. The past several publishing seasons have brought us a number of retellings of these old unsettling tales. For the most part their current revival is the work of accomplished children's book illustrators eager to take on the challenge of such rich material.

title: OPEC
description: To the Business Editor:

title: New York Political Notes
description: Two of the Republican legislators returning to Albany this week for the new legislative session may not be there for long. Assemblymen Dominick L. DiCarlo of the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn and John L. Behan of Montauk, L.I., rank among the leading New York prospects for appointment to Reagan Administration posts, according to New York Republican leaders. Mr. DiCarlo, 52 years old, was a leader of the Reagan campaign in the state. He has been recommended for a deputy position in the Justice Department or possibly in the narcotics section of the State Department. He was an assistant United States attorney before his election to the Assembly. Mr. DiCarlo is considered one of the Legislature's criminal-law experts and one of its most influential members. He has been at loose ends since he lost a bid to be Assembly minority leader two years ago.

title: HISPANIC RESIDENTS JOYFULLY PREPARE FOR 3 KINGS DAY
description: FOR members of Westchester's rapidly expanding Hispanic population, it is beginning to look like Christmas again. While Dec. 25 is the high point of the yuletide season for most in the United States, Jan. 6, the feast of the Epiphany, also known as Old Christmas because it marks the date of that holiday on the Julian calendar, is still observed in various ways by Christians; and to Hispanic people it has a special significance.

title: COUNTY FARM ATTRACTS INTERNATIONAL MARKET
description: THE auctioneer's staccato voice echoed across the Hilltop Hanover Farm in Yorktown Heights and by the end of the day a record was set for what has been called the world's richest Holstein dairy cow auction.

title:
GARDENING;
HERBS FOR YEAR-ROUND ENJOYMENT
description: HERBS are plants with many uses. They lend their fragrances to perfumes, their distinctive flavors to foods, their repelling qualities to ridding the home and garden of insect pests and their healing properties to medicines. Herbs may also be planted for the beauty they contribute to the garden.

title: Elizabeth L. Hauge Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel Hauge of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Larsen Hauge, to Richard Morgan Sword, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Sword of Princeton, N.J.

title: Death Fugue By Paul Celan
description: Black milk of dawn we drink it at dusk we drink it at noon and at daybreak we drink it at night we drink it and drink it we are digging a grave in the air there's room for us all A man lives in the house he plays with the serpents he writes he writes when it darkens to Germany your golden hair Margarete he writes it and steps outside and the stars all aglisten he whistles for his hounds he whistles for his Jews he has them dig a grave in the earth he commands us to play for the dance Black milk of dawn we drink you at night we drink you at daybreak and noon we drink you at dusk we drink and we drink A man lives in the house he plays with the serpents he writes he writes when it darkens to Germany your golden hair Margarete Your ashen hair Shulamite we are digging a grave in the air there's room for us all He shouts cut deeper in the earth to some the rest of you sing and play he reaches for the iron in his belt he heaves it his eyes are blue make your spades cut deeper the rest of you play for the dance Black milk of dawn we drink you at night we drink you at noon and at daybreak we drink you at dusk we drink and we drink a man lives in the house your golden hair Margarete your ashen hair Shulamite he plays with the serpents He shouts play death more sweetly death is a master from Germany he shouts play the violins darker you'll rise as smoke in the air then you'll have a grave in the clouds there's room for you all Black milk of dawn we drink you at night we drink you at noon death is a master from Germany we drink you at dusk and at daybreak we drink and we drink you death is a master from Germany his eye is blue he shoots you with bullets of lead his aim is true a man lives in the house your golden hair Margarete he sets his hounds on us he gives us a grave in the air he plays with the serpents and dreams death is a master from Germany your golden hair Margarete your ashen hair Shulamite

title: REGAN ASSAILS M.T.A. ON TERMS OF CONTRACT TO PURCHASE GRUMMAN BUSES
description: In what he called ''further evidence of the virtual management breakdown at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority,'' State Comptroller Edward V. Regan charged yesterday that the authority had accepted terms in its contract for 837 Grumman Flxible buses that exempt the manufacturer from warranty repair costs that other cities require it to pay.

title: Sidney Anne Peard To Be a June Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Furnival Peard Jr. of Boca Raton, Fla., formerly of Baltimore and Riverside, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sidney Anne Peard, to James King McClure, son of Mrs. William A. Flint of Hamden, Conn., and the late Lambert Hicks McClure.

title: IN BRIEF: THE E.P.A.
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, established Dec. 2, 1970, is an independent agency within the executive branch headed by an administrator appointed by the President.

title: Charles Fleischmann to Wed Miss Watkins
description: Torrance Watkins of Middleburg, Va., a member of the United States Equestrian Team, and Charles Fleischmann, an amateur steeplechase rider who manages his family's farm properties in The Plains, Va., plan to be married Feb. 14.

title: SHANGHAI PREVIEW
description: The international bridge scene will be marked in 1981 by the full emergence of the People's Republic of China. After many years of banning bridge as a bourgeois activity the Chinese government, perhaps influenced by Deng Xiaoping who is himself a player, indulged in a complete volte-face at the beginning of l979.

title: Nets Face a Big Rebuilding Job
description: The building of the New Jersey Nets' new home in the Meadowlands has apparently taken place more quickly than the rebuilding of the team into a contender.

title: HERSEY'S CHINA STORY
description: This year and next year and perhaps the year after, John Hersey, who has written some of the lasting books of reportage and fiction of our time (going back to ''Hiroshima,'' about the human devastation caused by the first atomic bomb, and ''The Wall,'' an imaginative story rooted in fact about the Warsaw ghetto), will be working on a large novel that reaches back into his own past. It is set in China and written in the form of biography. The author was born in Tientsin (now Tainjin) in 1914, the son of American missionaries, and spoke Chinese in his youth.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
HOW THE HOLIDAYS LOOK FOR 1981
description: THE first thing I do with the first new calendar I get is to see what day of the week my birthday falls on in the new year. Next year it will be a Saturday, which I find sort of nice.

title: Betsy Pritchard Is Wed To Justin P. Wheating
description: In the First Church of Christ, Congregational in New Britain, Conn., yesterday, Betsy Curtis Pritchard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Pritchard of New Britain, was married to Justin Philip Wheating of New York. He is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Russell Wheating of Bedford, England.

title: EAGLES RALLY TO TIN BY 31-16
description: The Philadelphia Eagles struggled for the first half today in their divisional playoff game against Minnesota, spotting the Vikings a 14-0 lead before defeating them, 31-16.

title: REAGAN'S INSIDE TEAM WILL HOLD MUCH OF REAL POWER
description: It has been no accident that most of the publicity surrounding President-elect Ronald Reagan's transition appointments has focused on the secretaries in his cabinet. Even his unusual decision not to appear with his appointees as they were announced was attributed to Mr. Reagan's determination to let his department heads have the visibility, and to avoid being seen as pulling the strings behind the scenes with a handful of personal assistants.

title: Virginia 64, Virginia Tech 51
description: Ralph Sampson scored 15 of his gamehigh 19 points in the second half as Virginia wore down Virginia Tech and gained a 64-51 victory tonight.

title: Pat Dye Named Auburn's Coach
description: Pat Dye, who resigned as the Wyoming football coach last month, was named Auburn's coach today. He received a four-year contract.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF others
description: REVITALIZING AMERICA Politics for Prosperity. By Ronald E. Muller. 352 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $13.95.

title: On Grand Concourse
description: To the Editor:

title: The Messenger Of the Media
description: By Margot Slade and Eva Hoffman Marshall McLuhan was probably less famous at his death last week than he had been in his heyday as a media prophet. But his seminal insights about the electronic age, thought sensational when they first appeared, have become firmly entrenched in the culture's perceptions.

title: BRITISH INDIA'S PAST LIVES ON IN SIMLA
description: Stalking the ghosts of the British raj is probably nowhere more rewarding than in the Himalayan hill stations of northern India, those outposts of rural England, complete with timbered houses, parish churches and flower gardens that were created as refuges from the subcontinent's searing summer heat. The queen of them all was Simla, for more than a century the summer capital of British India. Spread over a series of steep hills 6,000 to 8,000 feet high and accessible at first only by a grueling trek of many days on horseback or sedan chair from the edge of the plain, Simla - still not exactly easy to get to - stands as testimony to the audacity if not the absurdity of the British empire in India.

title: Smoke Detector Law Toughened
description: The City Council has adopted a tougher law on smoke detectors that is expected to affect about 180,000 dwellings. Smoke detectors have been required only in new single-family homes and in apartment buildings and hotels of combustible construction at least four stories high. The law will require smoke detectors in all single-family homes upon change of ownership and in all duplexes, apartment buildings, boarding homes and hotels made of combustible materials.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: WHEN Norman Heischober really gets wound up on his subject, he talks with the speed and the complexity of a rattling player piano, which is perfectly fitting, in a mad sort of way, since Mr. Heischober is a tuner, rebuilder and indeed a creator of player pianos.

title: MORE ON MEXICO'S SUBWAY
description: To the Editor:

title: GARDEN-VARIETY CAKES AND BREADS
description: Anyone who closely follows food journalism probably is aware that the popularity of certain dishes tends to run in cycles. The fashionable foods of the moment may be ''sophisticated'' recipes, such as quiche Lorraine, beef Wellington, gazpacho or ratatouille. Or they may be down-to-earth creations as homespun and tempting as carrot cake and zucchini bread. The latter, according to our observations, rank high on the current list of American favorites. In our own kitchen, we have recently tested the recipes for these tasty foods. The recipe for carrot cake is from ''My Mother Cooked My Way Through Harvard With These Creole Recipes'' by Oscar A. Rogers (University of Mississippi, Jackson, Miss., 1972). The recipe for zucchini bread is that of Shirley Estabrook Wood, an excellent cook in whose home we dined a couple of summers ago.

title: MUSINGS OF A (RELATIVE) CONSERVATIVE
description: O N recent mornings I have been looking in the mirror at an unusual or, anyhow, surprising image: a conservative or, at least, a relative conservative. Partly this could be from some button-down shirts from the last time they were obligatory; much more this results from comparison with the economics being promised by the Reagan administration.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: slovakia. EARTHLY POWERS, by Anthony Burgess. (Simon & Schuster, $15.95.) A lively, crowded story about novelist Kenneth Toomey, 81, homosexual.

title: LET US NOW PRAISE FAMOUS MEN, by James Agee and Walker Evans.  (Houghton Mifflin, $8.95.) In 1936, on a journalistic assignment, James Agee (1909-55) and Walker Evans (1903-75) shared the lives of three sharecropper families in the Depression-gaunt South. Their report on the experience, in Agee's eloquent words and Evans's 59 devastating photographs, became one of 1941's unforgettable books.  But this is more than a vivid record of a bygone time and place, for Agee wrote in a style that may be appreciated on many levels. This handsome new softcover edition is worthy of the classic it has become.
description: RETURN FROM THE RIVER KWAI, by Joan and Clay Blair Jr. (Ballantine, $2.75.) After surviving the ordeal of constructing a railroad bridge over the River Kwai in Thailand, 1,300 Australian and British prisoners of war were packed into two ships headed for Japan, only to be set awash on the high seas when the transports were sunk by American submarines. The Blairs interviewed many of the 182 survivors and a number of the submariners to report for the first time one of World War II's most harrowing and heroic episodes.

title: Fairleigh Dickinson 82 Manhattan 71
description: Michael Payne, with 20 points, and four other double-figure scorers led Fairleigh Dickinson to an 82-71 victory over Manhattan College tonight.

title: LANGUAGE SKILLS SAID TO DWINDLE IN ARMED SERVICES
description: Pentagon officials and members of Congress say they are worried about persistent shortages in the armed forces of personnel fluent in foreign languages. The situation is hurting American intelligence capabilities, they assert, and could pose serious problems if units of the Rapid Deployment Force must be rushed to the third world.

title: STATE PLAYS MAJOR ROLE IN DRIVE TO PRESERVE HISTORIC HOUSE
description: BACK in the 1920's, the Johnson Ferry House, constructed in the early 18th century in what is now Washington Crossing State Park, was turned over to New Jersey by a private owner who had restored the building.

title: DISCRIMINATION IN MASS TRANSIT
description: ''Those types of transit most frequently used by the poor are the least subsidized, and those most used by the affluent are the most heavily subsidized.''

title: BRITISH COLLEGES MAJORING IN AUSTERITY
description: DESPITE two decades of expansion that have more than doubled the number of students in British universities and seen the number in polytechnics and colleges increase more than threefold, Britain still has the smallest proportion of secondary-school graduates going on to higher education of any developed country.

title: HISPANIC RESIDENTS JOYFULLY PREPARE FOR THREE KINGS DAY
description: WHILE most Americans have put their feet up, exhausted after all that holiday cheer, the Hispanic population is revving up for the grand finale of its Christmas season, Jan. 6, the Feast of the Epiphany, or Three Kings Day.

title: Chinese Restaurant Owners Are Targets of Extortionists
description: Gangs from New York and Chicago have been linked to attempts to extort money from owners of suburban Chinese restaurants, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating, the police said today.

title: WHY OSHA MAY BE OBSELETE
description: I N the 10 years that the Occupational Safety and Health Act has been law, it has become increasingly clear that in its current form OSHA isn't working. A recent Supreme Court ruling on the OSHA standard for worker exposure to benzene is the latest evidence that the time has come for Congress to review the philosophy and the applicability of OSHA and decide what it believes public policy should be regarding worker health and safety.

title: Nancy Helen James Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald G. James of Ipswich, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Helen James, to Philip Schuyler Deming, son of Mrs. George Edward Deming Jr. of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Deming. Miss James, who is in the management training program of the New England Merchants National Bank of Boston, and her fiance, a special agent with the Philadelphia district office of the Treasury Department, will be married June 20 in Christ Episcopal Church in Hamilton, Mass.

title: PERSISTENCE PAYS OFF FOR AUTHOR
description: EAST BRUNSWICK ALAN SAPERSTEIN and his wife, Lynn, were on vacation in Paris last July when Mr. Saperstein was notified that his book, ''Mom Kills Kids and Self,'' had been awarded the Hemingway Prize for the best first novel of the year.

title: Fructose Fakery
description: Sucrose, glucose, fructose - is there a difference? Noting buyer confusion over the array of sugars on the market, the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a consumer group in Washington, zeroed in on fructose early last year and petitioned the Food and Drug Administration and Federal Trade Commission to halt ''deceptive advertising and labeling.''

title: Undercutting the Underground
description: By Barbara Slavin and Milt Freudenheim E.T.A., the underground organization that has been striving for Basque independence from Spain through terrorism, appears to have suffered two blows of its own last week. The first was the murder of an E.T.A. leader in southern France; the second and potentially more damaging was a decision by Madrid to restore to the Basque provinces taxation powers revoked by Francisco Franco during the Spanish civil war.

title: CONTROVERSY GROWS IN ISRAEL OVER DISMISSAL OF NATIONAL POLICE CHIEF
description: A controversy over the ouster of the Israeli police chief by Interior Minister Yosef Burg intensified tonight when Mr. Burg acknowledged that he had asked the chief to delay an investigation into politically sensitive cases until after elections this year.

title: A Distillery With Landmark Status; Visitors view a 100-year-old process of making bourbon in Loretto, Ky.
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- NED McGRATH is a news reporter for WHAS-TV, Louisville, Ky. By NED McGRATH

title: SKIDMORE'S UNIVERSITY WITHOUT WALLS SNARES PRISONERS
description: WHEN Prof. Philip West teaches Shakespeare Monday nights his style and approach to the subject alter considerably from that of his normal daytime class routine. For one thing, he dresses down for the occasion, wearing stained jeans, a worn corduroy shirt and casual herringbone sports jacket. For another, his discussion of the Bard's sonnets and plays is spattered with fourlettered words and an occasional bawdy story. These are tactics from which Mr. West refrains when teaching Shakespeare by day at Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, a campus dominated by young women from upper-middle-class homes. But on Monday nights the professor's audience is very different: all his students are male, most from out of town and all serving time at Great Meadow Correctional Facility, a maximum-security lockup in this hamlet in rural Washington County. Mr. West is one of 17 professors who weekly make the hour-long trip from the lush Skidmore campus to teach a course behind bars. The program of inmate education is considered to be among the nation's oldest, largest and most successful. The courses are part of Skidmore's external-degree program, ironically named the University Without Walls. It began as a controversial experiment in 1974 with a dozen professors teaching four courses to 30 inmates. Today, higher-education courses for inmates can be found in prisons across the country, partly as a result of the success of the Skidmore plan, which has grown to the point where it has been called "a mini-college behind bars."

title: Poll Reflects; Pessimism; Over Inflation; and Jobs
description: In contrast to the hopes that Americans had four years ago that Jimmy Carter would reduce inflation and unemployment, a Gallup poll has found that large percentages of them expect both inflation and unemployment to increase in 1981 with Ronald Reagan as President.

title: A WINTER'S TALE
description: By Larry Van Goethem

SEATED on a stool at one of the many roadside truck stops that flank U.S. 1-9 (Tonnelle Avenue), Elvio Ramirez wonders whether he'll be able to hold down his factory job through the winter. Although manufacturing is still the major employer in this predominantly bluecollar Hudson County community, many factories have gone out of business or moved out of the area in recent years.

title: RECENT CHOREOGRAPHIC NOVELTIES
description: As the new year begins, it seems only fair to record two events of interest that took place at the end of last year. One was a performance by the Joffrey II Dancers and the other was an anthology of avant-garde choreography presented as a benefit for Movement Research, Inc., an organization of dancer-choreographers formed ''to address the unique needs of the post-modern dance community.''

title: KEVIN KLINE- THE MAKING OF A PIRATE KING
description: Outside the 51st Street stage door of the Uris, the biggest theater on Broadway, it is 1 P.M. on a recent Monday, time for that day's rehearsal of the New York Shakespeare Festival's production of ''The Pirates of Penzance.''

title: BREAKING THE PATTERN OF JOBS WITH A GENDER
description: IN the high-ceilinged masonry shop, eight women leaned intently over low tables half full of mortar. With one hand on their trowels and their concentration on their wrists, each lifted a glob of mortar and flung it in a line parallel to and not far from the table's edge. They practiced making furrows through the mortar with the tips of their trowels and knew they had succeeded when the furrows were continuous.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
UNCLE SAM, INSURANCE AGENT
description: A RE you worried about your neighborhood nuclear plant blowing up? Do you think that your home may be inundated by a flood? Perhaps you own a plane that might be shot down in a war. Never fear. There's a big insurance company that offers protection against such contingencies: the United States Government.

title: WASHINGTON
description: T O have the right name and telephone number at one's fingertips can be an ''open sesame'' in this town where information, political power, grants and government contracts can often be found at the other end of the telephone.

title: Wichita State 77, Iona 46
description: Tony Martin and Ozell Jones combined for 30 points as Wichita State broke open a close game early in the second half and trounced Iona, 77-46, tonight.

title: PERSERVENCE WINS IN WORLD OF A.K.C.
description: THE exquisite pooch, a papillon, was fluttering about Ilsa Sternberg's lap. It had perched on the 31-year-old Hartsdale woman, abandoning its own pup, when the huge golden retriever wandered from the room.

title:
ON THE ISLE;
SPANISH CHRISTMAS
description: On the 11th day of Christmas - today - the Great Neck Library will celebrate with a Latin accent with ''Una Dia de Los Reyes Magos,'' or a Spanish Christmas party. Complete with the Three Wise Men, a magician, balloons and a pinata, starting at 1:30 P.M., the library, on Bayview Avenue, will be transformed into a setting for a traditional holiday fiesta to which adults and children of all ages and backgrounds are invited.RENAISSANCE MUSIC

title: Realty News; LAW FIRM SIGNS LEASE IN 101 PARK AVE.
description: The law firm of Hale Russell Gray Seaman & Birkett has leased 33,000 square feet of office space in the 50-story skyscraper under construction at 101 Park Avenue at 40th Street. The 15-year lease for the space, which consists of the 27th floor and a portion of the 28th floor, has an aggregate rent of more than $15 million.

title: COURT BATTLE GOES ON OVER JONES INSTITUTE
description: NOW that the Jones Institute has been boarded up - its beds, chairs and homeless residents scattered about the Island - the trustees who closed the building and the coalition that fought to keep it open are blaming each other for blocking attempts to relocate the facility.

title: JERSEY HIGH COURT UPHOLDS A SUIT FOR LOST SERVICES IN CHILD'S DEATH
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court has ruled that in the event of a child's wrongful death, the parents are entitled to recover the estimated value of services and benefits they could reasonably expect to have received from the child.

title: Kissinger Visits Israel On Mission for Reagan
description: Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, who is on an unofficial exploratory mission for the Reagan administration, arrived in Israel today and said he expected slow progress in the Arab-Israeli peace process. He added that he would not get involved in day-to-day peace talks.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: JOSHUA and Sandra Sumner bought a rundown 18-room house in New Rochelle three years ago for themselves and their four children. They began repairing it, and they expanded their family with two foster children.

title: No. Carolina Loses To Kansas, 56 to 55
description: Kansas held off a North Carolina rally in the last minute and scored a 56-55 victory over the Tar Heels in a non-conference college basketball game tonight.

title:
ART;
DRAWINGS AND JOYS OF LIFE CELEBRATED
description: TWO interesting and rewarding exhibitions have recently opened at the Neuberger Museum of the State University College at Purchase, which will itself reopen after the holidays on Tuesday. One celebrates in a particularly intense way the art of drawing, and the other, equally intensely, celebrates the joys of life.

title: REPRESSION INCREASED IN THE WORLD IN 1980, A HUMAN RIGHTS SURVEY SAYS
description: Repression increased worldwide in 1980, according to Freedom House, a nonpartisan human rights organization. The annual survey by the New York-based group said nearly 1.5 billion people in 17 countries lost some political rights and freedoms in 1980, while 169.2 million in 12 nations gained some freedoms.

title: Accused at 70
description: For four years, the feud had boiled in East Haven, Conn.: Emily Kruger Papuga, a 70-year-old widow, vs. rowdy youths. She had declined to let them cross her property to reach a wooded area; they taunted her by hurling stones and obscenities.

title: The Budget
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Nuclear Power: Still More Opinions
description: I agree with Herbert Jaffe (''Nuclear Power and the Need for Energy: More Opinions'') that we must free ourselves from dependence on OPEC, and while he has put his money where his mouth is, I have also invested a great deal of time researching and writing on the subject of energy and am working on a book tentatively titled ''Break OPEC Before They Break Us.''

title: POINTERS ON CHOOSING AND USING COLOR FILM
description: All color films are designed to render pleasing pictures of average subjects in good light when properly exposed, but there are many outside factors that can affect the color balance of every film. For example, our atmosphere is composed of gases of varying densities and as the sun's light passes through this atmosphere between the hours of 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. it will yield the best color results because daylight color films respond best to the quality or color temperature of light (5500 Kelvin) emitted under those conditions.

title: CARTER'S LEGACY
description: By Richard Joffe

title: AN AMERICAN VOICE
description: A SENTIMENTAL EDUCATION Stories. By Joyce Carol Oates. 196 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $11.95.

title: Pretoria Puts Two Blacks Under a Ban
description: By Barbara Slavin and Milt Freudenheim In Johannesburg, as in Warsaw, labor unions have been accumulating political clout that threatens the authoritarian system. The South African Government last week lashed back, suspending the civil rights of two black leaders of a union that had just settled a dispute with the country's big English-language newspapers.

title: EN.TRE.PRE.NEUR
description: The late Bing Crosby said in an interview in 1976 that he ''was entrepreneured into success.'' Today, colleges give courses in entrepreneurship, the titles of new how-to-do-it business books are littered with ''entrepreneur'' references, and Venture, ''the magazine for Entrepreneurs,'' uses the word 89 times in the 80 pages of its January issue.

title: Penguins 6, Red Wings 4
description: Greg Malone and Peter Lee scored two goals apiece as the Penguins defeated Detroit. The Red Wings lost despite a three-goal game by Reed Larson. It was the first three-goal game of Larson's N.H.L. career.

title: Pope Sees Greek Orthodox Cleric
description: Pope John Paul II received Metropolitian Georges Khodr of the Greek Orthodox Church today at a private audience, the Vatican reported. The Metropolitan is the chief Greek Orthodox delegate on a commission studying the possible reunification of the Roman Catholic and Greek Orthodox Churches.

title: VILLARD HOUSES
description: Celine of Paris, a men's and women's apparel and accessories boutique, has leased a 5,500-square-foot-store on the southeast corner of 51st Street and Madison Avenue in the Villard Houses that are part of the Helmsley Palace Hotel. The 20-year sublease from the Municipal Arts Society of New York is the first commercial lease in the Villard Houses and has an aggregate rent of approximately $6 million. Celine of Paris operates more than 60 boutiques around the world. Brokers: Edward M. Lederman, senior vice president, Edward S. Gordon Company, and Naomi Okada, executive vice president, the Futterman Organization Inc.

title: Unbeaten DePaul Captures 12th
description: Mark Aguirre scored 27 points as undefeated and No. 1-ranked DePaul overpowered Furman, 78-65, tonight in college basketball.

title: 'PREPPY HANDBOOK'
description: Last spring, Jonathan Roberts was 25 years old, a graduate of the Cambridge School in Boston and Brown, a funny young man who wanted to write. ''Usually, people tell you to write what you know,'' he says. ''For years, I thought - 'What do I know? I'm just a Preppy.'''

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
LETTER FROM WESLEYAN
description: DEAR Mom: How's the Midwest? Thanks so much for the vitamins and the articles about keeping healthy at college. I never knew there was such a thing as vitamin P12.5, but I'm sure I'll start each day with a turnip-rind milkshake, like the article says.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: In the history of numismatics, there has probably never been a year as eventful as 1980. The last 12 months witnessed so many recordbreaking auctions, so many eye-popping prices, and such intense dayto-day activity, that veterans of less frenzied times still have trouble grasping what has happened.

title: T
description: HE state's mass-transportation agency, NJ Transit, still has an order on the books for 271 of the controversial Grumman Flxible buses.

title: States News Service
description: WASHINGTON DURING a campaign swing through New Jersey last year, Vice President Mondale described Representative Robert A. Roe, Democrat of Wayne, as ''Mr. Jobs.'' It's a characterization that many people would use to portray the six-term Congressman and gubernatorial hopeful.

title: THE M.B.A. LOSING SOME OF ITS LUSTER
description: IS the meteoric rise of the M.B.A. running out of steam? As students enroll in record numbers in pursuit of the Master of Business Administration, the degree program that vies with medical and law school for the attention of the best, the brightest and the most ambitious college graduates, increasing numbers of critics have been grumbling about the inability of some highly paid graduates to live up to their billing. Some of the growning numbers of programs in the last 15 years have been challenged as too low in quality and others as too firmly anchored in the status quo. Since new M.B.A.'s are estimated to get starting salaries 60 percent above those for liberal-arts bachelors, it is not surprising that there has been mushrooming groth in business degrees. In 1980, more than 50,000 men and women received advanced business degrees, compared with only 5,000 a decade and a half earlier. Stanford University, for example, reports that its class of 1980 commanded median starting pay of $32,000, up from $27,000 the year before. The natinal average is $21,300. Yet, Business Week recently detected "disenchangment" with the business schools' product. It reported complaints from business about "the inability of newly minted M.B.A.'s to communicate, their overreliance on mathematical techniques of management and...expectations of becoming chairman in four weeks." Other critics complain that, at a time when American business is in need of change, business schools are not turning out enough young people with new ideas and a flair for shaking up existing procedures.

title: Wrong Number Sparks Suit
description: A lawyer sued New Jersey Bell Telephone yesterday because the company erroneously listed his phone number under Public Service Electric and Gas Company's heading in the Gloucester County directory. The lawyer, Jeffrey Puff, said in papers filed in Superior Court yesterday that the mistaken entry caused him mental anguish. He said that the''phone calls have come in the middle of the night, on weekends, during meals and constantly during business hours.''

title: L.S.U. 92, Florida 66
description: With Howard Carter scoring 25 points and grabbing 15 rebounds, Louisiana State routed Florida by 92-66 today in the Southeastern Conference opener for both teams.

title: Double Trouble On Staten Island's Commuter Line
description: By Don Wycliff and Alvin Davis New York City's commuter rail system suffers from an abundance of ills, but regular crashes of trains into each other or into third objects is, happily, not among them. Last week, however, a Staten Island train loaded with morning rush-hour passengers overshot its platform and slammed against a brick wall.

title: LOPEZ PORTILLO TO REAGAN ON CENTRAL AMERICA: DON'T
description: When Ronald Reagan crosses briefly into Mexico tomorrow on his only foreign trip before Inauguration Day, he will delve into the affairs of a region that may give his administration some of its earliest and biggest headaches.

title: Guess Who Isn't The Life of the Party in Peking
description: By Barbara Slavin and Milt Freudenheim In happier days, Chairman Hua Guofeng's gung ho willingness to skip the traditional xiu-xi, or midday nap, made the evening news in China, but last week he looked more like a political sleepwalker marking time until retirement.

title: A Quick Reference Resource Guide to State Parks
description: The offices listed below can provide detailed information on state parks, including locations, facilities, activities, fees and how and where to make reservations. In most states, actual reservations are made directly with individual parks. Telephone lines are generally open during normal working hours. In most states, brochures and maps are free. Alabama Division of State Parks, Department of Conservation and Natural

title: Television Week
description: A Long and Twisting Road

title: A Chilled Hunter Bags His Goose Limit
description: cited compensations of advancing years did not include a continuing resistance to cold.

title:
ANTIQUES;
EARLY FURNITURE AND PEWTER AMONG WARES AT WALLINGFORD
description: DEALERS prefer to believe that antiques are purchased for their intrinsic beauty and grace of line, their evocation of the past, and only peripherally for their investment value. But the truth is, there is a growing understanding, especially among newer and younger collectors, that good antiques more than keep pace with the rate of inflation.

title: MORE UNTHOUGHTFULNESS
description: To The Living Section: Thank you, Enid Nemy, for the article "New Yorkers, etc." (Jan.7). I heartily agree that we are all getting too self-centered, and have lost the attitude that we must all get along by helping each other. And what better way than to think of the other fellow as we purse our daily activities.

title: ROUTE TO THE INNER CIRCLE
description: W ITH the Reagan cabinet largely in place, the new administration will be moving in the months ahead to fill the hundreds of subcabinet posts and thousands of advisory positions that will help govern the country. Business is sure to be amply represented if the history of all recent administrations, whether Democratic or Republican, is any guide. Various studies show that one-third to one-half of the highest Federal posts have been occupied by those drawn from the corporate world, regardless of the occupant of the White House.

title: Swimmers Establish 4 Standards
description: For the second night in a row, Tracy Caulkins and Mary T. Meagher, turned in world-best times in the United States international swimming meet at the University of Florida's pool tonight.

title: BISTRO FOOD, NICELY PREPARED
description: LE PETIT PARIS in West Babylon takes French cooking seriously. The menu does not offer fettuccine, clams casino or steak Diane to satisfy diners with Continental or northern Italian tastes who might wander in, the way some so-called French restaurants on the Island do.

title: Critics' Choice; DANCE
description: Pauline Koner remains one of the key names in the development of American modern dance. As a child, she was a pupil of Michel Fokine and began her professional career dancing with the Japanese modern dancer Michio Ito.

title: OWNERS ASK UPDATE OF STABILIZATION CODE
description: The Rent Stabilization Association has written a proposed ''plainlanguage'' version of the rent stabilization code, incorporating changes that the association calls clarifications but which would undoubtedly cause controversy. The issue of code changes appears dead for the present, however, because of a negative reaction from Anthony B. Gliedman, the city's housing commissioner. Code revision is inappropriate, he wrote the association a week ago. With the Emergency Tenant Protection Act expiring in June, any present effort to alter the code would merely ''divert attention from the principal debate'' - the future of the rent stabilization system, he said.

title:
STAMPS;
FIRST 1981 U.S. ISSUE
description: It is almost as if the first U.S. commemorative of this new year is heralding the incoming Republican Administration and the first Republican-controlled Senate in years. Although it was actually selected long before the election, the new 15-cent stamp, commemorates Everett McKinley Dirksen, one of the great Republican luminaries of the recent past and the leader of the ''loyal opposition'' when he was Senate Minority Leader during some of the nation's most trying years.

title: A WORD ABOUT TRAPS
description: Agood opening trap would reap a fine harvest years ago when there were no such things as up-to-the-minute tournament bulletins disseminating game scores all over the world.

title: A CITY COLLEGE WEDS WORK AND CLASSROOM
description: shirt emblazoned with the letters T.A.R. is tacked to the wall like a trophy in one of the offices at LaGuardia Community College's bustling campus in Long Island City. Its message, no secret to the almost 7,000 students at the college, is ''teach, apply and reinforce,'' which might be called the school's guiding educational philosophy.

title: BEAUTIFUL AND CRUEL
description: THESPLENDORSOFTIBET Text and Photographs by Audrey Topping. Foreword by Seymour Topping. 185 pp. New York: SINO Publishing Co. $25. By JAY MATHEWS

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Soap. A growing number of Americans, more at ease with graphic images than with the printed word, aren't turning to books for their entertainment these days. Naturally, it's a situation that greatly concerns residents of Publishers Row. Little wonder that they'll be closely watching an experiment Pocket Books inaugurates this week when it stuffs the mass-market racks with ''And Baby Makes Three'' by Winifred Wolfe ($2.50), a 160-page paperback described on its cover as ''an original novel in pictures - the soap opera that fits into your pocket.'' In 338 black-and-white photographs and wisps of dialogue in the margins around them, the book narrates a domestic crisis in a young Manhattan family reminiscent of ''Kramer vs. Kramer'' and ''Ordinary People.''

title: Irish Rugby Union to Send A Team to South Africa
description: The Irish Rugby Union announced today that it would send a team to tour South Africa next May. Today's decision is likely to meet with strong opposition from critics of South Africa's racial policies but was not unexpected.

title: Dividends (Cont.)
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Miss Slusser And a Lawyer Plan Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. W. Peter Slusser of New York and Santa Rosa, Calif., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Elizabeth Slusser, to Robert Welch Mullen Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mullen of New York. The couple will be married in May in St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
FOR O'NEILL, PITFALLS AND OPPORTUNITIES
description: HARTFORD WHO is Bill O'Neill anyway? A Hartford cab driver asked me that question the other day. ''Nobody knows him,'' he said. ''Can he run this state?

title: ST.JOHN'S TURNS BACK VILLANOVA BY 90-78
description: David Russell and William Goodwin, sophomore forwards, scored 24 points apiece to lead St. John's to a 90-78 victory over Villanova tonight.

title: Marla E. Miller Is Married
description: Marla Ellen Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Miller of Atlantic Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Jerrold Foster Goldberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Goldberg of North Woodmere, L.I., where Rabbi Morris Friedman performed the ceremony at Temple Hillel. The bride is a marketing assistant with National Football League Properties. Her husband is an associate with the New York law firm of Shea & Gould.

title: THE EMPHASIS IN STUDENT-ATHELETE SHOULD BE ON STUDENT
description: Last May, the Rev. Edmund P. Joyce of the University of Notre Dame, in a speech at a College Football Association meeting, addressed many of the problems facing college athletics. Since then, more scandals have been uncovered, and the association has made recommendations to the National Collegiate Athletic Association regarding possible solutions. Some of those recommendations will be discussed at the N.C.A.A. convention, which will start a week from Tuesday. In light of the new scandals, Father Joyce's call for reform has become even more crucial. Following is an excerpt from his speech. By THE REV. EDMUND P. JOYCE

title: Blues 6, Canucks 3
description: Perry Turnbull scored his 13th and 14th goals of the season 74 seconds apart in the second period for the Blues. The victory by St. Louis, its third in a row, extended the Blues' unbeaten string to six games and lifted them into second place in overall league standing with a 25-9-5 record.

title: Suit Allowed On Agent Orange
description: By Margot Slade and Eva Hofffman Vietnam veterans claiming injuries from exposure to Agent Orange claimed a legal victory last week, but could yet lose their battle against the defoliant's manufacturers. Federal District Court Judge George C. Pratt ruled that the veterans could sue the chemical companies in a class action in Federal court, access to which had been denied in a previous Federal appeals court decision.

title: THE BUDGET
description: To the Business Editor:

title: ALL THE PRESIDENT'S BUSINESSMEN
description: WASHINGTON H E could be a commuter on the 7:29 from Bedford Hills riding in the club car to an executive job near Grand Central, keys to the Toyota Land Cruiser tucked in the pockets of his Brooks Brothers fine blue pinstripe.

title: SOVIET JEWISH EMIGRATION DECLINED SHARPLY IN 1980
description: The number of Jews permitted to emigrate from the Soviet Union declined sharply last year compared with 1979, according to figures released yesterday in New York by the National Conference on Soviet Jewry. Soviet officials relied on increasingly stringent, and apparently arbitrary, rules to curtail emigration.

title: LOCAL FOLKS ON THE MOVE
description: THEBACKYARDREVOLUTION Understanding the New Citizen Movement. By Harry C. Boyte. 271 pp. Philadelphia: Temple University Press. $14.95. By ROBERT SCHRANK

title: A CAPITAL GAME OF POWER
description: One Kissinger is currently worth two Brzezinskis. A George Will or an Al Haig outweighs a dozen liberal columnists or a cloakroom of Democratic senators.

title: photo of Saoul Mamby; SAOUL MAMBY PRESERVES LOST RING ART
description: A COLD was nagging at his chest and The Professional knew that his opponent for the fight to unify boxing's junior welterweight title was recovering from bullet wounds, so there seemed no urgency to train this day. But he was already in the gym.

title: PISSARRO-'THE UNEXPLORED IMPRESSIONIST'; LONDON
description: Among exhibitions scheduled for the year 1981 in this country, none has aroused more lively expectation than the retrospective of paintings, drawings and prints by Camille Pissarro (1830-1903) which will be seen at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston from May 19 through Aug. 9, 1981. The show is an Anglo-Franco-American venture, and its prime movers include John Walsh Jr. of the Boston Museum, Fran,coise Cachin of the Musee d'Orsay in Paris and Christopher Lloyd of the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford, which has a very large holding of Pissarro family material. More than 30 American institutions have lent to the show, as have 12 museums in France, 11 in England and Scotland, and private collectors from all over.

title: Third World
description: To the Editor:

title: Janet Tres Flanagan Married to Emory Lee Morsberger
description: In St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont, N.Y., yesterday aftenoon, Janet Tres Flanagan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J.T. Flanagan of Scarsdale, N.Y., became the bride of Emory Lee Morsberger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Morsberger of Catonsville, Md. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William V. Reynolds.

title: Eileen Ann Titus Married
description: Eileen Ann Titus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Austin Titus of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Gerard Joseph Fitzpatrick, who has begun an internship at St. Joseph's Hospital in Stamford, Conn. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Fitzpatrick of Commack, L.I. The Rev. Crispin Maguire performed the ceremony in St. Philip Neri Roman Catholic Church in Northport, L.I.

title: Luggage
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Brooks: No Regrets On Coaching Move

title: Prison Fears Voiced - And Confirmed
description: By Michael Wright and Caroline Rand Herron A year ago this February, 33 persons were killed when the New Mexico State Penitentiary exploded in violence. Since then, the potential for yet more violence behind prison walls everywhere has increased, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger warned last week.

title: 6 Sessions on Schedule For Council This Week
description: The following City Council meetings have been scheduled for this week: TUESDAY - Committee on Public Safety, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Finance, City Hall, noon. WEDNESDAY - Full Council, City Hall, noon. THURSDAY - Committee on Civil Service and Labor, City Hall, 10:30 A.M.; Committee on Housing and Buildings, City Hall, 1:30 P.M. FRIDAY - Committee on Health, City Hall, 11 A.M.

title: CONTINENTAL DINING IN GENIAL SETTING
description: HAMDEN ON looks alone, Shawn's might be awarded best-of-show. Much attention has been given to the two comfortable dining rooms and the spacious, separate bar in this house on Whitney Avenue. A copperycolored, pressed tin ceiling, rich dark wood paneling, graceful elongated mirrors lining one paneled wall, gaslights and etched glass wall sconces and a plethora of palms suggest a turn-of-century style that is natural and warmly inviting.

title: Italy's Terrorists Take Aim at Prisons
description: By Barbara Slavin and Milt Freudenheim Unable to bring down the Italian state, left-wing terrorists last week focused on that part of it closest to many of their comrades - Italy's maximum-security prisons.

title: Two Cities Sued On Police Hiring
description: By Don Wycliff and Alvin Davis The Federal Government last week sued White Plains and Yonkers over police hiring practices, charging that both Westchester County cities ''systematically deny'' equal opportunities to black, Hispanic and female applicants.

title: P.R. O'Flinn Fiance Of Kathleen Tracy
description: The engagement of Kathleen Tracy to Peter Russell O'Flinn has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Gerard B. Tracy of New Canaan, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Russell W. O'Flinn of Brooklyn and the late Mr. O'Flinn.

title: IN BRIEF: OSHA
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration, established Dec. 29, 1970, comes under the purview of the Department of Labor and is headed by an Assistant Secretary of Labor.

title: Judith Underwood Will Be the Bride Of G. B. Stewart 3d
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Nathanial B. Heard of Marion, Mass., of the engagement of Mrs. Heard's daughter, Judith Underwood, to G. Bennett Stewart 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Jr. of Wallingford, Pa.,

title: LITERARY GAMES
description: HOW GERMAN IS IT By Walter Abish. 252 pp. New York: New Directions, Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $5.95. In his previous books, Walter Abish has played the part of rubber-razer in our literary landscape, digging up the dust beneath the surface of our everyday words. He has played this part with wit and imagination, using language to question its own veracity; permitting syntactic ambiguities to hover quizzically over their object, only to zero in for a final demolition job. Now Mr. Abish has written a novel. (The earlier "Alphabetical Africa" was more a literary extravaganza than a novel.) In "How German Is It," Mr. Abish seeks to apply this rubble-razing technique to the new Germany. With what results? One is reminded of the gimmicky cards sent out recently by our local gas companies. The cards have a rough spot, and they say, "Scratch this surface and you will recognize the smell of gas." In both cases, the effect is less convincing than startling. The "surface" in this case is a modern German town built on the site of a mass-grave and former concentration camp. The town is new-named Brumholdstein after Germany's leading philosopher, a Heidegger think-alike, dot the pages of the book, "documenting" the ineffable Germanness of all things German. The main characters are two brothers who are seen as incorporating the Janus aspects of the new Germany. Helmuth Hargenau, the complacent conformist, is and has just completed a new police station where the files on his brother, Ulrich, author and one-time terrorist, are to be housed.

title:
GARDENING;
HERBS FOR YEAR-ROUND ENJOYMENT
description: HERBS are plants with many uses. They lend their fragrances to perfumes, their distinctive flavors to foods, their repelling qualities to ridding the home and garden of insect pests and their healing properties to medicines. Herbs may also be planted for the beauty they contribute to the garden.

title: No Headline
description: I read William Barry Furlong's article with interest. It is a relief to know that all of the warriors in the Pit are not Neanderthals, and that Joe Greene, the meanest of them all, is really a human being. I have only one complaint: That is not an ice cube Lee Roy Selmon is toying with; that's his mouthpiece. GREGORY ADDISON, Glen Ridge, N.J.

title: Kentucky Batters Georgia
description: Seven straight points by Fred Cowan early in the second half helped Kentucky defeat Georgia, 76-62, in a Southeastern Conference basketball game today.

title: DANCE: STRANGE JOURNEYS FROM EMERY HERMANS
description: Emery Hermans sent dancers off on mysterious journeys at Friday night's performance of the Emery Hermans Dance Company at the Washington Square Methodist Church.

title: Plan for Halting Alienation In Broken Families
description: Marguerite A. Keeshan's poignant article, ''A Season of Sadness for Some,'' resonates with many readers, as divorce becomes increasingly a fact of life for many families. But relationships with members of a former partner's family can be addressed flexibly and creatively. Both divorced people -and I am one - and professionals who work with families, troubled or even separating - and I am one of these also - know that there need not be any alienation from relatives by marriage when the marriage breaks up, if the relationship was sound originally.

title: MISGUIDED FEDERAL FOCUS ON THE SUN BELT
description: By Saul B. Cohen

title: PAROCHIAL: TRAINING A NEW CONSTITUENCY
description: AS a cafeteria full of exuberant students at Rice High School devoured the last morsels of lunch, the faculty monitor, a Roman Catholic monk, blew a sharp blast on a silver whistle and called the room to prayer. As he crossed himself, the students hushed, gathered and listened respectfully to the blessing and the dismissal.

title: I-78: An Argument For Its Completion
description: IN THE last year, a number of emotional appeals have appeared in The New York Times and other publications against the completion of I-78 through the Watchung Reservation in Union County.

title: Cynthia Hutchinson Wed to Richard Adams
description: Cynthia Sharron Hutchinson and Richard Nicholson Adams, New York lawyers, were married yesterday morning in St. Thomas Episcopal Church. The Rev. Gary P. Fertig performed the ceremony.

title: DICK CAVETT: 'I LOVE IT WHEN THE ICE GETS THIN'
description: If there is one encomium Dick Cavett loathes, it is being told he is the only intellectual on television. ''I spend half my life denying I'm an intellectual,'' he says, ''and can easily prove it.''

title: Sabres 3, Nordiques 3
description: Bill Hajt and Ric Seiling scored third-period goals to give Buffalo the tie with the Nordiques.

title: Saturday Night Favor
description: As convicted felons, Steven Rubell and his fellow former owner of the Studio 54 discotheque, Ian Schrager, could hardly be considered exemplars of the Boy Scout virtues. But since the Government came down on them for skimming profits and evading taxes, they have practiced one of those virtues and, last week, they learned that it had its rewards.

title: THE MOOD OF THE CAPITAL
description: By James Reston WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -We have a New Year and will soon have a new President in Washington, but the mood of the capital is still dominated by the habits and quarrels of the past and wondering anxiously about the future.

title: Back Through Clouds
description: The most advantageous point from which to start this journey is the bed itself, wherein, at midnight or early in the morning, the adventurous traveller lies moored, the terrain spread out before him. The most fortunate weather is warm to cool, engendered by a westerly breeze, borne from the open window toward the ashes in the grate. At midnight, moonlight lies upon the floor, to guide the travel-ler's eye; in the early morning, the bleak opacity that serves the traveller in this region as sun brightens the brick wall of the house across the yard, and sheds a feeble reflected glow upon all the objects which I shall presently name.

title: Go With the Flow to Sun Belt?
description: 'The center of power remains there (on the Eastern seaboard), while in the land behind them are assembling, almost in secret, the real elements of the great people to whom the future of the continent doubtless belongs.'

title: FOREIGN-POLICY 'STUNT' FOR THE NEW PRESIDENT
description: By John R. Woods

title: Suzanne C. Pettus Married to Lawyer
description: Suzanne Cameron Pettus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Erle Pettus Jr. of Birmingham, Ala., was married there yesterday to Nathaniel Madison Cartmell 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cartmell Jr. of Manchester, N.H. The Rev. M. William Asger performed the ceremony at St. Mary's-on-the Highlands Episcopal Church.

title: New Alabama Senator Gets 3-Day Head Start
description: Senator Donald W. Stewart, Democrat of Alabama, resigned yesterday and Jeremiah Denton was appointed to fill three days of his unexpired term, giving Alabama its first Republican Senator in this century.

title: APPLE PIE AND A SLICE OF LIFE
description: IFOUND the long-lost recipe the other day behind the bookcase where it had fallen. Encased in its dusty plastic envelope, the recipe I had typed in 1953 was still intact. ''Helen's Apple Pie'' brought back intense memories of Levittown in the 50's and of my vivacious, brown-eyed friend, Helen.

title: Critics' Choices; MUSIC
description: There are often curious conjunctions of composers on concert programs: the result can be intriguing musical conversations that would never happen if such eclectic gatherings were to take place in the flesh.

title: ATTRIBUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: HE SEEKS THE KEY TO A RIDDLE IN A FISH
description: IN a cluttered, tank-filled laboratory at the Ingersoll Extension on the Brooklyn College campus in Flatbush, a 45-year-old scientist from North Woodmere is pursuing one of mankind's oldest quests - the answer to the riddle of aging.

title: THE OLD STARGAZER'S ALMANAC FOR 1981
description: Bruce Feirstein is a writer living in New York. CAPRICORN (Dec. 22-Jan. 20. The sign of Juanita Kreps, William Colby, Bobby Hull, Albert Schweitzer, Ron Galella and tag-team wrestling.) It looks as if 1981 will be a banner year for the practical, ambitious and generally well-heeled Republican Capricorn personality. With the planets Mercury, Venus and Saturn making frequent appearances in your astral plane this year, you can expect things to go well at your Senate confirmation hearings in mid-February. Be wary, however, of cheaply dressed Arab emissaries who invite you to discuss immigration problems at a Maryland motel in mid-March. Despite the dismal social life you had last year, a new moon on Aug. 29 means that either Jacqueline Bisset or Omar Sharif should appear in your home on Sept. 3, in the early evening. On the financial side, early December seems like a good time to dump those speculative loser stocks you haven't told your spouse about yet.

title: INTELLIGENCE GROUP IS RENAMED IN SEOUL
description: The Korean Central Intelligence Agency, which was founded in 1961 and used by President Park Chung Hee for political repression until his murder by the agency's head, has been renamed the Agency for National Security Planning by President Chun Doo Hwan.

title: City Workers in Evansville Strike as Contract Expires
description: Municipal workers went on strike today, the first such walkout in Evansville's history.

title: Nuclear Materials Remain Intact In Crash of Special Tractor-Trailer
description: A cargo of plutonium and other radioactive materials remained intact after the first serious accident involving a ''super safe transport'' truck equipped to carry such material, a Department of Energy official says.

title: The New Nouveau
description: Some Los Angeles millionaires now refuse to drive Rolls-Royces. They are evidently afraid that envious onlookers might include criminals who will follow them home.

title: ARTIST SHIFTS FOCUS TO A FILM PROJECT
description: IRVINGTON HIGH on a hill overlooking the Hudson River sits a house of glass and wood. Amid the colorful Abstract Expressionist canvases and bas reliefs on the walls lives a family of cats, dogs, two children, a man and wife. Film posters, photographs and announcements supplement the cozy, lived-in appearance.

title: Lake Placid Olympic Facilities Still in Use
description: The 1980 Winter Olympics at Lake Placid may be only a memory, but the modern facilities used for the Games last February remain a useful reality.

title: HAROLD GENEEN
description: Evidently, Harold S. Geneen has decided to invest in cotton towels. Late last week, Cannon Mills disclosed that a small group of investors, headed by I.T.T.'s former acquisitive chairman, had offered to pay $376 million in cash, or $40 a share, for the nation's largest towel maker.

title: OPEN UNIVERSITY AMERICAN STYLE
description: AMERICAN versions of Britain's Open University, the 11-year old program of televised college courses for credit, are beginning to make headway, with three organizations in different parts of the nation having begun projects and testing audience response. "We're just in the crawling stages," said a director of one of them, Rick Bridenfield of the Maryland Center for Public Broadcasting, which is involved in the National University Consortium's television project begun in September. The consortium, the University of Mid-America centered in Nebraska and the Public Broadcasting Service in Washington are the new promoters of televised college education. Starting with a $400,000 grant from the Carnegie Corporation, the consortium, headquartered in Owings Mills, Md., involves seven colleges, each matched with a local public-broadcasting station or cable station. Besides the centers at the University of Maryland, the participants are Pennsylvania State University, California State University at Carson, University of Tennessee at Chattanooga, Iona College in New Rochelle, N.Y.; Southern Vermont College, in Bennington, and Linfield College in McMinnville, Ore. The concept of home study with televised lectures leading to a college degree, which has been such an accepted success at Britain's Open University (60,000 students), is relatively new to the United States. "People still think of the noncredit lectures that were on public television during the early 60's," said Gene Gage, the head of corporate planning for the University of Mid-America, which is the first television group that will grant its own degrees. "We rely primarily on print.

title: Lisa Dodds Fiancee Of Michael Conniff
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Dodds Jr. of Pittsburgh of the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Dodds, to Michael Andrew Conniff of Cambridge, Mass., son of Elizabeth Murray Conniff of Long Beach, L.I., and the late Frank Conniff.

title: GEORGIA RATED NO.1 IN BOTH WIRE POLLS
description: Georgia's undefeated and untied Bulldogs were declared the No. 1 team in major college football yesterday in the final polls of The Associated Press and United Press International. It was the first time that Georgia had won the unofficial national title since The A.P. conducted the first of these weekly and seasonal polls in 1936.

title: Trapper Sues Fund for Animals In Dispute on San Clemente Goats
description: Jim Clapp is suing Cleveland Amory and Mr. Amory's Fund for the Animals for more than $1 million in a dispute over the wild goats of San Clemente Island.

title: Thais Report 2 Troops Slain Repelling Vietnamese Force
description: Vietnamese forces stormed across the Thai-Cambodian border and battled with Thai troops today before being pushed back, according to Thai military sources.

title: Rabies Scare
description: It was just a cute baby raccoon that two youths had found near Lake City, Fla. They took it home, then to ''show and tell'' at two schools and on to a pet fair and football games.

title: HEROES ARE WHERE YOU FIND THEM
description: EVERY Catholic Youth Organization kid who ever picked up a basketball had a No. 1 idol, but mine never had a chance to do a commercial.

title: Free-Agent Stalemate Is Hinted
description: The special committee on baseball's free-agent issue will hold its final meeting tomorrow with signs that the players and club owners are still in a stalemate and that the start of the new season could be delayed by another strike.

title: MILK A GO-GO
description: In spite of increased milk production and sluggish commercial demand, the nation's dairymen have had a healthy year, according to Gary L. Benjamin, an economist at Chicago's Federal Reserve Bank. And Uncle Sam, an old friend, deserves most of the credit.

title: ACTRESS ADDS $1,000 TO DONATIONS EARMARKED FOR NEEDIEST ELDERLY
description: With a request that it be considered ''a contribution to benefit the elderly,'' Candice Bergen, the actress, has donated $1,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: SOURCE OF A DEADLY SYNTHETIC DRUG SOUGHT ON COAST
description: Law-enforcement officials in California have been unable to discover the source of a new synthetic drug that is said to be 80 times more potent than heroin, but they have expressed hope that its reputation for deadliness will keep its use from spreading.

title: EXPERTS SEE PROBLEMS WORSENING
description: IN what is becoming a New Year's tradition for this column, we asked representatives of all segments of the housing field - builders, real estate brokers, architects, public officials, land planners and market consultants - what they expect to see in the coming months.

title: BRZEZINSKI REBUFFS SENATE'S DEMOCRATS ON RECORDS ON HAIG
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser, said today that he had declined to supply Senate Democrats with the National Security Council's files on Alexander M. Haig Jr. He said he would not cooperate with ''some indiscriminate witch hunt'' against Mr. Haig, President-elect Ronald Reagan's choice for Secretary of State.

title: 99% OF FELONY ARRESTS IN THE CITY FAIL TO BRING TERMS IN STATE PRISON
description: The following article is based on reporting by Joseph P. Fried and E. R. Shipp and was written by Miss Shipp. Ninety-nine of every 100 people arrested on felony charges in New York City never serve a state prison term, and more than 80 are not even prosecuted as felons.

title: A Lawyer's 'Message' On Multifamily Housing
description: I would like to stress on an even narrower front what I believe to be the message of Mr. Justice John C. Marbach's North Salem decision, as reported in the article ''Gains for Multifamily Housing'' (Dec. 21).

title: CAREERS AND RECORDINGS
description: Recently RCA Records sent out a seven-inch promotional disk of Dylana Jenson, a young American violinist, playing Saint-Saens and Bach. The mailing was to announce Miss Jenson's new RCA contract, and while it was a little unusual - in the great corporate division of the spoils in the late 40's, seven-inch records were reserved for pop singles - it was hardly surprising.

title: NEW CENSUS COSTING STATE A SEAT IN HOUSE
description: RELEASE of the Federal census figures last week will trigger important political changes that will be felt in New Jersey for years to come.

title: THE MANY PRICES OF OIL
description: After last week's round of price increases in crude oil imports, differentials between light (generally more expensive because it needs less refining and makes better gasoline) and heavier crude oils have never been wider.
