However, hefty minimum purchase requirements, along with economic and political considerations, make it unlikely that American oil companies will attempt to take advantage of the discrepancy by shifting sources of supply.

title: THE BAR-REVIEW COURSE: HIGH ANXIETY, BIG BUSINESS
description: ''IT'S like going through World War III. Each day for almost eight weeks I crammed for 13 hours, drank 22 cups of coffee, smoked two packs of cigarettes, got up at 6 and fell out at 1 in the morning,'' said Michelle Anderson, recalling her studies for the New York State Bar Examination.

title: EAST MIDTOWN
description: The 20-story office building at 18 East 41st Street has been sold by the Hosean Corporation to Tarina Properties N.V., for $6 million. The building contains more than 95,000 square feet of office space and will be managed by OTIC Corporation, represented by Giorgio Laurenti and Roberto Riva.

title: ...AS STYLES MOVE TOWARD A DARING INFORMALITY
description: About a mile from each other in the northern Westchester community of Chappaqua stand two large groups of homes. One is called Whippoorwill Lake, a new development still in construction. The other is Lawrence Farms East, which was built over many years starting in the 1930's.

title: HIGH MILITARY POST IN PEKING REPORTED TAKEN OVER BY DENG
description: Deng Xiaoping, China's paramount leader, has taken over a key job as head of the Communist Party's Military Commission, which controls the armed forces, unofficial Chinese sources said today.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Putting On A Pretty Face
description: Regal Beautician Products Inc. began in Larchmont as a wholesale supplier 35 years ago. Over the last 10 years, a retail shop has been added and now accounts for 20 percent of the business.

title: Mailbox; Two Divisions Would Motivate N.F.L. Losers
description: To the Sports Editor: Having observed the last three or four football seasons here in New York, may I, as a European, offer up a European idea that might solve the Deadly Football Syndrome in the New York region. What is lacking in the National Football League today is a method of relegation and promotion.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JANUARY 4, 1981
description: International Control of China's armed forces has been taken over by Deng Xiaoping, the country's paramount leader, unofficial Chinese sources in Peking said. The post had been held by Hua Guofeng, who has evidently been forced to resign as party chairman. (Page 1, Col. 4.)

title: Action Urged on Reports Of U.S. Accounting Unit
description: Common Cause, the nonpartisan citizens' lobby, says the lack of follow-up action on investigative reports of the General Accounting Office may be costing the Government billions of dollars.

title: A 'Palatable' Form Of Public Service
description: By Don Wycliff and Alvin Davis New York City's legal establishment, having examined for almost a year its performance in providing public interest legal services, has found itself not wanting - at least not badly enough to warrant a mandatory ''pro bono'' requirement for members of the bar.

title: HAIG AND CALIFANO TEAM UP AGAIN FOR HEARINGS IN SENATE
description: When Joseph A. Califano Jr. huddles with Alexander M. Haig Jr. to discuss Mr. Haig's Senate confirmation hearings, it is more than a meeting of an attorney preparing a client for a difficult legal proceeding.

title: U.S. AND TURKS MONITOR SOVIET AT ISOLATED POST
description: Turkish and American flags now fly over the strategic outpost on the Black Sea here that is expected to play an important role in monitoring Soviet compliance with any future treaty limiting strategic arms.

title: The Experts Offer Some Advice On Approaching the Interview
description: Based on talks with alumni interviewers for several colleges, here are suggestions on how students should approach alumni interviews. 1. There is no special preparation.

title: LOWER MANHATTAN
description: Cameron & Colby, a reinsurance company that is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Hartford Group, has leased the entire 27th floor at 88 Pine Street with about 18,000 square feet of office space. The 10-year lease has an aggregate rent of approximately $3.4 million. The company has its headquarters in Boston and this will be its first office in New York. Brokers: Howard Malloy, Barrett Stern and Thomas Pascal of HelmsleySpear Inc.

title: FIRST CLONING OF MAMMALS PRODUCES 3 MICE
description: Scientists in Switzerland have reported achieving the first cloning of a mammal. Using cells from mouse embryos, they report producing three mice that are genetically identical with the original embryos.

title: HARLEM DANCEERS TO REVIVE 'SCHEHERAZADE'
description: ''Scheherazade'' is back. The ballet that established Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes as the ultimate purveyor of the exotic is a highlight of the Dance Theater of Harlem's winter season at City Center, where the company opened last night and will perform through Jan. 25.

title: Seton Hall 53, Princeton 51
description: Daryl Devero of Seton Hall sank two foul shots and broke a 49-49 tie with 30 seconds remaining as he led the Pirates a 53-51 victory over Princeton tonight at Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS LOOK TO BRIGHT FUTURE
description: JUST a few years after they were thought to be in a state of decline, the nation's private schools are enjoying a resurgence and looking forward to new gains as the political climate in Washington and across the country grows more favorable to them.

title: Borrowed Houses
description: To the Editor:

title: Emily C. DiMaggio Affianced to C. C. Gates
description: Emily Collette DiMaggio, a marketing manager for the Bowery Savings Bank, and Christopher Clark Gates, a corporate and pension portfolio trader with the International Business Machines Corporation in White Plains, will be married Feb. 28 in Wellesley Hills, Mass.

title: Mrs. Young Loses Lead In Non-Tour Men's Golf
description: John Mahaffey shot a threeunder-par 69 on the Spyglass Hill course today and moved past Donna Caponi Young into the third-round lead at the $135,000 Spalding invitation golf tournament.

title: HOUSING TROUBLES IN THE SUBURBS GROW
description: The drastic shrinkage in ''affordable'' housing is being described by a wide range of public and private specialists as the chief housing problem of the 1980's in the suburban areas of the metropolitan region.

title: THE HEAVY BURDEN OF THE PAST
description: VOICESWITHINTHEARK The Modern Jewish Poets. Edited by Howard Schwartz and Anthony Rudolf. 1,210 pp.

title: AND DON'T FORGET THE CHECK
description: PAYING bills - like breathing - is fraught with dangers. The expected danger, of course, is that the sum total of the bills will outweigh the sum total of one's total sums.

title:
DINING OUT;
INJECTING FAITH IN HOBOKEN'S FUTURE
description: APPROPRIATELY, the first review of 1981 features a relatively new restaurant that is proof of Hoboken's regeneration. Restaurateurs rarely invest in an area unless it has a pretty solid future.

title: ECOLOGY CLASSES GET A PLUS FOR WORK IN THREE TOWNS
description: WAYNE THREE New Jersey communities have saved money that otherwise would have gone to pay professional planners, thanks, the town officials say, to students who are majoring in environmental studies at William Paterson College.

title: LUGGAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: NASA Has Cause To Hail Columbia
description: America's space shuttle, Columbia, got as far as the launch pad last week, three and a half miles from the Vehicle Assembly Building where engineers had spent five weeks assembling and checking the 150,000 pound, 184-foot-tall vehicle. The journey took seven hours over land by mobile launch platform.

title: A BLUEPRINT FOR THE NEXT ADMINISTRATION'S POSITION ON IRAN
description: By Hans Smit

title: 100 YEARS AGO: THE BEGINNING OF STEREO
description: Aworld which little notes nor long remembers may just skip over it, and hardly anyone would realize that the new year marks the centennial of stereo. So it may be well to remind ourselves that early in 1881 a French engineer named Clement Ader filed for a patent for ''Improvements of Telephone Equipment in Theaters.'' His idea was to put telephones on stage so that subscribers could listen to the performance at home.

title: DIVERS PURSUE BETTER PICTURES IN 3-DAY CLASS
description: The painful scene is too familiar. My wife and daughter, devout non-divers, are enduring the results of my latest underwater photography expedition - 400 slides, none of them clear. Around slide 87, boredom provokes questions. "What's that?" my wife, Ellen, asks. "A grouper." "Where's its head?" "It kept swimming away from me. Actually it's not a bad tail shot of a grouper." After two frustrating years, my pictures ranged from bad to atrocious, despite my collection of underwater photography books, scubadiving magazines and equipment catalogues. What was the one magical gizmo I lacked that would integrate light, color, water and fish, and produce the dazzling pictures I sought? In search of the answer I enrolled in the underwater photography course given by Stephen Frink in Key Largo, Fla. In three days of classroom instruction and diving in the underwater Pennekamp Park, my pictures improved dramatically. More important, I discovered the magical gizmo was between my ears and not on the camera. Each year more than 200,000 divers explore Pennekamp Park, which was established in 1960 as the nation's first underwater preserve. Within its boundaries are 75 square miles of underwater treasure, including the only living coral reefs in North America. Stephen's three-day courses are held 10 times a year and each is limited to six students. The first session of the course I attended was a discussion of equipment. We all had Nikonos self-contained underwater cameras, which are small and watertight and handle easily, but each of us had a different underwater strobe.

title: Age-Old Problem Saddens a Jets Fan
description: To the Sports Editor: I am 63 years old, and I seriously question whether I will be around to witness the next time the New York Jets reach the playoffs. This is a most sorrowful problem as the insurance actuaries have tabled those born in 1917 to meet with their maker by 1992, which leaves me with little to look forward to. I suppose I can always shift my allegiance. But to whom, the Giants? HUGH D. BROWN

title: THE M.B.A. IS LOSING SOME OF ITS LUSTER
description: IS the meteoric rise of the M.B.A. running out of steam? As students enroll in record numbers in pursuit of the Master of Business Administration, the degree program that vies with medical and law school for the attention of the best, the brightest and the most ambitious college graduates, increasing numbers of critics have been grumbling about the inability of some highly paid graduates to live up to their billing. Some of the growing numbers of programs in the last 15 years have been challenged as too low in quality and others as too firmly anchored in the status quo.

title: SLAYER'S APPEAL IS DENIED DESPITE MOVE BY CUOMO
description: It was an unusual appeal: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo asking Governor Carey to commute the life sentence of a Bronx man convicted of murder.

title: DANCE: RACHEL LAMPERT OFFERS HER 'CUI BONO'
description: Rachel Lampert is one of the rare younger choreographers working in a dramatic vein today. Probably no one else would attempt her ''Cui Bono?'' which was given its first performance Friday in a concert of Miss Lampert's works at the American Theater Laboratory.

title: RAISING FUNDS: A REQUIRED COURSE
description: THIS YEAR, alumni of Wagner College will be asked to contribute to a new five-year fund-raising campaign. Yet the liberal-arts college on Staten Island has none of the plans usually associated with fund raising: a new gym or student union or an innovative study program. Instead, the college will try to raise $15 million from foundations and corporate benefactors as well as alumni for the unglamorous purposes of reducing debt, renovating buildings and paying for operating expenses.

title: Maryland 69 William and Mary 64
description: Greg Manning scored 22 points and led Maryland to a 69-64 victory over William and Mary tonight.

title: SUIT AND CONTERSUIT CONCERN WITNESS IN HARRIS TRIAL
description: HENRI VAN DER VREKEN lived with his wife, Suzanne, in Dr. Herman Tarnower's home on six acres in Purchase for 16 years and served as ''estate manager,'' the term he preferred, or as ''gardener,'' ''servant,'' ''butler'' or ''chauffeur,'' terms used by police officers, attorneys and others in the monthlong trial of Jean S. Harris, who is accused of murdering the noted cardiologist.

title: State of the Artful Public Servant
description: By Michael Wright and Caroline Rand Herron Massachusetts city halls and state offices have never been regarded as places where Diogenes would have wasted his time. But last week a special investigating commission issued a report on government corruption that was extraordinary, even for a commonwealth so thoroughly innured to such things.

title: THE STATE PARK ALTERNATIVE FOR VACATIONS IN 1981
description: As travel costs rise, more and more Americans are discovering that some of the most inexpensive, comfortable and gratifying vacation opportunities are offered by state parks.

title: WASHINGTON AMONG all the interest groups anxiously waiting the formulation of Federal policies once President elect Reagan takes office, none are so filled with anticipation - or trepidation - as those concerned about education.  Having become dependent on the billions in Federal money that support educational activity over the last two decades, few school districts, universities or colleges can imagine life without it. And Mr. Ronald Reagan and his advisers have stated that spending priorities must be subject to hard scrutiny, and cuts must be made.  Moreover, longstanding quarrels between liberals who have held sway over educational policy for years and the ascendant conservatives promise clashes over such questions as the right of public schools to have nearly full claim on Federal funds, mandatory busing for racial balance, s
description: certain school districts offer bilingual education, where youngsters raised speaking a foreign language would be taught at least initially in that language. The foundation also urged that compensatory education funds under Title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act be cut when officials cannot show that they enhance the education of youngsters who lag behind their schoolmates. Greater emphasis would be placed on research to find ways to teach basic classroom skills to youths who need them. Various forms of "quotas" allegedly used in affirmative-action programs to increase the racial mixture of students in schools would be dropped. And in a suggestion that strikes fear in many public school officials and teachers unions, the foundation recommends the use of vouchers by parents of students with special needs - such as lagging ghetto youths, or especially gifted students, or Hispanic students who want exposure to more Spanish culture - so that they may turn to nonpublic sources for their education If President Reagan pursues most of the foundation's objectives, he may find some surprising allies. For instance, the American Federation of Teachers has indicated that it strongly favors a reduction in regulations imposed on local districts by Federal officials. The union and many local officials say they would welcome relief from bilingual requirements, on restricitons regarding disciplinary measures against uncooperative students and on special provisions in normal classes so the handicapped can participate in them. The federation has raised questions about proposals to collect data on disciplined students and particularly their racial and ethnic classifications.

title: Debra Sue Belaga, Lawyer, to Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Myron W. Belaga of Westport, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Debra Sue Belaga, to Stephen Stublarec, son of Col. and Mrs. Michael J. Stublarec of Novato, Calif.

title: COUNTY ON COAST TO OPEN BATTLE AGAINST FRUIT FLIES
description: A ''house-to-house'' battle to wipe out the Mediterranean fruit flies threatening crops in Santa Clara County will begin next week in an effort to avoid aerial spraying of the controversial pesticide Malathion, officials say.

title: 2 SUSPECTS IN SHOOTING OFF DETECTIVE SEIZED ON PLANE
description: The police halted an Indianapolis-bound jet as it was taxiing for takeoff at La Guardia Airport yesterday and seized two men aboard the plane in connection with the shooting earlier of an off-duty detective during a holdup in a Queens tavern.

title: Rangers Savor Their Victory, But They'll See Islanders Again
description: Fifteen games remain on the Islanders' schedule, including tonight's with the Hartford Whalers at Nassau Coliseum, before they meet the Rangers again. But from now until the Feb. 4 meeting in Madison Square Garden, the Islanders can be expected to have the Rangers on their minds, seeking revenge for the convincing 3-1 defeat handed them last night.

title: CAN THE MET RECREATE ITS HISTORIC 'TRISTAN'?
description: ''Tristan und Isolde'' returns to the Metropolitan Opera stage on Friday night for the first time in seven years - too long an absence for a work most operagoers would place among the supreme masterpieces of the repertory. More than that, the company's current production, designed by Gunther Schneider-Siemssen and staged by August Everding, was extravagantly and almost unanimously praised as a breathtaking visual experience when it was first unveiled in November of 1971.

title: A TROVE OF UNFAMILIAR ART FROM KOREA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Peter Hyun is a Korean-born editor and writer whose latest book is ''Introducing Korea.'' By PETER HYUN

title:
INVESTING;
APPRAISING THE APPRAISER
description: A LL those collectibles - the jewelry, rugs, fine art and so on - that captured the fancy of inflation-wary investors in the last few years may show remarkable capital gains. But more than other investments, they are vulnerable to loss, damage and the burglar. So what do you do?

title: FOR PARENTS, RACE TO HARVARD STARTS IN NURSERY SCHOOL
description: RED brick, white trim, green hedgerows. Girls in plaid kilts, glossy hair pulled back tight under white headbands. Tall, brasshandled doors, and just inside them dozens of certifcates framed in wood, a school's proud tradition arrayed upon a wall.

title: ATLANTA SEEKS MAYORAL CHOICE WITH BIRACIAL APPEAL
description: As Maynard H. Jackson enters his final year in office, white and black leaders alike are seeking to find a candidate for Mayor who will not upset the racial balance among voters in a city that takes pride in its relative freedom from racial strife.

title: PRINCESS ALICE, AT LONDON HOME: A GRANDCHILD OF QUEEN VICTORIA
description: Princess Alice, Countess of Athlone and last surviving grandchild of Queen Victoria, died in her sleep today at her London home. She was 97 years old.

title: TRANSIT CLUB AT STUYVASNT REALLY EXPLORES THE SUBJECT
description: A personal interest in mass transit comes naturally to many of the 2,600 students at Stuyvesant High School, one of New York City's specialized high schools. More than 95 percent of them commute to the school, at 345 East 15th Street, bus or subway, and transit irritations can be a major problem.

title: New Products
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Urban Transit Has Few Ways to Go
description: By Michael Wright and Caroline Rand Herron Decisions taken last week in Boston, Chicago and New York illustrated three of the undesirable alternatives to which big-city public transit systems, more and more, are being driven in efforts to remain afloat financially. And they came as two members of Congress expressed alarm at a proposal by Ronald Reagan's transition team on transportation that, some fear, might sink some transit systems.

title: FOR ENVIRONMENTALISTS, THE BATTLE GOES ON
description: FOR the environmental movement in New Jersey, the coming years may require nothing less than a resurgence of the activism of Earth Day 1970 to score any substantial gains.

title: U.S. AGENCY WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: CHRISTINA PASZTOR was unemployed two years ago with an ailing, jobless husband and two small children in her Jamaica Plain, Mass., home. Although in desperate need of income, she lacked the skills to get a job. Then she began a four-month electronics training program sponsored by Project ACT (Access to Careers in Technology) at the Women's Enterprises of Boston Inc. Today Mrs. Pasztor is studying to be an engineer while working as an electro-mechanical technician at Digital Equipment Corporation. "Where it not for Project ACT," she said, "I could never have received the training I needed to land a job." But were it not for the Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education, Project ACT would never have existed, according to Janis Peters, ACT's project director. Project ACT is just one of 713 small but effective projects that since 1973 have received "feed" money from the Fund - a relatively small, seemingly underfinanced, but broadly innovative and increasingly popular Federal agency in the Department of Education. Created by Congress in 1972, the Fund was mandated to encourage "the reform, innovation, and improvement of postsecondary education and provide equal educational opportunity for all." Indeed, it is this spirit that has characterized and guided the Fund. While it has supported a wide variety of projects, its agenda has focused on the major problems confronting higher education. And in so doing, it has given fresh mea to the word "postsecondary," expanding it to include all post-high-school education, not just that at traditional universities.

title: Points Too Well Made
description: Sometimes, you've just got to spell things out in unmistakable terms.

title: Alexandra Murnane, a Senior at Trinity, And Christopher Hillyer to Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Murnane Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alexandra Murnane, to Christopher Dehli Hillyer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Peter Norman Hillyer of Devon, Pa.

title: Ann Joyce Is Bride Of Joseph Delano
description: Grace Episcopal Church in Amherst, Mass., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Ann Robinson Joyce, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack B. Joyce of Somerset, N.J., to Joseph Delano of Leverett, Mass., son of Mrs. Joseph Famm of Port Washington, L.I., and the late Joseph H. Delano. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James Clark.

title: Martha Winston Fontaine Wed to Dominic La Valla Jr.
description: Martha Winston Fontaine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Fontaine 3d of Jackson, Miss., was married there yesterday morning to Dominic Charles La Valla Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. La Valla of Fullerton, Calif. The Very Rev. Roderic L. Murray performed the ceremony in St. Andrew's Episcopal Cathedral. Msgr.

title: Michelle Sullivan Is Married to Franklin Lichtenberg
description: Michelle Sullivan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Browning Sullivan of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Franklin Lichtenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Al Lichtenberg of New York. The Rev. Frank Robertson of the All Souls Unitarian Church in Washington performed the ceremony at the Kennedy Warren Apartments, a caterer in Washington.

title: SYMBOLISM-IN SEARCH OF A STYLE
description: About the Symbolist movement in literature there is a substantial body of critical thought that, while not exactly unanimous in its findings or unified in its point of view, leaves us in little doubt that something answering to this name really does exist as an identifiable literary phenomenon. About the Symbolist movement in painting and the pictorial arts, however, there is no parallel critical consensus. A term that can be applied with a certain justification to artists as different as Van Gogh and Redon, Kupka and Vuillard, Munch and Kubin and Burne-Jones, may conceivably have something to commend it to the student of art history, but esthetic consistency will not be its hallmark, nor - to judge from the many minor artists of dubious gifts that are said to belong to the Symbolists' ranks - will artistic quality be found to be a fundamental desideratum.

title: EAGLES RALLY TO WIN BY 31-16
description: Statistically, the San Diego Chargers were the most successful offensive team in the history of the National Football League. But in their minds, they were something else: a team that lost in the first round of the American Conference division playoffs last year. They waited until today to be labeled a success.

title: NO MANDATE TO RENEW THE COLD WAR
description: By Gordon E. Cannon

title: Military Reserve Strength Rises
description: Military reserve strength, a chronic problem since the end of the draft in the early 1970's, registered an increase in the last fiscal year for the second straight time, the Pentagon has reported. The Selected Reserve, which increased by 43,700 men and women to 850,800, was still more than 100,000 short of peacetime objectives as of the end of the fiscal year on Sept. 30. The Army National Guard and Army Reserve continue to be the major problem areas.

title: Critics' Choices
description: Each week several Times critics will offer tips on attractions around town.

title: CITY PUTS NEW FOCUS ON STUDY FOR JOBS
description: THE wind whistles across the plains of East New York in Brooklyn as Nathan Green and about 10 of his classmates from Thomas Jefferson High School abandoned work on the skeletal steel frame that will eventually become a greenhouse for their new ornamental-horticulture class. They folded the ladder and put away the tools, but not the enthusiasm they have brought to the project.

title: VOLUMES OF DESPAIR, AS IT
description: WERE By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

title: A GOOD WORD FOR DETROIT
description: In spite of lagging performance over the past two years, and less than rosy prospects for 1981, the automobile industry was one of six cited in a recently completed Commerce Department study as displaying ''winning'' performance between 1966 and 1978. Chemicals, tobacco, electronic instruments and photo equipment, nonelectrial machinery and electrical machinery also outperformed other major manufacturing industries, the report said.

title: SKIDMORE'S UNIVERSITY WITHOUT WALLS SNARES PRISONERS
description: COMSTOCK, N.Y. WHEN Prof. Philip West teaches Shakespeare Monday nights, his style and approach to the subject alter considerably from that of his normal daytime class routine.

title: EX-C.I.A. AIDE'S ROLE SPURS CONROVERSY
description: A former Central Intelligence Agency analyst, forced to resign for violating the agency's security rules, has been reviewing highly classified documents for a Reagan transition team, stirring sharp controversy in the intelligence community, Carter Administration officials said this week.

title: WALLINGFORD, CONN.  THE attic room at the corner of the west wing building on the 400-acre campus of Choate Rosemary Hall - a 972-student coed boarding school created in 1973 by a merger of two single-sex institutions, was a timeless daguerreotype of teenage disarray.  The two bunk beds, covered in trendy colored sheets, were rumpled.  Soiled socks, athletic shoes, discarded soda cans and opened books - the hardware of a busy and active student life - lay strewn about like discarded toys. Wall posters of folk heroes fought for space with more sentimental photos of families and pets. On the floor sat a clock radio with the alarm set for 7 A.M. - a clue that, unlike the old days, bells no longer tolled to waken students.  Jeffrey Weisfeld of Hunter, N.Y., and Peter Tampas of Burlington, Vt., 10th-graders who occupy the room, say they enjoyed the chance to stuff the place w
description: students (66) as there were in 1960, many black and Orientals, and 21 percent of the student body is on scholarship, compared with 12 percent 20 years ago. Partly as a result of a decline of confidence in public schools, Choate Rosemary Hall, like most private schools, is being overwhelmed with applicants. This enables the school to choose from the cream of the adolescent crop and maintain higher academic standards. The school had a record 4,000 applications in the last school year, compared with 2,400 in 1973. In fact, there has been a substantial overall increase in boardingschool enrollment over the last decade, according to the Natinal Association of Independent Schools. Based on association membership figures, total enrollment has risen 15.5 percent. The association expects continued growth, citing such factors as the rise of the two-income family and the resulting increase in its disposable income, more working mothers needing this kind of service for their children, a more sophisticated public ready to spend the required amount of money to obtain the kind of education they feel their children should have, and the more specialized environment many of these schools now offer. "Because so many people are applying, I think morale is better than it used to be," said Jennifer Meagher of Hyde Park, N.Y., a senior at Choate Rosemary Hall. "They can be more strict about enforcing rules and they don't have to put up with any nonsense." Offenses punishable by expulsion include drinking on campus, possession of drugs, smoking in an off-limits area, cheating or lying.

title: Sound; TAKING NOTE OF THE 100TH ANNIVERSARY OF STEREO
description: Aworld which little notes nor long remembers may just skip over it, and hardly anyone would realize that the new year marks the centennial of stereo. So it may be well to remind ourselves that early in 1881 a French engineer named Clement Ader filed for a patent for ''Improvements of Telephone Equipment in Theaters.'' His idea was to put telephones on stage so that subscribers could listen to the performance at home.

title: Oilers 4, Maple Leafs 1
description: Wayne Gretzky scored a goal and had two assists to spark the Oilers. He scored his 18th goal in the first period and then set up goals by Brett Callighen and Paul Coffey in the second period. Don Murdoch had the other Edmonton goal.

title: THE ALUMNI INTERVIEW: AN EXTRA KEY TO ADMISSIONS
description: COLLEGE applications completed, visits to campuses made, S.A.T.'s and achievement tests behind them, high school seniors are in their ''silly season,'' awaiting notification of interviews in their local communities with someone variously known as an alumni interviewer, alumni rep, alumni counselor or member of a schools and scholarship committee.

title: DAY: A HAVEN IN THE BRONX
description: TREVOR SUTTON'S day begins at 5 A.M. with a reflexive jab at his cassette machine. Sleepwalking to a disco beat, he plunges into a steaming shower. When he re-emerges into the dark of day, he has begun to remember who he is and where he's headed. Leaving his Queens apartment, he catches a bus that drops him near a subway station. Three trains and two hours later, Trevor arrives at his destination, the Horace Mann School, a cloistered haven in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: SIX TOP EDITORS AT QUEST LEAVE IN POLICY FIGHT
description: The six top editors of Quest Magazine have resigned to protest what they said was the insistence by the magazine's owners, the Ambassador International Cultural Foundation, that Quest publish a cover article by a controversial California minister who heads the church that set up the foundation.

title: THE PROFESSOR-STUDENT BARRIER TO GROWTH
description: SHE sat down in the chair I indicated, unwound her scarf and unbuttoned her jacket. ''I don't know if you remember me,'' she began. ''Of course I remember you!'' I was astounded. Linda Harrison had been one of 15 students in a discussion section that had met weekly, just the previous semester, my first as a philosophy professor at Smith College. How could she suppose I wouldn't remember her?

title: Warwick, Teacher Reach Aussie Final
description: Kim Warwick of Australia moved into the final of the $350,000 Australian open tennis championship today with a five-set victory over Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, the defender.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: COMMUTERS on the New Haven line who may have thought their main worry was whether the Cos Cob power plant would supply enough juice to keep the trains running have been confronted with a new bad omen.

title: Perkins Is Unwise In His Comments
description: To the Sports Editor: I am no student of football, and I would be on shaky ground were I to comment on Ray Perkins's coaching ability. Certainly he is a totally dedicated man and spares nothing of himself.

title: HANA MANDIKLOVA: NETTING A PROFIT
description: WASHINGTON THE Saturday night queues already had begun at Gepetto, Viet Huong, Bistro Francais, The Big Cheese and other gourmet stops along Georgetown's restaurant row. Inside Yates Fieldhouse on the Georgetown University campus, however, Hana Mandlikova, her body still experiencing jet lag after a 15-hour trip from Prague and Amsterdam, was trading shots with Betty Stove, her coach and friend.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by United Press International in Saturday's editions reported incorrectly that Belau, formerly the Palau Islands in Micronesia, became an independent nation on Jan. 1. In fact, on that date Belau installed its first constitutional government, but it will continue to operate as a United States-administered trust territory.

title: by Edward C. Wallace
description: To any New York City tenant, the need to regulate landlord-tenant relations is self-evident. Without regulation, tenants - who lack real bargaining power - would be forced to pay unconscionable rent increases, or to move. Although the present rent regulations here do stabilize tenancies, they are often arbitrary. A creative solution is long overdue.

title: SHARON KING WED TO JAMES HOGE, PUBLISHER
description: Sharon Leigh King, a consumer reporter and host of the weekly television show ''Money Sense'' on WBZ, Boston, was married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday to James F. Hoge, publisher of The Chicago Sun-Times. The Rev. Larry M. Hill performed the Protestant ceremony at the home of John Kenneth Galbraith, the economist, and Mrs. Galbraith.

title: 1980: A 'SWELL YEAR' FOR FUTURES
description: The turbulent trading floor of the Chicago Board of Trade has often been described as a circus, but on the afternoon of New Year's Eve, it came closer than usual to being one. With traditional whimsy, the exchange fathers watched attentively from the trading pits as Dalmatians jumped roped, monkeys pranced through the aisles and clowns passed out presents and baloons.

title: GOOD LUCK MOVES SOME TO GIVE TO NEEDIEST CASES
description: From Theodore R. Janeczek of Clifton, N.J., who contributed $100 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, comes a reminder that one's ''own good fortune'' often spurs the impulse to give to others less fortunate.

title: Record-Seeking New Yorker
description: Some highly competitive offshore anglers, although they still fish medium or heavy tackle, have set their sights on new targets created by the International Game Fish Association's recent introduction of a 6-pound test-line class and they also are diligently seeking new saltwater fly-fishing records.

title: PUT YOUR DREAMS AWAY; by William Safire
description: On Dec. 12, 1980, the day after he was designated by President-elect Reagan to be the next Attorney General of the United States, William French Smith went to the 65th birthday party of a man that Newsweek magazine reports is the subject of a Federal grand jury investigation in New York.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Drum Financial Corporation, an insurance and financial holding company, elected Dudley B. Sanger a director.

title: DAVIDSON DOWNED BY IRISH, 87-67
description: Kelly Tripucka scored 21 points today to pace Notre Dame to an 87-67 victory over Davidson. Tracy Jackson had 15 points, Orlando Woolridge scored 10 and John Paxson added nine for Notre Dame, 7-1 on the season.

title: ANGUISH OF LOSING POWER
description: T HE age itself has done its best to school us in powerlessness and its many ways. But there is a special pain that accompanies the sudden loss of power, and its impact on one's state of mind. Soon, a host of the once-powerful will be cast down from the heights: A sitting President, a group of formidable Senators and Representatives, and the Myrmidons of Democratic Washington as well. Inauguration Day looms as a triumphant opportunity for Republicans - but what of the fate of leaders facing an end to life in the fast lane?

title: The War of the State Departments
description: Four years ago, Hamilton Jordan warned airily that his boss would court failure if he wound up appointing a Cyrus Vance as Secretary of State and a Zbigniew Brzezinski as national security adviser. Both men of course were appointed - and Mr. Jordan turned out to be righter than he knew. What can be called the War of the State Departments has erupted even before Mr. Carter steps down.

title: Jockeys Balk at Cold, Canceling 7 Races
description: The final seven races, including the $50,000 added Assault Handicap, were canceled at Aqueduct yesterday when the jockeys refused to ride because of the sub-zero temperatures. A crowd of 8,168 was present when the card was called off.

title: Philo W. Parker, 89, Retired Head Of Socony-Vacuum Oil Company
description: Philo W. Parker, retired president and chairman of the board of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, died last Thursday at Doctors Hospital after a long illness. He was 89 years old and lived in New York.

title: DAVID ROBERT OWEN PROSECUTED SIGNIFICANT RIGHTS CASES IN SOUTH
description: David Robert Owen, who as a lawyer for the Department of Justice in the 1960's investigated and prosecuted several celebrated civilrights cases in the South, died last Friday at New York University Medical Center after a seven-month illness. He was 50 years old and lived in Maplewood, N.J.

title: Doonesbury, $16.60, Triumphs on Coast
description: Doonesbury scored a mild upset in taking the $71,100 first division of the Malibu Stakes at Santa Anita today. The favored Raise a Man won the $71,400 second division.

title: U.S. TELLS OF CONCERN ON HOSTAGES' TRANSFER FROM IRANIAN MINISTRY
description: A report that Iran had transferred three Americans from the Foreign Ministry in Teheran to a secret location, possibly with some of the other 49 hostages, has left United States officials surprised and concerned, the Carter Administration said today.

title: LIBRARIES ON HISTORY OF WOMEN BUSY AND GROWING
description: Spurred by the feminist movement of the last decade, women's history libraries and collections across the United States have opened their doors and are expanding as never before.

title: Commodities; Diverse Price Views For Cotton
description: TALK of ''dollar cotton,'' a price level last recorded during the Civil War, is once again being heard in the futures market. And while dollar-a-pound raw cotton today would hardly match, in real terms, the prices paid during 1861-65, it has been a technical barrier at the top of the market ever since. The only time that cotton even neared that level was in late 1973, when the futures price briefly hit 99 cents.

title: DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM REVIVES 'SCHEHERAZADE'
description: THE Dance Theater of Harlem took a clear risk by staging a revival of Michel Fokine's ''Scheherazade.'' It has won the gamble. You will not be shocked by the slaughter and orgy scenes of this most famous of Serge Diaghilev's productions. Why should you be? Even at the premiere of the original in 1910, the sex on stage was too stylized to titillate the Parisians. To read contemporary French and Russian accounts, one would think the scandal of ''Scheherazade'' lay in Diaghilev's liberties with Rimsky-Korsakov's music.

title: Blasts Damage Gas Pipeline
description: Two explosions tore through a natural gas pipeline last night and sent flames shooting 65 to 85 feet in the air. There were no injuries.

title: FOR DOLLAR, '81 OUTLOOK IS STABLE
description: The value of the dollar in international financial markets should remain fairly stable during 1981, foreign currency analysts and economists predict.

title: ISLAMIC CLERICS DENOUNCE BANI-SADR OVER CONDUCT OF THE WAR WITH IRAQ
description: A bitter, running feud between the Islamic fundamentalists who hold most of the power here and President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr and his more liberal supporters has spread to what has been the main source of unity in this embattled nation: the conduct of the war with Iraq.

title: Is Another Borg On Way Up?
description: Joakim Nystrom, a 17-year-old Swede almost unknown in junior tennis circles when he first came to the United States three weeks ago, completed his three-tournament American stand today on a triumphant note.

title: SCALLOP 'PIRATES' REDUCE HARVEST FOR L.I. BAYMEN
description: The scallop harvest is under way off Long Island, and Bill Canaday, one of 200 baymen in Suffolk County who make a living by shellfishing, says that ''pirates'' began hauling the best of the catch as soon as the word got out that scallops were back in the Great South Bay for the first time in years.

title: Y.&R. Plans Campaign For Cadbury Schweppes
description: In Britain the Cadbury Creme Egg is a popular sweet, and more than 200 million of the Easter treats are sold there every year.

title: News Analysis
description: When President-elect Ronald Reagan sent word last month that he wished to meet President Jose Lopez Portillo before Inauguration Day, Mexican officials were delighted by his implicit recognition of Mexico's new importance to the United States.

title: Celtics 120, Blazers 111
description: Larry Bird scored 33 points as Boston beat the Trail Blazers.

title: 350 Hispanic People To Get Job Training
description: Under a one-year contract with the city's Department of Employment, the National Puerto Rican Forum will recruit and train 350 Hispanic people for public service jobs, starting this month. Candidates will be people eligible under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act.

title: U.S. SAYS IT'S SHOCKED BY THE KILLINGS IN EL SALVADOR
description: The State Department told El Salvador today that it was shocked and dismayed at the killings of two Americans who were helping the Government carry out a large-scale redistribution of land to peasant farmers.

title: PELL-BRZEZINSKI LETTER ON HAIG
description: Following are the texts of an exchange of letters by Senator Claiborne Pell, who will be the ranking Democrat on the incoming Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser. The letters deal with materials sought for hearings by the committee on the nomination of Alexander M. Haig Jr. to be Secretary of State.

title: Reconstructed 'Napoleon' In 3 Music Hall Showings
description: ''Napoleon,'' the classic 1927 film directed by Abel Gance, will be shown at the Radio City Music Hall on Jan. 23, 24 and 25, accompanied by the the American Symphony Orchestra conducted by Carmine Coppola.

title: THE INADEQUACY OF GUN CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: Wither Braniff's Account As Chairman Retires?
description: With the word out that Harding L. Lawrence is retiring as chairman and chief executive of Braniff International, agency executives are going to have a field day betting on when the airline will break with its agency.

title: REAGAN WILL MEET MEXICO CHIEF TODAY
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan, stepping up the pace of his transition activities as his inauguration approaches, leaves here tomorrow for a meeting across the Mexican border with Jose Lopez Portillo, the Mexican President.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JANUARY 5, 1981
description: International Two Americans were slain in El Salvador and the head of the country's Institute for Agrarian Transformation, with whom they had been dining, was also shot to death in the Sheraton Hotel in San Salvador. The Americans were Michael Hammer, 42 years old, of Potomac, Md., and Mark Pearlman, 26, of Seattle. Both were working as advisers to El Salvador's Government-sponsored land redistribution program. The slain Salvadoran was Jose Rodolfo Viera. President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador said the murders were ''almost certainly an action by the extreme right.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Surprise and concern were expressed by the Carter Administration over a report that Iranian authorities have transferred the senior American diplomat in Teheran and two aides from the Foreign Ministry to a secret place with some of the other 49 hostages. (A1:4.)

title: Airing a Difference
description: Two years ago, a television station in Philadelphia said it would provide $600,000 - added to its broadcasting contract with the Phillies - if the team could successfully lure Pete Rose, a free agent who had been with the Cincinnati Reds. The Phillies got Rose and the new television contract.

title: Audit Finds Fault With Sewer Bureau
description: A lack of inventory controls and poor warehousing practices at the city's 12 sewer storage yards and control storehouse have resulted in the city's collecting millions of dollars worth of unneeded, unused and nonoperational equipment, the City Comptroller's office said.

title: LOWER RATES WIDELY PREDICTED
description: Predictions that interest rates will drop over the first half of the new year are widespread, but analysts concede that there is great uncertainty about the assumptions underlying those forecasts.

title: British Leyland Strike Is Halted
description: Some 1,500 British Leyland auto workers voted overwhelmingly today to suspend a strike that the ailing state-owned company said jeopardized its future.

title: AGREEMENT REACHED OVER TEXAN'S WILL
description: Relatives contesting F.O. Masten's will leaving more than $50 million to a school he never attended reached an out-of-court settlement tonight, hours before trial of their suit was to begin, sources close to the case said.

title: Peking's Trial, and Error
description: All during the trial of the ''Gang of Four'' the court tried to keep Mao Zedong out of the proceedings. Jiang Qing, the last Mrs. Mao, was just as determined to show that condemning her meant condemning Mao. Because of her defiant attitude and open contempt of court, she may be sentenced to death. The confrontation exposes a major mistake in holding the trial, which her execution would only intensify. Denigrating Mao, even if by implication, can only betray the essential weakness of the Communist system: it cannot brook public opposition.

title: Lederer Trial to Start On Abscam Charges
description: Representative Raymond F. Lederer of Pennsylvania is scheduled to go on trial today in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on bribery and conspiracy charges stemming from the Abscam investigation into political corruption.

title: Ali Reported to Sign For Bout in March
description: Muhammad Ali and the European champion, John L. Gardner of Britain, have signed contracts for a 10-round fight the last week of March, Harold Smith, president of Muhammad Ali Professional Sports Inc., said yesterday.

title: BLAIRE A. FRENCH BRIDE OF PROF. JAMES CEASER
description: Blaire Atherton French, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Cole French of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to James Wilbur Ceaser, son of Mrs. Edward M. Ceaser of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, and the late Mr. Ceaser. Cantor Mark Lipson performed the ceremony at Waveny House.

title: U.S. SEEKING TO CLARIFY CANADA'S ENERGY POLICY
description: American officials, concerned with the continental impact of Canada's new nationalistic energy policies, have quietly initiated a series of discussions with their Canadian counterparts.

title: FIORELLO LAGUARDIA WAS A PERFORMER TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: Delaware Basin Dips Below Critical Line
description: Water supplies in area reservoirs dropped to drought emergency levels yesterday as the Delaware River Basin Commission prepared to consider a formal emergency declaration in the four-state area it serves.

title: SENATE DEMOCRATS ALTER THEIR DEMAND FOR HAIG DOCUMENTS
description: Senate Democrats preparing for the confirmation hearings of Alexander M. Haig Jr. have sent the White House a second letter asking for information about him, this time narrowing the request to specific controversial periods of his career. The Carter Administration will try to provide at least some of the tapes and documents requested, Jody Powell, President's Carter's press secretary, said today.

title: Welcome Help for Self-Help
description: In recent years, relations between the Hispanic and Jewish residents of two neighboring Brooklyn communities have improved, thanks to two self-help groups, the Sunset Park Redevelopment Committee and the Southern Brooklyn Community Organization in nearby Borough Park. The peaceful coexistence will soon take on a new dimension.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If you try hard, God will understand when you fail.'' - President Carter, teaching his last Sunday school class as President at the First Baptist Church in Washington. (B8:6.)

title: No Headline
description: Dollar Slips in Tokyo TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 5 (AP) - The dollar opened at 202.80 yen today on the Tokyo foreign exchange market, down from 203.6 yen at the Dec. 31 close, and a 22-month low. Dealers said the continuing drop in the dollar's value was to a strong Japanese economy and speculation about possible lower dollar interest rates.

title: WILLIAMS PROGRESSES IN LEAPS AND BOUNDS
description: LONG before he dreamed of a professional basketball career, Ray Williams was a Knicks' fan, adept at sneaking into Madison Square Garden when he didn't have the money for a ticket. He would pick up a stub on the sidewalk and flash it at the usher or wander in behind an adult who could pass as his father. ''The guy in back has the ticket,'' Williams would say. ''The guy in the blue coat.''

title: A TOUGH '81 SESSION LOOMING IN ALBANY
description: Criminal justice, rent control, gambling, aid for mass transportation and, most of all, how to spend New York State's money will be among the major issues facing the Legislature when it returns to Albany this week.

title: Dropped Ball?
description: Portland State University's school colors are black and gold, but despite a banner 1980 football season - with its record-breaking quarterback, Neil Lomax, and some astronomical scores (105-0, 93-7) - the program is not in the black, much less gold. The school lost about $50,000, on an operating budget of about $370,000, according to Athletic Director Roy Love.

title: Columbia, S.C., Police Chief Charged With Taking Bribe
description: Police Chief Arthur Hess of Columbia was arrested yesterday and charged with accepting a bribe, the state authorities said.

title: HOUSE UNIT SEES NATIONAL SECURITY THREATENED BY ARMS INDUSTRY LAG
description: The security of the United States is in jeopardy because of a serious decline in the nation's military industrial base, a special panel of the House Armed Services Committee warned in a report released today.

title: Ahmed Toukan, 78, Ex-Premier; Led Jordan During '70 Crackdown
description: Former Prime Minister Ahmed Toukan has died here at the age of 78 after a prolonged illness, a Royal Palace spokesman announced today.

title: CLASS SHOWS HOW ITS FEELINGS ARE SYMBOLIZED IN 'BLACK BOY'
description: In Joan Chabrowe's class on themes of adolescence in literature, the students had just finished ''Black Boy'' by Richard Wright. Miss Chabrowe asked them to write about what they had learned from the book that related to their lives. Here, in part, is what some of them said.

title: Campaign Program In Jersey Fundless
description: TRENTON (UPI) - Starting today, primary-election candidates in the gubernatorial race who raise and spend at least $50,000 on their own can apply to the State Election Law Enforcement Commission for matching funds.

title: Service for Watts Today
description: A funeral service for Richard Watts, former drama critic and war correspondent for The New York Post and The Herald Tribune, will be held today at 10 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell's, Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Mr. Watts died Friday of a cardiac arrest at the age of 82.

title: RETAIL CHAIN NAMES BANKER TO KEY JOB
description: Thomas W. McMahon Jr., who for many years had been a senior banking executive, has been named vice chairman of the United Department Stores, effective today. The company, with annual sales of about $300 million, operates 106 department and specialty stores in the Northeast and Middle West, including Hughes & Hatcher of Detroit, Jacob Reeds Sons of Philadelphia and S.P. Dunham & Company of Trenton.

title: MAUREEN REAGAN PROMOTING EXPORTS
description: Maureen Reagan, the daughter of President-elect Ronald Reagan, remembers the time during her father's campaign when she happened to pass some farm equipment while traveling through Iowa with a state legislator.

title: Greer Garson's Comeback
description: From El Dorado Country Club in Palm Springs, Calif., Greer Garson said yesterday that - after a year's absence because of ill health - she would return to New York in February or March as co-producer of ''Jitters,'' which is to open on Broadway in April with June Havoc.

title: The Raiders Of the Arctic
description: BEYOND the open end of Cleveland Stadium, the ice on Lake Erie resembled that of the Arctic Circle -flat and white and vaporous in the distance. Gusts of up to 28 miles per hour howled off that ice, turning the 1-degree temperature into a reported wind-chill factor of 37 degrees below zero. Even polar bears know enough to hibernate in weather like this. But yesterday 77,655 rational human beings did not. Mostly loyalists of the Cleveland Browns, they sat in this decrepit old ball park and watched a football game. Outside their bodies were bundled in various layers of fur, wool or nylon. Inside, many were stiff from various liquid anti-freezes. Up behind the frosted glass in the press box, Al Davis, the managing-general genius of the Oakland Raiders, huddled in a black coat over a silver gray turtleneck, peered through his sunglasses and pointed above.

title: Austrian Skier Wins Cup Giant Slalom
description: KAPPEL, Switzerland, Jan. 4 (AP) - Christian Orlainsky of Austria rallied in the final run today and won the second men's World Cup giant slalom ski race of the season today.

title: REPUBLICAN SENATORS SAY ECONOMY IS TOP PRIORITY
description: The incoming Congress should concentrate on "getting the economy on its feet" rather than on such issues as abortion, school prayer and busing to achieve integration, two Republican Senators said today. "We've got to be more flexible and work together," said Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, who is considered a conservative.

title: Two Men Indicted In Officer's Shooting
description: Two Queens men have been indicted on charges of attempted murder and robbery in connection with the shooting of a police detective early Saturday.

title: ACT IS CLAIMED BY ISLANDERS
description: A thunderous explosion destroyed the Chanel fashion and perfume store in central Paris today, and an anonymous telephone caller said the blast was the work of a group seeking independence for the French islands of Guadeloupe in the Caribbean.

title: ARTS, HUMANITIES AND A NEW ADMINISTRATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Teaching Literature; One of an occasional series on how different subjects are taught.
description: It is 8:30 A.M. and the seniors in Charlie Bonnici's literature class are discussing the difference between comedy and satire. Mr. Bonnici points out that while a satiric novel can be very funny, the funny parts are not necessarily satire. It is a difficult concept, and every one of the 20 students in the dingy yellow classroom is listening intently.

title: JULIA MIGENES-JOHNSON, FROM INGENUE TO THE MET
description: Fifteen years ago, Julia Migenes looked as if she might soon become one of Broadway's leading ladies. She had excited a good deal of attention as Maria in a 1964 revival of ''West Side Story'' at the City Center, and later that year she began a two-and-one-half year stint as Hodel, Tevye's daughter, in the original production of ''Fiddler on the Roof.'' On her off nights, she moonlighted with the New York City Opera, performing in Menotti's ''The Saint of Bleecker Street'' and ''The Consul'' at the City Center.

title: NETS DROP 8TH IN A ROW, FALLING TO PACERS
description: Although the Nets dropped their eighth straight game tonight, a 113-104 loss to the Indiana Pacers, Mike Newlin was not discouraged.

title: Gloomy Report By Purchasers
description: More purchasing managers reported a drop in production and new orders last month, in a trend similar to the negative figures of March, when interest rates also set record highs, according to the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: BRIAN TEACHER WINS CROWN IN AUSTRALIA
description: After losing in four consecutive final matches in the last two months, Brian Teacher of the United States finally prevailed today, capturing the $350,000 Australian open tennis championship with a 7-5, 7-6, 6-3 victory over a weary Kim Warwick.

title: KENTUCKY OFFICIALS SUE U.S. OVER UTILITY EMISSIONS
description: Local officials in Kentucky are suing the Federal Environmental Protection Agency for what they call the agency's failure to reduce pollution from a coal-burning power plant in neighboring southern Indiana.

title: DARLA CHAVKIN IS MARRIED
description: Darla Joyce Chavkin, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Roy Chavkin, was married yesterday afternoon to Jerome S. Stone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Stone.

title: Market Place; Key Companies Looking Better
description: SHARES of the most heavily capitalized industrial companies have done relatively poorly in the last two to three years. But better days may be ahead for the likes of Dow Chemical, Eastman Kodak and General Electric.

title: 10-0 Wake Forest Off to a Fast Start
description: They call it ''Operation Basketball.'' Before each Atlantic Coast Conference season, the members of the Atlantic Coast Sportswriters' Association meet at the Greensboro (N.C.) Coliseum and listen to the coach and two players from each of the nine conference teams talk about their prospects. The writers then predict where the teams will finish.

title: HOW CHINA RAISES ITS WELL BEHAVED CHILDREN
description: Picture this nursery school scene: 10 1-year-olds are squeezed next to one another on a bench, their backs against a wall. They sit motionless. None cry, push or shove.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF NORMALIZING U.S. RELATIONS WITH HANOI
description: To the Editor:

title: ST. LOUIS STRUGGLES WITH EBB OF PEOPLE AND BUSINESS
description: Five years ago, Nelson Laffey and his family moved from a small town of 700 people to St. Louis. It did not bother him that other people were moving out of the city at a near-evacuation rate.

title: Chess: Korchnoi Takes 7th Game To Pull Even With Hubner
description: Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland won the seventh game of his final Candidates' Match in Merano, Italy, with Robert Hubner of West Germany to pull even at 3 1/2-3 1/2. It takes 8 1/2 points to decide the series and qualify for the title match with Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union next summer.

title: You Could Look It Up
description: When Debrett's Peerage announced recently that it had traced Ronald Reagan's ancestry back to the 11th-century Irish King Brian Boru, Houghton Mifflin rushed to provide the President-elect with a copy of its 1980 novel, ''The Lion of Ireland,'' based on Boru's life.

title: Miss Caulkins Beats East Germans Twice
description: Tracy Caulkins turned the United States international swimming meet into her personal showcase tonight. She posted her third and fourth world-best performances and beat 1980 Olympic champions and world-record holders from East Germany each time.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By John Leonard PERSONAL IMPRESSIONS. BY Isaiah Berlin. 219 pages. Viking. $13.95.

title: CAESAR'S RANSOM
description: To the Editor:

title: FINK SEES ENOUGH FUNDS TO ASSIST CRIMINAL JUSTICE
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink said yesterday that despite projections for a tight New York State budget next year, there would be enough money to provide for an expansion of the criminal justice system.

title: Arab Radical Is Linked To Bombing in Kenya
description: Official Kenyan sources said today that an Arab radical who left Kenya on a flight to Saudi Arabia on New Year's Eve was responsible for the Norfolk Hotel bombing that killed 15 people.

title: RAIDERS INTERCEPT AND OUST BROWNS
description: The Cleveland Browns ran out of improbable last-minute comebacks today and lost to the Oakland Raiders, 14-12, in their American Conference semifinal playoff game.

title: British Hint at Breakthrough In 'Yorkshire Ripper' Case
description: Authorities indicated a major breakthrough today in the five-year hunt for the man who has come to be known as the ''Yorkshire Ripper,'' announcing that tomorrow they would arraign a man who has been questioned for the last two days ''on serious charges.''

title: FEDERAL RESERVE SEES LITTLE GROWTH IN '81 WITH CONTINUED HIGH RATES
description: Top officials at the Federal Reserve Board, including its chairman, Paul A. Volcker, say that their policy of reducing the expansion of money and credit will mean little or no economic growth in 1981 and continuing high interest rates.

title: 2 FROM RADIO JOIN PBS PROGRAM
description: Two correspondents from National Public Radio will join the regular staff of ''The Lawmakers,'' a weekly Public Broadcasting Service television program devoted to Congressional activities. The program will begin its second season at 10 P.M. on Friday on WNET.

title: REAGAN ECONOMIC STRATEGISTS HOPING TO SUBMIT BUDGET REVISIONS BY FEB. 3
description: The economic planning members of Ronald Reagan's administration have set Feb. 3 as the tentative date on which the new President will give Congress proposals for far-reaching reductions in Federal taxes, spending and regulation of business.

title: Washington Watch; Regan Hearing May Be Lively
description: WASHINGTON DESPITE criticism that Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith has aided some of its wealthy clients in side-stepping the Internal Revenue Service, Donald T. Regan does not appear to face serious confirmation problems as Treasury Secretary, Senate Finance Committee aides say.

title: STEPS TO IMPROVE RELATIONS WITH MEXICO
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan's meeting today with President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico in Ciudad Juarez should help set a new, constructive tone for relations between the two countries in coming years. I hope that they touch upon the United States' energy crisis, which continues to be one of the country's most pressing issues.

title: A Magazine for Travelers To Atlantic City's Casinos
description: There are magazines for passengers in commercial airplanes; there is a magazine for people bound for New York airports by bus from Fairfield County, Conn.; there is a magazine for guests at a certain motel chain, and there is a magazine for people taking the Gray Line sightseeing tours. So why shouldn't there be a magazine for folks taking the bus to Atlantic City for a little gambling?

title: Red Brigades Reports Plan To Kill Kidnapped Judge
description: A message signed by the Red Brigades said today that the terrorist group had sentenced to death a judge kidnapped in Rome last month.

title: Borg and McEnroe Will Meet
description: Bjorn Borg and John McEnroe, who last year thrilled tennis fans in the singles finals of Wimbledon and the United States Open, will provide the first top matchup of the new year next week.

title: MUSIC: PAVAROTTI SINGS TO SOLD OUT HOUSE AT MET
description: LUCIANO PAVAROTTI'S recital at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon was a curiously disappointing affair. The outer trappings were familiar enough. The tenor came onstage followed by his accompanist, John Wustman, with arms outstretched to the soldout auditorium. The ubiquitous white handkerchief dangled from his left hand and he fairly exuded the vulnerable teddy-bear presence that has endeared him to millions over television. Even the program was pretty much the same collection of chestnuts that almost invariably make up his recitals.

title: DR. CYNTHIA NAST MARRIED TO ROCCO LARDIERE, ENGINEER
description: The marriage of Dr. Cynthia Caroline Nast, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, to Rocco Joseph Lardiere, an electronics engineer with Astro Systems Inc. in Lake Success, L.I., took place yesterday in Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Albert W. Sturmer performed the ceremony at the Sunningdale Country Club.

title: 2 AMERICANS SLAIN AT SALVADOR HOTEL: AIDED LAND AGENCY
description: Two Americans working in El Salvador's land redistribution program and the head of the country's agrarian program were slain by gunmen last night as they sat in the coffee shop of the Sheraton Hotel here.

title: Advertising; McCann's Unified Approach
description: ERICKSON, whose structure over recent years has wavered between separate domestic and international operations and single worldwide managements, has once more decided on the one-world approach.

title: Flames 8, Maple Leafs 5
description: Paul Reinhart scored two power-play goals to pace the Flames. The Flames took advantage of defensive lapses by Toronto to score unassisted goals by Kent Nilsson and Eric Vail in the early going.

title: Mother and 5 Children Slain; Father Said to Kill Himself
description: A mother and her five young children were found shot to death today in their home in this small eastern Iowa community, and the authorities said that the woman's husband apparently committed suicide nearly 450 miles away.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A NIGHT FOR MABEL MERCER

title: Honeywell Sale
description: Honeywell Inc. reported that it has sold part of its traffic-control business to Traconex Inc., a privately held company based in Santa Clara, Calif., for an undisclosed price. The transaction announced last week included the sale of inventory and equipment and the licensing of technology for Honeywell's line of street and highway traffic controllers. The sale did not include large computer-based traffic-control systems, but Honeywell said it would phase out this segment within a year.

title: Home Edge
description: The University of Michigan has finally won a Rose Bowl game under the coaching of Bo Schembechler. But it paid for it: $1.825 million, to be exact.

title: Highway Deaths Decline in Jersey
description: TRENTON (UPI) - New Jersey had 35 fewer highway deaths in 1980 than in 1979, and officials said the state's ''vigorous campaign'' against drunken drivers was responsible.

title: Jerseyan's Nephew, a Leukemia Victim, Dies in Soviet
description: Early last month the New Jersey Assembly passed a resolution in support of the letter-writing campaign of Bella Belostozki of North Plainfield, who was trying to get her 17-year-old nephew, Aleksandr Landsman, out of the Soviet Union for treatment of his leukemia.

title: TRUDEAU TRIP: THIRD WORLD THEME
description: Although Canada is in deep political and economic trouble, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau is beginning his second visit abroad in two months to promote better relations between the rich and poor nations of the world.

title: The Talk of Oniipa
description: West Africa - In this lightly settled land of wide horizons and long vistas, nearly half the population of one million lives on less than one-sixteenth of the total area, a flat and dusty tropical plain known as Ovamboland.

title: Walker and Sister In Millrose Games
description: Herschel Walker, Georgia's all-America running back, and his sister Veronica intend to compete in next month's Millrose Games track and field meet in New York City, a school spokesman said today.

title: THE U.N. TODAY
description: Jan.5,1981 ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL INTERGOVERNMENTAL WORKING GROUP OF COMMISSION ON TRANSNATIONAL CORPORATIONS-10:30A.M.

title: Index; International
description: A bombing symbolizes the strug- gle in Namibia A2 Reagan and Mexican leader to meet today A3 Trudeau promoting third world in- terests in six-nation visit A4 Around the World A6 U.S. is ''perplexed'' by killings of 2 Americans in El Salvador A10 Begin's Cabinet upholds minister who ousted police commander A10 Government/Politics St. Louis struggles as city loses population and businesses A12 Fink expects enough funds for criminal-justice expansion B6 President Carter teaches a Sun- day school lesson on greatness B8 Panel warns of decline in U.S. military industrial base B8 Liberal group rates Senate and warns about conservatism B8 Aides say White House will supply some Haig materials B9 Exchange of letters over Haig files B9 General Around the Nation A12 The Region B2 District attorney attributes Buf- falo assaults to same man B2 Scallop ''pirates'' cut into L.I. baymen's livelihoods B2 The City B3 Surge in burglaries over holidays reported B3 Nominating judges for Pulitzer Prize in journalism named B5 Trial opening in Texan's $50 mil- lion bequest to college B12 PARKING REGULATIONS Alternate-side parking regulations are suspended throughout New York City today because of the weather, the Sanitation Department announced. SportsMonday Basketball: Nets lose eighth in row, to Pacers, 113-104 C7

title: No Headline
description: Question BoxS. Lee Kanner QUESTION: A pitcher throws a ball that bounces in front of the batter's box, skips up and hits the batter. Does he take first base?

title: L.I. Parents Oppose Life-Support Effort
description: The parents of a 17-year-old Long Island girl have applied for legal permission to disconnect the life-support equipment that has kept her alive since she went into a coma two months ago.

title: GEOLOGIST WARNS THAT SPRING MUD SLIDES COULD DUMP DEBRIS ON 2 TOWNS NEAR THE FOOT OF MOUNT ST. HELENS
description: A Federal geologist, speaking at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, said today that debris from the May 18 eruption of Mount St. Helens might generate devastating mud slides in the spring, seriously threatening two towns about 40 miles from the volcano.

title: REAGAN TO STAY IN ALL-MALE CLUB UNTIL A JUDGE RULES IN BIAS CASE
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan has no plans at this time to resign from the exclusively male Bohemian Club, which is being sued on charges of sex discrimination, according to a Reagan aide.

title: CARTER SAYS FAREWELL AT SUNDAY BIBLE CLASS
description: President Carter, teaching his Sunday school class at the First Baptist Church for the last time while in office, said today that greatness lay not in being President or a behind-the-scenes manipulator but in serving others.

title: CALLON BROTHER ADDS POST
description: John S. Callon, the 60-year-old president and chief executive officer of the Callon Petroleum Company, has been elected to the additional position of chairman. Mr. Callon succeeds his brother, Sim C. Callon, 64, who will become a consultant to the oil and gas exploration and production company based in Natchez, Miss.

title: JEFFERSON KEENER DIES AT 72 IN AKRON
description: Jefferson Ward Keener, a former chairman and chief executive officer of the B.F. Goodrich Company, died of an apparent heart attack on Friday at his home in Akron, Ohio. He was 72 years old.

title: LIBERAL GROUP RATES THE SENATE, BUT DISCOUNTS A SHIFT TO THE LEFT
description: Americans for Democratic Action, a national liberal organization, issued its ratings of the 1980 voting records of United States Senators today, describing an apparent liberal trend as merely a concerted effort to hold back the spread of conservatism. The organization's ratings of Senators' voting patterns rose in 1980 because moderates were forced to vote with liberals to stop ''harmful legislation,'' the group said.

title: CANADA'S PROVIGO SEEKING TO EXPAND U.S. FOOD HOLDINGS
description: Provigo Inc., the third-largest food wholesaler in North America, acquired 87 Quebec supermarkets earlier this month and plans to expand its small United States operations. But the 12-year-old Montreal-based company is also studying acquisitions in fields as diverse as restaurants, sporting goods and oil and gas exploration in hopes of doubling its sales by 1985.

title: U.N. PREOCCUPATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: A Double Dummy Problem If You're Not Watching TV
description: Those who like thinking about bridge deals on paper rather than at the table might care to consider whether South can bring home an unlikely contract of seven hearts on the diagramed deal, playing double-dummy after the opening lead of the spade seven.

title: COWBOYS RALLY TO BEAT FALCONS
description: Drew Pearson, the Dallas Cowboy wide receiver, made spectacular catches of touchdown passes in the final minutes of playoff games throughout the 1970's. The sight of the slim, graceful athlete leaping high to snare the football became common, and today he repeated his performance twice as the Cowboys scored 20 points in the fourth quarter and beat the Atlanta Falcons, 30-27, in a division playoff game.

title: NOMINATING JUDGES ARE CHOSEN FOR PULITZER PRIZES IN JOURNALISM
description: The names of 55 editors who will serve as nominating judges for the Pulitzer Prize in journalism were announced yesterday by Michael I. Sovern, president of Columbia University, which awards the prize.

title: MARKET SET FOR INCREASE IN NUMBER OF NEW ISSUES
description: After a hiatus over the holiday season, the credit markets are preparing for increased volume in new issues this month. The sharp drop in rates since mid-December should attract many corporations that were unwilling to borrow when rates were higher and that did not want to test the markets during the waning days of the year, when investors and underwriters curb their activity.

title: OUTDOORS: BIG GAME ANGLERS TEST WATERS FOR RECORDS
description: ANGLING for large, offshore saltwater fish attracts new devotees each year, even though it is a far cry from the contemplative endeavor espoused by Isaac Walton.

title: Faulty Heater Called Cause of Fatal Fire
description: Fire officials said that a faulty kerosene heater had caused a weekend blaze in which a Cumberland County woman and her three children died.

title: Sporting Gear; Computerized Exercise Cycle
description: The Computrim 900 Electronic Ergometer is a stationary cycle that enables the user to measure responses to exercise programs. The cycle provides settings for 10 different work loads, allowing for a gradual buildup of the user's stamina. The Computrim 900 also records pulse rate, pulse limit, time and total work performed and uses a conventional electric wall plug and a 12-volt transformer. The seat and the handlebar can be adjusted, and there is an alert system that warns of excessive heart-beat levels. The unit sells for about $1,000. For information as to retail outlets, write to the manufacturer, AMF Whitely, 29 Essex Street, Maywood, N.J. 07607. The telephone number is (201) 343-4762.

title: Squires Captures Central Park Run
description: Pete Squires of the New York Athletic Club braved yesterday morning's 6-degree temperature to win the opener of the Manufacturers Hanover Five-Borough Challenge five-mile race in Central Park in 24 minutes 32.8 seconds.

title: A WATER TUNNEL IS BADLY NEEDED, GOLDIN CAUTIONS
description: Unless New York moves rapidly to complete construction of its longstalled third water tunnel, the city risks ''a disastrous breakdown'' of its water-supply system, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin warned yesterday.

title: POLITICS OF TERROR
description: The most obvious difference between terrorism in Italy and terrorism in Iran is that in Italy the Red Brigades are trying to destroy the power of government, while factions in the Teheran Government are trying to consolidate power by holding hostages. In both cases, however, the primary purpose of the crimes is to affect internal politics. Revenge and bargaining for the status of prisoners or for billions of dollars are only secondary points.

title: 100 Highway Troopers Free Miami Police to Fight Crime
description: One hundred Florida Highway Patrol troopers arrived here today to assume traffic duties in an effort to free local police to battle crime.

title: Flying Horses
description: Travel costs have long been a major concern for professional and intercollegiate sports teams. But there is another group feeling the effect of the high price of air travel - thoroughbred race horses.

title: Pavarotti's Father, Tenor, Joins Son During Encores
description: Every opera fan is familiar with Luciano Pavarotti's voice, but yesterday afternoon the voices of two Pavarottis were heard at the Metropolitan Opera House. The other Pavarotti was Fernando, Luciano's 66-year-old father, who took part in his son's recital during the encores, singing a duet version of Franck's ''Panis Angelicus.''

title: AIDES SAY ADMINISTRATION WILL SUPPLY SENATORS WITH SOME HAIG DOCUMENTS
description: Carter Administration officials suggested today that they would not raise a blanket objection to Congressional requests for information on Alexander M. Haig Jr. and would try to provide much of the information sought.

title: Losers Are Left With Empty Feeling
description: Coach Leeman Bennett of the Falcons was distraught, having seen a victory snatched from his team today. He said the defeat by Dallas Cowboys left him with an empty feeling. But it also reminded him of ''quite a few'' Falcon victories this season.

title: BEGIN'S CABINET UPHOLDS MINISTER WHO OUSTED NATIONAL POLICE CHIEF
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin's ministers closed ranks today around the beleaguered Minister of Interior, Yosef Burg, who found himself in the eye of a political and public storm after he dismissed the national police commandant last week.

title: by Richard E. Feinberg
description: When, after his inauguration, a pro-United States regime in the third world starts floundering, the best course for Ronald Reagan may be to let history sweep it away.

title: By Jim Benagh
description: Sports World Specials Fine China

title: A LOOK AT WORLD STOCK PRICES
description: Despite a storm of adverse economic developments, including higher interest rates and increased oil prices, the world's major stock exchanges recorded impressive price gains last year on generally higher volume.

title: CITY LOCKSMITH REPORT HOLIDAY SURGE IN BREAK-INS
description: Locksmiths in Manhattan, in an informal survey, have reported a surge in break-ins and burglaries during the holidays that brought a sharp increase in their business.

title: Video Recordings Planned By Royal Opera House
description: The Royal Opera House in Covent Garden has announced that it signed an agreement to permit video cassette recordings of at least three operas or ballets a year produced under its auspices for the next five years.

title: NORDIQUES RALLY WITH GOALS IN FINAL PERIOD AND TIE RANGERS, 2-2
