description: Down, up and down again - that's the way it's been the last three games with the New York Rangers. For all the lift they expected to get from their surprise victory Friday over the New York Islanders, the Rangers let down again last night at Madison Square Garden. They let a 2-0 lead slip from their grasp and, in 87 seconds of the final period, allowed the Quebec Nordiques to tie them, 2-2.

title: Sabres 2, North Stars 2
description: Alan Howarth's goal late in the third period capped a Buffalo comeback as the Sabres tied Minnesota.

title: The Queen Requests That Reporters Go Away
description: ''I wish you would go away,'' Queen Elizabeth II shouted at reporters, in an uncharacteristic outburst, last week during her holiday visit to Sandringham. They had followed her to her privately owned country castle with the hope of learning whether Lady Diana Spencer was along as the guest of Prince Charles.

title: Get the Buses Moving Again
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's new Flxible buses are still as immobile as the Statue of Liberty. Flxible, its corporate parent Grumman and the M.T.A are all trying to make them move. If Comptroller Goldin, in an excess of protective zeal, has a different priority, it's time for him to get out of the way.

title: Borman's View On Braniff Link
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. will proceed with plans to merge with Braniff Airways ''only if our study shows conclusively that the merged company will be stronger and more profitable than Eastern alone,'' according to Frank Borman, president and chairman of Eastern. In his annual message to employees, Mr. Borman referred to the merger as one of several ''expansion possibilities.''

title: ISRAEL TOPS ALL IN RATE OF INFLATION
description: Last year ended with the kind of economic tidings this country would rather forget: Israel's inflation soared to the world's highest level and unemployment grew, but the economy remained nearly static.

title: Thai Troops Placed on Alert After Raid by Vietnamese
description: Thai troop reinforcements were rushed to the tense border with Vietnamese-occupied Cambodia today and put on alert against another cross-border raid by Hanoi's troops.

title: Mahaffey Is Victor By Shot on Coast
description: John Mahaffey broke a tie at the 18th hole by matching par and won the $135,000 Spalding invitation golf tournament today.

title: NEW VIEWS HINTED BY MRS. CHENNAULT
description: Anna Chennault, a Chinese-American who is a longtime supporter of the Nationalist Government on Taiwan, met for two hours today with Deng Xiaoping, China's top leader, and indicated afterward that she had changed some of her views about China.

title: THEATER: 'FRANKENSTEIN' HAS PREMIERE AT PALACE
description: CERTAINLY no expense has been spared in ''Frankenstein,'' the new horror show that opened at the Palace last night. This extravaganza boasts enough good actors, colossal sets and rafter-shaking special effects to equip a Shakespearean repertory company. But money is a neutral factor in the theater; it alone cannot create fun. At ''Frankenstein,'' we're keenly aware of the cash, effort and talent that have been stirred into the brew, but we wait in vain for the final product to come to a boil.

title: CABERET: GILLESPIE AND QUARTET
description: AMAJOR jazz star who has held his audience for 30 or 40 years is likely to be taken for granted. And, in turn, the musician is likely to cling to the kind of performance that brought his audience to him, as in the cases of Benny Goodman and Louis Armstrong.

title: TV: THE BEVERLY SILLS GALA, MORE LAUGHTER THAN TEARS
description: As might be expected, ''Beverly! Her Farewell Performance'' is more laughter than tears, more celebration than farewell. The twohour program, to be broadcast tonight over the Public Broadcasting Service, is a telecast of an Oct. 27 gala at the New York State Theater, the last of several national farewell appearances given by the much-loved Beverly Sills, now director of the New York City Opera. On hand are friends and colleagues from the concert stage, opera, ballet, theater and television, and the air is rich with affection.

title: 5th Ave. Store Cited For Sale Practices
description: Any advertised sale by the Fifth Avenue Music Shop, 545 Fifth Avenue, will have to have items reduced at least 5 percent from regular prices or the store will face possible penalties for contempt of court, the city's Consumer Affairs Department announced. The penalty could be a fine of $250 a day and up to 30 days' imprisonment.

title: FIORELLO LAGUARDIA WAS A PERFORMER TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: CHARGERS ARE FORCED TO REBUILD OFFENSE
description: The morning after the San Diego Chargers won their first playoff game in 17 years, as about 400 fans pitched tents and brought sleeping bags to wait overnight for the remaining 4,000 tickets for the American Conference championship game next Sunday, a lesser-known member of the record-breaking offense became its most important missing part.

title: Black Withdraws Candidacy For Chicago School Chief
description: The leading candidate for the superintendency of Chicago's schools withdrew his name from consideration today, surprising a racially polarized school board said to be on the verge of appointing him.

title: Arrows Win, 4-3
description: Steve Zungul broke a 3-3 deadlock at 1 minute 33 seconds of the fourth quarter and the New York Arrows held on to defeat the Philadelphia Fever, 4-3, this afternoon in a Major Indoor Soccer League game at Nassau Coliseum before 6,711. Zungul, who also had scored in the second period, raised his league-leading goal total to 49 as the Arrows extended their winning streak to 11.

title: OFFICIAL ASCRIBES BUFFALO ASSAULTS TO SAME PERSON
description: District Attorney Edward C. Cosgrove of Erie County said today that he believed that one white man was responsible for the five stabbing attacks on black men last week and the four shooting deaths of black men last September in and around this city.

title: Monday, January 5, 1980
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Abandoned Atlanta House Yields No Clues to Children
description: Lee P. Brown, the Atlanta Public Safety Commissioner, said tonight that the police had found nothing in an abandoned house discovered by searchers for Atlanta's missing children that would provide any leads.

title: SNOWY COLD CHEERS SOME AS OTHERS SUFFER
description: New York City sank into bitter, snowy cold yesterday, a situation that exhilarated some, including eager skiers and sledders in Central Park, but brought suffering to many tenants of buildings without heat.

title: Armenian Guerrilla Organization Calling Off Attacks on the Swiss
description: An organization calling itself the Armenian Secret Army issued a communique today calling on its members to ''stop all attacks against Switzerland'' until Jan. 15.

title: Turkey Quells Revolt At Prison in Adana
description: Security forces moved into Adana prison yesterday to quell a revolt in which a prisoner was killed and two guards wounded.

title: No Headline
description: Red Smith Bartender's Comeback

title: APOGEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: Shr earnings reflect 25 percent stock divds distributed in November 1979 and December 1980

title: PEKING WILL PRESS REAGAN FOR CHANGES
description: Cline WASHIN GTON - A funny thing happened to me on the way back from Singapore.

title: A BREAK IN 'YORKSHIRE RIPPER' IS INDICATED AS MAN, 35, IS CHARGED
description: A 35-year-old truck driver was charged with murder today, and the police appeared to feel that they had broken the case of the so-called Yorkshire Ripper, believed responsible for the deaths of 13 women during the last five years.

title: STAY IN IRAN LITIGATION DISPUTED
description: More than 30 of the companies that have tied up billions of dollars' worth of frozen Iranian assets in lawsuits filed court papers today in New York opposing the Carter Administration's efforts to suspend the suits while the Government seeks to free the hostages.

title: FROM GUADELOUPE, MESSAGE FOR FRANCE
description: By demolishing much of the Chanel couturier shop here with a bomb yesterday, separatists from Guadeloupe served notice that they would no longer be ignored.

title: NEW YORK AS LITTLE APPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: A.M.C. Reshuffles Its Ad Agencies
description: The American Motors Corporation has consolidated all of its fourwheel-drive vehicles at Compton Advertising and all of its twowheel-drive conventional cars at Grey Advertising.

title: OAKLAND SCHOOL CHIEF IS OFFERED THE TOP POST IN THE CHICAGO SYSTEM
description: Dr. Ruth B. Love, the 48-year-old superintendent of the Oakland, Calif., schools, has been offered the post of superintendent here.

title: TV: 'JECKYLL AND HYDE' AND A KARL MALDEN FILM
description: AN adaptation of Robert Louis Stevenson's ''The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde'' that makes Victorian London seem almost sexually trendy will be seen tonight and next Tuesday from 9 to 10 o'clock on WNET-TV, Channel 13.

title: LOBBYING BODY TO
description: PUSH CONGRESS FOR A NUCLEAR EDGE OVER SOVIET By Juan de Onis

title: No Headline
description: TEXT OF JOINT STATEMENT IN MEXICO

title: J.P. Stevens Labor Charges Upheld by Appeals Court
description: A Federal appeals court upheld unfair labor practice findings against the J.P. Stevens textile company today and said the concern's ''history of misconduct'' in labor relations was a factor in its decision.

title: U.S. SAYS 3 HOSTAGES FOUGHT EARLIER BID TO TRANSFER THEM
description: The United States said today that the three Americans formerly held in the Iranian Foreign Ministry had successfully resisted an attempt to move them 11 days before they were transferred on Saturday to a secret location in Teheran.

title: Advertising; Expecting A Spring Recovery
description: WEARING an overcoat against the cold in his corner office in the Exxon Building yesterday morning, James L. Till, for the last five years advertising director of National Geographic magazine, took a short-range, appropriately bleak view of 1981 and said, ''The first couple of months are lousy.''

title: Bridge: British to Get Good Chance For Championship at Home
description: The politics of 1980 has had an impact on the international bridge scene for 1981. The biennial European Championships, one of the world's strongest events for almost half a century, had been scheduled for Warsaw. However, the recent turmoil in Poland and the possibility of worsening conditions ahead persuaded the European Bridge League to change its plans.

title: BOOK CRITICS CIRCLE ANNOUNCES '81 AWARDS
description: The first book awards of 1981 were announced yesterday as the National Book Critics Circle picked the ''most distinguished'' books written by Americans last year in four categories. It was the closest voting in the six-year history of the organization of professional critics and editors.

title: PUBLIC-TV GUIDE GRANTED TAX-EXEMPT STATUS
description: The Internal Revenue Service has ruled that The Dial, the monthly public-television program guide, is a nonprofit tax-exempt venture. The status was given Dec. 31 by the I.R.S. to Public Broadcasting Communications Inc. of 304 West 58th Street, publisher of the threemonth old periodical. The Dial is sent to contributors of $25 or more to WNET-TV of New York, WETA-TV of Washington, WTVS-TV of Detroit, WTTW-TV of Chicago and KCET-TV of Los Angeles.

title: Stuffed Landmarks
description: Long before they can grasp the spatial layout of a terrain, children are capable of navigating by landmarks. Experiments described recently in the journal Child Development tested second graders, sixth graders and college students on an indoor course with toy stuffed animals for landmarks. When the animals were removed, the sixth graders and college students could still find their way, but the second graders were literally lost.

title: WILEY MANUEL,53,DEAD IN CALIFORNIA
description: Justice Wiley W. Manuel, the first black to serve on the California Supreme Court, died of cancer early today at Providence Hospital in Oakland, Calif. He was 53 years old.

title: M.T.A. WILL PAY GRUMMAN IN FULL FOR 837 BUSES IN RETURN FOR REPAIR
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will resume paying the Grumman Flxible Corporation a $54 million balance owed for 837 buses, 637 of which have been delivered and have developed structural cracking, and the authority will return the buses to use after they have been repaired.

title: BROWNS' CHOICE TO PASS NEAR GOAL UPHELD
description: There is something different -something special - about the Dallas Cowboys, and Drew Pearson, their wide receiver, is a perfect example of why, according to John Dutton.

title: GUERILLA WAR IN NAMIBIA: FRUSTRATION FOR BOTH SIDES
description: West Africa - Despite the severe losses that South African forces say they have inflicted this year on guerrilla units of the South-West Africa People's Organization, the insurgents continue to infiltrate across the long Angolan border into this disputed territory and to move with relative freedom here in the northern area, especially by night.

title: TENANTS COMPLAIN OF A LACK OF HEAT
description: Thousands of reports of heatless apartments have swamped New York City's emergency complaint switchboard during the last three days of bitter cold. Yesterday, throughout the city and the Northeast, people bundled against blustery winds and coped with widespread delays in transportation as cars, subways, buses and trains faltered.

title: RESERVOIRS' DROP TO 32% PROMPTS CALL FOR MEETING
description: SUB WATER/Page B1 By ROBERT HANLEY

title: THE WIDENING ROLE OF NEW YORK'S SECRETARY OF STATE
description: The New York Department of State, custodian of dusty, centuries-old ledgers and known as a collection of often obscure subagencies, is settling happily into its role as Albany's contact with communities.

title: Finance Executive Is Named by G.M.
description: Shuttling between a board meeting and staff sessions at the General Motors Building yesterday, F. Alan Smith apparently had no time to answer a reporter's inquiry. But one can logically assume, even without his confirmation, that the day's chores were indeed pleasant for Mr. Smith, who yesterday became executive vice president of finance for the General Motors Corporation, as well as a director of the nation's largest auto maker.

title: RACHEL ROBERTS RULED A SUICIDE
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan 5, Rachel Roberts, who was found dead at herhome in November, committed suicide, a coroner's spokesman said today. He said a medical report showed that the53 yearold Welsh actress, former wife of the actor Rex Harrison, died of acute barbiturate intoxication and her death has been listed as suicide

title: Jenkins Leaves E.E.C. Post
description: Roy Jenkins, in his last news conference as president of the European Common Market Commission, today praised the way the community had held together despite serious problems during his four-year term. He said the European Economic Community had learned ''to live in a harsher climate, dealing with a wider and less coherent Europe than that of the original six.''

title: Elizabeth Still Rules Among British Names
description: For years, Margaret Brown has been tabulating names of infants whose births are announced in The Times of London. Based on 4,446 birth announcements in 1980, Mrs. Brown reports that Elizabeth remains queen and James the king among the most popular names for British girls and boys, while Louise and Alexander, up from eighth and sixth places, were the second most popular during the year.

title: Undefeated UConn Tops Syracuse, 78-59
description: Connecticut, led by Chuck Aleksinas's 20 points, routed Syracuse, 78-59, tonight in the opening Big East Conference game for each team.

title: I.B.M. Cuts Prices On Selectric 111
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced that it had reduced the purchase price for its new Selectric 111 typewriter line by about 12 percent. The company said that the new purchase prices for the line range from $810 to $1,035.

title: CITY BALLET DANCERS WIN 41% RAISE IN 3-YEAR PACT
description: The dancers of the New York City Ballet voted yesterday to accept a new three-year contract, thereby insuring the continuance tonight of the company's winter season at the New York State Theater. The vote was 62 to 12 after a two-hour morning meeting at the Holiday Inn that one dancer described as ''comfortable.''

title: No Headline
description: lican Senators (Page B10) NEW CONGRESS: HARMONY AND SKIRMISHES BY MARTIN TOLCHIN

title: All Nippon Buys Boeings
description: The Export-Import Bank said today that that the All Nippon Airways Company was purchasing four Boeing 747-SR aircraft for $230 million, assisted by a $92 million loan from the bank.

title: CARTER TO SEEK SPACE FOR OFFICE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 President Carter will be looking after personal business when he goes home to Plains, Ga., on Thursday for a stay of three or four days, White House officials said today. Among other things, Mr. Carter will be seeking office space for use when he leaves the Presidency on Jan. 20.

title: Mental Health Chief Quits in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD (AP) - Eric A. Plaut, Connecticut's Commissioner of Mental Health, is resigning to take positions with Northwestern University Medical School and a Chicago hospital.

title: KOCH'S RE-ELECTION BID TO SHAPE LOBBYING IN ALBANY
description: As lobbyists for New York City prepare for the new session of the State Legislature, which opens Wednesday, they will be mindful that just about everything they do will be shaped to one degree or another by the fact that their boss, Mayor Koch, is up for re-election this year.

title: Charles F. Jarvis, 46, Producer Of Elvis Presley Records, Dead
description: Charles Felton Jarvis of Franklin, who produced Elvis Presley's records, died of a stroke at Baptist Hospital on Saturday.

title: DAVID DRABKIN, BLOOD RESEARCHER
description: Dr. David L. Drabkin, a pioneer in the study of human hemoglobin, died Dec. 31 in the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania after a short illness. He was 81 years old.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL BANK OF ARIZONA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN HOIST & DERRICK CO reports earnings for 10 weeks to Nov 30
DR. WILLIAM F. NEUMAN, AUTHORITY ON BONE TISSUE
description: Dr. William F. Neuman, professor of radiation biology at the University of Rochester Medical Center and an internationally known authority on the biochemistry of bone tissue, died Sunday at his home in Rochester. He was 61 years old.

title: Suspect Arraigned In PATH Murder
description: JERSEY CITY (AP) - A 21-year-old Irvington man was arraigned on a charge of having murdered a policeman on Dec. 22 after an argument over smoking on a commuter train.

title: No Headline
description: BRADY IS PRESS AIDE, REAGAN SOURCES SAY

title: Seoul Plans Ties With Libya
description: Libya and South Korea have agreed to set up full diplomatic relations and exchange ambassadors, the South Korean Foreign Ministry announced today. Libya established diplomatic ties with North Korea in 1974, according to Foreign Ministry officials.

title: N.H.L. Begins BrawlInquiry
description: The National Hockey League has started an investigation of last Saturday night's brawling game between the Colorado Rockies and the Boston Bruins. Five Rockies club records were broken for penalty-minute totals.

title: BONN LEFTIST FAULTS NATO MISSILE PALN
description: The foreign policy spokesman of the Social Democratic Party's parliamentary group says that if the United States Senate does not vote in favor of the second nuclear arms treaty, NATO's decision to place intermediate nuclear missiles in Europe will have to be reconsidered.

title: 2 Sentenced in Election Assault
description: Two Communist Workers Party members, who hurled eggs last fall at Representative John B. Anderson of Illinois, the independent Presidential candidate, were sentenced today to 30-day and 25-day jail terms for assault on a Congressman. Sentences were imposed in two separate Federal courts against Esmerejodad Guerrero, 26 years old, and Carlos V. Romero, 27.

title: U.C.L.A. 87, Wash. State 61
description: Kenny Fields, a freshman center, scored 16 points and grabbed 10 rebounds to lead U.C.L.A. to an 87-61 victory over Washington State.

title: Zimbabwean Official Assails Takeover of Newspapers
description: Home Affairs Minister Joshua Nkomo, leader of the minority wing in Zimbabwe's ruling coalition, today condemned the Government's takeover of Zimbabwe's main newspapers as an attempt by the dominant faction to control the news media.

title: HUMAN GROWTH HORMONE MADE BY BACTERIA: TESTS IN PATIENTS NEXT STEP IN
description: SEVERAL DISEASES By HAROLD M. SCHMECK Jr.

title: N.B.A. Owners Split On $16 Million Bid For Club in Canada
description: A reported $16 million offer to put a National Basketball Association franchise in Vancouver next season has drawn mixed reaction from the league owners.

title: Search Curb Placed On Parole Officers
description: A Federal judge's order limiting the authority of New York State's parole officers to search the homes of convicts who are free on parole went into effect yesterday, and officials said it was being followed throughout the state.

title: 'HEAVENS GATE' ACCENTS STUDIOS' WOES
description: LOS ANGELES SHAKEN by a decline in movie attendance, runaway costs and a realization that their industry had recently let a young director, Michael Cimino, spend $36 million on one movie, ''Heaven's Gate,'' while exercising virtually no control over him, Hollywood film studios are retrenching and having self-doubts these days after more than five years of euphoric optimism.

title: Advising And Rejecting
description: The Senate has customarily taken the attitude that a President is entitled to choose his own official family; hence it has not often exhibited a stern view of its constitutional duty to ''advise and consent'' on cabinet nominations. But maybe this is a year when even a Republican-controlled Senate will decide to get tough.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: George Eliot did not have one, but William Faulkner did. So did Proust, Einstein, Schweitzer and Hemingway. And Walter Cronkite still has his. ''I grew it,'' he said, ''to make myself look older, but now one could say that it's outlived its usefulness.''

title: Purdue 81, Michigan 74
description: Russell Cross scored 21 points and Drake Morris and Keith Edmonson added 20 apiece tonight as Purdue handed Michigan its first loss of the season, 81-74, in their Big Ten Conference opener.

title: MIDDLETOWN,Pa.
description: There is a great deal of hustle and bustle, but in the gray chill of a winter's day, nothing is really happening at Three Mile Island. Uniformed guards are busy with security. Parking lots overflow, tickets are issued to cars improperly parked, and platoons of workers in hard hats show up promptly for their scheduled shifts. In the bitter cold, tourists shiver on the adjacent banks of the Susquehanna River, their cameras recording the stark architecture an entire nation knows only too well - the four huge cooling towers of the power plant that has become the symbol of nuclear misadventure.

title: Polish Oil Find
description: Experts have determined that crude oil discovered in the Karlino region of northern Poland is of high quality and contains ''no sulphur at all,'' the official Polish news agency reported today. It said the samples were taken yesterday from a depth of 9,171 feet. A fire has been raging around the site for the last 28 days despite efforts to cap a well.

title: REP. LEDERER TO BASE HIS ABSCAM DEFENSE ON ENTRAPMENT ISSUE
description: Representative Raymond F. Lederer of Pennsylvania will argue that he is not guilty of bribery and conspiracy charges in his Abscam case because he was a victim of illegal ''entrapment'' by Federal undercover agents, his lawyer said as the Congressman's trial opened yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WHERE FAMILIES CAN DINE

title: RATES SINK WITH MONEY SUPPLY
description: Interest rates declined as much as 3/4 point yesterday, an extraordinary one-day move fueled by the unexpectedly large $2.8 billion decline in the money supply and hopes that short-term rates would decline further in the near future.

title: Bear Market
description: If you haven't qualified for a Chase Banker Bear, don't despair. If the Santa Bear didn't bring you a Running Bear in jogging suit and shoes, or a Ballerina Bear in tutu, do not flag.

title: GREECE JOINS THE MARKET WITH PROTOCOL AND PERPLEXITY
description: Greece is marking its newly acquired membership in the European Economic Community with Government pomp, persistent disapproval from the left-wing opposition and confusion over new price levels.

title: HOLMES MAY DEFEND TITLE IN MARCH AGAINST BERBICK
description: The Canadian heavyweight champion, Trevor Berbick, will fight Larry Holmes, the World Boxing Council champion, in a title fight, the Toronto promoter Irv Ungerman said today.

title: Vesco Returns to Nassau Home; VESCO RETURNS TO NASSAU HOME
description: The financier Robert L. Vesco, who dropped out of public sight last Tuesday, the day before Bahamian officials served deportation papers at his home, returned to Nassau today, stating that he had been out of town on a vacation. He is seeking political asylum, and a Government spokesman said that granting asylum was still being considered. Mr. Vesco, who has been evading American authorities since 1972, is accused of having looted Investors Overseas Services of $224 million.

title: WORLD BANK LOAN TO INDIA IS HELD UP
description: India appears to have lost a $250 million World Bank credit for the construction of much-needed fertilizer plants because of a controversial Cabinet decision to replace an American consulting company selected by engineering experts.

title: Exxon Leads Output Of Natural Gas
description: The Exxon Corporation led all other American producers of natural gas in 1979 despite a slight decline in output, a Dallas-based trade newsletter said in a survey of the gas industry.

title: Hagler-Antuofermo: Reviving a Rivalry
description: Their names had been linked in rivalry, yet there they were together in a foreign land, Vito Antuofermo helping Marvin Hagler to celebrate.

title: LA SCALA IS DAMAGED A 2D TIME, THIS TIME BY WATER FROM A FAUCET
description: A running faucet flooded a box at La Scala Opera House today, four days after a fire damaged the mezzanine and the royal box. La Scala officials said a cleaner had left the water running in a utility room, and it leaked out and slightly damaged the box's carpet and wooden floor. Firefighters and the police were trying to determine whether an arsonist set the New Year's Day fire that caused $60,000 damage or wheter a member of a group of Japanese tourists who toured the theater Thursday might have accidentally sparked the blaze.

title: RUTH LOWE SANDLER
description: Ruth Lowe Sandler, the composer-lyricist who wrote the 1940's hit ''I'll Never Smile Again,'' died in Toronto General Hospital Saturday.

title: ENOUGH OF THE GAME OF THE
description: NAME To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN NATIONAL BANK reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
TRANSITION AIDE BACKS TRADE UNIT
description: The leadership here of the Reagan transition team has urged the President-elect to maintain the independence of the Office of the United States Trade Representative instead of downgrading it and making it report to the President through the Commerce Department.

title: Mildred Frick Taylor, 75, Served In Assembly From 1946 to 1960
description: Former State Assemblywoman Mildred Frick Taylor, the first woman elected a Republican county chairman in New York State, died Sunday at Clifton Springs Hospital after a long illness.

title: HOW BUSINESS HELPED TO CLEAN UP LONDON
description: p0To the Editor:

title: COLORADO FACES LOSS OF COLLEGE BESET BY DEBTS
description: Colorado Women's College, the state's only institution of higher learning geared to women, is facing severe financial problems that threaten to force the 91-year-old private school to close.

title: NORM STANDLEE,62, STAR OF A STANFORD BACKFIELD;
description: Norm Standlee, a fullback who played for the famed Stanford University football team of 1940 and went on to star for the San Francisco 49ers of the old All American Football Conference, was found dead in a motel room here yesterday. He was 62 years old.

title: MORGAN CUTS PRIME
description: Prospects that interest rates will continue to fall improved yesterday as the Federal Reserve System announced a sharp drop in the nation's money supply and as a leading bank cut its prime lending rate to 20 percent, the lowest level among the nation's major banks.

title: Recovery by Steel Seen
description: The American steel industry is likely this year to continue the recovery it began late in 1980, David M. Roderick, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said today.

title: Wyoming Football Coach Given Incentive to Stay
description: The University of Wyoming has named its offensive coordinator, Al Kincaid, as its new head football coach and has signed him to a pact that will withhold nearly 20 percent of his salary until he completes his three-year contract.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 20.50-21.50** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Hunts to Purchase Terra Silver Claims
description: Terra Mining and Exploration Ltd. said it had agreed to sell a 50 percent royalty interest in some of its silver-mining claims and leases in the Northwest Territories to the Procan Exploration Company, a Canadian partnership owned by the Hunt brothers, Herbert, Lamar and Bunker of Texas.

title: Bendix Is Awarded $16 Million in Suit
description: A Federal judge has recommended that the Government be ordered to pay more than $16 million in damages to the Bendix Corporation for an infringement of a 1952 patent for fuel control device for jets, the company said.

title: LIMITED CUTS ADVISED IN FEDERAL TRAVEL
description: A study by the Office of Management and Budget has found potential savings in Government travel costs of $100 million, but officials say that large travel budget cuts advocated by aides to President-elect Ronald Reagan would not be attainable.

title: Neil Simon's 'Pictures' Ending Run on Sunday
description: Neil Simon's comedy ''I Ought to Be in Pictures'' will close Sunday after the matinee at the Eugene O'Neill Theater. The play, which will have given a total of 326 performances on Broadway, was produced by Emanuel Azenberg. Dick Latessa, Bernice Massi and Valerie Landsburg make up the cast of three.

title: TITAN STUDY IS SAID TO FIND MISSILE SAFE
description: An Air Force team has concluded that the nation's Titan 2 missiles are basically safe, but can be made safer, Congressional sources said today.

title: India Court Tells Bihar to Hasten Investigation Against Policemen
description: India's Supreme Court directed the northern state of Bihar today to speed up its investigation of the policemen who are alleged to have deliberately blinded 31 prisoners awaiting trial.

title: OLD SCHOOLS ARE A NEW RESOURCE
description: SCHOOL closings have turned into a nationwide epidemic. As enrollments continue to drop, local districts, already under fiscal pressure, rush to board up, rent or sell surplus school buildings. The current estimate offered by Educational Facilities Laboratories, a nonprofit agency that studies school utilization, is that by the end of the 1980's some 10,000 schools may have been closed. Only the Southern sunbelt with its still growing population remains largely unaffected.

title: 52 VICTIMS OF AMERICAN FOREIGN POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: The Census Bureau And Its Ad Campaign
description: The Bureau of the Census got 64.7 million of the 1980 mailed questionnaires completed and returned. But in 1970 only 33.1 million came back.

title: MEXICAN PRESIDENT AND REAGAN PLEDGE CLOSE RELATIONSHIP
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan joined President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico today in a pledge to establish a ''personal relationship'' as the basis for easing tensions and renewing friendship between Mexico and the United States.

title: Rapist-Robber Given 25 Years in Jailbreak
description: A convicted rapist and robber was sentenced to 25 years to life yesterday for a 1979 jailbreak in which he sexually assaulted a woman and held a man and his family hostage.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Cannon Mills Company said it had agreed to buy the assets and certain liabilities of the Beacon Manufacturing Company, the blanket manufacturing division of National Distillers and Chemical Corporation, for an undisclosed purchase price.

title: FREE SATURDAYS ISSUE IN POLISH TALKS
description: Lech Walesa, head of Poland's independent trade union, and Deputy Prime Minister Mieczyslaw Jagielski met for four hours today but failed to come to an agreement over the union's demand that all Saturdays be declared nonworking days starting this month.

title: TOYOTA LIFTS PRICES AN AVERAGE OF 2.7%
description: Toyota Motor Sales USA Inc. said today that the list prices of Toyota cars and trucks were going up by an average 2.7 percent, or $171.

title: 16 Judges Come to City In Effort to Cut Backlog
description: Sixteen judges who were reassigned to the State Supreme Court in New York City to cut backlogs of cases began presiding at trials yesterday.

title: ...NEVERTHELESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Interco Net Up 17%
description: Interco Inc., a St. Louis-based manufacturer and retailer of footwear and apparel for men and women, reported yesterday that earnings and sales in the third fiscal quarter ended Nov. 30 rose 17 percent from the comparable period in 1979. Interco, which is also a diversified general merchandise retailer and furniture manufacturer, said that net income in the latest quarter jumped to $33 million, or $2.02 a share, from $28.2 million, or $1.98 a share, in 1979. Sales advanced to $607 million from $519.2 million.

title: Steam Rises From Volcano
description: Light, hazy steam rose from Mount St. Helens today and a Forest Service spotter plane reported that no glow was visible in the volcano's crater. Occasional minor seismic activity has been recorded at the mountain since Friday and scientists said the volcano's latest dome-building stage could be over.

title: SALVADOR FARM PROGRAM IS DESCRIBED AS ENDURING
description: El Salvador's land redistribution program is described by American advisers helping to carry it out as one of the most extensive ever attempted in Latin America.

title: Rosen Has Heart Surgery
description: Al Rosen, the 56-year-old Houston Astro general manager, remained in Methodist Hospital's intensive-care unit today after open-heart surgery. He had chest pains several weeks ago and an examination revealed a blockage in the coronary artery, a club spokesman said.

title: House Ruled Out as Link To Slain Children in Atlanta
description: An abandoned house where searchers had found children's clothing, axes, shovels, and two Bibles nailed open to a wall was ruled out today as a link to the mystery of 15 slain or missing black children.

title: ANGUISH IS DESCRIBED IN DIARY OF TOURETTE SUFFERER
description: FOR 35 of the 60-odd years that Joseph Bliss strained to keep his mysterious illness a secret, he wrote down his observations of his own strange behavior - how he would uncontrollably and repeatedly hiss and make loud nasal noises, grind his teeth, blink and squeeze his eyelids, twist his neck and torso, jerk his arms and legs, twitch his nose, click his tongue, pluck at his clothing, tear paper or stab at it with a pencil point and become plagued by phantom fixations, such as the perception of a palpable bond between his eyes and the eyes of any person he might be speaking to.

title: JAMES F. MAHER
description: James F. Maher, former manager of the communications room of The New York Times, died Saturday at Southside Hospital in Bay Shore, L.I. He was 63 years old and lived in Islip Terrace, L.I.

title: City Unions Help T.W.U. to Pay Fine
description: Most of the city's uniformed service unions presented a check for $25,000 to Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union to help pay a $950,000 fine for its 11-day strike last April.

title: Campaign Promise on Reduced Salary Creates Problem
description: In Rhode Island, John Nolan Jr. is sticking to a campaign promise he made last fall, when he was elected welfare director of the Town of Burrillville. He said he would accept only $1,000 of the $10,000 annual salary because the job should be only a part-time one - if, indeed, it should exist at all.

title: STOCKS RISE SHARPLY AS PRIME SLIPS
description: Blue-chip and consumer stocks and those sensitive to interest rates led a rousing market rally in heavy trading yesterday. The Dow Jones industrials jumped 19.88 points, to 992.66.

title: Lane Bryant Plans A New Magazine For Large Women
description: Lane Bryant Inc., which has been selling clothing to larger women since 1900, will begin publishing next month a magazine aimed at those customers.

title: Nairobi Hotel Back in Business After New Year's Eve Explosion
description: The Norfolk Hotel reopened here today after a New Year's Eve bomb explosion that devastated part of the building and killed 15 people.

title: Lynn, Fisk Dispute New Red Sox Pacts
description: With George Steinbrenner continuing to show interest in obtaining Fred Lynn from the Boston Red Sox, another development arose yesterday in the Lynn and Carlton Fisk cases. The Red Sox, it was learned, sent 1981 contracts to Lynn and Fisk two days past the stipulated deadline and the players, as a result, could be declared free agents.

title: CABINET HEARINGS CAST A LONG SHADOW
description: The process of confirming Cabinet nominees, which begins on Capitol Hill tomorrow, usually results in quick approval of the President's choices with a minimum of conflict. But the confirmation process serves a variety of purposes, and can influence the policies and conduct of the nominees for years to come.

title: Bani-Sadr Kin Treated,
description: New York Hospital Says

title: bySteve Lohr; Investor in Cannon Bid
description: Last Friday, when it was announced that a group of private investors had offered to buy the Cannon Mills Company for $376 million in cash, only two members of the group were identified. One was a name instantly recognized by those who follow business news: Harold S. Geneen, the retired board chairman of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. The other was less well known: Ira J. Hechler of New York, a wealthy private investor.

title: Weyerhaeuser Sets Accord With Amoco
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company has granted the Amoco Production Company oil and natural gas exploration rights to 2.8 million acres of land in western Washington and Oregon, a Weyerhaeuser spokesman said.

title: Fordham 62, Army 60
description: Mark Murphy scored 6 straight points down the stretch as Fordham held off an Army rally to beat the Cadets, 62-60, tonight.

title: Pacific Exchange Volume
description: The Pacific Stock Exchange Inc. said today that equities trading volume on the exchange rose 26 percent in 1980, to a record 450 million shares from 357 million in 1979. Options volume increased 45 percent, to 5.5 million contracts from 3.8 million.

title: British Concerns Buy Aston Martin
description: Two British companies have acquired control of Aston Martin Lagonda Ltd., the small prestigious car maker. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: Index; International

title: National Vote for President
Talking Business with Schipper on Energy Conservation; The Bonanza Of Fuel Savings
description: The Reagan administration is expected to push strongly for policies to increase domestic energy supplies. Top energy advisers have described their strategy as ''production, production, production.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This has been a meeting of friends.'' - President Jose Lopez Portilla after conferring with President-elect Ronald Reagan in Ciudad Juarez. (A1:6.

title: Tandem Submits Fox Film Proposals
description: Tandem Productions Inc., a television concern owned by two producers, Norman Lear and Bud Yorkin, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had submitted two shareholder proposals to the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation for action at the next Fox Film stockholders meeting

title: SENATORS MEET ON SALVADORAN AID
description: Within hours of becoming chairman of a key subcommittee, Senator Jesse Helms, a severe critic of President Carter's Latin American policies, held a hearing today on resuming military aid to El Salvador.

title: MUSIC: HARVEY PHILLIP'S TUBA
description: HARVEY PHILLIPS'S brave crusade on behalf of the tuba registered only minimal gains at Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday afternoon. Whether because of the chill in the weather or the coldness of the music public, the size of his audience for this program of contemporary music was modest. It seems a shame, because Mr. Phillips combines a richness of tone with litheness of articulation that is remarkable.

title: Peru Lifts Price Of Fuel, Food
description: The Peruvian Government increased the price of fuel and basic foodstuffs today by an average of 48 percent as part of a policy to eliminate subsidies.

title: FRANK C. MCCANN, 70, STONE JOB CONTRACTOR ON CHRYSLER BUILDING
description: Frank C, McCann, a cut-stone contractor whose companies provided the exterior of many notable buildings in the New York area, died Sunday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J., at the age of 70. He lived in South Orange, N.J.

title: IRAN SAYS ITS TROOPS HAVE MOUNTED COUNTEROFFENSIVE
description: President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, under fire from his clerical opponents for his handling of the war with Iraq, declared today that the Iranian Army had gone on its long-awaited counteroffensive.

title: People
description: * Donald F. Riesett has been elected senior vice president at W.B. Doner & Company, Baltimore.

title: Credit Control Abuse Seen
description: Many credit card companies and retail stores used last year's credit controls to increase profits rather than restrict credit as the Government wanted, a House panel contended today.

title: 'FRANKENSTEIN' CLOSES AT THE PALACE
description: 813''Frankenstein,'' Victor Gialanella's new play that opened Sunday night to poor reviews at the Palace Theater, has closed after one performance. The play was originally capitalized at $1.25 million, but in the end cost a reported $2 million, a record for a nonmusical on Broadway.

title: THE DEVELOPING NATIONS' PLACE IN THE GLOBAL ECONOMIC ORDER
description: To the Editor:

title: SHORTS: A LOOK THAT'S MATURED
description: The fashion trend that is most likely to succeed in the months ahead is that toward shorts: Walking shorts, which is what Bermudas are being called; flaring shapes, puffy shorts much like rompers or bloomers. Some are in silks, some in sturdy cottons. Some are casually tailored for day, others are frivolous and flippy and meant for evenings, especially evenings at home.

title: 2 Killed by Gunman In Brooklyn Store
description: The owner of a Brooklyn grocery store and a neighborhood friend were shot and killed yesterday by a gunman who came into the store, opened fire and then escaped in a waiting car.

title: EXCERPTS FROM GUIDELINES ON COVERT OPERATIONS
description: Following are excerpts from the guidelines issued today by the Justice Department to govern undercover operations conducted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation:

title: Filipino Gold Miners, Defying Ban, Stage Strike
description: Defying a Government ban on strikes, thousands of gold miners walked off their jobs today in a wage dispute. It was one of the largest job actions in the Philippines since martial law was imposed eight years ago.

title: Ex-Aide of Rep. Kelly Tells Court Of Being Detained in Drug Case
description: The Abscam trial of former Representative Richard Kelly resumed today with a former aide testifying that he once was detained in Bolivia on suspicion of drug dealings, although he was never charged, and had worked on a case with Federal drug agents.

title: GEORGE BORMUTH
description: George Bormuth, an organizer for Lions Club International, died yesterday at the age of 88 at his home here.

description: Source: First Boston Corp.

title: The Economy
description: Interest rates continued to back away from their recent peaks as a decline in the nation's basic money supply prompted Morgan Guaranty, the nation's fifth-largest bank, to cut its prime lending rate 1 1/2 points, to 20 percent. The Federal Reserve reported that the money supply dropped $2.8 billion in the week ended Dec. 24, easing pressure for higher rates to curb demand for money. Economists, while expressing hope that the worst of the interest surge was over, still counseled caution. (Page A1.)

title: Judge Denies Trial Request For Suspect in Iowa Deaths
description: A Federal District judge today denied a defense motion asking that Joseph Paul Franklin be tried on state murder charges before he is tried on Federal civil rights charges in the deaths of two young black men.

title: NIATROSS RETIRED TO STUD
description: Niatross, the world champion pacer who won more than $2 million and became the fastest horse in harness racing history, was formally retired to stud today at Castleton Farm near Lexington.

title: MUSIC: FREDERICK ZLOTKIN, CELLIST
description: LAST season Frederick Zlotkin made his New York solo recital debut with the six unaccompanied Bach cello suites - an austere gesture on the part of a young musician who obviously means serious business. On Saturday night, Mr. Zlotkin presided over a more conventional program at the 92d Street Y, one calculated to show his capabilities in a variety of styles from the Baroque through Romantic showpieces to the early 20th century.

title: QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
description: Q. Why are satellites always launched from Cape Canaveral?

title: Robinson Is Reportedly Candidate to Manage Giants
description: Frank Robinson, who became major league baseball's first black manager when he was named to pilot the Cleveland Indians in October 1974, is reportedly being considered as the next manager of the San Francisco Giants.

title: Test Coming in February
description: "I think that here the church is a reflection of what is happening in our society, particularly at the level of Government," said Enrique Miret Magdalena, a liberal lay activist who heads the Association of Small Businessmen. "And, as socially and politically the country is goint to the right, too." An important test will come in February when Vicente Cardinal Enrique y Tarancon, the Archbishop of Madrid, steps down as president of the Episcopal Conference. In the hierarchy's top job since 1972, the 73-yearold prelate has been an open-minded conciliator among the Spanish church's several families; he sheltered foes of the Franco regime and tried to keep his bishops out of politics in the tense months after the dictator's death in November 1975. Since King Juan Carlos has renounced the privilege Franco had of naming bishops, the Vatican's influence in the Episcopal Conference has steadily grown, and Cardinal Enrique y Tarancon's successor will doubtless have the Pope's approval. Both conservatives and liberals have their favorites, but one leading compromise candidate acceptable to Rome is Jose Delicado Baeza, the 53-year-old Bishop of Valladolid. Cardinal Enrique y Tarancon successfully opposed the establishment of an Italian-style Christian Democratic party in Spain, which would have overtly involved the church in politics, and he muffled rightist clerical protests against the democratic Constitution that was adopted in 1978. The Constitution disestablished the church, but it notes the special place of the Catholic faith. However, one strong faction within Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez's governing Union of the Democratic Center considers itself "Christian Democratic," and, in Parliament, has successfully defended the maintenance of subsidies to church schools.

title: THE POLICE SEE NO TIE IN ATTACKS ON BLACKS IN CITY AND ELSEWHERE
description: Chief of Detectives James T. Sullivan of New York City said yesterday that there was no link between recent attacks on black men in Buffalo and Rochester and the fatal stabbing of three black men and a Hispanic man in midtown Manhattan on Dec. 22.

title: Mystery Patient's First Message: 'Leave Me Alone'
description: A stroke victim, given the name Long John Silver because hospital officials haven't been able to learn his real name, knew just what to say when he received a Christmas gift enabling him to ''talk'' via a computer.

title: Jewish Music Archive Opened to Students; Jewish Music Archive Opened to Students
description: An archive of Eastern European and Ladino music has been made available to students and researchers by the Martin Steinberg Center of the American Jewish Congress.

title: GUIDELINES FOR OPERATIONS OF F.B.I. PERMIT BRIBES, BUT BAR ENTRAPMENT
description: The Justice Department issued guidelines today under which the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation could, in some cases, authorize undercover agents to offer a bribe to a public official ''even though there is no reasonable indication that that particular individual has engaged, or is engaging'' in a crime.

title: FIRST PENN TO SETTLE BANK SUITS
description: The First Pennsylvania Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to pay $11.2 million in settlement of various shareholder suits, including 17 class actions, that were brought in opposition to terms of a rescue plan for a financially troubled banking subsidiary.

title: Turkey's Military Leader Vows to Restore Democracy
description: The head of the military junta today opened a year of celebration of the centennial of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk by pledging that the armed forces would carry out their ''historic task'' of restoring ''the supremacy of the state authority and its laws'' and ''the re-establishment of a functioning democracy and its institutions.''

title: Canada Draws On Standby Credit
description: Canada withdrew $900 million from its standby credit with a banking consortium and sold 82,500 ounces of gold, worth $54 million, last month to support the battered Canadian dollar, the finance department announced today.

title: ELECTROSOUND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $214,000 or 22 cents a shr tax credit... C-Including $419,000 or 32 cents a shr tax credit

title: 18-YEAR-OLDS START TO REGISTER FOR DRAFT
description: Eighteen-year-old men began registering for military service yesterday in the second nationwide sign-up since registration was reinstituted last year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, Pittsburgh, has named Charles L. May controller.

title: SALVADOR TROOPS ATTACKING GUERRILLAS ON VOLCANO SLOPE
description: The army was engaged today in an operation against suspected leftist guerrilla bases on the slopes of a forested volcano, 13 miles north of San Salvador, the capital.

title: COMMUTERS SUFFER EFFECTS OF COLD WAVE
description: In bone-penetrating cold, the first workweek of the New Year started yesterday with only 23 percent of Long Island Rail Road trains on time during the morning rush. Nearly 100 cars - triple the normal number - were laid up on Conrail's Harlem, Hudson and New Haven lines.

title: Braniff Offers Discounts
description: Braniff International said today that it would offer discount fares 50 percent below the normal coach price on some flights from Texas to Canada beginning Jan. 18. The airline said the discounts, on flights from Houston and Dallas-Fort Worth to Toronto and Montreal, would be offered through Feb. 28. Reservations must be made 14 days before travel and tickets purchased within seven days of making reservations.

title: Oregon State 61, Arizona 49
description: Steve Johnson scored 32 points and led undefeated Oregon State to a 61-49 victory over Arizona in a Pacific-10 game tonight.

title: STAGE: 'BEYOND THERAPY BY DURANG AT PHOENIX
description: IN the plays of Christopher Durang, characters suddenly speak their minds and act out their inhibitions: children talk back to parents, a nun hectors her students and the maid is the boss of the house. In Mr. Durang's new comedy, ''Beyond Therapy,'' a man and a woman begin, and almost end, their courtship by literally dashing cold water in each other's faces.

title: GATT Reports Pacts Accepted
description: Twenty-six industrial countries and 19 developing nations have accepted one or more of the international agreements worked out in talks to reduce nontariff barriers to world trade, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade announced today.

title: YARDNEY ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: The company is listed on the Boston Stock Exchange

title: Safe-Deposit Boxes Looted in Queens
description: Burglars broke through a ceiling of a Chase Manhattan Bank branch in Little Neck, Queens, over the weekend to loot several safedeposit boxes.

title: VOTER TOTAL LOWEST SINCE TRUMAN-DEWEY
description: The voter turnout in last November's Presidential election was the lowest in 32 years, according to an official count released yesterday by the Federal Election Commission.

title: FOOD FAIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 22
description: B-Including tax credits of $1,047,000 for the latest first qr and $18,000 for the previous first qr; the company is listed on the Pacific Boston and Philadelphia stock exchanges

title: EMBROIDERED ROSE
description: To the Editor:

title: BONN REPORTEDLY AGREES TO BACK LOANS TO POLAND
description: West Germany has agreed to guarantee $153 million in loans to Poland in an effort to help Warsaw pay for badly needed food and industrial raw materials in the first half of 1981, Government sources said today.

title: INTERCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Shr earnings are fully diluted; results for the latest periods include operations of Ethan Allen Inc, acquired as a purchase on Jan 28, 1980

title: Saudis Pray for an End To an Unusual Drought
description: King Khalid and thousands of his subjects prayed today for rain to relieve Saudi Arabia from a unusually long drought, the Saudi press agency said.

title: Digging Stops at Tar Pits
description: Excavations at the La Brea Tar Pits, graveyard of many prehistoric beasts, were halted yesterday for lack of money. But Stuart Ritter, executive vice president of the Natural History Foundation, said a private source had shown interest in providing major funding for the work.

title: Ashland Oil Raises Prices of Asphalt
description: Ashland Oil Inc. joined the growing list of petroleum companies that have increased the price of asphalt, the road-paving and roofing material produced as part of the oil refining process.

title: TOWN & COUNTRY MOBILE HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: Mysteries of the Deep Edited by Joseph J. Thorndike Jr. American Heritage, New York. $34.95.

title: G.O.P. SEEKING PAPERS ON HAIG FOR HEARING USE
description: Senator Charles H. Percy, the new chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, said today that Republicans on the committee wanted the executive branch to turn over the tapes and files on Alexander M. Haig Jr. that Democrats have requested for use in the confirmation hearings on Mr. Haig's nomination to be Secretary of State.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, the Advertising column in Business Day last Wednesday incorrectly stated the billings of the SSC&B advertising agency.

title: Reagan Rated No. 1 Celebrity Ahead of Two Singers
description: Since 1939, Earl Blackwell has been keeping track of the goings and comings of celebrities, with his Celebrity Service supplying subscribers with up-to-the-minute data on world notables.

title: More Murder in El Salvador
description: The cold-blooded murder of the peasant leader of El Salvador's land reform institute and of two key American advisers can best be answered by carrying on with the program to which they gave their lives. Some two-thirds of the country's peasants have been given ownership of the land they till, but the extremes of the left and right are resisting reform at every turn because they know it to be the only remaining hope for achieving a stable democratic society.

title: Phillips Warned on Raids Of Oilers' Coaching Staff
description: The Houston Oilers' new head coach, Eddie Biles, today said he would fight the possible raiding of his coaching staff by the dismissed head coach, Bum Phillips, in the event that Phillips gets another job.

title: U.S. Files Suits On Gasoline Pricing
description: The United States Department of Energy said it had begun legal action to recover $34 million from the Quaker State Oil Refining Corporation and $25.9 million from the United Refining Company for alleged violations of Federal pricing regulations.

title: Esposito Is Undergoing Some Strange Setbacks
description: It was Robert Burns who spoke of ''the best laid plans o' mice and men,'' and yesterday Phil Esposito became the latest victim of the poet's maxim. The Ranger center had to cancel his vacation.

title: Books of The Times
description: <TD WIDTH=2

title: DEC. 11-20 AUTO SALES DOWN 22%
description: Sales of domestic cars fell 22 percent in mid-December from the comparable period in 1979, with only the Chrysler Corporation showing an increase, according to company reports.

title: REDSKINS OUST PARDEE
description: Coach Jack Pardee, whose Washington Redskins suffered through a disappointing 6-10 season, was discharged today because of differences with General Manager Bobby Beathard. No successor was named immediately.

title: Air Florida Shares
description: The American Financial Corporation said in a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it planned to sell up to 1.7 million shares of Air Florida System Inc. common stock. It said it had already sold 1,050,000 shares to Salomon Brothers, which had agreed tentatively to come in on the underwriting with L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg & Towbin. According to the filing, American Financial holds the equivalent of 2,205,000 shares, or 19.1 percent of those outstanding.

title: DOCTOR SAYS MARINE WAS DRIVEN INSANE
description: A defense psychiatrist testified today that Pvt. Robert R. Garwood of the Marine Corps was driven insane by watching the execution of South Vietnamese prisoners, some forced to play Russian roulette, and that that caused him to collaborate with the enemy.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt NUNS AND SOLDIERS. By Iris Murdoch. 505 pages. Viking. $14.95.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: GENEVA IF tests of the first doses of an experimental leprosy vaccine are successful, they may mark the beginning of the end of a disease that has maimed millions and made them the victims of deep-seated prejudice and aversion since ancient times.

title: JURY SEES NOTE BY MRS. HARRIS SAYING SHE WANTED TO BE CREMATED
description: Jean S. Harris, who is accused of murdering Dr. Herman Tarnower last March 10, left a note before she drove to New York from Virginia that day saying, ''I wish to be immediately cremated and thrown away,'' according to testimony today in Westchester County Court.

title: by Robert Metz; Market Place  Robert Metz; Analysts Divide On GAF's Plans
description: THE GAF Corporation surprised and evidently pleased Wall Street with its decision to restructure the company as announced last week. The shares, unchanged yesterday at 13 3/4, have climbed more than 35 percent from their levels prior to the decision to simplify the business.

title: Lisbon's Premier-Designate Names His Cabinet
description: Prime Minister-designate Francisco Pinto Balsemao tonight announced the formation of Portugal's 13th government since the 1974 revolution.

title: DISAPPEARANCE OF A FINNISH STUDENT LEAVES FRIENDS IN SCARSDALE BAFFLED
description: It has been almost a month now since Juha Uronen, an exchange student from Finland who was spending his senior year at Scarsdale High School, left the home of his host family on what seemed to be a typical school morning.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JANUARY 6, 1981
description: International A vow to revive American-Mexican ties was made by President-elect Ronald Reagan and President Jose Lopez Portillo. They greeted each other at the Bridge of Friendship linking Ciudad Juarez and El Paso, pledged to establish a ''personal relationship'' as the basis for easing differences and held a 70-minute meeting, which a Reagan aide termed ''enormously successful.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) The three American hostages in the Iranian Foreign Ministry successfully resisted attempts to move them 11 days before they were transferred on Saturday to a secret place in Teheran to join some of the 49 other captives, the State Department said. (A1:1.)

title: Mortgage Cost Up 33% in '80
description: Mortgage payments grew 33 percent in 1980 because of rising housing costs and double-digit mortgage rates, the Chicago Title Insurance Company reported today.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: NEW YORK METS (NL) - Signed Dyar M iller, pitcher, to one-year contract. BASKETBALL NATIONAL BASKETBALL ASSOCIA- T ION - Named Richard Dorfman director o f broadcasting.

title: 3 RE-ENROLLED AT WHITE SCHOOL AS JUDGES CLASH AGAIN IN LOUISANA
description: Threatened with arrest by a state court judge if they refused, the authorities at all-white Buckeye High School today re-enrolled three white students who had been ordered by a Federal judge to attend a racially mixed school as part of an areawide desegregation plan.

title: A GIFT TO NEEDIEST CASES REFLECTS CONCERN ABOUT HOSTAGES IN IRAN
description: Contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund often reflect a concern over world conflict and tension as well as for the distress of one's less fortunate neighbors at home.

title: Mother Threw Baby To Death, Police Say
description: An hours-old baby was thrown 18 floors to her death in a Brooklyn housing project, the police said. Sgt. Lancelot Smith of the Housing Authority police said the infant fell 18 floors after being tossed from an apartment window yesterday at 131 Moore Street in the Williamsburg section.

title: COMMON CONCERN
description: To the Editor:

title: Famous Amos President
description: Sid Ross is one of those seemingly rare individuals who can honestly say that his business is his pleasure. ''I've always been a chocolate chip cookie freak,'' he explained in a telephone interview from his office in Van Nuys, Calif.

title: California Mortgage Rate
description: The Gibralter Savings and Loan Association of Los Angeles, a unit of the Gibralter Financial Corporation, reduced its prime mortgage rate yesterday to 15 1/4 percent from a range of 16 percent to 18 percent on various loan amounts.

title: SKIER DIES IN SWISS AVALANCHE
description: A series of avalanches in the Valais region of Switzerland isolated Alpine villages today and killed a skier.

title: D'AMATO AND DODD ARE SWORN IN AS 2 NEW SENATORS IN WASHINGTON
description: The new Senators from New York and Connecticut were sworn in today. Mayor Koch, a Democrat, flew in to embrace Alfonse M. D'Amato, the new Republican Senator from New York, and Christopher J. Dodd, wearing his late father's pocket watch, took the Democratic seat that had once been his father's.

title: SALVADOR LAND 'REFORM'
description: Jr. BOSTON - The tragic assassination of two American advisers to the El Salvador land-reform program and the head of the country's Institute for Agrarian Transformation is a further warning that the cornerstone of United States policy there is crumbling.

title: Polish Institution Giving First Degree to an American
description: Poland's Christian Academy of Theology had never awarded an honorary degree to an American, but today it will award one to the Rev. Billy Graham, the evangelist who has so many honorary doctorates - a couple of dozen -that he doesn't bother to list them all.

title: U.S. ENVOY TO SOVIET DEFENDS SANCTIONS
description: Thomas J. Watson Jr., the American Ambassador here, said today that the United States should maintain trade sanctions against the Soviet Union until the Kremlin takes steps toward withdrawing its forces from Afghanistan.

title: Steel Output Up 4.9%
description: Steel production rose to 2.3 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of 4.9 percent from the previous week's 2.2 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: How Extreme at Interior?
description: Environmental groups fiercely oppose Ronald Reagan's nomination of James Watt as Secretary of the Interior. They view him as a front man for business interests that would destroy environmental safeguards and open the vast Federal lands to rapid exploitation.

title: EASTERN AIR OFFERING COAST FARE DISCOUNT
description: Eastern Airlines announced yesterday that, beginning tomorrow, it would give passengers on its East Coast air shuttles coupons good for a 50 percent discount on its nonstop flights between New York and California.

title: UGANDA REQUESTING KENYAN AID
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 5 President Milton Obote of Uganda appealed today to Kenya's President, Daniel arap Moi, for assistance to aid the reconstruction of his country's economy, the Kenyan news agency reported. The two East AfricaN LEADERS MET FOR THE FIRST TIME SINCE Mr. Obote took office last month.

title: NEW YORK'S WESTERN TIER TRIES TO COPE WITH ECONOMIC WOES
description: Residents of this port and manufacturing city are ''talking proud'' about its assets and future, its effort to improve its image and, until their team lost last Saturday to the San Diego Chargers in the National Football League playoffs, the achievements of the Buffalo Bills.

title: Persico Trial Put Off On Bribery Charges
description: The pending trial of Carmine Persico on bribery-conspiracy charges was put off yesterday until May 11 after attorneys for both sides were replaced. The trial had been set for Feb. 17.

title: Buffalo Forge
description: The Buffalo Forge Company said that its directors had instructed the company's management and investment bankers to examine and report on the unsolicited tender offer that the Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation said last week it intended to make for Buffalo Forge common stock.

title: REAGAN'S LIAISON CHIEF ON CAPITOL HILL TO FOCUS ON HARMONY AS HIS PRIORITY
description: ''The Hill is a very unforgiving place,'' observed Max L. Friedersdorf, who will be the chief link with the Congress for the Reagan White House. ''If you make one mistake, they remember it forever; if you do something right, you never hear about it.''

title: Virginia 88, Delaware 69
description: Ralph Sampson and Jeff Lamp combined for 47 points as unbeaten Virginia overcame a sluggish start to defeat Delaware, 88-69, tonight.

title: Union College Dean to Take Over at Hollins
description: Hollins College, a predominantly women's school outside Roanoke, Va., has chosen a new president. She's Dr. Paula Brownlee, an organic chemist who has been serving as dean of faculty at Union College in Schenectady, N.Y.

title: uf825Suits for Punitive Damages Are Denied in DC-10 Crash
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that McDonnell Douglas Corporation and American Airlines were not liable for punitive damages sought on behalf of 273 persons killed in a 1979 crash of a DC-10 airliner.

title: Sports of The Times; Hosts to Their Tormentors
description: SEVERAL years ago Harland Svare, then the San Diego Chargers' coach, glanced up at a light fixture in the ceiling of his team's locker room at the Oakland Coliseum.

title: Suicide Victim Suspected In Slayings of Six in Iowa
description: Evidence points to Gene Gilbert, the husband and father, as the killer who shot Bonnie Gilbert and her five children as they slept in a small eastern Iowa farming community, officials said today.

title: First of Denver In Debt Default
description: First of Denver Mortgage Investors said yesterday that it was in default on its bank debt, currently $15.2 million, and added that it might have to seek Federal bankruptcy protection if talks to extend its debt fail.

title: Ford and Canada Set Plant Accord
description: One of three plants operated by the Ford Motor Company in Canada has been saved from possible closing by an agreement with the Canadian Government to ease the requirement to maintain a specific ratio between sales and production of vehicles in Canada.

title: ITALY REJECTS CONDITIONS OF RED BRIGADES FOR SPARING KIDNAPPED OFFICIAL
description: ROME. Jan. 5 - The Italian Government today rejected the conditions of the Red Brigades for sparing the life of a high-ranking magistrate who has been held by the terrorists for three weeks.

title: Cooper Receives 30% Of Crouse-Hinds
description: Cooper Industries, the machinery maker, said that it had received 4.45 million shares, or about 30 percent, of the Crouse-Hinds Company in response to its offer to pay 0.750 of a Cooper share for about a 50 percent interest in the electric equipment company. Cooper, however, cannot purchase the stock until after Jan. 15 and those who sent in shares can withdraw them until then.

title: KENNECOTT'S PROBLEMS PERSIST
description: The Kennecott Corporation, from a look at its balance sheet, has chosen a poor time to undertake the complicated and costly attempt to acquire a major block of stock in the Curtiss-Wright Corporation.

title: Nuclear Plant Plans Dropped
description: Northeast Utilities and the Western Massachusetts Electric Company have dropped plans to build a $2.5 billion nuclear power plant in western Massachusetts because, they say, the region does not need the extra electricity.

title: FRUSTRATIONS OF RESEARCH IN HUNGARY OUTLINED BY HEAD OF SCIENCE ACADEMY
description: BUDAPEST THIS country of only 10 million people, with a reputation of having produced some of the best scientific brains of this century, has some difficulties in making the best use of its best minds, said Dr. Janos Szentagothay, president of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences.

title: Dr. Beth T. Niemi, 38, Economist; Was Specialist in Sex Bias Cases
description: Dr. Beth T. Niemi, associate professor of economics at the Rutgers University Newark College of Arts and Sciences in Newark, died Dec. 22 of complications following surgery. She was 38 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: RECITAL: VIOLIN AND PIANO DUO
description: CORA GORDON, violinist, and Avraham Sternklar, pianist, offered a duo recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday evening, playing music by Dvorak, Schubert and Franck.

title: VENTURE CAPITALIST: A RISE TO RICHES
description: More than ever, as times get tougher, getting rich quick remains the American dream: an idea that sounds the depths of the national imagination. And nowhere in the American economy is the romance of riches as real as in the world of venture capital, where millions can still be made on investments of several thousand dollars.

title: The Washington Star
description: Last year, the American public finally began to regard women for the first time as equals to men, entitled to the same jobs, pay and higher levels of responsibility, according to a new study.

title: EDUCATION 'ANALYSTS' WIN BATTLE IN WAR OF PHILOSOPHY
description: BOSTON AS in Athens, so in America: Philosophers disagree, sometimes with passion. Last week, in a battle fought with virtually every traditional academic weapon short of hemlock, proponents of ''analytic'' philosophy reasserted their control of the Eastern Division of the American Philosophical Association.

title: Keeping Water in Mind
description: Every day a devastating water shortage becomes more likely. New York's reservoir levels have dropped to 35 percent, and only moderate rain and snow is predicted this week.

title: IDENTIFICATION CARD IDEA SHELVED BY A U.S. PANEL
description: After months of intense lobbying and internal dissension, a Federal immigration commission said today that it had decided American workers should not be issued national identification cards. The final vote on the identification proposal was 9 to 6 against the idea, a spokesman for the 16-member Select Commission on Immigration and Refuge Policy said.

title: Suns 113, Hawks 106
description: Len Robinson scored 33 points and Alvan Adams added 24 as Phoenix defeated Atlanta. The victory was the Suns' ninth in their last 10 games.

title: Notre Dame 94, Villanova 65
description: With Tracy Jackson scoring 20 points, Notre Dame crushed Villanova, 94-65, tonight. Jackson hit nine of 11 shots from the floor, pulled down nine rebounds and blocked two shots in leading the Irish to their eighth straight victory since losing to the University of California, Los Angeles, in the season opener.

title: Trudeau Snowbound in Austria
description: Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau of Canada, prevented by bad weather from meeting Chancellor Bruno Kreisky yesterday at Bad Hofgastein, was still trapped by snow today in the ski resort of Lech, a spokesman said. The two leaders spoke by telephone but canceled their meeting to discuss preparations for a conference on economic relations between rich and poor countries.

title: 5 Lemmon Films at the Modern
description: The Museum of Modern Art will honor Jack Lemmon, the actor, Jan. 16 with a marathon in which five of his films will be shown. The films, which span 25 years and show the range of Mr. Lemmon's talent in drama and comedy, are: ''It Should Happen to You'' (1954), ''Some Like It Hot'' (1959), ''Mister Roberts'' (1955), ''The Apartment'' (1960) and ''The China Syndrome'' (1979).

title: PEAK IN 2 WEEKS SEEN
description: The New York City Department of Health said yesterday that the flu that arrived here in November had reached epidemic proportions and that it would probably get worse in the next two weeks.

title: KHOMEINI APPROVES ALGERIAN ROLE IN MOVES TO GAIN HOSTAGES' RELEASE
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini gave his approval last night to Algerian assistance in efforts to release the 52 American hostages, raising new hopes for a solution to the 14-month-old crisis with the United States.

title: WEINBERGER EXPECTS 6-MONTH DELAY FOR RENEWAL OF TALKS ON ARMS CURB
description: Donald T. Regan, Treasury Secretary-designate, predicted today that the economy would decline this year but that ''major improvement'' would occur within 15 months if Presidentelect Ronald Reagan's economic program were adopted.

title: THE NORTHEAST IS WHERE IT'S AT
description: To the Editor:

title: EDUCATING HISPANICS
description: The United States has the fourth-largest Spanish-speaking population of any country in the world. By the end of this decade, people of Spanish-speaking origin, black and white, may constitute the country's largest minority group.

title: DECATUR'S AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: The City; Robber Slays Youth Over Lambskin Coat
description: A Bronx teen-ager was shot and killed and a companion was wounded last night after they refused to hand over their coats to a gang of robbers, the police said.

title: Service
description: Managing an ear-shattering, fume-filled New York garage for drivers who want their cars retrieved immediately and simultaneously can be a nerve-racking living. Maybe that's why there seem to be more and more garage men who have become such experts at driving some of their customers crazy.

title: PSEUDO FOOD: IT LOOKS GOOD ENOUGH TO EAT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- B.H. Fussell is a freelance writer specializing in food. By B.H. FUSSELL

title: British Steel Sees More Cuts
description: Britain's state-owned steel industry may be forced into liquidation if its workers do not accept a management plan requiring further production cuts and layoffs, Ian Macgregor, chairman of the British Steel Corporation, said today.

title: South Alabama 76 Virginia Commonwealth 62
description: John May, who managed only 10 points in three outings against Virginia Commonwealth last season, scored 25 tonight to lead South Alabama to a 76-62 victory over the Rams.

title: Careers; Agriculture Teachers Needed
description: TEACHING, anyone? After years of discouraging reports on jobs for teachers, there are indications of shortages in a few areas, such as physics, mathematics and industrial arts, and there is a continuing critical shortage of vocational agriculture teachers at high school levels, according to a survey by Dr. James Akin. He is associate director of the career planning and placement center at Kansas State University, a noted agricultural school in Manhattan, Kan.

title: RANSBURG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $631,000 for the qr and $961,000 for the yr...C-Including income from discon operations of $247,000 for the qr and $669,000 for the yr

title: LOST SOULS
description: To the Editor:

title: PITTSBURGH BREWING CO reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: This company is listed on the Philadelphia and Boston stock exchanges

title: MARKET GROWTH FOCUS SHIFTS TO MICROCOMPUTER
description: The Tandy Corporation is back in Wall Street's favor, just two years after the company's reputation as a star growth company lay in shambles.

title: Exchange Brokers Suit
description: The Justice Department announced yesterday that it had reached a settlement with two foreign-exchange brokers associations to end a civil antitrust suit that charged them with conspiring to fix commissions on currency trading. The settlement would bar the Forex Association of North America and Foreign Exchange Brokers Association, both of New York, from taking any steps to establish commission rates or to enforce compliance with them.

title: The City; Judge Who Refused Transfer Is Charged
description: A judge who refused to accept a transfer from criminal to civil cases was brought up on charges yesterday by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct.

title: HUNTS ENTER 2D CANADIAN MINING VENTURE
description: The Hunt brothers of Texas bought into another Canadian mining venture today, their second such move in two days.

title: Robinson and Giants Meet About Manager's Post
description: Frank Robinson, former star outfielder and major league baseball's first black manager, met with the San Francisco Giants' owner, Bob Lurie, for two hours today to discuss that club's vacant managerial post.

title: Emirates' Oil Rise Reported
description: The United Arab Emirates, which supplies 1 percent of the petroleum used in the United States, was reported yesterday to have followed Saudi Arabia in raising crude oil prices by $2 a barrel.

title: BRUNELLO DI MONTALCINO IS FIRST ITALIAN WINE TO BE AWARDED THE; by Terry Robards GOVERNMENT GUARANTEE OF QUALITY
