description: ONE of Italy's greatest wines, the celebrated Brunello di Montalcino, has achieved new stature under the Italian wine laws in a move that probably will mean greater scarcity and higher prices for consumers. Brunello, an intensely flavored red made near the medieval village of Montalcino in Tuscany, has become the first Italian wine of any kind to qualify for a government guarantee of quality.

title: Iranian Student Sued In Denver Shooting Case
description: An Iranian student, acquitted last month of charges stemming from the shooting death of one Denver teen-ager and the wounding of two others, is being sued for $750,000 in damages for physical and mental suffering by one of the wounded victims.

title: Richard S. Lessler Joins Canter, Achenbaum
description: Richard Sigmund Lessler, 56 years old, former vice chairman of the Interpublic Group of Companies and of its McCann-Erickson and chairman of Grey Advertising, is the latest marketing brain to join Canter, Achenbaum, Heekin, one of the more highly respected consulting firms in the field.

title: Index; International
description: German veterans come to bury, and to praise, Doenitz A2 Japanese Prime Minister plans trip to 5 Southeast Asia nations A3 Senator Stevens and Chennault meet with Taiwan's President A3 United States reporter is missing in El Savador A3 Around the World A5 Kissinger urges enhanced U.S. military presence in Mideast A6 Iran says its troops are expelling Iraqi invaders A8 Egypt bars Israeli paper's reporters over an article A9 American labor has collected $160,000 for Polish union A12 Government/Politics Extension of child support enforcement provisions urged A14 Three Reagan Cabinet nominees breeze through Senate hearings A16 Prosecutor in upstate inquiry on corruption resigns B4 Reagan panel urges options on mass transit for handicapped B5 General Around the Nation A14 Developer of skyscrapers buys blockfront on Third Avenue B3 Unusual cold has contributed to at least three deaths in city B3 John Durniak joins Times as picture editor B4 Obituaries Irving Abramson, labor lawyer and union organizer B5 Frederick Osborn, Army general and former U.N. deputy B12 PARKING REGULATIONS Alternate-side parking regulations are suspended throughout New York City today because of the snow, the Transportation Department said. The Living Section Food For the American steak, a gilded age is fading C1

title: Miami-London Flights
description: President Carter yesterday approved a Civil Aeronautics Board decision granting a new route between Miami and London's Gatwick Airport to Air Florida, effective Jan. 15. Back-up rights on the route were awarded to World Airways. Those rights can only take effect if Air Florida fails to provide nonstop service on the new route.

title: BOND PRICES ADVANCE SLIGHTLY
description: Bond prices rose slightly yesterday, but some analysts said the large price gains of the last three weeks might be followed by a period of consolidation before prices increased again.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I can give you me.'' - Representative Raymond F. Lederer, Democrat of Pennsylvania, describing, on a v/deotape shown at his Abscam trial, what he could give in exchange for $50,000. (B1:5.)

title: Notes on People; For Sevareid, a Fascinating Peek at a Wartime Secret
description: As a World War II radio reporter, Eric Sevareid was a familiar figure in London, providing firsthand accounts of the blitz and ferreting out exclusives on other military and diplomatic developments.

title: COMMODORE'S PRESIDENT
description: James Finke, 53, has joined Commodore Internatinal Ltd., the country's third-largest personal computer manufacturer after the Tandy Corporation's Radio Shack division and Apple Computer, as president and chief operating officer. As president, he succeeds Jack Tramiel, 52, the founder of the company who continues as chief executive officer. Irving Gould, 61, remains chairman, a position he has held since 1966.

title: The City; Brooklyn Man Held In 18 Robbery Cases
description: Detectives on stake-out duty arrested a 30-year old Brooklyn man on charges he committed 18 robberies at Strauss Stores and McDonald's food outlets in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: DESCENDANT NEW HEAD OF TIFFANY
description: Henry B. Platt, the 56-year-old descendant of Charles L. Tiffany, who founded Tiffany & Company in 1837, yesterday was appointed chairman and chief executive officer of the jewelry and silverware retailer and producer.

title: Soviet Newspapers Assail Japan For 'Unfriendly Act' on 4 Islands
description: Soviet newspapers criticized Japan today for reviving ''unfounded territorial claims'' against the Soviet Union over four islands in the Kurile chain that once belonged to Japan.

title: Cable System Gets 2-Way Services
description: A cable television information retrieval system, allowing a subscriber access to news, shopping and entertainment services, was announced yesterday in Columbus, Ohio, by Warner Amex, its Atari Inc. subsidiary and a Columbus computer services company, Compuserve.

title: Notes on People; Bernstein's Musical Party Draws a Demurrer
description: This week, Leonard Bernstein is in Munich, preparing for a series of telecasts during which he will record concert performances of each act of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde.'' He's also learned that one of his famous fellow conductors doesn't like noisy parties.

title: VERTICAL FOWL ROASTERS
description: SOME cooks, I'm sure, avoid vertical chicken roasters because they are unaccustomed to seeing a chicken standing on its end and find it comical. I'm not sure why I stayed away from them for so long. I didn't laugh at them, nor did I entirely believe the claims that made these devices sound like some kind of revolution in the effortless production of magnificent chicken.

title: Explosives Used in Belgian Theft
description: Thieves blasted open the window of a jewelry shop here today and stole about $9,000 worth of gems, the police said. They said that the burglary, the second in six months at the same shop, was the first time thieves had used explosives to rob a store in Belgium.

title: Hockey Fighters Fined $3,500
description: Thirty-six players from the Boston Bruins and the Colorado Rockies have received fines totaling $3,500 for a bench-clearing melee during a game last Saturday, the National Hockey League confirmed today.

title: TWO AMERICANS TALK WITH TAIWAN LEADER
description: After a three-day trip to Peking, Senator Ted Stevens, the deputy Senate Republican leader, and Anna Chennault, a prominent Republican, met here today with President Chiang Ching-kuo.

title: A C.I.O. ORGANIZER AND LAWYER
description: Irving Abramson, a labor lawyer who was an organizer of the Textile Workers Union of America, died yesterday at his home in Essex Fells, N.J. He was 74 years old.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Hobart Corporation argued before the Ohio Division of Securities that a United States subsidiary of Canadian Pacific Enterprises Ltd., planned to finance its purchase of Hobart with Hobart's own earnings.

title: DE BEERS STEPS UP GEM SEARCH
description: West Africa - De Beers, the dominant force in the world diamond trade, is stepping up the pace of prospecting in the immense desert preserve it controls, through a wholly owned subsidiary, in this disputed territory.

title: AMADAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: B-Net income...C-Including a $14,000 tax credit...D-Including a $112,000 tax credit

title:
RED SMITH;
Landry Gets the Close Ones
description: FOR what's getting to seem a good many years, the National Football League has been aware that, when the Dallas Cowboys go into a game that looks like an even match, it usually winds up in Tom Landry's locker. Though you couldn't tell it by his facial expression, which wouldn't change at a wedding or a hanging, Landry, the Dallas coach, does not approve of losing.

title: ISRAELI SOILDER IS JAILED FOR REFUSING TO SERVE IN OCCUPIED TERRITORY
description: Military judges today sentenced a soldier to jail for a year for refusing to obey an order although the judges said they admired him for repeatedly refusing to serve in occupied Arab territory for reasons of conscience. The soldier, Pvt. Gad Elgazi, has already served a total of 120 days for four previous refusals.

title: LABOR UNREST EMERGES AGAIN IN POLAND OVER LOCAL ISSUES IN TWO REGIONS
description: After a five-week lull, Poland's labor unrest began to emerge again today as workers in the west and southeast threatened to strike.

title: TRACY CAULKINS RULES SWIMMING WORLD
description: Tracy Caulkins spent the New Year's weekend in Gainesville, Fla. She returned home to Nashville about noon Monday, stretched out on a sofa and slept for six hours.

title: FREDERICK OSBORN, A GENERAL, 91, DIES
description: Frederick Henry Osborn, who ran the Army's Information and Education Division as a major general during World War II and then represented the United States at the United Nations in unsuccessful efforts to achieve international control of atomic energy, died Monday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 91 years old and lived in Garrison, N.Y.

title: ACCUSED LENNON SLAYER PLEADS INSANITY AS DEFENSE
description: Mark David Chapman, the 25-year-old Beatles fan accused of fatally shooting John Lennon last month, pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity yesterday morning to a charge of second-degree murder. But his court-appointed attorney said outside the courtroom that he would not contend that Mr. Chapman was unfit to stand trial.

title: Coupons On United
description: United Airlines announced yesterday that it would accept the halffare coupons on coast-to-coast flights to be distributed by Eastern Airlines.

title: NEW COPTER FLIGHTS CONNECT MANHATTAN AND 3 AIRPORTS
description: Regularly scheduled helicopter service connecting Kennedy International, La Guardia and Newark International Airports and the 34th Street Heliport alongside the East River began yesterday. The service was hailed by Governor Carey as ''reaffirmation of the improving economic strength of the region.''

title: HARRIS BANKCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
IRANIANS SAID TO ASK FOR A CLARIFACTION OF U.S. HOSTAGE PLAN
description: Iran has responded to the latest American proposals on freeing the hostages by asking specific questions about financial matters and procedures involved in ending the crisis, Administration officials said today.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of the most celebrated legends in French cooking has to do with dishes named imam bayeldi. It seems that the imam married a beautiful young woman whose dowry was copious vats of pure olive oil. Shortly after the wedding, she came to him and asked him to order more oil. He asked what had happened to her dowry and she replied that she had used it all in cooking his favorite food, eggplant. The imam, the story goes, fainted, which is what imam bayeldi, roughly translated, means.

title: New Kodak Plant
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it planned to begin construction immediately on a $50 million plant to make high-volume Ektaprint office copiers. The factory is planned in connection with attempts to increase overseas sales, it said. The plant, which will be built in the Rochester suburb of Gates, is expected to employ up to 4,000 people.

title: FORWARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
PRESS SECRATARY FOR THE REAGAN WHITE HOUSE
description: When President-elect Ronald Reagan appeared at a Washington news conference yesterday to announce that James Scott Brady would be his White House press secretary, he was asked if he thought Mr. Brady was ''good-looking enough'' for the job.

title: JAZZ: ABENE PIANIST, LEADS BECHET'S TRIO
description: Mr. Dodgion's pure-toned, singing alto, the warmth and fullness of Mr. Laspina's bass and Mr. Abene's probing, selective use of propulsive chords and fills.

title: TREATING THE COLD HANDS AND FEET OF RAYNAUD'S DISEASE
description: THOUGH often the butt of jokes in and out of the bedroom, cold hands and feet are not funny to millions of people - most of them women - who suffer from Raynaud's disease. As temperatures drop both indoors and out with the arrival of winter weather and energy-saving thermostat settings, the fingers and toes of Raynaud's sufferers often turn white with cold.

title: Jury Backs Ford in Trial On Transmission Damage
description: A jury has decided in favor of the Ford Motor Company in the first case alleging harm from defects in automatic transmissions to come to trial on Ford's home ground.

title: Rabbi Bernard Twersky, 67, Dies; Worked With Rabbinical Council
description: Rabbi Bernard Twersky, who was active in Orthodox Jewish programs, died last Wednesday at the age of 67 in Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan.

title: The Iowa Debate, Still
description: What with the holidays and vacation, it's taken us until now to clean out all the political papers that accumulated during the 1980 campaign - a process that discloses an anniversary.

title: CHINESE CITE GAINS IN LIMB ATTACHMENT
description: Since the development of microsurgery techniques in the early 1960's, Chinese hospitals, notably the Sixth People's Hospital in Shanghai, have reattached severed limbs or digits in more than 600 cases, it was reported here today.

title: Pact on Concorde Losses
description: The French Government will cover 90 percent of the losses incurred by Air France over the next two years on its operations of the supersonic Concorde under an agreement signed today with the state-run airline. Under a previous agreement, which expired at the end of last year, the Government's share of the loss was 70 percent.

title: People
description: * Stuart Bernhard has been appointed senior vice president of Times Mirror Magazines, where Louis George Pepe was named publisher of Outdoor Life magazine and Terence E. Moyes, advertising director for Popular Science magazine.

title: Kennecott View On Curtiss-Wright
description: Testimony began in a trial on the Kennecott Corporation's charge that a New Jersey law governing corporate takeovers was unconstitutional and should not be invoked to block its tender offer for stock in the Curtiss-Wright Corporation.

title: Salade de Melon (Melon Salad)
description: 1 small ripe cantaloupe melon 1 small ripe honeydew melon 3 tablespoons wine vinegar, preferably shallot-flavored 2 tablespoons plus 2 teaspoons white Port wine 2 tablespoons plus 2 teaspoons oil, preferably walnut oil 2 tablespoons plus 2 teaspoons heavy cream Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste.

title: Bridge: Rye, World Cup Play Site, Is Host for a Regional Test
description: This year will bring a world championship to the New York metropolitan area for the first time in 17 years. The Bermuda Bowl tourney will be played in Rye, N.Y., in October, and the United States will attempt to retain its title with a six players entirely new to international competition. Two of these, Bud Reinhold of Miami and John Solodar of New York, will take the opportunity for some Rye practice when the Tristate Regional Championships begin there in a week's time.

title: JAZZ: RANDY WESTON
description: RANDY WESTON, the jazz pianist who has lived abroad for many years, at present in France, paid one of his infrequent visits to New York last weekend when he appeared at Salt Peanuts, Greenwich Street at Beach Street, with Jamil Nasser on bass and Scobey Stromann on drums.

title: ABSCAM TRIAL'S TAPE SHOWS LEDERER ACEPTING $50,000
description: Representative Raymond F. Lederer of Pennsylvania is seen taking a paper bag filled with $50,000 in cash from an Abscam undercover agent in a surreptitiously made videotape played yesterday at his trial in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

title: Addendum
description: * Shaeffer & Associates, a new corporate communications consulting company at 445 Park Avenue.

title: Notes on People; BRUCE JENNER MARRIES 'HEE HAW' ENTERTAINER; Hawaiian Wedding
description: Bruce Jenner and Linda Thompson were married in Hawaii Monday, with the ceremony taking place at sunset in a palm-and-coconut-tree setting at the Oahu home of Allan Carr, the film producer.

title: De Paul Beats Maine
description: Playing despite a sprained ankle, Mark Aguirre scored a career-high 47 points tonight and led undefeated and top-ranked De Paul to an 85-77 victory over Maine.

title: 'FRANKENSTEIN' NEARLY CAME BACK TO LIFE
description: ''Frankenstein,'' the $2 million Broadway production that closed Sunday night at the Palace Theater after giving one performance to disappointing reviews, almost came back to life last night at the Palace. Efforts to resurrect ''Frankenstein'' - the most expensive dramatic production in Broadway history - began Monday morning after the play was pronounced dead and continued until 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when the producers finally gave up.

title: Telecom Combines Its U.S. Operations
description: Northern Telecom Ltd., a telecommunications equipment producer, said it had consolidated all its United States manufacturing, marketing and service operations under one company, Northern Telecom Inc.

title: Quaker State Recalling Some Oil Found Defective in Cold Weather
description: The Quaker State Oil Refining Corporation said today that certain shipments of its product could lead to hard starting or possible engine damage in cold weather, and it is asking distributors to return oil that did not meet performance standards.

title: LATE RALLY LIFTS DOW TO 1,004.69
description: The Dow Jones industrial average finished above 1,000 yesterday to reach its highest closing level in more than four years as longneglected blue chips starred in a spectacular final-hour rally.

title: The Region; Nurses End Strike
description: Licensed practical nurses at Waterbury Hospital ended a seven-week strike, voting 102 to 26 to ratify a three-year contract.

title: ANTICORRUPTION AIDE QUITS ONONDAGA POST TO HELP HIS SUCCESSOR
description: Deputy Attorney General Peter D. Andreoli announced his resignation today as special prosecutor in charge of investigating political corruption in Onondaga County.

title: Silas and Gervin Sink Knicks
description: James Silas and George Gervin, who sometimes advertise themselves as the best backcourt in pro basketball, lived up to their claim last night.

title: EGYPT BANS JERUSALEM POST REPORTERS OVER ARTICLE
description: The Israel Ambassador to Egypt met here today with the Egyptian Minister of State for Culture and Information, Mansour Hassan, to discuss an order issued here last night prohibiting reporters of The Jerusalem Post from working in Egypt.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO THWART LOUISIANA JUDGE IN INTEGRATION CASE
description: The Justice Department took today the rare step of seeking contempt-of-court proceedings against a state judge who has defied a Federal judge's desegregation order. The department asked that Judge Richard Lee be found in civil contempt of court for ordering local school officials to disregard an order that three white pupils attend a racially mixed school as part of an areawide desegration plan. The Federal motion was filed in Shreveport late today after the state judge appeared at all-white Buckeye High School this morning to order the admission of Michelle LaBorde and Lynda McNeal, both 13-year-old eigth graders, and Ramona Carbo, a 12-year-old seventh grader.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. SAYS $160,00 FUND FOR POLES IS USED FOR OFFICE SUPPLIES
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has raised $160,000 to help the independent Polish trade union movement. The money raised so far has been used by the Paris office of the American labor federation to purchase office equipment and supplies to help the Polish union, known as Solidarity, to administer its affairs and to communicate with local chapters.

title: HAIG AND REAGAN TALK IN CAPITAL
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr. conferred today with Ronald Reagan for the first time since the President-elect chose him to be Secretary of State.

title: HERSCHEL H. JONES
description: Herschel H. Jones, former head of the Herschel Jones Marketing Service, a New York import-export concern specializing in fruit, especially apples, died Dec. 29 in Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 93 years old and lived in Rumson, N.J.

title: Garwood Trial Told Vietnam Kept Mentally Ill Prisoners
description: Defense attorneys for Pfc. Robert R. Garwood of the Marines asserted today that the North Vietnamese did not free him as part of a 1973 mass release of American prisoners of war because they excluded from the release prisoners who had become insane or lost limbs.

title: PHIL MAHRE FINISHES 4TH
description: - Ingemar Stenmark today erased the memory of a rare defeat last Sunday with a solid victory in a World Cup giant slalom ski race, the speciality he has dominated since 1975.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 7, 1981; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Commission on Transnational Corpo- rations, Intergovernmental Working Group on a Code of Conduct - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: U.S. ASKS TIGHTER CHILD-AIDE RULE
description: uf814WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) - The Government has proposed permanently extending to people who do not receive welfare a service for collecting child support payments and paying three-fourths of the costs involved.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 19.50-20.50 ** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: DR. STERLING HENDRICKS, A GOVERNMENT SCIENTIST;
description: Dr. Sterling B. Hendricks, a physical and biological scientist with the Department of Agriculture, died Sunday of pneumonia at his daughter's home in Novato, Calif. He was 78 years old and lived in Silver Spring, Md.

title: Dome to Conduct Oil Search in Alberta
description: The Alberta Energy Company signed an agreement allowing Dome Petroleum Ltd. to conduct an exploration program in an area of 360 square miles in the southeastern portion of the Primrose Air Weapons Range in Alberta. Alberta Energy is half owned by the Alberta provincial government and half publicly owned.

title: AMERICAN HOME ELECTS CHAIRMAN
description: John W. Culligan, 64 years old, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the American Home Products Corporation - a generally unknown industrial giant with a household-name product line that includes Anacin, Dristan, Easy-Off and Preparation H.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1. Read All About Teddy

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LOOKING AT PICTURES There are tours and there are tours in New York, and if you can't find the one you want then you probably aren't trying. For the last 21 years, Gallery Passport Ltd., which says it has been doing it longer than anyone, has offered tours of art galleries and museums. Today and for the next five Wednesdays it will take you about the city, and on Saturday it will take you to Merion, Pa. The Saturday trip will be led by Bunny Mautner, the president of Gallery Passport, while the tour today will be led by one of Gallery Passport's lecturers. ''Our lecturers are young and they're super and they're wonderful,'' says Mrs. Mautner, who is generous with superlatives, ''and they have something to offer everyone.''

title: STAGE: 'TRIAL OF DR. BECK' AT HENRY ST.
description: HUGHES ALLISON'S ''The Trial of Dr. Beck,'' at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater is a theatrical oddity, a courtroom melodrama about eugenics, ''the science of improving the quality of the human race'' by means of ''a careful selection of parents.'' The play was first presented on Broadway in 1937 by the company's namesake, the W.P.A. Federal Theater, and has a minor significance in the history of black theater.

title: BANI SADR VISITS FRONT LINES AS IRAN CLAIMS GAINS
description: President Abolhassan Bani Sadr was at the front lines today to get an overview of Iran's counteroffensive against Iraq, the Teheran radio reported. Mr. Bani-Sadr, who is also Commander in Chief of the armed forces, studied the Iranian operation from an area that had been under Iraqi control until the counteroffensive began, the radio said. (In Washington, United States officials continued to discount Iranian reports of a major counteroffensive and also said that Iraqi reports of heavy fighting were exaggerated.

title: KELLY, AFTER JURORS SEE VIDEOTAPE, ACKNOWLEDGES $25,000 WAS BRIBE
description: Former Representative Richard Kelly, facing bribery conspiracy charges, acknowledged today on the witness stand what videotapes had already shown: that he accepted $25,000 from undercover agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation posing as representatives of fictitious Arab sheiks.

title: JUSTICE, SOCIAL AND
description: CRIMINAL Classic Lesson

title: GIFTS TO NEEDIEST EVINCE CONCERN OF SCHOOLCHILDREN IN THE SUBURBS
description: Many gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund demonstrate the concern youngsters in suburban schools feel for their less fortunate school-age colleagues in the inner city.

title: SOCIETY TO HELP KEEP YOUR GOLDFISH GOING
description: green, ranch-style house and Susan Law leaps, catching it on the first ring. It is a hot-line call from an anxious elderly woman, whose goldfish is blowing bubbles and turning upside down.

title: Former Radical Activist Gets a 9-Month Sentence
description: A former radical activist, Cathlyn Platt Wilkerson, who faces up to three years in prison in New York, was sentenced today to nine months in jail for her part in the 1969 ''Days of Rage'' disturbance in Chicago.

title: SFE TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Charles Schwab Sale
description: Charles Schwab, president of the Charles Schwab Corporation, announced yesterday in San Francisco the sale of 1.14 million newly issued shares, or 20 percent of the company's common stock, to the United Financial Corporation of California. The Charles Schwab Corporation is the nation's leading discount brokerage concern. United Financial is a subsidiary of the National Steel Corporation.

title: Muslim in Building Seizure Free
description: One of 12 Hanafi Muslims, convicted three years ago in the violent takeover of three buildings in Washington, has been released from prison after serving three years of his 36-to-108-year sentence. Judge Nicholas S. Nunzio of the District of Columbia Superior Court said that Abdul Hamid, 25 years old, was a ''model prisoner'' who had been rehabilitated. The judge released the prisoner last Friday.

title: Cleveland Ballet to Make New York Debut Jan. 20
description: The Cleveland Ballet will make its New York debut at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Jan. 20, in a program made up of Kurt Jooss's ''The Green Table,'' and the new ''Quicksilver'' and ''Brahms Quintet,'' both by Dennis Nahat, co-founder with Ian Horvath of the four-year-old, Ohio-based company. The Cleveland Ballet will perform through Jan. 25.

title: COACH OF LEAFS IN JEPARDY
description: John Tonelli scored five goals and Mike Bossy assisted on every Islander score to lead New York to a 6-3 victory tonight over the Toronto Maple Leafs at Nassau Coliseum. The loss, the Leafs' eighth in their last nine games, may also have spelled the doom of their coach, Joe Crozier, who was expected to be released tomorrow.

title: FOOD PROCESSOR BATTLE IS JOINED
description: THE French company that invented the food processor has dismissed its American distributor, Cuisinarts Inc., and begun a battle to wrest control of the United States market from Cuisinarts. RobotCoupe S.A., the French concern, will now do its own selling in the United States, offering not only the original models of the food processor but also new machines and new accessories -all under its own name. The first new machine will be available Feb. 1.

title: False-Arrest Suit Settled by City
description: New York City has settled a false-arrest lawsuit by agreeing to pay $2,500 to Frank A. Sturgis, one of the men convicted of the Watergate break-in. The suit grew out of his 1977 arrest in New York on a complaint by Marita Lorenz, who said he had threatened her and had told her not to talk to a committee investigating the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. Mr. Sturgis denied the charge, which was dismissed.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: The flaws in the buses called FLXIBLE May or may not be CORXIBLE So the old M.T.A. Hauled the buses away For fear they may prove to be WRXIBLE. SAM BAYER

title: Market Place; Gas Pipeline Stocks Favored
description: THE Lexington Management Corporation has done well over the years with undervalued stocks, buying shares, in effect, when they were cheap.

title: About New York; A SHORT VISIT WITH SOME OF THE DEFEATED
description: A thin, trembling woman with a faraway stare stops Ronald Walker in a gloomy hotel corridor and tells him her stomach hurts. ''I ain't been out of my room since New Year,'' she says.

title: RIOT VICTIM, 12, SPIRITED DESPITE LEG AMPUTATION
description: Nine months ago Shanreka Perry was a forward on the Holmes Elementary School basketball team and enjoyed an occasional neighborhood game of softball.

title: Earthquakes Shake Tadzhikistan
description: An earthquake, the second in two days, shook the Central Asian republic of Tadzhikistan today, the Soviet press agency Tass reported. The tremor, measuring 4 points on the Soviet scale of 12, was centered 170 miles from the Tadzhik capital of Dushanbe. There was no mention of casualties or damage.

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: B-Including tax crdits of $80,000 for the qr and $229,000 for the yr; 1979 results have been restated for a pooling of interests acquisition in April

title: NEW COLD FRONT LIKELY TO FOLLOW SNOWFALL IN CITY
description: After two days of warmer weather, with high temperatures of about 30 degrees, a snowfall of one to three inches was expected yesterday by the National Weather Service, followed by a plunge of the thermometer into the teens this evening.

title: WAR VETERANS COME TO BURY, AND TO PRAISE, DOENITZ
description: The funeral wreaths lay piled in the snow, and around them stood the men of Germany's past, shaking hands, introducing wives, and turning the funeral of Adolf Hitler's successor into a final grasp at justifying their part of history.

title: Giants Drop 2 Aides
description: Two members of the Giants' coaching staff, Ralph Hawkins, the defensive coordinator, and Don Pollard, a defensive backfield coach, were dismissed by the National Football League club yesterday.

title: OMEGA OPTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After registration costs of $13,033 for the qr and $119,830 for the yr

title: News Analysis
description: A conservative coalition of Republicans and Sun Belt Democrats that could well dominate the House of Representatives, particularly on economic and military issues, is starting to emerge on Capitol Hill.

title: CHEMICAL'S PRIME 19 1 2%
description: The Chemical Bank lowered its prime lending rate yesterday to 19 1/2 percent, the lowest level among the nation's largest banks. Despite signals from the Federal Reserve System that it does not intend to allow interest rates to drop as precipitously as they did earlier last year, some bankers believe that market pressures will force a rapid reduction in interest rates.

title: Sonics Under Inquiry
description: The National Basketball Association will look into the Seattle SuperSonics' travel arrangements to determine if they broke a league rule and forced the postponement of Saturday night's game with Phoenix, Joe Axelson, the league's director of operations, said today.

title: Marshall, Twins Settle Grievance
description: Mike Marshall, the relief pitcher released last June, and the Minnesota Twins settled yesterday on Marshall's grievance that the Twins had released him because of union activities. An arbitration hearing on the grievance had been scheduled to begin in Minnesota today.

title: KISSINGER URGES U.S. POST MIDEAST FORCE
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger urged today that the United States enhance its military presence in the Middle East to counter growing Soviet activity there.

title: TBWA Gets Vodka And Liqueur Accounts
description: TBWA Advertising has been assigned Grand Marnier liqueur and Absolut vodka by Carillon Importers, a division of Grand Metropolitan of Britain. The billings will be more than $5 million.

title: 'Danton's Death' for La Mama
description: The La Mama Experimental Theater Company will present Georg Buchner's ''Danton's Death'' in a new translation by Hedwig Rappolt, with new music by Dan Erkkila, for a four-week run beginning Jan. 28 at the theater's annex at 74A East Fourth Street. The director will be Linda Mussman, La Mama's new resident director.

title: Herring Fishermen Balking
description: Angered by a sharp drop in the price of herring, San Francisco fishermen say they will not go to sea until the prices rise. None of the 373 licensed commercial herring fishermen went out yesterday, the first day of the short herring season.

title: A Boston Broom
description: We hope that William French Smith, the Attorney General-designate, has been paying attention to the news of corruption in state and local government in Massachusetts.

title: A.I.A.W STRUGGLING
description: The Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women is 10 years old and fighting to stay alive, according to Donna Lopiano, president-elect of the group, the largest college sports organization in the country.

title: No Headline
description: TWO FIREMEN MISSING IN BOSTON: Firemen carrying an injured comrade to an ambulance yesterday in Boston's Back Bay section. Five firemen were trapped when two floors of the five-floor office building collapsed. Three of the men were quickly found in the rubble, but two others were reportedly trapped inside the building.

title: TV: A WILDLIFE DOCUMENTARY FILMED IN NAMIBIA
description: ''ETOSHA: Place of Dry Water,'' to be presented at 8 o'clock tonight on WNET-TV, Channel 13, is a National Geographic wildlife documentary filmed by David and Carol Hughes that's simply gorgeous. It stakes out watering holes in Etosha National Park, in South-West Africa, also known as Namibia, and patiently observes the behavior of various and abundant animals. Cheetahs stalk, bullfrogs mate, springbucks cavort like living pogo sticks. A lioness strolls up to a lion, bats him in the nose and marches away.

title: Economic Scene; Where Budget Might Be Cut
description: THE top economic advisers of President-elect Ronald Reagan are at last getting down to the serious business of deciding what their budget programs will be in the coming year. They do not have a lot of time. When Mr. Reagan takes office, the 1981 fiscal year will be almost one-third over, and budgets have a momentum that is hard to stop or turn around.

title: Milestone for Abdul-Jabbar
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 22 points, helping the Lakers gain a 107-98 victory over Washington and became the fourth-leading scorer in National Basketball Association history.

title: WAR FOE'S WORK LED TO H-BOMB
description: Harold C. Urey, a life-long critic of military force whose discovery of heavy hydrogen opened the possibility of thermonuclear warfare, died Monday night at his home in La Jolla, Calif.

title: George Radin, Lawyer, Author; Wrote Two Books on the Balkans
description: George Radin, an international lawyer and author of two books on Western European law and economy, died Sunday of a stroke at the Colonial Villa Nursing home here. He was 86 years old.

title: U.S.O. in Times Square
description: Since World War II, the U.S.O. has maintained its busiest and most famous facility in the heart of New York, just off Times Square.

title: Four Countries Said to Offer Help To Indonesia for Nuclear Plants
description: Canada and three European nations have offered services and technology to build Indonesia's first nuclear power plants, an official of the National Atomic Energy Institute said today.

title: G. M. SALES DOWN 22% IN DECEMBER
description: The General Motors Corporation sold 22 percent fewer cars in December 1980 than it did in December 1979, and Volkswagen of America's domestic sales were off 17 percent for the month, the two companies reported today.

title: CHEF-TEACHER STARTS A NEW LIFE
description: Last summer, Madeleine Kamman packed up her threegenerations-old copper pots, culled 600 books for her traveling food library, sold her Boston cooking school and headed home. Now, installed in a cheerful, contemporary apartment in the shadow of the French Alps, she's starting over. The cooking school. Another restaurant. A new life in Savoie, surrounded by familiar, favorite people and things. In her childhood days the region served as a refuge for ''a sickly little girl from Paris,'' and she has returned for solace.

title: GUIDELINES USED IN GRADING MEAT
description: The United States Department of Agriculture has established eight grades of beef, according to quality, which is determined by both the age of the animal and the amount of marbling, or flecks of fat, in the meat.

title: OXFORD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28

BOY, 7, SHOT TO DEATH IN QUEENS AND MOTHER IS CRITICALLY WOUNDED A 7-year-old boy was found shot to death the bathtub of his Queens apartment last night and his mother was found critically wounded a few feet away, according to the police, who said they were seeking to question the mother's boyfriend.
description: The police said that the boy, David Ruggerio, had been shot once in the head, and his mother, Karen, 27, was sprawled on the bathroom floor in the apartment on the second floor at 52-102 79th Street in Elmhurst with two bullet wounds in her face.

title: AFGHANISTAN AND PAKISTAN REPORT PROGRESS TOWARD PLANNING TALKS
description: In the last three days, Pakistan has issued a statement proposing the involvement of the United Nations in talks with Afghanistan, and Kabul has issued a statement accepting the idea.

title: GROUP SEEKING TO TAKE OVER WNYC-TV
description: Charging that the city is not making the best use of its television channel, True Witness Ministries, a not-for-profit corporation, is seeking to take over WNYC-TV.

title: 3 CABINET CHOICES BREEZE THROUGH SENATE HEARINGS
description: The men selected by Ronald Reagan to head the Health and Human Services, Commerce and Agriculture Departments breezed through their Senate confirmation hearings today without opposition, but Democratic Senators continued preparations for close questioning later this week of the President-elect's choices for Secretary of State and Secretary of the Interior.

title: PHILLIPS ACCUSED WITH TAMPERING
description: Ladd Herzeg, the new general manager of the Houston Oilers, accused Bum Phillips yesterday of tampering with the assistant coaches on the Oiler staff.

title: JAKARTA FEARS RIOTS WHEN SUZUKI VISITS
description: The coming visit of the Japanese Prime Minister is causing concern here about the possibility of violent demonstrations.

title: AMBULANCE READINESS
description: To the Editor:

title: 'MELVIN AND HOWARD' IS CHOSEN AS BEST FILM
description: ''Melvin and Howard,'' Jonathan Demme's film about Howard Hughes and the milkman he may have remembered in his will, was named best film of 1980 by the National Society of Film Critics Monday evening. The 38-member group, which includes critics from Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles, New York and other cities, also cited Peter O'Toole as best actor for his performance in ''The Stunt Man'' and Sissy Spacek as best actress for ''Coal Miner's Daughter.'' Martin Scorsese was named best director for ''Raging Bull.''

title: Parliament Accepts Government By Faeroe Islands Conservatives
description: Parliament approved a new Government led by Pauli Ellefsen of the Conservative Party last night after a 12-hour debate.

title: Italian Rightists Kill Youth, Calling Him an Informer
description: Right-wing terrorists shot and killed an 18-year-old collaborator-turned-informer today in the first political assassination in Italy this year, the police reported.

title: Pratt Engine Backed
description: The United Technologies Corporation's Pratt & Whitney subsidiary said the first two of its fuel-efficient JT9D-7R4 engine models had been certified for airline service by the Federal Aviation Administration. It said 14 United States and international airlines had placed firm orders and options for 197 wide-bodied jets equipped with the engines, including the Boeing 767, Airbus Industrie A310 and Boeing's stretched upper deck 747.

title: CHICAGO REJECTS MOVE TO CURB POLICE SPYING ON POLITICAL ACTIVISTS
description: Efforts by a group of citizens' organizations in Chicago to negotiate court-approved agreements prohibiting unwarranted surveillance by the police and other agencies have reached an impasse because of the city's insistence that the police should be allowed to spy on any organization or individual it chooses.

title: Israeli TV Series Stressing Role Of European Jews Draws Protest
description: An Israeli television series showing how the Zionist movement led to the establishment of Israel opened today amid protests by Jews from Islamic countries who charged discrimination.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE are some who say that New Year's resolutions should be scrapped because they are broken within two or three days, if not hours, and lead to nothing but self-fury and guilt. These people are wrong.

title: NEW PICTURE EDITOR OF THE TIMES
description: John Durniak has joined The New York Times as picture editor, it was announced yesterday by A.M. Rosenthal, executive editor. Mr. Durniak was the picture editor of Time magazine for more than eight years.

title: NEW YORK IS FACING RATIONING OF WATER
description: New York City environmental officials said yesterday that they were planning to impose mandatory water rationing as part of a ''drought emergency'' that they expect to be declared in the next few weeks.

title: Quota for Imports Of Peanuts Raised
description: The United States International Trade Commission agreed today with the Carter Administration that more peanuts can be imported - if any can be found.

title: Cartoon of a duck; WHY JAN. 20 BECAME INAUGURATION DAY
description: To the Editor:

title: POVERTY'S IMPACT ON BLACK CHILDREN CITED
description: THE Children's Defense Fund released a report yesterday that it said showed a cycle of poverty, poor health and educational deprivation that disproportionately affects black children and costs taxpayers unnecessary billions of dollars annually. A larger number of white children are actually affected by these conditions, according to the report, but the organization said the study focused on black children to emphasize the continued inequality in treatment.

title: Tennis Captures the Limelight
description: Once they were struggling events trying to buy their way into tennis with big money and elite fields. For years the Colgate women's championships and the men's Masters had neither geographic nor competitive identities.

title: Braves and Perry in Accord
description: Gaylord Perry, the 42-year-old free-agent pitcher who needs only 11 victories to reach the 300 mark, has agreed to a one-year contract with the Atlanta Braves, Perry's agent said today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard HOUSEKEEPING. By Marilynne Robinson. 219 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95.

title: NEW STYLE IS EXPECTED FOR BRANIFF
description: John J. Casey, the executive who is expected to be named chairman and chief executive officer of the financially troubled Braniff International Corporation today, plans a more collective style of management than that of his strong-willed predecessor, Harding L. Lawrence, according to airline industry informants.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Grey Advertising, which in the past has produced some extremely dramatic and poignant TV public service messages, has pulled a switch on its latest effort in behalf of the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission, which is committed to doing something about the 36 million product-related injuries and 30,000 deaths that annually cost the American people $9.5 billion. Grey is going to try humor.

title: Meeting on Massey
description: Meetings between Massey-Ferguson Ltd.'s senior management and the company's worldwide bank creditors will resume here during the next few days, with a major joint meeting representing some 250 lenders scheduled to start Jan. 15, a Massey spokesman said. He said the company hoped the joint meetings would implement an interest-forgiveness proposal, which is tied to a planned refinancing program of $700 million (Canadian). The joint meetings may be able to reach final agreements within two or three days, he added.

title: British Money Growth Slows
description: The growth in the British money supply slowed in December, the Bank of England announced today.

title: UNC SAYS COLUSSY IS ITS CHOICE IF AIRLINE MARGER IS SUCCESSFUL
description: Dan A. Colussy, who resigned last November as president of Pan American World Airways with his future plans unsettled, has found himself in the midst of a complex merger struggle.

title: A PROBLEM IN THE CLOAKROOM:FINDING SPACE FOR DOWN COATS
description: DOWN coats are warm. True. Down coats are chic. Oh, yes. Down coats are everywhere. Seems so. Everybody likes down coats. Not true. People who must walk about New York in zero weather love down coats. Working wholesale butchers love down coats. Skiers love down jackets. Mail deliverers now have down coats as part of their regulation uniforms. And on college campuses, the down coat, jacket or vest is virtually necessary for social acceptability.

title: Elf Gets Libyan Permits
description: Libya has granted the French state-owned oil company Elf Aquitaine five oil exploration permits, four onshore and one offshore, an Elf spokesman said today. Elf has operated in Libya for some 15 years and produces about 15,000 barrels a day there, the spokesman said.

title: LET THEM CONSERVE
description: To the Editor:

title: A SET OF VALUES FOR U.S. INTELLIGENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: TRIP BY JAPAN'S LEADER WILL STRESS ASIA TIES
description: Japan will continue its foreign policy overtures toward other Asian nations when Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki begins a trip to five Southeast Asian countries this week.

title: A BURDEN WRONGLY PUT ON JOHN LENNON
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN GROUP URGES LOCAL OPTION ON PUBLIC TRANSIT FOR HANDICAPPED
description: A Reagan transition group on transportation has strongly urged that it be left up to localities to decide how they will provide public transportation to handicapped people.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Can Company, Greenwich, Conn., has appointed John F. Roeser Jr. vice president, corporate transportation.

title: BLISS AMONG THE COCONUTS
description: A friend of mine goes down to the Sun Belt every year about this time, and a sensible thing it is to do, too, if you can swing it financially. I thought of him the other morning when the thermometer outside the window stood at 3 degrees below zero, and it is an absolute certainty that he thought about me, and felt better.

title: FOR AMERICAN STEAKS, A GILDED AGE IS FADING
description: ''I try to make them picture-perfect,'' Ken Stevens said, and they were: row upon row of 12-day-aged top sirloins, Tbones, rib eyes and porterhouses, blood-red and juicy, their suety white edges trimmed just so, with flecks and veins of marbled fat guaranteeing the locked-in flavor that is one of the most famous of American tastes. It made the mouth water just to look.

title: DEFEATED ASSEMBLYMAN HOLDS ON TO HARLEM OFFICE
description: The secretary says ''Assemblyman Miller's office'' when she answers the phone. But, according to the State Board of Elections, George W. Miller is no longer an Assemblyman. And according to the State Office of General Services, the office is no longer his.

title: No Headline
description: POPE JOHN PAUL II CONSECRATES 11 NEW BISHOPS: During an Epiphany day ceremony, 11 new bishops prostrated themselves before Pope John

title: MERRILL LYNCH FILLS FOREIGN BANKING POSTS
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, which has been trying to expand its international presence, appointed two new people yesterday to head its foreign banking and investment banking activities.

title: CONDITIONAL EXPANSION OF CHRYSLER AID HINTED
description: Treasury Secretary G. William Miller indicated today that the Administration was moving toward conditional approval of up to $400 million of additional loan guarantees for the Chrysler Corporation, with a final decision to be made after President-elect Ronald Reagan takes office on Jan. 20.

title: Industries Note Energy Gains
description: America's 10 largest energy-consuming industries say they saved the equivalent of one million barrels of oil a day in 1979, compared with what they used in 1972, the Energy Department reported today.

title: REAGAN REPORTEDLY READY TO NAME UTAH AIDE AS EDUCATION SECRETARY
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan was reported today to have selected Terrel H. Bell, a former Acting United States Commissioner of Education, to serve as Secretary of the newly created Department of Education, which Mr. Reagan has promised to dismantle. The choice of Mr. Bell, who is Commissioner of Higher Education in Utah, is expected to be announced this week, officials close to Mr. Reagan's transition said. Transition officials also said that Mr. Reagan was expected to choose Bill Brock, chairman of the Republican National Committee, as special trade representative, the only other Cabinet-level post that has not been filled. Word of the imminent selection of Mr. Bell and Mr. Brock came as the President-elect met with staff members and Cabinet designees here and also announced the appointment of James S. Brady, his transition spokesman, as press secretary. Making his first public appearance in connection with an appointment to his incoming administration, Mr. Reagan told reporters that both Mr. Brady and his newly announced deputy, Karna Small, a television news broadcaster, would have access to Mr. Reagan personally and to the inner workings of the government.

title: Who's In Charge?
description: On the whole, the transition between the Carter and Reagan administrations has gone fairly well, but on the question of how to deal with the American hostages in Iran, there have been some problems.

title: THE MORAL SLOTH OF GENERAL HAIG
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Travel/Holiday magazine to Kopf & Isaacson Advertising, Melville, L.I.

title: Sale of Indians Is Off, Club President Says
description: The Cleveland Indians called off the sale of the baseball club yesterday to a group headed by James Nederlander, the New York theater executive, and said that ''we'll just go along the way we have in the past.''

title: Remedies for Influenza Stress Rest and Aspirin
description: The flu is caused by a virus and it is easily spread from one person to another from the nose and throat. Its symptoms usually include a sore throat, runny nose, headache, fever, body aches and, occasionally, nausea, all of which can last up to 10 days.

title: Wrong Hail to the Chiefs
description: It is no disgrace for Caspar Weinberger to want to be confirmed as Secretary of Defense before he can articulate a coherent foreign policy and strategic doctrine. He comes to the Pentagon with the reputation of a vigorous budget cutter, an important attribute for an Administration that seems tempted to throw money at military problems. There will be time enough to learn the intricacies of arms control, naval deployments and recruiting. But there is not much more time for temporizing about the relationship between the civilian and military leaders of the armed forces. When asked whether he would fire the present Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff for the crime of supporting the Commander in Chief on SALT II, Mr. Weinberger's response should have been an eloquent no.

title: New Service to Boston
description: A Princeton-based commuter airline expanded its daily service to Boston today, using a fuel-efficient Australian-made plane designed for use on shorter runways.

title: EAGLES DEVISE COLOR SCHEME FOR COWBOYS
description: The Philadelphia Eagles flew to Tampa, Fla., yesterday for four days of warm-weather practice. Before they left, they invoked the so-called blue-jersey jinx in an effort to provoke the Dallas Cowboys, their opponents Sunday in the National Conference championship game.

title: DOLLAR SAGS IN JAPAN BELOW 200-YEN LEVEL
description: The United States dollar dropped below the 200-yen level here yesterday for the first time in almost two years, against the backdrop of a strengthening Japanese economy.

title: The Economy
description: An economic decline was forecast for 1981 by Donald Regan, the Treasury Secretary-designate. But he said at confirmation hearings that ''major improvement'' would occur within 15 months if the Reagan economic program were adopted. He also said that the new administration's target for balancing the budget had slipped a year, to 1984, as the outlook for the budget deficit had worsened steadily in recent weeks. (Page A1.)

title: COMPANY NEWS G. William Miller; CHRYSLER HOLDS PRICES STEADY; FORD'S RISE IS LESS THAN G.M.'S
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today it would not increase its auto prices, despite the raises announced last week by the General Motors Corporation, and the Ford Motor Company announced an increase well below G.M.'s.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Signed Mike S adek, catcher, to one-year contract. BASKETBALL WASHINGTON (NBA) - Extended the 1 0-day contract agreements of Andre Mc- C arter, guard, and Anthony Roberts, for- w ard.

title: NEW CONVENTION CENTER WILL HOUSE SHOPS, TOO
description: Jerry Lowery, who was named executive director of the New York Convention Center yesterday, said it would be open the year-round and that it would contain a promenade of restaurants and shops overlooking the Hudson River. Most convention centers are closed about a third of the time.

title: Iranian Leader's Cousin Recovering in New York
description: The Iranian President's second cousin, who is being treated for a heart condition, remained in stable condition yesterday under selfimposed security measures.

title: Salt Spreaders Sent Out - Armory Set for Heatless
description: An overnight storm dropped more than two-and-a-half inches of snow on New York City by 2 A.M. today, following two days of relatively mild, sunny weather in which temperatures peaked at 33 degrees. According to the Natinoal Weather Service, a cold front moving in from the Ohio Valley is expected to plunge the thermometer back into the teens this afternoon after the snowfall tapers off during the morning and ends around noon. The Weather Service predicted accumulation of four inches in the city and five to six inches in inland areas by daylight. Vito Turso, a Sanitation Department spokesman, said that 250 salt spreaders were on the streets last night and that at 1 A.M. snowplows were sent out to clear the streets for the first time this winter. He estimated that by morning 75 plows would be manned throughout the city. The New York City Department of Transportation suspended alternate side parking at 2 A.M. today because of the snow. The period of unusual cold, which began four days ago and reached a low of 5 degrees early Sunday morning, has resulted in complaints from thousands of New Yorkers that their apartments were without heat or had inadequate heat. Dr. Elliot M. Gross, Chief Medical Examiner, said the cold contributed to the deaths of three men, two in Brooklyn and one in the Bronx, and might have been a factor in the death of another Bronx man, whose body was to be examined today.

title: Vending Machine Suit
description: California's Attorney General filed suit today in Superior Court charging MCI Consultants Inc. of Toronto and Comcon Inc. of Los Angeles, with misrepresenting the profits investors could gain from a vending machine business. The Attorney General's office is asking $100,000 in damages from each company, plus an undetermined amount of restitution to investors, said Herschel T. Elkins, Senior Assistant Attorney General. The suit alleges that both companies made ''serious misrepresentations'' about the amount of money investors were likely to make by buying vending machines that dispense BIC cigarette lighters.

title: Chess: Hubner Howler Attributed To a Lack of Concentration
description: ''No, it wasn't bad nerves and it wasn't time pressure - it was a lack of concentration,'' said Vlastimil Hort, in discussing the incredible blunder committed by Robert Hubner on the 63d move of his seventh game with Viktor Korchnoi in their final Candidates' Match in Merano, Italy.

title: Allis-Chalmers Picks President
description: Wendell F. Bueche, an executive vice president of the Allis-Chalmers Corporation since 1976, has been named president and chief operating officer, the company announced today.

title: Peru Trade Union Calls for Strike To Protest Food and Fuel Rises
description: Peru's largest trade union today announced a 24-hour general strike for Jan. 15 to protest to sharp Government increases in the price of basic foods and fuel,

title: The Region; A Family Argument Ends in 2 Slayings
description: A 55-year-old retired postal employee shot and killed his father and brother during an argument over family debts, the Nassau County police said.

title: SUGAR PRICES ARE EXPECTED TO RISE FURTHER
description: THE United States Department of Agriculture estimates that sugar prices will rise further this year. Recently the average price of a five-pound sack of granulated sugar at the store dropped 10 cents to $3.08 - still 107 percent more than last year at this time. Some experts believe that a decrease in consumption is responsible for the small dip in price, plus the fact that on freezing winter days soft drinks and ice cream do not have the allure they manifest at the height of summer.

title: U.S. REPORTER MISSING IN SAN SALVADOR
description: United States Embassy officials fear that an American journalist missing or more than a week has been the victim of political violence. The journalist, John J. Sullivan, 26 years old, of Bogota, N.J., checked into the Sheraton Hotel on Dec. 28.

title: COSWORTH ENGINE BANNED BY USAC, STARTING IN '81
description: In an effort to hold down costs and increase competition, the United States Auto Club has banned the powerful Cosworth-type engines, effective next Jan. 1, officials said today.

title: Bank Warning On Inflation
description: The Bank of America said today that the nation could expect another upward surge of inflation ''disturbingly soon'' unless the Government adopted policies to stimulate productivity.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Libya and Chad Say Border Will Be Opened

title: PUTNAM COUNTY EMERGING AS AN AREA OF OFFICE PARKS
description: In the real world, people go where people are. Even so, said Harold Lepler, president of Spectra Realty here: ''It was tough to get the first sales up here. You can't just put up a sign and make it look like an office park.''

title: CERTRON CORP reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $265,000 extraordinary tax credit

title: DEVELOPER OF SKYSCRAPERS BUYS BLOCK ON THIRD AVE.
description: The east blockfront on Third Avenue between 53d and 54th Streets across from the Citicorp Center has been acquired by Gerald D. Hines, a real-estate developer who has reshaped most of the Houston skyline and is building major skyscrapers in San Francisco, Chicago and Denver.

title: Congress Tallies Ballots And the Election Is Over
description: Ronald Reagan's election as the 40th President of the United States was made official today with the formal tally of electoral votes by a joint session of Congress.

title: Advertising; Uniroyal To Use Tire Ratings
description: MOST of the tire industry may be opposed to Uniform Tire Quality Grading, but not Uniroyal. In fact it plans to use the Government mandated ratings in its new, highly competitive ad campaign.

title: Ali Will Apply Today For License in Hawaii
description: Muhammad Ali will apply for a boxing license in Hawaii today, 10 days before he turns 39, which is over the state's age limit for fighters.

title: The City; Agency Head's Wife Injured in Mugging
description: Aliette Goldmark, the wife of Peter C. Goldmark, executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, suffered a possible fracture of a cheekbone Monday when she fell as a young man tried to seize her pocketbook.

title: MRS. HARRIS CALLED RESIGNED TO TARNOWER'S LIFE STYLE
description: A lifelong friend of Jean S. Harris, who is accused of murdering Dr. Herman Tarnower, testified today in Westchester County Court that Mrs. Harris was unhappy that the doctor had been ''seeing other women'' but that she knew she ''would have to live with it.''

title: REAGAN DESIGNATES DEPUTY PRESS AIDE
description: Karna Small, who was named today to be Ronald Reagan's deputy press secretary, is a broadcast journalist who for two years has been a public relations specialist for the United States Chamber of Commerce, a private organization.

title: Notes on PeopleRomance; With U.S. Admiral Still Irks Soviet
description: Zoya Fyodorova, the Russian actress who was jailed in the Stalin era for having a romance with an American naval officer during World War II, has been denied a visa to visit the United States, according to her daughter, Victoria Fyodorova.

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: B-After reductions of $420,000 for the qr and $1,920,000 for th 9 mos from a change to LIFO accounting method...C-After deducti of $244,000 for the qr and $1,306,000 for the 9 mos from a chan to the LIFO accounting method

title: Q. You recently mentioned Sherry pepper, a famous seasoning to be found in Bermuda. I have had it there in Bermuda fish chowder and wonder if you have a recipe?
description: A. I have a recipe that comes, in fact, from Outerbridge, the best-known bottler of Sherry pepper. Here is an adaptation of that recipe: Bermuda Fish Chowder

title: Bid to Bar Cargo Handling Rules Seems to Be Temporarily Blocked
description: An attempt by the National Labor Relations Board to prevent new rules governing the handling of container cargo by longshoremen from being carried out appeared to be temporarily blocked yesterday.

title: CHANNEL 2 NEWS EDGES INTO NO.1 SPOT IN RATING-POINTS GAME
description: TV found a charismatic combination in the older man and younger woman anchor team of Rolland Smith and Michelle Marsh on the 11 o'clock news? Is the relentless cheerleading of recently recruited sportscaster Warner Wolf the explanation? Are viewers simply tired of the chattier, more personality-oriented format of WABC-TV's ''Eyewitness News''?

title: WIMBLEDON PURSE UP
description: - The All-England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club increased prize money for the Wimbledon tennis championships today and announced higher prices for center-court seats. Air Chief Marshal Sir Brian Burnett, chairman of the club, said the prize money would go up by 9.7 percent to $757,019. Center-court seats for the semifinals and finals will cost $26.40 apiece, compared with $19.20 last year.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Can Company and Maclean-Hunter Ltd., Toronto, said Maclean-Hunter Media Inc., a subsidiary, had acquired the business of American Communications group of American Can.

title: AN ALTERNATIVE POLICY TO PREVENT 'DUNKIRK'
description: The incoming administration is struggling over what to do about the faltering economy. We are promised a fast set of bold measures - and possibly a declaration of national economic emergency - to avoid the ''economic Dunkirk'' warned of in a well-publicized memorandum by David Stockman, director-designate of the Office of Management and Budget, and Jack Kemp, chairman of the House Republican Conference.

title: New Point-of-Sale Terminals by I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had introduced new models of its 5265 point-ofsale terminal with up to four times the information storage capacity of existing models.

title: GENERAL HEALTH SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
The City; DELAYS ON SUBWAYS; Trouble on IND Delays Thousands
description: A southbound IND local train that stalled between stations delayed thousands of passengers on Manhattan's West Side for up to two hours, Transit Authority officials said.

title: Change in Philippines Law Is Expected Jan. 17
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos will lift martial law on Jan. 17, official sources said today. The Manila Bulletin said Mr. Marcos would end martial law by mid-January and The People's Journal said the change could come in two weeks.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times last Saturday incorrectly reported the number of states in which Republicans hold the governorship and the full legislature and thus have apparent control, or effective veto power, over redistricting. Republicans have such power in seven states.

title: Tandem, T.A.T.  End Caesars Talks
description: Tandem Productions and the T.A.T. Communications Company have terminated talks with Clifford and Stuart Perlman, chairman and vice chairman of Caesars World Inc., regarding the sale of the Perlmans' stock in Caesars World, a Caesars spokesman said. They gave no reason, she said.

title: RODGERS AWARD IS GIVEN
description: A musical-comedy version of Federico Fellini's film ''8 1/2'' - called ''Nine'' - has won the first Richard Rodgers Production Award. The musical, with lyrics and music by Maury Yeston and book by Mario Fratti, will be directed by Tommy Tune. It is to open this year at the La Mama Experimental Theater Club, 66 East Fourth Street, where the award was announced yesterday by Barbara W. Tuchman, president of the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, which administers the award program.

title: CLARK, J L, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
Video Business Magazine
description: Here's an item that doesn't stray too far from the previous subject.

title: CHELSEA ENDS 'HIJINKS!' AND ALL PRODUCTION
description: The Chelsea Theater Center has posted the closing notice for its new musical, ''Hijinks!,' for Jan. 18 and has announced once again that a financial crisis is forcing it to cancel future productions.

title: Bassist in Fleetwood Mac Group Arrested on Drug Charge on Maui
description: John McVie, bass player with the rock group Fleetwood Mac, was arrested last month at his home on the island of Maui and charged with felony possession of cocaine, it was reported today.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: JERSEY ANTIQUES FAIR
description: Morristown Antiques Fair, National Guard Armory, Western Avenue, Morristown, N.J.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF GOV. CAREY'S MESSAGE AT OPENING OF 204TH SESSION OF
description: LEGISLATURE Following is a transcipt of Governor Carey's State of the State message to the Legislature in Albany yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: CITY EMPOYEES' STRIKE ENDS AMID WARNING OF INDIANA WALKOUTS
description: A four-day strike by 340 city workers ended last night, but a local union leader predicted that similar walkouts would occur in other parts of the state as a result of a more militant attitude among municipal employees.

title: MAJOR REVISIONS ASKED TO BATTLE STATEWIDE CRIME
description: Governor Carey proposed a major overhaul of the criminal-justice system today. He included plans for stricter sentencing of violent criminals, increased police protection, the construction of three new prisons and expansion of investigatory and prosecution resources.

title: Index; International
description: On a snowy Christmas Eve, faith blooms in Moscow A2 Iraqis say they have halted Iranian drive, trapping hundreds A3 Soviet warns again on subversive threat from Islamic nations A4 U.S. won't prosecute Ramsey Clark for Iran trip A6 Around the World A7 400 American clerics criticize Israel on Palestinian rights issue A8 U.N. endorses a report that fear would endanger a free press A11 U.S. journalist missing in El Salvador called ''determined'' A14 Government/Politics Grand jury to pay $25,000 for libeling concern A16 New York Assistant State Attorney General called suicide B2 The new State Legislature reacts in the old partisan style B4 Koch says he's pleased, generally, with Carey's annual message B4 Carey calls for major overhaul of criminal-justice system B5 The text of Gov. Carey's State of the State message B6 Program increases conviction rate for ''career criminals'' B7 Loft plan denounced by manufacturing and residential interests B9 Abscam witness says he was told Lederer took $5,000 of $50,000 B13 Inaugural entertainment to have Hollywood tone B17 General Around the Nation A16 Snow delays trains and shuts some schools in New York area B2 City needs 60 days of heavy rain to bring reservoirs to capacity B7 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of the snow, alternate-side parking regulations are suspended throughout New York City today. The Home Section Home Architects play with spatial illusions C1

title: WITNESS ASSERTS HE WAS TOLD LEDERER TOOK $5,000
description: A prosecution witness said yesterday at the bribery trial of Representative Raymond F. Lederer of Pennsylvania that he had been told Mr. Lederer ended up with $5,000 of the $50,000 he had been given by undercover agents in the Abscam investigation of political corruption.

title: PHILLIP'S RUSH TO SAINTHOOD
description: BUM PHILLIPS belongs with the Houston Oilers, nobody else. No other coach in the National Football League fit his franchise so perfectly. Bum talked country and dressed Western. He once worked in an oil refinery. He always wore cowboy boots. He had two-dozen pairs in his closet. All kinds - alligator, anteater, beaver, caribou, lizard, kangaroo. He even had some powder-blue boots to match the Oilers' colors. Luv ya, Blue. Luv ya, Bum. And when the Oilers played in an open stadium, he always wore one of his two-dozen cowboy hats. In the Astrodome, he never wore a cowboy hat. Just his crew cut.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Dire Predictions by Member of Reagan Transition Team

title: CHINA'S AIRLINE, CASUAL AT HOME, SPRUCES UP FOR ITS U.S. SERVICE
description: When a Chinese-owned Boeing 747SP left Peking for New York today, beginning the first regularly scheduled airline service between China and the United States in 31 years, the pilots were wearing uniforms.

title: CHAMBER: NARY A QUARTET FOR SIX QUARTET PALYERS
description: THE Tuesday evening program of the Chamber Music at the Y series was like some happily recreational excursion for moonlighting members of well-established string quartets. There were six players on hand. Jamie Laredo, who is the director of chamber-music activities at the 92d Steeet Y, was one of the violinists, and his wife, Sharon Robinson, was one of the cellists. The other four were Hiroko Yajima, second violinist of the Galimir Quartet; Michael Tree, violist of the Guarneri Quartet; Samuel Rhodes, violist of the Juilliard Quartet, and Joel Krosnick, cellist of the Juilliard Quartet.

title: Parcells Gets Giants' Defensive Job
description: Bill Parcells, who won high praise for turning the New England Patriot linebackers into a formidable force in his first season of professional coaching, has rejoined the Giants as defensive coordinator.

title: CAREY URGES BROAD TAX CUTS, A 10% RISE IN WELFARTE GRANTS AND BILLIONS FOR MASS TRANSIT
description: Governor Carey opened the 204th session of the Legislature today by calling for a broad program of tax cuts for individuals and business, increases in welfare grants, more aid for mass transportation, a state takeover of Medicaid costs and a series of tough new measures to combat street crime.

title: 'LAX QUALITY CONTROLS' FOR WHEELS ARE CITED IN SAUDI PLANE MISHAP
description: The National Transportation Safety Board yesterday said that ''lax quality control'' in supplying airlines with data about landing-gear wheels made by the B.F. Goodrich Company for Lockheed jumbo jets had contributed to an accident in which two children were blown to their deaths from a Saudi Arabian Airlines plane last month.

title: JUSTICE UNIT OPPOSES CBS-TV CABLE LINK
description: The Justice Department asked the Federal Communications Commission today to deny CBS Inc. a waiver that would allow the network to own cable TV systems.

title: Chief to Leave S.E.C. in March
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Harold M. Williams, has told President-elect Ronald Reagan that he plans to leave his post in March, giving Mr. Reagan an early chance to name a new chairman, a commission spokesman said today.

title: HOW TO ARRANGE FOR AN AUDIT
description: THE best auditing bargain in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut is a state-mandated inspection performed by the utilities. (Other states also were required by a Federal Residential Conservation Program to have organized similar programs by last October.)

title: CBS TOPS RATINGS, NBC A STRONG SECOND
description: ''It's a start, but it's only one week,'' said Fred Silverman, president of NBC, with uncharacteristic understatement yesterday. Actually it was perhaps the best news for NBC since the success of its small series ''Shogun'' in September. The network won four nights in the audience ratings last week, and finished a strong second to CBS, as ABC lagged more than two points behind.

title: BRIEFS
description: * First National Bank of New Jersey purchased five branches of the Newark-based Fidelity Union Bancorp in Bergen and Hudson counties.

title: 76ers 135, Spurs 102
description: Julius Erving and Darryl Dawkins helped Philadelphia take control early with a 35-point first quarter and the 76ers routed San Antonio.

title: Connelly's Last Play Closes in Rehearsal; Connelly's Last Play Closes in Rehearsal
description: ''The Stitch in Time,'' the last play written by the late Marc Connelly, closed in rehearsal Tuesday afternoon. The play had been in rehearsal since Dec. 29 and was scheduled to open Feb. 3 at the Anta Theater.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Equitable Gas filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission $50 million of debentures due 2006, to be offered through a First Boston Corporation group.

title: VENEZUELA AIRLINE, MIRED IN ITS LOSSES, LOOKS FOR WAY OUT
description: Viasa, Venezuela's international airline, after two consecutive years of losses totaling more than $54 million, has been pulled from the edge of bankruptcy by the Government and is undergoing a reorganization designed to restore the carrier's financial health.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In each of the areas I have outlined today there is the same single underlying need to accept the disciplines of austerity as a means of hope.'' - Governor Carey in his State of the State message. (B4:2.)

title: The New York Times Bronx Youth Slain by Police Officer Is Mourned Sharon Wright, left, sister of Donald Wright, being comforted by her aunt, Margaret Jackson, at funeral service yesterday in the Bronx. The 19-year-old unarmed youth was shot to death by Police Officer Cleveland Ladson outside a shoe store in Harlem on Dec. 30. The officer has been suspended and a Police
description: Department spokesman said the matter would be presented to a grand jury.

title: MISTUBISHI HOLDS BACK 'K' ENGINES
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation said today that it had suspended shipments of its engines for the Chrysler Corporation's ''K'' cars, the front-wheel-drive compacts, at Chrysler's request.

title: HEARING ON DONOVAN POSTPONED
description: The Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee last night abruptly postponed its scheduled confirmation hearing today for Raymond J. Donovan, designated by President-elect Ronald Reagan as Secretary of Labor, to await more information about an investigation of Mr. Donovan's construction company in New Jersey.

title: MURDER ON YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: Aqueduct Card Canceled
description: Racing was canceled at Aqueduct yesterday because of poor conditions resulting from the overnight snowfall. A track spokesman said racing would resume today as scheduled.

title: L.I. MEDICAL EXAMINER CALLS DEATH A SUICIDE
description: An assistant state attorney general, Allan N. Smiley, shot himself to death yesterday in his home in this affluent section of Long Island, the Nassau County medical examiner's office said today.

title: Suriname Official Is Ousted
description: The military Government ousted Vice President Andre Haakmat, who was also Foreign Minister, Justice Minister and Defense Minister, officials announced today. He was ousted yesterday, they said, for sowing discord between Cabinet ministers and military chiefs.

title: Virginia 63 North Carolina State 55
description: Ralph Sampson scored 24 points and Jeff Lamp 17 to lead unbeaten Virginia to a 63-55 Atlantic Coast conference victory over North Carolina State tonight.

title: Penguins Trounce Islanders
description: The Islanders knew last night's romp over Toronto was going to be a hard act to follow, but no one expected a complete collapse.

title: AT YOUR SERVICE: HOME FILING CABINETS
description: BECAUSE the New Year carries with it the promise of yet another beginning - ''And the sloppy shall be made neat'' -buying a filing cabinet for one's home might be an appropriate way to start 1981.

title: GRAND JURY TO PAY $25,000 IN CAIFORNIA LIBEL CASE
description: In what lawyers say may be the first such case in the nation, a Lake County grand jury that met more than five years ago will pay $25,000 and retract critical comments that it made about an engineering concern that never was indicted.

title: REAGAN DESIGNEE SAYS HE SUPPORTS REDUCTIONS IN AID FOR MASS TRANSIT
description: Drew Lewis, the Secretary of Transportationdesignate, told the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation today that he favored a gradual reduction in Federal aid to mass transit systems.

title: PREVENTING DAMAGE FROM DEICING SALT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Anne Simon Moffat is a science writer with a special interest in botany. By ANNE SIMON MOFFAT

title: 2 Held in Holdup Slaying Of Newark Police Officer
description: Two members of a black militant sect were arrested in Florida today on charges resulting from the fatal shooting of a Newark police officer during a bank robbery, the police said.

title: Bahamian Officials Order Vesco To Leave the Country by Jan. 20
description: Bahamian immigration officials who want to deport Robert L. Vesco have given the 45-year-old fugitive financier a new deadline of Jan. 20 to leave their country. Mr. Vesco was served with a deportation order yesterday at his home here.

title: MORE 'CAREER CRIMINALS' CONVICTED IIN STATE EFFORT
description: A New York State program to intensify the prosecution of persons who repeatedly commit major crimes has led to dramatically higher conviction rates and substantially longer sentences, the state's Division of Criminal Justice Services reported yesterday.
