title: News Analysis
description: Governor Carey promised something to everyone and borrowed something from nearly everyone - Democrat and Republican alike - in his State of the State address today. The result was a far-reaching blueprint of programs that charted Mr. Carey's future course for New York State and demonstrated his political skill.

title: A WELL-PLANNED WINTER GARDEN PUTS ALL THE SENSES UNDER SIEGE
description: MANY, many years ago, when I was theater struck, there was hardly a playhouse in Europe, from Aarhus to Zagreb, that I didn't know by name. And I was crazy about those names. I tried them for weight. I tested them for sound. I wrote them out in my best italic hand, and I pored over the listings the way young men in novels used to pore over Keats and Shelley.

title: NEW SCANDAL ROCKS PERTAMINA
description: Despite an impressive recovery from near bankruptcy in 1975 and subsequent investigations of widespread graft, Pertamina, Indonesia's national oil company, again faces the possibility of corruption within its ranks.

title: CLINICS AND CLASSES FOR OVERWEIGHT CHILDREN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Arlene Fischer is a freelance writer. By ARLENE FISCHER

title: Consolidated Gas Sells Some Holdings
description: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company announced that it had agreed in principle to sell substantially all of its Canadian gas and oil properties to the Merland Explorations Group for $62.8 million (Canadian).

title: Manhattan 66 Manhattanville 53
description: With Deucey Hughes, a reserve, scoring 19 points, Manhattan posted a 66-53 victory over Manhattanville Wednesday night.

title: No Headline
description: LOUISIANA JUDGE HALTS HIS DEFIANCE IN SCHOOL CASE

title: Nostalgic 'Tintypes' Fading After 93 Performances
description: ''Tintypes,'' the nostalgic musical featuring songs of the turn of the century, will close Sunday afternoon at the Golden Theater after 93 performances and 11 previews.

title: JOE DOLHON
description: Funeral services were held yesterday for Joe Dolhon, a former collegiate and professional basketball player, who was killed Monday in an automobile accident in Westchester County.

title: THE CONCORDE'S EXCLUSIVE CLUB
description: ''If people are traveling far,'' said Dr. Henry Jarecki, chairman of the Mocatta Metals Corporation, a gold bullion house, ''the purpose is to get there, not to spend your life in a plane. The difference in cost is considerable, but the ability to earn money is enhanced.''

title: Market Place; How to Invest In Mexico
description: MEXICO is using profits from its Government-owned, highly productive oil industry to raise the national standard of living. In so doing, it is also attempting to create opportunities for foreign investors.

title: Selling the Seaport
description: It is too late now to debate whether creating a marketplace in New York's South Street Seaport is a good idea. The project is in motion, with Board of Estimate approval, the promise of a $20 million Federal urban development grant and the Rouse Company committed as developer. What matters now is the plan for the project.

title: NO HEAT FOR TENANTS: A HARLEM TENEMENT'S PROBLEMS
description: From last Saturday, when blustery winds brought a bitter cold front to the New York metropolitan area, until yesterday, the 20 families in the five-story building at 503 West 140th Street in Manhattan were among the thousands of New Yorkers without heat.

title: SCHEDULED AIR SERVICE FROM CHINA TO U.S. RESUMES
description: Scheduled passenger airline service between China and the United States was restored today after a 32-year hiatus when a Boeing 747 with 139 Chinese passengers arrived exactly on time at San Francisco International Airport.

title: GUNMEN INVADE 6 BANKS IN CITY AND ONE ON L.I.
description: Gunmen and, in some cases, men armed only with threatening notes, yesterday robbed six banks in New York City, an armored van in the Bronx and another bank in Uniondale, L.I., authorities said. Attempts on two other banks failed.

title: CITY NEEDS 60 DAYS OF SNOW OR RAINFALL TO FILL RESERVOIRS
description: It would take 60 days of heavy snows -or equivalent rains - to bring New York City's reservoirs up to their capacity by June 1, when seasonal use start reducing water supplies.

title: Many of Carter's Aides Will Return to Georgia
description: Many of President Carter's Georgia aides are returning to their native state after he leaves office on Jan. 20, but some plan to stay in Washington.

title: Advertising; Fledgling Agency Has Konica
description: THE Konica Corporation, marketer of Japanese-made cameras, has found the agency it has been looking for since mid-November -Slater, Hanft, Martin - which, so far, barely exists.

title: LIQUID SOAP GROWS STEADILY
description: Those bits of soap that slip through fingers, dissolve into jelly or slide down the drain may be a problem of the past. At least that's the claim of the makers of ''liquid soap,'' the hottest entry in the soap market.

title: SUN TO PHASE OUT SHIPBUILDING
description: The Sun Company's withdrawal from ship construction underscores a general problem besetting American shipyards: a lack of business. The 12 major shipyards, including Sun's at Chester, Pa., that have been ready to take orders for oceangoing commercial vessels now have orders for only 28.

title: U.S. IS CRITICIZED ON LACK OF PLAN IN REACTOR CRISIS
description: The Government's committee to monitor nuclear safety told President Carter today that, nearly two years after the Three Mile Island reactor accident there was still no policy on planning for emergency protection of the 3.3 million people who live near the country's 73 operating atomic power plants.

title: 4 Subcontractors Indicted In Atlanta Airport Scheme
description: Four officials of subcontracting companies that worked on the $240 million concessions contract at Atlanta's new airport terminal have been indicted on charges of conspiring to take almost $1 million in a kickback scheme.

title: RECITAL: JEROME LOWENTHAL AT PIANO
description: JEROME LOWENTHAL clearly took special care to make his Tully Hall piano recital pleasurable on Tuesday night, and his efforts paid off. Having devised an unconventional program of mostly conventional works, he played it with aplomb, authority and virtuosity of the sort that long since carved a niche for him in the concert world.

title: INMATES ASK BAN ON DRUGS AS METHOD OF EXECUTION
description: Two death row inmates, held in states where prisoners may be executed by lethal drugs, are asking the Government to place a warning label on the drugs declaring them unsafe and illegal for executions. Larry Chaney, an inmate at the Oklahoma State Penitentiary, and Doyle Skillern, a prisoner at the Ellis unit of the Texas Department of Corrections, made the request in a petition filed with the Department of Health and Human Services. "There is strong evidence to believe" that use of the drugs "may actually result in agonizingly slow and painful deaths that are far more barbaric than those caused by the more traditional means of execution," the petition states. The petition, first disclosed by the Washington Drug Letter, a weekly newsletter, asks Patricia Roberts Harris, Secretary of Health and Human Services, to ban the use of lethal injections as contrary to laws enforced by the Food and Drug Administration. Approved in Four States No one has been executed by the method, which has been approved by Texas, Oklahoma, Idaho and New Mexico. Those states house 166 of the 691 people currently under death sentence in the United States, according to the petition. In addition Florida, Tennessee, Nevada, South Carolina, Washington and Kansas have "seriously considered" adopting the method, according to lawyers for the two men. Oklahoma regultaions specify that sodium thiopental, a quick-acting barbituate, be used in conjunction with a chemical paralytic - tubocurarine, succinylcholine chloride or potassium chloride. The other states do not specify which drugs are to be used, but all require intravenous administration of lethal doses until the prisoner is dead.

title: EXCERPTS FROM WATT'S STATEMENT
description: Following are excerpts from the opening statement of James G. Watt today before the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee considering his designation as Secretary of the Interior:

title: VOLCKER CAUTIONS ON INFLATION
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the board's tight hold on growth of money and credit was likely to cut off any strong economic recovery as long as inflation remained high.

title: E.P.A. LIFTS DEADLINE ON POLLUTION LIMITS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, saying it is trying to help ''financially troubled'' automobile makers, today announced it was extending by two years a deadline for the major car manufacturers to meet air pollution standards for certain models.

title: ARCHITECTS PLAY WITH SPATIAL ILLUSIONS
description: THE first word that comes to mind when his work is seen happens to be the one word that he dislikes. But, in fact, the work of Charles Boxenbaum is clever. The New York architect's special attitude toward design is exemplified in two recently completed projects: the new Woods restaurant at 148 West 37th Street and an apartment/office for a psychologist on the Upper West Side. In both, Mr. Boxenbaum emphasized the ways in which space can be manipulated to serve different functions.

title: CONNECTICUT GOVERNOR FAVORS CUTS IN SPENDING INSTEAD OF RISE IN TAXES
description: In his first State of the State address, Gov. William A. O'Neill said today that he favored cutting spending rather than increasing taxes to eliminate a deficit in this year's budget. But he said that balancing spending with existing revenues would be even harder for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

title: Boy, 3, Kills Himself With Gun He Found
description: A 3-year-old boy shot himself in the head yesterday with an unlicensed .38-caliber handgun he had found while playing in a bedrooom in his parents' Brooklyn home, the police reported.

title: BIOLOGIST TELLS OF FURTHER PROGRESS IN MICE CLONING
description: The successful cloning of mice, reported earlier this week by scientists in Switzerland and the United States, has been carried one step further, an experimenter disclosed yesterday. Multiple genetically identical mice have been produced by transplanting cell nuclei from a single embryo, he said.

title: No Headline
description: IRAQ REPORTS HALTING IRANIAN COUNTERATTACK

title: Changes Considered At Alexander's Units
description: Alexander's Inc. is considering changes in its store at 58th Street and Lexington Avenue that promise to bring ''dramatic benefits to the company,'' Robin L. Farkas, chairman, told the annual shareholders meeting in Denver. He also said that the company was considering building a shopping center at its Rego Park store in Queens, which might contain several other large stores.

title: Loews Discloses Holdings in ABC
description: The Loews Corporation said it had purchased 1,521,400 shares, or 5.4 percent, of the American Broadcasting Companies for $43.5 million. It said the acquisition, made through Loew's Theatres Inc., was ''solely for investment.''

title: Markets
description: Stock prices plunged and trading was the heaviest on record as investors responded to a warning by a prominent stock forecaster, Joseph Granville, to ''sell everything.'' He gave no explanation for the sharp turnabout from his advice of Jan. 3 ''to buy aggressively.'' The Dow Jones industrial average fell 23.80 points, to 980.89, as volume swelled to 92.9 million shares. The biggest casualties were the recently strong blue-chips and technology issues. Seven times as many stocks fell as advanced. (Page A1.)

title: IN A TOUCH OF CHARITY,NASA GETS $60,000 TO CONTINUE MARS MISSION
description: The nation's space program today received $60,000 in donations from 10,000 individuals concerned that the Viking robot is still working busily on Mars but that space scientists have been too financially pressed to listen to it.

title: LONG-TERM STUDY LINKS CHOLESTEROL TO HAZARD OF EARLY CORONARY DEATH
description: An analysis of deaths among 1,900 middle-aged American men whose diets and cholesterol levels were first examined more than 20 years ago has shown that consumption of large amounts of cholesterol increased their risk of dying prematurely of a heart attack.

title: FOR SKIERS, EQUIPMENT ORGANIZERS
description: THIS is the time of year to get ski equipment organized, and there are several items that can help. The Scandinavian Ski Shop, at 40 West 57th Street, carries several useful items.

title: ALASKA AIR ORDERS 2 737's
description: Alaska Airlines has ordered two Boeing 737 airliners, an order worth about $25 million, the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company reports.

title: General Ordered to Divulge 2 Names in Garwood Case
description: A military judge ordered a retired general today to divulge information that Pfc. Robert Garwood of the Marine Corps contends will support his story that torture by the Vietcong drove him insane.

title: ALGERIAMS SAID TO OFFER IRAN NEW IDEAS
description: The key Iranian negotiator in the hostage situation said today that the Algerian intermediaries had given Iran new suggestions aimed at freeing the 52 American hostages.

title: Brooklyn 66, Lehman 58
description: Larry Vitelli led a balanced attack with 20 points in Brooklyn College's 66-58 triumph over Lehman at the winner's gym Wednesday night.

title: Suspect Arrested In Slaying of Child
description: A 19-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested and charged with fatally shooting a 7-year-old boy and wounding the boy's mother as she bathed him Tuesday night in their apartment in Elmhurst, Queens.

title: ANONOMOUS DONORS AID NEEDIEST
description: An anonymous gift of $10,000 is among the contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, now in its 69th year, from benefactors who choose not to be identified.

title: Fighters Throw Punchlines at Garden
description: Thomas Hearns continued his campaign to get in the same ring with the welterweight he calls Chicken Ray Leonard as five of the eight main-event fighters on the Feb. 23 Madison Square Garden card cluttered a news conference yesterday.

title: IN REPONSE TO 'HERS': DOCTORS AND DECISIONS
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: While I agree wholeheartedly with Maggie Scarf's statement that people have to take responsibility for their own bodies and their own lives, her conclusion that women are intimidated by doctors and revert to being good little girls so that they will be taken care of does not follow from the story she relates.

title: CITY IMPLEMENTING PROGRAM TO REDUCE WATER LEAKS
description: New York City yesterday began to implement measures to reduce leaks that waste an estimated 100 million gallons of water daily. The measures, which anticipate the probable declaration of a drought emergency within the next two or three weeks, included the introduction of an electronic leak detector that officials say can pinpoint leaks in underground water mains to within an eighth of an inch.

title: TransCanada Signs 10-Year Gas Accord
description: TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. said it had signed a 10-year agreement that would enable the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation to deliver 300 million cubic feet of natural gas a day to the Eastern United States by late 1982.

title: Exxon Asia Plant
description: Exxon Chemical, a division of the Exxon Corporation, is setting up a $28.8 million plant to produce lubricating oil additives for sale in the Asia-Pacific region. The company said the plant, on the island of Ayer Chawan, will be operational in two years. Foster Wheeler Italiana, an engineering and construction company, has been appointed major contractor for the project, the company said.

title: Kenya Identifies Moroccan As Man Who Bombed Hotel
description: The Kenyan Government said today that the terrorist who bombed a hotel here on New Year's Eve was a Moroccan and a member of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine.

title: Begin Rebuffed on Teacher Pay; Some Papers Ask Him to Resign
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin made another unsuccessful attempt today to solve a teachers' pay dispute threatening his Government. Some Israeli newspapers called for his resignation.

title: News Analysis
description: As the Senate Foreign Relations Committee prepares to open confirmation hearings tomorrow on the nomination of Alexander M. Haig Jr. as Secretary of State, there are unanswered questions about the state of the 56-year-old retired general's health.

title: 1980 CAR SALES AT 19-YEAR LOW
description: Last year the domestic automobile industry had its worst sales year since 1961. The five United States manufacturers today reported sales of 6.58 million cars for 1980, down 20 percent from 1979. The 1961 figure was 5.56 million.

title: South Africa Gold Offer
description: South Africa is offering world investors a medallion of gold weighing one kilogram (2.2 pounds), but initially only in a limited edition of 100.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 8, 1981; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Commission on Transnational Corpo- rations, Intergovernmental Working Group on a Code of Conduct - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FIRE INSPECTOR SAYS DOORS MUST BE SHUT AT CITY HALL
description: On Tuesday, an inspector from New York's Fire Department walked through City Hall shaking his head. It was only in part because he marveled at the French Renaissance facade and the Corinthian columns of the 169-year-old building.

title: Fire at French Nuclear Plant
description: Fire broke out overnight in a silo containing radioactive wastes at the nearby La Hague nuclear reprocessing plant, plant officials said today. The fire, which was put out after several hours, did not spread outside the silo and there was no danger of contamination, the officials said.

title: SOVIET MOSLEM AREA SHOWS NEW CONCERN ON SUBVERSION
description: The Communist Party chief of Soviet Azerbaijan has called for stepped-up security in the southern regions of the Soviet Union bordering on Iran and Afghanistan.

title: St. Francis (Pa.) 78, Post 68
description: Charlie Kates pumped in 20 points and grabbed 13 rebounds as St. Francis College of Loretto, Pa., rallied from an early deficit and beat C.W. Post tonight, 78-68. Peter Blodnick led Post (4-5) with 16 points.

title: 4 FILMS WIN THE LAURELS, BUT CAN BE SEEN NOWHERE
description: Four of the films most frequently cited as among the best of 1980, ''The Great Santini,''''The Stunt Man,''''Coal Miner's Daughter'' and ''Melvin and Howard,'' are out of circulation.

title: Military Analysis
description: Fighting in Iran has intensified as a result of a counteroffensive that President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr announced Monday, but analysts in the United States and other Western countries say they find no basis for Iran's claims of great victories.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: ATLANTA (NL) - Agreed to terms with G aylord Perry, free-agent pitcher, for a o ne-year contract at a reported $300,000. METS (NL) - Signed Tom Hausman, p itcher, to a two-year contract, and Dave V on Ohlen, pitcher, to a one-year contract.

title: LATEST HOW-TO HELP IS ON VIDEOTAPES
description: AS the year 1984 approaches, practical applications of technology appear to be shaping a total picture that would do George Orwell proud. With the advent of videocassette players, afternoon television viewing need no longer be confined to soap operas.

title: KELLY SAYS HE TOOK $25,000 AS COVER-UP
description: Former Representative Richard Kelly steadfastly insisted today that that he went to a late-night meeting with an undercover agent a year ago and accepted a $25,000 payoff from him solely in an ''attempt to find out what these people were doing and what they wanted with me.''

title: Trudeau Leaves Austrian Alps
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada left Austria today for West Germany after being stranded in an Alpine village for four days by 10 feet of snow and extreme avalanche danger. Mr. Trudeau arrived in Austria last week for a vacation at Lech in the Austrian Alps. The bad weather prevented his departure until today.

title: JUDGE BARS TRIAL DELAY ON A.T.&.T.
description: A Federal District Court today ordered that the Justice Department's civil antitrust case to break up the American Telephone and Telegraph Company go to trial as scheduled on Jan. 15 despite a request by both sides for a postponement because of what the court called agreement ''on a framework for a settlement.''

title: Venezuela Takeover Of Reynolds Project
description: Venezuela reportedly has obtained majority control of an aluminumproducing venture with the Reynolds Metals Company. The Venezuelan Press Agency said that Venezuela had invested $51.5 million of new capital in the project, thus raising its stake in Aluminios del Caroni S.A. to 72.1 percent from 50 percent, and reducing Reynolds's interest to 27.9 percent.

title: 'Pirates' Cast to Celebrate, but Not in a Saloon
description: On Dec. 31, 1879, when Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Pirates of Penzance'' had its world premiere in New York, where did Gilbert and Sullivan go to await the reviews?

title: PANAMA CANAL REDUCES TRANSIT BACKLOG
description: Canal pilots and onshore crews, working large amounts of overtime, have sharply pared a record backlog of vessels waiting to transit the Panama Canal.

title: Bomb for Mrs. Thatcher Defused
description: A bomb in a parcel addressed to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's official residence at 10 Downing Street was intercepted at a London postal sorting office today, Scotland Yard said. A police spokesman said the parcel contained a ''genuine device'' and it was defused.

title: RESHUFFLE AT FIRST CHICAGO
description: Barry Sullivan, chairman of the First Chicago Corporation for the last six months, today announced an extensive reorganization of the troubled bank holding company. Richard L. Thomas, president, regains many of the responsibilities he lost a year ago when turmoil began in the bank's executive suite.

title: Semiconductor's Earnings Up 31.8%
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation, a major manufacturer of semiconductor components, reported that earnings in its second fiscal quarter of 1981, ended Dec. 14, rose 31.8 percent, to $14.5 million, or 65 cents a share, from $11 million, or 54 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter of the preceding year.

title: A.I.A.W. Sets Board Rules
description: The Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women voted today to increase from one to two the number of students on the 24-member executive board. At its annual convention, the association also voted that a minimmum of 20 percent of the members on most of its key committees and the executive board be minority women.

title: CITY'S MIXED-USE LOFT PLAN DENOUNCED
description: A proposal to preserve industrial loft space while providing for the conversion of lofts into residences met resistance from both manufacturing and residential quarters yesterday at a public hearing before the New York City Planning Commission.

title: Bridge: Some Conclusions Offered On Differences in Maturity
description: A player who makes a mark on the national scene as a teen-ager is nearly always male; but veterans who win major titles are nearly always female. The women, it would appear, mature more slowly but are more durable.

title: Reagan Voices Hope On the Hostage Talks
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan said today that he was ''hopeful'' about the latest developments in negotiations to free the American hostages.

title: ON SNOWY CHRISTMAS EVE, FAITH BLOOMS IN MOSCOW
description: The snow started falling around nightfall yesterday, great, soft, crystalline flakes, that special Russian kind of snow that Tolstoy wrote about.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK
description: GIVEN DIVORCE'S PREVALENCE IN FICTION, MARRIAGE APPEARS TO BE A BAD NOVEL By ANATOLE BROYARD

title: Jets 8, Leafs 2
description: Doug Smail, Rick Bowness and Dave Christian scored two goals each to give Winnipeg its first road victory of the season, an 8-2 decison tonight over the Toronto Maple Leafs. It was the Jets' fourth victory in 40 games.

title: CHOOSING SHAPES AND TEXTURES FOR WINTER TERRACES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Linda Yang writes frequently on gardening for The New York Times. By LINDA YANG

title: No Headline
description: terday in Marseilles, France. Minutes later the gunman and an accomplice were shot and killed by policemen. The hostage was uninjured, but a passerby was wounded.

title: BODY OF 2D OFFICIAL SOUGHT
description: A mountain man sought in the slaying of two Idaho game wardens was the object of a widespread air and ground search today 35 miles east of here in the extreme southwest corner of Idaho.

title: Building Repair Ordinance Voted
description: The City Council voted today to make owners of 8,000 brick and masonry buildings built before 1934 to strengthen the structures so that they would be less likely to collapse in a major earthquake. Ignoring opposition by landlords who contended that the law would force them to either evict tenants or raise rents drastically, the Council voted, 11 to 3, to require the repairs. Total cost of the work on the buildings, located mainly in the downtown, Hollywood and Wilshire districts, is expected to be about $750 million.

title: A FORMAL TOUCH MARKS CONVENING OF LEGISLATURE
description: There are some legislators who take their oath of office now by having their secretaries notarize a sheet of paper and mail it to the Capitol.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 20.00-20.50** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: North Carolina Tops Maryland by 75-66
description: Al Wood's second-half shooting and clutch free throws down the stretch by three other players enabled North Carolina to defeat Maryland tonight, 75-66, in an Atlantic Coast Conference basketball game.

title: U.N. REPORT ON PRESS IS CAUSING CONCERN
description: The United Nations has quietly moved toward endorsing a report that some Western journalists fear would strengthen government control of the press.

title: All-Pro Football By The Associated Press
description: The Associated Press All-Pro Team for the 1980 National Football League season: FIRST TEAM OFFENSE Wide Receiver - John Jefferson, San Diego Chargers; Charlie Joiner, San Diego Chargers. Tight End - Kellen Winslow, San Diego Chargers.

title: Dartmouth 68, St. Francis 62
description: Dartmouth extended its unbeaten streak to six games as it scored a 68-62 comeback victory over St. Francis of Brooklyn tonight. With the game tied at 60-60, Paul Anderson connected on a layup with 1:27 left to put Dartmouth ahead for good. Larry Lawrence of Dartmouth led all scorers with 18; Mark Woods had 16 for the Terriers (2-9).

title: Crocker Cuts Mortgage Rate
description: The Crocker National Bank, the nation's 13th-largest commercial bank, cut its home mortgage rate to 15 percent from 16 percent today.

title: Nick Cascio, 65, a Safecracker; Known as Thief 'You Could Trust'
description: Nick Cascio one of the last old-time safecrackers in the Southwest, was buried yesterday. He died Sunday at the age of 65.

title: Questions For the General
description: If the Senate Foreign Relations Committee is serious about checking the credentials of Alexander Haig, one subject its hearings will explore is the pardon of President Nixon. For there is good reason to think that General Haig played a critical role in the pardon. And, curiously, no official body has ever asked him about it.

title: MRS. LLOYD, CZECH STAR OPEN WITH TRIUMPHS
description: Andrea Jaeger showed up with an improved first serve and no braces on her teeth for the first time in three years. Pam Shriver was the hometown heroine from nearby Lutherville. Virginia Ruzici was well rested, and Wendy Turnbull had the best tan.

title: WHERE TO APPLY: A SELECTION OF CLASSES AND CLINICS
description: FOLLOWING is a selection of facilities in the metropolitan area and elsewhere that help obese and overweight children through food management and group interaction. Unless otherwise noted, clinic fees are based on a sliding scale according to ability to pay. The maximum fees are listed.

title: DUTCHESS COUNTY NEEDS NO FOURTH PRISON
description: To the Editor:

title: STOCKS DECLINE SHARPLY AS TRADING SOARS TO RECORD
description: The stock market had one of its most spectacular sessions yesterday as prices plunged in the heaviest trading on record after a widely followed investment adviser urged his clients to sell their shares.

title: Mets Sign Hausman, Jorgensen
description: The Mets solidified their ranks yesterday by signing Tom Hausman and Mike Jorgensen, two players who contributed to the team's midseason surge last year.

title: Father Is Accused Of Thefts From Son
description: A Long Island man has been arrested on charges of stealing more than $200,000 that his son had been awarded as damages for crippling injuries he received two years ago in a lacrosse game.

title: Executone Will Stay With Nadler & Larimer
description: After interviewing four ad agencies, Executone, marketer of telecommunications systems, has decided to stay with Nadler & Larimer, its agency since 1967. Executone, which spends more than $2 million a year for advertising, was acquired in 1979 by the Continental Telephone System.

title: All of Reagan's Movies
description: He was a soldier, a sailor, a pilot, a cavalry officer, a playboy, a social worker, a football player, a baseball pitcher, a pianist, a music publisher, a Broadway producer, a radio announcer, a sports reporter, a college professor, a plantation foreman, a rancher, a lawyer, an insurance investigator, a Secret Service agent, a crusading district attorney and even a gangster.

title: Refiners Raise Fuel Prices
description: Refiners across the country said yesterday that they had raised wholesale prices of home heating oil and gasoline as much as a nickel a gallon amid rising foreign and domestic crude oil prices and unusually cold weather that has increased consumption of heating fuel.

title: Varig Jetliner Lease
description: A Boeing Company subsidiary said that Varig, Brazil's international air carrier, had leased, with options to buy, three 747-200B jetliners valued at more than $200 million, including spare parts and supporting equipment. Terms of the lease package were not disclosed. The jets would be delivered over the next three months.

title: EXPERTS SEE '76 VICTORY AS CARTER'S BIG ACHIEVEMENT
description: ''History will treat him more kindly than the American people did on Nov. 4,'' said Clark M. Clifford, who has been watching Presidents come and go for 40 years. ''But there was nothing epochal about his Presidency, nothing really remarkable.''

title: REAGAN COMPLETES CABINET AND KEEPS MANSFIELD AS ENVOY
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan completed the selection of his Cabinet today by picking T.H. Bell as Secretary of Education and, in a dramatic gesture to Senate Democrats, announced that Mike Mansfield, the former Senate majority leader, would be retained as United States Ambassador to Japan.

title: Gary Bertini to Be Adviser To the Detroit Symphony
description: The Israeli-born conductor Gary Bertini is leaving the Scottish National Orchestra shortly to become music adviser to the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, it was announced today.

title: APPLYING A JACOBEAN FINISH ON OAK PIECES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Varese restores furniture for antiques dealers and collectors. By MICHAEL VARESE

title: F.T.C. Clears Sale Of Cooper Tool Unit
description: The Federal Trade Commission said it had approved the sale by Cooper Industries Inc. of its Rotar tool division for $24.1 million to the R.T. Acquiring Company, which is a group made up in part by the division's current management.

title: BIG OIL, CONSERVATIONIST
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINA AND GLASS: NEW AND NOSTALGIC
description: ACCESSORIES are a major part of the Atlantic City China and Glass Show, which is ending this week. ''Flooded with pastels,'' remarked Arlene Hirst, vice president of the Pottery Barn, ''and lots of roosters, hens and country looks.''

title: Order Kept for 'Princess' Film
description: Unitd States District Judge Gabrielle McDonald refused a request today by the State of Texas to stay her Dec. 18 order to the University of Houston's public-television station to broadcast ''Death of a Princess.'' KUHT-TV canceled the film depicting the alleged 1977 execution of a Saudi Arabian princess and her lover last May.

title: Carter Honors Millard Fillmore on His Birthday
description: President Carter yesterday remembered the 181st anniversary of the birth of Millard Fillmore, and so did some admirers in his hometown of Buffalo.

title: Massey Rating Cut
description: The financial problems of Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the largest Canadian manufacturer of farm machinery, led the Standard & Poor's Corporation to cut its rating to CCC from B for the sinking fund debentures of the Massey-Ferguson Credit Corporation.

title: People
description: * John P. Gill has been elected a senior vice president of Ogilvy & Mather.

title: SIMPLE STEPS CONSERVE WATER AND THE ENERGY USED TO HEAT IT
description: WE tend to think of water as a natural resource that is always available and costs little or nothing. But it is becoming evident that stringent conservation is growing more essential to our survival - as can be seen from the current water shortages in New York and New Jersey.

title: Connecticut Returns 12 Diesel Rail Cars
description: Eleven of Connecticut's 13 new diesel-powered rail cars were returned to the manufacturer last week for repairs, according to William Lynch, the state's Director of Rail Operations. A 12th was sidelined by fire damage.

title: Kentucky 79, Auburn 66
description: Kentucky, behind the balanced scoring of Sam Bowie, Fred Cowan and Dirk Minniefield, defeated Auburn, 79-66, tonight in a Southeastern Conference game. Cowan scored 17 points, Bowie 15 and Minniefield 13.

title: YOUNG U.S. JOURNALIST MISSING IN EL SALVADOR: A DETERMINED NOVICE
description: John J. Sullivan, the 26-year-old Bogota, N.J., freelance writer reported missing in El Salvador, was described yesterday as a man with one purpose in life - to be a journalist.

title: Immigration Panel Modifies Opposition to Identity Cards
description: A Federal immigration commission today retracted its earlier outright opposition to issuing identification cards for American workers, and said it favored the idea when coupled with penalties for hiring illegal aliens.

title: BRITONS DEBATE EFFICACY OF MONETARISM
description: As the pulse of British industry slows and thousands of jobs disappear every week, there is a shrill and growing national debate about what has gone wrong with the economy, causing Britain's worst recession since the 1930's.

title: THE STAGE: MERYL STREEP SINGS IN 'ALICE IN CONCERT'
description: THERE is only one wonder in Elizabeth Swados's musical adaptation of Lewis Carroll, ''Alice in Concert,'' and it goes by the name of Meryl Streep. Maybe it's gratuitous to rave about this amazing actress at this late date, but what else is there to do? Certainly it's more fun to sing Miss Streep's praises than contemplate Miss Swados's songs. Besides, one leaves the Public owing this star a considerable debt. Imagine ''Alice'' without her, and it's hard to picture any show at all.

title: Western to Consider UNC's Merger Offer
description: Western Airlines said today that it would consider an acquisition bid from UNC Resources Inc. but that it favored its previously announced merger proposal with Continental Airlines.

title: Campbell Is Seeking $1 Million a Season
description: Earl Campbell's agent, Witt Stewart, said today that Campbell, the three-time National Football League rushing champion, was seeking a new contract with the Houston Oilers worth approximately $1 million a year. Stewart said Campbell would sit out next season if the Oilers refused to renegotiate with him or trade him.

title: USE OF ENERGY CODES LAGS IN MANY AREAS
description: IN the last few years, most states passed some form of construction code governing the use of energy-saving materials in new homes, but the effectiveness is uncertain. Many localities within states have not yet adopted the code, and other states are unable to enforce it because of a shortage of trained building inspectors.

title: Lincoln Center to Exhibit Art With Musical Subjects
description: An exhibition of paintings, lithographs and sculpture depicting musical subjects and Wagnerian themes will be shown at the Cork Gallery in Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center from Jan. 30 through Feb. 13.

title: RAISE OF 22.3% SOUGHT FOR OFFICIALS
description: President Carter today recommended a salary increase of 22.3 percent for Cabinet members, members of Congress, Federal judges and most other high-level Federal officials.

title: STOCKS UP IN NERVOUS TRADING
description: The stock market produced a token gain amid nervous trading yesterday after suffering brutal losses in the two previous sessions. Improving prices for leading oil issues were a factor in yesterday's late recovery.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Stores Corporation has appointed Charles B. James president and division chief executive of the Joske's division, Dallas, and William C. Murray president and division chief executive of Donaldson's in Minneapolis.

title: P.S.C. Staff Urges Refund by Con Ed
description: ALBANY (AP) - The staff of the state's Public Service Commission said Consolidated Edison should be forced to refund $43 million to its customers because of a ''substantial likelihood'' that ''imprudent actions'' by the utility caused the Oct. 17 shutdown of the Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant.

title: PHIL ESPOSITO RETIRING AS PLAYER TO BE RANGER ASSISTANT COACH
description: Phil Esposito of the New York Rangers, a candidate for the hall of fame and the leading goal-scorer among active players, has decided to retire as a player and become the team's assistant coach.

title: Cotton Estimate Raised
description: The 1980 cotton harvest is now estimated at 11.1 million bales, 2 percent more than the 10.9 million bales estimated a month ago, the Agriculture Department said today. The crop still falls about 24 percent short of the 1979 harvest of 14.6 million bales.

title: REAGAN ADVISERS SEEK TO PUT OFF REDUCTION IN TAXES TILL SUMMER
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan's economic advisers now favor having his contemplated cut in personal income tax rates take effect next July or August rather than retroactively as of Jan. 1, as they had agreed six weeks ago, associates of Mr. Reagan disclosed today.

title: FIVE INCHES OF SNOW SLOWS TRAINS AND SHUTS SOME SCHOOLS
description: More than five inches of snow fell on New York City and surrounding areas yesterday, disrupting rail traffic and school systems and contributing to three deaths. The snow hardened in freezing temperatures overnight, and bitter cold and icy roads were likely today.

title: U.S.-JAPAN PANAL IN FREE TRADE PLEA
description: An economic task force appointed by the American and Japanese Governments has urged the United States to keep its trade doors open despite growing Japanese competition. At the same time, it also suggested that Japan ''substantially'' improve access to its market and society.

title: Jaworski Named Winner Of Bert Bell Award
description: The Philadelphia Eagles' Ron Jaworski was named winner today of the Bert Bell Award as the outstanding pro football player.

title: Elissa Sara Shay Is Married To Marc Steven Schneier
description: Elissa Sara Shay, daughter of Dr. Melvin Shay of Brooklyn and the late Lucy Bohm Shay, was married at the Park East Synagogue last Sunday to Marc Steven Schneier, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Arthur Schneier of New York. Chief Rabbi Shlomo Goren of Israel and Chief Rabbi Moses Rosen of Rumania participated in the ceremony with the bridegroom's father, spiritual leader of the synagogue since 1962.

title: 4 Oil Concerns Increase Prices
description: Four of the nation's largest refiners said yesterday that they were increasing wholesale prices of gasoline and heating oil as much as 3 cents a gallon, attributing the moves to rising crude oil costs here and overseas.

title: Westport Voters Bar Enlarged Marina
description: By a margin of almost 4 to 1, voters in a referendum have rejected a proposed $2.3 million marina plan.

title: WASHINGTON MEETING ON THE ARTS
description: A group of religious and arts organizations will sponsor a national meeting in Washington Sept. 13-16 to consider the importance of the arts in contemporary society.

title: Mrs. Chennault, in Taipei, Denies Peacemaking Role
description: Anna Chennault, a Republican Party activist, denied today that she was on a peacemaking mission between Taiwan and China and said her recent trip to Peking had not weakened her support for the Nationalist Government in Taipei.

title: NUCLEAR ENERGY AIDE AND FOREIGN ADVISER APPOINTED IN TRIPOLI
description: Libya restructured its Government today, creating a Ministry for Atomic Energy and naming a top foreign affairs adviser to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the nation's leader.

title: HERS
description: ''ISUPPOSE,'' said the woman, ''that many of the people who interview you about your book on women and depression really want to know about themselves - about their own problems, I mean, about whether they themselves are depressed?''

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JANUARY 8, 1981
description: International A direct role in the hostage crisis was pressed by Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher. In an unexpected move, the State Department announced that he was flying to Algiers to discuss the negotiations to free the 52 Americans held in Iran. Earlier, the department said that ''important questions remain to be solved'' to end the crisis. (Page A1, Column 3.) Efforts to break the deadlock over freedom for the hostages were accelerated by the Algerian intermediaries in Teheran. They presented new, undisclosed suggestions to Iran, according to a key Iranian negotiator who said that the ideas had generally been accepted in principle. (A4:4-6.)

title: Arrest of Court Clerk Leads to Investigation; Of Paterson Officials
description: The arrest of a deputy clerk of the Paterson (N.J.) Municipal Court after he allegedly promised a prostitute that he would take care of her $250 fine in exchange for sexual favors has led to a widespread investigation of alleged corruption among court officials, the city's Police Department reported yesterday.

title: BEGIN THE NEW YEAR BY CULLING PLANTS
description: THE start of a new year is important for gardeners. It strengthens their resolve and gives them courage to make decisions, hard decisions to do away with plants that are not loved.

title: IN RESPONSE TO 'HERS': DOCTORS AND DECISIONS
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: What happened to Maggie Scarf's daughter happened to me. After a gynecologist examined the lump in my breast, he sent me to a surgeon in the same building.

title: Products Introduced By Hewlett-Packard
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company introduced a new personal computer equipped with what the concern called ''powerful graphics abilities.''

title: Polish Woman, 112, Dies
description: Poland's oldest woman died today at the age of 112, the official press agency said.

title: Koussevitzky's Riposte
description: Just about everyone knows that old joke: ''What's the best way to get to Carnegie Hall?'' (Practice, sonny, practice!) But Lukas Foss, the composer, conductor and pianist credits Serge Koussevitzky, late conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, with teaching him, indelibly, the truly best way of getting to Carnegie Hall.

title: U.S. PRODDING 4 STATES TO PUT AN END TO SEGREGASTION IN HIGHER EDUCATION
description: Acting under Federal court order, the Department of Education notified the Governors of Alabama, Delaware, South Carolina and West Virginia today that their state colleges and universities were unconstitutionally segregated.

title: WALL STREET WITHSTANDS ANEXPECTED ONSLAUGHT
description: For months, Wall Street professionals had been building their bulwarks, preparing for a predicted deluge of 100-million, and even 150-million-share days. Paper-handling procedures were streamlined.

title: In Response to 'Hers': Doctors and Decisions TO THE HOME SECTION:
description: I was very interested in Maggie Scarf's account (''Hers,'' Dec. 18) of her daughter's experience with a breast cyst. About three years ago, at the age of 23, I was also diagnosed as having a fibroadenoma, which was removed by surgery.

title: State of the State, and the Governor
description: Governor Carey is not content to have his annual message read merely as a guide to what the New York Legislature should do this year. He offers it as a guide to a new era. This echo of New Deal and New Frontier and Great Society invites misgivings. Is the Governor succumbing to dreams of glory? Preparing for a re-election campaign in 1982? Such impressions are probably unfair. Beneath the immense detail of the message lies a coherent order and a shrewd understanding of what people want from their government. What the State of the State Message discloses most of all is that Mr. Carey's interest in the problems of the state has been reawakened, and that is very good news.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 19.50-20.50** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: New York Tech 74 City College 55
description: Bobby Jones scored a game-high 29 points, leading New York Tech to a 74-55 victory over City College at the Nat Holman Gymnasium Wednesday night. City College, which never led, trailed at the half, 34-30.

title: No Headline
description: JAILED ITALIAN WANTS JUDGE FREED

title: MONEY SUPPLY IS OFF AGAIN
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's money supply declined by $2.5 billion in the week ended Dec. 31. This enabled the Fed to achieve its 1980 growth targets for money supply.

title: Jealousy and Envy Cited by Pope As Among the 'Sins of the Flesh'
description: ROME. Jan. 7 (UPI) - Pope John Paul II said today that ''sins of the flesh'' included not only fornication but also emotions such as jealousy, envy and unfriendliness.

title: CHOICE FOR INTERIOR JOB VOWS BOTH TO PRESERVE AND TO DEVELOP LANDS
description: James G. Watt, whose designation as the next Secretary of the Interior is bitterly opposed by most environmental groups, declared today that he was a man who loved this nation's lands and was committed to preserving their beauty and environmental values.

title: TWO PRODUCTS MUST HALT CLAIMS OF ENDORSEMENT
description: The Government has cracked down on the use of such claims as ''doctors recommend'' in advertising for two widely sold products, Fleischmann's Margarine and the Water Pik teeth-cleaning device.

title: Missing Atlanta Teen-Ager Brings Toll to 16 Children
description: The count of missing and slain black children in Atlanta rose to 16 today when the name of a 14-year-old boy was added to the list of missing, rekindling fears that had begun to ebb since the most recent slaying two months ago.

title: GENEVA GENETICS
description: To the Editor:

title: Eurodollar Loan Planned by I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machine Corporation said that its overseas subsidiary, the IBM World Trade Corporation, was trying to arrange $200 million in financing in the Eurodollar market.

title: Germans Find North Sea Gas
description: A West German exploration company said today that it had struck natural gas in the North Sea, 40 miles west of the island of Helgoland.

title: CLAIR L. FARRAND, 85, THE INVENTOR OF THE CONE RADIO LOUDSPEAKER
description: Clair Loring Farrand, inventor of the radio loudspeaker and holder of more than 250 patents, died today of a heart attack at his winter home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 85 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Morgan Stanley Man To U.S. Fuels Unit
description: Donald T. Regan, chairman of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. who is the Treasury Secretary-designate, is not the only Wall Street executive going into Federal service. Yesterday, the United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation announced that Robert T. Blakely, a 39-year-old managing director of Morgan Stanley & Company had been elected vice president for finance, or senior financial officer, of that Government-sponsored corporation.

title: Turkey Says Security Forces Have Arrested 85 Leftists
description: Turkish authorities said today that security forces had arrested 85 people in a new sweep of extreme leftist organizations. Those detained include four militants accused of murdering an American serviceman in Izmir in 1979.

title: Air of Urgency At Chrysler
description: ''Judgment day'' is near for the Chrysler Corporation, a union official today quoted the company's top finance officer as saying.

title: APPROVAL FOR LOAN BID SEEN BY CHRYSLER OFFICIAL ,
description: A ranking executive of the Chrysler Corporation said today that the company and its bankers were ''finetuning'' their financial plan for Chrysler's survival and that he expected the Government would give conditional approval next week for another $400 million of loan guarantees.

title: Bus Crash Near Manila Kills 12
description: A passenger bus and a cargo truck carrying chicken feed collided head on 40 miles north of Manila today, killing at least 12 people and injuring 37, the police said.

title: Evacuation in Derailment Ends
description: About 1,300 people returned home late today after two derailed railroad cars were righted in this community south of Baton Rouge. The cars, which contained 30,000 gallons of toxic anhydrous ammonia, did not leak and no injuries were reported, officials said.

title: POLISH UNION GROUP VOTES 5-DAY WEEK
description: Defying Poland's Communist leadership, delegates of the independent trade union today proclaimed a five-day work week starting this Saturday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: VILLAGE ROLLER RINK

title: AN ENERGY AUDIT OF A TYPICAL ROW HOUSE
description: UDITING the energy efficiency of your home is the first, easiest and most important step in a program to conserve fuel and cash. You can do much of it yourself, with help from a fuel company's mechanic and any of the many workbooks widely available, but an inspection by a professional energy auditor lends additional authority to the conclusions. Some independent auditors, generally engineers or architects, can also recommend major improvements, such as the advisability of a solar addition or the most suitable brand of oil burner for your heating system.

title: Raiders' Hendricks Looms as Foil to Fouts
description: ''We have ways,'' Al Davis was saying recently, ''of getting to Dan Fouts.'' Davis is the chief executive of the Oakland Raiders, and one of his biggest ways is Ted Hendricks, the 6-foot-7-inch outside left linebacker, who has had unusual success this season against the San Diego Chargers and Fouts, their quarterback. The next meeting occurs Sunday at San Diego, in the American Conference championship game.

title: ADVERTISING photo of magazine cover; Three Join to Publish A Cable TV Magazine
description: An agency man, a magazine man and a printing specialist, having joined forces and raised $10 million, are now prepared to do for cable television what TV Guide did for broadcast television.

title: The Midwife Alternative
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: It is ironic that Deborah Rankin, in her Family Finance column (''The Rising Costs of Having a Baby,'' Dec. 18), failed to mention the services of a Certified Nurse Midwife (C.N.M.) as a safe, less expensive alternative to physician-managed obstetrical care for the normal, healthy pregnant woman.

title: 'A BRIDGE FROM WELFARE TO WORK'
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S GOING ON?
description: Strange things are happening. Little ''twilight zones'' and ''Bermuda triangles.'' They're everywhere. For instance, objects in the house move from drawer to drawer, or even out, untouched by human hands. Only recently, a credit card, last seen in the vicinity of the kitchen sink, after a maddening search and unfounded accusations was found lodged mysteriously in a crack behind the car's windshield. How? Who?

title: Worse Than a Department of Education
description: Terrel Bell's service as United States Commissioner of Education in the Nixon and Ford Administrations was uneventful, yet even he was unhappy with education's subordinate place in the giant Department of Health, Education and Welfare. Now President-elect Reagan has nominated him to be the second and last Secretary of Education. That is, he must preside over the intended dismantling of the new department. The question about Mr. Bell is whether, in the process, he can be sufficiently assertive to protect education's standing.

title: Trial Shift to London Sought In 'Yorkshire Ripper' Case
description: The lawyer for the man suspected of being the so-called Yorkshire Ripper invoked emergency legislation today to cancel a second court appearance by his client and said he wanted any trial moved to London's Old Bailey courtroom.

title: Agreement With Perry, 42, Is Confirmed by Braves
description: The Atlanta Braves confirmed today that they had reached agreement with Gaylord Perry, the free-agent pitcher who is only 11 victories shy of the 300 mark.

title: No Headline
description: Braced hard against the trunk of a huge, overladen grapefruit tree, 15 feet off the ground, Harold Robertson shouted, ''Yeee-hahhh! Yip!'' and, with help of a partner, gave a mighty shake, loosing a cascade of chrome-yellow fruit and filling the air with the scent of citrus.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Barber Oil Corporation sold its tanker operating subsidiary, the Trindad Corporation, for $25.5 million to Apex Shipping Inc.

title: The Floating Party
description: Pickled water chestnuts wrapped with strips of cold bacon, half-deflated cheese puffs and bite-sized Chinese egg rolls are all we live on during the capital's pre-Inaugural season.

title: JOSHUA H. NEUMANN
description: Dr. Joshua H. Neumann, a specialist in 18th-century English, died Sunday at the Newton-Wellesley Hospital, Newton, Mass.

title: DANCE: CITY BALLEY BACK TO REGULAR REPERTORY
description: NO more leaping snowflakes, unhinged nutcrackers and carefully smiling party guests. The New York City Ballet returned to repertory on Tuesday at the New York State Theater after its annual slew of ''Nutcracker'' performances. And it was a return with a vengeance to variety, with a program that moved from a rich play of abstract dance to faded passion and ended with sheer, high-spirited fun.

title: Court Papers Enumerate Arizona State's Violations
description: Boosters and coaches at Arizona State University offered cash, cars and land to football players and prospective student-athletes in violation of National Collegiate rules, according to documents released in court today.

title: CLERICS ISSUE PETITION CHIDING ISRAEL ON PALESTINIANS
description: An American organization engaged in the cause of Palestinian rights issued a statement yesterday signed by 400 clerics and other religious figures that criticized Israel for what it termed incidents of injustice toward Palestinian Arabs.

title: Your Money; Shop Around For a Car Loan
description: HIGH interest rates and varying rules in different areas of the country with regard to interest rate ceilings increase the need to shop around before contracting for a loan to finance an automobile purchase.

title: Japan Shapes Oil-Saving Goal
description: Japan, which depends on imports for virtually all the crude oil it uses, hopes to cut oil consumption about 7 percent in the fiscal year starting April 1, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: Algerian Port Reopens
description: Oil and gas exports from Algeria's port of Arzew, halted since storms hit on Dec. 27 and 28, will resume tomorrow, a port official said today. The storms drove a 69,000-ton tanker aground and damaged other installations. Closing of the port halted about about half of Algeria's normal oil and gas exports and cost the country about $10 million a day, according to oil industry sources.

title: Dorothy Lathrop, 89, Illustrator Who Won First Caldecott Medal
description: Dorothy P. Lathrop, an author, artist and prize-winning book illustrator, died Dec. 30 at her home in Falls Village, Conn. She was 89 years old.

title: ACCOUNTANT FOR ABC IS FOUND SLAIN
description: An accountant with the American Broadcasting Companies was found bludgeoned to death in his Greenwich Village apartment last night, the police said.

title: ST.JOHN'S SETS BACK GEORGETOWN, 68-60
description: St. John's treated a crowd of 6,442, the largest ever at Alumni Hall, to a 68-60 basketball triumph over Georgetown last night for its ninth victory against two losses.

title: CLARK IS NOT FACING U.S. CRIMINAL ACTION
description: The Justice Department announced today that it would not file criminal charges against Ramsey Clark, the former Attorney General, who defied President Carter's ban on travel to Iran by attending a conference in Teheran last June.

title: Hunt to Appeal Ruling on B.P.
description: Nelson Bunker Hunt, the Texas oilman, has decided to go ahead with an appeal to Britain's highest court, the House of Lords, to try to reverse an earlier court decision that he owes British Petroleum $40.8 million.

title: SENATORS TO QUESTION HAIG ON 7 KEY AREAS
description: Insisting they did not want to ''rehash Watergate, or witch-hunt,'' Senator Claiborne Pell and other Democrats on the Foreign Relations Committee met for two hours today to plan strategy for the confirmation hearings on the nomination of Alexander M. Haig Jr. to be Secretary of State.

title: WNYC WILL AIM FOR SMALL GROUPS
description: A reorganization of the 56-year-old municipal broadcasting system, WNYC-AM, FM and TV, is being planned, according to John Beck, manager of the system. The result will be programming principally for the elderly, handicapped, ethnic groups and residents of Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx.

title: GRANVILLE PROMOTES MARKET-TURN FLAIR
description: It all started last night, with a barrage of telephone calls around the world. The urgent message was to ''sell everything and go short,'' and thousands of investors did exactly that yesterday.

title: EXCERPTS FROM GOV. O'NEILL'S STATE OF THE STATE MESSAGE TO CONNECTICUT'S LEGISLATURES
description: Following are excerpts from Gov. William A. O'Neill's State of the State address to the opening session of Connecticut's General Assembly: Special to the New York Times

title: MUSIC: 9 FIGUEROAS PLAY
description: JOSE FIGUEROA is a distinguished Puerto Rican violinist with a big family, and most of them came out on stage at Carnegie Hall Tuesday night to help celebrate his 75th birthday.

title: Foxboro Official Named President and Director
description: Colin I.W. Baxter, a New Zealander who speaks somewhat like a New Englander, yesterday was named president, chief of operations and a director of the Foxboro Company, one of the world's leading producers of instrumentation and control systems. The 49-year-old Mr. Baxter, previously executive vice president, succeeds Earle W. Pitt as president, while Mr. Pitt remains chairman and chief executive officer.

title: THE DOOMED HOMELANDS POLICY OF SOUTH AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: 'SALTY' CABINET CHOICE
description: T.H. Bell, the former Marine Corps first sergeant who is Utah's Commissioner of Higher Education and was named today by President-elect Ronald Reagan to be Secretary of Education, still has, say his friends, a marine's ''salty flavor,'' but never does he tell Marine Corps stories.

title: Celtics 108, Suns 90
description: Larry Bird scored 24 points and Robert Parish 21, and they led a 24-6 third-quarter run to help Boston defeat Phoenix.

title: CASEY, PREDICTING 4TH-QUARTER LOSS, NAMED CHAIRMAN-PRESIDENT AT BRANIFF
description: John J. Casey was named chairman and president of Braniff International yesterday, succeeding Harding L. Lawrence and Russell Thayer, respectively. Mr. Lawrence retired last week, and Mr. Thayer was named vice chairman, the position formerly held by Mr. Casey.

title: FOR TALKS WITH PYONGYANG
description: The United States should start talking with North Korea. Although 27 years have passed since the end of the Korean War, and while there have been a few meetings between representatives of North and South Korea, the two sides stand no closer to an agreement that would end the dispute between them and unify the country than they did in 1953. The two Koreas maintain two of the largest armies in the world, each ready to fight the other on a moment's notice.

title: BRITAION'S TRIBUTE TO MILTON FRIEDMAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Mortgage Rates Up Again
description: Conventional home mortgage rates increased in December for the fourth month in a row and are expected to rise further, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today. In early December, the average commitment for a 25-year mortgage on singlefamily homes with a 25 percent down payment was 14.93 percent, up from 14.26 percent in the previous month. Since August, average mortgage interest rates have risen 2.41 percentage points.

title: Wagner 115, Catholic 78
description: Wilson Ross, a freshman forward making his first start, scored 8 of Wagner College's first 16 points, and the Seahawks went on to trounce Catholic University, 115-78, Wednesday night at the victors' court on Staten Island.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt WAYS OF ESCAPE. By Graham Greene. 320 pages. Simon & Schuster. $12.95.

title: NAMIBIA CONFERENCE CONVENES IN GENEVA
description: Opening a conference that brought the contending sides in South-West Africa face-to-face for the first time, Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations called today for ''a firm agreement'' on a cease-fire date that would clear the way to independence for the territory by the end of the year.

title: Rates Rise on Signals from Fed; Money Supply On Tight Rein
description: Interest rates rose sharply yesterday amid signs that the Federal Reserve Board does not want rates to decline too far or too fast. Short-term interest rates, which had plummeted three percentage points and more over the past three weeks, reversed direction and rose about five-eighths of a point yesterday.

title: NEW STATUS SYMBOL: A THATCHED COTTAGE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jean Mann is a freelance writer. By JEAN MANN LONDON THE inviting picture of a small straw-topped cottage with roses climbing round the white and half-timbered walls still exists in Britain. But this picture of rustic simplicity costs a lot these days.

title: MIAMI BEACH, HURT BY BOYCOTT, VOTES TO BAR SEX DISCRIMINATION
description: Trying to halt economic losses resulting from a boycott by proponents of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment, the City Commission voted unanimously today to enact an ordinance forbidding discrimination on the basis of sex.

title: 20% PRIME SPREADS
description: The prime lending rate, the interest that banks charge their most creditworthy corporate customers, generally settled at 20 percent yesterday as many major banks moved to that level.

title: CHRISTOPHOER FLYING TO ALGIERS TO GIVE REPLIES ON HOSTAGES
description: In a surprise move, Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher flew to Algeria tonight to discuss with Algerians the status of the negotiations to free the American hostages being held in Iran.

title: IF ARAFAT GETS HIS STATE
description: To the Editor:

title: BALLET: 'ALLEGRO BRILLANTE' BY THE HARLEM COMPANY
description: TO see George Balanchine's ''Allegro Brillante'' danced by the Dance Theater of Harlem is to see dancing at the highest level. It is a ballet that always brings out the best in this troupe and it was the highlight of the second program of the company's season Tuesday night at the City Center.

title: Technology; The Load Cell's Development
description: GETTING weighed is among our first experiences. It is a fitting welcome to the planet because, thanks to the earth's gravity, everything around us also has weight.

title: Iona 60, Fairfield 43
description: Gary Springer and Steve Burtt, both freshmen, combined for 41 points in leading Iona to a 60-43 rout of Fairfield tonight.

title: JERSEY CITY REVIVALS RAISING HOPES AND SOME EYEBROWS
description: Not long ago, Joe Nowicki was standing on the steps of his imposing Victorian brownstone when he beheld a man slowly coming down the street, peering doubtfully at the buildings around him. This happens frequently in Mr. Nowicki's neighborhood, so he asked if he could help.

title: Jobless Rate Up In West Germany
description: The number of workers unemployed in West Germany climbed sharply in December, to 1.1 million, the highest level in five years, the Government announced today. The increase indicated that the nation's economic slowdown was having a more serious impact on the labor market than had previously been expected.

title: G.O.P. Chief Deputy Whip Picked
description: Representative David F. Emery of Maine was named today the Republican Party's chief deputy whip in the House, making him the chamber's No. 3 Republican. Representative Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican whip, announced the appointment of the 32-year-old native of Rockland, Me., who has been in Congress since 1974.

title: L.S.U. 77, Vanderbilt 61
description: Helped by 18 points from Willie Simms in a substitute role, Louisiana State scored its 10th straight victory with a 77-61 Southeastern Conference rout of Vanderbilt.

title: Du Pont Campaign Seeks The 'Nonavid' Fisherman
description: According to N.W. Ayer ABH International, the new ad campaign for the Du Pont Stren Fishing line is aimed not only at the heavy user but also at the ''nonavid'' fisherman. It would seem that you'd be pretty darn nonavid to be completely sold by a headline like, ''Stren fishing is aching arms and a full fish box.''

title: KOCH HAILS CAREY'S MEDICAID PLAN
description: Mayor Koch, calling Governor Carey's message to the Legislature the best he had seen in three years for cities, towns and counties, gave the Governor ''extraordinarily high marks'' yesterday for proposing that the state eventually assume the 25 percent share of Medicaid costs now borne by local governments.

title: Chilean Bishops Ask Government To Study Return of Leftist Exiles
description: Chile's Roman Catholic bishops urged the military Government today to create a commission aimed at studying the return of political exiles as a way of achieving national reconciliation.

title: 11 Agencies Sponsoring Ad for Italian Quake Relief
description: A full-page ad soliciting funds for American Red Cross/Italian Earthquake Relief is scheduled to run in The New York Times next Monday.

title: Helen Diehl Olds, 85, Author Of Children's Books and Stories
description: Helen Diehl Olds, who wrote more than 30 books and many magazine stories for children, died Jan. 1 in Flushing Hospital in Queens. She was 85 years old and lived in Little Neck, Queens.

title: December Sales Up 11.2% in City
description: New York City's retail sales surged 11.2 percent in December from the level of a year before, a spot check has found.

title: WESLEY POWELL, AN EX-GOVERNOR OF NEW HAMPSHIRE, IS DEAD AT 65
description: Former Gov. Wesley Powell, who mounted 12 political campaigns over four decades in New Hampshire, died last night at his home. He was 65 years old.

title: Subway Vandalism Brings 265 Arrests
description: A special squad of Transit Authority police officers has made 265 arrests since November in a crackdown on vandalism in New York City's subways, including 58 for kicking out train windows.

title: DEE W. STONE
description: Dee W. Stone, a former partner of the New York law firm of Chadbourne, Parke, Whiteside & Wolf, which he joined in 1929, died Thursday in Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived in Tinton Falls, N.J. He lived in Forest Hills, Queens, for many years before moving to New Jersey after his retirement in 1965. Mr. Stone served in the Army with the rank of colonel in both World Wars and was awarded the Bronze Star and the Croix de Guerre. He also had been a colonel in the Army Reserve. He is survived by his wife, the former Irene Stockvis; two daughters, Mary Inwright of Tinton Falls and Grace Marrion of Niantic, Conn., and eight grandchildren.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have a ''disappearing staircase'' that goes up to my attic. The attic floor is fully insulated, but I have been unable to figure out how to insulate the opening around this staircase. Fitting insulation around the door panel would be difficult because of the mechanism attached to it, and even then, cold air would seep in around the edges of the door. Do you have any suggestions? - R.C.G., McLean, Va.

title: ANNA ESTES STRAWBRIDGE
description: Anna Estes Strawbridge, the widow of Francis R. Strawbridge Jr., a former director of the Strawbridge and Clothier department store chain, died Monday at her home in Philadelphia. She was 100 years old.

title: Market Created For S.D.R.'s
description: Seven major banks today started a new financial market based on special drawing rights, or S.D.R.'s, to minimize the risk investors run through currency fluctuations.

title: A GOOD DRAFT BOLSTERS KNICKS
description: Recently Sonny Werblin pointed to a table at Madison Square Garden and said, ''This is where I made the Bob McAdoo trade.'' Werblin, president of Madison Square Garden Corporation, which owns the Knicks, was referring to the February 1979 deal that sent McAdoo to the Boston Celtics for three first-round draft choices.

title: CAVE ART FROM STONE AGE DISCOVERED IN ENGLAND
description: A Canadian archeologist says he has discovered the first examples of representational Stone Age cave art in the British Isles. He says the discovery could prompt a radical reassessment of the nature of paleolithic man. In an article in the January issue of Illustrated London News, Dr. Tom Rogers describes two engravings of a bison and the head of an unidentifiable animal with two horns that he found aboce the Wye River at Symond's Yat East in Herefordshire on the border with Wales. The art is believed to date from between 15,000 and 13,000 B.C. Dr. Rogers, 48 years old, the director of the Stone Age Studies Research Association, Rodney Russell of the Bureau of Archeology in Zurich and Andrew Pinder of London's Institute of Archeology discovered the engravings by accident last summer. Cave Is Reinvestigated "I missed it for 19 years," Dr. Rogers said of the badly deteriorated "reindeer" head, 14 inches high, that he first spotted while resting under a rock overhang. The discovery prompted the archeologist to reinvestigate a cave 50 feet away, and he discovered the 10-inch-long representations of bison. Both works follow the natural contours of the rock into which they were carved. The composite head, with its reindeer horns and the face of a deer, is "unique in Western Europe; no continental parallels have been traced," Dr. Rogers said. The bison, on the other hand, resemble French and Spanish cave art of the same period.

title: Council Bill Would Dedicate Part Of Revenue to Police Protection
description: City Councilman Michael DeMarco, Democrat of the Bronx, yesterday introduced a bill that would require a fixed percentage of every tax dollar to be spent for police protection.

title: Red Barber Joins Public Radio
description: Red Barber, the sports announcer who for years broadcast Brooklyn Dodger baseball games and later those of the New York Yankees, has joined National Public Radio as a commentator on ''Morning Edition,'' heard daily 6 to 8 A.M. Mr. Barber, a sportscaster for over 50 years, can be heard live each Friday morning at 7:35 on WNYC AM (83.0) and WNYC FM (93.9). He joins the program's other sports commentators, Frank Deford, Frank Herzog, Jane Chastain and Harry Edwards.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JANUARY 9, 1981
description: International A qualified pledge to honor any accord made by President Carter with Iran to free the American hostages was given by Ronald Reagan, but he said he reserved the right to make new proposals if the crisis has not been resolved when he becomes President on Jan. 20. Meanwhile, Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher conferred in Algiers with the Algerian Foreign Minister on questions raised by the Algerian intermediaries over Washington's proposals to Iran. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Efforts to resolve the hostage crisis have been complicated by legal questions over the extent of President Carter's authority to meet Iran's demands. American lawyers representing Iranian interests have quietly been helping Teheran's leaders evaluate the apparent legal obstacles. But differences of opinion may have increased Iran's skepticism about the the extent of Mr. Carter's authority. (A8:1.)

title: Rutherford Will Compete In 12 to 14 Stock Car Races
description: Johnny Rutherford, a three-time winner of the Indianapolis 500, has announced that he will compete in 12 to 14 races this season on the circuit of the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing, beginning with the Daytona 500 Feb. 15. He will drive a Pontiac Grand Prix prepared by Buddy Parrott and sponsored by Levi Garrett, a manufacturer of chewing tobacco.

title: WHEN SOCIETY USES LABELS TO SHRUG OFF ALIENATED YOUTHS
description: To the Editor:

title: M.T.A. Panel Backs A Conrail Authority
description: The official citizens advisory group to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority endorsed ''in principle'' the concept of creating a separate state authority to manage the Harlem, Hudson and New Haven Divisions of Conrail.

title: Occidental to Sell An Offshore Lease
description: A subsidiary of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to sell substantially all of Occidental's holdings in an oil and gas field off San Pedro, Calif., for more than $200 million.

title: 14 MORE JUDGES TO HELP HANDLE CRIMINAL CASES
description: Administrators of the New York State and city court system said yesterday that they would make more judges available to try cases against people accused of serious crimes in New York City.

title: Blues, Flyers Play 5-5 Tie
description: Wayne Babych scored his second goal of the game and 29th of the season with 1 minute 4 seconds to play tonight, giving the St. Louis Blues a 5-5 tie with the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Military Analysis
description: About 26 Soviet Army divisions, well over a quarter of a million men, are marking time in East Germany, Czechoslovakia and the western regions of the Soviet Union along Poland's frontiers.

title: NEWSMAN AND WRITER OF BROADWAY MUSICAL
description: John Robert Pascal, a newsman who was co-author of the 1968-69 Broadway musical ''George M!,'' died of cancer Wednesday at the age of 48 at Roosevelt Hospital. He was a resident of Manhattan and at the time of his death was a Sunday columnist for Newsday.

title: WALL STREET'S FORTUNE TELLERS
description: In mythical times, seers lived on craggy mountaintops and foretold the victories and deaths of kings and queens. Today they live in Florida and California and predict the highs and lows of the stock market.

title: REAGAN BIDS AIDES DISCUSS ISSUES AS FREELY AS POSSIBLE
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan, holding his first working meeting with his Cabinet, told its members today that he considered it a ''no-no'' for them to be influenced by politics in their decisions.

title: INTEREST RATES EDGE HIGHER
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday as credit markets seemed to be in a holding pattern, awaiting further information about the timing of the tax cuts proposed by the incoming Reagan administration and the state of the economy.

title: THE COMPUTER AS RETAILER
description: If Walter A. Forbes is right, the future of American retailing is taking shape on the fourth floor of a nondescript office building in downtown Stamford.

title: PRESSURE IRAN THROUGH ISOLATION
description: To the Editor:

title: CAREY'S TRANSIT PLAN HAILED BY RAVITCH
description: Governor Carey's program for mass-transit improvements was called ''encouraging'' yesterday by Richard Ravitch, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REVISED CARTER BUDGET PLAN FOR '82 REDUCES THE DEFICIT TO $30 BILLION
description: The Carter Administration plans to propose a budget for the fiscal year 1982 with a deficit of about $30 billion, substantially less than was expected just a few weeks ago, Administration officials said today.

title: ADAMS EXPRESS CO reports earnings for As of Dec 31
NEEDIEST
description: DONOR TO THE NEEDIEST USES EMILY DICKINSON TO EXPLAIN MOTIVATION By WALTER H. WAGGONER

title: Nestle Picks A Director for North America
description: David Guerrant, a longtime American official of Nestle S.A., the Swiss food company, has been named to the new post of general director for the United States and Canada zone of the multinational parent company. He will have offices both in Vevey, Switzerland, where the parent company is based, and in White Plains, where the North American operations will be centered.

title: DR. ROBERT McCLANAHAN
description: Dr. Robert McClanahan, an attending surgeon in ophthalmology at St. Luke's Hospital for 50 years, died last Friday at his home in Manhattan.

title: PHIL ESPOSITO PLAYS FINALE TONIGHT
description: Phil Esposito will play his final hockey game tonight. Tomorrow morning he will start serving as an assistant to Coach Craig Patrick of the Rangers, but it appears that Esposito's future in New York is not as coach but as a television announcer with the Madison Square Garden Corporation, which owns the team.

title: The Economy
description: The Carter Administration plans to propose a 1982 budget that will show a deficit of about $30 billion, substantially less than was expected a few weeks ago, officials said. The budget figures do not include a tax cut endorsed by President-elect Reagan. (Page A1.)

title: Ex-Stagehand Testifies About Plan to Rig Lottery
description: A former stagehand accused in a scheme to fix the Pennsylvania lottery has testified that a former Pittsburgh television announcer, Nick Perry, approached him six weeks before the drawing on April 24 with the idea of rigging it.

title: New Orleans Transit Union Rejects Latest Wage Offer
description: Bus and streetcar drivers here voted today to reject a proposed 9.75 percent increase in wages and benefits and to go on strike Monday unless they get a better contract offer from New Orleans Public Service Inc.
