title: Cowboys, Chargers Seem to Have Edge
description: The matchups of individual players remain important in the National Football League's conference championships Sunday, even though the competing teams seem so even and are so familiar to each another. The Dallas Cowboys will have an edge because of their defensive line against the Eagles in Philadelphia (Channel 2, 1 P.M.), and the Oakland Raiders will be be at a disadvantage on offense against the Chargers at San Diego (Channel 4, 5 P.M.).

title: Courage, Caution and the Economy
description: An understandable nervousness has appeared in the economic planning of the Reagan administration. The economy that it promised to set aright looks even weaker than it did on Election Day, with budget deficits and interest rates running higher and Wall Street running scared. The Reagan strategists well remember last year's budget fiasco, when President Carter's ''tight'' spending plan sent inflation fears soaring and nearly collapsed the bond market. Seven weeks later, Mr. Carter had to produce an even ''tighter'' budget, but he never regained the nation's confidence.

title: NEW YORK'S CRUCIAL CASE AGAINST THE CENSUS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery untilization

title: IN ARMORY, TENANTS AND HOMELESS, TOO, FIND SHELTER
description: After suffering in the cold for four days, Kenneth Baylock moved his family out of their apartment in the Bronx last Friday and remained behind to guard his furniture. He was reunited with them Wednesday at the emergency shelter set up at the 369th Infantry Armory, where the temperature was a welcome 75 to 80 degrees. Outside at 11 A.M. yesterday, it was 17 degrees.

title: Julie Shea, Runner, Named Top Female Athlete of '80
description: Julie Shea of North Carolina State, the first woman in the 11-year history of the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women to win the group's 3,000, 5,000 and 10,000 meters races in the same year, has been named the winner of the fourth Broderick Cup. The award, based on voting by members of the A.I.A.W., is given to the outstanding female collegiate athlete of the year.

title: Hearing Set on Rally Planned in Buffalo
description: A Federal judge ordered Karl Hand, a leader of a neo-Nazi group in Buffalo, to appear in court on Monday to explain why it should not be prevented from holding a rally near a memorial service for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. next Thursday.

title: PACERS BEAT KNICKS IN OVERTIME, 116-115
description: A tip-in with two seconds remaining in overtime by Sly Williams of the Knicks was nullified because of offensive interference last night, and the Indiana Pacers gained possession and a 116-115 victory at Madison Square Garden.

title: FORMER C.I.A. AGENT WHOP SPIED FOR SOVIET SENTENCED TO 18 YEARS
description: David H. Barnett, who last year confessed selling sensitive American intelligence information to the Soviet Union while employed by the Central Intelligence Agency, was sentenced today by a Federal district judge here to serve 18 years in prison.

title: GOODRICH TO STRESS 'REPLACEMENT' SALES
description: In a bid to increase sales of replacement tires, the B.F. Goodrich Company said today that it would cease bidding for domestic sales of original-equipment auto tires in 1982.

title: U.S. SAID TO REJECT PLAN BY CHRYSLER
description: The Chrysler Loan Guarantee Board has found the recovery plan submitted by the Chrysler Corporation unacceptable and has decided to draw up its own plan, Douglas A. Fraser, president of the United Automobile Workers union, disclosed at a news conference here today.

title: Peek Freans Are in the Subway
description: Associated Biscuits of America, whose Peek Freans cookies' jingle has added one of the brighter spots in New York and Boston broadcasting in the last couple of years, has now contributed a vibrant ad touch to New York subways.

title: DECONTROL OF OIL IS NO CURE
description: The train for decontrol has long left the station. I realize that. The argument now within the Reagan administration-to-be is not whether we decontrol the price of domestic oil, but how fast we accelerate the train.

title: NAMIBIA CONFEREES CLASH, THEN GET DOWN TO BUSINESS
description: The two sides at the conference on South-West Africa exchanged bitter barbs today at a brief public session that was called to enable the political parties from inside the territory to assert their claim to equal status with the insurgent movement known as the South-West Africa People's Organization.

title: THE NONEVICTION CONVERSION FINDS FAVOR
description: Whenever a cooperative or condominium conversion plan becomes a possibility in a rental building in New York, the tenant reaction falls into three distinct categories, according to lawyers who have represented both sponsors and tenants.

title: SENATORIAL WAILERS
description: To the Editor:

title: NUCLEAR DATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ELECTRO RENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
HOW INSURERS WANT TO PASS ALONG INFLATION
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSERVATION PENDULUM
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Signs Bills To Aid Consumers
description: Mayor Koch yesterday signed bills designed to protect consumers dealing with tax preparation services and home improvement businesses as well as measures allowing City Council members to visit and inspect city correctional facilities.

title: Y SERIES OFFERS NEWER LYRICISTS
description: When the ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' series began at the 92d Street Y in 1970, it focused on the people who wrote the lyrics for Broadway musicals. Lyricists such as E.Y. (Yip) Harburg, Sheldon Harnick, Stephen Sondheim, Betty Comden and Adolph Green and Alan Jay Lerner discussed their methods of working, talked about the hit songs they had written, resurrected unknown songs they had also written and, with the help of a few guests, sang a considerable number of their songs.

title: Internorth Broadens Crouse-Hinds Offer
description: Internorth Inc., a major gas company, said it would pay $38.50 a share for any outstanding common stock of the Crouse-Hinds Company.

title: HEAD OF CHICAGO LYRIC OPERA RESIGNS
description: Carol Fox, who founded the Lyric Opera Company of Chicago 25 years ago and forged it into one of the three major opera companies in the United States, stepped down today as general manager under circumstances that were not made clear.

title: Fed Orders Fines Against Wilshire Oil
description: The Federal Reserve Board said it had ordered the Wilshire Oil Company and its officers to pay fines of $4,500 a day until the company either sells its New Jersey bank or ceases nonbanking activities prohibited by the Bank Holding Company Act of 1970.

title: Greene
description: Seven years ago, a group of 12 recently divorced and widowed men and women formed a committee to plan a cocktail party that would raise money to fight two diseases that were then considered to be ''unfashionable'' -ileitis and colitis.

title: energywatch
description: JAN. 2, 1980 Supplies of crude oil tumbled to 359.4 million barrels as imports slid, refinery output rose and domestic production dropped temporarily.

title: Peter O'Toole and a film they tried to ignore.
description: PETER O'TOOLE, who this week won the National Society of Film Critics award as best actor for ''The Stunt Man,'' took a sip of tea, stretched out on a couch in his midtown hotel suite, and talked about the frustration he felt when, for two years, no movie company would agree to release the controversial film.

title: Julie Harris in Hospital for Observation
description: The actress Julie Harris has been in Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center since Wednesday and is undergoing ''exploratory observation,'' it was confirmed yesterday.

title: Friday; BOXES AS ART IN HUNTINGTON
description: Boxes with things in them or on them are the subject of ''Kindred Spirits,'' an exhibition opening today at the Heckscher Museum in Huntington, L.I. Featured are works by Joseph Cornell, known for his enclosed constructions containing a surrealistic array of found objects, cutouts and type, and other artists, including Louise Nevelson -who also filled boxes but negated the ''otherness'' of the items by painting the entire structure the same color. Admission to the museum, on Prime Avenue off Route 25A, is free. A lecture on the legacy of Joseph Cornell by Lynda Roscoe Hartigan, a specialist on the artist, is scheduled at 8 P.M. in the Old First Church, Main Street. Admission is $4. Information: (516) 351-3250. 'MERRY WIDOW' OF 74TH ST.

title: WHAT HEAD DOES FOR CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: Reds Sign Larry Biitner, Team's First Free Agent
description: Larry Biittner, a free agent from the Chicago Cubs, has agreed to a three-year contract with the Cincinnati Reds, making him the first free agent signed by the Reds since the re-entry draft was instituted in 1976.

title: No Contamination Found After Titan 2 Explosion
description: An Air Force investigating team has reported that tests show no fuel or nuclear contamination of air, water or soil from the explosion of a Titan 2 missile in Arkansas in September.

title: 2 U.S. AIDES CRITICAL OF AN ABSCAM AGENT
description: Two Justice Department lawyers testified yesterday that they had criticized an undercover operator in the Abscam investigation for ''putting words'' in the mouth of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. that would later be used to incriminate him.

title: FRANCE ACTS TO COUNTER THE LIBYAN MOVE INTO CHAD
description: After long hesitation, the French Government has moved with some vehemence to protest Libya's move into Chad and to reassert its traditional position of influence in French-speaking West Africa.

title: Staring at Connecticut's Deficit
description: Taking a cue from the late Jimmy Walker, New York's song-writing Mayor, Connecticut's Gov. William O'Neill asked the legislators who gave him a rousing greeting for his State of the State address: ''Will you feel the same in ten minutes as you do at this moment?'' The former Lieutenant Governor, who on Dec. 31 succeeded the ailing Ella Grasso, has ample reason to fear his honeymoon will be over before it begins. The state faces a deficit of $50 million this year and nearly $200 million in 1982.

title: JAPANESE ARE PLEASED TO SEE MANSFIELD STAY AS U.S. AMBASSADOR
description: The announcement in Washington that Presidentelect Ronald Reagan would retain Mike Mansfield as Ambassador to Japan was acclaimed here today by 2,000 businessmen and Government officials who gave the Ambassador a standing ovation at a Tokyo hotel.

title: 500 EVACUATED IN FIRE ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan 8 (AP) Workers dismantling a wooden cooling tower atop a downtown office building touched off a fire today that forced the evacuation of 500 people. Two firefighters were overcome by fumes from the fire atop the American Telephone and Telegraph Company complex, which caused an estimated $20,000 in damage, according to the authorities.

title: READERS MOBILIZING TO SAVE THE LIBRARIES
description: If city library officials ever decide to close the Muhlenberg Branch in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, they might find the way blocked by some thoroughly militant readers.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Cooper Industries has received more than $35 million in orders for turbomachinery to be installed in Mexico, Canada and Britain.

title: SOVIET PAPER DENOUNCES 'ANTI-SOCIALIST RINGLEADER' OF POLAND'S DISSIDENTS
description: Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper, published an attack today on one of Poland's main dissident theoreticians. It was the first time since the beginning of the Polish crisis last summer that an individual and his arguments had been challenged so directly.

title: CAN PIANO AND BASS SPEAK AS ONE?
description: Sitting down, engaged in conversation, the 5 foot 9 inch Andre Watts and the 5 foot 6 inch James VanDemark seemed much more diminutive than their respective instruments - the 9-foot Steinway and the 6 foot 4 inch double bass. But the 34-year-old Mr. Watts has established a major career as a master of the keyboard, and Mr. VanDemark, at 27, has a growing reputation as a fine player of his 1695 Testore bass. So when they play together in Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night at 8, not as soloist and accompanist, but as equals, the results should be interesting - and not just because of the combination of unwieldy instruments rarely heard together on the concert stage. (All tickets are $9; box office, 362-1911.)

title: River Boat Sinks in Brazil, Drowning at Least 120
description: A river boat carrying the relatives of Brazilian workers hit a sandbar and sank in a tributary of the Amazon, drowning at least 120 people and possibly as many as 220, the authorities reported today.

title: EXPERT PREDICTS DROUGHT MAY WORSEN THROUGH '85
description: New York City and upstate areas may be facing years of worsening drought, according to experimental long-range forecasting by a Cornell University professor.

title: 2 IN MIDEAST SAID TO LIFT OIL PRICE $4
description: Oil price increases of $4 a barrel yesterday by Qatar - and apparently by Kuwait as well - provided mounting evidence that consumers would be paying more for petroleum products than analysts had expected just after the meeting last month of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: PSYCHOLOGIST SAYS GARWOOD TOLD OF G.I.'S KILLED BY AGENT ORANGE
description: Pfc. Robert R. Garwood, accused of collaborating with the enemy, says that he saw American prisoners of war in Vietnam killed by United States bombs and exposure to the defoliant Agent Orange, a military psychologist testified today.

title: Beware Of 'Gaposis'
description: The Reagan Administration has a new case of an old malady - military ''gaposis.'' As Secretary of Defense-designate Caspar Weinberger testified at his confirmation hearings, the new team will come into office believing that it must bridge a strategic gap that now gives the Soviet Union a distinct advantage over the United States.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard A LITTLE ORDER. By Evelyn Waugh. A Selection From His Journalism. Edited by Donat Gallagher. 192 pages. Little, Brown. $12.95.

title: VESCO SUBMITS APPEAL ON DEPORTATION ORDER TO BAHAMIAN CABINET
description: Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, has appealed the order for his deportation from the Bahamas, but he declined to predict today whether the appeal would be approved by the Bahamian cabinet.

title: U.S.-Algeria Gas Talks
description: The United States and Algeria will resume talks in Washington on Monday in their dispute over tariffs for Algerian natural gas, the Department of Energy said today. Since last April 1, the dispute has halted deliveries of Algerian liquefied natural gas under a contract providing for the eventual supply of about 350 billion cubic feet a year to the El Paso Company, which is based in Houston.

title: Ohio State 58, Iowa 56
description: Herb Williams hit a turnaround jump shot that gave Ohio State the lead for good with less than six minutes to play, and the Buckeyes went on to beat Iowa, 58-56, in a Big Ten Conference game tonight.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Creamer Inc., yesterday picked up the Duffy-Mott Company, a subsidiary of American Brands that makes Mott's applesauce, apple juice, Clamato and prune juice, as well as Grandma's Molasses and Grandma's Barbecue Sauce.

title: LEVI STRAUSS AND M-G-M PROFITS CLIMB
description: Levi Strauss & Company, the world's largest apparel manufacturer, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth fiscal quarter ended Nov. 30 rose 12.3 percent on an increase in sales of 28.4 percent.

title: SHELDAHL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including a loss of $57,000 from discontinued operations

title: ECONOMIC SHAKEUP STUDIED IN POLAND
description: A panel of experts set up to chart Poland's economic future has decided on a series of changes that would move Poland ahead of anything now existing in the Soviet bloc.

title: NOEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NEW DETECTORS SCOUR FOR WATER LEAKS
description: The engineer and the foreman peering into their instruments at 71st Street and Broadway yesterday were using a new electronic water-leak detector to try to find the source of water spilling into a subway tunnel.

title: UNIFLITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After a $150,000 reduction attributable to certain adjustment made by the company in the prior qtrs of fiscal 1980...C-Net in D-Including $1,641,434 extraordinary net income

title: CHEMPLAST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Shr net reflects the 15 percent stock divds paid on Oct 20, 198

title: Illinois 88, Northwestern 64
description: Craig Tucker scored 16 points and led Illinois to an 88-64 victory over Northwestern in a Big Ten game tonight.

title: M.T.A. Given Date On Plan for Disabled
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has been granted a sixmonth extension for submission of an alternative plan for making its subways and commuter railroads accessible to people in wheelchairs.

title: MIX-UP BLAMED FOR PRIOR RELEASE OF ALLEGED KILLER
description: Two weeks after he was freed from jail without bail on kidnapping and robbery charges, a 19-year-old Brooklyn man has been accused of fatally shooting a 7-year-old boy in Queens.

title: Socal Sets Spending 20% Higher for 1981
description: The Standard Oil Company of California announced that expenditures planned for capital investment and exploration worldwide in 1981 would rise 20 percent from last year, to a record $4.2 billion.

title: 'MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM' OPENING BAM REP YEAR
description: Bathed in blue-green light and inhabited by sprites, the Playhouse of the Brooklyn Academy of Music looked agreeably magical the other day, even though the fairies wore jeans and leotards as they darted among treelike pillars representing woods. Their strange, tattered costumes weren't ready yet.

title: Red Brigades Inmates Seek Publication of Documents
description: Imprisoned members of the Red Brigades said tonight that the life of the kidnapped magistrate Giovanni D'Urso could be spared if the national press published three documents written by detained guerrillas, leftist members of Parliament reported.

title: Rutgers 92, Massachusetts 58
description: Rutgers evened its season record at 6-6 and its Eastern Eight mark at 1-1 with a 92-58 victory over Massachusetts tonight at the Rutgers Athletic Center.

title: U.S. ISSUES MENUS TO GO WITH ITS DIETARY GUIDELINES
description: The Department of Agriculture issued today a booklet of menus and recipes designed to help consumers eat healthy foods.

title: Earthquake Shakes Los Angeles
description: A mild earthquake shook western Los Angeles early today, touching off a few telephone calls to the police but causing no damage.

title: 35 THRIFT UNITYS RESCUED, COSTING U.S. $1.3 BILLION
description: Thirty-five savings and loan associations, with total assets of almost $4 billion, would have failed last year if it had not been for rescue operations by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, according to agency spokesmen.

title: RIEGEL TEXTILE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including $6,232,000 income from the cumulative effect on prior yrs of an accounting change

title: ART: POSTCARD VIEWS BY PHILIP PEARLSTEIN
description: OVER the last year or two, Philip Pearlstein has come before us more and more as a traveling man. No longer walled up in his studio year after year with rueful collocations of bodies and parts of bodies, he has ranged the world in search of the landscape motif that will best release his gifts. And now, at the Brooke Alexander Gallery, 20 West 57th Street, we can see what came of it. ''Landscape Aquatints, 1978-80'' is the title of the show, and it is on view through Jan. 31.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: I T'S not only that the United States Postal Service takes its own good time about delivering anything entrusted to its care. It's also that people take their own good time about answering invitations once they do arrive. It's enough to frazzle any hostess. Or it was.

title: 1980 ANNUAL REPORT ON THE DEBENTURES, OF LAKEMONT, N.J.
description: The books are now closed on 1980, and by nearly all accounts it was a banner year for the William E. Debenture Family. On both sides of life's balance sheet - fiscal matters and personal relations - the Family surpassed its good performance of 1979, and we are pleased to report that the Standard and Poor's Family Rating Service has raised its rating of the Debentures from A to AA.

title: G.A.O. Criticizes High Steel Wages
description: The American steel industry would be more competitive if its workers were paid less and if Government policies were better geared to support modernization and expansion, the General Accounting Office said today.

title:
RED SMITH;
Lynn and Fisk: What Will the Traffic Bear?
description: WHEN George Steinbrenner mortgaged tomorrow to sign Dave Winfield to play ball for the Yankees at $1.5 million a year plus a million here and a million there, and Don Sutton agreed to pitch for the Houston Astros at $950,000 a season, it took most of the shine off this winter's free-agent business. The flesh market didn't shut down; there were still people like Ron LeFlore to wangle a three-year contract with the White Sox worth $2.4 million, and Claudell Washington was eligible to accept a possible $4.8 million from Atlanta in the next five years, but Winfield and Sutton had been the choice items on the shelves.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The one no-no that I'll tell you for discussions is, I don't want anyone ever to bring up the political ramifications of an act.

title: The Leadership Network Adds Wharton Magazine
description: The Leadership Network, a joint advertising sales effort for a number of prestigious and thought-provoking publications, has just added Wharton Magazine, a quarterly with 32,000 circulation.

title: U.S. TO SUE A SCHOOL DISTRICT IN CAROLINA OVER RACIAL BIAS
description: The Justice Department said today that it would carry out its threat to file suit against Charleston County in South Carolina because the state and local authorities had refused to propose a method of desegregating the county's public schools.

title: Economic Scene; 'A Sense Of Urgency'
description: THE securities markets are swinging wildly between hope and fear. This may reflect the uncertainty of the nation as it tries to get a fix on the policies of the coming Reagan administration, and whether these will mean a worsening of inflation, a steep slump or something in between.

title: Sonics' Absence Excused
description: The Seattle SuperSonics' failure to reach Phoenix for a game with the Suns last Saturday was unavoidable, the National Basketball Association director of operations, Joe Axelson, has ruled.

title: William M. Sale Jr., 81; An Authority on English
description: Dr. William M. Sale Jr., a former professor of English at Cornell University, died Tuesday at the age of 81 at the Oak Hill Nursing Home in Ithaca, N.Y.

title: Film Show Sunday at Brooklyn Botanic Garden
description: Three short films about George Washington Carver, Scott Joplin and black American art will be shown Sunday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue in Brooklyn, as part of a commemoration of the birthday of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., which is next Thursday.

title: WATT VOWS TO SHUN CONFLICT CASES
description: Another group of environmental and conservation organizations today opposed the confirmation of James G. Watt as Secretary of the Interior.

title: KENNECOTT TERMINATES ITS OFFER FOR SHARES OF CURTISS-WRIGHT
description: The Kennecott Corporation announced yesterday that it was terminating its offer to purchase 4.1 million shares of the CurtissWright Corporation.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: WHEN the Police, the English rock trio, announced that they intended to play Madison Square Garden on Saturday, Jan. 10, even some of their fans were skeptical. Two years ago they were crisscrossing America in a van, playing their fresh blend of rock and reggae in nightclubs. Two successful albums, a series of popular singles and an ambitious world tour have established them internationally. But in America they are still classified as ''New Wave,'' which hasn't been the sort of thing apt to fill the Garden. And while their third album, ''Zenyatta Mondatta'' (A & M), is now in the American top 10, that didn't guarantee a sellout at the Garden either. So everyone connected with the band was pleasantly surprised when the concert sold out just three days after it was announced. The Police are now trying to arrange another New York performance to accommodate fans who didn't get tickets for the Garden show.

title: NEW ACOUSTICS FOR STATE THEATER
description: The New York State Theater is scheduled for the kind of acoustic overhaul that Philharmonic Hall experienced in 1976. The project, which may begin next year, will not be as drastic an operation as Philharmonic Hall underwent, and the interior of the building will not be gutted. If the $5 million to $6 million plans being discussed are realized, money will be donated by a private foundation to improve the acoustics under the direction of Cyril Harris.

title: By TOM BUCKLEY
description: The works of unheralded German film makers who may turn out to be the Schlondorffs, Fassbinders and Herzogs of the coming decade will be on view at the Museum of Modern Art through Jan. 22 in a new series called ''New Films From West Germany.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 19.50-20.50** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: INTERNATIONAL SEAWAY TRADING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Explosion at R.A.F. Center Causes Extensive Damage
description: A bomb exploded at a Royal Air Force training center in West London today, causing extensive damage but no casualties, Scotland Yard said.

title: Fuel Plant Talks Stall
description: Negotiations aimed at resolving a major dispute over financing for the nation's first commercial synthetic fuels plant broke down here today, further dimming prospects that the planned $2 billion North Dakota facility will be built.

title: IRAN GETTING ADVICE FROM U.S. LAWYERS
description: Iran's American lawyers have quietly been helping Iranian leaders evaluate the apparent legal obstacles to compliance with some of Teheran's demands for the release of the hostages.

title: Armenian Dance Program
description: The Antranig Armenian Dance Ensemble of America, adorned in native costumes, will perform Russian and Armenian folk dances Sunday at 5:30 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center, Broadway and 65th Street.

title: CABARET: A NEW CARRIE SMITH
description: FOR more than six years, Carrie Smith has been trying to escape from the shadow of Bessie Smith that settled over her as a result of her success singing Bessie Smith songs in a program of the New York Jazz Repertory Company at Carnegie Hall in 1974. Everywhere she has gone since then, audiences have insisted that she be Bessie Smith, although she would rather be Carrie Smith.

title: THE BUSHES COME TO TOWN FOR A PRIVATE PARTY Mildred Hilson
description: Life at the top isn't all that different. Which is why Mildred Hilson looks like a grande dame who lives in the Waldorf Towers and, by no coincidence at all, she is a grande dame who lives in the Waldorf Towers. Last night, she had a party for former neighbors to, as she put it, ''wish them luck.''

title: Assets Increase At Money Funds
description: Assets in the nation's 97 money market mutual funds rose $1.4 billion, to $76 billion, in the week ended Wednesday. It was the largest one-week increase in seven months.

title: Loan Set for Iberia Air
description: The United States Export-Import Bank said today that it would guarantee a loan of $40.5 million to Iberia Airlines of Spain.

title: Bridge: Dramatic U.S.-Italy Contest In World Teams Is Recalled
description: Coinciding with the 1980 World Team Championship came the publication of the full story of the 1979 event, played in Rio de Janeiro. This publication by the American Contract Bridge League, written by a team of experts headed by Henry Francis, is outstanding in every way: If there were an annual award for the bridge book of the year, it would be an easy winner.

title: MEMBERS OF THE BEGIN COALITION TALK SERIOUSLY OF EARLY ELECTIONS
description: For the first time in the months of crisis politics that have afflicted Israel, some key members of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's coalition are beginning to talk seriously about calling early elections, probably advancing them by five or six months, from November to May or June.

title: BIAS SUIT STIRS TENSION AMONG POLICE IN WHITE PLAINS
description: For the White Plains Police Department, last week's suit by the Federal Government charging racial bias in hiring has rekindled bitter feelings among both blacks and whites and has added a rough edge to day-to-day activities.

title: THEATER: 'ADMIRABLE CRICHTON' REVIVED AT LONG WHARF
description: The decline of the Empire, a subject of great concern to many young British playwrights today, was clearly on the mind of James M. Barrie when he wrote ''The Admirable Crichton'' in 1902. This popular comedy, in revival at the Long Wharf Theater, under the skillful direction of Kenneth Frankel, proves to be not only an entertaining social commentary, but also an abrasive parable about the sinking ship of England.

title: JAMES L. WALKER
description: James L. Walker, a senior vice president and chief financial officer of the INA Corporation, the Philadelphia insurance and investment-banking concern, died yesterday at his home in Flourtown, Pa.

title: AUCTIONS
description: AMERICANA offerings are bound to add drama to the auction scene in the weeks and months ahead, as rarities in silver, a historic weathervane and autograph letters by the nation's early leaders come up for sale. The silver prize is a wine cup crafted in 17th-century London that once belonged to Gov. William Bradford of Plymouth colony. It will go on the block at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, on Feb. 4 and may bring as much as $45,000. The 7-inch-tall cup - a formidable Charles I piece - was uncovered by the auction house during a routine appraisal in the New Orleans home of Bernard Wiest, who had no notion of the cup's value. It was given to Mr. Wiest by his great-uncle, who was the great-great-grandson by marriage of Governor Bradford's great-grandaughter.

title: Mitsui Is Subject Of Federal Inquiry
description: A Federal grand jury here is investigating allegations that Mitsui & Company, the big Japanese trading concern, has made false declarations to the United States Customs Service and engaged in the ''dumping,'' or selling at less than fair market value, of steel on West Coast markets.

title: SEARCH SHIFTS FOR SUSPECT IN KILLINGS OF GAME WARDEN
description: The search for a 30-year-old man wanted in connection with the killings of two Idaho game wardens shifted to an area 45 miles northwest of here today.

title: SUN BELT FACING ITS GLOWING FUTURE CALMLY
description: As recently as three years ago, when an economic civil war between the sagging Northeast and the surging Sun Belt was widely thought to be heating up, a kind of defiance hung in the Texas air. ''Drive 70, Freeze a Yankee,'' snarled a bumper sticker often seen on Houston's freeways in those days.

title: PIONEER HI-BRED INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
by Mimi Sheraton; A Viennese nouvelle cuisine.
description: ALTHOUGH it seems quite natural that a negative review can damage a restaurant, it may be surprising to learn that a rave sometimes does a kind of damage all its own. Whether because of greed or inexperience, a restaurateur who gets a three-star or four-star rating, may pack the house beyond the capacities and temperaments of its kitchen and dining-room staff. The inevitable result of such action is poor food and rude or careless service, and a spate of justified complaints. It is gratifying, therefore, to discover that Vienna '79, which received a three-star rating last March, not only has been able to cope with success, but also has improved to the point where it well deserves a four-star rating. This despite the fact that the original chef left early in the fall to be replaced by the former sous-chef, Thomas Ferlesch, who is 24 years old.

title: Sox Directors Approve Offer
description: A $20 million offer to buy the Chicago White Sox, made by a local group headed by Jerry Reinsdorf, a real estate investor, and Eddie Einhorn, a television executive, was approved unanimously today by the American League club's board of directors.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 9, 1981; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Commission on Transnational Corpo- rations, Intergovernmental Working Group on a Code of Conduct - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Jersey Harness Horses Back
description: The 1,734 incandescent bulbs that bathe the Meadowlands track will flash on again tomorrow night, signaling the return of harness racing to the nation's leading horse park. And bettors at the first of 182 nights of action will find a new and cheaper way to lose money.

title: TOP POILISH PAPER WARNS UNIONS AGAINST ANARCHY
description: The Polish Communist Party's main newspaper today condemned ''anarchical incidents'' and urged ''peace and order'' in the country as the authorities and the independent labor organization Solidarity sparred over the organization's demand for a five-day workweek.

title: No Headline
description: ALTHOUGH New York's two newest major attempts at classic theater, the BAM Theater Company and the Lincoln Center Theater Company, have understandable attracted the most public attention, across the city many other companies have been struggling but surviving for years by offering theatergoers a steady diet of classics. Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway, the New York theater is known primarily as an arena of experimentation, a place where new plays and theatrical forms are introduced. But there's a place, too, for a number of small companies that specialize in classics.

title: Tradition of the Sea
description: The Navy may have an Ensign Seaman in a few years.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: BALTIMORE (AL) - Announced that K en Singleton, outfielder, has agreed to t hree-year contract extension. CINCINNATI (NL) - Reached agree- m ent on signing Larry Biittner, Cubs' first b aseman-outfielder, as a free agent.

title: Reagan's Chance In Namibia
description: Among urgent problems awaiting Ronald Reagan in the White House, there is one significant opportunity that has to be seized quickly or it may disappear.

title: DANCE: PAULINE KONER
description: BRAVE is the creative artist who dares to explain his or her work. Pauline Koner proved fearless and persuasive in this respect Wednesday night at the Riverside Church in a special program that opened two weekends of performances by the Pauline Koner Dance Consort.

title: INFLUENCED BLACK ARTS IN THE 60'S
description: Lawrence P. Neal, a poet, critic and playwright who was a major influence in the 60's black arts movement, died of a heart attack Tuesday in Community Memorial Hospital in Hamilton, N.Y. He was 42 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Misses Navratilova, Austin Gain Semifinal
description: Tracy Austin and Martina Navratilova, who met in last year's final, took different paths to the semifinals of the $250,000 Colgate Series Championships tonight.

title: CHAMBER MUSIC WITH FEW BIG NAMES FILLS CONCERT HALLS
description: CHAMBER musicians and their devoted audiences are thought to be reserved and sophisticated, and that they may be. But in recent years talk of a chamber-music ''boom'' or ''explosion'' -hardly the most reserved and sophisticated of words - has become common in music circles.

title: Landscapes at Library
description: F. Seymour Haden, a 19th-century surgeon who did not blend art with medicine until he was 40 years old, is one of a distinguished company of English artists whose landscape etchings are on display through March 15 at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street. Included besides Dr. Haden's work, a majority of the 70 etchings, are landscapes by Thomas Gainsborough, J.M.W. Turner, John Crome, John Constable, Samuel Palmer and Graham Sutherland. Weekend hours are 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. today and tomorrow.

title: MORNING'S RAIL COMMUTERS WAIT OUT EXTENDED DELAYS
description: Freezing temperatures, mechanical breakdowns and power shortages made getting into Manhattan a long, shivering ordeal yesterday morning for tens of thousands of rail commuters.

title:
NOTES ON PEOPLE;
Outlook for Bess Truman
description: Although she remains in satisfactory condition, Bess Truman is expected to be hospitalized for several more weeks, her family doctor said yesterday.

title: U.S. IS READYING RULE CONTROLLING A-WASTE ROUTES
description: The Department of Transportation intends to issue regulations shortly that would negate any attempts by New York City or other localities or states to ban the shipment of nuclear waste through their jurisdictions, officials said today.

title: News Analysis
description: In the immediate post-election euphoria, the steady refrain from Ronald Reagan's camp was that the new administration would ''hit the ground running'' on the day it took office, but as Inauguration Day approaches the complexities of the issues and of forming a government have been forcing delays. Symptomatic was the testimony of Caspar W. Weinberger, the Secretary of Defense-designate, to the Senate Armed Services Committee Tuesday, that it would take the Reagan administration ''a good six months'' to shape its military policy and thus prepare a strategy for arms negotiations.

title: Coming to the Aid of the Party
description: Ron Reagan, the son of the President-elect, is expected to be on hand this afternoon when the first 1981 inaugural medal is struck at Medallic Arts, a Danbury, Conn., medal-casting company that has provided medals for eight of the last ten inaugurals.

title: Montreal Hotel Fire Kills Woman
description: An early-morning fire in the Constellation Hotel today left one woman dead and another injured, the police said. Firemen evacuated the other guests from the building. The police said the fire broke out on the ground floor of the 12-story building about 5 A.M. Flames reached only to the third floor, but smoke spread throughout the building.

title: POWER FAILURE IN 3 WESTERN STATES CLOSES SCHOOLS, STORTES AND OFFICES
description: Electric power failed throughout Utah and in parts of Idaho and Wyoming today, trapping people in elevators and on ski lifts, snarling traffic and closing schools, stores and offices.

title: Indiana 55, Michigan State 43
description: Isiah Thomas scored a game-high 20 points, and Randy Wittman added 16 as Indiana defeated Michigan State, 55-43, in the Big Ten Conference opener for both teams tonight.

title: Jersey Lottery Offers A $2 Million Prize
description: TRENTON (AP) - New Jersey will begin a new lottery game on Wednesday with the biggest guaranteed grand prize ever offered in the state - $2 million.

title: Trying Times for Kate Smith
description: It's been estimated that Kate Smith, in her heyday as one of the most popular singers on radio during the 1930's and 40's, earned as much as $35 million. But the value of the ailing, 73-year-old singer's estate is now said to stand at about $500,000, and her extensive properties are being liquidated.

title: Esposito Felt Loss Of Scoring Prowess
description: Phil Esposito, the second-leading goal scorer in National Hockey League history, admitted yesterday that his announcement of retirement in the middle of a season was unusual, but said, ''I had thought for a month about it.''

title: A.I.A.W. Alters Rule on Transfer Students
description: The Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women revised its transfer rule for athletes today, making it more restrictive than the National Collegiate Athletic Association rule for men.

title: PUBLISHING: GLOOMY SCENE IN LONDON
description: Under a benevolent January sky, blush-pink and yellow roses are blooming in St. James's Park. But the unusually warm winter sun unfortunately is not shining on Britain's publishers and authors.

title: ART: A PAGEANT OF KOREAN ART AT THE MET
description: NO respectable international loan exhibition would nowadays be regarded as complete without its requisite share of glitter and gold. The big new show in town - ''5,000 Years of Korean Art,'' opening tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum of Art - meets this obligation very handily. In the very first section of the exhibition, which has been organized by the National Museum of Korea, visitors are treated to a gorgeous display of fifth- and sixth-century gold and jade crowns, gold girdles (elaborate gold belts from which are appended a variety of gold objects), gold earrings, gold bracelets, gold cups, a gold cap and some silver cups and bowls.

title: Ex-Sonic Is Thriving With Suns
description: When Dennis Johnson's summer vacation was interrupted by the news that the Seattle SuperSonics had traded him to Phoenix, he decided to think positively. Despite an acrimonious contract renegotiation, he did not want to leave the team that he led to the National Basketball Association championship in 1979. Yet here was a sportscaster in the Philippines telling him that he and Paul Westphal had changed places.

title: BROWN, F.C.C. DEMOCRAT, TO RESIGN FROM AGENCY
description: Tyrone Brown, a Democratic member of the Federal Communications Commission, notified the White House today that he planned to resign, effective Jan. 20, to become a partner in the Washington law firm of Steptoe & Johnson.

title: 'King David' Sunday
description: ''King David,'' Arthur Honegger's dramatic psalm, will be performed Sunday at 4 P.M. by the choir of St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street, and soloists.

title: AS MORE GETS LESS
description: To the Editor:

title: UCONN WINS 9TH IN ROW
description: Corny Thompson and Karl Hobbs combined for 19 points in the second half to lead unbeaten Connecticut to a 66-57 victory over Holy Cross tonight.

title: Ohlsson at Bosendorfer
description: Garrick Ohlsson will perform works on the Bosendorfer piano tomorrow night at 8 in the auditorium of the New York Times, 229 West 43d Street. The performance is the 15th in a series of free recitals featuring the Viennese-made instrument, which is noted for its longer keyboard and is often call the Rolls-Royce of pianos. Mr. Ohlsson, winner of the 1970 Chopin International Piano Competition, will play Beethoven's Sonata in E flat major (Op. 27, No. 1), Schubert's Sonata in C minor (Op. post.), Schoenberg's Five Pieces (Op. 23) and Debussy's Four Etudes. Information: 753-5200.

title: FRANCE EXTENDING AID TO CONCORDE
description: The economically ailing Concorde service of Air France to the United States and Latin America appears assured of at least three more years of life as a result of the French Government's decision this week to pay an increased share of the operating losses until 1983.

title: Russian Is Said to Defect To the Bonn Authorities
description: A Soviet interpreter at East-West troop-reduction talks in Vienna has defected to West Germany and is furnishing intelligence material to West German officials, informed sources reported today.

title: Faye Dunaway returning in new William Alfred play.
description: AFTER her 1965 Off Broadway triumph in William Alfred's ''Hogan's Goat,'' in which she played the wife of an Irish politician, Faye Dunaway left for Hollywood and hasn't been seen on a New York stage since. But if all goes according to plan, she will be on Broadway next fall in a new play Mr. Alfred has written for her. The title is ''Nothing Doing: A Tragic Vaudeville,'' and Miss Dunaway will be not only the star, but also the co-producer and co-director.

title: PERRY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After reduction of 10 cents a shr to reflect restatement of first and second qr earnings to capitalize interest expenses

title: CHAMPION HOME BUILDERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
QUALIFIED SUPPORT PLEDGED BY REAGAN ON A HOSTAGE PACT
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan gave a qualified pledge today to honor any agreement with Iran made by President Carter to free the American hostages, but said he reserved the right to draw up new proposals if the crisis was not ended by Jan. 20.

title: IMMIGRATION OFFICIAL SAYS CARTER'S BUDGET WILL CUT AGENCY STAFF
description: David Crosland, the Acting Immigration Commissioner, said today that President Carter was planning to propose significant manpower cuts for the Immigration and Naturalization Service at a time when ''everyone would agree we have more of a problem'' with illegal aliens.

title: Ford Dividend 30
description: The Ford Motor Company announced a dividend of 30 cents a share on outstanding stock for the first quarter, the third consecutive period that a 30-cent dividend has been paid.

title: by John Wilson
description: FREDA PAYNE has been coming along as a performer for more than a dozen years, and it can be said, on the basis of her current appearance at Marty's, Third Avenue at 73d Street, where she is appearing this week and next, that she is making progress.

title: Indoor Track Feels Economic Crunch
description: Indoor track, almost a world to itself, is neither dying nor decaying - but it is changing. Weaker and poorly run meets have suffered and some have disappeared.

title: GREGG SINGERS BLEND 2 GOLDEN AGES OF CHORAL MUSIC
description: When 20th-century composers reach into the future with bold experiments and fearless innovation, they often find themselves face to face with the past.

title: Minnesota 76, Wisconsin 60
description: Mark Hall scored 25 points and Trent Tucker added 17 tonight as they led Minnesota to a 76-60 victory over Wisconsin in the Big Ten.

title: Merrill Lynch Realty
description: Merrill Lynch Realty Associates Inc., a subsidiary ot Merrill Lynch & Company, said it had acquired a majority interest in Miller, Cowherd & Kerver, a real estate firm with nine offices and more than 300 sales representatives in Broward County, Fla.

title: Computer Sciences Charges Narrowed
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation said that a United States District Court had dismissed 43 of the 57 counts in an indictment against the company and six current and former employees.

title: Advertising; Keeping 2 Agencies Happy
description: THE Warner-Lambert Company, the country's eighth-largest national advertiser, has moved its fairly new Listermint mouthwash from J. Walter Thompson to the William Esty Company.

title: Arab Guerrillas Deny Accusation By Kenya on Bombing of a Hotel
description: A Palestinian guerrilla organization, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, denied today an assertion by Kenya that a member of the guerrilla movement was responsible for a New Year's Eve bomb explosion at a Nairobi hotel, in which 15 people were killed and 85 were injured.

title: Some Wrigley Prices Up
description: The Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company announced today that it had increased the wholesale price of its 17-stick Plen T Pak packaging of Spearmint, Doublemint, Juicy Fruit and Big Red chewing gum brands by 26 percent. A box of 12 packs rises to $3.78 from $3.

title: SERIES FROM JAPAN IS ALSO OPENING
description: ''Gassan,'' a film about a young man in search of spiritual fulfillment, will open a four-weekend series of recent Japanese films tonight at 7:30 in Japan House, 333 East 47th Street. All of the films are in Japanese with English subtitles, and include several local premieres.

title: DEATH IN EL SALVADOR; by Robert Kleiman
description: Michael Hammer, the American land reform adviser murdered in El Salvador Saturday night, knew he was putting his life on the line when he left Washington that morning. El Salvador was teetering on the edge of a rightist coup. Four assassination attempts had already been made, probably by rightist ''death squads,'' against Rodolfo Viera, the peasant leader Hammer was flying to help - and who would soon be slain with him and Mark Pearlman.

title: IRAQIS RIDICULE IRAN FOR ASSERTIONS OF TRIUMPH IN A COUNTEROFFENSIVE
description: Iraqi officials and the controlled press derided Iran today over its counteroffensive, accusing Iranian leaders of giving their people false hopes with their announcements of great victories.

title: SSS/Obit Page; Devin Adair Garrity Is Dead at 75; President of Publishing Company
description: Devin Adair Garrity, president of the Devin-Adair Publishing Company, died Tuesday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 75 years old. Mr. Garrity, whose father founded the company, was a graduate of Princeton University. He assummed the presidency in 1939 at his father's death.

title: Cold Wave Strikes Italy, And Sicilians See Rare Snow
description: Snow blanketed Palermo, Sicily, today for the first time in 19 years as a cold wave throughout Italy blocked mountain highways and isolated villages. The lowest temperature reported was 2 degrees below zero, in the mountains north of Venice.

title: Wriston to Be Council's Chief
description: Walter B. Wriston, chairman and chief executive of Citicorp, has been named the chairman of the Business Council, succeeding Reginald H. Jones, chairman of the General Electric Company, who completed a two-year term at the end of 1980.

title: Queens Art-Therapy Show
description: ''I Am Not a Wheelchair,'' a collection of 50 pieces of art work and poetry by disabled adults enrolled in a special art-therapy program, will be on view through Jan. 18 at the Queens Museum in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

title: STOCKMAN HEARING SUGGESTS FUTURE BUDGET CONFLICTS
description: David A. Stockman, who has been designated President-elect Ronald Reagan's budget chief, answered a Senate committee's questions for more than five hours today in a confirmation hearing that produced harbingers of conflicts over cutting the budget.

title: AAV COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
40 Years of the U.S.O.
description: In February, the U.S.O. celebrates 40 years of serving the men and women in the armed forces and their families.

title: CAPITAL TRANSPORT
description: To the Editor:

title: CAPITOL FOOD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
JUDGE'S STAND ON BUSING DIVIDES LOUISIANA TOWN ON RACIAL LINES
description: Outside the Rapides Parish courthouse, the brisk winter breeze lapped at the gas-fed eternal flame dedicated, according to an inscription, ''to those who sacrificed so much in the defense of freedom.''

title: Halldorson, on 63, Leads Tucson Open by 2 Shots
description: Dan Halldorson, a winner in the last tournament of 1980, posted a 7-under-par 63 and took a 2-stroke lead today in the first event of the 1981 PGA Tour, the $300,000 Joe Garagiola-Tucson open.

title: HIRSHHORN ADDS MAJOR WORKS
description: The Hirshhorn Museum has acquired a painting by Joan Miro and a seven-foot bronze sculpture by Gaston Lachaise, the Smithsonian Institution announced today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cooper Industries Inc., Houston, has named Waldemar A. Oelschlager president of the Cooper mining and construction operation, based in Dallas.

title: STAGE: 'PIRATES OF PENZANCE' ON BROADWAY
description: LAST night Joseph Papp's production of ''The Pirates of Penzance'' sailed into the Uris, and, yes, it is every bit as wonderful on Broadway in January as it was in Central Park in July. It may even be more wonderful. The chorus leaps higher; the band plays brighter; the powerhouse stars are now so self-assured that you may think they own the town. And, don't worry, they haven't forgotten about the moon that rose over the park in Act II. Thanks to the lighting designer Jennifer Tipton, there's a lovely full moon indoors at the Uris, too. The best things in life don't have to be free.

title: ART: PHOTOGRAPHING AMERICA'S CHILDREN
description: THE credit - or blame - for the invention of childhood has sometimes been laid at the door of 19th-century England. And there's no question that the Victorians, besides writing superlative books for the young, contributed greatly to the modern attitudes toward them. (Of course, they tended also, depending on their religious tilt, to regard children either as embodiments of innocence or vessels brimming with original sin.)

title: Washington to Lease 50 More Buses to City
description: The Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority has agreed to lease an additional 50 buses to New York City's troubled transit system. But officials say there will not be another convoy like the one that brought nearly 100 buses north last month.

title: 21 Years of Determination to Become a Nurse
description: When she graduated from high school in Livingston, La., Eddie Lott stood second in her class, and Southeastern Louisiana University was glad to award her a scholarship for nursing studies.

title: U.N. ENVOYS SAEE PAKISTANI SHIFT TOWARD KARMAL'S KABUL REGIME
description: Asian diplomats here have concluded that Pakistan is dropping its diplomatic support for the insurgent forces in Afghanistan and is moving instead toward recognition of the Soviet-installed Government of President Babrak Karmal.

title: U.S. WITHHOLDS FUNDS FOR THE PORTMAN HOTEL PLANNED FOR TIMES SQUARE
description: The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development yesterday formally withheld a key Federal grant for the proposed Portman Hotel on Times Square, throwing the project's future into doubt.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A stake-out at two East Side banks led to the arrest of three men moments after they robbed a Citibank branch at 23d Street and First Avenue of $3,385, the police said.

title: ALVAR LIDELL, WARTIME ANNOUNCER
description: Alvar Lidell, the British Broadcasting Corporation announcer whose measured tones informed the people of Britain of the abdication of King Edward VIII and the outbreak of World War II, has died at the age of 72, his family announced today.

title: 20 Injured in Confrontation On Baja California Campus
description: About 500 anti-unionists stormed the Autonomous University of Baja California last night to break up a strike by professors, campus workers and students who have been trying to win union recognition.

title: New York Bottler, Coke in Merger Pact
description: The Coca-Cola Company, the nation's leading soft-drink producer, and the Coca-Cola Bottling Company Of New York Inc. have executed an agreement for a merger announced in November, the companies announced.

title: CAREY WANTS CURBS ON SCHOOL AID AND A FREEZE ON REVENUE SHARING
description: Governor Carey will ask that New York State continue to freeze its revenue-sharing aid to local governments at the 1979 level and that public schools get far smaller increases than they did last year, aides to the Governor said today.

title: Strings on the Hudson
description: The Emerson String Quartet, winner of the 1978 Naumburg Award for chamber music, will perform Sunday at 3 P.M. in the Hudson River Museum, 511 Warburton Avenue in Yonkers. The quartet is made up of Eugene Drucker and Philip Setzer, violinists; Lawrence Dutton, violist, and David Finckel, cellist

title: AN AWARD FOR GREEN HAIR
description: All Jamie Friedman wanted when she went to the hairdressers in Boston three years ago was some dramatic highlighting for her blond hair.

title: FIRST CONNECTICUT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WITNESS ASSERTS MRS. HARRIS HAD APPEARED DESPONDENT
description: A colleague of Jean S. Harris testified today at her murder trial that she became ''especially depressed and despondent'' between a late-morning and midafternoon meeting at the Madeira School in McLean, Va., on March 10. Mrs. Harris is accused of shooting Dr. Herman S. Tarnower later that day at his home in Purchase, N.Y.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: 'DALLAS,' A MITCH MILLER PILOT AND A NEW SERIES ON ART By JANET MASLIN

title: CHEMICAL'S EARNINGS UP
description: The Chemical New York Corporation reported yesterday that operating income before securities transactions in the fourth quarter of 1980 rose 31.2 percent, to $51.3 million, or $3.25 a share, from $39.1 million, or $2.49 a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1979.

title: Norman E. Cash Joins A Communications Outfit
description: Tall and dignified Norman E. Cash, with probably hundreds of speeches behind him as president for 18 years of the Television Bureau of Advertising, has joined In-Person Communications.

title: KELLY,ON STAND, SAYS THAT HE WAS VICTIM OF POLITICAL ASSASSINS
description: Former Representative Richard Kelly, explaining to a jury why he had taken $25,000 in bribe money, testified today that he now believed the Government had set out to assassinate him politically.

title: G.A.O. Urges Law to Curb Fraud In Use of Social Security Cards
description: The General Accounting Office urged Congress today to pass a stiff law to crack down on fraudulent use of Social Security numbers, an abuse that reportedly cost taxpayers more than $15 billion a year.

title: KANSAS CITY PHILHARMONIC CANCELS ITS CONCERT SEASON
description: The Kansas City Philharmonic canceled its 1980-81 season today because of a musicians' strike, the first cancellation in the orchestra's 48-year history.

title: Antiabortion Unit Lists 12 Senators as Targets
description: Twelve United States Senators holding seats up for election in 1982, including Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, both Democrats, were selected today for defeat by a national antiabortion organization.

title: Mathew (Stymie) Beard, Actor; Was One of 'The Little Rascals'
description: Mathew (Stymie) Beard, one of the ''Our Gang'' comedy actors who were known on television as ''The Little Rascals,'' died today in the Los Angeles County-U.S.C. Medical Center.

title: HEALTH OFFICIALS REPORT WIDESPREAD OUTBREAKS OF FLU
description: Outbreaks of influenza are sweeping the country, with epidemics occurring in several areas, including Massachusetts and New York City, the national Centers for Disease Control reported yesterday.

title: 3 More Big Banks Cut Prime to 20%
description: Three major banks lowered their prime lending rates to 20 percent yesterday, lower than most major banks but higher than the 19 1/2 percent prime rate set earlier in the week by Chemical Bank.

title: DEFENSE IS GIVEN A POLICE SKETCH IN MURDER AT MET
description: The lawyer for a 21-year-old stagehand accused of pushing a violinist to her death from the roof of the Metropolitan Opera House last July 23 won the right to examine two key pieces of evidence yesterday.

title: WEINBERGER IS SAID TO INSIST ON PICKING HIS DEPUTY
description: Caspar W. Weinberger, the prospective Secretary of Defense, has informed Ronald Reagan that he will not serve in the Cabinet unless he is permitted to name his own deputy, according to insiders on the transition team.

title: Market Place; How Insurers Reduce Costs
description: TRADITIONALLY life insurance has been offered on a one-on-one basis, with the selling agent receiving a substantial part of the first year's premium as the bulk of his or her pay.

title: 'Productive' Tests Of Hibernia Oilfield
description: Mobil Oil Canada Ltd. said final tests indicated that its B-08 appraisal well in the Hibernia field off the coast of Newfoundland was ''the most productive yet tested.''

title: Sister Ann Joachim, 79, Is Dead; Lawyer Admitted by High Court
description: Sister Ann Joachim, the first nun in the United States admitted to practice law before the United States Supreme Court, died here today at the age of 79.

title: E.S.P.N. Advertisers
description: The parade of giant advertisers to cable network sponsorship continues. E.S.P.N., the Entertainment and Sports Network, which is owned by Getty Oil, announced yesterday that its new advertisers for this year are Panasonic, General Telephone and Electronics, Fuji, Subaru, Exxon, Panorama magazine, Dow Jones's National Business Employment Weekly and Sports Illustrated. The committments vary from a one-quarter buy by Exxon to a full-year for Fuji, the camera and film outfit.

title: Calcutta Demonstrators Seized
description: About 700 supporters of the opposition Old Congress Party were arrested today while demonstrating in favor of higher crop prices for farmers. Party officials said 15 people were injured when police charged into the demonstrators.

title: PNEUMATIC SCALE CORP reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $136,448 income from cumulative effect of an accounting change

title: LEVI STRAUSS AND M-G-M PROFITS CLIMB; M-G-M
description: The Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company reported that earnings in the first fiscal quarter of 1981 ended Nov. 30, rose 12 percent, as revenues remained level at $51 million.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch in The Times of Dec. 28 on the recent reversal of Marinus van der Lubbe's conviction for the German Reichstag fire in 1933 incorrectly identified the other defendants. Three Bulgarian Communists and a German Communist were tried with van der Lubbe and acquitted.

title: Emerson Executive Named Budget Aide
description: Edwin Harper, 39 years old, a member of the transition staff of President-elect Ronald Reagan and a former special assistant at the White House, has been nominated as deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget. The post is subject to confirmation by the Senate, with hearings tentatively scheduled to take place after Mr. Reagan's inauguration.

title: 'FERRO' AT THALIA
description: THE only reason to make an effort to see ''The Case Against Ferro,'' the 1976 French film having its New York theatrical premiere today at the Thalia, is to see the other half of the double bill, ''Daughters of Darkness,'' the English-language Belgian film that was reviewed when it opened in New York in 1971. It stars the beautiful, incomparably elegant Delphine Seyrig as a modern vampire, a Hungarian countess with a subsidiary taste for pretty girls. The setting is splendid, an almost empty Ostend hotel in midwinter, and though the whole business is silly, it's entertaining.

title: HOTEL INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $390,320 extraordinary gain from sale of a hotel

title: Index; International
description: France acts to counter Libyan move into Chad A2 Poland charts a program of wide economic reforms A3 Polish Communist paper assails ''anarchial'' labor agitation A3 Soviet Communist paper attacks a leading Polish dissident A3 Around the World A5 Namibia conferees clash, then get down to business A6 Japanese pleased that Mansfield will remain as Ambassador A7 Key members of Begin coalition talk of early elections in Israel A9 Government/Politics Immigration official complains of budget cut A13 14 more judges to handle criminal cases in New York City B1 Ravitch hails Carey's program for mass transit improvements B4 Energy Federal regulation pending on nu- clear shipment routes B2 General Around the Nation A10 People in the Sunbelt take rosy fu- ture calmly A10 Search shifts for suspect in Idaho deaths A10 Mixup blamed for release of de- fendant accused in boy's death B1 Witness says Mrs. Harris seemed depressed on day of slaying B2 Defense wins right to examine sketch in Met murder case B3 Families seek warmth in armory B3 Garwood linked to four mental disorders D14 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of expected bad weather, al- ternate-side parking regulations are suspended throughout New York City today. Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Theater: New York stage brushes up its classics C1

title: VOLUME OFF
description: The stock market yesterday incurred its second consecutive sharp loss. Trading was less active, however, with the blue-chip, energy and technology issues posting the largest losses.

title: LEVI STRAUSS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Princess Alice Is Buried Near Her Grandmother
description: Princess Alice, the last surviving grandchild of Queen Victoria, was buried today in the graveyard adjoining the mausoleum of her grandmother.

title: Miller Leads by 2 Strokes, Posting a 64 for 130 Total
description: Johnny Miller shot a six-under-par 64 and took a two-stroke lead today in the second round of the $300,000 Joe Garagiola-Tucson open, the opening event on the PGA Tour.

title: STATE NATIONAL BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Buffalo Forge Board Opposes Ampco Bid
description: The Buffalo Forge Company said its directors had unanimously determined that the recent tender offer by the Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation ''is inadequate as to price and is not in the best interests of the company or its stockholders.''

title: M.T.A. Signs Pact With Grumman
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority signed an agreement with the Grumman Corporation of Bethpage, L.I., clearing the way for the eventual return of 637 new Flxible buses to New York City streets.

title: Mastropieri Given A 3-Year Sentence
description: Former City Councilman Eugene F. Mastropieri was sentenced yesterday to three years for having helped three of his law clients to conceal nearly half a million dollars in income and evade more than $250,000 in Federal income taxes.

title: A.J. CRONIN, AUTHOR OF 'CITADEL' AND 'KEYS OF THE KINGDOM,' DIES
description: A.J. Cronin, a Scottish physician whose novels, including ''Hatter's Castle,'' ''The Citadel'' and ''The Keys of the Kingdom,'' made him one of the most popular authors in the English-speaking world, died at the age of 84 on Tuesday in a clinic in the village of Glion, near Montreux, Switzerland, where he had lived for the last 25 years. Dr. Cronin's death was made known yesterday after a private Roman Catholic service at the Notre Dame Church in Vevey that was attended by his three sons.

title: List of Panel Members At the Hearing on Haig
description: The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, which is considering President-elect Ronald Reagan's choice of Alexander M. Haig Jr. as Secretary of State, is headed by Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, and has 15 members.

title: IT'S TIME OF YEAR FOR FAKE WATCHES
description: J ANUARY is a great month for sales, but if you come across a sale offering $1,450 Cartier watches for $150, it's not a bargain. The watches are almost certainly counterfeit. For four years, cheaply made but remarkably similar counterfeits of fine watches, including those made by Cartier, Rolex, Omega and Seiko, have turned up in discount stores, peddlers' sidewalk suitcases and, in Mexico, even in counterfeit Cartier stores.

title: Brazil and Uruguay Meet in Soccer Final
description: The mini World Cup tournament in Montevideo, Uruguay, attracted the world's six most successful soccer nations. The 12-day event, which ends today with a championship game between Brazil and Uruguay, has shown that, with the 1982 World Cup only a year off, the South American powers are superior to the Europeans.

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times One Black Man's Rise By MEL WATKINS THE STRUGGLE THAT MUST BE. By Harry Edwards. Macmillan. 350 pages. $13.95.

title: PERCY AND CONSERVATIVES: SENATOR SEES NO TROUBLE
description: Charles H. Percy, an old Republican liberal who is the new chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, says he foresees no serious difficulties in working with conservatives in the Reagan administration and in the Senate.

title: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: Shr earnings figures are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split pai Sept 22, 1980 and recomputed in accordance with the F.A.S.B. In pretation No 31 to include the tax benefit attributable to unex stock options

title: Korchnoi Wins Match As Hubner Withdraws
description: Victor Korchnoi, a Soviet emigre now living in Switzerland, won the final world chess championship Candidates' Match today when Robert Hubner, a West German grandmaster, withdrew after eight games.

title: 5 Americans Ask Transfer From Prisons in Turkey
description: Five Americans, imprisoned on hashish smuggling charges, have sent a petition to the Turkish Ministry of Justice requesting their transfer to the United States under a new treaty on prisoner exchange.

title: NEW YORK CITY STANDS 1980 RECESSION BETTER THAN U.S. AS A WHOLE
description: New York City came through the 1980 recession better than the nation as a whole and also better than it did in the two previous recessions, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of labor statistics, said yesterday.

title:
PATENTS;
Straw Content Improved For the Feed of Animals
description: After research at the University of Oregon, three inventors have patented for the Department of Agriculture a process to improve the palatability, digestibility and protein content of straw for animal feed.

title: 6 Phillips Aides Freed by Oilers
description: General Manager Ladd Herzeg released all six Houston Oiler assistant coaches from their contracts today, saying that five could seek employment with any team in the National Football League except the New Orleans Saints. The sixth, Wade Phillips, son of the recently dismissed head coach, was given unconditional permission to talk with any N.F.L. club, including the Saints.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JANUARY 10, 1981
description: International A major weapons sale to Saudi Arabia is reportedly being considered by West Germany, which would reverse the West German policy of staying out of the weapons business in regions of tension. Members of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Social Democratic Party oppose the proposed sale on the grounds that it would be a potential danger to Israel and would conflict with longstanding policy. (Page 1, Columns 4-5.) One of Poland's Communist leaders sought to avert a showdown with the independent labor union Solidarity, urging in an unexpected appearance on television a ''reasonable solution'' to the union's disputes with the Government. Stefan Olszowksi, a member of the Politburo, suggested that a compromise was possible on the five-day workweek sought by the union. (1:6.)

title: COLLEAGUE SAYS MRS. HARRIS WAS RACKED BY JOB PRESSURE
description: Jean S. Harris believed that the board of directors of the Madeira School for girls, where she was headmistress, expected her to be ''all things to all people,'' a former colleague testified today at her murder trial, but ''she felt she was not succeeding.''

title: AL DAVIS ASSAILED BY KLEIN
description: With their teams preparing for Sunday's American Conference championship game here, Gene Klein bitterly attacked Al Davis yesterday, accusing him of using a Los Angeles newspaper as his mouthpiece in an ''insidious'' plot to intimidate officials.

title: EAGLES BOLSTER RECEIVING CORPS
description: The Philadelphia Eagles added Wally Henry to their depleted corps of pass receivers yesterday as a backup to Harold Carmichael and Rodney Parker for tomorrow's National Conference championship game against Dallas at Philadelphia.

title: WILLIAM PAYTON SMITH
description: William Payton Smith, a Harlem lawyer for more than 30 years, died Saturday at Montclair (N.J.) Community Hospital. Mr. Smith, who lived in Manhattan, was 56 years old.

title: WOMEN, N.C.A.A. TO CONFER
description: Donna Lopiano, installed today as president of the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women, said her first act would be to lead a delegation to the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention next week in an attempt to convince the men's organization not to get involved in the conduct of women's athletics.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: 1. Peter Sutcliffe, who once posed for the British trucking company advertisement pictured above, hid his face from photographers this week. Why?

title: Israelis Dismantle Explosive
description: A bomb squad today dismantled an explosive device that had been planted in the Mahane Yehuda marketplace here, the police said.

title: DR. CHARLES I. STOLOFF
description: Dr. Charles I. Stoloff, a New York dentist who wrote many scientific articles, died Monday at in Doctors Hospital.

title: SUN TO PHASE OUT SHIPBUILDING
description: The Sun Company, the country's 10th-largest oil corporation, stunned the economically depressed city of Chester today by announcing that its shipbuilding subsidiary, the city's leading employer, would phase out all new-ship construction, eventually eliminating about 3,100 jobs.

title: U.S. Fighter Crashes in England; Search Is Conducted for the Pilot
description: A United States Air Force A-10 Thunderbolt fighter crashed today at a Royal Air Force firing range at Donna Nook on the east coast of England, a Defense Ministry spokesman said.

title: PERRY PRATT, JET-ENGINE DESIGNER
description: Perry W. Pratt, a leading aircraft engine designer, died Tuesday at his home in Jupiter, Fla. He was 66 years old and a longtime resident of Glastonbury, Conn.

title: FOR 7 HOURS, HAIG STAYS IN CHARGE, AT EASE
description: With practiced confidence, Alexander M. Haig Jr. told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that Presidentelect Ronald Reagan wanted him as ''general manager of American diplomacy,'' and then Mr. Haig showed through seven hours of questioning that he knew how to take charge.

title: CITY STRENGTHENS ITS EFFORTS TO ASSIST HEATLESS TENANTS
description: Mayor Koch and Anthony B. Gliedman, New York City's Housing Commissioner, said yesterday that the city had restored heat and hot water to ''tens of thousands'' of tenants in 6,000 privately owned buildings so far this winter through its emergency repairs program.

title:
Patents;
Chemical Reactions 'Filmed'
description: WASHINGTON ALASER apparatus invented for the International Business Machines Corporation provides ''snapshots'' of what happens within a few billionths of a second in chemical reactions. The invention supplies valuable information on high-speed and high-temperature chemical events such as combustion in an automobile engine.

title: BEVERLY SUSER GRUNWALD, WRITER OF WOMAN'S WEAR DAILY COLUMN
description: Beverly Suser Grunwald, a columnist and book reviewer, died yesterday of cancer. She was 57 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Martha's Vineyard, Mass.

title: SABRES TIE RANGERS
description: Phil Esposito played the final game of his National Hockey League career last night, collecting no goals, one assist and countless cheers at Madison Square Garden.

title: U.S. SET TO REPLACE A CIVIL SERVICE TEST
description: Over the objection of President-elect Ronald Reagan's transition team, the Carter Administration settled a job discrimination suit today by agreeing to replace one of the Government's basic Civil Service examinations.

title: TESTS DUE ON 2 SKELETONS FOUND IN ATLANTA'S SEARCH FOR CHILDREN
description: Two skeletons that, the police say, could be those of children were found today in a southwest Atlanta suburb searched widely by police officers investigating the slayings of 11 black children here since 1979.

title: Big Suffolk Downs Payoff
description: Sid's Ambition, making only his second start, won the sixth race at Suffolk Downs today and returned the second highest payoff in the track's history. Sid's Ambition paid $442.20 to win, $181.80 for place and $36.60 for show on $2. The biggest payoff at Suffolk Downs is $445.20 returned by Sue Haroer in 1940.

title: Israelis Say They Exhumed Bodies of 5 Slain Guerrillas
description: The Israeli military authorities said today that they had exhumed the bodies of five Palestinian guerrillas to rebut charges that the bodies had been mutilated. The guerrillas were killed in a clash in southern Lebanon on Dec. 25.

title: Cerone Making Points With 10
description: Bare-chested, Rick Cerone smiles while a young woman, dressed in a pinstripe baseball shirt adorned with the number 10, gazes into his brown eyes. ''One good 10,'' the advertising copy reads, ''deserves another.''

title: LAZARE KAPLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including tax credits $81,000 for the qr and $236,000 for the C-Net income...D-Including $84,000 tax credit; 1979 figures are to give effect to the adoption of the LIFO inventory method for Stones Inventory retroactive to June 1, 1979

title: Princeton 44, Brown 41
description: Neil Christel sank two free throws with 33 seconds left to help Princeton beat Brown, 44-41, in an Ivy League game.

title: VERTIPILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CHICAGO TV AIDE TO RUN WABC
description: Bill Fyffe of WLS-TV in Chicago has been promoted to vice president and general manager of WABC-TV, the network's flagship station. He will replace Phil Boyer, who has been appointed vice president of programming for stations owned by ABC.

title: IRAN RAISES MORE QUESTIONS ABOUT U.S. PLAN
description: Iran has raised additional questions about the latest American proposals for freeing the hostages, and this has led Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher to extend his discussions in Algiers, the State Department said today.

title: ALFRED GOLDING
description: Alfred Golding, president of Golding Brothers, Canadian Ltd., a major supplier to the bedding industry, died Dec. 29 at his Manhattan home.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LECTURES AT SOTHEBY'S

title: HAIG WARNS PANEL OF NEED TO CONTAIN SOVIET ARMS GROWTH
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr., President-elect Ronald Reagan's choice for Secretary of State, warned the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today of the dangers presented by uncontrolled Soviet military power. And he responded to occasional critical questions about the Watergate scandals and other issues from his days in the Nixon White House.

title: MAJOR POINTS FROM APPEARANCE BY HAIG BEFORE SENATE COMMITTEE
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the opening statement by Alexander M. Haig Jr. before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in Washington yesterday on his nomination as Secretary of State, as recorded by The New York Times; from a written appendix that Mr. Haig submitted to the committee, and from questions and answers in the testimony:

title: Earthquake Hits Guadeloupe
description: A-PITRE, Guadeloupe, Jan. 9 (UPI) - An earthquake registering 4.8 on the open-ended Richter scale shook the French islands of Guadeloupe in the Caribbean early today, but no casualties or damage were reported.

title: NEW YORK STATE AND CITY VS. HOUSING FOR HELPLESS
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
Rotary Gasoline Engine Powers a Water Pump
description: An Argentine rancher has patented a rotary gasoline engine that he uses to pump water for his 10,000 head of cattle.

title: ANXIOUS RELATIVES FIND A CUASE FOR GRIEF, OR JOY
description: They generally came in pairs today, huddled together to help stave off the bitter cold, and to fortify themselves against the possible bad news.

title: IN PARIS, EFFEL'S GRAND TINKERTOY GETS AN OVERHAUL
