description: The Eiffel Tower is not a building; it houses nothing. It is not a monument; it stands for nothing. It is more of a lofty gesture, frozen in time and 13,000 tons of iron.

title: USLIFE INCOME FUND CORP reports earnings for As of Dec 31
Death Toll Rises to 230 In Amazon Boat Disaster
description: Rescue workers found 100 more bodies inside a capsized Amazon River steamer today, raising the death toll to at least 230.

title: FROM ALDOLFO TO HIS FANS: A COLLECTION WITH HUMOR
description: Nancy Reagan wasn't there, but her presence was almost palpable at the opening of Adolfo's spring and summer show yesterday. As everyone involved with fashion or first ladies must know by now, she has been a customer of his since 1967.

title: Taxpayer Calls a Trick Play Against the Cowboys
description: If there's anything that makes Douglas McCone angry it's having to pay Philadelphia's wage, or payroll, tax, since he only works there and lives in nearby Haddonfield, N.J. But as long as the courts say the tax can be legally collected, he wants Philadelphia to collect it without making exceptions, even for famous athletes.

title: FRASER MORTGAGE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BROOKS FASHION STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
Ashland Approved On Integon Bid
description: Ashland Oil Inc. said the insurance commissioners of Georgia and Kansas had approved Ashland's plan to acquire the Integon Corporation in a two-phased transaction valued at about $252 million.

title: Hanna Mining Plans To Shut Some Units
description: The Hanna Mining Company said it would suspend operations at one of its facilities in Michigan and two in Quebec, forcing the layoffs of about 1,150 people.

title: ALVIN GOULDNER, 60, A RADICAL SOCIOLOGIST, DIES OF HEART ATTACK
description: Alvin W. Gouldner, a prominent sociologist, died of a heart attack in Madrid on Dec. 15 as he was completing a lecture tour in Europe, it was learned yesterday. He was 60 years old and lived in St. Louis.

title: DAYTON IS STRIVING TO COPE WITH GROWING FISCAL WOES
description: Like a family whose breadwinner is facing a layoff, this city is beginning to wonder how it will be able to pay its bills in the state's continuing fiscal crisis.

title: KISSINGER'S MEDDLING
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Estonian Dissidents Reported To Receive Prison Camp Terms
description: Two Estonians have been sentenced to labor camps on charges of anti-Soviet agitation after a trial in the Republic of Estonia, exile sources here reported today.

title: No Headline
description: In the Events and Openings column in Weekend yesterday, the time was given incorrectly for a concert on Sunday by the National Urban Festival Orchestra at the Abraham Goodman Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. The correct time is 3 P.M.

title: GREIT REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $1,680,000 gain on the disposal of investment and $505,000 charge of proposed settlement of sharholders suits...C-Net loss including $12,000 gain on disposal of investment and $2.2 million investment loss provision

title: Staten Island 81 City College 75
description: Gerry Koenig poured in a game-high 20 and Tom Johnson added 15 leading the College of Staten Island to a 81-75 victory over City College last night in a CUNY Conference game on the winner's court.

title: FREDERICK'S OF HOLLYWOOD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
Transactions; BASEBALL
description: KANSAS CITY (AL) - Signed Clint Hur- d le, outfielder, and Rich Gale and Ken B rett, pitchers. BASKETBALL ATLANTA (NBA) - Placed Wayne Rol- l ins, center, on injured list with sprained a nkle.

title: SYRIA WARNS JORDAN OF AN INVASION IF ANOTHER CONFRONTATION DEVELOPS
description: A Syrian leader, accusing Jordan of continued conspiracies against the Government of President Hafez alAssad, has declared that Syrian forces will not stop at the Jordanian border if a new military confrontation is ordered.

title: MCCARTNEY, EX-BEATLE, DONATES TO FUND FOR THE NEEDIEST CASES
description: For the second consecutive year, Paul McCartney, the former Beatle, and his wife, Linda, have contributed $10,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: 20-Cent First-Class Stamp Is Urged by Postal Lawyer
description: The Postal Service made its final appeal today for authority to increase the price of a first-class postage stamp to 20 cents, from 15 cents.

title: 11TH STRAIGHT DEFEAT
description: The Phoenix Suns tonight achieved their first victory against the Nets in New Jersey, winning by 112-95 before the largest Net home crowd of the season, 8,305.

title: KEANSBURG DESCRIBED BY RESIDENTS AS A RESORT TOWN ON THE WANE
description: The New Jersey community that was the scene of the fatal fire in a home for the aged was described yesterday by many of its residents as a resort town on the wane whose occupants live in modest homes and largely work at nearby companies.

title: Bonn's Growth In '80 Was 1.8%
description: West Germany's economy, after adjusting for inflation, grew 1.8 percent last year, far short of the 2.5 percent growth rate the Government predicted last January, according to preliminary figures released today.

title: 'HANGER 18' A TALE ABOUT A CAPTURED U.F.O.
description: ''Hangar 18'' is the sort of melodrama that pretends to be skeptical, but requires that everyone watching it be profoundly gullible. It's about the efforts of the White House Chief of Staff to hide from the public the fact that the Air Force has caught a flying saucer and is studying it at a secret Texas base.

title: UNIFLITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After $150,000 or 25 cents a shr reduced net income adjustmen attributable to certain adjustments made by the company in prio qtrs of fiscal 1980 primarily related to inventory, bonuses, profit sharing contributions and income taxes...C-Net income... D-Including $1.6 million tax credit; results reflect operating income and a proration of business interruption insurance in th financial statement

title: SCHULMAN, A, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock divd payable Feb 4

title: SLIGHT RISE IN DECEMBER JOB TOTALS STILL DOES NOT WIPE OUT '80 LOSSES
description: Conditions for the nation's job seekers improved slightly in December, but at year's end the employment situation had still not recovered from the sharp slump of early 1980, the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: Sports of The Times; The Big Man's Final Shot
description: A certain ignoramus used to go around insisting there were only 18,000 hockey fans in all of New York City. These same 18,000 fans, the ignoramus insisted, crowded Madison Square Garden each game, but nobody else followed the sport.

title: Trivia: What's Nixon's Favorite Bird?
description: As one of the most investigated, inspected, examined and writtenabout men in the world, it would seem there's little the public doesn't know about Richard M. Nixon. But how many people know that one of the former President's very favorite birds is the cuckoo-like, long-tailed crested desert denizen, the roadrunner?

title: A DEVIL'S BREW OF RECIPES
description: Call it sheer perversity or a penchant for the macabre, but in my unending search for truly wonderful recipes I have amassed a cherished collection of others that are dreadful to the point of being bizarre.

title: McDonnell Douglas Wins U.S. Contract
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced it had been selected by the Army as the prime contractor on a project to develop technology for an antiballistic missile defense system, effective April 1.

title: COMPUTER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; the company has been operating as debtor in posse under Chapter 11 since Nov 6

title: Civiletti to Join Baltimore Firm
description: Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti said Friday that he had decided to rejoin the Baltimore law firm of Venable, Baetjer & Howard. The Attorney General said that he would join the firm on Jan. 20.

title: DANCE: PHOEBE NEVILLE AND COMPANY
description: Every art form has its dominant trends, but the dancerchoreographer Phoebe Neville remains determinedly apart. Her Gothic dreamlike studies are neither rooted in pure movement nor overt body language. And yet she constructs sturdy dramas of considerable impact that draw largely from formalist experiments.

title: GIVING A HAND TO THE NONTRADITIONAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Shanghai's Star Panda Attacks His 2 Handlers
description: Wei Wei, the world's only performing giant panda, attacked two of his handlers from the Shanghai circus today, Japanese officials said.

title: THE CHUTE OF MEMORY
description: IFTEEN below zero, and falling - the coldest Christmas ever in Maine. And I kept my house as warm as Santa's mittens without burning a drop of oil. A wood fire? Not on your life. Coal.Rememb er coal? Sure you do, if you're over 30 and grew up in, say, New York City.

title: The Way to Make Conrail Pay
description: Conrail, the receiver of the Penn Central and a half-dozen smaller bankrupt freight railroads, has absorbed $3.1 billion in Government subsidies in its five-year life. Now, Conrail's Federal overseers grimly predict it will take $2.1 billion more to keep the boxcars moving for another five years.

title: API TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including gains of $138,000 for the qr and $146,000 for the 6 mos on sale of real estate...C-Net income including gains of $484,000 for the qr and $507,000 for the 6 mos on sale of real estate

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; I.R.A. Says It Planted Bomb And Warns of More Attacks

title: FIRE KILLS 20 AT HOME FOR AGED IN NEW JERSEY
description: Twenty persons were killed and 13 others were missing and feared dead early yesterday in a fire of undetermined origin that roared through a two-story brick and stucco home for the elderly in Keansburg, N.J.

title: PARKER PEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
PAINTED ON GLASS
description: Martha Ryther Kantor, a painter and the widow of the American artist Morris Kantor, died at her home in New City, N.Y., last Saturday. She was 84 years old and had been ill with cancer.

title: Nevada Says It Pursues Investigation on Sinatra
description: Nevada gaming authorities said today that further work was being done on an investigation into the background of Frank Sinatra, partly as a result of recent statements by an informer that the singer had underworld ties,

title: TOMORROW'S CAREER WOMAN AT A CROSSROADS
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There are things that we Americans must be willing to fight for. I know this republic was spawned by armed conflict for the freedoms and liberties that we enjoy today.'' - Alexander M. Haig Jr. (10:4.)

title: FUGUE FOR TIN HORNS
description: Exit polls show that many Californians who watched the televised dropping of the New York's ball at midnight, Eastern Standard Time, were less likely to go out and celebrate themselves.

title: LANIER BUSINESS PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28

PATENTS;
Exercise Bicycle Records User's Muscular Activity
description: An electronic exercise bicycle called Computrim 900, which was patented this week for AMF Inc. of White Plains, has a microprocessor that records and displays the muscular activity of the user.

title: A Courting Poem Recalls Another Phyllis Schlafly
description: She may be the founder and national chairman of the Stop ERA movement, fighting fiercely to preserve the image of the at-home woman devoted to tradition and family.

title: Getty Sets Outlay
description: The Getty Oil Company said its board of directors had authorized a $2.24 billion capital expenditures budget for 1981 operations.

title: S.C.H. (Sammy) Davis
description: S.C.H. (Sammy) Davis, who won the Le Mans 24-hour automobile race in 1927, died today when fire swept his home just before the postman arrived with telegram greetings on his 94th birthday.

title: New Portuguese Premier And Aides Take Office
description: Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao and his center-right Cabinet took office today with a pledge to govern for four years and ''liberate civil society'' from the Marxist legacy of Portugal's revolution in 1974.

title: U.N. AIDE HELD IN POLAND IS FASTING
description: Alicja Wesolowska, an employee of the United Nations who was arrested as a spy in 1979 when she stopped off in her Polish homeland for a brief visit, has begun a hunger strike in prison with the aim of forcing the authorities to reconsider her case, relatives said today.

title: AIC PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $392,000 extraordinary tax credit

title: FRIGITRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After $44,996 loss from discontinued operation...C-After $75,659 loss from discontinued operation; Yr-ago figures have been restated to reflect discontinued operations

title: Three Officers Face Disciplinary Charges
description: Three New York City police officers will face disciplinary charges as a result of a departmental investigation into police action at a demonstration last March 10 outside the Harmonie Club, at 4 East 60th Street. The demonstrators included college students and members of the Jewish Defense League.

title: AMERICAN WELDING & MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
KELLY TRIAL TRANSCRIPT SHOWS DOUBT BY JUDGE ON ABSCAM OPERATION
description: The judge presiding over the bribery and conspiracy trial of former Representative Richard Kelly has privately told lawyers in the case that the undercover operation ''has an odor to it that is absolutely repulsive,'' according to a transcript of the judge's comments.

title: FIRE AT UTAH PRISON DUMP BLAMED FOR MAJOR BLACKOUT
description: An explosion and fire in a refuse dump at the Utah State Prison were blamed by utility officials today for causing a blackout yesterday that affected 1.5 million people in three states.

title: Cliff Tufte, 84, Chief Developer Of Road America Auto Racing
description: Cliff Tufte, who helped make Road America one of the most successful road courses in American motor racing, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Elkhart Lake, Wis. Mr. Tufte, who retired as president of the course two years ago, was 84 years old.

title: Haig Plans to Resume 'Beck and Call' Status
description: Senator Gary Hart and Alexander M. Haig Jr., adversaries of long standing, clashed again today at the Senate hearing on the retired general's nomination as Secretary of State.

title: TOMORROW'S CAREER WOMAN AT A CROSSROADS
description: To The Editor: As a first-year law student who looks forward to a legal practice and a family, I share much of the concern expressed by the interviewees in your article. It appears, however, that they expect to enter a world where choice exists as no more than a luxury.

title: Storer Cited In Libel Suit
description: A Boston-based cable television operation is seeking $80 million in a suit charging it was libeled by the Storer Broadcasting Company while competing for a cable franchise in a St. Louis suburb.

title: 60 Squatters at Housing Project Are Evicted by Police in London
description: Policemen carrying riot shields and crowbars stormed a low-income housing project in south London today to evict 60 squatters, the authorities said.

title: AKZONA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including $656,000 increase due to change in accounting metho and $756,000 gain from flood insurance proceeds...C-Including $ million gain resulting from an accounting change and $876,000 g from the purchase of debentures...D-Including $818,000 gain fro purchase of debentures and $400,000 loss related to shutdown an sale of plant

title: Peking Curbs Book Vendors
description: The police here have banned street vendors from selling books on sex and other topics at inflated prices, The Peking Evening News said today. The newspaper said one unemployed youth had bought 100 copies of ''Health and Sex,'' translated from an American publication, for 20 cents each and sold them for 30 cents.

title: TOMORROW'S CAREER WOMAN AT A CROSSROADS
description: To the Editor:

title: TO SAVE LIVES IN A FIRE
description: To the Editor:

title: Thomas A. Horey Is Dead at 45; Xerox Official Was Aiding State
description: Thomas A. Horey, an executive of the Xerox Corporation who was on a one-year loan to Governor Carey's administration to help promote business growth in the state, died of an apparent heart attack today. He was 45 years old.

title: MUSIC: CHOPIN MAZURKA
description: Just about the time a music reviewer concludes that he really has heard everything, someone proves him wrong. This week it was Andrzej Wasowski, who came to Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night to play all 51 of Chopin's Mazurkas in one concert. This may have been the first time any pianist ever did such a thing here, and, if good sense prevails henceforth, it should be the last.

title: Flu Afflicts 13 More States
description: Thirteen more states reported regional outbreaks of influenza this week, Federal health officials reported today. They were Rhode Island, Connecticut, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Illinois, Michigan, Iowa, Alabama, Texas, Colorado, New Mexico and Utah.

title: Bridge: Players in an Enclave Find The Pressure Hard to Take
description: A notable fictional enclave is the London street that proved to be part of Burgundy in the movie ''Passport to Pimlico.'' In real life, the most celebrated is surely Vatican City. In New York City, there is Marble Hill, a section of Manhattan stranded in the Bronx when the Harlem River changed course.

title: H.H. Robertson Switch
description: George T. Brophy has resigned as president and chief operating officer and as a director of the H.H. Robertson Company, a manufacturer of building products. Mr. Brophy, who was expected to succeed Douglas A. Jones as chairman and chief executive officer, resigned to pursue other business opportunities, the Pittsburgh company said yesterday. Mr. Brophy, 45 years old, declined further comment. He joined the company in 1979 as president and chief operating officer after having been executive vice president of the Masonite Corporation.

title: MRS. LLOYD DEFAULTS
description: Chris Evert Lloyd, the No. 1 player on the women's tennis tour, and Hana Mandlikova, the most impressive in recent months, were eliminated from the $250,000 Colgate Series championships tonight, but for different reasons.

title: JAZZ: SHEARING BACK AT CARLYLE
description: George Shearing, who has just started his fourth winter season at the Cafe Carlyle, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, where he will preside at the piano until Bobby Short returns at the end of March, is, in his 31st year as a jazz star, still refining and polishing his piano playing and developing individuality in his secondary talent as a singer. He is, in effect, emphasizing the contrast between the two - the smoothness of his control at the keyboard and the rough hewn quality of his voice.

title: HAIG STAND REFLECTS A FADING OF DETENTE
description: The testimony today by Secretary of Statedesignate Alexander M. Haig Jr. underscored the changes that have occurred in Soviet-American relations in the last year. Mr. Haig was tough and confrontational in his comments about the Russians, and he ran into virtually no opposition to his general themes from the members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: 1978 COAST TAX INITIATIVE NOW SPURS BUDGET CRISIS
description: This spring, more than two years after California's voters approved Proposition 13 and ignited a national tax rebellion, budget officers of the state and local governments must either find ways to cut costs or raise taxes. Frantic state maneuvers to avoid the political damage of cutting back on services delayed the problem, but they have now consumed a state budget surplus that was once almost $4 billion.

title: NEW AIR CONTROLS WILL BEGIN TODAY
description: After 12 years of operation in cramped quarters in an airport hangar - a period marked by increasing numbers of midair nearcollisions - control of air traffic in the New York metropolitan area will be switched today to a $25 million showcase of advanced equipment in Garden City, L.I.

title: WANTED: NEW HOME FOR AN OLD MURAL
description: A decorative mural, affixed to the facade of an Avenue of the Americas parking garage for nearly 25 years, will be removed by wreckers this month, and the mural's chief fan is seeking another wall.

title: Witness Says Garwood Got Rifle as Part of Torture
description: An Air Force psychologist testified today that Pfc. Robert Garwood had admitted carrying a rifle at a Vietnamese prison camp but had said he had it only because his captors would not carry heavy things themselves.

title: ENTRAPMENT ISSUE SPLITS PROSECUTORS IN ABSCAM ACTIONS
description: For the last 18 months there has been a sharp dispute among Federal prosecutors in New York and New Jersey over the undercover methods used in the Abscam investigation, according to an unpublished internal Government memorandum.

title: Index; International

title: BEATING A SPOUSE IS A CRIME
description: Initial jurisdiction over family offenses involving violence should be completely removed from family court in New York State and placed in the jurisdiction of the criminal court system. The family court, a civil court, is inherently incapable of providing an effective remedy to protect victims of violence.

title: Scholastic Body Curbing Below-the-Waist Blocking
description: The national organization representing 15,000 schools has outlawed nearly all blocking below the waist in an effort to reduce knee injuries in high school football.

title: TOMORROW'S CAREER WOMAN AT A CROSSROADS
description: To the Editor:

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15. 1. The police appear to believe that he is the so-called Yorkshire Ripper. His arrest for murder may have ended one of the biggest manhunts in British history.

title: MOBILE HOME INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After losses of $300,000 in the latest first qr and $80,000 i previous first qr on real estate sales

title: 2 Hurt in Basque Rebel Attacks
description: A policeman was wounded here today when his car was machine-gunned by Basque terrorists, the police said, and a truck driver was hurt in Navarre when a terrorist hand grenade accidentally hit his vehicle. The attacks coincided with the signing in Madrid of an accord giving more fiscal and economic powers to the local government in the Basque region.

title: FRANCE STRENGTHENS AFRICA FORCE IN REACTION TO CHAD INTERVENTION
description: President Valery Giscard d'Estaing has ordered the reinforcement of French military detachments in Africa, officials said today, to emphasize France's determination to support its African partners against further expansion by Libya. The Libyans recently moved into Chad.

title: f9226; Dreams of Libyan Empire
description: Libya's Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi is usually called mercurial, impulsive, volatile - and so he may be. But he is more than an enfant terrible. He has visions of empire for his Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya. When he speaks of the Arab world, there is no doubt who he thinks is its ordained leader. And there are intimations of a bolder dream: an Islamic empire spanning the Sahara, with Tripoli its Rome.

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $6,172 loss from discontinued operation... C-Net loss after $256,710 loss from discontinued operation; Yr-ago figures reflect the discontinuance of the company's EOM business division; shr earnings are adjusted to reflect a 100 percent stock distribution paid Nov 7, 1980

title: Edith A. Aynes, a Nurse; Operated Home for Aged
description: Edith A. Aynes, a specialist in the placement and supervision of professional and practical nurses, died Dec. 31 at Union Hospital in the Bronx. She was 71 years old and lived at the Andrew Freedman Home in the Bronx, a residence for the elderly, where she had been the administrator for the past 16 years.

title: Wilson Oil Rig Acquired by LTV
description: Dallas, Jan. 9 (Reuters) - The LTV Corporation said it had acquired Wilson Oil Rig Manufacturing, a subsidiary of the Dana Corporation, for $30 million in cash.

title: Vesco Says Fair Trial Guarantee Might Get Him to Return to U.S.
description: Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, said yesterday that it was unlikely he could get a fair trial in the United States but that he might return if a fair trial and his safety could be guaranteed.

title: WINE BY THE GLASS: OFTEN AN UNKNOWEN QUANITY
description: The waiter at the Post House was polite and eager to be helpful. What were the wines by the glass? He didn't know precisely, but the reds were a French table wine and a California cabernet, and the whites were a French table wine and a California chardonnay. Whose chardonnay and whose cabernet were they, and could the waiter please find out exactly what the French wines were?

title: BANI-SADAR PLEDGES IRAN WILLFIGHT ON
description: President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr of Iran, in a speech contrasting with earlier confident statements about victory in the war against Iraq, vowed today that Iranian forces would fight on despite the ''high price of holding out.''

title: REP. LEDERER FOUND GUILTY OF BRIBERY IN ABSCAM CASE
description: Representative Raymond F. Lederer of Pennsylvania was found guilty last night of bribery and conspiracy charges stemming from the Government's Abscam investigation into political corruption.

title: PRODUCER PRICES INCREASED 0.6% IN DECEMBER AND 11.7% FOR YEAR
description: Producer prices continued to rise along a broad front in December, with declines in food prices more than offset by brisk advances in energy, capital equipment and other goods, the Labor Department reported today.

title: ONLOOKERS TELL OF THE HORROR AND RECALL HAPPY TIMES
description: The roaring wall of flame engulfing the facade of the Beachview Rest Home awakened John W. Jones in his bedroom across the street on Laurel Avenue.

title: NEW LYRIC OPERA HEAD
description: The Lyric Opera of Chicago named Ardis Krainik general manager today and initiated sweeping accounting procedures in the wake of budget overruns that resulted in reducing performances this season.

title: The Feds Pursue the Child Snatchers
description: Thanks to some fancy footwork in the closing hours of the 96th Congress, there finally exists a law to punish child snatchers. The measure passed without debate, in the form of a floor amendment, and was signed by President Carter, almost unnoticed, during Christmas week.

title: ANTHEM ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A BROOKLYN TREASURE BECKONS TO MANHATTAN
description: ''The Brooklyn Bridge is the longest in the world,'' says Michael Botwinick, allowing himself a statistical lapse. Mr. Botwinick, the director of the Brooklyn Museum, is talking about something often viewed in Manhattan as an aversion to the hinterlands and just as often viewed in Brooklyn as a form of provincialism. The subject, of course, is the reluctance of many Manhattan dwellers to cross the East River to visit their sprawling neighbor across the water.

title: St. Louis Schools Support Integration With 3 Counties
description: The St. Louis Board of Education today asked a Federal judge to include all school districts in three surrounding Missouri counties in the city's desegregation case.

title: POLE URGES 'REASON ON 5-DAY WORKWEEK
description: On the eve of another test of wills with Poland's independent labor union, a leader of the Communist Party appeared unexpectedly on television tonight to urge a ''reasonable solution'' to outstanding disputes.

title: RED CROSS LIST OF THOSE DEAD, HURT OR MISSING
description: Following is a list of those dead or missing and a partial list of the injured in the fire here today, as released by the American Red Cross chapter in Shrewsbury, N.J.: Dead or Missing BASHE, Edward BUTLER, Atella CAVIANO, Ruth DELADEEGEN, Romano DREXEL, George EVERETT, Edward GORMLEY, Charles GRILLAD, Richard GUNTHER, Elsie KELLOG, Virginia KING, Stanley KLINE, Dorothy KNAPP, John KRITSIMALES, Jessie LEAS, Jessie LOPEZ, Juan MANOES, Lena McHARG, Ophelia OLBSIS, Dellia PATCINOSTER, Lucy PEPECK, Steve PERZLEY, N. PINKEROUS, L. SCOTT, J. SCOTT, Jean SHATUEL, George SIMONSON, William SMITH, Gerty SMITH, William TANNENBAUM, Danny VANSISE, Ruth WILK, Mary WILLS, Mildred Injured

title: MARIJUANA BALES DROPPED FROM PLANE IN FLORIDA
description: f814FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 9 (AP) - Robert Banta was in bed early yesterday morning when something hit his mobile home with a great jolt. When he went to look, he found the remains of a 100-pound bale of marijuana in his living room and a gaping hole in his roof.

title: AT TODAY'S REUNION YESTERDAY'S MOONLIGHT
description: She came up to me after dinner and introduced herself and I never told her how much I was hoping she would be there or that I had looked around more than once to see if she was. We talked for a minute or two and then we edged around to the table to look at the old photographs where we all stood frozen in time with long dresses and baggy pants and crew cuts and the bright and eager eyes of the youngsters we used to be.

title: BONN SAID TO STUDY SAUDI REQUEST FOR MAJOR SALE OF WEAPONS SYSTEMS
description: West Germany is reported to be considering a major weapons sale to Saudi Arabia that could basically alter Bonn's traditional position of avoiding the arms business in areas of tension.

title: STATE APPROVES CITY PLEA TO REVISE PROPERTY TAX
description: A state agency agreed yesterday to a New York City request that could allow the city to raise an extra $400 million in real-estate taxes. The city says it needs the revenue to maintain a balanced budget next year.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Canadian National Railway filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission $150 million of debentures due 2006, to be offered through a Salomon Brothers, McLeod Young Weir Inc. and Greenshields & Company group.

title: Bobsled Mark Set
description: East Germany's No. 1 sled, steered by Bernhard Germeshausen, broke the track record on the Igls Olympic course today in final practice for the European four-man boblsled championship. The sled was timed in 53.76 seconds on the first run. The two-day competition starts tomorrow with 20 sleds from eight countries.

title: OHIO-SEALY MATTRESS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $6,512,000 extraordinary net income from a judgement awarded from a lawsuit

title: No Headline
description: Maple Leafs Discharge Crozier

title: Not To Worry, Jimmy
description: A group of learned men quoted in the paper the other day gave it as their opinion that Jimmy Carter would not go down in the history books as much of a President. Possibly so. A George Washington doesn't come along very often and even if one did, under our present system for choosing Presidents he would probably be wiped out in the polls for showing badly fitted false teeth in his television smile.

title: NO SPRINKLERS REQUIIRED AT JERSEY REST HOME
description: The Beachview Rest Home, where at least 20 persons died in an early morning fire today, was granted a waiver by the State Health Department in September of a requirement that sprinklers be installed in the two-story frame building.

title: FIRE IN QUEENS BUILDING TIED TO SMOKING IN BED
description: A fire started by a woman who was smoking in bed swept through a six-story apartment building in Elmhurst, Queens, at 2:30 A.M. yesterday, driving 168 persons into the cold in their night clothes.

title: WHY ABRAHAM KAUVAR MUST RESIGN
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Herald Tribune Removes Editor

title: FORDHAM SETS BACK TEMPLE BY 62-59, IMPROVING RECORD TO 8-3
description: Fordham defeated Temple, 62-59, at the Rams' gym last night, prompting Coach Tom Penders to admit that even he was surprised to have a season record of 8-3 at this point.

title: CRIMES' COST GREW TO $890 MILLION IN '79 STATE SAYS
description: The cost of crime climbed to $890,371,260 in property and currency stolen throughout New York State in 1979, while law-enforcement agencies cost more than $1.4 billion to operate.

title: THEATER REOPENS WITH ROCK MUSICAL
description: BRIDGEPORT THE Downtown Cabaret Theater, dark for several months, has reopened. Patrons are again invited to bring their own edibles and potables, but the policy of cabaret entertainment, or something approximating it, seems to be gone. So is Claude McNeal, who created and directed all the shows. The credit now reads: ''Downtown Cabaret Theater in association with Leo B. Meyer.'' Mr. Meyer, for the record, did the sets for the last Claude McNeal show and for the current offering.

title: WHATEVER HAPPENED TO TV'S 'SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE'?
description: ''There are certain kinds of controversy we create by being unlike anything else on the air. The danger is, you start to think you're everything the reviews say you are.''

title: A Proposal for Writers Inspired By Scott Meredith
description: To the Editor:

title: Boat Show Has Crowded Field
description: The task of seeing everything at the 71st National Boat Show is herculean. When the nine-day show opens next Saturday at the Coliseum, more than 500 boats and thousands of accessories will cover four floors.

title: Elizabeth White Fiancee of David Herter
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Virden White to David Bigelow Herter has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert King White of New Canaan, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Miles Herter of Manchester, Mass., and a grandson of the late Christian A. Herter, Secretary of State in the Eisenhower Administration and a former Governor of Massachusetts.

title: REGIONS: NEW YORK STATE
description: ALBANY DOUBTS over the lingering national recession and over the effect that the policies of the incoming Reagan administration will have on New York and its finances have tempered hopes that the state would pull well ahead of the nation in the economic recovery.

title: Red Wings 4, Flames 1
description: John Ogrodnick scored two third-period goals and assisted on another in the second period to lead the Red Wings to a 4-1 victory over Calgary at Detroit last night.

title: Penn 70, Brown 57
description: Ken Hall scored 18 points as Penn rolled to a 70-57 victory over Brown tonight in the Ivy League.

title: Northwestern 50, Wisconsin 48
description: Jim Stack's 10-foot shot from the side with six seconds to play lifted Northwestern to a 50-48 victory over Wisconsin tonight in a Big Ten game.

title: THE DANCE: MARTA RENZI
description: And what do you do, dear? That question comes to mind on occasion when, immured in some impromptu theaterette, one is treated to an evening of loping, elaborately casual found-dance. Marta Renzi has the lope down pat. Her dance phrases don't come from any school. And the atmosphere is pretty friendly. Still, she's got a large and intelligent following. One reason may be that she choreographs dances like the chic, funny and altogether likable new ''What Do You Do, Dear?'' seen Friday at the Kitchen.

title: STATE FACES BUDGET CUTS TO OFFSET SHORTAGES CAUSED BY TAX REVOLTS
description: The citizens' tax revolt of the late 1970's is now, for the first time, causing substantial reductions in state and local services around the nation.

title: A Will and a Way
description: Scrawled on a doctor's memo pad six months before his death, F.O. Masten's will gave his entire $50 million oil and gas estate to Abilene Christian University and asked its president, Dr. John Stephens, to ''take over as soon as possible.''

title: OF ARMS AND MEN
description: In September 1969, I spent evenings for the better part of three weeks deliberately inhaling canvas dust from the sewing tables at a tent factory in Upstate New York. I was merely another college graduate evading the draft. Classified 1-A, and with the Vietnam War still raging, I was attempting to revive a childhood history of bronchial asthma that, I hoped, would keep me safely at home, morally and physically untainted.

title: SENATE COMPROMISE HINTS PROMPT VOTE ON HAIG'S APPROVAL
description: In a compromise that all but assured the prompt confirmation of Alexander M. Haig Jr. as Secretary of State, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee agreed today to subpoena logs summarizing 100 hours of tapes of 1973 conversations between Mr. Haig and President Nixon.

title: CAN SYNTHETIC FUELS FILL U.S. OIL GAP?
description: In November 1978, with the Iranian revolution about to send the world into oil shock for the second time in five years, President Carter signed the most comprehensive energy legislation ever enacted by the United States.

title: No Headline
description: The article ''Creating Computers That Think'' identified the computerized medical diagnostic program of Drs. Jack D. Myers and Harry E. Pople at the University of Pittsburgh as being called Internist instead of Caduceus, its correct name.

title: New Jersey Guide
description: NEW JERSEY GUIDE TRIBUTE TO DR. KING

title: PASSAGES; The Fun of Flying
description: We never cease to admire the airline pilots who steer their huge craft through the worst of fogs to a safe landing in the proper place. But what has happened to the pilots up in the business office? They seem to be working overtime at producing fog.

title: Miami Police Cheer Florida's 'Cavalry'
description: With last spring's riots in Liberty City followed by a crime wave this fall, all is not happy in Dade County's Chamber of Commerce, or in the Miami Police Department. Last week, they got some help, in the form of 100 Florida Highway Patrol troopers in 100 state highway cars.

title: A Proposal to Replace Runoffs in a Primary
description: Senator Bill Bradley's proposal to hold a runoff election if no candidate receives at least 40 percent of the vote in New Jersey's gubernatorial primary next June offers only a partial solution to finding the strongest candidate in a crowded field.

title: Rape Suspect May Be Moved
description: A judge said today that Tommy Lee Hines, a black accused of raping three white women, could be transferred to a state mental facility other than the one he is in.

title: COMPUTERS AND THE HUMAN BRAIN
description: 'Thinking' Computers: Not Quite Brains

title: MAINE WARRANTY LAW TESTED IN SUIT AGAINST FORD
description: In the first major test of Maine's implied warranty laws, the State Attorney General's office is attempting to force the Ford Motor Company to honor the statutes.

title: PRECEDENTS FOR HAIG: FIVE GENERALS IN POLITICAL ROLES
description: The selection of Alexander M. Haig Jr. to be Secretary of State has revived interest in the roles played by prominent soldiers in positions of political power in the postwar years.

title: HOW THE BAATH RULES IRAQ: WITH A VERY TIGHT FIST
description: Control, said an Arab ambassador in Baghdad, is the cardinal rule of the Baath Party. Everything it does is designed so it will always rule Iraq and, eventually, the Arab world.

title: DISMAL REDISTRICTING
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: known modern academic champion of laissez-faire. This ''personal statement,'' written with his wife, Rose Friedman, is notable - in the words of our reviewer Sidney Weintraub - for ''its clarity, logic, candor and unequivocal stand on political implications. It is sweeping and surgical in cutting up economic absurdities perpetrated by government agencies since the New Deal. But to close out this century, I would be wary of all its proposed constitutional amendments.''

title: HIGH RATES SNARL TRADING IN GRAIN
description: Unusually high interest rates, last year's crop shortfalls and internationall political tensions have combined to make the business of world grain trading particularly difficult.

title: LAW FIRMS BECOMING NATIONAL IN SCOPE
description: WASHINGTON MANY large law firms are rapidly becoming national in scope, and in some cases international, as they set up branch office networks to accommodate their large corporate clients.

title: LOW INCOME HOUSING SOUNDS 'OUT OF TUNE'
description: ''There are three reasons and it's hard to distinguish between them,'' said Henry Kinne, the former chairman of Glastonbury's town council. ''The no-growth syndrome is very prominent in this area; the last people who come in want to look at the cornfields. Then there are some economic feelings about poor people, and some racial feelings. ''

title: EXPLORING THE MYSTERIES OF TIBETAN MEDICINE
description: John F. Avedon is currently writing a book on Tibet to be published by Alfred A. Knopf. By John F. Avedon r. Yeshi Donden pressed the three middle fingers of his right hand gently along the inside of William Schneider's left wrist, bowed his head and appeared to listen to the pulse. The 52-year-old patient smiled, visibly perplexed. The physician before him wore neither white coat nor name tag. He asked no questions and carried no charts or instruments. Dressed in the maroon robes of a Tibetan monk, head shaved, a turquoise-studded charm box bulging beneath his orange shirt, he seemed to have materialized out of another time and place. For almost a minute, Dr. Donden remained motionless, deep in concentration, fingers arrayed on Mr. Schneider's left arm. He then examined the patient's other arm, quickly palpating the radial artery as if to confirm his findings. After ushering Mr. Schneider into an adjacent room, Dr. Donden gestured for him to undress, whereupon he pressed selected points along the patient's spine. With each touch, Mr. Schneider cried out in pain. Dr. Donden nodded sympathetically and had him get dressed.

title: WHY IT'S COLDER ON THE ISLAND
description: THE chill wind that greets commuters stepping off the 5:07 when the train arrives in Huntington is colder than the one they left behind in Manhattan, a fact that has dismayed many, especially as the temperatures in the metropolitan area have grown consistently cooler since mid-December.

title: ACCOUNTANTS TAKING THE MEASURE OF INFLATION
description: The 1980 anual reports that most stockholders will receive this spring will, for the first time, display the full measure of the struggle to present financial data that take into account the distorting effect of inflation.

title: THE DEEPEST PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: Beth Kathryn Slater Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Fred Slater of Needham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beth Kathryn Slater, to Michael Scott Bandes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Selwyn Bandes of Rockville Centre, L.I. The couple are graduates of the University of Rochester.

title: CAVALCADE 1980: THE PEAKS AND PITS
description: GETTING TOGETHER The urge to merge seemed to lessen somewhat, but there were enough unfriendly takeover attempts and white knights afoot to keep the corporate scene lively. Wheelabrator-Frye galloped to the rescue of Pullman, which fought off McDermott's advances. Justin Dart agreed to merge Dart Industries with Kraft Inc., but insisted on first things first, creating Dart & Kraft Inc.

title: Thurmond to Ask Review On School Segregation Suit
description: Strom Thurmond, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said today he would ask the next administration to reconsider whether to press a school desegregation suit against Charleston, S.C.

title: THE TIES THAT BIND ARE UNWINDING
description: THE American family is under siege, and many fear for its survival. Financial pressures, the pace of life and the pursuit of pleasure tend to drive people apart. The price we pay for ''doing our own thing'' comes high. Family ties that bind us together are unwinding with the resurgence of narcissism. A ''Lone Ranger'' complex characterizes relationships in many households, making members virtual strangers.

title: 'ALTERNATE' MORTGAGES DEVISED BY LENDERS
description: MORTGAGE lenders, having written the obituary for the conventional home loan, are busily looking over a broad range of ''alternative mortgages'' trying to determine which ones will become the industry standards of the future.

title: WALL STREET: STOCKS, BONDS AND, NOW, STONES
description: If you can't beat them, try to join them. This seems to be the attitude of many Wall Street institutions eyeing the growth of the markets in collectibles.

title: Alice Golembiewski And Greer Phillips Engaged to Marry
description: Alice Hughes Golembiewski, a summa cum laude alumna of Princeton University, class of '80, and Greer Laurence Phillips, who received his degree magna cum laude from Princeton in '79, plan to be married. Both are members of Phi Beta Kappa.

title: Sarah Steel Is Married To Jonathan L. Levine
description: Sarah MacLean Steel, an account representative with Comshare Inc., a computer services concern, was married yesterday to Jonathan Lorenz Levine, a government-bond trader with Goldman Sachs & Company. Judge Shirley Wohl Kram of Family Court performed the cermony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Brevard Steel Jr. of New York.

title: BACK TO SCHOOL, AFTER A MISPLACED DECADE
description: IWAS 19 years old when I decided that one year of college had already been one year too many. I had a career to pursue; far more important that I give it my full attention, rather than waste time buried in textbooks. Adult logic fell on deaf ears. Life would give me all the education I needed.

title: Jane Sandhaus Fiancee of Jeffrey E. Packer
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert S. Sandhaus of Hewlett Bay Park, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Holly Sandhaus, to Jeffrey Elliot Packer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Packer of Huntington, L.I. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Iowa 65, Michigan State 57
description: Bobby Hansen and Kevin Boyle combined for 22 points in the second half to lead Iowa to a 65-57 victory over Michigan State today.

title: PASSAGES; Gum Enders
description: To certain schoolteachers, movie janitors and others with pronounced views about the chewing of gum, the news from the Dow Chemical Company may sound like one step forward and one step back. But in health terms, it suggests genuine progress.

title: Red Brigades Issue A New Ultimatum
description: The Italian Government last week rejected the latest asking price set by Red Brigade guerrillas for the freedom of Giovanni d'Urso, the magistrate they kidnapped last month. The guerrillas replied that they would kill the magistrate tomorrow unless Italian newspapers published ''political documents'' from their colleagues in two maximum security prisons.

title: BUFFALO BRACES FOR A NZAI RALLY AND A COUNTERACTION
description: Controversy is increasing over a neo-Nazi demonstration and a counter-rally that are scheduled for Thursday in Buffalo despite a ban on the rallies imposed by the city's Mayor. A third, city-coordinated gathering that day will mark the 52d birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: ECONOMISTS: INFLUENTIAL BUT ERRATIC
description: the dismal science - might appear to be a reference to the track record of its practioners. For in recent years, economic pundits seem to have been wrong as often as they have been right.

title: 'IMPROVEMENts' DEBATED ON BROOKLYN'S FULTON STREET
description: ''Improvements? I'm dying from improvements,'' said Arthur Roberts, manager of Filmac Jewelers on Fulton Street in downtown Brooklyn, grabbing his throat and extending his tongue.

title: Paul Reiss Fiance Of Joanne Melloni
description: Joanne Melloni and Paul Julian Reiss plan to be married in July. Both are graduates of Fordham College, where the Mr. Reiss received his degree summa cum laude and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa.

title: 'Pay' for Pupils
description: With 9 percent of its 900 pupils playing hooky every day, Memorial Junior High School in San Diego began a ''cash for class'' program last September. Every pupil who showed up for school got a chit worth 25 cents, which could be spent for school supplies or teachersupervised field trips.

title: ROAD REPAIRS...HISTORICAL NOTE
description: IF Connecticut continues to resurface just 96 miles of roads a year - the average over the last six years - it will take until 2034 to repave the state highway system, Representative Christopher Shays, Republican of Stamford, noted last week.

title: CONCERTS: 3 EVENINGS IN THE 'COMPOSERS' SHOWCASE' AT THE WHITNEY MUSEUM
description: ''My Name Is'' was the name of the world premiere of a new work by Steve Reich, performed with his repertory players in the first of the three concerts of this year's Composers' Showcase at the Whitney Museum of American Art Tuesday night; it is a ''work in progress'' related to a similar piece dating from 1967.

title: CHRYSLER RESCUE PANEL SEEKS COOPERATION PROMISES
description: The Chrysler Loan Guarantee Board is seeking new promises of cooperation from the United Automobile Workers, the Chrysler Corporation's suppliers and banks in considering a request by the automobile maker for $400 million in additional loan guarantees.

title: BARRIERS TO INTERSTATE BANKING ERODE
description: Federal barriers to interstate banking have eroding for years, as bankers have used technicalities and technology to circumvent laws prohibiting establishment of branches across state lines. Many bankers expect the trend toward nationwide banking to accelerate in 1981 as competitive pressures begin to overcome political barriers.

title: Recruiting Deceit Is Not Widespread
description: To the Sports Editor: The National Association of Basketball Coaches takes exception to the implication by Dr. Victor Tchertkoff (Mailbox, Dec. 14) that all universities and athletic programs are deceitful and dishonest.

title: Transition Into Reality Encounters Some Complexities
description: With 9 days to go before their party takes out a four-year lease on the White House, Republicans last week were beginning to bump some unpleasant realities of governing. ''It's a little more complex than they thought,'' said a Reagan associate.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: COMIC FAITH The Great Tradition From Austen to Joyce. By Robert M. Polhemus. 398 pp. Chicago: University of Chicago Press. $25.

title:
ANTIQUES;
PIONEER DAYS OF AMERICAN COLLECTING
description: HARTFORD IN the 19th century, those who first began to collect old American furniture, china and silver did so not only out of veneration for the past but also because they believed that much of what was massproduced was shoddy and poorly designed.

title: DEFENSE ECONOMICS
description: The military budget is subject to many of the same economic pressures that drive up the cost of running anything else, from a business to a home. At the top of the list, of course, is inflation.

title: COULD WE HAVE AVOIDED VIETNAM
description: WHYVIETNAM? Prelude to America's Albatross. By Archimedes L.A. Patti. 612 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $19.50. By GADDIS SMITH

title: THE FREE WORLD AWAITS INSPIRED LEADERSHIP
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets' Flynn Hitting Musical Notes Now
description: Doug Flynn moves to a new position in New York this week. Instead of scooping up ground balls at second base for the New York Mets, the Gold Glove infielder will be picking and singing country-music songs at Cody's, a club at Sixth Avenue and 16th Street in Manhattan on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday nights.

title: TAX CUTS DUE, BUT WILL KEMP-ROTH BE THE PLAN?
description: WASHINGTON SOME form of tax cut seems almost assured this year, leaving the issue of whether a new President and a more conservative Congress want to experiment with multiyear tax relief in a single bill as the major question.

title: MARINA OPPONENTS PREVAIL IN WESTPORT
description: WESTPORT IT takes a hot issue to bring out more than a third of the voters on a cold day in January, and that's what happened here in last Tuesday's referendum, when 4,590 people rejected a proposal for a $2.3 million dollar marina, winning handily over the 1,815 who wanted it. In Westport's population of 25,317 there are 17,046 registered voters.

title: PROSECUTORS REJECTED OFFER OF PLEA TO F.B.I BREAK-INS
description: Prosecutors in 1979 rejected a proposal under which two former officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation could have pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor carrying almost as much punishment as the men ultimately received after being convicted of a felony.

title: 'CHICAGO' BOUNCES WHEN IT SHOULD BITE
description: "CHICAGO," the show about a cellful of "merry murderesses," is one of those "concepts" musicals that depend on superslick show business style to conceal negligible content and minimal musical values. The Broadhollow Theater has neither the resources to dress it up and do it right nor the resourcefulness to camouflage that. Its "Chicago" is a bad idea gone wrong. For some mysterious reason, this is one of the most requested musicals around the Island, according to those audience questionnaires that theater managers persist in handing out. It is all tinsel and not all that titillating; some local producers have even admitted disliking the show but putting it on anyway, just to cater to the customers. In the original director-choreographer Bob Fosse's quirky, jerky dissonances in dance, the decadence and sleaze of a specific era - the late 1920's - were blended with the show's general themes of instant stardom, phony fame, media manipulation and rampant feelinglessness. The dance numbers and the whole musical's movement were inseparable. What it added up to was derivative and ineffectual, but it had gloss, sass and energy, and it was showy. In the Broadhollow production, which is directed by Pat Meares and choreographed by E. Felix, an arrangement that proves neither complementary nor cohesive, the gangster girls bump (sometimes into each other) and grind (in the sense of doing a job mechanically) in some vague semblance of Mr. Fosse's stylized vision of Chicago gun molls. They also sashay and sway as though they were displaced ingenues from "Oklahoma!" The whole production is bouncy and cheerful when it should be tough, and it smiles sweetly at you when it is supposed to bite bitterly, or at least snarl a little.

title: U.S. Says Vehicle Recall Showed Decline in 1980
description: Almost five million vehicles and seven million tires were recalled in 1980 for safety-related defects, the Transportation Department reported yesterday, but the total was considerably lower than that for the two previous years.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: AFTER the Christmas rush, Northport Village curls up to wait for the return of the sailboats and the sun. Year-round customers find hand-lettered surprises on the doors: Closed Until April, On Vacation. The storekeepers who stay open hold desultory sales, visit one another a lot and welcome customers for their conversation as much as their cash.

title: 50 YEARS AGO-MUSICAL STEREO'S FIRST DISK
description: O ne imagines persons who took part in historic events long ago to look like relics or at least suitably venerable. So the tall gentleman who recently welcomed me to his office in a courtly, agreeably old-fashioned manner didn't meet my expectations at all. Spry and agile in his 70's, Arthur C. Keller seems amused at being regarded a historical figure. Yet it was he who made the first musical stereo recording 50 years ago.

title: ELECTION CHALLENGES IN PUERTO RICO PRODUCE POLITICAL STATEMENT OVER CONTROL IN LEGISLATURE
description: More than two months after the closest general election in the history of Puerto Rico, the Commonwealth has a new Governor but still no House of Representatives, and the political campaign continues unabated.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JANUARY 11, 1981
description: International Iran was told by the United States in its last set of proposals for freeing the hostages that within several days following their release it could probably recover more than 70 percent of its multibillions of dollars frozen in American banks. Iran was also given an American estimated value of those assets. The total, officials said, is about $9.5 billion, a figure considerably less than Iran's claim of $14 billion and the $11 billion estimated by some nonofficial American experts. (Page 1, Column 1.) An answer from Iran to the latest American proposals for freeing the hostages - ''most likely'' acceptance - will be issued by Friday, the deadline set by the Carter Administration, Ahmad Azizi, Iran's Director of Hostage Affairs, said. (1:2.)

title: EARL WILLIAMS TRIES TO OVERCOME HIS STATUS AS BASEBALL'S OUTCAST
description: Earl Williams, the rookie of the year in the National League in 1971, rode the buses in Mexican baseball the last two summers and then rejoined the army of unemployed north of the border. Now he is back home, and he wants an answer along with a job.

title:
LONG ISLAND HOUSING;
FUEL COST: IT CAN BE REDUCED
description: HOME heating oil is now selling for an average of about $1.14 a gallon, with more increases on the way, and industry spokesmen are reluctant to predict how high prices will go.

title: SONGS OF A RACIAL SELF
description: THE COLLECTED POEMS OF STERLINGA BROWN Selected by Michael S. Harper. 257 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: Identifying the Problem Is Easy
description: A Federal commission on immigration policy, like the Democratic President that appointed it, is finishing up appointed rounds. Among them is deciding whether to recommend that Americans adopt a timehonored European custom, and carry cartes d'identite.

title: MISS JAEGER JOINS MISS AUSTIN IN NET FINAL
description: Andrea Jaeger, 15 years old, stunned Martina Navratilova in three sets tonight and joined Tracy Austin in the final of the $250,000 Colgate Series championship.

title: Finish Line Nears On Talks, but Will Hostages Win Out?
description: Never in the 14-month hostage crisis did the end seem so near. But, even as the pace quickened, success remained out of reach. Officials carrying last-minute offers shuttled last week between Washington and Algiers and Teheran, racing the Carter Administration's deadline this Friday for arranging the release of the 52 Americans.

title:
Art;
SPECTACULAR 'PORTRAIT OF ICELAND' ON VIEW AT NEWARK MUSEUM
description: BJORN RURRICKSSON, whose color photographs are on view at the Newark Museum in a show called ''A Portrait of Iceland,'' has a special talent: He is an expert on the island's geology.

title: DOWNTOWN CABARET REOPENS TO MUSICAL
description: THE Downtown Cabaret Theater, dark for several months, has reopened its doors. Patrons are again invited to bring their own edibles and potables, but the policy of cabaret entertainment or something approximating it seems to be gone. For that matter, so is Claude McNeal, who created and directed all the shows.

title: 3 SLAIN IN BRONX IN ALLEGED DISPUTE OVER SALE OF DRUGS
description: Four men were shot, three of them fatally, early yesterday in what the police said was a territorial battle in the Bronx over marijuana distribution.

title: RICHARD BOONE OF 'HAVE GUN,WILL TRAVEL' DIES AT 63
description: Richard Boone, an actor who made his name as Paladin in the television series ''Have Gun, Will Travel,'' died of throat cancer today at his home. He was 63 years old.

title: Increase in Navy Re-enlistments Attributed to Raises in October
description: Navy re-enlistments have risen sharply as a result of pay increase that took effect in October, and the trend could alleviate personnel shortages in four years, according to the commander of the Atlantic Fleet.

title: 50 YEARS AGO-MUSICAL STEREO'S FIRST DISK
description: One imagines persons who took part in historic events long ago to look like relics or at least suitably venerable. So the tall gentleman who recently welcomed me to his office in a courtly, agreeably old-fashioned manner didn't meet my expectations at all. Spry and agile in his 70's, Arthur C. Keller seems amused at being regarded a historical figure. Yet it was he who made the first musical stereo recording 50 years ago.

title: ROBERT FROST'S TRUE VIEW OF GOOD FENCES
description: To the Editor:

title: Gulotta Wins Approval Of Hempstead's Board
description: The Hempstead Town Board unanimously approved the appointment yesterday of Thomas S. Gulotta, a Republican, as Presiding Supervisor, filling the unexpired term of Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: BUREAUCRACY BLAMED IN DETENTION OF HAITIAN CHILDREN
description: Forty-four Haitian children are being held in a refugee camp in a remote area of southwest Dade County while the authorities argue over how to reunite them with relatives.

title: Children's Books
description: ANARTIST Written and Illustrated by M.B. Goffstein. Unpaged. New York: Harper & Row. $7.95. (All Ages) LAUGHINGLATKES Written and Illustrated by M.B. Goffstein. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $6.95. (All Ages) By KARLA KUSKIN

title: De Paul Is Beaten By 63-62
description: Billy Mann stole an inbounds pass and scored a layup with seven seconds left tonight to give Old Dominion a 63-62 victory over De Paul, the nation's top-ranked major-college team.

title: Chemical Concern Cited in Blast
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration has cited Amoco Chemical Corporation in New Castle, Del., for an Oct. 21 explosion and fire at its plant that killed six employees and injured 27 others. David H. Rhone, the OSHA regional administrator, said Thursday that a two-month investigation uncovered one willful violation, with a possible penalty of $10,000, and two serious violations, with possible penalties of $1,800.

title: By NANCY ARUM
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS CUSTOMERS entering Lick Your Chops for the first time usually have a smile on their faces. Maybe it is the name of the store that makes people want to laugh, or the five-foot-long rawhide bone hanging in the front window.

title: HELEN J. A. RAND
description: Helen Joanna Arnold Rand, who was honored by two Popes for her work for the Archdiocese of New York, died Wednesday in Woodstock, Vt.

title: SERVICE-BASED ECONOMY RESISTS SLUMP
description: IN the national recession that may or may not be over, New York City has found itself in the position of the Catskills resort comic who is asked how he's doing. "Compared to what?" he replies. Compared to most people's idea of good times, New York is hardly doing very well. However, when city officials and private economists look back on all the might-have-beens that were raised only a year ago, they cannot help but conclude that things could have been a lot worse. After two years of growth, New York had a net loss of jobs in 1980, but not that many - about 4,000, a tiny fraction of its total of 3.3 million. That was a far cry from early predictions of a loss of 60,000 or more. And although actual enemployment ran about 9 percent in New York City compared with about 7 percent nationwide, the rate increased more slowly in the city than it did nationally. That phenomenon seems partly the result of an ongoing trend in New York in which expanding service industries have filled the job vacuum left by the contraction of the city's aging manufacturing sector. Increasingly, it is not the lather andthe printer who heads for work each day, but the accountant and the computer specialist. New Yorkers have thus fared comparatively well, leading some students of the job market to mull the possibility of a city that has become "recession-proof." "We've been able to function better than other cities," Kenneth S. Schuman, New York's Commissioner for Economic Development, said.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: PEEKSKILL WILLIAM MURRAY is tracking down his ancestors. From a tiny cemetery in nearby Verplank to the town of Slane in County Meath, Ireland, he has sought - and sometimes found - the whereabouts of those who are living and the birthplaces of those who have died. He is conducting the search, he said, because he wants to ''know about my people, to learn their culture.''

title: Film View; ON GOOD ACTORS IN BAD MOVIES
description: If one can say of a bad actor, ''He couldn't act his way out of a paper bag,'' one must believe that good actors can. Don't believe it. If 1980 did nothing else, it gave us dozens of demonstrations by good and great actors attempting to force their way through tissue-thin material but eventually giving up, trapped and rendered foolish by the witlessness of others.

title:
THE REGION;
Similar Targets, Separate Killers
description: Detectives from New York City and Buffalo compared notes last week and concluded that the recent multiple murders of black men in their cities were not the work of same person. Beyond that, however, they had little to go on except imprecise descriptions of at least two white men who attack without warning and for no discernible reason except the race of their victims.

title: COACH ESPOSITO'S DEBUT SMOOTH
description: Anders Hedberg swept across the blue line, swung wide around the simulated defenseman, Phil Esposito, and scored an easy practice goal against Wayne Thomas. Seconds later, Ulf Nilsson did virtually the same thing. Finally, Esposito, wearing his new coach's black windbreaker, and no protective padding, managed to poke check the puck away from one of the Rangers' smoothest stick handlers, Ron Greschner.

title: THE STRUGGLE OF WOMEN DIRECTORS
description: The past couple of days had been tough ones for the young film director. The filming the day before had involved difficult set-ups in the middle of Lake Ontario in a pitching boat. The weather was foul, the schedule tight and a few of the actors were seasick. The next morning, there was a fire on a set in an old Tudor mansion in Toronto that wiped out four hours of shooting.

title: Dutch Arrest 14 in Drug Case
description: Narcotics officers arrested 14 members of an international drug-running syndicate in an overnight raid and seized 2,640 pounds of hashish, the police said today.

title: Spontaneous Travel
description: To the Editor: Joan Cook's article on spontaneous travel, ''A Careful Planner Turns Footloose'' (Travel Section, Dec. 14), brought to mind my own Wessex weeks of serendipity-cum-research. I, too, recommend the unplanned journey, but with one difference: Do carry the guidebooks, less to lay out your itinerary than to see, at night before you turn out the light, where you have been.

title: Power Failure Interrupts Programs on Channel 5
description: Channel 5, WNEW-TV, went off the air for nearly an hour and a half last night after a microwave relay atop the Gulf and Western Building failed, according a station spokesman.

title: On Language; HIT THE GROUND RUNNING; by William Safire
description: Hit the Ground Running Kimble Mead

title: CONTROL OF AIR TRAFFIC MAKES SMOOTH SWITCH TO ADVANCED GEAR ON L.I.
description: Control of air traffic in the New York metropolitan area was turned over early yesterday to a new $25 million center in Garden City, L.I., and the switch was said to have gone ''just beautifully.''

title: Dr. Karen Kostroff Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Milton Kostroff of Kings Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Karen M. Kostroff, to Dr. Jon R. Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mickey Cohen of North Miami, Fla. The couple are second-year residents in general surgery at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: LOOKING BACK: ANILINE
description: Few corporations in America have so rich, or stormy, a history as GAF. And because many of the turbulent episodes in its legacy were the result of outside forces, some observers argue that the indifferent reputation of the company's management is largely undeserved.

title: HIGH INTEREST RATES STALL DETROIT'S RECOVERY
description: Just as the American automobile industry seemed poised for a comeback after two years of slumping sales, a rapid rise in interest rates combined with sharply higher prices to deepen the gloom over Detroit.

title: OIL SUPPLIES TO BE TIGHT DESPITE NEW EXPLORATION
description: Oil drillers in the United States are poking holes in the ground at an unprecedented pace, but virtually no one thinks this adds up to the solution to the nation's petroleum problems.

title: Jonathan Beales Fiance of Maria Lamberton
description: The engagement of Maria Lewis Lamberton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ian Ker Lamberton of Philadelphia, to Jonathan Towle Beales, son of Mr. and Mrs. James A.G. Beales 3d of Wyndmoor, Pa., has been announced by the future bride's parents. A Feb. 21 wedding is planned.

title: Tombstone
description: To the Editor:

title: A BETTER BREAK FOR EXPATRIATES
description: F OR the two million United States citizens who live overseas, the pro-business bias expected with the advent of the Reagan administration could be especially important. Without exception, experts in the accounting profession and industry lobbyists are predicting that the new Congress will enact legislation easing the taxation of Americans who live and work abroad. They predict that the legislators may throw aside a complex set of country-by-country deductions they laboriously produced just a few years ago in favor of a policy similar to the more generous regulations that they replaced.

title: Reality News; Midtown Sublease
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the stock-brokerage concern, has subleased 18,095 square feet of office space on the 31st floor in the Celanese Building at 1211 Avenue of the Americas between 46th and 47th Streets from the Satra Corporation.

title: Marshall to Be Professor Again
description: Labor Secretary Ray Marshall plans to resume an academic career after he leaves office Jan. 20 but will remain in Washington until fall as a labor consultant. Mr. Marshall, 52 years old, says he will return in the fall semester to the University of Texas, where he was an economics professor. In the interim, he will become a senior counselor to the Industrial Union Department Institute, serving in a part-time capacity.

title: DOWN SOUTH (AND ELSEWHERE) THE GEOGRAPHY DICTATES THE DEMOGRAPHY
description: In early 1860, James L. Petigru, an eccentric Charleston lawyer, passionately urged fellow aristocratic South Carolinians to remain in the Union, in part - he said in a much quoted aside - because the state was ''too small for a republic and too large for a lunatic asylum.'' According to Edmund Robinson, a young white attorney on the Charleston County School Board, Petigru was the ''one righteous man'' whose presence caused President Abraham Lincoln to spare the city from Gen. William T. Sherman's March to the Sea.

title: PENSIONS OUTPACING CONGRESSIONAL PAY
description: When John W. McCormack retired from Congress in 1971 he received a yearly pension of $50,000. At the time of his death last November his Government pension had increased to about $92,000.

title: PORTMAN HOTEL HURDLES, STEP BY STEP
description: Like the Perils of Pauline, the story of John Portman and his proposed $261.5 million Times Square hotel has been a story of one near-calamity after another. And like Pauline, Mr. Portman and his Atlanta-based development company are forever optimistic and somehow manage to escape catastrophe each time.

title: PSYCHO-IDEOLOGY
description: American psychiatry, having just recovered from one ideology, seems ready to succumb to another. The pattern, by now a cycle, is all too predictable, and its cost, to the profession as well as its patients, all too great.

title: REGIONS: LONG ISLAND
description: This island's dependence on New York City and its inadequate transportation links with the mainland are expected to hobble its economy during the early 1980's.

title: VILLANOVA FOUL SHOTS HELP BEAT SYRACUSE
description: John Pinone sank two foul shots and Stewart Granger came up with a steal in the last moments of play to give Villanova a 69-65 Big East Conference basketball victory today over Syracuse.

title: Dance View; CARL VAN VECHTEN'S CENTENARY
description: Arecent centenary that is still being marked in several ways is that of Carl Van Vechten, one of America's most famous polymaths of the arts. Van Vechten, who died in New York City on Dec. 21, 1964, was born in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, on June 17, 1880. An exhibition celebrating the ''cultural contribution of Carl Van Vechten'' was held in June at Iowa's Kirkland Community College. This past year as well, A.J. Pischl's dance-book publishing firm, Dance Horizons, issued a paperback edition of ''The Dance Writings of Carl Van Vechten,'' edited by Paul Padgette.

title: Bestsellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 12 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $15.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history. 2 2 16 THE KEY TO REBECCA, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $12.95.) German espionage in Cairo during the desert campaigns of 1942. 3 3 21 FIRESTARTER, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) E ightyear-old Charlie can look at anything and turn it into flames. 4 9 13 COME POUR THE WINE, by Cynthia Freeman. (Arbor House, $12.95.) A woman's long journey to self-discovery. 5 4 15 LOON LAKE, by E.L. Doctorow. (Random House, $11.95.) The strange, lyrical adventures of a young man during the Depression. 6 5 8 UNFINISHED TALES, by J.R.R. Tolkien. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.) Hitherto unpublished fragments of writing about Middle-earth. 7 8 18 THE FIFTH HORSEMAN, by Larry Collins and Dominique Lapierre. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.) Libyan terrorists have planted a thermonuclear device in New York and there are only 24 hours to find it.

title: CHRISTOPHER HAS 'GOOD' MEETING WITH ALGERIAN AIDE ON HOSTAGES
description: Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher held what he described as a ''very good'' meeting tonight with the Algerian Foreign Minister concerning the negotiations to free the American hostages being held in Iran. He said later that he would delay his return to Washington another day.

title: The James Bond Car
description: Agent-007 fans would know it instantly: a low-slung racer with front-mounted machine guns, ejection seat, rear vents for spewing a smokecreen or an oil slick - and more. It was the Espionage Special DB-5, built by Aston Martin Lagonda Ltd. in 1963 for the movie ''Goldfinger.''

title: Connecticut 57, Seton Hall 47
description: Vern Giscombe, a freshman guard, scored 12 points tonight, including 8 in the final 12 minutes, to lead undefeated Connecticut to a 57-47 Big East victory over Seton Hall.

title: Begin Government May Fall on T.K.O.
description: The air at Sunday Cabinet meetings in Jerusalem has often been hot with invective, but Prime Minister Menachem Begin's feuding coalition has stuck it out since 1977, surviving corruption scandals, resignations by six ministers and more than 20 no-confidence challenges in the Knesset. But last week, key members of the ruling Likud coalition were seriously talking about early elections for the first time.

title: Halldorson 2-Shot Leader On Late Eagle and Birdie
description: Dan Halldorson sank a 35-foot sandwedge shot for an eagle on the 16th hole today, then rolled in a 25-foot birdie putt on the 18th for a 66 that gave him a two-shot thirdround lead in the $300,000 Tucson open.

title: LISA PULLING BRIDE OF R.B. SEMPLE JR.
description: Lisa Pulling, executive director of the Fresh Air Fund in New York, was married yesterday in Manhattan to Robert Baylor Semple Jr., foreign editor of The New York Times. The Rev. Hays H. Rockwell performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. James Episcopal Church.

title: THE KING MUST DIE
description: In ''The King Must Die,'' the novel she built on Greek myths, Mary Renault told about the bloody political system of Naxos. Every year the ruling king of that island fought a stranger, and died. The stranger became king for a year and then lost his crown and his life. And the people celebrated.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Source of InspirationThe subject of ''The World of Mother Teresa'' (Monday at 9 P.M. on Channel 13) has proved doubly inspirational to the filmmaker who made it. This hour-long documentary portrait of the 70-year-old Roman Catholic nun who was awarded the 1979 Nobel Peace Prize in recognition of her work among India's destitute was produced by Ann Petrie. Miss Petrie recently won an Emmy for having written and produced ''YOU!,'' the public-affairs series on issues and problems in the metropolitan area that ran for close to two years on WABC-TV.

title: ST. AUGUSTINE RETAINS SPANISH COLONIAL STYLE
description: In the past, my wife, Carole Anne, and I had come to St. Augustine, Fla., for little more than the beach, an art festival, fishing or perhaps dinner, with a stroll down one of the city's lanes thrown in for good measure. During one such trip, we attended a ''preconstruction buffet'' given by the developers of one of the many new condominiums that have sprung up from the sand dunes on the southern end of Anastasia Island, which lies just east of St. Augustine. Whether the affair was successful from the standpoint of sales, I do not know, but many in attendance were already condominium owners, concerned that this newcomer might impose the ambiance they already enjoyed.

title: DESPITE THE ABUSES ATHLETICS CAN ENRICH A COLLEGE EDUCATION By ANDY
description: GEIGER College football is America's reincarnation of the Midaeval Tournament. Knights in suits of armor play a fascinating game of human jousting, bands play school songs and comely maidens dance on the sidelines. Heraldric flags with coats of arms and school fly over the stadium.

title: FEAR AND LOATHING ON THE SKI T
description: RAILS BY STEVEN B. CARROLL

title: FROSTBITE PREVENTATIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: BULLETS 106, MAVERICKS 94
description: Kevin Porter scored 25 points and Elvin Hayes 21 for Washington in the victory over Dallas that broke a five-game losing streak for the Bullets.

title:
DINING OUT;
THE 'GENTRIFICATION' OF HUNAN
description: THE county's towns on Long Island Sound, although reasonably well supplied with many other cuisines, have been oddly deprived of their share of the Chinese cooking so widely represented in the rest of southern Westchester. And so China Lion, which established itself several months ago in Mamaroneck, is a most useful resource for the area. One might wish the kitchen had a little more conviction - the common fault of the dishes is a tendency toward the indecisive and bland. But on the other hand, nothing we sampled in our recent visits were salted to death - a common enough flaw in many Chinese restaurants - and some of the food was undeniably good.

title: THE DIFFERENCE HALF A BLOCK MAKES
description: THE Giulio Cesare Ristorante, which recently moved to more spacious quarters half a block away from its original location in Westbury, now has a gracious tiled waiting area, a roomy bar and a seating capacity five tables bigger than before. Although the change has made the restaurant more comfortable, the quality of the food and service has declined.

title: STAGE: PATRICK MUSICAL, 'ORPHEUS AND AMERIKA'
