description: Myths can be liberating, or, in the case of Robert Patrick and his new musical, ''Orpheus and Amerika,'' at the Theater for the New City, they can hamstring a theatrical talent. Mr. Patrick, author of ''Kennedy's Children'' and scores of plays with a vaudeville approach to life, has turned Orpheus into a rock star and sent him to Hades in search of his lost love, an agronomist named Eurydice.

title: LILCO RATES: PROSPECTS FOR THE 80'S
description: THE controversy over the Shoreham nuclear power plant began as a debate over safety, but with electric rates on the Island rising dramatically over the last few years, the economics of the project, and their impact on the Long Island Lighting Company as a whole, are now receiving almost equal emphasis.

title: REGAN ASSAILS TRANSIT AUTHORITY ON USE OF BUILDING
description: The Transit Authority has poorly utilized space that it rented in a Brooklyn building plagued by poor heating, poor cooling and leaks, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan charged yesterday. He asserted that despite the building's problems, the authority went on to lease three additional floors.

title: Baltimore Zoo Plagued
description: By Packs of Pet Dogs

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SAN ANTONIO
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- JIM WOOD contributes to The Times from San Antonio. By JIM WOOD

title: NEEDLING JARGON
description: To the Editor:

title: 150 Statuettes Stolen in Naples
description: The police searched antique stores today looking for 150 18th-century statuettes stolen from a Christmas crib in the Santa Chiara Basilica. Intruders smashed the glass protecting the display Thursday night to reach the foot-tall terra-cotta figures, each worth about $2,200, church officials said.

title: Sarah Gordon Fiancee Of James C. DeGiovanni
description: Mrs. James A. Gordon of New Vernon, N.J., and Brewster, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Sarah Jane Gordon, to James C. DeGiovanni, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph DeGiovanni of Swampscott, Mass.

title: FURTHER TIGHT CREDIT MEANS PROBLEMS FOR HOUSING
description: PERHAPS no business is more sensitive to changes in the cost and availability of credit than housing. Thus, the high interest rates of 1980 and the prospect that they will continue have led to expectations that both new construction and home resales this year will be below even last year's depressed levels. The predicament has left housing specialists wondering if anything can be done to bring the stability needed by builder and buyer alike. As the year ended, the interest rate for conventional mortgages, where they were available at all, was running between 14 percent and 15 percent, severely curtailing house sales except in a few atypical areas. "There is a psychological barrier at 13 percent," Michael Sumichrast, chief housing economist of the National Association of Home Builders, said. "People stop looking." Even if they keep looking, fewer families can qualify financially for mortgages as interest rate increases stiffen the terms set by lenders. The primary sufferer is the prospective first-time home buyer who lacks the accumulation of equity in an existing house to make the minimum down payment. "The first-time buyer is the sufferer," Richard Lind, a builder in Wellesley Hills, Mass, said. "Even when there are two workers in the family, most families cannot qualify for mortgages at these rates." Furthermore, with widely fluctuating interest rates, it becomes impossible forbuilders to do the long-term planning required for any large residential development project, builders say. "People will stop doing it," Mr. Lind said.

title: A PHOTOGRAPHER FOCUSES ON HENRY MOORE
description: NEW ROCHELLE HENRY MOORE belongs to that generation of artists whose careers were delayed - more seriously in England, perhaps, than here - by both the Depression and World War II. His reputation began when he was 30 with the relief carving he did for the London Passenger Transport Board but did not take off until 20 years later, after he had won the sculpture prize at the 1948 Venice Biennale.

title: DEAR TEACHER: WE HAD TO GET SOME SUN
description: JUSTIFICATION is mandated for school absences, even those that extend a vacation. Such notes, although parent-written, often evoke quiet suspicion that is fueled by the wintertime practice of many Long Island families of traveling south for a long holiday period.

title: Jeremy Koch Fiance Of Miss Humpstone
description: Katherine Cheney Humpstone, a textile designer who owns Cheney Designs in New York, plans to be married in May to Jeremy Bowen Koch, who is in the circulation department of Life magazine at Time Inc.

title: HOLOCAUST HISTORIAN
description: ROADSTOEXTINCTION Essays on the Holocaust. By Philip Friedman. Edited by Ada June Friedman. Introduction by Salo Wittmayer Baron. 610 pp. Philadelphia: The Jewish Publication Society of America. $27.50. By LUCY S. DAWIDOWICZ

title: No Headline
description: It is not entirely clear that the only problem of developing artificial intelligence simulations is to get computers to be as smart as people.

title: THE COURAGE TO BELIEVE
description: DOES GOD EXIST? An Answer for Today. By Hans Kung. Translated by Edward Quinn. 839 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $17.50.

title: To Turn the Illegal Tide
description: At last, the country seems to be getting somewhere in the tormenting effort to reduce illegal immigration.

title: HOUSE SPECIALTY: CONVIVIALITY
description: OWNER Billy O'Neill would seem to be taking Gov. William A. O'Neill's economy message to heart. At least that's the way it appeared on a recent visit to O'Neill's Tap Room in East Hampton. It was a sunny but chilling day with the temperature at 10 degrees Fahrenheit. But inside O'Neill's the temperature wasn't so much warmer that you could eat lunch without a coat over your shoulders. And the lighting, except for the natural light afforded the few tables near the window, was dim even at midday, suggesting that energy conservation was very much on the O'Neill/O'Neill mind.

title:
REGIONS: NEW ENGLAND;
HARTFORD
description: THE relative economic success that New England has built up over the past year is being threatened by higher interest rates and the possibility that the nation may once again slip into recession."If the economy does stall out again nationally, the capital goods sector will not have recovered enough over the last quarter to be able to withstand it," said David C. Powers, president of the New England Economic Project, a forecasting consortium supported by major banks, utilities and universities.

title: Sydney F. Cary Is Bride Of Richard M. Van Nort
description: Sydney Flagler Cary, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sturges Flagler Cary of New York and Corning, N.Y., was married yesterday in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., to Richard Meade Van Nort, son of Laura Stewart of Briarwood, Queens, and the late Charles Van Nort. The Rev. Mills Omaly performed the Episcopal ceremony in the chapel at Vassar College, from which the bride graduated in 1979.

title: Population Center Shifts West
description: The nation's population center continues to move to the southwest and is expected for the first time to be west of the Mississippi River, according to the Census Bureau. The bureau defines the population center as ''the point at which an imaginary, flat, weightless and rigid map of the United States would balance if weights of identical size were placed on it so that each weight represented the weight of one person on April 1, 1980,'' the official census date.

title: Begin Is Reported Ready To Quit if Ministers Do
description: Aides to Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that Mr. Begin had decided to resign if his Government was further weakened by Cabinet resignations.

title: Architechture View; SHOWS WITH A PERSONAL VISION; by Ada Louise Huxtable
description: Architecture and design exhibitions are starting strong in the new year. I have not visited all of those noted below, because it takes a certain stoic heroism to get around New York at the height of the season; there are times when only Hillary and Tenzig could make it across town.

title: REGIONS: NEW ENGLAND
description: HARTFORD THE relative economic success that New England has built up over the past year is being threatened by higher interest rates and the possibility that the nation may once again slip into recession.

title: Lesley Finnell To Be a Bride
description: Michael Hartman Finnell of Pasadena, Calif., and Mrs. Edward King Aldworth of Chicago have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lesley Hartman Finnell of Boston, to Frederick Clifford Blanchard Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Blanchard of Chester and Mantoloking, N.J. A Sept. 12 wedding in Chicago is planned.

title: Purdue 73, Ohio State 65
description: Keith Edmonson scored 26 points and Brian Walker added 19, a career high, in sparking Purdue to a 73-65 victory over Ohio State today.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Arrests at Registration Protest
description: Twenty-two people protesting draft registration were arrested today as they tried to block the entrance to the Harvard Square Post Office. About 60 other demonstrators organized by the Boston Alliance Against Registration and the Draft chanted, ''The whole world is watching.'' The group is opposed to a Government requirement that all males born in 1962 register at their local post offices.

title: Speaking Personally; A LEGACY OF WORDS, WORDS, WORDS
description: IWAS 14 years old when Yoko, Anne's cat, drowned in a neighbor's swimming pool. Anne, my best friend, was heartbroken. That was 1970. Now it is 1981. John Lennon is dead. I didn't cry, and neither did Anne, although I did call her in Boston, where she now lives, to share with her my grief and disgust. We have both changed. The death of Sid Vicious and the appearance of Devo and Elvis Costello mean more to me now.

title: DODD PROMISES TO REMEMBER OLD FRIENDS
description: RESPONDING to teasing from his former collegues in the House of Representatives that he would forget his old friends when he moved across the Capitol to the United States Senate, Christopher J. Dodd has written his former associates on the other side of the Capitol promising not to do the following:

title: The Talk of Plains
description: ''We sent him off with a party four years ago, so it's only right that we welcome him home with one, too,'' Maxine Reese said cheerfully over the counter of her combined grocery, liquor store and gasoline station on the outskirts of town.

title: THE DEEPEST PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: STEAKHOUSES: SAMURAI VS. BENIHANA
description: The Benihana chain of Japanese steakhouses may be in for some new competition. Three months ago, Hardwicke Companies Inc. and Benihana of Tokyo Inc. terminated an agreement by which Hardwicke had managed the chain of 50 restaurants for three years. The parting was deemed amicable by both, and Benihana set out to manage itself under the auspices of its flamboyant chairman and chief stockholder, Hiroaki A. Aoki.

title: REGIONS: THE WEST
description: SAN FRANCISCO THE Pacific Coast states, with their heavy output of hightechnology products, aircraft, farm goods and lumber, are showing signs of an economic upturn in 1981. Like elsewhere, inflation and the gyrating rates of interest on commercial and home loans have taken a toll in this region. The lumber industry, for example, normally one of the largest in northern California, Oregon and Washington, has been brought to a standstill by the sharp nationwide decline in housing construction.

title: No Headline
description: PARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Jan. 10 (AP) - Steve Podborski of Canada won his second consecutive World Cup downhill ski race today. Another Canadian, Ken Read, was injured and might miss the rest of the season.

title: Rockets 106, Blazers 105
description: Allen Leavell scored his total of 14 points in the fourth quarter and Major Jones, a reserve, got 18 points in leading Houston's comeback victory over Portland.

title: No Headline
description: Dr. Judith Nina Wasserheit and Dr. Jeffrey Randall Harris were married yesterday afternoon in the Princeton University Chapel by Walter Lawton, a leader in the Society for Ethical Culture. The couple are residents in internal medicine at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

title: Khristi B. Howard To Be Wed in May
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Willliam P. Howard of New Vernon, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Khristi Bancroft Howard, to Edward Whitmore Miller, son of Mrs. Adrian C. Israel of Stamford, Conn., and Carl N. Miller Jr. of Jupiter Hills Village, Fla.

title: HEAVY WEATHER FOR BOATS
description: Last year was a rocky one for the $7 billion pleasure boat industry, which will have its 1981 models on display at the Coliseum in New York later this week.

title: SLIMMING DOWN: THE GAF CASE
description: A FEW days ago, during a picture-taking session in his spacious midManhattan office, Jesse Werner, the 64-year-old chairman of the GAF Corporation, was asked to move to the opposite side of the room so that the lighting behind him might would not produce a halo effect in the picture.

title: THE SOVIET AVANT-GARDE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Harlow Robinson teaches in the Slavic Department at SUNY-Albany and writes frequently on the arts. By HARLOW ROBINSON

title: Notes; A NEW ART VILLAGE RISES IN THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC
description: A new international arts center that is almost a work of art in itself has been carved out of the wilderness high above the Caribbean in the southeastern corner of the Dominican Republic. It will be opened to the public on Thursday.

title: Fatal Auto Crashes Found Rising With Refusal to Use Safety Belts
description: Fatal car crashes are on the upswing and motorists are still refusing to use their safety belts, the Transportation Department reported today.

title: CITIES, SUBURBS AND SCHOOLS FACE NEW SUITS ON RACIAL BIAS
description: AS civil rights advocates worried that new directions in Washington and the country will mean still further diminution of the liberal initiatives of the long-ago 1960's, the Carter Administration last week gave another set of signals on how it wants its rights record to be remembered. Clearly, it would like to be seen in the postwar Democratic tradition.

title: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: DANCE You couldn't mistake Phoebe Neville's dances for choreography by anyone else. Starkly painted, compressed tableaux vivants, they linger on long past their initial, sometimes frightening, sometimes almost hallucinatory effect.

title: Tass Sees Haig Remarks As Threat to Soviet Bloc
description: Tass, the Soviet press agency, said today that Secretary of State-designate Alexander M. Haig Jr. wants the United States and its allies to act against socialist and developing countries.

title: THE THUMB IS THE HERO
description: HANDS By John Napier. Illustrated. 176 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $13.95. By EVE AUCHINCLOSS

title: OSSINING ARTS FESTIVAL
description: An unusually large number of artists, writers, actors and musicians have planned a second Ossining Arts Festival from 6 to 11 P.M. on Friday, 11 A.M. to 11 P.M. on Saturday and noon to 6 P.M. next Sunday in the Community Center, Route 9 at Broadway.

title: HIGHER PRICES ASKED BY FARMERS IN INDIA
description: Yeshwantrao Deshmukh was excited by the prospect of going to jail for the cause of higher farm prices. Last month Mr. Deshmukh was one of the several thousand farmers in Maharashtra State who marched 300 miles before winding up at a rally in Nagpur, 20 miles from here, at which more than 10,000 protesters were arrested. It appeared, as far as time in jail and the good feeling of solidarity went, that Mr. Deshmukh was satisfied. As for higher prices, they remain elusive.

title: Headliners Attentive Audience
description: Joseph Granville doesn't use the word ''forecasting.'' He prefers to say that he applies to the stock market a ''theory'' that he declines to reveal but whose results he communicates to clients in a weekly investment newsletter.

title: CHARRED TIMBERS AND RUBBLE AT FIRE SCENE
description: The alarms were silent and the soot-streaked faces of terror were gone. Charred timbers, a ghastly brick shell and heaps of rubble were all that remained yesterday of the Beachview Rest Home in Keansburg, N.J., where as many as 30 of the more than 100 elderly residents died Friday in a predawn fire.

title: CONTROVERSY CONTINUES AT 'THE HOOK'
description: SANDY HOOK ALTHOUGH the Sandy Hook unit of the Gateway National Recreation Area has been reopened since last Memorial Day, when the Army finished searching for buried artillery shells and bombs, controversy surrounding the park and the clearance operation continues.

title: DEBATE OVER CANCER CARE IN THE COUNTRY
description: THE recent announcement of a new cancer center at the Westchester County Medical Center left a depressing sense of deja vu. As far as could be determined, the program has yet to begin, but that did not prevent all kinds of claims being made for it. Granted, even the possibility of improved cancer care in the county ought to be heartening but we have been left instead with a sense of dismay and foreboding.

title: BARGAIN HUNTERS LEAVE A DENT IN HARROD'S DIGNITY
description: Harrods, the elegant London department store, was the scene of pushing and shouting today as the first of 300,000 customers arrived and clashed over who would get first crack at color television sets that were on sale for $950.

title: MIDDLE-AGED WORKERS READY FOR NEW SKILLS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE FAIR, NEW WORLD OF ORCHESTRA AUDITIONS
description: This month, the Boston Symphony is holding auditions to hire a new principal trumpet, and the National Symphony is hearing candidates for two string openings in Washington. The Toronto Symphony needs a concertmaster; the Houston, one horn, three violins, one cello and a viola. Those auditions come soon after.

title: GRANVILLE
description: The Reagan Rally met the Granville edict last week. The Dow Jones industrial average floated ahead nicely to close over 1,000 on Tuesday, for the second time since Ronald Reagan's election.

title: NEW DUMPING BANS BECOME U.S.LAW
description: WASHINGTON THE 18-month ''war'' between Connecticut and Long Island has ended, with both sides relatively pleased and with New Jersey Congressmen relieved that the dumping of sewage sludge and toxic industrial wastes into the Atlantic will be illegal after the end of this year.

title: Dr. Martin William Held Fiance of Elizabeth Wolfe
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederic D. Wolfe of Perrysburg, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Wolfe, to Dr. Martin William Held of San Francisco, son of Theresa L. Held of Brooklyn, and the late Irving Held.

title: PHILLIPS WOULD HIRE HIS AIDES
description: Bum Phillips says that if he becomes coach of the New Orleans Saints, he will try to hire his former Oiler staff, despite a demand for compensation by Ladd Herzeg, the Houston general manager.

title: AFTERNOON EDITION OF DAILY NEWS ISN'T SELLING AT ITS EXPECTED LEVELS
description: Tonight, the afternoon edition started by The Daily News five months ago to attract a new, upper-income readership, has drawn only about one-third the number of readers News executives had informally projected as its potential.

title: 14 Killed in Philippine Flooding
description: At least 14 people were killed in flooding caused by two weeks of heavy rains in the southern Philippines, Government officials said today. They said that more than 2,400 homes had been destroyed.

title: FELIX GALIMIR RECALLS BERG AND WEBERN IN VIENNA
description: Remembering the composer Alban Berg, Felix Galimir reflects: ''I think Berg had the deepest feeling for music I have ever seen. You know, my sisters and I, who were a string quartet, played every Saturday. We always invited him, and he always came. Once when we were rehearsing, the doorbell rang, and we stopped. It was Berg. 'Oh no, don't stop,' he said. 'What were you playing?' It was the Schubert Quartettsatz. So we started playing again, and the man - I swear this is not an exaggeration - the man was sitting there crying like a child. He said, 'What a pity that Schubert was not allowed to finish this piece.' And of course the same thing happened to Berg. It was only several years later that he died, leaving 'Lulu' unfinished.''

title: A SOUND OF DISCORD AT MUSIC MOUNTAIN
description: year contract beginning this year, Music Mountain's 52d season.

title: IODINE DEMAND RISING
description: Major users of iodine are currently confronted with a classic economic problem. Increased demand has outstripped available supply, driving up prices.

title: Crime
description: Every two or three years along comes a Helen MacInnes spy story, and just off the presses is THE HIDDEN TARGET (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $12.95). Miss MacInnes is one of our veterans. She started with a sensation in her very first book - ''Above Suspicion'' in 1941 - and in recent years has been enjoying a succession of best sellers. Her latest effort follows the familiar MacInnes formula.

title: NEW CONCEPTS ARE EVOLVING ON OCEAN DUMPING
description: IS THE Atlantic Ocean more capable of assimilating sewage sludge and other forms of wastes than has been believed in recent yers? Some scientists of national repute think it may be, and their views could influence the amount of wastes that are dumped off the coasts of New Jersey and Long Island in the near future.

title: dad Lisa Feldman Sets Wedding To Michael A. Davis in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Feldman of Coconut Creek, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Lisa H. Feldman, to Michael Alan Davis, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Maurice Davis of White Plains.

title: RUTGERS 69, PITT 59
description: Balanced scoring, led by Clarence Tillman with 16 points, paced Rutgers to a 69-59 Eastern Eight basketball victory over the University of Pittsburgh today.

title: WASHINGTON
description: THE 18-month-old dispute between Connecticut and Long Island over which Federal regulations should govern waste disposal in Long Island Sound has ended with both sides apparently satisfied. Connecticut's pleasure-boat fleet remains intact, and Long Islanders seem reasonably assured that offshore waters will not be further sullied by dumping of wastes.

title: Judith Serkin, Ned Winsor, Financial Analysts, Are Wed
description: Judith A. Serkin, daughter of Mrs. Leon E. Serkin of West Newton, Mass., and the late Mr. Serkin, was married yesterday afternoon to Ned J. Winsor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Winsor of Fanwood, N.J. Rabbi Benjamin Rudavsky of Hingham, Mass., and the Rev. Andrew Frye, a Roman Catholic priest of Scotch Plains, N.J., officiated at the ceremony in the home of the bride's mother.

title: Japanese Premier Arrives In Jakarta on Asian Tour
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan arrived in Indonesia today on the second leg of a tour designed to convince the five members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations of his country's desire for mutually beneficial economic and political relations.

title: Perceptions Shift On Working Women
description: Young women may be re-examining the feminist imperative to succeed, as a recent Brown University study suggests. But if they choose to persist, public opinion now will approve their efforts - a dramatic shift, according to a report released last week.

title: DEREGULATION LIKELY TO BE EMPHASIZED BY REAGAN
description: WASHINGTON THE four-year effort to reduce Government regulation of the transportation, communications and other American industries is likely to be accelerated by the incoming Reagan administration.

title: REAGAN: CAN HE CURE INFLATION?
description: The first year of the Reagan era dawns bleakly, as the economic problems that helped Mr. Reagan gain the Presidency become his to solve.

title: EL PENON, El Salvador
description: THE weeds are high, the fence falling down, the administration building badly needs painting and repair and oxen lug carts with solid wooden wheels over the dusty road. But, if the former owners neglected this Pacific coast farm in the western corner of El Salvador, the army has not.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC Leo Smit is preparing to drop some impressive names at his piano recital Saturday night at the Abraham Goodman House. His program is entitled ''Composers I Have Known,'' and Mr. Smit has obviously made the acquaintance of many luminaries over the last several decades.

title: WALKER EVANS PHOTOS SHOWN
description: OLD LYME WALKER Evans was not a native of Connecticut, but he did spend the last decade of his life here, as a professor of photography at Yale. He also passed much of his leisure time in Old Lyme where, in the late 1940's, he acquired a shack that he eventually turned into a year-round house. A well-whiskered man who, in later life, sported fashionably round eyeglasses, Evans is still remembered in Lyme as an eccentric who could be both testy and charming and who liked to live and dress well.

title: NORTHEAST COLD BRINGS WOE TO MILLIONS
description: One of the coldest winters in years is whistling through the Northeast like the wind through a threadbare overcoat. From homeowners worried about their fuel bills to social service agencies trying to help poor families left without heat, the cold is making life miserable for millions of people.

title: Physician Deplores Curbs on Health Care
description: The New York Times published in its Connecticut Weekly section of Nov. 30, a front-page article by John S. Rosenberg entitled ''Hospital Costs Responding to Budget Rx,'' which tells only half the story. Unfortunately, this type of journalism creates an erroneous impression for readers who are seeking information. The front page promotes the concept that the Cost Commission (Commission on Hospitals and Health Care) has helped curb rising costs in hospitals in the State of Connecticut. It compares our hospitals to those of 44 states that do not have any regulatory agency. The Times published the second part of the article on the back page of the section where it begins to tell more facts of the whole story.

title: Michigan 68, Minnesota 67
description: Marty Bodnar sank a 12-foot jumper with five seconds to play in double overtime tonight, lifting Michigan to a 68-67 victory over Minnesota.

title: Kentucky 48, Tennessee 47
description: Fred Cowan's only basket of the game, an 18-footer with six seconds remaining, gave Kentucky a 48-47 Southeastern Conference victory over Tennessee today.

title: I-78: Are Tax Dollars At Work or Standing Idle?
description: I wish to add my two cents' worth to Peter E. Rosenfeld's article (Opinion Page, Jan. 4) calling for the completion of Interstate 78. I, too, am a conservative-minded, longtime resident of Union County who not only takes his newspapers and bottles to recycle, but also appreciates and enjoys the use of our priceless Watchung Reservation.

title: Julia M. Roe to Be Wed To Mortimer N. Sellers
description: The engagement of Julia Matheson Roe to Mortimer Newlin Sellers, son of Prof. and Mrs. Peter Hoadley Sellers of Philadelphia, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Moir Roe of Mendenhall, Pa.

title: Loretta Kelly Is Engaged
description: John T. Kelly of Satellite Beach, Fla., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Loretta Kelly, to Dr. Leslie C. Norins, son of Abe Norins of Baltimore and the late Mrs. Norins. The future bride, daughter also of the late Mrs. Kelly, and her fiance will be married Feb. 14. The bride-to-be's marriage ended in divorce. Dr. Norins is president of American Health Consultants, medical publishers in Atlanta.

title: THE FOUR NEW CONGRESSWOMEN ON THE ISSUES
description: The most striking similarity among the four candidates who beat the odds last November to become the newest female members of the House of Representatives emerges slowly.

title: DEBATING CIVIL LIBERTIES IN MAGNA CARTA LAND
description: A sensational murder case in Yorkshire last week has rekindled a perennial British debate about police procedures, freedom of the press, and a suspect's right to a fair trial. The case, in which a 35-year-old truck driver was charged with having committed one of the 13 ''Yorkshire Ripper'' slayings, provided Britons with one of several reminders that frontiers are changing in the definitions of cherished civil liberties here in the land of Magna Carta.

title: NEWS ANALYSIS: NEW GOVERNOR'S COURSE
description: HARTFORD IN his first major policy pronouncement as Governor, William A. O'Neill has staked out a conservative approach to the state's fiscal problems by emphasizing spending cuts rather than tax increases. Mr. O'Neill's message on the state of the state to the new General Assembly last Wednesday - a message that even the new Democratic Governor acknowledged was a discouraging one - delighted the Republican minorities in both houses, caught unawares some Democratic leaders who had been sending up trial balloons for higher taxes, and brought protests from municipal officials, who stand to lose state grants they had counted on.

title: STATE'S INFLUENCE IN CONGRESS WANES
description: WASHINGTON IN THE opinion of New Jersey's Washington office, the influence of the state's Congressional delegation has waned this year, largely because of the defeat of Representative Frank Thompson Jr., the 13-term Trenton Democrat, and the Republican ascendancy in the Senate.

title: CONSUMER RATES
by Shirley M. Hufstedler
description: USE THIS

title: 'BUT WHAT DO YOUN FIND TO DO...ON THE EAST END IN THE WINTER?'
description: WHENEVER I go back to the city to visit, people ask me, ''You're going to spend the winter in the Hamptons?'' They stare at me in disbelief, thinking of the East End only as ''the place to be'' in the warm months of July and August - where joggers and women in short shorts and high heels abound; a singles haven of discos and bars, beaches and bikinis. But the thought of being there when all that is gone seems absurd.

title: BODIES OF 6 FOUND IN HOUSE FREQUENTED BY MOTORCYCLISTS
description: The bodies of four men and two women were found throughout a house in suburban Chesterfield County that neighbors described today as a gathering place for a group of motorcycle enthusiasts.

title: DEBORAH DELAND BETROTHED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thorndike Deland of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Curry Deland, to Robert Edgar Reed, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman R. Reed of Pompton Plains, N.J.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: DETROIT (AL) - Signed Lou Whitaker, s econd baseman, to a two-year contract for a reported $400,000.

title: By CAREN GOLDBERG
description: IT is 9 P.M. and a fine snow has been falling steadily for hours. I always expend too much mental energy nervously anticipating winter storms, the forecast starting a day before the actual event with verbal overkill by the news media. I pull the office curtains back a dozen times, scanning the skies for the first flake, dreading the slippery drive home, should the storm start suddenly before the workday ends.

title: A 7-YEAR STRUGGLE BY WHITE ENCLAVE
description: With the appointment late last year of a ''special master'' to oversee his order that Parma provide low-income housing and so overcome what he called the city's image of inhospitableness to blacks and minorities, Federal Judge Frank J. Battisti carried fair housing case law further than it had ever gone. He also confronted a cherished Ohio practice - referendums as a favored way of setting public policy.

title: Rich-Torme Concert Jan. 29
description: Buddy Rich and Mel Torme will headline a concert Jan. 29 at 8 P.M. at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue.

title: Harvard 90, Manhattan 80
description: Don Fleming and Joe Carrabino combined for 44 points today to pace Harvard to a 90-80 victory over Manhattan.

title: Aston Villa, Ipswich Gain; In British Soccer Race
description: Aston Villa downed the defending champion, Liverpool, with a goal in each half today and moved back into first place in the English League First Division.

title: Austrian Triumphs In Pro Giant Slalom
description: Andre Arnold of Austria, the tour leader for three years, captured the world professional giant slalom race at this Catskill resort today. The pro troupe was making its first Eastern appearance of the season.

title: Albany Notes
description: A bitter partisan war is expected to begin next week when the State Senate's Democratic leadership tries to strip a senior Democratic Senator of his lucrative post as ranking minority member of the Finance Committee.

title: FOR NURSES, A SENSE OF NEED AND FUTILITY
description: WHITE PLAINS IT is just past 7 A.M. when Lesley Fessenden, R.N., enters the nurses' lounge on the fifth-floor medical-surgical ward of White Plains Hospital Medical Center for a procedure called report. Report is the briefing that the night nurse gives the day nurses on how the patients in unit 5F have fared during the night.

title: RED BRIGAES DECLARE A DEADLINE ON LIFE OF KIDNAPPED MAGISTRATE
description: The Red Brigades said today that they would kill a kidnapped Justice Ministry official if Italy's major newspapers did not publish a series of lengthy statements by the terrorists within 48 hours.

title: Is Cholesterol Dangerous? New Study Says Yes
description: Confused cholesterol ingesters, unite. In May, the National Academy of Sciences reported that high cholesterol foods are not bad for the average American's health, contradicting the low cholesterol diet advice of 20 organizations concerned with public health.

title: Barbara Delatiner; BROOKLYN PHILHARMONIA
description: In a rare excursion to the Island, the Brooklyn Philharmonia, conducted by Lukas Foss, will appear at Temple Israel in Great Neck tonight. With Ellen Shade, soprano; Rose Marie Freni, mezzo; Misha Raitzin, tenor, and Arthur Woodley, bass, as soloists, the concert will feature Ives's ''Johnny Poe'' and Sessions's Rhapsody in their New York area premieres. The concert is at 7:30 P.M. at the temple, 108 Old Mill Road. Tickets are $12.50; for students and the elderly, $6.25. 482-7800. LABOR HISTORY

title: M. Varina Mason Is Married
description: M. Varina Mason of New York was married at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond K. Mason, in Jacksonville, Fla., yesterday to Joseph J. Steuert, a senior vice president in the corporate finance department of E.F. Hutton & Company in New York. B.K. Roberts, retired Chief Justice of the Florida Supreme Court, performed the ceremony, in which the Rev. Roland Perdue, a Presbyterian minister, participated.

title: 6 FAMILES SHOW ARABS AND JEWS CAN SHARE LAND
description: On this rocky hillside in what until 1967 was a no man's land between the Israeli and Jordanian lines 20 miles northwest of Jerusalem, four Jewish families have settled with two Arab families and the family of a British Roman Catholic and his wife, an Israeli Jew.

title: TV View; A PROVOCATIVE NEW SERIES ON MODERN ART; by John O'Connor
description: Tonight at 8, public television begins an eight-part series entitled ''The Shock of the New.'' Once again, television is tackling the difficult subject of art, in this case the Modern Movement of the past 100 years. And once again, the content can be faulted for sweeping generalizations, questionable speculations and blatant biases. But, overall, ''The Shock of the New'' works remarkably well on its own carefully conceived terms. This is not a history of art. Paying homage to Kenneth Clark's ''Civilisation,'' it adopts the subtitle of that milestone series: ''A Personal View.'' In this case, the view belongs to Robert Hughes, a native of Australia and, among other things, art critic for Time magazine.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Carol Ruth Bride Of Richard Foote
description: In the Old Lyme (Conn.) Congregational Church yesterday afternoon, Carol McDonald Ruth of Rowayton, Conn., became the bride of Richard Lindsay Foote of Old Lyme.

title: QUOTATIONS
description: ''Sell everything. Market top has been reached. Go short on stocks having sharpest advance since April.''

title: MAJOR POINTS IN THE SENATE FOREIGN REALTIONS COMMITTEE'S QUESTIONING OF
description: HAIG

title: RUTGERS GALLERY GETS GIFT OF MODERN ART
description: NEW BRUNSWICK DAVID MORSE purchased his first work of art in 1948, a courtroom scene by Forain, the French artist. Although Mr. Morse does not now consider the painting an important example, the acquisition marked the beginning of his enduring romance with art and the first step in the development of an impressive and significant collection of modern art.

title: RULES FOR DUMPING IN SOUND ACCEPTED
description: WASHINGTON AN 18-month-old dispute between Connecticut and Long Island over which Federal regulations should govern waste disposal in Long Island Sound has ended with both sides apparently satisfied. The pleasureboat fleet remains intact, and Long Islanders seem reasonably assured that offshore waters will not be further sullied by dumping of wastes.

title: WHEN DEALERS BECOME COLLECTORS
description: Many antiques dealers have a problem deciding what they should and should not collect. If they focus on the wares they know best - the wares that they stock and sell - matters might become most confusing, for they would be hard put to decide which objects to keep and which to sell. If, however, they acquire period works that no one else appears to want, there will be neither competition with clients nor a fear that their possessions are what others seek.

title: ISLANDERS ARE DEFEATED BY BRUINS, 3-2
description: The Islanders found out tonight that when you are not playing too well, you are not so lucky, either. They lost their second game in a row and saw their 15-game unbeaten string at home halted by the Boston Bruins, who won, 3-2, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: U.S. Finds No Violations In Deaths of 2 Activists
description: The Justice Department announced yesterday that it had closed a second Federal inquiry into the deaths of two Puerto Rican separatists killed by the police in what appeared to be an attempt to sabotage a Puerto Rican television station.

title: Yale Is Paid $650,000 For Brasher Doubloon
description: A buyer identified only as a prominent collector from Palm Beach, Fla., has paid the asking price of $650,000 for Yale University's Brasher Doubloon, one of the world's most famous and valuable coins.

title: CANADIAN WEST: BRASH,RICH AND FEELING NEGLECTED
description: ABOARD TRAIN NO. 3, in Western Canada - The cowboy hats start appearing just west of Winnipeg, along with the grain elevators, the talk of separatism, the slight western twang and the intense dislike for the east generally and Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau specifically.

title: ROOM AT THE TOP: THE NEW LOOK OF THE EXECUTIVE OFFICE
description: T HE lights are dim, the tables polished, the carpeting soft, the plants tall and healthy. The view is expansive and the telephone rings faintly, if at all. It is a quiet, restful environment, as glamorous as a Fifth Avenue penthouse apartment. But this is not a home; it is the office of a chief executive.

title: Draft Registrants, The 1962 Vintage
description: Another batch of possible inductees - young men born in 1962 - trooped to post offices last week to register for the draft. It was the second such national signup; it could be the last.

title: Key Turkish Banker Resigning
description: The governor of the Turkish Central Bank, Ismail Hakki Aydinoglu, has given his resignation to Prime Minister Bulent Ulusu, banking sources said today. The sources said Mr. Aydinoglu, 48 years old, Central Bank governor for the past two years, had disagreed with the economic policies adopted by the military junta when it seized power in September.

title: THE GAS THIS DENTIST USES IS NEON
description: Just a year ago, Dr. Shel Kupper started a store-front dental practice on West 10th where Sutters Bakery had stood. Like other professionals starting out, he hung a shingle. Dr. Kupper's shingle, however, is a $1,000 neon sign. ''Smile,'' it says.

title: FOUNDATION HEAD DISCOVERS PROBLEMS IN DISBURSEMENTS
description: To his dismay, J. Roderick MacArthur, a Chicago businessman, has discovered that giving away millions of dollars annually can be a disheartening and frustrating experience.

title: PANEL URGES CHANGE IN COAL REGULATION
description: A study group appointed by the Carter Administration has produced a report endorsing many longstanding coal industry complaints about government regulations and conflicting rules. The group suggests changes, particularly in Federal stripmining controls, sought by producers.

title: A HEALTH INSPECTOR'S LOT IS NOT AN EASY ONE
description: RESTAURANTS like to have every table occupied, and most prefer their waiting areas full as well. But there's one visitor who comes at least once a year, sometimes more often, that many restaurateurs would just as soon not see.

title: SCHOOLBOY'S 4:13.8 WINS DARTMOUTH RELAYS MILE
description: Brian Pettingill of Bishop Cheverus High School, Portland, Me., won the mile run today in the meet record time of 4 minutes 13.8 seconds at the Dartmouth Relays.

title: Editor's Choice
description: ALICE JAMES, by Jean Strouse. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.) A judicious and beautifully written life of William and Henry's younger sister.

title: DEFENDANTS CHARGE DISCRIMINATION IN FEDERAL JURY SELECTION IN GEORGIA
description: An unusual mix of criminal defendants, from corporate presidents charged with price fixing to indigents accused of selling drugs, have joined forces here in the hope of having their indictments dismissed because of alleged discrimination in the way Federal juries have been selected.

title: HACKENSACK
description: The decline of New Jersey's six major cities will be the state's main economic problem in 1981, just as it was throughout the last decade. "Our urban areas are hemorrhaging jobs, particularly in manufacturing, and they have not recovered," said Joseph J. Seneca, a professor at Rutgers University and chairman of the Economic Policy Council of New Jersey, the chief economic advisory board to the Governor and Legislature.

title: OTHER TIMES AND PLACES
description: THE IDOL HUNTER By Barry Unsworth. 192 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $10.95.

title: Progress On National Market Plan
description: WASHINGTON ALTHOUGH progress toward the establishment of a national market system has been painfully slow since it was mandated by Congress in 1975, members of the securities industry are beginning to say that the higher trading volumes envisioned for the 1980's will make more automation and a broader trading mechanism almost a necessity.

title:
New Jersey Housing;
'ARMED TRUCE' INTERRUPTED IN BERGEN
description: estate brokers ''an armed truce.''

title: 3 Die in Florida Plane Crash
description: Three professors of engineering at the University of Florida were killed yesterday when a single-engine plane overshot the runway at the Gainesville Airport and crashed while making a second landing attempt, the authorities said. The victims were identified as John Biery, 53 years old, the pilot; James Rumble, 55, and John Justusson, 45. The men were returning from a trip to Houston.

title: ROBERT TRENT JONES TO GET GOLFER'S RICHARDSON AWARD
description: Robert Trent Jones, designer of more than 400 golf courses in 23 countries and 42 American states, has been chosen by the Golf Writers Association of America to receive its Richardson Award.

title: A FAST START ON BREAKING INFLATIONARY EXPECTATIONS
description: WASHINGTON IF both campaign and post-campaign promises are any guide, the election of Ronald Reagan has raised the prospect of the most dramatic set of new policies from a President since Franklin Roosevelt.

title: NEW VEGETABLES MAKE THEIR DEBUT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Ellen Henke is a landscape consultant and vocational education instructor. By ELLEN HENKE

title: 5 JUDGES FROM UPSTATE ARE SELECTED BY CAREY FOR APPELLATE DIVISION
description: Five justices from upstate New York have been appointed to the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court by Governor Carey.

title: Poland's Restive Workers Make Saturdays 'Free'
description: Poland's Communist Party newspaper last week published a provisional economic reform program that its drafters said would take the Polish economy ''beyond the Hungarian model'' toward Yugoslavstyle worker self-management. Impatient for improvement now, Polish workers stayed off the job by the millions yesterday demanding an established labor right in the industrialized West - the five-day, 40-hour week.

title: RECORDING SHOWS HAIG DELAYED RELEASE IN '74 OF WATERGATE TAPES
description: In a tape of a 1974 radio conversation between Air Force One and the White House made public today, Alexander M. Haig Jr., President-elect Ronald Reagan's choice for Secretary of State, is heard instructing the White House to delay releasing Watergate tapes to the special prosecutor.

title: Under Libyan Guns Chad Gets Merged
description: Muammar el-Qaddafi last week announced a merger between Libya and Chad, his southern neighbor. To neighboring nations, it looked more like an anschluss.

title: LAURIE NAN LANE WED TO CHARLES SCHAFFRAN, A LAWYER
description: The marriage of Laurie Nan Lane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lane of New York, to Charles Brad Schaffran, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Schaffran of Miami Shores, Fla., took place yesterday evening at the Pierre. Rabbi Ronald Sobel officiated.

title: U.S. JURY CONTINUING INQUIRY ON SINATRA
description: A grand jury is continuing an investigation to determine if Frank Sinatra and some close associates were involved in skimming money from the Westchester Premier Theater.

title:
Antiques;
TIME AGAIN FOR MEADOWLANDS SHOW
description: EAST RUTHERFORD MORE than 250 dealers from 12 states are scheduled to show their wares at the Meadowlands Antiques Exposition next Sunday. The show's strong points will be glassware, china, jewelry and pottery, with a special accent on glassware. There also will be country furnishings, oak and some Victorian furniture, prints, posters, toys, railroad and musical items, quilts, clothing, linens, lamps, statues and tools, among other objects.

title: KEROUAC TO KATMANDU
description: LESSONSOFTHEROAD An Overland Journey to the East. By Michael Schiffer. 252 pp. New York: Kenan Press. $10.95. By INGRID BENGIS

title: DIAL-A-MORTGAGE SYSTEM CHANGED TO A PRIORITY-LOTTERY PLAN
description: 202 457-6880 - By ANDRE F. SHASHATY

title: CLINT EASTWOOD'S NEW LOOK
description: Not long ago, when Clint Eastwood attended a daylong celebration in his honor at the Museum of Modern Art, he surprised the fans and autograph-seekers by never once exhibiting his famous squint - the glare, half-comic, half-chilling, that signals he is about to turn scourge or avenging angel. There was no trace of the look that has spelled doom for so many movie villains.

title: COST OF EXPANDING 3 AIRPORTS ESTIMATED AT $1 BILLION
description: The three major airports in the New York City area are in the midst of an expansion that officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey say will cost at least $1 billion by the end of the century.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: SUPPORTERS of Westchester County Aiport now have a set of statistics to cite when seeking to demonstrate its economic importance to the region. The statistics were compiled by the White Plains Regional Chamber of Commerce in an economic-impact study based on answers to questionnaires sent out to businesses, Government agencies, airport-based corporations and airport employees.

title: DR. ARNOLD STERNHEIM TO WED ANNE B. GLASBERG IN JUNE
description: The engagement of Anne Bernet Glasberg to Dr. Arnold E. Sternheim has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Oscar S. Glasberg of Weston, Conn., parents of the future bride. Mr. Sternheim is a son of Harold Sternheim of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, and the late Mrs. Sternheim. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Practical Traveler; WINTERTIME DAY TOURS FROM NEW YORK
description: Unless they are avid skiers, many Northeasterners avoid one-day outings at this time of the year. Yet a wide variety of options are available, and because it is off-season, many are exceptionally economical.

title: ANSWERS TO WHY PEOPLE CAN'T SLEEP
description: ''YOU cannot define insomnia in terms of hours of sleep,'' Dr. Alice Kuhn Schwartz of East Hampton said. ''Some people are happy with three hours of sleep. Some people are miserable with seven.

title: French Flutist and Harpist Share Duo-Solo Program
description: The French Government is presenting two duos and one trombone quartet at Carnegie Recital Hall under the overall title ''New Concert Artists of France'' this season. Wednesday night it was the turn of Catherine Cantin, a flutist, and Frederique Cambreling, a harpist. Although they were billed as a duo, they played solo pieces, too, and on the basis of her performance on Wednesday, one would like to hear Miss Cambreling have a whole evening to herself.

title: Ski Huts in Colorado's High Country
description: Niculae Asciu An Aspen resident, Fred Braun, built most of the system himself and now manages the huts as a nonprofit venture. --------------------------------------------------------------------- JOHN SABELLA, an editor who lives in Seattle, is a former sports editor of The Aspen Times. By JOHN SABELLA

title: Manic Magic on Wall Street
description: We tend to the view that if stock market forecasters, like race track tipsters, were worth listening to, they wouldn't be talking. Instead of peddling hot dope for $5 a newsletter, they'd hoard the information and get rich themselves. That they insist on practicing their augury only with other people's money is, to say the least, a constant confession of modesty.

title: 76ers 117, Bulls 102
description: Steve Mix scored 24 points and Darryl Dawkins 22 for Philadelphia. Mix got 15 of his points in the second quarter as the 76ers took a 57-48 halftime lead. In the third quarter, Andrew Toney, who scored a total of 21 points, and Julius Erving took up the burden for the winners.

title: SALVADORAN REBELS SAY OFFENSIVE STARTS
description: Heavy fighting erupted here tonight and leftist guerrillas broadcast from a captured radio station that their ''final offensive'' against El Salvador's ruling junta had begun.

title: SOCCER TITLE TO URGUAY
description: Waldemar Victorino, the tournament's leading scorer, netted a header with 10 minutes left today to give Uruguay a 2-1 victory over Brazil in the final of the six-nation soccer World Gold Cup.

title: AGAIN, IT'S THE SEASON FOR FIRES
description: ''IT was the worst Christmas we ever had,'' said Charles Kravitz, who spent the holidays at a motel with his mother, three brothers and two sisters. On Dec. 20, their three-bedroom apartment in North Tarrytown was gutted by fire.

title: A QUESTION BY A SURVIVOR: 'WHERE ARE THE OTHERS?'
description: Scattered around at relatives' homes and at shelters and nursing homes that had taken them in, survivors of the fire that enveloped the Beachview Rest Home here told today of the loss of friends and possessions and of harrowing escapes.

title: POLAND STUDIES PROGRAM TO CUT CENSOR'S POWER
description: The draft of a new law to limit censorship is shaping up as a document that would make Poland one of Eastern Europe's freest societies for writers, journalists and film makers.

title: 'BUT WHAT TO YOU FIND TO DO...ON THE EAST END IN THE WINTER?'
description: THERE are few people who would wonder what there is to do on the East End in summer. But having spent most of the last 29 winters on the South Fork, I have been asked countless times, ''But what do you do all winter?''

title: KUWAIT RAISES OIL PRICE TO $35.50
description: Kuwait announced today that it had raised the price of its crude oil by $4 to $35.50, retroactive to Jan. 1. The Kuwaiti announcement followed similar moves by other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, which agreed to raise prices by 10 percent from Jan. 1.

title: Closing Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW A PROFESSOR BECAME A DIRECTOR
description: Two weeks later, Mr. Lowenthal was in Washington, following Alger Hiss around the Georgetown University campus and giving instructions to a cameraman. That was the beginning of ''The Trials of Alger Hiss,'' Mr. Lowenthal's critically acclaimed documentary, and the end of his midlife crisis.

title: THE REGION
description: If the answer is, ''With mirrors,'' what is the question? To political skeptics hearing Governor Carey's State of the State message last week, it was: How, in a tight budget, do you simultaneously cut taxes and pay for a raft of expensive new undertakings? But while Republican and Democratic leaders of the Legislature were dubious about the dollars and cents, they supported the Governor's proposals.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; TAYLOR CALDWELL
description: After finishing her 35th novel early last year, Taylor Caldwell, age 80, took a three-month cruise with her husband, William Robert Prestie. Upon their return, she signed a two-book contract with G.P. Putnam's Sons for $3.9 million, then purchased a half-million-dollar estate in Greenwich, Conn. Two weeks later, in early May, Miss Caldwell suffered a stroke that paralyzed her and left her speechless. Although it will not be published until tomorrow, the first of those two books, ''Answer as a Man'' -the saga of a man of principle who is severely tested as he rises from impoverished IrishCatholic roots to a position of prestige and power - has already made The New York Times Best Seller List.

title: REGIONS: THE SOUTHWEST
description: HOUSTON THE big, rumbling flatbed trucks whip intimidatingly along Houston's freeways day after day, bearing their cargoes of drillpipe and oilfield machinery outward to the farthest reaches of the Southwest's Oil Patch, where the greatest drilling frenzy in history is going on.

title: INAUGURAL FESTIVITIES-THE LOCAL SCENE
description: WHITE PLAINS ANYONE who hasn't received an invitation to the inaugural festivities need not miss marking the installation of the nation's 40th President in style. And the uninvited don't even have to travel to Washington.

title: TECHNOLOGY: REMEDY FOR COSTLY ENERGY
description: THE era when American industry was able to cope with the rising cost of energy by turning off lights, installing computerized monitoring systems and recycling waste heat is drawing to a close.

title: INSPECTIONS BEFORE SALE INCREASING
description: ALTHOUGH David and Nancy York had bought and sold as many as seven houses over a period of 17 years, it was only when they came to Fairfield last spring that they decided to have a complete home inspection.

title: On Diplomats
description: To the Editor:

title: OF ARMS AND MEN
description: In September 1969, I spent evenings for the better part of three weeks deliberately inhaling canvas dust from the sewing tables at a tent factory in Upstate New York. I was merely another college graduate evading the draft. Classified 1-A, and with the Vietnam War still raging, I was attempting to revive a childhood history of bronchial asthma that, I hoped, would keep me safely at home, morally and physically untainted.

title: THE BAROQUE OPERA BATTLEGROUND
description: Controversies about performance practice are nowhere so fierce as in Baroque opera, given the complexity and variety of the form. And since Baroque operas can less feasibly be performed by modern opera houses than recorded in the studio, the tangible results of the controversy can best be heard on disks. In the past year, two Baroque opera recordings have appeared that can stand as demonstrations of the principal opposing views on the matter - and of the difficulties of importing unusual, expensive albums into the United States.

title: Alicia M. Tierney to Be Wed To Douglas Johnson May 9
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond M. Tierney Jr. of Shrewsbury, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alicia Marie Tierney, to Douglas Allan Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley A. Johnson of Orinda, Calif.

title: Camera; SOME TECHNIQUES FOR CAPTURING A MOVING IMAGE; by Jack Neubart
A New Congress With Old Echoes
description: The 97th Congress went to Washington last week, and while the 81 ''Mr. Smiths'' and more than 400 senators and representatives who kept their seats in November were only in town for a day, it was long enough to set the session's tone.

title: Bivouac in Britain
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart appearing today on page 53 of section 12, the National Economic Survey, incorrectly lists the largest cable television companies. A corrective article appears on page 19 of section 3, the Business section.

title: Caribbean Threat: French Go Home
description: Although a majority of Guadeloupeans have repeatedly voted against independence, a tiny fraction of frustrated proponents have turned to terrorism to further their aims.

title: THE SPIRIT OF SHELLEY IS LINKED TO NEWARK
description: NEWARK THE most important literary figure to come out of this city was Stephen Crane. Now comes major evidence that Percy Bysshe Shelley, the most sublime of English lyric poets, had significant ancestral links to America, and that those links were in Newark.

title: The 'New' 3 R's
description: The Fitler School in Philadelphia was reported the epitome of a ''new trend'' in public elementary education in March 1977. As an alternative school, it did not offer the usual progressive techniques.

title: THE WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: Wholesale prices rose six-tenths of a percent in December, or at an annual rate of 7.2 percent - the same as November's increase. For the year, wholesale, or producer, prices increased 11.7 percent, slightly less than the year before.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: WATER IS FRANCHISED TROUBLE IN JERSEY
description: The water shortage that has plagued northeastern New Jersey for the last several months is largely, but not entirely, the result of inadequate rainfall. To some extent it also is the product of New Jersey's policy of honoring water sales franchises that amount to inviolate territorial monopolies, regardless of whether a franchisee can supply sufficient water to meet customer demand.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a chart appearing on Page 53 of today's National Economic Survey, the leading cable television companies are incorrectly listed. The largest companies in the field, ranked by Television Digest according to the number of subscribers, are: Teleprompter, 1,337,515; American TV, 1,220,000; Tele-Communications, 1,034,000; Cox Cable Communications, 883,585; Warner-Amex Cable, 725,000; TimesMirror, 545,361; Storer Cable, 534,100; Viacom, 467,000; Sammons, 398,386; UA-Columbia, 380,000.

title: BELFAST PRISONERS CONTINUE THEIR PROTEST OVER CLOTHING
description: The Northern Ireland prison protest, which is one of Britain's major international embarrassments, appears now to turn upon a dispute over sweaters and slacks.

title: No Headline
description: In the not too distant future, test programs for complex circuit boards will not be written by engineers, like myself, but by computers, or even the circuit boards themselves. Then I'll have to look for other work! But there won't be any. The robots and computers will have all the jobs. JEFFREY H. ROBBINS, Long Beach, N.Y.

title: St. John's Trounces Providence by 83-63
description: St. John's completely dominated Providence last night and scored an easy 83-63 victory before a crowd of 6,042 at Alumni Hall. It was the type of basketball game that had the fans heading for the exits with six minutes left. With 2 minutes 19 seconds to play in the game, Coach Lou Carnesecca of St. John's sent in Tim Cluess, who had played a total of one minute all season, and Mark Calzonetti, whose total playing time had been five minutes.

title: STUNNING FOR SUNNING ; A bikini may not be the suit for an avid swimmer because it tends to slip and slide a bit in the surf. But for a die-hard sun worshipper, a two-piece suit is the next best thing to nothing at all.  Here are some new versions for 1981.
description: Striped acrylic bikini, $29, with a matching acrylic varsity-style cardigan sweater, $55. By Monika Tilley for Elon. At Saks Fifth Avenue in March.

title: Sarah Wyatt Smith Wed to William Escher
description: St. Peter's Episcopal Church in South Dartmouth, Mass., was the setting yesterday morning for the marriage of Sarah Wyatt Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter H. Smith of South Dartmouth, to William Jon Escher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Escher Jr. of Toluca Lake, Calif. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Benjamin Lee Lentz.

title:
Dining Out;
TWO REASONS FOR AN INN'S POPULARITY
description: WHEN a restaurateur is very much there and caring, not only does it make the patrons feel pampered, but it also affects the attitude and performance of the staff. Steve Leanheart, the genial owner of Steve's Wortendyke Inn in Midland Park, near Wyckoff, is just such an attentive host.

title: Labor and Business Amity
description: This does not mean that all will be harmony in 1981, the 100th anniversary of the American Federation of Labor, particularly as business groups seek to turn the conservative trend of the election to their legislative advantage.

title: Escalating Salaries Blamed on Owners
description: To the Sports Editor: In reply to Ben Calderone's letter ''No Baseball Player is Worth $12 Million,'' (Mailbox, Dec. 28) I'd like to say, no pro athlete is overpaid. It's the owners who give them the money.

title: CLASS OF '81 TAKES OVER AT THE TOP 1
description: AN unusually large number of major corporations will come under the direction of new executives this year. In what seemed like a tumultuous high-level reshuffling in 1980, executives who had been scrupulously groomed to accept the levers of power were named to replace retiring chieftains, while others were swept into top positions after stormy dismissals that cleaned out several corporate suites.

title: Pacers 106, Bucks 102
description: Billy Knight scored 21 points, including a pair of free throws that capped a 6-point Indiana burst in the closing minutes that carried the Pacers to victory over Milwaukee last night.

title: U.S. HELPS CAMDEN WITH TEEN PREGNANCIES
description: CAMDEN IN AN effort designed to cut a teen-age pregnancy rate that is almost three times the state average, the Federal Government has given Rutgers University a $450,000 grant to provide support and medical care for young pregnant girls in Camden.

title: When an Ill Wind Crosses State Lines
description: In a novel twist on the roles usually played in such disputes, local environmental guardians in Louisville, Ky. sued the Federal Environmental Protection Agency last week, charging regulatory laxity.

title: PROFIT GAINS AHEAD, BUT MOSTLY FROM INFLATION
description: ALTHOUGH analysts expect overall corporate profits to increase by about 10 percent this year over 1980, much of the gain will be simply the result of inflation. Still, certain sectors are expected to outperform the inflation rate, while others should be laggards.

title: 16 Food Establishments Fail Sanitary Inspection
description: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 16 food establishments that it said had violated the Health Code. The department also named five restaurants that had reopened after correcting earlier violations and one that was closed for failing to do so.

title: TROUBLE, TROUBLE
description: LOVE By Susan Fromberg Schaeffer. 390 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $14.95.

title: COWBOYS, CHARGERS ARE FAVORED TODAY
description: The National Football League's two conference championship games will be played today, the first in Philadelphia between the Eagles and the Dallas Cowboys under raw conditions (cold and wind); the second matching the Chargers and the Oakland Raiders in San Diego, where the forecast is for mild and sunny weather.

title: Tides of Terror Rise in Salvador
description: Striving to present the Reagan Administration with competing faits accomplis, El Salvador's extreme right and left last week redoubled attacks on supporters of the centrist junta, which has the backing of the outgoing Carter Administration.

title: The E.P.A.
description: To the Business Editor: In ''The E.P.A. Could Be Expendable'' (Dec. 21), I used the White House critique of the Environmental Protection Agency's new carbon monoxide standards to question the worth of the E.P.A. The critique, by the Regulatory Analysis Review Group, produced startling results: the E.P.A. wanted to impose standards carrying a society-wide cost of up to $250,000 for each sick day avoided by any person sensitive to carbon monoxide.

title: NOTRE DAME IS UPSET BY MARQUETTE, 54-52
description: Glenn Rivers, a freshman guard, banked in a 30-foot shot at the buzzer, lifting Marquette to a 54-52 college basketball upset of Notre Dame today. The loss ended an eight-game Irish winning streak.

title: 3 MORE FOUND SAFE AFTER FIRE IN HOME FOR AGED
description: As firefighters went through the ruins of the Beachview Rest Home today, officials lowered their estimate of the number believed to have died in the early-morning fire there yesterday from 33 to 30.

title: EVEN MIRACLES HAVE THEIR PRICE, GREEN REVOLUTIONARIES DISCOVER
description: In the 1960's, the conviction dawned on many people that if continued population growth was not matched by dramatic increases in the world's food supply, large parts of the globe would face widespread hunger and famine. One response to this potential crisis was the ''green revolution,'' a term first used to herald the development, by American plant geneticists working in Mexico and the Philippines, of dwarf varieties of wheat and rice capable of doubling or tripling yields per acre in those regions. The new plants had shorter, stiffer stems and, if heavily fertilized and irrigated, could produce much larger heads of grain that did not fall over from their own weight.

title: I.B.M.
description: To the Business Editor: In ''I.B.M.: The Making of a Chief Executive'' (Dec. 21) the outgoing chief executive, Frank Cary, forthrightly reveals that ''his singular disappointment during his tenure is that I.B.M. stock has hovered between 15 and 20 times earnings, compared with earnings multiples under the previous chairman of 40 and 50.''

title:
COMMENT;
THE REAGAN QUESTION
description: C AN Donald T. Regan, chairman of Merrill Lynch and President-elect Ronald Reagan's choice for Treasury Secretary, navigate the treacherous policy shoals as successfully as the Merrill Lynch bull steps around the china? Mr. Regan faces a tricky passage from chief of one of the country's most powerful private financial institutions to the top of government finance. Wherever he turns at the Treasury, he will find old problems but a new perspective. Most of these problems, whether technical or headline-makers, will involve huge sums of money.

title: Index; International
description: Around the World 4 Soviet reduces natural gas to West Germany and Austria 5 Belfast prisoners continue protest over issue of uniforms 6 Six families try to prove Arabs and Jews can coexist in Israel 7 Canadian west: brash, rich, and feeling neglected 8 Turkey gains a victory in battling attacks on diplomats 9 Poles study broad relaxation of censorship regulations 11 Christopher has ''very good'' meeting with Algerian official 14 India's farmers show increasing militancy for higher prices 15 Salvadoran soldiers said to kill 22 youths in a house 16 Indonesia resettles many from crowded Java and Bali 17 London bargain seekers trample on Harrods' dignity 19 Energy Kuwait raises price of its oil 12 Government/Politics Political standoff continues in Puerto Rico despite election 20 Justice Dept. says 1976 mine recovery team was negligent 22 Prosecutors rejected a guilt plea to break-ins by the F.B.I. 24 Plains, Ga., plans a party to wel- come Jimmy Carter back home 24 A young Congressman completes his first lessons 24 Democrats seek Nixon tapes covering 3-month period 26 Carlucci gets No. 2 job in Defense Department 26 Nazis and counter-group proceed with plans for Buffalo rally 33 Jurors in Abscam trial give de- tails on Lederer conviction 36 Transit Authority is assailed for poor use of a Brooklyn building 38 General Around the Nation 20 One of coldest winters in years belting Northeast 20 Renewed Social Security deduc- tions a shock for some 29 Defendants charge discrimination in Federal jury selection 30 Jury continues study involving Sinatra and a theater 31 Keansburg maintains vigil as hunt for fire victims continues 32 Industry/Labor U.S. seeks promises of coopera- tion in Chrysler rescue plan 35 Education/Welfare Cooke gives $500 to Neediest Cases Fund 42 Arts/Entertainment ''Tristan'' at the Met 50 Music debuts in review 50 Pauline Koner dancers open a Riverside Church series 51 Marti Renzi and Dancers at the Kitchen 51 Style The four new Congresswomen on the issues 52

title: FROSTBITE PREVENTATIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: PRODUCTIVITY ISSUE IS GROWING IN IMPORTANCE
description: IN 1910, each American farm worker supplied enough food products for 7.1 people. In 1940, each farmer supplied 10.7 people. By the beginning of the 1980's, each farmer supplied more than 65 people.

title: GRUMMAN OUTLOOK NOT TIED TO BUSES
description: THE future financial success of Grumman's much-beleaguered Flxible bus-manufacturing subsidiary will depend more on whether the Reagan Administration reduces Federal support of mass transit programs than on the cost of repairing New York City's 637 Flxible buses under the agreement the company and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority reached last week.

title: St. Joseph's 44, Jacksonville 42
description: Bryan Warrick scored the last 5 points tonight, including a 3-point play with 1:01 to play, to lift St. Joseph's a 44-42 victory over Jacksonville.

title: PORTIONS OF COUNCIL: DRAFT REPORT
description: Following is a portion of the executive summary of a draft report entitled ''Cooperation and Conflict: Regulating Coal Production,'' prepared by the staff of the United States Regulatory Council:

title:
ART;
'MANY SHADES OF WHITE' CELEBRATES WINTER
description: PORT WASHINGTON TO celebrate the season of snow and ice, the Graphic Eye Gallery's art exhibition, ''Many Shades of White,'' concentrates on prints in which color is subdued or absent. The show features a number of winter landscapes and quite a few examples of embossment, the process by which the paper is impressed with an uninked plate or other object to create relief effects.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because the information was not available, the legend material in Steve Heller's review of ''Of Mice and Magic'' (Dec. 21), did not specify that the book was published simultaneously in hardcover by McGraw-Hill Book Co. at $19.95 and in trade paperback by New American Library (in its Plume line) at $9.95.

title: HUNDREDS SEARCH IN ATLANTA AFTER DISCOVERY OF SKELETONS
description: Walking shoulder to shoulder, hundreds of police officers and volunteers searched heavily wooded areas here today following the discovery yesterday of what may be the skeletons of two of the 16 black children who disappeared from their Atlanta-area homes over the past 18 months. But no additional clues were found by nightfall and the search was suspended.

title: Titan Called Safe But Could Be Safer
description: Having just had cause to be very sorry, the Air Force reported on the Titan 2 missile system last week and implied that it is better to err on the side of safety.

title: South Korea Easing Ban On Political Activities
description: South Korea's martial law command announced today that it would ease its seven-month-old ban on political activities, beginning Monday, for presidential elections that are expected by spring.

title: REGIONS: CONNECTICUT
description: THIS state has been thriving on its defense industry and, with the incoming Reagan administration promising even more military spending, economic planners here see further growth ahead. In a state with a opoulation of 3.2 million squeezed into 5,009 square miles, 90,000 are employed in defense-related work, up 5,000 over the last few years. That has helped keep the unemployment rate between 1.5 and 2 percentage points below the national average of about 7.2 percent. The major defense company in Connecticut - which as helped the state win more armament contracts than all but three others and become the most heavilty defense-dependent in the nation - is the United Technologies Corporation. The company's Pratt & Whitney Aircraft division employs 38,000 workers here, mainly in the central portion of the state. While there has been plenty of work building engines for Air Force jet fighters, a record $600 million order for jet engines placed last year by Delta Air Lines virtually assures them employment through the decade.

title: No Headline
description: How to Discourage Foreign-Service Careers To the Editor:

title: OPERA: WAGNER 'TRISTAN' SUNG AT THE METROPOLITAN
description: Wagner did not invent the idea of love as a form of premature death, but he certainly did more than anyone else to popularize the concept in the 19th century. While the intertwined nature of these two forces may not strike everyone as unarguable truth in 1981, there is enough vitality in the notion to keep a modern audience enraptured at a good performance of ''Tristan und Isolde.'' The Metropolitan Opera's revival of the work last night proved to be a generally enrapturing experience, even though it fell short of musical excellence on some points.

title: CHAMBER MUSIC SERIES
description: Four chamber music concerts will be given at the Pequot Library in Southport beginning Thursday, under the auspices of Yale University's School of Music.

title: No Headline
description: Perhaps a clue to the artificial-intelligence scientists' dilemma about whether or not a machine is thinking may be found in the way that humans learn, store and retrieve information.

title: DORIS LESSING IN THE VISIONARY MODE
description: THESIRIANEXPERIMENTS The Report by Ambien II, of the Five. Canopus in Argos: Archives. By Doris Lessing. 288 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95. By ROBERT ALTER

title: POLLY FORD IS MARRIED TO EDWARD A. ROSTEN
description: The marriage of Polly Ford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herald Hayes Ford of Wellsville, N.Y., to Edward A. Roston, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward H. Roston of Hewlett, L.I., took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. AlleganyCounty Court Judge William Serra performed the ceremony.

title: Canadian Films Set For Series at the Modern
description: Several hundred animated, documentary and fiction films from Canada will be screened at a retrospective of the National Film Board of Canada, beginning Jan. 22 at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street. French and English short and feature-length films are included in the retrospective, which will run through Sept. 15 and cover more than 40 years of film making.

title: Niatross Unhurt by Fire That Kills 14 Broodmares
description: A fire tonight at the Castleton Farm near Lexington, where Niatross is at stud, killed 14 broodmares in foal, according to the farm manager, John Cashman.

title: Pamela Cook Thomas Is Engaged to John T. Strohmeyer
description: Announcement has been made by John C. Thomas Jr. of New York and Locust Valley, L.I., of the engagement of his daughter, Pamela Cook Thomas, to John Taylor Strohmeyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Strohmeyer of Bethlehem, Pa.

title: CONFIRMATION ISN'T THE ONLY AIM OF THE PROCESS
description: WASHINGTON ONLY eight Cabinet nominees have ever been turned down by the Senate (unless you count, as two, the fellow President Coolidge had rejected twice). And, as confirmation hearings for Ronald Reagan's nominees began last week, there seemed to be almost no chance that Alexander M. Haig, Jr., Mr. Reagan's choice for Secretary of State, would be the ninth.

title: MYSTERIOUS INSTITUTION
description: ANCIENT SLAVERY AND MODERN IDEOLOGY By M.I. Finley. 202 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95.

title: Andree Devendorf, James C. Dreyfous To Be Wed May 30
description: The engagement of Andree E. Devendorf to James C. Dreyfous, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules S. Dreyfous of Salt Lake City, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Waldo Hutchins 3d of New York and Glen Head, L.I., stepfather and mother of the future bride.

title: SOVIET NATURAL GAS FOR WEST CURTAILED
description: Natural gas distributors in West Germany and Austria disclosed yesterday that the Soviet Union had informed them that natural gas supplies in the first quarter of this year would, for technical reasons, be a third below agreed amounts.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
After New Year's, Happy Markdown!
description: Just after New Year's, most prices were reduced by as much as 20 percent at Scarborough Fair, a Bronxville gift shop and tea room, with markdowns on holiday merchandise up to 40 percent. The reductions remain in effect throughout the month on some household and kitchen wares and on some jewelry and toys. The charges on consignment items and on home-cooked and home-baked foods, however, will not change.

title: FOR JACK NICKLAUS, THERE ARE OMENS OF GREATER GLORY
description: f1033 By DAVE ANDERSON

title: by Peter G. Davis
description: Nothing embarrasses hardened 20th-century sensibilities more than a militant visionary. Take Allan Pettersson, the Swedish composer who died last June at the age of 68. ''I am a voice crying in the wilderness,'' he once wrote, ''a voice that is threatened to be drowned in the noise of the times....When I work I forget about Pettersson of whom I am sincerely tired. But then, inside my ribs, is a square, the heart's red square, where I meet mankind, where everybody always lives and where everybody is one.'' Statements like that automatically invite a sneering reponse from today's ''sophisticates.''

title: PARTY LINES ARE GETTING ALITTLE FUZZY
description: ALTHOUGH the Island has stronger party organizations than New York City or many other areas of the state, a breakdown in party politics is evident in the bipartisan action of Long Island politicians in just the last few months.

title: THE GENESIS OF A KOSHER RESTAURANT
description: PELHAM WHEN Cathy and Chris Cunningham went into business, they said, they thought of calling themselves Cunningham Kosher Caterers. ''But we didn't think our name would go well with matzah balls,'' said Mr. Cunningham, who had cooked in kosher establishments from the Catskills through Florida.

title: Food; SALADS FOR ALL SEASONS
