description: When the word ''salad'' is bandied about, the image that springs to mind is a simple concoction of one or more varieties of greens tossed together in a bowl. The fact is that some of the most interesting salads in the modern vein are fairly substantial, salads that can easily serve as a main course any season of the year. These salads also are great for party giving because they stand nobly as a buffet item.

title: Kings 99, Jazz 92
description: Phil Ford scored 10 of his 20 points in the fourth quarter and Scott Wedman hit 7 consecutive points for Kansas City in the final four minutes to rally Kansas City over Utah.

title: The New Contempt for Civil Rights
description: A local judge in Alexandria, La., has given a perverse twist to an old racial story. A generation ago many Southern black children needed armed escorts to attend desegregated schools. Last week Judge Richard Lee provided constables, state troopers and even himself as escorts - all to help three white students avoid a desegregation order. The theme that unites the old and new is state court defiance of Federal authority. Once again is heard the transparent claim of states' rights to nullify a Federal civil right. Once again a strong but measured Federal response is needed to contain the fight and maintain respect for the law.

title: THE COPYRIGHT LAW AND DANCE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Nicholas Arcomano, counsel for SESAC, Inc., is a member of the American Bar Association and chairman of a subcommittee on problems of choreographic works. He contributes to Dance Magazine. BY NICHOLAS ARCOMANO

title: CARLUCCI GETS NO. 2 PENTAGON JOB AS WEINBERGER WINS A STRUGGLE
description: Caspar W. Weinberger, the Defense Secretarydesignate, apparently prevailed today in a struggle over control of the Defense Department as President-elect Ronald Reagan's transition office announced that Mr. Weinberger's choice, Frank M. Carlucci, would be Deputy Secretary of Defense.

title: WARRING STYLES ON THE BAROQUE OPERA BATTLEGROUND
description: C ontroversies about performance practice are nowhere so fierce as in Baroque opera, given the complexity and variety of the form. And since Baroque operas can less feasibly be performed by modern opera houses than recorded in the studio, the tangible results of the controversy can best be heard on disks. In the past year, two Baroque opera recordings have appeared that can stand as demonstrations of the principal opposing views on the matter - and of the difficulties of importing unusual, expensive albums into the United States.

title:
GARDENING;
THE PINEAPPLE AS A HOUSEPLANT
description: AMONG the more interesting groups of plants adapted to indoor culture are the bromeliads. Almost all are native to the Western Hemisphere and range in habitat from the southern United States to the slopes of the Andes. Most are found in warm climates and are not sufficiently resistant to cold to be grown outdoors in our country other than in the southernmost regions.

title: Miss Barry Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip Barry of Brentwood Park, West Los Angeles, and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Stephanie Anne Thankful Barry, to Mark William Agnew, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Wilson Agnew 3d of West Boxford, Mass. The future bride's mother is Patricia Barry, an actress.

title: RENEWED SOCIAL SECURITY DEDUCTIONS SHOCK SOME
description: When Edmund Obregon received his paycheck this week, it was for $38 less than the checks he had received in December. It was not that Mr. Obregon, who is manager of sales promotions for the Prudential Insurance Company here, had got a pay cut or that his salary in December was greater than now.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article about a child-custody case involving an interracial couple that appeared in the Long Island Weekly on Dec. 21, 1980, the views of Dr. David Bearison, an associate professor in the doctoral programs in education and development at the City University of New York, were given incorrectly. Dr. Bearison believes that race is an important factor to be considered in a custody case, but not the sole criterion.

title: HOLISTIC HEALTH CARE GAINING SUPPORT
description: HOLISTIC health or holistic hoax? is what the American Medical Association's journal once titled an editorial concerning this controversial approach to health. Despite the skepticism, medical professionals have been taking a second look at the holistic approach to health and healing, and the A.M.A. has sponsored a holistic medicine and health-care symposium.

title: WHY DEFENSE COSTS SO MUCH
description: WASHINGTON W HEN President Carter sends his final military budget to Congress this week, it will call for spending almost $200 billion in fiscal 1982, up 14.5 percent from the previous year, and will project further increases that will result in spending more than $1 trillion in the next five years.

title: Constance Comstock, Banker, Bride of James Abrams 3d
description: Constance Comstock of New York, an assistant vice president with the private-banking division of Citibank, was married yesterday in Essex, Conn., to James S. Abrams 3d, a member of the New York Stock Exchange. The Rev. Joshua L. Crowell, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Peter H. Comstock, the bride's parents.

title: Tennessee Coaches Backed In Dispute on Team Prayers
description: Tennessee coaches who defied the State Attorney General and encouraged their football teams to pray were commended yesterday by the state Board of Education.

title: A MOVABLE FEAST IN A SEAGOING CONDOMINIUM
description: For years it has been an acknowledged status symbol to own a vacation condominium in Palm Beach, Torremolinos or the Caribbean. But how about owning one that can move to all three --and to the Greek islands, Hawaii and the South Seas as well?

title: Elizabeth Watson Ellis Is Wed
description: Elizabeth Watson Ellis of Dedham, Mass., was married there yesterday to John Adams Blanchard of Needham, Mass., a widower and retired senior vice president of the First National Bank of Boston. The Rev. Blayney Colmore performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church. The bride has seven children from her marriage to Dr. F. Henry Ellis Jr. of Brookline, Mass., which ended in divorce. Mr. Blanchard and his first wife, Mary Procter Blanchard, had five children.

title: UBIQUITOUS SHERLOCK HATS POINT TO OBVIOUS DEDUCTION
description: The houndstooth deerstalkers favored by Sherlock Holmes, with devotees of the great detective under them, are popping up on midtown Manhattan streets this weekend like mushrooms after a spring rain, puzzling strollers and startling more than a few hat-check attendants.

title: MONITORING THE SEA OFF SANDY HOOK
description: SANDY HOOK UNTIL recently, scientists at the National Marine Fisheries Laboratory here used to dive in regulation scuba gear. However, when they started developing warts on their hands, and when testing indicated that the water was contaminated with polio, cholera, salmonella and dysentery viruses, they refused to dive without special protection.

title: The Special Pleasures of Going to the Movies in Rome; The lights dim and the action-packed commercials begin; only rarely is the feature film the first item on the screen.; Randy Jones
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- KERRY GREEN is a freelance writer who lives in Rome. By KERRY GREEN

title: LOS ANGELES SEEKING EARTHQUAKE SAFETY
description: City officials, seeking to limit casualties, have embarked on a 15-year program to reinforce or raze 8,000 buildings they say would be unsafe in the massive earthquake that geologists contend is inevitable some day in southern California.

title: Wake Forest 73, Clemson 71
description: SALEM, N.C., Jan. 10 (UPI) - Guy Morgan scored the last 3 points of the game on a jumper and a free throw in the final 10 seconds tonight to give undefeated Wake Forest a 73-71 victory over Clemson.

title: China's Premier Urges U.S.  To Change Policy on Korea
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang accepted an invitation today to visit North Korea and said the United States should withdraw its troops from South Korea and conclude a peace agreement with the Pyongyang Government.

title: HOLLYWOOD ON THE POTOMAC
description: WILL a poet read at Reagan's inauguration, as James Dickey read at Carter's? ''Negative,'' says a ranking member of the inaugural committee. Books rank considerably below fenceposts in the Presidentelect's hierarchy of pleasurable objects. Nancy Reagan confessed to me aboard a campaign plane last summer that she enjoyed ''Sophie's Choice.'' Her husband says his favorite book is the Bible. His own book, ''Where's the Rest of Me,'' an autobiography, was out of print on the eve of the election, a situation that suited the Reagans and the people at Dutton just fine. The reading habits of the Reagan cabinet remain artfully concealed behind the disclaimers of their spokesmen. If there is a novelist with universal appeal among the Reagan organization, it is Ayn Rand, proponent of enlightened selfinterest. Some of Reagan's close advisers, including his director of domestic policy, Martin Anderson, sat at her feet when they were fledgling disciples and a Reagan Presidency just a gleam in the eye of G.E. Theater's host.

title: VIEWS
description: with social security monster cartoon Hy Rosen The Albany Times-Union with Latin America cartoon James Margulies Rothco with Georgia movers cartoon Tim Menees The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette with Reagan's confirmation of General Haig Lou Grant The Los Angeles Times Los Angeles Times Syndicate NO FORMAT SPECIFIED Views A portfolio from around the nation

title: Marist 71, C.W. Post 62
description: Bill DeWinne scored 28 points and grabbed 21 rebounds, leading Marist College to a 71-62 victory over C.W. Post at McCann Center tonight. Marist raised its overall record to 6-6 and gained sole possession of first place in the Big Apple conference with a 4-1 mark. C.W. Post, 4-6 and 3-1, was led by Mike Dias, with 14 points. It was the third straight loss for C.W. Post.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Ford to Carter to Reagan

title: HAIG ON THE STAND
description: Like an experienced general, Alexander Haig approached his confirmation battle in the Senate with his defenses in good order, and he prevailed by attacking the Democrats and the Soviets, two easy targets.

title: THE MIXED BLESSINGS OF MEXICO'S OIL
description: Alan Riding is The New York Times's Mexico City bureau chief. By Alan Riding

title: REMOVING AND REPLACING FLOOR BOARDS IS TRICKY BUT NOT HARD
description: WHEN a board in a wood floor warps, splits or gets stained and damaged so badly that refinishing will not solve the problem, then complete replacement of the board (or boards) is often the only cure.

title: NEW TEAM TACKLES WORSENING INFLATION
description: WASHINGTON THE most immediate challenge facing the new administration is how to arrest and reverse a deeply entrenched peacetime inflation that has exceeded 10 percent annually for two years in a row.

title: Susan Taylor Stout Wed To John Philip Jackman
description: Susan Taylor Stout, daughter of Barbara Martin Stout of Bethlehem, Pa., and Robert C. Stout of Baltimore, was married at noon yesterday in Bethlehem, to John Philip Jackman, son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Jackman of Raleigh, N.C. The Rev. Mervin C. Weidner and the Rev. John W. Fulton performed the ceremony in the old chapel of the Central Moravian Church.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; O.A.U. Head Urges Meeting On Libya-Chad Merger Plan

title: Computer Chess
description: The prize was $100,000, and Carnegie-Mellon University said in May 1980 that it would award it to the first person to come up with a computer program that would defeat the world chess champion. Dr. Hans Berliner, a computer scientist at the university and a former world champion in chess by correspondence, was named head of a rules committee for the competition. He said that no computer could defeat the chess champion in the next five years, but that this was a 50-50 possibility by 1990 and a certainty by the year 2000.

title:
GARDENING;
THE PINEAPPLE AS A HOUSEPLANT
description: AMONG the more interesting groups of plants adapted to indoor culture are the bromeliads. Almost all are native to the Western Hemisphere and range in habitat from the southern United States to the slopes of the Andes. Most are found in warm climates and are not sufficiently resistant to cold to be grown outdoors in our country other than in the southernmost regions.

title: A SENSE OF ECONOMIC EMERGENCY
description: As President-elect Ronald Reagan nears office, there is a rising sense among his advisers that the nation's economy is deteriorating at a rate that will not permit the patient, long-term doctoring he advocated during the campaign.

title: Knicks Down Cavaliers, 104-99
description: Bill Cartwright scored 32 points and Campy Russell made a 20-footer that broke a late 95-95 tie as the New York Knicks downed the Cleveland Cavaliers, 104-99, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

title: MUSIC: LEINSDORF CONDUCTS BRUCKNER
description: When Erich Leinsdorf was music director of the Boston Symphony, his programs often looked fascinating on paper. But in practice they were less impressive; ''prosaic'' was a word often applied to his interpretations. And prosaic was the impression left by Mr. Leinsdorf at his New York Philharmonic concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night.

title: Author's Query
description: For an illustrated biography of Lafcadio Hearn, I would appreciate photographs of his close friends and acquaintances during the time he was in Cincinnati (1869-77) and New Orleans (1877-87). I am also interested in photographs of Dr. George Gould, a biographer of Hearn, and Henry Alden, editor of Harper's magazine at the time Hearn contributed to it. DAVID H. WATERBURY, Sapporo Medical College, Minami 1, Nishi 17, Chuo-ku, Sapporo, Japan 060

title: Van Morris to Wed Susan Shillingburg
description: Susan Ann Shillingburg of Brooklyn, an assistant merchandise representative at the Associated Merchandising Corporation in New York, plans to be married April 4 in Alexandria, Va., to David Van Riper Morris, a market representative with Digital Systems Inc. in Pensacola, Fla.

title: AN ANGRY YOUNG CONGRESSMAN CRITICIZES SPECIAL INTEREST GROUPS S
description: In the session of Congress that ended last month, a bill came to the floor extending a program on juvenile justice. An amendment was offered that would make it easier to send juvenile offenders to adult jails without a hearing, and Representative Michael L. Synar was stunned to see it pass overwhelmingly. When he asked around, he was told that the vote would be used on the Congressional report card of Christian Voice, a conservative religious group that had been very active in the fall campaign.

title: REVENGE FOR THE RUSSIANS
description: The Soviet Union won the 24th Olympiad in Malta, but only on a tiebreak over the Hungarians, who posted an identical 39-17 score. The Russian team - Anatoly Karpov, the world champion, and Grandmasters Lev Polugayevsky, Mikhail Tal, Yefim Geller, Yuri Balashov and Gari Kasparov - thus got revenge for Hungary's victory in the previous Olympiad in Buenos Aires in 1978.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Women's Outerwear At Norwalk Outlet
description: JUST COATS LTD. is a true outlet for an American women's outerwear manufacturer. Low markups from the wholesale costs result in prices 20 to 50 percent below price tags elsewhere. A sale on Chinese down coats at $99, formerly $149, means holiday gift money goes even farther now. Although the manufacturer has been in business for 50 years, the retail business started just three years ago in Norwalk and later expanded to Danbury and Orange. Another shop will open in Springfield, Mass., in September.

title: AIR FORCE MUSEUM NEAR DAYTON DISPLAYS 160 MILITARY PLANES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- PAUL LANE Jr. is an aerospace engineer and freelance writer. By PAUL LANE Jr.

title: OFFICIALS RUSH PLANS FOR COUNTY CELEBRATION
description: ALTHOUGH the county's 300th birthday is still two years away, its historians, the Westchester County Historical Society and government officials are rushing plans into completion for 1983's tricentennial celebration.

title: Deborah K. Tear Fiancee of Student
description: Deborah Kohler Tear, an estates coordinator at Sotheby Parke Bernet in New York, and Byron Weiler Haynes, an architecture student at the Institute for Architecture and Urban Studies here, plan to be married in May in the First Congregational Unitarian Church in Northborough, Mass. Both are graduates of Colgate Uiversity.

title: More on Luggage
description: To the Editor:

GARDENING;
THE PINEAPPLE AS A HOUSEPLANT

Almost all are native to the Western Hemisphere and range in habitat from the southern United States to the slopes of the Andes. Most are found in warm climates and are not sufficiently resistant to cold to be grown outdoors in our country other than in the southernmost regions.

title: THE FUNNY THING THAT HAPPENED TO MR. CLINE
description: To the Editor:

title: EARLY SIMON: WORTH ANOTHER LOOK
description: and Connie's ambition is to be a housewife. So Connie wins the ultimate prize - a husband - Alan. Peggy (Jacqueline Craig) is flighty and fickle.

title: Virginia 63, North Carolina 57
description: Lee Raker and Othell Wilson led a 19-4 run late in the second half today that rallied Virginia from an 11-point halftime deficit to a 63-57 Atlantic Coast Conference basketball victory over North Carolina.

title: Diana Rockwell Fiancee Of Joseph E. Rooney 2d
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Trowbridge Cook of St. James, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Cook's daughter, Diana Elizabeth Appleton Rockwell, to Joseph Edward Rooney 2d of San Francisco, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harry Leo Rooney of San Lorenzo, Calif.

title: CHAMBER: THE JUPITERIANS
description: How did Ludwig van Beethoven spend his time when he wasn't storming the heavens or taking fate by the throat? Why yodeling, of course. Jens Nygaard and his Jupiter Symphony Chamber Players pointed out this and other little known facts about the master from Bonn Friday in an evening of Beethoven esoterica at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Miss Hopfield, Charles Lifland To Be Married
description: Prof. and Mrs. John J. Hopfield of Pasadena, Calif., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Alison Hopfield, to Charles Coleman Lifland, son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Lifland of Princeton, N.J. An Aug. 1 wedding is planned in Princeton.

title: U.N. OFFERS TO CUT GUERRILLA TIES IN EFFORT TO SPUR NAMIBIA TALKS
description: In an effort to get serious negotiations under way at the conference on South-West Africa here, the United Nations offered today to take steps to break its ties with the insurgent movement known as the South-West Africa People's Organization in exchange for South Africa's agreement on a date for a cease-fire in the disputed territory.

title: A SHRINKING LONG-TERM BOND MARKET
description: THE long-term bond market is not likely to disappear soon, as some had feared, but its role in the nation's financial life is diminishing as investors shift to shorter term issues in response to the uncertain direction of inflation and interest rates.

title:
GARDENING;
THE PINEAPPLE AS A HOUSEPLANT
description: AMONG the more interesting groups of plants adapted to indoor culture are the bromeliads. Almost all are native to the Western Hemisphere and range in habitat from the southern United States to the slopes of the Andes. Most are found in warm climates and are not sufficiently resistant to cold to be grown outdoors in our country other than in the southernmost regions.

title: Miss Kreamer, K.B. Andersen Will Be Wed
description: The engagement of Anne Enggas Kreamer to Kurt Byars Andersen of New York, an author and son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Keith Andersen of Omaha, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Harrison Kreamer of Kansas City, Mo. A spring wedding is planned.

title: SHOULD PRIMARIES BE IN SEPTEMBER
description: THESE days, more than a few political leaders and legislators in New Jersey are singing that old favorite, ''September Song,'' for a new reason. They are entertaining the idea that the electoral process this year - and in the years to follow - would be better served if the primary election were held in early September rather than in June.

title: A SNAPSHOT OF AMERICA
description: Despite THe political and legal controversies surrounding the 1980 census, there is no indication that the findings will be any less valuable to a wide range of business, marketing and professional interests this year than in the past.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: THIS is the Hot Stove League season, when official baseball averages are released by the major leagues to keep the fans dreaming of the ''boys of summer'' through the long, chilly winter days.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES MAGAZINE January 11, 1981
description: WILLIAM SAFIRE 9 On Language Hit the Ground Running RUSSELL BAKER 16 Sunday Observer The Reaganites in Power ALAN RIDING 22 The Mixed Blessings of Mexico's Oil The oil boom is energizing Mexico's economy, but soaring inflation and the growing gulf between rich and poor have created new social tensions. JOHN F. AVEDON 26 Exploring the Mysteries of Tibetan Medicine After the Dalai Lama fled Tibet, his physician preserved the arcane secrets of his country's healing arts.

title: A MARXIST AMONG THE CAPITALISTS
description: BERTOLT BRECHT IN AMERICA By James K. Lyon. Illustrated. 408 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. $19.75.

title: THE WOMEN EXECUTIVES
description: The Women Executives

title: MOST OF POLAND'S FACTORY WORKERS HEAD UNION AND TAKE SATURDAY OFF
description: Most workers in Poland's heavy industries appeared today to have defied the Government and heeded the call of Solidarity, the independent labor union, to institute a five-day workweek by not showing up for work.

title: CUT WAGES 4 PERCENT-EVERYBODY'S
description: F ROM the point of view of stopping inflation, the American economy is both too competitive and too monopolistic. Consider the 1979 inflationary facts of life. During the course of that year, productivity (output per hour of work) fell 2 percent and rising OPEC oil prices took an extra 2 percent of the American gross national product. This meant that the nation could only have a noninflationary society in 1980 if the average American's income fell 4 percent.

title: AT HOME
description: WHEN we were growing up, my brother and I frequently vowed to kill each other. Naturally, we will go to almost any lengths to be together regularly now. It isn't just a matter of uniquely shared genes and history. Accepting each other completely, nonjudgmentally, we are free to tell one another the truth as we can tell no one else.

title: DOWN ON THE FARM, HIGHER PRICES
description: WASHINGTON AMERICAN consumers are expected to face 10 to 15 percent higher food bills this year because of drought-damaged harvests last year and increasing export demand. And while higher prices and strong demand are good news for farmers, rising interest rates could put a squeeze on their profit margins as they borrow more this spring for seed, fuel, fertilizer and animals to restock their feeder pens.

title: Numismatics; THE GRAND FINALE; by Ed Reiter
description: All good things must end and the Garrett Sale, coin collecting's ''Sale of the Century,'' is no exception. This landmark four-part sale which began rewriting the record book nearly 14 months ago will come to a close with the final segment that will be held March 25-26 in Los Angeles.

title: SWISS HOTELMAN AND INNOVATOR COMES TO GOTHAM
description: A Swiss developer who advocates the use of psychology in hotel operations has taken a 99-year lease on the Gotham Hotel at 2 West 55th Street at Fifth Avenue on which he plans to practice what he preaches.

title: CRITICS CHOICES
description: ART Every month or two there surfaces a rumor that this London gallery or that is planning to open up in New York. The people concerned come over.

title: THE FREE WORLD AWAITS INSPIRED LEADERSHIP
description: To the Editor:

title: Nancy Reagan Picks Press Aide
description: Sheila Patton, 38 years old, a vice president at Hill & Knowlton, a public relations firm, will serve as Nancy Reagan's press secretary, the transition office of Presidentelect Ronald Reagan announced today. Robin Orr, an Oakland Tribune society columnist, was originally named to the post but served only 28 days.

title: SUDDENLY, A FLURRY OF GUIDELINES FOR THE F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON IN 1978, when Congress was writing the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, a law professor in Washington said he did not understand why the heads of all the Federal intelligence agencies had enthusiastically endorsed the bill. It restricted their power to use wiretapping in the investigation of spies and terrorists. A similar question might be asked about the guidelines that Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti has imposed on the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Why has the F.B.I. welcomed the new rules on the use of paid informers and undercover techniques? And why is the Carter Administration, in its final weeks, releasing a paper blizzard of guidelines for criminal investigators?

title: N.C. State 93, Georgia Tech 68
description: North Carolina State, behind the shooting of Art Jones and Dereck Whittenburg, defeated Georgia Tech tonight, 93-68.

title: Von Lettow
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: WHEN the faces of Ronald Reagan and George Bush are outlined in bursts of red, white and blue fireworks in Washington on Saturday, Felix Grucci Sr. of Bellport will be lighting the fuses.

title: City Council Meetings Scheduled This Week
description: The following City Council meetings have been scheduled for this week: MONDAY - Committee on Economic Development, City Hall, 10 A.M. TUESDAY - Committee on Environmental Protection, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Consumer Affairs, City Hall, 1:30 P.M. WEDNESDAY - Full Council, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Transportation, City Hall, 1:30 P.M. FRIDAY - Committee on Rules, Privileges and Elections, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, 23dfloor hearing room, 250 Broadway, 11 A.M.

title: HAIG LEADS THE CABINET CADRE
description: BEFORE the fact, it appeared that the Senate Foreign Relations Committee might have a real scrap on its hands when it considered President-elect Reagan's choice for Secretary of State. But, in confirmation hearings last week, doubting Democrats on the committee failed to make a dent in Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s assertions that, as President Nixon's chief of staff in the months immediately before the fall, he had done nothing dishonorable or illegal.

title: Time to Ask Questions About Television Viewing
description: David Tyson documented his New Jersey televiewing expertise (Opinion Page, Dec. 28). He did not discuss the restrictions. He failed to mention the cost of duplicate service.

title: Stage View; OF SHEPARD'S MYTHS AND IBSEN'S MAN
description: REGEN KERR FOR THEATER PAGE

title: RENTERS FINDING WELCOME IN HOMES
description: Residents in as many as three-quarters of the communities ringing New York City are busy turning single-family houses into two-family dwellings. So far about 15 percent of the region's homes have been affected by these conversions, and the trend is growing.

title: U.S. PROMISES IRAN $5.5 BILLION ON DAY HOSTAGES ARE FREED
description: The United States, in its most recent set of proposals for ending the hostage crisis, informed Iran that within several days of the release of the 52 Americans it could probably recover more than 70 percent of its billions of dollars in assets frozen by this country.

title: Contents
description: January 11,1981 NONFICTION ANCIENT SLAVERY AND MODERN IDEOLOGY. By M.I. Finley. 8 BERTOLT BRECHT IN AMERICA. By James K. Lyon. 3 COMIC FAITH: The Great Tradition From Austen to Joyce.

title: NEW FREEDOM AWAITS NATION'S RAILROADS
description: AMAJOR piece of legislation, the Staggers Rail Act of 1980, has fundamentally altered the regulatory rules under which the railroad industry had been acting for decades, and the railroads along with their customers are trying to adjust to the new environment.

title: Jo-Ann Verrier Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Verrier of Oradell, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jo-Ann Mary Verrier, to Mark Charles McGuire, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles William McGuire of Stony Point, N.Y. Miss Verrier, who was graduated magna cum laude last May from Douglass College, attends the University of Pennsylvania School of Law. Mr. McGuire expects to graduate next May from Trenton State College. A September wedding is planned.

title: Charles C. Nast, 77, Dies; Ex-Chief of 42d Infantry
description: Charles Coudert Nast, former general counsel of Conde Nast Publications and commanding general of the 42d Infantry (Rainbow) Division from 1957 to 1964, died Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: O'NEILL'S DEBUT CATCHES BOTH PARTIES BY SURPRISE
description: Balancing a budget in which outlays exceed revenues means apportioning pain. The Democrats who control Connecticut's General Assembly have been hinting recently that they would like to do it by adding another one-half percentage point to the state's 7.5 percent sales tax. Republicans, meanwhile, have railed about the need to hold taxes down by eliminating waste and, in some cases, services.

title: George Foca-Rodi, Pianist, Offers Chopin, Beethoven
description: George Foca-Rodi's piano recital at Alice Tully Hall Monday evening trod well-worn ground, including familiar excerpts from the Chopin repertory along with the still more familiar ''Moonlight'' Sonata of Beethoven.

title: Midwives Perform Mammalian Cloning
description: Whether scientists have cloned the first mammal to everyone's semantic satisfaction was a question for the uninformed in the face of an undoubted experimental achievement. Dr. Karl Illmensee, of the University of Geneva, and Dr. Peter C. Hoppe, from the Jackson Laboratory in Bar Harbor, Me., reported using cells from mouse embryos to produce three offspring that are genetically identical with the parent embryos - the first time such a procedure has been successfully performed in mammals.

title: Paperback Talk
description: The quest for Castaneda. Richard de Mille of Montecito, Calif., is a man with a mission. Mr. De Mille, a former university psychology teacher, is determined to discover the truth about the life and works of Carlos Castaneda, whose five books - ''The Teachings of Don Juan,'' ''A Separate Reality,'' ''Journey to Ixtlan,'' ''Tales of Power'' and ''The Second Ring of Power'' - profess to report the author's conversations during an 18-year apprenticeship with a Mexican Indian shaman named Don Juan Matus. These collections of ''anthropological fieldnotes'' have sold over 10 million copies in this country and are among the most influential testaments of the youth culture of the past dozen years.

title: WHEN TO USE A DISCOUNT BROKER
description: W HY would an investor pay $50 in commissions to buy or sell 100 shares of, say, an $18 stock, when he could go to a discount broker and pay $30 or less for the same market order? And if the discounters offer such cut-rate commissions, why is it that they handle only about 8 percent of the stock brokerage business?

title: AT HOME
description: WHEN we were growing up, my brother and I frequently vowed to kill each other. Naturally, we will go to almost any lengths to be together regularly now. It isn't just a matter of uniquely shared genes and history. Accepting each other completely, nonjudgmentally, we are free to tell one another the truth as we can tell no one else.

title:
THE REGION;
Westport Voters Reverse the Tide
description: ''If you don't own a boat, why are you buying the marina?'' That question, put to the voters of Westport, Conn. in advertisements over the last several weeks, apparently made an impression. In a referendum last week, they rejected by a 4-to-1 margin a proposal for a $2.3 million bond issue to replace the city's old marina with another twice its size.

title: REGIONS: MIDDLE ATLANTIC
description: WASHINGTON IT takes a far-sighted visionary to peer from Baltimore Harbor over the top of the White House to Virginia's Blue Ridge Mountains. But, figuratively, that is what planners are doing to lay the groundwork for a Washington-Baltimore ''common market'' of more than five million people.

title: Elizabeth Landreth Wed to S. G. White
description: Elizabeth Jones Landreth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Powis Jones of New York, was married in the chapel of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More yesterday to Samuel Giltinan White, son of Mr. and Mrs. F.L. Peter White of St. James, L.I., and a great-grandson of Stanford White, the architect. Msgr. Christopher Huntington, godfather of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: KEY AIDE IN IRAN VOICES OPTIMISM ABOUT HOSTAGES
description: Sounding an optimistic note, a key Iranian official said today that an answer - ''most likely'' acceptance - on the proposed terms for the release of the American Embassy hostages would be given by Friday, the deadline set by the Carter Administration.

title: CAREY ASKS FOR $240 MILLION FOR STATE DEFICIENCY BUDGET
description: Governor Carey today submitted a $240 million deficiency budget to the Legislature, including funds to cover the costs of the state's collective-bargaining agreements, increased borrowing expenses and a variety of programs in mental health, education, transportation and the Division for Youth.

title: Princeton 66, Yale 50
description: Craig Robinson scored 16 points and Randy Melville and Steve Mills added 14 each tonight to lead Princeton to a 66-50 Ivy League victory over Yale.

title: RECYCLER CHANGES STRATEGY
description: Rockrose Development corporation, a company whose early success with recyling old industrial buildings helped establish a firm market for the finished apartment in loft buildings, has changed its development direction to new construction projects.

title: GOV. O'NEILL LISTS JUDICIAL CHOICES
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill said today that he would nominate Joseph W. Bogdanski, an Associate Justice of the Connecticut State Supreme Court, to succeed Chief Justice John P. Cotter on March 2.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In its statement, the Algerian delegation has raised certain points, which have been considered, in principle, acceptable, and which will, most likely, be accepted by the Iranian Government.'' - Ahmad Azizi, Iran's director of hostage affairs. (1:1.)

title: TINY TOWN WINS 6-YEAR BATLLE FOR OWN ELECTRICITY
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation is giving up a six-year battle against the efforts of the tiny Town of Massena to set up its own municipal power corporation.

PHILADELPHIA THIS gray old town, this dowdy dowager of American cities, is up on the piano in designer jeans leading the band. The Phillies are champions of the baseball world for the first time in their 98 years. The 76ers are rolling at the top of the Eastern Conference in the National Basketball Association. The Flyers, who lost the Stanley Cup final to the New York Islanders last season, are a close second in the Patrick Division of the National Hockey League, one game behind the Islanders.

title: Firefighters Sentenced for Arson
description: Two former North Windham volunteer firefighters have been sentenced to jail terms after pleading guilty to charges of setting a series of fires in the Windham area, officials said. Jonathan P. Jay, 21 years old, was sentenced to two and a half years, and Robert M. Vining, 18, to a year and a half.

title: REGIONS: THE SOUTH
description: ATLANTA WITH some international business decision-makers viewing the Southeast much like a developing nation, the region is expected to continue to attract new investment from abroad, as well as from other areas of the country.

title: REMEMBERING JEAN SEBERG
description: Remembering Jean Seberg Mel Gussow's article on Jean Seberg greatly touched me (''The Seberg Tragedy,'' Nov. 30). Certain incidents in the past seem to stay with you, trivial as they may be at the time.

title: JAPAN GOES COURTING IN SOUTHEAST ASIA
description: Zenko Suzuki last week became the first postwar Japanese Prime Minister not to make a pilgrimage to Washington his first official overseas trip. Instead, he began a two-week tour of the five members of the Association of South East Asian Nations, acknowledging their importance to Japan's economy but treading lightly in deference to popular fears of Japanese ''economic imperialism.''

title: New Designs Ease Old Diesel Problems
description: HILE research goes on for new fuels and alternatives to gaspowered mobility, Rudolph Diesel's 83-year-old invention - the Rational Heat Engine - just keeps getting better and better and looking more like the real choice, at least for this decade.

title: Cordero Makes Visit To Aqueduct Pay Off
description: ''I'm home! I really feel like I'm home,'' said Angel Cordero at Aqueduct yesterday on his one-day return to New York. His ebullience was heightened by a visit to the winner's circle with his first mount, in the fourth race, an experience he has seldom enjoyed since moving his tack to California two weeks ago.

title: All Aboard for Namibia Meeting
description: The South African delegation took a back seat, literally, in Geneva's Palais des Nations last week at the first face-to-face negotiations among all parties to the Namibia dispute. But giving the limelight to local parties in the territory of nearly 900,000 blacks and 100,000 whites did not change anyone's perception of where the real decisions would be made.

title: THE POLITICAL HARVEST ALSO GROWS WHEN PEASANTS RULE
description: SAN ISIDRO, El Salvador ''WE are not going to distribute the profits this year,'' the plantation president said. ''We are going to improve our capital situation.'' He added that he expected coffee production at San Isidro to be 10 percent higher this year than last.

title:
FOOD;
BREAKFAST AFTER THE TRAIN PULLS IN
description: FOR Long Island Rail Road commuters who missed breakfast, Pennsylvania Station offers a hearty opportunity - in New York City style - to brace themselves for the day ahead. Freshly squeezed orange juice, just-baked bagels or melt-in-your-mouth buttery croissants provide a cheerful note and can easily make a commuter forget a late train.

title: NEEDLING JARGON
description: To the Editor:

title: Gallery View; A NEW TEXT ON THE ERA OF DIDEROT; by John Russel
description: One of the good things that happened in Paris in the year 1759 was that the audience could no longer buy seats on the stage at the Comedie Fran,caise. This had always been a thoroughly bad practice, in that the actors felt hemmed in, lost their concentration, and fell into a stagey and unconvincing style of performance. When the audience filed in on May 23, 1759, and saw that the stage seats were no longer there they clapped till their hands were sore. As for the actors, they soon developed a freer, more straightforward, less selfconscious way of playing.

title: SALES OFG AGSOHOL SHOW 50% DECLINE
description: SALES of gasohol, which was introduced on the Island in April 1979, have dropped by about 50 percent, according to the Long Island Gasoline Retailers Association.

title: Minor Quakes Shake Mt. Shasta
description: Scientists are keeping a careful watch on Mount Shasta, where 80 minor earthquakes were recorded this week, because the northern California volcano is part of the same chain of mountains as Mount St. Helens. Mount Shasta was last active thousands of years ago.

title: OLD ECONOMIC ILLS ARE LIKELY TO BURY ANY QUICK CURES
description: Although Ronald Reagan and his advisers appear determined to make the new President's first 100 days ones of dramatic new policies, to bypass what one Reagan adviser last month termed a looming ''economic Dunkirk,'' recent developments demonstrate once again that the new President will inherit economic circumstances bleak enough to make an instant reversal unlikely.

title: DISMAL REDISTRICTING
description: To the Editor:

title: ...ADVERTISERS LOOK CLOSER AT CABLE TV
description: MAJOR advertisers and agencies are slowly beginning to test cable television as an advertising medium. How fast the medium grows will depend on how quickly cable operators and advertisers develop the new technology's place in the advertising spectrum. It also remains to be seen what other advertising media will be hurt by cable's growth.

title: AMERICANS FACE A DIFFICULT ROAD TO 1984 OLYMPICS
description: By CRAIG MASBACK American amateur athletes, having survived the despair that resulted from the boycott of the Moscow Olympics, now look with great uncertainty toward the 1984 Games.

title: No Headline
description: IRAQ CLAIMS A VICTORY NEAR IRANIAN CITY

title: Indiana 78, Illinois 61
description: Ted Kitchel scored a career-high 40 points today, including 18 straight free throws, an Indiana record, as the Hoosiers scored a 78-61 victory over Illinois in a Big Ten Conference game.

title: Elizabeth Ide Downing Engaged to Wed Scott Sartorius, N.Y.U. Business Student
description: Mrs. Edmund R. Beckwith Jr. of Skillman, N.J., and James B. Downing Jr. of Trappe, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ide Downing, to Scott C. Sartorius, son of John M. Sartorius of Tenafly, N.J., and Quogue, L.I., and the late Frances Cauchois Sartorius.

title: COMPUTERS GET A BIGGER ROLE IN MANY L.I. SCHOOLS
description: AT the end of the day, when the last student charges out of her classroom, Judy Beckerman, a Commack teacher, erases the blackboards, waters the plants and makes neat piles of papers and books. Then she ''logs out'' for the day.

title: PLANT-CLOSINGS BILL REVIVED
description: HARTFORD THEIR commitment renewed by several recent factory closings in Connecticut, a coalition of community groups and labor unions is drafting legislation to require prior notice of future closings. Previous versions of the bill were defeated in the 1979 and 1980 sessions of the General Assembly, but Senator William E. Curry Jr., Democrat of Hartford, has announced he will try again.

title: Book Ends; O'HARA, JOHN
description: John O'Hara stands proudly, one hand on his hip, one foot on the bumper of his Rolls-Royce, which has a New Jersey license plate that reads simply: JOH 1. It is one of the more revealing photographs of him in a biography, ''The Life of John O'Hara,'' by Frank MacShane, to be published later this month by E.P. Dutton.

title: Millstone II Plant to Remain Shut Until Safety Report Is Approved
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has told Northeast Utilities to keep its Millstone II nuclear plant shut down until the Federal agency approves a report on a safety injection tank, a company spokesman said today.

title: THE FUNNY THING THAT HAPPENED TO MR. CLINE
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday Observer; THE REAGANITES IN POWER; by Russell Baker
description: The Reaganites in Power Patrick McDonnell

title: No Headline
description: Reserve Leads West In 24-17 Hula Victory

title: NETS PUT UP BATTLE, BUT LOSE TO CELTICS
description: f889 By AL HARVIN

title: EVA LE GALLIENNE: 'IF I ONLY PLAYED MYSELF THAT WOULD BE A BORE'
description: Today is the 82d birthday of Eva Le Gallienne. Four days later, on Jan. 15, she will be on Broadway once again, at the Biltmore, in a play by Joanna M. Glass named ''To Grandmother's House We Go.''

title: ROBERT FROST'S TRUE VIEW OF GOOD FENCES
description: To the Editor:

title: R.M. Wiener Fiance Of Linda A. Fisher
description: Mrs. Harold A. Fisher of Great Neck, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Linda Ann Fisher, to Ronald M. Wiener, son of Mr. and Mrs. William V. Wiener of St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: 4 Arrested in Shootout On the Upper East Side
description: Four men were arrested on Manhattan's Upper East Side last night after a shootout with plainclothes policemen that followed the armed robbery of a neighborhood supermarket, the police said.

title: DROPOUT RETURNS TO SCHOOL TO 'FILL IN THE GAPS'
description: IWAS 19 years old when I decided that one year of college had already been one year too many. I had a career to pursue; far more important that I give it my full attention, rather than waste time buried in textbooks. Adult logic fell on deaf ears. Life would give me all the education I needed.

title: WHITE HOUSE TAPES AT ISSUE COVER 3-MONTH PERIOD IN 1973
description: The 100 hours of tapes sought by the Democratic minority on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee have not been released previously because inquiries into the Watergate scandals focused for the most part on an earlier period of the Nixon Presidency.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ Carnegie Tavern, which is directly behind Carnegie Hall at 165 West 56th Street (757-9522), is a handy place to drop in for a drink or a meal before or after a concert or if you're just passing through the area. But a much better reason for seeking it out is the presence of Ellis Larkins, who has been playing the gleaming black August Forster piano there from Tuesdays through Saturdays for more than two-and-ahalf years.

title: WESTERING JOURNALS
description: WINTERBROTHERS A Season at the Edge of America. By Ivan Doig. 246 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $10.95. By RAYMOND A. SOKOLOV

title: Stamps; NEW PLATE BLOCK SYSTEM; by Samuel A.Tower
description: Collectors of plate blocks of United States stamps should from be paying less from now on under a new plate numbering system instituted at the beginning of this new year by the U.S. Postal Service. But these collectors, who have been complaining about the ever-increasing cost of plate blocks, will shortly be paying more for their stamps - 20 cents a stamp or 25 cents, who knows?

title: ABSCAM JURORS TELL WHY THEY CONVICTED LEDERER
description: Representative Raymond F. Lederer of Pennsylvania was convicted of bribery and conspiracy charges in connection with the Abscam investigation Friday night because the jury rejected his defense that he had been illegally entrapped into taking a $50,000 payment from Federal undercover agents, jurors in the trial said yesterday.

title: Art View; ANDREJEVIC- AN ALLEGORICAL REALIST; by Hilton Kramer
description: For anyone attempting to chart the course of contemporary Realism, the paintings of Milet Andrejevic constitute something of a conundrum. He is clearly one of the most gifted painters of the contemporary Realist school. He brings to his art an unusual sense of refinement - an eye calmly and exquisitely attuned to pictorial nuance. His best pictures achieve a purity of tone and a gravity of feeling unusual in the Realist painting of any period and very different, certainly, from some of the more clamorous Realist styles of our own day. His strongest affinities are obviously with painters of an earlier age, and while his subject matter is unquestionably contemporary -consisting, for the most part, of groups of figures disporting themselves in New York's Central Park - his attitude toward it is not. This, indeed, is the conundrum.

title: By Peter G. Davis; Music: Debuts in Review; Alan Kogosowski, Pianist, Plays 'Appassionata'
description: Alan Kogosowski obviously enjoys making large-scale statements when he plays a recital. At his London debut in 1977, the 28-year-old, Australian-born pianist tackled Liszt's complete Transcendental Etudes, and for his first New York recital last Sunday night in Alice Tully Hall he took on an equally demanding program: Beethoven's ''Appassionata'' Sonata, Schumann's Fantasy in C, Chopin's Fantasy in F minor and Liszt's Reminiscences of Bellini's ''Norma.''

title: LLOYD RICHARDS IS LAUNCHING NEW PLAYWRIGHTS WITH A WINTERFEST AT YALE
description: NEW HAVEN In 1959, when the Broadway success of ''A Raisin in the Sun'' made him suddenly famous, there was agitation in Paramount Pictures' Manhattan executive dining room, where Lloyd Richards had earned pocket money in another metier.

title: Middle Managers
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''The Middle Manager, Oppressed'' (Dec. 28): Isn't it terrible that qualified people have chosen to carry out their business lives as ''men with no choice but to exist as things ...,'' as Earl Shorris put it.

title: MANAGERS ADOPTING LONG-TERM OUTLOOK
description: FOR years, calculating annual bonuses for top managers at Rexnord Inc. was simple: They were linked to howmuch profit managers were getting from the assets thay controlled. Last year, however, executives at the diversified industrial manufacturer tinkered with the old method. There is now a mix of figures to be taken into account, including sales growth, cash flow and return assets. And the mix varies with eah of Rexnord's 65 business units. "The new plan ties in directly with the strategy for each business," Richard Seaman, vice president of corporate planning and development, said. "Our managers understand more clearly what the objectives of their units are." Planning with more distant horizons has become a familiar theme among major American businesses, especially those competing in global markets where foreign competitors, particularly Japanese trading companies, have used the technique to achieve big gains in market share. As a result, the old systems for rewarding American managers have to be adjusted to keep in tune with the new planning. It is critical, executives say, to shift the rewards from quarter-to-quarter profit gains to the achievement of longer term goals. American companies are only "just now getting around to the idea of tying incentive plans to the achievement of operating and strategic objectives," Sterling Livingston, a former professor of planning at the Harvard Business School, said. He now heads his own firm, the Sterling Livingston, a former professor of planning at the Harvard Business School, said.

title: LABOR AND BUSINESS AMITY
description: Although some union leaders are planning to adopt a defensive posture as a new administration, generally expected to favor business, moves into the nation's capital, labor-management relations could actually improve in some areas in the near future.

title: CARDINAL GIVES $500 TO NEEDIEST, 'WHO LACK BAREST NECESSITIES'
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke, Archbishop of New York, has contributed $500 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in recognition of ''the thousands upon thousands of our neediest brothers and sisters who lack the barest necessities of adequate shelter, warm clothing and sufficient food.''

title: NEW HAVEN
description: THE Capitol Market, boarded up with weatherworn plywood, stands empty on the west side of Dixwell Avenue. Across the street, graffiti can be seen in the hallways of old public housing barracks, their doors wide open in the middle of winter. Down one block, teen-aged boys in leather jackets smoke marijuana cigarettes, eyeing the few passers-by. An old man limps across a massive, foreboding concrete courtyard.

title: Caging a Mole
description: As a mole in the Central Intelligence Agency, David H. Barnett bored rather deeply.

title: U.S.C. Topples U.C.L.A. on Shot at Buzzer
description: Maurice Williams made a 20-foot jump shot from the left corner as time ran out today, giving Southern California a 68-66 upset victory over U.C.L.A. in a Pacific-10 Conference game at Pauley Pavilion.

title: DANCE: THE KONER CONSORT IN 3-DECADE PERSPECTIVE
description: Those who are interested in the work of Pauline Koner or in the middle generation of American modern-dance choreographers in general should spend a little time at the Theater of the Riverside Church. Miss Koner's company is appearing there through Jan. 18, its only New York engagement this year, in an ambitious three-program series of recent dances and revivals spanning a little more than 30 years.

title: SHOPKEEPERS CONVENTION: TRYING TO RECAPTURE THE MIDDLE CLASS
description: T HE middle-income American family, beset by an eroding disposable income but still hungry for goods and services, will be the trophy this year in a looming battle royal among retailers. It could be bloody.

title: ENERGY BOOM OVERTHRUSTING WESTWARD
description: EVANSTON, WYO. IN the morning, this old railroad town awakens to the rumble of heavy trucks and the echo of blasting in the rolling sagebrush hills nearby. Just five years ago, Evanston was a quiet retirement community of barely 4,000 near the fishing and wildlife areas of southwestern Wyoming. But overnight Evanston has become a center for the booming Western energy region.

title: BUDGET CUTS THREATEN MUSEUM
description: THE recent decision by the New Rochelle City Council to cut back on its assistance to Wildcliff Museum, part of a general trimming of the municipality's 1981 budget, may have greater consequences than intended. Museum officials say it may spell the beginning of the end for the nine-year-old institution, which last year attra0ted more than a quarter of a million patrons throughout Westchester and the rest of the metropolitan area.

title: TURKEY GAINS TOOL TO FIGHT ATTACKS ON DIPLOMATS
description: Just before Christmas, Sarik Ariyak, the Turkish Consul General in Sydney, was driving to his office when a motorcycle pulled up alongside his car. A rider on the motorcycle pulled out a submachine gun, fired through the car windows and killed Mr. Ariyak and his bodyguard.

title: China's Leaders Said to Be Split On the Sentencing of Jiang Qing
description: China's deeply divided leadership appeared today to have delayed a decision on whether to execute Jiang Qing, the widow of Mao Zedong, as officials sought to reach a consensus on her fate.

title: SAMPLING THE MANY CULTURES OF WEST AFRICA'S TOGO
description: In the small Togolese border town of Dapaong, we stop in a busy tailor shop and ask where to find a restaurant. All work stops as four tailors discuss our problem. The tailor's apprentice, seeing that we do not know our way around, says in clear schoolbook French: ''Come. I take you there.'' He leads us down dirt lanes, past mud huts, toward the dark hills outside of town. Finally, about half a mile from the tailor's, we get to Lafia, an outdoor restaurant with high-life music on the loudspeaker.

title: New Jersey Opinion; GOVERNMENT AND THE OIL INDUSTRY: THE MYTH AND THE REALITY
description: WITHIN the last decade, Americans have experienced major shortages of gasoline in 1974 and 1979 and in natural gas in 1977. The specter of closed factories and long lines at gasoline stations still lingers in our memories and haunts our future.

title: IT'S HARD TO GO BACK TO GEORGIA
description: HUBERT L. HARRIS always thought that, when his glory days in Government were done, he would easily leave the Carter White House and go back home to Georgia to resume a banker's career in Atlanta.

title: SPARKING THE GROWTH OF MUIR
description: H ANGING in one corner is a photograph of a mule, in the opposite corner a fire extinguisher. Along one wall are desks for two secretaries, in sweaters and blue jeans, who answer jangling telephones as people amble in and out. Two men in shirtsleeves, oblivious to everything else, discuss a real estate deal. A legend on the blackboard exhorts: ''Get it done in '81!''

title: WHAT THEY SEE IN THE FUTURE
description: It's the nature of the think tanks to have an opinion on almost anything. What, for example, is in store for the American family? SRI International has given it some thought and says that during the next 15 years or so, the family will grow stronger, ''resulting in a more decentralized, more community-centered, person-honored society.''

title:
THE REGION;
M.T.A., Grumman Heal the Bruises
description: If you were Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and 637 new buses had to be pulled off the streets for repairs after less than six months of service, would you want to buy 500 additional buses from the same manufacturer? Not on your life. But that was the embarrassing prospect under the transit authority's contract with the Grumman Corporation.

title: No Headline
description: The time will come when sex will make no difference in employment opportunities, promotions and salaries. But it has not arrived yet. We will know it has when there is silence on the subject. DIVNA CIPRIS, Morristown, N.J.

title: Phyllis Gelman Will Be Bride In March of Marrick L. Kukin
description: The engagement of Phyllis Gelman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Gelman of New Haven, to Marrick L. Kukin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ira Kukin of West Orange, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: No Headline
description: William Stockton's articles assume that computers are becoming more powerful and in time will be capable of the same informationprocessing ability as the human nervous system. This prediction is based on the decreasing size of the basic computer elements and their tremendous speed.

title: NYKOLUK COACHES TIE IN DEBUT
description: Mike Nykoluk, former assistant coach of the Philadelphia Flyers and New York Rangers, was named head coach of the Toronto Maple Leafs today and said he expected a transition period while the players became accustomed to him.

title: VOLUNTEER MINE RESCUERS CALLED NEGLIGENT BY U.S.
description: Nearly five years after a coal mine explosion in eastern Kentucky killed an 11-man disaster recovery team, the Justice Department is seeking dismissal, on the ground of contributory negligence, of damage claims by widows of the eight miners who volunteered to accompany Federal inspectors underground.

title:
THE REGION;
Drought Emergency Crosses the Hudson
description: Last week, as New Yorkers took their morning showers, put their automobiles through car washes or drew water for coffee or tea, the city's water supply, normally at 89 percent of capacity at this time of year, dropped below 35 percent and set off cries of alarm among officials.

title: PROPHETS AND PROFITS: WHY THINK TANKS THRIVE
description: W HILE most people worry about coping with this year's rising costs of food and energy, a handful of Americans are taking a longer-range view. They are the staff members of the nation's ''think tanks,'' those theorists, academicians and others who are considered prescient by their admirers and intellectual skywriters by their critics.

title: A LEGACY OF ALFRED SLOAN
description: Ten-day auto sales figures are widely regarded as the most immediate, if not altogether accurate, barometer of industrial performance. Many analysts and auto historians credit the late Albert P. Sloan, former president of General Motors, with the innovation.

title: I spent the summer of 1956 with Jean Seberg at the Priscilla Beach Theater, In Plymouth, Mass., as well as time later with her, in Cape May, N.J.
description: We cannot allow the F.B.I., or anybody else, to continue such actions as were apparently involved in the Seberg case. Through the reporting of people like Mel Gussow and Karen Lerner, we, the public, will have better knowledge of past excesses to guide us in making certain they will never happen again. CHARLES T. FISCHER

title: CHAMBER PROGRAM TO INCLUDEBACH
description: MOST Wall Streeters play the market, but the Wall Street Chamber Players have put their stock in music. This newest of Connecticut ensembles takes its name from the New Haven street that has a concentration of cultural activities, as well as the intimate 300-seat hall at 53 Wall Street (formerly the parish house of Trinity Church), its performing headquarters.

title: HOPES RISE IN FIGHT AGAINST SNAIL FEVER
description: Several recent developments have increased hope that one of the great scourges of mankind, affecting an estimated 200 million people in Asia, Africa, South America and the Caribbean, can be brought under control and some forms of it even eradicated.

title: HOW TO REFORM SOCIAL SECURITY
description: I N addition to possible wage increases, millions of American workers, and their employers, are noticing a major change in their first paychecks of the new year: an increase in Social Security payroll taxes.

title: THE ROAD TO VICTORY
description: Aunique event in the world of bridge is in some ways comparable to the grand prix of auto racing or tennis, but more demanding and in a financial sense far less rewarding. It is the McKenney race which takes place each calendar year, ending in Reno, Nev., around New Year's Eve.

title: MIDDLE-AGED WORKERS READY FOR NEW SKILLS
description: To the Editor:

title: Peter Maeck Weds Jessie Sayre
description: Jessie Wilson Sayre, a daughter of the Very Rev. and Mrs. Francis B. Sayre of Vineyard Haven, Mass., and great-granddaughter of President Woodrow Wilson, was married at Christ Episcopal Church in Sharon, Conn., yesterday to Peter Cooper Burritt Maeck. He is the son of William T. Maeck of Greenwich, Conn., and Elizabeth Maeck of New York and Allenspark, Colo.

title: More on Kashmir
description: To the Editor:

title: REGIONS: THE MIDDLE WEST
description: DETROIT A RETIRED Ford Motor Company executive returned recently from a trip to the South with a tale often told here in the industrial Middle West: ''Some people in Atlanta say their unemployment rate is up a point and isn't it a terrible recession,'' he said. ''I told them if they think they have a recession, they ought to come up here and see what a depression looks like.''

title: ONLY 3 ANSWER CALL FOR MATCHING FUNDS
description: ONLY three of the two dozen potential candidates for Governor put their money where their mouths were last week, when the state's Election Law Enforcement Commission issued its first call to those who want matching public funds to finance their campaigns.

title: Maryland 94, Duke 79
description: Buck Williams and Ernest Graham sparked Maryland rallies in the first and second halves as Maryland routed Duke, 94-79, in an Atlantic Coast Conference game today.

title: Georgetown 57 Boston College 55
description: Eric Floyd scored 18 points and Georgetown survived a frantic finish tonight to register a 57-55 victory over Boston College in a Big East Conference game.

title: JAKARTA FIGHTS OVERCROWDING IN BALI AND JAVA
description: This village of 4,000 in the swampy region southwest of the provincial capital of Palembang in Sumatra's Lampung Province is what is known as a transmigration village, an agricultural settlement established as a new home for Indonesians who were willing to leave the overcrowded islands of Java or Bali.

title: Kansas 94, Iona 64
description: Six Kansas players scored in double figures and the Jayhawks shot 57 percent from the field in defeating Iona, 94-64, before a crowd of 14,250 tonight in the Allen Field House.

title: Muncie Powers Charger Offense
description: They sat together on the airplane, one a fullback of the 1950's and the other a fullback of the 80's. Chuck Muncie had been sent here from New Orleans to join the San Diego Chargers and start what he hoped was a new life. Paul (Tank) Younger, the assistant general manager of the Chargers, had been sent to New Orleans to help Muncie begin on time.

title: No Headline
description: How to Discourage Foreign-Service Careers

title: POLICE TERM CIVILIAN HIRING PROGRAM BOTH A HELP AND A HINDRANCE
description: New York City's Seventh Precinct covers the heart of the Lower East Side, from the soup kitchens of the Bowery to the busy shops and stalls crammed along Orchard Street. It is a high-crime precinct - thick with robbers and drug dealers.

title: STAGE: BAM COMPANY IN SHAKESPEARE 'DREAM'
description: IN its first season, the Brooklyn Academy of Music Theater Company got off to a rousing start. David Jones, the director, and Richard Nelson, his literary manager, fielded a repertory of fair-to-terrific productions of rarely seen works by the eclectic likes of Gorky, Brecht and Charles MacArthur. This season, the troupe is taking a somewhat more conventional tack by offering five brand-name plays. The choices are worthwhile, but one worries if Mr. Jones might not be setting himself up for a fall. Classics can be severe tests for the acting mettle of a young theater company that is still shaking down its ranks.

title: Big Board Sets Rules Review
description: The New York Stock Exchange plans an overall review of its rules and the worldwide financial, trading and sales operations of its member firms through a new Advisory Committee on Regulatory Policy, William M. Batten, chairman of the Big Board, announced yesterday.

title: VIOLA RECITAL: KIM KASHKASHIAN AT THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM
description: IF an instrument is played well, it is heard clearly and plainly for what it is: an instrument, whose function is to communicate something more than mere capabilities of fingers or arms. Distracted by the music, one can even forget what instrument is being heard.

title: Dorsett Takes Blame
description: Nobody had to tell Tony Dorsett how many lost opportunities he cost the Dallas Cowboys today in their 20-7 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: STERN SEEKS APARTMENT-HOUSE WATER METERS
description: Legislation to require water meters for all apartment buildings and multiple dwellings has been introduced in the City Council by Councilman Henry J. Stern, who estimated that such metering would cut water consumption by 20 percent in New York City.

title: 'Frankenstein' Poster Will Go to Modern Art Museum
description: That $2 million production of ''Frankenstein'' may have sunk ignominiously as a one-night stand on Broadway, but the distinctive poster for the production will live on in the Museum of Modern Art.

title: EAGLES AND RAIDERS ADVANCE TO THE SUPER BOWL
description: The Oakland Raiders, a team that was considered by some the weakest in its division even before the starting quarterback broke a leg, won the American Conference championship game today, defeating the San Diego Chargers, 34-27.

title: NEW BOOKS ON JOHN KENNEDY DEATH QUIETLY ISSUED
description: For several days, the Macmillan Publishing Company has been moving 75,000 copies of a new book, ''Best Evidence,'' about the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, into stores across the country without the publicity that publishers usually give to what they regard as an important book.

title: Teaching the Arts
description: It is third period in Mr. Chase's classroom, and Rocky has just inhaled the Blob. The students are having a good time in the film-animation class at Columbia High School here. One is working the motion-picture camera while his co-producer engineers supervise the inhalation of one clay figure by another between bright lights and a painted backdrop. Others interrupt their own projects to voice approval and offer suggestions.

title: No Headline
description: McEnroe Beats Connors

title: Chess: Why Did He Pull the Plug?  No One but Hubner Knows
description: Why Robert Hubner resigned his final Candidates' Match with Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland is a mystery, for the West German gave no explanation. A half-hour before the adjourned ninth and 10th games were to have been played off, he went to Korchnoi's room in the Palace Hotel in Merano, Italy, shook hands cordially and left.

title: Doubt Seen On Extra Saudi Oil
description: Saudi Arabia, which had been supplying at least 12 countries with extra crude oil to offset shortages caused by the Iraq-Iran conflict, has not yet renewed its ''war relief'' contracts for 1981, Petroleum Intelligence Weekly reports in today's edition.

title: Middle East Exposure
description: The Leo Burnett Company of Chicago, which already has outposts in much of the non-Communist world, has filled in the blank marked Mideast with an agreement with the H&C Agency of London to set up joint venture agencies in Lebanon and Egypt called H&C-Leo Burnett and an affiliation in Saudi Arabia with the Targets Agency.

title: U.N. NOMINEE ENVISIONS FIRM STANCE
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the Reagan administration's delegate-designate to the United Nations, takes exception to those who find her overall views on American foreign policy ''hawkish.''

title: TEXT OF THE SUBPOENA ON HAIG-NIXON DATA
description: Following is the text of a subpoena from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee ordering the National Archives to produce a log of 1973 White House conversations between President Nixon and Alexander M. Haig Jr., then the White House chief of staff: To Dr. Robert Warner Archivist of the United States Greeting:

title: Red Smith Philadelphia Story
description: TWO hungry young animals with Phi Beta Kappa feet rushed into this town's growing company of demigods, adding another chapter to the Philadelphia Story in the game for the championsip of the National Conference of the National Football League. Wilbert Montgomery, a greyhound with muscles, and Leroy Harris, who runs like an infuriated beer truck, ripped through and around the Dallas defenses for the points that qualified the Eagles for Super Bowl XV two weeks hence.

title: Mrs. Thatcher to Get William J. Donovan Award
description: Britain's Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, will become the first woman to receive the William J. Donovan Award, named for the late major general who founded the Office of Strategic Services in World War II.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: As a 10-year veteran with the Pittsburgh Steelers, Mike Wagner was one of the lesser-known stars on one of pro football's greatest dynasties. By his own count, he says: ''A number of my teammates became bigger than life. I had six or seven future Hall of Famers playing with me. I don't think people realize yet how great these teams were.''

title: CONCERT: U.S. PREMIERE FOR PETTERSON SYMPHONY
description: ''IAM a voice crying in the wilderness,'' the Swedish composer Allan Pettersson said, ''a voice that is threatened to be drowned in the noise of the time.'' On Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, nearly six months after Mr. Pettersson's death, Sergiu Comissiona and the American Symphony Orchestra presented that voice in the American premiere of the Seventh Symphony, composed in 1967.

title: REAGAN, MIDEAST, AND OIL
description: The 1973 Arab-Israeli war resulted in an increase in the world oil price from $2.50 a barrel to $10, and the fall of the Shah sent it to $32. Another revolution in an oil country, or a military conflict that blocks the Strait of Hormuz, the Persian Gulf passage through which more than 58 percent of interational oil exports pass, could send it to $75 or $100. The Reagan administration should seek to dissolve this nefarious connection between Middle Eastern turmoil and the world oil price, for it poses the single greatest threat to peace and prosperity. In so doing, the administration should keep in mind some recent lessons.

title: Austin-Jaeger: Youngsters With Big Shots
description: Tracy Austin led, 4-0, in the first set when Hana Mandlikova tried a backhand drop shot that landed four feet past the net.

title: About Washington; AN ARCHIVIST'S VISIONS OF RED TAPE
description: Just as Dorothy found the horse of a different color prancing in Oz, so President-elect Ronald Reagan should be briefed on the fact that there actually is red tape doled out to Federal workers. On the requisition forms it is designated as ''tape, textile, cotton, 5/16 inch width, red 11105.''

title: Brazil Ferryboat Toll Set at 230
description: The search for victims from the sinking of a ferryboat in northern Brazil ended today with the official death toll at 230, but officials feared as many as 300 people may have died.

title: WRITERS ON NEWSPAPERS FOR HOMOSEXUALS SAY THEIR WORK NOW GAINS MORE
description: RESPECT By JONATHAN FRIENDLY

title: REAGAN ADVESERS ASK FAST ACTION ON BUDGET PLAN
description: Ronald Reagan's economic advisers say they are timing their preparation of his economic package to set the stage for a dramatic 100 days of Congressional action on the Federal budget, aimed at avoiding a legislative stalemate.

title: Plant Set in North Carolina
description: The Reliance Electric Corporation, a subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation, said Friday that it planned to build a $33 million plant near Shelby, N.C., to make large electric motors and generators for industrial customers. It said construction of the 211,000-square-foot plant would start in March and completion was scheduled for late 1982.

title: Egypt Welcomes Proposal For African Parley on Chad
description: A high-ranking Egyptian official today welcomed a proposal by the President of Sierra Leone for a meeting of African leaders to discuss the proposed merger of Libya and Chad, and he said Egypt would be willing to attend with a high-level delegation.

title: FLEET FLU
description: So you're suffering from a fever ... and a headache ... and chills ... and a dry cough ... and the kids are home sick from school ... and your colleagues are missing from work. If it's any consolation, you are suffering from one of the most baffling and interesting of all virus diseases - influenza, the flu. Scientists have learned an enormous amount about the structure and behavior of this virus in recent years, but they remain as confused as ever about how to arrest its frequent rampages around the world.

title: PLAYERS FOR THE NEW YORK KNICKS GIVE $1,200 TO FUND FOR NEEDIEST
description: The New York Knickerbockers basketball team has contributed $1,200 to the 69th annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The donation, representing a contribution of $100 from each player on the team, should be used ''to add some joy to the underprivileged during this holiday season, as that is the wish of the management and players of the New York Knickerbockers,'' Mel Lowell, the team's controller, said in a note accompanying the check.

title: RECITAL: PETER FRANKEL HONORS BARTOK
description: PETER FRANKL paired Bartok with Beethoven in a piano recital at the 92d Street Y on Saturday night. This automatically lent a sober, serious musical tone to the evening, especially because Mr. Frankl chose to explore the profundities of Beethoven's last two sonatas and Bartok's Suite (Op. 14) and Dance Suite, two of the Hungarian composer's most astringent works for the keyboard.

title: 11 Children, Left Alone, Die in Fire in East St. Louis
description: Eleven children, left alone by their mother, died today in a fire that gutted their two-story home. Their mother, Virginia Williams, was jailed but was not formally charged.

title: SALVADORAN JUNTA ENACTS MARTIAL LAW
description: El Salvador's civilian-military junta today declared martial law and imposed a nationwide dusk-to-dawn curfew following last night's announcement by leftist guerrillas that they had begun a ''final offensive'' to topple the United States-backed regime.

title: Connecticut to Grant 9.75% Mortgages
description: HARTFORD (AP) - The Connecticut Housing Finance Authority has announced it will make $20 million available for low-interest mortgage loans on Jan. 19.

title: News Analysis; REPORT TO CARTER ON CITIES: SCHOLARS 1- POLITICIANS 0; News Analysis
description: The urban report of the President's Commission for a National Agenda for the 80's has aroused more animosities across a broad spectrum of political philosophy than any other document on the cities in recent years, even though it has not yet been presented to the President.

title: UConn On the Run (10-0) With Thompson
description: Along the East Coast people will remember Feb. 6, 1978, as the day of the Big Blizzard, when a coastal storm brought up to 18 inches of snow to the Northeast.

title: By Jim Benagh
description: Sports World Specials

title: Name of the Game
description: Last fall, when the Philadelphia Phillies won the World Series, the team found that there were Phillie Phanatics around the world. Recently, the Philadelphia Eagles found that they also have some fanatics in the outreaches.

title: STONES RELAYS VICTOR WITH A JUMP OF 7-2
description: Dwight Stones, the two-time Olympic bronze medalist, won the high jump with a leap of 7 feet 2 inches today in the 12th Dartmouth Relays.

title: CITY BALLET: 2 DISTINCT INTERPRETATIONS OF 'SCOTCH SYMPHOMNY'
description: THE question of how pure is a pure-dance ballet by George Balanchine was subliminally debated by two excellent casts that danced a revival of ''Scotch Symphony'' separately and very differently Saturday with the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater.

title: NEW SURGE OF ARCTIC AIR TORMENTS CITY'S HEATLESS TENANTS and Fifth Avenue
description: As air from the Canadian Arctic continued to bring bitterly cold weather to New York City, a Coast Guard cutter plowed up the Hudson River yesterday, breaking through a growing field of ice to try to keep the route for fuel barges clear to the Port of Albany.

title: TWO SKELETONS IN ATLANTA LINKED TO MISSING YOUTHS
description: The Fulton County Medical Examiner said tonight that two small skeletons recovered by the police here on Friday had been tentatively identified as belonging to two of the four black children missing from their Atlanta area homes for several months.

title: Iowa Auto Workers' Local Votes To Bar Foreign Cars From Its Lot
description: Members of Local 838 of the United Auto Workers have voted to ban foreign cars from the parking lot at union headquarters here, the local president, David Neil, says.

title: CITY TO SELL AN OLD WATER SITE TO NASSAU
description: New York City has agreed to sell Nassau County 1,750 acres of land on Long Island where, for 50 years, millions of gallons of water were drawn to supply reservoirs in Brooklyn.

title: Israeli Is Slain, 2 Injured In Attacks in Gaza Strip
description: An Israeli taxi driver was shot to death in the Gaza Strip today, and an Israeli couple was seriously injured there yesterday by a grenade in what an army spokesman called ''a new wave'' of violence against Jews in the area.

title: SCORES ON SCORES
description: A gambler once said that the best thing about placing a National Basketball Association team on the West Coast was that he could make money while he slept. Then came all-news radio, Sports Phone, ESPN and other outlets for scores and news. No one, the gambler or the inveterate sports fan, is immune from being in the dark about sports news anymore. Self-inflicted insomnia is in.

title: Miss Holtzman Will Teach Politics at N.Y.U.
description: Former Representative Elizabeth Holtzman, who gave up her seat in Congress to run unsuccessfully for the United States Senate last year, will teach two graduate courses at New York University this spring, and may stay on for the 1981-82 academic year if the lure of a political comeback is not too great.

title: Marilyn Lytle Bride of R. Thomas Herman
description: The marriage of Marilyn Lytle, a lawyer with the New York admiralty firm of Bigham Englar Jones & Houston, to R.
