Thomas Herman, a reporter in the New York news bureau of The Wall Street Journal, took place at the St. Moritz Hotel yesterday. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel of Temple Emanu-El performed the ceremony.

title: Bonuses Suggested For 1-Officer Patrols
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire suggested that officers in one-officer patrol cars be given productivity bonuses similar to those for sanitationmen on the new two-man refuse trucks.

title: WITH JOHNSON OUT, THE LAKERS ARE HAVING THEIR PROBLEMS
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif. THAT the Los Angeles Lakers are struggling should be no surprise. After all, there is precedent. It has been 12 years since the Boston Celtics won consecutive championships in the National Basketball Association. That was before further expansion diluted the talent pool even more and before longer seasons increased the chance of injury and before longer individual contracts decreased the urgency of constant effort. In the last 12 years, teams that were called dynasties soon found themselves rebuilding.

title: TV: PREMIERE OF 'DYNASTY,' A SERIES ON AN OIL FAMILY
description: IT'S mighty low-grade crude that comes oozing out of the tube in ''Dynasty,'' which will have a three-hour premiere showing from 8 to 11 P.M. tonight on ABC-TV.

title: MALCOLM MACDONALD, BRITISH ENVOY AND SON OF EX-PRIME MINISTER
description: Malcolm MacDonald, long a British diplomat and colonial troubleshooter, died today at the age of 79. He was the son of James Ramsay MacDonald, who in 1924 became the first Labor Party leader to serve as Britain's Prime Minister. Mr. MacDonald died in the garden of his home near Sevenoaks, Kent, his family told The British Press Association. They said they were awaiting a medical report. Mrs. MacDonald, vacationing in Canada, was expected to return home tomorrow.

title: SCHOOLS AND TAXATION
description: To the Editor:

title: WEST SIDE TRAFFIC COULD GET WORSE DURING WORK ON IMPROVING ROADS
description: Motorists on Manhattan's West Side, who for years have had to yield, merge, detour, bump or simply grind to a halt, can expect matters to get worse before they get better.

title: INDONESIAN OIL FIELDS BOOM WITH PROMISE
description: This sprawling East Kalimantan town of 200,000 on the edge of the jungle owes its start to the timber industry and its present boom to oil.

title: MARKET FOR BONDS VERY FLUID
description: With billions of dollars worth of long-term corporate bonds being readied, calendars of upcoming sales are very tentative. For example, the Conoco and Tenneco issues sold last Friday were not on any calendars at the start of the week; the companies did not even announce their intention to sell debt until Tuesday.

title: William Dunas Dance Program
description: William Dunas, the avant-garde choreographer, will present an eveninglong work of his recent choreography at the Paula Cooper Gallery, 155 Wooster Street, on Feb. 13 and 14 at 8 P.M. The piece, called ''Pyramid,'' will be performed by Pat Graf, Janna Jensen, Susanna Weiss and Mr. Dunas. Mr. Dunas calls it an expression of ''the physicality of the dancer as a performer dancing in an intimate and multifaceted space, comprised of random and synchronous movement phrases.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article by The Associated Press in The Times yesterday stated incorrectly that Ellis Judd Staley Jr., a former associate justice in the Appellate Division of New York State State Supreme Court, was dead.

title: ESPOUSING LIBERALISM, WITHOUT APOLOGIES
description: I am losing my embarrassment. I used to be embarrassed by the platitudes of liberalism, by the self-congratulatory air that accompanied speaking of what seemed obvious: the evils of discrimination, the sufferings of the poor, the hazards faced by coal miners, the famines of foreign countries. We all know these things, I thought. But, then, I also thought, we all had the capacity to feel guilt about them.

title: DERELICT DIES IN FIRE
description: A derelict was burned to death in a fire in an abandoned railroad switching tower under the West Side Highway at 72nd Street, authorities said. The cause of the fire was not immediately determined.

title: U.S. Skier Captures World Cup Slalom
description: PARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Jan. 11 (UPI) - Steve Mahre of Yakima, Wash., taking advantage of a costly mistake by Sweden's Ingemar Stenmark, won the World Cup slalom ski race today.

title: STRONG AFRICA TIES PROMISED BY REAGAN
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan, in a message to an African-American conference here, said today that his administration would ''strengthen our African ties'' by increasing United States ''investment, trade and economic assistance and security-related support'' for the continent.

title: SEOUL INVITES NORTH KOREA LEADER
description: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea today invited Kim Il Sung, the North Korean leader, to visit Seoul and also said that he was willing to go to Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, for what would be the first meeting of Korean heads of state since the peninsula was divided after World War II.

title: RATE VOLATILITY SEEN IN COMING WEEKS
description: Volatile interest rates are now a fact of life in the credit markets, but even the most hardened of traders were startled last Friday when prices plunged early in the day, only to recover all the earlier losses after the Federal Reserve reported a $2.5 billion decline in the basic money supply.

title: Reagan Finishes 'Short' Speech
description: Before leaving by Marine Corps helicopter for his ranch near Santa Barbara for his last preinaugural visit, President-elect Ronald Reagan said at the Santa Monica Airport that he had finished work on his inaugural address, ''unless someone comes up with some better ideas.'' Asked whether the Jan. 20 speech would be short or long, he said, ''short,'' adding that it would last about 15 minutes.

title: CONCERT: GREGG SMITH CHORAL GROUP
description: WHEN the great soul searching of Romanticism had run its course, when the grand social occasions of the 19th century had become oppressively confining and when tonal narrative seemed to have nothing left to say, modernist composers looking for music to plunder often turned to the Renaissance, when life was more formal and more intimate.

title: Arnold of Austria Captures Pro Slalom
description: Andre Arnold, a 25-year-old house painter from Solden, Austria, captured his fourth straight world professional skiing tournament today in near-zero weather.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 12, 1981; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Statistical Commission - 11 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: TRIBUTE TO A TRADE UNIONIST DRAWS THE CITY'S LEADERS
description: ''Everybody else was recognizing her,'' said Jessica Williams of Computer Operators Local 2627, District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, ''and we thought why everybody else when we know her.''

title: LAKERS BEAT PISTONS AS WILKES SCORES 33
description: Jamaal Wilkes scored 33 points, including 12 in the final period, to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 117-108 victory last night over the Detroit Pistons at Inglewood, Calif.

title: PRELUDE TO AN INFORMED DECISION ON CASINO GAMBLING FOR NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: POLAND'S LEADER WARNS FARMERS NOT TO TRY TO FORM LABOR UNION
description: Poland's Communist Party leader, Stanislaw Kania, publicly warned the country's private farmers tonight against trying to organize an independent labor union modeled after Solidarity, a largely urban industrial organization.

title: Boxer Scott Ordered To Be Tried Jan. 26
description: A Superior Court judge has refused to dismiss a murder indictment against the light-heavyweight boxer James Scott and has ordered the Rahway State Prison inmate to stand trial beginning Jan. 26.

title: Last-Minute Transit Pact Averts New Orleans Strike
description: Negotiators in a tense transit contract stalemate announced a new agreement today, less than 10 hours before the strike deadline of 12:01 A.M. tomorrow. A strike would have affected 300,000 bus and streetcar users.

title: HOLDUP MEN KILL OFF-DUTY POLICEMAN IN A QUEENS BAR
description: An off-duty New York City police officer was shot and killed early this morning during an apparent holdup of a Queens bar, the police said.

title: Warriors 106, Sonics 98
description: Joe Barry Carroll and John Lucas combined for 39 points in the second half as Golden State defeated Seattle.

title: Mohave Bus Crash Kills One
description: A charter bus going from Las Vegas to Los Angeles ran off a rain-slickened highway in the Mohave Desert early today and overturned, killing a woman and injuring 27 persons. The bus was operated by the Robinson Charter Lines of La Canada-Flintridge.

title: LENNOE'S MEMORY IS NOT FOR SALE, HIS U.S. FANS SAY
description: ''Imagine no possessions,'' John Lennon sang. ''I wonder if you can.'' Since the slaying of the 40-year-old former Beatle Dec. 8, his legions of admirers around the United States seem to be following his advice, at least in regard to Lennon souvenirs.

title: ALGIERS IS REPORTED STEPPING UP NEGOTIATIONS ON IRAN'S DEMANDS
description: Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher remained in Algiers for a fourth day today, hoping for word from Teheran that Algerian intermediaries had persuaded Iran to accept American financial proposals for freeing the 52 hostages.

title: POLL FINDS AMERICANS OPTIMISTIC
description: Americans are looking forward to 1981 with much more hope than they had for last year or for 1979, and with considerably more optimism than Western Europeans, according to a Gallup Poll of 28 countries made public yesterday.

title: Brewer Plans To Raise Prices
description: Anheuser-Busch Inc., the nation's largest brewer, says it is increasing its wholesale beer prices, effective Jan. 26, as a result of higher production costs.

title: The Economy
description: Reagan economic advisers plan a dramatic 100 days of legislative action on the Federal budget. The advisers said they were also considering ways to ram the program through Congress unhindered. One method would be to promise to veto any rise in the Federal debt ceiling. (Page A1.)

title: Index; International
description: Father of Costa Rican democracy calls for ''emergency'' regime A2 Mrs. Kirkpatrick, Reagan's U.N. choice, hopes for ''input'' A3 Americans more optimistic about 1981 than West Europeans are A4 Around the World A5 Brzezinski proposes expansion of allied economic meetings A7 Italian papers reject demands to print terrorists' statement A7 Iran seems to step aside from $24 billion demand on hostages A10 Reagan tells Africa conference he'll emphasize economic ties A12 General Around the Nation A14 At the Bohemian Club, men join and women serve A16 Defense lawyer in Tarnower murder trial adept with juries B2 Pluses and minuses found in police use of civilian manpower B3 Arts/Entertainment Two separate casts dance Balan- chine's ''Scotch Symphony'' C14 BAM Theater opens season with ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' C15 Emlyn Williams, the actor, a first novelist at 75 C15 John Dizikes's ''Sportsmen and Gamesmen'' is reviewed C17 New book on John Kennedy's assassination reaches stores C17 Dance Theater of Harlem gives program at City Center C17 Equity Library Theater revives the musical ''Godspell'' C20 F.C.C. planning to vote on radio deregulation C20 PARKING REGULATIONS Alternate-side-of-the-street parking regulations are suspended in New York City today because of expected bad weather. SportsMonday Basketball:De Paul takes its first loss of season in stride C7

title: CAMPAIGN AIDES FOR REAGAN FEAR THEY'RE LEFT OUT
description: As President-elect Ronald Reagan was winning praise two weeks ago for selecting so many ''nonpolitical'' people for his Cabinet, tempers among Mr. Reagan's former campaign officials were reaching the boiling point. The officials approached E. Pendleton James, a professional executive recruiter who is serving as personnel director for the transition effort, with their fear that they would be left out.

title: OUT OF A MOTHER'S QUESTIONS, A SCANDEL IN MILK PRICES
description: Six years ago a Parent-Teacher Association committee began checking the ''junk food'' content of cafeteria lunches, and along the way discovered that all the bids for milk contracts were identical.

title: SUPPLIERS OFFERING AID TO CHRYSLER
description: The Chrysler Corporation's suppliers, who have been characterized by the auto maker's executives as the unsung heroes during Chrysler's continuing crises, are now carrying about $200 million in deferred payments, up from $140 million last last month, a Chrysler official confirmed today .

title: 25-YEAR MINISTRY NOTED WITH JOY AND REFLECTION
description: About one thousand members and friends of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, including politicians and Roman Catholic and Jewish clergymen from neighboring houses of worship, filled the Upper East Side church to capacity yesterday to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the ministry of the Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read, one of the country's leading Protestant clergymen.

title: Repair Pace Decried
description: Carol Bellamy, the City Council President, said the pace of the preventive-maintenance program on the city's subways had been ''very disappointing.''

title: CAREY PLANS EASING OF CABLE TV RULES
description: The Carey administration is preparing a series of far-reaching proposals to change the way New York State regulates telephone service and a variety of other industries, including cable television.

title: ATTORNEY FOR JEAN HARRIS OFTEN ADEPT WITH JURIES
description: It was during jury selection in the murder trial of Jean S. Harris that Joel Aurnou, her lawyer, was making a point about appearances being misleading, ''just as sometimes a short, pudgy, balding lawyer can be pretty aggressive.''

title: New Mexico Loses N.C.A.A. Tourney
description: Jim Frank, secretary-treasurer of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, said today that the University of New Mexico would not be allowed to be host to the West Regional of the 1982 basketball tournament. The university is in Albuquerque.

title: 5 MORE BODIES FOUND AT SITE OF FIRE IN HOME FOR ELDERLY
description: Five more bodies were recovered today from the charred shell of the Beachview Rest Home, bringing to 29 the total recovered from the predawn fire on Friday.

title: News Analysis
description: For the Reagan administration, the beleaguered Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in Britain has become more a political object lesson than a lesson in economics.

title: Changes at Sears Unit
description: Albert W. James Jr., 44, has been appointed president of the Sears Roebuck Acceptance Corporation, the financing subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck and Company based in Wilmington, Del. He succeeds Robert F. Gurnee, 53, who was named vice president and treasurer of the parent company in Chicago.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JANUARY 12, 1981
description: International Israel's Finance Minister resigned in a controversy over raises in teachers' pay, signaling the apparent demise of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's coalition Government. Early parliamentary elections seemed certain. When the Cabinet voted overwhelmingly for substantial raises for the teachers, Finance Minister Yigael Hurvitz, who had been trying to deal with the world's highest inflation rate, decided to step down, effective Tuesday. (Page A1, Column 1.) Algerian intermediaries in Teheran reportedly intensified their their talks with Iranian officials on the hostages as Friday's deadline for a cutoff, imposed by the Carter Administration, approached. Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher remained in Algiers, waiting for a decision by Iranian officials. (A1:4.)

title: Bridge: Picking Top Player Is Hard In North American Region
description: If the cognoscenti were asked to select the best North American card player, it is not easy to say who would receive the accolade. No doubt Bob Wolff of Dallas, Sam Kehela of Toronto, Peter Weichsel of New York, and a rising young star, Jeff Meckstroth of Columbus, Ohio, would be among the nominees.

title: No Aqueduct Card
description: High winds and bitter cold forced cancellation of yesterday's ninerace program, including the $50,000-added Rockaway, at Aqueduct Race Track. A spokesman said the track planned to resume racing today. Cold temperatures also forced cancellation of races at Suffolk Downs in Boston yesterday.

title: John Nelson in Debut With Philharmonic Jan. 22
description: John Nelson, music director of the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra , will make his New York Philharmonic debut Jan. 22 when he conducts the first of four concerts he is to take over from James Levine, the guest conductor originally engaged for that period. Mr. Levine, who is music director of the Metropolitan Opera, asked to be relieved of the Philharmonic commitment because of the extra work involved in replanning of Metropolitan schedules following the delayed opening of the opera company's season.

title: British Seamen Begin Strikes After Talks Collapse
description: British seamen began a series of 24-hour strikes last midnight that could affect Britain's deepwater merchant fleet and large segments of its ferry traffic with the Continent.

title: ISLANDERS SCORE 3 IN 2D AND TOP FLYERS, 4-2
description: The New York Islanders and Philadelphia Flyers are considered by many fans to be the two best clubs in the National Hockey League. When they meet, they usually play with emotion and physical intensity.

title: SONG: HARRY CHAPIN'S STORIES
description: HARRY CHAPIN has given 2,000 concerts by his own count, and to celebrate he gave six more at the Bottom Line over the weekend. Remarkably enough, he's still believable as the Singing Cab Driver chronicler and friend of the working man, and not just because he still tends to sing flat.

title: RESOLUTIONS' FATE
description: To the Editor:

title: Confessed West Coast Killer Is Found Strangled in Cell
description: Vernon Butts, who confessed to taking part in some of the ''Freeway killer'' slayings of young men and boys, was found strangled with a towel in his jail cell today. Sheriff's officers termed it a suicide. Mr. Butts's attorney, Joe Inger, said that he ''doubted it,'' but offered no other explanation.

title: Greece Complains to U.S.  Over 1982 Military Aid Plan
description: The Greek Government has formally protested to the United States over the Carter Administration's planned military aid to Greece and Turkey for the fiscal year 1982, saying it would upset the balance of power between the hostile NATO members, Foreign Ministry officials said today.

title: Illuminating the Energy Bill
description: The Connecticut Light and Power Company has developed a useful prod to energy conservation. Its monthly bills carry a notation that reads: ''Kilowatt hour usage shown below was 12 per cent less per day than in the same period last year and it was 15 per cent colder this year.''

title: Shelved
description: The big-money payoffs now prevalent in professional tennis have cut down on the awarding of trophies for victories. To some players - and their families - that is no loss because their homes were becoming cluttered with all that metal.

title: Bucks 123, Suns 109
description: Milwaukee, sparked by 28 points from Marques Johnson, pulled away in the second half. Junior Bridgeman added 21 and Mickey Johnson 17 for the Bucks, who won their 13th straight home game.

title: Baker Enters Hospital For Intestinal Ailment
description: The new Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, was admitted today to Sibley Memorial Hospital here with an apparent case of acute diverticulitis, an intestinal malady with symptoms similar to appendicitis.

title: Miller Posts 65-265, Wins by 2 at Tucson
description: Johnny Miller broke a tie with a birdie on the 17th hole, finished with a 65, and won the Tucson open golf tournament today by two strokes. The event was the opening event on the PGA Tour.

title: PLANNING AHEAD AT INTERNORTH
description: Internorth Inc. has grown from a natural gas pipeline company of modest size into a diversified concern with significant interests in liquid fuels, petrochemicals and exploration. But keeping its headquarters here has given the company a ''land-andcattle'' image on Wall Street, jokes Sam F. Segnar, president and chief executive.

title: FINLANDIATION IS NO ANSWER FOR AFGHANISTAN
description: To the Editor:

title: GOVERNOR TO SEEK TAX CUT TO LURE BUSINESS
description: In the executive state budget to be presented next Monday, Governor Carey will call for at least three business tax reductions that he hopes will have a dramatic effect on bringing new business investment into New York.

title: De Paul Sees Loss As Plus In Future
description: Ray Meyer was attempting to put De Paul's first loss of the season in perspective, but there was no need to. He was obviously a man who had just had a great burden lifted from his shoulders.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In the last two recessions, '69-'70 and '73-'75, when the country caught a cold, we caught pneumonia.

title: A Friend at Justice
description: It may be Benjamin Civiletti's fate to have a number of proud achievements as Attorney General obliterated in public memory by his gross mishandling of one case. It was no thanks to Mr. Civiletti, who withheld intelligence from his own Criminal Division, that the Justice Department was able to force Billy Carter to register as a foreign agent. The Attorney General failed to give his President information that even Billy Carter knew to be in Government hands. He lied about what he did tell the President. And his explanation, drawing what he called a ''fine legal distinction'' about what constitutes talking with the President, was a parody of the lawyer's craft.

title: BROOKS, BACK HOME, PICKS UP PIECES
description: Halfway through the 1981 hockey season the man who coached the United States hockey team to its startling Olympic gold-medal victory last February is not coaching.

title: ASTON MARTIN: CHALLENGE FOR NEW OWNERS
description: The recent acquisition of Aston Martin Ltd., maker of hand-built, high-performance automobiles, by two British companies was the latest twist in a 60-year history that includes two bankruptcies and a succession of owners.

title: Washington Watch; I.R.S. Retreats In Bank Battle
description: WASHINGTON A10-second quiz: Which is, beyond a shadow of a doubt, the most zealous Federal agency? Answer: the Internal Revenue Service. But sometimes it may overreach, as appears to be the case with a revenue procedure published Dec. 15 from which the service has already retreated twice in setting dates for implementation. The betting is that under a new Secretary of the Treasury, the procedure itself will be dropped.

title: CITY IS EXPECTING AN ORDER TO CUT ITS WATER SUPPLY
description: New York environmental officials said yesterday that they expected the city to be ordered later this week to further reduce the amount of water it draws from its principal source - the headwaters of the Delaware River in the western Catskills.

title: STAGE: EQUITY LIBRARY REVIVES 'GODSPELL'
description: WHEN ''Godspell'' was first seen in 1971, it was, along with ''Jesus Christ Superstar,'' part of a small invasion of Broadway by musicals using the Bible as a source and with scores that were at the time identified as rock. In the perspective of a decade, it is evident that Stephen Schwartz's score for ''Godspell,'' as exemplified by such songs as ''Day by Day,'' ''Bless the Lord'' and ''All for the Best,'' is less rock than a contemporary version of the kind of melodic and rhythmic scores that were written by Richard Rodgers in the days of his collaborations with Lorenz Hart, by Vincent Youmans and, musically, by Cole Porter in the 20's and 30's.

title: TERRORISTS' DEMAND REFUSED BY MOST ITALIAN PAPERS
description: Most of Italy's major newspapers refused today to print a propaganda statement by jailed members of the Red Brigades organization, even though terrorists had warned that they would kill Giovanni D'Urso, a Rome magistrate they are holding hostage, unless the full text of the statement was published by the entire press.

title: Ross Roy Agency Names A New Chief Executive
description: Glen W. Fortinberry, who returned to Detroit and the presidency of Ross Roy Inc. a year ago, has now been named its chief executive officer as well, taking that title from John S. Pingel, 64, who had it for 15 years.

title: Boy, 5, Is Killed In a Fire in Newark
description: NEWARK (AP) - A fire destroyed a single-family house, killing a 5-year-old boy, but 15 other persons escaped unharmed, fire officials said.

title: MITSUBISHI SPURNS A CHRYSLER MERGER
description: The president of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation disclosed in an interview that someone approached his company here last month with the suggestion that it take over the Chrysler Corporation, or go into joint car and truck production in the United States.

title: New Munford President
description: Russell C. Fellows, 41, has been elected president of Munford Inc., which operates convenience food stores, imported-merchandise stores and refrigerated warehouses. He succeeds Herbert J. Dickson, 54, who resigned after four years with Munford and almost a year with that title to become president of the McDonough Construction Company.

title: STAR OF 'HAVE GUN WILL TRAVEL'
description: Richard Boone, the actor best known for his role as the hired gun Paladin in the ''Have Gun Will Travel'' television series, is dead at the age of 63. A spokesman at Craig Funeral Home in St. Augustine said today that Mr. Boone's body was to be cremated and a private service held.

title: THE DANCE: THEATER OF HARLEM TROUPE
description: 813 By JACK ANDERSON

title: KALLUR IS ACHIEVING HIS N.H.L. GOALS
description: HE was the best hockey player in Sweden and he also was a physical education instructor - at the same time. Under Sweden's amateur structure, Anders Kallur taught classes by day and played top-level hockey at night.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt SPORTSMEN AND GAMESMEN. By John Dizikes. 350 pages. Illustrated. Hough- ton Mifflin. $15.

title: F.C.C. PLANNING TO VOTE ON DEREGULATION OF RADIO
description: The Federal Communications Commission, in the closing days of the Carter Administration, plans to vote Wednesday on a policy to deregulate nearly 9,000 radio stations.

title: WEST VIRGINIA MINISTER AND WIFE FIND REFUGE FROM KLAN TERROR
description: Seven hundred miles from their former parish in rural West Virginia, the Rev. Michael S. Curry and his wife, Ella, driven from Mr. Curry's first denominational call by what he described today as ''a six-month campaign of terror'' by hooded Ku Klux Klansmen, have begun trying to recover their equilibrium.

title: LOOK IN ON THE CLASSICS
description: To the Editor:

title: SQUIRES, MISS KUSCIK WIN SIX-MILE RACES
description: Pete Squires of the New York Athletic Club, running in 9-degree temperatures at Central Park yesterday morning, captured the six-mile run that marked the opening of the New York Road Runners Club winter series.

title: Protest Reconsidered
description: There's no law against changing your mind, Sam Brown will tell you.

title: LEAFS DEFEAT RANGERS BY 5-3 FOR NEW COACH
description: Mike Nykoluk, who was supposed to succeed Fred Shero as coach but didn't, returned to Madison Square Garden last night as the new coach of the Toronto Maple Leafs. A mild-mannered person, he refused to gloat as the Leafs defeated the Rangers, 5-3.

title: Market Place; A Long-Term Point of View
description: DIZZYING swings have kept the stock market off balance in a period of political limbo between Washington administrations. Last week the Dow Jones industrials soared 40 points, to top 1,000, in response to signs of peaking interest rates. But virtually the entire advance evaporated in the following two sessions after Joseph Granville, the market analyst, sent a flash message to his customers who pay extra for early warnings. He advised them to ''sell everything.''

title: MARRIAGE: ITS STYLES ARE FEW
description: A MERICAN marriages are characterized by an astounding lack of diversity, according to recent studies. For all the individuality that husbands and wives may bring to their marriages, research in several large cities disclosed that more than 1,000 couples had fewer than a dozen ways of interacting with each other.

title: Mexican Defense Chief in Israel
description: The Mexican Defense Minister, Gen. Felix Galvan Lopez, arrived in Israel today to study the possibility of buying Kfir fighter planes. He is to meet with Prime Minister Menachem Begin, President Yitzhak Navon and military officials during a five-day visit.

title: How Not to Build a City
description: New Yorkers with a fear of high places or crowds should avoid reading the real estate pages. The news that the huge Citicorp Building on Lexington Avenue between 53rd and 54th Streets is about to be twinned on the next block has been followed by announcement of a new office tower opposite Citicorp on Third Avenue. This skyscraper triple play is typical of New York's current superbuilding syndrome. The biggest buildings flock together on the smallest amount of the most expensive land with the most wanted East Side addresses. It is a phenomenon that can also be observed on Madison Avenue in the Fifties, where the mammoth I.B.M. and A.T.&T. Buildings are being joined by a clutch of oversized new towers. All of these buildings are larger than anything ever permitted in New York before except for a few famous landmarks. Their density will put an unprecedented strain on the city's already overburdened streets and services.

title: Stock Market Peak in Tokyo
description: The Tokyo stock market surged to another record high Friday as foreign investors, worried about recession in the West and last week's slump on Wall Street, plunged into Japan's robust economy.

title: Black Hawks 2, Flames 1
description: Tom Lysiak scored a goal in the first period, and Denis Savard, a rookie, got his 15th of the season early in the second as the Black Hawks beat Calgary for their fourth straight victory.

title: BRZEZINSKI TO PROPOSE THAT ECONOMIC TALKS BE 'STRATEGIC' SESSIONS
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser, will propose tomorrow that the leaders of the United States, Canada, Japan and key Western European nations expand their yearly economic meetings into ''strategic summit'' sessions to meet the challenges posed by the Soviet Union.

title: U.S. EXTENDS BID-RIGGING INQUIRY
description: The Justice Department's successful campaign against bid-rigging in public highway and airport projects has been extended to five more states, officials say.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bunker Ramo Corporation, Oak Brook, Ill., has elected Arie Verhagen president of Borg Textiles Canada Inc., a subsidiary.

title: U. S. Terpsichore to Open 2-Week Season March 2
description: New works by Victoria Simon and Daniel Levans will highlight a two-week season of ballet and modern dance presented by the U.S. Terpsichore Ballet Company from March 2 through March 15 at the Brandeis High School Auditorium, 145 West 84th Street.

title: Essay; THE SINCERE USURPER
description: Charles Percy, Republican of Illinois, who took over last week as chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, is the most earnest, well-intentioned, public-spirited member of the Senate. Nobody out-sinceres Chuck Percy.

title: Foreign Affairs; FRENCH CHOICE IN AFRICA
description: For nearly a generation since he ousted a tottering monarchy and proclaimed his own brand of revolution, Libya's irrepressible Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi has been trying to put his mark on the world. He has never really succeeded in his grandiose scheme because he represents too few people, and his Islamic fundamentalism is too murky, his revolutionary ideas too cloudy, his tactics too offensive to appeal to masses outside Libya.

title: NEW YORK CITY ECONOMY PROSPERED AMID NATIONWIDE RECESSION OF '80
description: From Madison Avenue retail stores to Broadway theaters to Wall Street law firms, a broad band of New York City businesses prospered during the 1980 recession, surpassing their counterparts nationwide and confounding the expectations of many economists.

title: A PERILOUS BRUSHOFF OF CIVIL LIBERTARIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: N.C.A.A. Ponders; One-Network Deal
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association may try to turn its $30 million-a-year football television contract with ABC and its $9.9 million-a-year basketball tournament contract with NBC into a TV package worth considerably more than the sum of the two parts - possibly $50 million a year with one network.

title: AT 75, EMLYN WILLIAMS BOW AS A FIRST NOVELIST
description: AT the California Theater in San Diego recently, Emlyn Williams found himself suspended between his past and his present, able to turn back and advance the clock of his life and career by walking only a few feet across the stage.

title: Man Gets Life Term
description: ELIZABETH (UPI) - A 25-year-old Newark man has been sentenced to life in prison for the December 1979 murder of an off-duty Hillside police officer during an attempted robbery at a local fast-food restaurant.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BEFORE THE THEATER

title: THRIFT UNITS CAUTIOUS ON EXPANSION PLANS
description: Except for offering NOW accounts, the nation's 4,400 savings and loan associations are not rushing into the new world of banking that opened to them on Jan. 1.

title: SENATE PANEL ISSUES SUBPOENA TO OBTAIN LOGS OF HAIG TAPES
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee tonight subpoenaed logs summarizing about 100 hours of tape-recorded conversations that took place between Alexander M. Haig Jr. and President Nixon in 1973. The subpoena was issued after Mr. Nixon's attorneys refused to allow the National Archives to turn over the logs voluntarily.

title: Commodities; Rates and Financial Futures
description: INTEREST rates again dominated all commodity futures markets last week as traders watched the banks' prime lending rates settle at 20 percent, dashing many traders' hopes for an easing of bank credit. This is particularly true in the financial futures market, which is naturally the most sensitive to any change in interest rates.

title: Rich-Torme Concert Jan. 29
description: Buddy Rich and Mel Torme will headline a concert Jan. 29 at 8 P.M. at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue.

title: Houston Developer Looks to New York
description: Gerald D. Hines, the 55-year-old Houston real-estate developer who just purchased the Third Avenue blockfront across from the Citicorp Center for $28 million, has a history of creating unusual and welldesigned projects. And he pledges that the one he will build in New York will follow that pattern.

title: WHEN LEASED U.S. LAND REMAINS UNDRILLED
description: To the Editor:

title: PIANO RECITAL: LYDIA ORIAS PLAYS RAVEL
description: LYDIA ORIAS'S concert at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday was predicated on virtuosity. The Ravel Toccata and individual etudes by Chopin, Debussy and Liszt seemed spread out along the first half of her program like hurdles on an obstacle course - one piece often totally alien to the other in key, style and sentiment, and the four, taken together, having really only their difficulty in common.

title: STANDING UP TO THE HAIRDRESSER CAN TAKE A KIND OF COURAGE
description: On her first visit to Monsieur Marc's Beauty Salon, Betsy Bloomingdale stared into the mirror, smiled and said: ''Today we have just met. The next time we will get engaged. Maybe someday we will be married.''

title: Sporting Gear; Portable Cordless Whirlpool
description: Portable Cordless Whirlpool

title: Mississippi at Record Low; River Traffic Is Hampered
description: The Mississippi River is at its lowest point since record-keeping began more than a century ago, forcing shippers to resort to lighter loads and endure frequent delays because of groundings and channel closings.

title: News Analysis
description: Asked recently about the chances for an agreement at the conference here on South-West Africa, the nation to be known as Namibia, a South African Cabinet Minister replied that he was pessimistic.

title: CONCERT: CONTEMPORARY MUSIC
description: THURSDAY night's concert by the League of Composers-International Society for Contemporary Music at Carnegie Recital Hall touched lightly on most of the styles and techniques preoccupying composers of this generation.

title: A HARD-LINER TAKES A STANK
description: Yigael Hurwitz, who brought Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Likud Government to the brink of collapse yesterday by announcing his resignation as Finance Minister, is the only Israeli to quit the same Government twice.

title: AT THE BOHEMIAN CLUB, MEN JOIN, WOMEN SERVE
description: A few years ago a scholar examining the sociology of ''ruling class cohesiveness'' decided that the Bohemian Club of San Francisco's annual summer encampment was a gathering of ''the decision-makers and opinion molders of corporate America.''

title: MUSIC: THE CLEVELAND QUARTET PLAYS MENDELSSOHN BARTOK
description: ON the face of it, a concert series devoted to the string quartets of Mendelssohn and Bartok would seem to present an odd pairing of composers. In practice, they make a surprisingly complementary twosome as the Cleveland Quartet demonstrated at the 92d Street Y on Thursday night, the first program of four that will examine the complete string quartets of these composers. The remaining concerts in the series are scheduled for Jan. 21 and Feb. 5 and 18.

title: City Ballet to Perform Premiere of Martins Ballet
description: Peter Martins's ''Suite from Histoire du Soldat'' will be given its world premiere on Jan. 29 by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: When a team in the National Football League makes a first down, and the markers have to be moved, is there an automatic timeout? What is the rule in college football?

title: FOR RUDDERLESS COSTA RICA, A QUIXOTIC RESCUE EFFORT
description: At 5 feet 3 inches, Jose Figueres Ferrer is rather small for the role of Don Quixote. But like Cervantes's hero, he is a dreamy philosopher and political adventurer, the butt of jokes and anecdotes in times of tranquillity, a man of action when a crisis erupts.

title: Advertising; Dreyfus Mulls Lion Comeback
description: THE Dreyfus lion, which led the rest of Wall Street into television advertising, may return to that medium again, and soon, even though the Dreyfus Corporation is extremely successful in its print advertising.

title: AT LEAST 1,000 PEOPLE ARE KILLED AS NIGERIA CRUSHES ISLAMIC SECT
description: At least a thousand people, and possibly many more, were killed here over the last two weeks as members of an Islamic cult attacked the local authorities, and Government forces were sent to quell what Nigerian officials said they believed to be a Libyan-backed insurrection.

title: People
description: * Burtch Drake has joined Foote, Cone & Belding/New York as a senior vice president.

title: IN STENMARK'S WORDS
description: When Ingemar Stenmark took a spill in a downhill event in September 1979, the result - a brain concussion - was known immediately but the movtive for the best slalom racer attempting the downhill wasn't. The Silent Swede wasn't one to tell all.

title: 10 Subway Riders Hurt In Brooklyn Derailment
description: Ten subway riders suffered minor injuries early this morning in Brooklyn when a D train derailed on the IND line near Kings Highway, the Transit Authority said.

title: HARRY LEVY, EX-OFFICIAL AT CITY U.
description: Harry L. Levy, a visiting professor of classical studies at Duke University and a former vice chancellor of the City University of New York, died today at his home in Durham. He was 74 years old. ---- Began Career at Hunter By WOLFGANG SAXON

title: Speidel Decides to Change Its Advertising Direction
description: Fred Massotti, president of Speidel, a division of Textron Inc., was in town from Providence, R.I., Friday to talk about the new advertising direction for the company's watchbands.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE NATION; 8 Military Jets Destroyed At Air Base in Puerto Rico

title: 30 Are Reported Killed In Guatemala Violence
description: At least 30 people have been killed in Guatemala in the last 24 hours in an upsurge of political agitation.

title: Arrows Defeat Fog As Zungul Scores 4
description: Steve Zungul scored four goals and assisted on a fifth as the New York Arrows rallied from a 2-1 halftime deficit to defeat the San Francisco Fog, 5-2, today in a Major Indoor Soccer League game at Nassau Coliseum before 4,823 fans.

title: FINANCE CHIEF QUITS THE ISRAELI CABINET: NEW ELECTIONS SEEN
description: Early parliamentary elections in Israel became a virtual certainty today after Prime Minister Menachem Begin failed to find a way to forestall the resignation of his Finance Minister over the issue of higher pay for teachers.

title: Super Drama For Plunkett black
description: IN the last crisis of yesterday's American Conference championship game, Jim Plunkett wanted to run the ball himself for the first down that would clinch the Oakland Raiders' 34-27 triumph over the San Diego Chargers. With 1 minute 52 seconds remaining, the Chargers had taken a timeout and Jim Plunkett walked over to talk to Tom Flores the Raider coach, about their third-and-4 situation at the Charger 29-yard line.

title: Turks Arrest an Editor, Saying He Fabricated News
description: The martial law authorities today detained Salim Bayer, managing editor of Hurriyet, Turkey's largest-selling newspaper, on charges of publishing ''fabricated'' news, the paper reported.

title: Mild Quake in San Luis Obispo
description: A mild earthquake rattled San Luis Obispo County for 30 seconds at 8:45 o'clock last night, a spokesman for the seismological laboratory at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena said. The laboratory technician, Tom Heaton, estimated the magnitude at 3.5 on the Richter scale.

title: BYRNE ASKING BOARD TAX OVERHAUL IN HIS FINAL STATE OF STATE MESSAGE
description: Governor Byrne will ask the Legislature tomorrow to consider a broad overhaul of the state's tax structure and to review laws governing the multimillion-dollar casino gambling industry.

title: Belgium Warns on Autos
description: Belgium's Minister of Economics, Willy Claes, said today that he would impose import limits on Japanese automobiles, saying the competition threatens domestic production and employment. Japanese cars now represent 30 percent of the Belgian market, the highest level in Europe. Mr. Claes added he would open talks with Japanese officials this month. He also said he could only make a decision in agreement with his counterparts in the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FEYDEAU FARCE

title: ADVERTISING
description: The drooping housing industry was a big factor in the decision by Conde Nast Publications to drop its Guides series of special-interest magazines this April.

title: The Newing of the President
description: The Reagan Inaugural Address won't be delivered for a week yet, but we like it already. It's finished, the President-elect says with appealing modesty, ''unless someone comes up with some better idea,'' and it will be short, lasting only about 15 minutes. Mr. Reagan's calm practicality suggests that he understands how cold it is likely to be outside the Capitol at midday next Tuesday - and also that he has conquered the inevitable dangers of grandiloquence.

title: TARNOWER CASE JURY TOLD OF NEW BLOODSTAIN
description: A forensic expert called by the defense in the Jean S. Harris trial testified today that a bullet hole and bloodstains found in the glass door of Dr. Herman Tarnower's bedroom ''are consistent'' with a gun's having been fired through his hand ''three to four feet'' from the door, or in the area of his bed, where Mrs. Harris said they struggled.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Style page on Sunday incorrectly stated the position of Representative Marge Roukema, the newly elected Congresswoman from New Jersey's Seventh District, on the abortion issue. Mrs. Roukema supports Federal funds for abortions in all cases.

title: British Airways Seeking Loans
description: State-owned British Airways said today that it would borrow more than $200 million from banks by the end of its financial year in March to meet a serious cash-flow problem. A company statement said the money was needed to pay wages and fuel bills and make payments on new aircraft.

title: Vietnamese Said to Exploit Release to Control Garwood
description: Pfc. Robert R. Garwood's North Vietnamese captors promised to send him home in 1967 as a gesture to an antiwar delegation headed by Dr. Benjamin M. Spock and Joan Baez, but only if the marine became ''progressive and re-educated,'' a senior Air Force psychiatrist testified today.

title: U.S. WARNS OF 'LIMITED' BENEFITS IN LOW-TAR CIGARETTES
description: The Surgeon General, Dr. Julius B. Richmond, said today that the low-tar and low-nicotine cigarettes to which millions of American smokers have switched in recent years for health reasons do confer some ''limited'' reduction in risk of lung cancer compared to brands high in those substances.

title: James River Offer For Sorg Modified
description: The James River Corporation and the Sorg Paper Company said that the recent offer made by James River to acquire the stock of Sorg Paper by a merger had been modified.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Home Products Corporation has elected to its board William Wrigley, president and chief executive officer of Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company.

title: SECOND OPINIONS ON SURGERY DO WORK
description: To the Editor:

title: An International Encore, 32 Years Later
description: Back in 1948 when he was a music critic for the English-language China Press in Shanghai, Fritz A. Kuttner was so impressed with the playing of a 20-year-old concert pianist that he waxed rhapsodic.

title: INDONESIANS YEARN FOR EMIGRATION TO ESCAPE OVERCROWDING AND FIND JOBS
description: A 21-year-old pedicab driver recently withdrew one-quarter of his savings and took the 15-hour, $10 bus ride to Jakarta to visit the Swiss Embassy. ''I wanted a visa to go work in Basel,'' said the pedicab driver, a man named Fery's-Kono. ''The man at the embassy said: 'There are no Indonesians in Switzerland. I keep telling you people, no visa.'''

title: FAWN BRODIE, JEFFERSON BIOGRAPHER
description: Fawn McKay Brodie, a historian whose biography of Thomas Jefferson was a best-seller in 1974, died of cancer Saturday night at St. John's Hospital. She was 65 years old.

title: THEATER: TANYA BEREZIN AS FRAU WOLF IN HAUPTMANN'S 'THE BEAVER COAT'
description: GERHART HAUPTMANN'S ''The Beaver Coat'' is a subversive thieves' comedy in which social justice can only be achieved through duplicity and a reversal of the order of the classes. The heartbeat of the play, Frau Wolf, is a scheming washerwoman who will not allow herself to be downtrodden. In fact, through the exercise of her ingenuity, she is moving up in the world, stealing, lying and cheating her way to respectability.

title: COLD COMFORT
description: uf9231 The Right Remedy for No Heat

title: McHale Rewarding Foresight of Celtics
description: Last June when the Boston Celtics sat down to discuss the draft, General Manager Red Auerbach, Coach Bill Fitch, and Harry Mangurian, the owner, disagreed on whether the 7-foot center Joe Barry Carroll would best serve the team's needs.

title: SUBWAY DELAYS LENGTHEN FOR TAXI SEEKERS
description: Finding an available taxi, a challenge during any morning rush hour, was made all the more difficult yesterday by 3-degree temperatures and extensive subway delays.

title: No Headline
description: Talking Businesswith Nageotte of Greyhound Wide Decontrol Of Buses Urged

title: Another Fonda Honor
description: It was a time for celebration for Henry Fonda when he returned to his native Nebraska over the weekend to be honored as the state's most famous actor.

title: Museum to Observe Black History Month; Museum to Observe Black History Month
description: The ''Good Time Duo,'' a performance of gospel music, field hollers, spirituals and work songs by Don Oliver and Steve Freeman, and a program of the recorded speeches by Paul Robeson and live music and poetry readings are the two headline attractions of next month's black history programs at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: MADE RULING ON ABORTION FUNDS
description: Judge John Francis Dooling Jr., the Federal judge who declared unconstitutional the so-called Hyde Amendment restricting Federal financing of abortions for indigent women, died of a heart attack yesterday a block away from his home in Brooklyn while walking to work. He was 72 years old.

title: A JEWELRY DISPLAY FIT FOR A KING
description: A romance with the Renaissance is under way here and in Paris, inspired in part by Yves Saint Laurent's Shakespearean short doublets, frilly ruffs, swirling capes and jewel-tone velvets.

title: NOVEMBER CONSUMER CREDIT UP
description: Consumer installment credit grew by $839 million in November, the fourth consecutive monthly increase, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: Met Switches Bills And Lists 'Fidelio'
description: The repertory and schedule of the final weeks of the Metropolitan Opera season were announced yesterday. Beethoven's ''Fidelio'' will be substituted for Wagner's ''Parsifal.''

title: Drinan Back on Campus
description: Former Representative Robert F. Drinan of Massachusetts, the Jesuit priest who gave up his seat in the House of Representatives at the behest of Pope John Paul II, has signed on to teach a seminar in international civil rights at the Georgetown University Law School in Washington, D.C.

title: Legislator Admits Role on Kickbacks
description: SYRACUSE (AP) - State Senator Martin S. Auer pleaded guilty yesterday to a misdemeanor charge of taking part in a scheme requiring insurance companies doing business with Onondaga County to make political kickbacks to the local Republican Party.

title: FAREWELL, SHINY G.I. BOOT
description: Spit-shined boots are being eliminated by the military because soldiers wearing them are too easily spotted by enemies using infrared lenses, the Defense Department says.

title: Looking Behind Davis's Screen
description: and-silver smokescreen around Super Bowl XV. Instead of an analysis of the game between the Oakland Raiders and the Philadelphia Eagles, much of the emphasis somehow is on what will happen if Pete Rozelle, the National Football League commissioner, has to present the Super Bowl trophy to Al Davis, the Raider managing general genius who has accused him of Super Bowl ticketscalping. It's almost as if St. Peter had to present the keys to the kingdom to Lucifer.

title: Cairo Expels Russian for Spying
description: The state-controlled Middle East News Agency said today that the Egyptian authorities had arrested an unnamed Soviet Embassy official and ordered him expelled from the country for spying. It said he had been ''in contact with an Egyptian civil servant with a view to obtaining information'' but did not name the Egyptian.

title: Personnel Director Appointed by Koch
description: Mayor Koch appointed as the city's Personnel Director Juan Ortiz, a 34-year-old co-founder of the city's first Hispanic law firm in Wall Street and current part-time chairman of the city's Civil Service Commission. He replaces S. Michael Nadel, who was appointed to the new post of deputy chief administrator of the state court system.

title: Midway Lowers Fares
description: Midway Airlines said today that it would lower its unrestricted fares on flights from Chicago to New York, Omaha, Kansas City, Mo., Cleveland and Detroit, starting Wednesday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It looks better, but I can't predict success.'' - President Carter, speaking of the hostage negotiations with Iran. (A1:6.)

title: Joe Traver Conflicting 'Rights' Rallies Scheduled to be Held in Buffalo Gayle Graham, of the Buffalo Against Racism organization, telling of plans by a coalition of civil-rights groups to hold a rally in Buffalo Thursday, the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Meanwhile, a Federal judge reserved decision on a move to block a neo-Nazi rally planned for the same day in front of Buffalo's City Hall.
description: Because of recent murders of black men, community leaders say they fear a possible confrontation.

title: Yamaha to Expand Overseas Production
description: The Yamaha Motor Company said it was planning to expand its overseas motorcycle production. It said it would shortly set up a joint venture company, Maztra S.A., in Mexico with Group Industriale Alfa to make about 100,000 motorcycles a year beginning later this year.

title: FUZZY THINKING ON CRIME
description: Jr. ,00During World War II, when the entire police force of Copenhagen was imprisoned by the German Army of occupation, the city was immediately hit by a crime wave. The burglary rate increased tenfold the moment the risk of arrest, prosecution, and punishment disappeared.

title: GUN CONTROL NEEDS NO ARMY OF POLICEMEN
description: To the Editor:

title: ODETTA: FOLKSINGER WHO SURVIVED THE ROCK YEARS
description: ODETTA, the folksinger, will give a concert tomorrow at 7 P.M. at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, a setting that she thinks is ''a natural'' for her songs.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: ATLANTA (NL) - Signed Gaylord Perry, r ight-handed pitcher, to one-year contract e stimated at $300,000. Perry, twice winner o f the Cy Young Award, has been a major l eaguer 19 years, with 289 victories.

title: A Damaging Silence
description: Alexander M. Haig's appearance before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee turned out to be less a confrontation on Watergate than a forum for General Haig's hard-line views on countering Soviet military power, which he described as ''a global offensive army, navy and air force fully capable of supporting an imperial foreign policy.''

title: FUR, DOWN AND SHEEPSKIN: STAYING WARM IN STYLE
description: When the thermometer doesn't rise much above zero and the weathermen tell you the wind-chill factor makes it seem even colder, the main point of dressing is to keep warm. Some people end up looking like trussed turkeys. Some people do it with style.

title: 2 U.S. JOURNALISTS INJURED IN SALVADOR
description: Two United States journalists and a South African were wounded today when a land mine exploded as they were driving to a town north of here that was reported under guerrilla attack.

title: Kansas-Nebraska Uranium Prospect
description: A subsidiary of the Kansas-Nebraska Natural Gas Company discovered a uranium prospect in northwest Nebraska that could yield as much as 25 million pounds of uranium oxide, Kansas-Nebraska Natural Gas officials said today.

title: CHARACTER ACTRESS
description: Beulah Bondi, whose career on the Broadway stage, in films and on television spanned more than 50 years, died yesterday at the Motion Picture Country House and Hospital in Hollywood. She was 92 years old.

title: Policemen Kill Robbery Suspect
description: A robbery suspect was shot and killed last night by two police officers when he allegedly aimed a loaded .38 caliber revolver at them following an auto chase through the streets of Queens, the police said.

title: No Headline
description: DON WHITEHEAD, PULITZER WINNER

title: s Johnson Wins Court Ruling
description: A Superior Court judge ruled today that evidence obtained by the police in bringing cocaine charges against the Atlanta Hawks guard Eddie Johnson was inadmissible because it had been seized illegally.

title: HAIG IS SAID TO CHOOSE HIS CHIEF AIDES
description: Secretary of State-designate Alexander M. Haig Jr. has quietly selected most of his senior aides and reportedly plans to announce them after his own confirmation by the Senate. Many are former colleagues and some may run into opposition from Senate conservatives. Present State Department officials, who have been privately informed of Mr. Haig's choices, have noted that Mr. Haig seems to have chosen a mixture of career professionals and political appointees. The career Foreign Service officers seem for the most part to be those with whom Mr. Haig worked when he was on the National Security Council staff from 1969 to 1973. The most important assignment, that of Deputy Secretary, remains unfilled because Justice William P. Clark of the California Supreme Court reportedly turned it down over the weekend. He had been President-elect Ronald Reagan's personal choice. Post for Senator Buckley The Under Secretary for Political Affairs, the senior career position, has been offered to Walter J. Stoessel Jr., the Ambassador to West Germany. When Mr. Haig was commander of North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces in Europe he got to know Mr. Stoessel well. The No. 4 position, that of Under Secretary of Economic Affairs, will go to Myer Rashish, a trade consultant in Washington who worked in Mr. Reagan's election campaign. Former Senator James L. Buckley of New York is expected to be the Under Secretary for Security Assistance. The choices to head the Bureau of Inter-American Affairs and the Bureau of Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs are said to be uncertain.

title: Japanese Dies on Mount Everest
description: A member of a Japanese expedition to Mount Everest slipped and apparently fell to his death today on the mountain, the world's highest peak, the Ministry of Tourism said. The climber, Noboru Takenaka, 28 years old, was descending from one camp to another when he slipped at 22,309 feet, the ministry said.

title: CONTEMPT THREAT FOR AMY
description: Jose Amy, whose testimony helped to convict Con Errico of racefixing charges last year, refused yesterday to answer questions about another former jockey, Eddie Belmonte, and was threatened with contempt charges by the State.

title: QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
description: Q. What is fermentation?

title: Perrier's Media Planning Goes to Mathieu, Gerfen
description: The Great Waters of France, the Greenwich, Conn., marketers of Perrier, has closed down its in-house media operation, called Media Source, and assigned the media-planning and buying to its agency, Mathieu, Gerfen & Bresner. Shelly Milchman, a vice president who ran Media Source, has moved along to the agency as associate media director.

title: Express Bus Line Accused by Goldin
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charged that New York Bus Tours, which provides express bus service on six routes between the Bronx and Manhattan, had been overstating it costs so that it could receive excess government subsidies.

title: Pemex Stake in Petronor
description: Petroleos Mexicanos, Mexico's state oil company, signed an agreement today making it the largest shareholder in Petronor, the Spanish refining company. Under the agreement, the Spanish state oil company, Campsa, accepted the $47 million offer by Pemex for the 19.28 percent interest it held in the refiner.

title: A Second-Best Nixon Autograph Up for Auction
description: In the view of Charles Hamilton, the New York dealer in autographs, one of the 10 rarest autographs in the world is the signed resignation of Richard M. Nixon, a document in the National Archives on which Mr. Hamilton places a value of $100,000.

title: Barry Commoner's Debut
description: Queens College scored a coup last year when it announced that Barry Commoner would move his Center for the Biology of Natural Systems to the Queens campus from Washington University in St. Louis.

title: BONANNO IS SENTENCED TO A 5 YEAR JAIL TERM ON CONSPIRACY CHARGE
description: Joseph Bonanno Sr., the 76-yearold reputed Mafia leader, received a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a $10,000 fine today for a conspiracy conviction.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Electrosound Group Inc. agreed in principle to acquire the Telcom Corporation, a Phoenix-based manufacturer and supplier of data communications equipment and systems. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: Buffalo Forge Seeks To Bar Ampco Bid
description: The Buffalo Forge Company has filed suit to prevent the Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation and its AmpcoPittsburgh Securities II subsidiary from acquiring shares of Buffalo Forge at $25 a share, Ampco-Pittsburgh said today.

title: Racing Canceled Again
description: For the second straight day racing at Aqueduct was canceled yesterday, this time because the jockeys refused to ride, calling the cold weather hazardous. The temperature was in single-digit figures, and the wind-chill factor created the equivalent of 17 below zero. The card also was canceled Sunday because of high wind and the cold. Today is the track's regular dark day; racing is scheduled to resume tomorrow.

title: ENERGY CHOICE BACKS FASTER DECONTROL
description: James B. Edwards today told the Senate committee considering his nomination as Secretary of Energy that he was strongly inclined to recommend that President-elect Ronald Reagan lift the remaining price controls on crude oil, gasoline and some other products ''as soon as possible'' after taking office next week.

title: EXCERPTS FROM BYRNE'S STATE OF STATE MESSAGE TO JERSEY LEGISLATURE
description: Following are excerpts from the State of the State message that Governor Byrne plans to deliver to the Legislature tomorrow: Special to the New York Times

title: FRASER SEES LOAN BOARD ON CHRYSLER
description: Douglas A. Fraser, president of the United Automobile Workers, paid calls today on each of the three members of the Chrysler Loan Guarantee Board as the union and the financially distressed car manufacturer began negotiating a new round of wage concessions.

title: DOW UP 0.08 AFTER EARLY RALLY
description: Stock prices turned lower yesterday after a strong start and finished with only nominal advances in the popular averages. The Dow Jones industrial average, ahead by more than 11 points half an hour after the market opened, closed at 968.77, with a token gain of 0.08.

title: SAGAN SELLS FIRST NOVEL TO SIMON & SCHUSTER
description: Carl Sagan, the astronomer and best-selling author, has negotiated a $2 million contract with Simon & Schuster for a first novel, to the chagrin of his current publisher, Random House. Simon & Schuster won the book at auction after publishers were told by Mr. Sagan's agent that the four-book contract the author signed with Random House in 1976 applied only to works of nonfiction.

title: DANNON YOGURT'S PREMIER SALESMAN
description: When Juan E. Metzger was named one of the ''top marketers of the decade'' last year, few outside his own industry could probably identify him -or his product.

title: U.S. Legislator Predicts Softer Human-Rights Line
description: Clement J. Zablocki, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said here today that the House this year is likely to take a softer human-rights line toward Argentina and other military governments.

title: SENATORS QUESTION DONOVAN ON JERSEY RACKETEERING
description: Raymond J. Donovan, President-elect Ronald Reagan's choice for Secretary of Labor, spent most of his Senate confirmation hearing today answering questions about incidents that seemingly link his construction company to figures allegedly involved in political corruption and labor racketeering.

title: Ad Placement Examined
description: You may have no idea of the amount of time given over to battles by advertisers and their agencies seeking better locations in magazines. Now it turns out that, with the inside of the back covers and the back covers themselves, the placement of an ad makes little or no difference in the readership. This fact, if fact it be, is the result of research by Starch, INRA, Hooper and is reported in the monthly newsletter, Starch Tested Copy.

title: Dr. Israel L. Efros, Teacher, Poet And Scholar in Jewish Philosophy
description: Dr. Israel L. Efros, Hebrew and American poet and scholar who was the coauthor of a definitive Hebrew-English dictionary, died on Jan. 4 in Tel Aviv. A long-time resident of New York City, he was 90 years old.

title: WARNER TO DEVELOP CANCER TEST
description: The Warner-Lambert Company has entered the race to develop marketable tests for cancer with an agreement allowing it to commercialize cancer-detection technology pioneered by researchers at Pennsylvania State University, according to an announcement yesterday.

title: GIFTS TO NEEDIEST CASES FUND STRESS PLIGHT OF ELDERLY
description: The distress of the elderly on fixed incomes and those who have seen their savings and retirement hopes ravaged by inflation evokes a special compassion among many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Moritz Jagendorf, Folklorist, 92, Who Wrote Stories for Children
description: Moritz Jagendorf, a folklorist who turned American, European and oriental folk tales into stories and plays for children, died last Thursday at Tompkins Community Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 92 years old, and lived in Manhattan.

title: SUBWAY DERAILMENT ADDS TO STRAIN ON TRANSIT LINES
description: New York City's faltering subway and bus service was strained still further yesterday when a train derailed in Brooklyn and transit officials were forced to divert buses to carry stranded subway riders.

title: Westinghouse Ends Suit Against Getty
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it had reached an out-of-court settlement with the Getty Oil Company in its uranium antitrust lawsuit.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE SIRIAN EXPERIMENTS. The Report by Ambien II, of the Five. Canopus in Argos: Archives. By Doris Lessing. 288 pages. Knopf. $11.95.

title: Hobart Fights Offer By CPE for Shares
description: The Hobart Corporation said it had asked the Federal District Court in New York to issue a preliminary injunction against the continuation of the tender offer by Canadian Pacific Enterprises United States Inc. for the acquisition of all of Hobart's outstanding common shares.

title: PUNISHMENT IS URGED FOR FEDERAL OFFICIALS TIED TO ABSCAM LEAKS
description: Deputy Attorney General Charles B. Renfrew and William Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, have recommended that two prosecutors and about five bureau agents be disciplined for their involvement in news disclosures about Abscam and other investigations, Government sources said today.

title: Texas Ordered to Expand School Bilingual Programs
description: Federal District Judge William Wayne Justice today ruled that bilingual education programs in Texas public schools were seriously flawed and ordered the state to expand the programs, a move that could affect thousands of Mexican-American children.

title: 30th Victim Found At Jersey Fire Site
description: Workmen found the body of the 30th, and presumably last, victim to die in a fire at the Beachview Rest Home last Friday.

title: PINE BARRENS PLAN STIRS FUROR ON LAND USE
description: ''Planning-board meetings have become standing room only, with applicants for building permits on one side and residents on the other,'' said Gregory Crescenzo, a consultant to the Hamilton Township planning board. ''It's like the old cowboy movies, with the sodbusters who are already there and the big cattlemen who are moving in.''

title: United Airlines Plans to Expand
description: United Airlines, the nation's largest air carrier, announced that it would expand its operations further into the Southwest, adding service to Oklahoma City, Tulsa, Okla.,and Wichita, Kan., on June 12.

title: FUEL SHORTAGE DISRUPTS LIFE IN MASSACHUSETTS TOWN
description: Schools and some businesses here closed today after utilities in this city and on Cape Cod declared an ''energy emergency'' to alleviate a natural gas shortage caused by intensely cold weather that is continuing to drive up demand and deplete reserves throughout the Northeast.

title: U.S. Steel Price Rise
description: The United States Steel Corporation said it was increasing its base prices and some special charges for plates, structural shapes and piling, effective with shipments on March 1. The increases average about 7 1/2 percent on the affected products and will raise United States Steel's revenues by about 1 1/2 percent, the company said. It said the additional revenue was needed to help cover the impact of continuing cost increases.

title: Leak Reported At Indian Point
description: What apparently was a leak in a test line at the Indian Point 3 nuclear plant 35 miles north of Manhattan accidentally released ''small'' amounts of radioactive gases into the air Sunday morning, according to the State Power Authority, which operates the plant.

title: IMAGINATIVE RESEARCHER WAGES 30-YEAR WAR AGAINST VIRUSES
description: THE human population is a hunting ground for viruses that stalk every man, woman and child throughout life. Only a few persons ever turn the tables to pursue, capture and defeat these universal predators. Among those few is Dr. Robert M. Chanock of the National Institutes of Health, a specialist in virus research for 30 years. His team at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, a unit of the N.I.H., continues to score victories and broaden the scope of human knowledge of virus infections. Their formula; a blend of imagination, scientific creativity and much persistent hard work.

title: LOUISIANA JUDGE AGAIN DEFIES DESEGREGATION ORDER
description: A state judge enrolled three white girls at an all-white school again today, less than a week after he pledged to cease his defiance of a Federal judge who has ordered the students bused to a racially integrated school.

title: Italian Papers Let Deadline On Judge Pass Unheeded
description: A 48-hour deadline set by the Red Brigades for national newspapers to publish two long statements from the terrorists passed tonight with no sign that the papers would comply.

title: AN INSURGENT WHO PRESERVES
description: ''I have never seen Sam Nujoma agree to anything,'' a Western diplomat who has been following the negotiations on South-West Africa for four years said last week just before the start of what was supposed to be the conference to end all conferences on the subject.

title: Key Rates
description: * Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Dr. Bernard E. Pinck, 64, A Former Passaic Mayor
description: Dr. Bernard E. Pinck, a former Mayor of Passaic, N.J., and chief of urology at Passaic General Hospital and Beth Israel Hospital in Passaic, died Sunday at St. Mary's Hospital in Passaic. He was 64 years old and lived in Passaic, where he was Mayor from 1967 to 1971.

title: POLES, IN FIRST USE OF FORCE IN CRISIS, BREAK UP PROTEST
description: The use of the police to oust a group of demonstrators from the town hall of a small city in southeastern Poland last night was the first time that the authorities resorted to force to resolve a political issue since Poland's labor unrest began last summer.

title: CONGRESSMAN FROM ARTS CAUCUS
description: A Congressional Arts Caucus has been formed. It intends to spearhead efforts to guide more arts legislation through Congress and to protect arts agencies from anticipated budget cuts under the Reagan Administration.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Beneficial Corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission $75 million of debentures due July 15, 1991, Series A, with warrants to purchase $75 million debentures due July 15, 1991, Series B. Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc. and Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group are managing underwriters.

title: TELEPRINTER FLAT RATES PROPOSED
description: The Western Union Telegraph Company said today that it plans to begin charging flat rates for its teletypewriter services, regardless of the distance between the originating and terminating points.

title: OFFICER'S SLAYING IN QUEENS IS DESCRIBED AS 'EXECUTION'
description: An off-duty police officer who was shot to death early in the morning was slain as he lay wounded and helpless after trying to stop a holdup at a bar near his home in Queens, New York City's chief of detectives said yesterday

title: COAST MUSEUM PICKS ARCHITECT
description: The Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, an institution that has yet to have a permanent home, has announced it has selected Arata Isozaki, the Japanese architect, to design its building to be erected in the Bunker Hill redevelopment area of downtown Los Angeles. The museum will be a building occupying a section of a large urbanrenewal project being constructed for the Cadillac-Fairview Corporation and designed by Arthur Erickson, the Canadian architect.

title: TV: LINDA LAVIN AS A NURSE
description: ''WHAT is this thing you have with death,'' a friend asks Linda Lavin. Miss Lavin, who plays a nurse who cares for the terminally ill, replies unhelpfully, ''Maybe it has to do with living.''

title: S. & H. IN TALKS ON POSSIBLE MERGER
description: The Sperry & Hutchinson Company, one of the nation's largest carpet and furniture manufacturers, said yesterday that it was conducting ''serious discussions with a possible purchaser.''

title: A Bronx Senator Ousted From Finance Unit Post
description: The State Senate's Democratic minority voted overwhelmingly today to remove one of its most senior members, Senator Abraham Bernstein of the Bronx, as ranking minority member of the Finance Committee. He was replaced by Donald M. Halperin of Brooklyn, a 10-year veteran of the Senate.

title: No Headline
description: BANI-SADAR SAYS WEST'S SANCTIONS ARE HAMPERING IRAN IN THE WAR

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Police Reportedly Break Up Extremist Group in Turkey

title: News Analysis
description: The Labor Party is heading into what could be one of the most crucial years in its history as badly divided as ever. Members of the left wing are dissatisfied with what they see as a drift away from pure socialism despite the recent acession of Michael Foot, one of their heroes, to the leadership. At the same time, members of the right wing are theatening to leave because of what they see as a sharp and undemocratic move to the left.

title: Spacecraft Controls Fail
description: Flight controllers have lost all but minimal control over the Solar Maximum Mission spacecraft, usually called Solar Max, the centerpiece of a worldwide effort to observe the sun during its period of greatest sunspot activity, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced.

title: Phillips Petroleum Outlays
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company has budgeted $3 billion for 1981 projects, a 20 percent rise over 1980 capital expenditures, it announced today. It said more than 80 percent of the total capital budget would be authorized for energy-related projects, with the rest supporting the company's chemicals business and staff groups, including research and development. Phillips added that it would concentrate on exploration and development in the Rocky Mountain Overthrust Belt, the Santa Barbara Channel and the Tuscaloosa Trend of Louisiana.

title: (000 omitted in dollar figures) 3-Mo. Bills 6-Mo. Bills Average Price 96.128 92.807 Discounted Rate 15.318% 14.228% Coupon Yield 16.16% 15.54% Low Price 96.094 92.745 Discounted Rate 15.452% 14.351% Coupon Yield 16.30% 15.69% High Price 96.221 92.917 Discounted Rate 14.950% 14.010% Coupon Yield 15.75% 15.29% Accepted at low 22% 72% Total applied for $6,476,190 $6,839,055 Accepted $4,300,025 $4,301,145 Noncompetitive
description: Both these issues are dated Jan. 15, 1981. The three-month bills mature April 16, 1981 and the six-month bills, July 16, 1981. 6-MONTH ISSUE BRINGS 14.23% AT WEEKLY AUCTION By MICHAEL QUINT

title: Rangers Lose Allison
description: The Rangers said yesterday that the rookie center Mike Allison would be out for a week because of a strained right knee. He sat out Sunday night's loss to Toronto after injuring the knee Friday in the tie with Buffalo.

title: BLUES WIN, 5-2, LIFT STREAK TO 11
description: Brian Sutter and Mike Zuke scored power-play goals last night at Hartford to lead St. Louis to a 5-2 victory over the Whalers. The triumph extended the Blues' unbeaten streak to 11 games.

title: Hispanic Leaders Voice Concern About Cabinet; HISPANIC LEADERS VOICE CONCERN ABOUT CABINET
description: Hispanic American leaders told President-elect Ronald Reagan today that they were disappointed by the absence of a Hispanic American in his Cabinet.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: TELEDYNE NET OFF 12%; INTEL ALSO SHOWS DROP By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

title: A Top Grumman Executive Is Assigned to Washington
description: In an unusual move for a major company, the Grumman Corporation has assigned John F. Carr, its vice chairman and third-highest-ranking officer, to work in its Washington office. Grumman, based in Bethpage, L.I., is a major defense contractor and also manufactures the Flxible bus.

title: IRAN'S PARLIAMENT POSTPONES DEBATE ON 2 HOSTAGE BILLS
description: The Iranian Parliament today failed, for procedural reasons, to approve emergency legislation designed to speed an agreement for the release of the 52 American Embassy hostages.

title: GILBERT GOES ON TRIAL IN CONRAC FRAUD CASE
description: Edward M. Gilbert went on trial yesterday on charges of having used ''fraudulent and manipulative devices'' in 1975 to inflate stock prices of the Conrac Corporation, an electronic-equipment producer that is traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: RAMS TOP PRINCETON IN 3 OVERTIMES, 53-50
description: Edward Bona, Fordham's sophomore forward, scored 5 points in the third overtime period and Mark Murphy sank two free throws that clinched a 53-50 victory for the Rams over Princeton at Jadwyn Gymnasium tonight.

title: Chrysler Cash Plan Extended
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it was extending its interest allowance plan indefinitely to continue giving car buyers a rebate on the cost of credit.

title: Advertising; Aetna's Campaign Goes on TV
description: THE Aetna Life and Casualty advocacy advertising campaign, one of the hottest insurance communications programs in print during the last four years, yesterday began testing the effectiveness of television.

title: WALLACE SAW IT FIRST
description: Saxon WASHINGTON - John B. Anderson's valiant effort in the otherwise vapid Presidential marathon reminded me of another maverick candidate - one who, unable to win the Presidential nomination of his own party, mounted separate campaigns for the White House: George C. Wallace.

title: Market Place; Phoenix Stock And Peru Oil
description: ALTHOUGH few have heard of the Phoenix Canada Oil Company, the Toronto-based concern may soon become as well known as the mythical bird after which it is named.

title: Shock and Nonshock
