description: Shock treatment, or electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), is generally accepted as a safe and effective treatment for serious depression. But a recent study suggests that the electricity passed through the patient's brain to produce a convulsion is not the essential therapeutic ingredient.

title: Accidents Delay Jersey Commuters
description: Accidents involving a tractor-trailer collision in Weehawken and a freight train derailment in Elizabeth caused heavy delays for New Jersey rush-hour commuters.

title: English Will Get Super Bowl TV
description: The sports promoter Jarvis Astaire said today that the Super Bowl game would be carried live by satellite to an English audience for the first time. Because of the six-hour time difference, it will begin at 11 P.M.

title: Washington
description: Price controls on crude oil and gasoline should be removed ''as soon as possible,'' James B. Edwards, Secretary of Energy-designate, told a Senate confirmation hearing. The marketplace should determine the cost of energy, he said. (Page B6.)

title: Surgery for Canadian Skier
description: The Canadian downhill skier Ken Read underwent surgery today to repair damage to his left knee and will not be able to resume training for six to eight months. A spokesman at St. Paul's Hospital said Read, 25 years old, tore two of the four major ligament complexes in his left knee. Surgeons also repaired the fractured nose Read sustained in the same fall during a downhill race Saturday at Garmisch-Partenkirchen, West Germany.

title: Kroger Announces Japan Food Pact
description: The Kroger Company, one of the nation's largest retail food chains, and Daiei Inc., Japan's largest food and general merchandise retailer, announced they had reached an agreement to jointly explore opportunties for ''mutually attractive and profitable business relations'' in the future.

title: George Papadopulos; Head of Sheriffs Group
description: George Papadopulos, former Stark County Sheriff who was president of the National Sheriffs Association, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 53 years old.

title: E.P.A. and Six Steel Plants Agree on Pollution Controls
description: The Government has signed a consent agreement that may result in up to $350 million in pollution controls being installed at six steel plants in Pennsylvania, Indiana and Ohio, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: Polish Strike Is Showen In Warsaw
description: The Grand Theater of Opera and Ballet was filled to capacity here tonight, but the production was neither opera nor ballet. It was Poland's hottest film - ''Workers 80,'' a documentary account of last summer's 16-day strike in the Gdansk shipyards.

title: MINIMUM SUPERVISOR PAY RAISED
description: The Carter Administration, rejecting a Republican request for a delay, today ordered a 45 percent increase in the minimum salary for supervisory employees who are exempt from Federal requirements for overtime pay.

title: WALDHEIM'S BOW TO THE ARAB VOTE
description: To the Editor:

title: USE OF MAILBOXES TO DISTRIBUTE LEAFLETS FACES STUDY
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Federal Government can prosecute someone for depositing unstamped mail in a neighbor's mailbox.

title: Baker, in Hospital, Is Improving
description: Physicians confirmed today that Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, was suffering from acute diverticulitis, an inflammation of the intestinal tract. Senator Baker, 55 years old, began experiencing abdominal pains yesterday noon and was hospitalized. A spokesman said that the Tennessee Republican ''is responding well to intravenous antibiotics'' and might be out of Sibley Hospital by the end of the week.

title: RAIDERS USED CLOCK
description: For all the wild similarities between the high-scoring American Football League games of the early 1960's and yesterday's American Conference championship, there was one major difference. When it was time for the Oakland Raiders to earn a trip to Super Bowl XV, they did what football players did when they wore leather helmets and crooked noses. The Raiders knocked people over.

title: Championing the 18th-Century Fortepiano
description: A man with a mission is Steven Lubin, a champion of the fortepiano, a small, light-toned, late-18th-century forerunner of the 12-foot concert grand used by most of today's pianists.

title: U.S. CITES MACK IN PRICING SUIT
description: The Justice Department filed a civil antitrust suit today alleging that Mack Trucks Inc. and the National Distributors Advisory Council conspired to raise and fix the prices of truck parts in the United States.

title: Linda Ronstadt, Ill, Misses Performance of 'Pirates'
description: Linda Ronstadt, who has a starring role in the new musical hit, ''The Pirates of Penzance,'' at the Uris Theater, was unable to perform last night because of illness. Joseph Papp, the producer, said that Miss Ronstadt was suffering from ''an acute sore throat - laryngitis.''

title: PICKUP IN RETAILING FORECAST FOR 2D HALF
description: Consumer spending is expected to be sluggish in the early months of 1981 but should improve during the second half of the year as inflation and interest rates ease off and credit buying begins to pick up, more than 1,000 retailers were told here yesterday.

title: Acid Snow
description: The soft white snow that bedecks the Adirondack Mountains these days may please skiers, but for fish in mountain lakes the snow may be even more toxic than acid rain, according to preliminary results of a study of Adirondack watersheds.

title: Kennecott Filing
description: The Kennecott Corporation said that it had disclosed in a final amendment to its tender offer filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission that 2.1 million shares of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation's common stock had been tendered and accepted for purchase. It said that included in the number were 39,787 shares subject to further documentation. Last Thursday, Kennecott terminated its offer to buy 4.1 million shares of Curtiss-Wright apparently because it was able to buy only about half the stock it wanted at the $40 a share price it was offering.

title: Dividend for MGM Grand
description: MGM Grand Hotels Inc. declared a regular quarterly cash dividend of 11 cents per share of common stock today despite the Nov. 21 MGM Grand Hotel fire that claimed 84 lives.

title: N.A.A.C.P. TO ASK REAGAN TO CALL PARLEY ON THE PLIGHT OF MINORITIES
description: The board of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People plans to ask President-elect Ronald Reagan this week to convene a conference in the first 100 days of his administration to address the economic plight of minorities.

title: Winnipeg Futures Offer
description: The Winnipeg Commodity Exchange said today that its financial division will offer futures contracts in Canadian Government Treasury bills and bonds, starting Feb. 2.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: LIKE news stories about sea monsters during the summer doldrums, reports about the college admissions ''rat race'' are hardy perennials every winter and early spring. The campuses are pictured as fortresses with deans of admissions pouring rejections from the battlement. By April, when the most selective colleges mail their dread letters, parents' and students' nerves are supposedly near the breaking point.

title: COURT BACKS U.S. ON TAX SHIFT
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the retroactive application of a 1976 change in Federal income tax law did not violate the constitutional rights of a taxpayer who acted on the basis of the old law and incurred an unexpected tax liability.

title: KOCH EXPECTED TO ADD TO FORCE OF TRANSIT POLICE
description: The Koch administration plans to continue a program of subway security through a combination of new hiring of up to 200 transit police officers and continued overtime for the equivalent of about 200 more, City Hall officials said yesterday. The program, in operation for the past three months, would have expired Jan. 26. It has provided for the equivalent of about 420 transit policemen.

title: Hart Schaffner Head Switches To Real Estate
description: John D. Gray, chairman of Hart Schaffner & Marx and one of the best-known executives in the men's clothing industry, will retire from the company in April to enter the real estate development business. His partner in the venture, which will develop areas in the West, particularly Colorado, is James Otis Jr., a Chicago architect and builder and a principal in Otis Associates Inc.

title: NOTES ON FASHIONS
description: They looked good last year, but this year they look even better: tweedy overcoats with raglan sleeves; loden coats with, but preferably without, inverted back pleats; stadium coats with toggle closings; traditional overcoats of all kinds worn with jeans or khakis, penny loafers or tennis shoes. New ones, though, cost a fortune and lack the patina that only age can impart to a garment. So buy an old one.

title: No Headline
description: Coach Don Coryell of San Diego said today that Gary Johnson, the Chargers' top defensive lineman, became ill and missed most of yesterday's American Conference championship after an act of sabotage on his car.

title: Nets Talk to Hawks' Brown
description: Nets officials have met with Hubie Brown, the Atlanta Hawks' coach, and have talked to him about the possibility of coaching the New Jersey team next season. The meeting took place Sunday in New York at the home of one of the Nets' owners.

title: INTEL; Intel
description: The Intel Corporation, a major producer of semiconductor memory circuits, reported yesterday that net income for the fourth quarter of 1980 slipped four-tenths of 1 percent, to $22.9 million, or 52 cents a share, from $23 million, or 54 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1979. Revenues rose 12.5 percent, to $219.2 million, from $194.8 million.

title: CARTER SAYS POSSIBILITY THAT HOSTAGES WILL BE FREED NOW 'LOOKS BETTER'
description: President Carter said today that the possibility of freeing the hostages in Iran before he leaves office ''looks better,'' but he cautioned that he was still unable to predict success in the negotiations.

title: BEGIN SAYS CABINET FAVORS EARLY VOTE
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that most of his Cabinet favored early parliamentary elections and that a final decision would be made this week.

title: ADVERTISING
description: PHILIP H. DOUGHERTY Rhode Island Agency For Wood Stove Marketer

title: REAGAN ECONOMIC TEAM REFLECTS POLICY CHANGES
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan's economic team is falling into place. Individuals identified with free-market economics and tax cuts have been selected for key jobs in the Treasury Department while highranking State Department posts have been filled with specialists in international economics.

title: Al Rosen Doing Well
description: Al Rosen, general manager of the Houston Astros, was described in ''great'' condition today as he recuperated from single bypass heart surgery.

title: 23 Arrested in Clash At Construction Site
description: Twenty-three men seeking jobs were arrested yesterday and two security guards were injured during a clash at the new convention center site on the West Side.

title: NORTHEASTERN CHILL BEGAN AS SIBERIAN WIND
description: Air that blew across the ice floes of the East Siberian Sea to the Chukotsky region of Siberia and its neighboring regions was sweeping down on the New York metropolitan area yesterday as it has been doing much of the time since the first of the year.

title: GUN CONTROL NEEDS NO ARMY OF POLICEMEN
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Edward A. Haymes, senior vice president of finance at Needham, Harper & Steers Inc., has been elected to the board.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 13, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on the Exercise of the In- alienable Rights of the Palestinian Peo- ple - 10:30 A.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: MISS AUSTIN OVER MISS JAEGER IN FINAL BY 6-2, 6-2
description: Despite a hamstring injury that flared up after her previous match, Tracy Austin beat Andrea Jaeger, 6-2, 6-2, tonight for the $75,000 first prize in the Colgate Series Championship.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JANUARY 13, 1981
description: International The Iranian Parliamet was forced to postpone at least untill tomorrow debate on two urgent government bills designed to clear the way for reaching agreement with the United States on the release of the American hostages. The delay dealt a blow to efforts to achieve a breakthrough before the end of President Carter's term next tuesday. A deputy speaker of the parliament , explaining the delay , said not not enough of Iran's Council of Guardians were present for the debate to proceed. (Page A1, Column 6.) Washington was warily hopeful about an early resolution of the 14-month hostage dispute. President Carter said that the prospect for reaching an accord to free the Americans in Iran before he leaves office ''looks better'' in light of the latest developments in Teheran, but he cautioned that he was still not able to predict success in the negotiations. (A6:1.)

title: BEDOUIN MEMBER OF THE ISRAELI PARLIAMENT IS SHOT TO DEATH IN JERUSALEM
description: A Bedouin Member of Parliament, Hammad Abu Rabia, was shot to death in Jerusalem tonight by gunfire from a jeep. Police roadblocks were immediately set up throughout the city and on the highways to Tel Aviv and the Dead Sea, but no arrests were reported in the killing, the first assassination of a member of Israel's Parliament.

title: Chicago Bank's Shift Bolsters President
description: Announcement last Friday of a realignment of top management responsibilities at the First National Bank of Chicago left little doubt that Richard L. Thomas, its 50-year-old president, had strengthened his position in the executive ranks after a year of struggle for himself and the bank.

title: Cold and Snow Disrupt Travel in Western Europe
description: Heavy snow fell across Western Europe today, disrupting train and highway traffic, trapping thousands of travelers in cars or at snowbound stations and keeping others at home.

title: U.S. Takes Bids For Alaska Oil
description: The Government announced today that it had begun accepting applications from private companies seeking to explore for oil and gas in the National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska.

title: CHAOS IN THE WINGS
description: THERE have been exhilarating discoveries during the past year about the ultimate nature of matter, the destiny of the universe, the structure and nature of the human animal. And yet the new year, beset with relentless economic decline, growing threats of war and other bad news brings little cheer.

title: Bridge: Phillip Martin Used Logic For a Remarkable Victory
description: One of the most satisfying experiences at the bridge table comes rarely to the expert and never to the inexperienced player. In a difficult contract, a series of delicate inferences permits the declarer to pinpoint the high cards and distribution in the opposing hands. Based on this he makes an abnormal play and brings home his contract.

title: GHOST-WRITING MATERIAL SEIZED IN STATE INQUIRY
description: College and university students awaiting ghost-written term papers are in for an unpleasant surprise, according to the office of State Attorney General Robert Abrams.

title: GUN CONTROL NEEDS NO ARMY OF POLICEMEN
description: To the Editor:

title: IRAQ RAISES OIL PRICE BY $4, TO $36 A BARREL
description: Iraq, the second-largest producer in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries before the outbreak of fighting with Iran, has joined other oil-producing countries in raising the price of its crude oil by $4 a barrel, the Middle East Economic Survey reported yesterday.

title: JUDGE APPOINTS OVERSEER TO INTEGRATE OHIO SUBURB
description: ''We might as well be living in Russia,'' said Thomas Rodano. ''It's probably something that has to be done,'' said Anthony Sagovic. ''I doubt it'll ever happen,'' said George Brayliss. ''Reagan won't let it.'' Just about everyone in Parma, Cleveland's largest suburb, has an opinion about the latest attack by Federal Judge Frank J. Battisti on practices that allegedly exclude blacks from this community on Ohio's populous northern edge.

title: Blowout at Drilling Rig Kills 1 in Gulf of Mexico
description: A blowout at a natural gas drilling rig today killed one man, injured two others seriously and forced dozens of workers to jump into the frigid Gulf of Mexico.

title: Ford Layoffs in Bordeaux
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it planned to lay off 3,650 workers at its Bordeaux transmission plant for up to two weeks this month to cut stocks in a declining European car market. Workers making automatic gear boxes will be laid off for two weeks from Jan. 19 while production of front-wheel axles will stop for one week from Jan. 26. The company said two or three weeks of layoffs were likely before the end of March and more stoppages were probable after that. blood sample.

title: Boris Bloch in Y Piano Recital
description: The pianist Boris Bloch will play a recital at the 92d Street Y on Thursday at 8 P.M. Mr. Bloch, who won the Young Concert Artists International Auditions in 1976 and the Grand Prize in Italy's Busoni Competition in 1978, will play Stravinsky's Serenade in A, Beethoven's Sonata in A (Op.2, No.2), Schumann's Three Fantasy Pieces (Op. 111), a selection of Chopin works, and Pabst's Concert Paraphrase on Tchaikovsky's ''Eugene Onegin'' (Op. 81). Tickets are $8.50, $7, and $6 at the 92d Street Y box office.

title: A.T.&T. System Lifts Call Capacity
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced that it had put in operation a new transmission system, called ''single sideband'' that can triple the call-handling capacity of most existing long-distance telephone facilities.

title: TV: FLAMINGO ROAD' SPORTS 2 BIG DADDIES
description: BIG daddies are big business in television these days, and ''Flamingo Road,'' an NBC-TV foray into ''Dallas'' territory, is so big it has two of them. Sheriff Titus Semple (Howard Duff) dresses like Colonel Sanders and oversees legal matters in Truro, Fla., while Claude Weldon (Kevin McCarthy) is the hamlet's reigning aristocrat. Together, these patriarchs meddle in the affairs of the townsfolk, who supply plenty of affairs to be meddled in.

title: N.C.A.A. Woman Criticized
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association calls Ruth Berkey director of women's championships. Some members of the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women call her turncoat.

title: Steel Output Edges Higher
description: Steel production rose to 2.327 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of eight-tenths of 1 percent from the previous week's 2.309 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry's production amounted to 78.8 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 78.2 percent in the previous week. Estimated figures for the year to date showed production at 3.317 million net tons, a decrease of two-tenths of 1 percent from the 3.325 million net tons in the previous year.

title: ATOP BRUTAL MT. WASHINGTON, SCIENTISTS MEASURE THE NATION'S WORST WEATHER
description: MOUNT WASHINGTON, N.H. IT is eight miles to the summit by the winding auto road, eight hard miles in driving winds through snow drifts and over ice in a snowplow tractor that grinds, groans, lurches, but manages to keep a grip on the treacherous terrain. At the top finally, after an hour and a half, the tractor comes to a stop at the door of the Mount Washington Observatory, where meteorologists maintain a vigil in some of the most forbidding winter weather known to earth.

title: SIMPLE TEST COULD SCREEN ALL EXPECTANT MOTHERS
description: ALL expectant mothers, not just those known to be at risk of producing deformed or diseased babies, may soon be able to take a simple test for the presence of certain common crippling or lethal birth defects which may strike at random in families with no history of the disorders.

title: ARCHIVST TO SUPPLY LOGS OF HAIG TAPES IF NIXON ACQUIESCES
description: Robert W. Warner, the National Archivist, said today that if former President Nixon did not object before Saturday, he would supply the Senate Foreign Relations Committee with logs summarizing 100 hours of taped 1973 conversations between Mr. Nixon and Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title: U.S. AID FOR NEEDY STUDENTS
description: Gladieux WASHINGTON - If the Reagan administration and the 97th Congress want to focus Federal policies more sensibly, aid to students is one place to begin.

title: Toyota's '81 Outlook
description: The Toyota Motor Sales Company expects exports to decline and domestic sales to increase in 1981, Sadazo Yamamoto, president, said. He added that Toyota Motor sales has set 1981 targets at 1.7 million vehicles for export and 1.6 million for domestic sale, compared with 1980 exports of 1.8 million and domestic sales of 1.5 million. Mr. Yamamoto said the lower 1981 export target followed increasing competition from small United States-made cars, reduced price competitiveness because of the yen's appreciation against the dollar and other factors, including trade frictions.

title: Canada Warned On Oil Sands
description: Canada's national energy program has probably delayed development of two major oil sands projects in northern Alberta by at least two years and is bound to cut production, Texaco Canada's chairman, Robert Sparks, said today.

title: THE PERILS OF QUANTIFIED LIFE
description: To the Editor:

title: Index; International
description: Soviet actor says his popularity is preventing his emigration A2 An Arab Member of Parliament is slain in Jerusalem A3 Begin says most of his Cabinet favors early elections A3 2 U.S. journalists and South African injured in El Salvador A3 Around the World A10 Poland ousts demonstrators from town hall in southeast A10 Government/Politics Louisiana judge again defies school desegregation order A12 Jersey plan to restrict building provokes furor in Pine Barrens B1 Supreme Court Roundup B7 Judge's order turns over Abscam documents to defense lawyers B7 General Air Force psychiatrist says isolation made Garwood paranoia A12 Around the Nation A12 Tarnower trial witness tells of a new bloodstain B2 Finding a taxi is harder than usual on a cold day with no subways B3 Derailment in Brooklyn increases strain on transit service B3 N.A.A.C.P. wants national parley on plight of minorities B7 Dismissal of Hells Angels charges rejected B7 Style Notes on Fashion B8 Fur, down and sheepskin: staying warm in style B8 A jewelry display fit for a king B8 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of the cold weather, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. All other parking regulations remain in effect. Science Times New tests may allow universal screening for birth defects C1 Scientists brave nation's worst weather at Mt. title: Bids of Lynn And Fisk Unresolved
description: Representatives of the Major League Baseball Players Association and the owners' player relations committee met yesterday on the grievances filed by Fred Lynn and Carlton Fisk, but the Boston players will have to wait to learn if they can be free agents.

title: Hormone Is Tested
description: Genentech, the gene-splicing technology company, today said it has started the first tests on humans of a synthetic growth hormone manufactured by genetically altered bacteria.

title: MET OPERA: MOZART'S 'DIE ZAUBERFLOTE '
description: IN this abbreviated, hastily put-together season, Metropolitan Opera audiences probably must learn to subsist on half-loaves and emergency rations. It would be unreasonable to demand casts crammed with world-class artists in a season that we are fortunate to have at all. With that reservation in mind, it may be allowed that last night's performance of ''Die Zauberflote,'' the first of the season, held to a level of ensemble and individual effort that did not seriously embarrass anyone. Mozart's final opera should offer higher rewards, ideally, but a night such as this one at least can remind us now and then of those heights.

title: Marschalk's Reshuffle
description: Marschalk, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, had a busy board meeting yesterday. They made Myron Polenberg a senior vice president, promoted Richard Villante and Robert Gold to the executive committee and put board seats under Daniel E. Cohen, Jack Dauer, Lester A. Delano, Gary Geyer and Arthur Wilen. The executive committee now has eight chairs and the board 17, a nice round number.

title: PROTEIN RESEARCH CHALLENGES A POPULAR VIEW ON DIETING
description: THE popular belief among dieters that it is easiest to lose unwanted pounds of fat on a high-protein, low-carbohydrate diet has been challenged by an experiment in rats at the University of Virginia.

title: SCHOOLS TRY TO TEACH LANGUAGES TO EVERYONE
description: WILLIAM RODRIGUEZ, a freshman at New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn, began the school year last September in a regular Spanish course, but when he could not keep up with the work he transferred into an easier conversational Spanish class, where, he says, he is getting more attention from the teacher and learning more.

title: Secretary Haig, Medals and All
description: We are ready to concede that Alexander Haig is more diplomat than militarist. Behind a cloud of polysyllabic fog, he has dodged the snipers of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, maneuvered past the booby traps that the Reagan campaign left lying around and unhitched his team from the dead weight of the Republican Party platform. Respectful of the politics of the day, he promises a reversal of President Carter's direction; respectful of reality, he supports all of Mr. Carter's major diplomatic achievements. General Haig's confirmation testimony was the sort that leaves mere soldiers stumbling in confusion, but invigorates diplomats everywhere. He is tough and flexible, articulate and fuzzy, devious and direct: a Secretary of State.

title: Pro Hockey: A Numbers Game
description: Numbers in record amounts have had National Hockey League fans buzzing this season. The Rangers' Phil Esposito retired last Friday with the second highest point total in league history. Marcel Dionne of the Los Angeles Kings reached the 1,000-point plateau last week in fewer games than any other player. And Mike Bossy of the Islanders and the Kings' Charlie Simmer were threatening the goal-scoring records, one of which is held by Esposito.

title: JUDGE ORDERS U.S. TO GIVE ABSCAM DATA TO DEFENSE
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered the Justice Department to turn over to defense lawyers thousands of documents on the Abscam investigation for use in a defense effort to overturn corruption convictions of four present or former members of Congress and three other men.

title: SURPRISE CITY
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 MILE ISLAND: FINANCIAL FALLOUT
description: A biting, insistent cold gripped Three Mile Island in the middle of the frozen Susquehanna River here the other day.

title: TO REDUCE THE PENALTY FOR SERVING A PRESIDENT
description: To the Editor:

title: HEAT COMPLAINTS AND USE OF FUEL BOTH SHOW RISE
description: Complaints of heatless buildings mounted yesterday as New York City officials reported a ''substantial increase'' in the number of housing inspectors on duty and the bitter cold continued.

title: WATER LEVELS ARE BELOW NORMAL IN MUCH OF NATION, STUDY FINDS
description: Last year was the driest since 1977, and water levels remain below normal in many parts of the country, particularly the Northeast, the United States Geological Survey reported today.

title: Reds Release Geronimo To Put Biittner on Roster
description: Cesar Geronimo, the Cincinnati outfielder, was released tonight by the Reds to make room on the 40-man roster for Larry Biittner, the newly acquired free agent.

title: HELLS ANGELS LOSE PLEA OVER U.S. PAYMENT TO WITNESS
description: A Federal judge today denied a motion to dismiss racketeering charges against 11 members of the Hells Angels motorcycle club, rejecting a defense argument that a $30,000 payment to a key prosecution witness constituted misconduct by the prosecution.

title: Room on the Shelf
description: In ''A Room of One's Own,'' Virginia Woolf tells how she is denied access to a library in a great university because she is unaccompanied by a gentleman. Then, researching a lecture she is to give on women in fiction, she discovers that although woman ''pervades poetry from cover to cover she is all but absent from history.''

title: Kodak's Spending to Rise
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said today that it had budgeted nearly $1.4 billion in capital spending for expansion and improvements in 1981, a 55 percent rise over 1980. The company said its photographic division planned expenditures of $967 million, with $658 million for projects in the United States and Canada and $309 million for its international divisions.

title: Frederick Croton in Los Angeles Arts Post; Frederick Croton Named To Los Angeles Arts Post
description: Frederick Roy Croton, executive director of the Bronx Council on the Arts, has been appointed general manager of the new Cultural Affairs Department of Los Angeles.

title: STARDOM BARS SOVIET ACTOR'S VISA
description: Savyely Kramarov complained today that his popularity with Soviet movie audiences was standing in the way of his being permitted to emigrate to Israel.

title: HURT TO STAR IN 'CHILDE BYRON'
description: DESPITE his new status as a sought-after film star - his latest picture is Ken Russell's ''Altered States'' - William Hurt remains a Circle Repertory perennial. The actor's next role at the tiny Off Broadway theater will be Lord Byron in Romulus Linney's new play ''Childe Byron,'' opening Feb. 18. Mr. Hurt's co-star as Countess Augusta Ada, Byron's daughter, will be Lindsay Crouse, his co-star in the Circle Rep's ''Hamlet'' last season. Marshall W. Mason, the theater's artistic director, will stage the play.

title: COUNTERING THE SPREAD OF THE FLU VIRUS
description: AS an illness that predominates during the winter months, it's not unusual for flu to spoil the Christmas holidays for millions of Americans, and this year was no exception. In cities and towns throughout the country, flu-afflicted hosts and hostesses were forced to cancel parties, others directed preparations from bed, and still others postponed planned gatherings because so many of their guests were laid low by this fast-spreading virus.

title: Advertising; Shulton's New Men's Fragrance
description: OVER at Shulton, the toiletries division of American Cyanamid, it is being called the biggest new-product introduction in the history of men's fragrances.

title: THEATER: AMERICAN PLACE OPENS WITH 'WHITENESS'
description: ''WE beat each other with words,'' explains the young hero in Richard Hamburger's family play, ''Memory of Whiteness.'' He isn't exaggerating. If words were weapons, Mr. Hamburger's would be baseball bats. His characters talk and talk and talk, only to send both themselves and the audience into a stupor. ''Whiteness,'' which opened last night, is a bleak curtain raiser for the American Place's new season.

title: SORG PRINTING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
An Italian Businessman Escapes From Kidnappers After 2 Months
description: A businessman escaped today from the house where kidnappers had held him for more than two months, the police said.

title: Pitcher Is Top Draft Pick
description: A left-handed pitcher from Morris Community College in Dover, N.J., was the No. 1 selection yesterday in major league baseball's annual draft of amateur players.

title: Index; International
description: Urguayans apprehensive as re- buffed military ponders future A2 Soviet head of Warsaw Pact makes surprise visit to Warsaw A3 Around the World A4 Israel arrests six in murder of Bedouin Parliament member A5 Government/Politics New Federal project requires hearing protectors A12 U.S. commissions suggests Social Security funding changes A12 Casey, at confirmation hearing, opposes C.I.A. reorganization A16 General Around the Nation A12 Study links high-absorbency tam- pons to toxic shock syndrome A13 Housing secretary-designee testi- fies on retrenchment A16 Witness indicates Dr. Tarnower had held gun used to kill him B2 DR. KING OBSERVANCE Tomorrow is the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Following are holiday schedules: Sanitation - Regular collections in New York City. Federal offices - Open. State offices - Open in New York, closed in Connecticut and New Jersey. Municipal offices - Open in New York, many closed in Connecticut and New Jersey. Post offices - Open; regular schedule. Banks - Open in New York, closed in Connecticut and New Jersey. Stock and commodities exchanges -Open. Transportation - Regular schedules. Libraries - Open. Schools - In Connecticut and New Jersey, most closed tomorrow. In New York, open tomorrow, closed Monday.

title: EX-PRESS SECRETARY JOINING FORD MOTOR BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Jerald F. terHorst, 58, a Washington correspondent for The Detroit News and former President Gerald R. Ford's press secretary for the first 30 days of his Administration, has been named Washington public affairs director for the Ford Motor Company, effective tomorrow. The position is new and separate from Ford's Government affairs operation in Washington.

title: DATA GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 20
description: B-Including $5,100 extraordinary gain

title: Books Of The Times
description: John Leonard GOING FOR THE GOLD. By Emma La- then. 251 pages. Simon & Schuster. $11.95. THE BURGLAR WHO STUDIED SPINOZA. By Lawrence Block. 213 pages. Random House. $8.95. THE BLOOD OF AN ENGLISHMAN. By James McClure. 270 pages. Harper & Row. $10.95.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Airwick Industries Inc., Carlstadt, N.J., has named Wesley M. Buckner president of the Consumer Products division; Richard P. Polizzotto president of the Airwick of Canada Ltd. subsidiary, and Richard W. Bankart senior vice president/marketing in the Consumer Products division.

title: DAMON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $118,441 extraordinary tax credit

title: No Headline
description: Rozelle, Davis Meet With Judge; No Gain

title: TV: 'TERROR AMONG US,' MOVIE ABOUT A RAPIST
description: ''TERROR AMONG US,'' the CBS-TV ''Wednesday Night Movie'' at 9:30 o'clock, sends a mixed message, possibly because it is itself so confused. Ostensibly, it is about a rapist, who murders one woman and brutalizes five others. Actually, it is about some airline flight attendants who live next to a marina in California and chat about their problems. Will Jennifer take a job at ground school? Will Vicki marry her flight engineer? Will Cathy pursue her affair with a married man? The ambience, not to mention the background music, is from ''The Love Boat,'' and it is the most fetching part of the movie.

title: A JUDGE A TRADITION; Spit and Polish
description: The wise man of the week, so far, is George Huffman, a military policeman in Norfolk, Va. He was asked about a report that the Defense Department will do away with spit-shined black boots and replace them with a new rough-textured, earth-colored variety.

title: U.S. EASES INQUIRIES ON BRIBERY
description: In an effort to allay concerns expressed by lawyers, accountants and top corporate executives, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission laid out publicly today a policy of relaxed enforcement of the accounting provisions of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act of 1977.

title: U.S. FAVORS PLAN TO GIVE 'VILLAGE' BUILDING TO CITY
description: The General Services Administration agreed in principle today to turn over to New York for residential use a massive, empty Federal building in Greenwich Village.

title: PAUL CUNNINGHAM
description: Paul Cunningham, former associate producer and London correspondent for NBC-TV's ''Today'' show and NBC News, died of cancer yesterday at his home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 63 years old.

title: India Lifts Gasoline Price
description: The Indian Government raised the price of gasoline and all domestic petroleum products today following a 10 percent increase in crude prices announced by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: 'THE GOOD SAMARITAN WAS NOT USING FOOD AS A WEAPON
description: John R. Block, the Secretary of Agriculture-designate, has stated that food can be used as a weapon in international relations. The idea of ''food as a weapon'' as a major thrust of the United States' international food policy is unacceptable. The idea of food as a weapon, though not a specific guide to policy, implies certain actions and motives, and rules out others.

title: ARIZONA BANK (PHOENIX) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reagan Names Personnel Aide
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan today named the chief talent-hunter for the Presidential transition, E. Pendleton James, to be assistant to the President for personnel in the new administration. Mr. James, 51 years old, who heads a Los Angeles-based executive-recruitment concern, served as an assistant on personnel matters to President Nixon from 1971 to 1973.

title: SHOOSMITH CHARGED
description: The Justice Department filed felony bid-rigging charges against Shoosmith Bros. Inc. of Richmond as part of a major criminal antitrust investigation.

title: REAGAN'S BID ADIEU TO THEIR CALIFORNIA
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan reminisced today about his first screen test, his ''addiction'' to jellybeans and his jousting with Democratic foes as he said goodbye to his fellow Californians in a day filled with nostalgia and what Mr. Reagan said were his ''mixed emotions'' about leaving for the White House.

title: JERSEY CASINOS EXPECT FIRST MONTHLY DEFICITS SINCE THEIR OPENINGS
description: The gross revenues of Atlantic City's casinos decreased sharply last month, the New Jersey Casino Control Commission reported yesterday. Industry spokesmen said the figures would translate into the first net losses for any month since casino gambling began in the state in 1978.

title: DON WHITEHEAD, PULITZER PRIZE WINNER FOR DISPATCHES ON KOREAN WAR
description: Don Whitehead, a war correspondent for The Associated Press who won two Pulitzer Prizes for international reporting for dispatches on the Korean War, died at his home in Knoxville, Tenn. on Monday of lung cancer after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

title: McEnroe-Borg Duel Looming
description: A reporter, ready with a notepad, a pen and a carefully constructed question, approached the curly haired tennis player. ''How would you compare your style to Borg's and McEnroe's?'' she asked. ''I am McEnroe,'' the player replied, with a combination of pique and amusement.

title: BLACK WOMAN GIVEN CHICAGO SCHOOL JOB
description: Ruth B. Love was hired as Chicago's first black general superintendent of schools today after a vote by the school board that ended a long and agonizing search.

title: EDWARD'S FRIENDS
description: To the Editor:

title: SHIVERING TENANTS CONTINUE COMPLAINTS AS KOCH LISTENS
description: As heatless tenants continued to call New York City's emergency complaint office in unprecedented numbers yesterday, Mayor Koch, accompanied by a phalanx of housing aides, visited the office ''to dramatize that people can call here and get help.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report yesterday incorrectly described Governor Byrne's message to the New Jersey Legislature. Mr. Byrne will deliver his final State of the State message next January, shortly before he leaves office.

title: WINE Q&A
description: Q. Thank you for the vintage chart you ran a few months ago. However, I always found the A, B, C, D ratings of great help. Is there any chance that these ratings will be included in your next chart or any possibility for you to have something like that available shortly? IRWIN ROBINSTON Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: Penn Central Sets Redemption Dates
description: The Penn Central Corporation said it had set tentative dates for the redemption of some of its securities. The redemption is to be made out of the approximately $2.1 billion proceeds the company expects to receive tomorrow from its valuation case settlement with the Federal Government and the United States Railway Association.

title: Syncrude Suspends Oil Sands Project
description: The management committee of Syncrude Canada Ltd. said today that it had indefinitely suspended preliminary engineering studies for the long-planned multibillion-dollar Syncrude oil sands plant expansion because of unfavorable economics resulting from Government policies.

title: California Men Held In Art Dealer's Death
description: Two California men have been extradited to New York and charged with slaying a Manhattan art dealer and his associate during a robbery last year. They were ordered held without bail yesterday.

title: JAPANESE SAY GROUNDWORK IS LAID FOR MILITARY BUILDUP
description: After a year of debate within the Government, Japan ended 1980 with a budget in which the military received a 7.6 percent increase.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE wine boom had begun, and speculators were buying up the 1970-vintage Bordeaux with reckless abandon. It was a very large crop, the quality was good and everybody was convinced that prices would rise. The French were buying as usual, and so were the British and the Swiss, but a new element of demand was being exerted by the Americans, who for the first time seemed to be focusing their mass buying on a single French vintage.

title: RANGERS PLAY 4-4 TIE
description: The Rangers scored three third-period goals and gained a 4-4 deadlock with the Flames last night in Calgary, Alberta. Article on page A21.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I cannot bring myself to render a judgment on Richard Nixon, or for that matter, Henry Kissinger.

title: Telecom Merger Wins Approval
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission said it had approved a merger agreement under which the Telecom Corporation will acquire Spector Industries Inc., which does business as Spector Freight System.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE NATION; Radical Puerto Rican Group Denounces Statehood Fight

title: NOMINEE DISCUSSES ARMS POLICY
description: Frank C. Carlucci, who has been nominated to be Deputy Secretary of Defense, indicated the possibility today that the Reagan administration might sell military weapons to China.

title: Tighten the Federal Blue Collar
description: The Reagan administration, pressed to reduce spending, might well look at Federal wages for blue-collar workers. In theory, the pay of the Government's 400,000 hourly-wage earners is linked to the pay of those working for private companies. In fact, the Government's wages are often substantially higher. Closing the gap could save the taxpayers $6 billion over the next five years.

title: KNICKS SAG AT END, CELTICS WIN
description: The Knicks went without a field goal for the final 4 minutes 17 seconds last night and were beaten by the Boston Celtics, 93-89, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Leonardo Codex in Show At the Corcoran in Capital
description: A 470-year-old da Vinci manuscript, the Codex Leicester, will be exhibited at the Corcoran Gallery of Art as part of the activities for the inauguration of President-elect Ronald Reagan.

title: Economic Scene; Budget Deficit's Effect on Policy
description: ELECT RONALD REAGAN'S bold campaign program of big tax cuts, which supposedly would pay for themselves by stimulating economic growth while simultaneously checking inflation, is being postponed as his economic advisers contemplate the large budget deficit looming in the fiscal year 1981.

title: Chess: In Averting Sunday Punch, Watch for One on Monday
description: There are days when nothing seems to help - when you guide the game away from the channel of your opponent's greatest strength and he clobbers you with something else.

title: FROST IN FLORIDA WILL MEAN HIGHER VEGETABLE PRICES
description: IT is no consolation for those suffering in the freezing North to learn that all is not balm and sunshine down in Florida. Frost and temperatures as low as 17 degrees have seriously affected the vegetable harvest and prices are going to rise.

title: Australians Seize Suspect In Woolworth Bombings
description: The police ordered shoppers out of all stores and supermarkets in the Woolworth chain today after a man was arrested in connection with a wave of bombings and extortion threats against the company.

title: Miss Austin Stakes Claim to No. 1 Spot
description: All Tracy Austin wanted after her victory over Andrea Jaeger in the Colgate Series championships last night was a giant hot fudge sundae and a No. 1 world ranking for 1980, although not necessarily in that order.

title: SIGNS OF 'STRUGGLE' CITED AT HARRIS HALL
description: uf881 By JAMES FERON

title: WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE FORCES THAT THWART PRESIDENTIAL BUDGET AIMS; News Analysis
description: One of President Carter's legacies to President-elect Ronald Reagan is a 1981 Government budget that is running $47 billion above the spending figure that Mr. Carter proposed a year ago and may climb higher.

title: EX-RADICAL LEADER GETS PROBATION AND FINE IN 1969 CHICAGO PROTESTS
description: Bernardine Dohrn, the reputed former leader of the radical Weather Underground, pleaded guilty today to two counts of aggravated battery and two counts of jumping bail, charges stemming from violent protests here against the Vietnam War in 1969.

title: CITY PLANS TO ADD 1,000 MORE OFFICERS IN NEXT FISCAL YEAR14>
description: The Koch administration plans to hire 1,000 more police officers in the next fiscal year and to free 500 officers in clerical jobs for possible street duty by replacing them with lower-paid civilians, New York City officials said yesterday.

title: RETAILERS TOLD INDUSTRY NEEDS BOLDNESS TO THRIVE
description: The retailing industry is going through one of its most difficult periods in decades, necessitating ''bold breakthroughs and creative thinking,'' Lasker M. Meyer, chairman and chief executive officer of Abraham & Straus, warned retailers at a national convention in New York yesterday.

title: 2 Sides Speak At Gilbert Trial
description: The trial of Edward M. Gilbert on stock-fraud charges opened yesterday in Manhattan's Federal District Court. Peter J. Romatowski, a Federal prosecutor, told the jury that Mr. Gilbert had fraudulently manipulated the stock price of the Conrac Corporation, a maker of electronic equipment.

title: Merrill Lynch
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. has informed the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has acquired 36 percent of General Health Services Inc. by purchasing 1 million of its common shares at $32 each, or a total of $32 million. In its filing, the nation's largest securities firm said it had bought the shares from two estates ''in the course of its normal arbitrage activities.'' The filing also said that a merger was to be consummated between General Health Services, which operates acute-care general hospitals and laboratories, and a subsidiary of the Hospital Corporation of America, one of the world's largest hospital management companies.

title: Cagney Is Slightly Injured in Auto Accident
description: The 81-year-old actor James Cagney had what a friend yesterday described as ''a very close call'' when a car in which he was a passenger reportedly ran a stop sign and collided with another auto. He suffered a bruised knee but was not hospitalized.

title: GOLDEN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DECEMBER RETAIL SALES DOWN 1.3%
description: Sales by United States retailers fell in December after climbing slowly but steadily since May, the Commerce Department announced today.

title: THE BONING KNIFE
description: MOST legs of lamb sold in this country come with an extraneous bone, the hip bone, which takes up space, makes the roast harder to carve and contributes virtually nothing of value to the roast. But it is apparently too much trouble for most butchers to remove. And if that extra bone weren't irritating enough, there is the fat: thick armor-like coats of it, when all anyone wants is a thin layer.

title:
RED SMITH;
A View From the Top
description: ''P HILADELPHIA is a most pecksniffian of American cities, and thus probably leads the world.'' When Henry L. Mencken wrote those lines, pecksniffery - ''being addicted to fatuous and hypocritical talk of benovolence and other kindly virtues,'' according to the American Heritage Dictionary - was just about the only area where Philadelphia led anybody. The city was honeycombed with subway tunnels where trains never ran, you could blow dust off the drinking water, and the sports teams were good for a laugh almost any time they took the field.

title: Real Estate; The Empire State Building
description: FOR those who take up the annual challenge of the Road Runners Club of New York to dash up 86 flights of stairs at the Empire State Building, a tough climb awaits them on Feb. 12. Last year 36 men and women competed in the invitation-only event. The winning man was clocked at 12 minutes, 20 seconds. The woman with the fastest time was clocked at 14 minutes, 39 seconds.

title: NEMEROV, MAY SWENSON SHARE THE BOLLINGEN PRIZE
description: The poet Howard Nemerov, winner of the Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Award in 1978, and May Swenson, whose most recent collection of poems is ''New and Selected Things Taking Place,'' have been awarded the Bollingen Prize in poetry by the Yale University Library.

title: Theokas to Shift Job
description: Joe Taub, the principal owner of the Nets, confirmed yesterday what had been suggested informally for a while: No matter whom the Nets select as coach for next season, their first in the new Meadowlands Arena, this season is Charlie Theokas's last as general manager.

title: LAUREN BACALL IS WOMAN OF THE YEAR
description: FROM the days when she was a teen-ager selling a show-business weekly outside Sardi's, Lauren Bacall regarded herself as ''a frustrated musical performer.'' And years later, after Hollywood and after Bogart, when she finally opened in ''Applause,'' the acclaim was instant and unanimous. ''With this thundering appearance,'' wrote Walter Kerr of the 1970 show, ''Miss Bacall ceases being a former movie star and becomes a star of the stage.'' Given such an auspicious debut - and two Tony awards, to boot - it was hardly surprising that the actress responded with enthusiasm when Lawrence Kasha, the producer of ''Applause,'' recently approached her with a similar project. This month, she began rehearsals for ''Woman of the Year,'' a musical adaptation of that classic 1942 film starring Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy.

title: MIDLANTIC BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TOILERS OF THE GARMENT DISTRICT
description: Ralph Lauren, Mollie Parnis, Bill Blass - Angelo Leone has pleated for them all. In the parlance of the apparel trade, Mr. Leone is a pleater. Every day he unrolls bolts of fabric sent by garment manufacturers to his loft on West 40th Street. Then he folds them - into box pleats, butterfly pleats, side pleats and sunburst pleats. He does not always pleat, of course; sometimes he tucks.

title: Cash in Jenrette's Home Linked to Abscam Bills
description: Justice Department officials said tonight that serial numbers of some of the currency reportedly found at the home of former Representative John W. Jenrette Jr. matched those on cash given to one of his friends in the Abscam investigation.

title: U.S. PRESSING TOKYO TO BUTTRESS FORCES
description: Senior American officials have quietly urged Japanese officials in recent months to build conventional military power capable of defeating Soviet naval and air forces above, on and below the seas for a distance of 1,000 miles from Japan's shores.

title: NUCLEAR PHARMACY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
AT HOUSEWARES SHOW, GADGETS AND COOKWARE OF ALL SORTS
description: CHICAGO ''AN up show,'' Yann Weymouth, an architect, said of the 74th exposition sponsored by the National Housewares Manufacturers Association, which is being held at McCormick Place this week.

title: U.S. Appellate Court Hands Down A Key Ruling on Sex Harassment
description: A Federal appellate court ruled yesterday that a woman could sue her employer to stop sexual harassment on the job without having to prove that she lost job benefits by resisting the harassment.

title: President Again Extends Heat and Cooling Limits
description: Citing continuing instability in the oil-producing Persian Gulf states, President Carter today extended for nine more months the restrictions that limit most nonresidential buildings to winter space heating of 65 degrees Fahrenheit and summer air-conditioning of 78 degrees.

title: MILLER ASKS BETTER PLAN ON CHRYSLER
description: Treasury Secretary G. William Miller said today that the survival plan submitted by the Chrysler Corporation must be improved to provide a greater financial cushion for the company before the Government could approve $400 million in additional loan guarantees.

title: FOR MARATHON SPONSERS, THANK YOU'S THUNDER IN
description: Out in Eugene, Ore., Ardie Arnis, who describes herself as ''a 46-year-old woman with dark, graying hair,'' still has her mind on a man she met in New York last October.

title: COMMODITY OPTION ENTICES EXCHANGES
description: Just as stock options and financial futures developed into the hot investments of the 1970's, the nation's financial exchanges hope to make a new product, commodity options, the trading star of the 1980's.

title: U.S. SET TO RESUME MILITARY ASSISTANCE TO SALVADOR
description: The Carter Administration is expected to announce tomorrow the resumption of $5 million in military aid to El Salvador that was suspended early last month after reports that Salvadoran security forces were involved in the slaying of four American women.

title: New Rate for Ruble
description: The Soviet Union announced a new exchange rate yesterday for the United States dollar and the Soviet ruble. The rate is now 66.80 rubles per $100, changed from 67.50 rubles.

title: Sipe of Browns Cited
description: Brian Sipe, the Cleveland Browns quarterback, yesterday was named the National Football League's most valuable player for 1980 by the Professional Football Writers of America. Sipe was presented the football writers' Schick Trophy at a luncheon in New York City.

title: IN LIEU OF MISSILES ON WHEELS
description: To the Editor:

title: One-Day Strike Set At British Airways
description: Nine thousand British Airways employees voted to stage a 24-hour strike Jan. 23 over a pay dispute that could ground the national airline and worsen its already shaky financial position.

title: B-O-P CORP (READING, PENNA) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 14, 1981
description: International American officials expressed concern that their hopes of freeing the 52 hostages by the time the Carter Administration leaves office next Tuesday might be dashed by the latest indications of political disarray in Iran. Several officials said they suspected that a militant group was seeking to block an accord with Washington, and a senior official said that time was ''running out.'' (Page A1, Columns 3-4.) A procedural delay in Teheran caused the postponement of parliamentary action on legislation required by Iran for the release of the American hostages, but officials said a vote would be taken today. The postponement resulted from the failure of enough members of a key panel to attend a meeting to approve the legislation. (A10:1.)

title: New Man Magazine Aims at Single Men
description: American Communications and Entertainment has been established to publish New Man, subtitled National Magazine for Single Men.

title: PAYLESS CASHWAYS (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: 1980 net was reduced by $684,000 or 7 cents a shr for the qr and $2.4 million or 21 cents a shr for the yr from conversion from FIFO to the LIFO inventory accounting method effective in the fourth qr

title: 'Ordinary People' Tops Golden Globe Nominations
description: ''Ordinary People,'' ''Raging Bull'' and ''The Stunt Man'' yesterday captured the most nominations for Golden Globe Awards.

title: DORCHESTER GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Shr earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid this month

title: Household Finance's Wien Bid Accepted
description: The Household Finance Corporation said that Robert Miller, a former director of Wien Air Alaska Inc. and owner of 48,749 shares of Wien stock, had accepted the cash merger price of $6 a share under which Household Finance had proposed acquiring Wien.

title: CAMBEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
COMFORTS OF SAUSAGES AND POTATOES
description: THIS is the weather in which even the most die-hard non-cooks will turn to cooking for themselves, partly to keep warm and partly as a way of warding off depression and inertia brought on by freezing winds and icy sidewalks.

title: A JUDGE A TRADITION; Well-Tempered Justice
description: Last summer, when the Supreme Court struck down the ''Dooling decision'' on Medicaid abortion funds, the Federal District Court judge who wrote it thought of those whose lives would be intimately affected. ''How could they do this to the poor?'' he asked an acquaintance.

title: STUDT LINKS HIGH-ABSORBENCY TAMPONS TO DISEASE
description: A three-month study by the State Health Departments of Minnesota, Wisconsin and Iowa has concluded that users of high-absorbency tampons have a greater risk of developing toxic shock syndrome than do women who use less absorbent tampons.

title: Dutch Court Upholds Conviction Of Menten for Wartime Murders
description: The Dutch Supreme Court today upheld the conviction and sentence against the art collector Pieter Nicolaas Menten, who has twice been found guilty of murdering Jews in World War II.

title: South Alabama 80 North Carolina-Charlotte 63
description: Ed Rains made 14 of 19 field-goal attempts and had 31 points as South Alabama scored an 80-63 Sun Belt Conference victory over North Carolina-Charlotte tonight.

title: U.S. PANEL BACKS USE OF INCOME TAX MONEY TO AID SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The Government should aid the Social Security system by using income tax revenues to meet a coming cash shortage, a Congressional study said today,

title: FULLER, H B, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After $472,000 extraordinary loss; 1980 net includes unrealiz foreign currency translation gains of 8 cents a shr for the qr and 16 cents for the yr

title: Eban Says Labor Party Would Speed Arab Rule
description: Abba Eban, former Foreign Minister, said today that a government formed by the Labor Party would begin granting powers of self-government to Palestinians in the occupied West Bank even before a formal agreement on autonomy.

title: Farm Policies Draw Warning
description: This country's farm policies and laws, originally conceived to combat crop surpluses and low farm prices and basically unchanged in the past 50 years, are out of date, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: CARROLS DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $264,000 tax credit for the 1980 qr and $233,000 tax credit for the 1979 qr...C-Including $936,000 tax credit fo the 1980 6 mos and $836,000 tax credit for the 1979 mos

title: RANGERS TIE FLAMES
description: The New York Rangers scored three thirdperiod goals, two on power plays, to tie the Calgary Flames, 4-4, tonight.

title: WOMAN PLACED IN DIVISION I
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association, after three votes and a long parliamentary struggle, voted today to conduct women's championship tournaments in Division I, the group that until now had been exclusively the division of the major men's football and basketball schools.

title: Schlitz to Challenge Michelob's Taste
description: For its next contest of taste preference, the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company is going to take on Anheuser-Busch's Michelob, America's best-selling super-premium beer.

title: Coast Guard Finds 2 Vessels At Fault in Tampa Collision
description: Both the Coast Guard cutter Blackthorn and the oil tanker Capricorn were to blame for the Jan. 28, 1980 collision at the mouth of Tampa Bay that killed 23 Coast Guardsmen, a Coast Guard marine board of inquiry ruled today.

title: NIAGARA SHARE CORP reports earnings for As of Dec 31
AILING CAR INDUSTRY CALLED PERIL TO U.S.
description: The Transportation Department warned today that the current difficulties of the automobile industry posed a threat to national security, and it urged the Government to negotiate an agreement with Japan setting ceilings on shipments of Japanese vehicles to this country.

title: Pomme Dauphinoise
description: 1 large potato 1 1/2 tablespoons butter, in small pieces Coarse salt and freshly ground pepper to taste 1/2 cup heavy cream.

title: GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: 1979 results reflect a change in computing LIFO inventory valuation which increased 1979 earnings by $1.6 million or 29 cents a shr

title: Auto Leasing Sale
description: National Car Rental System Inc. said that it had entered into an agreement in principle to purchase for an undisclosed price substantially all assets of the rental division of the Consolidated Leasing Corporation, a subsidiary of C.L.C. of America Inc. The rental division of Consolidated Leasing, based in Los Angeles, has been operating as the National Car Rental licensee throughout southern California, National Car Rental said. Car rental locations being purchased include Los Angeles International Airport, which is the largest car-rental, revenue-generating airport in the country. Minneapolis-based National Car Rental is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Household Finance Corporation.

title: COMMERCE SOUTHWEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rhody McCoy Taking Post in Washington
description: Back in the 1960's, one of the most controversial figures in the New York public school system was Rhody A. McCoy, administrator of Ocean Hill-Brownsville, an experimental decentralized school district in Brooklyn with about 9,000 students.

title: No Headline
description: Ellis Staley Jr., 66, Dies; Formerly on State Court

title: ALGERIA GAS TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 13 (Reuters) United States and Algerian officials have resumed attempts to settle a dispute over the import price of Algerian natural gas, an Energy Department spokesman said today. He declined to say if progress had been made or how long he expected this round of talks, which began yesterday, to last.

title: U.S. AIRLINES SET MODERN SAFETY RECORD
description: The National Transportation Safety Board reported today that the domestic commercial airline industry set a modern-day safety record last year, posting sharply reduced accident rates and far fewer fatalities than in 1979.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Burroughs Corporation's components group plans to expand its engineering and manufacturing facilities in Jacksonville and Coral Springs, Fla., by an additional 180,000 square feet.

title: BRONX MAN DIES LEAPING FROM FIRE
description: Two sisters and their four children were killed in a three-alarm fire Monday night in Jersey City that started in the ground-floor hallway of their four-story building and raced through to the top floors, blocking their escape.

description: B-Including $2,120,000 tax credit for the qr and $5,800,000 tax credit for the yr

description: HEARINGS Following are excerpts from a transcript of the hearing in Washington yesterday by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on the confirmation of Alexander M. Haig Jr. as Secretary of State, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: SOUP-EASY, VERSATILE AND ROBUST
description: Jacques Pepin is a teacher, chef and the author of ''La Technique'' and ''La Methode.'' By JACQUES PEPIN

title: Court Refuses Stay On Limit to Searches
description: A Federal appeals court unanimously denied a request from New York State officials to stay a lower court's ruling limiting the authority of the state's parole officers to search the homes of convicts free on parole.

title: France Honors Flora Lewis
description: The French Government has awarded the cross of the Chevalier of the Legion of Honor to Flora Lewis, columnist for The New York Times. Miss Lewis, who writes on foreign affairs, is based in Paris. She was Paris bureau chief and European diplomatic correspondent for The Times from June 1972 until May 1980, when she assumed her present duties.

title: RECITAL: JAN DEGAETANI
description: AS all good students of Walt Whitman know, the solitary singer loved the opera and heard a lot of it during his Brooklyn and Manhattan years. In fact, his poetic style, rather often seems to reflect the oratorical extravagance of 19th-century grand opera, translated into his own peculiar idiom of unaccompanied chant. Of all the singers whom he heard Whitman most admired the soprano Alboni and the tenor Bettini. Once, after hearing the latter, he was moved to write: ''Never before did I realize what an indescribable volume of delight the recesses of the soul can hear from the sound of the honied perfection of the human voice.''

title: SUBPOENA FOR FILES ON HAIG ROOTED IN HISTORIC STRUGGLES
description: The power of Congress to subpoena documents and testimony for use in its investigations, described by the Supreme Court as ''broad'' but ''not unlimited,'' has been used and abused in numerous battles dating back to the earliest days of the United States.

description: B-Including $52,000 tax credit for the qr and $102,000 tax credit for the 6 mos...C-Net loss

title: URUGUAYANS TENSE AS MILITARY, OUTVOTED, PONDERS FUTURE
description: Mate, a bitter herbal tea, is said by Uruguayans to make lions of the meek and workers of the lazy, to cool the sweltering, to help the digestion and to solve most other daily maladies.

title: PASSING FANCY
description: Jamaal Wilkes of the Lakers flipping his wrist to pass to a teammate after getting pressure from Cavaliers' Roger Phegley last night at Richfield, Ohio, Lakers won, 108-104.

title: Bridge: Contract League's '81 Head To Be at Westchester Event
description: The position of president of the American Contract Bridge League is held for one year and involves substantial traveling to tournaments in all parts of North America.

title: Home Resales Down in 1980
description: Sales of existing homes in 1980 fell to a five-year low as high interest rates kept potential buyers out of the market, the National Association of Realtors reported today.

title: SHAWMUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Dec 22

title: Compulsory Black Schooling Begins in South Africa
description: The first black children in South Africa facing compulsory education were ordered to attend classes today at the start of the academic year.

description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GOLDWYN RETROSPECTIVE

title: 6 ARE SEIZED IN ISRAEL IN DEATF OF A BEDOUIN WHO WAS A LEGISLATOR
description: Israeli authorities have arrested six men in connection with the slaying last night of a Bedouin Member of Parliament.

title: SERVED IN AIR FORCE
description: John Koehler Gerhart, a retired four-star general in the United States Air Force who headed the North American Air Defense Command in the 1960's, died Friday of a coronary thrombosis at Penrose Hospital near his home in Colorado Springs. He was 73 years old.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: who was, once upon a time, a terrific jumper and a gifted turner - is at it again. She's been updating the words of some of the traditional street refrains called out by the children of New York. Of course, city kids still skip rope, play stoop tag and sing the classics of street poetry, like: A - my name is Anna, my husband's name is Al, we come from Alabama, and we sell APPLES.... One, two, three o-lairy, I spy sister sairy, sitting on a bumble-airy: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5....

title: Drilling Rig Stops Gas Blowout
description: An offshore drilling platform choked itself off today and stopped a flaming blowout that sent 31 rig workers into the frigid Gulf of Mexico, killing one and leaving two others hospitalized, an official of the Placid Oil Company said. The rig burst into flames last night, about eight hours after the blowout sent rig workers scrambling overboard, a Coast Guard spokesman said. John Brerwbridge, 55 years old, of South Bend, Ind., died after spending nearly half an hour in the water.

title: SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: 1979 results have been restate 1979 results have been reclassified and shr earnings figures reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in Sept

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 14, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Intergovernmental Committee on Science and Technology for Develop- ment - 10:30 A.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: A Federal judge has approved an agreement in a discrimination case that requires the United States Air Force to establish a $2 million fund and Eglin Air Force Base to hire 100 black workers for its civilian labor force and to promote immediately 20 who are already employed.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Se vi povus legi cition, vi komprenas Esperanton. Betty and Julius Manson agree the sentence is a tough one. But, they say, it can be mastered in much less time than it takes to learn a similarly complex sentence in any of the several thousand languages and dialects that help keep the globe carved up into nations, spheres of influence, fiefs and tribes.

title: OTTAWA TRIES TO EASE OPPOSITION TO ITS PROPOSALS ON CONSTITUTION
description: Ottawa has begun a major effort to soften opposition to its proposals for control over the Canadian Constitution by proposing extensive amendments.

title: The Abscam Paradox
description: Courts keep turning out guilty verdicts against Abscam defendants - and questions about the innocence of Abscam itself. Juries in Philadelphia, Washington and New York have convicted five Representatives of public corruption, but judges in all three cities question whether the Government handled the cases properly. These actions may seem paradoxical, yet each is correct in its own way. Juries are expressing revulsion at official greed; judges are expressing concern for the integrity of the legal process.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Avco Financial Services filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amended registration statement for $100 million of senior notes due Feb. 1, 1991, to be offered through a group headed by Kidder, Peabody & Company and Salomon Brothers.

title: AN ARAB WHO SEIZED IRAN'S LONDON MISSION SAID TO ACCUSE IRAQIS
description: The only surviving member of a group of six armed men who seized the Iranian Embassy in London last spring told the British police that the operation was planned and organized in Iraq with Government help, a court here was told today.

title: FROZEN CHINESE DELICACIES TO TAKE HOME
description: WHY, reasoned Yung Fu Chow, couldn't he provide the sort of frozen spring rolls, sweet soup dumplings and freshwater fish that Taiwan and Hong Kong food producers had been shipping into Chinatown food stores for years?

title: INAUGURAL FESTIVITIES REFLECT THE TIMES
Washington
description: A weakened auto industry is a threat to national security, the Transportation Department warned. In a grim assessment of the impact of unrestricted foreign competition in the American marketplace, the agency, in a report to Congress, called for a ceiling on the level of Japanese auto imports allowed into the country. (Page A1.)

title: Marriage A la Mode
description: In our third year of marriage my wife telephoned to ask if I would like to meet her. I did not want to meet her or anyone else. It had been seven years since I had met anybody at all, and though I had recently thought it might do me good to meet somebody - if only to see whether people still looked the way they used to - I did not want to start by meeting my wife.

title: STAFF BUILDERS INC (NY) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: 1980 shr earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split distributed Apr 3, 1980

title: HAIG AND DEMOCRATS IN REPEATED CLASHES ON WATERGATE VIEW
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr., President-elect Ronald Reagan's choice for Secretary of State, repeatedly clashed with Democratic senators today over the Watergate scandals, accusing them of demanding that he admit to a guilt he did not feel.

title: Mack Trucks Vows To Fight Suit
description: Mack Trucks Inc. said it would contest a Government antitrust lawsuit that it branded as unfair, ''unnecessary and burdensome.'' The Justice Department, in a civil suit filed Monday, charged Mack and an association of its distributors with conspiring to raise and fix the prices of truck parts in the United States since 1978 or earlier.

title: Nordiques 3, Jets 3
description: Michel Goulet scored two goals to give the Nordiques a tie with Winnipeg. With the Jets leading, 3-2, Goulet took a pass from Larry Lariviere in the slot at 3:54 of the third period and slipped his 19th goal between the legs of the Winnipeg goalie, Markus Mattsson.

title: FLORIDA'S ORANGES FREEZE, NORTH'S CARS STALL
description: The cold weather in the New York City area has played havoc with essentials of life in the suburbs - the automobile and the commuter railroads, which run late even in warmer times - while causing concern about other essentials, the uninterrupted flow of gas and the continued delivery of oil. The cold has also placed unusually heavy demands on emergency service personnel.

REPUBLIC OF TEXAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,000 for the q and $22,000 for the yr

title: DELIVERY OF GAS, NOT ITS SUPPLY, PLAGUES A WINTRY NEW ENGLAND
description: Despite an overall surplus of natural gas in the United States, the New England states are facing a severe shortage because of distribution and storage problems peculiar to the region.

title: MOVIE STAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
Court Told of Secret Fund For Oregon's Recruiting
description: The University of Oregon basketball program used a secret travel fund to recruit players in violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules, a county prosecutor said today.

title: CBT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A CLEAN-FOOD COURSE-IN SIX LANGUAGES
description: A food-handling course in Korean? No problem. You can also take it in Spanish, Italian, Greek, Chinese or English and - if you are a little shaky in the written versions of these languages - the final examination is also given in French and Persian. A Russian translation may soon be added, by popular demand.
