title: HORROR MOVIE
description: ''SCANNERS,'' the new Canadian horror film by David Cronenberg (''They Came From Within,'' ''Rabid'' and ''The Brood''), features some uproariously revolting special effects, the kind that are so outrageous they make you laugh, and the frequent use of a by-prescription-only tranquilizer trade-named Ephemerol. Aside from those things, though, the quality of the film's inventiveness is not always of the first order, which is too bad because Mr. Cronenberg does seem to be a director-writer of some style.

title: COFFEE PRICES DROP TO PRE-FREEZE LEVEL
description: THE frequent complaint that only bad news makes headlines seems to apply to coffee prices. They received considerable attention when they began to skyrocket four years ago, but a recent drop has gone largely unpublicized.

title: Three New Programs Announced by NBC-TV
description: Two football stars and a country-and-western singer are among those cast in new NBC pilots and series. Terry Bradshaw, quarterback for the Pittsburgh Steelers, and Mel Tillis, the singer, will star as a stock-car racing team in ''Stockers,'' a half-hour comedy pilot the network describes as an ''action-comedy.''

title: REFUGEES AND IMMIGRANTS AID NEEDIEST IN GRATITUDE
description: Many immigrants and refugees who have found sanctuary in New York City are among the contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: National Silver Picks President For Two of Its Subsidiaries
description: Kenneth M. Freedman, 53, has been appointed president of the F.B. Rogers Silver Company, a manufacturer of silverplated holloware, and the National Silver Company, a housewares importer. Both are operating units of National Silver Industries, a New York-based corporation whose top management previously also headed the two subsidiaries.

title: SAUDIS TO LEND GERMANY ANOTHER $2.7 BILLION IN '81
description: Saudi Arabia has agreed to buy about $2.75 billion of West German Government notes this year, a move that will help Germany finance a persistent deficit in its international trade account, Finance Ministry officials said today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Empire State Building Suicide
description: An unidentified man jumped to his death from the observation deck of the Empire State Building yesterday afternoon, the police reported. They said the man landed on a van parked on 33d Street.

title: WATERCOLOR CORN AND A STYROFOAM CARROT
description: HOLD FOR CAMPOSA By RON ALEXANDER

title: GRANT FOR ARCHITECTURE TV SERIES
description: The National Endowment for the Arts today awarded a $700,000 matching grant to WETA-TV, the Public Broadcasting Service station here, for a series of programs on architecture and design.

title: TRUST CO OF GEORGIA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Skeleton in Atlanta Is Identified
description: One of the two skeletons found last week in southwest Atlanta has been identified as that of 11-year-old Christopher Richardson, who disappeared June 9 from his home in suburban Decatur. Lee Brown, the Public Safety Commissioner, said today that a skeleton found near the Richardson child's remains had not been identified.

title: OWL BREEZES IN FOR THE HOLIDAYS AND FINDS A CENTRAL PARK HOME
description: uf813 By PAUL L. MONTGOMERY

title: BOND PRICES UP A BIT AFTER DROP
description: While the corporate bond market was digesting a large volume of new issues, prices of outstanding bonds gyrated widely yesterday before closing slightly higher.

title: SLEEPING BAGS, FROGS AND CHIC CHUTES
description: HOLD FOR CAMPOSA 1. Luxurious Sleeping Bags If you've ever spent a weekend in a frigid country house, you might have wished you had a sleeping bag to snuggle into. Roof of the World, which makes down garments for rugged outdoor types, has some sleeping bags that are so luxurious one would want them for indoor use. The bags are filled with goose down and almost weightless. Outside, they are made of nylon taffeta in bright colors. The lining is a sumptuous-feeling synthetic that looks like China silk. Since Karen and Peter Czarnomski, who own the shop, have a baby, 7-monthold Pilar has a miniature of the bag to wear in her stroller. The adult bag is $250, the child size $75. Roof of the World is at 86 West Third Street.

title: U.S. ORDERS HEARING PROTECTION FOR SOME WORKERS
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration ordered industry today to provide hearing protectors for a group of workers estimated to number 5.2 million as part of a new hearing-conservation program.

title: U.S. STUDY WARNS OF EXTENSIVE PROBLEMS FROM CARBON DIOXIDE POLLUTION
description: The President's Council on Environmental Quality warned today that national and international energy policies must immediately start addressing the problem of carbon dioxide pollution if major long-range climatic and economic problems were to be avoided.

title: OPERA: FIRST 'ZAUBERFLOTE' OF SEASON AT THE MET
description: In this abbreviated, hastily put-together season, Metropolitan Opera audiences probably must learn to subsist on half-loaves and emergency rations. It would be unreasonable to demand casts crammed with world-class artists in a season that we are fortunate to have at all. With that reservation in mind, it may be allowed that Monday night's performance of ''Die Zauberflote,'' the first of the season, held to a level of ensemble and individual effort that did not seriously embarrass anyone. Mozart's final opera should offer higher rewards, ideally, but a night such as this one at least can remind us now and then of those heights.

title: JUSTICES SAY OFFICIAL MISCONDUCT DOES NOT INVALIDATE PROSECUTION
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a violation by the Government of a defendant's constitutional rights is not ground for dismissing the charges unless the defendant has suffered harm from the violation.

title: Solomon Replaced As Lead Manager
description: Comptroller Edward Regan of New York State confirmed yesterday that Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets and Citibank would replace Salomon Brothers as the lead manager of the securities firms scheduled to handle the state's spring financing.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IT was part of my training, when I was a young boy in a Burgundy town about 15 miles from Chablis, that you didn't waste food. Leftover ends of bread were saved for toasting or turning into bread crumbs; leftover scraps of cheese were scraped into a crock to age and blend with garlic and white wine (it was my family's version of a dish called cancoillotte from another region of France), and leftover cooked meat was always turned into a hachis, which is where the English word ''hash'' comes from.

title: Lilco Device Warns Of Delinquent Bills
description: The Long Island Lighting Company is warning its customers that if they turn on their TV sets and the refrigerator goes off or if the lights start to flicker for no apparent reason, they should check whether they have paid their Lilco bills.

title: JOBLESS SINCE JUNE, AND WAITING, WAITING, WAITING
description: When one is unemployed, as I am, waking up in the morning can, at times, be quite a job in itself. I used to be a jump-out-of-bed person. When I was working, I would get up the minute my alarm clock buzzed at 5:30 in the morning. These days, I sleep until about 7, and then I have to drag myself out of bed. I find that at that hour there's usually not too much to look forward to. The day seems incredibly long and full of things I know I should do but probably won't, like call up some of the places I've been to already and see if any jobs have developed. Somehow, I just have this sneaking suspicion none have.

title: NATIONAL DETROIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KAISER'S NET DROPS 32.6%; DIAMOND SHAMROCK OFF
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, one of the nation's largest aluminum companies, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980 plunged 32.6 percent on an increase in revenues of 7.5 percent.

title: OPTICAL COATING LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net income including $72,000 income from discontinued operati C-After $42,000 loss from discontinued operations...D-After $16 loss from discontinued operations

title: Quorum Is Present After Delay - Measures Would Pave the Way for Agreement With U.S.
description: Iran's Parliament opened debate today on two urgen Government bills designed to help authorities in Teheran reach agreement with the United States on terms for releasing the 52 American hostages. Debate on the bills was scheduled yesterday, but was delayed for 24 hours because of the absence of some members of the Council of Guardians, a constitutional watchdog body that has to be present for urgent legislation. A quorum of the council was present today, and the debate proceeded. Votes were expected later today. Bills Enable Iran to Proceed By John Kifner Special to The New York Times

title: NAMIBIA PARLEY FAILS TO ACHIVE ACCORD ON TRUCE
description: The effort to obtain agreement on a date for a cease-fire in Namibia failed here today as the leader of the South African delegation declared that it was ''premature'' to put into effect a Western settlement proposal that was accepted nearly three years ago by both South Africa and the insurgents fighting on the territory's northern frontier.

title: 2 SEATTLE NEWSPAPERS PLAN JOINT PUBLICATION IF REGULATORS APPROVE
description: The owners of Seattle's two daily newspapers, The Post-Intelligencer and The Times, have agreed in principle to begin joint publication as soon as details can be negotiated.

title: FAMILY DOLLAR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PROVIDENT NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including $4,950,000 gain on the disposal of discontinued ope

title: BOSSY'S 4 GOALS LEAD ISLANDERS TO 6-3 TRIUMPH OVER PENGUINS
description: With four goals tonight, Mike Bossy nearly made the Islanders' 6-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins seem insignificant. The Islanders hadn't beaten Pittsburgh since Oct. 18, 1978, a span of eight games, but that was all but forgotten when Bossy went on his scoring surge at Nassau Coliseum.

title: HONG KONG INVESTOR SHOWS NEW POWER OF LOCAL CHINESE
description: When the chairmanship of Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. passed quietly into the hands of Li Ka Shing, a powerful developer, on Jan. 1, it was one more sign that local Chinese investors, many with official connections to the Chinese Communists, are challenging the British for control of Hong Kong's economy.

title: De Paul 93, St. Louis 67
description: Mark Aguirre scored 36 points and Bernard Randolph came off the bench to add 20 tonight to lift De Paul to a 93-67 victory over St. Louis University.

title: THE CITY
description: Nurses have ratified a new two-year contract with the Visiting Nurse Service of New York Inc., which will raise their starting salary from $15,985 to $18,731 as of next Jan. 1, it was announced by the Federation of Nurses, United Federation of Teachers.

title: Much of Japan Buried in Snow
description: A wide area of Japan has been buried in the last month by the worst snowfall in nearly two decades. The police said today that 43 people had been killed and 173 injured in snow-related accidents and that 5 mountain climbers have been killed, 24 injured and 23 reported missing.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Lawrence J. Blum, a 50-year-old trader, has been elected chairman of the executive committee of the Chicago Board Options Exchange. This is the highest elected position held by a member of the nation's largest options exchange.

title: Compton Announces Some Promotions
description: O. Milton Gossett, chief executive of Compton Advertising for three years, called his first press conference yesterday to announce some promotions. At the top of the list were two executive vice presidents.

title: Kissinger Ends Morocco Visit
description: Henry A. Kissinger, former Secretary of State, left here today after a three-day private visit during which he conferred with King Hassan II.

title: M.T.A. COMMITTEE FORMED TO SEEK NEW L.I.R.R. HEAD
description: The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has formed a search committee to find a replacement for Francis S. Gabreski, the president of the Long Island Rail Road.

title: IONA TOPS WAGNER IN OVERTIME BY 82-80
description: Gary Springer hit a 10-foot jumper at the buzzer to give Iona College an 82-80 overtime victory over Wagner College at Mulcahy Center tonight.

title: MARLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $121,000 for the qr and $533,000 for the yr; 1980 results include operations of Wylain Inc acquired as a purchase on Feb 4, 1980 except for Wyl discontinued Friedrich operations; 1980 rsults for the full yr revisions of previously reported second and third qr results fo discontinued Friedrich operations and for certain Wylain acquis adjustments

title: Shopping With Uncle
description: Patient auto shoppers would have no trouble discovering that a Mazda 626 gets about 27 miles to the gallon while a Mercury XR7 manages only 18. But they might be hard pressed to ferret out the fact that the Mercury is safer in a 35-mile-an-hour head-on collision or that replacing its transmission costs only a third as much.

title: EATON & HOWARD, VANCE SANDERS INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: 1979 net excludes nonrecurring income equal to 46 cents a shr; results reflect the first complete fiscal yr of the combined operation of the former Eaton & Howard and Vance Sanders which merged April 30, 1979

title: CORPORATE LAW SHIELD BROADENED
description: The Supreme Court handed an important legal victory to corporations and their lawyers today in a unanimous decision that broadened the scope of the so-called attorney-client privilege in a corporate setting.

title: CASEY, AT SENATE HEARING, OPPOSES SHAKE UP OF C.I.A.
description: William J. Casey, designated to become Director of Central Intelligence, said today that he was opposed to a sweeping reorganization of the Central Intelligence Agency at this time, but he vowed to reinvigorate the agency and reverse what he termed its ''institutional self-doubt.''

title: THROUGH THE ECONOMIC LOOKING GLASS
description: To the Editor:

title: DIAMOND SHAMROCK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Market Place; Savin's Growth In Copier Field
description: IF Xerox is reminded of the old magazine ad about piano lessons - ''They laughed when I sat down to play'' - concerning the Savin Corporation's success in the office copying market, it is understandable.

title: 2 LEGISLATORS TO RESURRECT BOTTLE BILL
description: Efforts to require refundable deposits on bottles and cans began anew today in the State Legislature. The two sponsors of a bill providing for such a surcharge said they would seek a provision of up to $1 million to protect people who might lose their jobs if the legislation is approved.

title: Tufts University Branch Cancels a Marcos Chair
description: Plans to establish an academic chair at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy to honor President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines, announced three years ago, have been dropped because the school received only $500,000 of the $1.5 million that Mr. Marcos pledged, according to the school's dean.

title: CARTER AIDES SAY IRAN FACTIONLISM MAY UNDERCUT HOPES ON HOSTAGES
description: Carter Administration officials expressed concern yesterday that their hopes for freeing the 52 American hostages by the time the Administration leaves office Tuesday could be dashed by new political uncertainties in Iran.

title: Alfa Romeo Layoffs
description: Alfa Romeo said today that it was putting 12,000 workers at its Arese and Portello plants in northern Italy on shorter working hours for the next four months to limit stocks of unsold cars, now totaling 17,000. The workers affected will be laid off for a total of 32 days between January and April, a spokesman said.

title: Canada's Jobless Rate Up
description: Seasonally adjusted unemployment in Canada rose to 7.4 percent of the total work force in December from 7.3 percent in November and 7.1 percent in December 1979, Statistics Canada said today. Seasonally adjusted employment rose 22,000, to 10.78 million, while seasonally adjusted unemployment rose 3,000, to 856,000, the Government agency added.

title: Norway Approves U.S. Plan To Store Arms for Marines
description: The Norwegian Parliament voted today to approve an agreement with the United States for storage of weapons and military equipment in the country, to be picked up by a brigade of United States Marines in the event of a Soviet attack.

title: Mets Extend Flynn's Pact to '86
description: The Mets extended Doug Flynn's contract for five years yesterday at a cost of nearly $2 million, and thereby avoided a free-agent showdown with the man they rank as the leader of the infield.

title: Synthetic Fuel Plans Set for Federal Aid
description: Synthetic fuel projects submitted separately by the Union Oil Company, Tosco Corporation and the Koppers Company were selected by the Energy Department yesterday for possible Federal aid.

title: RUSSIAN ALLIANCE CHIEFS TURN UP IN POLAND
description: f881 By JAMES M. MARKHAM

title: PERFORMING ARTS SCHOOL WANTS TO BE JUST THAT
description: To the Editor:

title: BILLS ENABLE IRAN TO PROCEED
description: Iranian officials said today that Parliament would vote tomorrow on ''emergency'' legislation to enable the Government to make an agreement for the release of the 52 American hostages.

title: CITY COUNCIL PANEL APPROVES BILL ON REGULATION OF FUNERAL HOMES
description: The Consumer Affairs Committee of the City Council cleared legislation yesterday that the Consumer Affairs Department said would make New York the first major city in the United States to regulate funeral homes.

title: FINN OLAV GUNDELACH
description: Finn Olav Gundelach, vice president of the European Commission, died last night of a heart attack, European community officials reported today.

title: Careers; Blind Ads: Removing The Fear
description: MANY job seekers face what might be called ''the box number syndrome.'' It can involve a traumatic struggle between wishful thinking and fearful mind.

title: KNOWING IT'S SUB ZERO IN SUBURBS CAN WARM A CITY DWELLER'S CHILL
description: When it was 5 degrees in Central Park yesterday morning, some New Yorkers could admit that it warmed their hearts a bit to have their clock radios tell them that it was below zero in many suburbs.

title: The Complete and Unabridged Version
description: How do you stretch a 52-word text into a 132-page book? It wasn't easy, but James Harris, a young New Yorker who packages and manufactures books for other publishers, decided that a certain brief message deserved a full-length book.

title: Mr. Connally Going to Washington, Again
description: With time out for Government service, John B. Connally has since 1969 been a partner in the Houston law firm of Vinson & Elkins.

title: HOUSING DESIGNEE VOWS TO SHOW COMPASSION FOR POOR IN CUTBACKS
description: Samuel R. Pierce Jr., Ronald Reagan's designee to become Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said today that the new administration might reduce the department's budget by as much as 10 percent, but he promised that he would not turn his back on the poor.

title: PIER 1 IMPORTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-The company did not report yr-ago first qr revs since the import business was purchased on Nov 30 by Newcorp Inc, whose name was subsequently changed to Pier 1 Imports...C-Including $28,000 extraordinary gain...D-Net income

title: Ford Workers Agree To British Contract
description: Twenty thousand Ford of Britain auto workers, apparently fearful of losing their jobs, have voted to accept a 9.5 percent pay increase, defying union leaders who had rejected the offer, Ford officials reported.

title: GMR PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $1,382,613 tax credit and exchange of investments with the company's credit banks and $1,095,047 loss...C-Includi $176,260 tax credit and gain on acquisition of senior subordina

title: News Analysis
description: While Governor Byrne was fighting the image of a lame-duck Governor in his State of the State address today to the New Jersey Legislature, the Democratic-controlled Senate was overriding a veto by him for the first time in his seven years in office.

title: IRAQ-IRAN WARFARE IS EBBING AGAIN AFTER BRIEF FLAREUP
description: Fighting in the Iran-Iraq war appears to be diminishing again, and Arab and Western diplomats here say a counteroffensive that Iran announced on Jan. 5 has resulted in weakening its own military position.

title: MELLON NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: 1980 results for the fourth qr and the yr include a $2 million gain on early retirement of notes and a $3.2 million gain from settlement of a tax contingent

title: Despite Ban, Judge Enrolls 3 White Girls in Louisiana
description: Risking $1,000-a-day fines for defying a Federal busing order, a state judge, Richard Lee, returned to the all-white Buckeye High School today to supervise the re-enrollment of three white girls.

title: Owens-Corning To Divest 4 Plants
description: The Owens-Corning Fiberglass Corporation, a major manufacturer of construction materials, has agreed to divest four asphalt roofing plants to settle an antitrust case, the Federal Trade Commission said.

title: Hydroelectric Loan Is Signed
description: Itaipu Binacional said it had signed a $266.6 million medium-term loan to finance part of the $10.2 billion Itaipu hydroelectric project on the Parana River between Brazil and Paraguay.

title: Park Renovation In Harlem and Bronx
description: The 20-acre Marcus Garvey Recreation Center in Harlem will undergo a major renovation, along with six South Bronx recreation sites, Mayor Koch and Gordon J. Davis, Commissioner of Parks and Recreation, announced.

title: Judge Won't Enjoin Nazi Rally in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO (AP) - A Federal judge refused yesterday to block a neoNazi group's planned demonstration in downtown Buffalo on Thursday, the 52d birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the slain civil-rights leader.

title: ISRAEL CLEARS WAY FOR OFFICIAL'S TRIAL
description: The Israeli Parliament lifted the immunity from prosecution today of the Minister for Religious Affairs, enabling the Government to put him on trial for corruption.

title: COMMERCIAL METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After $1,225,000 loss for 1980 qr and $459,000 gain in 1979 qr due to foreign currency rate fluctuation; per shr figures ad for a 3-for-2 stock split to be paid Jan 30, 1980

title: Carter's Farewell Speech Ready
description: President Carter today put the finishing touches on a farewell address to be given tomorrow that aides said would reflect his dedication to control of nuclear arms, conservation of natural resources and protection of human rights.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I recently dined in a restaurant on spaghetti alla chitarra. It was like very thin noodles and delicious. Can you tell me the origin of the name? Also a source in Manhattan?

title: Dissidents Lose Vote For Vestry Members
description: Parishioners of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church elected an official church slate of candidates for the vestry, defeating six nominees placed on the ballot by dissidents.

title: BUSINESSES TO INCREASE INVESTMENTS
description: American businesses plan to increase their capital investment by 10.8 percent this year, but this would amount to a rise of just slightly more than 1.5 percent in ''real'' spending if the rate of inflation stays the same, the Government reported today.

title: ITALIAN TERRORISTS APPARENTLY DELAY KILLING OF OFFICIAL
description: Giovanni D'Urso, the Rome magistrate kidnapped and condemned to death by the Red Brigades terrorist organization, was still alive last night or early this morning as his captors apparently postponed the carrying out of their threat to kill him.

title: AMERITRUST CORP OF CLEVELAND reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mexico Raising Gas Export Price
description: Mexico said yesterday that it was raising the price of its natural gas exports by 8 percent; all the gas goes to the United States. This increase follows an 11 percent rise in crude oil export prices announced by Mexico last month.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: NEW YORK METS (NL) - Extended the c ontract of Doug Flynn, second baseman, f or five years.

title: DIRECTING DEBUT
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
U.S. PANEL URGES BAN ON SOME INSULATION
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission proposed today to ban urea formaldehyde foam insulation as a health hazard and possible cancer-causing agent in humans.

title: New York City Bond Group Set
description: A syndicate management group headed by Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group Inc. and Goldman, Sachs & Company was selected yesterday to handle New York City's $110 million bond sale.

title: STOCKS DROP AS TRADING SLOWS
description: Selected natural resource issues advanced yesterday, while stock prices generally edged lower as trading contracted. The Dow Jones industrial average, after rising less than a point Monday, dropped by 3.67 points, to 965.10. Volume declined to 40.9 million shares from 48.8 million in the previous session. Superior Oil rose 10 7/8 points, to 203, responding to a report in yesterday's New York Times that the company holds an 80 percent interest in a major oil and gas prospect in Peru.

title: Changing Of The Guard
description: The changing of the guard in Washington is much more than a switch of power and policy. For those going out and those coming in, it is a deeply moving personal experience.

title: Hawaii Ring Group Defers Action on License for Ali
description: Muhammad Ali's plans to begin a campaign in April to win the heavyweight championship for a fourth time ran into trouble today when the Hawaii Boxing Commission deferred action on his request for a boxing license.

title: GARWOOD'S PROSECUTORS ASSAIL PSYCHIATRIC DEFENSE
description: As attorneys for Pfc. Robert R. Garwood prepared to rest their case, prosecutors moved today to discredit attempts by defense attorneys to portray the 34-year-old marine as a victim of Vietcong torture who was brainwashed into collaborating with the Communists.

title: Photos at Italian Institute
description: Photographs by Lewis W. Hine, Anthony Vaccaro and Santi Visalli will be on view through Friday at the Italian Cultural Institute, 686 Park Avenue, near East 68th Street.

title: REDSKINS NAME GIBBS COACH
description: The Washington Redskins named Joe Gibbs, the San Diego Chargers' offensive coordinator, their coach today. Gibbs served as an assistant coach in the college and pro ranks for the last 17 years.

title: Chickasha Bought
description: Toyo Menka Kaisha Ltd., a Japanese trading company, said today that it had purchased, for about $30 million, the Chickasha Cotton Oil Company, an American concern, in an attempt to insure a supply of ginned cotton. Chickasha, based in Fort Worth, has 17 silos, 46 cotton ginning plants, seven oil crushing plants and two cotton compressing plants, the Japanese company said. It plans to import about 240,000 bales of ginned cotton a year for sale to Japanese customers.

title: Honda Is Projecting 1981 Sales Increase
description: The Honda Motor Company plans to raise auto sales in 1981 by 15.3 percent, to 1.08 million cars, with exports scheduled to rise 14.1 percent and domestic sales 18.1 percent, officials said.

title: Article 224278 -- No Title
description: Super Bowl tickets, which have a face value of $40 each, are being sold for as much as $500. In many if not most instances, there is nothing illegal about the practice.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allis-Chalmers Corporation signed an agreement with B & W Diesel A-S of Copenhagen to build B & W's slow-speed diesels in the United States.

title: Crop Estimate For '80 Raised
description: The 1980 corn and soybean crops, shriveled by hot, dry weather, still turned out to be slightly higher than Agriculture Department experts had previously thought.

title: GIRARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ABSCAM OFFICIAL SAYS A COLLEAGUE PERILS OPERATION
description: A Justice Department official who helped supervise the two-year Abscam investigation last night accused another department official of seeking to ''sabotage or jeopardize'' the undercover operation and described him as a ''crusader against Abscam.''

title: Jury May Disregard Story Garwood Told Psychiatrists
description: A military judge said today that jurors may disregard the story Pfc.

title: DANCE: CONTRASTING APPROACHES
description: ACONCEPTUALIST of sorts and a pure-dance choreographer shared the program last Saturday at the Emanu-El Midtown Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. It should have been a revealing balance. But the dances of both Karen Bernard and Diane Jacobowitz lacked one crucial element: a point of view.

title: OIL-EXPORT RISE BY IRAN IS REPORTED
description: Iran appears to have restored its exports of crude oil to levels equaling, or perhaps even exceeding, those that prevailed before the start of its war with Iraq, United States Government and industry sources said today.

title: Private Clubs and Public Duty
description: Why raise a fuss about William French Smith and other Reagan appointees belonging to the Bohemian Club? He says he hadn't noticed that women were excluded and doesn't think becoming Attorney General requires him to quit. Membership allows him to frolic with other rich and famous fellows at a summer camp and to lunch at the club's allmale digs in downtown San Francisco. There to conspire in the management of industry and government? Hardly; more to sport a badge of renown and success, and to forge some bonds that may consummate a deal, open a door, find a job for a nephew. Though full of prominent figures, the club is not a significant political institution. But neither is it a mere club of classmates or fishing buddies.

title: NIGHTLY DRAMAS UNRAVEL AT CITY'S SHELTERS IN COLD
description: At 8:30 Tuesday night, Brendan Collins sat alone at the long brown admissions table just inside the National Guard Armory in Harlem. He was patiently mired in the accumulating chaos that had become familiar since the city and Red Cross opened the building last week as a shelter for those suffering from the cold.

title: FIRST BANKERS CORP OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sinatra Concert Role Defended
description: The Inaugural Committee today defended a decision to have Frank Sinatra preside over a concert next week despite reports that he has links with organized crime. The biggest event of a series of inauguration parties is to be a concert being organized by Mr. Sinatra at a sports arena in suburban Maryland for Monday night. Charles Wick, an inauguration committee cochairman, told a National Press Club luncheon today that the decision was made ''before any of this publicity came out.''

title: Transcript of Carter speech, page B10.
description: President Carter said farewell to the nation tonight in an address from the Oval Office in which he called on Americans to continue the struggle to avoid nuclear war, protect the environment and enhance human rights.

title: A.T.&T. May Cut 1981 Borrowings
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company can ''reduce substantially'' its external financing needs this year because of rulings by the Federal Communication Commission relating to depreciation, Virginia Dwyer, A.T.&T.'s treasurer, told financial analysts yesterday.

title: BAYBANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOTTEST TICKET IN LONDON: ROYAL SHAKESPEARE DICKENS
description: THE Royal Shakespeare Company's eight-and-a-half-hour adaptation of Dickens's ''Nicholas Nickleby'' at the Aldwych Theater in London is a monumental event, perfectly encapsulating the entire text of the novel, 65 chapters distilled into two marvelous evenings of theater.

title: Black School Principals Receive Threats of Death in Cape Town
description: Police units were placed on alert today in black and mixed-race townships where at least nine black school principals were threatened with death by a radical student group that also threatened to burn down schools.

title: FLORES RECALLS RAG-TAG RAIDERS
description: Two decades before Tom Flores became the coach of a Super Bowl team, he arrived here as a young quarterback with a surgical shoulder that had kept him out of the big-time National Football League. He was trying to win a job in a new league with a new team that had nowhere to play.

title: 4 CHARGED WITH BROTHEL EXTORTION
description: Federal authorities charged four men yesterday with operating an organized-crime ring to extort protection payments from houses of prostitution in Manhattan.

title: MAJOR REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $7,623 for t and $15,969 for the 6 mos...C-Net income after $17,527 loss fro discontinued operations and $50,200 tax credit for the qr and $ income from discontinued operations and $1,617,200 tax credit

title: Low Lumber Inventories
description: The Western Wood Products Association in Portland, Ore., reported today that lumber mills' inventories were at a record low of 1.7 billion board feet. This could mean a shortage if interest rates drop and building picks up, industry officials say.

title: AMERICAN METALS SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
VINTAGE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: B-Including $78,000 tax credit...C-Including tax credits of $64 for the qr and $483,000 for the 9 mos

title: CORRECTION
description: In The Times of Jan. 7 on proposals by a special commission on immigration policy included incorrect information. A clarifying article appears on page B9. wore a parka

title: Bethlehem Views 1981 Steel Prospects
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation expects a ''slight decline'' in steel consumption this year, but it said that ''some improvement in the foreign trade situation'' and the ending of inventory liquidation should mean improved domestic industry shipments.

title: POLISH WORKERS CONTINUE 'WARNING STRIKE'
description: A two-hour ''warning'' strike today in Rzeszow idled a number of industries in the southeastern city, it was reported here. At the same time, the Warsaw chapter of Solidarity, the independent labor union, raised a possibility of a brief bus and streetcar strike tomorrow to protest Government ''intimidation'' of workers who stayed off the job last Saturday.

title: INVESTMENT CORP OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FLOYD'S OPERA 'WILLIE STARK' TO HAVE HOUSTON PREMIERE
description: CARLISLE FLOYD is something of an anomaly among American composers in that he concentrates his energies almost exclusively on opera - and with a fair amount of success, judging from the number of productions his works receive on the regional opera circuit. ''Willie Stark'' is the title of Mr. Floyd's latest effort, and it will be given its world premiere by the Houston Grand Opera on April 24, the final production of the company's 25th-anniversary season. Based on the novel ''All the King's Men'' by Robert Penn Warren, the opera is the composer's 11th since ''Susannah,'' written just 25 years ago and one of the most popular contemporary American operas in the repertory.

title: RPM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Abrams Challenging Lilco Rate Increases
description: The state's Attorney General, Robert Abrams, has petitioned the Public Service Commission to suspend recent increases in the fuel adjustment charges made by the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Fordham 77, Vermont 62
description: Fordham, led by Dud Tongal's 16 points and 10 rebounds, scored a 77-62 victory over the University of Vermont last night at Rose Hill Gymnasium. The Rams (10-3) jumped to a 20-10 lead midway through the first half.

title: ACME PRECISION PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-After loss of $70,824 from discontinued operations and gain o $347,139 on disposal...C-Net loss...D-After $119,912 loss from discontinued operation

title: DISNEY, WALT, PRODUCTIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FOR ISRAEL'S TEACHERS, SALARY IS JUST PART OF PROBLEM
description: The Zalman Aran Elementary School hardly seems like the sort of institution that could topple a government. And its principal, Zilla Ish-Shalom, is no wheeler-dealer in the hard world of professional politics. But the educational and budgetary issues with which she and her school struggle every day are precisely those that have placed the Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin in crisis.

title: EARLY REAGAN MOVE ON OIL IS PREDICTED
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan will carry out a campaign pledge to accelerate decontrol of domestic crude oil prices with an executive order ''early'' in his administration, his chief domestic policy adviser said today.

title: SOUTHEASTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Jerry Rubin to Direct Development at Muir
description: Jerry Rubin, the former Yippie and Chicago Seven defendant who surprised many who knew him by taking a job on Wall Street six months ago with John Muir & Company, has been promoted to director of business development of the brokerage firm. Sounding like a born and bred capitalist, he spoke yesterday about his plans in his new post.

title: LOAN BOARD GRANTS CHRYSLER NEW HELP BUT SETS CONDITIONS
description: The Chrysler Loan Guarantee Board gave conditional approval tonight for $400 million in loan guarantees for the ailing auto maker. But the board insisted that there be major concessions from the United Automobile Workers, the company's lenders and its suppliers.

title: Olympia Beer Account Moving to Chiat/Day
description: Chiat/Day in Los Angeles has just become the agency for Olympia Beer, which is sold in about 60 percent of the country and is backed by an ad budget of about $9 million or $10 million.

title: NEW PRODUCTS THAT WILL HELP SPEED CHORES
description: DESIGNED so that it can be mounted on a bench top or fastened to a board for easy moving, the stationary belt sander illustrated here can be powered by any portable electric drill and can be used for a wide variety of sanding, sharpening, shaping or smoothing jobs.

title: WATER EVERYWHERE
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. CALLS FOR EFFORTS TO COMBAT GLOBAL ENVIORONMENTAL PROBLEMS
description: The Carter Administration called today for a major, sustained national and international effort to cope with what it said were ''increasingly critical global resource, environmental and population problems.''

title: Highest Civilian Honor Will Be Presented to 15
description: President Carter announced today that he was awarding the 1981 Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian honor, to 15 persons, including several who served in his Administration.

title: Philip R. Phillips Is Dead at 85; Ran Apparel Store for 65 Years
description: Philip R. Phillips, who headed Levine and Smith, a women's apparel store on Division Street, for 65 years, died Sunday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: SMITH CALLED COOL, DESPITE SINATRA ISSUE
description: A day or two after William French Smith, the Attorney General-designate, was criticized by a newspaper columnist for socializing with Frank Sinatra, Mr. Smith's wife, Jean, phoned a close friend to complain about the unfairness of it all.

title: President Eanes Sworn In For Second Term in Portugal
description: Antonio Ramalho Eanes was sworn in today for a second term as Portugal's President, but his differences with the ruling Democratic Alliance appeared to be far from resolved.

title: Hester Honored
description: When the United Nations University was started in Tokyo in 1975, its first rector was James M. Hester, a former president of New York University.

title: St. John's Steals Ball And Beats Villanova
description: A layup by Ron Plair with three seconds remaining in overtime enabled St. John's to edge Villanova, 56-54, last night at Alumni Hall. Three seconds earlier, Plair had stolen the ball from Stewart Granger, the Wildcats' best ball handler.

title: WOMAN HELD IN PARENTS' SLAYING
description: A 21-year-old woman and two men were charged today with killing the woman's parents at their Rockland County home last Dec. 28.

title: Anheuser-Busch Record
description: Anheuser-Busch Inc. announced today that it sold an all-time industry record 50.2 million barrels of beer in 1980.

title: Insider Reports for Exchanges
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: Spanish Industrialist Kidnapped
description: Armed guerrillas believed to be Basque separatists kidnapped Luis Sunyer Sanchis, one of Spain's richest industrialists, from his office last night, warning employees not to leave the factory because of a ''bomb'' that was nothing more than a box of biscuits, the police said today. Mr. Sunyer Sanchis, 70 years old, heads the Avidesa poultry producer and candy manufacturers of eastern Valencia province.

title: Gregory Hines, in Dispute, Quits 'Sophisticated Ladies'
description: Gregory Hines, a co-star with Judith Jamison in the Broadway-bound musical ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' left the show yesterday after the opening-night performance in Washington at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. Mr. Hines said through a spokesman for the show that he quit ''because of irreconcilable differences with the director-choreographer, Donald McKayle, and the producers.'' Roger S. Berlind, Manheim Fox, Sondra Gilman, Burton Litwin and Louise Westergaard are the producers of the show, based on Duke Ellington's music.

title: Kentucky 64, Mississippi 55
description: With Sam Bowie scoring 18 points and Derrick Hord 14, Kentucky overcame Mississippi's pressing defense for a 64-55 Southeastern Conference victory tonight.

title: Air Florida Gets Westgate Approval
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board tentatively approved the purchase by Air Florida of a controlling interest in Air California.

title: DAIG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
White Motor Units May Be Divested
description: The White Motor Corporation, trying to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, said it was considering sale of portions of its operations to Daimler-Benz A.G. of West Germany and Consolidated Freightways Inc. of San Francisco.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JANUARY 15, 1981
description: International The way for a U.S.-Iranian accord to free the 52 American hostages was apparently opened by enabling legislation approved by Iran's Parliament after more than four hours of sometimes raucous debate and impassioned appeals by the chief Iranian negotiator. The bill, which seems to be the key to resolving the 14-month dispute, authorizes the arbitration of claims against Iranian assets. (Page A1, Column 6.) Washington was warily optimistic about the Iranian Parliament's approval of the arbitration of claims in the hostage dispute. United States officials called the vote ''apparently a step in the right direction,'' but noted that a final agreement had not been reached. It was anticipated that the next 48 hours would be crucial in determining whether the 52 Americans will be freed before the Carter Administration leaves office on Tuesday. (A1:5.)

title: Cowboys to Wash Out Blue
description: Though insisting that he does not believe in a blue-jersey jinx, Tex Schramm, president of the Dallas Cowboys, says he plans a change in the team's dark-colored football shirts before next season.

title: 2 U.S. Prisoners Die in Peru
description: Two Americans charged with drug trafficking committed suicide at a hospital-prison, officials said today. They were identified as John Stephen Brigsson, 62 years old, and David Paul Tracy, 43.

title: HAIG HEARINGS END IN BURST OF COURTESY ON BOTH SIDES
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr. completed more than 30 hours of confirmation hearings before the Senate Foreign Relations Commitee today with committee approval of his selection as Secretary of State assured and the anger of yesterday's exchanges over the Watergate scandals replaced by subdued courtesies.

title: SOLICITOR GENERAL CALLS 2 AMERICANS KILLED IN EL SALVADOR 'UNDER COVER'
description: Solicitor General Wade H. McCree Jr. said today that two American agricultural advisers who were killed in El Salvador this month were ''under cover,'' suggesting an association with the Central Intelligence Agency, but later said that he had been misunderstood.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
'LES BONS DEBARRAS, ABOUT JEALOUSY
description: ''LES BONS DEBARRAS,'' the official Canadian candidate for an Academy Award nomination, is a meandering movie with a curious kind of staying power. Its bleak locale is so realistically outlined and its characters so vividly etched that it's possible to feel as if you know the people and the place intimately, even while wondering why you'd want to.

title: Nets Bow To 76ers, 110 to 105
description: PHILADELPHIA Jan. 14 - For a while in the first half of the Nets' loss to the Philadelphia 76ers this afternoon, it looked as if the sun shining on the floor of the Spectrum from the exit doors might be an omen for the slumping Nets.

title: DESIGNERS FORM BUSINESS NETWORK
MONSANTO HALTS A FIBER LINE
description: The Monsanto Company, after five years of losses amounting to more than $200 million in its polyester filament operations, said yesterday that it would no longer manufacture the fiber.

title: Residents Near Refinery Evacuated After a Blast
description: Residents in a 10-@ to 15-block area of this Illinois town were evacuated tonight after an explosion and fire at a Texaco refinery, the authorities said.

title: MERCANTILE TEXAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bruins and Rockies Fined $5,900 for Denver Battle
description: Fines totaling $5,900 were levied by the National Hockey League today against members of the Boston Bruins and the Colorado Rockies for three incidents during their game in Denver Jan.3.

title: DANKER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Muskie's Career May Come Full Circle
description: What does a Secretary of State do once he isn't Secretary of State anymore? Edmund S. Muskie has been keeping his own counsel about his plans, suggesting that he's been looking forward to some leisure to mull over a variety of possibilities, from returning to law practice to entering the academic world.

title: A.M.C. Cuts Prices Of Some Models 10%
description: The American Motors Corporation announced today that it was temporarily cutting base prices of some cars by 10 percent, effective tomorrow. The move does not effect Renault or Jeep vehicles.

title: Energy Audits
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: ''An Energy Audit for a Typical Row House'' (Jan. 8) was a most worthwhile endeavor, particularly when there are still thousands of home owners who have yet to take the first small step toward mankind's energy conservation. As a heat engineering consultant, I was especially pleased to see you point out the saving possible by a proper tune-up of the oil-burner heating system - possibly hundreds of dollars per year.

title: Companies
description: The Chrysler Loan Guarantee Board gave conditional approval for the auto maker's application for an additional $400 million in Government loan guarantees. Approval was conditioned on ratification by United Automobile Workers union members of wage concessions and presentation by Chrysler of agreements to convert $500 million in loans to preferred stock and to pay off another $500 million at 30 cents on the dollar. (Page A1.)

title: WATT AND EDWARDS WIN APPROVAL OF SENATE PANEL
description: James G. Watt, whose nomination as Secretary of the Interior was strongly opposed by environmentalists, and Energy Secretary-designate James B. Edwards today became the first of President-elect Ronald Reagan's Cabinet choices to win Senate committee approval.

title: FIRST CITY BANCORPORATION OF TEXAS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, vowed today to oppose a proposal by one of President-elect Ronald Reagan's transition staffs to eliminate Federal subsidies for operating costs of local mass-transportation systems.

title: GMR PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $1,382,613 extraordinary gains and provision for lo of $1,095,047...C-Including $176,260 extraordinary gain and rev of $700,000 were made to the allowance of possible losses

title: Tadzhikistan Is Jolted by Quake
description: An earthquake has shaken parts of Soviet of Tadzhikistan but no damage was caused, the press agency Tass reported today. The tremor measured 4, on the 12-point Soviet scale, at its epicenter 20 miles from Dushanbe, a city of 500,000. Soviet Central Asia has experience a succession of earthquakes recently but no deaths have been reported.

title: 'Significant' Phillips North Sea Oil Find
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company said it has found ''significant'' amounts of oil and gas in a well 150 miles northeast of Aberdeen, Scotland, in the British section of the North Sea.

title: HODGKIN'S DISEASE TIED TO WEALTHIER FAMILIES IN A STUDY AT HARVARD
description: Children brought up in a sheltered, upperclass environment are more likely than children of lower classes to develop a form of cancer called Hodgkin's disease when they grow up, according to a study at the Harvard School of Public Health.

title: M.A.C. APPROVES SALE OF BONDS WITH WARRANTS
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation, in an attempt to broaden the market for its tax-free bonds and lower the average interest rate it pays, yesterday approved the sale next week of bonds carrying a warrant to buy additional M.A.C. bonds at the same interest rate.

title: Index; International
description: For Israel's teachers, salaries are only part of the problem A2 Israelis rebuff move to keep Begin in office a bit longer A2 Opposition in West Berlin moves for early elections A3 11 killed in crash of 2 U.S. planes in Europe A4 Red Brigades say they will free magistrate A5 Common Market membership forces meat prices up in Greece A6 Around the World A7 Nigerian development plan puts new emphasis on defense A8 U.S. aide says 2 advisers killed in Salvador were ''under cover'' A10 Hong Kong drastically curbs in- flow of Chinese A11 U.S. urges effort to combat global environmental ills A12 U.S. doubts Moscow and Kabul relax opposition to negotiations A14 Government/Politics Chicago City Council moves to re- store patronage system A18 Louisiana judge is forbidden to defy desegregation order A19 Carey bids Legislature pass law on legalized gambling B4 Justice official accuses colleague of trying to sabotage Abscam B9 Jellybean makers expect boom in Reagan years B12 Attorney General-designate angry for a change B13 General Around the Nation A18 Witness says Mrs. Harris signed will on day of shooting B2 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of the cold weather, alter- nate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. All other park- ing regulations remain in effect. The Home Section Home Neighborly crime prevention C1

title: Lord Avie Gets High Weight for Experimental Handicap
description: Lord Avie, the champion 2-year-old thoroughbred of 1980, received strong support yesterday as the likely winner of this year's Kentucky Derby when he was accorded high weight of 126 pounds in the Experimental Free Handicap.

title: AMF Cutting Back On Pleasure Boats
description: AMF Inc. said that, largely because of the continuing depressed market for medium-sized runabout boats, it was withdrawing from that business and was also offering for sale the related operations of its powerboat division.

title: POPULAR BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports of The Times; Frank Robinson's Return
description: DURING the 1975 season, Billy Martin had been abruptly dismissed as the Texas Rangers' manager. title: Q. Our 30-year-old brick house has casement windows and two of them have been a problem because they have lots of moisture around them.  The plaster around each window is badly damaged and stained. All the windows have storm sashes, but these two are the only ones that are a constant problem. Caulking on the outside did not help. The plaster around the two windows is bubbly and falling out. Could the moisture be coming from cracks in the bricks on the outside? -L.G., Bethesda, Md.
description: A. It sounds to me as though you do have a problem with moisture working its way into the wall from the outside. The amount of plaster damage you describe could not be merely due to condensation or sweating.

title: NOT SEEING THE TREES FOR THE FOREST
description: The incoming Reagan administration appears to provide grounds for some hope that the recent headlong rush to ''preserve'' additional millions of acres of productive public forest land will be slowed down, and perhaps even reversed. Despite all the findings of modern forestry research, the appetite for setting aside vast areas as wilderness, parks, and private ''preserves,'' where no timber cutting is allowed, has apparently been insatiable. Aside from the the nation's having been deprived of the more than 5,000 useful forest products that these areas could have provided in perpetuity, this program definitely has not been in the public interest. The advocates of ''forest preserves'' stubbornly refuse to recognize the dire consequences of the application of the natural laws of plant succession in such areas. These laws decree that the vast majority of our tree and shrub species, like the majority of our garden plants, require direct access to sunlight to reproduce themselves and grow. So forest stands, if they are left undisturbed, will steadily progress toward a stage in which they will be composed of those few species that can reproduce themselves and survive through their juvenile years in dense shade. This ultimate stand is called a ''climax'' forest.

ROCK: POLICE, ENGLISH TRIO
description: IN America, the English rock trio known as the Police is generally categorized as ''new wave,'' and although the term is concededly vague, in this case it is at least reasonably appropriate. Reggae rhythms, guitar playing that is orchestral rather than solooriented, loosely improvisational group interplay and non-Western influences define the Police's music and distinguish it from the older brands of rock that still command the loyalties of most American rock fans.

In agreeing to pay the penalty, Raytheon neither admitted nor denied any wrongdoing.

Smaller scale, in other words, is what defines furniture as being suitable for children, not any difference in design.

From concepts and planning to manufacturing and presentation, their success has been notable in a country where women, in general, are conspicuously absent from high positions.

title: REAGAN SHOULD USE REAGANISM
description: Even before he takes the Inaugural oath next Tuesday, we must ask: Is President-elect Ronald Reagan moving away from the very positions that elected him? There are early signs that he may be. His campaign promised more than a new personality with a different world outlook. He especially signaled a shift in the most pained area of American life: He vowed to change the domestic economic and social policies that began with Franklin D. Roosevelt and grew through Democratic ''thick'' (Lyndon B. Johnson's ''Great Society'') and Republican ''thin'' (Richard M. Nixon's ''We're all Keynesians now'').

title: JAZZ:HENRY THREADGILL SEXTET
description: IN an otherwise bleak area near the Lincoln Tunnel, 450 W. 31 Jazz is a pleasant surprise, a comfortable loft with tables and other nightclub amenities. The Henry Threadgill sextet, which performed there on Tuesday and Wednesday and will be back on Tueday and Wednesday at 11 P.M. and 1 A.M., is also a pleasant surprise. Mr. Threadgill is best known as composer and saxophonist with the cooperative trio Air, but that group's angular minimalism doesn't really prepare one for the brassy richness of his sextet.

title: FOR WASHINGTON'S OUTS,' TIME TO MOVE ON
description: For one Washington family, the vote on Nov. 4 meant a probable loss of three jobs and a household income totaling $83,000. As Congress reconvened this week, Mary Jo Peterson was "in limbo," as she put it, waiting to hear her fate as a Democratic staff member of the newly reorganized Senate Finance Committee. Her stepson, 16-year-old Jeffrey Jr., a Senate page, was also anxiously awaiting with other Democratic pages to learn his fate. "And my husband is definitely out as of Jan. 20," Mrs. Peterson said. Her husband, Jeffrey, is a $500,000-a-year deputy to the assistant secretary of legislative affairs at the Treasury Department. The Petersons' life has been intertwined with politics. They first met while working on Capitol Hill, where Mr. Peterson was staff assistant to former Senator Abraham Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, and they are still paying off debts that Mr. Peterson incurred during his own unsuccessful bid for a House seat from Connecticut in 1976. For the next four years at least, Mr. Peterson will be directing his attention to the private sector. "He's been interviewing with law firms," Mrs. Peterson reported, "but he hasn't gotten any bites as yet." Election Day just moved Ernest G. Green's plans up by a year. "I had determined that even if we were successful at the polls, I would move on to other things in a year or so," explained the bearded Assistant Secretary of Labor for Employment and Training.

The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, had contended that material in ''The Cat and the Mouse,'' an earlier work by Mr. Mosley, had been used in Mr. Follett's novel.

description: By most standards, Charles Moss has achieved a comfortable and secure middle age. As a highway engineer, he invested wisely, bought land, retired in Mount Shasta in northern California and undertook a lucrative second career in real estate.

description: For Elizabeth Davies, the New Year began with the kind of tenant headache that can be life-threatening for someone who is 77 years old: The heat went off in her Chelsea brownstone apartment for nine arctic days.

title: MUSIC: JAMES VANDEMARK ON DOUBLE BASS
description: Solo double-bass virtuosos may be counted on the fingers of one hand, and James VanDemark, who teaches the instrument at the Eastman School of Music, is now generally reckoned to be among their number. A little over two years ago he gave a well-received New York debut recital, and on Sunday night he was back in Alice Tully Hall as one member of a distinguished duo. Presiding at the piano was none other than Andre Watts, who has been increasingly active as a chamber-music collaborator of late in addition to keeping up a busy solo career.

title: JUDGE IS REBUFFED IN INTEGRATION CASE
description: Federal District Judge Nauman Scott issued a permanent court order today forbidding Judge Richard Lee of the State District Court or anyone else to interfere with a desegregation plan for the public schools of Rapides Parish.

title: HARD COAL FOR HOMES IS HARD TO GET
description: Tens of thousands of residents in the New York metropolitan area want coal for home heating and cannot get it. Coal dealers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut report that residential customers are offering more than their asking prices - already inflated because of demand - and one said he was being offered $50 bribes to move customers up on his waiting list. The dealers say many customers are paying for more coal and better grades of it than they are actually receiving.

title: SHEARSON LOEB RHOADES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Illinois Aid for Chrysler
description: Both houses of the Illinois Legislature voted today to free $20 million from lottery revenues for a state loan to the Chrysler Corporation. The measure now goes to Gov. James R. Thompson. He and the state's commerce director would have to approve such a loan.

title: Dutch Say They Will Reconsider Export of Submarines to Taiwan
description: The Netherlands, under pressure from China, said it would reconsider its decision to export two submarines to Taiwan, a Foreign Ministry official said today.

title: CIVILETTI DISCIPLINES 7 IN ABSCAM INQUIRY
description: Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti said today that the Justice Department was taking disciplinary action against two Government lawyers, including a United States Attorney, and five agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, including an assistant director, for prematurely releasing information about three undercover investigations of public corruption.

title: Enlarging the Criminal Justice Pipeline
description: It has taken years for public officials to grasp a central point about law enforcement: To have a chance of working, the criminal justice system must be dealt with as a whole. Hiring more police officers may mean more arrests; but what if those arrested then end up merely waiting longer to be prosecuted? What if, on conviction, there are no prison cells to put them in? The result is not deterrence but cynicism.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LA CAGE AUX FOLLES

title: LET RETIRED POLICEMEN UNSNARL CITY TRAFFIC
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW RULES RESTRICT USING OF U.S. WATER
description: New regulations limiting the farm acreage eligible for federally subsidized irrigation were made public today, signaling resumption of the Interior Department's four-year conflict with large Western landowners.

title: RED BRIGADES FREE ABDUCTED MAGISTRATE UNHARMED
description: Giovanni D'Urso, the Rome magistrate kidnapped by the Red Brigades on Dec. 12, was released unharmed early today, the police said.

title: U.S. Car Sales Off 19.8% In Jan. 1-10; Chrysler Up
description: Domestic new-car sales in the first 10 days of January tumbled 19.8 percent from the strong sales in early January last year, the nation's major auto makers reported today. Only Chrysler reported a sales improvement.

title: VTN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
Hail And Beware
description: The way we install our Presidents says something about the mythic nature of the office. In Britain the winning party leader moves matter-of-factly into 10 Downing Street the day after the election. We wait 75 days and then have a republican coronation. The President is invested with the nation's dreams.

title: AN INIMITABLE PARTY SETTING
description: IF there's one thing to be said about Mary McFadden, it's that she certainly is a good sport. As chairman of the Winter Antiques Show, which opens at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Jan. 24 and benefits the East Side House Settlement, the designer invited committee members to her new apartment last week for a party.

title: Arthur Brooks Hatcher, 92, Dies; Ex-Officer of Guaranty Trust Co.
description: Arthur Brooks Hatcher, an officer of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York for 43 years, died Monday at a nursing home in Southbury, Conn. He was 92 years old.

title: VOTE PRESSED AFTER WEST BERLIN SCANDAL
description: Reacting to widespread criticism of the West Berlin Government's handling of a financial scandal, the opposition Christian Democrats have decided to set in motion unusual proceedings aimed at holding new elections this summer, two years ahead of schedule.

title: December Oil Bills Up $110 in a Year
description: The typical New York City homeowner spent $110 more on home heating oil last month than in December 1979, according to the City Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Bruce C. Ratner.

title: Paper Thieves Outsteal Conventional Robbers
description: White-collar criminals armed with computers and calculators stole four times as much money as bank robbers in the first half of 1980, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau said yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adolph Coors Company, Golden, Colo., has appointed Alva Pipkin vice president-controller.

title: GIANTS PICK ROBINSON TO MANAGE
description: Frank Robinson, who served two and a half years as the first black manager in the major leagues before he was dismissed in 1977, returned to the ranks yesterday when he was named to succeed Dave Bristol as manager of the San Francisco Giants.

title: COMMERCIAL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
TEXAS OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid Jan 15

title: FELICIA SLATKIN COLEMAN
description: Felicia Slatkin Coleman, the author of books designed to prepare children for surgery, died at her home in Manhattan on Sunday. She was 65 years old.

title: Officer Suspended In Fraud Inquiry
description: A probationary police officer was suspended yesterday because a character investigation had disclosed that she was charged with welfare fraud, the police said.

title: HAEMONETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
11 KILLED AS U.S. PLANES CRASH IN SPAIN AND GERMANY
description: Two United States Air Force planes on routine flights crashed 20 minutes apart in Western Europe today, killing 11 people.

title: U.S. Halts Australian Talks On Use of Bases by B-52's
description: The United States has suspended negotiations with Australia over staging use of bases in the north of the country by B-52 bombers, the United States Ambassador, Philip H. Alston, informed the Government today.

title: Nazi Rally Organizer Arrested in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO (AP) - The organizer of a neo-Nazi rally planned here today on the 52d birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the slain civil rights leader, was arrested by Federal marshals yesterday on a weapons charge.

title: RETAILERS ACT TO IMPROVE THE BOTTOM LINE
description: Retail executives, facing profit pressures, high interest rates, rising overhead and a troubled consumer, are beginning to move in a variety of ways to improve their businesses.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Accounts

title: NOT EVERYTHING AT AUCTION SELLS, EVEN IN A GOOD YEAR
description: EVEN in a boom auction year, owners and bidders know that not everything consigned to an auction sells for the prices expected, and many works do not sell at all. At most of the top art-auction houses, 10 to 25 percent of the offerings do not find buyers. The reasons vary from no bids at all to bidding that stops short of the object's reserve price - a level below which the owner will not sell.

title: People Howie Brodsky has been named senior vice president at Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson Inc.
description: * Fred Tierney joining TDI/Winston as vice president and manager of New York sales.

title: Herbert Hill, Professor Emeritus Of History at Dartmouth College
description: Herbert W. Hill, a professor emeritus of history at Dartmouth College who twice ran unsuccessfully for statewide office in New Hampshire, died Sunday night in a nursing home in Hanover, N.H. He was 78 years old.

title: NEIGHBORLY CRIME PREVENTION
167-DAY MUSICIANS' STRIKE ENDS
description: A 167-day strike by the American Federation of Musicians against motion picture and television film producers was settled late today, a union spokesman said.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S FAREWELL REMARKS ON MAJOR ISSUES FACING THE
description: NATION

title: DANCE: HARLEM'S ONE-ACT 'SWAN LAKE'
description: THOSE who once thought the Dance Theater of Harlem would be a copy of the New York City Ballet in style and repertory have been receiving a few surprises lately.

title: Virginia Wins, 66-64
description: Jeff Lamp hit an 18-foot jump shot with six seconds remaining to give Virginia a 66-64 victory over Maryland tonight in an Atlantic Coast Conference game.

title: HERS
description: IN the mid-1950's, the mathematician John von Neumann built one of the first computers ever - the Johniac - in the basement of the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif. My husband, a newly minted mathematics Ph.D, came home and described this electronic marvel: ''It can do some pretty elaborate calculations very rapidly,'' he told me. ''Things that take hours, even weeks, can be run through in minutes - even seconds.''

title: BUILDINGS UNION INTENSIFIES TALKS TO AVERT A STRIKE
description: Negotiators for service employees and for the owners of major office buildings in New York City intensified their bargaining talks yesterday in an effort to reach an agreement that would avert a strike threatened for tomorrow.

title: Carey Urges Action To Legalize Casinos
description: Governor Carey called on the Legislature yesterday to pass a constitutional amendment to legalize casino gambling in the state, but appeared to limit it to slot machines.

title: Fire Inspector Shot
description: An inspector for the New York City Fire Department was shot and critically wounded by an unknown gunman Tuesday night when he returned home from work in what the Nassau County police said might have been a ''job-related'' shooting.

title: Foreign Policy Unit Picks Editor
description: Nancy L. Hoepli has been appointed editor of the Foreign Policy Association, it was announced yesterday.

title: LAXALT AIDE IS AMONG 4 NAMED BY REAGAN TO WHITE HOUSE STAFF
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan's transition office announced the filling of four White House staff positions today as Mr. Reagan flew from Los Angeles to Washington to prepare for his inauguration Tuesday.

title: CONTRADICTIONS IN EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Conrail Head Outlines Goals
description: The new head of the Consolidated Rail Corporation, which has lost more than $1.3 billion since it was created from the wreckage of six bankrupt Northeastern railroads in 1976, said today he hoped ''to make a winner out of Conrail'' by getting out of the passenger business and trimming unprofitable freight services.

title: ARLEN REALTY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $12 million credit from tax loss carryforwards and debt restructure and a $24.3 million gain on the sale of real properties for the qtr and $15.5 million extraordinary credit for the 9 mos...C-Including $16.3 million gain on sale of prope and $13.3 million gain from debt restructure; net profits for t three and 9 mos periods ae after deducting realty depreciation amortization of deferred charges totalling $2.6 million and $7. million respectively compared with $3.6 million and $12.6 milli from the comparable 1979 periods

title: TELEPHONE RATES IN STATE GO UP BY $240 MILLION
description: An annual increase of $240 million in New York Telephone Company rates is to be approved by the State Public Service Commission, the staff attorney who had presented a case against any increase said yesterday.

title: HALBERSTAMS ASSAIL PICTURE AGREEMENT BY LIFE WITH SLAYING SUSPECT
description: An agreement by Life magazine to pay $8,000 to Bernard C. Welch, the man charged in the death of Dr. Michael L. Halberstam in Washington, was assailed yesterday by the cardiologist's brother, the author David Halberstam, who called the arrangement for use of the suspect's pictures ''journalistically contemptible.''

title: EVAN FRANCES MARRIED TO KENNETH G. AGNEW
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation yesterday Evan Frances, widow of Alexander Frances, was married to Kenneth Gordon Agnew by the Rev. Robert Lewis.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt SISTER WOLF. By Ann Arensberg. 209 pages. Knopf. $9.95.

title: CHATTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
What's in Those 'Safer' Cigarettes?
description: The latest Surgeon General's report on smoking points to a lunatic inconsistency. To appeal to smokers concerned about health hazards, the tobacco industry has been reducing the tar and nicotine content of cigarettes. But at the same time, it has been adding chemicals, in part to replace the lost flavor. These, it turns out, may pose their own danger to health.

title: Montreal Hotel Has Second Fire
description: A fire in a 12th-floor room of the Four Seasons Hotel in downtown Montreal forced the evacuation of all guests to the lobby today.

title: REPORTS OF AFGHAN READINESS FOR PEACE TALKS MEET U.S. SKEPTICISM
description: American diplomats said here today that, contrary to reports from India and the United Nations, they had no evidence that either the Soviet Union or Afghanistan had relaxed opposition to negotiations with Afghanistan's neighbors.

title: HALCYON ERA FOR THE JELLYBEAN
description: The makers of America's jellybeans are expecting good times when Ronald Reagan moves into the White House. With luck, they say, the jellybean, Mr. Reagan's favorite sweet, could become a symbol of the Reagan years in Washington. ''From what we've heard, the boom's supposed to start in a month or two,'' said John Ralphs, an executive of the Jaffe Candy Company here. Even in the peanut-oriented Carter years, Jaffe produced a million pounds of jellybeans a year.

title: No Headline
description: FLORIDA LOSSES RISE AS FREEZE CONTINUES

title: DR. OWEN WANGENSTEEN, PIONEER IN SURGERY, DIES OF HEART ATTACK
description: Dr. Owen H. Wangensteen, a pioneer in various types of surgery who trained generations of other surgeons, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Minneapolis. He was 82 years old.

title: Walesa Visits Cassino To Honor Polish Dead
description: Poland's trade union leader, Lech Walesa, who is on the second day of a visit to Italy, paid homage today at the Polish Military Cemetery here, the scene of one of the toughest battles of World War II.

title: Director of Peace Corps Warns Against Using Workers as Spies
description: Richard Celeste, the departing director of the Peace Corps, said today that the biggest problem the volunteer service agency faced was the temptation to use its workers as spies.

title: SUMMIT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Shearson's Earnings Up 145%
description: Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc., one of the best performing firms on Wall Street in recent years, continued to show sharp earnings increases in the most recent quarter. The company said its earnings for the quarter ended in December jumped 145 percent, to a record $29.1 million, or $2 a share, from $11.9 million, or $1.07 a share, in the comparable period in 1979. The earnings gain came on a 75 percent increase in revenues, to $257.7 million from $147 million.

title: N.C.A.A.  Is Warned By Women
description: After yesterday's vote by the N.C.A.A. for total commitment to conducting women's tournaments, the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women warned today that the fight was far from over.

title: STANDARD SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $116,000 for the qr and $1,214,000 for the 9 mos

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Restated for a 4-for-3 stock split in April

title: SHARP DECLINE IN DAILY SMOKING BY HIGH SCHOOL SENIORS IS FOUND
description: The number of high school seniors who daily smoke cigarettes dropped by more than a quarter from 1977 to 1980 and the rate of decline is accelerating, according to a study done for the National Institute on Drug Abuse by University of Michigan researchers here.

title: Senate Committee Puts Off Vote On Designee for Labor Secretary
description: The chairman of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee today ordered an unexplained postponement of the panel's scheduled vote on whether to recommend the confirmation of Raymond J. Donovan as Secretary of Labor.

title: States and Localities Will Share In Grant for Expense of Refugees
description: States and localities that incurred extra costs in handling the recent influx of Cuban and Haitian refugees will be eligible to share in a $5 million grant, Federal officials said today.

title: THE SELF-INFLICTED DECLINE OF AMERICA'S ORGANIZED LABOR
description: To the Editor:

title: 'GIVING IN COULD BANKRUPT THE FIRM
description: What Marxists call the locomotive of history has taken an eccentric turn in Communist Poland. One of the oldest working-class battle cries - the demand for a 40-hour week - has been taken up by Solidarity, the insurgent union. And impoverished Government managers resist with an argument wryly familiar to the West: giving in could bankrupt the firm.

title: Three Big Refiners Raise Fuel Prices
description: The Exxon Corporation, the Mobil Corporation and the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) were among several refiners that announced rises in the wholesale prices of gasoline and heating oil yesterday of a penny to 4 cents a gallon.

title: CAREY OPPOSES A 5
description: RISE IN FARE TO ADD TRANSIT POLICE By RICHARD J. MEISLIN

title: 2 New York Dance Groups Get Major Federal Grants
description: Major grants have been awarded to two New York dance institutions.

title: EASTERN AIR'S SPECIAL TROUBLES
description: Jolted by last year's recession and burdened by debt, Eastern Air Lines Inc. has been staggered further by powerful competition from other lines.

title: NICOLET INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
CONNORS, BORG AND LENDL WIN
description: Playing his first match in the $400,000 Volvo Masters, Gene Mayer stunned an ailing John McEnroe, 3-6, 7-6, 6-2, last night before a crowd of 15,637 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Erie Car-Train Crash Kills Three
description: A Conrail freight train struck a car at a crossing on Erie's west side today, killing three young persons and injuring a fourth, the authorities said. The victims were not immediately identified.

title: FUNDS FOR NEEDIEST TOPS A MILLION IN GIFTS FOR 11TH STRAIGHT YEAR
description: Halfway through its 69th annual appeal, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has received contributions totaling $1,030,530.51, making it a million-dollar fund for the 11th year in a row.

title: In This Corner, the Governor's Computer. ...
description: One of the battles that rages in Albany each year is the debate between Governor Carey and John J. Marchi, the chairman of the Senate's Finance Committee, over the size of New York's expected revenues.

title: J.P. MORGAN GAINS 26%
description: J.P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter income before securities transactions rose 26 percent, to $92.1 million from $73.2 million in the comparable 1979 period. Net income after securities transactions amounted to $84.0 million, or $2.05 a share, in the most recent quarter, up from $74.1 million, or $1.82 a share, in the comparable period a year earlier.

title: Penguins Triumph, 6-3, Halting Blues' Streak at 11
