description: Rick Kehoe scored three goals to lead the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 6-3 victory over the Blues tonight, ending an 11-game St. Louis unbeaten streak.

title: Advertising; Standard's Overseer of Advertising
description: STANDARD BRANDS, which includes among its products some of the country's most widely known brands, is getting even more serious about advertising. An increase in its total annual advertising spending, from $30 million to more than $50 million, is one indication. Creating a new job of corporate vice president for advertising and marketing, and filling it with Arthur S. Pearson, is another.

title: Jobless Rate in City 8.3% in November
description: The unemployment rate in New York City in November was 8.3 percent, unchanged from the month before, the Labor Department said.

title: U.S.O. in Times Square
description: Since World War II, the U.S.O. has maintained its busiest and most famous facility in the heart of New York, just off Times Square.

title: Name Change at Wesson
description: Wesson, Cohen, Neglia is the new name for the 16-year-old agency that has been called Wesson & Warhaftig.

title: Marathon Plugs Well
description: A group of American and Canadian oil companies plugged and abandoned an exploratory well off the coast of Indonesia after finding ''no significant shows'' of oil or natural gas, the Marathon Oil Company said yesterday. The well, 750 miles north of Jakarta in the Natuna Sea, was drilled to 10,329 feet, Marathon said. Its partners in the venture are the Amerada Hess Corporation and the Hudson Bay Oil and Gas Company.

title: BANKERS TRUST EARNINGS UP BY 36%
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation, parent company of the Bankers Trust Company, the eighth-largest commercial bank in the country, said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings before securities transactions rose 36 percent, to $40.8 million, from $30.1 million during the same period in 1979.

title: LOIS LONG RIKER
description: Lois Long Riker, a dramatic soprano who was well known in New York, Seattle and San Francisco in the 1920's and 30's, died on Friday in Statesville, N.C. She was 96 years old.

title: SWEDISH HERO IS IN SOVIET, PANEL SAYS
description: An international panel called on the Soviet Union today to reopen the case of Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat presumed to have disappeared in Soviet prisons after saving thousands of Jews from the Nazis in the final days of World War II.

title: Sly Williams of Knicks Is Ailing
description: The Knicks placed Sly Williams on the injured list yesterday and signed Kurt Rambis to a 10-day contract. Williams, a 6-foot-7-inch forward who reinjured his left ankle in Monday's practice, is expected to be out for 10 days.

title: 800 Workers at Lockheed End a 2-Month Walkout
description: About 800 engineers and scientists returned to work today at Lockheed Aircraft, ending a two-month strike that began with demands for cost-of-living increases similar to those paid to the company's blue-collar workers.

title: FIRST NATIONAL CHARTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Memorial for Lawrence Neal At Davis Arts Center Tomorrow
description: Friends and associates of Lawrence P. (Larry) Neal, the poet, playwright and author who died Jan. 13 at the age of 43, will hold a memorial celebration tomorrow at the Leonard Davis Center of the Performing Arts, Convent Avenue at 135th Street, on the City College campus, from 3 to 5 P.M.

title: KOCH EXPECTED TO SEEK RISE IN STREET-CLEANING WORKERS
description: Mayor Koch is expected to call for the hiring of 225 additional sanitation workers for street-cleaning duties in the preliminary New York City budget that will be announced today.

title: MED-PAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
JUDGE WRIGHT STEPPING DOWN BUT STAYING; Judge Wright Stepping Down but Staying
description: Because he turned 70 this week, J. Skelly Wright was required to step down as chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. But he said he was in good health and would not retire as a member of the 11-judge court.

title: TEMCO SERVICE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-After $218,300 extraordinary net charge...C-Net income.

title: SEAFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cathlyn Wilkerson Begins 3-Year Term
description: Cathlyn Platt Wilkerson, a former member of the radical Weather Underground, turned herself in yesterday afternoon to begin serving a three-year prison term in Bedford Hills, N.Y.

title: SOUTHERN PACIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES GAINS; AMSTAR SOARS
description: Burlington Industries Inc., the nation's largest textile producer, reported yesterday that it had a 13 percent gain in net income for the first quarter ended Dec. 27, 1980, over the comparable period in 1979. Sales for the quarter rose 5.6 percent from the year before.

title: Penn Central Gets $2 Billion From U.S.
description: The Penn Central Corporation received about $2.11 billion from the Federal Government for railroad properties transferred to the Consolidated Rail Corporation in 1976, ending a five-year-old valuation dispute.

title: COAST MUSICIANS GOING BACK AFTER SETTLING 5 1 2 MONTH STRIKE
description: After a 5 1/2-month strike, 5,000 musicians who play scores for movies and television shows began returning to work today, having reached a tentative agreement with producers that failed to win their key demand.

title: BORG, AFTER PENALTIES FOR DELAY, OUSTS MCENROE IN 3 SETS
description: It was not Wimbledon or the United States Open, but Bjorn Borg and John McEnroe wrote another memorable chapter in their tennis rivalry last night in the $400,000 Volvo Masters tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: Synthetic Fuels Selects Officer
description: John C. Sawhill, the chairman of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, said today that he intended to nominate Leonard Axelrod as vice president-technical and engineering at the next board meeting on Jan. 23.

title: CHRIS CONNOR'S COMEBACK
description: CHRIS CONNOR, whose career since she left Stan Kenton's band to sing with her own trio 28 years ago has been a roller coaster ride of highs and lows, is now rising on what may be the best high she has had. She has been singing on Sunday nights since September at Sweet Basil and, she says, ''I know I'm singing better than I ever did.''

title: SOUTH CAROLINA ELECTRIC & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: 1979 results have been restated to reflect refunds.

title: PAULEY PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Jazz on 19th St.
description: Jazz fans can hear the UJC Jazz Quartet, presented by the Universal Jazz Coalition, or attend a jazz clinic-workshop this weekend at the Jazz Gallery, 55 West 19th Street.

title: Policeman on 2d Job Shot in Jersey City
description: An off-duty Jersey City policeman was shot last night as he was surprised by two men while bringing bingo-game proceeds from a parish house to a church rectory, the police reported.

title: MCI COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $1,657,000 for the quarter and $3,82 the 9 months...C-Including $1,196,000 tax credit.

title: DOW ADVANCES 3.50, WITH OILS IN LEAD
description: Energy-related issues, buoyed by prospects of an early decontrol of domestic oil prices, stood out yesterday as the stock market's strongest group. However, certain high-technology issues displayed weakness as the result of order slowdowns and lowered earnings estimates for 1981 by Wall Street analysts.

title: AMERICAN SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CITY OF SHIPS CALLING SOS IN LOST JOBS
description: Robert Doud, 32 years old, father of two children, stood in a snow-drifted parking lot, shrinking deeper into his jacket from a biting wind that swept off the Delaware River, dwarfed by the cold gray steel of a towering vessel nearing completion in the shipyard behind him.

title: BROCK APPOINTED BY REAGAN TO BE TRADE REPRESENTATIVE
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan today selected Bill Brock, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, as special trade representative, but sources in the Reagan transition office said there was still some debate within the President-elect's staff over whether Mr. Brock's new job ought to retain its Cabinetlevel rank throughout Mr. Reagan's term.

title: Leon Spinks Tells Police He Was Attacked, Robbed
description: Leon Spinks, the former heavyweight boxing champion, told police today he was attacked on a city street and awakened hours later in a motel to find he had been robbed of $45,000 worth of clothes, jewelry and other items.

title: MOSCOW'S REACTION TO CRITICISM AT MADRID
description: To the Editor:

title: 24-Hour General Strike Disrupts Peruvian Economy
description: A 24-hour general strike, the first test of strength between organized labor and the six-month-old Government of President Fernando Belaunde Terry, disrupted operations in some of the country's main industrial, mining and commercial sectors today.

title: U.S. AIDE ELECTED TO WORTD COURT
description: Stephen M. Schwebel, Deputy Legal Adviser at the State Department, and Abdullah Fikri al-Khani, Syria's Ambassador to India, were elected by the General Assembly today to be judges on the International Court of Justice.

title: Muskie Says Foreign Aid Is Vital to U.S. Security
description: Edmund S. Muskie, in what he said would probably be his final speech as Secretary of State, asserted today that the United States must provide aid to poor nations or their worsening economic plight would pave the way for Soviet gains.

title: SPARTAN MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Yr to Nov 1
India Arrests 600 Demonstrators In Protest Over Rise in Bus Fares
description: The Indian authorities arrested more than 600 people today during a protest in the state of Maharashtra against an increase in bus fares, the United News of India said. Most of those detained were said to be members of opposition political parties.

title: Southern Pacific Up
description: Southern Pacific Company said earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980 increased by 13.4 percent, to $64.4 million, or $2.38 per share, from $56.8 million, or $2.10 per share in the final quarter of 1979. Earnings for the year, however, dropped 13.3 per cent below 1979 levels, to $155.9 million, despite an 8.9 percent increase in total revenues. The company said it suffered a $7.3 million operating loss for 1980 in its trucking operations.

title: Gibson Elected to Hall of Fame
description: In his first appearance on the ballot, Bob Gibson of the St. Louis Cardinals was voted into baseball's Hall of Fame yesterday, but he was the only one of 39 candidates to make it.

title: BRITISH STEEL: MOMENT OF TRUTH
description: Ian MacGregor, the Scottish-born American who was brought back to Britain last year to try to save the British Steel Corporation, is polling his work force on what he says is a lastchance survival plan for the company.

title: Victoriana coming up.
description: COLLECTORS of Victorian furnishings this weekend can view an abundance of late-19th-century wares, which will be auctioned next Friday and Jan. 24 at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby Parke Bernet's York Avenue Galleries (at 72d Street). Hundreds of lots will be up for bidding, including furniture, silver, porcelains, bronzes, clocks, rock crystal and ivory decorations. Particularly notable is furniture by John Henry Belter, the German-born American cabinetmaker - a pair of rococo recamiers carved around 1855 (expected to bring as much as $6,000) and a parlor suite of three sofas, four side chairs and two open armchairs. The suite's nine pieces will be sold separately, with one of the sofas carrying a presale estimate of up to $10,000.

title: Copasetics in the Oranges
description: The Copasetics, the team of five veteran dancers, will tap to the songs of the 1920's and 30's, the ''golden age'' of tap, tomorrow night at 8:30 in the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Metropolitan New Jersey, 760 Northfield Avenue in West Orange.

title: MICHIGAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NORTHWESTERN MUTUAL LIFE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including $984,000 gain for the quarter and $130,000 loss for months on the sale of real estate.

title: ZIEGLER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. MIGHT CONSIDER REVIVING THE ABM'S
description: In its drive to improve the nation's strategic posture, the Reagan administration will consider reviving plans for an antiballistics missile defense system and basing a new mobile offensive missile at sea rather than on land, Caspar W. Weinberger, the Secretary of Defense-designate, said today.

title: STANDARD COOSA THATCHER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
BANKS CALLED A KEY TO HOSTAGE RELEASE
description: A dozen major American banks that have been negotiating secretly in New York with lawyers representing Iran and its central bank have made their ''last and best offer'' for settling financial disputes that appear increasingly interlocked with the fate of the hostages, sources close to the bank negotiations said today.

title: Elevator Falls 56 Floors; 11 Hurt
description: At least 11 people were injured tonight when an elevator carrying 21 people plunged 56 stories in the First National Bank of Chicago building in the city's downtown Loop, the authorities said. A brake failure might have caused the accident, the authorities said, but a maintenance man told the police that a braking device might have slowed the elevator.

title: RAINIER BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LIETZKE IS LEADER WITH 131
description: Bruce Lietzke may be getting greedy. On three consecutive holes today he scored eagle-birdie-eagle and he called his score of 66 frustrating.

title: TEHERAN AIDE SETS TODAY AS DEADLINE
description: Iran gave the United States a formal response today to the Carter Administration's efforts to resolve the hostage crisis before leaving office.

title: RESEARCH INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Trailer-Boating at a Crossroads as Smaller Cars Increase
description: Has the growth of trailer-boating as a family sport and as an industry peaked? Have we seen its maximum potential? Twenty-five years ago technology changed the course of an industry that depended primarily on the wealthy and made boating affordable for the average family.

title: STAGE: STIRRING 'CYMBELINE' BY LAMOS IN HARTFORD
description: Mark Lamos, the new artistic director of the Hartford Stage Company, earned his reputation as the head of the California Shakespeare Festival. For the third show of his first season in Connecticut, he has chosen to direct that unwieldy epic ''Cymbeline'' and to put his credibility on the line in a single production.

title: NONESSENTIAL USE OF DELAWARE RIVER WATER BANNED
description: A mandatory ban on nonessential uses of water was imposed today on 7.5 million people in New York State, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware because of a deepening water shortage within the Delaware River Basin.

title: EX-FAIRCHILD CHIEF STARTS A BUSINESS
description: Wilfred J. Corrigan, the 42-year-old British-born engineer who headed the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation until shortly after it was acquired by Schlumberger Ltd. in 1979, is starting his own company next week. The corporation, LSI Logic (the initials stand for large-scale integration) will be based in Santa Clara, Calif., and financed by some $6 million raised from some major venture capital firms.

title: Erving Passes 20,000 Points
description: Julius Erving passed the 20,000-point mark for his pro career tonight, but the Milwaukee Bucks scored a 113-110 victory over the 76ers, ending Philadelphia's six-game winning streak.

title: PITTSBURGH NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ISOLATION FUELS HAGLER'S INTENT
description: The crown has not turned the head of Marvin Hagler, the longtime ''uncrowned'' middleweight champion. He still talks to birds and, he insisted today, ''I'm as mean as ever.''

title: Market Place; A Way to Gauge Advisers' Results
description: FOR years investors have had to settle for fragmentary information in their efforts to evaluate and compare investment advisers. Since the information was offered at the investment advisers' whim, those with a poor performance were loath to take part. As one result, there were too few participants for a meaningful frame of reference.

title: Effort Pressed to Avert Building-Service Strike
description: Negotiators for service employees and the owners of commercial office buildings in New York City continued talking past a midnight strike deadline in an attempt to avert a walkout today by 30,000 employees.

title: Soviet Gas Won't Choke the Allies
description: The economic incentives for a major East-West energy deal are compelling. Western Europe needs fuel, the Soviet Union needs capital. That is why allied governments want to provide $15 billion for a 3,000-mile pipeline that will tap Siberia's gas fields for their public utilities.

title: Isobel Elsom, 87, Dead; Stage and Film Actress
description: Isobel Elsom Harbord, a British-born actress who as Isobel Elsom appeared in supporting roles in dozens of Broadway plays and Hollywood films in a 50-year career, died of heart failure Monday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. She was 87 years old.

title: Canada Raising Price of Gas Sold to U.S. by 11%
description: Canada announced today that it would raise the price on the natural gas it exports to the United States by about 11 percent, to $4.94 per thousand cubic feet.

title: PARENTS ARE ENCOURAGING BILINGUALISM FROM INFANCY
description: Five-year-old Jan Lee scolds her 2-year-old sister in the small park atop Knob Hill. ''You don't speak Chinese here,'' she warns, waving her finger and pointing to three other children building sand castles in the white sandbox. ''They can't understand you because they speak only one language - English.''

title: The Economy
description: Industrial production increased 1 percent in December, the Federal Reserve reported. It was the fifth consecutive month of production gains, after six months of declines. Economists said the rate was likely to slacken in coming months, but none foresaw a big new recession. A preliminary estimate showed 1980 industrial production to be off 3.5 percent from the 1979 total. (Page D1.)

title: Turk Says an Assembly Will Be Set Up by October
description: The head of Turkey's ruling junta, Gen. Kenan Evren, said in a speech here today that the Government would establish a constituent assembly by October to draw up a new constitution and frame new laws. However, he said that the junta would have the power to accept or reject the assembly's recommendations.

title: Loan to Turkey
description: West Germany agreed today to lead a new Western financial aid package for Turkey, Turgut Ozal, Turkish Deputy Prime Minister, told reporters after meeting Chancellor Helmut Schmidt. Bonn also led efforts within the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development for credit packages last year and in 1979.

title: An Urban 'Legend'
description: In the 1960's, one of the most controversial figures in the New York City public-school system was Rhody A. McCoy, administrator of Ocean Hill-Brownsville, an experimental decentralized school district in Brooklyn with about 9,000 students.

title: EXPLORING RESTORED CHELSEA, AN AREA ON THE WAY UP
description: Chelsea is one of those delicate, almost fragile New York neighborhoods - it is defined by a few special streets and a few notable buildings, and it is possible to pass through it without knowing you have been there at all. Those elements that make Chelsea Chelsea, and not someplace else, are all subtle, and relatively easy to miss. For those certain blocks in the West 20's, the long, even grid of Manhattan stays the same as it is elsewhere, and the storefronts on 8th, 9th and 10th Avenues are not so very different from those a few blocks uptown or downtown. There is no great park, or waterfront, or monument to provide a focus and to serve as a neighborhood symbol. A traveler can pass in a taxicab from Greenwich Village to the Upper West Side and not see any part of Chelsea at all.

title: RALSTON PURINA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Article 226359 -- No Title
description: Peter Falk, the New York City-born screen and television actor who has a home in Scarsdale, N.Y., has contributed $500 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Giammona: Eagles' Blithe Spirit
description: Louie Giammona is not your everyday 9-to-5 working man. Or even your everyday 9-to-5 professional football player. To start with, he says, ''I do a lot of crazy things.'' Like racing his Datsun 280Z round the field before practice. Or working out for 45 minutes to an hour for the Jan. 3 playoff game against the Minnesota Vikings wearing football shoes, pants, pads and everything else - except a shirt.

title: ON DR. KING'S BIRTHDAY, PUPILS LEARN THE MEANING OF A LIFE......A LESSON
description: THEIR ELDERS PROMISE THEY WON'T FORGET By DENA KLEIMAN

title: PROGRESS SEEN IN BLACK AND POOR PUPILS' WRITING SKILLS
description: A nationwide survey shows that the writing skills of black children and children from low-income urban areas have improved significantly over previous surveys.

title: Friday; AT A PIAZZA IN THE BRONX
description: The Acting Company - the official touring arm of the John F. Kennedy Center in Washington - is taking an 18th-century farce on the road, starting with preview performances tonight at 8, tomorrow at 3 and 8, at the Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts. The play, ''Il Campiello, a Venetian comedy by Carlo Goldoni, deals with the inhabitants of a poor piazza who fill their days with dance, gossip, squabbles, stories and matrimonial scheming. It's directed by Liviu Ciulei, artistic director of the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis. Tickets are $8 and $9. The college, in the northwest Bronx, is near subway and express bus stops. Information: 960-8833. RETURN OF A 1300'S POET

title: RARITIES; Bird of a Feather
description: There is a long-eared owl roosting somewhere in Central Park. Judging by his feathers he's warmer than anyone else in town.

title: 2-for-1 Alcoa Split
description: The Aluminum Company of America said directors voted a 2-for-1 stock split and an increase in the quarterly dividend.

title: GOVERNMENT, A.T.&.T FIRE FIRST SALVOS AT TRIAL
description: The attorney for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, responding to the Justice Department's opening charge today in its huge antitrust suit against A.T.&T., said the department was deliberately trying to destroy ''the greatest enterprise on earth.''

title: THINGS YOU CAN DO THERE JUST FOR FUN
description: In addition to its attractions of history and dining, Chelsea offers a wide array of diversion. This weekend, for example, you could hear a manic monologue on dirt, visit a doll hospital, browse among turn-of-the-century posters and vintage toasters, listen to a jazz trio and watch printmakers work.

title: CUTS IN BUDGET BY CARTER SPARE NEW YORK AREA
description: President Carter's final budget was viewed today as one that established a financing ceiling for programs affecting New York City and other large urban areas, with the incoming Administration of Ronald Reagan almost certain to make substantial cuts in it.

title: Record Drilling For Oil and Gas
description: The American petroleum industry, encouraged by rising oil prices, set a drilling record in 1980 and should do so again this year, the Oil and Gas Journal said today.

title: Emanuel Celler, Former Brooklyn Congressman, Dies at 92
description: Emanuel Celler, who served a half-century in the House of Representatives, died yesterday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 92 years old.

title: 'FISH HAWK' AT GUILD
description: ''FISH HAWK,'' which opens today at the Guild Theater, is about the coming of age of a farm boy named Corby (Charlie Fields) and the rehabilitation of an Osage Indian named Fish Hawk (Will Sampson), who turned into the town drunk after his wife and young son were carried off by smallpox many years before.

title: NEW YORKERS GEARING UP FOR THE INAUGURAL WHIRL
description: New Yorkers were in a tizzy. Just when they thought they had everything organized for their inaugural trek to Washington - the hotel rooms booked, the limousines reserved, the gowns and white ties packed, and the invitations firmly in hand, the telegrams began arriving at some doors and not others.

title: Boat Show to Open Amid Indications Of Recovery in Sales
description: As the 71st National Boat Show at the Coliseum prepared to open its doors to the public tomorrow, the mood among industry leaders was one of hope that the worst slump in two decades was coming to an end.

title: Index; International
description: U.S. envoy's parting advice to Reagan: Court Canada A2 Panel calls on Soviet to reopen case of Swede who aided Jews A3 Italian police continue search for freed magistrate's abductors A3 In Polish provincial town, strikers demand union for farmers A3 Around the World A5 Marcos expected to lift martial law within days A7 Government/Politics Koch expected to call for rise in street-cleaning force B3 D'Amato's name comes up at extortion trial B4 Senate committee overwhelmingly backs Haig nomination B5 T.H. Bell wins Senate panel's approval as Education Secretary B5 Energy Two are accused of overbilling New York City for fuel oil B3 General Around the Nation A12 Puerto Rican groups concentrate attacks on U.S. military A13 Tarnower's bloodied pajama top shown to back defense B2 3,500 fellow officers pay tribute to slain New York policeman B3 New Staten Island ferryboat fails trials in Gulf of Mexico B3 Tens of thousands march in the nation to recall Dr. King B4 Obituaries George Skibine, dancer, choreographer and company director D17 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of forecasts of snow, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. All other parking regulations remain in effect. jv46.1 Weekend Events: Weekender Guide C1 Exploring New York's Chelsea, an area on the way up C1 Lots to see, do and buy in the new Chelsea C16 Theater: Broadway C2

title: GOVERNOR OF MASSACHUSETTS CLOSES GAS-HEATED SCHOOLS
description: All schools in Boston were ordered closed tomorrow and all nonresidential natural gas customers in the Boston area were ordered to set their thermostats no higher than 55 degrees as New England's gas shortage worsened today.

title: Jersey Crash Kills 3
description: A Piscataway man and his two daughters were killed yesterday when their car was struck by a commuter train at a railroad crossing here, the police said.

title: Conditional Discharge for Son of Senator Kennedy
description: A Municipal Court judge in New Jersey has granted Edward M. Kennedy Jr. a conditional discharge on misdemeanor charges of possession of less than 25 grams of marijuana.

title: INTERNATIONAL MINERALS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net earnings for the year ago quarter and first half have been the adoption during the fourth quarter of a policy of capitaliz costs incurred during the construction of certian plant and equ This restatement increased the year ago quarter and first half $1.5 million, or 5 cents a share, and $2.5 million, or 9 cents

title: Ski Trips to Vermont
description: Cross-country skiing excursions sponsored by Country Cycling tours begin this weekend with a trip to the Green Mountains of Vermont.

title: Fluor Buys Shares In Genentech Inc.
description: The Fluor Corporation has purchased an undisclosed number of shares in Genentech Inc. and will cooperate in exchanging technical information, the companies announced.

title: ART: EARLY MAX WEBERS AT THE FORUM GALLERY
description: BORN in 1881, Max Weber came here from Russia at the age of 10. Enrolling seven years later at the Pratt Institute, he studied sculpture and carpentry as well as drawing and design. He left the school in 1901, taught art for a while, then proceeded to Paris, where he resumed his studies and eventually signed on, with Patrick Henry Bruce, as one of the first Americans in Matisse's new academy.

title: TWO ACCUSED OF OVERBILLING FOR FUEL OIL AT CITY-OWNED APARTMENTS
description: Two suppliers of fuel oil who had contracts to provide about a third of the oil for city-owned apartment buildings were indicted yesterday on charges of overbilling the city and bribing a city official to assist them.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JANUARY 16, 1981
description: International The way for release of the hostages may have been cleared by Iran's latest formal response to the Carter Administration's efforts to resolve the 14-month crisis before leaving office Tuesday. Publicly, the Administration was unwilling to predict a breakthrough, but one official said the message indicated that a speedy settlement was possible. (Page A1, Column 6.) A demand for Iran's frozen assets was pressed by the chief Iranian negotiator in the talks over the release of the 52 Americans. Hours after Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini apparently approved the latest efforts to resolve the crisis, the negotiator hinted that unless Washington deposited the unencumbered assets in Algerian banks by the close of business today Iran might break off the talks. He also said that the money must be in the Algerian banks before the hostages are freed. (A1:5.)

title: ART: NEW SHOW EMPHASIZES RUSSIAN ROOTS OF MODERNISM
description: By HILTON KRAMER

title: No-Heat Landlord Sentenced to Same
description: A landlord who pleaded guilty to leaving his tenants without heat was sentenced to spend last night and tonight at the armory here and Saturday and Sunday night in two of his own buildings, which have been without heat for several days. And he must repeat the visits next week or go to jail.

title: Independent T.V. Stations Are Called Competitive
description: Among the more prominent second-class citizens in medialand are the independent television stations. Their leaders and their ad salespeople have long chafed under the superior image of the network-affiliated stations, angered by the belief by some advertisers that affiliated stations delivered a special kind of commercial time.

title: J.@M. GARDNER
description: State Representative J.@M. Gardner, the brother of Ava Gardner, the actress, died yesterday hours after he was sworn in as a member of the General Assembly.

title: Key Rates
description: * Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Economic Scene; The Reagan Priorities
description: IN his farewell address, President Carter did not mention the economy - a matter not dear to his heart since it probably had more to do with his defeat than any other issue. If Mr. Carter has had second thoughts on what he might have done differently to achieve more vigorous and less inflationary growth, he has not yet disclosed them.

title: SCM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST UNION BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INSILCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share amounts reflect 5 percent stock dividend in August 1980.

title: STANDUN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After $46,000 loss for the quarter and $1,333,000 gain for th the sale of investments and extraordinary tax credits of $104,0 quarter and $354,000 for the year...C-Including extraordinary t of $282,000 for the quarter and $914,000 for the year...1980 re include operations of Fey Manufacturing Co, acquired in Septemb

title: 1980 U.S. OIL IMPORTS DOWN 18%
description: The United States imported 18 percent less oil last year than it did in 1979 as rising prices continued to slow energy demand, the American Petroleum Institute said yesterday.

title: CONCERT: BROOKLYN PHILHARMONIA IN IVES, SESSIONS AND BEETHOVEN
description: NOTHING, perhaps, should be allowed to upstage Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, but the New York premieres of two short American works performed before the symphony did manage to capture much of the attention in Carnegie Hall last Monday night. Lukas Foss led the Brooklyn Philharmonia, and the scores in question were Charles Ives's ''Johnny Poe'' and Roger Sessions's Rhapsody for Orchestra.

title: Newlin Says He'll Appeal Ejection From 76ers Game
description: Mike Newlin of the Nets said today that he will appeal an official's decision to eject him after a fight with Lionel Hollins of the 76ers in Philadelphia Wednesday.

title: FEDERAL URBAN NONPOLICY
description: If, 30 years ago, the Federal Government had developed a deliberate plan to destroy our cities, it would not have been more successful than has been the case.

title: Abscam 'Cat Fight'
description: A dispute between Justice Department offices over actions in the Government's Abscam investigation into political corruption was termed a ''cat fight'' by a Federal judge.

title: WHAT IT TAKES TO RUN A NUCLEAR PLANT
description: To the Editor:

title: Bosendorfer Program
description: The pianist Lev Natochenny and the violinist Albert Makov, both Soviet emigres, will perform together tomorrow at 8 P.M. in a free concert on the Bosendorfer piano in the auditorium of the New York Times, 229 West 43d Street. The musicians, who are also scheduled to appear at Carnegie Hall this month, will play Beethoven's Sonata No. 4 in A minor (Op. 23), Prokofiev's Sonata No. 2 in D major (Op. 94a) and Franck's Sonata in A major. Information: 753-5200.

title: U.S. ENVOY PLEDGES HELP FOR SALVADOR IN HALTING ARMS
description: Ambassador Robert E. White, saying that the United States was ''under an obligation'' to help El Salvador's civilian-military junta counter a leftist guerrilla threat, appeared today to leave open the possibility that Washington might increase its military aid.

title: REDLAKE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary income of $14,892 for the quarter and the 9 months.

title: 'America' Musical to Open At Music Hall on March 13
description: ''America,'' a musical its producers say will celebrate ''the optimistic spirit of a great nation'' with hoedowns, Sousa marches, jam sessions and Broadway melodies. will open March 13 at Radio City Music Hall.

title: Real Estate; Developer Focuses on Rockland
description: SUFFERN, N.Y. AMONG residential developers with substantial production over many years, there is a certain breed making a special effort to concentrate on a specific location. The organization adopts a home base, as it were, and tries to build both a reputation and a following. One hope is that it will sell houses to the same customers more than once, since housing needs change as life progresses.

title: CHAMBER: VOICE, THE PERFECT INSTRUMENT
description: THE human voice is the instrument that all other instruments aspire to. It can speak to us more directly and more expressively than any orchestra or virtuoso-powered piano. Because of this intimate nature, therefore, the voice is the perfect chamber-music instrument, a fact that the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has recognized by instituting a separate series centered on singers and songs. The second concert in the society's new Vocal Chamber Music Series was given last night at Alice Tully Hall, where the soprano Barbara Hendricks and the tenor John Aler were the focal points of a program that was marvelously various and wide-ranging.

title: News Analysis; CARTER'S LAST BUDGET: PORTRAIT OF ECONOMIC TROUBLES AWAITING NEW PRESIDENT
description: If Ronald Reagan and his budget advisers require any further evidence of the difficulty of the task facing them, they need only look to President Carter's latest and final budget, released today.

title: INSURANCE QUANDRY
description: To the Editor:

title: LOW CHOLESTEROL LINKED TO CANCER
description: A new study has added to growing evidence that there may be a link between very low blood cholesterol levels and at least one form of cancer.

title: JACK SCHLISSEL, GENERAL MANAGER AND PRODUCER ON BROADWAY, 58
description: Jack Schlissel, a general manager and producer on Broadway, died of a heart attack Tuesday night in his apartment on West 67th Street. He was 58 years old.

title: PANEL, 15-2, BACKS NOMINATION OF HAIG
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today overwhelmingly recommended the confirmation of Alexander M. Haig Jr. as Secretary of State. Two Democrats who had clashed with him over the Watergate scandals cast the only dissenting votes.

title: U.N. Employees Hold a Sitdown In Support of Prisoner in Poland
description: Several hundred United Nations employees held a sitdown today in front of the organization's cafeteria to protest the imprisonment of Alicja Wesolowska, a United Nations employee accused by the Polish Government of being a spy.

title: SENATORS PUT OFF VOTE ON l
description: DONAVAN AS PANEL GETS WORD OF ALLEGATIONS By PHILIP SHABECOFF

title: DAVID A. MOSS
description: David A. Moss, director of operations of SJR Communications Inc., 655 Madison Avenue, owner of of a chain of radio stations, including WKTU in New York City, died Monday at University Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan and Bedford Village, N.Y.

title: WEST BERLIN'S GOVERNMENT RESIGNS
description: In the wake of a financial scandal, Mayor Dietrich Stobbe of West Berlin resigned today with the entire city government after suffering a legislative defeat on his plan for shuffling his coalition cabinet.

title: BELMONTE TAPE PUT IN EVIDENCE
description: A 45-minute tape recording of a conversation in which Eddie Belmonte purportedly discussed the fixing of horse races with another jockey was introduced yesterday at the State Racing and Wagering Board hearing on the suspension of Belmonte.

title: NEW S.I. FERRYBOAT FAILS TRIALS
description: A new Staten Island ferryboat that New York City transportation officials have been waiting more than two years for has failed its sea trials in the Gulf of Mexico near New Orleans.

title: AMERICAN BANK & TRUST CO OF PA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
POP: TOM SCOTT'S BAND
description: TOM SCOTT'S genteel brand of pop-funk is never less than pleasant. Mr. Scott, a saxophonist, composer and arranger who opened a fournight run at the Bottom Line on Wednesday, has recorded a number of albums with various groupings of studio luminaries, provided excellent pop arrangements for Joni Mitchell and Steely Dan, and scored a number of television series and films. At the Bottom Line, he was the front man for an all-star lineup of New York-based musicians.

title: TEXAS PACIFIC LAND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are per sub-shares and reflect a 3-for-1 stock s March 12.

title: DOWN-HOME FARE AND POLICE SHOWS
description: SHUCKS. Television is going folksy this weekend, with a down-home new comedy series, ''Harper Valley P.T.A.,'' tonight at 8 on Channel 4 and a two-hour country music extravaganza (''Country Countdown,'' tomorrow night at 8:30 on Channel 11). Does this constitute a trend? It does not. But it may indicate, correctly, that the country shows were available for preview, whereas a new detective series (''Nero Wolfe,'' tonight at 9 on NBC), a new cop show (''Walking Tall,'' tomorrow at 9 P.M. on NBC), and another new cop show (''Hill Street Blues,'' tomorrow at 10 P.M. on NBC) were not. Had these programs been on hand at press time, they might well have constituted a trend of their own.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Analog Devices Inc. agreed in principle to sell 263,158 of its common shares for $10 million to Standard Oil (Indiana).

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Company has named Hugh H. Smith senior vice president, government affairs.

title: 3 LEO SMIT VENTURES INTO THE UNUSUAL
description: As far back as Leo Smit can remember, he has never played a conventional recital program - and the pianist's career is now well into its fourth decade. In view of this, Mr. Smit's unusual threeconcert marathon at the Abraham Goodman House this weekend represents, for him, a typically enterprising event.

title: IPCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including $260,000 gain on the sale of land for the quarter a and tax credits of $488,000 for the quarter and $783,000 for th C-After losses of $103,000 for the quarter and $579,000 for the

title: Squibb Creates Group For Consumer Products
description: The Squibb Corporation has created a Consumer Products Group that contains both the Charles of the Ritz Group and Life Savers Inc., and has named Martin H. Schmidt, president of the cosmetics company, to also be president of the confection company, according to a confidential ''executive bulletin'' distributed Wednesday and signed by Richard M. Furlaud, chairman and chief executive.

title: Boating Literature Available
description: Although few showgoers actually buy a boat, it seems that nearly every one leaves as a collector - of brochures. At the New York Boat Show this is made easier by a stop at the Boating Information Booth in the lobby. Here 50 different pamphlets are available on subjects ranging from fuel efficiency guidelines to safety materials.

title: 2 JUDGES COMPROMISE ON 3 GIRLS ATTENDING ALL-WHITE LOUISIANA SCHOOL
description: A compromise was struck here today between a state judge and a Federal judge who had clashed over a school desegregation plan for a central Louisiana parish.

title: MARCOS IS EXPECTED TO LIFT MARTIAL LAW SHORTLY, BUT OPPOSITION IS WARY
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos spent most of today in consultations with his Cabinet and top military commanders in what was described as an appraisal of the economic, social and political situation prior to the expected lifting of martial law.

title: U.N. INQUIRY IS URGED INTO A LOAN 'SCANDAL'
description: An unpublished United Nations report has urged an internal inquiry into charges that high officials in at least two departments have been involved in financial ''scandal'' or ''impropriety.''

title: DECLINE IN RIDERS FOREBODES A RISE IN SUBWAY FARES
description: Ridership on New York City's subways has decreased sharply, according to figures obtained yesterday from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The decline adds weight to the prospect of a fare increase by July 1.

title: Texas International Cancels Merger
description: The Texas International Company has ended its plans to merge with the Phoenix Resources Company, a transaction that was valued at about $90 million.

title: Bridge: Prizes Seem to Be Immune To the Influence of Inflation
description: It does not often happen that the game of bridge merits an appearance on the front page of this or any other newspaper. It happened 15 years ago when a cheating scandal broke in Buenos Aires. It happened half a century ago when Ely Culbertson met Sidney Lenz in a famous rubber bridge match. And it happened on a more obscure occasion, on Jan. 18, 1916.

title: The ride-by subway mural.
description: IT is fundamental to our century that we spend a great deal of time sitting still and watching a moving picture. But what if the situation were reversed, and it was we who were on the move and the picture that sat still? What if, when the subway train ran through a deserted station, we could stay in our seat and look out at a painted image that flashed by, frame by frame, as a film flashes by in a movie projector?

title: CARTER SEEKS $180 BILLION FOR 1982 MILITARY BUDGET
description: The military budget that President Carter sent to Congress today was intended to provide what Secretary of Defense Harold Brown called a ''steady and sustained'' expansion in military financing that would average 5 percent a year over the next five years.

title: MAYFAIR SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
House Panel to Consider Legality Of Federal Undercover Inquiries
description: Congress will conduct hearings next month into Constitutional issues raised by Federal Bureau of Investigation undercover operations such as the Abscam case.

title: Bosetti Gets Jays Pact
description: The Toronto Blue Jays said today that they had agreed to terms for 1981 with Rick Bosetti, the center fielder who spent most of last year on the disabled list. Bosetti, who suffered a fractured wrist June 22 after being hit by a pitch, will receive $100,000.

title: Grand Jury Indicts Suspect In Death of Dr. Halberstam
description: A District of Columbia grand jury today handed down an 11-count indictment against Bernard Welch, the alleged master burglar who was charged with killing Dr. Michael Halberstam, the Washington cardiologist and writer.

title: ARMED PUERTO RICAN GROUPS FOCUS ATTACKS ON MILITARY
description: The Macheteros, the pro-independence group that claimed responsibility for Monday's bombings of 11 fighter planes at the Muniz Air National Guard base, is one of four armed groups that have mounted attacks on United States military targets here.

title: SECURITY PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said securities gains or losses were not significan in either yr

title: BANK LENDERS SEEM RESIGNED TO CHRYSLER DEBT PLAN
description: The Chrysler Corporation's lead bankers have decided that they are willing to settle, in effect, for 15 cents on the dollar for the more than $1 billion they have lent the company. The bankers believe it is the best they can hope for in the troubled situation.

title: CASH FLOW INTO FUNDS SETS RECORD
description: A record $2.8 billion of new cash flowed into the nation's money market funds in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: A Failure Of Politics
description: President Carter's farewell address became him well. He offered best wishes to the man who defeated him, reminded the nation of its enduring values and made a modest final appeal for the goals that had most engaged him.

title: A NEW FAMILY ROBINSON
description: ONLY a new triple-G rating, ''certain to outrage the intelligence of any child over the age of 7,'' rather than the G it actually has, seems suitable for ''Mountain Family Robinson.'' It opens today at the Eastside Cinema and other theaters.

title: Carter message excerpts and other budget articles, pages B6-7.
description: President Carter, in a final budget peppered with warnings to President-elect Ronald Reagan, today proposed to Congress a series of substantial increases in military spending in the 1980's and cuts in many nondefense programs.

title: INAUGURATION DAY
description: To the Editor:

title: TRITON GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Net income including tax credits of $1,589,000 for the quarte $705,000 for the 6 months.

title: A STEADY HAND FROM TENNESSEE
description: William Emerson Brock 3d, the man named today as Ronald Reagan's special trade representative, is a one-time sales manager whose steady, firm handclasp and look-you-in-the eye manner as Republican National Committee chairman helped sell Mr. Reagan to the American people.

title: South Korean President Enters Election Race
description: President Chun Doo Hwan declared his candidacy today for South Korea's presidential elections next month.

title: Borden to Decide On Snack Food Account
description: It is understood that the Borden management in Columbus, Ohio, will decide today whether it will move its Wise/ Old London Foods snack products from Bozell & Jacobs to another of its agencies, as recommended by George J. Waydo, president of the snacks products group in Atlanta.

title: CARTER SEEKS NEW INDEX TO CURB SOARING BENEFITS
description: In an attempt to hold down a staggering increase in the cost of Government retirement programs, President Carter asked Congress in his budget proposals today to adopt a new method for calculating automatic cost-of-living increases in benefits.

title: No Headline
description: Books: A Lesson in Irony By Anatole Broyard OTHER PEOPLE'S WORLDS. By William Trevor. 243 pages. Viking. $10.95.

title: MONDALE TELLS OF PLAN TO LECTURE AT COLLEGES AND HINTS AT 84 HOPE
description: Vice President Mondale confirmed today that he would begin a new career as a college and university lecturer after leaving office next week.

title: PBA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RARITIES; Brodie's Lives
description: Fawn Brodie, the distinguished biographer and historian who died last week at the age of 66, won no Pulitzers and was never lionized on the talk shows. Yet few American writers addressed themselves to so many controversies with such meticulous skill and exemplary effect.

title: CHRISTMAS PLUS ALMOST CURE HOLLYWOOD'S ANXIETY ATTACK
description: Hollywood approached Christmas last month with all the dread of a long deferred visit to the dentist. The pallid spring of 1980 had been followed by a soggy summer and lackluster fall at the box office. No one knew what quite to expect when theater doors opened wide for 19 movies in December.

title: METPATH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Acosta Nichols Jr. Is Dead at 70; Former Teacher at Groton School
description: Acosta Nichols Jr., a former history teacher who taught at the Groton School in Massachusets for 40 years, died Saturday at his home in Oyster Bay Cove, L.I. He was 70 years old.

title: 200 POLES STAGING A SIT-IN TO WIN LEGALITY FOR FARM UNION
description: The 200 or so men and a few quiet women in black who have been occupying a three-story building in this city near the Soviet border for two weeks think they are going to make history for Poland's independent farmers.

title: No Headline
description: The dollar ante and intensity of the so-called tar wars - that marketing struggle for success in selling low-tar, low-nicotine cigarettes - has been stepped up in recent months.

title: S.E.C. Cites Brokerage
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation and one of its representatives had violated Federal securities laws.

title: DAUGHTER IS CHARGED WITH MASTERMINDING HER PARENTS' MURDER
description: The Rockland County District Attorney said today that the murders of Arnold and Elaine Sohn in their home two weeks ago were the result of a robbery plot ''masterminded'' by their 23-year-old daughter. He said she had ''left the door open'' for two male acquaintances who allegedly committed the murders.

title: Northern California Cities Shaken By Year's Strongest Earthquake
description: The fourth and strongest earthquake of the new year rocked northern California early today, knocking a radio station off the air and causing a brief blackout at a jail. No damage or injuries were reported.

title: For Angler, Show Is a Trove of Ideas
description: For one whose boyhood recollections of saltwater angling includes surf casters whirling handlines over their heads or the slow, heavy beat of a one-lung Lathrop engine pushing a dory through the earlymorning fog, the abundance of new equipment and new boats displayed at the New York National Boat Shows never ceases to amaze.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt AMBITION. The Secret Passion. By Joseph Epstein. 312 pages. Dutton. $13.95.

title: MUSIC: THE MOZARTEANS, WITH TWO FORTEPIANOS
description: IF history was not exactly made on Wednesday night in Tully Hall, there was at least one aspect that made the concert of the Mozartean Players a ''first'' in New York. Not one but two fortepianos graced the stage. This was a Mozart concert put together by Steven Lubin, and the second fortepiano was used for the Two-Piano Concerto in E flat, played by Mr. Lubin and Anthony Newman.

title: MARYLAND NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bill Brock's Plum
description: Appointing the Republican Chairman, Bill Brock, as Special Trade Representative makes about as much sense as naming the Democratic Chairman, Robert Strauss, to the job four years ago - a lot of sense.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 16, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets on Security Council represen- tation at 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Spending growth can be constrained; not easily, not quickly, but it is possible.

title: SEED OUR CLOUDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Carter Restricts Exports Of Hazardous Products
description: President Carter today ordered a restriction on the export of hazardous products that are banned or controlled in the United States.

title: DAIRYMAN SEES A FUTURE IN AN OLD CHEESE PRODUCT
description: Martin Schanback, 57, has been making cultured dairy products for his entire business life. And recently, Mr. Schanback, president of Friendship Food Products Inc., a major New York area producer of cottage cheese, yogurt and pot cheese, has noticed a mini-boom in another of these old-line products: farmer cheese.

title: DECEMBER PRODUCTION UP BY 1%
description: American industry increased its production by a full 1 percent in December, the fifth consecutive month at that rate or higher, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: GEORGE E. LINTON
description: George E. Linton, a former dean of the textile science department at the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York City, died yesterday at a nursing home in Brainerd, Minn., after a long illness.

title: BLAZE AT STOUFFER'S DESCRIBED AS ARSON
description: The Westchester District Attorney said today that the fire that killed 26 persons at a Stouffer's Inn conference center in the Town of Harrison on Dec. 4 was ''a deliberate act of arson.''

title: Hall of Fame Voting Results
description: The voting for the Hall of Fame by the 10-year members of the Baseball Writers' Association of America: (301 votes required for election) Bob Gibson 337 Don Drysdale 243 Gil Hodges 241 Harmon Killebrew 239 Hoyt Wilhelm 238 Juan Marichal 233 Nelson Fox 168 Red Schoendienst 166 Jim Bunning 164 Maury Wills 163 Richie Ashburn 142 Roger Maris 94 Harvey Kuenn 93 Elston Howard 83 Orlando Cepeda 77 Thurman Munson 62 Ted Kluszewski 56 Luis Aparicio 48 Lew Burdette 48 Bill Mazeroski 38 Don Larsen 33 Elroy Face 23 Vada Pinson 18 Jim Perry 6 Dave McNally 5 Claude Osteen 2 Glenn Beckert 1 Gates Brown 1 Leo Cardenas 1 Lindy McDaniel 1 Jim Northrup 1 Sonny Siebert 1 The following failed to get a vote: Ken Berry, Johnny Briggs, Bill Hands, Bob Locker, Dal Maxvill, Dick McAuliffe and Sam McDowell.

title: Utilities Cut Appropriations
description: Faced with rising interest rates, utilities sharply curtailed their appropriations for capital spending in the third quarter of 1980, but such appropriations were still at a record level during the first nine months of the year, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

title: CANCER STUDY REPORTS HIGH RISK FOR WIVES OF SMOKING HUSBANDS
description: Wives who did not smoke but were exposed to their husbands' cigarette smoke developed lung cancer at a much higher rate than nonsmoking wives of nonsmoking husbands, according to results of a major 14-year study in Japan.

title: CENTRAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE RUTH LAREDO-SERGEI RACHMANINOFF LOVE STORY
description: Ruth Laredo will bring her long-standing love affair with the music of Sergei Rachmaninoff to Carnegie Hall on Sunday evening. In one sense, the recital will be a celebration. With her seventh and last volume of Rachmaninoff's solo piano music now recorded and available to the public, Miss Laredo will be marking the end of a project that has lasted most of the last decade.

title: Itel Board to Weigh Bankruptcy Action
description: The Itel Corporation's board of directors will meet tomorrow to consider bankruptcy proceedings, a company spokesman said.

title: Restless Bossy Eyes Record
description: The Islanders did not play last night, a rarity for Thursdays on the National Hockey League schedule, and Mike Bossy did not like that. With 45 goals in 46 games, Bossy is bidding to break Maurice Richard's record of 50 goals in 50 games, set 36 seasons ago.

title: WITH ROME AIDE FREE, CAPTORS ARE SOUGHT
description: The police began a new search today for the Red Brigades kidnappers who this morning released a magistrate they had held for 33 days.

title: PEPPERIDGE FARM ENTERS RESTAURANT FIELD
description: Pepperidge Farm, in an effort to broaden its traditional business of baking, has moved into the restaurant field. The company, a subsidiary of the Campbell Soup Company, opened its first restaurant, called Greenings, in Westport, Conn., last June as a market trial. The outlet is also being used to test new products that may eventually be sold in supermarket frozen-food sections.

title: BIDS BY IRAN TO RECOVER SHAH'S WEALTH FACE OBSTACLES
description: Attempts by Iran to recover the fortune of the late Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi and his family face a series of difficult, if not insurmountable, obstacles, according to a survey of records pertaining to the Pahlevi fortune.

title: LED U.S. EFFORT IN ATMOIC POWER
description: David E. Lilienthal, former chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority and the first chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, died of a heart attack at the Sheraton Centre Hotel in New York City yesterday. He was 81 years old and was a resident of Princeton, N.J.

title: energywatch
description: JAN. 9, 1981 Crude oil inventories continued to rise, reaching 364.7 million barrels.

title: PORTRAYED STELLA DALLAS ON RADIO
description: Anne Elstner Matthews, who played Stella Dallas on the long-running radio serial of that name, died of a stroke in Doylestown, Pa., on Jan. 29. Mrs. Matthews, who had lived for many years in Stockton, N.J., was 82 years old.

title: KHOMEINI URGES IRANIANS TO CEASE CRITICIZING BANI-SADR OVER THE WAR
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini called on the Iranian people today to stop criticizing President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr for his conduct of the war against Iraq.

title: U.S. ENVOY'S PARTING WORD TO REAGAN: COURT CANADA
description: The United States has to be less clumsy and casual and more sensitive and caring in its relations with Canada. This is the advice that the Ambassador here is preparing to deliver to the new Republican Administration.

title: Move Against All-Male Clubs
description: Mayor William J. Green 3d of Philadelphia has signed two ordinances aimed at ending sex discrimination in exclusive Philadelphia clubs that either bar women or require them to eat in separate rooms.

title: BLACKOUT HITS BIG AREA OF MEXICO
description: A power failure affected much of Mexico today after three generators failed, stranding commuters and creating rush-hour traffic jams here, and cutting power to Acapulco and to Guadalajara, the nation's second largest city.

title: MILLER INSISTING CHRYUSLER PURSUE MERGER SEARCH
description: Treasury Secretary G. William Miller is insisting that the Chrysler Corporation continue to take all possible steps to find a merger partner or form a joint venture to improve its long-term viability, according to people involved in the auto maker's efforts to get additional Federal loan guarantees.

title: 4 FORGOTTEN AMERICANS
description: To the Editor:

title: Labor Panel Job Creates A Rift in Reagan Camp; The Washington Star
description: A controversy has broken out in Presidentelect Ronald Reagan's transition team over the appointment of a new member to the National Labor Relations Board.

title: MISSOURI AND KENTUCKY TOLD TO INTEGRATE COLLEGES
description: The Department of Education notified officials in Missouri and Kentucky today that their public college systems retained traces of illegal segregation practices, and said that Texas had submitted a satisfactory plan for correcting similar violations.

title: EXCERPTS FROM BUDGET MESSAGE TO CONGRESS ON FISCAL YEAR 1982
description: Following are excerpts from the text of President Carter's Budget Message to Congress today for the Federal Government's fiscal year 1982, starting next Oct. 1:

title: INTERMARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including $2,023,000 gain on the sale of stock...C-Including gain on the sale of stock.

title: UNIVERSAL FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ken Russell on 'Altered States' controversy.
description: KEN RUSSELL, the director of ''Altered States,'' which is showing all the signs of becoming a big commercial success, described l'Affaire Chayefsky from his perspective over lunch the other day. The controversy exploded, it will be recalled, not long after the film went into production. Paddy Chayefsky charged that his screenplay, which he adapted from his novel of the same title, was being ruined by Mr. Russell's directorial quirks. Mr. Chayefsky insisted on having his name removed from the picture, so the screenplay is credited to the pseudonymous Sidney Aaron.

title: Dance at the Museum
description: A Japanese mask dance, an Irish jig and a Middle Eastern karshilama will be among the fancy footwork demonstrated by the Matteo EthnoAmerican Dance Theater on Sunday at 2 P.M. in the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street.

title: RCA Has Agreed To Sell Raco Inc.
description: The RCA Corporation said it had agreed in principle to sell Raco Inc. to Harvey Hubbell Inc. for $40 million less a credit for liabilities that could amount to between $2 and $2.5 million.

title: MET OPERA GIVES BLISS GENERAL MANAGER TITLE
description: The Metropolitan Opera yesterday formally elevated Anthony A. Bliss, the company's executive director since 1974, to the post of general manager. But at the same time Met officials stressed that the promotion was for purposes of administrative efficiency, and did not constitute a radical shift in the Met's manner of operation.

title: 'ANTI-WESTWAY IS PRO-BUSINESS'
description: To the Editor:

title:
RED SMITH;
Gibson, the Deity
description: THE Royal Ballroom in the Sheraton Centre is done in cardinal red - drapes, carpets, red chairs in ranks facing a standup microphone in the front of the room. Bowie Kuhn, baseball's supreme being, wore a red handkerchief in his breast pocket. Bob Gibson, who pitched for 20 years in the St. Louis Cardinals' organization, broke the scheme with a blue jacket, blue shirt, beige slacks and an expression of affability that hitters in the National League never saw on the mound. Bob Gibson was always his own man.

title: THEATER: EVA LE GALLIENNE IN 'TO GRANDMOTHER'S HOUSE'
description: IT'S very easy to fall in love all over again with Eva Le Gallienne, who returned to the theater last night in ''To Grandmother's House We Go.'' As Grandie, an octogenarian Connecticut matriarch, she is on stage for much of the evening, and there's plenty of time to contemplate her face, her voice, her poise. Though it's no secret that Miss Le Gallienne is a fine actress, it's just as much a pleasure to re-encounter her beauty. When she flows about her comfy, antique-laden living room in a bathrobe, her gray hair tumbling to her shoulders, she seems as lyrical as any Juliet: she pays no mind to the staccato movements of old age. And while Miss Le Gallienne's features are aristocratic, even regal, they can melt, without warning, into a diaphanous smile that has no equal on Broadway.

title: DATSUN PRICES UP BY AVERAGE OF $192
description: Nissan U.S.A. announced today that it was increasing suggested retail prices for its complete line of Datsun cars and trucks by an average of $192, or 2.6 percent.

title: The President's Report Card
description: ''It's funny,'' a friend of Jimmy Carter said the other day, ''how, since the election, somebody who is merely President of the United States has disappeared from sight. It's as though Jimmy Carter has fallen off the table.'' It's true, but the reason is not simply that the public is fickle. Even when the President has sought visibility, as with his farewell address Wednesday night, it has been hard to pay attention. His Presidency has lived in the shadow of the hostage crisis for 14 months, and never more than now.

title: Advertising; Needham Forms New Issues Unit
description: ''W E'RE putting ourselves in line to get business from two great growth areas - corporate and trade-association advertising,'' said Barry Biederman, senior vice president of Needham, Harper & Steers, who has been named president of the company's newly formed NH&S/ Issues & Images unit.

title: 1,000 MEET IN BUFFALO IN TRIBUTE TO DR. KING AS COUNTER RALLY FAILS
description: A thousand people gathered at Lafayette Square here today in the winter chill to observe the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Sale of G.T.E. Unit Set
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation said today that the Justice Department had told the company it would not oppose the planned sale of G.T.E.'s consumer electronics operations to the North American Philips Corporation. G.T.E. said the companies would proceed promptly to conclude the transaction, which was announced last October.

title: STARS AND STARGAZERS FILL GARDEN
description: Like a heavyweight championship fight, a Super Bowl or a World Series, a tennis match between Bjorn Borg and John McEnroe has acquired that special cachet that makes being there, to see or be seen, a status symbol.

title: Sleeping With Elephants
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski gave his swan song as national security adviser here this week, and it was fitting that he summed up his view of the world the United States faces in a capital that is highly conscious of facing the United States.

title: BLOODIED TARNOWER PAJAMA TOP SHOWN TO BACK DEFENSE'S VERSION OF SHOOTING
description: Herbert MacDonell, a forensic expert testifying for the defense in the Jean S. Harris murder trial, put on Dr. Herman Tarnower's bloodied pajama top today as part of an effort to demonstrate that ''considerable activity'' had occurred the night he was shot.

title: UNIFI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Court Upholds Subpoena In Lance Loan Investigation
description: A Federal appeals court, in a rare decision by the full bench, today upheld a subpoena against Bert Lance, the former Federal budget director, in connection with an investigation of loans he obtained.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday incorrectly listed the number of em- ployees of telephone companies in the United States and the number of tele- phone companies operated by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. A.T.&T. employs 1,046,000 people, and other United States tele- phone companies employ 190,000. A.T.&T. operates 23 phone companies. An article with the chart incorrectly described the ownership of A.T.&T. The company is publicly held.

title: D'AMATO'S NAME BROUGHT INTO U.S. EXTORTION TRIAL
description: A Federal prosecutor said at the opening of an extortion trial in Brooklyn yesterday that a Long Island contractor would testify he was asked to make an illegal $30,000 payoff in 1977 that was to go to Alfonse M. D'Amato when he was Presiding Supervisor of Hempstead, L.I., and to other politicans.

title: EQUAL PENSIONS FOR UNEQUAL WORK
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Sigma Research Clarifies Position
description: In a letter to W.R. Simmons, president of the Three Sigma Research Center, Ingrid C. Kildegaard of the Advertising Research Foundation, having noted that the foundation's review of the Three Sigma Newspaper Study of audiences was running behind because the foundation had not received all of the necessary material from the research company, questions the use of the phrase ''the methods were made subject to Advertising Research Foundation review'' in a Three Sigma brochure.

title: SCOTTY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
PHILADELPHIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1979 earnings include a gain of $5.8 million or $1.00 a shr from the sale of the corporation's British consumer banking unit

title: SHORT-TERM RATES EDGE HIGHER
description: Interest rates rose modestly in all sectors of the credit markets yesterday amid a slackening of demand for new bonds. ''If we don't see some easing out of the Fed and more encouraging economic statistics, this market is not out of the woods yet,'' one Government securities trader commented. ''Everyone is quite nervous about the money supply data and confused about the true state of the economy,'' he added.

title: REAGAN AIDES VOW TO ALTER 'POLITICAL' BUDGET OF CARTER
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan's top economic advisers assailed President Carter's final budget today as ''a very political document'' that would have to be revised ''from top to bottom'' by the new administration.

title: Jackie Robinson story returning as 'The First,' a musical.
description: IDEAS for Broadway shows can spring up in offhand ways. In the case of ''Annie,'' the show presented itself to Martin Charnin while he was browsing in a bookstore one day. And in the case of ''The First,'' Mr. Charnin's next project, the origin can be traced to a casual conversation between two strangers in a midtown office.

title: 'LET THERE BE LIGHT,' JOHN HUSTON VS. THE ARMY
description: FOR more than 30 years, the United States Army has been suppressing public showings of ''Let There Be Light,'' one of the documentaries made for the Army Signal Corps by John Huston toward the end of World War II. That's not to say the film has gone unheralded. The late James Agee wrote about it with enthusiasm in Time and The Nation in 1947 and 1948. Though the picture is now, at long last, opening a limited run today at the Thalia, the Army - which didn't supply this print - apparently continues to be alarmed. At this late date, it's difficult to see what the fuss is about.

title: BANKERS TRUST NY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split; 1980 results include net income of $16.6 million or $135 a shr for the qr an $33.1 million or $2.87 a shr for the yr from the sale of branch 1979 results have been reclassified for comparative purposes

title: Warren Zevon album: live, raw and powerful.
description: AFTER Warren Zevon's show at the Palladium last spring, a number of the rock critics who have been among his staunchest admirers skulked away down 14th Street with their heads half-buried in their upturned coat collars, muttering to themselves. Hadn't they always loved Warren Zevon? Hadn't they singled him out as early as 1976, when his first album was released, as the most talented singer-songwriter to have emerged from the neon sprawl of Los Angeles in a decade? And hadn't they all respectfully suggested, when he gave his first New York performances and hid behind his piano, that he should try being a little more, well, outgoing? Yes, and apparently he'd listened to them. He spent half his Palladium show running around the stage as though he was practicing for the marathon. He crouched and jumped and shouted and raised a clenched fist and finally ripped off his shirt. Frankly, he made an embarrassing spectacle of himself.

title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE EVENING HOURS
description: The invitation began quite simply: ''You are invited to a 200th birthday.'' Even blase New Yorkers who think they have seen everything when it comes to unusual parties would probably be intrigued by the idea of feting a 200-year-old.

title: ROLM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
Dr. Arthur Niederhoffer, A Professor at John Jay
description: Dr. Arthur Niederhoffer, a professor of sociology at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice and a former member of the New York City Police Department who wrote several books about the police, died Wednesday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 63 years old.

title: Israel Approves Creation Of 2 West Bank Settlements
description: A Cabinet-level committee approved the establishment of two new Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank, officials said today.

title: MORTON-NORWICH PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PIONEER TEXAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SMITH SEEKS EFFORT ON VIOLENT CRIMES
description: William French Smith, the Attorney Generaldesignate, said today that his ''top priority'' for the Justice Department was the leadership of a national effort to combat violent crime.

title: The 'Self-Cleaning Floor' and Other Misunderstandings
description: Although Julia Child likes to keep her cooking advice on the light side, she said the other day in Chicago, her word is ''too often considered gospel.''

title: GEORGE SKIBINE, 60, DANCER SINCE AGE OF 5 AND CHOREOGRAPHER
description: George Skibine, dancer, choreographer and artistic director of the Dallas Ballet, died Wednesday night at his home in Dallas after a short illness. He was 60 years old.

title: REINING THE FED
description: Once again a not-so-funny thing has happened on our way to economic recovery. Economic signs were generally pointing upward last fall when the Federal Reserve Board decided, as it has so often in the past when an economic boomlet appeared on the horizon, that it was time to slam on the brakes by pushing interests rates up, this time piercing the 20 percent barrier.

title: Texan Wins George Jean Nathan Award
description: The most lucrative prize in theater criticism, the $5,000 George Jean Nathan Award, will go this year to Sean Mitchell of The Dallas Times Herald.

title: MEREDITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PUBLISHING: 'KINFLICKS' AUTHOR IS BACK
description: FOR a first novel, it elicited remarkable critical praise indeed. When ''Kinflicks'' was published in 1976, its author, Lisa Alther, was compared with Doris Lessing and J.D. Salinger; its bright, funny heroine with Augie March and Huckleberry Finn. In Miss Alther's next novel - ''Original Sins,'' which will be published in April by Alfred A. Knopf - she traces an emotional terrain familiar to readers of ''Kinflicks.'' This time, however, the story is not told through the eyes of one survivor of the 1960's, but through the experiences of five young Southerners who came of age during those perilous times.

title: RESTAURANTS: A PROMISING CROP SPROUTS IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: IF a proliferation of new restaurants can be considered one of a neighborhood's vital life signs, then Chelsea is taking nourishment in an encouraging way. Like truffles growing darkly and secretly under the fertile soil of Perigord forests, new and interesting eating places have been quietly sprouting along the graceful old streets and avenues of this revitalized section of the city. Anyone venturing around Chelsea to admire its gracious brownstones and gardens, to shop for antiques or to seek out its nighttime diversions, can find rest and personal restoration in a variety of settings.

title: SENATE PANELS BACK TWO REAGAN CHOICES
description: T.@H. Bell won unanimous approval from the Senate Labor and Resources Committee today to be Secretary of Education, and Jeane J. Kirkpatrick was unanimously approved by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to be chief delegate to the United Nations.

title: A DEATH PENALTY IS URGED AT RITES FOR SLAIN OFFICER
description: The first New York City police officer slain this year was buried yesterday after angry pleas from his pastor and comrades for the return of capital punishment.

title: Purcell to Run Again
description: Francis T. Purcell the Nassau County Executive, announced that he planned to seek renomination by the Republican Party for a second four-year term.

title: PREPARING MINORITY YOUTHS FOR JOB
description: To the Editor:

title: Cassidy's Cause
description: His new hourlong television show, ''Breaking Away,'' appears to be ending on the ABC-TV network, and Shaun Cassidy was in New York yesterday to try to save it.

title: Head of Westway Project Named
description: The state's coordinator of activities at the Love Canal hazardous waste site has been appointed the state's director for the Westway project in New York City, William C. Hennessy, the State Transportation Commissioner, announced today. The new director, Michael J. Cuddy, a 40-year-old construction engineer, has worked in the Department of Transportation for 16 years.

title: Bus and Streetcar Drivers Vote To Accept Pact in New Orleans
description: Bus and streetcar drivers voted nearly 2 to 1 today to accept a contract that gives most drivers a pay increase of 10.62 percent.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $11.4 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday announced a record $11.4 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply for the week ended Jan. 7, but warned that the rise could have been caused by shifts of deposits within the banking system rather than a by real increase in the amount of money in circulation. A narrower measure of the money supply showed a much smaller rise.

title: Jersey Utility Seeks Increase
description: The Jersey Central Power and Light Company filed today for an 11.4 percent rate increase in its energyadjustment clause, which would raise the average customer's bill by $4.20 a month if approved.

title: 5 Tremors Jolt Southern Italy
description: Five earth tremors jolted Potenza Province in southern Italy today, causing panic but no injuries or damage, earthquake officials said. Thousands of frightened people ran into the streets after the strongest tremor, which occurred at 1:30 A.M.

title: FACTORIES' UTILIZATION IS UP AGAIN
description: United States manufacturers operated at 79.8 percent of capacity last month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. That represented a gain of half a percentage point from November and was the fifth consecutive month the percentage has risen since the recession of last year.

title: A Former Diplomat Is Tired of 'Sophisticated Begging'
description: Back in 1976, when he retired from the State Department after 25 years' service to become president of American University in Washington, Joseph J. Sisco said he was ''very high on education as a second career.'' All, however, apparently did not go well.

title: SETTING OFF IRAN'S ASSETS AGAINST ITS DEBTS
description: What is usually discussed by only accountants and bankers, a form of bookkeeping called offsets or setoffs, has emerged at the center of the negotiations for the release of the 52 Americans held hostage in Iran.

title: PULLING TOGETHER THE CASH FOR COLLEGE TUITION
description: First, the bad news: College costs are rising rapidly, many parents feel they can't cope with the financial demands, and some students never even apply to college and vocational schools because they think they won't be able to afford them.

title: DONOVAN ACCUSER NAMED AS HOFFA INQUIRY WITNESS
description: The man whose allegations have delayed Senate committee action on the confirmation of Raymond J. Donovan as Secretary of Labor is Ralph M. Picardo, a Government informer and convicted murderer, according to law-enforcement sources in New Jersey and Washington.

title: THOMAS J. KNAPP
description: Thomas J. Knapp, a former vice president and manager of transportation for the Freeport Minerals Company, died Thursday in Hialeah Hospital in Hialeah, Fla. Mr. Knapp, who was 83 years old, had homes in Miami Springs, Fla., and Monmouth Beach, N.J.

title: * To the Editor:$
