description: It seems to me that Mr. Galbraith and his Keynesians have, through long abuse, so damaged the American and British economies as to put them beyond repair - by Mr. Friedman, Mrs. Thatcher or anybody else. L.B. SPENCER New York, Jan. 9, 1981

title: Swan Reports Lack of Pain After Testing Right Arm
description: Craig Swan of the Mets tested his pitching arm yesterday for the first time since last Aug. 21 and reported no pressure or pain from his injured right shoulder.

title: Charles Kleinberg, Lawyer, Weds Judith A. Eschweiler
description: Judith Adams Eschweiler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Cowles Eschweiler of Milwaukee, was married at the Municipal Building yesterday to Charles Steven Kleinberg, son of Sam Kleinberg of Plantation, Fla., and the late Doris Cohen Kleinberg.

title: PACT AVERTS STRIKE BY BUILDING WORKERS
description: Negotiators for the owners of major office buildings in the city and for the union representing their service employees reached a tentative agreement on a contract last night, Hubert Robinson, a Federal mediator announced.

title: Garwood's Defense Rests Without Calling Him
description: The defense rested its case today in the court-martial of Pfc. Robert R. Garwood, the only American serviceman to be charged with collaboration with the enemy in Vietnam.

title: DONOR BENEFITS NEEDIEST CASES A SECOND TIME
description: Longtime contributors are among the major supporters of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, but few have given twice during the same annual drive, as Robert S. Herzog of Larchmont, N.Y., has done this year.

title: BANKERS CITE OBLIGATIONS TO PROTECT STOCKHOLDERS ,
description: United States bank executives, caught in conflicting pressures in the hostage situation, discussed their legal responsibilities to shareholders at their extraordinary meeting yesterday with State Department officials on the question of releasing deposits to Iran, according to sources close to the participants.

title: EXPERTS AND ENVOYS MEETING IN ALGIERS
description: A team of American and British legal and financial experts met late into the evening here with Algerian and American officials in an effort to resolve the remaining problems blocking the release of the American hostages in Iran.

title: TAKING THE PUNCH OUT OF FLAVOR TO CATER TO MASS TASTE
description: One of the more dependable if paradoxical truisms is that as a particular food or style of preparation becomes fashionable, it declines in quality. Anxious to order what is currently in vogue, yet not really liking its characteristic flavor, would-be gastronomes demand bland modifications.

title: TEXT OF LETTER FROM MAYOR KOCH ACCOMPANYING PROPOSED BUDGET FOR FISCAL
PARTING NOW SWEET SORROW IN CARTER CAMP
description: uf881 By BERNARD WEINRAUB

title: WORKERS LAMENT DODGE PLANT DESTRUCTION
description: The cars that stop along Joseph Campau Street ignore the 'no standing' signs and sit there, their motors sighing idly, their drivers watching silently as wrecking balls chew away on a piece of the past.

title: Auto-Train Loan Denied
description: The Federal Railroad Administration announced today that it had turned down a request by the Auto-Train Corporation for a $5.7 million loan. John M. Sullivan, the railroad agency's administrator, cited these reasons for rejecting the request in a letter to Auto-Train's trustee, Murray Drabkin: It did not believe Auto-Train could become self-sustaining or was an essential service, and if the company was liquidated it would not be able to cover its debts. The company, which entered into bankruptcy proceedings in September, has auto-carrying trains that run between Lorton, Va., and Sanford, Fla.

title: Hobart to Seek Other Merger Bids
description: The Hobart Corporation, which is being pursued by Canadian Pacific Enterprises Ltd., said that, ''as a protection of our shareholders' interest,'' it would seek other merger partners.

title: Sanyo to Market Videodisk Players
description: The Sanyo Electric Company said that it will start marketing videodisk players in the United States in June or July under its own brand name.

title: U.S. Aide Hints MGM Fire Smoldered Several Hours
description: The fire at the Las Vegas MGM Grand hotel that killed 84 persons in November may have smoldered for several hours before it was detected, a Federal fire official said today.

title: City Finances: Neither Red Nor Rosy
description: Mayor Koch forecast a $733 million deficit last September for the budget year starting next July; presto, that deficit has disappeared in his new four-year financial plan. Not only that, he now talks of providing badly needed increases in city services and still balancing the budget. What magic did the last four months work on the deficit?

title: Key Rates
description: Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: The authorities said it was relatively calm today after six days of fierce fighting to blunt a left-wing guerrilla offensive.

title: Islamic Conference Is Preparing Summit Meeting in Saudi Arabia
description: Islamic foreign ministers will meet in Saudi Arabia tomorrow to prepare for a summit conference that must tackle the bitterly divisive issue of the war between Iraq and Iran.

title: ROBERT D. VAN ROIJEN
description: Robert D. van Roijen, a former officer of the Central Intelligence Agency and the owner of Robert B. Luce, Inc., a Washington-based publishing house, died Tuesday at his Virginia home.

title: Los Angeles Bolstering Patrols
description: The city Police Commission, responding to complaints of inadequate police protection in a wave of violent crime, voted yesterday to put 102 desk officers on city streets and the equivalent of 381 more officers on patrol by giving officers cash for all overtime worked instead of a combination of cash and compensatory time off. The Police Department said it was also exploring the possibility of horseback patrols in such high crime areas as beaches and parks where there are wide-open spaces.

title: Coast Suspect Changes Plea
description: One of four defendants in the so-called freeway killings case has amended his plea from not guilty to one of not guilty by reason of insanity. Gregory Matthew Miley, 19 years old, added the insanity plea at a pretrial hearing yesterday. He faces trial Feb. 23 on five felony counts stemming from the stranglings of Charles Miranda, 14, and James McCabe, 12.

title: MILTON AND ROSE
description: There I was sitting in my bank, the Termagant Savings & Loan, at 073-34-8358 Queens Boulevard. I was struggling pathetically to convince a certain Vera Ingot, vice president for delinquent accounts, to take a laissez-faire line on my Babel-like pile of overdraft notices, when all of a sudden this heavily armed man and woman storm in and announce a stickup.

title: Concert Feb. 3 Will Mark Music Copyrights in 1831
description: The 150th anniversary of the extension of copyright protection in the United States for musical compositions will be marked on Feb. 3 with a reception and a concert of American popular music from 1830 to 1910 at the Library of Congress.

title: DALLAS VOTES TODAY ON PLAN TO CUT PROPERTY TAXES
description: Helen E. Thornburg, a 74-year-old retired nurse, sounds ready to do battle when she discusses the tax referendum scheduled here tomorrow.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16. 1. It is a long-eared, foot-tall owl that has been sighted for several weeks in Central Park. 2. Alexander M. Haig Jr. made the remark while testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on his confirmation as Secretary of State. The committee approved his nomination by a vote of 15 to 2.

title: STAGE: 'BRIXTON RECOVERY'
description: The Irish-American prizefighter played by Barry Cullison in Jack Gilhooley's ''The Brixton Recovery'' at the Westside Mainstage is neither a champion nor a deadbeat. He is a journeyman professional, who has lost more bouts than he was won, has taken a few dives and will never be a contender.

title: WALDHEIM'S STAND ON TERRORISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Italian Premier Wins Test On Detention of Judge
description: Prime Minister Arnaldo Forlani won a vote of confidence in Parliament today as the Republicans, one of the four parties in his coalition Government, decided not to press their criticism of his actions in the case of Giovanni D'Urso. The vote was 353 to 243.

title: City Water Emergency Is Decreed in Stamford
description: A water emergency was declared here today by Mayor Louis A. Clapes, who said the city was down to an 89-day supply.

title: Index; International
description: Banks stress responsibility to shareholders on Iran funds 2 For the families of the hostages, crossed fingers and rising hope 2 U.N. envoy arrives in Iran from Iraq on truce mission 2 Bookkeeping of Iran's assets and debts at center of negotiations 3 Beer and swimsuits are the thing in Rio in summer 4 Around the World 6 Marcos says he will end martial law today 16 William French Smith 9 An objection is raised to a subpoena for data on Nixon tapes 9 Tide of reform beginning to ebb in Congress 11 Dallas voting today on tax-slash referendum 24 F.A.A. suspends air controller in Aeroflot case 26 Connecticut's Governor is setback in his first legislative test 27 General Around the Nation 8 The Talk of Yonkers: A trying time for a conservative city 25 Pathologist contradicts prosecution witnesses in Harris trial 26 Brisk trade in airline half-off coupons 26 The Region 26 The City 27 Lawyers for suspect in Lennon murder seek missing log book 27 Music therapist found strangled in home in New Rochelle 27 Health/Science F.D.A. criticizes drugs for gastrointestinal disorders 7 Johns Hopkins named site of new NASA institute 7 Industry/Labor Workers depressed as George Vecsey on the basketball player and the doctor 18

title: MARCOPS PUTS AN END TO MARTIAL LAW, BUT PLANS TO RETAIN WIDE POWERS
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos declared an end to eight years of martial law today, but said he would retain wide powers as the Philippines moved toward full democracy in 1984.

title: China Curbs Funds Abroad
description: China has tightened its foreign exchange controls by ordering that all foreign currencies deposited overseas be transferred back to the country.

title: REPLY SENT TO IRAN, GOLD AND FUNDS READIED
description: The United States sent to Iran early this morning the final language of an accord that, if accepted by Teheran, could end more than 14 months of captivity for 52 Americans.

title: YET ANOTHER BRAVE NEW WORLD?
description: To the Editor:

title: 31 PRIZES ARE GIVEN FORDISTINGUISHED ARCHITECTURE
description: It is always hard to give precise definition to a moment in architectural history. A look at the latest finished buildings tells only part of the story - the process of architecture is so slow that this year's openings tend to represent not this year's ideas, but those of three, four, five or more years ago. The most current thinking of architects remains on paper, in models, and in ideas not yet given even that much form.

title: BERNADETTE DEVLIN IS SHOT BY RAIDERS
description: Bernadette Devlin McAliskey, the fiery opponent of what she calls the British occupation of Northern Ireland and a former member of the British Parliament, was shot and seriously wounded this morning by armed men who burst into her home near a village 30 miles west of Belfast.

title: KNICKS DEFEATED BY DALLAS
description: With Abdul Jeelani scoring 21 fourthquarter points, Dallas rallied for a 118-110 victory over the New York Knicks tonight that gave the Mavericks their first two-game winning streak.

title: JOSEPH L. FRISTACHI
description: Joseph L. Fristachi, who had been an executive assistant to Jacob K. Javits, former United States Senator, and to Louis J. Lefkowitz, former New York State Attorney General, died yesterday at his home in Bayside, Queens.

title: GALBRAITHIAN ERRORS
description: To the Editor:

title: Cubs Deny Plans to Trade Kingman, Now Recovered
description: Bob Kennedy, the general manager of the Chicago Cubs, said today that he had no plans to trade Dave Kingman, adding that Kingman had recovered ''satisfactorily'' from a shoulder injury suffered last season.

title: TEHERAN DECLARES IT PRESENTS NO OBSTACLE TO HOSTAGE PACTuf814> TEHERAN,
description: Iran, Jan. 16 (Reuters) -Iran declared today that from its point of view ''no obstacle'' remained to concluding an agreement permitting the release of the American hostages.

title:
PATENTS;
Furnace to Produce Uranium Fuel Pellets
description: An industrial furnace described as more energy efficient was patented this week by the General Electric Company by Wilmore S. Scott Jr., an engineer in the company's plant at Wilmington, N.C.

title: PROBABILITY OF A STRUGGLE CITED BY HARRIS WITNESS
description: A pathologist testifying for Jean S. Harris, who is charged with the murder of Dr. Herman Tarnower, contradicted prosecution witnesses today in Westchester County Court by saying there was a ''probability of struggle'' the night of the shooting.

title: A DAY OF BANKING FRENZY IN PLANNING FUND TRANSFERS
description: The Carter Administration set off a day of frenzy in international banking circles today. Officials and bankers in Washington and Algiers worked through the day on details for the transfer of billions of dollars in frozen Iranian assets if Teheran agrees to last-minute American proposals for the release of the hostages.

title: Alice B. Toklas Goodies
description: The price, $20 a dozen, seemed steep, even for homemade brownies, but they were selling like hot cakes, and no wonder. According to flyers circulated by the San Francisco baker, Mary Rathbun, her wares were ''original recipe brownies'' and ''magically delicious.''

title: WAITER IS SUSPECT IN ARSON AT STOUFFER'S
description: A waiter at Stouffer's Inn at Harrison, N.Y., who had reportedly been told that he was going to be dismissed is suspected by Westchester County authorities of setting the fire that killed 26 persons at the hotel's conference center on Dec. 4, according to sources close to the investigation.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JANUARY 17, 1981
description: International Terms of a final agreement with Iran were drafted by the United States, and officials said if it was accepted the release of American hostages could come as early as Sunday. (Page 1, Col. 6.) Iran said it presented ''no obstacle'' to concluding an agreement permitting the release of the hostages. Executive Affairs Minister Behzad Nabavi no longer demanded, as he did Thursday, that the United States start transferring frozen Iranian assets to Algeria by the ''end of working hours'' yesterday.''Only the real willingness of Washington can bring decisive results today,'' he said. (3:1-2.)

title: Barbara Joan Stark, Lawyer, Is Married to Karl Thorndike
description: Barbara Joan Stark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Stark of Maplewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Karl E. Thorndike, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan M. Thorndike of Bellport, L.I. Mayor Thomas Tansey of Edgewater, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Edgewater Town Hall.

title: i
description: PHOTOGRAPHER'S WOUNDS REPORTED SERIOUS: Olivier Rebbot, a photographer for Newsweek magazine, lying on a street in San Francisco Gotera, El Salvador, after being shot by a sniper on Thursday. Harry Mattison of Time magazine kneels over him, shielding him with his body, while a Government soldier moves in to provide cover. Mr. Rebbot, who is 33 years old, was taken to a hospital with internal injuries and three broken ribs.

title: TV: 'HILL STREET BLUES,' NEW NBC POLICE SERIES
description: ''Ten-thirteen'' is the police-radio code for ''assist patrolman.'' Too bad there isn't a signal for ''assist writers,'' because ''Hill Street Blues'' needs help badly. The first of five related installments of this limited-run police series was seen on Thursday on NBCTV. The second will be shown by the network tonight.

title: Grasso Scholarship
description: The college preparatory school attended by Ella T. Grasso has established a $25,000 scholarship in the name of the former Governor of Connecticut, who resigned recently because of poor health.

title: SPIRITED LIVES
description: David Lilienthal's death at 81 this week recalls memories of an America as confident and daring as Elizabethan England. One of three original members of the Tennessee Valley Authority, he was the center of the political storm raised by its broad use of Federal powers to explore and develop one of the nation's backward regions.

title: OLATUNJI PLAYING HIS FAREWELLS TO U.S.
description: When Babatunde Olatunji came to the United States 30 years ago, his ambition, he recalled the other day, ''was to be a big-time diplomat.'' He became, instead, a musician and lecturer and America's best-known resident Nigerian. Now, his original goal still unmet, but his talent established, he is going home.

title: Secretary of Interior Clears Pineland Plan
description: The United States Secretary of the Interior yesterday approved a New Jersey Pinelands Commission plan for protecting 1.1 million acres in the Pine Barrens from overdevelopment.

title: Lawrence Wiseman, 92, a Lawyer And Former Brooklyn Prosecutor
description: Lawrence Wiseman, who from 1955 until he retired in 1971 was an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn in charge of special assignments, died Tuesday in a hospital in Menlo Park, Calif. He was 92 years old and lived in San Jose, Calif.

title: CHRYSLER STUDIES MERGER ACTION
description: The Chrysler Corporation is constructing detailed ''scenarios'' for mergers with each of the world's major auto companies, the company's treasurer disclosed in an interview today. At the same time, the Government postponed until Monday its final consideration of Chrysler's bid for $400 million in additional loan guarantees.

title: Norway Said To Lift Oil Cost
description: Norway has increased the cost of its North Sea crude oil by $3.50 a barrel, the trade newspaper Platt's Oilgram Price Report said yesterday.

title:
PATENTS;
ULTRASONIC CLEANING UNDERWATER
description: WASHINGTON THE underwater heat exchangers that draw heat from the ocean or transfer it in power plants can be cleaned by ultrasonic vibration with an apparatus invented by engineers at the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory in Laurel, Md. A patent on the device, number 4,244,749, was granted this week to Samuel L. Sachs and Freeman K. Hill and has been assigned to the university.

title: What the Last Carter Budget Measures
description: Finally there is a Federal budget whose detail can be comfortably ignored. Who but zealous historians will care that President Carter wanted to spend $46.6 billion on Medicare and only $18.2 billion for Medicaid in fiscal 1982? Who cares how much the Carter Administration now wants to spend on anything? Mr. Carter will be home in Plains writing his memoirs by the time Congress passes its first budget resolution this spring. It is next month's Reagan budget that will be worth studying in detail.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Associates Corporation of North America, a unit of Gulf and Western Industries Inc., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission $100 million of senior notes due Aug. 1, 1991, to be offered through a Kidder, Peabody and Salomon Brothers group.

title: S.& H. Identifies Merger Candidate
description: The Sperry & Hutchinson Company confirmed that it was engaged in talks with the Baldwin-United Corporation on possible acquisition of S.& H. by Baldwin but the company said that no offer had yet been made. S.& H. announced earlier in the week that it was holding ''serious discussions'' with a purchaser it would not identify. A spokesman also said that there were ''other interested parties, but we are not actively talking to them at the present time.''

title: TURNAROUND AT HART SCHAFFNER
description: Despite the impact of the economic downturn on retail operations and the apparel industry nationally, Hart Schaffner & Marx has managed to continue to produce gains in an otherwise sluggish market.

title: SONG: ODETTA AT MUSEUM
description: To classify Odetta as ''a folk singer'' is to miss the breadth of her repertory, the range of her style and the mother-earth quality of her presence.

title: DEFENSE SEEKS LOG BOOK IN LENNON SLAYING CASE
description: Defense attorneys are attempting to subpoena a missing log book that Mark David Chapman, the man accused of killing John Lennon, had signed with the name of the former Beatles star.

title: HOW TO CHOOSE LIFE INSURANCE
description: How much life insurance do young married couples need? There is no simple answer because of such variables as life style, financial status, expectations of inheritances and obligations.

title: FAIR AND PRUDENT FLXIBLE BUS DEAL
description: To the Editor:

title: STORM KING SETTLEMENT WAS RIGHT FOR CON ED
description: To the Editor:

title: Dan River Reports Purchase of Stock
description: Dan River Inc., a large textile manufacturer, announced that David H. Murdock and three affiliated companies had purchased 353,500, or 6.2 percent, of Dan River's common shares.

title: CHICAGO PATRONAGE BACKERS SEEK TO BLUNT CRITICISM
description: The Chicago city council, facing rumblings of public displeasure after voting to gradually return most city jobs to the patronage system, appeared today to be seeking ways to blunt the harsh reaction.

title: Eastern Studies Braniff Merger
description: Eastern Airlines' board of directors will decide on Jan. 27 whether to pursue aggressively a merger with the Braniff International Corporation or stop merger talks with the financially ailing carrier, Frank Borman, Eastern chairman, president and chief executive officer, said.

title: Jazz on 19th St.
description: Jazz fans can hear the U.J.C. Jazz Quartet, presented by the Universal Jazz Coalition, or attend a jazz clinic-workshop this weekend at the Jazz Gallery, 55 West 19th Street.

title:
PATENTS;
Two Top Officials Resign From the Patent Office
description: Sidney A. Diamond has resigned as Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, effective today.

title: Iran Notes Anniversary Of Day the Shah Left
description: Iranian television carried special programs tonight celebrating the second anniversary of the departure of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

title: Air Portugal Orders a 727
description: Air Portugal has placed an order for one model 727 trijet, according to the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company.

title: SOME OBSERVANT WEST SIDERS ARE WAITING IN THE WINGS
description: uf813 By WILLIAM E. FARRELL

title: I.B.M. NET UP 21.8% IN FOURTH QUARTER
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, the world's largest manufacturer of computers, reported yesterday that substantial gains by its business outside the United States helped lift fourth-quarter earnings by 21.8 percent and revenues by 14.3 percent.

title: Ambassador East Sold
description: The Ambassador East Hotel, a Near North Side Chicago landmark built in 1926, has been sold to a subsidiary of the London-based Guinness Peat Group.

title: Factories, Offices Checked In Boston Gas-Saving Move
description: Seventy inspectors toured factories and businesses in the Boston area today to make sure thermostats were turned down to 55 to conserve a dangerously low supply of natural gas in eastern Massachusetts.

title: F.A.A. SUSPENDS AN AIR CONTROLLER IN AEROFLOT CASE
description: The Federal Aviation Administration decided yesterday to suspend for 60 days an air traffic controller accused of tampering with radar data and contributing to the ''potential endangerment'' of a Soviet airliner descending to Kennedy International Airport a year ago.

title: RECITAL: EPSTEIN'S PIANO
description: The first three pieces on Daniel Epstein's piano recital Wednesday night at the 92d Street Y all demanded a quick, direct, un-Romantic style. Mr. Epstein can muster up that sort of fashionably contemporary playing workably enough, although he lacks the ultimate in precise virtuosity and linear intensity, and his tone seemed monochromatically hard and insistent.

title: PRESIDENT QUITS GAF ABRUPTLY
description: In a move that surprised Wall Street analysts, Richard Fleming, who joined the GAF Corporation just five months ago as its president, resigned yesterday.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 26.

title: Sports of The Times; Athlete and Doctor
description: BOB McADOO has heard the criticism. As he fluctuates in and out of the lineup of the Detroit Pistons, he knows some people feel he is not willing to play in pain.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My fingers are braided to the elbows.'' - Louisa Kennedy, wife of Moorhead Kennedy, a hostage in Iran. (2:1.)

title: Hofstra, Facing the Irish, Will Meet Its Mismatch
description: ''What's a Hofstra?'' was the supercilious putdown used by Notre Dame basketball fans four years ago in Philadelphia as the Irish defeated Hofstra University of Hempstead, L.I., in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: CONNECTICUT LEGISLATORS BALK AT PLAN BY GOV. O'NEILL TO AVOID DEFICIT
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill suffered a setback in his first legislative test today when the General Assembly's Appropriations Committee balked at his proposal to erase a state budget deficit by eliminating $23.8 million in state grants to cities and towns.

title: SOURCES OF FINANCIAL AID
description: A number of financial options are open to students who seek help from the Facts program, according to its founder, Milton Heimlich: Basic Educational Opportunity Grant: A federally financed program that grants students up to $1,900 a year for tuition, board, room, books, transportation and other expenses. The money can be used for attendance at colleges and technical schools throughout the country, and at some foreign schools. Part-time students are eligible for partial grants.

title: Isuzu of Japan Sets U.S. Car Sales Plans
description: American Isuzu Motors expects to sell 20,000 diesel-engine passenger cars and 10,000 trucks in its first year of operation in the United States, J.E. Reilly, general manager of the Japanese-owned company, said.

title: Bridge:; A Deal in Tri-State Regional Displays Defense at Its Best
description: The first two days of the Tri-State Regional Championships, which began Wednesday at the Rye Town Hilton, Port Chester, N.Y., were devoted to men's and women's events. Winners of titles were: Men's Pairs - Jerome Weissman and Dr. Sam Marsh of New York. Women's Pairs - Wanda Gabrilovich of Stamford, Conn., and Martha Fingerle of Old Greenwich, Conn. Men's Teams - Warren Rosner of Nanuet, N.Y.; Allan Stauber of Poughkeepsie, N.Y.; Marty Bergen of White Plains, and Ethan Stein of New York. Women's Teams - Kathie Wei and Judi Radin, both of New York; Joan De Witt of Chicago, and Esta Van Zandt of Houston.

title: PRESIDENT OPPOSES REPORT URGING SHIFT TO SUN BELT
description: President Carter took issue today with a Presidential commission's recommendation that the Federal Government encourage migration of people from Northern industrial cities to the South and the West.

title: HOW ADS CNA BEND STATISTICS
description: ''D OCTORS recommend....'' ''Four out of five people preferred....'' ''Twice as many repairmen choose....'' The slogans and claims are survey advertisements, a technique of selling products that has grown in use over the last five years and one in which the Federal Trade Commission is increasingly interested.

title: Teheran Reportedly Places Order For U.S. Planes and Spare Parts
description: The Iranian Government has placed an order with the United States for military supplies, including sophisticated warplanes, a Kuwaiti newspaper reported today.

title: TAX CHIEF AND TREASURY AIDES CHOSEN
description: Roscoe L. Egger Jr., the partner in charge of the Washington office of Price Waterhouse & Company, a nationwide accounting firm, has been chosen to be commissioner of internal revenue in the Reagan administration, Congressional sources reported today.

title: KOCH CALLS FOR EXPANDING SERVICES IN $14.8 BILLION FISCAL '82 BUDGET
description: Mayor Koch yesterday announced his budget plans for the next fiscal year, and, as expected, they called for an expansion of critical municipal services and virtually no additions to the financial discomfort that for years has been a way of life in New York City.

title: 3 CITIES IN WESTCHESTER SETTLE BIAS SUITS AGAINST FIRE DEPARTMENTS
description: A Federal judge approved plans yesterday to increase ''equal employment opportunities for blacks, Hispanics and women in the Fire Departments of New Rochelle, Mount Vernon and White Plains.''

title: No Headline
description: F.D.A. SEEKING PROHIBITION ON SALE OF 18 DRUGS FOR STOMACH DISORDERS

title: TO CATCH A THIEF, RUN FAST
description: The Kennedys always were fast on their feet when it came to running for office. But yesterday afternoon, one of the younger generation helped the police run down a pickpocket inside Bloomingdale's.

title: TransAmerica
description: The TransAmerica Corporation announced that earnings in the fourth quarter rose 5.6 percent, to $58.4 million, or 89 cents a share, from $55.3 million, or 84 cents a share, in the comparable 1979 period.

title: AGREEMENT ON MASSEY REFINANCING
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the big debt-burdened farm machinery manufacturer with headquarters here, announced tonight that it had reached agreement in principle with its bankers on a large part of its vital refinancing plans.

title: THE SUBWAY BEAT
description: With all of the experts seeking solutions for what appears to be an uncontrollable problem - subway crime -it seems to me, as a transit cop who pounds the subway beat, that they all seem to point their fingers in the wrong direction. Strangely, they all point them in the same direction -they place the blame on a variety of superficial problems while never addressing or correcting the real ones.

title: GAME FIXING-HAS LEFT ITS TAINT
description: The Federal investigation of alleged point shaving by Boston College players marks the latest occurrence in a series of incidents that have tainted college basketball with scandal over the last 35 years.

title: THE DEFENDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: FEAR OF LOBBIES STIRS MOVES TO MAKE CONGRESSIONAL HEARINGS LESS VISIBLE
description: Several key members of Congress say they are devising ways to reverse some of the changes that have made Congressional meetings more open and voting patterns more visible to the public as part of a tide of reform over the last decade.

title: NASA PICKS JOHNS HOPKINS SITE FOR ITS SPACE TELESCOPE INSTITUTE
description: Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore has been selected as the site for the new Space Telescope Science Institute, which is expected to be a leading international center of astronomical research for the rest of the century.

title: Selection of New Mayor Is Postponed in West Berlin
description: West Berlin's Social Democrats today postponed the naming of a successor to Mayor Dietrich Stobbe, who resigned yesterday with his entire coalition government of Social Democrats and Free Democrats.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PRESIDENT'S LAST MESSAGE TO CONGRESS ON THE STATE OF THE UNION
description: Following are excerpts from President Carter's written State of the Union Message to Congress, issued by the White House today:

title: SPIRITED LIVES; Two White Gentlemen
description: To get the great civil rights legislation of the 50's and 60's took marches, tragedy and the determined support of two old white gentlemen in the United States House of Representatives.

title: ONE OF THE FOUNDERS OF THE ISRAELI AIR FORCE
description: Yehuda L. Rabin, an aircraft company executive and one of the founders of the Israeli Air Force, died of a heart attack while seeing a friend off at Kennedy International Airport Jan. 4, it was learned yesterday. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SENATA PANEL SUPPORTS CONFIRMATION OF SMITH FOR ATTORNEY GENERAL
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee voted unanimously today to recommend the confirmation of William French Smith, a longtime adviser to President-elect Ronald Reagan, to be Attorney General.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A police raid on an apartment at 2406 Newkirk Avenue in Brooklyn yielded an unloaded 66-millimeter disposable light antitank rocket launcher, a loaded .38-caliber handgun, 100 bags of cocaine with an estimated value of $15,000 and $4,500 in cash. Arrested were Jerome Singleton, 34 years old, of 1647 Brooklyn Avenue; Steven Jenkins, 19, of 2415 Newkirk Avenue; Ernesto Eduardo Allen, 22, of 2410 Newkirk Avenue, and William Knight, 20, of 1674 Brooklyn Avenue. ... Charles Lee, 21, of 392 East Fourth Street, Brooklyn, was charged with assault and reckless endangerment after allegedly attacking a passenger on an IRT subway platform with a hatchet. ... Anthony Seliz, 34, of 350 East 62d Street, Brooklyn, was arrested following a chase down 56th Street after he allegedly robbed a Marine Midland Bank at 919 Third Avenue. The suspect was carrying a ''security pack'' of decoy money from the bank that exploded, releasing tear gas and red dye.

title: Bethlehem Steel To Raise Prices
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it would raise prices an average 7.25 percent on most steel plates, structural shapes and pilings.

title: Backup Role Is Step Forward for Pisarcik
description: A year ago, with the Giants, he was cannon fodder, an inviting target for defensive linemen who swarmed over his inadequate offensive line and sacked him play after play.

title: PARKING REGULATIONS
description: Because of snow, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. All other parking regulations remain in effect.

title: Milwaukee Road
description: The Milwaukee Road, stripped of thousands of miles of unprofitable track and undergoing reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws, can be a viable regional carrier, the courtappointed trustee, Richard B. Ogilvie, says. Proceeds from freight revenues and sale of assets of the railroad have exceeded projections of eight months ago, according to a report submitted in United States District Court by lawyers for Mr. Ogilvie.

title: Ship Orders Rise in Japan
description: Export orders for Japanese ships reached a four-year high in 1980, the Japanese Ship Exporters Association announced today.

title: CHINA AND REAGAN
description: ''If a friend shakes hands with you warmly, but deliberately steps on your toes over and over, can you long stand it?'' A young Chinese asked me this while talking about the Sino-American relationship. He used the expression ''stepping on toes'' to explain his feelings about some United States Government practices in dealing with Taiwan.

title: NETS LOSE ON BASKET BY WILKES
description: The New Jersey Nets stayed with the Los Angeles Lakers for 47 minutes 58 seconds tonight. Then Jamaal Wilkes took a pass from Norm Nixon to the left of the key and pumped in a basket at the buzzer. It gave the Lakers a 113-111 victory and the Nets their 14th straight defeat, the 13th since Bob MacKinnon replaced Kevin Loughery as coach.

title: Algeria-U.S.  Gas Talks End
description: Negotiations to end a nine-month deadlock between Algeria and the United States over liquefied natural gas ended this evening without producing an agreement under which American imports of Algerian L.N.G. could be resumed.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ILLUSTRATIONS FOR TODAY

title: WHERE TO OBTAIN INFORMATION
description: Information on financing a college education is available from a number of sources. Milton Heimlich, founder of the Facts program, recommended that help be sought first from the Facts office, if there is one, in the student's high school, or from the school's college counselor or guidance counselor.

title: No Headline
description: STATE JUDGE SAYS U.S. JUDGE FAILED TO HONOR PLEDGE IN SCHOOL DISPUTE

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anta Corporation's Bonray Drilling Corporation subsidiary purchased three drilling rigs from the Tiger Drilling Company for $13 million in cash.

title:
PATENTS;
Plastic Teeth Implanted Quickly in Gums or Jaw
description: Dr. Arthur Ashman, a New York rehabilitative dentist, was awarded a patent this week for plastic dental implants supported by the jawbone and gums.

title: Hagler Foe: Quality Unknown
description: The problem with selling Marvin Hagler's first title defense in this city where he is a hero, the promoter was saying, is that it takes two to tango, and no one knows much about the champion's dancing partner tomorrow night.

title: Lietzke, at 20 Under, Leads by 5
description: Bruce Lietzke, 20 shots under par after three rounds, ran away and hid from the field today in the Bob Hope Desert Classic.

title: PALME, U.N. ENVOY, GOES TO IRAN FROM IRAQ ON CEASE FIRE MISSION
description: Olof Palme, a special United Nations envoy, arrived in Iran from Iraq today to try to convince Iranians to agree to a cease-fire in the war.

title: MUSIC THERAPIST FOUND BEATEN AND SLAIN IN BURNING NEW ROCHELLE HOME
description: A music therapist was beaten and strangled in her New Rochelle home Wednesday night and five separate fires were set in the house, police and medical officials said today.

title: FOREIGN LANGUAGES SHOULD BE PART OF AMERICA'S ARSENAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Killed in Crash of a Plane In Lake Near New Orleans Field
description: The founder and two other executives from one of the world's largest ammunition manufacturers were killed yesterday in the crash of a twin-engine plane in adverse weather.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Tippy Mar- t inez, left-handed relief pitcher, to five- y ear c ontract. MINNESOTA (AL) - Signed Cedric G ray, outfielder, who was No. 2 pick in a mateur d raft. TORONTO (AL) - Signed to one-year c ontracts Ernie Whitt and Brian Milner, c atchers, and Paul Hodgson and Jorge Bell, o utfielders.

title: 40 Americans Invade U.S. Embassy in Managua
description: About 40 American residents of Nicaragua, including nine members of the New York-based Maryknoll religious order, occupied part of the United States Embassy here today to protest the resumption of American military aid to neighboring El Salvador.

title: 3 Coal Mines on Strike in West
description: At least three Peabody Coal Company mines in Colorado and Montana were shut down by strikes after contracts with the United Mine Workers of America expired, company officials said today.

title: 7 EXILES SEIZED IN FLORIDA LINKED TO RAIDS ON CUBA
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it had arrested seven anti-Castro Cuban exiles in the Florida Keys and seized a small arsenal of weapons that were apparently to be used in training for an expedition to Cuba.

title: Arizona State Beats Bruins In Triple Overtime, 78-74
description: Paul Williams, a sophomore guard, hit two baskets in the third overtime period to lift Arizona State to a 78-74 victory over U.C.L.A. in a Pacific-10 Conference game tonight.

title: City Acknowledges Ferry-Crash Liability
description: The city admitted it was liable for all personal injury claims stemming from a Nov. 7, 1978, crash of a Staten Island ferryboat with 2,000 people aboard.

title: The Talk of Yonkers
description: ''They got enough problems,'' said Gregory Williams from behind the counter of a shoe shop in Yonkers' dowdy downtown section, referring to city officials. ''They don't need the lawsuits.''

title: Yemeni Official Is Reported Shot
description: Assailants have shot and killed a Cabinet minister in Yemen, the Gulf News Agency said today.

title: Riding With the Subway Angels
description: When youthful ''Guardian Angels'' stride commandingly through a subway car late at night in white shirts and red berets, some New Yorkers feel understandably uneasy, but most seem grateful even for this much apparent protection. It's a scandal that a great city should have to rely on such adolescent protectors of ambiguous reputation. And it's easy to imagine how even the most benign corps of organized youth could itself cause trouble.

title: MARKET MOVES UP, BUT MODERATELY
description: Stock prices, locked in a narrow trading range for the last six sessions, posted a modest advance yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average, benefiting from gains in two prominent components, rose 3.32 points, to 973.29. International Business Machines rose 1 1/8, to 66 7/8, while the American Telephone and Telegraph Company climbed 1 1/4, to 50 1/8. I.B.M., the volume leader, reported that profits for its 1980 fourth quarter rose to $2.11 a share from $1.73 a share one year earlier.

title: Toxic-Waste Plant
description: ALBANY (UPI) - An independent report on a proposed hazardous waste disposal plant in the state estimated that such a plant would not be operational until the end of 1987.

title: WARSAW BUS DRIVERS STRIKE FOR 4 HOURS
description: Bus and streetcar workers held a four-hour strike here today to support union demands for a five-day workweek. The strike, which was called by the capital's chapter of the trade union organization Solidarity, began at 8 A.M. and ended at noon, forcing many people to double up in taxis or miss work altogether.

title: MEDAL OF FREEDOM AWARDED TO 15
description: President Carter today awarded the Medal of Freedom to 15 Americans, including Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher, who was in Algeria negotiating for the release of the hostages in Iran. President Carter had a telephone line kept open to Algiers so that Mr. Christopher could hear the presentation to his wife, Marie.

title: Let's All Pull Together
description: To ease the difficulties of city living this column today begins a new service under the direction of Andrew Cavour, urbanologist and confidant. Will you explain, Mr. Cavour, how the new service will work?

title: CORPORATE SALES AND EARNINGS REPORTS
description: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES (A) Qtr to Nov. 30 1980 1979 Sales 27,700,000 19,300,000 Net income 103,000 273,000 Share earnings .09 .24 6-mo sales 48,500,000 40,500,000 Net income 721,000 614,000 Share earnings .63 .56 MARVIN JOSEPHSON ASSOCIATES (O) Qtr to Dec. 31 1980 1979 Revenue 10,108,400 10,328,500 Net income 1,169,100 1,489,700 Share earnings .50 .57 6-mo revs 19,247,100 19,394,200 Net income 1,940,400 2,450,800 Share earnings .79 .95 NATIONAL DATA COMMUNICATIONS (O) Qtr to Oct. 31 1980 1979 Revenue 2,071,259 2,429,258 Net income 135,826 b825,287 Share earnings .06 .35 Year revs 7,505,186 5,509,501 Net income 856,,483 b1,089,189 Share earnings .35 .46 b-Including $227,555 extraordinary credit for the quarter and $331,555 extraordinary credit for the year. Share earnings reflect a 25 percent stock dividend to be paid Feb. 27, 1981. NORTHWEST NATURAL GAS (O) Qtr to Dec. 31 1980 1979 Revenue 84,459,000 94,610,000 Net income 3,984,000 3,844,000 Share earnings .39 .44 Shares outst. 7,905,939 7,537,581 Year revs 335,610,000 298,110,000 Net income 13,714,000 15,453,000 Share earnings 1.40 1.88 Shares outst. 7,849,185 7,117,989 NORTHWESTERN FINANCIAL (O) Qtr to Dec. 31 1980 1979 Op earns 4,693,000 2,594,000 Per share .92 .50 Net income b5,692,000 c2,297,000 Per share 1.11 .44 Year op ea 13,616,000 11,788,000 Per share 2.64 2.28 Net income b14,132,000 c13,271,000 Per share 2.74 2.57 b-Including income from discontinued operations of $41,000 for the quarter and $198,000 for the year and $1,158,000 gain for the quarter and year on the sale of a unit. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $149,000 for the quarter and $95,000 for the year and $1,789,000 gain for the year on the sale of a unit.

title: Savings Units' Mortgages Off
description: Mortgage lending by the nation's savings and loan associations reached a five-year low in 1980, largely as a result of a reduction in the influx of savings deposits, according to an official of the United States League of Savings Associations.

title: Food Stamp Recipients Told They Must Look for Work
description: Food stamp recipients must look actively for jobs or be dropped from the program under new rules announced today by the Departments of Agriculture and Labor.

title: News Analysis
description: Never having come close to negotiating, let alone agreeing on anything, at the conference here on Namibia, South Africa and the insurgent movement known as the South-West Africa People's Organization both appeared to be stiffening their terms as their representatives prepared to continue their conflict in Africa and the United Nations.

title: M.T.A. OFFICIAL IS NAMED HEAD OF CITY TRANSIT
description: John D. Simpson, named yesterday to head the New York City Transit Authority, said subway service had deteriorated to the point that ''there are safety hazards'' because of rush-hour crowding on some platforms and trains.

title: Barnes Pleads Innocent To Marijuana Possession
description: Marvin Barnes, arrested last night for eluding police and for marijuana possession after a carand-foot chase , pleaded innocent to the charges today.

title: NO A HOT RIO DAY, ICY BEER AND MINIMAL SWIMSUITS
description: News of jewel thefts at luxury hotels gave way the other day to an account of a truck hijacking that could be taken as a sure sign of summer. Four gunmen commandeered the rig and made off with its cargo, 11,000 quart bottles of beer.

title: NIXON LAWYER OBJECTS TO ARCHIVIST'S RELEASE OF WHITE HOUSE DATA
description: The lawyer for former President Richard M. Nixon formally objected today to having the National Archivist release details of White House tape recordings to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: Swastikas Painted On Brooklyn Doors
description: Small, white swastikas were found painted on the apartment doors of 38 Jewish residents at 60 Division Avenue in Brooklyn's Williamsburg section, the police said.

title: CARTER WARNS U.S. OF MAJOR OIL PROBLEMS
description: President Carter, in a final State of the Union Message to Congress, warned today that the United States confronted ''serious problems,'' including unemployment and inflation rates that are ''unacceptably high'' and an increasingly tight world oil market.

title: Hotel for Women To Be Open to All
description: The Barbizon Hotel for Women will change its name to the Barbizon and be open to all on Valentine's Day, Feb. 14, according to David Teitelbaum, a developer with Barbilex Associates, the partnership that acquired the hotel last May.

title: AN AURA OF RESTRAINT
description: Mayor Koch's proposed budget containing a financial projection for the next four years, which provides the first opportunity in a long time for real optimism about New York City's prospects, is notable for the administration's restraint in how it expects to allocate the city's increasing revenues.

title: HOW AID PLAN DEVELOPED
description: To qualify for $1.5 billion in federally guaranteed loans, the Chrysler Corporation has negotiated two survival plans in less than a year that require major concessions from its lenders, suppliers and the union representing its workers.

title: CONNORS COMPLAINS AFTER BETAING LENDL
description: Jimmy Connors routed Ivan Lendl, 7-6, 6-1, last night and then complained about Lendl's performance in the second set of their match in the $400,000 Volvo Masters tennis tournament.

title: Maureen Howard Bride Of Mark Probst, Broker
description: Maureen Howard, author and playwright, was married yesterday morning to Mark Probst, a stockbroker with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. Associate Justice Harold Birns of the Appellate Division, First Judicial Department, State Supreme Court performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: WAGE FREEZE BACKED AT BRITISH STEEL
description: The 130,000 workers of the British Steel Corporation voted today to approve a wage freeze and the elimination of 20,000 jobs in a plan to save the company.

title: BOSTON COLLEGE GAMES UNDER INQUIRY
description: Federal law enforcement officials in New York are investigating whether Boston College basketball players took bribes of $1,000 to $2,000 apiece during the 1978-79 season to shave points, according to sources close to the inquiry.

title: Judge Frees Russian Held in '77 Spy Plot
description: NEWARK (AP) - A former Russian merchant seaman charged in 1977 with conspiring to pass classified data on the United States space shuttle program was released from Federal custody without ever standing trial.

title: British Trade: Record Surplus
description: Britain had a record trade surplus of about $5.47 billion last year, the Government announced today. Another encouraging sign for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Government was a slight drop in the annual inflation rate in December to 15.1 percent, the seventh consecutive monthly fall.

title: SATURDAY, JANUARY 17, 1981; Iranian Situation
description: Bankers in Washington and Algiers, in a frenzied day, tried to work out details for shifting billions of dollars in frozen Iranian assets, if Iran agrees to the plan by the Carter Administration for release of the hostages. The President ordered a ''swap'' of more than $900 million in gold with Britain, which would transfer it to Iran, and the sale of Iranian-owned Treasury securities. An Air Force plane flew banking and Government officials to Algiers. (Page 1.)

title: COOL HOSTAGE NEGOTIATOR
description: Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher has seldom enjoyed the limelight, preferring instead to work hard and discreetly backstage, so it probably suited him fine this afternoon to be absent from the White House when President Carter named him one of 15 recipients of the Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian honor.

title: BIDDING ACTIVE IN 50%-OFF FLIGHT COUPONS
description: ''Forty dollars a coupon! Who wants forty dollars? Forty a coupon!'' A fistful of $10 and $20 bills in his hand, Stanley Ryback called out to passengers disembarking at La Guardia Airport from an Eastern Airlines shuttle flight from Boston yesterday morning.

title: Hatch Meets Reagan Aides
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, chairman of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, met with advisers of Mr. Reagan today to discuss the allegations against Mr. Donovan.

title: WHERE IS RAOUL WALLENBERG?
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Are Said to Question A Man in Atlanta Deaths
description: The police were reportedly questioning a man today in the deaths and disappearances of 16 black children, but had ruled out as a suspect another man arrested today on unrelated charges.

title: CONSIDERS TALK ON THE STATE OF THE UNION
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan was in seclusion with his aides and his Cabinet designates today, selecting options for budget cuts and preparing a series of executive orders to be issued in the first hours and days of his Presidency.

title: Connecticut Warned on Energy
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill today urged Connecticut residents to conserve natural gas to avoid shortages that he indicated could be as serious as in Massachusetts.

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times Beyond the Parameters By ANATOLE BROYARD FREE ASSOCIATION. By Paul Buttenwies- er. 239 pages. Little, Brown. $11.95.

title: Navy Pilot Killed in Jet Crash
description: The pilot of a training jet headed for the aircraft carrier Lexington was killed today when the jet crashed into the Gulf of Mexico.

title: TRIAL AGAINST A.T.&T. HALTED AFTER PACT WITH JUSTICE DEPT.
description: A Federal judge today halted an historic antitrust trial that pits the Justice Department against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company because the two sides said they had reached a ''tangible, concrete agreement'' to settle the case.

title: JAPAN'S AMAZING AUTO MACHINE
description: TOKYO T HERE was a time when Detroit set out to rule the world. American auto makers built up domestic production, started to export and then followed up by moving plants overseas, to make cars and trucks within the markets they served. With this one-two-three punch, Detroit's Big Three became synonymous with American industrial strength, unquestioned leaders in the automotive field.

title: Mass Transit
description: To the Business Editor:

title: HIGH COSTS SIAD TO FORCE ILLEGAL HOUSE CONVERSIONS
description: Because of the rising costs of owning a house, a growing number of single-family homeowners in the metropolitan New York area are illegally converting their houses into two-family dwellings.

title: THE SARDONIC STYLE OF STEELY DAN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Stephen Holden writes frequently about popular music and is the author of ''Triple Platinum,'' a novel about the record business. By STEPHEN HOLDEN

title: SHOULD NOVELS ARGUE?
description: IDEASANDTHENOVEL By Mary McCarthy. 128 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $7.95. By DENIS DONOGHUE

title: MOVING BILLIONS OF DOLLARS TO IRAN: LARGELY A BUTTON-PUSHING EXERCISE
description: An agreement to free the hostages will necessitate the transfer of billions of dollars to Iran, but this will almost certainly not involve extensive packaging and shipment of American currency.

title: Returnable Bottles And Their Costs
description: In the recent article on Suffolk County's proposed ban of throwaway beverage containers, William Mimnaugh, vice president of Joyce Beverages, threatens higher prices similar to those of Connecticut, which has a deposit law. Before determining that ''Suffolk's suggested solution to the litter problem is naive and simplistic,'' he should have considered other factors before blaming Connecticut's prices on returnables.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Dishes, Cookware, Gifts For the Discount Seeker
description: The Mr. Pottery Corp. began discounting on Long Island, where there are now three branches, moved to White Plains three years ago - and more recently to Norwalk. Each sells domestic and imported dinnerware, glassware, gifts, flower pots, cookware and stainlesssteel flatware, all at discounts averaging 20 percent off the manufacturers' suggested retail prices. There are some factory closeouts, and the bulk of the stock is first quality, according to a spokesman.

title: 'NAPOLEON'- RESCUING AN EPIC FILM
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Annette Insdorf, who teaches film at Yale University, was Abel Gance's translator at the Telluride Film Festival. By ANNETTE INSDORF

title: Florida, Pennsylvania Tied To Segregation in Colleges
description: The Government accused Florida yesterday of failing to carry out a plan to end ''vestiges of segregation'' in its public colleges and threatened to begin secondstage steps to cut off the state's Federal education aid.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ: BOB WILBER QUARTET
description: A program billed as ''the first Sidney Bechet festival in the U.S.A.'' is being presented this week at, appropriately, Bechet's, the restaurant and jazz room on Third Avenue near 75th Street named for the great clarinetist and soprano saxophonist.

title: EFFORT TO SAVE 1845 SCHOOL
description: WEST CORNWALL THE preservation of an unusual 19th-century private secondary school, where the prevailing theory was that it was good to work the soil and study Greek and music, is the goal of a small committee consisting of members of the Cornwall Historical Society, representatives of the Cornwall Conservation Commission, and descendants of the school's founders.

title: FOR SPYING, OLD HANDS ARE STILL BETTER THAN THE LATEST GADGETS
description: A Navy ballistic missile submarine rocks in the currents, 200 feet deep and 800 miles from the big Soviet base at Murmansk. A Russian Backfire bomber, venturing into northern Canada, monitors the response of the North American Air Defense Command outside Colorado Springs. An Awacs aircraft flying up the Rhine registers the movement of a Soviet tank regiment near the Polish border.

title: STEELY DAN'S NEW SONGS
description: N early three years in the making, Steely Dan's ''Gaucho'' (MCA-6102) is as refined as pop music can get without becoming too esoteric for a mass audience. Though it consists of only two men, Steely Dan must be counted one of the most influential rock ''groups'' of the past decade. Founded by the songwriting team of Walter Becker and Donald Fagen eight years ago, they started out as a touring sextet. With Mr. Becker, the lead vocalist and bassist, and Mr. Fagen on keyboards, the group had a string of hits including ''Do It Again,'' ''Reeling in the Years,'' and ''Rikki Don't Lose That Number.'' After 1974, they stopped performing and made the recording studio their artistic base, using a shifting array of session musicians instead of fixed personnel. Over the course of seven albums, they've evolved an unusually subtle and literate brand of pop-rock that blends modal jazz harmonies, fusion instrumentation and funktinged polyrhythms within extended pop structures. Though other rock groups like Blood, Sweat & Tears and Chicago have enjoyed commercial success blending jazz and pop, none has come close to matching Steely Dan in sophistication and taste. They helped inspire rock singers like Joni Mitchell to explore jazz and paved the way for the Doobie Brothers' brand of pop-funk. Even stylistically unrelated groups like the Eagles were influenced by Steely Dan's carefully blocked arranging style.

title: Eric B. Levine to Marry Terri E. Simon on June 7
description: Terri E. Simon and Eric B. Levine, lawyers in New York, plan to be married on June 7 in Westport, Conn. Their engagement has been announced by Miss Simon's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Simon of Westport. Mr. Levine is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Levine of Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Fairfield 48, St. Peter's 44
description: Ken Daniels and Mike Palazzi scored the Stags' last 8 points tonight to lead Fairfield University to a 48-44 victory over St. Peter's College.

title: C.A. Kristoff Fiance Of Miss Newberry
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Newberry of Riverside, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Newberry, to Christopher A. Kristoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Kristoff of Greenwich, Conn.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: FARFROMHOME By Ouida Sebestyen. 191 pp. Boston: Atlantic-Little, Brown. $8.95. (Ages 13 and Up) By PATRICIA LEE GAUCH

title: No Headline
description: John McEnroe lost all three of his singles matches in the Volvo Masters, but apparently his spirits were not diminished. Last night, in the doubles semifinals, he and Peter Fleming easily defeated Kevin Curren and Steve Denton, 6-2, 6-2.

title: WEST VIRGINIA 93, UMASS 51
description: West Virginia outscored Massachusetts by 35-3 in the first 10 minutes of the second half today to break open a tight game and went on to score a 93-51 Eastern Eight victory over the Minutemen.

title: BRZEZINSKI SAYS CRITICS ARE IRKED BY HIS ACCURACY
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser, said today that critics who accused him of having spoken out too publicly actually resented him for being too accurate in his analysis of the Soviet-American strategic rivalry.

title: London Times Says Talks On a Buyer Are Going Well
description: The Times of London, which has been beset by chronic financial and labor difficulties, printed an article today that quoted unidentified sources as saying that negotiations to find a buyer were running ''at least a week ahead of schedule.''

title: No Headline
description: Karl Rahner's perceptive comment that ''the status of women in the church is always conditioned by the role of women in contemporary society'' is certainly applicable to the social conditions present when Christ began His church. Thus, despite Christ's uncommon acceptance of women as true and full followers of the faith, He knew that to hand ''the keys of the kingdom of Heaven'' to the Virgin Mary, Mary Magdalene or any other woman would have been sheer folly.

title: REAGAN INAUGURAL: EVEN THE PLATFORM IS FOR SALE
description: In the tribute to capitalism that sets at least part of the theme for the $8 million extravaganza to inaugurate the 40th President of the United States, even the wood from the official Presidential inaugural platform is for sale.

title: THE RISE AND FALL OF GETTING AHEAD
description: AMBITION The Secret Passion. By Joseph Epstein. 312 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $13.95.

title: POWER PERSUASIVE IN POLITICAL GIVING
description: Public-employee unions, bankers, health-care professions, law firms and business groups helped the Legislature's central campaign committees raise more than $2.7 million for the 1980 election campaigns, more than twice the amount they raised two years ago.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH TRUST FUNDS
description: M OST investors know that the bulk of their savings will eventually be passed on to their surviving spouses and children, and to insure that their families will receive these assets, a common practice has been to set up trust funds. But in recent years, trust funds have generally performed far worse than the portfolios of most investors who have handled their own trading and investments, and now some advisers see the need of changing the traditional investment strategy for trust funds.

title: Smiting Smut
description: No matter where he turned last October, 61-year-old George Smith of Baldwin, L.I., a dealer in supposedly pornographic ''European magazines,'' appeared trapped. The Nassau County District Attorney accused him of fraud for selling through a mail offer six publications that were too ''tame'' to qualify as pornographic and too small to be called magazines.

title: MEMORANDUM TO THE PRESIDENT
description: By now, you have received a barrelful of memos telling you how to organize the Government, making it very clear who your friends and enemies will be and explaining how you can solve most problems by applying the best business techniques to the business of running the Government. However, if your transition period is anything like that of your predecessors, no one has sent you a memo telling you - given what you said in the campaign and how the transition has gone to date - where you might, just might, have some major misperceptions and be heading toward some major mistakes.

title: BLUES 5, FLAMES 2
description: Bernie Federko scored a goal and added two assists Tuesday night to lead the St.Louis Blues to a 5-2 victory over the Flames in Calgary, Alberta.

title: Maple Leafs 6, Canadiens 5
description: Pat Hickey recorded his first three-goal night in a Toronto uniform and the third of his National Hockey League career in leading Toronto to the victory over Montreal.

title: Edith Lambert Gibbons Is Bride
description: St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Edith Lambert Gibbons, daughter of Mrs. Charles O. Thompson of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Prime Minister John David Gibbons of Bermuda, to John Theodore Winkhaus 3d of Greenwich, Conn., son of Mr. Winkhaus Jr. of Locust Valley, and the late Kathryn Hayfield Winkhaus. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony.

title: North Stars 7, Nordiques 1
description: Bobby Smith posted his first three-goal game of the season in leading a Minnesota rout of Quebec. Smith scored in each period for the second three-goal game of his career.

title: WATER BANS IN THE WEST: THE POINT WAS PUBLICITY
description: TRENTON THE ban on nonessential water uses, imposed last Thursday for the entire Delaware River Basin, extends some form of controls from the six rationed counties in New Jersey's northeastern corner to the state's western and southern borders.

title: Scott Beats Howe in 5 Sets For 6th Court Tennis Title
description: Gene Scott recovered from 1-4 in the fifth set to defeat Ralph Howe by 6-5, 6-4, 4-6, 2-6, 7-5, and retain the United States court tennis championship today at the Racquet Club.

title: LIBRARIES BECOMING CENTERS FOR THE ARTS
description: ART in the the suburbs has found a new base of operations - in the local library. Those hushed sanctums, once reserved for scholarly pursuits, now quake with rock music or vibrate gently to the sound of chamber ensembles. Modern-dance troupes vie with budding baritones, poets, celebrity lecturers and theatrical productions for bookings. Walls are laden with revolving exhibitions of frequently traditional, but occasionally avant-garde, painting and photography.

title: Cavaliers 110, Bulls 98
description: Mike Mitchell hit a game-high 26 and Richard Washington added 22 to lift Cleveland to victory.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: MASS TRANSIT
description: To the Business Editor: Prof. George Sternlieb's unequivocal assertion in the mass transit article that the ''Erie Lackawanna...has become a disaster'' merits a rebuttal.

title: A Tougher Rule on Sex Harrassment
description: Deciding that insult was sufficient without injury, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled last week that a woman can sue her employer for sexual harassment, without proving that she suffered any actual economic loss in addition.

title: EIFFEL'S LOVE
description: To the Editor:

title: AN EXHIBIT OF ENGLAND'S STAINED GLASS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- MERIDA WELLES is a member of the staff of the London bureau of The Times. By MERIDA WELLES

title: Salvador Junta; Getting Fresh Aid; From Washington
description: Guerrillas in El Salvador got their ''final offensive'' off to an uncertain start last week. Nearly 1,000 deaths were reported in hitand-run fighting in the countryside and provincial cities.

title: 'THE ARDENT SUPPLY-SIDERS ARE ON THE RIGHT TRACK'
description: To the Editor:

title: Monica Blum Is Married
description: Monica Blum, widow of Dr. Daniel Leabman, was married at noon yesterday to Robert P. Lemieux, an assistant director of the New York City Office of Management and Budget.

title: MAKING OF AN HEIRLOOM ALBUM RECORDS A FAMILY HISTORY
description: PHOTOGRAPHY is my younger son's hobby; genealogy is mine. So together we put our heirlooms in an album. One day my daughter asked me, ''What's the history of this old clock? Was it Grandma's?'' That gave me the idea for the project. Her mother was already gone, and I was getting older, so the story should be recorded - in words and color photographs - before it was too late.

title: Pamela Small Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Patterson M. Small of Garden City, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Small, to Eddy L. Steinkoenig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Steinkoenig of Rapoid City, S.D. A July wedding is planned.

title: INAUGURATION SITES HAVE LONG HISTORY OF CHANGE
description: While most Presidents have taken their oaths of office on the East Portico of the United States Capitol, the shift to the West Front for this year's inauguration does not break any precedents.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: U.S. CONGRESSMEN LEAVE ATHENS
description: A 16-man Congressional delegation led by Representative Melvin Price, Democrat of Illinois, left today after two days of talks with Government officials, including Prime Minister George Rallis.

title: CONSUMER RATES
No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; China Again Warns Dutch Against Sale of Subs

title: MANASQUAN RESERVOIR PLANS QUESTIONED
description: FREEHOLD TOWNSHIP ALTHOUGH New Jersey has spent more than 10 years and some $7 million planning a reservoir along the Manasquan River, the project may have to be re-evaluated because the river is so heavily polluted.

title: CRIME SUDDENLY PRESSING TOPIC FOR CANADIANS
description: Canada, a country that views itself as far less violent than the neighboring United States, has suddenly seen one policeman slain and four wounded in separate shooting incidents since Christmas, and this has led to demands that all officers be equipped with bulletproof vests.

title: DO AND DON'T: ADVICE FOR REAGAN
description: R ONALD REAGAN takes office this week with no shortage of economic problems and no shortage of advice on what to do about them. Inflation, productivity, energy, growth - they're all crowding for attention.

title: TOP POST DISPUTED IN ILLINOIS SENATE
description: The new Illinois Senate has ended a week of political maneuvering with an anomaly: two people laying claim to the presidency of that chamber, a Republican and a Democrat.

title: Art View; TWO POLEMICISTS RESPOND TO THE MOOD OF THE TIMES
description: The way art responds to the historical mood of the times, and even to certain specific events of the times, is bound to vary greatly in a culture like ours, which places a high value on subjective expression and lacks, in any event, the sort of tradition that allows art to deal with public themes in an impersonal or conventional manner. For an artist to address his work to the historical mood, therefore, requires a prior decision about style. His attitude toward style will determine not only the formal attributes of the work but his attitude toward his subject. Most especially will it determine the degree of polemical intensity he brings to it.

title:
Antiques;
OLD YANKEE WAYS TO KEEP WARM
description: DANBURY AS cold winds whip around New England houses and indoor temperatures sometimes drop to 50 degrees Fahrenheit, Connecticut residents are learning what winter was like in 18th century homes. Rather than shiver, however, collectors who want to save energy might well regard some of their antiques not just as decorative accessories but as warmth-providing utensils. Instead of electric blankets and portable heaters, canny Yankees 200 years ago used foot stoves, warming pans and virgins to ward off the chill.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 13 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $15.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history. 2 3 22 FIRESTARTER, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) E ightyear-old Charlie can look at anything and turn it into flames. 3 2 17 THE KEY TO REBECCA, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $12.95.) German espionage in Cairo during the desert campaigns of 1942. 4 5 16 LOON LAKE, by E.L. Doctorow. (Random House, $11.95.) The strange, lyrical adventures of a young man during the Depression. 5 6 9 UNFINISHED TALES, by J.R.R. Tolkien. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.) Hitherto unpublished fragments of writing about Middle-earth. 6 12 4 ANSWER AS A MAN, by Taylor Caldwell. (Putnam's, $12.95.) A man who has made it big in early 20th-century America struggles against the corruption that engulfs his life. 7 7 19 THE FIFTH HORSEMAN, by Larry Collins and Dominique Lapierre. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.) Libyan terrorists have planted a thermonuclear device in New York and there are only 24 hours to find it.

title: AN ORDINARY LIFE
Carter Proclaims Heart Month
description: President Carter has proclaimed the month of February as American Heart Month, saying diseases of the heart and blood vessels cause 950,000 deaths annually.

title: BY MARC RAIZMAN; DENVER
description: I T'S 12:15 A.M. and Denver's new downtown skyscrapers are dark - except for the southwest corner of the 15th floor of 1 Park Center tower, where phones ring in steady staccato.

title: WHY HOLLYWOOD BREEDS SELF-INDULGENCE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Hans Koning is a novelist; he has assisted in the filming of his novels ''A Walk With Love and Death'' and ''The Revolutionary.'' By HANS KONING

title: Elizabeth H. Rudel Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Escott Rudel of Waquoit, Mass., formerly of Old Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Hardin Rudel, to Arnold Linn Mayersohn Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mayersohn of Little Rock, Ark. The future bride was graduated in 1978 from the University of Colorado. Her fiance, an alumnus of Colorado, class of '77, expects to receive a J.D. degree from the University of Arkansas in May.

title: PARTY'S ORGANIZATIONAL MAN
description: On the afternoon of Nov. 4, a campaign aide to Ronald Reagan decided he did not like the lettering in a banner mounted behind the podium at the Century Plaza Hotel in Los Angeles, where, a few hours later, Mr. Reagan would accept victory and election as the 40th President.

title: G.E.'S EXPANSION INTO CAD CAM
description: United Telecommunications Inc.'s announcement last month that the General Electric Company had agreed to pay up to $170 million to acquire the Calma Corporation from it came as no surprise to those familiar with G.E.'s plans to develop the automated ''factory of the future.''

title: In Poland, It's Still Who'll Blink First
description: The Soviet Union sent Red Army Marshal Viktor G. Kulikov to Warsaw last week as a reminder to Poles that Russian troops, who ''liberated'' the city 36 years ago, are still close by. Yesterday, while officials walked through ceremonies marking the liberation anniversary, workers had the day off in accordance with the Government's new policy of two ''free'' Saturdays a month.

title: FEAR: THE NORMAL, CRUCIAL BUT IGNORED FACTOR
description: ONE summer in the mid-1930's I, as an 8-year-old, represented Camp Colang in a tennis match against another 8-year-old from Camp Delewaxen, our hated rivals from a few miles away.

title: DEBORAH SMIRLOCK ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Smirlock of Westbury, L.I., of the engagment of their daughter, Deborah Ann Smirlock, to Brian F. Dakss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Dakss of Bellerose, Queens. A September wedding is planned. The future bride is with Astrodyne Computer Industries in Garden City, L.I. Her fiance is a newswriter for the Wall Street Journal Radio Network.

title: THE PINCH ON SAVINGS AND LOANS
description: LOS ANGELES Deregulation of the country's savings and loan industry, bringing with it the pressure to invest heavily in new checking accounts and consumer lending services, has come at a time when savings associations across the country are suffering the lowest profit margins since World War II.

title: RUTGERS BOWS, 64-58, TO ST. BONAVENTURE
description: Earl Belcher and Mark Jones combined for 44 points and St. Bonaventure scored the game's final 10 points to defeat Rutgers tonight, 64-58, in an Eastern Eight contest.

title: STATE AND U.S. CONTEST CLEANUP OF OIL SPILL 13 YEARS AGO
description: THIRTEEN years after an Air Force work crew discovered that a valve on a storage tank had been left open and that 84,000 gallons of jet fuel had spilled onto the ground at the Suffolk County Airport in Westhampton, the state and the Federal Government are arguing over responsibility for the cleanup.

title: MARKET STAYS STRONG FOR BIG POWER BOATS
description: THE last year has been a tough one for yachtsmen and the pleasure boating industry in general. Inflation, recession, high interest rates, increasing fuel costs, proliferating government regulations, and the (happily) aborted proposal that the Federal Department of Energy be empowered to ban powerboat usage on weekends all combined to unsettle a lot of yachtsmen and to cut sharply into the sales of new boats and engines.

title: 2 SHORT PLAYS SHARE BILL WITH CHEKOV
description: SYOSSET OSTENSIBLY, David Litt formed the Contemporary Playwrights Theater to develop new playwrights and feature new plays on the Island. Last April, ''A Moment of Truth,'' a one-act play by Mr. Litt, was presented as part of a double bill - the theater's only production of the year. This season, the same play is being done in what Mr. Litt calls an ''evolved'' version. This time it is the second part of a triple bill, which includes yet another play by Mr. Litt: ''Tricks.''

title: FOR FIRST TIME, JERSEYANS GET A NIGHT CIVIL COURT
description: Stephen McGlynn Jr., an Elizabeth police officer who works days, went to court to press for $1,000 in back rent he said was due on a house he owns at the Jersey Shore.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
LEAVE HIM TO THE ANGELS
description: AYOUNG woman asked, ''what was Casey Stengel like?'' I thought she was pulling my leg until I realized that she was nine years old when Casey, retiring as manager of the New York Mets, dropped out of public view. ''Casey Stengel,'' I said, ''was - well, just a minute.'' I dug up my copy of Casey's testimony before the Senate Subcommittee on Antitrust and Monopoly on July 9, 1958. It seems to me that those of us who covered Casey in his time owe it to history to reintroduce him to readers in this fashion at least once a decade.

title: ALTERATIONS; Insuring Against Arson
description: After spending years chasing criminals who have been burning down the South Bronx, District Attorney Mario Merola has concluded that ''insurance companies are part and parcel of the arson problem.'' He's right.

title: Lietzke's 70-262 Leads by 2 as Pate Closes
description: Bruce Lietzke had a chance to run away with the Bob Hope Desert Classic today, but, as he said, ''I threw away four or five shots.'' The result was that, although Lietzke came in with a two-under-par 70, Jerry Pate gained three shots with a 67.

title: Sunday Observer; JIMMY STEWART'S BEST FRIEND
description: Jimmy Stewart's Best Friend Patrick McDonnell

title: WHEN THERE'S NO HEAT, CITY HALL FEELS
description: IT By MICHAEL GOODWIN

title: Miss Lowish Has Nuptials
description: Virginia Mae Lowish and Robert Danahey Burns were married in New York yesterday in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Bryant Kirkland performed the ceremony.

title: TEMPLE 56, LAFYETTE 50
description: Neal Robinson scored a season-high 20 points and temple converted eight of nine free throws in the final 38 seconds to hold on for a 56-50 triumph over Lafayette in East Coast Conference action today. Temple, now 8-4 over all and 4-0 in the conference, gained the lead for good when a reserve guard, Jim McLoughlin, hit a 15-foot jumper with 10:30 remaining to make the score 37-35.

title:
New Jersey Housing;
A YOUNG WOMAN WITH A MISSION
description: EQUALLY conversant in the complex language of finance and the often-arcane language of construction, Robin Flitt has worked for the last two years to be precisely where she wants to be.

title: NANTUCKET SMILES OVER ITS ICY ISOLATION
description: As a small convoy of ships crunched toward Nantucket through eight miles of foot-thick ice, the hardy year-round residents of this resort island calmly shrugged off the troubles of icy isolation and smiled at mainland rumors of evacuation.

title:
Antiques;
A LOW-COST WAY TO DECORATE TASTEFULLY
description: PRINCETON ONE of the most frequent complaints heard these days is how costly antiques have become. However, for those who wish to decorate tastefully with things from the past, a small print shop here may provide a partial solution without putting a huge dent in one's pocketbook.
