title: Dance View; THE CURRENT STAGING OF 'SCHEHERAZADE'
description: kisselgoff trimmed for dance page/ blurb tk

title: Maggy Sawin Wed To Stewart Wolf 3d
description: The marriage of Maggy Joyce Sawin to Stewart George Wolf 3d took place yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in Nyack, N.Y. The Rev. R.W.D. Jewett performed the ceremony.

title: New Jersey Guide
description: NEW JERSEY GUIDE BLOOMFIELD PIANO CONCERT

title: BURDEN OF FEDERAL PAPERWORK: A BILLION CITIZEN-HOURS A YEAR
description: The Federal bureaucrats assigned to ease the paperwork forced on Americans have come up with some numbers. This year, they found, Americans will spend 1.276 billion hours filling out 5,000 different kinds of Government forms.

title: Practical Traveler; WHAT STEPS TO TAKE WHEN YOU GET BUMPED FROM A FLIGHT
description: Half an hour after its scheduled departure time for Philadelphia, a fully loaded jumbo jetliner of Eastern Airlines was still at the San Juan departure gate. A harried attendant advised the passengers that the flight had been oversold and ''we need 20 volunteers to give up their seats.'' Time passed, and then the passengers were told, ''We need two more.'' Finally the plane took off, more than 90 minutes late.

title: GOOD HEDGES MAKE GOOD NEIGHBORS
BYRNE'S FINAL YEAR: 'NO BED OF ROSES'
description: TRENTON GOVERNOR BYRNE ended his seventh annual State of the State message to the Legislature last week by quoting Sean O'Casey: ''Let the timid tiptoe through the way where the paler blossoms grow; my feet shall be where the redder roses grow, though they bear long thorns, sharp and piercing, thick among them!''

title: June Elections Loom in Israel
description: The life expectancy of the Begin Government, even as a caretaker, dropped last week from 10 months to six when Finance Minister Yigael Hurwitz carried out his threat to quit and took the Government's parliamentary majority with him. Resisting hardliners who sought more time to expand Jewish settlement on the occupied West Bank, Prime Minister Menachem Begin indicated that he would prefer a dignified end to the Government at a time of his choosing to a sudden pulling of the plug by Parliament in a no-confidence vote.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Stoneware, Stainless At Norwalk Outlet
description: The Mr. Pottery Corp. began discounting on Long Island, where there are now three branches, then opened in White Plains and, two years ago, moved to Norwalk. Each store sells domestic and imported dinnerware, glassware, gifts, flower pots, cookware and stainless steel flatware, all at reductions averaging 20 percent off the manufacturers' suggested retail price. There are some factory closeouts, although the bulk of the stock is first quality, according to a spokesman.

title: More Terrorism In Puerto Rico
description: The Macheteros, a Puerto Rican independence group that uses bombs and bullets to make political statements, last week exploded a postscript to the antistatehood message sent by the island's voters in their recent gubernatorial election.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ANNUAL REPORT OF THE PRESIDENT'S COUNCIL OF ECONOMIC
description: Following are excerpts from Chapter 1 of the Annual Report of the Council of Economic Advisers, released today: In the 1980's, the United States will confront a variety of stubborn problems that have developed during the past 15 years. Chief among these problems is one that is shared by most other industrial countries - the persistence of large wage and price increases, even in the face of high unemployment and slack production. This problem poses the single most important challenge to U.S. economic policy - reducing inflation while maintaining a reasonably prosperous and growing economy.

title: Chess; THE MALTESE LESSON: BEWARE THE UNDERDOG
description: The lesson of the 24th Olympiad in Malta was that the days of foregone conclusions are over. While the leading chess countries did maintain their overall supremacy, they could not take for granted a sweep, or even a 3-1 victory over lower-ranked opponents.

title: Music; HARTT REVISES MOZART
description: OPERA fans can give three cheers over the next fortnight, as ''Cosi fan tutte'' and ''Tosca'' come to Hartford, while ''Carmen'' spins her seductive web in Stamford.

title: Eleanore Williams Fiancee of Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Williams of Pueblo, Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eleanore DeLoach Williams, to M. William Macey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Macey of Atlanta. A June wedding is planned.

title: LIFTS MARTIAL LAW
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos released 341 prisoners today, hours after ending the state of martial law under which he had ruled the Philippines for eight years and four months.

title: NO FAREWELL TO ARMS
description: ''As one who has witnessed the horror and the lingering sadness of war -as one who knows that another war could utterly destroy this civilization which has been so slowly and painfully built up over thousands of years - I wish I could say tonight that a lasting peace is in sight.

title: Cowboy Players, Staff Are Warned on Scalping
description: Players and executives of the Dallas Cowboys who buy Super Bowl tickets will have to sign statements that they will not resell their tickets to scalpers, the Cowboys' general manager, Tex Schramm, has ordered.

title: Connecticut Guide; SHOW OF BRITON'S ART
description: Stanley Spencer, a British artist who died in 1959 at the age of 68, is little known here. More than 60 selections from a retrospective of almost 300 of his paintings, presented at the Royal Academy of Arts in London last fall, will be on exhibition Wednesday through March 22 at the Yale Center for British Art, 1080 Chapel Street, New Haven.

title: Home Clinic; HOW TO THAW FROZEN PIPES
description: THE spell of extremely cold weather in this area has caused many homeowners to cope with the problem of frozen water pipes - a problem that many have seldom, if ever, been faced with before.

title: Gallery View; ARCADIAN VIEWS OF THE WHITE MOUNTAINS
description: Around a hundred years ago, the White Mountains of New Hampshire had the kind of prestige among enlightened travelers that Kashmir has today. They were not quite as far away, of course, but they were terrific to look at. The air was clear, the climate perfect, the hotels very good indeed and the general atmosphere one of comfort, tranquillity and exalted seclusion. When people came back from their five or six weeks' vacation (short visits were considered vulgar in those days) there was a spring in their step, a brightness in their eye and a bounce in their general demeanor that spoke well for the White Mountains.

title: Lawyer Is Fiance Of Janet L. Wilkov
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Wilkov of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Louise Wilkov, to Thomas Nathan Twomey, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Twomey of Aurora, Ky., formerly of Stamford.

title: Two Cleared in 11 Fire Deaths
description: An investigation by the State Department of Children and Family Services has cleared two social workers of negligence in the deaths of 11 East St. Louis children in a house fire last weekend. A statement by the department said yesterday that the investigation had found that there was ''no significant cause'' for removing the children from the custody of their mother, Virginia Williams, 28 years old, before the fire broke out while the children were left unattended.

title: TRYING TO UNDERSTAND CANCER AND ITS EFFECTS ON LOVED ONES
description: HE is out of intensive care now, resting uneasily in a room on the surgical floor. The stomach and oxygen tubes are gone, the catheter removed, the IV and EKG machines disconnected. I kiss him goodnight and go downstairs to the seminar. He knows the topic to be discussed. We keep no secrets.

title: Antiques
description: KNOWN TREASURES OF EGYPT'S LUXOR MUSEUM OF ANCIENT ART By Rita Reif

title: Rhode Island 59 Old Dominion 54
description: Pappy Owens, who had a game-high 28 points, scored 8 points in a 15-2 run in the second half tonight that propeled Rhode Island to a 59-54 upset of Old Dominion.

title: On Language; GETTING DOWN
description: ! !! Getting Down Kimble Mead

title: Strong Enough, Now
description: On those rare occasions when the law catches up to a Mafia don before his friends do, it seems he's always too old or infirm to serve time.

title: FOUR RESPONSES TO THE PROVOCATIVE 'PELLEAS'
description: Debussy's British biographer, Edward Lockspeiser, once described the play ''Pelleas et Melisande'' by Maurice Maeterlinck as ''an opera libretto in search of a composer.'' That definition could just as well be extended to include all the Belgian writer's dramatic works, scenarios that seemed to be waiting for a composer to flesh them out with music. During the first half of the 20th century, Maeterlinck's works exercised a strange fascination over many musicians - at least a dozen of his plays inspired such diverse figures as Rachmaninoff, Webern, Humperdinck and Dimitri Mitropoulos as well as over 40 other composers.

title: Julie May Garfunkel Married In Michigan to Steven Spencer
description: Julie May Garfunkel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Garfunkel of New York and Block Island, R.I., was married yesterday evening in Traverse City, Mich., to Steven Lee Spencer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eusiebierus R. Spencer of Williamsburg, Mich. The Rev. Joseph Garshaw performed the ceremony in the First Christian Church.

title: MINSKOFFS SET THE STAGE FOR NEW OFFICE PROJECTS
description: The Minskoff family, which runs one of the city's oldest building organizations, is planning new projects in the metropolitan area as it makes changes at the top and welcomes a third generation as junior partners.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: The year-end figures have been toted up, and the news seems to be good. The overall holiday sales, booksellers report, were up 12 to 20 percent over the same period in 1979.

title: MARGUERITE OSWALD
description: Marguerite Oswald, mother of Lee Harvey Oswald, died today of cancer. She was 73 years old. Mrs. Oswald waged a campaign against the findings of the Warren Commission, which concluded that her son murdered President Kennedy in 1963.

title: South Alabama 95 Nicholls State 62
description: Ed Rains scored 23 points tonight to lead South Alabama to its 14th straight victory, a 95-62 triumph over Nicholls State.

title: RECITAL: HARPSICHORDIST
description: There was scarcely an hour of playing at Fernando Valenti's harpsichord recital at the Metropolitan Museum on Monday night, but it contained more music than most concerts twice its length.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Yun-Boh Cheung, Pianist, Plays Bach, Beethoven
description: Yun-Boh Cheung is a young pianist who comes to us from Korea by way of the Juilliard School, where she has studied for the last 10 years. She made her debut in Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday afternoon in a program of Bach, Beethoven, Chopin and Prokofiev.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JANUARY 18, 1981
description: International Among the messages sent to Teheran from Washington was a proposal, that if accepted by Iran, could produce a final agreement on the release of the American hostages, Jody Powell, the White House press secretary said, but he added that there was no ''overall response'' from the Algerian intermediaries. Instead, Iranian messages sent through the intermediaries to Deputy of State Warren M. Christopher in Algiers, asked for ''specific details.'' (Page 1, Column 6.) An agreement to drop lawsuits against Iran reportedly was made by representatives of 12 major American banks, which sought payment of loans, if Teheran agrees to repay a portion of the debts immediately and to settle the rest later. (1:4.)

title: No Headline
description: If Paul Wilkes is quoting Sister Theresa Kane accurately, it is surprising that she should say, ''I'd sure like to give it a try,'' in referring to ordination.

title: BUSINESSMEN ARE BULLISH ON STATE'S PROSPECTS
description: THE Connecticut economy performed well during the short, sharp 1980 recession, which for the state proved so mild that several economists expect businesses to endure the current wave of high interest rates with little trouble. These observers also envisage rapid economic growth in the later years of this decade as the nation invests in new capital goods and military hardware, major industries in the state.

title: DANCE
description: Some of the ways in which theatrical dance has treated art forms with specific ethnic roots can be sampled in two very different types of concerts. Sunday at 8 P.M., Ayako Uchiyama appears at Japan House with a group of Japanese musicians. Miss Uchiyama is unusual in that she spent the earlier part of her career researching and performing the songs and dances of the Ainu, the aborigine people of Japan.

title: Fashion; KEEPING UP WITH THE REAGANS
description: It is still two days before Ronald and Nancy Reagan are officially the First Family of the nation, but already widespread interest has been generated in the Reagans' style - the way they dress and their approach to public functions and private entertaining.

title: Westchester Guide; CELEBRATION OF WINTER
description: The first White Plains Winter Festival, to be held from noon to 5 P.M. Saturday in the Plaza Park opposite the Abraham & Straus department store, will be distinguished by iceless ice-skating and, unless there is an unexpected blizzard, snowless skiing.

title: WHO'S WHO
description: HONDA MOTOR

title: TWO COURTS REBUFF OPPONENTS OF STATE'S PINE BARREN PLAN
description: TRENTON LEGAL assaults on New Jersey's controversial plan to protect the Pine Barrens from overdevelopment intensified last week, as efforts were made to head off implementation of the plan.

title: POP: NRB BAND AT RITZ
description: Lou Albano, a mountainous, manic gentleman who is something like a cross between a television wrestler and a used-car salesman, introduced NRBQ at the Ritz on Thursday night and periodically stomped around the stage, his arms windmilling wildly, while the band played. He is rumored to be NRBQ's manager, and it is utterly typical of the group's approach to making music that he is allowed - even, one suspects, encouraged - to blunder through their performances.

title: L.I. Girl Dies Just Before Hearing On Her Removal From Respirator
description: A comatose Long Island girl died at University Hospital here yesterday, just days before a judge was to hear her parents' arguments for disconnecting her from a respirator.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: IDAEARLYCOMESOVER THEMOUNTAIN By Robert Burch. 145 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $8.95. (Ages 9 to 12) By JEAN FRITZ

title: A SORT OF AUTOBIOGRAPHY
description: WAYSOFESCAPE By Graham Greene. 320 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $12.95. By JAMES ATLAS

title: CAR SALES, JAPANESE STYLE
description: TOKYO

title: Reality News; West Side
description: The American Telephone & Telegraph Company has leased 45,000 square feet of space on three floors at 450 West 33d Street for 10 years at an aggregate rent of more than $2 million.

title: About Bayswater
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge; FINDING NEW STRAINS
description: The terminology of bridge suffers from a gap that irritates all those who write about the game. It is easy to refer to ''one of the four suits,'' but if you want to include no-trump there is no good word. The laws of the game use ''denomination,'' but that is clumsy. A better term, now gaining favor is ''strain.'' South, we can say, ''was willing to play in any strain.''

title: Wake Forest 60, N.C. State 52
description: SALEM, N.C., Jan. 17 (AP) - Frank Johnson scored 4 points in the last 40 seconds today and helped Wake Forest hold on for a 60-52 Atlantic Coast Conference victory.

title: Elizabeth Ashforth Fiancee of E.W. Bacon
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Ashforth Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth M. Ashforth, to Edmund W. Bacon, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Bacon Jr. of Wayne, Ill.

title: GREEK ORTHODOX LEADERS URGED TO TRY TO WIDEN CHURCH APPEAL
description: A member of the highest lay council of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America has challenged the group to begin a vigorous media campaign to explain the Greek Orthodox faith to a broader cross section of Americans.

title: Tennis Star Sven Davidson Suffers Heart Attack at 52
description: Sven Davidson, the Grand Masters tennis player and former Davis Cup player for Sweden, suffered a heart attack today, according to his daughter, Mia.

title: CONCERT: Y CHAMBER SYMPHONY
description: The distant calm of Claudio Arrau's recent Beethoven recordings had little relation to his appearance Friday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. Here Mr. Arrau joined the Y Chamber Symphony and its conductor, Gerard Schwarz, in performances of Beethoven's last two concertos that were warm and intense.

title: FINDING THE 'WHY' OF THE NEWS
description: IF asked to cite one of his finer moments, Dr. Salvadore V. Didato would probably tell you it was when, still a student in the doctoral psychology program at Loyola University in Chicago, the American Psychological Association accepted for presentation at its annual convention, a study on schizophrenia he had done at the Chicago State Hospital.

title: 'Overregulated' Coal Is Overstated
description: Ronald Reagan assumes the Presidency with a pledge to cut Federal rules that shackle the economy, especially new energy supplies. James Baker, the next President's chief of staff, says one of Mr. Reagan's first official acts could be to suspend all pending Federal regulations to allow time for review. Some environmental safeguards may well be challenged in the process.

title: FINAL ECONOMIC REPORT ASKS FISCAL RESTRAINTS TO BATTLE INFLATION
description: In its final Economic Report to Congress, the Carter Administration said today that the only way to reduce inflation was to continue restraint in tax reduction, Government spending and the growth of the money supply.

title: Dr. Richard Fraser to Wed Sara Rasmussen
description: The engagement of Sara Anne Rasmussen to Dr. Richard Alexander Ross Fraser of New York and Siasconset, Mass., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Harold Forbes Rasmussen of Rye, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Ross Fraser of Victoria, British Columbia.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
After Cold and Drought...?
description: At least for a little while, nature let up on the metropolitan area last week. On Wednesday the temperature actually climbed to the freezing point, after mostly staying below it - sometimes way below it - for more than a week.

title: MONOLINGUAL SUCCESS
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: JAPAN AS NUMBER ONE, by Ezra F. Vogel. (Harper/Colophon, $4.95.) in politics and government, public welfare, crime control, an economy in which large corporations are more committed to their employees than to their stockholders, a thorough educational system and its application - and suggests ways in which America might benefit from the examples. Our reviewer Frank B. Gibney called it ''an objective and immensely rewarding appraisal that deserves a wide readership.''

title: F.C.C. Cuts Radio's Regulatory Strings
description: Relying on forces of the marketplace to bend broadcasters to the public interest, the Federal Communications Commission voted 6 to 1 last week to deregulate the nation's 8,933 radio stations.

title: DRUG DEALER LINKED TO POINT-SHAVING
description: Henry Hill, the Federal informer who has told New York law enforcement officials about alleged point-shaving at Boston College during the 1978-79 basketball season, was introduced to a Boston College player by Paul Mazzei, a convicted drug dealer from Pittsburgh, according to a source close to the point-shaving investigation. Mr. Mazzei is currently under indictment, along with Mr. Hill, in a Nassau County drug case.

title: Carter and Staff to Use U.S. Building in Atlanta
description: Jimmy Carter and 22 members of his transition staff will occupy a well-secured floor of the Richard B. Russell Federal Building here when he returns to Georgia, a White House press aide said.

title: Transactions; BASKETBALL
description: Obtained Don Collins, g uard-forward, from Atlanta in trade for W es Matthews, guard. Signed Andre Mc- C arter, guard, and Anthony Roberts, for- w ard, for remainder of season.

title: Theater; 30 YEARS ACTING AND A FAMILIAR LOCAL FACE
description: THEATERGOERS in Westchester and Connecticut may recognize the actor Robert Nichols. He was at the Hartford Stage Company a few weeks ago in the play ''Einstein and the Polar Bear.'' He has played the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn., in ''Hit the Deck'' and ''Louisiana Purchase.'' Then there was ''Show Boat'' at the Coachlight Dinner Theater in East Windsor, Conn. He played Cap'n Andy, a role he did again for the Coachlight Dinner Theater of Nanuet. At odd hours, he pops up on television screens as kindly, folksy Mr. Merritt, spokesman for a well-known brand of flea collars.

title: Samarkand To the Editor:$
description: R.W. Apple Jr.'s article, ''Samarkand the Golden: An Ancient City Deep in Soviet Central Asia'' (Travel Section, Dec. 28), recalls my own trip to Samarkand in 1976. Our group was billeted in a hotel that catered to trade union visitors, a low rambling stucco building on a quiet tree-shaded street, with communal wash-up facilities that also included shower enclosures (we learned after a short time to keep towels and robes at a distance from the spray).

title: CARTER'S FAREWELLS ECHO SOME OF THE ERALY HELLOS
description: If the farewell address Jimmy Carter delivered from the Oval Office Wednesday sounded familiar, it was. The tone was reflective and less combative, but the content was strikingly similar to some of the early speeches he delivered as an obscure candidate stumping through the cornfields of Iowa five years ago. Nuclear arms control, human rights, protection of the environment, the threat posed by ''special interests'' - all were vintage Carter issues, part of the basic sermon he has been preaching since he first arrived on the national scene as an ex-governor of Georgia with Presidential ambitions.

title: Negotiations Continuing On Release of 4 Britons
description: Negotiations are still going on over the release of four Britons held prisoner in Iran since August, the Archbishop of Canterbury said today.

title: No Headline
description: The old streetcar gleams, even in the dim light in the warehouse. It looks ready. George Benson, a pharmacist in gold-rimmed glasses, has applied a lot of that gleaming paint. City Councilman Benson wants to see the streetcars run on the short route he envisions.

title: DECONTROL THE PRICE OF OIL-NOW
description: I T may not make sense at first glance. But immediate decontrol of domestic crude oil prices could end up saving the American consumer a lot of money - by helping to prevent another devastating run-up in world oil prices that might well result from the Iran-Iraq war.

title: SOME WINTER TALES: MISHAPS AND RESCUE
description: PORT WASHINGTON IT is 8:37 A.M. - halfway through what the Automobile Club of New York says is its busiest hour of the day. Billy Ryals, who drives one of the 165 emergency road-service trucks dispatched by the club, is fiddling with something called a ''butterfly valve,'' hoping that any device with a summery name will get a frigid engine going on one of the coldest days of the year.

title: UF2Humphrey Studying For Super Bowl Test
description: Claude Humphrey and Henry Lawrence are friends. Day by day, they are getting to know each other better. Henry Lawrence plays right offensive tackle for the Oakland Raiders. On passing plays, Claude Humphrey plays left defensive end for the Philadelphia Eagles. When Jim Plunkett, the Raiders' quarterback, attempts to pass in the Super Bowl next Sunday in New Orleans, Henry Lawrence will try to block Claude Humphrey out of the play, Humphrey will try to shed Lawrence and wrap himself around Plunkett before he can throw the ball.

title: POLAND MARKS 36TH ANNIVERSARY OF ITS LIBERATION FROM THE NAZIS
description: Under a brilliant winter sky Warsaw today officially celebrated the 36th anniversary of its liberation from Nazi oppression.

title: Long Island Opinion; 'ENOUGH IS ENOUGH. SOMEBODY OUGHT TO PUT A STOP TO IT'
description: WE live in the age of the equal rights amendment and women's liberation, of unions and antidiscrimination and antidefamation laws. We believe in personal freedom. We take training courses in assertiveness so that no one gets the best of us. We teach our children to stand up for their rights, not to be shy, to speak up.

title: LORILLARD: A CONFRONTATION AHEAD IN LOW TAR
description: L ORILLARD'S president and chief executive officer, Curtis H. Judge, says he's amused at the contradictory antics of three of his competitors - R.J. Reynolds, Philip Morris and American Brands - as each boasts in its ads to sell the cigarette with the lowest tar content. But it's an uneasy kind of amusement, because the 56-yearold head of the nation's fifth-largest cigarette maker also says he's bracing for a long battle to keep Lorillard's share of the booming low-tar market.

title: Alabama 59, Kentucky 53
description: Eddie Adams scored 20 points, 12 in the second half, to lead Alabama to a 59-55 upset of fourth-ranked Kentucky tonight in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: FLAT ROCK BROOK: A SUN-POWERED TOUCH OF WILDERNESS
description: ENGLEWOOD LAST January, the 700 members of the Flat Rock Brook Nature Association here took pleasure, but little physical comfort, in roaming their 150 acres of woodland.

title: Off-Duty Police Officer Is Stabbed in Woodside
description: An off-duty police officer was stabbed in the stomach early yesterday morning as he left a Woodside, Queens, tavern with his wife and a friend. The officer, William McMonigle, a 10-year veteran of the force, was listed in stable condition at Elmhurst Hospital.

title: A VOLUNTEER DIG IN OLD JERUSALEM
description: To be part of an archeological excavation in Jerusalem that may rewrite that city's history is memorable by itself. But to be able to combine a two-week stint as a volunteer digger with the comfort of a deluxe hotel lends a special flavor to the whole experience.

title: No Headline
description: Below, the black gown that Nancy Reagan will wear to the Inaugural Gala Monday night at the Capital Centre in Landover, Md. The gown, designed by Bill Blass, has a full satin skirt bordered in velvet and an elongated velvet top with puffed sleeves.

title: Two Cleared as Suspects In Atlanta Child Killings
description: Efforts to track down Atlanta's child killer or killers were stalled again today with the release of one suspect and the freeing on bond of a another man who the police apparently decided was not connected with the case.

title: JAMIE KANTROWITZ, A TEACHER, FIANCEE OF MARK LORBERBAUM
description: The engagement of Jamie Kantrowitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S.Edward Kantrowitz of Teaneck, N.J., to Mark Bruce Lorberbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lorberbaum of Boca Raton, Fla., has been announced by the future bride's parents. A November wedding is planned.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SAN JUAN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- MANUEL SUAREZ contributes to The Times from Puerto Rico. By MANUEL SUAREZ

title: BOATING RESURGENCE EXPECTED
description: WITH one of the coldest winters on record turning Manhattan's streets into frigid wind tunnels and clogging the rivers and bays with ice, summer seems far away, indeed. But the next best thing to escaping South is a trip to the 71st National Boat Show.

title: Traveler's Checks To the Editor:
description: I am relieved to learn from ''Checking Up on Traveler's Checks'' (Travel Section, Dec. 28) that I am not the only respectable adult finding it difficult to cash traveler's checks in the United States.

title: Underlining, Again Perils to the Earth
description: A report released last week by the President's Council on Environmental Quality and the Department of State added another to the Carter Administration's farewell messages which have struck familiar themes in newly urgent tones.

title: Design; NEWPORT AT THE ARMORY
description: John Duka is a reporter for the Style section of The New York Times. By John Duka The name of Newport conjures up a place and a time that, at this juncture, seem merely mythical. But it is there, a seaport and refuge for the social elite where people and things were always well taken care of -and still are for a very few. Where, during the 17th and 18th centuries, when Newport was young, her harbor bristled with the ships of a lucrative trade equaling that of the other pre-Revolutionary ports. Where gentlemen and their ladies wore silk brocade and lived intimately with the harmonious proportions of the furniture crafted by the great Newport furniture makers. And where today, thanks to the efforts of the Preservation Society of Newport County, the famous 19th-and 20thcentury estates - The Breakers, The Elms, Marble House, Chateau-SurMer, Kingscote, Rosecliff - still stand as beautiful but vacant hallmarks of a time which resonates only faintly with the cadence of waltzes.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. SAYS SOVIET ACTS TO DISRUPT HOSTAGE TALKS

title: 1.5 MILLION IRANIANS CALLED REFUGEES OF THE GULF WAR
description: Prime Minister Mohammed Ali Rajai of Iran said today that the war with Iraq had created a million and a half Iranian refugees. The statement, broadcast on Teheran Radio, was the closest Iran has come to conceding that its two-week-old military counteroffensive in the oil province of Khuzistan had failed.

title: BABY SITTER, 10, RULED NOT LIABLE FOR INJURIES TO YOUNGER BROTHER
description: When a 10-year-old girl is looking after her 4-year-old brother and he gets hurt, the girl cannot be held legally liable for damages.

title: Headliners Sharply Negative
description: Celebrity, however acquired, is as good as gold in modern America.

title: ALTERATIONS; Sow's Purse
description: Industrial America has demonstrated wondrous skill in converting luxuries once available only to the very rich into items that everyone could afford: warm, attractive clothing; automobiles loaded with extras; TV sets; innumerable other appliances. Silk purses for all, even if made of nylon that only looked like silk.

title: SUPER BOWL BRINGS MILLIONS IN BUSINESS
description: WHILE 26 football teams look on with envy this week as the Philadelphia Eagles and the Oakland Raiders prepare for the Super Bowl, at least one city will watch with envy as the city of New Orleans prepares for the Super Bowl.

title: STUDY CRITICIZES EMERGENCY FOSTER-CARE PROGRAMS
description: Hundreds of adolescents - more than 60 percent of those coming into New York City's emergency foster-care programs because of sudden need for shelter -have been ''bouncing in and out of placement'' for years, according to a civic group.

title: The Chrysler Precedent
description: Chrysler's managers, workers, creditors, suppliers and Federal overseers have been staring at bankruptcy for months. Now, it appears, they have blinked. In return for cost-cutting concessions - notably a conversion of bank debts to preferred stock and a 20-month wage freeze - the Government will guarantee an additional $400 million loan for the desperate car producer.

title: Politics; AMBRO SURPRISED BY NEW JOB
description: JUST hours before the premature announcement of his appointment as a Washington lobbyist for the Carey administration, Jerome A. Ambro had sounded discouraged and disheartened over his unaccustomed role as job seeker rather than an influential Congressman who dispenses favors rather than seeking them.

title: FRANKLIN D. REAGAN
description: Nearly half a century ago, in 1932, the year that Ronald Reagan has said was the most important in forming his own views, the American people threw out a well-meaning but discredited engineer and turned to a man about whom they knew little other than that he seemed kindly and trustworthy. Few expected much of him. Walter Lippmann, the sage of the day, scathingly described him as an ''amiable boy scout,'' merely ''a pleasant man who, without any important qualifications for the office, would very much like to be President.''

title: A MICHIGAN LAWYER CONVICTED IN JERSEY
description: A lawyer from Michigan was found guilty in Superior Court today of violating New Jersey adoption laws by placing an infant and taking $5,500 from the adoptive parents. At the same time, the lawyer, Bernard Lampear, was acquitted of a similar charge contained in a four-year-old, two-count indictment.

title:
Gardening;
EVERYDAY VS. SCIENTIFIC NAMES FOR PLANTS
description: THE other day I came across a problem, really very simple, that required four reference books for a solution. I wished to look up information about the dogtooth violet, but the name was not listed in the first three books consulted.

title: THE ONLY-CHILD PHENOMENON
description: Didi Moore, a freelance writer living in New York, is the eldest of four children. By Didi Moore ntil two years ago, Jonathan Frank, a self-possessed second grader from Albuquerque, N.M., asked his parents with some regularity for a baby brother or sister. His 35-year-old mother, Karen, fed up with the questions and fairly convinced there would be no more children, sat Jonathan down one day and said: ''Let me tell you what it would be like if we had a new baby. The baby would cry at night. It would keep you up. You'd have to look after it. And I wouldn't have as much time to play with you.''

title: Probation in Linkletter Death
description: A woman was sentenced yesterday to a year's probation on her plea of no contest to vehicular manslaughter in the death of Robert Linkletter, the 34-year-old son of Art Linkletter, the entertainer. Grace Jones, 24, was also ordered to attend traffic education school by Municipal Judge Sherman W. Smith Jr.

title: THE NEW 'FIRST BROTHER' GRACIOUSLY ENDURES ROLE
description: A resident of this pleasant community north of San Diego stopped at a local inn for a drink the other night and was approached by a stranger who ''talked like the sun sets and rises on Ronald Reagan.''

title: Allison Whipple Fiancee of C.P. Combemale
description: Mrs. George Carroll Whipple Jr. of Carmel, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Allison Hall Whipple, to Christopher Porte Combemale, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Combemale of New York and Monaco. A wedding in April is planned.

title: NEW SALES TOOL: OLD MORGAGES WITH LOW RATES
description: As mortgage interest rates continue to cling to record levels, homes with existing low-interest financing that can be assumed are being eagerly sought by buyers.

title: Council on Environmental Quality Finds Air Cleaner in Most Cities
description: The air is becoming cleaner in most American cities, the President's Council on Environmental Quality said today.

title: Steven B. Caruso Fiance Of Leslie Noel Bechtel /
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Warren Bechtel of Ridgewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Noel Bechtel, to Steven Bruce Caruso, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leroy F. Caruso of North Woodmere, L.I.

title: NEW YORK INVESTIGATING BURIAL OF WASTES ON FARM
description: New York State investigators who dug up drums of illegally buried toxic wastes at an upstate farm last week expect to question officials of a Rockland County packaging company and a Pennsylvania trucking contractor when a grand jury is convened, probably this week, according to authorities close to the case.

title: HOSTAGE CRISIS CRACKED U.S. MIRROR-AND THE WORLD'S
description: PARIS THE story of the American hostages in Iran was a peculiar episode in United States and world history, not unique in itself, because the fate of prisoners is one of the oldest recurrent dramas, but quite extraordinary in its impact.

title: JERSEY SMOKE DETECTOR LAW UNHEEDED
description: There has been so little compliance with a new state law mandating smoke detectors in virtually all the 700,000 apartments in the state and nearly all rooms in hotels that Newark's Fire Director is calling for greater publicizing of the law.

title: TRIPUCKA HELPS IRISH BEAT HOFSTRA BY 65-55
description: A layup by Tracy Jackson and four free throws by Kelly Tripucka in the closing minute lifted Notre Dame to a 65-55 victory today over Hofstra.

title: FIRE DEPARTMENT TESTS NEW ROPE
description: A colleague kept the line taut as firemen demonstrated a two-man slide during field testing of a new type of rescue rope at the Fire Department Academy yesterday on Randalls Island. The 9/16-inch nylon line, thicker and heavier than the half-inch rope that figured in the deaths of two firemen last year, passed the dynamic shock and slide performance tests and is scheduled to be tested for aging characteristics and resistance to heat.

title: Robb Smith to Wed Joan Kerrigan in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. James J. Kerrigan Jr. of Larchmont, N.Y. and Naples, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Margaret Kerrigan, to Robb Evan Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Smith of Sun City, Ariz.

title: Iona 57, Holy Cross 56
description: Gary Springer hit a jumper with six seconds remaining in overtime to give Iona a 57-56 victory over Holy Cross today at the Mulcahy Center.

title: SUFFOLK WEIGHS COST OF UPDATING CAMP
description: SOUTHOLD THE scene at Suffolk County's Peconic Dunes camp is bleak and chilly, a far cry from the laughter and tumult of the summer. Here, for the last 10 years, 1,000 children a week have been building campfires on the beach, exploring a hardwood forest and swimming in the Great Pond, an estuary of Long Island Sound.

title: DESIGNERS PUT STRESS IN LIGHTER BOATS
description: MANY boat owners think that by traveling under sail they are beating the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and saving American petrodollars. There is one problem with their reasoning, however. If a person is sailing in a modern fiberglass boat, OPEC has already taken its everincreasing share. Most modern boats are built fiber-glass layers bonded together with polyester resin, and the resin is an oil-derivative whose cost has skyrocketed in recent years. Because 50 to 70 percent of a boat hull is resin, the cost of traditionally constructed boats has soared dramatically. This is one reason why designers and builders have started producing boats that are much lighter and simpler.

title: Flames 4, Jets 2
description: Bob MacMillan opened and closed the scoring for Calgary with his 13th and 14th goals of the season.

title: CRIME
description: Dame Ngaio Marsh is over 80, and she has been writing mystery stories since 1934, but you wouldn't know it from her prose. By some kind of miracle she has retained stylistic freshness, as witness PHOTO FINISH (Little, Brown, $10.95). Most veterans, even such great ones as Rex Stout, eventually fall into a mannered kind of cliche writing. They seem to dry up. Dame Ngaio, drawing on the resources of the classical British mystery, seems to avoid all such pitfalls; and if ''Photo Finish'' is vintage Marsh, with such familiar characters as Superintendent Roderick Alleyn and his wife Troy, it also manages to present a neat little puzzle, sparkling writing and the civilized veneer that characterize most of her books.

title: By Caren Goldberg
description: It is 9 P.M. and a fine snow has been falling steadily for hours. I always expend too much mental energy nervously anticipating winter storms, the forecast starting a day before the actual event with verbal overkill by the news media. I pull the office curtains back a dozen times, scanning the skies for the first flake, dreading the slippery drive home, should the storm start suddenly before the workday ends.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ARUSSIANFAREWELL By Leonard Everett Fisher. Illustrated by the Author. 133 pp. New York: Fours Winds Press. $9.95. (Ages 10 to 14) By ELLEN SCHECTER

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''History is much more the product of chaos than of conspiracy.'' - Zbigniew Brzezinski. (3:4.)

title: RIDER 80, LASALLE 63
description: Tom O'Hara scored 19 points, including 12 in the second half, to lead Rider to an upset 80-63 victory today over La Salle, the defending East Coast Conference champion.

title: MASS TRANSIT
description: To the Business Editor: Initially, the graph accompanying ''Discrimination in Mass Transit'' (Jan. 4) rather startles the reader with what appears to be a gross inequity.

title: WASHINGTON
description: ONE of the worst aspects of the hostage crisis for Jimmy Carter was that for the last 14 1/2 months of his Presidency, he often appeared as much a prisoner of Iran as the 52 Americans held captive. If he succeeds, in the waning days and hours of his office, in liberating them, he also will insure that Ronald Reagan can start his term in office on Tuesday with a much freer hand, not only toward the Persian Gulf region, but toward his overall foreign policy objectives, no matter how imprecise they seem now.

title:
Numismatics;
A NEW MEDAL FOR 'IVANHOE'S' REBECCA
description: Readers of "Ivanhoe," the novel by Sir Walter Scott, probably never knew that the heroine, Rebecca, was patterned on an American woman, Rebecca Gratz. A forthcoming medal will mark her induction into the Jewish-American Hall of Fame at the Magnes Museum in Berkeley, Calif. Its issuance on March 4, the 200th anniversary of her birth, will also spotlight the many accomplishments of this truly remarkable woman.

title: Triocala, Wayward Lass Aqueduct Stakes Victors
description: Triocala, trained by Frank (Pancho) Martin, won the $53,900 Rockaway Stakes, and Wayward Lass, trained by Martin's son, Jose, won the $56,000 Busanda Stakes yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: AMERICAN OUTBACK
description: TOOOLDTOCRY By Paul Hemphill. 249 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $11.95. By DAN WAKEFIELD

title: How to Get There
description: Here are the hours, admission fees and a description of public transportation to the 71st National Boat Show, which opened yesterday at the Coliseum in Columbus Circle, between West 58th and 60th Streets.

title: Japanese Premier in Thailand
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki visited King Phumiphol Aduldet today and gave him three station wagons, two pickup trucks and two bulldozers for use by northern hill tribes, Japanese officials said. The vehicles are worth $155,000. Mr Suzuki is on the final leg of a 12-day tour of Southeast Asian nations.

title: Virginia 85, Georgia Tech 48
description: Undefeated Virginia overcame a sluggish start and went on to rout Georgia Tech, 85-48, behind the hot shooting of Jeff Lamp tonight in an A.C.C. game.

title: Bullets 103, Spurs 93
description: Elvin Hayes poured in 27 points and grabbed 15 rebounds to pace injury-riddled Washington. The Bullets, playing without Wes Unseld, may have lost high-scoring Kevin Grevey, who left early in the third quarter to have his injured jaw X-rayed.

title: New York Times Magazine January 18, 1981
description: William Safire 6 On Language Getting Down Russell Baker 10 Sunday Observer Jimmy Stewart's Best Friend Leslie H. Gelb 14 Memorandum to the President Some counsel for the new man in the Oval Office from an old Washington hand. Deborah Trustman 18 France's First Woman 'Immortal' The election of the writer and poet Marguerite Yourcenar to the hitherto all-male French Academy is casting the reticent Maine resident in unaccustomed limelight.

title: Investing
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''Appraising the Appraiser'' (Jan. 4): He hedges with fate - a collectible merged with his treasures as advised by his peers - all seers. Sure things Guaranteed in his mirage. GEORGE MARQUISEE Forest Hills, N.Y., Jan. 4, 1981

title: A CODE IS SOUGHT TO CURB HEAT LOSS
description: With New York City in the grip of a cold wave, one of the two jobs currently being filled by Mary Brennan at the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development has taken on an extra sense of urgency. That is her role as assistant commissioner of the Office of Energy Conservation.

title: RACISM IS ISSUE IN CLASH OVER NEW ORLEANS MONUMENT
description: A granite obelisk inscribed with the words ''white supremacy,'' used in the past as a rallying point for the Ku Klux Klan, has become the object of protest here since Mayor Ernest N. Morial announced that the city administration was taking steps to put the monument in storage.

title: U.S. and Canada Dispute Salmon Pact's Prospects
description: Efforts to devise an international treaty aimed at insuring a fair harvest of the wide-ranging Atlantic salmon are continuing, although Canada, the world's major salmon-producing nation, is troubled by the attitude of the American negotiators.

title: SEA DRIVE EXAMPLE OF REFINED ENGINES
description: DESPITE the claims of disbelievers, the internal combustion piston engine will survive for a while as the primary source of power for land and marine vehicles. No other system will be sufficiently proven or ready to go into large-scale production within the next generation. The familiar internal combustion system, however, is not static. It constantly evolves, improves, and finds new expressions, as the current world of marine power demonstrates. Nothing is radically different, but much has been refined. The prize for originality in 1981 goes to Outboard Marine Corporation for its Sea Drive system for applying outboard power to larger boats. The system, developed from Evinrude's experiments two years ago with a pair of big outboards on a Bertram 28 convertible, amounts to a modified outboard - either a V-6 or a V-4 - mounted in a special bracket that obviates the need for a low transom, but which provides full-tilt and trim. Stored in Separate Tank The power head has reworked ignition timing and carburetion for superior torque in the cruising speed range, and the mounting bracket allows the wiring and air duct to be brought inboard, out of the way of a following sea. For the convenience of long-range cruisers, the Sea Drive units have oil injection. That is, two-cycle oil need not be mixed with the fuel. Rather, the oil supply is stored in a separate tank and injected into the motor by a pump that varies the rate of injection according to engine speed.

title: Mary Ann Lasson, Joseph F. Dryer 3d To Marry April 25
description: Mary Ann Lasson, an art consultant with Gallery New York, a division of the Circle Fine Art Corporation, and Joseph F. Dryer 3d of New York, an international management trainee in the Latin American division of Manufacturers Hanover Trust, plan to be married April 25 in St. Edward's Roman Catholic Church in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Clocks and Quakes
description: It was a clock that could measure time to a trillionth of a second and remain accurate to a millionth of a second over three years, and a report a year ago this month said that the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory had developed it.

title: French Canal Barges To the Editor:$
description: The article ''On France's Burgundy Canal'' (Travel Section, Dec. 28) was especially interesting to us because just last summer we made the trip from the Mediterranean to the Atlantic on the Canal du Midi, which cuts across the south of France to Bordeaux. Our experiences were much the same as those described in the article, since we made our way through countless locks, shopping in the villages, getting acquainted with other boat people and enjoying the beautiful countryside. v. e had come down by the same route four years ago to spend some time cruising in the Mediterranean and the Aegean. Now going back, we observed many changes, ''improvements,'' if you will - more electric locks, more fleets of do-it-yourself boats and more traffic in general. Some of the grain and wine barges are now hotel barges with all the amenities.

title: Borg, Lendl Win To Gain Today's Final in Masters
description: Jimmy Connors won the battle for respect but lost another match with Bjorn Borg yesterday in the semifinals of the $400,000 Volvo Masters tennis tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: BROWN SAYS AN ACCORD WON'T MAKE TEHERAN INTO A 'BUDDY' OF U.S.
description: Secretary of Defense Harold Brown has cautioned that while the release of the American hostages in Teheran ''would remove a completely disabling factor in United States-Iran relations,'' it ''would not make the United States and Iran instant buddies.''

title: CARNEGIE HALL AND TENANTS WRANGLE OVER RENT RISES
description: Eviction notices have been sent to a group of artists living or working in studios and apartments at Carnegie Hall who have refused to pay what they consider steep rent increases.

title: Miss Navratilova Gains Final With Miss Jaeger
description: Martina Navratilova broke Barbara Potter's serve in the fifth game of the second set tonight and went on to a 6-3, 6-2 victory in the semifinals of a $150,000 Avon tennis tournament.

title: DEBATING THE ROLE OF PSYCHIATRISTS IN LIFE AND ON FILM
description: To the Editor:

title: Speaking Personally; OUR HOMES HAVE BECOME OUR CASTLES UNDER SIEGE
description: I GREW UP in Jersey City in a house protected by a burglar-alarm system. Installed after our home was robbed for the second time, it was quickly integrated into our normal routines: Set the alarm and release the timer before leaving, run and ''dial in'' within two minutes of returning home.

title: BIRTHPLACE OF EX-SLAVE IN VIRGINIA DESIGNATED A NATIONAL LANDMARK
description: The birthplace of Lott Cary, an American missionary to Africa better known in Liberia than in his native Virginia, has been designated a national landmark for inclusion in the National Register of Historic Places.

title: WHERE N.J. LEADS, 16 STATES FOLLOW
description: SINCE 1974, when New Jersey became the first, 16 other states have adopted some form of public campaign financing. They are Hawaii, Idaho, Iowa, Kentucky, Maryland, Maine, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Montana, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Oregon, Rhode Island, Utah and Wisconsin.

title: Food; CORRECTION
description: In the list of ingredients for the coconut-cake recipe in the Dec. 28, 1980, issue, the amount of baking powder required should have been three teaspoons.

title: Cynthia Robb, R. D. Stevens To Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Randolph L. Robb of East Aurora, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia B. Robb, to Raymond D. Stevens 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stevens Jr. of Buffalo.

title: 17 Hurt in Nebraska Motel Fire
description: Fire swept through a Holiday Inn last night, and more than 200 guests fled smoke-filled rooms and hallways. Officials said 17 persons were taken to hospitals and six were admitted, one with serious burns.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Happy Fiscal Days Are Here Again, Sings the Mayor
description: Not that he really needed the boost, since it appears he'll face only token opposition, but Mayor Koch last week gave New Yorkers the kind of news a politician loves to give in an election year. He unveiled a new four-year financial plan that envisions balanced budgets with no new taxes and promises added services within a year in several highly visible areas, most notably police protection.

title: VOTING SAFEGUARDS PROPOSED
description: IF Barbara B. Kennelly, the Secretary of the State, has her way, the days of Connecticut's ''honor system'' of voting in elections may be numbered.

title: DESIGNER GOWNS FOR THE HOSPITAL
description: Humana Inc. of Louisville, Ky., a company that operates 90 hospitals, has an answer to the drab and drafty hospital gown. This month it will begin marketing a designer version of the traditional hospital johnny.

title: PRINCETON AND EXECUTORS CLASH ON EINSTEIN PAPERS
description: Last week, as a prolonged legal battle over publication of the vast collection of Dr. Albert Einstein's papers neared a climax, Princeton University announced that its library was making photocopies of the 43,000 documents available to qualified scholars.

title: About Westchester
description: SHARON LATIMER, 20 years old, was studying civil engineering at Westchester Community College last spring. But trigonometry was making her feel like ''pulling my hair out,'' and she also needed to earn some money. So she took the following semester off, and enrolled in a program in which she would learn plumbing skills.

title: Susan G. Marino Is Married To James H. Doyle 3d on L.I.
description: Susan G. Marino, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Marino of Patchogue, L.I., was married there yesterday to James H. Doyle 3d of Hackensack, N.J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Doyle Jr. of Belle Harbor, Queens. The Rev. Kevin Gruber performed the ceremony in St. Francis deSales Roman Catholic Church.

title: HILTON PUTS OFF PLANS FOR ATLANTIC CITY CASINO-HOTEL
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation says it has postponed plans to build a $250 million, 700-room casino hotel in this city's marina area.

title: CHRYSLER
description: Chrysler won tentative approval last week of $400 million in rescue funds from the Government.

title: LOMAX EXCELS AS NORTH WINS SENIOR BOWL, 23-10
description: David Overstreet of Oklahoma and Clifford Chatman of Central Oklahoma State scored touchdowns and Penn State's Herb Menhardt kicked three field goals as the North overpowered the South, 23-10, today in the 32d Senior Bowl game.

title: THE PITFALLS IN AIDING CHINA'S MILITARY BUILDUP
description: To the Editor:

title: LAWYERS AND AVOIDING TAXES
description: L AWYERS for tax shelter promoters are anxiously awaiting the tax package which the Reagan administration will soon present to Congress. The ink will hardly be dry on the new law before they rush to redesign their shelter deals to squeeze out every last dollar of tax benefit. But they should pause to pose a question to themselves: Are they doing their duty?

title: Nuts
description: To the Business Editor: One frequently sees macademia for macadamia, as happened in ''Profits From Macademia Nuts'' (Dec. 21).

title: GREENWICH GIRL SETS RECORD AS RUNNER
description: GREENWICH CURIOSITY would seem to dictate that Ceci Hopp look back more often in a cross-country race. After all, that's where her rivals usually are while trying in vain to overtake the swift and supremely confident 17-year-old Greenwich High School running phenomenon.

title: BOARD OF EXAMINERS IS FEELING CRITICISM
description: New York City's Board of Examiners, created at the turn of the century to eliminate patronage in the appointment of teachers and supervisors, has become bogged down in internal dissension and bureaucratic delays that are lessening its ability to carry out the functions of a new era, according to education officials and some members of the board.

title: Jackie Glassberg Is Bride Of Stanley M. Friedman
description: Jackie Gordon Glassberg of Forest Hills, Queens, administrative manager of the New York City Office of Special Events, was married yesterday to Stanley M. Friedman of Riverdale, the Bronx, chairman of the Bronx County Democratic Committee. Rabbi Shulen Rubin performed the ceremony at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof.

title: WOMEN AND THE CHURCH
description: Women and The Church

title: Theresa Mara To Be a Bride
description: Theresa Louise Mara, a corporate credit analyst with the Chemical Bank, and William Henderson Woolverton 3d, a lawyer with the New York firm of Carter, Ledyard & Milburn, will be married June 27 in St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church.

title: SALE OF FRENCH PUBLISHER RAISES BOKMEN'S FEARS
description: The acquisition of controlling interest in Hachette, France's biggest publishing and distribution company, by Matra, a large communications and industrial conglomerate that manufactures and exports arms and missiles systems, has disturbed some French editors and publishers.

title: The Rogeri Trio Presents Works by Haydn and Ives
description: The Rogeri Trio, founded in 1976, has done quite a bit of performing in its relatively brief existence, but until Tuesday night it had not given a concert in New York. Appearing at Goodman Concert Hall, the ensemble -Richard Young, violinist; Carter Brey, cellist, and Barbara Weintraub, pianist - demonstrated its technical fluency, musicality and liveliness in Trios by Haydn (C major, Hob.

title: RICE SHORTAGE IN NIGERIA BRINGS CHARGES OF CORRUPTION
description: Despite the spectacular growth in Nigeria's oil income in recent years, the nation has been unable to keep up with the demand for rice, the price of which has tripled in the last six months.

title: No Headline
description: Constance Horner writes of the importance of parent-child communication about sex.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE MANIAC IN THE CELLAR Sensation Novels of the 1860's. By Winifred Hughes. 211 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. $15.

title: SOLDIERS AND CONSCIENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: South Carolina 91 Marquette 89
description: Zam Frederick had 31 points and Jimmy Foster added 20 to spark South Carolina to a 91-89 victory over Marquette tonight.

title: Wine; A GREAT VINEYARD REVIVED
description: isiting St. Emilion is a pilgrimage that every devotee of great wine contemplates and that many accomplish. The medieval village is carved into a hillside in the eastern reaches of Bordeaux, and it is a place where some of the world's greatest wines are made. Cobbled streets plunge and twist among ancient houses, and the limestone soil beneath the cobblestones is honeycombed with dark and humid caves containing not only millions of bottles of wine but also countless mushrooms cultivated for Bordeaux restaurants.

title: Jane D. Schurman, John Clark Womer Plan May 23 Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Taube Schurman of Woodbridge, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Donnell Schurman, to John Clark Womer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Womer of Moreland Hills, Ohio.

title:
Photography View;
A MIXED BAG OF EXHIBITONS
description: When Sandy Skoglund decided to become a photographer, the world lost a great department store window decorator. Or so it seems from her first New York exhibition, entitled ''Revenge of the Goldfish,'' at Castelli Graphics, 4 East 77th Street, through Jan. 31.

title: Pitt's Sherrill and Russo Of Wagner Are Honored
description: Jackie Sherrill, whose University of Pittsburgh team had an 11-1 record including a victory over South Carolina in the Gator Bowl, was named yesterday as winner of the Joseph M. Sheehan Memorial Award as Eastern major college football coach of the year. This is the second year in a row that Sherrill has won the award presented annually by the New York Football Writers Association.

title: High Jump to Williams at 7 Feet
description: Two days ago, Eldred Williams's leg muscles were so stiff he could not practice the high jump. Yesterday, the senior at the High School of Music and Art cleared a meet-record 7 feet in the 31st annual Cardinal Hayes Games at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: CRONKITE SCALES DOWN A DREAM OF SAILING ROUND THE WORLD
description: WALTER CRONKITE'S wife, Betsy, once quipped that her sailing husband would like to retire on a 60-footer with a 20-year-old mistress, but that it was more likely he would end up on a 20-footer with a 60-year-old mistress.

title: THE CLEVELAND BALLET TAKES TO THE ROAD
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- James Wood is arts editor of Cleveland Magazine. By JAMES WOOD CLEVELAND For the Cleveland Ballet's first performances outside its own hometown, a New York-Florida tour that opens Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the company leased five, 45-foot semitractor trailers.

title: Wine; FRANCE'S FORGOTTEN RED
description: The sun-drenched vineyard of Domaine de Beaucastel lies not far from the Rhone River in southeastern France, and its reddish soil is composed almost entirely of flat rocks the size of grapefruit. The rocks absorb the heat of the Mediterranean sun during the day and reflect it back onto the grapes, enabling them to achieve great ripeness. Then, at night, the heat stored in the rocks is released, keeping the vines warm and adding a further element to the ripening process. Delicious red wines are made from these grapes, wines sought by oenophiles all over the world.

title: Joane McLaughlin Sets June Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. McLaughlin of Great Kills, S.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joane Marie McLaughlin, to Charles F. Peterson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Peterson of Setauket, L.I., and Point Pleasant, N.J.

title: Cambodia Is Left Out of Parley
description: A spokesman for India's External Affairs Ministry said today that Cambodia had not been invited to next month's meeting of foreign ministers of nations calling themselves nonaligned. He said that India, which recognizes the Vietnam-installed regime in Cambodia, was abiding by the nonaligned nations' 1979 decision to keep the question of Cambodian representation in the organization open.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW HIGHWAY SIGNS ARE STIRRING DEBATE
description: In the last year, signs have sprung up along the interstate highways in New York that some people say bear a close resemblance to billboards.

title: NATIONAL ARCHIVES, A NATIONAL MEMORY
description: Robert W. Warner had never set foot inside a Congressional hearing room until last week. As Archivist of the United States, and so head of the National Archives and Records Service, he had come to tell the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that he could not produce requested logs summarizing taped conversations between former President Nixon and Alexander M. Haig Jr., then White House chief of staff and now Secretary of Statedesignate, until Mr. Nixon had a chance to object. (On Friday, Mr. Nixon exercised his option; if the Archives reject the objection, his attorneys will have five more days to file suit.)

title: Sports of The Times; For Rooneys, a Funeral and a Wedding
description: HE belonged in a movie, the legendary priest who was as tough as he was tender. His ordination name in the Franciscans was Father Silas Rooney but he had been baptized Daniel, one of Art Rooney's five younger brothers. As the Pittsburgh Steelers' cherished 79-year-old chairman, Art Rooney is the patriarch of the five Rooney sons (Dan, Art Jr., Tim, Pat and John) who operate the Steelers and three race tracks.

title: Arizona State 69, U.S.C. 55
description: Sam Williams scored a career-high 27 points, 23 in the second half, to lead Arizona State to a 69-55 victory over Southern California tonight.

title: TIPTOEING AROUND THE CENSOR IN POLAND
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Nina Darnton is a freelance writer who lives in Warsaw. By NINA DARNTON WARSAW For years Polish playwrights have dreaded the special preview, just before opening night, when they stage a command performance for an audience of one - the censor.

title: JEWELRY THAT'S MORE THAN AN ACCESSORY
description: The jewelry designed by Mary Ann Scherr includes necklaces, rings and bracelets that one might be happy not to need. But for women who have had a tracheotomy, who have lost part of a finger or who suffer from heart disease, Mrs. Scherr's designs serve as cosmetic cover-ups or medical alerts.

title: Georgetown 62, Syracuse 57
description: Eric Floyd scored 15 points tonight as he paced Georgetown to a 62-57 victory over Syracuse in a Big East Conference game.

title: A RAGE TO RECORD
description: THELIFEOFJOHNO'HARA By Frank MacShane. Illustrated. 274 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $15.95. By ALFRED KAZIN

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: Tennysonian poet.

title: Dallas Voters Defeat Plan To Cut Property Taxes 30%
description: One of the most sweeping tax cut plans since California's Proposition 13 was overwhelmingly rejected today as Dallas voters defeated a proposal that would have cut property taxes almost 30 percent.

title: ARE NUMBERS FUNNY?
Welcome Fadeout; On A.T.&.T. Trial
description: It may have been faintly foreshadowed, but the anticlimax could hardly be more dramatic. The historic antitrust trial pitting the Justice Department against American Telephone and Telegraph Company had been six years in preparation and was expected to last several more. Last week, after both sides announced they were near an agreement, a Federal judge for the District Court in Washington, D.C., halted the proceedings after only one day.

title: EX-CITY U. TEACHERS AWAIT RESTITUTION FOR DISMISSAL IN '50S
description: If nothing else, they have learned how to wait. There were 17 of them, all teachers at what is now the City University of New York and all dismissed nearly three decades ago, during the McCarthy period, for refusing to answer questions from a United States Senate judiciary subcommittee investigating membership in the Communist Party.

title: Homosexual Sergeant Released
description: Staff Sgt. Harold Bryant, who says he is a homosexual, has been discharged from the Air Force after the refusal of a Federal appeals court in Washington to block the action. Sergeant Bryant's attorneys said they would seek his reinstatement.

title: IN CAPITAL, NEW DAY FOR WINE
description: The nation's capital will be virtually awash in wine - American wine - during the inaugural celebrations this week as domestic producers from coast to coast deluge Washington with thousands of bottles donated in efforts to capitalize on what is perceived as a more open attitude toward wine at the White House. It may be the most intensive public relations effort undertaken by the industry since the repeal of Prohibition.

title: Miss Geer Fiancee Of William Bilbao
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. Geer of Manhattan have made kown the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Clayton Geer, to William E. Bilbao, son of Mr. and Mrs. Santiago P. Bilbao of St. George, S.I.

title: DOHRN GOT PROBATION, BUT WHAT OF THE OTHERS
description: In a Chicago courtroom last week, Bernardine Dohrn, the former Weather Underground leader, was fined $1,500 and placed on probation for three years. Before the sentencing, Miss Dohrn, who recently emerged from 10 years in hiding, pleaded guilty to charges stemming from violent protests against the Vietnam War.

title: STREET VENDORS PROVIDEE BASICS TO INDONESIANS
description: Away from the high-rise splendor of modern business districts and without the benefits of shelter from rain or tropical sun, street merchants provide the most basic level of Indonesian commerce - one man, one service.

title:
Gardening;
EVERYDAY VS. SCIENTIFIC NAMES FOR PLANTS
description: THE other day I came across a problem, really very simple, that required four reference books for a solution. I wished to look up information about the dogtooth violet, but the name was not listed in the first three books consulted.

title: TV View; CABLE FARE- AT A CROSSROADS
description: tv pg REVISED goodman

title:
LETTER FROM DUBLIN;
THE WRITING OF TALKERS
description: ONE expects books to loom large on the literary scene but, in Ireland, not so large as authors. Dublin never forgets that the national tradition is an oral one. Is there any other city in the world, I asked myself, where it is impossible to walk 100 yards without being stopped at every step of the way to listen to anecdotes? The oral tradition may explain what puzzled every publisher I talked to: the marked preference Irish writers show for the short-story form. Where Liam O'Flaherty, Frank O'Connor, Sean O'Faolain, Mary Lavin walked before them, a new generation is in hot pursuit. David Marcus is as much responsible for this as any single person, by his page every week in The Irish Press given to new Irish writing, and his foresight in helping to found the Poolbeg Press five years ago. This enterprise is flourishing, reprinting established Irish writers as well as newcomers - for the most part women.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Lame Duck Limps To Trenton Podium
description: Beginning the last year of his second and last term, Governor Byrne's opportunity for arm-twisting is running out. But that didn't stop him from unveiling an ambitious legislative program in his State of the State message last week, even if his goals seemed to the statehouse audience more wishful than political.

title: Kathryn Nay, Actress, Engaged
description: The engagement of Kathryn Ann Nay to Dr. Lucius Dubignon Clay 3d has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Howard Riley Nay of Tenafly, N.J., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of General Clay Jr., U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Clay of Colorado Springs and a grandson of the late General Clay, commander of United State Forces in Europe and Military Governor of Germany following World War II.

title: Mets Are 8th Stop for Roberts
description: David Arthur Roberts is impatient for the beginning of his 13th majorleague baseball season, as he spends time in Houston installing underground water sprinkler systems and helping coach junior high school boys in basketball.

title: U.S. LAW PASSED FOR PENSIONS AT THE NEW YORKER
description: Some of the writers and artists at The New Yorker magazine were so upset that they felt they had been thrown out of the family. But since President Carter signed a piece of special legislation late last month, things have been getting back to normal in the magazine's offices at 25 West 43d Street.

title: Oregon State 82, Oregon 55
description: Steve Johnson scored 18 of his 24 points in the second half today to lead No.1-ranked Oregon State to a 82-55 Pacific 10 Conference rout of Oregon.

title: Oklahoma Schoolboy Sets Pole-Vault Mark of 17-4
description: A Marlow, Okla., student had a national high school indoor best in the pole vault today, clearing 17 feet 4 inches at the Oklahoma Track Coaches Winter Games.

title: ONE WOMAN VS. THE HALEDON POLICE FORCE
description: HALEDON JANET SHAW is - depending on who's doing the talking - a qualified cop and a classic victim of sex discrimination, or a troublemaker who sought special treatment and didn't do her job. Or the answer doesn't matter, since some people here think that women shouldn't be cops in the first place and Janet Shaw ought to go home.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: A.T.&.T. AND U.S. CLOSE IN ON A SETTLEMENT
description: A.T.&T. reached what was termed an ''essentially complete'' settlement with the Justice Department that would end a six-year-old antitrust case. The surprise accord was announced by Federal Judge Harold H. Greene on the second day of trial. Further proceedings were delayed until Feb. 2. The Government had sought divestiture of Western Electric and Bell Labs.

title: ALTERATIONS
description: Smart marketers know that people will buy almost anything by mailalarm watches that play Beethoven, books on how to meet girls, and more. But there is nothing so diverting about the latest mail-order offer.

title: EDWARD ISAACS
description: Edward Isaacs, executive chairman of the accounting firm of Edward Isaacs & Company, died of a heart attack Friday at Stamford Hospital. Mr. Isaacs, who was a resident of Westport, Conn., was 74 years old.

title: How to Enjoy; A Healthy Marriage:; Please Don't Smoke
description: To selfish reasons for quitting, smokers may now add altruistic ones. Results of a major Japanese study published in the British Medical Journal last week indicated that nonsmoking wives exposed to their husbands' cigarette smoke developed lung cancer at a much higher rate than abstaining wives of nonsmoking husbands.

title: The Down Home World of Richard Todd
description: Richard Todd was at ease and a world away from New York, the place where his stomach often churns anticipating boos at Shea Stadium.

title: U.C.L.A. 79, Arizona 76
description: Darren Day's 12-foot jump shot with two seconds remaining lifted U.C.L.A. to a 79-76 victory over Arizona tonight.

title: ARTS OF INDIA AT COLUMBIA
description: More than 15 ensembles from the Northeastern United States who present the folk dances and music of India will compete for cash prizes tomorrow at 4 P.M. in an Indian Day celebration in the Wollman Auditorium of Columbia University, Broadway and 116th Street.

title: HOW TO SURVIVE THE WINTER BREAK
description: BY the time our daughter went off to college, we had read dozens of booklets that helped prepare us for just about every aspect of the experience. We learned how to evaluate a school, what things to consider when choosing a course of study, how to apply for financial aid.

title: PRICES DOWN ON DRESSING UP
description: CALVIN KLEIN, Pierre Cardin, Yves Saint Laurent and many other lofty American and European designer names are being sold at less than lofty prices at thousands of stores across the country. Due to growing price-consciousness among middle-income and even affluent consumers, there has been a burgeoning recently in the number of outlets that sell brand-name clothing at prices signficantly below those of conventional retailers.

title: Jean Lithgow Paul Wed To Dr. Oglesby Paul
description: Jean Lithgow Paul, widow of the Rev. James A. Paul, was married in New York yesterday afternoon to Dr. Oglesby Paul, a cardiologist, of Dedham, Mass. The ceremony was performed in the chapel of St. James Episcopal Church by Bishop Horace W.B. Donegan, retired of New York.

title: No Headline
description: The cautious mood that has enveloped the families of the hostages after each new disappointment in their long vigil began to return yesterday as their loved ones remained in captivity.

title: St. Francis 69, Baltimore 64
description: Mark Woods and Kevin Henry combined for 40 points to lead St. Francis to a 69-64 victory over Baltimore Saturday night. The game was tied at 44-44 with 12:14 left, when the Terriers (3-11) outscored the Super Bees, 15-4, to take a 59-48 lead. Baltimore (2-12) battled back to within 3, but clutch free throws by Ken Berry and Henry insured the victory.

title: Undercover Tavern
description: The place was called the Scotland Yard Tavern. It was really an undercover front in Denver for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in 1978 and 1979.

title: CODEX LEICESTER ADDS TO THE INAUGURAL LUSTER
description: As of 10 A.M. today and through next Sunday, Leonardo da Vinci's Codex Leicester, the annotated scientific manuscript that fetched $5.8 million when it was sold by Christie's in London last month, will be on view at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington as part of the inaugural celebrations. Made available to the gallery by Dr. Armand Hammer, its owner, the manuscript is being shown in such a way that visitors can scrutinize the front and the back of every one of its 36 sheets. At no time in its nearly 500-year history, therefore, has the codex been so accessible.

title: PITFALLS IN LOFT UPGRADING TRIP THE UNWARY
description: Buyers of raw or semi-raw loft space usually learn the hard way some of the unglamorous details of dealing with contractors and developers and setting up a co-op.

title: ...AND A MUSEUM LIKE TRUMAN, DOWN-TO-EARTH
description: Visiting a Presidential library when a President is about to be inaugurated is like visiting Cooperstown during the World Series: It becomes less a journey into history and more a reminder of current events. That was especially true recently of the Harry S. Truman Library and Museum in Independence, Mo., because the place is as down-to-earth and contemporary as feisty H.S.T. himself.

title: Long Island Journal
description: THE Eglevsky Ballet's ''Nutcracker'' did not do as well as the company expected at the Adelphi-Calderone Theater in Hempstead this season. Suffering perhaps because balletgoers had been accustomed to watching the ballet at the Nassau Coliseum, the company broke even and did not get the financial cushion it wanted for the winter and spring seasons.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Tests Show Arson In Stouffer's Fire
description: Almost before it was extinguished, officials of Stouffer's Inn had concluded that last month's fire, killing 26 persons at the hotel's conference center, was deliberate. Last week, Westchester District Attorney Carl A. Vergari concurred.

title: Nuclear Power, Pollution And Human Rights
description: In characterizing my comments about nuclear coercion as the creation of ''a special definition of human rights for the nuclear power industry,'' Herbert Jaffe (in ''Nuclear Power and the Need for Energy: More Opinions'') selectively ignores the fact that my premise encompassed other forms of pollution besides nuclear power. The very existence of a strong and growing environmental movement in the United States, ever since Rachel Carson sounded the alarm, is proof that when people are informed they will not submit to violation of their human rights.

title: Nancy A. Edmondson Fiancee of James Richard Tarolli
description: The engagement of Nancy Ann Edmondson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Clagstone Edmondson of Pound Ridge, N.Y., to James Richard Tarolli, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Dominick Tarolli of Syracuse, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A June 6 wedding is planned in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: ART
description: With his first solo exhibition in a New York gallery, John Stuart Ingle makes a notable contribution to the current movement in Realist painting. Indeed, this 47-year-old painter, a resident of Minnesota, is something of a discovery.

title: Chargers' Ex-Coach Given Another Post With Team
description: The San Diego Chargers announced today that Jack Pardee, dismissed as head coach of the Washington Redskins last month, has been hired as ''assistant head coach in charge of defense.''

title: ON DISCOVERING HOME AFTER A LIFETIME'S JOURNEY
description: TWO years in western Connecticut and I'm showing early promise of becoming a rugged individualist. To be sure, Washington, Conn., isn't exactly the backwoods wilderness of, say, the Ozark highlands of southern Missouri, but for someone who has spent all his adult life in Kansas City, Boston, New York City and Washington, D.C., water well pumps and septic tank systems were once remote things associated with a romantic yesteryear. Yet, here I am, periodically adjusting the air pressure valves of our water tank or worrying about the capacity of the septic tank every time clusters of our city friends visit, stay too long, and unnecessarily use I should say, abuse - the systems.

title: Michael Wright and Caroline Rand Herron; The 40th President Plans a Fast Pace After Inauguration
description: Ronald Reagan, who has made the most of an appealing personality, a shrewd band of associates and a timely brand of conservatism, moves onto one of the biggest stages of them all day after tomorrow. Last week, the President-elect and his supporting cast began blocking out a detailed scenario for the new administration's first few weeks.

title:
Leisure;
IT'S TIME TO PLAN A HOME ORCHARD
description: Although George Washington may have favored cherries, New York nurserymen report it would not be "telling a lie" to say that apples - especially the dwarf and semi-dwarf trees - are their strongest sellers for spring planting.
