Sales volume for fruit trees has risen dramatically this year as home growers try to offset the effects of double-digit inflation and spiraling costs of the family market basket.

title: Roosevelt Clerks Vote Strike
description: The parimutuel clerks union voted last night to strike Roosevelt Raceway when that harness track opens a 66-night meeting Monday night. Local 23293 of the AFL-CIO took the unanimous action at a membership meeting in Mineola.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: FIRESNAKE The Railroad That Changed East Africa. By Francine Jacobs. Illustrated by Lloyd Bloom. 95 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co.

title: QUOTATION
description: ''An enormous but friendly elephant, somewhat of a slow thinker, stumbling through the regulatory jungle. The elephant can't quite figure out what its regulatory masters want, but there is that feeling that the beast can at any time reach out, reach out and crush someone.'' - Gerald A. Connell, attorney for the Justice Department describing the American Telephone and Telegraph Company at the opening of the trial on Thursday between the United States and the Bell System.

title: PHILIP CAPUTO
description: Four years ago ''Rumor of War,'' Philip Caputo's widely-acclaimed memoir of his combat experience in Vietnam, appeared briefly on the nonfiction best-seller list. Now ''Horn of Africa,'' his novel about soldiers of fortune in Ethiopia, appeared on the fiction best-seller list last week. Add to that a Pulitzer Prize in 1972 for reporting on voter fraud in his hometown, Chicago, and it would seem that the 39-year-old former foreign correspondent leads a charmed life.

title: Stage View; A BUBBLING AND BOUNCY STAGING OF 'PIRATES OF PENZANCE'
description: The New York Shakespeare Festival's ''Pirates of Penzance'' is innocence unalloyed and doodling unlimited - I loved the innocence but am going to question some of the doodling - and now that it's finally found its way from Central Park to the midtown Uris I'm sure its very guilelessness of soul will guarantee its continued, galloping success. After all, who among your acquaintances is prepared to resist the radiantly rapacious smile of a buccaneer too tender-hearted to prey upon orphans, who would dare avert his gaze from an ingenue whose blushing sweetness is the purest steel?

title: FARMS: THE COST SPIRAL
description: Energy prices, higher interest rates and more costly feed and livestock prices have caused a tripling of production costs on the nation's farms in the last decade. And the prices they get have not kept pace, according to Jeffrey Miller, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.

title: Maryland Subdues Clemson in Overtime
description: Albert King scored 22 points, including 6 in overtime, as Maryland outlasted Clemson, 68-62, in an Atlantic Coast Conference basketball game today.

title: HARTFORD RESIDENTS SWAP WORK FOR PPOPERTY TAXES
description: HARTFORD WHEN Matthew Zivich, a 68-year-old retired musician, offers his regular nostalgic weekend sing-along to a crowd of about 90 elderly people at the Center House senior center, he isn't exactly singing for his supper. It's more a matter of crooning for his castle - a one-bedroom cottage in the South End of the city that he is trying to keep going despite rising property taxes and maintenance costs.

title: Creighton 54, Bradley 51
description: George Morrow's 22 points sparked Creighton to a 54-51 victory over Bradley today.

title: BRAVE NEW ECONOMIC WORLD
description: THEECONOMICCRISISAND AMERICANSOCIETY By Manuel Castells. 285 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. Cloth, $20. Paper, $7.50. DECADEOFDECISION The Crisis of the American System. By Michael Harrington. 354 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $11.95. By MANCUR OLSON

title: OPERA: BRONX COMPANY
description: In recent years, the Bronx Opera has made quite a name for itself presenting exotica from the past. But Friday night at Hunter College the company came up with a particularly interesting double bill of comic operas by Romantic composers better known for their serious works, Weber's ''Abu Hassan'' and Mussorgsky's ''The Fair at Sorochinsk.''

title: SWINGING THROUGH SAN JUAN
description: MACHOCAMACHO'SBEAT By Luis Rafael Sanchez. Translated by Gregory Rabassa. 213 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $10.95. By JEROME CHARYN

title:
Gardening;
EVERYDAY VS. SCIENTIFIC NAMES FOR PLANTS
description: THE other day I came across a problem, really very simple, that required four reference books for a solution. I wished to look up information about the dogtooth violet, but the name was not listed in the first three books consulted.

title: A Murder Charge Is Considered In Death 20 Years After Shooting
description: Fred Ray was 34 when he was shot on Sept. 11, 1960. He was 54 when he died last November as a result of that shooting, and the authorities are considering whether the man who shot him should now be charged with murder.

title: Consumer Prices
description: To the Business Editor: Prof. Alfred E. Kahn's protest about the Consumer Price Index in a letter ''Kahn and the C.P.I.'' (Dec. 28) is misleading. The cost of housing and automobiles should be included in the C.P.I. Naturally, his facetious comment about securities being included in the C.P.I. is merely to cloud the issue. Shelter and transportation are essential, securities are not.

title: Music View; DICHOTOMIES, UNCERTAINTIES AND LIMITS OF TASTE
description: The human race is divided evenly between those who collect trash and those who do not. The blessed are those who do not: they save not string, neither do they hoard old magazines or concert programs. Above all, they certainly do not fill desk drawers with scraps of paper on which are scribbled wispy hints of ideas whose relevance no longer can be determined. If the non-collector does happen to put an idea down on a slip of paper he loses it immediately. His days are uncluttered and filled with bliss.

title: BYRNE'S BRAINCHILD BEGINS TO LOOK LIKE A MONSTER
description: TRENTON WHEN he was first elected in 1973, Governor Byrne made enactment of a public campaign financing law his top priority. Since then he has watched the law grow to cover the gubernatorial primaries as well as the general election and has seen the field of potential candidates in this year's race swell to 20.

title: LIFESAVING SPRINKLERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Diane Patricia Krisinger Bride of to Charles Meyer
description: Diane Patricia Krisinger and Charles H. Meyer, both of Pound Ridge, N Y., were married yesterday in Stamford, Conn. The Rev. George Eckstein performed the ceremony in the Long Ridge Congregational Church.

title: Black Hawks Win Sixth in Row, 3 to 2
description: Al Secord scored and snapped a 2-2 tie at 16:26 of the third period last night, lifting the Chicago Black Hawks to a 3-2 victory over the Whalers at Hartford. The victory extended the Black Hawks' winning streak to six games.

title:
Dining Out;
ODE TO A LIVELY GREEK SUPPER CLUB
description: WITH certain restaurants, the food is secondary to other factors in the enjoyment of an evening. Such is the case at Molfetas 46, a lively Greek supper club just opposite Teterboro Airport in South Hackensack. And why the 46? Because the club is on U.S. 46. It is owned by Spiros Molfetas, who founded Molfetas restaurant on Manhattan's West Side.

title: NEW FEDERAL COURT MAY OPEN THIS YEAR
description: IT appears that after five years of preparation and waiting, lawyers from Westchester and other New York State counties are finally going to get their day in Federal District Court.

title: OFF WHOSE BACK?
description: During the election campaign, Ronald Reagan repeatedly raised the cry, "Let's get the Government off our backs!" It is arguable whether politicians take their own slogans seriously, but, alas, often those slogans prove effective.The minds of many citizens have been captured by the notion that theG overnment is a latter-day Leviathan that crushes individual i nitiative while hogging and wasting resources that otherwise would a llow for the prosperous workings of a free economy. Hence, Mr. R eagan's slogan was effective to the extent that it reinforced the m yth that the Government has been the relentless adversary of the p rivate sector and of all the good things it offers the people. But n o matter how tenacious myths may be, the facts about the historic r elationship in the United States between government and the p rivate-enterprise system ought to be made clear so that the public c an have the opportunity to put government's role in perspective.

title: HAITIANS IN BAHAMAS FACE EXIT DEADLINE
description: The deadline for Haitians living illegally in the Bahamas to leave the country is midnight tomorrow. Yesterday, the Haitian Consul's office was packed with thin, worried men and women seeking travel documents.

title: Nerve Gas Bomb Move Planned
description: The Pentagon announced yesterday that it planned to move 888 Weteye nerve gas bombs from the Rocky Mountain Arsenal in Denver to the Tooele Army Depot in Utah. The action marks the third change in policy since 1978. But the issue may end up in the courts because Gov. Scott M. Matheson of Utah has threatened legal action to block the shipment of the Navy bombs into his state.

title: Squeezing, Hoping In Chrysler Talks
description: By now, Chrysler Corporation managers are used to cliffhangers. But even by their own standards, last week may have been a bit much.

title: CINEMATIC ECHOES
description: PORTTROPIQUE By Barry Gifford. 185 pp. Berkeley, Calif.: Creative Arts Book Company. Cloth, $9.95. Paper, $5.95. THEINTERCEPTORPILOT By Kenneth Gangemi. 127 pp. Salem, N.H.: Marion Boyars Publishers, Inc. $11.50. By JONATHAN BAUMBACH

title: Irish Terrorists; Hit New Targets
description: Bernadette Devlin McAliskey, the fiery Irish republican orator and former member of the British Parliament, left home last month and led sympathy marches in support of jailed Ulster republicans fasting to attain political prisoner status. She and her husband, Michael, evidently returned home too soon.

title: MORAL TRAINING IS A DESIDERATUM
description: WHAT would our self-appointed libertarian guardians do with themselves without some cause to wring their hands over?It was 230 years ago that Jean Jacques Rousseau already realized the hopelessness of trying to suppress books. He remarked, with some irony, in his ''First Discourse'':

title: 20 OF 100 FELONY ARRESTS ON L.I. LEAD TO PRISON, A HIGHER RATE THAN IN
description: CITY By BARRY ABRAMSON

title: THE STATELY HOME THAT IS THE WHITE HOUSE
description: When Ronald and Nancy Reagan take over the White House on Tuesday they will have to share it with l.5 million tourists who tramp through each year to see how the President lives. The Reagans also will be sharing the mansion's rooms and corridors with what Jacqueline Kennedy once called ''historic ghosts'' - perhaps Abigail Adams, with her basketful of laundry, interrupting the Garfield youngsters' pillow fights, or Herbert Hoover, hurrying to his daily game of horseshoes, stopping to chat with the ladies attending one of Dolley Madison's fashionable receptions.

title: Some Tips on Making Decoys at Home
description: WITH the waterfowl season over or drawing to a close across the nation, many hunters, unless they are extraordinarily well-equipped, must realize that they could benefit from more and better decoys.

title: BOLTS AND BRACKETS BY (COMPUTER) DESIGN
description: P ICTURE an engineer hovering over a tablet in front of a display screen that looks like a small television set. When the engineer draws on the tablet, the drawing appears on the screen.

title: Food Living; HEALTH-FOOD STORES BROADEN APPEAL
description: FOOD stores, with their light, natural wood interiors, rustic bins and hanging plants, have become commonplace in virtually every community on the Island. But now there are signs that the stores may be attracting a wider market.

title: A SHORT HISTORY OF '15 YEARS OF STUBBORNESS'
description: PRISCILLA McKENNA, president of the Englewood City Council, speaks of Flat Rock Brook as ''15 years of sheer stubbornness.'' She should know; most of it was her own.

title: Final Outrage
description: Rita Jenrette said she had endured her husband's alcoholism, forgiven his womanizing and, during his Abscam trial, publicly condemned Senator Strom Thurmond for calling him ''a lying skunk.'' But Mrs. Jenrette herself smelled a skunk when she looked in a closet in their Washington townhouse recently and found $25,000 in cash - her husband's. Last week, authorities said serial numbers on some of the bills matched those that John W. Jenrette, the former South Carolina Congressman, was convicted of taking in Abscam. Mrs. Jenrette was looking for a divorce lawyer.

title:
Art;
BOX AS THEME: TINY WORLDS OF FANTASY AND ILLUSION
description: HUNTINGTON WHEN the word ''box'' is used in a discussion of art, the name of Joseph Cornell automatically comes to mind. Although not the first or the only artist to build boxes to contain his works of assemblage, Cornell was by far the most prolific exponent of the form. The tiny worlds of fantasy, illusion and delight that he created are hermetically sealed in containers as idiosyncratic as their contents.

title: BRITISH ACTOR HAD ROLES IN JAMES BOND MOVIES
description: Bernard Lee, a British character actor who appeared in more than 100 films and was perhaps best known as the spy chief ''M'' in James Bond movies, died of cancer Friday at a London hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: INNOVATION IS VANISHING AT RAMAPO
description: MAHWAH EVEN on the bitterest of winter days, the sleek buildings on the Ramapo College campus here seem to give off a shimmering warmth. But the warmth - like the college's spirit of innovation and adventure - is an illusion that runs no deeper than the buildings' mirrored facades.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. SENDING SALVADOR WEAPONS AND SUPPLIES VALUED AT $5 MILLION

title: KEEPING A WEATHER EYE ON CURRENT COMPONENTS
description: The coldest winter in ages is keeping people indoors, and those with musical interests are probably spending their housebound evenings in the company of their stereo systems.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
A Broken Streak On the Boardwalk
description: The house never loses, goes the gambler's lament. But last month the take in Atlantic City dipped to $47.9 million (from November's $59.5 million) and casino executives said last week that, for the first time since legal betting began on the Boardwalk, every house will come up short.

title:
Art;
INDIANS: UNTAINTED IMAGES
description: NEW CANAAN ''EDWARD S. CURTIS: Images of the American Indian'' is a striking exhibition at the PhotoGraphics Workshop in New Canaan that will be open until Jan. 27. Consisting of some 65 original photographs and photogravure prints, most from early in this century, the exhibition is comprehensive enough to give a good overall impression of Curtis's life work of documenting the American Indian in photographs. Because he was one of the greatest photographers this country has produced, his work has strong esthetic appeal as well.

title: INTEREST IN SITING OF CONENTION CENTER MOUNTS
description: IT'S become the saga of six cities plus one town in search of a multimillion-dollar convention center as the county gears up to render a decision, expected by late spring, on where and whether to go ahead with a project that could also involve offices, apartments and a new hotel.

title:
Stamps;
NEW U.S. COMMEMORATIVE FOR TOURO SYNAGOGUE
description: Acommemorative for the Touro Synagogue of Newport, R.I., the oldest existing Jewish house of worship in the country, will be issued by the United States in 1982. The stamp will commemorate the synagogue as a symbol of America's tradition of religious freedom and as an historic American building.

title: Chambers of Black Judge Defaced During Break-In
description: The chambers of a black State Supreme Court justice were ransacked and the letters ''KKK'' scrawled on the walls sometime between Friday night and yesterday morning, the police said yesterday. The chambers of five other judges, all on the 17th floor of the Criminal Courts Building at 100 Centre Street in Manhattan, were also broken into and nine typewriters were stolen.

title: EX-NEW YORKERS HELP NEEDIEST
description: Fond memories of New York City inspire continuing support of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund by many former residents of the area.

title: DEBTS UNDER SHAH CLOUD ASSETS ISSUE
description: The release of the frozen Iranian assets held by American banks has been complicated by the variety of debts and obligations incurred by private and public Iranian institutions to American corporations and banks before the fall of the Shah.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
GETTING THE CORPORATE STRUCTURE UNDER CONTROL
description: T HE specter of the 1970's economic policy-making is the professor as Presidential adviser saying, ''Don't stand there, do something.'' In the Carter Administration, the something turned out to be the wrong policy package that year, and to be subject to reversal a year later just before the next election. The vision of the 1980's has to be the professor-adviser proposing a five-year plan and then each month repeating the admonition, ''don't do something, stand there'' on the plan.

title: BUSY BURGESS
description: Some authors have second-novel problems; others have 43d-book problems. For Anthony Burgess, one of the more prolific authors of our time, the only problem with his 43d book, ''Earthly Powers,'' published by Simon & Schuster, is that the 607-page novel took him a little longer than usual -''nearly 10 years in the creation, including research, living, thinking and writing.'' But please do not blame it on Princess Grace of Monaco.

title: OVER-AMPLIFIED?
description: To the Editor:

title: DEDE ALLEN CORRECTS THE RECORD
description: Dede Allen Corrects The Record

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: INFORMATION A RARE COMMODITY IN ALGERIA
description: The American Embassy swimming pool here stands empty in the weak winter sunlight. But for reporters covering the intricate, drawn-out negotiations over the release of the hostages in Iran, the most important thing is to have one of the swimming-pool passes that the embassy is issuing to accredited journalists. The pass allows them to hang around on the grounds of the big white Moorish villa on the hill overlooking Algiers bay, though they learn absolutely nothing.

title: Film View; SPECULATING ON TALENT:12 ACTORS TO WATCH IN 1981
description: Even though movies are not in great shape, there are at the moment an unusual number of interesting new performers, some of whom appear to be on the verge of becoming major stars. That doesn't mean they're all great actors. Acting ability has no relation to success in films unless it's associated with something else that defines an actor's particular presence. This ''something else'' can't be easily explained, being quite often a mysterious mixture of talent, manner, looks, hype and the performer's luck to have been where he was at the opportune time.

title: SALARIES
description: To the Editor:

title: GUERILLA CHIEF DISCUSSES GUNS, GOALS, WHITES
description: THE Carter Administration ran out of time last week in its fouryear effort, with Western European countries, to end the guerrilla war in South-West Africa. Declaring in Geneva that it would be ''premature'' to arrange a cease-fire now, Danie Hough, South Africa's administrator-general for the territory also called Namibia, brought negotiations under United Nations auspices to a standstill.

title: F.B.I. Chief Said to Praise Informer in Donovan Case
description: William H. Webster, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has said that the informer who made the allegations of improper acts by Raymond J. Donovan, Presidentelect Ronald Reagan's choice to be Secretary of Labor, had provided ''reliable'' information in the past, a staff aide of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee reported today.

title: BEYOND ENTRAPMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: REMEMBRANCES OF A RUSSIA PAST
description: SUZANNE MASSIE lifted the large poinsettia from the floor to a nearby table, saying, ''Van Cliburn has sent these every year, since the publication of 'Nicholas and Alexandra.' I know why the Russians loved him so. He is a warm, giving person.'' Robert and Suzanne Massie and their youngest daughter, Elizabeth, live in a cavernous Victorian house in Irvington with a long porch and a view of the Hudson.

title: FINDING AN OASIS OF CALM IN A WORLD FULL OF TROUBLE
description: INFLATION still gallops, unemployment remains chronic, the Mideast is still in a chaotic state and the Russian bear is again poised ready to devour, in ''Socialist Friendship,'' another of its smaller neighbors.

title: No Headline
description: In Constance Horner's article, Dr. Joseph Adelson of the University of Michigan is quoted as saying that ''strongly established heterosexuals'' would find a film which shows gay people speaking with self-respect about themselves ''just a piece of exotica.'' That most straight people would react to a decent and self-respecting gay person as an exotic curiosity is sad, if true.

title: Barbara Stern Is Betrothed To Craig Mitchell Patterson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ludwig Stern of Jackson Heights, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Terry Stern, to Craig Mitchell Patterson, son of Marjorie Kimball of Berkeley, Calif.

title: BUSINESS CONDITIONS
description: While critics and viewers continue to bemoan the sagging quality of American television, viewers in other industrial countries apparently hold Hollywood's product in somewhat higher esteem, especially since the dollar's decline has made them relatively cheap.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: MORE than 100 state leaders in business and education have been studying for a year the feasibility of creating a science/technology center in the north-central part of New Jersey. Such a center, they feel, would attract 1.6 million visitors annually.

title: STRONG INTUITIONS AND LURKING WIT
description: SELECTEDPOEMS By Mark Strand. 152 pp. New York: Atheneum. $10.95. By R. W. FLINT

title: SOUTH-WEST AFRICA: THE PLACE AND THE PLAYERS
description: South-West Africa, a sparsely populated, arid region twice the size of California, has been called Namibia at the United Nations since 1968.

title: Food; A DELICIOUSLY DEPRESSED CAKE
description: o our minds, one of the most interesting and curiously named pastries bears the name Mary Ann. Although we have been asked many times over the years, we have never been able to pinpoint the origin of this dessert's name, and we would give much to know.

title: MUSIC: BY ANTHONY DAVIS
description: Music that emphasizes repetition or stasis has probably been heard more often and in more permutations at the Kitchen than anywhere else in New York. This season has been a little different in that the new musical director, George Lewis, has been including more improvisational and jazz-related music.

title: About Long Island
description: ROSLYN DID Publlic School 158 in Brooklyn have a school nurse? I cannot remember. In those days, you did not go to doctors or nurses when you got sick. You only saw them when you were ready to die.

title: Ann Hutton Fiancee Of Henry J. Conley
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Hutton of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Christine Hutton, to Henry Jackson Conley, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Allison Conley of Stockton, Calif. A March 21 wedding is planned.

title: Notes; VACATIONING AT AN OVERSEAS UNIVERSITY
description: How would you like to spend your summer vacation studying at Oxford or Cambridge or Edinburgh? These learning vacations - in which you settle in at a great university abroad for a few weeks, take courses with recognized scholars and use your spare time to explore the country and its culture - are an attractive alternative for experienced adult travelers who are weary of the usual sightseeing tours and hotels. Many of these holidays also offer the opportunity for college credits; this need not, however, deter anyone from signing on purely for the joy of learning and the experience of living at a historic university.

title: Florida 74, Mississippi 71
description: Ronnie Williams scored 24 of his game-high 28 points in the second half to lead Florida to a 74-71 Southeastern Conference victory over Mississippi today.

title: Efforts in Massachusetts Said to Ease Gas Shortage
description: Gov. Edward J. King said today that conservation efforts were beginning to take hold for the first time since a natural gas shortage in Massachusetts came to the attention of officials.

title: MAYOR AND PRIEST SPAR IN A SMALL TOWN IN FRANCE
description: The snow is deep and the mountain air frigid, but tempers are running hot in this hamlet in eastern France. The Mayor has ousted the priest from the church rectory for nonpayment of rent, and a group of Roman Catholics has occupied the building, hoping to force the town to back down.

title: Douglas L. Boles Fiance Of Carolyn Donkervoet
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Cornelius Donkervoet of Baltimore have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Daralice Donkervoet, to Douglas Luce Boles, son of Dr. and Mrs. Russell Sage Boles Jr. of Wellesley, Mass.

title: Karen Horney
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG STRIKES STIR DEBATE ON UNIONS FOR NURSES
description: THe nurses at Syosset Hospital and at Brunswick Hospital in Amityville who went on strike last summer for improved working conditions, job security and higher wages are still on strike, but their numbers and support have dwindled, raising serious questions about the future of unionization of Long Island nursing.

title: KNICKS DEFEAT ROCKETS, 99 TO 98, oON
description: RUSSELL SHOT WITH 0:45 LEFT By United Press International

title: AIDES TO REAGAN SEEN AS SEEKING DISMISSAL OF 60 AT WHITE HOUSE
description: Aides to President-elect Ronald Reagan plan to dismiss about 60 nonpolitical White House employees who normally retain their jobs after a change in administrations, a source in the Carter Administration said today.

title: Blues 7, Oilers 6
description: Perry Turnbull scored two goals and set up Mike Crombeen for a score on a breakaway, helping St. Louis hold off a late Edmonton rush and preserving the victory.

title: MATUSZAK A FORCE IN RAIDERS PALNS
description: THE booth, a semicircle near the back of the hotel restaurant, is reserved on Saturday nights on weekends when the Oakland Raiders play at home. The booth is big enough to fit four people comfortably, but on those Saturday nights, before the Raiders are sent to their rooms the night before a game, it is filled by a party of one, a 6-foot-8-inch, 280-pound defensive end.

title: Twists and Turns In Abscam Maze
description: While no one has yet unraveled the Abscam web, more rips appeared. In ordering the Justice Department to turn over thousands of documents to lawyers appealing the corruption convictions of four former or present Congressmen, Judge George C. Pratt in Federal District Court in Brooklyn last week joined colleagues in Philadelphia and Washington who have questioned the concept as well as the conduct of the undercover operation.

title: CUTBACKS EXPECTED IN TRANSIT SUBSIDIES
description: WASHINGTON ASKED recently about the future of Federal operating subsidies for the state's rail and bus lines, a top New Jersey mass-transit official offered a sobering assessment.

title: No Headline
description: MICHIGAN UPSET BY IOWA, 73-58

title: TRIO SEEKS TO WIDEN THE ROLE OF WOMEN
description: SPURRED by the women's movement, three gifted freelance musicians joined forces eight years ago to form the Teaneck-based Walden Trio. Today, it is one of the busiest and most versatile of the state's chamber-music ensembles.

title: Connecticut Journal; WATER: DOWN... O'NEILL'S PENSION :UP
description: WINTER drought has hit Connecticut and, according to Richard Woodhull, chief of the water supply division of the state Health Department, the water supply of utilities in seven areas - Stamford, Greenwich, Groton, Darien, Manchester, New Canaan and a part of Norwalk,- has reached the ''critical'' stage. Several of those towns have already officially proclaimed themselves in a ''water emergency.''

title: NEW ROCKET FOR SPACE SHUTTLE WILL BE DISCONTINUED
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has notified Congress that because of excess costs and technical problems it plans to discontinue development of a new rocket system for launching planetary spacecraft from aboard the space shuttle, replacing it with a modified version of the proven Centaur rocket.

title: Gigahertz Cooking
description: A microwave oven that would give consumers two choices for cooking was proposed by Litton Industries in 1976. It asked the Federal Communications Commission to let it operate ovens at 10.6 gigahertz in the radio spectrum, as well as at the 2.45 gigahertz at which all microwave ovens were operating.

title: ALGIERS IS DIPLOMATIC STAGING AREA IN FINAL PUSH FOR LIBERATION
description: THE individual agony of 52 hostages and the national trauma of 228 million other Americans neared an end last week. In a frenzied sprint toward the finish line of the Carter Administration on Tuesday, Iranians, Americans and Algerian intermediaries made final preparations for a swap of the hostages for Iran's frozen assets in the United States that would restore the status quo ante in practical, if not geopolitical and emotional terms.

title: Dining Out; SATISFYING STEAKHOUSE FARE
description: THE New Yorker Restaurant in Rockville Centre is Scotty Passarelli's third steakhouse on the Island. He originated Scotty's in Rockville Centre and owned the Corner House in Huntington after selling Scotty's in 1977. The New Yorker opened last May, and Mr. Passarelli, a very congenial host, said that returning to Rockville Centre was like coming home.

title: Westchester Housing; IT'S NO LONGER 'UPSTAIRS, DOWNSTAIRS'
description: SUBURBAN household employees have come a long way from the style of ''Upstairs, Downstairs'' - if that strict protocol ever existed in this country - and today, according to domestics, employers and agencies, it is the servant who has the upper hand.

title: On the Trail Of the Mounted Police
description: In response to the recent article ''Police Expand Mountie Corps at Budgetary Reins Tighten'': Perhaps they shouldn't hold the reins so tightly. HORSE POWER ''If it is ... It's in Great Neck,'' the signs boast In most of the shops on the street.

title: CABERET: BOBBI BAIRD
description: Bobbi Baird, who has been absent from cabarets for almost two years, is singing once again at Freddy's, 308 East 49th Street, where she wound up an engagement this weekend in which she has been offering a program filled with unusual and provocative material.

title: BEING FREE IS FINE, UNTIL...
description: THE baby stood in her playpen, laughing and giggling. Aunts and uncles, Grandma and Grandpa rushed around excitedly. Conversations were no longer about the Jets and whom they were playing, but about how well Christy stood, how her teeth were coming in, what her first word would be.

title: Bruins 6, Flyers 4
description: Dick Redmond, Rick Middleton and Stan Jonathan scored goals with less than six minutes to play to spark the Bruins. Redmond broke a 3-3 tie with his 10th goal of the season as he converted a pass from Terry O'Reilly and slid a 25-foot shot past the Philadelphia goalie, Pete Peeters.

title: EDUCATORS COMBATING BAD INFLUENCES OF TV ON CHILDREN
description: THE darkened living room, the comfortable chair, the child motionless in front of the television set watching his favorite detective story; at his feet the family dog snoozing away.

title: NOT JUST HAIG, BUT PERCY & CO. ALSO MADE THEIR SENATE
description: DEBUT By ADAM CLYMER

title:
Dining Out;
A NEW TASTE OF THE OLD FRENCH
description: THERE are serious eaters around who believe that the best French restaurants of the past two decades have created a (some would even say the) golden age of cuisine. They point not only to the explicit triumphs of the new French cooking but also to the less-dramatic effects of the contemporary style upon quite traditional kitchens. For every nouvelle cuisine establishment in the New York City area, there must be a half dozen others that have adopted several of the fashionable badges of the nouvelle style: lightly cooked skinny-cut vegetables, sauces thickened without flour, elegant arrangement with bright color contrasts, novel ingredients like kiwi fruit. Moreover, even though these restaurants may chose most of their dishes from those in the Larousse Gastronomique, they chose the ones less traveled by, and their menus do not bore.

title: Betsey H. Dolben Married To Larry D. Clark in Texas
description: Betsey Howland Dolben, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Howland Dolben of New York and Sam Rayburn, Tex., was married yesterday afternoon in Sam Rayburn to Larry D. Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Clark of Lufkin, Tex.

title: FRANCE'S FIRST WOMAN 'IMMORTAL'
description: The black stubs of cornstalks poke through snow covering the flat fields surrounding the medieval Belgian town of Bruges. Patches of ice glaze the walled city's cobbled streets. Marguerite Yourcenar is wrapped in an old gray cape and she has tied a gray plaid wollen scarf around her head. Her blue eyes seem black. Cold rises from the sidewalks, and, though she has buttoned plastic rain boots over her shoes, she decides it is still too cold to walk. Her traveling companion, Jerry Wilson, drives her around the corner to the main square in their little red Citroen. As the crewcut young American, wearing one gold earring, and the striking 77-year-old woman enter the restaurant, people turn to stare. Mme. Yourcenar chooses a window table, facing the square, its ancient belfry illuminated by orange spotlights. She orders oysters and discusses the process of fiction: You cannot write about things that are too close. For instance, if I were to write about this dinner, there would be so many things to consider, I wouldn't know where to begin."

title: At Home
description: WHEN we were growing up, my brother and I frequently vowed to kill each other. Naturally, we will go to almost any lengths to be together regularly now. It isn't just a matter of uniquely shared genes and history. Accepting each other completely, nonjudgmentally, we are free to tell one another the truth as we can tell no one else.

title: NATIONAL THEATER OF DEAF OFFERING 'ILLIAD' IN BENEFIT
description: In a gesture of celebration and salute, the National Theater of the Deaf will present ''The Iliad, Play by Play'' - an adaptation by Shanny Mow of Homer's ''Iliad'' - at the Public Theater tomorrow to benefit the Actors Fund.

title: Boston College 109 Merrimack 79
description: John Bagley scored 20 points tonight to lead Boston College to a 109-79 victory over Merrimack.

title: BANKS AGREE TO 14 COMPROMISE
description: The United States and Iran exchanged more messages today on terms for releasing the American hostages, but the White House said there was still no ''overall response'' from Teheran that could produce a final agreement.

title: A POET ON PICTURES
Health Code Violations Cited in 37 Food Places
description: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 37 food establishments that it said had violated the Health Code. The department also listed five food establishments that had reopened after correcting earlier violations and one that had been closed for failing to do so. VIOLATIONS Nedicks, 16 Beaver St. Angela Teti-Bar and Restaurant, 141 Mott St. Merrill Lynch Employees Cafeteria, 570 Washington St. La Perla, 637 Broadway. Yang Yang, 283 Columbus Ave. Vorilas Babatsikos, Vorilas Traylos, 317 Greenwich St. Michael Phillips Restaurant, 994 First Ave. Happy View Restaurant, 59 Ninth Ave. Fu Shin, 318 E. 86th St. Jen's Kitchen, 308 W. 13th St. Ms. Eva's Varietie Restaurant, 445 W. 125th St. Anthony's Pizzeria, 1015 Allerton Ave., Bronx. Bruno's Pizza & Heros, 2254 East Tremont Ave., Bronx. Circle Pizzeria, 118 Hugh Grant Circle, Bronx. Dom's Cold Cut City 4 Deli, 719 Lydig Ave., Bronx. Melrose Candy Store, 896 Melrose Ave., Bronx. Mark V, 1819 Southern Blvd., Bronx. Step Up Pizza, 12 West Burnside Ave., Bronx. Pumpkin Lounge, 1511 Westchester Ave., Bronx. McDonald's, 1540 Westchester Ave., Bronx. Bronx Community College Cafeteria, Gould Student Center, 181st St. and University Ave., Bronx. Roma Cafe, 158 E. 188th St., Bronx. Pony & Trap Pub, 211 E. 188th St., Bronx. Adventurers Inn, 1438 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn. Nell Flaherty's, 7509 Third Ave., Brooklyn. Lucky Coffee Shop, 61-01 Fresh Pond Rd., Queens.

title: ROBERT GERARD STOREY, A PROSECUTION COUNSEL AT NUREMBERG TRIALS
description: Robert Gerald Storey, who was executive trial counsel at the Nuremberg war trials and a member of the first Federal Civil Rights Commission, died Friday of heart failure at a Dallas nursing home. He was 87 years old.

title: INMATES IN 60'S TEST OF A POISON SOUGHT
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency is searching for 70 former inmates of Ho@l@m@e@sburg Prison here who received applications of the virulent poison and carcinogen dioxin in testing by the Dow Chemical Company from 1964 through 1967.

title: VIEWS
description: Cartoon layout pg 6 CARTOON CAPTIONS with economy monster cartoon Pat Oliphant The Washington Star Universal Press Syndicate with Kissinger on the tube cartoon Scott Willis The Cleveland Press with smokey bear cartoon Don Wright The Miami News New York Times Special Features with donkeys in the forest cartoon Dana Summers The Fayetteville Times Views A portfolio from around the nation with Dana Summers' donkeys in the forest cartoon ''Hey, call me paranoid, but there's something about these trees...''

title: NEW LIFE FOR NUCLEAR CITY
description: Stewart McBride is a correspondent for The Christian Science Monitor. By Stewart McBride Building 111's Blue Battle Room: The scientist pushes a plastic button and switches on nuclear war. A squadron of 10 Soviet T62 tanks, supported by tactical nuclear artillery and a trio of Hind attack helicopters, has smashed through the West German border near Hunfeld and is rumbling toward a lone American platoon defending the ridge northeast of town. The Russians open fire on the hillside. A cloud of white hyphens (computerized symbols for explosions) erupts at tree line, and a capital ''C'' (conventional kill) flickers nearby. An American antitank unit has bitten the dust; the clock is running. Nuclear war in the Blue Battle Room has been known to last three or four hours. This, however, is a limited engagement, 20 minutes. The scientist is scrimmaging the Russians in lieu of lunch.

title: Robert David Schmicker To Wed Catrina Linhart
description: Catrina Linhart, an assistant vice president and industrial economist at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, and Robert David Schmicker, a lawyer with the New York law firm of Goetz & Fitzpatrick, plan to be married Feb. 22 in St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Learning to Lose Is a Necessity
description: To the Sports Editor: I could not agree more with Roy Meador on the need to learn how to lose (''Here's to the Thrill of Defeat and the Agony of Victory,'' The New York Times, Dec. 28). It is not just an individual necessity for an athlete, but, as he says, it might be a national necessity.

title: BABYLON OFFERS PARKING AT $125
description: IN an effort to insure that residents of the Town of Babylon will be assured parking at Long Island Rail Road stations, commuters are being offered a guaranteed space at $125 a year, and town residents appear eager to pay the fee. Town officials say they are trying to end residents' daily competition with out-of-towners for parking spaces at the stations.

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;
ARCHITECTURE
description: If you have been wondering what the unnamed prestigious corporation that has offered to buy St. Bartholomew's Church for $100 million might build in its place, Tim Prentice, architect-turned-artist, has let his fancy soar. His ''St. Bart's Sketchbook,'' a series of montages based on Bertram Goodhue's landmark building at Park Avenue and 50th Street, explores the possibilities with tongue in cheek and a wicked eye.

title: MIME GIL TORRES GROUP AT VISUAL ARTS FOUNDATION
description: Gil Torres is a skillful young mime with a friendly smile who takes obvious delight in his art. These qualities alone make him an ingratiating performer. But Friday night's program by the Gil Torres Mime Theater at the Vital Arts Center suggested that Mr. Torres may often be more concerned with the sheer act of saying something without using words than with saying anything of any real consequence.

title: Cornelia Wagstaff Engaged to Officer
description: Col. David Wagstaff, U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. Wagstaff of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cornelia Ann Wagstaff, to Lieut. Gifford Wiggin Slater, U.S.A.R., son of John E. Slater of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Mrs. Grenville K. McVickar of Old Lyme, Conn.

title: FRESHMAN REPRESENTATIVES FIND REALITY IS CHANGING THE ORATORY
description: Clay Shaw has a problem. He was elected to Congress last November as a conservative Republican, and he came to Washington eager to slice the size of the Federal Government. But he also represents a growing Florida district that needs money for roads, airports and harbors.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: DOWNTOEARTH ATWALDEN By Marilynne K. Roach. Illustrated by the Author. 88 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $7.95. (Ages 10 to 14) By SAMUEL PICKERING JR.

title: Long Islanders; HE STILL AIDS OTHERS WHO ESCAPED NAZIS
description: ''MAKING money is not the most important thing to me - especially when you've been so close to the death of the Nazi Holocaust,'' said Werner A. Stein of Great Neck.

title:
Nunismatics;
A QUICK SALE FOR YALE'S BRASHER DOUBLOON
description: For a coin of great rarity the Brasher doubloon has become an almost familiar sight in the numismatic marketplace. Another example of this famous Colonial gold piece came up for sale early this month when Yale University offered its specimen for a fixed price of $650,000. Within a week a buyer was found.

title: COLLEGE AT PURCHASE STAGING STEIN PLAY
description: WHEN the theater department of the State University College at Purchase presents Gertrude Stein's ''Listen to Me'' next month, the production will reflect the innovation of the department's new dean, Howard Stein. Mr. Stein - who taught playwriting at the University of Iowa in the early 1960's, was an associate dean of the Yale Drama School from 1967 through 1978 and was chairman for the last two years of the theater department of the University of Texas at Austin - assumed the deanship last September.

title: Premieres of 3 Dances By Nikolais Next Month
description: The premieres of three works by Alwin Nikolais will highlight the two-week season of the Nikolais Dance Theater at the City Center-55th Street Theater, Feb. 11-22.

title: Podborski Wins Third Downhill
description: Steve Podborski of Canada won his third straight World Cup downhill today in a race that marked the downhill debut of Ingemar Stenmark, the Swedish slalom star. Stenmark completed the course some 10 seconds behind the winner.

title: NEW ASSEMBLY PREPARES CROWDED AGENDA
description: HARTFORD AT the top of the heap of legislation waiting for action by the General Assembly this year is a bill that would limit the number of new bills. Senator Marcella A. Fahey, Democrat of East Hartford, is proposing a moratorium on new legislation for the 1982 session, to cut the cost of government and allow time for review of the statute books to weed out obsolete laws.

title: G.O.P. Group in Ohio Plans Speech by Nixon
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon is to speak here Feb. 18 at a fund-raising dinner for Republicans in the State Senate, according to a Republican official.

title: CAREY PLANS STATE TAKEOVER OF MEDICAID COSTS BY 1985
description: Governor Carey will propose Monday that the state take over the entire local government share of Medicaid costs within four years.

title: Miss Petruseva Is Winner In 2 Speed Skating Events
description: Natalya Petruseva of the Soviet Union won the 500- and 1,500-meter events today on the opening day of the European women's speed skating championships.

title: Future Events Antiques and Irises
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:From the Other SideJan. 21 -The 18th-century furniture, artifacts, silver, books and manuscripts that turned the late Marjorie Wiggin Prescott's houses in Greenwich, Conn., and Hobe Sound, Fla., into homes for her and her husband, the late Sherburne Prescott, will be on view from 6 to 8 this evening at a cocktail party arranged by the English-Speaking Union at Christie's on Park Avenue. Guests of honor will be Sir Anthony Parsons, Britain's representative at the United Nations, and Lady Parsons. Mrs. Prescott's home furnishings also came from England and will be auctioned as the Prescott Collection of Fine English Furniture at Christie's this month and in February. Mrs. Prescott was also the author of ''New England Son,'' a biography of her father, Albert Henry Wiggin, president of the then Chase National Bank. Proceeds of tonight's gathering will support the English-Speaking Union's educational, cultural and social programs, including exchange scholarships for British and American students. Tickets at $25 may be reserved through TR 9-6800, ext. 24.

title: No Headline
description: In Paul Wilkes's article, the director of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception is quoted (in part) as saying: ''Why did she (Sister Theresa Kane) have to do what she did and here? A man would have called me up beforehand and said he was going to do it.'' Isn't it evident that this courageously outspoken woman never would have been permitted to address the Pope had she revealed her intentions in advance? THOMAS G., MORGANSEN, Jackson Heights, N.Y.

title:
Camera;
WHY FILTERS ARE NEEDED IN COLOR PHOTOGRAPHY
BOSSY STEPS UP PACE WITH 3 IN 6-4 VICTORY
description: Mike Bossy continued his assault on the National Hockey League record book tonight, scoring three goals and an assist in leading the Islanders to a 6-4 victory over the Washington Capitals at Nassau Coliseum. It was the eighth time this season that Bossy had scored three or more goals in a game, breaking a record held by three players.

title: FROST'S TOLL ON FISHING
description: Abnormally cold weather, which is playing havoc with Florida's citrus crops and threatening next spring's wheat crop, has also kept many East Coast fishermen out of the water this winter, driving wholesale and retail prices for fresh fish up far more sharply than is usual in the winter months.

title: Westchester Journal
description: THE Yonkers Police Department has decided ''not to wait for Uncle Sam to give us the dollars'' to fight drug traffic, according to Commissioner Charles P. Connolly.

title: 'DANGEROUS' PEANUT BUTTER
description: 'Dangerous' Peanut Butter

title: COMPUTERS BROADEN THE USE OF AUTOPILOTS
description: FOR decades, autopilots have taken the tedium out of man-handling helms in fair weather and foul - especially foul. Like miniature think-tanks, sensors have detected deviations from pre-planned headings.

title: Nuggets 123, Kings 122
description: David Thompson scored 29 points, 16 in the final eight minutes, to help Denver beat the Kings. Thompson scored 9 straight points in the final three minutes, and his basket with 1:12 left cut Kansas City's lead to 122-121.

title: GIVING SCHOOLS THE BUSINESS
description: THE trouble with American education is that it lags behind society in adjusting to new conditions. It's always been that way. Too conservative. But with the Reagan Administration now entrenching itself in Washington, local school systems would do well to take a fresh look at some old sacred cows. The business of America is, after all, not education.

title: STEPHANIE POGUE FIANCEE OF M.F. BIEDERMAN
description: The engagement of Stephanie Wallace Pogue to Mitchell Frederick Biederman, son of Irving Biederman of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Anita Biederman, has been announced by the future bride's stepfather and mother, Dr. and Mrs. Arthur de Long Philson of New York, and her father, Henry Pogue Jr. of New London, N.H.

title: Albany To the Editor:$
description: In ''What's Doing in Albany'' (Travel Section, Dec. 28), Joann M. Crupi states that the present building of the First Church in Albany (Reformed) was designed by Thomas Hooker.

title: THE SECOND SEASON- FIERCE BATTLE OVER 'SAFE' FORMATS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Peter Funt is a freelance writer who frequently reports on the television scene. By PETER FUNT

title: KEEPING A WEATHER EYE ON CURRENT COMPONENTS
description: T he coldest winter in ages is keeping people indoors, and those with musical interests are probably spending their housebound evenings in the company of their stereo systems. In this climatically enforced intimacy they may become more aware of the shortcomings as well as the merits of their sound gear. Minor flaws tolerantly ignored at other times have a way of becoming quite irritating when one listens long and often. So, quite likely, a frigid winter turns a listener's fancy to thoughts of updating his sound equipment. With this in mind, the next several columns will pinpoint a number of current components especially notable not only for good performance but also for the quality and imagination of their design.

title: Martha Robinson Engaged
description: The engagement of Martha Robinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour B. Robinson of Armonk, N.Y., to Peter Kimberly West, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. West of Kansas City, Mo., formerly of Chappaqua, N.Y., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: Barbara Uhlig to Be Wed To Jeffrey Ostroth June 7
description: Barbara Joan Uhlig, an account executive with the Frank Vos Company, and Jeffrey White Ostroth, copy chief for Peter Vane Advertising Inc., will be married June 7.

title: A FEW HINTS FOR NOVICES
description: A good, simple text for making cork-bodied working decoys is Paul W. Casson's "Decoys Simplied" (Freshet Press). Dr. George Ross Starr, a general practitioner who lives in Duxbury, Mass., and is a student of the history of waterfowl decoys, a few years ago wrote "How To Make Working Decoys," (Winchester Press). This first-class book concentrates on wood as the decoy material.

title: ALGERIA SENDS MEDICAL TEAM TO CHECK THE CAPTIVES
description: Algeria sent a medical team to Teheran today at the request of the Iranians to check on the health of the American hostages.

title:
Gardening;
EVERYDAY VS. SCIENTIFIC NAMES FOR PLANTS
description: THE other day I came across a problem, really very simple, that required four reference books for a solution. I wished to look up information about the dogtooth violet, but the name was not listed in the first three books consulted.

title: Childhood Clues to An Adult Disease
description: An ounce of exposure to illness during childhood may go a long way toward preventing an often fatal cancer of the lymph glands, called Hodgkin's disease, in adulthood, according to a study published last week in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: THE FOOTLIGHTS BEGIN TO LEND A GLOW TO 'EGG'
description: After nearly two years of virtually total darkness, the footlights have begun to glow at ''the Egg,'' the Performing Arts Center in the Empire State Plaza.

title: Archibald L. Gillies Elected Head Of Vocational Foundation in City
description: Archibald L. Gillies, the former president of the John Hay Whitney Foundation, has been elected president and chief executive officer of the Vocational Foundation Inc., which finds jobs for disadvantaged youths in the city.

title: UConn Conquers St. John's
description: Connecticut took a 14-point lead early in the second half today and seemed to have St. John's soundly beaten in their Big East basketball game. It appeared that it was going to be a snap.

title: Catharine M. Kane Plans June Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Kane of Wilmington, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catharine Mary Kane, to Bradley Chapman Irwin, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Irwin of Darien, Conn.

title: BLUMENTHAL ASSESSES U.S. ATTORNEY'S ROLE
description: NEW HAVEN EIGHT books on mountain climbing, including Sir Edmund Hillary's account of his ascent of Mt. Everest, are stacked on a conference table in the office of Richard Blumenthal, the United States Attorney for Connecticut.

title: At Home
description: WHEN we were growing up, my brother and I threw each other down stairs and frequently vowed to kill each other. Naturally, we will go to almost any lengths to be together regularly now.

title: D'Urso Is Freed but; Italy Still Trembles
description: Red Brigades terrorists released their latest hostage unharmed in Rome last week, after a 33-day ordeal that chipped anew at some pillars of Italian society. Eluding police roadblocks, the kidnappers left Magistrate Giovanni D'Urso, tied and gagged under a blanket in the back of a small brown Fiat parked near the closely guarded Justice Ministry.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Reagan Takes Off

title: THE COMPETITIVE ERA IN SAVINGS
description: LOS ANGELES T HE chairman and chief executive of one of the nation's largest savings and loan associations, Robert R. Dockson, looked thoughtfully across his huge, crescent-shaped desk. ''I lie awake nights,'' he said. ''When I try to anticipate the results in 1981, it makes me ill.''

title: Army 68, Manhattan 60
description: Army converted eight of nine free throws in the final 3:15 to seal a 68-60 victory over Manhattan Saturday at the loser's Draddy Gym.

title: NORTH CAROLINA 80, DUKE 65
description: Al Wood scored 20 points to pace North Carolina to an 80-65 rout of Duke tonight in an Atlantic Coast Conference basketball game.

title: Marjorie Johnson and Simon Hewett to Marry in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Johnson of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Anne Johnson, to Simon Christopher Hewett, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Michael Hewett of Palma, Majorca. Plans have been made for an April wedding in Bronxville.

title:
On The Isle;
PRIZE WINNERS
description: To keep young performing artists on their toes - and in the money - both the Great Neck Symphony and the Port Washington Library's Music Advisory Committee hold annual competitions to discover and then provide a showcase for some of the nation's most promising newcomers. Today, three winners of these contests will get their just rewards: solo recitals - the cash came earlier.

title: THE LAST CHAPTER IN IRAN
description: This time of transition from one administration to another, as the last chapter in the tragedy of the American captives in Iran seems to be drawing to a close, is a good time to reflect on who these people are and who did the dog-work for their liberation.

title: The Lively Arts; 'SIZWE BANSI' TRIUMPHS AT PAF
description: HUNTINGTON STATION ''SIZWE Bansi Is Dead,'' a play about the survival of the South African black man under the strictures of apartheid, is a strange and strangely structured work, unsettling in its immediate and aftereffects.

title: ENJOYING ITS MAJORITY, G.O.P. MAKES PLANS
description: ON Tuesday, there will be a Republican in the White House, a Republican majority in the Senate and a strong minority in the House. The Week in Review asked Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, chairman of the Budget Committee, Representative Trent Lott of Mississippi, House minority whip, and Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, chairman of the Republican Conference, to talk about how this new balance of power will work, from the G.O.P. perspective.

title: A JOB IN SOUTH AFRICA FOR THE MANAGERS
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Good reading. Drop in at a number of the paperback houses along Publishers Row these midwinter days and you're apt to find editors, promotion people and sales executives at work on projects that share a serious yet quite refreshing quality. To wit:

title: L.S.U. 78, Georgia 65
description: Durand Macklin scored 12 of his game-high 21 points in the first five minutes of play to give Louisiana State a lead it never relinquished in a 78-65 victory over Georgia today.

title: No Headline
description: The Sex Education Coalition has sponsored an annual Media Fair for the last five years that displays a variety of films, tapes, slides, charts and other teaching tools. It was quite disturbing to me to see that the event was referred to as ''Sex Media Fair, 1980,'' which seemed to connote an audiovisual extravaganza of explicit materials. In contrast, what actually took place was the presentation of a variety of education films ranging from a film dealing with the birth of a baby to one portraying the need of an elderly woman, in a nursing home, for human contact and affection. PAMELA M. WILSON, President, Sex Education Coalition of Metropolitan Washington

title: Penguins 5, Kings 4
description: Rick Kehoe scored his second goal of the game with 53 seconds remaining to give Pittsburgh the victory. Kehoe took a pass from Mark Johnson and flipped the puck past the Los Angeles goalie, Mario Lessard, for the game-winner.

title: ACTION IS SOUGHT TO HELP PROTECT U.S. FARMLANDS
description: The incoming administration of Presidentelect Ronald Reagan and the new Congress were urged yesterday to help check the annual loss of more than three million acres of agricultural lands to urban developers.

title: Music; MANY WORKS TO FILL A BUSY WEEK
description: IF you haven't yet visited the Greater Ossining Arts Festival II, there are still a few hours left to sample the far-ranging exhibits, lectures, demonstrations and recitals that have turned the Ossining Community Center into a veritable explosion of the creative arts.

title: No Headline
description: Bernadette Devlin Is Put In an Intensive Care Unit

title: Auto Racing Snug Inside Hall in Jersey
description: For most auto racing participants, winter is a time to be holed up in garages preparing for the opening of the race tracks three months from now. Spectators have to settle for television broadcasts of major races in Florida.

title: CONCERT: MUSIC OF JAPAN GIVEN AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: If there was one thing proven by the ''Music From Japan'' presented in Carnegie Hall on Friday night, it was that our contemporary musical culture is both less homogeneous and more homogeneous than is usually thought.

title: NEW G.O.P. CHAIRMAN CRITICIZES PARTY'S RIGHT WING
description: Richard Richards, newly elected as chairman of the Republican National Committee, today warned ''right-wing organizations'' not to exaggerate the role they served in getting Ronald Reagan elected as President or to try to tell the Presidentelect what to do in office.

title: VICTORIAN HOUSE TIES CONDOS TO YESTERDAY
description: OYSTER BAY AS a result of an unusual arrangement between two developers and the Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities, those who purchase homes in the Landmark Colony town-house development will be getting a little bit of Victoriana along with their brand new condominiums.

title: A New Opposition Party Formed in South Korea
description: Opposition politicians officially formed a Democratic Korea Party today and selected a candidate for the presidential election scheduled Feb. 25. The party is among the first formed since opposition parties were abolished by military leaders last year.

title: THE NEW SEX EDUCATION
description: The New Sex Education

title: MUSIC
description: Eight celebrated jazz pianists, ranging from the venerable Eubie Blake to the modernists Herbie Hancock and Sir Roland Hanna, will be manning up to six Steinways at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night at 8 for a special concert, ''One Night Stand: An Evening Of All-Stars.'' The pianists, (the others are Kenny Barron, George Duke, Charles Earland, Rodney Franklin, and Bob James) will perform as soloists and in groups of varying sizes.

title: ZHEJIANG BECOMES OUR SISTER STATE
description: FOR several years, New Jersey's advanced research facilities, prominent universities and modern industrial plants have attracted the attention of the Chinese, who have embarked on an ambitious modernization program.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Eyes on WashingtonThis Tuesday, events in the nation's capital will dominate the small screen, as television carries to viewers across the country and overseas unprecedented coverage of a Presidential inauguration.

title: CONTROVERSY ARISES OVER LEAGUE'S POWER TO SEIZE ANIMALS
description: HUNTINGTON THE seizure of two privately owned horses by members of a local humane society has raised questions about whether such powers are warranted in a volunteer group.

title: ALTERATIONS; A Failed Success
description: Major league baseball subtly removed another barrier last week. Frank Robinson, the ex-slugger of the Baltimore Orioles and former manager of the Cleveland Indians, was given another chance to manage, this time the San Francisco Giants.

title: Seton Hall 80, Lehigh 63
description: Dan Callandrillo scored 22 points tonight to lead Seton Hall to an 80-63 victory over Lehigh.

title: Texas-El Paso 64 Brigham Young 62
description: Julius Wayne sank a 20-foot jump shot with four seconds left today to give Texas-El Paso a 64-62 upset victory over Brigham Young in a Western Athletic Conference game.

title: Art; 'AMERICAN VISIONS, 1980,' A SHOW OF THE LONELY ART
description: MONTCLAIR THE OTHER night, I saw a man making exposures of a New York City park. The temperature was near zero - too cold even for muggers - but the photographer, his camera steadied on a railing, was oblivious of it.

title: DRUCKER AT $83
description: There's a legend about management consulting. A small company facing some prickly problems invites in a consultant. He asks the president to describe what his company does. ''Why, we manufacture glass bottles for soft drinks and beer,'' is the answer. Significant pause. ''No, I don't agree,'' says the consultant. ''It seems to me that you're in the packaging business.''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THEPOWEROFLIGHT Eight Stories for Hanukkah. By Isaac Bashevis Singer. Illustrated by Irene Lieblich. 87 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95. (Ages 9 and Up) By SAUL MALOFF

title: FEMALE DIPLOMATS TAKE STOCK OF GAINS
description: The warm professional club emitted such an air of privilege that it seemed incongruous when the well-dressed feminists of the Foreign Service sang a chorus of ''Union Maid,'' the rallying tune for factory women.

title: MINORITY REPORT
description: BRITISHGOVERNMENTAND ITSDISCONTENTS By Geoffrey Smith and Nelson W. Polsby. 202 pp. New York: Basic Books. $12.95. By BERNARD D. NOSSITER

title: REAGAN INAUGURAL SIGNALS A CONTINENTAL
description: TILT By JOHN HERBERS

title: BANKS AGREE TO
description: COMPROMISE 14) By STUART TAYLOR Jr.

title: COAL TALKS TO OPEN ON AN OMINOUS NOTE
description: Less than a week before the start of East Coast contract talks in which both coal management and labor say they hope to avoid a strike, more than 900 members of the United Mine Workers under a separate contract in Western strip mines have begun a strike.

title: L. J. Krule Fiance Of Susan D. Fader
description: Susan Deborah Fader and Lawrence Jay Krule, both of New York, plan to be married in July. Both work for General Foods in White Plains, where the bride-to-be is an assistant product manager and her fiance a financial associate with the Maxwell House Coffee division.

title: Miss Conners Becomes Bride Of Executive
description: At the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity yesterday, Louise B. Conners, a performance analyst for chartered vessels with Exxon International, was married to Gerald W. Puschel, president of Waverly Fabrics. The Rev. Chrysanthos Zois performed the ceremony.

title: LOS ANGELES
description: Natassia Kinski sat - perhaps ''crouched'' was a more apt description - on the floor in front of a small sofa in her dressing room at the American Zoetrope studios in Hollywood and tried to describe how she felt about being compared with the young Ingrid Bergman and Greta Garbo.

title: Sally Peters, Media Planner, Fiancee of William S. Daley
description: Sally Anne Peters, a media planner at the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency in New York, and William Stewart Daley, a vice president of Shearson Loeb Rhodes, investment banker, plan to be married June 6.

title: FANFARE FOR REAGANS BEGINS WITH FIREWORKS IN CAPITAL
description: As laser beams streaked the darkness and fireworks burst against the night sky, President-elect Ronald Reagan and his wife, Nancy, tonight attended the opening ceremony of the most expensive inaugural celebration in American history.

title: Mailbox; For Amateurs, Political Decisions Are Also a Factor
description: To the Sports Editor: Craig Masback correctly cites the athletes' despair resulting from the United States boycott of the Moscow Olympics (''Americans Face A Difficult Road To 1984 Olympics,'' The New York Times, Jan. 11). He is mistaken, however, in suggesting that only economic factors are causing the athletes' present uncertainty and equally mistaken in proposing only economic solutions to instill renewed interest in amateurs for the ''pursuit of sporting excellence.''

title: ROSTROPOVICH- 'I FEEL LIKE A NATIVE'
description: WASHINGTON Given his recent emigration to the west, it might seem surprising that it has been 25 years since the Russian cello virtuoso Mstislav Rostropovich made his American debut at Carnegie Hall.The fourth of his four anniversary anocerts there this year, on April 4, will fall on the exact day of his debut, in 1956. The series - with the same programs also being presented in Washington -begins this Friday, when Mr. Rostropovich will appear both as soloist and conductor of the National Symphony. The following Friday he returns to conduct the New York premiere of Penderecki's Te Deum and the Beethoven Violin Concerto, with Yehudi Menuhin. And on Feb. 8 he will lead the Choral Arts Society of Washington in Rachmaninoff's rarely heard Vespers.

title: INFLATABLES: STABILITY AND SAFETY
description: THE current crop of inflatable sport and utility boats has come a long way since the first such boats appeared during the second World War. How to illustrate that? Going the rounds recently has been a postcard featuring a cartoon of an inflatable ocean liner. The caption says, ''Coming your way,'' and the boat is labeled the QEIII.

title: Reader Protests Use of 'Reverends'
description: Reference - this date, Page CN1: ''The Reverends Ann and Michael Coburn,'' etc.

title: HAGLER KEEPS CROWN ON KNOCKOUT IN 8TH
description: After he had scored an eighth-round technical knockout in the first defense of the middleweight championship, Marvin Hagler still didn't know too much about ''what's his name? Fully Obel?'' For instance, Hagler said, ''I didn't know what was keeping him up.''

title: FORMER CITY AMNULANCE CHIEF DIES
description: Peter Murray, a former director of operations for the city's Emergency Medical Service, died of a heart attack early yesterday in the emergency room of Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 44 years old.

title: RADICAL HISTORY
description: REVOLUTIONINJUDAEA Jesus and the Jewish Resistance. By Hyam Maccoby. 256 pp. New York: Taplinger Publishing Co. $9.95. By JULIAN N. HARTT

title: Experience Counts
description: Almost every pro football fan has a theory on who will win the Super Bowl, but here is one to ponder: Go with the team that has been there last.

title: COACHES ARE SEARCHING FOR BIDS, TOO
description: MOBILE, Ala. HUNDREDS of pro football's assistant coaches are back home all over North America today, as insecure in their jobs as they were a week ago. But perhaps, after spending a week at the Senior Bowl, they have impressed a head coach and, perhaps, he will remember them.

title: CHINA ATTACKS U.S. ON DUTCH-TAIWAN DEAL
description: Chinese officials have accused the new administration, United States officials and the Netherlands of conspiring in the sale of two Dutch submarines to Taiwan in what Peking called a ''perverse trend'' that threatened to upset the peace in Asia.

title: Flyers 7, Kings 2
description: Philadelphia continued its mastery of Los Angeles - the Kings have not beaten the Flyers since Oct. 10, 1974 -thanks to shorthanded goals by Behn Wilson and Tom Gorence, plus a relentless attack.

title: WROTE COMEDY FOR TV AND FILMS
description: Sydney Zelinka, a comedy writer whose credits included movies for the Marx Brothers and television series for Jackie Gleason and Phil Silvers, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Amagansett, L.I. He was 74 years old.

title: REAGAN ATTENDS 3 INAUGURAL CONCERTS RANGING FROM OPERA TO MOVIE MUSIC
description: For the three days leading up to Tuesday's Presidential inauguration, Washington has been humming with music and art. Every museum in the District has been presenting all-day programs that have taken in everything from jazz and folk music to the classical and contemporary repertory. In addition, some of the museums have shows that relate to the inauguration.

title: How to Lose the Namibian Game
description: What has been called the oldest established permanent floating negotiation at the United Nations has sunk in Lake Geneva. Whether the Namibia peace talks resurface will depend on the still private (and perhaps unjelled) attitudes of the Reagan Administration, as well as those of the South African Government that brought about the Geneva conference - and then decided its initiative was ''premature.''

title: AFTER A LONG WAIT, HOSTAGES' FAMILIES ARE JOYFUL AS THE AGREEMENT IS INITIALED
description: It was not quite 1 A.M. in California when the news came over the radio: The Americans had initialed the agreement signed by Iran on the release ofthe hostages. After 443 days, it looked as if they were finally coming home. Dorothea Morefield, the wife of Richard Morefield, the Consul General at the United States Embassy in Tehran, stood up in her living room in San Diego, crowded with relatives and reporters, and hugged her youngest son, Kenneth, 14 years old. They didn't say anything. They just hugged. Then Mrs. Morefield said, "I like it," and the others cheered. Her mother-in-law, Maria Morefield; her sister-in-law, Anita Oran, and some of the other women began to cry. 'Oh, My God, It's Over' She hugged her oldest son, Daniel, 21, and she spoke a few words to her husband's mother. Then, her eyes filling with tears, Mrs. Morefield exclaimed in a jouous rush, "Oh, my God, it's over. It's done. It's finished." She did not even try to stop the tears. It had been a long, agonizing day for the Morefields and the other hostages' families. They had been electrified early in the day by a report from the official Iranian news agency that the United States and Iran had come to an agreement on releasing the hostages. Mrs. Morefield had heard the news in a telephone call from a reporter as she sipped her morning coffee. Finally, she thought, they were coming home.

title: Saudis Said to Sell More Relief Oil
description: Saudi Arabia will renew temporary crude oil supply contracts with 11 of the 12 countries it had been aiding after their fuel supplies were reduced by the Iran-Iraq war, the Middle East Economic Survey reported Sunday.

title: SOVIET SOLDIERS GET WARNING
description: In a warning on protection against Western intelligence, the Soviet Army newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda said today that soldiers had grown lax in communications discipline and had "careless dealings with important documents." A front-page editorial said: "Certain soldiers, trying to sparkle with information, tell in their letters to relatives and friends about their assignments in the service and name the equipment in their units' arsenals.

title: ANALYSTS GIVE CARTER HIGHER MARKS IN FOREIGN AFFAIRS THAN IN DOMESTIC POLICY
description: As Jimmy Carter ends his term as the 39th President, political analysts and historians are already debating his record and the mark he will leave. The most common view is that while he can point to a few notable accomplishments, Mr. Carter will not bequeath a particularly distinguished legacy to the nation.

title: Product Introductions Up
description: Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News reports that not only did 1980 reverse the two-year downturn of new product introductions; it also marked the high point for introductions for the 16 years that the agency has been tabulating them. For 1980 the final figure was 1,268, a 9 percent increase from the previous year. December accounted for 116, compared with 85 in December 1979.

title: DALLAS REJECTS BID FOR A 30% TAX CUT
description: Voters in Dallas yesterday overwhelmingly turned down one of the nation's most sweeping tax rollbacks since California's Proposition 13 in 1978.

title: RECITAL: SAMETH SINGS DEBUSSY, HAYDN AND SATIE
description: MARTEN SAMETH'S song recital at Carnegie Recital Hall last Wednesday evening offered one delicacy after another. There were Haydn and Debussy, Satie and Wolf; and to protect us from too much seriousness there were four different settings of ''Flohlied des Mephisto,'' Goethe's poetic saga of the famous flea.

title: TRAM REPAIRED, STILL IDLE WHILE AN INQUIRY IS MADE
description: The Roosevelt Island aerial tramway, which has been shut down since early November, is now operational but is expected to be out of service for another month or more, pending a report on the competency of the company that maintains it.

title: BEWILDERED, INEFFECTIVE RANGERS HANDED 4-0 BY SABRES
description: The Rangers appeared bewildered tonight as they were defeated, 4-0, by the Buffalo Sabres. Coach Craig Patrick attributed the loss to ''mental mistakes'' and excellent goaltending by Don Edwards. He also noted that the Rangers, who have failed to win in six games, were trying ''experiments'' - using different combinations on their lines.

title: Iran Parliament Drops Plan to Transfer Shares
description: The Iranian Parliament today dismissed a proposal to transfer to the state all shares in Iranian companies held by foreigners.

title: Military Analysis
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan's first major decision on arms procurement, after taking office, will involve the future of the MX mobile missile program.

title: MOST OF ATLANTA'S PONOGRAPHY SHOPS TO CLOSE IN A PACT WITH PROSECUTOR
description: Almost all of Atlanta's adult bookstores and movie theaters have agreed to close in return for dismissal of charges against their employees. A prosecutor hailed the bargain as proof that ''law enforcement now has the upper hand'' against pornography.

title: WHAT WERE 1980'S MOST POPULAR MOVIES?
description: LOS ANGELES WHAT movies are the public going to see and why did the studios decide to make them? Of the 15 movies that brought studios the most film rentals from theaters in the United States last year, two - ''Kramer vs. Kramer'' and ''Coal Miner's Daughter'' - had serious and, at moments, painful, themes. The others aimed only to divert, to amuse or to scare their audiences.

title: Seiko to Introduce A Higher-Priced Watch
description: Seiko, the No.1 seller of middle-priced watches ($70 and up) in America, is introducing its Lassale line of higher-priced ($350-$900) timepieces in the spring with $6 million in TV and print ads.

title: COMPANY SEEKING TO SHIP TOXIC WASTE TO BAHAMAS
description: The State Department has notified the Government of the Bahamas that a Birmingham, Ala., company is negotiating a contract with a Bahamian concern to dispose of toxic chemical wastes in that country, a department official said Jan. 9.

title: Police Prisoner, 18, Kills Himself in Cell
description: A teen-ager committed suicide in a Staten Island police station late last night after being arrested for illegal possession of a pistol earlier in the day, the police said.

title: SAMPLE OF WORK BY REMEDIAL STUDENTS IN QUEENS
description: One remedial English assignment at Flushing High School consists of writing a short report based on a set of notes. Students are told that their social studies teacher asked them to take the notes while watching a film on discoveries made by ancient civilizations. They are then given the following notes:

title: Index; International
description: U.S. military quietly prepares for hostages' release A5 American military personnel in Turkey hope for a better year A10 Flow of arms to rebels cited in U.S. aid to Salvador A11 Canadian and Mexican leaders promoting development talks A11 Leningrad cultural events are reported broken up A12 Around the World A13 China assails U.S. over Dutch submarine sale to Taiwan A14 Panel feels there is still time for U.S-Soviet strategic talks A15 Soviet press starts to criticize Reagan policies and aides A22 Government/Politics Government efforts provide little hope for saving dusky sparrow A18 Inaugural concerts range from opera to film score A20 Republicans in Washington reemerging from social Siberis A20 About Washington A20 At parties in capital, the game is seeing and being seen A21 A Federal report says pollution is threatening ground water B2 California Democrats seek to revive party's appeal D11 Style Relationships B10 When married children come home to live B10 The 37th annual black-tie ball for the unsung superintendent B10 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of expected bad weather, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. All other parking regulations remain in effect. SportsMonday Basketball: South Alabama and Ellis gaining esteem C7

title: Billboard Buys Magazine
description: Musician, Player & Listener magazine, four years old and published in Gloucester, Mass., has been sold to Billboard Publications Inc. for $2.1 million, according to Gordon P. Baird, its 30-year-old publisher. The magazine, which he founded with Sam Holdsworth, editor and art director, on a bankroll of $20,000, is now up to a circulation of 120,000.

title: Subway Closings Rejected by Ravitch
description: The security costs of closing the subway system down late at night would far outweigh the savings that could be realized from such a move, Richard Ravitch, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday.

title: AMERICANS IN TURKEY: WILL SPOTLIGHT EASE THEIR LOAD?
description: American military personnel and their families have stocked candles and lanterns for the frequent power failures, procured heaters against the rigors of winter and generally learned to laugh at other hardships in Turkey.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE RADIANT FUTURE by Alexander Zinoviev. Translated from the Russian by Gordon Clough. 287 pages. Random House. $13.95.

title: POP: SONGS AND PATTER BY PETER ALLEN
description: PETER ALLEN has grown from a cabaret cult figure into a transfixing all-round entertainer.
