Last Thursday, at the first of three shows at the Radio City Music Hall, Mr. Allen proved he could turn a large theater into an intimate cabaret. He fronted an orchestra in the pit and a rock band on the stage and breezed through more than 20 songs, interspersed with uproarious patter about Tom Snyder, Mayor Koch and meeting Queen Elizabeth II. For the evening's theatrical climax, ''I Go to Rio,'' Mr. Allen rode out on a camel and gleefully waved maracas amid a hail of golden streamers. Joining the Rockettes in ''Everything Old Is New Again,'' he matched them kick for kick and then went into his own dance, which suggested Fred Astaire choreographed by Bob Fosse.

title: TENANTS DIVIDE ON HOW LONG HEAT WILL LAST
description: Edward Farmer, wearing a short-sleeved silk shirt and slacks, sat in his superintendent's apartment, where the thermometer registered 75 degrees.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. Sees No Great Risk In East Coast Oil Drilling

title: HARD TIMES IN DIAMOND TRADE
description: Diamonds may still be a girl's best friend, but they have proven to be unfaithful companions for investors and dealers in recent months.

title: REPUBLICANS IN CAPITAL EMERGE FROM SOCIAL SIBERIA
description: In the past, few members of Congress dined at the home of Roger Stone and reporters never clamored to cover his parties. Washington hostesses did not vie for Mr. Stone's presence at their tables and, in fact, few of them knew his name.

title: IRAN'S COUNTER-INAUGURAL
description: After dominating the news on the weekend of our election, a nation led by kidnappers is staging another spectacular on the weekend of a new President's inauguration.

title: Japan's Output Of Steel Declines
description: Japan's crude steel production fell three-tenths of 1 percent last year to 111.41 million tons, following a slow recovery of domestic demand in the second half of the year, the Japanese Iron and Steel Federation said Friday.

title: LENINGRAD POLICE DISRUPT UNOFFICIAL CULTURE EVENTS
description: The state security police in Leningrad, in a recent series of arrests and apartment searches, have in effect warned that unauthorized cultural activities will no longer be tolerated, according to friends of those affected.

title: Henrik Antell, Purchasing Agent At The Times for 17 Years, Dies
description: Henrik Antell, a former purchasing agent of The New York Times, died Friday at the Veterans Medical Center in Canandaigua, N.Y. He was 85 years old and a resident of Brooklyn Heights.

title: No Headline
description: Indiana 67, Ohio State 60

title: DEALING WITH MOSCOW
description: When I said farewell to the American press corps in Moscow the other day, I complimented them on the quality of their reporting. They have done much to explain the workings of that country to all of us. But, at the same time, I had to tell them that despite their best efforts, the Soviet Union is not basically understood by most Americans.

title: NEGOTIATOR IN WALKER BID FOR DAVIS OIL
description: Alex M. McIntosh, president of the Home Oil Company, the Calgary, Canada, unit of Hiram Walker-Consumers Home Ltd., spent 60 hours traveling in his company's jet last month as he negotiated and wrapped up the transaction to purchase American gas and oil properties from the Davis Oil Company for about $600 million. But as he sees it, if the deal closes on schedule on March 11, the demanding pace will have been well worth his while.

title: Oregon State Star Right on Target
description: Steve Johnson, the Oregon State center whose .710 field-goal shooting percentage last season set a National Collegiate record, is doing even better this season.

title: Newark Man Held In Fire That Killed 2
description: NEWARK (AP) - A 26-year-old man was arrested in connection with a fire that killed his estranged wife and daughter, officials said. The man, Eduardo Gonzales, will be arraigned today on charges of murder and arson involving the fire that destroyed a three-story building on Saturday and killed Rosa Gonzales, 20, and the couple's daughter, Marisella, 4, according to John Caufield, the city fire director.

title: IRAN'S HANDLING OF FUNDS MAY UPSET MONEY MARKETS
description: The emerging agreement unfreezing blocked Iranian funds in return for the release of the Americans held hostage in Teherean could create tension in world financial markets next week as Iran withdraws its dollar deposits from American banks and switches them into other currencies or gold, according to sources close to the negotiations.

title: Federal Agents Arrest 10 In Theft of Fuel for Boats
description: Fifty Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and harbor police swarmed over three ocean-going shrimp boats and arrested eight fishermen and two fuel barge workers in connection allegedly involved in a multi-million-dollar fuel theft ring, the bureau said today.

title: EXPERTS SEE CHANCE TO PRESS ARMS TALK
description: Negotiation of the next step in Soviet-United States nuclear arms limitations is likely to remain possible for the next year or so because neither Moscow nor Washington is likely to build new strategic weapons during that period.

title: Clippers 115 Mavericks 109
description: The Clippers squandered a big lead but held on to beat Dallas before a crowd of 3,980, smallest in the three-year history of the San Diego franchise.

title: The Ferris Communications Commission
description: Liberating radio stations from some programming rules is a fitting farewell gesture by the Federal Communications Commission to its energetic chairman, Charles Ferris. His tenure will be remembered for a major effort to offer television and broadcast audiences the wider choice of programs now technologically possible. Congress and the courts have been left with large questions of law and policy. But the validity of Mr. Ferris's thesis must be acknowledged: a competitive marketplace should accommodate the public's taste and even the public interest more reliably than Government regulators.

title: Bernadette Devlin Remains In 'Very Serious' Condition
description: Bernadette Devlin McAliskey, the Northern Ireland civil-rights campaigner who was wounded in an assassination attempt Friday, was listed in stable condition today but remained ''very seriously ill,'' doctors here said.

title: DAVIDSON'S COLLAPSE NOT A HEART ATTACK
description: Sven Davidson, former Davis Cup tennis player, was listed in stable condition at a hospital today after he collapsed druing a tennis tournament this weekend, a spokesman said.

title: U.S. BASES IN WEST GERMANY MAKE PREPERATIONS QUIETLY
description: The American military establishment moved quietly into high gear here today as the long ordeal of the hostages in Iran seemed to near its end.

title: Actor May Be Puzzled but He Has the Last Laugh
description: About 200 actors and actresses were gathered at New York's Century Theater on West 46th Street one afternoon last week to audition for ''Jitters,'' a planned production billed as ''a backstage comedy.''

title: Budget Cuts Force Bell-Ringer Out of University Job
description: Dependent as it is on automaking, Michigan, in the 1980 recession, was hit with layoffs of thousands of mechanics, machinists, lathe operators, truckdrivers, and assemblymen, and of hundreds of whitecollar workers. Also laid off in Michigan last year was one carillonneur.

title: BRAZIL DEVALUES CRUZEIRO
description: The Central Bank of Brazil said it adjusted the cruzeiro downwards for the second time this year to 68.80/67.13. The rate was last changed Jan. 6 and the accumulated downward adjustment since the start of the year was 4.496 percent.

title: Rockets 98, Nuggets 97
description: Moses Malone scored 37 points and pulled down 19 rebounds, and Allen Leavell's jump shot from the corner with 1:14 remaining was decisive.

title: QUESTION BOX By S. Lee Kramer
description: QUESTION: In professional football, Team A's kick for an extra point is blocked, but one of its players recovers the ball behind the line of scrimmage and runs into the end zone with it. How many points does Team A get? What happens if the player who recovers the ball attempts a pass and the ball is intercepted? Can the ball be run back for a touchdown?

title: PRESIDENT MUST TAKE SEVERAL STEPS TO FULFILL U.S. SIDE OF AGREEMENT
description: Under the agreement with Iran on freeing the hostages, President Carter must take several steps to fulfill the American side of the accord.

title: RECITAL: BORIS BLOCH, PIANIST, PLAYS STRAVINSKY, PABST, CHOPIN
description: RARELY do musical intelligence, enthusiasm and technique come together so harmoniously as they do in the music-making of Boris Bloch. His piano recital at the 92d Street Y last Thursday evening was a victory of taste over the arrogance of technique. Mr. Bloch's physical resources in matters of velocity, power and color seem unlimited. Yet they are never allowed to go their own way. With this program of Stravinsky, Beethoven, Schumann, Chopin and Pabst, Mr. Bloch seemed to rise up out of the massive proletariat of young piano virtuosos and establish his undisputable aristocracy. There may be more good pianists than ever before, but there are just as few truly good ones.

title: Madden, Ex-Raider, Picks His Old Team
description: The Oakland Raiders head for New Orleans tomorrow for next Sunday's Super Bowl game against Philadelphia, and their former coach, John Madden, picks them them to win.

title: U.S. GIVING SALVADOR COMBAT EQUIPMENT
description: After months of controversy and hesitation within the Administration over supplying ''lethal'' military aid to El Salvador, President Carter has authorized the emergency delivery of $5 million in combat equipment to help the Salvadoran armed forces combat a major uprising by Marxist guerrillas.

title: 'A TINGE OF ELITISM'
description: To the Editor:

title: Roosevelt to Open Despite Strike
description: Roosevelt Racway plans to open a 66-night meeting tomorrow night despite the threat of a strike by the parimutuel clerks, the track president, William B. Hopkins, announced today.

title: Chile Power Plant Pact
description: The Chilean state copper corporation, Codelco, has ordered an $80 million electricity plant from the Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan to supply power to its Chuquicamata mine, Codelco said Friday. The 75-megawatt plant will start in 1983 and replace existing smaller units. The purchase is being financed by the Export-Import Bank of Japan, it added.

title: BULLETS DEFEAT NETS AS PORTER SCORES 31
description: The New Jersey Nets, who won two games in a row only three times this season, came into the Capital Centre today after ending a 14-game losing streak last night. They were hoping to put two straight victories together for Coach Bob MacKinnon, something he hasn't enjoyed yet this season.

title: Speed Skating Title To Miss Petruseva
description: Natalya Petruseva of the Soviet Union won the women's European all-round speedskating championship today.

title: Deflation Policy Held In Error
description: Major industrial countries could lead the world economy out of endemic recession and reduce inflation by accepting higher oil prices and expanding output, according to a group of British economists.

title: Sporting Gear; New Cross-Country Skis
description: The Impala and the Horizon AR are two new cross-country skis that are suitable for both men and women. The Impala, whose sizes range from 180 to 215 centimeters, has an acrylic foam core and a fiberglass torsion box. The ski has a base made of P-Tex 2000 material, a metal tail protector and a binding plate made of a fiberglass and ash composite. The Horizon AR comes in sizes ranging from 183 to 213 centimeters. With replaceable multistep strips on its base, the Horizon AR is a waxless ski. It is made similarly to the Impala except that its base is of supernabutene. The Horizon AR weighs only 1,540 grams and is recommended for racing, track skiing, light touring, backpack skiing and mountaineering. The Impala sells for $120 a pair, the Horizon AR for $110. Both skis, made by Rossignol of France, are available at many ski shops in the metropolitan area.

title: STUDY FINDS GROUND WATER PERILED BY TOXIC CHEMICALS
description: The Council on Environmental Quality said in a report to President Carter yesterday that it had been able to document that the ground water in much of the country was being threatened by widespread contamination from toxic organic chemicals.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Beech Aircraft Corporation, Wichita, Kan., a subsidiary of the Raytheon Company, has elected Edward C. Burns president, succeeding Frank E. Hedrick, who was elected vice chairman and chairman of the executive committee.

title: BORG DEFEATS LENDL, 6-4, 6-2, 6-2, WINS 2D MASTERS TITLE
description: Bjorn Borg reaffirmed his dominance as the No. 1 player in tennis with a 6-4, 6-2, 6-2 rout of Ivan Lendl for the $100,000 first prize in the Volvo Masters tournament at Madison Square Garden yesterday. It was Borg's second consecutive Masters crown, and he won both without losing a set in the finals.

title: U.S. AND IRAN SIGN ACCORD ON HOSTAGES: 52 AMERICANS COULD BE SET FREE TODAY
description: The United States and Iran reached formal agreement early this morning on the terms for releasing the 52 American hostages and returning to Iran billions of dollars of its assets frozen by American authorities.

title: I.B.M. FACES EUROPE ON ANTITRUST CHARGE
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, the world's largest computer maker, is girding itself for a protracted legal battle in Europe over accusations that it has exploited its domination of the Continent's multibillion-dollar computer business to hamper competition.

title: No Headline
description: NOW that Super Bowl XV is about to be played, there have been enough games to justify the solemnity of a tribal right - the selection of an all-time Super Bowl team. Unfortunately, there is not enough evidence available to choose the all-time Super Bowl ticket-scalper or the all-time Super Bowl money-under-the-table hotel room clerk. But the games, for better or for worse, are burned into memory. Some of the selections were easy, others difficult. When in doubt, those who made big plays were given higher priority, if for no other reason than that Super Bowl games are decided by big plays.

title: Raiding the Raiders
description: Last Thursday, a photographer for The Philadelphia Inquirer, Vicki Valerio, showed up at the Oakland Raiders training site and was greeted by a comment from Lester Hayes, the Raiders star defensive back: ''Oh, a spy.''

title: THE CAPITAL PARTY GAME IS SEEING AND BEING SEEN
description: The Californians are here en masse, as are the New Yorkers, the Texans and the social and political heavyweights from all points in between, for a pre-inaugural round of activities that would fell ordinary mortals. But the game here is to see and be seen at the right places, and with vitamins, limousines and cast-iron stomachs, the chances are the visitors will all survive.

title: FLOW OF ARMS TO REBELS GIVEN AS REASON FOR AID
description: United States Embassy officials have been warning over the past week that the flow of weapons to Salvadoran guerrillas from Nicaragua has been rapidly increasing and have given this as the reason for the resumption of military aid, including combat supplies, to El Salvador.

title: LOW-POWER TV PROJECT ISDELAYED
description: The Federal Communications Commission's approval 10 days ago of a plan to allow hundreds of new low-power television stations has touched off an angry reaction from commercial and public broadcasting interests, possibly derailing the project.

title: STAGE: 'OH ME, OH MY, OH YOUMANS'
description: ALTHOUGH Vincent Youmans is usually included with George Gershwin, Jerome Kern, Richard Rodgers and Cole Porter in the top rank of composers of the musical comedies that were characteristic of the 1920's, he is so little known to contemporary audiences that people leave ''Oh Me, Oh My, Oh Youmans,'' the lively survey of his career at the Wonderhorse Theater, exclaiming, ''I didn't know he wrote 'Time on My Hands',''''I didn't know he wrote 'Without a Song.'''

title: Argentina Projects '81 Budget Deficit
description: Argentina's draft budget for 1981 envisages a deficit equal to 2.9 percent of the gross national product, Economy Minister Jose Martinez de Hoz said today.

title: SQUIRES TAKES RUN FOR FIFTH STRAIGHT
description: Pete Squires of the New York Athletic Club captured his fifth straight race yesterday when he won the Metropolitan Athletic Congress and the New York Road Runners Club 15-kilometer championship at Central Park in 46 minutes 6 seconds.

title: People
description: * Richard F. O'Brien named executive vice president of Grey Advertising.

title: Trudeau's Linguistics
description: When Canada's Prime Minister, Pierre Trudeau, addressed a group of Brazilian businessmen in Sao Paulo last week, a local radio station reported that he had begun his speech in Spanish, switched to French and finished in English.

title: CANADIAN GATEWAY TO THE PACIFIC RIM
description: Businessmen here on Canada's west coast have always talked about doing business with "the East." Nowadays, more often than not, that means the Far East. As Canada's gateway to the rapidly expanding group of countries around the Pacific Ocean, the so-called Pacific Rim, British Columbia is taking a leading role in developing mass markets there. Many economists expect the rim countries to be the world's fastest growing area in 1980's. A provincial trade delegation, led by Premier William Bennett, is preparing to depart for the area in February. It is the latest such business mission since Canada's Government held a Pacific Rim Opportunities Conference for several hundred executives here in November. "The future for us is the Pacific Rim," said J. Arthur Lower, a Canadian historian who has written widely on the area. Comprising almost three dozen nations, the Pacific Rim stretches from here to Chile, across to Australia and New Zealand and up to China, Japan and South Korea. Together, the area encompasses more than 1.75 billion people, or about 48 percent ofthe world's population. Many of the land - such as South Korea, for instance, which has 50 percent more people than all of Canada - have undergone impressive growth in recent years with basic investments and rising per capita incomes. This has fueled mounting demand for foreign expertise, raw materials and manufactured goods. Besides the attractiveness of Asia's expanding markets, the reasons for the trade growth include proximity (Vancouver is 350 miles closer to Tokyo than it is to Halifax on the eastern coast of Canada), the Canadian West's growing economic power and assertiveness, a need to branch beyond relatively mature domestic markets and a desire for diversification from reliance on United States sales.

title: WEST VICTOR IN JAPAN BOWL
description: Freeman McNeil and his U.C.L.A. teammate, Kenny Easley, sparked the West all-stars to a 25-13 victory over the East today in the sixth Japan Bowl at Yokohama Stadium.

title: IN 2 TOWNS, VOICES ARE RAISED IN PRAYER AND SONG
description: Eleven months ago a group of citizens here vowed to raise one American flag each day that the 52 Americans remained held captive in Iran. Tonight, they raised flag No. 442 and said they hoped it would be the last.

title: MOOD OF SUBDUED ANTICIPATION OVER NATIVE SON'S FATE GRIPS ARIZONA TOWN
description: Jesse and Mary Lopez were lining up for communion at Holy Angels Church this morning when the screen of the television set in the modest rectory across the courtyard went blank. Moments later, an announcer was reading a report from the official Iranian press agency that an agreement to release the 52 American hostages, including their son, apparently had been reached.

title: Polar Bears Accord Is Prepared
description: Five countries with Arctic territories are expected to extend an expiring accord protecting the polar bear, now an endangered species, according to the Norwegian Ministry of Environment. It said representatives from the United States, the Soviet Union, Norway, Denmark and Canada were to meet in Oslo for two days beginning Tuesday to officially extend the pact, which was signed in 1973.

title: Turkish Seamen Feared Drowned
description: The 34-member crew of the Turkish freighter Deniz Sonmez, which sank off Crete yesterday, are feared to have drowned, the Ministry of Merchant Marine said today. A spokesman said a search for the seamen, who abandoned ship after sending a distress signal, had proved fruitless.

title: Pro Football Briefs Saints and Phillips Still Holding Talks
description: John Mecom, the New Orleans Saints' owner, says there are things still to be discussed, but that he is ''ninety-nine percent sure'' Bum Phillips will become his head coach.

title: DANCE: LIZ PASQUALE PERFORMS 'BIRD FAUVE CAT' AT DANSPACE':
description: ''BIRD FAUVE CAT,'' a program conceived by Liz Pasquale and Jeffrey Lew and seen on Saturday at Danspace, opened with Miss Pasquale crawing noisily onto the stage on all fours, dressed in colorful tatters and roller skates and swathed in toilet paper. Not a promising entrance even in performance art, infected as it often seems to be with studied irrelevance. But the performer is the constant in an art form that throws off the restrictions of content and style inherent in traditional drama and dance. And Miss Pasquale is a mesmerizing performer. She does not look as if she could do a fouette to save her life, or had ever sprinted into a Cunningham cantilever. But there was something about that snub face, those thoughtful eyes and that lithe dancer's body with its soft but clearly defined arms.

title: Bernard Hibel, Executive, Marries Annette Weiser
description: At the Sutton Place Synagogue yesterday, Annette Weiser, director of the investment property division of the First American Realty Group Ltd., was married to Bernard Hibel, an executive vice president of the Kayser-Roth Corporation. Rabbi David B. Kahane performed the ceremony.

title: No Headline
description: DIPLOMAT REPORTS NO MOVEMENT IN DISCUSSIONS ON IRAQ-IRAN WAR

title: MUSIC: RUTH LAREDO'S RACHMANINOFF
description: SERGEI RACHMANINOFF is one of those artists who loom larger as they recede in time. As a composer his place is secure, though somewhat below the highest level. As a pianist, his reputation has long since passed into the empyrean of legend, a legend not at all threatened by the existence of his many astonishing recordings. Ruth Laredo, who recently recorded all of his solo piano works for CBS, saluted both the composer and the pianist last night at Carnegie Hall, in a program called ''Homage to Rachmaninoff.''

title: HOMEOWNERS IN TRISTATE REGION REDUCE USE OF FUEL OIL AS PRICES INCREASE
description: Home insulation, the use of gas or wood, and a greater willingness to lower the thermostat have sharply cut oil use by homeowners in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut this winter, according to industry and government estimates. Oil use, which was down about 20 percent last winter compared with the winter of 1978-79, has fallen again, despite this winter's colder weather, according to most estimates. The motivating factor is the price, now at $1.15 in some areas. "It's going up faster than we expected," said Charles Garrity, a spokesman for the New Jersey energy office. Fuel dealers and state and Federal energy officials say that between 2 and 3 percent of oil users have converted to gas in recent months, and those who remain with oil have insulated attics and installed storm windows, used more wood for heat and simply refused to use their oil furnaces on chilly nights at the beginning and end of the heating season, cutting consumption sharply. Part of National Trend The changes in the three states are part of a national trend, which saw demand for middle distillates - a category that includes home heating oil - drop 12.1 percent in 1980, the American Petroleum Institute, and industry group, estimated last week. The institute said that the demand for petroleum products was more responsible to price than had previously been believed. Middle distillates include diesel fuel, a substance chemically identical to No. 2 heating oil. According to Al Linden, a spokesman for the Federal Department of Energy, "the only difference between them is the tax."

title: Doonesbury Is First In Santa Anita Race
description: Doonesbury scored a 1 1/4-length victory today in the $119,300 San Fernando Stakes at Santa Anita.

title: Delay at Itel
description: The Itel Corporation, whose board of directors met late Friday to consider the possibility of entering bankruptcy proceedings, will have no announcement until tomorrow, the company said. Itel said late last week that it might file for bankruptcy because of its severe financial problems.

title: Persian Gulf War and Afghanistan Are Put on Islamic Parley Agenda
description: Islamic foreign ministers agreed here today to include the Iran-Iraq war and Afghanistan on the agenda for the Islamic summit conference starting next Sunday.

title: CARTER, AIDES AND REPORTERS SHARE A VIGIL AND CONCERN
description: With his Presidency winding down, Jimmy Carter spent long hours in tense meetings with his aides yesterday awaiting a solution to the crisis that dominated his last 14 months in office, and then waited into the early morning for word from the Middle East.

title: LOUISVILLE 71, MISSOURI 49
description: Lancaster Gordon, a freshman, scored 19 points and keyed one of two Louisville streaks that enabled the Cardinals to post a 71-49 victory over Missouri today.

title: YEAR OF CAPTIVITY: THE LONG, FRUSTRATING EFFORT TO END A NATIONAL HUMILIATION
description: Not since Pearl Harbor had the nation been so humiliated. Several dozen of its diplomats and servicemen were held captive for more than a year in a far-away land by a seemingly irrational mob led by an aged Islamic ascetic, and Americans, from President Carter on down, were powerless to act.

title: MOSCOW STARTS TO TURN ITS ATTENTION TO REAGAN'S POLICIES AND ASSOCIATES
description: The Soviet Union is gradually beginning to criticize the policies and associates of President-elect Ronald Reagan as Inauguration Day approaches.

title: In a Change of Heart Evan-Picone Expands Ads
description: Joseph Picone, founder and head of Evan-Picone Inc., the women's apparel division of the Palm Beach Company, was never a big believer in advertising programs for the company. Co-op advertising by the retailers was all right, but he seemed to think the department store sales people should do the selling.

title: IRAN SAYS HOSTAGE 'ADVENTURE' IS ENDING
description: ''I think the adventure is reaching its final point,'' Behzad Nabavi, Iran's chief hostage negotiator, said early this morning in telling the nation that an agreement had finally been reached for release of the 52 American captives.

title: Washington Watch; Auto Regulations: A 'Federal Menu'
description: WASHINGTON FOR the first time, all of the Federal Government's regulations affecting the auto industry are set out under one cover, the wish list, or hit list, depending on one's priorities.

title: THE DANCE: HSUEH-TUNG CHEN AND WORKS IN THE MODERN IDIOM
description: TWO choreographers staged works on varied themes at Saturday night's performance by Hsueh-Tung Chen and Dancers at Pace University's Schimmel Center for the Performing Arts. These works, all of them in the modern-dance idiom, were carefully constructed, yet they tended to be bloodless.

title: THE 37TH ANNUAL BLACK-TIE BALL FOR THE UNSUNG SUPERINTENDENT
description: It was the perfect evening for a superintendents' ball. The temperature outside the Biltmore Hotel was 16 degrees, the windchill factor was 11 degrees below zero, it was in the dead of night and in the depths of the weekend. In short, the sort of conditions when an encounter with a building superintendent was no more likely than a sighting of the elusive Ross's gull.

title: New York State Facing A Run on Heating Aid
description: Social Services Commissioner Barbara B. Blum said today that so many people were applying for help with their heating bills that the state might have to seek more Federal money.

title: Black Hawks 7 Nordiques 2
description: Tom Lysiak scored his 15th and 16th goals of the season and assisted on two other scores in the Black Hawks' victory over Quebec, Chicago's seventh straight triumph.

title: MARSHALL BERGEN
description: Dr. Marshall Bergen, an orthopedic surgeon who headed orthopedic departments in three Jersey City medical institutions, died of a heart attack Saturday at the Jersey City Medical Center.

title: MUSIC: OLATUNJ BIDS FAREWELL
description: BABATUNDE OLATUNJI, who is returning to his native Nigeria after living in the United States for 30 years, gave the first of a projected series of farewell concerts at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday night. The concerts are intended to endow the Olatunji Center of African Culture, which opened its doors in 1967. Mr. Olatunji has long been America's most celebrated teacher of African drumming and dance, and he has said that he hopes the center will carry on this work while he pursues a political career in Nigeria.

title: WITH EACH FRESH BULLETIN ON THE HOSTAGES, GROWING HOPE NUDGES DOUBT ASIDE
description: The bells were tolled for the hostages once again today at All Saints Episcopal Church, and the volunteer pulling the bell ropes, Robert A. Aylward, felt an adrenal surge in a task that had become physically draining through months of crisis.

title: 'AUDIO AND VISUAL KIDS' LEARNING TO WRITE PROSE
description: Eleanor Friedman and Madeline Staffanell, teachers of English, agree that there is a sure way to recognize the average classroom in which high school students are working on a writing assignment. Most of them will be counting.

title: Calgary Hostage Siege Over Foreclosure Ends
description: A six-day hostage drama stemming from a home mortgage foreclosure ended early today when the home buyer released his last hostage and surrendered, the police reported.

title: No Headline
description: For many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the handicapped person is often the one most deserving of help.

title: HIGHLY PROFITABLE HIGH INTEREST RATES
description: To the Editor:

title: Policeman on Leave Kills Holdup Suspect
description: A Transit Authority police officer on leave pending his retirement shot and killed a man who was attempting to steal a hired limousine that the officer was driving on East 57th Street, the police said. His accomplice fled.

title: Commodities; Worrisome Stagnation In Copper
description: BECAUSE copper has traditionally served as an accurate barometer of economic activity, the last two months of depressed futures prices have cast a shadow over all metals markets. And prices have not been helped by the widespread belief that the new administration plans to increase defense spending greatly to stimulate the economy.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE NATION; Pennsylvania Investigation Cites Transportation Dept.

title: HAYES: THE LAST DEFENSE
description: OAKLAND THE interceptions have come so often, in so many places, that the players and coaches of the Oakland Raiders cannot pick a special one. They just remember what Lester Hayes, their left cornerback, has done over and over this season.

title: TALE OF DUSKY SPARROW REFLECTS DIFFICULTY IN SAVING RARE SPECIES
description: Five of the last dusky sparrows known to be living on this planet are awaiting their fate in captivity on what amounts to a pension of $9,200 each. A sixth dusky sparrow, believed to be still alive, is on his own. But all are males, and, so far as is known, no female of the species has survived.

title: Peru Sells Oil to Japan
description: Peru is to receive a record oil price of $41.15 a barrel for a 600,000-barrel shipment to Japan, oil industry sources said Friday. The previous highest price for Peruvian oil was $40 a barrel paid on the spot market, they said. The shipment of 600,000 barrels is the first under an agreement reached last November for Peru to deliver 1.3 million barrels of crude as part payment of a $330 million loan granted in 1974.

title: A Parade Is Planned Only If Eagles Win
description: If the Philadelphia Eagles defeat the Oakland Raiders in Super Bowl XV Jan. 25, there will be a celebration parade here, according to Leonard Tose, owner of the National Football Conference championship team.

title: A New Clerk Takes Over Supreme Court Post
description: When the Supreme Court reconvenes this morning, Michael Rodak Jr. will not be in his accustomed place, recording orders of the Court. Mr. Rodak, who had been Clerk of the Supreme Court since 1972, retired on Friday just in time to take advantage of special pension benefits that expired that day.

title: Rutgers Trackmen Take Jersey Crown
description: Walter Kirkland, a Rutgers senior, tied for first place in the 800-meter run and helped Rutgers' two-mile relay team to a meet-record time of 7 minutes 42.10 seconds as the Scarlet Knights won the New Jersey college track championships at Jadwin Gymnasium today.

title: SOME COMPANIES ARE LIKELY TO SUE U.S. OVER IRAN CLAIMS
description: The outcome of more than 300 legal claims that United States companies have filed against Iran was unclear last night as word spread of a settlement between the United States and Iran. The company claims total about $3 billion.

title: Schuchter of Austria Captures Pro Slalom
description: Robert Schuchter of Austria won the slalom event on Mount Mansfield today, the fifth stop in the Avis Cup competition of the World Pro Ski Tour.

title: SAVING THE EAST SIDE FROM
description: GIGANTISM To the Editor:

title: BEHIND THE CHRYSLER AGREEMENT
description: At one point in working out the plan for additional loan guarantees for the Chrysler Corporation, Treasury Secretary G. William Miller paused duing a lunch with some of the key people involved in the effort.

title: Western Urges Halt by UNC
description: Western Air Lines Inc., which is planning to merge with Continental Airlines, is asking UNC Resources to stop its ''bizarre'' and ''disturbing'' actions hinting at a merger proposal with Western. The request was made in a letter, dated today and released yesterday.

title: Jacqueline Anne Braun Wed to Alan Weinstein
description: Jacqueline Anne Braun, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Braun of Jackson Heights, Queens, was married yesterday to Alan Andrew Weinstein, son of Mrs. David Baumrin of New York, and the late Seymour Weinstein. Rabbi Irving Rockoff performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

title: Market Place; Age of Spin-Offs In Technology
description: ANYONE who has used ''pioneering equipment,'' such as 30-year-old escalators in a department store knows that, technologically speaking, first is worst.

title: White Parents of 3 Girls Said to Balk at School Shift
description: The parents of three white girls will not sign an agreement sought by a Federal district judge under which the girls would be bused to an integrated high school starting next week, one of the parents and their attorney said today.

title: THE AMERICAN AILMENT
description: They say here that only one Frenchman ever wrote a good book about the United States, though many have tried. The one was, of course, Alexis de Tocqueville, and from what I've seen of others, his superiority resulted not least from the fact that he liked the country without envying it.

title: Eglevsky Ballet Giving Two Series on L.I.; Eglevsky Ballet Sets Two Series on L.I.
description: Two new dances choreographed by Edward Villella, artistic coordinator of the Eglevsky Ballet, will open the company's February series at two Long Island locations - the State University of New York at Stony Brook and Hofstra University in Hempstead In addition, Gelsey Kirkland and Patrick Bissell will dance with the company in previously unscheduled performances at Hofstra.

title: RICHARD WILSON, WON A PULITZER
description: Richard Lawson Wilson, a Pulitzer Prize-winning national correspondent who headed the Washington bureau of The Des Moines Register and Tribune for 37 years, died in Washington yesterday of cancer. He was 75 years old.

title: Advertising; Nikon Moving To Scali
description: THE three-month search by Nikon Inc. for a new agency has ended: Scali, McCabe, Sloves has won the $10 million account. Behind the decision are many days of work and the expenditure of considerable money by a handful of agencies that made the speculative creative presentations required by Nikon.

title: Capitals 3, Whalers 2
description: Washington continued to win with the rookie Dave Parro in goal. He has won in his last three starts while filling in for the injured Wayne Stephenson and Mike Palmateer.

title: 3 BOYS SAVED FROM ICY HUDSON ARE ACCUSED OF PURSE SNATCHING
description: Three youths being carried down the Hudson River on an ice floe yesterday were rescued by a police helicopter near the George Washington Bridge. But, once back ashore, they were charged by the police with second-degree robbery in a Fort Tryon Park pursesnatching.

title: CITRUS PRICES SET TO RISE IN STORES
description: The icy blasts that swept across much of Florida's 859,000 acres of citrus groves early last week caused losses to orange growers estimated at $36 million by the industry, and price increases to consumers around the nation are expected to result.

title: THE BLACK-WHITE GAP
description: The gap between the living standards of white and black people in the United States is wider today than it was when the civil rights movement gained momentum in the early 1960's.

title: Maple Leafs 5, Jets 4
description: Darryl Sittler scored his 25th and 26th goals, including the winner with 11:05 left, in Toronto's triumph. Sittler, after sidestepping a goalmouth scramble, tipped the puck past Pierre Hamel, the Winnipeg goalie.

title: FORECAST ON RATES IS REVISED
description: The long-awaited decline in interest rates, already overdue according to forecasts made a month or more ago, may be slow in coming, credit market analysts now say.

title: FOOTBALL AUCTION WEEK IN MOBILE: SOME PRIZES, SOME SURPRISES
description: AN extraordinary week of football ended Saturday, a week described by many here as a meat market of college talent all of it prodded, inspected, weighed, measured for toughness and tenderness, by pro football's coaches, assistants, talent scouts and agents.

title: IN CAPITAL, A CONVERGENCE OF 100,000 INAUGURAL VISITORS AND SOME SPECIAL HOPES
description: Two kinds of expectancy hung over the capital today as 100,000 visitors jammed sidewalks and hotels and joined in small ceremonies of exasperation at the Inaugural Committee's ticket counters.

title: Wax Moves to Wells, Rich
description: Edward L. Wax, 44 years old, president and chief operating officer of the New York office of Geers, Gross, the London agency, will be joining Wells, Rich, Greene/East as executive vice president and assistant to the president, Ken Olshan. Mr. Wax was working for Compton Advertising when he decided to go to Richard K. Manoff Inc., as president. That agency was acquired by Geers, Gross.

title: East Germany Issues Glowing Economic Report
description: An East German Government report issued during the weekend showed that the nation's economy was in better condition last year than at any time since the mid-1970's.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The U.S. Government has finally accepted all the terms set by the Government of the Islamic Republic of Iran for the release of the American hostages.'' - Behzad Nabavi, chief Iranian negotiator. (A1:4.)

title: Pope Celebrates a Mass For Polish Labor Leader
description: Pope John Paul II celebrated a private mass for Lech Walesa and a 14-member delegation of his Polish independent union movement today and then had breakfast with them in the papal quarters. Vatican officials did not say what was discussed.

title: TV PORTRAIT OF ELDERLY CRITICIZED
description: ''People over 65 appear to comprise less than 5 percent of the people population on television,'' Dr. Richard H. Davis told a White House Mini Media Conference, sponsored in New York at the Interchurch Center by the Gray Panthers Project Fund. According to surveys he said, ''This percentage, far less than the proportion in the real population, reflects an apparent conviction that interesting things happen only to the young.''

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 19, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY; Council for Namibia - 3 P.M.; ECONOMIC AND; SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Statistical Commission - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Massachusetts Will Allow Gas-Heated Schools to Open
description: Gov. Edward J. King said today that gasheated schools in Massachusetts would be allowed to reopen tomorrow after a one-day shutdown Friday that was due to a shortage of natural gas.

title: Ad Pages Fell for Month
description: Member magazines of the Publishers Information Bureau carried 12,186 ad pages in November 1980, 4 percent fewer than a year earlier. But revenues rose 4 percent, to $311.5 million, as a result of rate increases, according to the Magazine Publishers Association.

title: LOPSIDED HAGLER BOUT DELIGHTS ANTUOFERMO
description: Vito Antuofermo happily drank in the boos last night before the Boston Massacre of Fulgencio Obelmejias with the fervor of a man thirsting for a rematch with Marvin Hagler, easy winner and still middleweight champion of all the world boxing authorities.

title: Jack Winter Picks Homer & Durham
description: Jack Winter Inc., manufacturer of women's sportswear, confirmed Friday that it had selected Homer & Durham to replace AC&R Advertising, a subsidiary of Ted Bates & Company.

title: MUSIC: JUDITH LASKIN SINGS YIDDISH SONGS
description: ACOMPLETE world of sense and sensibility could be heard when Judith Laskin sang Lazar Weiner's Yiddish songs at the 92d Street Y on Sunday afternoon. The lyrical sighs of ''Shtile Licht'' were framed by weighty silences. The dreamy and playful sincerity of ''Volt Majn Tate Rajch Geven'' was untouched by cynicism or irony.

title: CIVILETTI'S INTEGRITY AND ACCOMPLISHMENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Projection, Infection, Election
description: With Inauguration Day upon us, the wake of the 1980 election should have dissipated at last. Yet concern still bubbles about two problems.

title: WHEN MARRIED CHILDREN COME HOME TO LIVE
description: Whenever Marie Claire Wright, a young mother with a 7-month-old baby, cooks meat loaf for dinner these days, she makes sure she remembers to pack all the chopped onions toward one end of the dish.

title: Marschalk Names Wilen As Nonmedia Media Man
description: It looks as if the Marschalk Company keeps an open mind: It has named a media director with no media department experience.

title: Monday, January, 19, 1981; The Iranian Situation
description: American banks are ready to transfer some $6 billion in frozen Iranian deposits. Iran would, in turn, repay its debts to big American banks. Bankers said the plan, initiated by Iran, was more favorable than one it had rejected.. The agreement appeared to remove a final obstacle toward the release of the 52 American hostages. (Page A1.)

title: KOCH TO DECLARE WATER EMERGENCY
description: Mayor Koch will declare a drought emergency today, officials said yesterday as the city's upstate reservoirs fell to 31.4 percent of capacity, the lowest level in 15 years. John Cunningham, spokesman for the Department of Environmental Protection, said that the city had a 110-day supply of water, and that reservoirs were dwindling at a rate of three-tenths of a percent a day.

title: State Seeking Grant For a Fuel Study
description: The Power Authority of the State of New York has reapplied for a Federal grant to study the feasibility of developing a syntheticfuels complex in western New York, John S. Dyson, the authority chairman, said. Complaining that New York was virtually ignored by the Department of Energy when the original grants were awarded, Mr. Dyson said the state had applied for a $900,000 grant incorporating the major features of a $1.2 million request that was rejected last month.

title: Out of One National Guard and Into Another
description: Last July, concerned about what he called ''all the stuff going on in the world - the trouble in Iran and Afghanistan and all that,'' Ed Feuz enlisted in the Army National Guard in his hometown of Jesup, Ga., and began giving one weekend a month to his country.

title: BUSY MONTH DEVELOPS FOR NEW BOND ISSUES
description: January is shaping up as the heaviest month for new corporate bond issues since last August. Salomon Brothers, the investment banking house, predicts that $3 billion of corporate issues might come to market this month, though many proposed issues are contingent on interest rates' not rising substantially.

title: READY-MADE CASINOS
description: To the Editor:

title: Arrows (22-2) Win 16th Straight, 12-5
description: Fred Grgurev scored five goals and assisted on two others as the New York Arrows beat the Baltimore Blast, 12-5, today in a Major Indoor Soccer League game before a crowd of 6,725 at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Scout Team
description: On the day before the Super Bowl, in a less impressive New Orleans setting than the Superdome, 98 football players will perform for less glory - but equally professional goals. They are minor-league aspirants who seek N.F.L. jobs. The 98 are taking part in the first national all-star game for minor leaguers and they were selected from 217 teams that encompass about 10,000 players. The game was organized by the Minor Professional Football Association, which is bringing the non-N.F.L. teams under one umbrella.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AMERICAN INDIAN ART

title: COMPLEX FUNDS TRANSFER MERELY MATTER OF CABLES
description: The transfer of several billion dollars of Iranian assets out of the United States, one of the largest financial transactions in history and the result of extremely complicated negotiations, is a surprisingly simple process.

title: Aguirre Sets Mark as De Paul Wins, 90-75
description: Mark Aguirre became De Paul's career scoring leader with a 25-point performance today to lead the Blue Demons to a 90-75 victory over Wagner.

title: CHAMBER: OPENER OF AX'S SERIES OFFERS LIEDER BY BENITA VALENTE
description: WITH chamber music all around us these days, a musician's performing personality is defined as much by the musical company he keeps as by his solo efforts. Even the starriest names now eagerly join in with their musical peers, so it was no surprise to find a distinguished company of guests performing at the first of three ''Emanuel Ax Invites ... '' programs yesterday afternoon in Alice Tully Hall.

title: Morgan Plans Taiwan Branch
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York has been granted approval for a branch office in Taipei, the Ministry of Finance said Friday.

title: ALGERIANS IN HOSTAGE TALKS: 3 ASTUTE DIPLOMATS WHO ARE RISING STARS AT HOME
description: Throughout the delicate diplomacy to free the hostages, the three Algerians who have served as intermediaries between the United States and Iran cultivated a low public profile, seemingly reluctant to appear as anything more than message-carriers.

title: FORMING A BOND WITH THE NEWBORN
description: T HE bond formed between parents and infants in the moments after birth can make a lasting imprint on the attachment they will have later on, or so current thinking in some circles goes.

title: Carradine Back at Work
description: Another ''Frankenstein'' victim has landed on his feet. When the Broadway production closed after a single ill-received performance recently, among those thrown out of work was John Carradine.

title: ABOUT WASHINGTON
description: Beyond making a living by making fun of Jimmy Carter, Mark Russell always felt sorry for him.

title: South Alabama and Ellis Gaining Esteem
description: Lee Rose, Tates Locke and Gene Bartow came to the Sun Belt Conference with big coaching reputations. Cliff Ellis has built his reputation at South Alabama.

title: TV: 'CORONATION OF POPPEA' ON PBS
description: PIERRE PONELLE is one of opera's cleverest and most extravagantly inventive designers and stage directors. No opera he touches ever emerges looking quite the way the composer envisioned it, and he has unleashed the works on his Zurich staging of Claudio Monteverdi's ''The Coronation of Poppea.'' The production has been filmed for television, and it may be seen tonight at 8 on WNET-TV, Channel 13.

title: LIETZKE POSTS 69- 335 TO WIN BY 2
description: Bruce Lietzke, a rangy 29-year-old Oklahoman who supports his expensive car hobby with his winnings as a golf pro, won the Bob Hope Desert Classic today, beating Jerry Pate by two strokes.

title: Nina Streisand, a Teacher, Married to Dr. Aaron Sher
description: At Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, L.I., yesterday, Nina Kerry Streisand, a kindergarten teacher at the Town School, was married to Dr. Aaron Emanual Sher, an assistant professor of otorhinolaryngology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and chief of otorhinolaryngology at the North Central Bronx Hospital. Rabbi Seymour Siegel and Lieut.

title: Air Force Flies Balloonist's Craft To Egypt for Flight Around World
description: A balloon that Maxie Anderson hopes to fly around the world has been sent to Egypt on an Air Force C-5 transport plane, Senator Harrison H. Schmitt, Republican of New Mexico, said.

title: Dollar Up in Hong Kong
description: The dollar opened higher against major currencies here, dealers said. Sentiment was bullish for the dollar, both because of the likelihood the hostages in Iran would be released soon and because of Friday's United States report on the money supply, which indicated interest rates would remain high.

title: INNOVATIONS GET RESULTS FOR THE CITY'S LAW DEPT.
description: New York City's Corporation Counsel, Allen G. Schwartz, has implemented a series of far-reaching innovations in the three years since his appointment that have turned the Law Department into a rarity among city agencies: It is making money for the city treasury.

title: DROUGHT BRINGS HARD TIMES TO SKI RESORTS IN THE WEST
description: ''Normally, it's a good business,'' 34-year-old Marty Heffner said, looking dolefully around the deserted ski rental shop he manages here in the normally bustling Sierra Nevada ski country. ''With snow, there's a lot of money to be made. No snow, it's terrible. It's like farming - some years good, some bad; the wrong weather and it's a disaster.''

title: SALTWATER FISHING WITH FLYRODS GAINS MORE APPRECIATION
description: THE American penchant for competitive angling has enveloped saltwater flyfishing. More than a century ago, East Coast anglers were going after such species as tarpon, striped bass and bluefish with a flyrod, but they were a rare breed. The sport limped along on both coasts until World War II when such men as the late Joe Brooks, an accomplished angler and author, and Harold Gibbs of Rhode Island helped to make it more popular.

title: REAGAN PANEL'S STUDY ON THE INTERSTATE CASTS DOUBT OVER UNCOMPLETED ROADS
description: A Reagan task force's recommendation that most of the missing portions of the Federal Interstate System of highways be left uncompleted has left some state officials in the New York area uncertain about the future of projects they have been planning.

title: ISRAELI PREMIER WILL SEEK GENERAL ELECTIONS IN JULY
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin announced today that his Cabinet had decided to introduce legislation setting July 7 as the date for parliamentary elections, four months earlier than originally scheduled but two months later than the date advocated by the opposition Labor Party.

title: MAJOR INCREASE IN BURGLARIES TROUBLES NEW YORK SUBURBS
description: Burglaries have increased sharply in recent months throughout the suburbs of New York City, mainly because of the increased value of gold jewelry, silver flatware and dishes and rare coins, the police report.

title: Celtics Beat Lakers For 7th in Row, 98-96
description: Chris Ford scored a 3-point goal with 59 seconds to play and Nate Archibald added a free throw with nine seconds left to lead the Celtics to a 98-96 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers yesterday in Boston.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JANUARY 19, 1981
description: International The United States agreed on freedom for the 52 American hostages, a senior White House official said, but an announcement of the accord still awaited final word from Teheran. He said that despite the statement by Iran's chief negotiator that an accord had been reached, Iran had not yet notified Algerian intermedidaries of the its acceptance of the final texts of the agreement. (Page A1, Column 6.) An accord on unfreezing Iran's assets was reached early yesterday between the United States and Iran, banking sources said. Iran has agreed to immediately pay almost all its loans from American banks when its assets in the United States are released, the sources said. (A1:1.)

title: CONCERN OVER PUGET COULD DELAY PIPELINE
description: The Northern Tier Pipeline, the Carter Administration's effort to try to relieve oil shortages in the Rocky Mountain states and Upper Middle West, has run into a thicket of problems in Washington state that could delay the start of construction.

title: CALIFORNIA DEMOCRATS FACE DECLINE OF PARTY'S POWER IN STATE
description: Nudged by the fact that Ronald Reagan will be inaugurated as President this week, activists in California's Democratic Party spent a lot of time at their biennial convention yesterday discussing ways to revive their appeal to the party's constituency again.

title: Nancy J. Pressman Wed to Accountant
description: Nancy Jane Pressman, a lawyer in Philadelphia, was married there yesterday to Richard Morgenstern, an accountant. Rabbi Ivan Caine performed the ceremony at the Powel House.

title: 2 Earthquakes Occur Off Japan
description: Two strong earthquakes occurred within six minutes of each other early today about 100 miles off the east coast of Honshu, Japan's largest island. The United States Geological Survey said that the first quake had a Richter Scale magnitude of 6.4 and that the second had a magnitude of 6.7.

title: Miss Jaeger Victor
description: Andrea Jaeger defeated Martina Navratilova for the second time in nine days, 3-6, 6-3, 7-5, in the final of the $150,000 Avon tennis tournament today.

title: IN RIDGEWOOD, THEFT IS TABLE TOPIC
description: At a Saturday evening dinner party in this suburb, conversation turns from business and volunteer to burglary. "We are the only people in the neighborhood who haven't been robbed," says the hostess, who lives in a large Tudor-style house in this affluent Bergen County community near Manhattan. The guests talk of recent burglaries in their neighborhoods, of watching for the car of a known burglar, of burglars convicted and back on the street, of the fear that their homes will be next and the hope that if their homes are invaded, there will not be a confrontation with a burglar. The dinner guests have always viewed Ridgewood as a retreat from such problems. But the police say that when 1980 figures are tabulated, burglaries of residences and businesses here will number "more than 250," up significantly from 159 in 1979 and 189 in 1978. Sharp increases are being registered throughout the suburbs. Kay Shaw, whose home has not been broken into, said she believed the attitude of her fellow Ridgewood residents was one of "concern, not worry or fear." The concern leads many to ask that their names not be used. Fear and Anger Combine Betsy Kimmerle, who has been victimized by burglars, sees things differently. "Everyone in Ridgewood is hyper," she said. "Those who haven't been robbed are worried they will be." A friend, she added, keeps a baseball bat near the bed and is considering buying a gun. "He is so mad about the situation that he wants to catch burglars in the house and blow their brains out." she said. Mrs. Kimmerle and others interviewed in Ridgewood, however, said they did not keep guns in their houses.

title: ASSAULT CASES THAT DON'T BELONG IN CRIMINAL COURT
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILADELPHIA AND OAKLAND LOOK FOR AN EDGE
description: THE Philadelphia team is one that plays to its ability always and that's a pat on the back for the coach, Dick Vermeil, and his staff. One of the toughest problems for us football coaches is to get all team members to believe they are good enough to win. The Eagles feel that way now. They are going to New Orleans to win a football game and they have an excellent chance.

title: Sports World Specials By Jim Benagh
description: Beginnings and Endings

title: CONTAMINATION OF L.I. WELLS A CONSTANT WORRY TO MANY
description: When Emanual and Barbara Logan closed the sale on their house here seven years ago, they learned that their water would come from a private well in the backyard. As transplanted Brooklynites, that fact struck them as just another suburban curiosity - until about a year ago, when an organizer from a citizens' group knocked on the door.

title: TRUDEAU, IN MEXICO, DISCUSSES PLAN FOR MEETING ON DEVELOPMENT ISSUES
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada wound up a four-nation swing today after exchanging notes with President Jose Lopez Portillo on their joint efforts to promote discussions between industrialized and developing countries.

title: Suns 120, Hawks 86
description: Walter Davis had 21 points and Len ''Truck'' Robinson added 20 as the Suns defeated Atlanta for Phoenix's fourth straight victory.

title: Dwyer Says He Does Not Expect Iran to Release His Wife in Deal
description: State Department officials have not given John Dwyer any indication whether his wife will be among the American hostages released in any deal between the United States and Iranian Government.

title: David Rank, a Physicist Known for Optics Work
description: David H. Rank, a professor emeritus of physics at Pennsylvania State University and a leader in the field of optics, died yesterday at Centre County Community Hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: 10 Killed and 30 Injured In Fire at London Party
description: A fire swept through a three-story house today during an all-night teen-age birthday party, killing 10 people and injuring 30. The police said there were reports that the blaze had been caused by a firebomb thrown into the house.

title: SELLER OF A SUCCESSFUL WENDY'S
description: The restaurant with the best sales in Wendy's fast-food chain of 2,000 stores is on Seventh Avenue across from Pennsylvania Station. Last week, the owner of this Wendy's, Allen J. Bernstein, sold his business to a Cleveland shopping center developer. Mr. Bernstein's operation, the Wenco Food Systems Company, becomes the property of Jacobs, Visconsi & Jacobs of Cleveland. In all, Wenco operates 17 units, mainly on Long Island.

title: CITY BALLET: 'MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM' IN REVIVAL
description: IT was a pretty performance the New York City Ballet turned out for its revival of George Balanchine's ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' at the New York State Theater. But those who remember the past force and poetry of this unusual ballet to Mendelssohn's music might wonder why this time it appeared to lack consistency of dramatic projection.

title: A One-Shot Catch
description: If you could play pro football and make only one catch, where would it be? Undoubtedly, in the Super Bowl. In Super Bowl X in 1976, Percy Howard lived such a dream. As a rookie wide receiver for the Dallas Cowboys, Howard was still learning the game, having been signed for his athletic ability as a basketball player at Austin Peay. During the regular season and the playoffs, he did not catch a ball in a game. Late in the Super Bowl against Pittsburgh, he replaced Golden Richards, who was injured.

title: MONTGOMERY: OFFENSIVE TALENT
description: PHILADELPHIA THERE are years to remember and years to forget. Wilbert Montgomery isn't sure which this one is. Montgomery is the star running back of the Philadelphia Eagles, the one who must succeed if the Eagles are to beat the Oakland Raiders next Sunday in Super Bowl XV in New Orleans. If Montgomery stays well and runs well, he thinks it will be a year to remember.

title: DANCE: HARLEM TROUPE IN 'SERENADE'
description: SOME ballets are works for dancers to grow into. One is George Balanchine's ''Serenade,'' which the Dance Theater of Harlem presented for the first time this season at the City Center.

title: Citrus Growers in Florida Fighting a New Cold Spell
description: Citrus growers in Florida fought another wave of frigid temperatures today, and a 10-day embargo of fresh-fruit sales and shipments was begun after last week's damaging freeze.

title: Mae West Left Million, Mostly to Her Sister; Mae West Left Million, Mostly to Her Sister
description: Mae West, who died in November at the age of 87, left $1 million, according to her will filed in court here.

title: UNION OIL SUCCESSES SCARCER IN INDONESIA
description: Nearly 10 years after the Union Oil Company of California began negotiations with the Indonesian Government, the Los Angeles-based company made the first offshore oil discovery here in 1970, off Kalimantan, formerly Borneo. But the glow of success quickly wore off. For the find, the Attaka field, was just about on the Equator, 12 miles out in the Macassar Strait "in the middle of nowhere," said John N. Turk, managing director of Union Oil's Indonesian affiliate. Kalimantan had no roads, no manpower, no housing, no equipment. "There was nothing there but oil, at least 400 million recoverable barrels of it," Mr. Turk added. Union Oil then faced a situation that nearly all oil companies have since confrontation in energy investments in developing countries. "Finding energy is only the beginning," according to B. F. Miller, acting general manager of Union Oil's East Kalimantan operations. "Getting the energy is another problem." The Attaka field and subsequent finds at Kerindangan, Melahin, Yakin and Sepinggan on Kalimantan cost Union Oil more than $500 million in the first seven years, not for rigs but for basic installations and facitlities. "The rigs are just like those in the Gulf of Mexico," said Eddy Darmawan, a Union Oil engineer. "But we had to build a town, train workers, bring in the equipment. We had to start from scratch." Union Oil spent $10 million building a twon for its workers on Pasir Ridge in Balikpapan, an 80-minute helicopter ride from Attaka.

title: 52 AMERICANS COULD BE SET FREE
description: TODAY By ROBERT A. BENNETT

title: Second Prisoner Dies After Fire
description: A prisoner died today of injuries from a fire at the city jail yesterday.

title: Jersey Plant Leaks Chemical Fumes
description: A cloud of chemical vapors leaked from Allied Chemical's reprocessing plant after an instrument malfunctioned, officials said.

title: Pacers 110, Jazz 89
description: Mike Bantom scored 25 points, and George McGinnis and James Edwards each had 19 to lead the Pacers over Utah. The Pacers broke open the game with a 17-2 burst late in the second quarter.

title: HOPES FOR RELEASE BRINGS JOY AND ANGER
description: Some people unfurled flags, some grinned and hugged their families. Cheers went up, and church bells rang. But as reports spread throughout the New York metropolitan area yesterday that the release of the American hostages might be imminent, happiness was leavened with anger at their captors and concern for their condition. The long-awaited day evoked for some the fury they first felt when their countrymen were taken prisoner.

title: HOW DOES THE PROFESSOR DO IT?
description: To the Editor:

title: Stenmark Notches 56th Cup Ski Victory
description: Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden, ninth after the first heat, turned in a strong second heat here today to win the slalom ski race for his 56th World Cup victory.

title: Red Smith Ages of Sin Go Far Back
description: STILL another letter came along describing Roberto Duran's tryst with Sugar Ray Leonard as a fix. Like his predecessors, the writer submitted no evidence, pretended to no inside information and ignored logic. Apparently, it did not occur to him that if Duran had meant to go in the water, there were 37 approved dives from the one-meter board and 49 from the three-meter, and any of them could have been executed without raising the suspicions that were stirred when Roberto retired in mid-round.

title: C.A.B. SETS PAN AM ROUTE
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board recommended on Friday that Pan American World Airways receive authority to fly passengers between Mexico City and the Florida cities of Miami and Tampa. The recommendation was sent to the White House, which must make the final decision because international routes are involved.

title: WHEN A POLICE OFFICER SHOULD SHOOT FIRST
description: To the Editor:

title: DANES MAY EASE STAND AGAINST MORE ARMS SPENDING
description: Denmark, a country that has always liked the Atlantic alliance but has never been keen about helping pay for it, is giving signs of willingness to increase its military expenditures after more than a year of talk of no increases.

title: Penn State 63, Army 52
description: Frank Brickowski and Rich Fetter each scored 14 points tonight as Penn State held off an Army rally and defeated the Cadets, 63-52.

title: FEW PUBLISHERS PLANNING BOOKS ON THE HOSTAGES
description: The returning hostages are the focus of national attention, but book publishers are guessing that few Americans will want to know more about the hostages than what they read in the newspapers or see on television. As a result, few of them are planning books about the hostages, either ''instant'' paperbacks or hard-cover editions.

title: Israeli Cabinet Names New Finance Minister
description: Yoram Aridor, who joined Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Cabinet on Jan. 4 as Communications Minister, was chosen today to be Finance Minister.

title: No Headline
description: FLORIDA CITRUS HURT BY MORE COLD

title: Australia Travel Drive
description: ''Australia. Civilized Adventure,'' is the headline that will run on all ads in a new ad campaign by N.W. Ayer ABH International for the Australian Tourist Commission.

title: Consolidated Gas Sells Canada Interest
description: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company has agreed in principle to sell nearly all its Canadian gas and oil properties to Merland Explorations Ltd. of Ottawa for $62.8 million, the company announced.

title: T.V.A. PLANT SHUTS DOWN AGAIN
description: - Generator turbine malfunctions shut down the Tennessee Valley Authority's new $1.9 billion Seqyoyah nuclear power plant today for the second time in two days, officials said. The plant, 14 miles north of Chattanooga, shut down at 5 A.M., just 24 hours after a similar shutdown, said a spokesman Gil Francis. Mr. Francis said the reactor would not be put back into operation until operators and engineers can identify the problem in the nonnuclear portions of the plant and correct it.

title: STUDIES DECODE FLASHING LIGHTS OF CREATURES THAT GLOW
description: JUST as visitors flying into New York are often dazzled by the city's flickering lights on a clear night, so have scientists been fascinated and perplexed by the dim glows and multicolored lights produced by an enormous variety of animals in forests, in caves and in the ocean depths.

title: BANK OF ENGLAND NEGOTIATING WITH CUSTOMARY DISCRETION
description: This afternoon, as the Bank of England was busy setting up the transfer of billions of dollars in gold and other assets under the agreement that was to free the American hostages in Iran, a bank official said blandly, in answer to a reporter's inquiry about the transaction:

title: RONALD REAGAN'S LONG POLITICAL ASCENT FROM HOLLYWOOD ACTOR TO PRESIDENCY
description: For the tens of thousands of supporters of President-elect Ronald Reagan who are in the Capital today, the inauguration of the 40th President of the United States amounts to much more than a change of administrations and a shift in philosophy of government.

title: LIBERIA'S YOUNG SERGEANT STILL LEARNING HOW TO RULE
description: It has been nine months since 17 noncommissioned officers in the Liberian Army rose up from their tumbledown, tin-on-tin barracks on a beach below the Executive Mansion here, shot and bayoneted President William R. Tolbert Jr., and took over the Government without half a notion of how to run a country.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Gilbert AND SULLIVAN Can the Light Opera of Manhattan compete with the New York Shakespeare Festival? Of course. The Light Opera of Manhattan, or LOOM, as most people call it, has been doing Gilbert and Sullivan for 13 years. The Shakespeare Festival is new at it, even if its ''The Pirates of Penzance'' is such an enormous success. LOOM was born with a ''Pirates'' performance in a West Side apartment in 1968, but since 1976 it has been at the Eastside Playhouse, at 334 East 74th Street. It is a tiny theater, with only 284 seats, and the orchestra more often than not is made up of a piano, an electric organ and a couple of timpani. The organist plays the timpani. The company, however, comprises 40 singers, and you can hear some of them when LOOM opens its Gilbert and Sullivan Festival tomorrow night.

title: CAREY'S BUDGET MESSAGE PROPOSES TAX CUTS FOR INDIVIDUALS AND BUSINESSES
description: If Governor Carey gets his way in the State Legislature, New Yorkers could see reductions in their personal and property taxes. Businesses would enjoy at least three new tax reductions, which the Governor hopes could have a dramatic effect on bringing new business investment into the state.

title: PRIVATE SECTOR NOW DOMINATES REGION
description: ''Nation's Capital,'' the District of Columbia license plates proclaim, and indeed the area does include the Capitol itself as well as the White House, the grid of bureaucracies, memorials and museums that magnetize tourists and the rest of the buildings where 400,000 Federal workers toil in highvisibility Washington.

title: Bruins Beat Sabres 5-1
description: Wayne Cashman cracked Buffalo's strong penalty-killing unit for two power-play goals tonight, leading the Boston Bruins to a 5-1 victory over the Sabres.

title: Boston U. 62, Fairfield 59
description: Jay Twyman sank a pair of foul shots with two seconds left in the game and gave Boston University a 62-59 victory over Fairfield tonight.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Boeing Company received a $155.8 million Air Force contract for support equipment for the mobile MX missile's shelters.

title: CARTER AIDES FIND JOBS SCARCE
description: What do you do after you've had a high-paying job directing 12,000 employees, managing an annual budget of more than $5 billion, and formulating national regulatory policy, and are suddenly out of work?

title: BRAZIL OFF AND RUNNING FOR '82 ELECTION
description: Miro Teixeira is a young man so on the go that his body inclines forward at the waist like a racer straining for the finish line. Until recently, Brazilian politicians with his kind of ambition were simply leaning into space.

title: U.S. BANKS DENY RESPONSIBILITY FOR SNAG IN FREEING OF HOSTAGES
description: American banks holding frozen Iranian assets denied yesterday that they were responsible for a negotiating snag that delayed the release of the American hostages.

title: Treasury Aide Reported Set
description: Roger W. Mehle, a senior vice president and director at the investment banking firm of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., has been chosen as the new assistant secretary of the Treasury for domestic finance, sources said yesterday.

title: ARE THESE HOLLYWOOD'S FINEST
description: Academy Award season has rolled around again, and the studios are once more spending hundreds of thousands of dollars advertising their candidates. Columbia has budgeted $400,000 for trade-paper advertisements in an attempt to get nominations for its seven pictures, while 20th Century-Fox is spending $250,000 on its seven films.

title: THE KEY TO A CODE IN CAPITAL; WASHINGTON
description: The people in Washington are very different from you and me. They are healthy, pink-cheeked and polite. They are not opposed to sharing cabs with total strangers. And there is a certain kind of cultural homogeneity here, a pervasive upper-middle-class suburban conservatism in dress and carriage that is quite unlike New York eclecticism.

description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 20.00 20.00 15.25 DISCOUNT RATE* 13.00 13.00 12.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 19.82 19.82 14.06 3-MO. TREASURY BILLS 15.75 15.40 12.22 6-MO.
