Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Richard: Good Luck to Bossy
description: ''I hope Mike Bossy gets it, and I think he will,'' Maurice (Rocket) Richard said yesterday, referring to Bossy's attempt to match Richard's feat of 50 goals in 50 National Hockey League games. ''I'm as excited as he is because I've known him since he first started playing.''

title: Walter G. McGahan Is Dead at 75; A Councilman and State Senator
description: Walter G. McGahan, a former Republican State Senator and City Councilman from Queens, died Saturday at his home in Bayside, Queens.

title: The Inaugural Program
description: Following is a schedule for tomorrow's inaugural ceremonies: Early morning - President-elect and

title: IRAN DRAMA ELICITS CYNICISM AND FEARS ON TOP OF RELIEF
description: Exasperation vied with anticipation as Americans tracked their hostage countrymen through the long hours ahead of promised freedom yesterday, searching for lessons from the ordeal and claiming little in the way of national victory.

title: SCHMIDT HAS CANDIDATE FOR BERLIN
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, in an effort today to resolve the Berlin Government crisis, urged Justice Minister HansJochen Vogel to run for mayor of West Berlin and head a new Social Democratic-Free Democratic coalition.

title: Marshall Concerned Over Future Of the Black Lung Disability Fund
description: Black lung benefits totaling $1.4 billion were paid to 219,000 claimants over the last two years, Labor Secretary Ray Marshall told Congress today in his final report on the program.

title: COMMITTEES APPROVE 8 MORE REAGAN CABINET CHOICES
description: Senate committees approved eight more of President-elect Ronald Reagan's Cabinet choices today, including Defense Secretary-designate Caspar W. Weinberger, and prepared for the first confirmation votes in the full Senate tomorrow, Inauguration Day.

title: TEXT OF AGREEMENT BETWEEN IRAN AND THE U.S. TO RESOLVE THE HOSTAGE SITUATION
description: Following, as made public by the State Department today, are the texts of two documents signed by Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher in Algiers this morning. The first outlines the commitments undertaken by Iran and the United States in connection with the release of the hostages; the second concerns the settlement of claims.

title: FLORIDA WATER EXPERTS ASK CURBS ON HAZARDOUS WASTES DISPOSAL
description: - Strict controls must be placed on hazardous waste disposal to salvage the quality of drinking water in south Florida, according to a panel of water management experts. The State Department of Environment Regulation has identified 6,267 potential hazardous waste producers in south Florida, but only 29 sites where waste can be disposed of properly, according to Jim Bauch, a former engineer for the department.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think there will be a concern that all of us will feel until we know they're airborne, actually on their way, in view of the history of this whole thing.

title: U.S. RULING FUELS CONTROVERSY OVER BILINGUAL TEACHING
description: LAST month the Department of Education delivered an explosive ruling on Fairfax County, Va. The department said that it was all right for the county to teach non-English-speaking pupils by other means than bilingual classes.

title: PERSONAL INCOME UP BY 0.9% IN DECEMBER
description: The personal income of Americans rose nine-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Commerce Department reported today. The pace seemed almost certain to fall short of the rate of inflation.

title: 2 Dow Workers Killed in Texas
description: A steam line ruptured at a Dow Chemical Company plant here early yesterday morning and killed two Brazoria County men and seriously injured a third worker. John G. Hughes, 51 years old, the shift foreman, and Tunis R. Colvin, 52, a plant operator, died hours after the accident. Alfred D. Anderson, 50, also a plant operator, suffered burns and was hospitalized.

title: HAILED AND FEARED CORTISONE NOW SAFER AND MORE VARIED
description: CORTISONE, a powerful hormone hailed three decades ago as a miraculous treatment for rheumatoid arthritis, then quickly discovered to be as dangerous as it was useful, has now found its way into the medicine chests of millions of Americans as a nonprescription remedy for common skin ailments.

title: Bomb Damages Spanish Plant
description: A bomb caused serious damage today to the offices of a company building a nuclear power plant 10 miles from the Basque provincial capital of Bilbao. The police said explosives were attached to a barred window of the Iberduero company's offices in the center of San Sebastian, presumably by members of the Basque guerrilla organization E.T.A. The guerrillas have carried out a long campaign against Iberduero, vowing to prevent the power plant from starting up.

title: F.A.A. PLANS CHANGE IN AIRLINER DESIGN
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has agreed to consider a new rule on airplane design based on the proposals of a National Research Council committee formed after the crash of an American Airlines DC-10 in Chicago in May 1979.

title: 'NEW YORK HAS TOO FEW AMBULANCES'
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME BEST SELLERS FOR SPRING
description: 8 By BERNADINE MORRIS

title: DIGITAL CLIMBS BY 29.9%
description: Strong computer sales and gains in foreign-exchange translation increased Honeywell Inc.'s earnings and revenue to record levels for the fourth quarter of 1980 and the year, the Minneapolis-based company reported yesterday.

title: Leonard to Seek W.B.A. Title in 154-Pound Class
description: Mike Trainer, Sugar Ray Leonard's lawyer, will be here tomorrow to sign an agreement for the World Boxing Council welterweight champion to fight Ayub Kalule of Uganda, the World Boxing Association junior middleweight champion, in May or June, the promoter Bob Arumsaid yesterday.

title: Fire in Derailed Tank Car Disrupts Kansas City Traffic
description: A derailed railroad tank car containing a highly flammable liquid, which caught fire after a train crash last night, continued to burn today, forcing rerouting of traffic on an interstate highway.

title: British Ford Plants Back 9.5% Pay Rise
description: Ford of Britain auto workers have voted overwhelmingly to accept the company's ''final'' offer of a 9.5 percent pay increase, despite the opposition of union leaders, a Ford spokesman said.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why do you ache when you have a cold?

title: CONFUCIUS SAY: POLITICS CAN PUT SQUARE PEG IN OVAL OFFICE
description: Since Washington is a town of cookie-pushers, Ronald Reagan may be in luck. If the cookies pushed in his direction contain fortunes that are the distilled insights of ancient cultures, he may find that they help him deal with the legions of lobbyists, lawyers, consultants, newsmen, and politicians far more effectively than reams of memos and reports.

title: New Yorkers Are Told Of Ways to Save Water
description: To conserve water, New Yorkers were advised by city officials to:

title: HIGH COURT TO RULE ON PENSIONS
description: In a case that could affect the pension rights of millions of workers, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether an employer is required by Federal labor law to bargain with a union over the creation and management of a common type of pension fund. The Justices granted the Federal Government's request for review of a Federal appeals court ruling that management decisions concerning multi-employer trust funds are not subject to mandatory collective bargaining.

title: Jamaica Is Getting U.S. Loan
description: The United States and Jamaica signed a $40 million loan agreement today to promote the economic recovery of the island, the White House said. A White House statement said the $40 million will bring the total aid to Jamaica in fiscal year 1981 to more than $60 million.

title: DeRosa, in Switch, Pleads Not Guilty
description: Anthony DeRosa, accused of helping Howard (Buddy) Jacobson escape from the Brooklyn House of Detention last May 31, changed his mind yesterday and pleaded not guilty.

title: Arco Reports Capital Plan
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, an integrated energy concern, announced capital spending plans of $25 billion over the next five years, with 75 percent of the spending aimed at exploiting domestic energy resources.

title: Nissan to Raise Mexican Capacity
description: A Mexican subsidiary of the Nissan Motor Company of Japan will increase its automobile engine production capacity in Mexico with an investment of $333 million, a Nissan spokesman said.

title: 5% of British Shipping Idle
description: The General Council of British Shipping said today that 5 percent of Britain's registered fleet, or 60 vessels, had been held up by the seamen's dispute. Of this total, 24 deep sea foreign-bound and 20 deep sea homebound vessels have been halted in British ports, while 13 deep sea vessels are held up abroad. The National Union of Seamen earlier said that 29 vessels had been stopped in foreign ports and 83 in Britain.

title: House of Fabrics Head
description: Barney Sofro, 38, has been named president and chief operating officer of the House of Fabrics, a chain of 553 retail fabric stores throughout the country. He succeeds Allan M. Getz, 52, who resigned after 31 years with the company and about a year in the presidency.

title: Article 231251 -- No Title
description: Communities in Canada particularly hard hit by the current economic downturn will get special help under a new $300 million federal program announced today.

title: REPAIRS AT WOLLMAN RINK RENEW A30-YEAR DISPUTE
description: January at the Wollman Memorial Rink usually means ice skaters against a backdrop of the Central Park South skyline. Not this year. The worn-out rink has been ripped up and all that remains is the earth.

title: 'Tony Brown's Journal' Starts 4th TV Year Feb. 1
description: ''Tony Brown's Journal,'' a television magazine-type series that its producer says is ''about black people for all people'' and has ''the largest commercial listening audience in the world,'' will begin its fourth year on television on Feb. 1 on WNBC-TV at 11:30 A.M.

title: OHIO UTILITY OFFERS AIR AGREEMENT
description: The Ohio Edison Company has proposed an agreement with the Justice Department today under which the utility would spend $500 million on pollution control at 10 Ohio power plants.

title: SUN OF POLITICAL INFLUENCE IS RISING IN THE WEST AND SETTING IN THE SOUTH
description: As a Westerner takes over the White House tomorrow and with the Republicans in the ascendancy in Congress, the South, that distinctive region long able to amass political power disproportionate to population or wealth, appears to be losing much of its influence in Washington.

title: Corco Ends Dispute With U.S. on Pricing
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, a 36.7 percent-owned subsidiary of the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation, said yesterday that it had settled a pricing dispute with the Energy Department by agreeing to refund its Puerto Rican wholesale customers a total of $10 million.

title: HOUSIG STARTS DIP TO 1.56 MILLION
description: Housing starts declined 1 percent in December, to 1.56 million at an annual rate, the first loss since May, and permits for future building plunged 9 percent in a possible indication of more trouble ahead, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: SENATOR TOWER GETS POWERFUL NEW POST
description: In Senator John G. Tower's office, there is a plaque, a gift from a military officer. ''Enlisted men are stupid,'' it reads, ''but extremely cunning and sly and bear considerable watching.''

title: Italian Pilots Go on Strike Against 2 National Airlines
description: Pilots went on strike today against Alitalia and ATI, Italy's international and domestic air carriers, forcing cancellation of all but one international flight and 90 percent of the nation's domestic flights.

title: SUPer BOWL FOES FLY TO SCENE
description: Those old hands from the West, the Oakland Raiders, and those tenderfoots from the East, the Philadelphia Eagles, arrived today for their meeting in Super Bowl XV on Sunday.

title: James River's Bid For Sorg Lapses
description: The Sorg Paper Company said it had allowed the James River Corporation's $14 million offer to acquire Sorg to lapse because during the period of negotiations the market price of James River common stock had risen by 30 percent, to close to its record high, D.M. Yost, president of Sorg, said.

title: Market Place; Fairfield Fund's Stock Portfolio
description: IN October 1979, when Harold J. Ireland Jr. became portfolio manager of the Fairfield Fund, he began selling some big-name stocks owned by the mutual fund. In time, his sell list included the RCA Corporation, Reynolds Metals, the Chase Manhattan Bank, Boeing, American Broadcasting Companies and International Business Machines.

title: Taft in Ventures On Cable TV
description: The Taft Broadcastng Company of Cincinnati announced establishment of two joint venture partnerships with Tele-Communication Inc. of Denver.

title: Unsolicited Advice for Mr. Smith
description: At his confirmation hearing last week William French Smith showed why Ronald Reagan values him as a friend, political confidant and personal attorney, but disclosed little about the kind of Attorney General he will make. Mr. Smith was courteous, cordial and careful. But he was so reticent about his own values and so unprepared to discuss issues that few Senators could say they knew the man they voted to confirm.

title: RANGERS WIN, 6-3, FROM THE FLAMES, ENDING 6-GAME SLIDE
description: The New York Rangers ended a six-game stretch in which they had gone without a victory by defeating the Calgary Flames, 6-3, last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Notre Dame Beats Rams, 67-61
description: Kelly Tripucka scored 21 points and Orlando Woolridge had 16 tonight as they led Notre Dame to a 67-61 victory over Fordham.

title: Gas-Heated Schools Reopen As Boston Weather Warms
description: Schools heated by natural gas were permitted to reopen today as warmer weather and reduced consumption eased a natural gas shortage in Massachusetts. Mandatory conservation rules remained in force for commercial buildings.

title: COMPETITORS PUZZLED
description: Competitors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company expressed concern today that a Justice Department antitrust case against A.T.&T. might be settled on terms too favorable for the giant phone company.

title: Carbohydrate Diet for Diabetics
description: Since the early 1960's, studies have hinted that the traditional advice to diabetics to eat lots of protein and very few carbohydrates may not be the wisest approach. Such a diet is likely to be rich in cholesterol-raising fats, which would further increase the diabetic's already high risk of developing atherosclerotic heart disease.

title: A Greeting Card That's Full of Scotch
description: The people at Somerset Importers are quite aware that many people go into liquor stores with no more concrete intention than getting a gift, a gift that is frequently better then they would buy for themselves. The marketers at the Norton Simon subsidiary are also very aware that since the wine explosion much of the floor space in liquor stores has been pre-empted by the juice of the grape.

title: 3 Soldiers in U.N. Force Shot at Post in Lebanon
description: Three Senegalese members of the United Nations peacekeeping force were shot and killed last night near the Israeli border.

title: Accounts
description: * Country Living magazine from the Magazine division of the Hearst Corporation to Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss, which is also announcing the resignation of the Ventura Travelware account.

title: 2 AIDES IN ABSCAM DISPUTE ACTED ETHICALLY, EXPERTS SAY
description: How far should a Government prosecutor go in making sure that a defendant in a criminal case receives a fair trial? The question underlies a series of hearings last week in Brooklyn concerning the Abscam investigation, which produced the rare occurrence of two Federal prosecutors testifying in behalf of a criminal defendant and disclosing information that could damage the Justice Department's own efforts.

title: TREASURY BILL RATES RISE A BIT
description: Treasury bill rates increased slightly at yesterday's auction when new six-month bills averaged 14.47 percent and three-month bills averaged 15.60 percent. Last week the average auction rates were 14.32 percent for six-month bills and 15.32 percent for three-month bills.

title: Hobart's Complaint Against Bid by CP
description: The Hobart Corporation, of Troy, Ohio, announced the filing of an amended complaint in Federal Dustrict Court for the Southern District of New York against Canadian Pacific Enterprises-U.S. Inc. and certain affiliates.

title: CARTER IS THWARTED IN WISH TO WELCOME 52 PRESIDENT
description: Jimmy Carter's last full day as President of the United States was a marathon struggle against the clock and the seeming determination of the Iranian authorities to deny him a reunion with the American hostages as a climax to his Presidency.

title: MEDIA HOSTAGES
description: From the day that Iran seized the Americans, news coverage has profoundly affected the hostages and their families, and will continue to do so when the hostages return home. The extraordinary invasion of the privacy of the hostages' wives, children, and friends speaks to the nature of the news media's sensitivity - and insensitivity - to the personal nature of the hostages' and hostage families' experience.

title: PHILADELPHIA LAND VALUATION FIGHT
description: Mayor William J. Green and the City Council have become ensnarled in a confrontation over the city's much-criticized system of property tax assessments.

title: CELEBRATION AND DRAMA FILL THE AIR AS REAGAN PREPARES TO TAKE OFFICE
description: In an atmosphere of celebration, and high drama generated by the hostage crisis, Ronald Reagan prepared today to assume the Presidency at his inauguration tomorrow.

title: At 81, He Starts a New Career
description: At the age of 81, Jesse Hurwitz is starting a new career this week. Mr. Hurwitz, who spent 60 years in his own lower Manhattan textile jobbing and converting company, has liquidated his business and joined the Pearl Waste Material Company, a larger concern with more sources of supply.

title: Belinda Aberbach Is Married To Wade Stevenson on L.I.
description: Belinda Aberbach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julian J. Aberbach of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., and Paris, was married yesterday morning in Southampton, L.I., to Wade Stevenson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Porter Stevenson of Buffalo, and Southampton. Justice Paul H. Smith of the Justice Court of the Town of Southampton performed the ceremony in Town Hall.

title: Reagan Likeness Ads Near End
description: Is it imagination or have there been lot of ads featuring President-elect Ronald Reagan? There was that clever one from the Phillips Van Heusen Corporation featuring him in a 28-year-old shirt ad. Yesterday Lone Star Industries used Mr. Reagan's likeness in a cartoon illustrating an ad. Allied Chemical has an ad scheduled for newspapers this afternoon and tomorrow morning with the headline, ''Ronald Reagan took his first stand as President on a carpet of Anso nylon,'' and the tagline: ''Anso.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: There are good reasons that Verdi's ''Nabucco'' is performed infrequently, not the least of which are the technical problems posed by the opera's libretto. These include the sacking and burning of the Temple of Jerusalem, a lightning bolt that strikes the Babylonian emperor and knocks off his head, and the destruction of the Temple of Baal that includes the toppling of a gigantic image of Baal.

title: LEADER OF IRAN'S NEGOTIATING TEAM
description: The key Iranian in the negotiations to free the American hostages has been a 38-year-old bearded revolutionary with a background in law, literature and electrical engineering.

title: CULVER CAVALRY LEADING ITS 7TH INAUGURAL PARADE
description: It has taken a farrier five painstaking weeks to make special non-slip shoes to fit the 83 all-black horses that the Culver Military Academy is sending to Washington for a single hour of precision prancing in Ronald Reagan's inaugural parade.

title: FORMER TEXAS SPEAKER FOUND DEAD
description: Price Daniel Jr., former Speaker of the Texas House of Representatives, was found shot to death in his home outside this southeastern Texas town tonight, according to sheriff's officials. He was 39 years old.

title: ARIZONA RANCHERS FACE 3D TRIAL ON CHARGES OF BEATING MEXICANS
description: Two Arizona ranchers, Thomas and Patrick Hanigan, are scheduled to go on trial tomorrow in Federal District Court in Phoenix on charges that they beat and robbed three Mexicans who crossed their land in August 1976.

title: The Police Blotter
description: The manager of Citibank's real property services, who apparently went to the roof of the bank's building at 111 Wall Street to take pictures, fell 24 floors to his death. The police identified the victim as Byron A. Thorpe, 51 years old, of Ridgewood, N.J., who was found with a camera around his neck. ... A truck driver for The Daily News was abducted briefly, and more than $5,000 was taken from the truck's safe. The driver, George Curtis, 45, said several gunmen forced their way into his truck at Madison Avenue and 117th Street and tied him up after firing one shot. ... Four persons were overcome by fumes from a furnace at 510 West 151st Street and were taken to Presbyterian Hospital for treatment.

title: THE PRIZED CANNONBALL CHANGES HANDS
description: An award for creativity in science that started as a joke, but is beginning to suffer from creeping respectability was presented today to two American virus specialists and a Briton.

title: LOCAL LEAERS BACK PAY CUT AT CHRYSLER
description: Leaders of locals of the United Automobile Workers recommended today that their members ratify a 13 percent pay cut to keep the Chrysler Corporation alive. Voting by workers will begin Wednesday and must be completed by Feb. 2.

title: CROWDS OF REPORTERS VIE FOR NEWS AND FACILITIES
description: At first, the American Embassy in Algiers told reporters and photographers trying to cover the hostage negotiations that they would have to wait outside in the street. But the crush of 160 reporters caused such traffic jams that the officials finally relented and let them into the compound, issuing them swimming pool access cards as passes.

title: Super Bowl Notebook; Raiders and N.F.L Urged to Avoid Trial
description: While the Oakland Raiders prepare to battle on the football field Sunday against the Philadelphia Eagles, developments continue in their off-the-field battle against the National Football League.

title: HUNGER STRIKE: WHAT IS ROLE OF PHYSICIANS?
description: ALTHOUGH starvation affects millions of people throughout the world, attention has been focused recently on just a few cases - prisoners who have fasted as a political weapon. The newest episodes were in Poland, Ireland and at the United Nations.

title: T.V. Contracts Get U.S. Stay
description: A judge in the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit in St. Louis over the weekend granted a stay of the Federal Communications Commission decision to extend the deadline for low-power television station applications.

title: Bridge: Attendance of 2,630 Breaks At Tri-State Breaks Record
description: All attendance records were broken at the Tri-State Regional Championships, which ended Sunday at the Rye Town Hilton, Port Chester, N.Y. The total table count of 2,630 in five days makes it the biggest regional ever held in the New York City metropolitan area on a single weekend.

title: The Iranian Situation
description: The U.S. will return almost half of Iran's frozen assets in return for the hostages. Washington also will accept international arbitration of some private American claims, and will support some Iranian claims against the late Shah's assets. U.S. officials emphasized that they would hand over to Iran only assets that had belonged to the Teheran Government prior to the revolution. (Page A5.)

title: EXCERPTS FROM GOVERNOR'S BUDGET STATEMENT LIST SOME GOALS FOR NEXT DECADE
description: CONTENTS OF CAREY'S MESSAGE AFFIRM STATE INTENT TO ABSORB LOCAL MEDICAID COSTS

title: COMMITTEE TO SETTLE CLAIMS IS SET UP BY PACT WITH IRAN
description: In addition to agreeing that billions of dollars in frozen Iranian assets would be exchanged for the release of the American hostages, the United States and Iran pledged to set up an international claims commission and to take other steps.

title: SOME VIEWS BACK TO 1913
description: Following are excerpts from the seven previous Inaugural Addresses in the 20th century that marked a transfer of executive power from one political party to another. Woodrow Wilson, 1913

title: SCIENCE AND THE DRAMATIC VISION: A CRITIQUE
description: ENMESHED in Judeo-Christian tradition is the notion that knowledge is sinful, and that when Adam's successors taste its forbidden fruit, they risk damnation. Whatever the theological merit of this viewpoint, sin and damnation are the stuff of drama, and campaigners against the exploitation of nuclear energy have appropriated drama as a weapon.

title: CAREY OFFERS $16.2 BILLION BUDGET THAT COVERS LOCAL MEDICAID COSTS
description: Governor Carey today proposed a $16.2 billion budget for 1981-82 under which the state would take on the annual billion-dollar local costs of Medicaid. But at the same time the Governor would impose what he called a ''discipline of austerity'' on state and local governments.

title: DROUGHT EMERGENCY IS DECLARED BY KOCH
description: Mayor Koch declared a drought emergency yesterday that requires a 15 percent decrease in daily consumption of water by business and industry and a 25 percent, or 30-gallon-a-day, cutback by residential users. He also signed a bill setting stiffer fines for violations of specific water use bans.

title: PEKING SAID TO DECIDE ON PRISON, NOT EXECUTION, FOR MAO'S WIDOW
description: Chinese authorities appear to have decided against putting Jiang Qing, the widow of Mao Zedong, to death. Instead, unofficial Chinese sources suggest, she appears headed toward spending the rest of her life in a prison cell.

title: BARBARA ROSEN ENDURES ONE MORE DAY OF A RITUAL
description: For Barbara Rosen, it was a day of now-familiar ritual. Once again, she stepped out of her parents' pink clapboard house in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn and into a phalanx of cameras and microphones.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Public Service Company of Indiana filed separately with the Securities and Exchange Commission $125 million of first mortgage bonds due Feb. 1, 2011, and the proposed sale of three million common shares, to be offered through a group managed by Morgan Stanley & Company and Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

title: FOR REAGAN, A TICKING ECOLOGICAL 'TIME BOMB'
description: Nothing in Jimmy Carter's political life, to paraphrase ''Macbeth,'' has become him like ''the leaving it.'' And nothing that Jimmy Carter has said during his years in the White House is of more long-range significance than the warning contained in his moving and thoughtful farewell address:

title: IRAN AIDE CONDEMNS U.S. BANKS IN DELAY
description: Iran's chief hostage negotiator said early today that American banks had filed an unexpected appendix to the hostage agreement reached with the United States that he described as ''an underhanded maneuver for delaying the final solution of the problem.''

title: THE POSTAL SERVICE'S 40-CENT SECRET
description: To the Editor:

title: BROWN OFFERS SOMBER PARTING VIEW OF SOVIET'S GOALS
description: Secretary of Defense Harold Brown today left his designated successor, Caspar W. Weinberger, his most somber assessment yet of the military capabilities and intentions of the Soviet Union.

title: Big Board Studies Nonstock Options
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it was studying the possibility of opening trade in nonstock options such as gold and silver.

title: Suns Not Benefiting In Westphal Trade
description: Life with the Seattle SuperSonics has not been pleasant for Paul Westphal. When the Sonics acquired him from the Phoenix Suns for Dennis Johnson last June, the trade was termed ideal, an exchange of allstar guards that was supposed to help both teams. Johnson has become an integral part of the Suns, who are first in the Pacific Division, seven and a half games ahead of the Los Angeles Lakers. On the other hand, Westphal has become just another player on the 11-man roster of the sagging Sonics.

title: L.S.U. 81, Kentucky 67
description: Willie Sims scored 8 of his 22 points in the last eight minutes of the first half and paced Louisiana State to an 81-67 rout of Kentucky in a Southeastern Conference game tonight.

title: NATURAL SHARK REPELLENT IS ALLURING TO SCIENTISTS
description: TORONTO AMILKY substance exuded by a Red Sea fish known as the Moses sole has proven to be frustrating to scientists, as well as repulsive to sharks.

title: Mandate And Burden
description: Ronald Reagan is being inaugurated as the 40th President of the United States for one reason above all others - because high inflation and interest rates and continuing unemployment convinced the public that his economic promises offered more hope than Jimmy Carter's discredited policies.

title: U.S. AND HOOKER IN ACCORD ON CLEANING UP WASTE SITE
description: The Hooker Chemical and Plastics Company will be required to clean up and monitor its chemical dump site in the Hyde Park area of Niagara Falls, N.Y., at a cost of $15 million under an agreement filed today in Federal Court by the Justice Department.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt AMERICAN TONGUE AND CHEEK. A Populist Guide to Our Language. By Jim Quinn. 219 pages. Pantheon. $11.95.

title: INAGURAL SPOTLIGHT SHIFTS TO SINATRA AND SHOW BIZ
description: Tonight it was show biz. Last night the capital celebrated the inaugural of President-elect Ronald Reagan with concerts of art, music and dance, but now it was Frank Sinatra's turn as producer of a gala at the Capital Center, and Johnny Carson's turn as master of ceremonies for a list of entertainers that included Bob Hope, Debby Boone, Grace Bumbry, Charlton Heston, Rich Little, Dean Martin, Donny and Marie Osmond, Ethel Merman, Charley Pride, Mel Tillis, Ben Vereen and the United States Naval Academy Glee Club.

title: IRAN WOULD REGAIN HALF OF ITS ASSETS IMMEDIATELY
description: The Carter Administration has agreed to return to Iran immediately less than half of the $8 billion to $10 billion in frozen Iranian assets in exchange for the 52 American hostages, according to agreements made public today and to banking sources.

title: HAIL, BUT WHY FAREWELL?
description: To the Editor:

title: M.A.C. Bond-Warrant Issue Is Set at Par
description: A $100 million issue of Municipal Assistance Corporation 10 3/8 percent bonds due in 2008 is being offered at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: ARCHIBALD J. MOTLEY
description: Archibald J. Motley, a artist whose work has been shown in various museums, including the Corcoran Gallery in Washington, the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York and the Art Institute of Chicago, died Friday in Chicago.

title: The Human Side of Freud TO SCIENCE TIMES:
description: I was gratified to read in Dava Sobel's article ''Rare Views of Freud Emerge From Amateur Films'' (Dec. 30) that my father's films of Sigmund Freud (''Sigmund Freud, His Family and Colleagues, 1928-29'') had been recently shown at the American Psychoanalytic Association meeting in New York. I assisted my father, Dr. Philip R. Lehrman, in editing the films, several copies of which, including the original, are owned by our family and are in my trust. He gave a copy to the Freud Archives shortly after it was established in l952.

title: JUSTICES REFUSE TO HEAR APPEAL BY ABSCAM REPORTER
description: The Supreme Court refused today to hear an appeal by a newspaper reporter who faces a six-month jail sentence for refusing to testify about her sources of information for articles about the Justice Department's Abscam investigations.

title: I.B.M. Offerings For Minicomputers
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced a series of hardware and software improvements to its Series/1 minicomputer and other small computer systems.

title: Astros' Richard Is Ready to Train
description: Doctors cleared J.R. Richard today to pitch again and begin full-scale workouts in preparation for rejoining the Houston Astros.

title: Connecticut May Sue Lilco on Air Pollution
description: HARTFORD (AP) - Connecticut announced it would go to court, if necessary, to stop the Long Island Lighting Company from burning high-sulfur fuel in violation of air-pollution standards.

title: STOCKS DECLINE OVER RATE FEARS
description: Concern on Wall Street over the possiblity of continued high interest rates sent the stock market down slightly yesterday in much slower trading. Analysts noted that the apparently imminent release of the American hostages in Iran had little effect on prices.

title: Union Pacific Invests
description: The Union Pacific Corporation announced a 1981 capital-investment program of $1.2 billion for its four operating companies - the Champlin Petroleum Company, the Union Pacific Railroad, Rocky Mountain Energy and Upland Industries - representing an increase of $66 million over the record investment of last year. The largest outlay will be $891 million for Champlin Petroleum, of which $683 million, or 80 percent more than in 1980, will go for exploration and production.

title: Captain of Coast Guard Ship To Face a Court-Martial
description: The Coast Guard today ordered a courtmartial for the captain of the cutter Blackthorn, which collided with another ship in Tampa Bay last year and capsized, killing 23 crew members.

title: ROOSEVELT OPENS WITHOUT BETTORS AS CLERKS WALK OUT
description: There was racing at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, but the circumstances were far from normal. The trotters trotted and the pacers paced before an empty grandstand as the 10-race program was conducted in an eerie nonbetting atmosphere.

title: THE STORY OF THE MAN WHO SAID HE HAD NOT SLEPT FOR 10 YEARS
description: Doctors in Edinburgh have recently released the case history details of a man who claimed that he had not slept for 10 years. Since he traced his remarkable story of insomnia to a road accident that had knocked him unconscious for a moment, he was able to collect more than 12,000, or about $28,000, in seven years of litigation, and to stay out of work all the while on various disability pensions.

title: Tanker Grounded
description: A 621-foot American tanker with a cargo of eight million gallons of No. 6 fuel oil was intentionally grounded off Brooklyn after she sustained hull damage and began taking on water. The Coast Guard said none of the cargo oil had leaked from the tanker Concho.

title: A FOE OF ISRAEL ISSUES HIS ANNUAL DECLARATION
description: To the Editor:

title: 'I Remember Harlem' on TV
description: ''I Remember Harlem,'' a four-part documentary series produced by William Miles, will be broadcast on WNET-TV in hourlong segments on Feb. 1, 2, 3 and 4 at 10 P.M. Mr. Miles's previous production for public television was ''Men of Bronze,'' the story of the 369th Infantry Regiment and its experiences in World War I.

title: Carter Orders Ingram Freed
description: President Carter has commuted the fouryear prison sentence given the former chairman of the Ingram Corporation for his role in bribing Chicago officials to obtain public-works contracts, the Justice Department disclosed today.

title: North Stars 6, Canadiens 3
description: Tim Young and Bobby Smith of Minnesota scored power-play goals 49 seconds apart to help the North Stars to a 6-3 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight.

title: Virginia 74, Clemson 59
description: Ralph Sampson paced a pair of secondhalf sprees that carried Virginia to a 74-59 victory over Clemson tonight and extended the nation's longest major college winning streak to 19 games.

title: Marash Returns to WCBS As Co-anchor at 11 P.M.
description: Dave Marash has returned to WCBS-TV, Channel 2 in New York, as an anchorman and correspondent after three years on the ABC television network, as correspondent for the magazine program ''20/20.''

title: OPPENHEIMER AND THE FIRST A-BOMB
description: The beginning of the nuclear age is not a single subject but a series of subjects that lead one to another in an unending chain reaction - the United States development of the atomic bomb during World War II, the initial use of the bomb against the Japanese in the summer of 1945, the particular personalities of the people who collaborated on what was known as the Manhattan Project, the moral issues raised, the scientific problems solved and unresolved, the political consequences of the bomb's development and use, and the long-term effects on mankind of what is euphemistically called ''nuclear capability.''

title: CONTRIBUTIONS BY SCHOOLCHILDREN AIDING FUND FOR NEEDIEST CASES
description: Inspired by their parents and teachers, school-age children are among the most enthusiastic contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, now conducting its 69th annual appeal.

title: News Analysis
description: Just when the Legislature may have thought it knew the budget game, Governor Carey has changed the rules. The underlying message that Mr. Carey sent to the Legislature today in submitting the annual budget for approval was the same as last year's: austerity in state spending for all but the most critical government services. But unlike last year's budget, which made virtually no political concessions to the Legislature, today's $16.2 billion spending plan included almost irresistible programs to take over local Medicaid costs and to add strength to the state's beleaguered criminal justice system.

title: ADDENDUM
description: * Museum magazine to add a New York edition, effective with the September/October issue.

title: Gunmen Kill Boy, 16, And Wound 3 Others
description: One youth was killed and three others were wounded on an Upper Manhattan street corner last night when gunmen drove up to a crowd of unarmed people and opened fire, the police said.

title: Unscrambling the Egg
description: Neither triumph nor humiliation. Only the prospect of relief. The agony will apparently end on tolerable terms. Releasing Iran's assets is not paying ransom. But it does grant a kind of amnesty. Tomorrow will be soon enough to recognize why the end of this debilitating crisis does not liberate the United States or Iran from a maddening mutual dependency.

title: IRANIAN REPORT ON A NEW OBSTACLE
description: Following is the text of a report issued today by the official Iranian press agency Pars in English concerning the delay in the release of the 52 American hostages. The English-language report was monitored and recorded here.

title: Du Pont Flat in Final Quarter; Armco, Archer-Daniels Higher
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's largest chemical concern, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980 remained even with the final three months of 1979 but that net income for all of 1980 fell 23.7 percent. Revenues in the latest quarter climbed 10.1 percent, while revenues for the year were up 8.7 percent.

title: BASKETBALL INQUIRY IS WIDENED
description: Federal authorities investigating a scheme in which organizedcrime figures allegedly paid members of Boston College's basketball team to shave points are seeking to determine whether a third player was involved.

title: MARCOS YIELDS SOME POWER TO CONGRESS
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos opened the session of the National Assembly today by formally transferring to it the legislative power that he had exercised during eight years and four months of martial law.

title: U.S.-Saudi Arms Deals Worth Nearly $2 Billion
description: The Defense Department announced today that it had authorized the sale of nearly $2 billion in military equipment and services to Saudi Arabia.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday incorrectly translated the amounts involved in the debt restructuring of Massey-Ferguson Ltd.

title: Safe Deposit Vault Robbed in Roslyn
description: Burglars stole the contents of about 150 safe deposit boxes in the vault of a branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank here, the Nassau County police said.

title: TV: 'MALICE AFORETHOUGHT' AND 'CIRCUS'
description: THE first installment of ''Malice Aforethought,'' which begins at 9 P.M. tonight on WNET-TV, Channel 13, as part of the ''Mystery!'' series, isn't a whodunit but a when-will-he-get-around-to-it. It is clear from the very first moment of the drama, which is adapted from Francis Iles's novel, that Dr. Edmund Bickleigh would be well advised to kill his wife.

title: Ford Executive Gets Top Post at Hertz
description: Bennett E. Bidwell, 53 years old, an executive of the Ford Motor Company for 27 years, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of the Hertz Corporation, the car and truck leasing company, effective Feb. 1. He will succeed Joseph V. Vittoria, 45, who served in those posts for seven months and was named vice chairman of the RCA Corporation subsidiary.

title: Chinese Cancel U.S. Wheat
description: China has canceled orders for 100,000 metric tons of American wheat that had been scheduled for delivery in 1981-82, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: I.R.S. IS CHALLENGING MAIL-ORDER PASTORS
description: -The Internal Revenue Service, in a move it hopes will discourage increasing attempts by ''mail-order ministers'' to avoid paying Federal income taxes, has begun seeking criminal charges against a group of nontaxpaying Texas airline pilots, all of whom say they are ministers in the Basic Bible Church.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: North Korea rejected as a ''foolish burlesque'' today the proposal by President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea for an exchange of visits with President Kim Il Sung of North Korea.

title: ITEL GETS COURT APPROVAL TO BEGIN REORGANIZATION
description: The Itel Corporation, faced by an overwhelming debt of $1.3 billion, sought permission in United States District Court here today to reorganize under Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: Atlanta Officials Identify Skeleton As That of Boy Missing Since July
description: The second of two small skeletons found 10 days ago was identified today as that of 10-year-old Earl Lee Terrell, who had been missing since July 30, 1980, when he vanished from a swimming pool near his southeast Atlanta home.

title: EVIDENCE IS REPORTED FOR BIGGEST STAR OF ALL
description: University of Wisonsin astronomers have reported evidence for a star 35 times more massive than any previously known. The star, if further evidence confirms its existence, would seem to have 3,500 times the mass of the sun.

title: Attorney for 3 Girls Asks Judge to Rescind Order
description: An attorney for the parents of three white girls asked a Federal judge today to withdraw his order that would cause them to lose six months of class credit unless they enrolled in a racially integrated school.

title: AS PRESIDENTIAL POWER SHIFTS, INAUGURAL SPEECHES PLEDGE CHANGES
description: Presidents have usually preferred to strive for eloquence rather than newsworthiness in their inaugural addreses. The results have been alloys of memorable phrases and forgettable moral dictums, enduring political milestones and now-withered platitudes.

title: Strong Quake Strikes Indonesia
description: A strong earthquake struck West Irian in Indonesia early today, the United States Geological Survey reported. The quake, which registered 6.8 on the Richter scale, was centered on the western end of the island of New Guinea, about 850 miles northeast of Darwin, Australia, a spokesman for the survey said. There were no immediate reports of injuries.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL ACTION ENTERS NEW ERA
description: When the 97th Congress considers the renewal of the Clear Air Act of 1970 early this year, it will provide the first clear indication of how environmental issues will fare with the ascendancy of conservative politics.

title: Providence 61, Georgetown 58
description: Billy Fields scored 18 points tonight and Providence shot 12 of 16 from the floor in the second half to gain a 61-58 victory over Georgetown and its first Big East Conference victory.

title: TIME NOW TO CLARIFY THE REAGAN MANDATE
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESS ELECTED HEAD OF NATIONAL ACADEMY
description: Dr. Frank Press, the geophysicist who has spent the last four years as science adviser to President Carter, has been formally elected to be the next president of the National Academy of Sciences.

title: REAGAN URGED TO SPUR VOLUNTARISM IN PHILANTHROPY
description: Looking back on a 20-year career in philanthropy and education, Landrun R. Bolling of the Council on Foundations has urged the incoming Reagan Administration to enhance the role of the country's volunteer workers in providing social, economic and cultural services.

title: CARTER'S STATEMENT ON IRAN PACT
description: Following is a transcript of President Carter's announcement this morning of the agreement between the United States and Iran resolving the hostage crisis:

title: American Is Kidnapped In Colombian Capital
description: Five hooded gunmen kidnapped an American economic adviser outside the building where he worked in central Bogota early today, the police said.

title: OUTBREAK OF MERCURY POISONING IN ARGENTINE BABIES IS LINKED TO DIAPERS
description: More than 1,600 cases of babies who have been poisoned by mercury apparently picked up in commercially laundered diapers have been reported here in recent weeks, and hospitals and the Red Cross have responded with a crash treatment program.

title: 7 Michigan Cities Are in Top 10 For Worst Unemployment Rates
description: Two Michigan cities, Flint and Muskegon, had the highest unemployment rate in the nation for November, 15.2 percent, the Labor Department reported today. Lafayette, La., and Lincoln, Neb., had the lowest, 3.5 percent.

title: By Thomas Hayes
description: uf4 Talking Businesswith Lowell G. Fowble of A.T.&T. Testing to Find New Managers

title: SPRINTING CAPTIVATES WALKER
description: Sprinting Captivates Walker By FRANK LITSKY

title: Tractor Sale to Soviet
description: Fiat-Allis Construction Machinery Inc. of Deerfield, Ill., announced yesterday that it would sell $90 million of tractors and parts to the Soviet Union. It said that the sale, including 300 large crawler tractors, was its biggest single equipment sale.

title: Advertising; Milliken's Visa Fabric Promotion
description: MILLIKEN & COMPANY, the sphinx of Seventh Avenue, has been testing consumer advertising for its Visa fabric for a year and is now prepared to roll out a television and print promotion program. Or so it says.

title: THE REGION;
description: A $231.1 million annual rate increase for the New York Telephone Company was approved yesterday by the Public Service Commission.

title: FOUNDATIONS ASSIST CONSERVATIVE CAUSE
description: A number of foundations have spread their money discreetly, supporting academic studies of capitalism, offering money to conservative research organizations and underwriting the salaries of free-market economists and scholars examining military strategy.

title: Knowlton to Give Up 2 Posts at Harper & Row
description: Winthrop Knowlton, chairman and chief executive of Harper & Row, announced yesterday that he planned to relinquish both positions at the company's annual meeting in August. He will continue on the board as chairman of its executive committe.

title: Steel Production Up
description: Steel production rose to 2.351 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of 1 percent from the previous week's 2.327 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Celtics Defeat Pistons, 92-90 00.3-
description: Cedric Maxwell scored 21 points and Larry Bird added 19 tonight as Boston lost a 21-point lead but managed to beat the Detroit Pistons, 92-90. It was the Celtics' ninth straight victory.

title: Interns Renew Hospital Talks
description: The Committee of Interns and Residents renewed contract negotiations yesterday with the administration of Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn, a hospital spokesman said. Contract talks resumed at the Greenwood Baptist Church, 461 Sixth Street, in the Park Slope section. At the center of the dispute is the doctors' demand for physical safety following a rash of recent burglaries in their residences.

title: NO MENTION OF DR. TARNOWER MADE BY MRS. HARRIS IN WILL
description: The last will and testament of Jean S. Harris, apparently written the day she allegedly shot Dr. Herman Tarnower, was read today in Westchester County Court. It leaves the bulk of her estate to her two sons and certain personal items to other family members.

title: President Acts to Set Up A Waste Cleanup Fund
description: President Carter signed an executive order today putting into effect a trust fund to be used to clean up hazardous substances released into the environment.

title: Gems Beat Fillies, 98-88;
description: Carol Blazejowski, the leading scorer in the Women's Basketball League, had 36 points tonight to lead the New Jersey Gems to a 98-88 victory over the Minnesota Fillies.

title: Toyota Files Suit On Tariff Changes
description: Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. has sued to overturn last year's higher tariff on imported small pickup trucks, the importer announced.

title: People
description: * Thomas Mabley has joined Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein Inc. as a senior vice president, creative.

title: CITY AND STATE STUDY PLANS FOR ARMORY'S AIR RIGHTS
description: The state and city governments are looking into proposals to erect a hotel or luxury apartments over the Lexington Avenue drill-hall area of the landmark Seventh Regiment Armory between 66th and 67th Streets.

title: Barbara Coggin Is Dead; Was Lucille in 'Gemini'
description: Barbara Coggin, who played Lucille for the last two years in the Broadway comedy ''Gemini,'' died in her sleep yesterday in her apartment at 121 West 72d Street. A medical report said that the actress had died of natural causes.

title: Moscow Attacks Tokyo Official For Remarks on 'Soviet Threat'
description: MOSCOW (AP) - The Soviet news agency Tass on Monday charged Joji Omura, director general of the Japanese Self-Defense Agency, with resorting to ''demagoguery about a Soviet threat'' in a speech before the National Press Club in Tokyo.

title: IMPACT ELSEWHERE MUTED
description: Governor Carey's 1981-82 budget appears to satisfy New York City's financial needs by proposing major assistance to both the city and the metropolitan area's county governments through the state's assumption of local Medicaid costs over the next four years.

title: Davy Sues to Stop Enserch Merger
description: The Davy Corporation, a major British engineering and construction company, filed suit in Federal District court here in an effort to block a tender offer for all its stock by the Enserch Corporation of Dallas.

title: Entitled
description: All a President-elect has to do to take office is to raise his right hand, place his left hand on a Bible and make a brief promise. Why then, some say, all the fuss? One might as well ask why live in any house but a lean-to, or aspire to be cloaked in more than a fig leaf.

title: DISCLOSURE REQUIRED ON SHAH'S ASSETS
description: The part of the hostage agreement between the United States and Iran concerning the late Shah's wealth will require American companies, banks, lawyers and Government agencies to turn over to the Treasury Department any information they have about the assets of Mohammed Riza Pahlevi and his family in the United States.

title: Tensor Acquisition
description: Franklin G. Bishop, chairman and a major shareholder of the Tensor Corporation, said yesterday that Tensor had agreed in principle to the merger into a new Tensor subsidiary of two Texas companies, Listo Exploration Inc. and Heather Oil and Gas Inc. The two concerns are engaged in a joint venture in exploration and development of oil and gas properties, mainly in the Gulf Coast area. Tensor said it expected Jack R. Curtsinger, president, and other officers of the joint venture to continue in the new subsidiary.

title: REDUCING CHILD CUSTODY FIGHTS
description: Responding to what is termed ''a significant caseload of child abductions and custody controversies,'' the American Bar Association's Family Law Section and Young Lawyers Division have begun a joint, two-year project to reduce the jurisdictional confusion, the costs and the personal friction that often accompany custody fights.

title: Mayor Vetoes Chicago Plan To Reduce Job Protection
description: A controversial city ordinance that would have virtually abolished Civil Service protection for most future city employees was vetoed today by Mayor Jane M. Byrne.

title: MGM Hotels Net Falls in 1st Quarter
description: MGM Grand Hotels Inc. today reported earnings of $8.6 million for the first quarter of its fiscal year, down from $10.3 million in the first quarter one year earlier. The company said results for the latest quarter included $2.5 million recovered from business-interruption insurance related to the Nov. 21 fire at its Las Vegas hotel-casino,

title: The Push and Pull Over Education Department's Fate
description: Although President-elect Ronald Reagan takes office publicly committed to abolishing the Education Department, there has been a debate among his top aides over just how fast this can be accomplished, and Mr. Reagan, himself, has expressed some recent doubts on the subject.

title: NEW POWER STRUCTURE EMERGING FOR THE INCOMING ADMINISTRATION
description: For a Strauss, or a Lane Kirkland, the head of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, a change in administrations may mean they cannot ask for things as often, but, several top Reagan backers agreed, they may be more certain of getting something if they do ask. But the Washington power structure, in a Reagan administration, will be something more than the usual figures in slightly altered roles. At the White House, Mr. Meese has no experience of this city, just like his boss, the President, and he is already being referred to as "Deputy President." His title is counselor, and policy decisions, not meeting deadlines, are his strength. James A. Baker 3d, as chief of staff, will be more in charge of day-to-day operations. Mr. Baker has had experience in Washington, and he has overcome whatever stigma ever attached to his having run George Bush's Republican primary campaign against Mr. Reagan. Political Doorkeeper Another very important aide, deceptively underrated in title, is Michael Deaver. Assistant to the President, who will act as main political doorkeeper. Mr. Deaver has probably spent more time with Mr. Reagan, as his public relations aide, than anyone except Mrs. Reagan in the last 15 years. Martin Anderson, Richard V. Allen and Lyn Nofziger, at the next level of influence, have defined areas of responsibility. Mr. Anderson on foreign policy and Mr. Nofziger is to look after politics. Mr. Nofziger, close to Mr. Laxalt and Senator Bob dole of Kansas, also has the key role of reassuring the political right.

title: CHRYSLER'S FIGHT FOR SURVIVAL
description: 813 By WILLIAM SERRIN

title: Columbia 63, Seton Hall 61
description: A pair of free throws by Darren Burnett with six seconds remaining gave Columbia a 63-61 victory over Seton Hall tonight.

title: FEDERAL PROSECUTOR CALLS ABSCAM 'BAD' AND 'IMMORAL' IN TESTIMONY
description: A Federal prosecutor who has been critical of the Government's Abscam investigation into political corruption said yesterday that he considered the inquiry ''bad'' and ''immoral'' because ''the things going on in this case cannot withstand judicial scrutiny.''

title: EXPERIMENT TO JOIN HIGH SCHOOL AND COLLEGE IS LONELY EFFORT
description: SIMON'S ROCK is part high school and part college, a hybrid institution where students come directly from the 9th, 10th or 11th grades to combine the end of their secondary education with the start of their higher education. Last week, the institution's snow covered campus here in western Massachusetts became a conference center as educators gathered to discuss why this experiment and similar ones elsewhere have remained isolated innovations that affect few students.

title: THE REAGAN ADDRESS HAS PERSONAL TOUCH
description: Between church and lunch yesterday, President-elect Ronald Reagan found time to put some finishing touches on his 2,000-word inaugural address, which, senior transition officials said, remained virtually identical to his first draft 11 days ago.

title: Music: Levine of the Met Leads the Philharmonic
description: WHEN Pierre Boulez was music director of the New York Philharmonic, he never conducted at the Metropolitan Opera, and Zubin Mehta has not done so yet, either; both cited the risk of overexposure. James Levine, music director of the Met, feels no such compunctions, and that seems reasonable enough. If a conductor is admired in opera, it is interesting to hear what he can do with the symphonic repertory, and not just on records. And the reverse is certainly true; it might be even more interesting to encounter Mr. Mehta at the Met, given that house's paucity of top-level conductors.

title: CHILD-CARE STUDY CHALLENGES STEREOTYPE ON WELFARE
description: A study of 13,000 children in publicly subsidized day care centers in Massachusetts indicates that 70 percent of the welfare families enrolling their children do so in order to work or seek work.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: New York's Mayor Koch, disclosing that he has had trouble dealing with his administration's fine print, showed up at City Hall yesterday wearing a new pair of wire-rimmed aviator-type glasses. The Mayor said he had gotten the glasses - and another pair in tortoise shell - to deal with longstanding eye defects: nearsightedness in his right eye and farsightedness in his left.

title: Pitch and Heave in Zimbabwe
description: Zimbabwe watchers can interpret the recent Cabinet changes in two ways. The generously inclined will think Prime Minister Mugabe has taken yet another step away from the long guerrilla war and a Cabinet of warlords.

title: UNTHINKING KILLERS
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Burlington Industries Inc. has named Joel Futterman president of the Studio Prints division.

title: SETTLEMENT OF CLAIMS
description: Declaration Declaration of the Government of the Democratic and Popular Republic of Algeria concerning the settlement of claims by the Government of the United States of America and the Government of the Islamic Republic of Iran.

title: Deferred Consent for Mr. Donovan
description: Much as the new Administration needs to get off to a quick start, it needs one thing more: full confidence in its integrity. Given the serious questions that have been raised about Raymond Donovan's suitability as Secretary of Labor, that confidence requires full investigation by the F.B.I. and the Senate Labor Committee.

title: American Can Sets In-Home Services
description: The American Can Company's acquisition of a controlling interest in Homserv Inc., a privately held company in the field of in-home electronic banking and other services, was announced by both companies.

title: Vann Is Named to Lead A Caucus of Legislators
description: Assemblyman Albert Vann, Liberal of Brooklyn, was elected chairman of the New York State Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus today after the incumbent chairman, Senator Vander L. Beatty, Democrat of Brooklyn, suddenly withdrew as a candidate. Mr. Vann defeated Assemblyman Victor Robles, Democrat of Brooklyn, 13 to 10.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 20, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Committee on the Drafting of an International Convention Against Mercenaries - 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: CONGRESS LEADERS PLAN INQUIRY INTO SEIZURE OF HOSTAGES
description: Republican and Democratic Congressional leaders today pledged investigations of the circumstances that led to the seizure of the American hostages in Iran as part of a larger inquiry into the problems of protecting American diplomats abroad.

title: RADIOACTIVE FALLOUT IN WEST
description: borne radioactivity, an E.P.A. official said yesterday. Stockman, who will be director of the Office of Management and

title: U.S. CLEARS THE WAY FOR DELIVERY OF $40 MILLION IN ARMS TO SOMALIA
description: The Carter Administration has cleared the way for President-elect Ronald Reagan, after he takes office, to deliver $40 million in United States military aid to Somalia that had been held up by Congressional objections.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JANUARY 20, 1981
description: The Hostages The hostages' freedom was delayed by objections raised in Teheran over a reported appendix that American bankers added to the hostagerelease agreement announced by the United States and Iran. Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie confirmed that there was a agreement, but he believed that it could be resolved by noon today, before the Carter Administration formally leaves office. Bankers and Administration officials described the appendix as a ''routine'' instrument of the accord. (Page A1, Column 6.) An unexpected American demand delayed the release of the hostages, according to Behzad Nabavi, Iran's chief negotiator. He said that Algerian intermediaries had given Iran an appendix to the AmericanIranian agreement, drawn up by American banks and aimed at forcing Iran to drop claims to certain of its assets. He described the new condition as ''an underhanded maneuver for delaying the final solution to the problem.'' (A1:5.)

title: TASS SAYS U.S. USES HOSTAGES IN POLITICAL PLOY
description: Tass, the official Soviet press agency, accused the Carter Administration last night of using the issue of the hostages in Iran to ''end its stay in Washington on a high antiSoviet note.''

title: The Best and Worst of Men's Tennis Tour; News Analysis
description: The Volvo Masters, which wound up Sunday at Madison Square Garden, spotlighted some of the best and worst aspects of the men's professional tennis tour.

title: SIMON ROSE
description: Simon Rose, a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Phillips, Nizer, Benjamin, Krim & Ballon, died Sunday at Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 71 years old and lived in Bedford, N.Y.

title: ARCHIVIST REJECTS SUBPOENA FOR NIXON-HAIG TAPE DATA
description: Robert M. Warner, the National Archivist, refused today to comply with a subpoena from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee seeking logs summarizing 1973 conversations between President Nixon and Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title: NEAR-EUPHORIA OF HOSTAGES' FAMILIES GIVES WAY TOLAST-MINUTE UNCERTAINTY
description: The documents have been signed. President Carter has said he believes the hostages are coming out. But the waiting continues. Some of the families of the hostages have already started celebrating with champagne and fireworks. But others were still guarding yesterday against the possibility of yet another heartbreaking reversal.

title: Montclair Student Dies in Plane Crash
description: A Montclair High School senior, Oliver Larkin, was killed when the small Cessna airplane he was flying crashed into a 48-unit apartment complex at 125 Gates Avenue.

title: Connecticut General To Alter Status
description: The Connecticut General Insurance Corporation's board of directors approved a proposal to convert Connecicut General from an insurance company into a general business corporation to be known as the Connecticut General Corporation.

title: ALLIES MOVE TO END SANCTIONS AGAINST IRAN
description: With the release of the 52 American hostages, the Common Market countries and other Western nations have moved toward lifting the economic sanctions they imposed against Iran in support of the United States.

title: Tahuantinsuyo Music Trio To Play at Museum Jan. 28
description: The music trio Tahuantinsuyo and the 12-member Andes Dancers will perform together on Jan. 28 at 7 P.M. at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street.

title: THE PLEDGE OF PRIVATE TREPTOW
description: Martin A. Treptow, a young and obscure American private killed in France in World War I, was written into American history books by President Reagan today because of a letter Mr. Reagan received from an unidentified admirer.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE AND ITS CREW BEGIN SIMULATION WITH BUILT-IN ERRORS
description: Astronauts and flight controllers began a fullscale simulation today of the first flight of the space shuttle Columbia amid growing optimism that the complex and versatile new vehicle, after many development delays, will soon be getting off the ground.

title: SMITH NOT APPRAISED BY F.B.I. ON SINATRA
description: William French Smith, the nominee for Attorney General, has told the Senate that he was unaware of files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation that are said to describe Frank Sinatra's alleged association with members of various organized crime families.

title: A FAST, POWERFUL JUICER
description: THE Champion Juicer is precisely that, a lightning-fast and extraordinarily powerful juicer. It is vastly better than and intrinsically different from any of the more common centrifugal juicers I've seen. In those, the fruits or vegetables to be juiced are fed through the top into a spinning container that hurls them against a cutter and forces the juice through a screen. The machines too often overload quickly, do their job incompletely and are prone to considerable vibration.

title: BUFFALO FORGE BATTLES A NEW TAKEOVER BID
description: The Buffalo Forge Company, a 103-year-old concern still largely controlled by the founding family, is fighting off its second unwelcome takeover attempt in two years, arguing heatedly that the company is worth more than the offering price.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: STREETS OF DREAMS

title: ATTEMPTING A DEFINITIVE FOOD ENCYCLOPEDIA
description: ONE of the things that I covet most is a dictionary or encyclopedia of food as all-encompassing and elaborate as the Oxford English Dictionary. The sad truth is that such a volume does not exist and probably never will.

title: South Carolina Judge Sentences Two Cuban Hijackers to 40 Years
description: Two Cubans who pleaded guilty to hijacking a Delta Air Lines flight over South Carolina and ordering it to Cuba were sentenced yesterday to 40-year prison terms by Federal District Judge Charles E. Simons.

title: U.S. Gives $1.8 Million For Carnegie Renovation
description: New York has received a Federal grant of $1.8 million to help renovate the entranceway, lobby and elevators of the 90-year-old Carnegie Hall and to install air-conditioning equipment to allow the hall to be open during the summer.

title: Japanese Avoid Chrysler Aid
description: Japanese banks that have extended credit to the Chrysler Corporation will not be required to help save it from bankruptcy.

title: STEAL BY RICHARDSON SEALS KNICK VICTORY
description: Michael Ray Richardson, who led the National Basketball Association in steals last season and is the pacesetter this season, made only one steal last night. But it came with six seconds remaining and it protected a 98-97 victory for the Knicks over the Seattle SuperSonics at Madison Square Garden.

title: LETTERS
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: While reading ''A Problem in the Cloakroom: Finding Space for Down Coats'' (Jan. 7), I didn't think ''down'' would be referring to a ''put-down'' such as the one in the statement by Tom Margittai of the Four Seasons restaurant regarding, or rather disregarding, secretaries.

title: Psychiatrist Challenges Garwood's Insanity Plea
description: A prosecution psychiatrist testified today that Pfc. Robert R. Garwood was, in his opinion, sane in the nearly 14 years he spent behind enemy lines.

title: In Cronkite's Mailbox
description: Betsy Cronkite, discussing the wry sense of humor of her husband, Walter, recalls in an interview in the February issue of McCall's that after a national magazine asked Mr. Cronkite to write his own obituary for it, he sent one in immediately.

title: JUDGE AGAIN DENIES GIRLS' CREDITS
description: A Federal judge stood firm today on his decision to withhold credit from three white girls who defied his order to attend a predominantly black school.

title: Mets and Allen Settle On a 1-Year Contract
description: The Mets cured a contract headache yesterday when they signed a one-year contract with Neil Allen, their best relief pitcher, and avoided the complication of pursuing the problem in arbitration.

title: Article 232902 -- No Title
description: About 40 oil companies, including the Exxon Corporation, have filed a $1 billion suit against the Department of Energy in Federal District Court over whether auxiliary wells should be counted as oil-producing wells when computing an oilfield's average yield.

title: Relatives of 8 Who Died Are Praised in a Tribute
description: The families of the eight Americans who died in the attempt to rescue the hostages in Iran last April were remembered and praised today by the wife of one of the hostages.

title: OATH ON THE BIBLE USED BY REAGAN'S MOTHER
description: President Reagan took the oath of office today on a Bible used by his late mother, Nellie Reagan, opened to II Chronicles 7:14, and bearing inside its front cover a sonnet composed by Mrs. Reagan dedicating her life to ''higher, nobler things.''

title: TOPS IN STREET THEATER
description: At the opening ceremonies at the Capitol, Senator Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon asked everyone to reach out and shake hands with their neighbors as a ''touch of unity.'' Few of the many thousands did so, but President Carter dutifully responded. Turning first to Vice President Mondale, he grapsed both of his hands warmly. He then shook hands with Vice President-elect George Bush and, finally, with President-elect Ronald Reagan.

title: EXECUTIVE POLL CITES OPTIMISM
description: Ronald Reagan's election has played a key role in increasing optimism about the economy among business leaders to its highest point since last year's second quarter, according to a Dun & Bradstreet survey released yesterday. But executives are less sanguine on the outlook for employment in 1981, according to the poll.

title: MURDOCH AROUSES CONTROVERSY WITH OFFER TO BUY THE TIMES OF LONDON
description: The strong possibility that Rupert Murdoch, the publisher of The New York Post, might be about to buy The Times of London has aroused a growing controversy in Britain.

title: QUALITY SCHOOLING FOR INNER-CITY CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Sales Down For Toyota, Nissan
description: Japan's two largest auto makers, the Toyota Motor Company and the Nissan Motor Company, today reported slight increases in their December exports, but said sales to their largest market, the United States, were down sharply.

title: Graphic Acquisition
description: Graphic Acquisition Inc., a new company owned by certain officers of Carl Marks & Company, the New York investment banking and security firm, announced that it had acquired for $55 million cash the assets and business of Arnold Graphic Industries, a private concern, and Baltimore Business Forms Inc. John W. Jordan 2d, a vice president of Carl Marks, said in announcing the acquisitions that that the combined annual revenue of the two companies exceeds $150 million. Arnold Graphic, which has headquarters in Akron, Ohio, designs, makes and distributes a broad range of business forms.

title: No Headline
description: Fred Glick, who set an American Football League record with 12 interceptions in 1963 as a safety for the Houston Oilers, has been named defensive backfield coach of the Giants.

title: South African Government Silences Two Black Papers
description: The South African Government today silenced major black newspapers for the second time in three years.

title: OPERA: RESTAGED 'BALLO IN MASCHERA'
description: LAST February, the Metropolitan Opera unleashed a new production of Verdi's ''Un Ballo in Maschera'' and won howls of anguish for its pains. A few critics found the decision to accept the Boston setting foisted on Verdi by the censors, but to update that setting to the Revolutionary period, to be thought-provoking. Others liked some of Elijah Moshinsky's tableaus, in conjunction with Peter Wexler's scenery of stark, slatted wooden panels and the sumptuous costumes of Peter J. Hall. But most found the production clumsy, willful and illogical.

title: WHITE HOUSE STAFF SLIDE BY EACH OTHER
description: Some of them wept, walking through the West Gate of the White House, others grinned, and several were awed. ''I'm still shaking, I'm very exhilarated,'' Karna Small, the new White House deputy press secretary, said moments after entering her office.

title: POOH'S PEERS
description: To the Editor:

title: AIR QUALITY SAYS MANY AREAS CANNOT MEET CRITERIA ON SCHEDULE
description: Many parts of the country will be unable to meet the health and environmental standards of the Clean Air Act on schedule, and some will never be able to meet them without economic disruption, according to a long-awaited draft report released today by the National Commission on Air Quality.

title: George Burns, 85, on the Secret of Staying Young
description: George Burns, the one-time vaudevillian and radio comedian who has made a new career out of being old, turned 85 yesterday in Beverly Hills, Calif., an event, he suggested, of no particular significance.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is time for us to realize that we are too great a nation to limit ourselves to small dreams.

title: SUCCESS OF U.S. IMPORTS PUTS ITALY'S SHOEMAKERS ON THE DEFENSIVE
description: PARMA, Italy The Sioux have long been stock characters on Italian television and in ''spaghetti Westerns,'' but when they lately started invading shoe stores in this country, the Italian shoe industry took a very dim view of it.

title: PAST POSSESSIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: The New Administration
description: President Reagan reiterated his campaign promises to take bold and immediate actions to remedy the nation's ''economic afflictions.'' The primary targets would be the excessive taxes and government, which he said were responsible for curbing industry, individual achievement and thrift, and which were hobbling the solution to the problem of ''the longest and one of the worst sustained inflations in our national history.'' The President also vowed to reduce Federal spending sharply and shift more government from Washington to the states. (Page A1.)

title: Futures Board Chairman
description: Leslie Rosenthal, managing partner of Rosenthal & Company, was elected without opposition as chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, the country's biggest futures exchange. In addition to Mr. Rosenthal's election on Monday, Ralph I. Goldenberg, an independent trader, was elected without opposition as vice chairman.

title: Economic Scene; Reagan Policy: Quick Action
description: IN his Inaugural Address yesterday, President Reagan clearly come down on the side of those advisers who have urged him to establish a momentum in the first days and weeks of his Administration, when he can capitalize on broad public support and Congressional good will to achieve the basic economic programs and policies on which he campaigned for the Presidency.

title: DISNEY PLANS A MOVIE ABOUT 'OZ' FOR NEXT YEAR
description: Walt Disney Productions, which has owned the movie rights to all of L. Frank Baum's ''Oz'' books - except ''The Wizard of Oz'' - since 1954, plans to make a movie about the mythcal land next year.

title: U.S. CITIES IN THE 80'S
description: The urban-policy report by the Commission for a National Agenda for the 80's, which recommended that the Government encourage migration from Northern industrial cities to the South and West, focuses welcome attention on cities' needs. But its unsupported generalizations concerning the causes of urban decline, and its simplistic presentation of urban-policy options, may inhibit focused national debate under the Reagan Administration.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have a recipe from North Africa for couscous, and it calls for harissa. I am curious to know if this is a spice and where it can be obtained.

title: Kirby Merger Is Off
description: The Kirby Exploration Company of Houston announced termination of an agreement in principle for merger with a privately held New York investment concern that was to have been formed by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, a New York investment firm. The agreement would have involved a cash merger in which Kirby shareholders would have received $96 cash for each of 1.6 million oustanding shares. Kirby Exploration said that the parties involved could not agree on the precise structure of the interest to be retained by Kirby shareholders after the merger.

title: LIGHTS GO ON, BELLS RING IN BIG CITIES AND VILLAGES
description: The nation flew its flags, rang its church bells, sounded its fire alarms, draped bunting across its main streets, put welcome signs in its windows and tied yellow ribbons everywhere to celebrate the freedom of 52 of its citizens yesterday.

title: Lonrho Loses Latest Fraser Bid
description: Lonrho Ltd. has lost its latest battle to gain more control of House of Fraser Ltd., the owner of department stores throughout Britain, including London's prestigious Harrods.

title: Officer Is Suspended
description: A New York City police officer, Owen Reiter, has been suspended from duty for 120 days after being found guilty of acting improperly and violating diplomatic immunity on May 12 when he became involved in an altercation after he stopped a car with diplomatic license plates for an alleged traffic infraction.

title: 3 MILE PLEA ON RATES HITS SNAG
description: The staff of a Pennsylvania state regulatory agency proposed yesterday that the General Public Utilities Corporation receive only 18.5 percent of the rate increases it had requested as a result of the 1979 nuclear accident at its Three Mile Island power plant.

title: WHY HAITI STILLS THE OPPOSITION
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberations
description: At a most delicate point in the negotiations for the hostages last weekend, the Soviet press felt moved to warn that the talks were merely a ''game,'' or cover, for an American military attack on Iran. For a moment it seemed as if Moscow hoped to facilitate a deal by reinforcing some hawkish American noises, particularly from the Reagan team.

title: Tremor Shakes Southern Italy
description: A strong tremor jolted the Potenza area today but caused no additional damage to buildings affected by the quake that killed nearly 3,000 people in southern Italy in November. Today's tremor, measuring V on the Mercalli scale of XII, was described by authorities as an aftershock of the November quake.

title: COAT MAKER MARKS 125 YEARS IN THE RAIN
