description: KARL FINK, the industrial designer, and his wife, Sona, had a night on the town earlier this week thanks to a coat he bought in 1932 when he was an art student at Parsons School of Design. ''It was the only coat I had for years,'' he said, recalling that it protected him during the Depression era.

title: Organ Prelude Series Will Begin Feb. 25
description: The 1981 Organ Prelude Series of twilight recitals presented by Lincoln Center at Alice Tully Hall will begin Feb. 25 with a recital by Calvin Hampton, the organist whose midnight programs at Calvary Episcopal Church have become something of a New York musical institution.

title: ANXIOUS FAMILIES AND TOWN ERUPT INTO LONG-POSTPONED CELEBRATIONS
description: Saying his final farewells at Andrews Air Force Base yesterday, Jimmy Carter spotted Anita Schaefer, the wife of one of the hostages, and exuberantly embraced her.

title: News Analysis
description: For a President who has promised Americans a new beginning, an era of national renewal at home and restored strength and stature abroad, the release of the American hostages in Iran was exquisitely timed.

title: British Steel Union Gives Talk Approval
description: Britain's biggest steel union, the Iron and Steel Trades Federation, gave its members approval to take part in talks on the British Steel Corporation's survival plan, which calls for 22,000 fewer jobs in the industry, the British Press Association reported.

title: Jersey Boy, 13, Held In Fire That Killed 6
description: JERSEY CITY (AP) - A 13-year-old boy was arrested yesterday and charged with setting the fire that killed six people in a tenement here Jan. 12, the police said.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 21, 1981
description: The Hostages The hostages flew to freedom 444 days after they were seized in Teheran. Jimmy Carter, a few hours after ending his Presidency, said that all 52 Americans were ''alive, well and free.'' The Algerian airliner carrying them stopped in Athens to refuel and went on to Algiers, where they were transferred to United States Air Force hospital planes for a journey to Wiesbaden, West Germany, for a week or less to ''decompress,'' as an official said. (Page A1, Column 1.) As the Algerian airliner left Teheran with the 52 Americans aboard, the Moslem militants who kept custody of them to the last minute of captivity hustled them to the stairs of the plane and shouted, ''God is great! Death to America!'' The Americans appeared dazed as they stumbled aboard. (A1:2.)

title: CARTER'S REMARKS IN HOMETOWN ON HIS 'EMOTIONAL EXPERIENCES' OF RECENT
description: DAYS Following is a transcript of the statement made by former President Jimmy Carter on his arrival in Plains, Ga., yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Reagan Takes Oath as 40th President; Promises an Era of National Renewal--Minutes Later, 52 U.S. Hostages In Iran Fly to Freedom After 444-Day Ordeal
description: WASHINGTON--The 52 Americans who were held hostage by Iran for 444 days were flown to freedom yesterday. Jimmy Carter, a few hours after giving up the Presidency, said that everyone "was alive, was well and free."

title: WINE TALK
description: AMERICAN wines are often challenging French wines in tasting competitions these days, and the results often suggest that certain carefully chosen California wines are superior to the best that France can offer. Such contests are nearly always controversial because of the probability that wines from each country reach maturity at different times and because of the biases of the tasters.

title: BUSH PLANS TO EMULATE MONDALE ROLE
description: At 8 o'clock this morning, Walter F. Mondale, who had been up all night, in and out of the Oval Office, telephoned George Bush, who had got a reasonably good night's sleep, to apprise him of the overnight developments in the hostage crisis.

title: Reagan's Dramatic Success
description: President Reagan has made a good beginning. His inaugural speech was a theatrical triumph, a cautious compromise between his supporters and opponents at home and abroad. And that is not all. He has something else more important going for him, which is that he is a lucky guy.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bath Iron Works Corp., announced it would build two 666-foot tankers at a cost of $142 million.

title: MIAMI OPERA: 'NABUCCO'
description: In recent years, the cooperative financing and trading of productions has become one of the most volatile and energizing developments in American opera. To-night, for instance, the Greater Miami Opera opened its 40th anniversary season with a new production of Verdi's third opera, ''Nabucco.'' After five performances here, the Nicola Benois sets and costumes will not be allowed to molder away in some dank warehouse but will travel to New York, where the City Opera will use them for its own version of ''Nabucco'' next fall. Later, they will move to Houston, Seattle and San Diego.

title: Ragout of Beef
description: 3 pounds stewing beef, preferably rump 2 tablespoons cooking oil 1 large onion, finely chopped 2 carrots, scraped and finely chopped 2 stalks celery, scraped and finely chopped (optional) 3 cloves garlic, minced 1/2 can tomato paste 2 cups dry red wine 1 large pinch oregano Salt to taste Freshly ground black pepper, a generous amount.

title: FIX SUSPECT INDICTED ON NEW DRUG COUNT
description: A convicted drug dealer, said to have introduced a Boston College basketball player to gamblers who allegedly fixed games, surrendered to Federal authorities in Pittsburgh yesterday on a new narcotics charge.

title: FEDERAL FUNDS RATE OFF SHARPLY
description: Interest rates declined yesterday though securities dealers hastened to add that the lower rates were largely the result of speculative trading rather than investor buying.

title: BERNARD J. QUINN
description: Bernard J. Quinn, a chemical engineer and former senior vice president of Pfizer Inc., a diversified concern that produces pharmaceuticals and other products, died of a heart attack Saturday while dining at a restaurant in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 66 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: BUSINESSMEN CITE NEED FOR SPEEDY ACTION
description: As J.W. McSwiney, chairman and chief executive of the Mead Corporation, sat in the stands on Inauguration Day and listened to President Reagan's address, he was impressed.

title: CITICORP'S PROFITS PLUNGE, MANUFACTURERS' IMPROVE
description: Citicorp, moving against a strong upward trend, yesterday became the nation's first major bank holding company to report a sharp decline in fourth-quarter profits. It attributed the poor return to the ''unprecedented volatility'' of interest rates.

title: DIXON, ILL., GLOWS IN HOMETOWN PRIDE
description: This small, unpretentious western Illinois city, straddling the icy waters of the Rock River amid some of the nation's richest farmland, basked in the 40-degree warmth of a January thaw today and in the reflected glow from Washington, where a hometown boy, Ronald Reagan, was inaugurated as the 40th President of the United States.

title: NORTHERN TELECOM'S SETBACK
description: When Walter Light was promoted to chief executive officer of Northern Telecom Ltd. 16 months ago, he inherited a host of problems arising from the telecommunications equipment company's expansion of a subsidiary.

title: Careers; Executive Aides Get 'Visibility'
description: REMEMBER the poem: ''For want of a nail, the shoe is lost, for want of a shoe the horse is lost, for want of a horse the rider is lost''? The end result was a lost battle because an aide carrying an important message could not deliver it.

title: Druse Sheik Takes Seat In the Israeli Parliament
description: A Druse sheik, Jaber Muadi, ignored warnings of vengeance by armed Bedouins against his clan and took a seat in the Israeli Parliament today to replace a Bedouin leader who was murdered in Jerusalem on Jan. 12.

title: Winds of Change
description: It seemed remarkable at first to read that Sam Brown, once a leader of vigorous protests against the Vietnam War, had changed his mind about the draft. On leaving a job as the head of Action, the Federal umbrella agency for voluntary programs including Vista and the Peace Corps, he said the other day, ''As one who spent a number of years, I think incorrectly, opposing the draft, it seems to me all of us owe some obligation to society.''

title: PAPAL SOLUTION TO BOUNDARY QUARREL VEXES ARGENTINA
description: It has turned into a long-running suspense story. The Argentine junta meets in secret almost daily, but the announcement each night is the same: still deliberating.

title: POLISH UNION CALLS FOR URGENT TALKS ON A PROPOSED FIVE-DAY WORKWEEK
description: The Polish labor union leadership called today for urgent negotiations with the Government over the issue of a five-day workweek and said all Saturdays would continue to be nonworking days pending an accord.

title: U.S. DOCTORS IN GERMANY ARE PREPARED TO HELP HOSTAGES RESUME NORMAL LIVES
description: State Department officials said here today that a team of American doctors would begin to check the health of the hostages immediately after their arrival and psychiatrists would interview them in an effort to detect clues to any emotional illnesses.

title: 'LET US BEGIN AN ERA OF NATIONAL RENEWAL'
description: Thank you. Senator Hatfield, Mr. Chief Justice, Mr. President, Vice President Bush, Vice President Mondale, Senator Baker, Speaker O'Neill, Reverend Moomaw, and my fellow citizens:

title: Governor Carey's Balancing Magic
description: Father William, the character in Lewis Carroll's poem, could balance an eel on his nose. Governor Carey can do more. He can balance a book-length, five-pound budget message in midair while making a chalk talk. Using a pointer and charts, he can persuade almost everyone that, with $1 billion or so a year in extra revenues generated by inflation, New York State can perform all these balancing miracles:

title: COUNTRY: RAY HUBBARD
description: RAY WYLIE HUBBARD and the Floyd Domino Band, who shared the bill at the Lone Star Cafe on Monday, each represents a different aspect of Texas country music. Mr. Hubbard, a second-generation ''outlaw'' of the Willie Nelson-Waylon Jennings school, is best-known for his amusing send-up of motherhood tributes, ''Up Against the Wall, Redneck,'' which was popularized by Jerry Jeff Walker. The Floyd Domino Band is an offshoot of the Texas swing revivalist group Asleep at the Wheel, Mr. Domino and Tony Garnier having been its pianist and bassist for several years.

title: PROMISES AN 'ERA OF NATIONAL RENEWAL' MINUTES LATER, 52 U.S. HOSTAGES IN IRAN FLY TO FREEDOM AFTER 444-DAY ORDEAL
description: Ronald Wilson Reagan of California, promising ''an era of national renewal,'' became the 40th President of the United States today as 52 Americans held hostage in Iran were heading toward freedom.

title: FREEZE IS ORDERED ON HIRING BY U.S.
description: Only minutes after completing an Inaugural Address in which he vowed to attack the nation's economic problems, President Reagan today ordered a freeze on the hiring of civilian employees by all executive departments and agencies of the Federal Government.

title: A QUESTIONABLE CASE FOR SECOND OPINIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: No Longer a New Career
description: Edward K. Hamilton, 42-year-old former Deputy Mayor of New York City, began a new career as a management consultant after leaving office in 1974. Now, as president of Hamilton, Rabinovitz and Szanton of Los Angeles, he serves as a link between the corporate and the public sectors.

title: PROMISES AN 'ERA OF NATIONAL; RENEWAL'- MINUTES LATER, 52 U.S. HOSTAGES IN IRAN FLY TO FREEDOM AFTER 444-DAY ORDEAL
description: The 52 Americans who were held hostage by Iran for 444 days were flown to freedom yesterday. Jimmy Carter, a few hours after giving up the Presidency, said that everyone ''was alive, was well and free.''

title: The Police Blotter
description: A 13-year-old girl was killed in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn when a 14-year-old boy walking behind her in the street put a bullet into a .38-caliber revolver and shot her, the police said. They declined to identify either of them. ... Two unidentified men were shot dead as they left a social club at 435 West 147th Street, in Harlem. ... Two gunmen robbed a check-cashing office at 187 Rodney Street in Williamsburg and escaped with an estimated $100,000 in cash. ... Two Queens men were arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the highjacking last fall of three truckloads of merchandise valued at $34,000. They were identified as Roberto Filipe, 29 years old, and Pedro P. Linares, 27.

title: Smoking Your Wife to Death
description: Those personal marriage-solicitation ads listing all the qualities sought in an ideal mate - good looks, brains, tenderness, energy, wealth - sometimes add ''nonsmokers only.'' The smell of stale tobacco can turn off even the most ardent suitor.

title: Bonn's Interest Rates
description: The president of the Bundesbank, Karl Otto Pohl, said today that West German interest rates were too high, but added that it was difficult to reduce them when the mark was under pressure because of high United States interest rates.

title: HOBBLING A PROBATION SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDIES OF GUN LAW DIVIDED ON IMPACT
description: Nearly six years after Massachusetts enacted the nation's first gun control law with a mandatory minimum jail sentence, disagreement remains over whether it has had a major effect on violent crime.

title: Norfolk & Western In French Coal Talks
description: The Norfolk & Western Railway said it was beginning negotiation of a long-term contract with Association de Importation Charbonniere of France for the shipment of Appalachian coal to France. The signing of a letter of intent for a contract exceeding two years and covering shipment of at least 800,000 tons a year was announced by John P. Fishwick, the railway's chairman and chief executive, and Albert Viala, vice chairman and chief executive of the French concern.

title: Abscam Case Recess
description: Judge George C. Pratt of Federal District Court in Brooklyn recessed until Feb. 2 a hearing on motions to overturn the corruption convictions of four current or former members of the House of Representatives. The hearing, which started Jan. 12, deals with the results of trials stemming from the Government's Abscam investigation.

title: Simmer: 46 in 48 Games
description: Charlie Simmer of the Kings scored two goals tonight, giving him 46 in 48 games, as Los Angeles routed the Detroit Red Wings, 11-4.

title: DEMOCRATS MAINTAIN THE PARTYING SPIRIT
description: The Carter White House's Presidential personnel office threw a party a few days ago, and a banner, its foot-high letters proclaiming ''We Will Be Back,'' was left hanging to greet today's new White House tenants.

title: Rookies to Play Key Roles
description: Flying in yesterday with his Eagle teammates, Roynell Young looked out the window at the city and its massive dome, and ''so much went through my mind.''

title: BOSSY FAILS TO SCORE
description: Mike Bossy's bid for 50 goals in 50 games will have to wait. Though the Islanders beat the Calgary Flames, 5-0, tonight at Nassau Coliseum, their high-scoring wing failed to pick up a goal and, with 48 goals in 48 games, has two more games to match Maurice Richard's feat.

title: CARTER COMMUTATION STIRS ANGER
description: Rejecting the recommendation of the Federal Parole Commission, President Carter has commuted the fouryear prison sentence given a New Orleans businessman for his role in a $1.3 million conspiracy to bribe Chicago officials.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE average weekly cost of feeding a family of four in New York City went down 10 cents to $101.27 during the two-week period from Jan. 5 through Jan. 16, according to the market basket survey conducted by the Department of Consumer Affairs. But prices are going to rise. ''From all indications, Government experts tell us the consumers' honeymoon with price inflation may be coming to an end,'' said Bruce Ratner, Commissioner of the consumer agency.

title: CITY PROGRESS LIMITED
description: To the Editor:

title: Cut-Rate Fare For Concorde
description: British Airways said today that it would introduce a cut-rate standby fare of $1,620 on its supersonic Concorde flights between London and New York starting March 1.

title: Rise Is Forecast In Coal Exports
description: A Government task force, predicting a bright future for United States coal exports, has said that the United States would be supplying 38 percent of total world demand by the end of the century.

title: Bonwit Teller Picks Flagship Store Head
description: Ronni Stern has been named by Bonwit Teller to head its new flagship store at Fifty-Seventh Street and Fifth Avenue, reporting to Helen Galland, the president and chief executive officer of the 11-unit group of stores owned by the Allied Stores Corporation.

title: New German Entry In Women's Magazines
description: Heinrich Bauer Verlag of Hamburg, West Germany, one of Europe's largest magazine publishers, has entered America's highly competitive women's service magazine field with, believe it or not, a weekly.

title: Fuel-Additive Campaign To Rosenfeld Agency
description: North American Combustion Technology has just picked Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson to be agency for its new product, Propel, a gasoline additive that it says gives cars 11 to 14 percent more mileage.

title: BUSINESS INTERESTED IN TRADE WITH IRAN
description: United States companies expressed cautious interest yesterday in resuming trade with Iran, although they question the feasibility of doing business there in the near future.

title: EATING IN - A SKIER'S WAY TO SAVE
description: IN the last few years, more and more skiers, especially those with families, have found renting a condominium to be the most comfortable - and economical - way to spend a ski week. Many ski resort condominiums, both in the Northeast and the West, are located a short schuss from the lifts, and meals prepared in your own kitchen are likely to be less expensive, and can be savored at leisure, with your boots off. No need to fight lunch-time cafete@ria lines in a steamy base lodge or to drive to restaurants every night.

title: GIVE OUR FIRST LADY A CHANCE TO BE HERSELF
description: While conventional wisdom has agreed that we are hard on our Presidents, it has never really come to grips with their wives.

title: Enter President Reagan
description: Ronald Reagan was a wise actor and secure human being at his inaugural. He did not struggle against the climactic drama in Iran or try to upstage it in the emotions of Americans. On the contrary, he gave proper thanks for the release of the hostages, which also liberated the nation and his Presidency from a corroding challenge. One had to be listening closely to catch Mr. Reagan's quiet assertion that terrorists, and aggressors, had better not let the hostage affair lead them to misjudge America's forbearance.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: FOR about two days each month Ellen's efficient, well-controlled and sunny self gives way to an argumentative, hypersensitive, distracted personality who picks fights with her family and anyone else who crosses her. Her sometimes venomous attacks, which usually end in remorse, have seriously eroded her marriage.

title: A WEARY CARTER RETURNS TO PLAINS
description: Jimmy Carter came home today to a rollicking, rain-soaked welcome from his neighbors and was visibly exhausted from two nights without sleep but exultant over the release of the 52 hostages.

title: 1. A Warm Helmet
description: One of the most becoming ways to bundle up these days is with a helmet that replaces both hat and scarf. Joan Vass, the Special Coty Award winning designer, has produced a beauty. The helmet is hand knitted of wool and mohair, comes in stripes or hazy mixtures of lovely colors. The bib is large enough to fill in any coat neckline and the whole business is wonderfully soft and cozy. It's $80 on Bendel's main floor.

title: Marilyn Horne and Her Victory Over Aggressive Viruses
description: That virulent strain of Bangkok influenza has affected hundreds of thousands in the past several weeks, and lately, aided by the cold weather, it seems to have struck many performers. In the theater, for example, Linda Ronstadt and Meryl Streep have missed performances in recent days because of throat problems.

title: SPIRIT RETURNS TO SICKMANN FAMILY NOW THAT 'ROLLER COASTER' RIDE IS OVER
description: The cruel uncertainty of the 444 days of Sgt. Rodney V. Sickmann's captivity afflicted his family until the last possible moment, the moment of the Presidential inauguration, the supposed final deadline for the consummation of the Carter Administration's deal with Iran. The television networks reported that the hostages were free, and the State Department, confirming nothing at first, coolly responded to the Sickmanns' call by inquiring as to its subject.

title: Market Place; Drug Stocks Finding Favor
description: DURING the first half of the 1960's, the shares of the Syntex Corporation went up like a rocket on the American Stock Exchange. That performance stemmed from the company's role as the leader in selling oral contraceptives.

title: BACKING IN ALBANY FOR BANK BILL
description: The State Assembly's Banking Committee approved a bill today that would allow banks from other states to open branches with broad services in New York City if New York banks were allowed to open branches in their states.

title: Bridge: Being Dummy No Disgrace Even If a Hand Is Powerful
description: If you hold a strong eight-card suit, it is most unlikely that partner has a better suit. But you should never confuse the improbable with the impossible, as one of the characters of the late P. G. Wodehouse used to say.

title: REFORMER WHO WOULD REVERSE THE NEW DEAL'S LEGACY
description: The nation today arrived at a fascinating and quite remarkable moment in its political history: A 69-year-old citizen politician who spent most of his working life in another profession has entered the White House and won the opportunity to lead what he hopes will become a political revolution.

title: CHILDREN'S MAGAZINES: A VARIED CHOICE
description: dotted vales of the northern Poconos. After 35 years, Highlights for Children has reinvented its cover.

title: TEXT OF REAGAN'S LUNCHEON TOAST
description: Following is a transcript of a toast by President Reagan at a luncheon with Congressional leaders in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Japanese Premier Ends Trip
description: Prime Minister Zen-ko Suzuki returned here today from his first official overseas trip, a 13-day tour designed to forge stronger political and economic links between Japan and the five countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.

title: Index; The Inauguration
description: Reagan to seek conservative polit- ical reformation B2 T-shirts, hats, mink coats and ec- centrics mingle in Capital B4 Republican revelers greet Reagan era with lavish parties B6 Nancy Reagan's style different from that of Rosalynn Carter B6 Reagan Inaugural Address gives prominence to obscure soldier B7 Reagan takes oath on Bible used by his late mother B7 Democrats hold their own inaugu- ral balls B8 The Hostages Hostage talks were unprece- dented and unpredictable A2 At U.N., some diplomats hope U.S. will improve ties with Iran A2 Bells ring and lights go on across the country A3 Hostages land at Algiers and fly on to West Germany A4 Mental health experts assess the problems of readjustment A4 Doctors wait in Germany to check hostages A4 Barbara Rosen lets children break news of father's release A5 Carter's comments on arrival in Plains, Ga. A8 Family of ''another'' Iran hostage feels mixed emotions A8 International Pope's solution to boundary dis- pute is problem for Argentina A10 Foes of Marcos urged by U.S. aide to forswear violence A11 Government/Politics Effects of Massachusetts gun law disputed A17 Carter's Army Secretary sees politics and racism in criticism A19 Health/Science Space shuttle Columbia and crew begin simulation test A16 The Living Section Food Root vegetables: No class, maybe, but lots of taste C1

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: BOSTON (A) - Signed Danny Todd Sheaff- e r, catcher; Dave Scheller and John Soren- s on, pitchers, and Mike Jefferson, outfielder. CINCINNATI (N) - Signed Mike O'Berry a nd Steve Christmas, catchers.

title: WEINBERGER APPROVED, 97-2
description: Caspar W. Weinberger, a man known more for his budget-cutting talents than military expertise, was confirmed tonight as Secretary of Defense. The vote, the first taken by the Senate on the President Reagan's Cabinet choices, was 97 to 2.

title: Key Rates
description: Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Advertising; Selling to Physicians As People
description: IF about 180,000 physicians are annually writing prescriptions for some $6.4 billion worth of pharmaceuticals, it is no wonder that drug manufacturers spend more than $742 million trying to reach them either with salespeople or advertising.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard EARLY AUTUMN. By Robert B. Parker. 212 pages. Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $10.95. THE TRADE. By William H. Hallahan. 323 pages. Morrow. $12.95 JUST CAUSES. By Malcolm McConnell. 325 pages. Viking. $13.95.

title: Walton Named For Offense Job Walton Jet Offense Coordinator
description: The New York Jets, whose inconsistent offense was a critical factor in their disappointing 4-12 campaign, hired Joe Walton today as offensive coordinator, a post that did not exist this season.

title: Victor Henningsen, 85; Headed Food Company
description: Victor W. Henningsen, chairman of Henningsen Foods Inc. of White Plains, died Monday at his home in Pelham, N.Y. He was 85 years old and also lived in Pine Orchard, Conn.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL URGS FOES OF MARCOS TO FORSWEAR THE USE OF VIOLENCE
description: Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke, after meeting with President Ferdinand E. Marcos in a farewell visit here at year's end, strongly urged leading opposition figures to accept the President's impending lifting of martial law as a ''generous offer'' and to forswear violence.

title: BOND'S CASINO, NEW ROCK CLUB, OPENS
description: New York City's younger rock-and-roll bands will have a new showcase for their talents beginning tonight, when Bond's Casino, at 45th Street and Broadway, formerly a lavish disco, begins presenting live rock four nights a week, Wednesdays through Saturdays. The new series, which will feature adventurous New York bands such as the Bush Tetras, the Lounge Lizards and the Nitecaps, is being coordinated by Charlie Martin, whose familiarity with the breadth and depth of the city's rock subculture is a result of his experience as a talent booker and sound engineer at C.B.G.B. Doors Open at 10 P.M.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THERE are many sauces in French cooking that are more or less uniform in the minds of well-trained chefs and, generally speaking, do not differ greatly from one professional kitchen to another, sauces such as as bechamel, soubise and americaine.

title: WHAT TO TAKE
description: In most condominium units you can be certain of finding a relatively new four-burner range (invariably electric). A toaster is likely to be sitting on the counter; if you're lucky it will be the oven type that can be used for warming rolls or toasting sandwiches.

title: y Reagan WITH A NEW FIRST LADY, A NEW S
description: TYLE BY LESLIE BENNETTS

title: VOLUME UP
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 20 points in relatively slow trading yesterday. Analysts cited intensifying concern on Wall Street over high interest rates, but also said President Reagan's Inaugural Address and the release of the American hostages had done little to stem the selling.

title: GIDDY MRS. ROSEN LETS CHILDREN DO THE TALKING
description: In the end, Barbara Rosen left it to her two small children to break the news about their father. They were in her arms, carrying small American flags, as she stepped out of the clapboard house in Brooklyn's Gravesend section to face the platoon of microphones and cameras that had been there for three days to record the moment.

title: ALCOA NET OFF 23.8% IN QUARTER AND BURROUGHS REPORTS A LOSS
description: The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's leading aluminum producer, announced yesterday that the recession and higher costs helped cause earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980 to fall 23.8 percent on a 4.9 percent increase in revenues.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 21, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee Against Apartheid - 10:30 A.M. Decolonization Committee - 3:30 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Nassau Jail Inmates Cut Wrists in Protest
description: Nassau County Jail officials reported that 10 inmates being held in a row of cells separate from those in the general prison area -most of them at their own request -had slashed their wrists and arms with razor blades in a protest.

title: Laker's Florida Flights
description: Sir Freddie Laker, looking to the growing British tourist trade in Florida, said today that he was considering charter airline service between London and two more Florida cities, Orlando and Daytona Beach, by mid-1982. Sir Freddie, who pioneered low-cost trans-Atlantic travel, said he expected service to Tampa to begin in early April. Last May, Laker Airways began service between Miami and Gatwick Airport near London.

title: ROOT VEGETABLES: NO CLASS, MAYBE, BUT LOTS OF TASTE
description: ROOT vegetables such as turnips, parsnips or rutabagas remain resolutely out of fashion. They are bulbous and nobby and lack the refinement of their brightly colored or leafy cousins.

title: PAINE WEBBER NET RISES
description: Two brokerage firms, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. and Paine Webber Inc., reported yesterday that they had higher earnings for the quarter ended in December. The quarter saw record stock trading and active commodity markets, but also witnessed another surge in interest rates.

title: Five Sentenced on Coast On Racketeering Charges
description: A Federal judge sentenced five reputed organized crime figures to prison today on racketeering, extortion and conspiracy charges, but he allowed them to remain free pending appeals.

title: Iran's Deposits Earned Interest of Nearly 17%
description: American banks paid an unusually high rate of interest on deposits in their foreign branches turned over to Iran as part of today's hostage settlement, Treasury officials reported.

title:
Sports of the Times;
Winning One for the Gipper
description: SO, at long last, they win one for the Gipper. Ronald Reagan undertakes his juiciest role since he played George Gipp in the film, ''Knute Rockne All American,'' 40 years ago.

title: JAMES A. MICHEL
description: James A. Michel, president of the Airco Carbon Division of Airco Inc. in Montvale, N.J., died Friday at the National Institutes of Health in Baltimore. He was 52 years old and lived in St. Mary's, Pa. ; He is survived by his wife, the former Shirley Perkins; two children, Anne and Jeffrey; his mother, Lydia Michel of Frankenmuth, Mich., and a brother, Philip Michel of Walnut Creek, Calif.

title: Vesco May Stay in the Bahamas
description: As Cabinet Reviews His Appeal1.3-

title: SOME ENVOYS IN U.N. HOPE FOR A U.S.-IRANIAN THAW
description: The feeling of relief over Teheran's release of the 52 American hostages is unlikely to alter the essential character of United States relations with Iran - frigid and distant.

title: Salvador Fighting Deprives 35 Towns of Phone Links
description: At least 39 people were killed in political violence and the telecommunications office said today that fighting between government troops and leftist guerrillas had left 35 towns without telephone links.

title: McCartney Asked to Waive 'On, Wisconsin' Royalties
description: Every time ''On, Wisconsin,'' the official state song, as well as the theme song of the University of Wisconsin, is played, Paul McCartney, the former Beatle, is supposed to be paid a royalty.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Bank and Trust Company, Reading, Pa., has appointed Robert C. Williams executive vice president in charge of the trust group.

title: THE HUDSON WATER SOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Meanwhile Back at The Ranch
description: Welcome back, ladies and gentlemen. The world you are re-entering, I am happy to report, is not markedly changed from the world you departed late in 1979. As you doubtless know, the United States, continuing its irritable quest for political happiness, has yet another President, while the Philadelphia Phillies have won the World Series, the American ice hockey team has won the Olympics and the Republicans have won the Senate.

title: ELEGENT FASHION FOR CELEBRATION
description: They came from Newport Beach, Calif., and Newport, R.I., from backwater towns and bedroom communities to celebrate the Inauguration of President Reagan. And they brought all the clothes they could carry and wore most of them. The celebrants had risen to the occasion in style. And judging from the attire worn at the events of the past three days one could further say that this is not going to be a cloth coat Republican Administration.

title: Philips N.V. Unit Plans a 25% Layoff
description: Societe la Radiotechnique-Compelec, a subsidiary of Philips N.V., a major European producer of television sets and other electronic equipment, said that during the next 18 months it would dismiss 1,474 employees, or 25 percent of its work force, as part of a restructuring plan.

title: SOME KEY DECISIONS WILL BE MADE EARLY
description: ''We must act today in order to preserve tomorrow,'' President Reagan told the nation today, adding, ''And let there be no misunderstanding - we are going to act beginning today.''

title: Socialist Office Bombed in Spain
description: The offices of the Socialist Party in this northern Spanish town were bombed today, the police said, but no one was injured. In San Sebastian, the Basque separatist group E.T.A. said it fired an antitank grenade at government offices yesterday and exploded a bomb in the headquarters of Iberduero, a company that is building a nuclear plant.

title: STATE DEPARTMENT OUTLINES AID AWAITING HOSTAGES AND FAMILIES
description: The State Department published regulations yesterday that outline the educational, medical and other benefits that await the American hostages and their families. The action puts into effect the Hostage Relief Act of 1980, passed last year by Congress.

title: U.S. Jury Indicts Jersey Executive In a Plot to Defraud Toy Company
description: A vice president of an international toy company with headquarters in Manhattan was indicted yesterday on charges that he took part in a scheme to defraud his company of tens of thousands of dollars.

title: DANCE: CLEVELAND BALLET MAKES DEBUT IN NEW YORK
description: THE Brooklyn Academy of Music's ''Ballet America'' series continues merrily if intermittently along and last night, the Cleveland Ballet - in its New York debut - became the third entry in this festival of six visiting companies from other parts of the country.

title: UNFROZEN ASSETS RECIEVED SO FAR BY IRANIANS COME TO $2.9 BILLION
description: Iran received about $2.9 billion of its more than $12 billion in frozen assets after the hostages were released today, the former Treasury Secretary, G. William Miller, disclosed this afternoon.

title: Bernadette Devlin Regains Consciousness After Attack
description: Bernadette Devlin McAliskey, the anti-British activist, who was seriously wounded in an assassination attempt four days ago, has regained consciousness, relatives said today.

title: Supreme Court in Oregon Strikes Down Death Penalty
description: The Oregon Supreme Court today struck down as unconstitutional a death penalty law adopted by voters in 1978, saying that provisions of the law allowing judges instead of juries to decide whether a death penalty would be imposed violated the state Constitution guarantees of trial by jury.

title: EVENTS THAT LED UP TO TAKEOVER OF U.S. EMBASSY ON NOV. 4, 1979
description: Members of an Iranian mob displayed the American captive before a security camera and threatened to cut his throat. Three officials of the United States Embassy, locked in a vault and working fast to destroy classified documents, saw the scene on a television monitor and opened the thick steel door. Thus, a little past noon on Nov. 4, 1979, about an hour and 20 minutes after the first demonstrators scrambled over the compound walls, the last stonghold in the American Embassy in Teheran fell to militants.

title: ARTHUR BRUAN
description: Arthur Bruan, supervising attorney for the New York City Housing Authority for more than 25 years, died yesterday at his home in Brooklyn.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: How is it possible to characterize the verse of Louis Phillips, Manhattan playwright and frequent contributor to Metropolitan Diary? Phrases like ''monumental triviality'' and ''breathtaking silliness'' leap to mind, when one thinks of the poetic inventions of the author of ''The World Famous Hay Hay Hay Poem As Translated by the Author'' and ''Banana Split Verse.'' Speaking of which, here is the latter: BANANA SPLIT VERSE Ban ana

title: Real Estate; Manhattan Developer's Headaches
description: IT took John W. Galbreath and Henry G. Waltemade only 20 minutes in the winter of 1978 to work out the initial deal for the sale of the 58,000-square-foot construction site in downtown Manhattan bounded by Broad, Pearl and South William Streets.

title: OIL LEASES OFF JERSEY CUT BACK
description: Several major oil companies have given up some of their five-year leases in the offshore Baltimore Canyon area because they are convinced there is no significant oil or gas to be found.

title: A COWBOY HERO, MYTH AND REALITY
description: The metaphor seems inevitable: a cowboy in full regalia moves on Washington from out of the West, looking grim and ready for battle with the gang of looters that has taken over the town.

title: C. BERNARD WESTERHOFF
description: C. Bernard Westerhoff, the former proprietor of John Duck Jr.'s Southampton (L.I.) Restaurant, died Monday at Southampton Hospital.

title: TV: THE PANOPLY OF THE INAUGURATION
description: OVERSHADOWED or, perhaps more aptly, upstaged by the hostages' story, the Presidential inaugural nevertheless manages to expand its television presence. The inauguration itself is covered in details that are not excruciating but, in terms of manpower involved, stunningly expensive. The occasion's every aspect, however trivial or forgettable, is pounced on by the electronic brigades.

title: Rubbermaid to Trim 2 Losing Operations
description: Rubbermaid Inc. of Wooster, Ohio, announced plans to dispose of its domestic automotive accessory business and its in-home party plan business known as Rubbermaid Party Plan Inc. It said that negotiations were in progress for sale of the automotive accessory operation to a group of management employees, while termination of the party-plan operations would come promptly and affect about 350 employees.

title: NEWCOMERS APPALUD 'GOOD WILL' OF THE CITY WITH GIFT FOR NEEDIEST
description: The ''spirit of good will'' that they found in New York City inspired an Illinois couple who recently moved to Hoboken, N.J., to contribute $25 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in honor of the first year of their marriage and their first holiday season in the city.

title: GLITTERING FESTIVITIES USHER IN REAGAN ERA
description: In white and black tie, in sequins and sables and clouds of perfume, Republican revelers stepped out tonight to the most lavish series of inaugural balls ever held in the nation's capital.

title: News of the Theater; AT LAST, 'THE LITTLE PRINCE' WILL OPEN
description: AFTER years in the planning stage and at least one false start, ''The Little Prince'' at last appears headed for a Broadway production. Now that Hugh Wheeler, the librettist for ''Sweeney Todd,'' has completed the book based on Antoine de Saint-Exupery's novel, ''The Little Prince'' is expected to go into rehearsal in April and open the first week in June. The show has music by John Barry, whose lengthy film credits include eight James Bond movies and ''Born Free,'' and lyrics by the poet Derek Walcott. The director is Mel Shapiro, who staged ''Two Gentlemen of Verona'' on Broadway.

title: QUESTIONS ON U.S.- IRAN RELATIONS
description: Even after the hostages are home, a number of questions about the United States' relationship with Iran may remain. Among them are the following:

title: Celeriac With Potatoes
description: 1 pound potatoes 1 1/2 pounds celeriac Coarse salt 3 tablespooons butter 1/4 cup heavy cream Freshly ground pepper.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, an article in The Times yesterday on property assessments in Philadelphia incorrectly stated the assessment ratein predominantly black areas of the city. The rate is 88 per cent.

title: The Pop Life; Winwood, at 32, a rock traditionalist.
description: WHEN Steve Winwood was 16 years old he was a rock star in England, as vocalist, pianist and guitarist with the Spencer Davis Group. When he was 20 he made an impressive American debut with Traffic, one of the finest and most influential progressive rock bands of the 1960's. Traffic rapidly won a large and loyal American following but by 1975, when Mr. Winwood was only 26, he had lived through 12 years on the road and felt he badly needed a rest. So Traffic disbanded, he bought a small farm north of London, and little was heard from him until last week, when his new solo album, ''Arc of a Diver,'' was released by Island Records.

title: POMP, FUR COATS AND SUN FOR THE HAPPY NEW PRESIDENT
description: Blowing kisses, singing the Marine Hymn and waving his greetings all the way from Capitol Hill to the White House, Ronald Reagan took charge of the nation's core today at the head of his own parade, and even filled in the lulls by working the Presidential reviewing stand with handshakes and kind words for the happy workers of his new Administration.

title: Avalanches Disrupt Swiss Travel
description: As much as three feet of new snow caused several avalanches in the Swiss Alps today, blocking roads and railroads. Motorists were told not to attempt approach roads to the Lotschberg, Great St. Bernard or Mont Blanc tunnels, and authorities in Davos issued a general avalanche alert.

title: Ford Skips Day's Event To Stay in Background
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford skipped Ronald Reagan's inauguration as President Tuesday, saying he wanted to play golf and stay ''in the background.''

title: TRACES OF PCB'S REPORTED IN GAS LINES BY 3 UTILITIES
description: Traces of a toxic chemical have been found in natural-gas systems by the three New York metropolitan utilities. But two of the utilities, the Consolidated Edison and Brooklyn Union Gas Companies, said yesterday that the chemical - polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's - was trapped at entries for interstate pipeline gas rather than in customer systems.

title: Super Bowl Notebook Raiders on the Town, but Eagles Leave It
description: "The city that care forgot'' is a description of New Orleans widely used in its tourist and travel promotions. But, of the two football teams here for the Super Bowl game this Sunday, only the Oakland Raiders are acting a little like tourists. The Philadelphia Eagles are all business.

title: NEW YORK REPUBLICANS ENJOY A ROLE
description: Most of the Republicans here from New York celebrated the Reagan presidency tonight at the inaugural ball held at the Shoreham Hotel outnumbering by a wide margin the party faithful from Oregan, Washington state and Guam who were also assigned there.

title: ANGUISH FOR FAMILY OF 'OTHER' HOSTAGE
description: For the families of 52 American hostages, the long excruciating wait for freedom is over. But for the husband and children of Cynthia B. Dwyer, 49 years old, of Amherst, N.Y., the wait has simply entered what might be called phase two.

title: Nissan-VW Cars
description: The Nissan Motor Company's president, Takashi Ishihara, said that Nissan will not start joint car production in Japan with Volkswagen until the summer of 1982 at the earliest. He said that a joint Nissan-Volkswagen group will complete a study by June to decide the type of car and production volume. Last month he said Volkswagen suggested the cars be based on Volkswagen's Audi Passat series.

title: Kodak Is Extending Accounting Method
description: The Eastman Kodak Company announced that, effective for 1980, it will extend the LIFO (last in, first out) accounting method to all of its worldwide inventories.

title: Belzbergs Add To Bache Stake
description: The First City Financial Corporation, the Canadian company controlled by the Belzberg family that has been accumulating stock in the Bache Group for more than a year, appears to be taking a more aggressive stance with regard to Bache.

title: DESIGN CHANGE ALLOWED TO BOLSTER INJURY CLAIM
description: The highest court of New York State ruled today that a consumer could use more widely the changes made by a company in a product's design to help prove he was injured by an earlier version of the product.

title: GROCERIES TO BUY
description: The following is a suggested shopping list (for use at the ski area) that will provide breakfasts, lunches and at least three dinners for a family of four for a week. The quantity of a number of the items will vary according to your family's taste and appetite. Dairy and Refrigerator Products

title: Forgotten Americans
description: More than five million Americans make up our nation's military family, serving around the country and abroad.

title: HOSTAGES IN GERMANY AFTER STOP IN ALGIERS
description: The 52 Americans released by Iran arrived in West Germany early today, ending a period in United States history marked by extraordinary collective frustration and pain.

title: Cleanup Under Way In Brooklyn Oil Spill
description: Cleaning efforts were under way yesterday after 500,000 to a million gallons of oil spilled from the damaged tanker Concho into Brooklyn's Gravesend Bay, a Coast Guard spokesman said.

title: DEFENSE REBUTS NEW TEST RESULT FOR HARRIS TRIAL
description: Dr. Cyril H. Wecht, a defense pathologist testifying in the murder trial of Jean S. Harris, said today that none of the skin tissues found in Dr. Herman Tarnower's chest wound could be identified as having come from the doctor's hand.

title: ACCORD CAUSED HECTIC DAYS IN BANKING
description: 14 By ROBERT A. BENNETT

title: WIFE LINKED TO DEATH OF EX-TEXAS SPEAKER
description: The authorities investigating the slaying of Price Daniel Jr., whose family was prominent in Texas politics, said today that his estranged wife fired the shots that killed him, but no charges would be filed until they knew why.

title: Executive Joins Chiat/Day As New York Manager
description: After only a year as a senior vice president with the Radio Advertising Bureau, Mark H. Mullin is moving into the agency business. He willll be executive vice president and manager of the New York office of Chiat/Day, the Los Angeles-based agency.

title: NEXT TASK FOR HOSTAGES: READJUSTING TO FREEDOM
description: Released at last, after 14 1/2 months in captivity, the Americans who were taken hostage in Teheran are not quite home free. They face a difficult readjustment to freedom, judging by the experiences of other hostages and prisoners of war.

title: Muskie Farewell Menu: It Is Politics a la Carte
description: Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie left office on a politically gustatory note that touched on old and new adversaries, one of his aides said today.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Proposals for reviving Manhattan's West Side along the Hudson River have been around so long they have become abstractions, even as they continue to be weapons and levers in political trade-offs.

title: CARTER'S ARMY SECRETARY SEES POLITICS AND RACISM BEHIND CRITICS ATTACKS
description: The United States Army has been unfairly maligned in recent years and attacks on its readiness have sometimes been politically or racially motivated, asserts Clifford L. Alexander Jr., who has just left office as Secretary of the Army.

title: DUMPING RULING APPEALED
description: TOYKO, Jan 20 (AP) The Asahi Chemical Company has appealed a ruling by the United States International Trade Commission that the Japanese producer of synthetic fiber 'dumped' its product in the American market, a company official said today.

title: STATE SCHOOL AID SOUGHT BY CAREY CALLED TO SMALL
description: The State Board of Regents and the Legislature reacted with disbelief today to Governor Carey's plans to increase public-school aid in the coming fiscal year by only 2.5 percent, or $83 million. The Regents had recommended an increase of $407.2 million in the present school aid budget of $3.8 billion.

title: Frances Sternhagen to Star In 'Prevalence of Mrs. Seal'
description: Frances Sternhagen will star in Otis Bigelow's comedy ''The Prevalence of Mrs. Seal,'' which begins its New York premiere on Feb. 5 at the Manhattan Punch Line Theater, 260 West 41st Street.

title: MUDD CLUB REGULARS CELEBRATE INAUGURAL
description: THE Monster Party was more bizarre. The Joan Crawford Mother's Day Party was more decadent. But none of the regulars at the Mudd Club could recall a more fashionable party than the Inaugural Gala, which climaxed at 3 A.M. yesterday with a fierce contest for ''best ballgown.''

title: INNOVATIVE FISHERMEN IN INDIA TRYING MOTORBOATS
description: Mariappan Jayapalan has become a pioneer in this fishing community on the outskirts of Madras City since he acquired a motorboat to replace his sailing raft.

title: G.M. Will Recall Station Wagons Because Rear Windows Shatter
description: The General Motors Corporation agreed today to recall 80,000 intermediate-size station wagons manufactured last year because of a defect that has caused some rear windows to shatter.

title: WITH SON SAFE, PROUD FAMILY SHARES SECRET OF HOW HE HELPED OTHERS ESCAPE
description: For most of the past year Jesse and Mary Lopez kept the secret bottled up inside them. Their pride was nearly boundless but they feared that disclosure would place their 22-yearold son, Sgt. James M. Lopez of the Marine Corps, in greater danger from the Iranian militants holding him hostage in Teheran.

title: Calls Besiege Algerian Mission
description: The Algerian Mission to the United Nations received hundreds of telephone calls yesterday from persons offering words of gratitude for their work in freeing the Americans. ''It was our duty to help, but the thanks are very much appreciated,'' said an embassy spokesman. ''Tell everybody, they are welcome.''

title: The Economy
description: The economy was stronger than expected in the fourth quarter, and economists said that a decline in the first quarter decline was now unlikely. The Commerce Department reported that the economy grew at a 5 percent annual rate in the last quarter and that the G.N.P. was almost exactly the size it was a year earlier, after adjustment for inflation. The fourth quarter growth is expected to intensify the debate over the timing of a tax cut. (Page D1.)

title: PIANO RECITAL: MOZART'S LETTERS WED TO HIS MUSIC BY LEO SMITH
description: A COMPOSER'S life and music are usually seen separately -as if abstract ciphers of sound have nothing to do with concrete everyday cares, as if the way a man courts his wife has no relation to the structure of a melodic line, as if harmonic modulations are shaped in a world without roast mutton or mugs of ale.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 22, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on the Drafting of an In- ternational Convention Against Merce- naries - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: TICKETS AND ROOMS: THERE'S NO SHORTAGE
description: The proper barometer to measure the impact of a major sports event, such as the Kentucky Derby, the Indianapolis 500-mile race or the Super Bowl, has often been the availability of tickets and hotel rooms. In this city today, 96 hours in advance of Super Bowl XV, there was no shortage of either - provided the customers had money to pay the going prices.

title: A Chairman-Chief For New York Life
description: At a board meeting of the New York Life Insurance Company yesterday, Donald K. Ross, 55 years old, was elected chairman and chief executive officer, effective May 20. He will succeed R. Manning Brown, who will step down at the mandatory retirement age of 65 after 30 years with the big New York-based insurer. Mr. Ross will be succeeded as president and chief administrative officer by Jacob R. Underhill, 54.

title: Mother of a Hostage Is Stricken By Heart Attack After Phone Talk
description: Anna Ragan, 70 years old, the mother of Master Sgt. Regis Ragan, one of the freed hostages, suffered a heart attack today shortly after speaking by telephone with her son in Wiesbaden, West Germany.

title: AT REAGAN WHITE HOUSE: NEW FACES IN OLD SPACES
description: ''Hail to the Chief'' is back, Truman and Jefferson are out, Coolidge and Eisenhower are in, and James S. Brady has taken possession of Jody Powell's bulletproof vest.

title: 'SELLING' A DROUGHT IS JOB FOR CITY AIDE
description: ''We are not kidding, although I know it is hard to convince people in the depth of winter that there is a drought when you don't have cow bones bleaching on 42d Street in the noonday sun,'' said Francis X. McArdle, Commissioner of Environmental Protection.

title: Index; The Hostages
description: Transcript of Carter's remarks at Rhein-Main Air Base A8 Diplomats say marine guard's ac- tions enabled 5 to escape A9 Hostage to parents: 'Hello, is this Krakow Store?' A9 Transcript of Sgt. Sickmann's first call home to Missouri A9 Good grooming is a priority for freed Americans A10 New U.S. rules provide benefits for former hostages A11 Daughter of former hostage travels to Wiesbaden A11 Christopher leaves State Depart- ment on flamboyant note A13 Canadian tells how Americans' es- cape was planned A13 International Soviet dispels hopes it will halt whaling A3 Afghan rebels reported to obtain some advanced weapons A4 Around the World A5 Two Greek publishers persevere in their muckraking efforts A6 U.S. envoy in Salvador disputes report on killing of 4 A14 Peking's warnings to U.S. on Tai- wan seen as reflecting anxiety A16 In Canadian northwest, assimila- tion befalls the Dogrib tribe A18 Innovative fishermen in India try out new crafts: motorboats A19 Former Premier Ecevit of Turkey returning to journalism A20 Government/Politics Hundreds of ticket holders angry at being locked out of parties B7 At Reagan White House, Coolidge and Eisenhower are 'in' B8 General Direction of bullet is at issue in Tarnower murder trial B2 Around the Nation B6 Three girls in busing dispute en- roll in private school B6 The Home Section Home The rooms where writers write C1

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: THE WINTER ANTIQUES SHOW
description: 27th Annual Winter Antiques Show, Seventh Regiment Armory, 67th Street and Park Avenue.

title: New York Air to Add Television Commercials
description: New York Air, the recent arrival in this town that has been troubling Eastern and its Washington shuttle, will branch out from newspaper and radio advertising, which it has had since going into business, and next month try television. Ketchum/New York, already the agency for Air Jamaica and B.W.I.A. International, does advertising for New York Air as well.

title: JAZZ: 16 MUSICIANS PLAY FOR A 'ONE NIGHT STAND'
description: WAS the ''One Night Stand'' at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday ''an evening of all stars,'' as the program advertised on its front page, or ''a keyboard concert,'' as the same program stated inside? Or was it an expensive promotion for Columbia records' roster of jazz artists? The 16 jazz musicians who performed, mostly in rushed 10-minute segments, couldn't be sure, but whatever ''One Night Stand'' was, it resulted in some moments of fine jazz, along with some that were not so fine. And it was all recorded for a forthcoming Columbia album.

title: CATERPILLAR SOARS; GENERAL FOODS GAINS
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company, the largest manufacturer of earth-moving and construction machinery, reported a profit gain of better than fivefold for the last three months of 1980, attributable largely to a strike by the United Automobile Workers a year ago that depressed earnings in the last quarter of 1979.

title: A VICTORIAN AUCTION FOR ECLECTIC TASTES
description: THE Victorian era, for some people, evokes images of horsehair sofas, cluttered drawing rooms and cabbage roses unlike any seen in nature. For others, the Victorian style represents the last era of elegance, gentility and rational order.

title: Coast Dockers Drop Boycott; 2d Union Still Bars Iran Cargoes
description: West Coast dockworkers have ended a boycott of goods shipped to or from Iran upon the release of the American hostages, Jim Herman, president of the International Longshoremen and Warehousemen's Union, announced yesterday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HISTORICAL ART

title: NEW ADMINISTRATION SAYS IT DEFERS JUDGMENT ON AGREEMENMT WITH IRAN
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it was reserving judgment on the agreements with Iran for release of the 52 American hostages that were negotiated in the last hours of the Carter Administration.

title: Colombian Guerrilla Group Says It Holds American
description: A leftist guerrilla movement took responsibility today for the kidnapping Monday of Chester Bitterman, an American linguist.

title: Handwritten Reagan Letter About Sinatra Up for Sale
description: Back when Ronald Reagan was campaigning for the Presidency, he attended a dinner for 130 persons at the home of an old friend, Walter H. Annenberg, the former Ambassador to Britain, and wound up writing a letter to a supporter to defend his friendship with Frank Sinatra, a fellow guest.

title: GAS CAN TAKE THE PLACE OF GASOLINE
description: To the Editor:

title: 52 FORMER HOSTAGES START READAPTING IN U.S. AIR FORCE HOSPITAL IN GERMANY
description: The 52 Americans freed from captivity in Iran began readapting slowly today with medical examinations, telephone conversations with their families, and a visit from former President Jimmy Carter.

title: Advertising; Decorating Magazine Sets Debut
description: decorating magazine called American Taste.

title: REALTY INTERESTS COUNTER CITY'S MIDTOWN PROPOSAL
description: Declaring that many of New York City's proposals to overhaul its midtown zoning are either too complex or unworkable, the city's leading real-estate industry organization has prepared a counterproposal to guide midtown development.

title: TALES OF BEATINGS AND FEARS EMERGE
description: Tales of beatings, months in solitary confinement, constant fear of death and physical and mental mistreatment emerged yesterday, relatives said, as the freed American hostages shared the details of their long captivity in telephone conversations with their families.

title: Dr. Maurice Greenhill; Ex-Psychiatry Professor
description: Dr. Maurice H. Greenhill, professor emeritus and director of the department of psychiatry at the hospital of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died Tuesday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 71 years old.

title: CATALOGUES FOR GARDENS TO COME
description: FEW serious gardeners can do without mail-order catalogues. Those who live in the city or rural areas depend on them for seeds, plants and supplies, while suburban gardeners rely on them for hard-to-find items not carried by local garden centers. Shoppers will notice an inflationary trend this year. Seed packet prices are generally 10 to 15 cents higher and nursery stock may have 25 or 50 cents added to the price.

title: Ex-Congressman to Leave Prison
description: For 3 Months in Halfway House

title: BURNS URGES CAUTION IN CUTTNG TAXES
description: Arthur F. Burns advised Congress today to reduce and stretch out the cut in personal income taxes that President Reagan has promised to sponsor - 30 percent over three years.

title: 'Yellow Ribbon' Tune Gives Composers Pride
description: Two New Jersey composers said today that they were proud that one of their hit songs, ''Tie a Yellow Ribbon,'' had become a popular anthem and a symbol of hope during the 15-month hostage crisis.

title: RCA AWARDED POST OFFICE JOB
description: The United States Postal Service said today that it had awarded to the RCA Corporation's Government Communications Systems division a contract to install its E-COM electronic message system.

title: Vienna Airport Mishap Kills 1
description: One man was killed and two were seriously injured when an aircraft fire extinguisher burst open and exploded in the cargo building at Schwechat airport today, an airport official reported.

title: Saudi Calls for a Holy War To Settle Israeli Conflict
description: In an article described in Saudi Arabia as setting the stage for a conference of Islamic leaders opening in Mecca on Sunday, Crown Prince Fahd said a ''jihad,'' or holy war, was the only course for resolving the Arab-Israeli conflict.

title: St. John's Subdues Seton Hall, 73 to 62
description: St. John's defeated Seton Hall last night, and although the final score of 73-62 did not reflect it, the game was close until the Redmen pulled away in the final eight minutes at Alumni Hall in Queens.

title: Choices In Angola
description: Secretary of State Alexander Haig told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee last week that he opposed United States recognition of the Angolan Government ''so long as there are 20,000 or 18,000 Cuban mercenaries within their borders.'' The day he said that the French Foreign Minister, Jean Fran,coisPoncet, ended a four-day official visit to Angola with a joint statement pledging development of the two countries' economic and political relations.

title: HAIRCUTS HIGH ON THE LIST FOR MANY OF THE FREED 52
description: About the first thing that the 52 former hostages did when they arrived here early this morning was to rush to a bank of telephones to call their relatives and friends.

title: Airlines Get Permission to Offer Free Flights to Kin of Hostages
description: Most of the nation's major domestic airlines have obtained special permission from the Civil Aeronautics Board to offer free flights to families of the 52 American hostages freed yesterday by Iran.

title: 'Officer' Is Sought In Assaults on Boys
description: Two boys, aged 12 and 14, were abducted and sexually assaulted in separate incidents within the last three weeks here by a man posing as a police officer, according to the police.

title: SEVERAL RINGS, A FEW LOVING WORDS, THEN AN OUTBURST OF ELATION AND TEARS
description: Shortly after the hostages landed in West Germany, the telephone calls started coming. Sgt. Kevin Jay Hermening told his mother he could hardly wait to have some of her barbecued pork chops. Kathryn L. Koob, one of the two female hostages, said she had lost 60 pounds while in captivity and her sister, Vivian Homeyer, said she was jealous.

title: Border Patrol's Searches For Aliens Are Resuming
description: Almost a year after the United States Border Patrol was ordered to stop its searches of camps for alien farm workers because the searches might complicate the 1980 census, two-man teams are again searching for illegal aliens.

title: BOY, 14, HELD IN BROOKLYN GIRL'S SLAYING
description: A 13-year-old girl on her way home from school was shot and killed in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn Monday by a boy who was apparently playing with a gun, the police said yesterday.

title: Angola Reports Downing 4 South African Aircraft
description: The official Angola press agency reported today that Angolan forces shot down three South African helicopters and one fighter-bomber in fighting along the southern border with South-West Africa.

title: CON ED'S FRUSTRATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: INADEQUATE RECOURSE FOR FREEZING TENANTS
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 PSYCHIATRISTS SUSPECT GARWOOD OF FAKING INSANITY
description: Two court-appointed psychiatrists testified today that Pfc. Robert R. Garwood gave such bizarre responses on a personality test that they believed he might have been faking mental illness.

title: U.S. Audit Says Carter Campaign Overspent Itself in Three States
description: Former President Jimmy Carter's primary election campaign went over the spending limit in three states and must repay the Government at least $129,443, the Federal Election Commission reported today.

title: FARRELL LINES PROFITABLE AGAIN
description: After dropping three ocean routes, laying off a third of its employees and restructuring its management, Farrell Lines, the venerable but struggling freighter line, ended three years of losses with the reporting of a small profit for 1980.

title: Virginia Wins, 86-56
description: Ralph Sampson, Lee Raker and Jeff Lamp combined for 47 points tonight as No. 2-ranked Virginia routed George Washington, 86-56.

title: A COLLECTOR OF BENTWOOD SELLS HIS FINDS
description: HE bought his first rocker 10 years ago, and for the last three years Barry Harwood has been a serious collector of bentwood furniture. Now, he is selling his chairs, stools, settees, hat racks and cribs.

title: LEO CLIFFORD YOUNG
description: Leo Clifford Young, a former United States Navy scientist whose research helped develop the first radio detection of aircraft, died at a nursing home here Friday.

title: REVUE: MUSIC OF THE PRESENT IN 'SHAKESPEARE'S CABARET'
description: AS theater lyricists go, William Shakespeare is hard to beat. He may even be better than Lorenz Hart. But where would Hart have been without Richard Rodgers? Lyrics alone cannot carry a song; there must be music, too. In a new revue called ''Shakespeare's Cabaret,'' many of the Bard's immortal verses (as well as a few of the mortal ones) have been set to music by a composer named Lance Mulcahy. Though Mr. Mulcahy is a professional enough tunesmith, he's quickly overpowered by his collaborator. One leaves ''Shakespeare's Cabaret,'' which opened at the Bijou last night, humming the lyrics but not the score.

title: No Headline
description: IRANIANS CLASH OVER HOSTAGE NEGOTIATIONS

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in The Times on Monday incorrectly described the role of Robert Kiernan in the inaugural gala. He was production designer and technical director; the director of orchestrations was Don Costa.

title: THE HOSTAGES IN ALEGRIA-IN 1785
description: Algerian diplomats have won America's spontaneous affection. How different things seemed 194 years ago, when Algeria humiliated our young Republic and showed that Americans could be miserable diplomats.

title: FORMER TURKISH PREMIER IS GOING BACK TO JOURNALISM
description: Former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit is going back to his original profession as a journalist and is encouraging his political friends to follow his example.

title: Bridge: Circumstances Should Alter Strategy and Theory of Play
description: Circumstances alter suit combinations. Suppose that with plenty of entries you need four tricks from this holding:

title: No Headline
description: The Justice Department filed papers in courts around the country today defending the legality of former President Carter's agreements with Iran, and a Federal judge here preliminarily upheld the agreements.

title: Rhode Island Underworld Figure Denies He Ordered Killing in '65
description: Raymond L. S. Patriarca, the reputed chieftain of organized crime in New England, pleaded not guilty in his hospital room today to a charge that he ordered a killing 15 years ago. The judge later granted bail, setting it at $100,000 cash.

title: RIFT SURFACES IN EAGLE CAMP
description: The Philadelphia Eagles' usually bright and optimistic world has grown clouded with the surfacing again of a division between Coach Dick Vermeil and his place-kicker, Tony Franklin, a major figure in what is expected to be a close Super Bowl game.

title: Q. I have a wood deck outside my house that is made of untreated wood. I stained this deck with a widely advertised brand of heavybodied oil base shingle stain, but I have been told that outside decks will soon rot if not made of treated wood. Is there anything I can put on the deck to preserve it and make it last longer? - D.K., Frankfort, Ky.
description: A. The oil stain you used was made for use on shingles and siding - it is really not designed to stand up for very long on surfaces that are walked upon. As a result, it will wear off pretty fast on the decking.

title: Jobless Rates Rise in Europe
description: Unemployment in the European Common Market reached record levels in December and was 27 percent higher than at the end of 1979, the European Economic Community statistics office said today.

title: No Headline
description: IN the tradition of Super Bowl week, Tom Flores, the coach of the Oakland Raiders, was at the podium, providing dull answers to dull questions. But suddenly, from the rear of the Fairmont Hotel ballroom, a different question woke up everybody.

title: SAVING WATER- AND MONEY
description: The charts look deceptively simple: an array of 10 or so boxes, connecting lines and a smattering of numbers. ''This is what we started with in 1977,'' William F. Shay, the engineer responsible for water management for the Schering division of the Schering-Plough Corporation, told a recent visitor to the company's sprawling pharmaceutical production complex in Union, N.J. ''These are block diagrams of our utility systems.''

title: Minneapolis Bank Plans Expansion
description: The First National Bank of Minneapolis, the largest subsidiary of the First Bank System Inc., said it had reached an agreement in principle to purchase two units of the Rainier National Bank of Seattle to increase its capabilities to handle international business.

title: No Headline
description: Former Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie being greeted by crowd at Rhein-Main Air Base in Frankfurt, West Germany. He joined former President Jimmy Carter and American officials who visited hostages at Wiesbaden hospital.

title: CHRISTO'S PLAN FOR PROJECT IN PARK STARTS FIREWORKS
description: With the controversial proposal by the artist Christo to construct 27 miles of fabric ''gates'' along walkways in Central Park awaiting decision by Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis, the ''pros'' and the ''cons'' seem solidly lined up. And many of them declared themselves this week at a lively panel discussion at New York University. The discussion, sponsored by the university's Graduate School of Public Administration, packed a big lecture room in the main building with vociferous Christo fans, art lovers, and representatives of Central Park interest groups. The latter provided much of the opposition.

title: RECITAL: SONGS BY DAME JANET BAKER FOR CARNEGIE HALL
description: IT seems highly unlikely that New York will ever see Dame Janet Baker in opera, an activity she pursues only in her native England. Perhaps for that reason the mezzo-soprano offered some highly charged dramatic music at her annual Carnegie Hall recital last night.

title: FOUNDER OF THE A.C.L.U. REFLECTS ON HIS 97 YEARS
description: The conversation had wandered about and explored all matter of people and things - Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan, the economy, the inauguration (''wooden'') and Nancy Reagan's beaded ball gown (''vulgar'') - when Roger Baldwin was finally brought back to the subject at hand: his 97th birthday today.

title: SEX AND PENSIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: JETS SCORE 4 IN 3RD TO TOP RANGERS, 5-1
description: The line of Normand Dupont, Ron Wilson and Willy Lindstrom sparked the Winnipeg Jets to a 5-1 victory over the New York Rangers tonight before a crowd of 12,010.

title: Hertz North America Ads Consolidated With Scali
description: The Hertz Corporation has consolidated all of its North American advertising in one ad agency, Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

title: SUPER BOWL ATTRACTS BUSINESS
description: On a torrid day in July 1979, with the Super Bowl XV kickoff still a year and a half away, the office of Antoine's Restaurant here was abuzz with activity.

title: POUND AS CRITIC: MORE THAN A FOOTNOTE?
description: FEW knowledgeable people are likely to argue with the proposition that poets make the best critics of poetry. But do they also make the best critics of the visual arts? Despite the Niagaras of purple prose and moldering metaphors that poets have been known to lavish on certain works of art, there are many people who think so. The illustrious examples of Baudelaire (writing on Delacroix) and Apollinaire (writing on the Cubists) are often cited. Within recent memory, the late Frank O'Hara wrote a great deal of art criticism (about the painting and sculpture of the New York School) in the 1950's when Art News magazine was edited by Thomas B. Hess. So did James Schuyler and Parker Tyler and Barbara Guest and numerous other writers of verse. One of the most admired contemporary poets - John Ashbery - comes out of this milieu, and continues to write art criticism today.

title: 'Funnies' to Open Feb. 12
description: ''Real Life Funnies,'' a new musical revue based on the Stan Mack cartoons in The Village Voice, will begin previews next Tuesday and open Feb. 12 at the UpStage Theater of the Manhattan Theater Club, 321 East 73d Street.

title: ITALIAN INVESTORS BUY IL PROGRESSO
description: Il Progresso, the Italian-language daily newspaper that for 100 years has helped waves of immigrants stay in touch with current affairs in Italy while chronicling their lives in the United States, has been sold to a group of Italian investors for $1 million.

title: 2 Hurt in Shooting At Newark Station
description: NEWARK (AP) - A New York woman and a 16-year-old youth were shot at Pennsylvania Station and an Indiana woman was being held, the police said.

title: Fiat-Allis to Build Tractors for Soviet
description: The Fiat-Allis Construction Machinery Company has announced the sale of $90 million in tractors and parts to the Soviet Union.

title: Texaco Additive Plant
description: Texaco Inc. said today that it would build a plant in Port Neches, Tex., to manufacture MTBE, a chemical used to improve the octane of gasoline. Texaco said the plant, to be completed by fall, would make 6,300 barrels a day of the additive, methyl tertiary butyl ether. A barrel contains 42 gallons.

title: JUSTICES REVOKE U.S. CITIZENSHIP OF A NAZI GUARD
description: The Supreme Court, in a ruling today that Government lawyers said would help the Justice Department's effort to deport hundreds of former Nazis, revoked the citizenship of a former guard at a Nazi extermination camp who concealed his past when he entered the United States as a refugee after World War II.

title: Lukens President Adds Chief Executive's Duties
description: W. Robert Wilson, 53, who joined the Lukens Steel Company as president and chief operating officer last May, has been appointed to the additional post of chief executive officer, effective after the annual meeting on April 15. He will succeed Charles A. Carlson Jr., 62, who will also retire as chairman of the steel plate producer at that time.

title: Seven Killed, Two Survive As Small Plane Strikes Hill
description: A commuter airplane attempting an instrument landing in fog yesterday struck a hill, killing seven persons, but two men were thrown out of the tail section and survived.

title: Stiffer Controls Backed In Gallup Poll on Pistols
description: A majority of Americans favor stricter control of pistols, according to a Gallup poll, but not a complete ban on their possession.

title: Doctors at Methodist Ratify 2-Year Pact
description: A strike of doctors at the Methodist Hospital of Brooklyn ended in its ninth day with unanimous ratification of an initial two-year contract. The 117 doctors composing the house staff of the 531-bed private, nonprofit hospital agreed to return this morning,

title: EUROPE TAKES STEPS TO LIFT ITYS EMBARGO
description: Members of the European Economic Community began lifting their trade sanctions against Iran today, while estimates indicated that despite the sanctions there had actually been an increase in trade between Europe and Iran during the hostage crisis.

title: Mobil Oil Canada To Cut '81 Outlay
description: Mobil Oil Canada Ltd., saying it expects the Canadian Government's new energy plan to cut its profits, announced a 46 percent reduction in its 1981 capital budget and indicated it may reconsider its oil and gas exploration program off Canada's Atlantic coast.

title: 5,000 Misled by Jobs Ad Snarl East Chicago Traffic
description: Five thousand people responded today to an advertisement by the Inland Steel Company seeking applicants for future jobs, creating a major traffic jam.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Company has appointed Robert E. Masterson president and chief operating officer of its First Data Resources Inc. subsidiary.

title: Technology; Raising Speed Of Computers
description: purpose computers have trouble keeping pace with the millions of calculations required for such tasks as analyzing geological structures or forecasting the weather. Machines speedy enough for those tasks, the so-called supercomputers, are also superexpensive.

title: HOSTAGE TO PARENTS: 'HELLO, IS THIS THE KRAKOW STORE?'
description: With almost his first breath as a free man, Sgt. Rodney V. Sickmann let his family know that he was coming home with his sense of humor intact.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JANUARY 22, 1981
description: The Hostages ''Acts of barbarism'' were carried out against the American hostages by their Iranian captors, a visibly shaken Jimmy Carter said after a 50-minute meeting with the freed Americans in Wiesbaden, West Germany. The former President gave no details, but a senior aide who accompanied him said that several of the Americans had been subjected to ''mock firing squads'' as well as to other physical and mental torture. (Page A1, Column 6.) Gross physical and mental abuses by their captors were reported by the freed Americans. They told their families of beatings, months in solitary confinement and constant fear of death. Some said they were not allowed to talk or read and were forbidden fresh air, exercise, outside news, mail and showers. (A1:5.)

title: Gordon Russell, TV Writer, Dies; 'One Life to Live' Among Credits
description: Gordon Russell, who wrote many popular daytime television dramas including the ABC-TV series ''One Life to Live,'' died of cancer Monday at St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived in New York City.

title: The Land Is Bright
description: The line originally ran ''no barriers born of discrimination.'' Going over a draft of the inaugural address with a writer, Ken Khachigian, Ronald Reagan said: ''There's been such an increase in anti-Semitism around the world -let's include the word 'bigotry.' '' As delivered, the phrase read ''no barriers born of bigotry or discrimination.''
