title: CHINA'S WARNINGS ON TAIWAN SAID TO REFLECT ANXIETY
description: Although China's recent warnings to the Reagan staff over Taiwan may appear in Washington to be bluster, some Chinese sources as well as diplomats here contend that there is as much hidden anxiety as public anger involved in Peking's propaganda.

title: U.S. Agency Buys Wisconsin Steel Co.
description: The Wisconsin Steel Company, a subsidiary of Envirodyne Industries Inc., has been purchased by the United States Economic Development Adminstration for $35 million.

title: GUY'S PUNTS A BIG WEAPON
description: The television screens hang over the floor of the Louisiana Superdome for the benefit of the customers who have a better view of the roof than the field. The screens dangled 90 feet above the floor yesterday. The plan is to have them 200 feet above the field Sunday. Ray Guy has seen to that.

title: 70 ARE TREATED AFTER EXPOSURE TO CAUSTIC GAS
description: A ruptured safety valve on a tank truck loaded with sulfur trioxide at the Allied Chemical Corporation plant released a caustic cloud this morning that dissipated as it drifted toward Staten Island. More than 70 people in Elizabeth were taken to hospitals for treatment of skin, eye and throat irritations.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Borg-Warner Corporation signed a letter of intent to exchange the assets of all of its automotive after-market divisions for about 22 percent of the Echlin Manufacturing Company's stock.

title: THE ROOMS WHERE WRITERS WRITE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michaele Weissman is a radio journalist and a freelance writer. She wrote one book in her bedroom and now has an office of her own. By MICHAELE WEISSMAN

title: CANADIAN EX-ENVOY TELLS HOW SIX FLED
description: The Canadian plan that allowed six American diplomats to escape the takeover of the American Embassy in Teheran was produced after six weeks of coded telex messages between Teheran, Ottawa and Washington.

title: BANKAMERICA, CHASE NET FLAT
description: The BankAmerica Corporation and the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the largest and third-largest bank holding companies in the United States, reported yesterday that there was virtually no change in their net operating earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980, compared with the similar 1979 period.

title: PAPER AND CLAY IN SCULPTURE SHOW
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Roslyn Siegel is a potter and editor of the New York State Craftsmen Bulletin. By ROSLYN SIEGEL

title: CELLS IN DISEASE STUDY SAID TO COME FROM MONKEYS
description: Three out of four strains of cultured cells thought to have originated in human patients suffering from Hodgkin's disease have proved to be derived from monkeys. The discovery endangers a prominent theory about the origin of the mysterious disease, a cancer of the lymphatic system.

title: Arthur Robert Burns Dies at 85; Economics Teacher at Columbia
description: Arthur Robert Burns, a professor of economics who taught at Columbia University for 36 years, died Tuesday at the Foulkeways Rest Home in Gwynedd, Pa.

title: SHOULD WASHINGTON SHARE REVENUE WITH STATES?
description: Congress spent much of its time last year debating whether the states should receive general revenue-sharing funds from the Federal Government, a seemingly mundane issue that in fact has become highly emotional.

title: A MUTT JUDGED THE BEST OF 5 OF TV'S 'AMAZING ANIMALS'
description: It was basically, of course, just a publicity stunt - ''Those Amazing Animals'' searching for the most talented pet in America.

title: Supporting Cast Named For 'The Little Foxes'
description: Zev Bufman, who will present Elizabeth Taylor as Regina Giddens in her Broadway debut in a revival of Lillian Hellman's ''The Little Foxes,'' has announced the supporting cast for the production. Contracts have been signed with Tom Aldredge for the role of Horace Giddens, Miss Taylor's husband, and with Maureen Stapleton for the part of Birdie Hubbard.

title: L.I.R.R. Rider Wins Reimbursement Suit
description: A Civil Court judge in Queens has ordered the Long Island Rail Road to reimburse a commuter $29.90 for trips he took last summer in trains without air-conditioning.

title: CONCERT: THE ORCHESTRA OF OUR TIME
description: IT is rather astonishing how much contemporary composition these days is based on Romantic premises, a definite reaction to the puremusic abstractions of a decade ago. This does not necessarily mean that the actual sounds hark back to a 19th-century esthetic - far from it in most cases - but that a great many works reflect intense poetic states, either specific or implied. Certainly this was true of the music played by the Orchestra of Our Time conducted by Joel Thome at the Abraham Goodman House on Tuesday night.

title: EXXON LIFTS ITS OUTLAYS
description: The Exxon Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to spend $11 billion this year on capital investment and exploration, a 35 percent increase over 1980. More than 90 percent would be spent in the energy sector.

title: MAN HELD IN DAUGHTER'S SLAYING
description: Steven Sconfienza, 26, of West Babylon- was also charged with sexually abusing the child. He pleaded not guilty to the charges and was ordered to undergo psychiatric tests. Mr. Sconfienza was identified as a pilot for Nassau Flyers Inc. at Republic Airport in Farmingdale.

title: Scorsese and De Niro To Do 'King of Comedy'
description: The next film on the schedule of the director-actor team of Martin Scorsese and Robert De Niro will be ''The King of Comedy,'' which is scheduled to begin shooting in New York about June 1. It will be produced by Robert Greenhut, who served as producer of several Woody Allen movies, and will be financed as an independent film by the Gurena Corporation, a Swiss company, for release later this year.

title: AMERICAN TO BUY 15 BOEING 757 PLANES
description: American Airlines Inc. said today that it planned to purchase 15 Boeing 757 aircraft at a cost of about $375 million.

title: Nuclear Advocates Urge Speedier Plant Licensing
description: Advocates of nuclear energy, warning of the possibility of blackouts in this decade and serious power shortages by the year 2000, urged the Government today to speed up the licensing of nuclear power plants.

title: Market Place; Analyst Favors Counter Issues
description: SAMUEL BRAUDE is a Wall Street analyst who hates to kiss an overthe-counter stock good-bye. As a research vice president at Moseley, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden, he closely follows 30 unlisted issues picked for their market potential.

title: QUIET CHRISTOPHER LEAVES OFFICE ON FLAMBOYANT NOTE
description: Warren M. Christopher left the State Department today on an uncharacteristically flamboyant note. His face flushed, his eyes glistening and waving to welcomers, the normally low-keyed diplomat stepped through a crowd of State Department colleagues praising the ''resilience'' and ''courage'' of the former American hostages.

title: No Headline
description: For residents of the city to reduce their daily water consumption to the level desired under the drought emergency declared Monday by Mayor Koch, the awareness of how much water is used in normal household activities is an important factor. The drought measures are also in effect in Westchester County.

title: INDIANA STUDENTS TO DISPLAY TALENTS IN NEW YORK
description: THE campus of the Indiana University School of Music should be uncharacteristically quiet between April 25 and May 3, for during that week virtually the entire student body will be making music in New York City. An ambitious five-part showcase has been planned for the school's visit, featuring the Opera Theater's American premiere production of Bohuslav Martinu's ''The Greek Passion'' at the Metropolitan Opera House on April 26.

title: Trucks Damaged in Puerto Rico
description: A group calling itself the AntiNavy Commandos said it had burned a truck owned by a retired United States Navy officer and damaging a Navy jeep on the small island of Vieques. The police confirmed the attacks on the vehicles.

title: 2 GREEK PUBLISHERS PERSEVERE IN MUCKRAKING
description: A muckraking Greek newspaper that began publication last March has found its co-publishers sentenced to prison terms for libel and is facing 16 other libel suits.

title: GUNMEN KILL PROMINENMT PROTESTANT AND DEMOLISH HIS CASTLE IN ULSTER
description: Terrorists using explosives blasted their way today into the castle of Sir Norman Stronge, a Protestant leader who was speaker of Northern Ireland's parliament for 24 years, shooting Sir Norman and his son to death.

title: Union Pacific Plans Capital Investment
description: The Union Pacific Corporation announced plans for a 1981 capital investment program totaling $1.2 billion, including about $1 billion for the development of natural resources and energy properties.

title: DEALING WITH CHINA
description: Ronald Reagan's campaign rhetoric damaged our relations with Peking to the extent that the leading Chinese architect of normalization, Deng Xiaoping, has been talking openly about a ''crisis.'' Unwise policy choices early in the new Administration could completely upset United States-China rapprochement, setting back our most important strategic initiative of the last decade and raising questions about our consistency among friend and foe alike.

title: SPECIAL REASONS LISTED BY MANY AIDING NEEDIEST
description: Among the contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund who give to help the troubled and destitute are some who support victims of misfortune for whom they have a special concern.

title: POLISH UNION CALLS STRIKES AFTER TALKS FAIL
description: Leaders of Poland's independent labor union tonight announced a series of strikes for tomorrow after six hours of talks with the Government failed to make progress on the union's demand for an immediate five-day workweek or other issues.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN BAN STILLS THE 'VOICE OF BLACK PEOPLE'
description: The headlines and the handbills stuck on lampposts by newspaper vendors this morning cried out ''outrage'' and ''fury'' over the banning of the largest-circulation black newspaper in South Africa, but they were not describing the reactions of the black journalists who were silenced by the closure.

title: NEW LEGISLATION TO SPEED JUSTICE SOUGHT BY KOCH
description: Mayor Koch yesterday announced major new legislative proposals to speed the criminal-trial process in New York City and the state. The recommendations, which the Mayor said were primarily designed to insure ''swift and tough'' punishment after conviction, include changes in sentencing to limit judicial discretion and procedural changes to ease the congestion on court calendars. Most of the proposals would require approval by the Legislature.

title: LONG JOB STOPPAGE ENDS AT U.S. PRISON
description: One of the longest work stoppages by inmates in the history of the Federal prison system is over with the transfer of the prison's printing plant and probable closing of its metal furniture factory, the warden of the Marion Federal Prison has reported.

title: Delta's Profits Rise 111.8% in Quarter
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. said yesterday that its after-tax profits in the last three months on 1980 rose 111.8 percent, partly because of higher fares.

title: Ted Cowell Dog Rescued From Icy River
description: Wet, cold and frightened, a stray dog scrambled to stay atop a bobbing ice floe yesterday after falling into the Hudson River off Morton Street in Greenwich Village. Before drifting very far, he was spotted by officers in a police launch who lifted him to firmer footing and brought him back to dry land.

title: RUTH CONSTANTINO, ART GALLERY HEAD
description: Mrs. Ruth T. Costantino, president of Connoisseur Inc., an art gallery at 717 Madison Avenue, and one of the first women to be a dealer in fine arts in America, died Sunday. She was 88 years old.

title: A 90-TON SCULPTURE OVER A CANYON? THEY'LL SOON CALL IT HOME
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Peter Applebome is a writer who lives in Dallas. By PETER APPLEBOME LAKE RANSOM CANYON, Tex. THE idea for a house over the canyon came to the sculptor Robert Bruno one day as he stood beneath one of his works, a 16-foot-tall, 21,000-pound steel sculpture that resembled a prehistoric beast lumbering toward the nearest messy bog.

title: Son of Theft Figure Is Seized in Queens
description: The 21-year-old son of James Burke, whom the Federal officials suspect of being a key figure in the $5.8 million Lufthansa robbery in 1978, was arrested on charges of trying to kill two detectives who had forced his car to a stop, authorities reported.

title: BOSSY COOL AS PRESSURE INTENSIFIES
description: If Mike Bossy of the Islanders were another sort of person, he might be trying to break a stick over someone's head rather than break Maurice (Rocket) Richard's record of 50 goals in 50 games.

title: 4 Guerrillas in Gaza Strip Get Life for Grenade Attacks
description: Four Palestinian guerrillas convicted of committing acts of terrorism resulting in the deaths of two Israelis and the wounding of others were sentenced today to life imprisonment by a military court in Gaza.

title: Chrysler Union Voting on Cuts
description: Members of the United Automobile Workers union began voting today on $622 million in proposed pay cuts and other reduced benefits that make up part of a rescue plan for the Chrysler Corporation.

title: 18 Indicted in Kidnapping Tied to Synanon Members
description: Eighteen members and former members of the Synanon Foundation were indicted today in the kidnapping and imprisonment of a former member.

title: KENNEDYS SAY THEY ARE DIVORCING AFTER 22 YEARS
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy and his wife, Joan, announced today that they would seek a divorce after 22 years of marriage.

title: Gov. Byrne Issues Proclamation
description: Governor Byrne today marked the hostages' release with a ''proclamation of thanksgiving'' that hinted at the anger other New Jerseyans expressed. ''I ask all of the citizens of New Jersey to join in prayers of thanks,'' the statement read. ''We should couple those prayers with a resolve that the United States never again be in a position where we have to negotiate with criminals.''

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE TIME FALLING BODIES TAKE TO LIGHT. Mythology, Sexuality, and the Origins of Culture. By William Irwin Thompson. 280 pages. A Lindisfarne Series Book. St. Martin's. $14.95.

title: Instruction Chief Named for Schools
description: Thomas K. Minter, assistant secretary for elementary and secondary education in the United States Department of Education, was named deputy chancellor for instruction of the New York City public schools.

title: DIRECTION OF BULLET A KEY ISSUE IN JEAN HARRIS MURDER TRIAL
description: A pathologist testifying for the defense in the Jean S. Harris murder trial said today that the ''irregular'' shaped bullet wound in Dr. Herman Tarnower's chest could have been caused by the bullet's ''changing direction'' as it hit a collarbone.

title: SGT. SICKMANN, IN HIS FIRST CALL HOME, YEARNS FOR MISSOURI'S GOLF AND
description: The following are excerpts from a transcript of the first phone call by Sgt. Rodney V. Sickmann to his family, received at 1:30 A.M. today, Central Standard Time.

title: Marathon Oil Find In Gulf of Mexico
description: A group of companies led by the Marathon Oil Company reported a ''significant'' oil discovery in the Gulf of Mexico, about 95 miles southeast of New Orleans.

title: Trans Union Ends G.E. Merger Talks
description: The Trans Union Corporation said it had terminated discussions with the General Electric Company for a possible merger. The company, which is engaged in tank and rail car leasing, vessel chartering and waste treatment, did not give any reason for the action.

title: FOR 52, HAIRCUTS AND CALLS HOME
description: A visibly shaken Jimmy Carter said after an emotional meeting with the freed hostages last night that they had been subjected to ''acts of barbarism that can never be condoned.''

title: 'Warning Shot' Reported In Texas Speaker's Death
description: Vickie Daniel, wife of Price Daniel Jr., former Speaker of the Texas House, told her attorney that she fired one ''warning shot'' as her husband came toward her before she fired the fatal shot, Sheriff C.L. Eckols of Liberty County said today.

title: Two-Year Notes Yield 13.69%; Fed Drains Money Supply
description: The Treasury sold $4.5 billion of new two-year notes at auction yesterday at an average yield of 13.69 percent, down from the record average last month of 15.15 percent.

title: Former Greyhound Executive Named to Two Posts at Webb
description: Robert K. Swanson, 48, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Del E. Webb Corporation, a leisure, real estate and construction company. He succeeds Robert H. Johnson, 64, who remains chairman and chief executive officer of the Phoenix-based corporation.

title: SWISS MAY NOW SEEK IRAN TRADE
description: The Swiss Government announced today that with the freeing of the hostages it had advised Swiss businesses that they need no longer restrain their trade with Iran.

title: Dane Named to European Post
description: The European Common Market Commission tonight appointed Poul Dalsager of Denmark as its new agriculture commissioner, succeeding Finn Olav Gundelach, also a Dane, who died last week, commission officials reported. Mr. Dalsager was Denmark's Minister of Agriculture until this week.

title: People
description: * Lawrence J. Lesser, president and chief executive of Medicus Intercon International Inc., has been appointed to the board of its parent company, Benton & Bowles Inc.

title: Third Editor Is Detained in Turkey Over Article on Price - Rise Plans
description: The authorities have detained a third member of the staff of the mass-circulation newspaper Hurriyet, a spokesman for the paper said today.

title: SOVIET DISPELS HOPE IT WILL END WHALING
description: On Jan. 13, the Soviet press agency Tass carried an article reporting that the Soviet fleets in the Far East had abandoned whaling.

title: From Rage to Reason on Iran
description: The blood will boil as the returned hostages tell of beatings, robbery, isolation and other barbarities. Their tales will reinforce an obvious yearning for revenge. Let there be rage and revulsion in these first hours of release - and a realization that though it was right to promise kidnappers anything, there is no moral duty to honor such extortion. But when the time comes for action, let it be from cold calculation. The right question, as it has been for 14 months, is not what we owe the Iranians but what we owe ourselves.

title: THE LOYALTY OF AUTHORS TO PUBLISHERS HAS NEW NAME: IT'S SPELLED
description: O-N-E-Y By EDWIN McDOWELL

title: LEFEBVRE SIGNS WITH YANKEES
description: The Yankees reached contract terms yesterday with two young players, signing Joe Lefebvre for two years and Mike Morgan for one.

title: Prime Computer's Profit Climbs 96%
description: Prime Computer Inc., a fast-growing manufacturer of minicomputers, reported a 96 percent profit gain for the three months ended Dec. 31. After-tax earnings in the fourth quarter jumped to $10 million, or 33 cents a share, from $5.1 million, or 19 cents a share, a year before.

title: Maytag and Lever In Joint Refund Offer
description: The Maytag people (they make dishwashers) and the Lever folks (Dishwasher All is among their products) have entered into a joint promotion with a price tag of more than $1 million.

title: THE MILITARY AS A LIFE-BUILDING SERVICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Trade Surplus
description: Japan posted a current-account surplus of $1.18 billion in December, the first surplus in that broad measure of Japan's exports of goods and services since September, the Finance Ministry announced today.

title: Key Rates
description: Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: IN CANADIAN NORTH, ASSIMILATION BEFALLS THE DOGRIBS
description: On the surface, the midwinter gathering of the Dogrib Indian tribe looked the same as it has for uncounted generations. There was the fur trading, the visiting relatives, the weddings at the Roman Catholic mission, the dancing to drums and the feasting on boiled caribou and chunks of lard.

title: AFGHANS SAID TO GET BETTER GUNS AFTER TRIP TO EGYPT
description: Western diplomats said today that reports about recent guerrilla attacks against Soviet forces in Afghanistan contained information indicating that rebel groups were receiving new types of weapons.

title: HOW TO BUY AND USE PORTABLE HEATERS
description: PORTABLE electric heaters consume a lot of electricity, but they put out a lot of heat and this may interest tenants in poorly heated apartments as well as thrifty homeowners who want to save on central heating. Task heating, as it is called, produces the heat where you need it and when you need it. In addition, the new quartz models are radiant heaters and work like a fire in a fireplace: warming people directly without wasting energy heating the air.

title: ISLAMIC VIEWS ON INDUSTRY
description: The charging of interest has had a mixed history in the Islamic world. In modern times accepting and paying interest on bank deposits has become commonplace among many banks and in many Islamic countries. The Koran, however, condemms the practice of what it calls riba, which is generally interpreted to mean usury or the charging of excessive interest, although the exact meaning of the word has been debated by scholars.

title: HERS
description: ''THIS is a pretty peculiar party,'' murmured the man on my right. I looked around at the six couples at the table and turned back in puzzlement: ''Peculiar?'' ''Yes,'' he said, ''we're a rare gathering, because we're all in our first marriage, and most of us have been married for a very long time. Fifteen years minimum, wouldn't you say?''

title: Hard Times in Hollywood
description: He's the World Boxing Council welterweight champion two times over, but, says Sugar Ray Leonard, he would have never become a professional boxer if he hadn't been rejected by Hollywood in 1976.

title: Iron Ore Use Drops in Month
description: Iron ore deliveries to United States iron and steel plants dropped 15.3 percent in November 1980 from the same month a year earlier, the American Iron Ore Association reported today.

title: 3 Held in Inauguration Protest
description: Three persons were arrested yesterday at a downtown rally protesting President Reagan's inauguration, according to the police. A man from the Presbyterian Task Force for Peace, another from Citizens Against Nuclear Power and a woman from the Coalition Against Military Escalation were taken into custody after allegedly clashing with the police in Daley Plaza, the authorities said.

title: Strikes Curtail Zambian Copper; Some Workers Agree to Go Back
description: Unofficial strikes curtailed production today at three more Zambian copper mining divisions but some workers who stayed away from work yesterday returned to their jobs, industry sources said.

title: Roosevelt and Union Push Talks
description: Progress toward a settlement of a strike by parimutuel clerks was reported today, but Roosevelt Raceway conducted the third night of its harness racing meet for offtrack bettors only.

title: Appeals Court Lifts TV Stay
description: A Federal appeals court in St. Louis has lifted a stay imposed last Friday that temporarily prevented the Federal Communications Commission from extending a Jan. 16 deadline for applications for low-power television stations, F.C.C. officials said.

title: MAYOR DALEY'S SON GIVES CONSENT TO CURB PATRONAGE IN COUNTY POST
description: Richard M. Daley, the State's Attorney of Cook County, whose father's Democratic machine thrived on patronage, has agreed to refrain from political hirings for all but a small percentage of his staff in the new office that he won Nov. 4.

title: 2 Are Found Dead In Cold Apartments
description: Two women were found dead in unheated apartments in the Bronx and Brooklyn, the police and the City Department of Housing Preservation and Development reported yesterday.

title: G.N.P. UP AT 5% RATE IN QUARTER
description: The Commerce Department reported today that the nation's economy grew at a 5 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter. The report demonstrated once again that the economy was stronger than economists had expected.

title: Giovanni Battista Meneghini, 85; Former Husband of Maria Callas
description: Giovanni Battista Meneghini, former husband of Maria Callas, the operatic soprano, died here last night at the age of 85, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: MUSIC: PIANIST AGUSTIN ANIEVAS
description: THERE is something seductive about great technical abilities at the piano, not only for the listener but for the player as well. Hearing Agustin Anievas play in Carnegie Hall on Monday night -nearly 20 years after winning the first International Dimitri Mitropoulos Music Competition - one was more aware of the latter seduction and barely affected by the former.

title: 100-Foot Yellow Ribbon Placed Around a Statue in Philadelphia
description: Philadelphia honored the newly released hostages today by placing what is believed to be one of the world's largest yellow ribbons on the city's highest structure, the City Hall tower.

title: TICKET HOLDERS FOR PARTIES ANGRY
description: Hundreds of people with $100 tickets who were locked out of last night's overcrowded inaugural balls were still seething with anger today as they packed up their gowns and tuxedos and prepared to go home.

title: Sylvia Sydney Learns Isaac Stern Isn't Forbidding at All
description: The famous can also have heroes of whom they stand in awe, and Sylvia Sidney is a good example.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''One very serious fact is becoming evident. And that is that our Americans in Iran were mistreated much worse than has been previously revealed.

title: 'Dangerous Precedent' Seen
description: The United States Ambassador to Algeria, Ulric St. Clair Haynes Jr., said here tonight that the agreement with Iran was ''a dangerous precedent'' but stressed that it was ''worthwhile'' because the 52 American hostages had been freed.

title: NEWLIN GETS 35 AND HELPS NETS BEAT SONICS IN OVERTIME, 126-122
description: Of the few things that the New Jersey Nets can be sure of this season is that when Mike Newlin scores 30 points or more, they have a good chance of winning.

title: WATER PLANNING ASSAILED IN GREENWICH
description: A study group here charged today that a major cause of the water shortage in Greenwich and two Westchester County, N.Y., communities has been the failure of the ConnecticutAmerican Water Company to increase storage capacity.

title: Tribute to 8 Killed in Iran
description: The state House of Representatives observed a moment of silence this afternoon for the eight American servicemen killed in the aborted mission to rescue the hostages in Iran on April 24, 1980. Gov. William O'Neill's office also announced that the Governor would lead a ''hostage freedom day'' celebration Friday at 12:15 P.M. at the Old State House.

title: STAGE: ICE CAPADES AT THE GARDEN
description: JUST did two and a half pirouettes, one in the air, on a patch of curbside ice last night, rushing back from the Ice Capades opening at Madison Square Garden, where they do that sort of thing intentionally and worlds more gracefully.

title: Rene-Emile Godfroy, 96, Is Dead; A French Admiral in World War II
description: Adm. Rene-Emile Godfroy, who commanded the French fleet at Alexandria, Egypt, during the first part of World War II, died at Frejus, southern France, the French Navy announced today. He was 96 years old.

title: ENVOY DISPUTES U.S. ON SALVADOR DEATHS
description: Robert E. White, the United States Ambassador to El Salvador, said today that the Salvadoran Government had failed to conduct ''a serious investigation'' into the killing of four American missionaries last month.

title: REAGAN MOVES FAST TO SWEAR IN STAFF AND DROP HOLDOVERS Jr.
description: President Reagan, spending his first full day in office, held a swearing-in session today for his White House staff, sought the dismissal of hundreds of Carter Administration holdovers and exhorted his Cabinet to help him cut the Federal budget.

title: Goodbye and Hello
description: When it was announced that S. Michael Nadel would leave his job as New York City's Personnel Director to become deputy administrator of the state court system, some of his friends in city government were distressed since Mr. Nadel has been a mainstay of after-hours conviviality around City Hall.

title: NEW RULES FOR HUMAN RESEARCH APPEAR TO ANSWER CRITICS' FEAR
description: New rules to protect human beings who are the subjects of scientific research have been made final by the Federal Government, and they appear generally to satisfy the complaints of social scientists and historians who had expressed fears that the regulations would unfairly hamper their work.

title: Stocks Drop Again on Rate Concerns
description: The stock market ended broadly lower yesterday in moderate trading, as Wall Street's apprehension over high interest rates continued to depress prices.

title: A NEW OPULENCE TRIUMPHS IN CAPITAL
description: For the past year, fashion designers in New York and California have been saying that business, despite the recession, has been booming. Last night at the Kennedy Center Inaugural Ball, it was easy to see what they meant. All the fruits of their labor, it seemed, were being worn by women there, not only in celebration of the Republican victory but also in emulation of a kind of woman who, for them, represents a new ideal.

title: INSURING MEDICAL AID IF PARENTS ARE ABSENT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Suzanne Ramos is a freelance writer specializing in legal problems. By SUZANNE RAMOS

title: U.S. PLANNING TO PROVIDE WIDE RANGE OF BENEFITS
description: The State Department today issued formal regulations providing educational and medical benefits and other forms of relief to the former hostages in Iran and their families.

title: WINTER LIGHT CHANGES OUR PERCEPTION OF ARCHITECTURE
description: THERE is something about the nature of sunlight in the winter that changes everything. It is intense, crisp and hard, and it offers no tricks, it has no illusions. It affects our moods, and it also affects the way we perceive architecture.

title: RCA POSTS 12.8% RISE IN QUARTER, 11% IN YEAR
description: The RCA Corporation reported yesterday that its net income rose 12.8 percent in the fourth quarter of 1980 and 11.1 percent for the entire year , although earnings per share fell 10.9 percent for the quarter and 9.9 percent for the year.

title: MURDERER OF TRANSIT OFFICER GIVEN 15-YEAR PRISON TERM
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan yesterday criticized ''cosmetic'' reforms of the criminal-justice system and the premature release of mentally ill people as he sentenced a man who had admitted killing a transit police officer.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS U.S. ON STOCK FRAUD ISSUE
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a fraudulent pledge of stock as collateral for a loan violates the Securities Act of 1933.

title: Parks Employee Accused of Larceny
description: A Parks Department employee was charged with stealing and cashing $13,000 in teacher's pension checks. The employee, Leonard Moore, 27 years old, of Manhattan, was charged with grand larceny, forgery and possession of stolen property. He faces a maximum of seven years in prison.

title: A TOY CHEST KEEPS THINGS NEAT, AND IT IT EASY TO BUILD
description: ANY home that has youngsters in it more than likely also has an increasingly large number of stuffed animals, games and other toys, especially now that new ones have been added during the holidays. As a result, getting the youngsters to keep these out from underfoot is probably more of a problem.

title: THE MILITARY AS A LIFE-BUILDING SERVICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Lower Imported-Car Share
description: Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. said today that its market studies indicated the import share of the new-car market in the United States would decline to 23 percent in 1981 from 26.7 percent last year. Toyota said it believed that the import share peaked in 1980 and that future demand in the United States for fuel-efficient vehicles would be increasingly met by domestic manufacturers, whose volume and selection are rapidly expanding.

title: ALYSSA KEOUGH JETS TO GERMANY BUT IS THWARTED
description: Allyssa Keough journeyed 4,000 miles to see her father, William Keough Jr., and successfully talked her way into the United States Air Force Hospital here, where Mr. Keough and 51 other former hostages are staying.

title: 3 IN BUSING DISPUTE JOIN PRIVATE SCHOOL
description: Three white girls fighting a Federal judge's desegregation order have enrolled in a private academy, but it is uncertain whether they will receive credit for their stay at an all-white high school, a teacher at the private school said today.

title: HELMSLEY PROPOSAL FOR OFFICE TOWER ON EAST RIVER PLAYGROUND OPPOSED
description: A wide range of opposition was expressed yesterday against a proposal by the real-estate interests of Harry B. Helmsley to build a 50-story apartment-and-office tower on a city playground just south of the United Nations on the East River.

title: TOBACCO AND LUNACY
description: To the Editor:

title: Scotch Exports Down 5%
description: The worldwide recession caused a 5 percent drop in Scotch whisky exports last year, the Scotch Whisky Association said today, adding that falling demand threatens hundreds of jobs in one of Scotland's most important industries.

title: SHOULD THE I.R.S. CALL THE TUNE?
description: A landslide, if not an avalanche, of proposed rulemaking by Federal agencies usually takes place when one Congress ends and a new one begins. When this event coincides with a change in Administration, the mad dash of the regulators can be heard throughout the bureaucratic land.

title: U.S.O. in Times Square
description: Since World War II, the U.S.O. has maintained its busiest and most famous facility in the heart of New York, just off Times Square.

title: The High Price of Hating Agee
description: President Carter finally dropped his foolish idea of prosecuting Ramsey Clark and others for violating his order against traveling to Iran. But the Carter State Department left a time bomb ticking at the Supreme Court that could endanger the rights of Americans to travel anywhere.

title: THE MILITARY AS A LIFE-BUILDING SERVICE
description: To the Editor:

title: HAIG IS CONFIRMED BY SENATE, 93 TO 6
description: By a vote of 93 to 6, Alexander M. Haig Jr. won confirmation from the Senate today as Secretary of State. But on President Reagan's first full day in office, political skirmishing between Capitol Hill and the White House was already echoing through Washington.

title: Watkins Glen Is Dropped From Grand Prix Schedule
description: The end of Grand Prix auto racing at Watkins Glen, N.Y., was threatened yesterday when the upstate village was omitted from the tentative world schedule announced by a commission of Formula One manufacturers in Modena, Italy.

title: 103 Dead in Philippine Floods
description: Floods caused by nearly a month of heavy rains have left 103 people dead and seven missing in the southern Philippines.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF CARTER'S REMARKS IN WEST GERMANY AFTER TALKING TO
description: AMERICANS Following is a transcript of remarks by former President Jimmy Carter at Rhein-Main Air Base near Frankfurt, West Germany, yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: DANCE: CLEVELAND BALLET'S 'CELEBRATIONS' AND 'US' photo of Cleveland Ballet
description: CURIOUSLY, the saloon number is apparently an obligatory ballet for visiting companies in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's ''Ballet America'' series, and ''US,'' the newest version, popped up Wednesday night on the Cleveland Ballet's second program.

title: AN ANTI-SUPER BOWL PARTY
description: For years, Super Bowl Sunday had seemed like ''macho Sunday'' to Eleanor Dienstag, and finally she decided to do something about it. This Sunday she is throwing what she calls ''A Women's Party: An Alternative to the Super Bowl'' for 40 of her friends.

title: Toyota, Nissan In Taiwan Talk
description: The Toyota Motor Company and the Nissan Motor Company, Japan's two largest automobile manufacturers, said today that they were negotiating with Taiwan on joint production of small passenger cars.

title: 2 WOMEN CHARGE POLICE DEPT. BIAS
description: Two women who served on New York City's police force sued the Police Department yesterday on charges that its medical practices ''endanger the health and lives of women police officers who receive line-of-duty injuries.''

title: Red Cross Committee Rules Out Inquiry Into Captives' Treatment
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that it would receive any formal United States protest about Iranian mistreatment of the American hostages but would be unable to conduct an investigation.

title: No Headline
description: Dick Van Dyke packs along his family photographs, his collection of well-read Graham Greene paperbacks, his tape deck with his cassettes of Johann Sebastian Bach and his computerized chess set.

title: CLAIMANTS AGAINST IRAN BID REAGAN HOLD UP ACCORD
description: A group of a hundred companies that have tied up more than $1 billion in Iranian assets in lawsuits in Federal courts in New York urged President Reagan today to delay enforcing President Carter's executive orders under the hostage agreement, ''including those compelling turnover of Iranian assets.'' They cited ''serious constitutional and other legal questions.''

title: SON TESTIFIES OF DISCOVERING MEDICATION AT MRS. HARRIS'S
description: Jean S. Harris's two sons, James and David, testified in their mother's behalf today in Westchester County Court. They recounted pleasant times with Dr. Herman Tarnower, whom she is accused of murdering, and described the discovery of a ''medication'' she was evidently using at the time.

title: Slayer Refuses to Testify At Libel Trial in Phoenix
description: John Harvey Adamson, a convicted murderer, has repeatedly invoked the Fifth Amendment at a libel trial against a group that investigated the murder of Don Bolles, a reporter.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard ALL FALL DOWN. One Man Against the Waterfront Mob. By Donald Goddard. 312 pages. Times Books. $12.95.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER'S NET UP SHARPLY
description: The International Paper Company, the world's largest paper company, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter more than doubled on an increase in sales of 8.3 percent.

title: D'Amato Drinks Champagne, but Isn't Celebrating
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the conservative Republican from Long Island, yesterday lifted a plastic glass of New York State champagne to toast Marion S. Barry Jr., the activist-turned-Mayor of Washington.

title: SPORTING GEAR
description: Mooring System for Boats The Moor King is a flexible system for boats that works on a push-pull principle through the use of mooring arms. It is constructed in such a manner that there is little or no noise created by the constant motion of the water, and there is no mechanical slack to create the type of noises that are generated if metal fittings are coupled together. The Moor King, which can be used for fresh or salt water, is made of stainless steel. Nylon bushings eliminate the need to use grease. The standard set of two arms can take boats up to 7,000 pounds; the heavy set can take up to a 45-ton cruiser. The standard set costs $500, the heavy set $800, shipping charges not included. The Moor King is available in many marine outlets. For Road, Rochester, N.Y. 14610, telephone (716) 482-7700.

title: MATUSZAK'S COSTLY NIGHT OUT
description: The Oakland Raiders are fining the defensive lineman John Matuszak $1,000 because he visited bars in the French Quarter early this morning, after the Raiders' curfew.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Federal Home Loan Bank has elected to its board James M. Cirona, president and chief executive officer of the First Federal Savings and Loan Association, Rochester, and Robert T. Holland, president of the Columbia Savings and Loan Association, Fair Lawn, N.J.

title: Texaco Reports Oil From 2 Gulf Wells
description: Texaco Inc. announced successful tests on two new oil wells drilled in an area of the Gulf of Mexico. A Vermillion Block 380 well, 130 miles southwest of Morgan City, La., was said to have struck a new reservoir in the Pleistocene geologic formation and tested at a rate of more than 800 barrels of oil a day.

title: FOOTBALL 'DOLLS' AND CALIFORNIA DREAMS
description: THIS is Super Bowl Sunday, and the 15th annual production of this football event will be seen in the flesh by nearly 77,000 fans in the New Orleans Superdome and, if past figures hold, by more than 100 million television viewers. This time, beginning at 6 P.M. on NBC-TV, the Oakland Raiders will face the Philadelphia Eagles. The last and only other Super Bowl to be played indoors - also in New Orleans, between the Dallas Cowboys and the Denver Broncos in 1978 - was the sloppiest in the event's history. If nothing else, the finer points of turf, indoor artificial versus outdoor real, should get an impassioned airing.

title: BAHAMAS, ONCE A HAVEN, IS LAND OF FEAR FOR HAITIANS
description: With the expiration yesterday of a deadline for leaving the country, most of the 25,000 illegal Haitian residents in the Bahamas are now subject to arrest and deportation.

title: MUSIC: BRAHMS CONCERTO PLAYED BY PETER SERKIN
description: IN the standard repertory, there probably is no more heroically difficult a piano concerto than the Brahms Second, unless it is the Brahms First. Either work can try the technical and temperamental resources of even the greatest pianists, while the less-than-great generally steer away from Brahms altogether. Peter Serkin, certainly one of our superior artists, faced up to the Brahms Second Concerto last night and came away from the tussle with honor, if not blinding glory. Mr. Serkin played the mighty B-flat with the New York Philharmonic under the baton of John Nelson, who was making his Philharmonic debut as a substitute for James Levine. Mr. Levine had to cancel his concerts owing to heavy duties across the Lincoln Center plaza at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Border Patrol Aide Hails U.S. Supreme Court Ruling
description: An official of the Border Patrol has said that a ruling by the United States Supreme Court could effectively restore the patrol's authority to stop vehicles in border areas and search for illegal aliens.

title: KENNECOTT ACQUIRES MORE CURTISS STOCK
description: The Kennecott Corporation, engaged in a bitter struggle to acquire the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, announced yesterday that it had purchased an additional 498,100 shares of common stock in the aerospace and industrial manufacturer.

title: PRICE RISE FOLLOWS JOBS REPORT
description: Interest rates were little changed in light volume yesterday. In a day of quiet trading, prices were lower most of the day but rose sharply in the last hour. Early in the day one dealer commented that, ''in the absence of buyers, some traders got tired of waiting'' and marked down prices.

title: MANHATTAN APARTMENT BUILDER IS DOING CONVERSIONS, TOO
description: The general rule is that producers of Manhattan apartment houses are either in the new construction business or the conversion business but not both.

title: U.S.-CANADA CLASH PUTS SQUEEZE ON CHRYSLER AID
description: The Chrysler Corporation and its Chrysler Canada Ltd. subsidiary are caught between conflicting demands from American and Canadian authorities in the fight to stave off corporate bankruptcy.

title: ''Facade'' on 90th St.
description: ''Facade,'' a multimedia staging of poems by Edith Sitwell set to music composed by William Walton in the 1920's, will be performed through next weekend by the York Players Company at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th Street.

title: WHAT CAUSED DROUGHT IN NEW YORK CITY AND HOW TO COPE WITH IT
description: To forestall the possibility that New York City might run out of water, Mayor Koch declared a drought emergency this week - the first since 1965, when the city was declared a Federal disaster area. Following are some questions and answers about how the city got into the emergency and what is needed to get out of it:

title: Which Yardstick for the Philippines?
description: The lifting of martial law in the Philippines can be welcomed for what it is: a symbolic offering to Ronald Reagan and Pope John Paul II. Symbols matter, and President Ferdinand Marcos could do worse than end eight years of martial law and at the same time release 341 prisoners, half of them charged with political crimes. But he retains all his emergency powers; he can restore martial law at any time. That is the hard substance beneath the welcome symbol.

title: ABORTION FOES MEET WITH REAGAN AFTER MARCH IN CAPITAL
description: Thousands of foes of abortion marched from the White House to the Capitol today to demand a constitutional amendment to protect the life of the unborn.

title: MINE WORKERS BEGIN DISCUISSIONS ON NEW PACT WITH COAL PRODUCERS
description: Leaders of a resurgent coal industry and the weakened United Mine Workers opened negotiations for a new contract today, with a settlement deadline of mid-March.

title: WHAT'S THE USE OF OUR TALKING WITH NORTH KOREA?
description: To the Editor:

title: America The Greatest
description: President Reagan may be the best Fourth of July orator to reach the White House since William Jennings Bryan was invited to dinner. What's more, in this television age, he surely knows how to reach more millions, more effectively, than any other golden-throated American in history. That's good, to a point.

title: MISS KEOUGH GETS TO TALK TO HER FATHER
description: ''Hi, baby,'' said William Keough Jr. to his 19-year-old daughter, Allyssa. ''Hi, daddy,'' Allyssa replied, and they hugged and cried. Thus did Miss Keough describe her meeting, after a 29 1/2-hour wait here, with her father, one of the 52 former hostages. Miss Keough, who has been besieged for the last 14 months by reporters asking questions, refused to disclose in much detail what she and her father had talked about for an hour. Her father asked her not to, she said.

title: People
description: * Connie Kiernan has been named director, advertising and promotion for the Mutual Broadcasting System, Washington.

title: LATHROP DOUGLASS, URBAN PLANNER
description: Lathrop Douglass, an architect and urban planner who was a pioneer in the design of shopping centers in the United States and Europe, died Wednesday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: BAKER MAKES EFFORT TO CALM COLLEAGUES ON IRANIAN DEAL
description: Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, the Senate Republican leader, urged his colleagues today to ''let the wound heal'' before making decisions concerning Iran, but others in Congress urged immediate renunciation of the agreement that freed the 52 American hostages.

title: Report Says Stella Walsh; Had Male Sex Organs
description: Stella Walsh, who won a gold medal and several silver medals in track competing as a woman in the 1932 and 1936 Olympics, had male sex organs, according to an autopsy report released today. The report also said that Miss Walsh had no female sex organs.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error, the short-interest table in Business Day yesterday incorrectly stated the position of the International Business Machines Corporation. The correct figure is 557,558 shares.

title: Bulls 125, Pistons 92
description: Dwight Jones had 20 points and Bobby Wilkerson and James Wilkes added 18 each to lead a well-balanced Chicago scoring attack over Detroit.

title: Libya Says Its Force in Chad Could Resist French Move
description: Libya's Foreign Minister said today that his country had enough troops in Chad to fight off any French military intervention.

title: Festival of one-acters reopens Newhouse Theater in March.
description: THE Vivian Beaumont Theater is open again at Lincoln Center, almost. There still remains the matter of the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, the 299-seat experimental space downstairs at the Beaumont. The Newhouse will have its own grand reopening on March 4 with a festival of new one-act plays organized by Edward Albee, the playwright who is part of the Beaumont's six-member directorate. The first program is scheduled to run six weeks and consists of three new one-act plays - ''Vivien'' by Percy Granger, ''In Fireworks Lie Secret Codes'' by John Guare and ''Stops Along the Way'' by Jeffrey Sweet. Mr. Guare will direct his own play. Kevin Conway will direct the other two.

title: Text of statement, page A13.
description: Rupert Murdoch, the publisher of The New York Post and other newspapers around the world, has completed a conditional agreement to buy The Times of London and its affiliated publications.

title: DAVID GRAHAM AND NELSON SHARE STROKE LEAD ON 65'S
description: David Graham shot a six-under-par 65 today in his first competitive round of the year and tied Larry Nelson for lead in the $300,000 Phoenix open.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: . MCI Receives Credit For Planned Outlays

title: Economic Scene; G.O.P. Rifts On Tax Policy
description: IN the crucial area of fiscal policy, President Reagan's economic advisers have hit the ground fighting among themselves. Arthur F. Burns, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has told the Senate Budget Committee that, if he were economic czar, he would not cut personal income taxes at all at this time.

title: REAGAN ADMINISTRATION PRESSING FOR FAST START ON 4-YEAR COURSE
description: At the Commerce Department, the senior spokesman who gave the Reagan Administration's first economic report was Courtenay M. Slater, a liberal Democrat. At the Council of Economic Advisers, the person in charge today was Susan J. Irving, the 31-year-old aide to the departed Democratic chairman of the council.

title: TWO ASSEMBLYMEN SUE CAREY OVER TAX TABLES
description: Two leading Republican Assemblymen are suing Governor Carey in an attempt to force him to issue immediately new withholding tax tables reflecting a 1 percent cut in the state's maximum personal income tax.

title: Guinness Ads Focusing on Taste
description: Sports fans who turn to their newspaper Monday morning to read all about the Super Bowl that they watched between the beer commercials by Anheuser-Busch (for Budweiser, Michelob and Michelob Light), Miller and Schlitz will get hit in the eye with this headline from Guinness Extra Stout: ''It's time to blow the whistle on those tastealike beers.''

title: 40 Years of the U.S.O.
description: Next month, the U.S.O. celebrates 40 years of serving the men and women in the armed forces and their families.

title: A NEW DONOR TO NEEDIEST GIVES THANKS FOR 'BEING ABLE TO SHARE'
description: Many first-time donors have helped swell The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to a total of more than $1 million for the 11th consecutive year.

title: ARTHUR YOUNG POSITION
description: William L. Gladstone, 49, has been appointed managing partner and deputy chairman of Arthur Young & Company, the second-ranking position at the certified public accounting firm, effective April 1. William S. Kanaga, 55, continues as chairman of Arthur Young, which, as one of the Big 8 in the industry, has about 18,000 employees worldwide and took in about $700 million in revenues last year.

title: UNC Is Warned On Bid for Western
description: Continental Airlines said it had threatened UNC Resources Inc. with legal action if it persisted in its attempt to acquire Western Air Lines, which has already agreed to merge with Continental.

title: The Case for the Deal
description: Offensive though it is to have made a financial deal for the hostages, the bargain that was finally struck looks more and more like a good deal for Americans. There is no moral obligation to honor an extortion or, in the bloated language of the accord, to ''restore the financial position of Iran'' to that which existed in late 1979. But there are compelling reasons of national interest for honoring any undertaking by the United States Government. And so far, at least, there seem to be good commercial reasons for holding to the deal.

title: Writers and Officials Ask That Baraka Not Go to Jail
description: The poet and playwright Imamu Baraka, who used to be known as LeRoi Jones, is scheduled to begin serving a 90-day jail term Feb. 2, but 39 prominent persons have written letters to Criminal Court asking that the jail term be set aside.

''MOUNTAINS are the beginning and end of all natural scenery,'' John Ruskin observed in the 1800's. In their slopes and valleys are found ''the noblest and best ground given to man,'' Ruskin continued. ''In these districts only, art of the highest kind seems possible.'' These words of the English art and social critic inspired another Briton, Ralph Whitehead, who set out in 1902 seeking such surroundings of unbridled scenic beauty in which to start an artsand-crafts colony.

title: Lord Avie Is Syndicated; Stud Duty to Start in 1982
description: Thoroughbred racing's 2-year-old champion of last year, Lord Avie, has been syndicated for future stud duty for at least $10 million, but the figure could reach as high as $20 million.

title: Indoor Game Drags For Arrows' Zungul
description: In the last two and one-half seasons, Steve Zungul of the New York Arrows soccer team has scored 225 goals in 80 games, including playoffs. But because of legal problems, Zungul, a 26-year-old native of Yugoslavia, has been playing only the indoor game - ''not soccer,'' he says - and that bothers him.

title: HURTING VOLUNTARY AGENCIES
description: Ronald Reagan and many of the people here with him and with the new Congress believe that more public services should be delivered by voluntary organizations. Even without this conviction, it is likely that we are headed for a period of large Federal budget cutbacks, when Government will look to voluntary organizations to pick up the slack.

title: FUNDS GET A RECORD $3 BILLION
description: A record $3 billion in new cash flowed into the nation's money market mutual funds in the week ended Wednesday, lifting their total assets to $81.7 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: SAN FRANCISCO PINS BIG HOPES ON CONVENTION CENTER
description: The George R. Moscone Convention Center is not exactly rising - burrowing would be more accurate - as San Francisco tucks out of sight and under ground an addition to its impressive convention attractions.

title: LAWYERS URGED BY KOCH TO AID COURT LEGISLATION
description: Mayor Koch asked a statewide lawyers' group yesterday to help convince the State Legislature to pass 33 bills he has proposed dealing with criminal justice. But he received a generally unenthusiastic response from lawyers and judges, who questioned his proposals and his recent public statements about the courts.

title: 7 at V.A. Hospital Held on Drug Sales
description: Seven employees of the Veterans Administration Hospital in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx, including two security officers, have been arrested on charges of selling cocaine to employees and patients,the hospital's director, Roy C. McCracken, said. Nine other employees were issued summonses for possession of marijuana.

title: Tamara McKinney of U.S.  Takes World Cup Slalom
description: NENDAZ, Switzerland, Jan. 22 (AP) - Tamara McKinney, an 18-year-old skier from Olympic Valley, Calif., led the strongest American women's World Cup showing in two years today with her first giant slalom victory on the circuit.

title: MEAD NAMES GARNER TO SOLE POST OF CHIEF
description: In an unusual move for a major company, the Mead Corporation has named C. Greene Garner, 60 years old, to the sole position of chief executive officer. James W. McSwiney, 65, who had been chief executive, will continue as chairman but will retire as an employee of the forest products corporation.

title: FILM: WAJADA'S 'MAN OF MARBLE,' A POLISH-STYLE 'CITIZEN KANE'
description: ''Man of Marble'' was shown at Hunter College as part of an Andrzej Wajda festival. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby published in The New York Times on March 17, 1979. The film opens today at the Cinema Studio, Broadway and West 66th Street.

title: Sears Plans Outlets For Office Machines
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company announced that it will open five business machine specialty stores in three test markets by late fall of this year in a sales effort aimed mainly at small businesses.

title: The Economy
description: Railroads will no longer be able to set rates collectively under a new policy of the Interstate Commerce Commission. Seeking to stimulate competition, the I.C.C. directed the railroads to end their pricing agreements in 90 days and to propose alternative pricing arrangements. The industry opposes the measure. (Page D1.)

title: U.S. HALTS NICARAGUA AID OVER HELP FOR GUERILLAS
description: The United States suspended payments to Nicaragua from a $75 million economic support fund last week because of evidence that left-wing guerrillas in El Salvador have been supplied with arms from Nicaragua, an official source said today.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JANUARY 23, 1981
description: The Hostages The pledges to Iran will be carried out as long as they are ''consistent with domestic and international law,'' the Reagan Administration announced. The White House said that former President Carter, after meeting with the freed hostages, had advised President Reagan to abide by the accords but never to do ''any favors for the hoodlums who persecuted innocent American heroes.'' (Page A1, Col. 6.) Anger increased in Washington amid the many reports of harsh conditions forced on the Americans during their 444 days of captivity. Members of Congress introduced resolutions to renounce the accords with Iran, but Congressional leaders warned against precipitate action. (A7:5-6.)

title: NEW YORK'S SUBWAY LOSES A CUSTOMER
description: To the Editor:

title: Allbritton Acquires Riggs Bank Shares
description: An investment group headed by Joe L. Allbritton has exercised an option to buy more than 13 percent of the outstanding shares of the Riggs National Bank for $29.1 million.

title: Mother Bids Reporters Not So Fond Farewell
description: Dorothy Hall, mother of Joseph Hall, one of the freed American hostages, has released a letter she wrote to reporters with whom she dealt in the hostage ordeal.

title: COACH SAYS HE INVESTIGATED SHAVING IN '79
description: Tom Davis, the Boston College basketball coach, said yesterday that he investigated during the 1978-79 season the possibility that someone on his team was shaving points but was soon satisfied that nothing was wrong.

title: MET'S CARLO BERGONZI, EXPONENT OF TRUE ITALAIN TENOR SINGING
description: James Levine, music director of the Metropolitan Opera, is forever lamenting the decline in the voices needed to cast the standard Italian operas. But the Met's generally strong cast for Verdi's ''Un Ballo in Maschera,'' which will be given tonight, boasts a genuine paragon of Italian vocal style in its veteran tenor, Carlo Bergonzi.

title: Market Place; Bullish View On Australia
description: WHEN the average securities analyst leaves New York on a field trip, he may venture as far, say, as Atlanta or Chicago. But Miles P.H. Seifert likes to fly halfway around the world to prospect for investments.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Asarco Inc. shareholders approved the purchase of 20.6 percent of Asarco shares from the Bendix Corporation for about $335.5 million.

title: British Ford Labor Pact
description: Union leaders at the Ford Motor Company's British unit today accepted a 9.5 percent pay increase for 56,000 production workers at the company's 24 plants. The new contract, retroactive to Nov. 24, raises workers' average earnings to between $288 and $300 a week.

title: energywatch
description: JAN 16, 1981 Crude oil inventories showed a slight decline, to 362.6 million barrels.

title: Reagan Planning Canadian Visit
description: President Reagan is likely to visit Canada between late February and the end of March, Canadian diplomatic sources said today. Mr. Reagan telephoned Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau yesterday, they said, and the question of a visit was among the topics discussed.

title: Garwood Said to Have Told Of Prisoners Still in Vietnam
description: Pfc. Robert R. Garwood reported that ''a couple hundred other Americans'' were still in captivity in Vietnam when he left the country two years ago, a Navy psychiatrist testified today.

title: MANY IRANIAN STUDENTS IN U.S. GLAD HOSTAGES ARE FREE
description: Iranian students at the University of Southern California crowded around big square tables at the university commons yesterday and, in Moslem tradition, they celebrated with strong cups of coffee.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 20.00 20.00 15.25 DISCOUNT RATE* 13.00 13.00 12.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 19.00 17.63 13.89 3-MO. TREASURY BILLS 15.70 15.75 12.19 6-MO. TREASURY BILLS 14.69 14.65 11.94 TREASURY NOTES 12.87 12.87 10.98 TREASURY BONDS 12.34 12.25 10.84 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 13.36 13.28 11.76 MUNICIPAL BONDS 10.50 10.25 7.92 6-MONTH SAVINGS 14.721 CERTIFICATES * Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ZIONIST DOCUMENT OMITS ARAB PHRASE
description: After a tense and unexpected floor fight, a meeting of the World Jewish Congress deleted any mention today of ''recognition of the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people'' from a resolution supporting Israel and the Camp David agreements.

title: HATCH ASSERTS F.B.I. HAS DECIDED INFORMER ERRED ON DONOVAN PAYMENTS
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, chairman of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, said today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had told him that its informer was ''mistaken'' about allegations that President Reagan's nominee for Secretary of Labor, Raymond J. Donovan, had made illegal payments.

title: Economists Ask Benefit Cutback; End to Inflation Raises Advised
description: Three economists - two conservatives and a liberal - told Congress today that moderating future increases in Federal spending required scaling back cost-of-living increases in Social Security benefits to less than the law allows now.

title: Westchester Project
description: Joseph E. Seagram and Sons, the Manhattan-based distillers, will build a $10 million office and hangar complex at Westchester County Airport under an agreement announced by county officials. The project is the first under a county policy requiring companies to agree to build office space at the airport before they can build hangars for their planes.

title: TEXT OPF STATEMENT ON PURCHASE ISSUED BY THE TIMES OF LONDON
description: Following is the text of the statement issued here today by the management of Times Newspapers Holdings Ltd.:

title: SINGAPORE: BANKER TO REGION
description: In a region where a 7 or 8 percent growth in gross national product is not exceptional, Singapore is in a position to make good on its plans to become the banker for Southeast Asia.

title: Hartford Buses Idled
description: HARTFORD (UPI) - Connecticut Transit, which serves Hartford, New Haven and Stamford, will pull half its 280 new Grumman Flxible buses off the streets in the next few weeks for structural repairs. The 140 buses are among 2,600 nationwide found to have defects.

title: MARVIN DAVIS: MR. WILDCATTER
description: In the oil industry, he is called Mr. Wildcatter. And despite the recent sale of a hefty part of his smaller leases to a Canadian conglomerate, Marvin Davis, from all indications, intends to hold onto that title.

title: WHAT OIL CONTROL WILL DO FOR AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title:
RED SMITH;
Sugar Ray Is Getting Bigger
description: THE fist fight between Sugar Ray Leonard and the Ugandan Dane, Ayub Kalule, for the junior middleweight championship of the World Boxing Association will come off on a Friday night, either June 12 or June 19, at the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, N.J., or Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., or the Checkerdome in St. Louis or Madison Square Garden. It is planned for closed-circuit television.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: BALTIMORE (AL) - Traded Joe Kerri- g an, pitcher, to Cincinnati for John Hale, o utfielder. Assigned Hale to Rochester of t he International League. CLEVELAND (AL) - Signed Miguel Di- l one, outfielder, and Alan Bannister, i nfielder. METS (NL) - Signed two players from t he free-agent draft: Steven Ray, pitcher, t heir second selection, and Robert Smith, in- f ielder and outfielder, their 13th selection. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Signed John Mil- n er, free-agent outfielder and first base- m an, to a multiyear contract. Milner be- c ame a free agent after playing three sea- s ons with Pittsburgh. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Signed Robert Hayes, p itcher, its sixth selection in free-agent d raft.

title: JOBLESS FUNDS CURBED IN 25 STATES
description: The Government reported today that extended unemployment benefits were being halted for jobless workers in 25 states, including New York and Connecticut, plus the District of Columbia and the Virgin Islands.

title: COAT SEIZED BY VICTIM IN PURSUIT OF A ROBBER ON IND BRINGS ARREST
description: A 19-year-old man was arrested and charged with robbery last night after a woman he had allegedly held up in a West Side subway station pursued him up and then down the Eighth Avenue line, grabbing his coat as he jumped off a train and ran from a group of officers who were also chasing him, the police said.

title: 2 FROM 70'S IN THALIA PREMIERE
description: JOHN G. AVILDSEN'S 1975 ''The President's Wife'' has its premiere today at the Thalia, along with ''Acting Out,'' a pornographic film that accomplishes the nearly impossible feat of making ''The President's Wife'' look good.

title: CITIBANK WILL INTRODUCE NEW HOUSING LOAN PLAN
description: Citibank, the biggest home-mortgage lender in New York State, said yesterday that it would introduce a new kind of loan next Monday for homes and apartments with an interest rate that would initially be lower than currently charged but with provisions to raise or lower the rate every three years. The maximum it could change the rate would be three percentage points in each three-year period.

title: No Headline
description: THE MESSAGE SENT BY REAGAN

title: F.B.I. and Police Sued Over Raid
description: Residents of a Harlem apartment building filed a $91.8 million suit against the New York City Police Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a raid last April 19 that they say was made without a warrant.

title: Loan Forgiven By Harvester
description: The International Harvester Company, which reported a $397.3 million loss for 1980 following a six-month strike by the United Automobile Workers, has forgiven a $973,438 loan to the company's president, Warren J. Hayford.

title: A potboiler of gold at the end of his rainbow.
description: TO describe the director Sean Cunningham as unheralded before last May would have been an overstatement. He had made three films. The first was, in his words, a ''soft X'' called ''Together,'' back in 1972. The second, ''Here Come the Tigers,'' was inspired, to put it mildly, by ''The Bad News Bears'' and starred his 8-year-old son, Noel. The third went through several title changes before ending up as ''Kick,'' but by any name at all it couldn't find a distributor. The total cost of the three, he said, came to under $1 million, which is one-fifth the budget of his ''A Stranger Is Watching,'' which will begin shooting in New York next month.

title: THEY ARE CRIMINALS BY CHOICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Beirut Peace Force to Stay On
description: The Arab League Council, at the request of the Lebanese Government, voted today to extend the mandate of the Arab peacekeeping force in Lebanon for another six months.

title: Sharp Rise in Neo-Nazism Is Reported by Bonn
description: Neo-Nazi activity in West Germany rose sharply last year, Interior Minister Gerhard Baum said today. Based on 1980 statistics, which are not yet complete, Mr. Baum told Parliament's legal committee that 1,533 incidents involving rightist extremism were reported.

title: HOSTAGES' FAMILIES DISTRESSED AND ANGERED BY ACCOUNTS OF MISTREATMENT AT
description: EMBASSY By ANNA QUINDLEN

title: Motorman in Crash On S.I. Is Suspended
description: The motorman who was at the controls of a Staten Island Rapid Transit commuter train that plowed into a brick wall last month, injuring 100 people, was suspended.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY: EISENSTAEDT AND 3 OTHER REPORTERSS
description: SOME day the whole field of photojournalism is going to make a fertile subject of study for the critic or historian who has the capacity to explore the many different interests this branch of photography has served. Especially in the heyday of the largeformat, mass-circulation picture magazines that flourished in the period between the 1920's and the 50's, photojournalism was a visual medium of immense power and influence - second perhaps only to the movies in influencing the way people saw the world in which they lived.

title: OLD FRIENDS BRING DETROIT STYLE TO SERIES AT HEAVENLY REST
description: TOMMY FLANAGAN met Bess Bonnier at Northern High School in Detroit in the 1940's. ''I heard her playing the piano in the school auditorium,'' Mr. Flanagan recalled the other day, ''and I thought, 'That sounds like something I've been working on.' ''

title: MUSIC OF SUICIDE DUO AN AFFIRMATION OF LIFE
description: SUICIDE. It's not a pretty word, and for more than a decade the two-man rock-and-roll band that calls itself Suicide has been getting audience reactions that are as extreme, and sometimes as negative, as its name. ''At some of our early gigs,'' recalls Alan Vega, who sings along with Martin Rev's keyboards and an electronic rhythm machine, ''there would be maybe 300 people sitting there, and a minute or two after we started playing there would be three people left, total fanatics with their heads jammed into the amplifiers. The other 297 people would be fleeing in panic.''

title: TWO MEDICAL MAGAZINES AT ODDS OVER RESTRICTIONS ON INFORMATION
description: One of the nation's major medical journals has accused another of suppressing the free flow of information in the medical world.

title: BROWN STUDIES BID FOR HAYAKAWA SEAT
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, who made clear after early and overwhelming defeats in the Democratic primaries last year that his quest for the Presidency was not so much abandoned as postponed, is now giving priority consideration to running for the United States Senate in 1982.

title: ROLE OF U.N. IN THE HOSTAGE SITUATION PROVED MINOR
description: In the early months of the hostage crisis the United States turned to the United Nations and its Secretary General as the best means of isolating Iran and creating machinery that could bring the captives home. By the time the drama came to an end the United Nations had disappeared from the stage.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: REAGAN ORDERS CUT IN FEDERAL TRAVEL AND CONSULKTANT USE
description: President Reagan, in another set of actions underscoring his Inauguration Day declaration that ''government is the problem,'' today ordered a 15 percent reduction in travel by Federal employees, a 5 percent reduction in consulting services, and limits on furniture procurement and ''unnecessary'' office refurbishments.

title: Saudi Output Reported Level
description: Saudi Arabia, the world's largest petroleum exporter, probably will keep its crude oil output at the current 10 million to 10.1 million barrels-a-day level at least through March, industry sources and trade press reports said yesterday.

title: Korda Rand Levine Sails Out on Its Own
description: The newly christened Korda Rand Levine cut loose from its berth yesterday and sailed out into the hazardous marketplace with three old and proven hands at the helm.

title: Former Hostage Plans to Pursue $60 Million Lawsuit Against Iran
description: Sgt. Kenneth Kraus of the Marine Corps has reaffirmed his intention to pursue a $60 million lawsuit against Iran for alleged physical and mental torture inflicted while he was held captive in Teheran two years ago.

title: VICARIOUS UPHEAVALS
description: To the Editor:

title: LIBERALS SEEK NEW ANSWERS IN REAGAN ERA
description: As the Republicans swept into Washington this week, a group of beleaguered liberals met in New York City to take stock of their beliefs and prospects for the future.

title: Allyn Joslyn, 79, Actor In Movies and on Radio
description: Allyn Joslyn, the wisecracking actor of stage, screen, radio and television, died of cardiac failure yesterday at the Motion Picture and Television Country Home and Hospital in suburban Woodland Hills. He was 79 years old.

title: ART: NEW 46-FOOT EPIC BY ROSENQUIST ON VIEW
description: GREAT nonsense has often been talked about the ''giant scale'' of American painting since World War II. The truth is rather the other way around: that most American painters have too much sense to work on the scale of Tintoretto and Veronese, Delacroix and Gericault at their most expansive. Bigger is not necessarily better. For every idea there is a right and a wrong scale, and very big American paintings sometimes leave an impression of energies dissipated and dispersed rather than of a momentum that could not be contained within a smaller arena.

title: FAST REUNION URGED FOR 52 EX-HOSTAGES
description: William F. Niehous, the American businessman who was held captive for more than three years by revolutionaries in the jungles of Venezuela, where he slept chained to a tree every night, says that the sooner the American hostages released Tuesday by Iran can rejoin their families, the better off they will be.

title: McDonnell Enters New Fuel Venture
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, a leader in the aerospace industry, said it was exercising an option to acquire a controlling interest in Coaliquid Inc. of Louisville, Ky., a maker of a fuel for power plants that could save industrial consumers about 10 percent on their fuel bills.

title: Ore. State 66, Wash. State 53
description: Top-ranked Oregon State broke the game open in the second half to beat Washington State tonight, 66-53.

title: ANGOLAN AIDE LINKS CUBANS' EXIT TO A FREE NAMIBIA
description: Angolan leaders say they want to keep working with Western countries to find a ''diplomatic way'' to achieve independence for South-West Africa. If the problem is solved, they say, Cuban troops can start to leave Angola.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We thought the Americans couldn't care. We'd say to ourselves: 'They don't care.

title: Index; The Hostages
description: Hostages' families get more dis- tressing accounts of captivity A6 Allyssa Keough is reunited with her father A6 Claimants against Iran bid Rea- gan to hold up accord A8 Many Iranian students in U.S. re- joice at freeing of hostages A9 A court agreed to block transfer of some Iran assets A9 U.N. unable to play more than minor role in hostage crisis A10 Hostages' fast return urged by man held 3 years in captivity A11 International Bahamas is land of fear for 25,000 illegal Haitian residents A2 World Jewish Congress spurns mention of Palestinian rights A3 I.R.A. claims responsibility for killing of two Protestants A3 Around the World A4 Three dissidents abroad deprived of Soviet citizenship A5 Thomson confident that Murdoch will keep paper's character A13 Government/Politics Thousands of foes of abortion march in Washington A14 Philadelphia passes law requiring disclosure on chemicals A14 Gov. Brown says U.S. Senate race is his top political option A15 Senate approves eight more of Reagan Cabinet choices A15 Koch seeks lawyers' support for criminal justice proposals B1 Race for comptroller to highlight the next citywide elections B1 Panel of liberals look to future B3 Jersey Senate again votes to over- ride a Byrne veto D15 Two G.O.P. Assemblymen suing Carey on state tax-table delay D15 Health/Science Machine for rapid assembly of genetic material is shown A21 Weekend Events: Weekender Guide C1 Woodstock in winter for sports or a cozy fire C1 Theater: Broadway C2

title: Advertising; Chrysler Banking on Super Bowl
description: THE biggest Super Bowl advertiser during the NBC-TV coverage on Sunday will be the Chrysler Corporation, and it will use its nine commercials that will take up four and a half minutes to project the image of a company on the move - up.

title: IRAN FUND TRANSFER BLOCKED BY COURT
description: In possible conflict with the agreement worked out between the Carter Administration and Iran to free the 52 American hostages, a Federal court agreed Wednesday to block the transfer of $91 million of Iranian funds from the Bank of America to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, it was learned yesterday from court papers.

title: Marilyn Horne Recital
description: A recital by Marilyn Horne, canceled twice because of illness, will be given Sunday at 3 P.M in Carnegie Hall, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street.

title: Jordan's Queen Expecting Baby
description: Queen Noor, the American-born wife of King Hussein, is expecting a second child in June, palace officials said today. The 30-year-old Queen gave birth to a boy last year. She lost a baby in 1979.

title: Cambodian Arts Sunday
description: Cambodian music and dance will be presented Sunday at 2:30 P.M. at Asia House, 112 East 64th Street.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. BRAINWASHING CHARGED BY IRANAIAN

title: Philips and G.T.E.
description: The North American Philips Corporation disclosed that in its purchase of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation's television receiver business, completed earlier this week, it had paid $128 million cash and notes. The value of the transaction, which had not previously been announced, was reported by Philips in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Philips makes television sets and other products under the Magnavox brand name; the businesses it acquired from G.T.E. make Sylvania and Philco sets

title: Wake Forest Beaten
description: Al Wood led a second-half surge that carried North Carolina to a 74-60 victory tonight over previously unbeaten Wake Forest.

title: Black Students End Boycott in South Africa
description: An eight-month-old school boycott by 60,000 black students ended early today, the South African Press Association reported.
