title: A PAPER HOARY WITH TRADITION: 2 HOMES, 4 OWNERS IN 195 YEARS
description: ''Marie Antoinette had on a white loose dress and her hands were tied behind her back,'' read the eyewitness account in The Times of the French Queen's execution in October 1793. ''She looked firmly 'round her on all sides and, once on the scaffold, preserved her natural dignity of mind. After the execution three young persons dipped their handkerchiefs in her blood. They were immediately arrested.''

title: China Raising Crude Oil Price
description: China has notified Japanese clients that it wants to raise the price of its crude oil by just over $3, to $37 a barrel, oil importers said today.

title: DEATH SENTENCE OF KEY DISSIDENT IS COMMUTED BY PRESIDENT IN SEOUL
description: President Chun Doo Hwan today commuted the death sentence given Kim Dae Jung, the leading opponent of South Korea's military-supported Government, after the Supreme Court upheld it.

title: SENATE VOTE BACKS 8 MORE OF REAGAN CABINET CHOICES
description: President Reagan's Cabinet filled out today as the Senate approved eight of his nominations, but not before several Democrats angrily denounced the choice of James G. Watt as Secretary of the Interior.

title: Vocal Recital in Brooklyn
description: Frank Guarrera and Rita Shane, singers who have appeared with the Metropolitan Opera, will give a recital from opera and Broadway tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Brooklyn College's Whitman Hall, Nostrand and Flatbush Avenues.

title: Iowa 56, Indiana 53
description: Bob Hansen, a sophomore guard, sank four free throws in the last six seconds and lifted Iowa to a 56-53 over Indiana tonight.

title: ENVOY SAYS IRAN FAVORS ALGERIA AND P.L.O. AS MEDIATORS IN WAR
description: Iran's Ambassador to Kuwait said today that his country was ready to accept Algeria and the Palestine Liberation Organization as mediators of its war with Iraq.

title: STAGE: RESTORATION COMEDY IN BROOKLYN
description: THERE is a smidgin of good news from Brooklyn today. The BAM Theater Company's production of George Farquhar's ''The Recruiting Officer'' is an improvement over the ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' that it joined in repertory last night. But I wouldn't break out the fireworks yet. By any objective standard, this is a very spotty version of a play that the company might better have avoided. ''The Recruiting Officer'' has its moments, but it's not worth a detour.

title: Friday; BLUEBEARD ON 13TH ST.
description: Bluebeard has arrived at the Classic Stage Company's Repertory Theater, 136 East 13th Street. His legendary image, as the murderer of a succession of wives, is based on Baron Gilles de Rais, who was, it seems, even more terrifying than that in life, but also heroic and a friend of Joan of Arc. ''Gilles de Rais'' by Roger Planchon - the playwright and actor who is director of France's Theatre National Populaire - explores the nature and times of the man. It has its English-language premiere tonight at 8 and after that it will run in rotating repertory with the C.S.C.'s Sophocles Oedipus Cycle. Tickets on weekends are $10 ($8 for students and the elderly). Information: 677-4210. HUDSON RIVER AT SOUTH ST.

title: SENATE IN JERSEY OVERRIDES BYRNE'S VETO OF REGULATORY BILL
description: The New Jersey Senate voted today to override a veto by Governor Byrne of a bill that would give the Legislature power to oversee the rule-making abilities of some state agencies.

title: Cabaret for Youngsters
description: ''The Early Show,'' a cabaret for youngsters and their parents, is presented every Sunday afternoon at 1 by 18 young singers and dancers, at Once Upon a Stove, on Third Avenue between 24th and 25th Streets.

title: INFIGHTING FOR TRADE JOBS BESETS ADMINISTRATION
description: Prospective high-level appointments related to international trade are causing intense infighting in the Reagan Administration and are heightening speculation about shifts in the relative importance of key departments and agencies.

title: uf813
description: BOOKS by dissident and exiled authors are now a familiar feature of American publishing, and publishers say they will continue to be as long as governments keep oppressing their citizens. At least seven such books are scheduled to appear in the next few months, but even more impressive than the number of titles is the stature of the authors.

title: A LIST OF PROPERTIES OWNED BY MURDOCH
description: Based on the latest available records, Rupert Murdoch owns or has a major interest in the following properties: UNITED STATES The New York Post New York magazine (now including Cue magazine) The Village Voice The San Antonio Express and The News The Star About 12 suburban newspapers in the Houston area BRITAIN The Sun The News of The World About 27 provincial newspapers About 7 suburban newspapers and magazines London Weekend Various interests in printing, papermaking, recording and motion pictures. AUSTRALIA The Australian (of Sydney) The (Sydney) Daily and Sunday Mirror The (Sydney) Daily and Sunday Telegraph The Adelaide News Several provincial papers Several magazines, including a leading woman's magazine, New Idea About a dozen suburban papers Ansett Transport Industries, which owns a television station in Melbourne, Australia's only nongovernment airline, Ansett Airlines, and an interest in Santos, a natural gas company.

title: COLLEGE WOMEN AND CAREERS
description: Many young women now say they'd pick family over careers, according to a recent newspaper article. Are we, then, witnessing a conservative backlash on the college campuses?

title: MUSEUM SALUTES CANADA'S FILM BOARD
description: produced 32 feature films, including the much acclaimed "Mon Oncle Antoine" in 1971. It is a far cry from the early days when the board opened in a converted sawmill and dispatched squads of projectionists on regular routes to hundreds of small communities like cinema circuit riders. There, for the first time Canadians, until then exposed mostly to films from the United States, could see the wonders of their own country and lives through the labors of homegrown talent. For much of the early years the board, under the direction of John Grierson, founder of the British documentary movement, dealt with propaganda, boosting and documenting virtually every aspect of Canada's World War II role. By the late 1950's, the Film Board was entering its golden decade, when it was a homespun mecca for many artistically inclined Canadians. In a 10-year flurry of activity, the board concentrated on animation and documentary, using its newly developed cameras and recording equipment to take viewers right into the midst of crowds. In animation, Norman McLaren was continuing his experimentation, pioneering with drawing directly on film and hand-drawn sound.

title: I.R.A. SAYS IT KILLED 2 LEADING PROTESTANTS
description: Guerrillas of the outlawed Irish Republican Army said today that they were responsible for killing an 86-year-old Protestant politician and his son last night and burning their ancestral home with fire bombs.

title: Bridge: London Pairs Begin Today Under a New Sponsorship
description: The world's strongest pairs tournament, judged by the average ability of its players, is played each January in London, and for 17 years was sponsored by The Sunday Times.

title: Offer Is Rejected In Trot Walkout
description: An effort to end the four-day strike by parimutuel clerks against Roosevelt Raceway failed tonight when members of the clerks' union rejected by a show of hands a new offer at its meeting hall in Mineola.

title: Bohemian Club Is Upheld On Refusal to Hire Women
description: An administrative law judge has recommended that the exclusive, all-male Bohemian Club, of which President Reagan is a member, should not be required to hire female employees at its woodland retreat 70 miles north of San Francisco.

title: THEATER: 'NUIT BLANCHE,' A PING CHONG COLLAGE
description: PING CHONG calls his new theater piece, ''Nuit Blanche,'' a ''bricolage.'' He defines the word as ''a new world created out of any and all available materials from an old world.'' A bricole is also a billiard shot, a carom effect that results in an ''indirect action or unexpected stroke.''

title: Penn Central Net Up Sharply
description: The Penn Central Corporation, a diversified energy and real estate concern, said yesterday that its pretax earnings for the final quarter of 1980 rose about 200 percent, in part on the strength of several key acquisitions.

title: BIG POWWOW AND DANCE DOWNTOWN TOMORROW
description: Beating a drum that he held in one hand, Louis Mofsie cried out in song, while his Thunderbird American Indian Dancers performed the rhythmic side steps of a round dance. ''Eh-yah, eh-yo, eh-yo-oh,'' Mr. Mofsie sang, and, afterward, likened the syllables to ''be-bop talk.''

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''L ET'S see you anagram this,'' Mel Taub snapped at Will Weng, as he fanned out six lettered cards that spelled ''COMBAT.'' Mr. Taub, it should be explained, had a right to be upset because Mr. Weng had, just one card earlier, taken his ''SOME,'' rearranged the letters, stuck in a ''U'' and created ''MOUSE.''

title: CONGRESS URGED IN STUDY TO ADD 5 MORE DIVISIONS AND 3 CARRIERS
description: The Congressional Budget Office suggested today that Congress appropriate funds to add five armored divisions to the Army, three aircraft carriers to the Navy and other programs to build up the armed forces over the next five years.

title: Nouvelle cuisine in a setting of surprises.
description: GREENE STREET in SoHo is a Chinese puzzle of surprises, offering a series of unexpected delights that slowly reveal themselves. The first surprise comes upon discovering that this restaurant has been in existence for a year in the middle of an otherwise dark and deserted block. Once inside, there is the pleasant shock of beauty - soaring arched brick walls, a profusion of potted trees, a big airy mural across one wall and a catwalk balcony where drinks are served.

title: THOMSON CONFIDENT ON STANDARDS
description: Kenneth R. Thomson said today that the unusual set of provisos to protect the journalistic integrity of The Times of London was vital to the sale of the publication to Rupert Murdoch.

title: Marcello Deportation Order Is Upheld by Appeals Court
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld an order to deport a reputed organized crime chief, Carlos Marcello of New Orleans, an effort that began almost 30 years ago.

title: uf1 Car Output Off in Week
description: United States car production this week will dip slightly from last week as a result of shutdowns of 10 assembly plants to hold down inventories, a trade publication reported today. The weekly Automotive News said this week's output would total 117,886 cars, off 2.5 percent from last week's 120,850 and down two tenths of 1 percent from 118,077 turned out in the same week of 1980. That should bring the production for the year so far to 345,531 cars, 16 percent below the 413,228 built to the same point last year.

title: KOCH WILL NOT BACK RIVAL
description: Who will be the next Comptroller of New York City? Can Harrison J. Goldin rebound from his unsuccessful effort to win state office and win a third term as the city's chief fiscal officer? Will Assemblyman John C. Dearie build an identity beyond his Bronx neighborhood and defeat Mr. Goldin in the Democratic primary? Is this what New York politicians are gossiping about? As a matter of fact, it is. The expected contest between Mr. Goldin and Mr. Dearie, a former Notre Dame basketball player, is shaping up as the only interesting citywide race this year.

title: BOSSY THWARTED
description: The Islanders played their 49th game of the season tonight, beating the Detroit Red Wings, 3-0, and Mike Bossy still needs two goals to match Maurice (Rocket) Richard's record of 50 goals in 50 games. For the second straight time, the Islanders shut out their opponents, and their opponents kept Bossy from getting any goals.

title: THREE ABROAD LOSE SOVIET CITIZENSHIP
description: Three Soviet writers who were pressured into emigrating to the West last year have been stripped of their Soviet citizenship and effectively barred from their homeland.

title: ART: GARDEN DRAWINGS BY JENNIFER BARTLETT
description: WHEN a theme has an artist by the throat, it can produce the most exciting kind of work; obsessional stuff that lets us see deep into the makings of art. Think of Monet's fascination with the facade of Rouen Cathedral; Cezanne's absorption in Mount Ste.-Victoire or Picasso's preoccupation with the famous Velasquez painting ''Las Meninas.'' The artist's worrying of a subject until it's threadbare gives insight into essential decisions: how light should play on a surface, the placement of forms in relation to one another, the adjustment of colors, what compositional elements to put in or throw out. Seen together, such serial explorations can build a tension that makes less fixated art seem relaxed indeed.

title: KEEP THE INCOME TAX OUT OF
description: CONNECTICUT To the Editor:

title: CLOSINMG ARGUMENTS BEGIN IN KELLY TRIAL
description: A Government lawyer, in closing arguments at the Abscam bribery trial of former Representative Richard Kelly, replayed for the jury today a videotape that showed the Florida Republican filling his pockets with $25,000 in cash. The prosecutor asked repeatedly, ''Is that the way the business of the United States is to be conducted?''

title: Water: Questions and answers, page B3.
description: Governor Byrne ordered a ban yesterday on nonessential uses of water in 34 towns in central New Jersey. The move supplements a similar ban imposed last week on 153 towns in the Delaware River Basin in the southern part of the state.

title: OILS, DEFENSE STOCKS LEAD MARKET DOWN
description: The stock market declined broadly again yesterday, as fears grew that interest rates would rise further. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 5.81 points, to 940.44, led by slumps in oil, gold mining and defense companies. Volume was moderate, with 39.9 million shares traded, up slightly from 39.2 million on Wednesday.

title: U.S. SAYS ABUSE OF CAPTIVES EXCEEDED FEARS OF OFFICIALS
description: The State Department said today that examinations of the 52 freed hostages showed a pattern of abuse by their Iranian captors more grave and extensive than American officials had initially feared.

title: FIRST WOMAN TAKES SEAT WITH FRANCE'S IMMORTALS
description: A procession of immortality, looking extraordinarily mortal with its white hair and stiff backs, cautiously descended the main staircase of the Academie Fran,caise this afternoon. In its midst, for the first time in 346 years, was a woman.

title: NEW ADMINISTRATION SAYS IT WILL HONOR ACCORD ON HOSTAGES
description: The Reagan Administration said today that ''consistent with domestic and international law alike'' it ''fully intends'' to carry out the commitments to Iran made by the Carter Administration to obtain the release of the 52 American hostages.

title: Mondale Joining Law Firm in Washington
description: Only three days out of office, Walter F. Mondale has found a new job.

title: RETAILERS GETTING NEW TECHNOLOGY
description: From antipilferage devices camouflaged as lighting fixtures to electronic cash registers that report transactions by number and word descriptions, technology has moved into retailing.

title: Revamp S.E.C., Reagan Is Told
description: A group of advisers to President Reagan is urging an overhaul of the Securities and Exchange Commission through cuts in its budget, staff, enforcement activities and regulation of the financial community.

title: Pacific Phone's Bond Rating
description: The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company's chairman, Donald E. Guinn, said yesterday that it had received ''clear signals'' from the bond-rating agencies that the utility's bond rating would be lowered to BBB unless it received sizable rate relief soon.

title: New Portuguese Cabinet Gets Vote of Confidence
description: The new Government of Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao won its first vote of confidence in Parliament today.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 23, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Committee on the Drafting of an International Convention against Mercenaries - 10:30 A.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: 10 CITIES IN POLAND ARE SWEPT BY BRIEF WORK STOPPAGES
description: Poland was swept by brief warning strikes by hundreds of thousands of workers in at least 10 cities today as the independent trade union marshaled its forces in the campaign for a five-day workweek.

title: Tubing Makers Are Convicted
description: A Federal jury has convicted three tubing manufacturers and four executives in a conspiracy to fix the prices of steel tubing.

title: AWARD SYSTEM IS CHANGED
description: Cecile Licad, a 19-year-old pianist from the Philippines, has won the first Leventritt Foundation award given in 10 years, it was announced yesterday. As winner of the Gold Medal Award, Miss Licad will receive $10,000, a three-year contract with CBS Records and appearances with some of the world's major orchestras over a threeyear period.

title: Snow Isolates Italian Villages
description: Severe snowstorms and strong winds isolated villages and blocked traffic in central Italy today for the second day and high seas hampered communications between the mainland and Italian islands. The snow, which reached nearly 10 feet in some mountainous areas of the Abruzzi and Molise regions, blocked the Pescara-Rome railway line and several roads.

title: The Science Gap
description: Ex-President Carter is not alone in making control of the arms race, especially nuclear arms, an urgent national priority. But somehow, repetition of the threat of vast annihilation has dulled the public sense that danger is still real and growing.

title: LEE KONITZ AND HIS NONET AT VANGUARD
description: SINCE 1975, Lee Konitz, the saxophonist, has from time to time led a nine-piece jazz group that, because of its arrangements and its instrumentation, which includes a tuba and a baritone saxophone, was an obvious descendant of the Miles Davis Nonet of the late 1940's whose record album ''The Birth of the Cool'' is viewed as the transition from be-bop to cool jazz. Mr. Konitz, who was a member of the Davis group, has included a few of the Davis Nonet's arrangements in his group's repertory, along with new arrangements by Sy Johnson, Jimmy Knepper and himself.

title: HOSTAGES WORST MOMENTS: DID AMERICA REALLY CARE?
description: At the worst times in his cell, when the light was only a thin strip of gray slipping in for about an hour at 10 in the morning, Barry Rosen said, ''we thought the Americans couldn't care.''

title: RUSSELL PROCOPE, 72, CLARINETIST WITH ELLINGTON 29 YEARS, DEAD
description: Russell Procope, the clarinetist and saxophonist who was a star soloist in Duke Ellington's orchestra for nearly three decades, collapsed and died, apparently of a heart attack, Wednesday evening at Ninth Avenue and 43d Street, outside Manhattan Plaza, the apartment building in which he lived. He was 72 years old.

title: ABBOTT INCREASES 17.8%
description: Pfizer Inc., one of the nation's leading pharmaceutical companies, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980 rose 10.1 percent on an increase in sales of 11 percent.

title: RELEARNING THE OBVIOUS; Learning to Write
description: Some truths, it seems, are still self-evident. A survey of American students' writing skills suggests that those with more class instruction in writing tend to write better essays.

title: Fallen Sparrow
description: There are five dusky sparrows living in the avian equivalent of an old folks' home in Florida. But for a sixth, presumed alive somewhere, they are the last on this planet. When they die, an entire species dies with them.

title: Buffalo Forge Bid
description: The Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation said the New York State Attorney General's office has ordered an investigation into the company's tender offer for the Buffalo Forge Company.

title: EX-HOSTAGE SAYS IRANIANS FAILED TO 'BREAK' CAPTIVES
description: ''Those people tried to break us,'' Richard H. Morefield, a former hostage, has told relatives and others in telephone calls from Wiesbaden, West Germany, to San Diego since he was freed two days ago. But, he said, ''We won on that. We beat them.''

title: Rhode Island Suspends Zarchen, Athletic Director
description: Maurice Zarchen, the University of Rhode Island athletic director, has been temporarily suspended with pay by the school's president, Frank Newman.

title: RELEARNING THE OBVIOUS; Sense in Housing
description: To foster racial integration, the Department of Housing and Urban Development in recent years has been requiring a shift in the location of subsidized housing from the center of cities to predominantly white or integrated communities. But the guidelines didn't work very well.

title: LAW REGULATING CHEMICALS WINS IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Environmental activists today popped champagne corks and waved giant cardboard hands proclaiming ''Philly No. 1 Right To Know'' as the City Council passed the first laws in the nation aimed at forcing manufacturers to disclose to the public what toxic chemicals are stored on their premises or emitted into the air.

title: 3 Iranian Men Killed In Jersey Rail Crash
description: Three Iranian men in the United States on visas were killed when a Conrail train struck their car at a grade crossing, the police reported yesterday.

title: G.E. HAD SMALL GAIN IN QUARTER
description: The General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the nation's two largest electrical equipment suppliers, both reported modest income and sales gains for the fourth quarter of 1980 yesterday, but G.E.'s statistics gave it more to look forward to in 1981, analysts said.

title: Hartford Courant Names Editor
description: The metropolitan editor of The Los Angeles Times has been named vice president and editor of The Hartford Courant, according to Keith L. McGlade, the publisher and chief executive officer of The Courant. The new editor, 47-year-old Mark Murphy, will be responsible for all news and editorial operations of the newspaper, Mr. McGlade said.

title: MOBIL, SOHIO, GETTY POST HIGHER PROFITS
description: The Mobil Corporation reported yesterday that fourth-quarter net earnings were 5 percent higher than a year earlier. The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) reported a 3.7 percent gain and the Getty Oil Company a rise of 15.6 percent.

title: L.I. Vandalism Study
description: A panel on vandalism formed last summer by the Nassau County Executive, Francis T. Purcell, has called for a countywide crackdown.

title: GENE-LINKING MACHINE DEVELOPED
description: A machine for the rapid, automatic assembly of genetic material was demonstrated here yesterday by scientists of a Canadian biotechnology concern.

title: SAINTS GIVE PHILLIPS 5-YEAR PACT AS COACH
description: The appointment of Bum Phillips as coach of the New Orleans Saints was confirmed today when the team's owner, John W. Mecom Jr., announced at a news conference in the Louisiana Superdome that Phillips had signed a five-year contract.

title: SAWHILL ON WAY OUT, CAPITAL AIDES REPORT
description: The Reagan Administration has apparently decided to replace John C. Sawhill as chairman of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, industrial, Congressional and other well-placed sources said today.

title: IRAN HOLDS TO REFUSAL TO ATTEND ISLAMIC MEETING IN SAUDI ARABIA
description: A five-member Islamic delegation was rebuffed today by Iran's Prime Minister as it appealed for a reconsideration of Teheran's refusal to attend a meeting of leaders of the Islamic Conference opening Sunday in Saudi Arabia.

title: ARRAY OF GIFTS OFFERED TO EX-HOSTAGES
description: If the returned American hostage wishes, he or she can drop by the local tavern for a drink, take in a baseball game, stop at the supermarket for groceries, then stretch out on a new Oriental rug while contemplating a warm-weather location to go to on vacation.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, JANUARY 24, 1981; The Economy
description: Consumer prices rose 1.1 percent in December, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. For all of 1980, inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index was 12.4 percent. It was the second straight year of double-digit inflation, following a 13.3 percent surge in 1979, and gave the Reagan Administration a tough situation to tackle. (Page 1.) In the New York metropolitan area the rises were 1.3 percent for the month and 10.6 percent for the year. (27.) The nation's basic money supply fell $2.3 billion, to $416.9 billion, in the week ended Jan. 14, the Federal Reserve reported. Economists cautioned that shifts of money into new interest-bearing checking accounts may be distorting the money-supply figures. (29.)

title: 2 Senators Seek to Aid Journalist Held in Iran
description: New York state's two Senators asked Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today to press Iran for the release of Cynthia Dwyer, a freelance journalist from Buffalo who has been held in Teheran since May.

title: FRANCE SET TO BUILD REACTORS
description: France announced today that it had developed its own technology for building the pressurized water reactor, the civil nuclear reactor first developed by Westinghouse, and said it would compete with the United States company by selling French-built reactors on the world market.

title: MOTHER OF AN EX-HOSTAGE CHARGES U.S. INEPTITUDE
description: Five months after the eldest of her five children was taken hostage at the United States Embassy in Teheran, Barbara Timm defied the President of the United States and flew to Teheran for a 45-minute visit with her son.

title: The Worst of Times and the Best of Times
description: It was a New York downer followed by an upbeat, or as Mitch Miller put it, ''the best and worst of New York all at once.'' It began Wednesday morning when Mr. Miller's secretary, Olga Kovacs, was robbed on West 52d Street by a young man who snatched an envelope from her hands and ran.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, an article in Business Day on Thursday incorrectly described Wembley Industries. The company manufactures men's neckwear.

title: CAREERS, MOTHERHOOD AND THE REAL WORLD
description: To the Editor:

title: ECONOMIC PROBLEMS DOMINATE ACTIVITIES OF PRESIDENT'S DAY
description: President Reagan's search for remedies for the nation's economic problems continued to dominate his working schedule today as he met with Republican Congressional leaders and announced his intention to appoint Murray L. Weidenbaum to be chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

title: MORTGAGING THE FUTURE
description: ''Dad, didn't Grandma and Grandpa once own their own house?'' ''Yes, son, it's true.'' ''Why don't people own houses now?'' ''Well, it started back in the early 1980's.'' ''The Age of Recession?'' ''That's right. People used to borrow money from a bank to buy a house; they'd pay back the bank little by little, with interest. That was a ''conventional mortgage.'' But in the 80's, interest rates were too high and houses too expensive for most people. So, in order to keep people in the market, banks came up with what they called ''shared equity'' mortgages. People who wanted to buy a house could get a lower interest rate on their mortgage by agreeing to split the profit with the bank when they later sold their house. Since house prices had hardly ever gone down, this seemed okay. The way people figured it, part of a house was better than no house at all.

title: G.M. Sets More Robot Use
description: The General Motors Corporation expects to increase the use of robots in its factories from about 300 now to some 14,000 by 1990, an official of the nation's largest auto maker said today. Richard Beecher, head of the machine perception and robotics department of G.M.'s manufacturing staff, said that G.M. plans to have 2,500 robots in operation by 1983 and 5,000 by 1985. The company's existing robots are mostly used for spot-welding auto bodies, he said.

title: SWITCH BACK TO COAL CAUSES SHORTGAE
description: Decades after most homeowners throughout the Northeast threw aside their ashcans with relief and switched to clean, cheap and convenient oil furnaces, coal is suddenly coming back.

title: Holdup Man Is Slain In Battle With Police
description: A gunman was killed and an 11-year-old boy wounded during a shootout in a Brooklyn home as the police thwarted a robbery. Two police officers burst into the ground-floor quarters of a twofamily house at 198 17th Street in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn Thursday while a dozen members of the Rosado family were being robbed of jewelry and money by two gunmen, the police said.

title: ESCAPING FUMES AT BRONX CENTER FATAL TO WOMAN
description: A patient in a drug treatment program in the Bronx died yesterday and at least 100 people were treated for symptoms of carbon monoxide poisoning, apparently as a result of fumes that leaked from a boiler, New York City officials said.

title: Tiger Gains 5.5% Of Purolator Stock
description: Tiger International Inc. has acquired 244,400 shares, or about 5.5 percent, of the oustanding shares of Purolator Inc. for $8 million, according to a filing by Tiger with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: City Reservoir Level At 29.7% of Capacity
description: The city's reservoir level dipped to below 30 percent of capacity for the first time since the 1965 drought, when the city was declared a Federal disaster area.

title: A Former Hostage Works to Ease Another Ordeal
description: One of the former hostages of the Iranians will be seen in television spot announcements around the nation, for a cause poignantly close to him - research into multiple sclerosis.

title: WALKER IS LAST IN SPRINT DEBUT
description: Herschel Walker, the wunderkind of college football, made his indoor track debut tonight. He finished last, but he left a strong impression that he could get better and faster.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JANUARY 24, 1981
description: International Poles were urged not to work today by Lech Walesa, head of the independent union Solidarity, in a further effort toward a five-day workweek. In a dramatic appeal, Mr. Walesa said there must be an effective work boycott today to preserve the unity of the union movement. Meanwhile, the Soviet Union increased its antiunion pressure on Poland, and Warsaw was shut down by a four-hour strike. (Page 1, Col. 6.) The former hostages will fly home tomorrow and will be taken to the United States Military Academy at West Point for a weekend with their families, the State Department said. Some of them have serious pyschiatric problems, according to Dr. Jerome M. Korcak, the department's chief medical officer, who heads a 30-member medical team assigned to them. (1:1.)

title: Nina Haight Bride Of Timothy Frost
description: Nina Edwards Haight, daughter of Judge Charles S. Haight Jr. of Federal District Court in Manhattan and Mrs. Haight, was married yesterday to Timothy Tyler Frost, son of Dr. John W. Frost of Chicago and Isabelle F. Frost of Haverford, Pa.

title: Sports of The Times; The Super Bowl's Other Owner
description: AT the Super Bowl this week, Leonard Tose is the other owner, the all-but-invisible other owner. Because of his mystique as the Oakland Raiders' rebellious genius, Al Davis is the owner everybody is talking about. Hardly anybody is talking about Leonard Tose, the 65-year-old trucking tycoon, who prefers it that way.

title: OBSERVER
description: A new President always makes everybody feel so good that it's a pity we can't have one every two weeks. There are several reasons for the flush of delight. For one, you are usually so glad to be rid of the old President that you'd feel good even if the new man was your brother-in-law.

title: U.S. Suit Cites Mexico Oil Spill
description: The United States is suing a private Mexican oil well drilling contractor seeking payment, for the first time, of damages resulting from a 1979 well explosion in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: REGION OF AUTO UNION OPPOSES PLAN TO JOIN THE LABOR FEDERATION
description: Regional representatives of the United Automobile Workers from three states have voted overwhelmingly against the possibility of rejoining the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

title: Some Rate Ceilings Raised by C.A.B.
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board announced today that it would allow increased flexibility for United States air carriers to raise their fares on routes to Britain, Australia and New Zealand.

title: Walls Gets Sentence of 25 Years In Killing of 2 Lewisboro Women
description: James Walls, who was convicted of two counts of felony murder in the murder and rape of two Westchester women, was sentenced today to two concurrent terms of 25 years to life in prison.

title: MUSIC: CLARION OFFERS NEGLECTED SCORES
description: We deify music's past because of the gigantic composers who once trod the earth. But for every Haydn or Mozart, there were innumerable lesser figures, industrious Kapellmeisters who turned out the fashionable music of the day and whom posterity has inexorably banished to obscurity.

title: U.S. PROTESTS TO SOVIET AGAIN OVER ITS REPORT ON HOSTAGES
description: The United States protested to the Soviet Union today for the third time in a week about Soviet broadcasts and press reports dealing with the hostage crisis and its aftermath.

title: The Firetrap Dilemma
description: More than 120 elderly Americans have perished in boarding home fires over the last 18 months. Such fires are increasing, and New Jersey now holds a grisly record. Thirty-one people died when flames recently swept Keansburg's Beachview Rest Home. Seven months ago, 23 perished in a boarding home fire in nearby Bradley Beach.

title: Rangers Beat Oilers, 7-4, On 3 Last-Period Goals
description: Don Maloney scored what proved to be the winning goal on a third-period power play tonight night as the New York Rangers beat the Oilers, 7-4.

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times The Poet as Hero By ANATOLE BROYARD THE STRANGE DESTINY OF RUPERT BROOKE. By John Lehmann. 178 pages. Illustrated. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $12.95.

title: EX-GOLDIN AIDE TELLS INQUIRY HE SOUGHT TO BLUNT CRITICISM OF UNION FUND
description: A former aide to City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin has said that he intervened with Mr. Goldin at the behest of a municipal laborunion president in an effort to soften criticism in a news release about the union's welfare fund, the State Commission of Investigation disclosed yesterday.

title: JAZZ CORNETIST: NAT ADDERLEY LEADS QUINTET
description: Nat Adderley, who plays cornet, is a small, compact man, quite the opposite of his older brother, the late Julian (Cannonball) Adderley, the saxophonist, who was big and expansive. Their physical characteristics are, to some extent, reflected in their playing styles - Cannonball's playing was open and soaring, while Nat tends to use lean, staccato phrases, squeezing out some notes or singing soft, shimmering phrases through a mute with an occasional crackling outburst as contrast.

title: MIDWIFE BIRTHS GAINING WIDER ACCEPTANCE
description: ''Obstetrician or nurse-midwife: It's a difficult decision,'' said Anne Kelly after a guided tour of Roosevelt Hospital's maternity ward. While a doctor might ''foist unnecessary medical procedures on you,'' a midwife might not respond well to an emergency, she said.

title: Car Makers List Layoffs
description: United States auto makers reported today that long-term layoffs will rise a bit again this week with temporary furloughs falling off.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Sammy S tewart, pitcher; Lenn Sakata, infielder; B enny Ayala and Gary Roenicke, outfield- e rs. BOSTON (AL) - Traded Fred Lynn, out- f ielder, and Steve Renko, pitcher, to C alifornia for Frank Tanana and Jim Dorsey, p itchers, and Joe Rudi, outfielder.

title: Hoffman Pleads Guilty To 1973 Drug Charge
description: Reversing an original plea of not guilty, Abbie Hoffman, the former Yippie leader, pleaded guilty yesterday to a reduced charge in connection with a 1973 drug indictment.

title: A TALE OF TWO ERAS
description: To the Editor:

title: Previous Engagement
description: Tomorrow Mary Steenburgen is scheduled to receive the award as best supporting actress from the New York Film Critics Circle for her performance in ''Melvin and Howard.''

title: A.&P. Terminates 100 Employees
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company this week terminated 100 employees of a total of 550 in its headquarters in Montvale, N.J., as part of an expense-cutting program, a spokesman said.

title: 31st Victim of Fire At Jersey Rest Home
description: An 80-year-old man has become the 31st victim of the fire Jan. 9 at the Beachview Rest Home in Keansburg.

title: BOMB SHATTERS WINDOWS IN COURTHOUSE DOWNTOWN
description: A pipe bomb exploded early yesterday afternoon in the sub-basement of the New York State Supreme Court Building in lower Manhattan, halting trial sessions and forcing out 2,000 employees, jurors, lawyers and others. There were no injuries.

title: COMPNEWS BRIEFS
description: BRIEFS

title: SCREEN: Gance's SILENT 'NAPOLEON' IS RECONSTITUTED
description: Nearly 54 years after its premiere at the Theatre de L'Opera in Paris, ''Napoleon Vu Par Abel Gance,'' now titled simply ''Napoleon,'' is being given its first New York showing in a fourhour version that approximates what Abel Gance conceived in 1927: a vision of history and cinema so brilliantly innovative, so unabashedly romantic, so huge that it reduces most motion pictures to the size and interest of shabby Soupy Sales re-runs as they might look on a 1950 television set.

title: West German Held; Had Spying Device
description: A 36-year-old West German has been arrested in New York and charged with seeking to smuggle out of the United States a sophisticated espionage device that can be used to intercept American intelligence messages and strip transmissions from United States Embassies abroad.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: '' We know that there are 10 million of us. Ten million members that should be talked to, dealt with and not split.

title: Graham Is at Ease In 2d Place
description: David Graham, a 34-year-old Australian whose accent has been a fixture of the PGA Tour for 10 years, is proud but he is no egotist. He does not mind the fact that the golf clubs he designs carry Jack Nicklaus's name. And unlike those touring pros who seek complimentary memberships in country clubs, Graham insists on paying full dues, the same as any other member.

title: COST IN NEW YORK AREA UP BY 1.3%, TO 10.9% FOR 1980
description: The cost of living rose 10.9 percent last year in the New York metropolitan area, making it the first time since World War I that there had been two consecutive years of double-digit inflation, the Federal Government announced yesterday. Prices rose 10.6 percent in 1979.

title: ASTRONAUTS CERTAIN OF SHUTTLE'S SAFETY
description: The astronauts who are to fly the first orbital test mission of the space shuttle Columbia said here today that they had confidence that the new space plane was flightworthy, despite its years of development problems, and that they would be ''140 percent trained'' by the launching day.

title: MOBIL PROPOSES 2-FOR-1 STOCK SPLIT
description: The Mobil Corporation said that its interest-free loans to its subsidiary, Montgomery Ward & Company, last year had totaled $300 million, or $100 million more than previously disclosed.

title: NEWS ORGANIZATIONS, SEEKING AN EDGE ON STORY, COURT TIES TO EX-HOSTAGES
description: When Richard I. Queen went on television Tuesday night to describe his mistreatment as a hostage in Iran, he did so under an agreement with CBS News that bars him from giving similar interviews to other television networks.

title: TIERI GETS 10-YEAR TERM FOR ROLE AS CRIME CHIEF
description: Frank (Funzi) Tieri received a 10-year sentence yesterday for his conviction as ''the boss of a family of La Cosa Nostra'' in New York City.

title: WHY MANY SHUN CITY'S SCHOOLS
description: It is no secret that the public schools have been losing for a long time. They have lost their guidance counselors and music programs, their gym teachers and supplies. But they have also lost what some say is even more fundamental to their future: much of the middle class.

title: DON'T MIND THAT LION, JUST PASS THE LOBSTER
description: For 77 years, Nairobi's Norfolk Hotel was a crossroads for early British emigrants to Africa, world travellers and hunters; for the last 17, it had been a symbol of the transition from a British colony to an independent Kenya proud of its African and European traditions. In a few horrifying seconds on New Year's Eve, Kenya lost that symbol to a bomb, planted by alleged terrorists, that destroyed the hotel, killing 20 people and injuring 85 others.

title: Judge Delays Funds for Iran
description: Saying he would not be rushed in dealing with a country that held Americans hostage for 14 months, a Federal judge today declined to permit payment of an Iranian bank's claim for $3.4 million against a major United States defense contractor.

title: ROZELLE DENIES BIAS
description: Pete Rozelle, commissioner of the National Football League, said today that he was indifferent as to which team, the Oakland Raiders or the Philadelphia Eagles, won the Super Bowl game here Sunday, and that he would feel comfortable if it turned out to be the Raiders.

title: 651 Graduate As Police Officers
description: The city gained 651 new police officers - almost half of them members of minority groups - in ceremonies at Brooklyn College that marked the graduation of the second class of police officers since the 1975 hiring freeze.

title: ABC'S VETERAN COMEDIES AFFLICTED BY A SHARP DROP IN POPULARITY
description: For all the attention focused on the continuing problems at NBC-TV, it is actually ABC-TV that has been suffering the sharpest drop in its prime-time audience-popularity ratings this season. The very shows that helped catapult ABC into first place in the ratings four years ago - most of them half-hour situation comedies - are suffering the most dramatic attrition.

title: WALDHEIM DEFENDS HOSTAGE ROLE
description: Secretary General Kurt Waldheim yesterday defended his role in seeking the release of the American hostages in Iran, after his efforts were criticized on an ABC television program.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: FOOD CAN BE A STRUGGLE IN ANGOLA
description: A drive around this sprawling city any morning makes a visitor immediately aware of Angola's No. 1 problem: the distribution of food. There are lines outside the supermarkets waiting for the doors to open at 10 A.M. Some have been there since the midnight-to-6 A.M. curfew ended.

title: IRONIES IN THE ATTACK ON BERNADETTE DEVLIN
description: To the Editor:

title: M.P. SLAIN BY SONS OF SUCCESSOR, ISRAEL SAYS
description: The national police said today that the Jan. 12 shooting of a Bedouin Member of Parliament was carried out by three sons of the Druse sheik who inherited the dead man's legislative seat.

title: Mormons Say Eldridge Cleaver's Planning to Convert
description: The spiritual odyssey of Eldridge Cleaver now seems to be taking him toward becoming a Mormon. In the 1960's, Mr. Cleaver was a fiery activist in the Black Panthers and wrote the best seller ''Soul on Ice.''

title: Rate Cut Cited On Ecuador Oil
description: Ecuador, a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, was reported yesterday to have sold a substantial amount of crude oil at nearly $3 a barrel below its official export price.

title: Libya Tells France to Pull Its Troops Out of Africa
description: Libya demanded today that France withdraw its troops from Africa and said that the former French colony of Chad joined in the demand.

title: Auction Surprise
description: Follow-up: Earlier this week, it was reported that a handwritten letter by President Reagan, in which he defended his friendship with Frank Sinatra, would be sold at auction and was expected to bring as much as $3,000.

title: Soviet Carrier in Mediterranean
description: The Soviet Union's huge new aircraft carrier Kiev has returned to the Mediterranean from the Atlantic for the first time in about nine months, Pentagon sources said today. The 40,000-ton Kiev is rated as one of the world's greatest warships. The Pentagon officials say they did not know whether the Kiev would stay in the Mediterranean or go to its Black Sea base.

title: Philip Glass Will Present Retrospective of His Music
description: Philip Glass will present a four-concert retrospective of his music composed for his own ensemble Feb. 12-15 at Town Hall. The programs include two complete concert performances of the opera Mr. Glass created with Robert Wilson, ''Einstein on the Beach,'' Feb. 12 and 15 at 8 P.M., with a chorus and Paul Zukofsky, solo violinist.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 20.00 20.00 15.25 DISCOUNT RATE* 13.00 13.00 12.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 18.50 19.05 14.00 3-MO. TREASURY BILLS 15.50 15.70 12.30 6-MO. TREASURY BILLS 14.50 14.69 11.97 TREASURY NOTES 12.70 12.87 11.08 TREASURY BONDS 12.23 12.34 10.95 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 13.20 13.36 11.85 MUNICIPAL BONDS 10.50 10.50 7.92 6-MONTH SAVINGS 14.721 CERTIFICATES * Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Now, the Right Court for Ma Bell
description: For legal historians it was a bit of an anticlimax. More than six years after charges were filed, but just two days into the trial, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Federal Government reached a tentative settlement of the biggest antitrust case ever brought.

title: End to World Population Growth Urged by Audubon Society Chief
description: An end to world population growth after the population reaches eight billion in the next century is the most crucial step to improving the quality of life in developing nations, the president of the National Audubon Society said yesterday.

title: GETTING THINGS STRAIGHT
description: I F you are planning to rent an apartment, get married, have a baby, hire a lawyer, consult a doctor or enter a hospital, you might appreciate some plain advice. Plaintext is a new venture trying to fill that need and provide legal documents for agreements.

title: Zaire Expels 7 Belgian Reporters
description: Seven Belgian journalists have been expelled from Zaire, where they were compiling a series of reports at the invitation of President Mobutu Sese Seko, a spokesman for Belgian television said today. He said that no reason had been given for the expulsion but noted that it had followed a request by a film crew to visit an area near Zaire's border with Tanzania.

title: VERMEIL HAS STERN VIEW ON CURFEWS
description: If John Matuszak, whose curfew violation saw him skip out of his hotel room and go dancing at 3 o'clock Thursday morning, had been a Philadelphia Eagle, he would have been sent home by now, Coach Dick Vermeil said today.

title: Jerseyan Indicted In PATH Slaying
description: JERSEY CITY (AP) - A 21-year-old Irvington man was indicted in the slaying of a Port Authority police officer at a PATH station on Dec. 22.

title: TWO JURIES WEIGH MEXICANS' CHARGES
description: Opening statements started this afternoon in the retrial of Thomas Hanigan and his brother Patrick, the Arizona ranchers accused of robbing and torturing three Mexicans who crossed their ranch adjoining the border in 1976.

title: PRESS IS PRIMARY TARGET OF SECURITY AT WIESBADEN
description: On the surface, security around the United States Military Hospital here where the 52 freed hostages are being examined looks as if terrorists were loose in the West German countryside.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SINGER'S TALE

title: House Gets Proposal for Medals To Honor Hostages as Heroes
description: Legislation was introduced in the House yesterday to honor as heroes the Americans who suffered long captivity in Iran and to award them Congressional gold medals.

title: 2 GET $500,000 IN DIAMONDS IN HOLDUP ON W. 47TH ST.
description: Two masked men, one brandishing a pistol, held up a diamond merchant in his office in the jewelry district in midtown yesterday and escaped with $500,000 to $1 million in uncut stones, the police said.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12. 1. At 11:57 A.M. on Tuesday, Ronald Reagan took the oath as the 40th President of the United States; at 12:25 P.M., 52 Americans took off from the airport at Teheran after 444 days of captivity.

title: LONDON TIMES SAYS BID BY MURDOCH OFFER SECURITY
description: The Times of London explained today that Rupert Murdoch, the publisher of The New York Post, had been chosen to be its new owner because he offered the paper the best chance of becoming financially successful while preserving its editorial independence and journalistic excellence.

title: Quake Strikes China, Killing at Least 100 People
description: A major earthquake struck a mountainous area of Sichuan Province near Tibet today, knocking down many buildings and killing at least 100 people, the seismological bureau in the region reported.

title: CONNECTICUT ASSEMBLY UNIT VOTES TO CUT GRANTS TO CITIES
description: With the help of Republicans, Gov. William A. O'Neill's proposal to eliminate $23.8 million in state grants to Connecticut's cities and towns was approved today by the General Assembly's Appropriations Committee.

title: COASTAL CREATURE
description: ''Blood Beach'' is a cut or two above the recent run of low-budget horror films. In fact, the work of an attractive and professional cast, a rarity in the genre, is undermined by plodding direction and a talky and incoherent script that is short on action, suspense and even the gore that the title promises.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Sign & Indicator is offering $25 million of 15 percent subordinated debentures due Jan. 15, 2001, at a price of 88.67 percent to yield 17 percent, to be managed by a Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. group.

title:
Patents;
Pedal-Plane Inventor Honored
description: WASHINGTON PAUL B. MacCREADY of Pasadena, Calif., has been named Inventor of the Year for his pedal-operated planes patented last June. His Gossamer Condor and Gossamer Albatross won substantial British prizes for man-powered flights, including one across the English Channel, and his Gossamer Condor is on permanent display at the Smithsonian Institution.

title: BENCHING OF BRANCH UNLIKELY
description: Tom Flores, the Oakland Raiders' coach, said at his news conference today that John Matuszak would start at defensive end in Super Bowl XV on Sunday despite having broken curfew Wednesday night.

title: TWICE WINNER OF PULITZER PRIZE
description: Samuel Barber, the American composer who twice won the Pulitzer Prize and whose Adagio for Strings became one of the most popular works in the orchestral repertoire, died yesterday in his Fifth Avenue apartment after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: BONN PLAYED KEY ROLE IN OPENING WAY TO HOSTAGE TALKS
description: Foreign Minister Hans Dietrich Genscher and other West German officials played a significant role in paving the way for release of the 52 Americans held hostage by Iran, it was disclosed here today.

title: Woman Scores Record 70 Points
description: Annette Kennedy, a junior guard, scored 70 points tonight, setting a women's college basketball record as she led the State University of New York at Purchase to a 116-21 victory over Pratt Institute.

title: Salvatore Bonanno Sought On California Theft Charges
description: A bench warrant was out today for Salvatore Bonanno, son of Joseph Bonanno Sr., the former New York City crime figure.

title: Kennecott Gains 32.3% of Curtiss
description: The Kennecott Corporation said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had purchased on Thursday an additional 91,000 shares of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, bringing its stake in the aerospace concern to 32.3 percent. Kennecott paid about $4 million for the additional shares

title: TOWN HOUSE IS SOLD FOR $4.24 MILLION
description: A five-story, Georgian-style town house at 121 East 73d Street has been sold by Ben Heller, the art dealer, for $4.24 million as a residence and place of business to Monkton Corporation, N.V.

title: No Headline
description: Treasureria Theft Chargess Chester Bitterman, an employee opf the U.S. Summer Lang

title: U.S. IS ASSURING A CHANNEL TO FILE CLAIMS AGAINST IRAN
description: Nearly every United States company and individual with a commercial claim against Iran will have a channel to seek compensation under the hostage agreements with Iran, a State Department lawyer assured lawyers for claimants at a meeting in New York City yesterday.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $2.3 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced a $2.3 billion decline in the nation's money supply for the week ended Jan. 14, reversing a portion of the previous week's $11.4 billion increase.

title: U.N. Reports Cambodia Has Sufficient Food
description: Cambodia, gripped by famine last year, now has all the food it needs, United Nations relief officials said today.

title: WOMAN SHOT IN BROOKLYN IN CROWDED CAR ON BMT
description: An 18-year-old Brooklyn woman was wounded by gunfire, possibly from a sniper, and narrowly escaped death as she was riding a crowded rush-hour subway train bound for Manhattan yesterday afternoon.

title: THE ONLY WAY TO CURE TRAFFIC CONGESTION
description: To the Editor:

title: RARE METAL POISONING PUZZLES HEALTH AIDES AT TEXAS GULF COAST
description: The sudden appearance of up to 21 cases of poisoning by a rare metal, prohibited in consumer products since 1972, has led state health investigators to wonder how many other Gulf Coast residents may be carrying the metallic chemical in their bodies.

title: ANGELS OBTAIN LYNN FROM THE RED SOX FOR TANANA, RUDI
description: The Boston Red Sox, faced with the loss of Fred Lynn as a free agent, interrupted the star center fielder's arbitration hearing yesterday and settled his grievance by trading him to the California Angels, who promptly signed Lynn to a four-year contract.

title: Blazers Trounce Knicks, 117-90
description: The Knicks landed in a fog early this morning and played in one tonight, losing a blowout to the Trail Blazers, 117-90, New York's largest margin of defeat this season.

title: MONSANTO REPORTS LOSS; CROWN ZELLERBACH UP
description: The Monsanto Company, the nation's fourth-largest chemical concern, reported yesterday that two previously announced write-offs caused a net loss of $69.4 million in last year's fourth quarter while sales increased 7.7 percent.

title: CAREERS, MOTHERHOOD AND THE REAL WORLD
description: To the Editor:

title: STOCK PRICES OFF SLIGHTLY
description: A Government report that the inflationary spiral was increasing helped send stock prices down slightly on comparatively light volume. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had been declining all week mainly because of high interest rates, eased 0.25, to 940.19. For the latest five trading sessions the blue chip barometer lost 33.10 points.

title: 51 OF FREED HOSTAGES FLY HOME TOMORROW
description: The freed American hostages will be flown home Sunday to be reunited with their families at the United States Military Academy at West Point. Some, according to the State Department's chief medical officer, will bring with them serious psychiatric problems growing out of their 444 days of captivity.

title: Further Aid Indicated to BL
description: Another big Government subsidy aimed at propping up BL Ltd. is expected to be announced next week, sources said today.

title: SOVIET INDUSTRIAL GROWTH, HARVEST SHORT OF '80 GOAL
description: The Soviet Union today disclosed its final economic figures for 1980. The results were disappointing for the Russians in a number of areas, especially agriculture and energy. For the second consecutive year, industrial growth was less than 4 percent.

title: Unflappable Artist
description: The new Kansas City Philharmonic season was delayed for weeks because of a prolonged musicians' strike, during which the appearances of several visiting artists were canceled. Last week, however, musical peace came to Kansas City, and one of the first artists to be rebooked was the pianist Grant Johannesen.

title: ON THE NEED FOR GLOBAL NEGOTIATIONS
description: President Reagan may soon have to amend his present list of priority foreign policy decisions when his Administration is challenged in the next few weeks to join the on-going preparatory consultations for ''Global Negotiations'' now being conducted at the United Nations.

title: TEXCAN IN HOUSE OVER 3 DECADES
description: Former Representative Olin E. Teague, noted for his leadership in veterans' affairs and the nation's space program, died Friday at the Bethesda Naval Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: READERS SHARE GOOD FORTUNE WITH NEEDIEST
description: Concern felt by the ''fortunate'' for the victims of adversity is the motivation most often mentioned by contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, now conducting its 69th annual appeal on behalf of the poor, the distressed, the lonely and the neglected.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; SALVADORAN JOURNALISTS ASK RELEASE OF 2 REPORTERS

title: COLUMBIA U.STUDENT IS CRITICALLY WOUNDED ON MORNINGSIDE DRIVE
description: A Columbia University student was critically wounded late last night during a robbery outside his apartment building near the Columbia campus on Manhattan's Upper West Side, the police said.

title: Virgin Isles Vacation for Carters
description: Former President Jimmy Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, will fly Tuesday to the United States Virgin Islands to begin a vacation of two to three weeks, their spokesman said today. The Carters delayed their vacation until a week after the President left office, allowing him to travel to West Germany to greet the American hostages who had been in Iran, and to give the Carters' daughter, Amy, time to enroll in her new school near Plains.

title: HONEYWELL TO RAISE COMPUTER CHARGES
description: Honeywell Inc. will increase rental and leasing charges for its large and medium-sized computers by 7 to 10 percent, the company said yesterday. Prices for most other computer products and services, except minicomputers, will rise by 5 to 20 percent.

title: Bridge: Accurate Bids Not Always The Best Course to Follow
description: Most textbooks on bridge assume that the accurate bid is always the right bid, but this is not so. A slight underbid is recommended if your partner generally underplays and is about to be declarer. Conversely, a modicum of aggression is acceptable if your partner happens to be one of the country's best dummy-players.

title: Japan-Canada Coal Deal Set
description: A multibillion-dollar contract to sell northeastern British Columbia coal to Japanese steel interests will be formally signed in Tokyo on Sunday, the provincial government announced today.

title: Ecuador Sends Peru a Protest
description: Ecuador has protested to Peru over an incident in which it says a Peruvian helicopter fired on an Ecuadorean border post, seriously injuring a soldier, the Foreign Ministry said.

title: REAGAN'S ECONOMIC ECHO
description: Just 17 months ago Murray Weidenbaum, who had already done two stints in the Federal Government, told an interviewer, ''I think my Government service is behind me, but I think I have some potential as a kibitzer.'' Today the 53-year-old economics professor, a native New Yorker, was appointed chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. What changed his mind?

title: Man Gets Life Term For a 1954 Murder
description: Rudolph John Hoff of Freeport, L.I., who was convicted last month of a murder committed 26 years ago, has been sentenced to life imprisonment by Judge Robert W. Doyle in Suffolk County Court.

title: Norway '80 Oil Output Up
description: Norway increased crude oil output by about 30 percent in 1980, to 490,000 barrels a day from 375,000 barrels a day in 1979, the Petroleum Directorate said today. A barrel contains 42 gallons.

title: JUSTICE MINISTER IN BONN IS ELECTED WEST BERLIN MAYOR
description: The West German Justice Minister was elected Mayor of West Berlin today. The choice of Hans-Jochen Vogel was seen here as proof of the seriousness with which the Bonn Government viewed the political situation in West Berlin after the surprise resignation last week of Mayor Dietrich Stobbe and his entire Social @Democratic-Free Democratic cabinet.

title: Seamen Continue Strikes At British Ports
description: Strikes in British ports caused widespread disruption today and left residents of the Shetland Islands cut off from the mainland and short of food and other essentials.

title: AMOCO RISES
description: Evidence mounted yesterday that the earnings of oil companies for the fourth calendar quarter of 1980 would be rather undistinguished, as Texaco Inc. reported earnings declines from levels a year earlier and the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), whose brand name is Amoco, announced a slight increase.

title: N.B.A. Rejects Canadian Bid
description: A proposal to expand the National Basketball Association into Canada was rejected ''at this time'' by the league's expansion committee today.

title: News Analysis
description: In the Senate debate last night over the nomination of James G. Watt as Secretary of the Interior, Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio took the floor and declared, ''I want to send a message to Mr. Watt -that we'll be watching.''

title: STATE AIRLINE MIRRORS BRITISH ILLS
description: Less than a year ago hopes were high that British Airways, the state-owned airline, would be traded on the stock market in 1981. But those hopes seemed dashed last week when the company went to the Government asking for a $200 million increase in its borrowing power simply to get through to the end of its fiscal year on March 31.

title: CHARTING A JUDICIAL PEDIGREE
description: One of the most sensitive prerogatives facing an incoming President is his selection of Federal judges. But while all agree that the President's appointments to the Federal bench are among his most important functions, few have articulated what characteristics he should seek in his nominees.

title: Index; International
description: U.S. welcomes Seoul's pardon of opposition chief 3 West German Justice Minister is elected Mayor of West Berlin 3 Some freed hostages are said to have problems adjusting 4 Mother of former hostage is angry at U.S. handling of crisis 4 West Point prepares welcome for ex-hostages 4 U.S. protests to Soviet again about reports on hostage issue 5 Security for freed hostages is tight, but news gets out 5 Bonn played a key role in openning way to hostage talks 6 Iran says former U.S. Embassy to be used to care for injured 6 Waldheim denies ABC charge he mishandled hostage talks 6 News organizations use ties with families for better coverage 7 Various gifts are being offered to the former hostages 7 Iran rebuffs Islamic delegation's appeal to attend conference 8 Around the World 8 Reporter's Notebook: Shortages of food and personnel in Angola 9 Government/Politics Reagan is urged to retain sanctions against Soviet 8 Testimony ends in the court-martial of Pfc. Robert Garwood 16 Assembly panel backs Gov. O.'
