Teague, Texas Congressman for 32 years 16 Sports Walker last in sprint debut 18 Red Sox send Lynn to Angels, get Rudi and Tanana 19 Vermeil takes stern attitude toward any curfew violators 19 Branch a likely starter despite missing practice 19 Dave Anderson on the other Super Bowl owner 19 Rozelle plays no favorite despite conflict with Davis 19 Webster and the weather aid Knicks in clutch 20 Celtics win 11th straight 20 David Graham feels at ease in second place in Phoenix golf 20 Super Bowl Notebook 20 Nordiques game tonight is Bossy's final shot at Richard record 21 Features/Notes Going Out Guide 13 Saturday News Quiz 17 About New York 26 Man in the News: Murray Weidenbaum, top economic adviser 29 Notes on People 46 News Analysis Steven V. Roberts on the Cabinet confirmation process 10 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: MASSEY IS REHIRING 215 IN U.S.
description: With a survival plan coming into place and the demand for tractors apparently rising, Massey-Ferguson is recalling workers who have been laid off for months at United States and Canadian factories.

title: WALESA URGES POLES TO STAGE A BOYCOTT OF THEIR JOBS TODAY
description: As the Soviet Union stepped up pressure against Poland today and Warsaw was crippled by a four-hour strike, Lech Walesa issued an appeal for members of Solidarity, the independent trade union organization, not to work tomorrow.

title: Davis, Yank Relief Pitcher, Agrees to a One-Year Pact
description: Ron Davis, the No. 2 man to Rich Gossage in the Yankee bull pen, agreed yesterday to sign a one-year contract that would more than double his salary of $80,000.

title: CAREERS, MOTHERHOOD AND THE REAL WORLD
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. APPLAUDS SEOUL FOR SPARING OPPOSITION LEADER
description: The United States welcomed today the decision by President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea to commute to life imprisonment the death sentence imposed last fall on Kim Dae Jung, the opposition political leader.

title: TIGHT SECURITY FOR A TROPHY
description: The National Football League has a security force here numbering 250 in and around its headquarters at the Hyatt Regency Hotel, across from the Louisiana Superdome. The most carefully guarded object is the trophy that will be presented to the winning team in a ceremony immediately after Sunday's Super Bowl game.

title: KOCH REPORTS THAT HAIG IS SKEPTICAL ON A PARADE
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. told Mayor Koch that he did not believe many of the freed American hostages were ''psychologically ready'' for the ticker-tape parade city officials had planned, Mr. Koch said yesterday.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: It's the end of a work day and Mayor Koch is slumped comfortably in an armchair in his City Hall office brimming over with talk about his recent trip to Israel and Egypt.

title: 3 EXPERTS REBUT MEDICAL FINDING AT HARRIS TRIAL
description: Three defense pathologists took the stand in the murder trial of Jean S. Harris today to confirm what three other defense pathologists had said earlier - that they could not identify fragments of tissue in Dr. Herman Tarnower's chest wound as having come from the doctor's palm.

title: PRICES UP 1.1% FOR DECEMBER, 12.4% FOR 1980
description: The Consumer Price Index, continuing to climb sharply, rose by 1.1 percent in December, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 27. 1. Two momentous events occurred 28 minutes apart. Explain.

title: FORMER HOSTAGE SAYS SOME OF THE 52 WOULD NOT VIEW TAPES OF TAKEOVER
description: Bruce W. German, one of the freed hostages, said today that some of his colleagues were having more problems than others in adjusting. ''They showed us videotapes of the embassy takeover,'' he said, ''and some of the group simply would not look at them.''

title: No Headline
description: ANOTHER BODY FOUND BY ATLANTA POLICE: Police officer standing guard at a roadblock outside Atlanta yesterday near the area where police found the body of another young black boy. For 18 months police have been searching for clues in the deaths of thirteen black children in the Atlanta area. However, authorities said the youngster found yesterday was not one of three other children still listed as missing .

title: Bossy Taking Last Shot at Richard Record
description: With 48 goals in 49 games, Mike Bossy has one more opportunity to catch Maurice (Rocket) Richard, who scored 50 goals in 50 National Hockey League games 36 seasons ago. That chance comes tonight at Nassau Coliseum, where Bossy and the Islanders will play their 50th game.

title: Mobil Increases Gasoline 2
description: The Mobil Corporation, the nation's second-largest oil company, yesterday announced a nationwide 2-cent-a-gallon increase in wholesale gasoline prices.

title: JUDGE IN KELLY TRIAL SAYS JURORS WILL GET ABSCAM CASE MONDAY
description: Jury deliberations in the bribery trial of former Representative Richard Kelly and two co-defendants will begin next Monday, Federal District Judge William B. Bryant said tonight.

title: IN JOUYOUS MOOD, FAMILIES PREPARE FOR HOMECOMING
description: With almost uncontainable joy, the families of the freed Americans prepared yesterday to go to West Point for the reunion tomorrow that has been more than 14 months in coming.

title: STAGE: 'MACBETH' RETURNS
description: To put it simply, there can be no ''Macbeth'' without Macbeth. Such is the sad case with the Lincoln Center Theater Company's production of the play, which opened Thursday night. The evening is by no means without its incidental merits. Sarah Caldwell, the director, has conceived a commanding physical production that at times solves the problems of the Vivian Beaumont's vast stage. Her supporting cast is often outstanding, and Shakespeare's text rings through the huge auditorium with nary a word lost. But without a Macbeth, the audience might just as well go home. Miss Caldwell has erected a gargantuan theatrical contraption only to leave out the motor that would make it fly.

title: Military Sales: New York Is 2d
description: The state of New York received the secondlargest amount in military procurement contracts in the nation during the fiscal year that ended last Sept. 30, the Pentagon said today.

title: CONRAIL ON MORE OF ITS OWN STEAM
description: To the Editor:

title: VOLUNTEERS SEEK TO SET DEEP-DIVING PRESSURE MARK
description: Three volunteers entered a pressure chamber at Duke University in Durham, N.C., yesterday to start a 36-day simulated dive that may reach a pressure equivalent to that at 2,250 feet under water, a new world record.

title: WEST POINT PREPARING FOR EX-HOSTAGES
description: Harvey Gledhill of Coldenham, N.Y., was painting a large ''Welcome Home'' sign at the Stewart Airport today while, inside the terminal building, excited staff members tied yellow ribbons to their sweaters.

title: HOW NOT TO WASTE OUR WASTE WATER
description: To the Editor:

title: PANEL URGES PRESIDENT TO MAINTAIN ECONOMIC SANCTIONS AGAINST SOVIET
description: A panel of experts on Soviet-American relations recommended today that the Reagan Administration maintain economic sanctions against the Soviet Union until there is progress on disputes involving Afghanistan and Poland.

title: No Headline
description: IRAN SAYS FORMER U.S. EMBASSY WILL BECOME CENTER FOR DISABLED

title: TESTIMONY ENDS IN GARWOOD CASE
description: Testimony in the court-martial of Pfc. Robert Garwood of the Marine Corps concluded today. As the 10-week-old trial neared its end, psychiatric experts testified for the Government and defense.

title: Wrong Signals to Central America
description: Of the legacies of the Carter Administration, surely the sloppiest is its policy in El Salvador. The decision, in its last days, to resume the shipment of combat weapons to a besieged and divided junta made a hash of whatever political objectives Washington once had there. Now the Reagan Administration has added to the confusion by halting economic aid to Nicaragua because its regime is allegedly aiding the rebel forces in El Salvador.

title: Georgia High Court Backs Mandatory Caesarean
description: The Georgia Supreme Court ruled unanimously late today to let stand a lower court's ruling that Jessie Mae Jefferson must submit, despite her religious objections, to an operation to save the life of her unborn child.

title: CHRYSLER UP 13%
description: Domestic new-car sales in mid-January fell 8.8 percent from the comparable period in 1980, the nation's major auto makers reported today. The Chrysler Corporation, meanwhile, posted a gain for the period.

title: No Headline
description: Talking Businesswith William R. Dill of N.Y.U. U.S. Course For Chinese

title: Day to Honor Hostages Backed
description: The House today gave final Congressional approval to a resolution declaring Thursday as a day of thanksgiving to honor the returned hostages.

title: Sunday Obverver; THE DECLINE OF MANNERS
description: BAKER COLUMN adv25/ OBSERVER:The Decline of Manners/ By RUSSELL BAKER/

title:
On The Isle;
DOCUMENTARY MAKER
description: The New Community Cinema's Independent Film Maker Series is focusing on Jill Godmilow today, and the documentary maker who created ''Antonia: Portrait of the Woman'' will discuss how she got started in films and developed her skills. She will illustrate her talk with her new video work on the folk singer Richard Dyer-Bennet and part of her film on the sculptor Louise Nevelson. The seminar will take place at 3 P.M. at the cinema, 423 Park Avenue, Huntington, and admission is for members and film students, $6.50. Information: 423-7619.FREE SAMPLE

title: LEADERS OF 37 NATIONS AND P.L.O. TO OPEN TALKS TODAY
description: Leaders of 37 Moslem nations and the Palestine Liberation Organization converged on this resort city today for tomorrow's opening of the Islamic summit conference, which is expected to focus on collective action against Israel.

title: Robert Lawrence Lane Fiance of Mary P. Guck
description: Dr. and Mrs. John Kelly Guck of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, and Quogue, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Patricia Guck, to Robert Lawrence Lane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Lane of Oradell, N.J.

title: THUROW AND WAGES
description: To the Business Editor: The tongue-in-cheek recommendation to cut wages 4 percent, half to compensate for productivity losses, is too restrained. Not just wages, but also salaries will have to be pared.

title: CONGRESS PLAYS PARTY GAMES BY
description: COMMITTEE By MARTIN TOLCHIN

title: DEMOCRATS IN SEARCH OF IDEAS
description: 4,747 words Tom Wicker writes The New York Times's ''In the Nation'' column twice weekly. By Tom Wicker Campaigning for re-election last year in a South Dakota supermarket, George S. McGovern met two elderly women who said they would vote against him because he was too liberal. Then he watched them pay for their groceries with food stamps - the fruits of a liberal Democratic program that no one had supported more vigorously than he.

title: HOSTAGE SETTLEMENT, POINT AND COUNTERPOINT
description: * To the Editor:

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: Fordham 70, Fairfield 61
description: Tony Foust and Dud Tongal scored 18 points each to help Fordham overcome an early Fairfield lead and defeat the Stags, 70-61, Saturday night at the Rams' gym.

title: Long Island Journal
description: Since 1892 the Village of Freeport has had a part-time mayor, a situation that could change if the residents decide in a March 17 election to approve a full-time mayor with the current Mayor, William H. White, as the man for the job.

title: VICTORIES ON COURT ADD ZEST AT UCONN
description: THERE are moments when Prof. Richard Norgaard thinks that he is back in the Big 10, where sports loom large in campus life. ''That's odd because when I joined the faculty at the University of Connecticut I realized that the atmosphere wasn't at all like it was in the Midwest when I was at Minnesota or, for that matter, when I was at Southern California or Texas,'' he said the other day. ''Everything was very loose here.''

title: Pamela Witte Sets Nuptials
description: Pamela Lee Witte, a candidate for a master's degree in clinical nutrition at Cornell University, and Robert Childress Beck, a candidate for a Master of Business Administration degree at Dartmouth College, plan to be married in August.

title: JAZZ ON CAMPUS: IT'S JUMPIN'
description: IN THE 1950's, Dave Brubeck took his quartet to a number of college campuses and recorded the satisfying results in a series of albums, the title of one being ''Jazz Goes to College.''

title: TRUDEAU IS JOUSTING WITH INTELLECTUALS
description: Almost 20 years ago a leading Montreal lawyer, teacher and essayist by the name of Pierre Elliott Trudeau declared war on most of his fellow Quebec intellectuals by accusing them of betraying their vocation. Today the battle flags have been raised once again as Mr. Trudeau, now Prime Minister, in defending his effort to obtain a new constitution for Canada, finds himself embroiled in particularly bitter polemics with some of Quebec's leading thinkers.

title: Elizabeth M. Blair Fiancee of Stephen Jones
description: Mr. and Mrs. William D. Blair Jr. of Chevy Chase, Md., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Mason Blair, to Stephen Rowe Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin H. Jones Jr. of Darien, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title:
Dining Out;
A SMALL PLACE FOR THE TRIED AND TRUE
description: SQUEEZED almost from view in a corner of the Station Shopping Mall in Tuckahoe, Mamma Assunta is a homey place popular with neighborhood diners who come for their tried-and-true favorites. The main dining room has only about a dozen tables; a few others in a screened-off private room take care of the overflow. In a restaurant this small, a single waiter can handle all the orders except at the most critical moments, and so Mamma Assunta's waiter, Giovanni Bucci, once of the Republic of San Marino, exerts by his extremely efficient presence a primary influence on the tone of the place. He makes it seem very Italian, in the style of establishments in towns off the main tourist routes, small palces that are nevertheless very proud of being ristorantes rather than mere tavernas.

title: ARTHUR SIEGEL'S SURPRISING SONGS
description: Arthur Siegel is a songwriter, although not a widely-known songwriter. His best-known songs are a pair he wrote with June Carroll for ''New Faces of 1952'' - the catchy ''Love is a Simple Thing'' and ''Monotonous,'' which is more apt to be associated with Eartha Kitt, who sang it, than with Arthur Siegel.

title: Cynthia Callachan Bride Of Dr. Harold Bornstein
description: Cynthia Ewing Callachan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Callachan of Pine Orchard, Conn., and Dr. Harold Nelson Bornstein, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jacob Bornstein of New York were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. John W. Vannorsdall, the Protestant chaplain of Yale University, officiated.

title: THUROW AND WAGES
description: To the Business Editor: Professor Thurow's major contribution in his book ''The Zero-Sum Society'' was that he challenged all of us to face squarely the issue of how income losses were to be allocated when increased energy prices or other unavoidable circumstances reduced aggregate income.

title: IN AFTERMATH OF IRANIAN DEAL, REAGAN FACES SHARP DILEMMA
description: WASHINGTON THE advice to Ronald Reagan from Jimmy Carter was roughly put for the man who had counseled calmness and restraint during the long months of tortuous negotiations to free the 52 American hostages in Iran. Abide by the agreement, he said, ''but never do any favors for the hoodlums who persecuted innocent American heroes.''

title: LINKAGE IN AFRICA
description: What hints there have been of the Reagan Administration's likely outlook toward black Africa suggest, not surprisingly, an emphasis on stability. America will keep supporting Robert Mugabe's effort to hold Zimbabwe on course. It will try to prevent economic collapse in Zaire. It will work to maintain improved relations with Nigeria, the economic giant of the region, with its new civilian government.

title: Kathleen Brady to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard M. Brady Jr. of North Arlington, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Brady, to Craig D. Moore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard E. Moore of Upper Montclair, N.J. Miss Brady is a sportswear buyer with Hahne & Company in Newark, a division of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation. Her fiance is a sales representative with the Moore Equipment and Engineering Company, Bloomfield, N.J., manufacturers' representatives, of which his father is president.

title: Dance View; THE APPEALING HARLEM TROUPE
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem has had so remarkable a season at the City Center that a closer look at the entire enterprise is in order. Some of the Balanchine ballets were danced on the highest level and the season's programming has come up with real winners. Frederic Franklin's revival and new production of ''Scheherazade'' was an artistic and public success and the standard of dancing this season in his production of the one-act ''Swan Lake'' was so improved over last year's first performances that the difference was astounding. Add the fascination of Roystoon Maldoom's eccentric but inventive modern-dance works, the pleasure of a revival of John Taras's 1948 ''Designs with Srings,'' the unexpected beauty of Geoffrey Holder's ethnic piece, ''Bele,'' and you have many highlights.

title: SYRACUSE CONQUERS ST. JOHN'S BEFORE 23,913
description: Erich Santifer and Danny Schayes combined for 30 points as Syracuse rallied and upset St. John's, 79-71, tonight before 23,913, the largest crowd to watch a collegiate basketball game on a college campus.

title: CANDY FOLLOWS A TRADITION
description: MOUNT KISCO IN a sparse kitchen, on a four-burner gas stove with only one large heavy stockpot and a long wooden spoon, Guy Pietrobono cooks gallons of honey with pounds of walnuts and certain unnamed spices in pursuit of his career as a candymaker. For the last three years the 28-yearold Mr. Pietrobono has been the head chef, chief dishwasher, president, secretary, treasurer, mail boy and, ''best of all,'' according to Mr. Pietrobono, ''head taste tester of Filomena's candy.''

title: ONE WHO STOOD UP
description: ALL FALL DOWN One Man Against the Waterfront Mob. By Donald Goddard. 312 pp. New York: Times Books. $12.95. By EVAN HUNTER

title: MUSIC: CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: The most interesting way to be lost in a composition is to be guided into confusion by the music itself. The sounds, floating in space, feint and swerve into unexpected regions as foundations are pulled away. Surprise and wit, suspense and nostalgia, are the results of such play.

title: PITTSBURGH TO OPEN $40 MILLION CONVENTION CENTER
description: Industrial and scientific exhibits, a convocation of 21 Nobel laureates and an exhibition of international art will highlight the opening of a $40 million convention and exposition center Feb. 7-15.

title: Westchester Housing; TENANTS AND LANDLORDS IN FUEL BATTLE
description: DURING the recent cold spell, Wilbur Tucker's Mount Vernon apartment got so chilly, he said, that it was impossible to sit in his living room and watch television. Instead, he'd ''pile on five or six blankets and go to bed.''

title: REDS SIGN HUME, PITCHER
description: Tom Hume, a relief pitcher, has agreed to a one-year contract with the Cincinnati Reds for the coming season, the Reds' president, Dick Wagner, said today.

title: SAVING JOBS BY CUTTING WAGES
description: CHICAGO C HRYSLER'S production workers, now in the process of voting on a package of $622 million in pay cuts, face an excruciating decision in determining whether to ''give back'' wages and benefits negotiated in previous contracts. But they need not feel alone in their agony.

title: About Long Island
description: I thought of something, all of a sudden. ''Hey, listen,'' I said. ''You know those ducks in that lagoon right near Central Park South? That little lake? By any chance, do you happen to know where they go, the ducks, when it gets all frozen over? Do you happen to know, by any chance?'' I realized it was only one chance in a million.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: MEXICO SUBWAYS(CONT'D)
description: To the Editor:

title: VINTAGE SPEECH BY REAGAN, AND MORE MELLOW FOR FOR THE EVENT
description: WASHINGTON SIXTEEN years and a huge difference in circumstance separate the two nationally televised speeches that are the major mileposts of President Ronald Reagan's political career. On October 27, 1964, Mr. Reagan spoke on behalf of a Republican Presidential candidate and a hardline philosophy that was about to be repudiated at the polls. On Tuesday, Mr. Reagan delivered his inaugural address as the 40th President of the United States, who, in the hopes of his supporters, can bring a new era of conservative dominance to American politics.

title:
NEW JERSEY HOUSING;
HOME PRICES - HIGH, MEDIUM AND LOW
description: SOMEWHERE in Somerville, an imaginary three-bedroom house is being built for $56,900, while at the same time its counterpart in Morristown is being constructed for $63,400. For real bargains, however, one's attention is directed to the Jersey City-Bayonne area, where an imaginary home is being built for $44,000, or to Asbury Park, where it is being erected for $51,500.

title: Critics' Choice
description: DANCE This is a week for strong performers. Topping the list is David Gordon, a leading avant-garde choreographer who will appear with his Pick Up Company at the American Theater Laboratory, Wedneday through Saturday at 8 and next Sunday at 3.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Skaters Waltz, But Not Everyone
description: The $4.9 million renovation of Wollman Memorial Rink in Central Park, reported last week, should please skaters, rock music promoters and park preservationists - in descending order of enthusiasm.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: LAYERS OF HISTORY YIELD AT WHITE HOUSE
description: LAST summer Jimmy Carter -wearing a jogging outfit - cut around the corner of the White House and landed on his rump, courtesy of a sticky puddle left by the Hartford-based Rudco Air Maintenance Company.

title: POPULATION INDICATORS PROVIDE CAUSE FOR ARGUEMENT
description: With New York City complaining that the Federal census failed to count some of its residents, what would other population indicators show?

title: Dr. Paula M. Elbirt To Be Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Elbirt of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Paula Miriam Elbirt, and Dr. Adam Norman Bender, son of Dr. and Mrs. Morris B. Bender of Great Neck, L.I.

title: Study Explodes an Old Welfare Myth
description: Welfare recipients who enjoy life on government handouts seem to be more fiction than truth, at least in Massachusetts. Data released last week by the state's Department of Social Services found welfare mothers preferring to work, and often rejecting welfare status even when they qualified.

title: CABARET: SONGS BY FREDDIE COLE
description: Freddie Cole is working his way along the same musical path that his older brother, the late Nat (King) Cole, took. He started as a pianist who also sang, as Nat Cole did.

title: STUDY FINDS THAT ACID RAIN IS INTENSIFYING IN NORTHEAST
description: Acid rain and snow have intensified and spread over the Northeast and Canada in the last three decades, according to a Government task force that has mapped out the most comprehensive study yet of the phenomenon.

title: Slain Black YouthIdentified in Atlanta
description: The body of a young black boy found strangled along a road 25 miles south of Atlanta was identified today as a 15-year-old from Atlanta, the 17th black Atlanta child to disappear or be found slain in the last 18 months.

title: LET'S STOP MAKE-BELIEVE MURDER
description: THE children in our neighborhood hang from the limbs of trees, their weapons, given to them for Christmas, poised. They lie in ambush with guns trained on one another, eager to re-enact the play ritual of killing.

title: BURGLARIES INCREASE SHARPLY ON EAST END
description: TOWN police officials say burglaries have increased dramatically on the rural East End in recent months. The prime targets are gold and silver, both because of their high price and the relative ease in disposing of the loot.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There will not be a greeting party, as such, when the families arrive at Stewart Field.

title: YOUTH AND VIOLENCE: A LOK AT 4 LOST LIVES
description: Donna Piser was a wisp of a woman, 4 feet, 11 inches tall and 100 pounds, with delicate features and size-four feet. At the age of 20, her mother says, she was just becoming pretty. Less than six months after she left her family on Long Island and joined the great middle-class migration to Houston, her life had begun to flower, and the future seemed full of promise and love.

title: 'LARGEST FINANCIAL TRANSFER IN HISTORY'
description: IN the end, the complexity of the arrangement almost killed the deal to free the hostages. Officials of the former Carter Administration called it ''the largest private financial transfer in history.'' It was surely the most intricate. The round-the-clock negotiations were conducted by representatives of 12 big American banks, three governments, four central banks and hundreds of officials and lawyers in Washington, New York, London, Algiers and Teheran.

title: Melinda Williams Married to John H. Davis
description: Melinda Wallace Williams, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Carrington Williams Jr. of Irvington, Va., and John H. Davis, son of Mrs. Chester Barnet Davis of Lincoln, Ill., and the late Dr. Davis, were married yesterday. The Rev. Reno S. Harp performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Richmond.

title: CHIMNEY FOR A HEAD? PREPOSTEROUS!
description: THE radio-alarm roused me the other morning with this pronouncement: ''The temperature today won't climb out of the single numbers, so remember to keep your head covered. Experts say the head is like a chimney. Body heat rises and dissipates through the top of one's head. Covering said head keeps the body heat in.''

title: Antiques; THE ANCIENT GLASS TREASURES OF ISRAEL
description: Two of the finest ancient glass collections formed in this century are found not far from where much of the glass originated - at the Israel Museum in Jerusalem and at the Museum Haaretz, in Ramat-Aviv outside of Tel Aviv. Both were formed by men who became connoisseurs and deeply interested in the evolution of the material in antiquity.

title: Transit Cures
description: Two ways to ''reduce transit operating expenses while improving transit service'' were suggested to New York City in February 1980. The Natural Resources Defense Council, a private research group, said that one way was the return of trolleys to busy streets and the other the use of 60-foot-long buses jointed like trailer-trucks.

title: REBUILD THE DEOMCRATS ONE BY ONE
description: When the Democratic National Committee meets in Washington on February 26 and 27 to select a new chairman, it must also decide how it will rebuild from the wreckage of this past election.

title: Byrd, Praising Iran Pact, Also Urges 'Reflection'
description: Robert C. Byrd, the Senate minority leader, said today that the United States was honor-bound to uphold the agreement that gained freedom for the 52 American hostages, and urged ''a period of reflection and re-evaluation'' before setting new policy concerning Iran.

title: A CARD-PLAYING DEVIL
description: British celebrations honoring the 80th birthday of the Queen-Mother serveed to recall a curious legend about her family home. Visitors to Glamis castle are shown an ancient wall behind which is a sealed room. It has one small window at a high level and no door.

title: RCA PICKS CHAIRMAN AS GRIFFITH'S RESIGNS
description: The RCA Corporation announced last night that Edgar H. Griffiths, its chairman and chief executive officer, would resign on July 1 and that he would be succeeded by Thornton F. Bradshaw, president of the Atlantic Richfield Company and a member of RCA's board of directors.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
LITTLE 'PVC' HOLDERS CAN CAUSE BIG PROBLEMS
description: Little things can often do a lot of good - for example, New York City recently escaped a potentially major tragedy when a small 15-cent hardware item helped keep a propane tank truck from exploding. But, as coin collectors are learning, little things can also do a lot of harm: for instance, many coins worth thousands of dollars are being ruined these days by plastic holders worth only two or three cents.

title: Guests of The de la Rentas
description: Everyone applauds a success story (''Living Well is Still the Best Revenge,'' by Francesca Stanfill, Dec. 21).

title: SOFTENING OF RESTRICTIONS ON COAL USE MAY BE SOUGHT
description: STAMFORD IS there coal in Connecticut's future? ''There are the coal dealers who are advocating that we use coal in the abundance that Mother Nature created it, and environmental groups who say that coal should not be used at all,'' said Leonard Bruckman, director of the division of air compliance in the State Department of Environmental Protection.

title:
Gardening;
TREES, SHRUBS CAN SAVE ENERGY INDOORS
description: PLANTS play a variety of roles in the landscape. Their esthetic appeal is universally recognized. Everyone appreciates an attractive flower, a red-fruited espalier trained against a stone wall, a flowering vine clinging to a white trellis or a well-proportioned grouping of shrubs nestled against the foundation of a home.

title: Fashion; NEW SUITS WITH SURPRISE ENDINGS
description: SUITING UP FOR NEXT SPRING Now, in the midst of winter, people are apt to think longingly of spring, and women begin to ponder their first spring purchase - probably a suit. This year, many of these end unexpectedly in pants or divided skirts.

title: IN SOME JOBS, LONGER LIFE IS A HIDDEN BENEFIT
description: Symphony conductors ''enjoy superior longevity.'' Major league baseball players generally outlive their fans. Congressmen are longer-lived than their peers, as are state governors, members of the President's cabinet, Justices of the Supreme Court, New York State legislators - particularly those from upstate - corporate executives and prominent women.

title:
Antiques;
LET YOUR FEET DO THE WALKING
description: NYACK, N.Y. THE 40 or more antiques stores lining Main Street and South Broadway here offer a panorama of furniture styles in a range of prices. All the shops are within walking distance, even on a winter afternoon.

title: RETAILERS FALL BEHIND
description: Although many economists expect rocky times for retailers in 1981, an examination of figures supplied by Data Resources Inc. shows that, in the aggregate, a poor performance this year would merely continue a trend.

title:
PATERSON TAKES HEALTH CARE TO THE STREETS;
PATERSON
description: RIGHT in the heart of the downtown area, amid the begrimed factories and apartment buildings that are typical of this aging city of 150,000, stands a new municipal health center with 125 employees. The center, which cost $2 million to build three years ago, is as impressive inside as it is outside, with extensively furnished laboratories and hanging plants thriving in white, airy rooms. But what is perhaps most impressive about it cannot be seen. It is the center's aggressive approach to reaching the residents of a city where so many are ignorant about preventive-health care, or are unable to afford it.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Hooker to Clean Up One of Its Acts
description: Blamed for one of the nation's biggest environmental disasters - the contamination of Love Canal near Niagara Falls - the Hooker Chemical and Plastics Company has agreed to undertake one of the nation's biggest environmental cleanups at another chemical dump five miles away.

title: Jennifer Colagiuri Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Patrick M. Colagiuri of Upper Montclair, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Lynn Colagiuri, to Thomas John Eccles, son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Eccles of Wallingford, Conn.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
A Clutch of Designer Bags At Shoe Horn Shop
description: Coach bags, made of glove-tanned natural cowhide in limited quantities and each numbered, are prized by shoppers seeking sturdy, capacious and long-wearing handbags. One source for them is The Shoe Horn in Mamaroneck, where all merchandise is discounted on arrival, normally up to 20 percent off the manufacturer's suggested list price, with winter clearance through February cutting the cost by a minimum of another 20 percent. Men's shoes are discounted by 15 percent, now minus 20 percent again. Women's shoes are discounted up to 30 percent, and the seasonal markdown sometimes makes the discount more than 50 percent.

title: KOPELEV CALM OVER SOVIET'S BAN
description: Despite the shock that Lev. Z. Kopelev felt after Moscow's announcement on Thursday that it was stripping him of citizenship, the dissident writer said that his love for Russia was undiminished.

title: North Carolina 100 Georgia Tech 60
description: North Carolina used a swarming pressure defense and a fast-break offense to defeat Georgia Tech, 100-60, in an Atlantic Coast Conference game today.

title: Manfred Brotherton, 81, A Physicist and Writer
description: Manfred Brotherton, a physicist and writer who specialized in making technological concepts understandable for laymen, died Friday of a heart ailment at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital.

title: Kathryn Dolan Fleming Fiancee of Phillip Suse
description: Eugene D. Fleming of Ann Arbor, Mich., and Vera Fleming of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Dolan Fleming, to Philip J. Suse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Suse of Springfield, Mass. A September wedding is planned in St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Guerrillas Regroup As Carter Switches On Salvador Arms
description: The ''final offensive'' of Salvadoran guerrillas against the civilian-military junta has turned out to be just another bloody chapter in that country's civil strife. But it did provide a justification for increased United States military and economic aid to the junta that blurred the distinction between the outgoing Carter Administration's policy toward Central America and the Reagan Administration's pre-inaugural rhetoric.

title: DEFENSE COSTS
description: To the Business Editor: ''Why Defense Costs So Much'' (Jan. 11) did not mention one procurement practice concerning the Buy American strictures of the Defense Appropriations Act. These virtually exclude imports from defense procurement of textiles and food, and from business procurement of specialty metals used in products purchased by defense agencies.

title: Elisabeth Luce to Wed May 23
description: Mrs. Ralph E. Howe of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Peter P. Luce of Boulder, Colo., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elisabeth Root Luce, to John J. Hagenbuch, son of Mr. and Mrs. David B. Hagenbuch of North Caldwell, N.J. A May 23 wedding is planned in Cold Spring Harbor.

title: Wine; TASTING CHABLIS AT IT'S CELEBRATED BIRTHPLACE
description: he village of Chablis is nestled in the hills 110 miles southeast of Paris, yet the distance from the capital of France seems much vaster, for Chablis is no more than a modest farming town, albeit a town with the most famous, most copied name in the entire world of wine. Travelers with an abiding interest in wine occasionally stop here, but otherwise there is no tourism, for there is little to see that is different from the rest of the Burgundy country. Driving along the rough street that passes between the whitewashed houses takes less than a minute, which somehow seems too brief for such a celebrated place.

title: SUNSHINE BOY AT 85
description: Joseph Morgenstern, director of writer development at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, is a journalist and screenwriter. By Joseph Morgenstern unch at the Hillcrest Country Club was a ritual joy for George Burns in the old days, 40 or so years ago, when the clubhouse on Pico Boulevard, across the street from 20th Century-Fox, was a modest clapboard building surrounded by corn fields. Each noontime, such Hillcrest regulars as Jack Benny, Al Jolson, Groucho and Harpo Marx, Harry, Al and Jimmy Ritz, George Jessel, Lou Holtz and Burns himself met at the Round Table, the comedians' table off in a corner of the men's grille, to nibble their whitefish and sharpen their wits on each other's stone faces. Hillcrest was exclusively Jewish in those days, in response to the anti-Semitism of early Hollywood - and it cost $300 to join. Now you don't need to be Jewish - the current roster includes Jack Lemmon and Burt Lancaster - but the membership fee has gone up to $34,000.

title: THE OTHER HILTON COMES HOME
description: I N the beginning there was Conrad N. Hilton. And he came out of Texas after World War II to create the hotel empire that bears his name. In 1964 the empire was divided. The hotels overseas were grouped into a separate company, and that company, Hilton International, was sold to Trans World Airlines in 1967.

title: TV View; BUSINESSLIKE VS. HOMESPUN IN THE EARLY MORNING
description: Television comes its closest to functioning as an appliance during the prime early-morning hours, when ''The Today Show'' and ''Good Morning America'' hold sway. Anyone watching these programs is probably doing other things as well; this is the time of day when the audience is least likely to be sitting still. So, television, which in the evening can hope to hold the viewer's full attention, must settle in the morning for a fleeting, collaborative role. The best it can do, along with the toaster and the coffeepot, is help send you on your way.

title: DESPITE CRY FOR CUTS, TECHNOLOGY FIRMS REMAIN BULLISH
description: DESPITE recent predictions by major industrial and Government figures of a reduction in Federal funds for science research, optimism is still being voiced about the future of high technology on the Island.

title: SHANGRI-LA
description: To the Editor:

title: MARTINA NAVRATILOVA, MISS HANIKA IN FINAL
description: Sixth-seeded Sylvia Hanika shook off a cold to upset second-seeded Hana Mandlikova and Martina Navratilova routed JoAnne Russell to advance to the final of the $150,000 Avon Women's Tennis Championships of Cincinnati.

title: Hard Line at Small Colleges
description: To the Sports Editor: The Rev. Edmund P. Joyce (''The Emphasis in Student-Athlete Should Be on Student,'' The New York Times, Jan. 4), moved me to applause. But I cannot help but reflect on a sentiment that has existed in the New England Small College Athletic Conference for years.

title: Headliners; A Couple Gives Up
description: The scene last fall, when he announced his Presidential candidacy, bespoke the depth of their estrangement.

title: No Headline
description: June Charlene Pine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Pine of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Robert Alan Neadel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Neadel of Matawan, N. J. Rabbi David Kahane performed the ceremony in the Sutton Place Synagogue. The bride's father is a public-relations counsel. Mr. Neadel is assistant to the controller of the Pathmark division of the Supermarkets General Corporation in Cranford, N. J.

title: Dining Out; STORE'S RESTAURANT SHOWS POTENTIAL
description: WILL'S PLACE, the new restaurant in Bloomingdale's, Garden City, has more style than a typical department store restaurant. It is done in rich, deep brown leather and wood brightened with brass accents for a warmly masculine pub look. The menu emphasizes delicatessen sandwiches and platters for lunch, for an early supper or, on the evenings that the store is open late, for dinner.

title: Louise A. Hutner Engaged to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. Simeon Hutner of Princeton, N.J. and Ripton, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Louise Anne Hutner, to David M. McInerney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. McInerney of Saginaw, Mich. A wedding this May is planned in Princeton.

title: Miss Peloubet Is Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Louis G. Peloubet 2d of Ridgefield, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Anne Lynn Peloubet, to Stephen Welch Potter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Potter Jr. of Providence, R.I., and Edgartown, Mass.

title: Gallery View; THE PROVOCATIVE DRAWINGS OF JASPER JOHNS
description: The exhibition of drawings by Jasper Johns at the Leo Castelli Gallery, 420 West Broadway, is by any standards a major event. It is of work done between 1970 and 1980, and in both of the main rooms of the gallery it sets up that specific vibration - irresistible to some, exasperating to others - that belongs to Johns alone.

title: EXOTIC NEW SUBSTANCES ADVANCE THE DESIGN OF THE PHONO CARTRIDGE
description: I f you are thinking of updating your sound system, there is no better place to start than the phono cartridge. Because the cartridge is so small and inconspicuous - all but hidden in the tip of the tonearm - its importance is seldom appreciated. But with the exception of the speakers, no other component so strongly influences the character of the sound you hear from your records.

title: GOOD SAMARITAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Super Ball
description: The people who bet on 444 in state lotteries the day the hostages were released are not the only ones eager to connect real-world destiny with sports. Consider the mysterious link between tonight's Superbowl and the nation's financial health. It provides a predictive rule, reported by William LeFevre, the editor of the Monday Morning Market Memo for investors. And it makes the Superbowl sound like a super crystal ball.

title: DO IT YOURSELF IS THE MESSAGE
description: THE NEXT WHOLE EARTH CATALOG Access to Tools. Edited by Stewart Brand. Illustrated. 608 pp. Sausalito, Calif.: Point/Random House. $12.50.

title: GORTON JUNIOR FIRST IN COACHES' MILE RUN
description: Steven San Antonio, a 16-year-old junior from Gorton High School in Yonkers, won the one-mile run yesterday with a time of 4 minutes 20.3 seconds in the Nassau Coaches' Association track and field meet at the 102d Engineers' Armory.

title: MALARIA RESEARCHER WORKS ON SHOESTRING
description: PISCATAWAY MALARIA ravages more people than any other disease, yet only a dozen laboratories in the world are devoted to its study. One such research facility is the comparative virology laboratory at Rutgers University's Waksman Institute of Microbiology. At its head is Dr. Karl Maramorosch, who recently won the $100,000 Wolf Prize in agriculture, the most prestigious award in that field.

title: NOTRE DAME BEATS MARYLAND BY 73-70
description: Notre Dame beat Maryland on the boards, at the foul line, on defense and, most importantly, by a final score of 73-70 today at Cole Field House.

title: PASSAIC RIVER EFFLUENT INCREASES IN DROUGHT
description: The flow of water in the Passaic River - a source of drinking supplies for about 2.2 million people under mandatory rationing in northern New Jersey - has declined so sharply recently that sewage effluent now accounts for 55 percent to 70 percent of the river's content.

title: WHEN A NEWS PRODUCER TRIES HIS HAND AT A 'DOCU-DRAMA'
description: Few types of television shows have aroused more critical concern than the ''docu-drama'' -a made-for-television motion picture ostensibly based on fact. Many such productions, the critics claim, present history through a blurred prism: They contain factual errors, invented scenes and dialogue; yet, viewers are led to believe they are witnessing a documented re-enactment of actual events.

title: HARLEM'S SCHOMBURG RESEARCH CENTER ENJOYS POPULAR BOOM IN NEW BUILDING
description: Harlem's Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, created because a teacher told pupils ''the Negro had no history,'' is settling into its new quarters and enjoying a boom.

title: ECONOMIC PROPHETS: GET OUT OF TOWN
description: ''MOST OF WHAT YOU HAVE WILL BE WIPED OUT IN THE COMING CURRENCY COLLAPSE,'' reads the big, black headline in the full-page ad in this newspaper. It goes on: ''Hyperinflation will render the dollar utterly worthless - probably within 3 years.'' The ad promotes ''The Coming Currency Collapse,'' by Jerome F. Smith, which is now a best seller with 140,000 copies in print. It followed by five weeks another full-page ad with big, black headlines: ''IN THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF THE 1980's, MOST INVESTORS WILL BE STUNNED BY THEIR LOSSES: MANY WILL BE UTTERLY DESTROYED: A CANNY FEW WILL NOT ONLY SURVIVE, BUT PROSPER.'' That one promotes ''Crisis Investing,'' by Douglas R. Casey, which has 450,000 copies in print and is the No. 1 best seller. Mr. Casey is published by Robert J. Ringer, who wrote ''Winning Through Intimidation.'' Last year we had ''How to Prosper During the Coming Bad Years,'' by Howard J. Ruff, which was a best seller for 46 weeks. The Ruff book followed a 1978 book by Harry Browne, ''New Profits From the Monetary Crisis.'' While there are hundreds of books on inflation, taxes, real estate and financial affairs, these particular authors represent a phenomenon. They trade endorsements and prefaces as naturally as John Kenneth Galbraith and Arthur Schlesinger.

title: Richard Offers Congratulations
description: Maurice Richard, after his feat of 50 goals in 50 games was tied tonight by Mike Bossy, offered congratulations to the New York Islanders' right wing.

title: Connecticut Journal; 'UNAUGURAL' DOINGS... CAUCUS CONTEST
description: CONNECTICUT politicians celebrated Ronald Reagan's inauguration as the 40th President of the United States in diverse fashion last Tuesday night.

title: California Tops in Defense Pacts
description: California surpassed all other states in receiving defense procurement contracts in the 1980 fiscal year, getting $13.8 billion or 20.9 percent of the total, according to the Defense Department. New York State was second to California, with $5.6 billion, or 8.5 percent of the total.

title: Solidarity Raises New Warning Fists
description: Even convicts struck in Poland last week - 2,000 inmates in a prison near Warsaw beginning a hunger strike to dramatize demands for food at least ''as good as the police dogs get.'' This unusual origin of protest in a Commmunist country reflected the increased militancy among Poles generally and their determination to see that official promises of reform, broken before, are not broken again.

title: Music; CHAMBER EVENTS MOVE TO FORE
description: THE explosion of interest in chamber music has clearly revitalized the music scene in Westchester, and a glance at the culture calendar over the next fortnight reveals an absolutely splendid array of chamber concerts.

title: POLES AND PEASANTS
description: Although workers have led the way in Poland over the last few months, the Polish peasantry has not been far behind. Like the workers - and like the Communist Party itself - the peasantry understands that political organization is the key to the restoration of its liberties.

title: THUROW AND WAGES
description: To the Business Editor:

title: MAO'S WIDOW SENTENCED TO DEATH, BUT PENALTY IS SUSPENDED 2 YEARS
description: Jiang Qing, the widow of Mao Zedong, received a suspended death sentence today from a special court that found her and nine other former Chinese leaders guilty of counterrevolutionary crimes during the Cultural Revolution from 1966-76.

title: Future Events Jazzmatazz
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.Toots That CountJan. 31 -Jimmy Owens trumpets his pride this evening at the Hunter College Elementary School as the proud father of Ian Owens, his 8-year-old son and third-grader there. The jazz trumpeter will be accompanied by Eric Johnson, guitar, Jerry Jermott, electric bass, and Daryl Washington, drums. Together they form the quartet that has played at jazz festivals in Germany and that soon leaves for tours in Europe and North Africa. Mr. Owens, a native New Yorker, offered to present the 7:30 o'clock concert in the school auditorium at 94th Street and Park Avenue to raise money for more books for the library, which quickly runs out of its meager government funds. ''They are voracious readers, these kids,'' says Dr. Stanley Seidman, the principal, of the 406 Manhattan children aged 3 to ll, who were chosen for their above-average learning ability for the school where classes range from nursery through sixth grade. Black and Hispanic pupils form 40 per cent of the student body. Money from the concert also will be spent on a science room. The evening ends with a catered buffet supper in the downstairs cafeteria, where minglers will include performers, jazz buffs, faculty members, parents of the gifted children, and others who just love New York. Tickets are $20 for everything, or $12.50 just for the concert, from Barbara Feld, 722-7837.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 14 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $15.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history. 2 3 18 THE KEY TO REBECCA, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $12.95.) German espionage in Cairo during the desert campaigns of 1942. 3 6 5 ANSWER AS A MAN, by Taylor Caldwell. (Putnam's, $12.95.) A man who has made it big in early 20th-century America struggles against the corruption that engulfs his life. 4 2 23 FIRESTARTER, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) E ightyear-old Charlie can look at anything and turn it into flames. 5 9 15 COME POUR THE WINE, by Cynthia Freeman. (Arbor House, $12.95.) A woman's long journey to self-discovery. 6 4 17 LOON LAKE, by E.L. Doctorow. (Random House, $11.95.) The strange, lyrical adventures of a young man during the Depression. 7 5 10 UNFINISHED TALES, by J.R.R. Tolkien. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.) Hitherto unpublished fragments of writing about Middle-earth.

title: Dean Lynch, Lawyer, Fiance of Debra Franchi, Sculptor
description: Pasquale Franchi of Weston, Mass., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Debra Louise Franchi, to Dean Lynch, son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Lynch of Oradell, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: ALONG WITH POPPING CORKS, WORRISOME BACKGROUND NOISE
description: IT was the hostage's week. But it was also Ronald Reagan's, and so most of all it was unabashedly American, a seven-day glide proclaiming an end to the age of limits and reasserting the will to succeed. ''After all,'' declared the newly inaugurated President, ''we are Americans,'' and therefore, ''We have every right to dream heroic dreams.'' Republicans, denied for over a decade, exercised their right to celebrate to the fullest.

title: BALLET: 'PIANO CONCERTO' AND 'SERANADE' AT THE CITY
description: The New York City Ballet had a night of wild variety Friday at the New York State Theater. Peter Martins's ''Calcium Light Night'' takes its Charles Ives score for all its homely eccentricity, exploring the music's crannies with dance that is itself effervescently eccentric, and giving the music a witty physical flavor. Body line is taut, ending in boldly flexed or stabbing, nibbling feet. The pace is cool and deliberate, the attack forceful but circumscribed. When, at the end, the two dancers calmly manipulate each other's sitting bodies into neatly geometric forms, the effect is of almost dazzling physical intimacy. Ib Andersen combined the precisely defined thrust of classical ballet with a looser jazz slide and ooze for amusingly quirky effect, particularly when played against Heather Watts's appropriately ruthless stylization.

title: Children's Books
description: THE PIGMAN'S LEGACY By Paul Zindel. 183 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $8.95. (Ages 12 to 15) By PAXTON DAVIS

title: A PREVIEW OF SPRING BOOKS
description: THE spring catalogues of many prominent publishers appear thinner this season. Economic pressures have forced some publishers to trim their lists, but many are still promising large printings of promising books and high advertising budgets for them. Some things never change, but publishers seem to be taking fewer risks with unknown writers and unpopular subjects. Among the books scheduled for publication are a large number by established, ''brand-name'' authors who, in some cases, seem to be retreating into the safety of familiar themes.

title: Leslie Ulon Fiancee Of Timothy Harkins
description: The engagement of Leslie Marie Ulon to Timothy S. Harkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Harkins of Fairfield, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Ulon of Fairfield, parents of the bride-to-be.

title: Rally Driver Left Stranded
description: Jacques Dagat of France proved to be the unluckiest driver at the opening today of the annual Monte Carlo auto rally.

title: Westchester Journal
description: FIFTH graders at the R. J. Bailey School in Greenburgh are comparing life along the Hudson with life along the Ganges River in India through an exchange of essays, paintings, poetry and maps made by students, along with newspapers and various cultural artifacts.

title: No Headline
description: The current generation of women at midlife may be unique in human history in that many of us have been fortunate in being able to lead ''vertical lives'' - that is, having the traditional roles and activities of wife and mother and then later starting a whole new life involving a career.

title: An Author's Footnote
description: Immortality is a thing not to be taken lightly - especially the halo that attaches to membership in the Academie Fran,caise and especially if one is, as Marguerite Yourcenar was, the first woman admitted in its 346 years. So Miss Yourcenar, the 77-year-old author, was properly solemn during her ceremonial induction last week.

title: No Headline
description: In her article on the de la Rentas, Francesca Stanfill writes: ''In many ways they are counterparts of Gerald and Sara Murphy in the 1920's. ... Guests will find no failures at the de la Rentas' table. ... As Fran,coise points out, 'You have to see the people you are catering to.' ''

Translated and with an Introduction, Postscript, and Additional Notes by Geoffrey Skelton. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book. Illustrated. 1,200 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $35.

title: BATTLE BEING WAGED ON MILITARY POLICY
description: A many-sided tug-of-war over military policy has broken out within the Reagan Administration, according to officials in the Pentagon, on Capitol Hill and in the White House.

title: MILLIONS IN POLAND BOYCOTT THEIR JOBS, DEMAND 5-DAY WEEK
description: Millions of Polish workers heeded Solidarity's call today and took a ''free Saturday'' to back the independent union's demands for a five-day workweek.

title:
Antiques;
FLORENE MAINE AUCTION AT SOTHBY'S
description: TUESDAY the collection of household furniture and decorations owned by the late Florene Maine of Ridgefield, for many years one of this country's most colorful and successful antiques dealers, will be sold at auction by Sotheby Parke Bernet. The sale is scheduled to begin at 2 P.M. in the gallery's sales room at 1334 York Avenue, New York City.

title: MAKE PEACE WITH IRAN?
description: The hostages have dominated the politics of the United States for 14 months, and they are now getting the loving reception they deserve for their patience and sacrifice. But there is a feeling in the new Administration that one day fairly soon we will have to turn our minds to the problems of the future.

title: Patronage Politics In the Second City
description: The citizens of Chicago have been angrier than usual lately about political patronage, and last week Mayor Jane Byrne and State Attorney Richard M. Daley, her likely opponent in the 1983 election, took steps that may put them on the right side of public opinion.

title: Villanova 85, Colgate 75
description: Tom Sienkiewicz scored 28 points tonight to lead Villanova to an 85-75 victory over Colgate.

title:
INVESTING;
PUTS, CALLS, AND NOW, STRADDLES
description: E CONOMIC uncertainty? Whiplash moves in the stock market? Such conditions are anathema to most investors. But not to those who have discovered the ''straddle.''

title: By LISA BRAUN; Lisa Braun works for Doubleday & Co. in New York City.
description: I AM not ashamed to admit it: I was born in Huntington Hospital 22 years ago and have remained an official resident of the town since that time. I am a born and bred Long Islander. The Long Island Expressway, shopping malls and the beaches are in my blood.

title: CROWNING ACHIEVEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Editor's Choice
description: ALICE JAMES, by Jean Strouse. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.) A judicious and beautifully written life of William and Henry's younger sister.

title: POLITICS IN ISRAEL IS GETTING EVEN MORE CHAOTIC
description: Israel's most popular spectator sport is politics and Israelis watch with a mixture of fascination and disgust. A brutal and vital game, often vulgar, rarely uplifting, always intriguing, its high season is about to begin.

title: BALANCHINE EMISSARY STAGES 'DONZETTI' IN NEW HAVEN
description: NEW HAVEN WEARING gray wool pants, and a mauve turtleneck, Vicky Simon, former soloist of the New York City Ballet, stood amid members of the Connecticut Ballet in New Haven last week rehearsing George Balanchine's ''Donizetti Variations,'' which will highlight the company's first performance of its winter season.

title: PRESIDENTIAL PANEL AIMS TO CUT BUDGET
description: President Reagan assigned budget-cutting duties to his Cabinet secretaries this morning and set up a series of meetings for next week between the Cabinet officers and a high-level group to decide on major reductions in Federal spending.

title: BUENOS AIRES
description: WHEN Salvador Allende's more extreme followers turned what had been a progressive land reform program in Chile into a revolutionary one, they created chaos in the countryside that contributed to the 1973 military coup. The progressive program, begun in 1962, had been steadily changing Chile into a country of middle-sized farms averaging 200 acres.

title: Article Is Said to Err On U.S. Labor Party Role
description: In ''The State House: Forum for the One and the Many'' (Dec. 21), the author, Carl Golden, referred to the Socialist Labor Party. This was an error.

title:
CAMERA;
A LOOK AT WHAT'S NEW IN 'POCKET' CAMERAS
THE DAY CONNECTICUT MOVES TO THE COUNTY
description: PEOPLE who have a problem deciding where Westchester County ends and Connecticut begins, take heart: on Thursday, a part of Westchester will become Connecticut, at least for a 24-hour period. That's the day that Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will film exterior shots of an old Bedford millhouse for its upcoming movie, ''Rich and Famous,'' starring Candice Bergen and Jacqueline Bissett.

title: South Alabama 64 McNeese State 60
description: Herb Andrew and Scott Williams made seven free throws in the last minute tonight and South Alabama held on to beat McNeese State, 64-60.

title: NEW YORK STATE PARKS
description: To the Editor:

description: This is just to sub signature part of letter not whole letter. Writer's title was in wrong size type On Battery Project

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE State Police have had some help lately in tracking down drunken drivers on the 173-mile-long Garden State Parkway. If a driver seems drunk, toll collectors in recent months have been radioing descriptions of the car to troopers. Each toll plaza has a two-way radio that operates on the State Police band.

title: CHURCHES ORGANIZE VOLUNTEER PROGRAMS
description: ''ICAN'T believe there would be a person alive today in this world who wouldn't benefit from having another friend,'' says Nancy Steed, president of the Rye Youth Council and an elder of the Rye Presbyterian Church. With this in mind, Mrs. Steed and Jane Mickatavage, a member of the board of deacons, organized a lay pastoral program for their church members last year to supplement the counseling work of their pastor, Dr. Joseph P. Bishop.

title: 'THE MOST EXCITING MAGAZINE IN EDUCATION'-IN MEMORIAM
description: MEDIA AND METHODS, the teachers' trade magazine, is distributing its last 30,000 copies to schools across the country. After 16 years of ''disturbing, provoking and subverting,'' the North American Publishing Company decided to stop publication with this month's issue. For those of us who wrote regularly in what The New York Times called ''the most exciting magazine in education today,'' the announcement was sobering and regrettable.

title: UNITY STILL ELUDING TEACHERS' UNIONS
description: AT the end of this month, Walter Tice will lead the 1,540-member Yonkers Federation of Teachers, Westchester's largest teachers union, into contract talks with the Yonkers school district. Similar scenarios will be repeated many times throughout the county this year.

title: By SIR GEOFFREY HOWE
description: I N recent weeks I have been struck by a number of articles in the United States press advising President Reagan on the main problems that would face him on taking office and the main steps the authors felt he should take.

title: Patricia Ann Relf, a Writer, Fiancee of William Hanavan
description: The engagement of Patricia Ann Relf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George O. Relf Jr. of Reno, to William F. Hanavan, son of Mrs. Earle W. Beck Jr. of Buffalo and the late William M Hanavan, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A March wedding is planned.

title: TAKEOVER OF REPUBLIC AIRPORT DEBATED
description: FARMINGDALE WHILE Republic Airport has become one of the busiest generalaviation facilities in the Northeast, it continues to run one of the largest deficits -$370,000 last year. And while hangar space near the runways is fully rented, the number of takeoffs and landings declined last year by more than 8 percent, to 280,000.

title: Merck Official Clarifies Ocean-Dumping Practices
description: We read with interest the Jan. 4 article on ocean dumping by Leo H. Carney. We are concerned that the reference to Merck may lead to misunderstanding of our present practice with respect to the disposal of wastes from our chemical manufacturing operations.

title: LEAVING IT BUT STILL LOVING IT
description: GO west, young man, I thought. The time arrived when I knew I had to leave the comfortable womb I've called Long Island, and start a new chapter of my life.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: STATE FACES DEFICIT, ITS SIZE STILL IN DOUBT
description: HARTFORD IF you think you have problems coping with possible deficits in the family budget, consider the plight of the General Assembly's Appropriations Committee as it tries to figure out Connecticut's possible deficit.

title: FAMILIES OF HOSTAGES FLY TO CAPITAL AS THEY PREPARE FOR REUNION TODAY
description: From across the nation, relatives of the former American hostages gathered here today in the first leg of a journey that will finally unite them with their husbands, sons and daughters.

title: WHAT THE BOND MARKET WANTS FROM PRESIDENT REAGAN
description: W HEN Jimmy Carter was inaugurated just four years ago, 8 1/4 percent Treasury bonds due 2005 earned about 7.6 percent and long-term bonds were a popular investment. By the time Mr. Carter left office last week, however, the same bond yielded about 12 percent, meaning its value had fallen by more than a third. And investors were avoiding long-term bonds like the plague.

title: Film View; PONDERING THE MYSTERY AT THE HEART OF LAUGHTER
description: Herewith some notes on laughter prompted by such current films as Buck Henry's ''The First Family,'' which opened to smash business and mixed reviews on Christmas day and very quickly began to decline at the box office; Sidney Poitier's ''Stir Crazy,'' which is becoming one of the biggest money-makers of the year; ''Nine to Five,'' the feminist water-cooler comedy with Jane Fonda, Lily Tomlin and Dolly Parton, which is also, apparently, a hit; and Neil Simon's ''Seems Like Old Times,'' with Goldie Hawn, Chevy Chase and Charles Grodin, a movie so slick that, almost involuntarily, I found myself slipping out of the theater after the first hour, dumped on the sidewalk without warning. While watching the Simon film, I'd been laughing from time to time but not really enjoying it. Most of the laughter at ''Nine to Five'' was prompted by hope that things would get better, which they didn't. The opening sequences of ''The First Family'' are thunderously funny, after which the laughter subsides though the enjoyment continues. There are no conclusions to be drawn from these experiences, but they do invite speculation.

title: Wisconsin 54, Illinois 45
description: John Bailey and Larry Petty scored 13 points each today to lead Wisconsin to a 54-45 upset victory over Illinois in the Big Ten conference.

title: BAD WEATHER IS BAD BUSINESS
description: T HE Nebraska-reared author Willa Cather, in her farm novel, ''My Antonia,'' observed bleakly: ''On the farm the weather was the great fact, and men's affairs went on underneath it, as the streams creep under the ice.''

title: WEEKEND VACATIONS AT DOWNTOWN HOTELS
description: ''Have some tea - it's tax-free,'' urged our sightseeing guide as he parked the tour bus and directed us into a long wooden shed on a wharf in a Boston harbor channel. Helping ourselves to little Styrofoam cups of tea from a steaming samovar, we crossed a gangplank to the deck of the Brig Beaver II and gazed across the water at the spot where, on the night of Dec. 16, 1773, a group of American colonists disguised as Indians stormed aboard the original Beaver and tossed overboard English tea in a momentous tax protest that history remembers as the Boston Tea Party.

title: A Reader Exercises His Prerogative
description: I appreciate Frank Lynn's view that the Suffolk County Legislature ''has had a checkered if brief history'' and ''is about to take another significant shift in direction and emphasis'' (''Suffolk Legislature Taking New Turn,'' Dec. 28). Nevertheless, I seriously doubt that one of the turns that Anthony Noto might envision is to begin to legislate etymology.

title: Power Plant Scaffold Falls; 7 Construction Workers Die
description: A scaffold collapsed yesterday deep inside a shaft at a hydroelectric plant under construction in the Sierra Nevada, killing seven construction workers, the authorities said today.

title: ASSEMBLY EXPECTED TO ACT ON JUVENILE JUSTICE
description: TRENTON THE Assembly Judiciary Committee is expected to announce this week a package of bills aimed at improving the state's juvenile-justice system. Assemblyman Martin A. Herman, Democrat of Woodbury, the committee chairman, said that details of the legislation would be disclosed after all the finishing touches had been made.

title:
Gardening;
TREES, SHRUBS CAN SAVE ENERGY INDOORS
description: PLANTS play a variety of roles in the landscape. Their esthetic appeal is universally recognized. Everyone appreciates an attractive flower, a red-fruited espalier trained against a stone wall, a flowering vine clinging to a white trellis or a well-proportioned grouping of shrubs nestled against the foundation of a home.

title: Suspect Shipyard
description: The charge was that workers on the nation's first nuclear submarine, the Nautilus, were contracting leukemia at up to six times the national rate. The Navy denied that working conditions at the site, the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard in Kittery, Me., were unsafe.

title: MODULAR EXPRESSIONS: JOHN POWELL AT THE STATE MUSEUM
description: TRENTON IN HIS paintings now on view at the State Museum, John Powell provides a clear clue to their meaning through their format and dimensions. Most of the canvases are large and square, measuring such sizes as 36 by 36 inches, 66 by 66 inches and 70 by 70 inches.

By WALTER TERRY

title: S.B. Kutzer to Wed Patricia Susie Rice
description: Mrs. H. Edison Rice of Chappaqua, N.Y., has made known the engagement of her daughter, Patricia Susie Rice, to Stephen Bernard Kutzer, son of Mary Friel Kutzer of Abington, Pa., and Theodore Charles Kutzer of Philadelphia.

title: Conn. Cities See A Vanishing Act
description: Connecticut's Urban Problems grants may end up causing more problems than they solve. The grants, under which the state would have distributed $23.8 million to cities and towns, became the first target of Gov. William A. O'Neill in his attempts to avoid a budget deficit.

title: GALBRAITH
description: To the Business Editor: Professor Galbraith observed of President Reagan and his team: ''Instead of ... conservatism ... they avow a forthright and risky radicalism. Anything resembling the Nixon-Connally-Schultz-McCracken success is to be wholly eschewed.

title: No Headline
description: The New Middle- Aged Woman Today, women in midlife happen to be living in a transitional period (''A New Start for Women at Midlife,'' by Grace Baruch, Rosalind Barnett and Caryl Rivers, Dec. 7). Those of us in the 40-plus group are still influenced by past pressures; therefore our problems are unique but transient.

title: LONG-AWAITED JOURNEY BEGINS FOR LOPEZ FAMILY
description: There was something special about the sunrise that greeted Jesse and Mary Lopez this morning as they set out from their home in Globe, Ariz., on the cross-country journey that would reunite them with their son.

title: HOME OF FUTURE: SIZE WILL SHRINK BUT NOT THE RPICE
description: More than 40,000 of the nation's home builders gathered here this weekend amid their industry's worst slump in almost a decade, and they sent a message to Americans: Think small.

title: Judith Greene Wed To W. B. Winship
description: Judith Carlson Greene, a lawyer in the general counsel's office at Smith Barney Harris Upham & Company, was married yesterday afternoon in Manhattan to William Barr Winship, a partner in the New York law firm of Davidson, Dawson & Clark. The Rev. John O. Mellin performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

title: ATTICS AND REC ROOMS AIDING NEW CO-OP PROJECT
description: ''It all depends which way you are looking,'' Albert Schwartz, one of the city's most active rehabilitators of tenements, remarked the other day as he stood in front of his latest project, a row of four tenement buildings at 325 West 52d Street in the heart of Clinton. ''To the west are drab tenements, but to the east is the elegance of Rockefeller Center.''

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP 12.4% IN YEAR
description: Consumer prices rose 1.1 percent in December, bringing the total for all of last year to 12.4 percent. The result was a slight improvement over 1979's rate of 13.3 percent. Not since 1918-19, however, has inflation exceeded 10 percent for two years in a row.

title: Rhode Island 53, Providence 44
description: Marc Upshaw made five of Rhode Island's 12 free throws in the last three minutes tonight, helping the Rams to a 53-44 victory over Providence.

title: Music View; ABOUT THOSE CUTS IN OPERA
description: In the midst of a particularly arid stretch of a drab performance of ''Tristan und Isolde'' at the Metropolitan Opera the other evening, King Marke stepped forward to begin his doleful monologue, an episode that ordinarily is enough to make the heart of even a perfect Wagnerite sink a little. This time, however, something unusual happened, thanks to a Finnish bass named Matti Salminen who was making his Met debut. But more about that later. The old king, you remember, has discovered his young wife in the arms of the knight Tristan, his most trusted friend, which causes him such anguish that he declaims his miseries and disappointments at what generally seems interminable length. Faced with the average King Marke, the operagoer is tempted to slip off into a reverie of aptly Wagnerian dimensions - contemplation of past and future sins is a pleasant way to fill the time.

title: Architecture View; IT'S STYLISH, BUT IS IT ART -OR SPINACHE?; by Ada Louise Huxtable
description: Oh taste, oh fashion, can thy name be architecture? Well, yes. Architecture follows the whims of style and change more than any of us who have been taught to believe in building as an act of timeless truth and enduring art would want to admit. Fashion is spinach, and so, alas, is a lot of construction. Much of it belongs in Women's Wear Daily rather than in the professional press.

title: URBAN STUDIES CENTER WILL SEEK WAYS TO MAKE THE CITY WORK BETTER
description: What would be the impact on New York City's population if Puerto Rico were to achieve independence? Given the city's experience with Grumman Flxible buses and other procurement troubles, is competitive bidding for municipal contracts always a good idea?

title: Crime
description: Leo Rosten, known before the war for his ''The Education of H*Y*M*A*N K*A*P*L*A*N'' and, more recently, ''The Joys of Yiddish,'' has been turning to the detective novel, with results that are predictable in at least one aspect. Mr. Rosten's private eye, Silky Pincus, is very Jewish, and Yiddish pours out of him like dollars from the Federal Reserve. There is so much Yiddish in the latest Pincus book, KING SILKY (Harper & Row, $11.95), that a glossary is thoughtfully included.

title: Florida 97, Alabama 91
description: Vernon Delancy scored 38 points and Ronnie Williams added 22 as Florida defeated Alabama, 97-91, today in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: FREE AND KING PACE WARRIORS IN 117-110 VICTORY OVER KNICKS
description: Lloyd Free scored 35 points tonight to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 117-110 victory over the New York Knicks, who ended a quick three-game Western swing with their second straight loss.

title: SUPER BOWL VILLAIN
description: NEW ORLEANS U NLESS his team is in it, the Super Bowl does not interest him. When the Oakland Raiders missed qualifying for one of the previous games here, Al Davis scowled when he was asked if he were going anyway.

title: Hofstra 70, Delaware 61
description: Lionel Harvey scored 21 points and led Hofstra to a 70-61 East Coast Conference victory over Delaware tonight.

title: MANASQUAN DAM PROPOSAL SAID TO IMPERIL 5 SPECIES OF FISH
description: WALL TOWNSHIP THE chief of the state's Bureau of Fresh-Water Fisheries said last week that the design of the $40 million Manasquan Reservoir, as proposed, would destroy five species of fish indigenous to the Manasquan River.

title: Lori Schucker Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving Schucker of Spring Valley, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lori Pamela Schucker, to Mitchell Gordon Pitkof, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Pitkof, also of Spring Valley.

title: Pistons 117, Cavaliers 94
description: Phil Hubbard scored 25 points and Keith Herron added 22 to lift Detroit to victory over Cleveland.

title: DISTANT DONORS SHARE CONCERN WITH NEEDIEST
description: Reflecting concern for New York City's poor and distressed from people around the world, contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have come from supporters on four continents.

title: HOSTAGE EXIT COULD SIGNAL A CROSSROAD FOR THE REVOLUTION
description: ROME FOR the Islamic Republican Party of Iran, the hard days of power may be just beginning. The release of the 52 Americans, the weapons the religious traditionalists used for 14 months to solidify their control, may mark a turning point in the course of the revolution.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; GLORIA SWANSON
description: ''Ready or not, here I come,'' a woman could be heard announcing from her boudoir, and out stepped Gloria Swanson. ''Don't think of me as a Hollywoodite,'' the 81-year-old former movie queen warned as she led the way into the ornate living room of her ground-floor apartment on Fifth Avenue. ''I've lived here since 1938 and made pictures on Long Island.''

title: SKI RESORTS OFFERING BARGAINS THIS WEEK
description: VERNON ENCOURAGED and enriched by recent snowfalls, New Jersey's ski resorts are conducting an all-out campaign to attract beginners, as well as seasoned aficionados, to their slopes.

title: MACHINE TOOL ORDERS OFF IN 1980
description: For the first time since 1975, new orders for machine tools declined on a dollar basis last year, to an estimated $4.7 billion, down nearly 16 percent from 1979.

title: No Headline
description: I fail to understand the hostility of some American Jews toward the recent Israeli and Russian immigrants. The new immigrants have come here for a better life - precisely the same reason Jews immigrated to America two and three generations ago. DANIEL M. ADAMSON, Shaker Heights, Ohio

title:
Art;
PHOTOS THAT EXPLORE CONFLICTS
description: RIVERHEAD TEN years ago, when Robert D'Alessandro was working as a staff photographer for New York Magazine, he trained his camera on divers aspects of the American scene, unified by the recurring image of the Stars and Stripes. The resulting photo document, called ''Glory,'' is a highly critical, at times caustic, often touching and affectionate collection, commenting on a nation whose attitudes were shaped by the Vietnam War.

title: FAMILIES BECAME THE 'OTHER HOSTAGES' IN THE LONG WAIT FOR THEIR LOVED ONES
description: The 52 Americans held 444 days in Iran were not the only hostages involved in that crisis. Their wives, children, parents and other relatives also found themselves held captive by the incident, trapped on what one called ''an emotional roller coaster of hope and despair,'' never knowing when or how the terrifying ride might end.

title: Oregon State 97 Washington 91
description: Steve Johnson scored 5 of his game-high 38 points in overtime tonight as he led unbeaten and No. 1-ranked Oregon State past Washington, 97-91, in a Pacific-10 Conference game.

title: Julius Berger, a Cellist, Presents Kodaly, Debussy
description: Julius Berger, a young West German cellist with considerable playing experience on both sides of the Atlantic, made his New York debut Tuesday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: ARTIST RECREATES NATURE WITH AIRBRUSH AND IMAGINATION
description: THORNWOOD ALARGE diorama of a coastal marsh has been designed and most of it created in the living-room studio of a 65-year-old artist in his hillside home here overlooking the village.

title: 11-4 MINNESOTA TOPS IOWA,60-48
description: Randy Breuer scored 17 points today, including 9 in the second half, to lead Minnesota to a 60-48 victory over Iowa in a Big Ten game.

title: Science Fiction
description: IF ALL ELSE FAILS ... By Craig Strete. With an Introduction by Jorge Luis Borges. 182 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $8.95.

title: HOSTAGE SETTLEMENT, POINT AND COUNTERPOINT
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT TO CHEER ABOUT; Women on Women
description: Two quotes from two women: ''All of the women here have husbands who have worked hard for what they have,'' said one at an Inaugural ball.
