Pointing to herself, she added: ''If a little girl from Alabama ... can appear in public wearing beautiful jewels and gowns, it should be a symbol to everyone that they can do it too.''

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
PETE ROZELLE'S IMPECCABLE STYLE
description: of-the-league message the other day, and once again displayed the footwork of young Muhammad Ali, the quicksilver reflexes of Sugar Ray Robinson, the adroit moves of Willie Pep and the punch of Slapsie Maxie Rosenbloom.

title: LITTLE VICTORIES HELPED THE HOSTAGES RESIST
description: On the good days, when they felt strong and angry, they resisted as best they could. Even the ones locked off by themselves, shut away with only their own voices and a deck of cards.

title: A SAMPLING OF PACKAGED AMENITIES: MUSEUMS, THEATERS AND HISTORIC SITES
description: The weekend package at discount rates has become a feature of downtown hotels around the country. It may have originated decades ago in New York; at least the Convention and Visitors Bureau has been promoting such packages for years and for the last three years has been putting out a booklet listing many of the possibilities. Here are some samplings from the latest list.

title: TRIAL REVEALS REFUSAL TO INDICT GIBSON FOR TAX FRAUD
description: The former Federal prosecutor in New Jersey, Robert J. Del Tufo, sought to indict Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark on tax fraud charges, but the Justice Department refused permission, according to testimony at the Abscam hearings in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: 70,000 FOOTBALL FANS MAKE NEW ORLEANS THROB WITH SUPER BOWL MANIA
description: There was a gridlock of people in the French Quarter almost every night this week as New Orleans prepared for Super Bowl XV tomorrow. And it's a good thing the people couldn't move any faster. If they could have, they would have been staggering into one another.

title: HOSTAGE SETTLEMENT, POINT AND COUNTERPOINT
description: The hostages are back. And who, who anywhere, is not happy for them and their families? But now we begin to pay ransom -again and again - if some ''hostage policy'' is not clearly, unequivocably formulated. JAMES A. MILLER, Cleveland, Jan. 20, 1981

title: Sex and the Single Hominid
description: Man has laid claim to species distinction on diverse grounds, usually having to do with superior intelligence. Now, in a new version of human origins published in last week's issue of Science magazine, Dr. C.Owen Lovejoy, a professor of anthropology at Kent State University, argues that homo sapiens mainly owes its unique development not to language, tool-making, upright posture or a larger brain, but to its sexual characteristics and mating habits.

title: Caroline P. Rockefeller, Duke Alumna, To Be Bride in Spring of David Spencer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey A. Rockefeller of Gibson Island, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Parker Rockefeller, to David Robert Spencer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert C. Spencer of Petersburg, Ill. A spring wedding is planned.

title:
Gardening;
TREES, SHRUBS CAN SAVE ENERGY INDOORS
description: PLANTS play a variety of roles in the landscape. Their esthetic appeal is universally recognized. Everyone appreciates an attractive flower, a red-fruited espalier trained against a stone wall, a flowering vine clinging to a white trellis or a well-proportioned grouping of shrubs nestled against the foundation of a home.

title: Southwest Bail Bondsmen Vow Not to Assist any Iranian in U.S.
description: About 130 bail bondsmen representing the International Fidelity Insurance Company in the southwestern United States have vowed not to provide bail ''at any price'' for Iranians jailed in this country.

title: WATER SHORTAGE CALLED A LONG-TERM PROBLEM
description: EVEN though the effects of the drought in some communities from Greenwich to Groton may be temporarily relieved by heavy rain or snow, the long-term water-supply difficulties of certain areas in Connecticut will continue, according to academic experts, water company executives and public officials.

title: DIVORCE RATE IN THE COUNTY IS HIGH-WHY?
description: FOR every two marriages in Westchester County in 1979, there was one divorce. While the number of marriages in the county decreased to 5,586 from 5,649 for 1978, the number of divorces increased 15 percent to 2,541 from 2,220 for the year before, according to a report issued recently by the New York State Department of Health. In the entire state, the ratio of marriages to divorce was 2.4 to 1 or 141,350 to 59,898. In Westchester the ratio was 2.2 to 1.

title: Television Week
description: Fresh Blood''I hate the word 'relevance.' We live in the suburbs of history. Shakespeare lives in the metropolis.'' Jonathan Miller was describing one aspect of his approach to mounting productions of Shakespeare for presentation on television. Dr. Miller - a neurologist as well as one of Britain's foremost stage, opera, film and television directors - has picked up the reins of the third and fourth seasons of ''The Shakespeare Plays,'' the six-year project, co-produced by the BBC and Time-Life, that aims to present all 37 works in the canon on public television. Dr. Miller was in town recently in connection with this season's offerings, which begin with a new production of ''The Taming of the Shrew,'' directed by him and starring John Cleese and Sarah Badel, on Monday at 8 P.M. on Channel 13.

title: THE GOVERNOR RACE ENTERS A NEW STAGE
description: THE race for Governor moved out of the posturing stage last week when State Senator Frank J. Dodd, Democrat of West Orange, challenged John J. Degnan, the state's Attorney General, to come out and fight.

title: RETIREMENT PLANS ATWESTERN
description: Western Air Lines has for years been looking for a merger partner -one unsuccessful try with American Airlines and one with Continental Air Lines preceded the current Continental agreement - and its top officers have, perhaps not surprisingly, failed to groom managers to succeed them.

title: TEN MILLION CIVILIZATIONS NEARBY
description: COSMOS By Carl Sagan. Illustrated. 365 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: Arizona State 83, Arizona 65
description: Byron Scott tallied 14 of his 21 points in the first half as Arizona State opened up a 14-point lead and coasted to an 83-65 victory over Arizona in a Pacific 10 Conference game.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Top Drawer Fashion- s In Westport
description: Top Drawer in easternmost Westport buys direct from top-notch designers of women's fashions in sizes 2 to 14, leaves the labels in, and immediately reduces the prices by 20 to 30 percent.

title: THEATER: REVIVAL OF PRIESTLY AND FEYDEAU
description: Two old plays have been dusted off by small New York companies; one is a musty melodrama, the other a brash and lively farce. As luck and talent would have it, the first, ''Dangerous Corner,'' by J.B. Priestley, is given a worthy production at the No Smoking Playhouse, and the second, Georges Feydeau's ''Tied by the Leg,'' is overcooked at the Production Company.

title: Thomas L. Saeli, Sales Aide, To Marry Molly A. Reading
description: Molly Ann Reading, who expects to graduate from Hamilton College in May, and Thomas Louis Saeli, a Hamilton alumnus who expects to receive an M.B.A. degree in May from Columbia University, plan to be married July 18 in Jamestown, N.Y.

title: Duke 75, Clemson 57
description: Vince Taylor and Gene Banks sparked a second-half surge to lead Duke to a 75-57 rout of Clemson tonight in an Atlantic Coast Conference game.

title: Finally, a Good Agenda on Crime
description: New York's discussion about the soaring crime rate has taken a thoughtful turn. When last we looked, Mayor Koch and the city's judges were squabbling about how they should be cooperating, and impugning each other's motives. Since then, Governor Carey has offered several sensible proposals for enlarging the capacity of the entire criminal justice system. And Mr. Koch has emerged with a solid list of proposals from his unusual canvas of judges, prosecutors and defense attorneys. Many are clearly desirable and practical; some are usefully provocative. It's time to move to a concrete legislative program.

title: TV Coverage Of Long Island News
description: The Long Island Coalition for Fair Broadcasting has been working to expand coverage of Long Island subjects on news programs of the major New York stations. The recent article ''L.I. TV Coverage: Does Pressure Pay?'' included a pertinent and excellent analysis of pressures concerning the selection of news shows. The point is made that selection of news stories is governed at least in part by a requirement for ''entertainment.''

title: N. L. Ormasa, Brooke Barton Are Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Barton of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Brooke Millon Barton, to Newton Lee Ormasa, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Ormasa of Tustin, Calif.

title: NEW DELHI
description: Through nearly two decades of false starts and dashed hopes, Sir Richard Attenborough has been trying to make a film on the life of Mahatma Gandhi. Last month, filming finally began on a dusty plain in Gurgaon, southwest of New Delhi. Was there elation? Exhilaration? ''I think the principal emotion has been waking up in the morning and feeling absolutely convinced that I had been dreaming that we've actually begun,'' Sir Richard said while pacing the floor of the New Delhi hotel suite that serves as one of the offices for the production.

title: Roosevelt Racing Is Suspended
description: Roosevelt Raceway, which has conducted its harness-racing program for offtrack bettors only during a week-long strike by parimutuel clerks, will hold no further racing after tonight until a settlement is reached.

title: Susan Haltmaier Bride Of Raymond H. Todd Jr.
description: Susan Marie Haltmaier and Raymond Holmes Todd Jr. were married yesterday at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in North Andover, Mass. The Rev. James Hession and the Rev. James McDonald officiated.

title: SNOWSHOES KEEP THEIR OLD VIRTUES
description: Suggesting that snowshoes can often be better than skis for traversing the winter landscape is utterly logical, but it goes against the grain of our style-conscious, group-oriented society.

title: IN DEFENSE OF A GURU
THE G.N.P. COULD BE AN ARTIFACT
description: If a statistic can be an institution, gross national product would certainly qualify. It is the standard measure of the nation's output of goods and services - the measure, indeed, that confirms this country's position as the world's strongest.

title:
STAMPS;
COMMEMORATIVE HONORS BLACK LEADER
description: The United States is issuing a commemorative for Whitney Moore Young Jr., one of the leading figures in the Negro struggle for civil rights and a protagonist in the concomittant effort for economic and social gains for blacks.

title: Music View; THE IMPACT OF TV ON OPERA
description: Assuming that past audience estimates hold true, some seven million people will see and hear Birgit Nilsson in Richard Strauss's ''Elektra'' this week. The opera, taped during a live performance at the Metropolitan Opera last February, will be telecast Wednesday night at 8 on Channel 13 in New York, and will be shown at that time or within the following week on most Public Broadcasting Service stations around the country, often simulcast with participating FM classical-music radio stations.

title: No Headline
description: Mike Spinks Victor in 8th

title: CIVIL SERVANTS' WORTH
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW DO WE FACE OUR OWN 'ABSCAMS'?
description: LATELY the subject of ethics has appeared with increasing frequency in the media. It has centered on Watergate, Abscam, foreign kickbacks on aircraft contracts and the questionable scruples of some professionals and businessmen.

title: By Janice Fenimore
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE ON KASHMIR
description: To the Editor:

title: CRAFTS: AFRICAN ANTECEDENTS AT NEWARK
description: NEWARK ''THE Afro-American Tradition in the Decorative Arts,'' an exhibition that evolved from a serious effort to trace African antecedents in the crafts and skills of black Americans from early slaves to present artisans, is currently on view at the Newark Museum.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Blowing Hot and Cold on Commuters
description: Does a commuter have an inalienable right to air conditioning? It depends. Yes, said Queens Civil Court Judge William D. Friedmann last week.

title: EXCITED ACADEMY NEIGHBORS PAINT THE TOWN YELLOW N.Y.
description: ''You wouldn't believe the offers we've had,'' said Al Konecny, a public affairs official at the United States Military Academy's Thayer Hotel, where the returning hostages are to be reunited tomorrow with their families.

title: Military Analysis
description: The Soviet Union has embarked on the building of major surface ships that appear to be designed for service in the third world, outside the ''choke points'' that NATO analysts believe would constrain Soviet naval strategy in the event of war.

title: Speaking Personally; WHY CAN'T A WOMAN BE MORE LIKE A MAN?
description: WHEN I lunched with seven women recently, I discovered a lot of things that I like about men. Men are better than women at some things.

title: FLORENE MAINE ANTIQUES AUCTION AT SOTHBY
description: TUESDAY the collection of household furniture and decorations owned by the late Florene Maine of Ridgefield, for many years one of this country's most colorful and successful antiques dealers, will be sold at auction by Sotheby Parke Bernet. The sale is scheduled to begin at 2 P.M. in the gallery's sales room at 1334 York Avenue, New York City.

title: ARTHUR SIEGEL'S SONGS
description: A rthur Siegel is a songwriter, although not a widely-known songwriter. His best-known songs are a pair he wrote with June Carroll for ''New Faces of 1952'' -the catchy ''Love is a Simple Thing'' and ''Monotonous,'' which is more apt to be associated with Eartha Kitt, who sang it, than with Arthur Siegel.

title: Serious Drinking
description: Critics scoffed when Dr. Alan Marlatt, a psychologist at the University of Washington in Seattle, said he was opening a ''free'' bar on campus to study whether social drinkers could be taught to drink sensibly. But open the bar he did in 1978 with a $43,000-a-year grant from the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism.

title: L.I.U. 72, Army 50
description: Jeff Meriwether helped Long Island University score the game's first 12 points and the Blackbirds went on to crush Army, 72-50, tonight.

title: MALAYSIA CONFRONTS ENVIROMENT ISSUES
description: Here in the municipality of Penang, beside the busy Strait of Malacca in northwest Malaysia, is Butterworth, one of Malaysia's principal free-trade zones. Within a few miles are two industrial parks with nearly 100 factories producing everything from umbrellas to steel and sugar.

title: FOR COLLEGES, NEW LESSON FOR A NEW ERA
description: HIGHER education stands at the threshold of an exciting era - a time when the major thrust of education is moving toward a reemphasis on educational fundamentals. As colleges and universities respond to the needs of the 80's, a new generation of degree aspirants will be acquiring more than just a sheepskin; the emphasis will be on a broad-based system of studies that lends itself to the development of the liberally educated, cultured person.

title: Mass Transit
description: To the Business Editor: Professor John Pucher's finding of ''Discrimination in Mass Transit'' (Jan. 4) is an interesting exercise in academic research. The author presents statistical data showing that operating subsidies for commuter rail average $1.53 per trip, while subway subsidies averaged only $0.41 per trip. This is discriminatory, in his opinion, because some 38 percent of commuter passengers earn over $25,000 per year, while only 13 percent of subway passengers are in this higher income (and tax) category. (He neglected to note that a higher percentage of subway passengers have to stand while riding - still further evidence of discrimination.)

title: Pacers 107, Mavericks 89
description: Indiana's George McGinnis scored 19 points and Billy Knight added 18 as Indiana, bolting ahead with a 22-8 burst in the third quarter, routed Dallas.

title: LISTENING TO THE MELODIE OF FRANCE
description: From Berlioz to Messiaen, the French have developed a rich song tradition, although precious little of it ever surfaces in recitals. Singers often program the token French group, but it generally consists of the same familiar standards. Debussy, for example, wrote about 85 songs, less than a dozen of which ever turn up in concert - 25 even remain unpublished to this day. Until recently, the picture was just as bleak on recordings, but thanks to the arrival of several imported disks, it is now possible to examine French song at length and in detail.

title: Two Nicaraguan Officials Held on Smuggling Charges
description: Two Nicaraguan Government officials are among six men being held in Texas on charges of conspiracy to smuggle two helicopters out of this country, a United States Attorney said.

title: Boston College 72, Seton Hall 68
description: John Bagley and Martin Clark hit baskets in the final 25 seconds of overtime tonight to give Boston College a 72-68 victory over Seton Hall in a Big East game.

title: THE STATE OF THE ART
description: The future of chess computers is the subject of wildly fluctuating opinions. Dr. Hans Berliner of Carnegie-Mellon University expects that a computer will defeat the world champion in 10 years. Dr. Claude Shannon, who published the landmark article ''Programming a Computer to Play Chess'' 30 years ago, judges that the machine will not pose a threat to a human champion for many more years to come.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
INFLATION REMEDIES: REAL AND MAKE BELIVE
description: I NFLATION is the nation's most perplexing economic problem. Every analyst appears to have a different solution. Given the disarray, it is worthwhile to see what mainstream economics says about inflation control.

title: Nonfiction In Brief
description: A LITTLE ORDER A Selection From His Journalism. By Evelyn Waugh. Edited by Donat Gallagher. 192 pp. Boston: Little, Brown and Co. $12.95.

title: JAPANESE BANKS TO CANCEL MOST CLAIMS ON CHRYSLER
description: Seven major Japanese commercial banks that supplied money to the Chrysler Corporation decided today to write off a large portion of their claims against the United States auto maker, banking sources said.

title: HIRING OF 1,200 OFFICERS WILL STILL LEAVE FORCES THIN
description: Mayor Koch's announcement last week that 1,000 more city police officers and 200 more transit police officers would be hired in the fiscal year starting July 1 brought a measure of comfort to New Yorkers frightened by the sharp increase in crime. But if the announcement had an immediate effect on the public, the actual hirings will have only a delayed effect.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ZURICH
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- PAUL HOFMANN, formerly a Times correspondent, lives in Rome. By PAUL HOFMANN

title: GALBRAITH
description: To the Business Editor: Professor Galbraith's article provided us with the socialist's view of supply-side economics. He began with the presumption that monetary stability and control of Federal budget expenditures must necessarily produce a decline in real output.

title: ON LANGUAGE BY WILLIAM SAFIRE
description: Cheap Shots

title: Patricia Ann Sinnott Married
description: Patricia Ann Sinnott of Larchmont, N.Y., widow of William T. Sinnott, was married yesterday to E. Gabriel Perle, corporate vice president-law of Time Inc. State Supreme Court Justice Michael Dontzin performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home. The bride is a sales executive in the New York headquarters of J.P. Stevens & Company. Mr. Perle's first wife died and his second marriage ended in divorce.

title: STARTING FROM SEED WITH INDOOR PLANTING
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Elda Haring is an experienced gardener and author of ''The Complete Book of Growing Plants From Seed.'' By ELDA HARING

title: EARLY SKIING
description: To the Editor:

title: HATCH PLANS INQUIRY INTO CORRUPTION IN WORKPLACE
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the new chairman of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, is planning a fullscale investigation of corruption in the workplace and will also try to change what the Senator calls ''the ridiculous quota system'' of Federal affirmative action programs.

title: Canadiens 6, Flyers 3
description: Mario Tremblay scored three goals, and Rejean Houle had two to lead the Canadiens over Philadelphia before a crowd of 18,096, the largest at the Forum this season. Montreal extended its home unbeaten streak to 11 games, 10 victories and a tie.

title: The Band Plays On
description: After Glenn Miller died, a war casualty in the 1940's, the band leader's wife, Helen, became executor of his estate. When Mrs. Miller died in 1966, David MacKay, a lawyer, became the executor.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA'S SUPERMARKET OF GOLF
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- JOHN S. RADOSTA covers golf for The New York Times. By JOHN S. RADOSTA

title: Kansas 66, Colorado 59
description: Darnell Valentine and Victor Mitchell combined for 27 points as Kansas rallied for a 66-59 victory tonight over Colorado in Big Eight play.

title: FEUD OVERSHADOWS HOPES OF LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS IN ALBANY
description: The New York State Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus began its 15th year with its largest membership ever, and members said they were confident that the group's new numerical strength would enhance its ability to effect change on minority-group issues.

title: RIO DE JANEIRO
description: IN the waning days of 1980, President Joao Baptista Figueiredo added another fete to the round of red carpet affairs held in Brasilia each Christmas. He invited 11 rural families to the glossy Planalto Palace and gave them each titles to farms.

title: A COMING ATTRACTION ON CHINA'S TELEVISION: 'SESAME STREET' SHOW
description: At the China Central Television station in Peking, a purple creature with a big pink nose appears on television monitors and says: ''Hello there boys and girls. This is your cute furry little pal Grover, and today I am going to demonstrate the difference between up and down.''

title: Sandra Emery Taylor Married
description: Sandra Emery Taylor and Dr. Melvin Harris Goodwin 3d were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Lattingtown, L.I., by the Rev. Charles G. Newbery.

title: WEIDENBAUM
description: The new chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers will be Murray L. Weidenbaum, 53 years old, a professor at Washington University in St. Louis. Mr. Weidenbaum, who last served in government as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for economic policy from 1969 to 1971, was nominated by President Reagan last week.

title: Aguirre Hits for 35 In De Paul Victory
description: With an outstanding performance by Mark Aguirre, De Paul beat La Salle, 69-62, today before 8,558 fans at the Palestra and a national television audience.

title: FOR A TIGHTER REIN ON FEDERAL AID
description: THEY are available to fill potholes and repair bridges. Theycan be utilized to finance education, to create jobs, and to clean up our air and our streams. Almost nothing is as versatile as Federal dollars. Yet few things can cause as many problems. Federal funds flow into Connecticut with strings attached, often escape fiscal review and later force burdens on state and local budgets.

title: Nancy Ilberman Is Betrothed to Peter A. Gold, Lawyer
description: Nancy Ilberman, a senior analyst with the Trans World Corporation, and Peter A. Gold, a lawyer with the New York firm of Kramer, Levin, Nessen, Kamin & Soll, plan to be married in April.

title:
By THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Carey's Budget Tradeoffs Offer Risks and Rewards
description: Though there was something to please everyone in the $16.2 billion budget Governor Carey presented last week, there was also something to displease everyone. Often, the two seemed linked.

title: 'RANSOM' DEBATE HAS FEW HELPFUL PRECEDENTS
description: WASHINGTON EVEN as the hostages flew out of Teheran last week, a politically charged debate flared over the terms of the agreement that freed them. The question: Did the United States pay a ransom for the captives? Former President Carter, members of his Administration and a few Republicans such as Senator Charles Percy of Illinois, chairman of the Foreign Relations Commitee, defended the arrangement as the best way to return Iran's property while safeguarding American claims and interests. ''Iran has suffered severely,'' said Mr. Carter. ''Their attempts to extort money from us did not work.'' As the negotiations progressed, Iran had backed off steadily from earlier demands totaling $24 billiion. Former Vice President Mondale responded to angry demands to renounce the deal. ''We have had a tradition of 200 years in this nation of abiding by the civilized rules of international law,'' he said, ''and if they have resorted to barbarity, maybe it's a higher standard that we live by.''

title: AIR-SEA CRUISE
description: Air-Sea Cruise To the Editor:

title: Sharon Zane Bride Of Gregory Mocosko
description: Sharon Zane, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Manuel D. Zane of White Plains, was married yesterday to Gregory Martin Mocosko, son of Theodore J. Macosko of Berea, Ohio, and Mrs. Mary-Jeanne Macosko of Olmsted Falls, Ohio. The ceremony was performed at the Winton Place on the Lake in Lakewood, Ohio, by Mayor Jack Kafer of Berea.

title: Eleanor Allen Is Wed to John W. Bitner Jr.
description: Eleanor Lenssen Allen and John W. Bitner Jr., both of Boston, were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. Alanson B. Houghton performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: STATE AIDS ELECTRIC UTILITIES
description: HARTFORD IN the last half of 1980, Connecticut's Public Utilities Control Authority, confronting requests for $374 million in additional annual revenues, granted the electric, gas and telephone companies in the state rate increases worth $258 million. Beyond the size of the increases, the rate proceedings are important because they indicate the regulatory priorities of a utility authority to which four of five commissioners had been appointed since the middle of 1979. Prior to these proceedings none of the four had voted on a major rate increase.

title: TRYING TO EXPLAIN
description: ALIENATED AFFECTIONS Being Gay in America. By Seymour Kleinberg. 256 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $13.95. By RICHARD P. BRICKNER

title: Judge Refuses to Dismiss Maine Suit on Ford Defects
description: Superior Court Justice Daniel E. Wathen, rejecting arguments by the Ford Motor Company that it was exempt from Maine's unfair trade practices law, has refused to dismiss a state suit to force the company to make free repairs on some vehicles.

title: FIRE VIOLATIONS MAY CLOSE SOME CITY CLUBS AND DISCOS
description: Some New York City nightclubs, discotheques and social clubs could be ordered to close in the next several weeks for violating fire safety laws, according to officials from the city's Fire and Buildings Departments.

title: Merryl Mandelker to Be Wed In June to Steven Altarescu
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morris J. Mandelker of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Merryl Jill Mandelker, to Steven Altarescu, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Altarescu of Queens Village, Queens.

title: PENTAGON DELAYED PINELANDS APPROVAL
description: FOUR hours before he approved the Pinelands Commission's controversial master plan, Cecil D. Andrus was still trying to convince Defense Department officials that it would not impair military operations in New Jersey.

title: HOW A VETERAN ACTOR DEFINES HIMSELF
description: YOU say to yourself, ''He looks familiar but where did we meet?'' Possibly you never did, but theatergoers in Connecticut may very well recognize Robert Nichols, the actor. He was at the Hartford Stage Company a few weeks back in the play, ''Einstein and the Polar Bear.'' He has played the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam in ''Hit the Deck'' and ''Louisiana Purchase.'' Then there was ''Show Boat'' at the Coachlight Dinner Theater in East Windsor. He played Cap'n Andy, a role he created again for Coachlight Dinner Theater of Nanuet, N.Y. At odd hours, he pops up on television screens as kindly, folksy Mr. Merritt, spokesman for a well-known brand of flea collars.

title: MEXICAN FARM DISTRIBUTION IS MODEL CASE OF BREAKDOWN
description: MEXICO CITY MEXICO'S agrarian reform, decreed after the 1910 revolution, is still held up throughout Latin America as an example of how land distribution should not be carried out. Its disastrous results are visible today in the grim living conditions of the peasantry and the rising cost to the country of imported food. But there is another, perhaps more cynical, certainly more political way of judging the reform: By handing out tiny, often arid plots to millions of peasants, Mexico bought six decades of rural peace.

title: Vietnamese Says Soviet Won't Be Granted Bases
description: Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach of Vietnam said in an interview published today that his country did not plan to allow the Soviet Union to establish bases on its territory.

title: By Peter G. Davis; Music: Debuts in Review; Royal Harris, Tenor, Displays Lyric Repertory
description: Royal Harris, a tenor who has frequently been heard in concert, oratorio and opera around the New York metropolitan area, gave his New York recital debut in Alice Tully Hall last Sunday night. Although Mr. Harris possesses an extremely light-textured voice that is not always technically secure in its upper register, he chose a sensible program, concentrating on a lyric repertory that would generally show his resources off to best advantage.

title: Art; WORKS OF STANLEY SPENCER ON VIEW AT YALE CENTER
description: NEW HAVEN THE 58 paintings by Stanley Spencer at the Yale Center for British Art are but an excerpt from a large retrospective that was staged last year at London's Royal Academy. But for some viewers, they may be more than enough. A figurative painter who died, knighted, in 1959, Spencer was no formal revolutionary even by the standards of his own time. Yet his work, often willful, mystical and more than a little erotic, is as likely to embarrass its spectators as inspire them.

title: 2 Children Are Killed and 5 Hurt By Fire in a Brooklyn Apartment
description: Two sleeping children were killed and five others injured early yesterday in a supicious fire in their Brooklyn apartment, officials said.

title: WIND CHILL, ICE AND SNOW HAVE ADHERENTS
description: THERE are some very warm-blooded residents of the county who have a passion for winter. In a simple cosmology, they can be divided into those who favor ice, some who prefer snow and a minority who literally thrive on a good wind-chill factor.

title: The Week of the Split Screen
description: Inauguration is always a time for emotions. The Outs try, with mixed success, to keep stiff upper lips as they pack up. The Ins, sure that theirs is a triumph of principle, not just party, flaunt furs and dance till dawn. The feelings of both are understandable and healthy, releasing the energies that keep the political merry-goround turning. But this year, the emotional climate is vastly more complex; roller coaster is more like it. What energies will be released now?

title: THUROW AND WAGES
description: To the Business Editor: Professor Thurow occupies one of the world's most prestigious chairs and every time he writes a book it is reviewed as if he were the new Keynes or Schumpeter. But the best suggestion he offers to counter inflation, exemplifying last year, is to reduce incomes by 4 percent. What would this do but replace stagnation with inflation by stagnation without inflation? WILLIAM STANNAGE Associate, the Society of Petroleum Engineers Stamford, Conn., Jan. 12, 1981

title: THE PSYCHIATRIST IN TODAY'S MOVIES:HE'S EVERYWHERE AND IN DEEP TROUBLE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Linda B. Martin is a freelance writer based in New York. By LINDA B. MARTIN

title: HIGH, UNSTEADY INTEREST RATES GIVE BUILDERS FITS
description: Peter Kalikow pulled back the drapes at the window in the 26thfloor executive suite of the Park Avenue headquarters of Kalikow Construction Corporation.

title: Sled Dogs to Compete in Championships
description: In a setting that evokes a wilderness story by Jack London, the International Sled Dog Championships will take place at Saranac Lake in upstate New York from Friday through Sunday.

title: A SUBTLER RELATIVE OF ANOREXIA IS GATHERING VICTIMS
description: TEANECK ''IHATED my fat body and was unable to stick to a diet,'' said 31-year-old Joanne. 'I'm 5 feet 1 inch, and have weighed as much as 186 pounds. At the age of 19, I discovered that I could lose weight by forcing myself to vomit after eating. I still binged, but - afraid of losing my new, slender figure - eating/vomiting became a way of life.''

title: THERE'S NOTHING OFFHAND ABOUT MR. CAREY,
description: NOW By RICHARD J. MEISLIN

title:
The Lively Arts;
NASSAU GIVES PUPPETRY A BOOST
description: EAST MEADOW ANOTHER opening, another show. So today at noon the lights in a tiny theater nestled in a corner of Eisenhower Park here will dim and then go up to reveal a wicked gypsy sorceress, a gentle queen and a puzzled king, a bewitched princess and, naturally, a heroic young man.

title: Judson Griffin, a Violist, Plays 20th-Century Pieces
description: Judson Griffin has been so busy as a violist around New York and elsewhere that his solo debut at Carnegie Recital Hall Monday evening seemed more an afterthought than an initiation.

title: RANGERS SET BACK CANUCKS, 7-5
description: The Rangers recovered from a 5-1 loss in Winnipeg Wednesday night by routing the Oilers in Edmonton Friday night, 7-4, scoring the last five goals while holding the Oilers scoreless over the last 27 minutes 25 seconds of the game. They made it two straight last night with a 7-5 triumph over the Vancouver Canucks at Vancouver. The game was marked by fights and scrappy offensive play between two struggling teams.

title: IRANIAN REFUGEES VISIT EX-HOSTAGES' HOSPITAL TO EXPRESS SYMPATHY
description: A delegation of 52 Iranian refugees living in West Germany and representing groups that are seeking the overthrow Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini came to the hospital today where the former hostages are staying and presented them with bouquets of 52 red roses and a copy of ''The Rubaiyat'' of Omar Khayyam, the Persian classic.

title: HOW THE COUNTY IS DEALING WITH THE WATER CRISIS
description: WESTCHESTER residents will have to cut their water usage in progressive steps beginning immediately, officials say: For now by using a third less water for bathing and for washing dishes and clothes; in the spring, by watering their gardens only with ''gray'' or second-hand water, and in the summer, by cutting back on airconditioning. Commercial and industrial enterprises are also being asked to find ways to conserve.

title: City Hall Notes
description: Nearly 18 months after Mayor Koch proposed a study of the merger of the city's three police forces, he has reportedly concluded that it would be too costly, both financially and politically, to go ahead with the merger. Instead, he has decided to continue the forces' less formal ''operational unification'' and ''coordination'' under Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire. But there are a number of subjective and practical considerations behind the objective reasons for this decision, which were cited in a memorandum to the Mayor from his criminal justice coordinator, Robert G. M. Keating.

title: L.I. FOOD SHOPPERS FEEL FLORIDA'S COLD
description: THE frigid temperatures that invaded the fruit and vegetable fields of Florida two weeks ago have already forced up some prices in Long Island grocery stores by as much as 25 percent. Produce buyers warn that good weather for the rest of the harvest season might not bring them down to prefreeze levels before summer.

title: A WILD 'TARTUFFE' AND A BLAND 'FORUM'
description: MONTCLAIR HAS SOME mad Italian chef cooked up a deep-fried mozzarella dish and then splattered it over the Whole Theater Company's stage? Not at all. Harold deFelice, ''Tartuffe's'' adapter-director, has concocted a spicy gastronomical platter that most audiences should find a welcome house specialty.

title: Atlanta Puts Porn Purveyors to Flight
description: The going got too tough, so Atlanta's ''adult entertainment'' businesses got going last weekend, leaving only three adult theaters and one peepshow where four years ago 44 such businesses had flourished. Under terms of an accord with Fulton County prosecutors, if the stores ''stay gone'' for the next six months, more than 40 cases pending against their employees will probably be dismissed.

title: CONCERT: SHOSTAKOVICH FIFTH CONDUCTED BY ROSTROPOVICH
description: In one obvious sense, Friday night belonged to Mstislav Rostropovich, as he began the New York portion of a four-concert celebration of the 25th anniversary of his American debut at Carnegie Hall.

title: Rockets 106, Jazz 91
description: Moses Malone and Calvin Murphy combined for 36 points as Houston dealt Utah its fifth straight loss. Houston forced 25 turnovers by the Jazz during the game to score 32 of its points.

title: ANXIETY INAGRICULTURE
description: Anxiety is widespread among agricultural economists that if 1981 also proves to be a disappointing crop year, the consequences could be severe.

title: POLITICAL GIFTS BY GRUMMAN COVER A BROAD SPECTRUM
description: THE Grumman Corporation Political Action Committee last year dispensed at least $166,675 to political candidates not only on the Island, but also across the country and across the party and ideological spectrum.

title: Michigan State 74, Purdue 68
description: Kevin Smith scored a seasonhigh 28 points today, including 14 free throws in the second half, to lead Michigan State to a 74-68 Big Ten victory over Purdue.

title: The London Times Succumbs to an Offer by Murdoch
description: Just the rumor that Rupert Murdoch was a likely purchaser of the Times of London sent shivers along Fleet Street. But when it was announced last week that the Australian publisher and owner of The New York Post had closed the deal, albeit conditionally, it was more than some could take.

title: GALBRAITH
description: To the Business Editor: Tax reduction would not, as noted by Prof. John Kenneth Galbraith in ''Musings of a (Relative) Conservative'' (Jan. 4), increase the cash flow of loss-ridden corporations. Fortunately, much of American industry earns enough to pay taxes.

title: HOSTAGE SETTLEMENT, POINT AND COUNTERPOINT
description: To the Editor:

title: The Wellesley researchers have discovered that middle-aged American women are quite happy. As a middle-aged man, I conclude from the article that: (1) American ''midlife'' women really do not need men at all, and (2) the happiest are those who take charge of important things as well as raise a family.
description: There is nothing entirely new here. Women have been in charge in America where it matters - in the mind and the heart, and in the culture - for many, many years.

title: A DAY FOR DR. KING
description: To the Editor:

title: MAURICE SCHEXNAYDER
description: Bishop Maurice Schexnayder, who served as head of the Lafayette Roman Catholic diocese for more than 16 years, died yesterday. He was 85 years old.

title: TAIWAN, CHINA TRADE WORDS-BUT THEY TRADE
description: Delighted to have a traditional friend enter the White House, Taiwan last week began openly lobbying the Reagan Administration for favors refused by Jimmy Carter since he transferred formal diplomatic recognition from the island of 17.5 million people to the mainland of more than 1 billion two years ago.

title: Thomas Moore to Wed Barbara Bennett, Artist
description: Mr. and Mrs. James G. Bennett Jr. of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Therese Bennett, to Thomas Nelson Moore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph F. Moore of Greenwich, Conn.

title: ERROR ON WINFIELD CONTRACT HAS YANKS RENEGOTIATING
description: Dave Winfield and the Yankees are on the verge of signing a contract -again. The first contract between the celebrated free agent and the team most noted for signing celebrated free agents could have a maximum value of $23.3 million to Winfield. The second one, which is being written because George Steinbrenner apparently didn't read the first one closely enough or didn't understand it, is expected to be worth $3 million to $4 million less.

title: Connecticut Wins in Overtime
description: Bobby Dulin and Karl Hobbs made seven foul shots in overtime to give Connecticut a 75-73 victory today over Georgetown in a Big East Conference basketball game.

title: WHAT TO CHEER ABOUT; Clemency in Seoul
description: Wisely, South Korean President Chun Doo Hwan has commuted the death sentence hanging over his troublesome democratic challenger, Kim Dae Jung. It is also welcome news that the President is ending martial law and has reduced the prison sentences of others tried on political charges along with Mr. Kim.

title: Peter Sellers's Widow Is Married To David Frost in British Village
description: David Frost and Lynne Frederick, the widow of Peter Sellers, were married near here today. Mr. Frost, a 41-year-old television personality, and the British actress, who is 26, have been seen together frequently since December.

title: SKIING THE STEEPS
description: Peter Miller is a photographer and a contributing editor of Ski Magazine. By Peter Miller The headwall of Tuckerman Ravine on Mount Washington in New Hampshire is shaped like the inside of a teacup - and it is just about as steep, relatively speaking. A person standing on the rim of the headwall with skis on looks down and sort of under to the ''lunch rocks'' and the outrun half a mile below.

title: VIEWS
description: CARTOON CAPTIONS with sinking ship cartoon Pat Oliphant The Washington Star Universal Press Syndicate with Haig's confirmation cartoon Gene Basset Scripps-Howard Newspapers United Feature Syndicate with dollar sign cartoon Don Wright The Miami News New York Times Special Features with small Ayatollah cartoon Jim Borgman The Cincinnati Enquirer King Features Syndicate Views A portfolio from around the nation with Jim Borgman's little ayatollah cartoon ''The Imam says he misses the hostages.'' with Oliphant's big dollars cartoon ''Your ship, Captain!''

title: Critics' Choice; MUSIC
description: When Eduardo Fernandez made his New York debut in 1977, it was immediately clear that the somber-faced young Uruguayan guitarist typified the new generation of superior technicians and scrupulous musicians who were flooding into the world's concert halls. Following in the wake of Andres Segovia and profiting from the Spaniard artist's pioneering successes, these virtuosos, many of them products of strict academic schooling in universities and major conservatories, have lifted the classic, unamplified instrument to new levels of acceptance in serious music and new levels of public popularity as well. Mr. Fernandez, whose recital at the 92d Street Y on Thursday at 8 P.M. will open the sixth annual classic guitar series there, impressed this reviewer four years ago as an outstanding example of the new breed.

title: REPUBLICANS PLAN A WIDER CONTEST
description: The inauguration of the 15th Republican President may have been a moment of more than ordinary historic note. It may have been a significant marker on the road to a classic political realignment. With the Presidency, the Senate for the first time in a quarter century, a narrower deficit than usual in the House, gains in state capitals and a strong political apparatus, the Republicans are in a position to exploit conservative strains in the national mood. They may well manage to convert themselves from a minority party that sometimes wins big, as they did in 1980, into a majority party.

title: Westchester Guide; ARCHITECTURAL EXHIBITIION
description: Those who are fascinated by architectural drawings will be in their element at the ''City Segments'' exhibition opening today in the Neuberger Museum of the State University College of New York at Purchase. The show runs through March 15.

title: BRITISH LABORITES MOVE SHARPLY TO LEFT
description: The Labor Party took a decisive step to the left today, radically altering the rules by which it selects its leader, a move that seemed likely to provoke a major ideological split within the party.

title: THE RISE OF AMERICAN EXPORTS
description: T HOUGH not widely recognized, a new trading power is making its presence felt on the global stage: the United States. ''We always used to talk about the U.S. being less trade-oriented than other countries, but that has changed markedly in recent years,'' says Helen B. Junz, an international economist at Townsend-Greenspan & Company, an economics consulting firm. ''American industry is more and more dependent on exports for its business.''

title: Temple 59, Manhattan 53
description: Temple survived nearly six and a half minutes without scoring at the start of the second half yesterday to post a 59-53 victory over Manhattan.

title: Cabinet Seems Set, Although It's Slow At Lower Levels
description: There was grumbling, to be sure. Senator William Proxmire, in the best tradition of the opposition, complained last week that, during their time in the confirmation dock, most of Ronald Reagan's Cabinet prospects had acted like ''prisoners of war trying to keep vital secrets from the enemy.''

title: FEMALE ATHELETES: MORE TO LOSE THAN JUST THEUR ORGANIZATION
description: ALMOST two weeks ago at a cocktail party in Miami Beach, a man tried to give me a present, ''a token of our future friendship'' he called it. It was a silver coin embossed on one side with the face of a pig and on the other side with the other side of a pig - the side with the tail.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
The Long, Dry Spell Gets Longer, Dryer
description: Greenwich, Conn., has always been known as Perrier country, and in about three weeks reality may catch up with its reputation. If there is no rain by then, officials say, the town's reservoirs will run dry.

title: Jane Connolly, E. J. Schwarz, Lawyer, Wed
description: Jane D. Connolly, daughter of Edward J. Connolly of Brooklyn and the late Jane Burke Connolly, was married yesterday to Edward Jon Schwarz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Schwarz of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Michael G. Campanalonga, Roman Catholic chaplain at the Stevens Institute of Technology, and Rabbi Philip E. Schechter of Temple Shaari Emeth in Englishtown, N.J., performed the ceremony jointly at the Burden Mansion in New York.

title: West Virginia 85 St. Bonaventure 69
description: Greg Jones, a sophomore guard, scored 31 points to lead West Virginia to an 85-69 triumph over St. Bonaventure today and keep the Mountaineers undefeated in Eastern Eight competition.

title: GROWTH INSERVICES
description: The largest single contributor to the United States balance-ofpayments position is services, not manufactures or agriculture and raw materials.

title: U.S. Ships Visiting Egyptian Port
description: Two United States Navy vessels have arrived for a four-day visit to Alexandria. The destroyer John Rogers and the frigate W.S. Sims docked yesterday and will rejoin the Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean on Tuesday, a United States Embassy spokesman said.

title: BOSSY GETS 50TH TO EQUAL MARK
description: The Islanders' Mike Bossy became tonight the second player in National Hockey League history to score 50 goals in the first 50 games of the season. After being held scoreless by the Quebec Nordiques at Nassau Coliseum, Bossy got his 49th and 50th goals in the final 4 minutes 10 seconds to match the feat first accomplished by Maurice (Rocket) Richard of Montreal in the 1944-45 season.

title: FARMERS ASK REAGAN TO KEEP VOW TO LIFT GRAIN EMBARGO
description: President Reagan, in office only five days, is already threatened by a gathering political storm in the Middle Western Farm Belt as he ponders whether to keep his campaign pledge to lift the partial embargo on grain sales to the Soviet Union.

title: Dulwich Gallery Reopens
description: The Dulwich College Picture Gallery in southeast London reopened its doors this month after being closed for redecoration and already it is attracting many visitors with its enriched rooms, long-hidden treasures and new exhibits.

title: Keene Valley Duo Wins Lake Placid Bobsledding
description: The two-man team of Bob Nicholson and Donald Lawrence of the Hurricane Bobsled Club of Keene Valley, N.Y., won the Lucien Miron bobsled event today.

title: CLERGYMAN DENIES HE SPOKE IN ANGER
description: Your feature article in the Connecticut section of this morning's Times ("Sharing Life and Priesthood," Dec. 21) on the Reverend Ann and Michael Coburn ("Reverends" in your caption is comparable to describing a pair of judges as "the Honorables John and Mary Doe") contained an attribution to me on which I would comment. I quote: "... At their ordination...the Rev. William D. Loring...stood up in anger and stormed, 'I am convinced that Ann Coburn's womanhood is an impediment to the priesthood.'

title: About Westchester
description: IRVINGTON THE auditorium in Town Hall on Main Street here is being restored, and at least one village resident is concerned. Katharine Randall, who is 88 years old, is worried that people arriving to attend theatrical events may have trouble finding a parking space. After all, she said, ''When I went to the theater there, I traveled in a horse and carriage.''

title: The A.F.C.'s Dominance Is an N.F.L. Product
description: To the Sports Editor: On Jan. 12, 1969, the New York Jets and Joe Namath of the American Football League made sports history by beating the heavily favored Baltimore Colts of the National Football League, 16-7, in Super Bowl III. This established a parity between the leagues, which was accentuated the following year, when Len Dawson and the Kansas City Chiefs beat Minnesota, 23-7.

title: The New Jewish Immigrants
description: In the analysis of Jewish migration patterns, one loses sight of the crucial problem (''America's New Wave of Jewish Immigrants,'' by Drora Kass and Seymour Martin Lipset, Dec. 7). Without greater commitment to Jewish ideals, Jews will ''be lost to the Jewish world'' regardless of their points of origin and destination. Most important, this includes Israelis living in Israel. ERIC SEGAL, Teaneck, N.J.

title:
Long Island Housing;
BANS ON KEROSENE STOVES AROUSE IRE
description: KEROSENE stoves, which are commonly used to heat homes in Europe and Japan, are creating controversy. New York State building and fire codes - which are applicable only when adopted by local authorities - ban them completely, a provision of the Real Property Law restricts the amount of fuel a kerosene heater can contain at any one time, and some local housing codes also ban their use.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JANUARY 25, 1981
description: International Millions of Poles did not go to work, taking a ''free Saturday'' to back the independent union movement's demands or a five-day workweek. The response to the boycott, which had been urged in a personal and dramatic appeal by Lech Walesa, Solidarity's leader, was even more widely observed than a similar protest Jan. 10. (Page 1, Column 6.) The freed hostages' families gathered in the Washington area from where they will depart today for Stewart Airport near Newburgh, N.Y. for their long-awaited reunion with the former captives, who will arrive there from West Germany. The group will stay at Thayer Hotel at the United States Military Academy at West Point for the rest of the weekend. On Tuesday the reunited families will be honored at a full-scale White House reception, similar to those given to visiting heads of state. (1:1-2.)

title: Pornography
description: To the Editor:

title: THUROW AND WAGES
description: To the Business Editor: Professor Thurow focuses on the most perverse, although probably the least discussed, procedural obstacle to feasible price stabilization: the scattered scheduling of major union contract negotiations and the overlapping maturities of multi-year agreements.

title: Jody Williams Rice, Student, Betrothed to John B. Crouse
description: Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey Lewis Perry of Norwalk, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Perry's daughter, Jody Williams Rice, to John Bouvier Crouse, son of Michelle Scott Crouse of Darien, Conn., and William McIntosh Crouse Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: TAKING THE BOUNCE OUT OF BAD CHECKS
description: ''When a customer is buying a $200.00 dollar item and we won't take his check he bristles a bit, and I don't blame him,'' says the owner of To Boot, a Manhattan store specializing in high quality clothing and cowboy boots. ''But since we started with this check service, the store and customer have had peace of mind.''

title: Paige and Belger Win Despite Obstacles
description: When track and field athletes finish college, they often discover that training becomes more difficult, more demanding, more disruptive and less routine. And as training problems increase, their level of performance often diminishes.

title: DANCE: SHORT-SHORTS FROM SHELA XOREGOS
description: Certain very short short stories have been nicknamed ''shortshorts.'' Although such stories are scarcely more than anecdotes, within their confines writers may cram twists of plot, surprise endings and flashes of insight.

title: Eagles' Practice Shortened As Coach Notes Tenseness
description: Coach Dick Vermeil abruptly halted the Eagles' final practice for the Super Bowl after 25 minutes today.

title: Index; The Hostages
description: Reporter's Notebook: How to tor- ment your Iranian captor 1 The hostages' ordeal: initial pieces of an unfinished mosaic 10 U.S. repeatedly protests Soviet re- porting on hostages 11 Iranian refugees visit ex-hos- tages' hospital in Germany 11 West Point prepares private reun- ion for freed 52 and kin 12 Long-awaited journey begins for family of Sergeant Lopez 12 International Trudeau battles Montreal intellec- tuals on Quebec issue 4 Around the World 5 Taiwan Premier hopes Reagan will send arms, including jets 6 Verdict due in Peking for 10 for- mer leaders 7 China is preparing to try a new learning tool: 'Sesame Street' 7 Japanese said to decide to drop most claims against Chrysler 8 Leaders of 37 nations and P.L.O. set to open Islamic conference 13 Kopelev says he believes in Rus- sia, despite loss of citizenship 14 Malaysia confronting environ- mental issues 15 Government/Politics Senator Hatch urges curbs on powers of OSHA 18 Philadelphia in dispute over tax assessments 21 Pittsburgh invites 21 Nobelists to opening of convention hall 22 Refusal to indict Newark Mayor for tax fraud disclosed 34 General Farmers urge that President Rea- gan lift the grain embargo 16 Around the Nation 20 New Orleans throbs with Super Bowl mania 20 Education/Welfare College taps natural gas well to help meet heating bills 30 New Center for Urban Studies to focus on New York City 31 Donor from Kenya sends $250 to Neediest Cases Fund 39 Arts/Entertainment 7 Short Dances by Xoregos Per- forming Company reviewed 41 Music debuts in review 42 Small New York companies re- vive two old plays 43 Four works by the City Ballet 46 Susan Hayes and Neill Clegg offer French music 47 Style On Seventh Avenue, a foretaste of summer 49 Obituaries Harold K. Hochschild, former head of large metals company 32 Stephan Hurwitz, Denmark's first ombudsman 32

title: WHAT BECAME OF CHILDHOOD INNOCENCE?
description: Once upon a time, in the Golden Age of Innocence, an imaginary 12-year-old girl from New England named Lolita slept with a middle-aged European intellectual named Humbert Humbert and shocked American sensibilities; the daily reviewer of The New York Times called Vladimir Nabokov's novel ''repulsive'' and ''disgusting.''

title: BADLY NEEDED: SAFE DUMPS FOR NUCLEAR WASTE
description: More than 35 years ago, the United States began making atomic weapons; 24 years ago, the country's first commercial nuclear powered generating plant opened in Shippingport, Penn. Yet this country has still to dispose of its first pound of high-level waste from either armament factories or utility plants.

title: COLLEGE STUDENT WAS SHOT IN HEAD AFTER MAKING REMARK TO A ROBBER
description: A Columbia University graduate student in philosophy was near death in St. Luke's Hospital yesterday, apparently the victim of a chance remark he made to a holdup man on Morningside Drive the night before.

title: Plankton Gives Hernandez 4th Stakes Winner of Year
description: The jockey Ruben Hernandez won his fourth stakes race of the year, driving Plankton to a 2 3/4-length victory over Sweet Maid yesterday in the $57,300 Affectionately Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: L.S.U. ROUTS TENNESSEE, 80-63
description: Howard Carter and a freshman, Leonard Mitchell, combined for 37 points tonight as fifth-ranked Louisiana State won its 16th straight, an 80-63 Southeastern Conference victory over Tennessee.

title: HOSTAGE SETTLEMENT, POINT AND COUNTERPOINT
description: To the Editor:

title: THERE'S ROUGH RIDING ON THE L.I.R.R.
description: ''Change at Jamaica,'' the conductor repeats as he collects tickets in a crowded car of Long Island Rail Road, a reminder to many generations of commuters that they must switch trains at the mammoth Jamaica Station, the mechanical and administrative heart of the country's busiest passenger railroad.

title: WELLS COLLEGE TAPS A GAS WELL ON CAMPUS FOR FUEL
description: From wherever entrepreneurs go when they die, Henry Wells might look favorably on Patti McGill Peterson's first major act as the new president of Wells College, which he founded in 1868. Within two weeks of taking on the job, Dr. Peterson raised $100,000 to drill for natural gas on the campus.

title: Citing History, Voiding Citizenship
description: Once granted, American citizenship can be revoked only for the gravest of reasons, and the Supreme Court last week found such a reason in the case of Feodor Fedorenko. The Court ruled, 7 to 2, that Mr. Fedorenko's failure to disclose, when he applied for a displaced person's visa in 1949, that he had been a guard at the Nazi extermination camp of Treblinka, meant that his citizenship, obtained in 1970, was ''illegally procured'' and therefore subject to automatic revocation.

title: Seoul's Enlightened Self-Interest Shows
description: Executing Kim Dae Jung, the South Korean opposition leader, would have made for ''inconvenient relations'' with the Reagan Administration, a headline in a Seoul newspaper suggested last week. President Chun Doo Hwan, who is scheduled to meet Mr. Reagan on Feb. 2, agreed and commuted Mr. Kim's death sentence to life imprisonment.

title: A NATION OF BUTTON PUSHERS
description: What do computer terminals, videotape machines, TouchTone telephones, electronic calculators and microwave ovens have in common? Along with wires and plastic housing, every one has at least one push button. And with the boom in such gadgetry, push-button production could soon displace the paperclip.

title: STEPHAN HURWITZ, DANISH OMBUDSMAN
description: Prof. Stephan Hurwitz, an international jurist who became Denmark's first Parliamentary Commissioner for Public Affairs, or ombudsman, died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Landrieu Hints Presidential Bid
description: Moon Landrieu, the former Mayor of New Orleans who spent two years in the Carter Administration as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, says he is considering running for President in 1984. ''I recognize that if I decide to run for the Presidency it will be a long, hard struggle,'' Mr. Landrieu said Thursday. ''But the opportunity is there.''

title: HOSTAGE SETTLEMENT, POINT AND COUNTERPOINT
description: To the Editor:

title: SKI VICTORY FOR MISS MCKINNEY
description: Tamara McKinney, an 18-year-old skier from Olympic Valley, Calif., won her second women's World Cup giant slalom in a row today.

title: Anne Hawthorne Dallas Fiancee of Gerald A. Vernon Jr.
description: The engagement of Anne Hawthorne Dallas to Gerald Angier Vernon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon of Darien, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Kevin D. Dallas of Pleasantville, N.Y. A wedding in June is planned.

title: ONE BUSBOY'S CORPORATE PERCEPTION
description: To the Editor:

title: THE RUNOFF:A CHANCE FOR A MAJOR CHANGE
description: OVER the years, election laws have been changed to meet the demands of democracy. This century has seen the extension of suffrage, the advent of the primary election and the introduction of popularly elected United States Senators.

title: Ohio State 69, Michigan 63
description: Ohio State got 23 points from Herb Williams and played a tough man-to-man defense tonight to beat Michigan, 69-63, and move into a share of the Big Ten lead.

title: WILLIAM LEVITT,73, IN BUSINESS, BUT NOT AS 'LEVITT'
description: William J. Levitt's construction crews are carving vast tracts of pine scrub land just south of this city into a retirement community that is a subtropical, 1980's-priced version of the Levittowns he began building outside of northeastern cities following World War II.

title: ON SEVENTH AVENUE, A FORETASTE OF SUMMER
description: Oscar de la Renta believes so strongly in the need for fresh summer dresses for all those parties and festive weekends starting with Memorial Day that he always plans a formal fashion show to present his warm-weather clothes. Besides, the deadline of the show itself helps him pull his thoughts together, he insists.

title:
Art;
2 TAKE EXPERIENCE TO HASTINGS GALLERY
description: ISABEL BISHOP and Dorothy Dehner are the artists whose work is on view at the gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson through Feb. 22. Although space is limited, the exhibition, which includes 68 objects, never seems cramped, because it has been beautifully designed and most of the work is relatively small.

title: WHAT 52 CAPTIVES UNDERWENT IN IRAN: INITIAL PIECES IN AN UNFINISHED MOSAIC
description: For some, life as a hostage was a nightmare of death threats, mock executions, beatings and humiliations. For others, it was an agony of solitary confinement in dank, windowless dungeons and dark, frigid cells. For many, it was an ordeal of deprivation in which conversation, fresh air, exercise, news, mail and showers were forbidden. And for a few, such as the two women kept hostage for the 14 months, it was the fear of the unknown.

title: Book Ends; BECKETT IN PARIS; PARIS
description: As he walked into the little cafe on the Blvd. St. Jacques in the 14th Arrondissement, everything about Samuel Beckett seemed at once familiar and unexpected. The penetrating blue eyes, the furrowed brow, the strong beak, the lined face that seemed as if it had been carved in polished granite: They were all there. But the impression of hardness and diffidence acquired from remembered photographs and stories didn't match this man. For everything about him was softer and warmer by degrees: the pleasant voice, the ironic glint in his eyes, the cordial air he conveyed made a stranger in his beloved city feel like a guest.

title: U.S. Institute in Colombia Rejects Demand to Close
description: The Summer Language Institute has rejected a demand by leftist guerrillas to leave Colombia, despite a threat to kill a kidnapped American linguist, Chester A. Bitterman 3d.

title: Priming the Pump For Arms Outlays
description: The new Administration isn't expected to say until well into next month how it wants to tinker with the budget for the Department of Defense that the old Administration left behind. But the Reagan team is getting plenty of notice that Congress is in a hawkish - and insistent - mood.

title: A FRENCH 'TITIAN' COMES TO NEW YORK
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Henry Popkin is a professor of English at the State University of New York at Buffalo. By HENRY POPKIN

title: CORRECTION
description: In the National Economic Survey published Jan. 11, a chart listing law firms incorrectly showed the number of lawyers working at Baker & Botts.

title: Children of the Extended Family
description: In ''The New Extended Family''(Nov. 23), Michael Norman interviewed one parent, both a father and a stepfather, who captured the complexity of his multiple roles when he said: ''... if one of my boys and one of (my wife's) girls were about to be hit by a car and I could only save one of them, which would it be? I'd save my own kid.'' Fortunately, it is very unlikely that this parent will have to make such a choice.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Fed Hits Housing

title: WASHINGTON PRESSES PROTESTS TO SOVIET
description: The United States Embassy said today that it had protested repeatedly to the Soviet Government over the last 10 days about the way Moscow's state-controlled media have reported the news of the Iranian hostages.

title: AUTO EMISSIONS PLAN IS DRAWING CRITICISM
description: WHILE few question the goal, irate service-station owners and some motorists are protesting state implementation of a new program to control automobile emissions in the metropolitan area.

title: 'Easy' Marriage Annulments Are Denounced by the Pope
description: Pope John Paul II today denounced ''easy and hurried'' marriage annulments granted by Roman Catholic Church courts.

title: Louise Woolworth Bride in Bahamas Of G. H. Lamphere
description: Louise Gorton Woolworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Griswold Woolworth of Lancaster, Pa., was married yesterday to Gilbert Hicks Lamphere, son of Mr. and Mrs. Renfield Dews Lamphere of Indian Head Park, Ill. and Bridgeton, Me. The ceremony was performed in St. Christopher's Episcopal Church, Lyford Cay, Bahamas, by the Rev. George E. Andrews of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich.

title: JOHN KELJIKAN
description: John Keljikan, an industrial developer and head of Cariboil Inc., a concern that had been exploring for oil in Santo Domingo, died of a heart attack Wednesday while at a business conference in the Petroleum Club in Houston. Mr. Keljikan, who was a resident of Manhattan, was 55 years old.

title: Critics' Choice
description: GUIDE Page 3

title: No Headline
description: The following letter was received by Katherine Heaviside of Huntington Bay from her friend Suzanne Guzzo, who moved from the Island to St. Louis. DEAR Kathy:

title: Christine Corcoran Bride Of Philip Wiswell, Editor
description: Christine Barbara Corcoran, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Corcoran of Moorestown, N.J., and Philip Merrill Wiswell, son of Dr. and Mrs. John G. Wiswell of Baltimore, were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Rev. Patrick F. Magee of Belfast, Northern Ireland, performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: EXAMINING IN DETAIL THE ALLURING MELODIE OF FRANCE
description: F rom Berlioz to Messiaen, the French have developed a rich song tradition, although precious little of it ever surfaces in recitals. Singers often program the token French group, but it generally consists of the same familiar standards. Debussy, for example, wrote about 85 songs, less than a dozen of which ever turn up in concert - 25 even remain unpublished to this day. Until recently, the picture was just as bleak on recordings, but thanks to the arrival of several imported disks, it is now possible to examine French song at length and in detail.

title: State Is Taken to Task On Prescription Program
description: On Dec. 29, Thomas M. Russo, director of the state's Division of Medical Assistance and Health Services, sent a Medicaid long-termcare services bulletin, No. 80-17, to all long-term-care skilled nursing and/or intermediate-care facilities. It stated that, effective Feb. 10, 1981, among the various services to be eliminated would be pharmacy services, including all legend and nonlegend drugs.

title: ADVANCES IN CARTRIDGE DESIGN
description: If you are thinking of updating your sound system, there is no better place to start than the phono cartridge. Because the cartridge is so small and inconspicuous - all but hidden in the tip of the tonearm - its importance is seldom appreciated. But with the exception of the speakers, no other component so strongly influences the character of the sound you hear from your records.

title: Arrows Beat Fever, 10-8, For 18th Straight Victory
description: Steve Zungul, leading scorer in the Major Indoor Soccer League, registered two goals and increased his season total to 71 as the New York Arrows outlasted the Philadelphia Fever, 10-8, last night at Nassau Coliseum before 7,411.

title: Explanation of Valley In Iceland Is Offered
description: In the Jan. 11 issue was an art review whose author, John Caldwell, wrote: ''A photograph of a U-shaped valley in North Iceland (Bleiksmyaradalur) shows a perfectly geometrical trough in a totally uninhabited snow-covered landscape.

title: METROPOLITAN MUSEUM EMPLOYEE IS HELD IN THEFT OF ANCIENT JEWELS
description: A cleaning man employed by the Metropolitan Museum of Art was arrested yesterday on charges of stealing six small items of ancient jewelry valued at more than $180,000.

title: N.Y. Tech 81, Hartwick 78
description: Billy Williams, a 6-foot-7-inch center, sank two free throws with five seconds remaining in the first overtime to give New York Tech an 81-78 victory over visiting Hartwick College Saturday night.

title: Tax Revolt Comes Up Short in Dallas
description: The outcome of last week's election on Dallas's version of Proposition 13 had been awaited eagerly by its proponents, who felt sure it would be approved, and apprehensively by City Hall, which shared that certainty.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE MAN WHO KEPT THE SECRETS, by Thomas Powers. (Pocket, $3.50.) A history of the C.I.A., centering on the career of Richard Helms, chief of the organization from 1966 to 1973, that raises disturbing questions about the proper role of such an organization in a democracy. Our reviewer John le Carre called it ''a splendid spy story, the best I have read in a long time.''

title: Fifth Avenue
description: Buccellati, one of the world's foremost jewelry concerns, has leased space in the Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue and 56th Street. The company will vacate its present location in the St. Regis Hotel on the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 55th Street.

title: TEACHER REMEMBERED WITH GRATITUDE
description: I'd like to match my Hannah Kirk against Jack McGarvey's Betty Brown ("A Downside to Teacher Controls," Opinion Page, Dec. 28) any day.

title:
Gardening;
TREES, SHRUBS CAN SAVE ENERGY INDOORS
description: PLANTS play a variety of roles in the landscape. Their esthetic appeal is universally recognized. Everyone appreciates an attractive flower, a red-fruited espalier trained against a stone wall, a flowering vine clinging to a white trellis or a well-proportioned grouping of shrubs nestled against the foundation of a home.

title: Jeanne Crumm Wed to Architect
description: Jeanne Crumm of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., widow of Martin P. Crumm, was married yesterday to Frank W. Munzer of Bedford Hills, N.Y. The Rev. John Duffell performed the ceremony in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Yorktown Heights.

title: Jonathan Abrams to Marry Ellen Finkelstein in August
description: Faye Finkelstein of Harrison, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Ellen Finkelstein, to Jonathan Abrams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Abrams of Johannesburg.

title: Long Islanders; SPREADING THE WORD ON C.P.A. EXPERTISE
description: ''THE 1970's were a time of very big turmoil for our profession,'' said Ralph A. Rehmet of Perelson & Rehmet, certified public accountants of Manhattan and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. ''The profession was under attack from critics for large-firm audit failures, and the large firms also became aggressive in merchandising their service, and our code-of-ethics rules were being changed. It was an era of change in our profession, and a lot of regional, medium-sized local firms started to feel threatened.''

title: GOOD BUYS IN FINE ART
description: ''W HAT your home could have in common with the Met, the Tate, and the Louvre,'' the advertisement begins enticingly. The offering? Limited edition prints by well-known - and some less-known - artists which, for a price, ''you can exhibit in your own home.''

title: THE JOYS AND PERILS OF JOGGING ABROAD
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- CHRISTOPHER S. WREN is a foreign correspondent for The New York Times. By CHRISTOPHER S.WREN

title: NEVADA WINS AND LOSES IN GAMING INDUSTRY BOOM
description: Through the l970's, Nevada was the fastestgrowing state in the country. With 110,540 square miles, it is the seventh largest state, and it now has as many people as Baltimore.

title: GRUMMAN, IN NOTICE TO 27 CITIES, CITES HAZARDOUS NEW BUS FLAW
description: The Grumman Corporation told officials in 27 cities yesterday that a newly discovered flaw in its Flxible buses could cause drivers to lose control unless repairs were made.

title: THE URBANE OLD PARIS SUBURB OF SAINT-GERMAIN-EN-LAYE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- MILT FREUDENHEIM is an editor on the staff of the Week in Review section of The Times. By MILT FREUDENHEIM

title: Relocation
description: U.S. Industries, a diversified manufacturer of consumer and industrial products, is relocating from New York City to Stamford, Conn.

title: Practical Traveler; CHOOSING A SPORTS VACATION
description: A couple from Dedham, Mass., checked into the Castle Harbour Hotel in Bermuda for a long-awaited four-day vacation. Their passion is golf, and they selected the hotel because it has an 18-hole, par-71 championship course. Through a travel agent, they bought what the Castle Harbour calls its ''golf special,'' which includes, besides accommodations and two meals a day, unlimited greens fees, three golf balls each, tees and souvenir caps and towels. The total cost for two was about $500.

title: RECITAL: VOCAL SAXOPHONE
description: The saxophone is a flexible instrument and as such, it invites the most sensitive of treatments and the most garish of abuses. In the orchestras of Berg and Ravel, its subtleties of intonation provide a new and almost human singing voice. In the complex passagework of jazz, the saxophone is willingly agile, but often less than lovely.

title: Birch Hincks Is Bride of Galen Burghardt Jr.
description: The marriage of Birch W. Hincks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Hincks of Farmington, Conn., to Galen D. Burghardt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Burghardt of Seattle, took place yesterday evening in Amherst, Mass. The Rev. James Clark performed the ceremony in the Grace Episcopal Church.

title: JAWORSKI TAKES STAR'S ROLE
description: NEW ORLEANS R ON JAWORSKI, who still goes bowling on Monday nights and calls himself ''the guy from the small city, small school,'' will become a Super Bowl quarterback today.

title: Dan Riddle, Pianist, In Mozart, Ravel and Liszt
description: Dan Riddle made his New York debut last Sunday evening in Carnegie Recital Hall playing piano music by Mozart, Ravel, Liszt and Brahms. Mr. Riddle's ideas are straightforward, sensibly organized and not overly troubled with subtlety. In one sense, his technique is impressive, capable of hammering through Liszt's ''Gnomenreigen'' and the sixth ''Hungarian Rhapsody'' with remarkable efficiency and power.

title: Phone Companies on Coast Told To Provide Free Devices for Deaf
description: California telephone companies have been ordered to start taking bids to provide free special service for deaf customers.

title: DAVID GRAHAM TAKES SHOT LEAD ON 69-202
description: The finale of the Phoenix open tomorrow promises to be tight and crowded, with 11 players within three strokes of the leader and 25 within four shots. This means a lot of players will be shooting aggressively at the flagsticks because anyone who plays a safe and conservative game will be left far behind.

title: TAIWAN'S PREMEIR HOPES REAGAN WILL SEND NEW ARMS
description: Taiwan hopes the Reagan Administration will quickly supply it with long-requested ''defensive arms,'' including modern American fighters, Prime Minister Sun Yun-suan says.

title: MANY STORIES
description: THE LONE PILGRIM Stories by Laurie Colwin. 224 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $9.95.

title: With Tears, Smiles And Grim Accounts The Hostages Return
description: ''When we got off the plane, we set our watches ahead 2,000 years,'' said Marine Sgt. Rodney V. Sickmann, one of the 52 hostage Americans who flew back to Western civilization last week, 4,000 miles across the centuries from Teheran.

title: THEY'RE FEEDING BIRDS THEY'LL LATER HUNT
description: CENTER MORICHES WILD ducks and geese flock to the shore when Frank Abel and his son, Robert, begin flinging dry corn on Moriches Bay. These birds, prey for the Abels and other Long Island hunters in the fall, have become beneficiaries of an extensive feeding program from Jamaica Bay to Shelter Island. In the next month the Abels and 150 others will disperse 40 tons of corn in order to save the waterfowl from what the men call the cruelty of starvation.

title: Eleanor Hodenpyl Sets June 6 Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Hodenpyl of Sag Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eleanor Payne Hodenpyl, to Robert Brendan Kirby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Kirby of Roosevelt, L.I.

title: Alison Keller, Banking Aide, Plans Nuptials
description: The engagement of Alison Dixon Keller to Charles Coe Townsend 3d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Oliver J. Keller Jr. of Atlanta and Harbor Springs, Mich., parents of the future bride. Mr. Townsend is a son of Mrs. Harold P. Salembier of Oyster Bay and East Hampton, L.I., and Mr. Townsend Jr. of New York and Germantown, N.Y.

title: Paperback Talk
description: For children of the 80's. Last year, you may recall, we reported that a gloomy air pervaded the children's book departments of many houses along Publishers Row. Their sales to schools and libraries - which once accounted for some 80 percent of their income - had dropped precipitously because of drastic reductions in those institutions' budgets. Moreover, like many educators, they were troubled by the fact that large numbers of the newest generation of young people, raised on the pictures-and-sound fascinations of television, seem reluctant to read printed matter.

title: No Headline
description: Clearly, we women at midlife are discovering that we are people - individuals on the brink of a new phase in our lives.

title: Children's Books
description: HAUNTED By Judith St.George. 158 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $7.95. (Ages 12 to 15) By JANE O'CONNOR

title: Yet Another Young Victim in Atlanta
description: Last week, for the 14th time in 19 months, Atlanta-area police made the same announcement. A black child had been found, murdered.

title: No Headline
