description: At a time when most of us are tightening our belts, cutting back and trying to make ends meet on macaroni - let alone meat - you feature prominently the life of the de la Rentas, whose life style and profligacy border on the decadent.

title: Critics' Choice
description: ART One of the hottest problems in the history of modern art, and one of the most difficult to resolve, is the question of whether or not the late paintings of Picasso were a total disaster. It is a hot problem, because almost every other period in Picasso's long career has held up well under very close scrutiny.

title: More Bloodletting In Bleeding Ulster
description: Fortress walls last week could not keep Northern Ireland's sectarian hatreds from consuming an aged Protestant leader, Sir Norman Stronge, and his son, James. Irish Republican Army terrorists shot the two in the library of the family's 18th-century castle, Tynan Abbey, then dragged the bodies outside and exploded bombs inside the castle, which was gutted by fire.

title: HOSTAGE SETTLEMENT, POINT AND COUNTERPOINT
description: To the Editor:

title: Stage View; SO WHAT ELSE IS NEW?  EVA LE GALLIENNE IS NEW; by Walter Kerr
description: Whenever an elderly performer is allotted a few warm paragraphs of heady praise in the press, there's usually a feeling among readers that the nice adjectives are offered out of ancient fondness, out of loyalty, out of respect for work past. ''Of course,'' the reader says, folding the newspaper and looking for the crossword puzzle, ''what else are they going to say about the old girl (or old boy) at this point?'' And sometimes it's true that the compliments are essentially conventional, a reward for unforgotten performances given long, long ago. Memories, you know, are like bank interest. They do yield dividends, even when nothing new has been paid in lately.

title: FREED HOSTAGES FINISH TESTS AND PREPSRE FOR TRIP HOME
description: The 52 former hostages in Iran spent their last full day of testing and rehabilitation at the Air Force Hospital here today, visiting friends or strolling around the grounds looking at the traffic jams caused by curious West Germans.

title: Theater In Review; 'SAME TIME': LOVE AS A PAT FORMULA
description: HERRICKS LIKE the wholesome, warm-hearted adulterous affair it celebrates, ''Same Time, Next Year'' should be acknowledged annually, if only for amenity's sake. For sure, the play comes up with fearsome regularity on local theater calendars. Let's say that seeing it once a year seems unavoidable; more than once is simply unnecessary.

title:
MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW;
Edgar Dittemore, Singer, Offers Niles, Rorem Songs
description: Edgar Dittemore, bass-baritone, made his debut at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday, Inauguration Day, and offered an exclusively American program. He began with a group of John Jacob Niles's ''Gambling Songs'' and continued with Robert Baksa's Housman Songs, a scene from Carlisle Floyd's ''Markheim'' and Ned Rorem's ''War Scenes.''

title: RYE,PORT CHESTER COUNT DAYS AND GALLONS
description: American Water Company in Greenwich for their water, life is a little harder.

title: Marti Bellingrath And Charles Atkins Set March 7 Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ferdinand McMillan Bellingrath of Pine Bluff, Ark., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Frances Martin Bellingrath, to Charles Agee Atkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Orin Ellsworth Atkins of Ashland, Ky.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: PURE SHELLAC AND ADULTURATED TOBACCO
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut Housing; FOR MORGAGE LOANS, CHECK OPTIONS
description: IS it still possible to obtain a mortgage loan at only 9 percent or 11 percent? Is it possible to avoid the large down payment? With conventional lending rates hovering in the mid-teens and house prices remaining high, it seems unlikely. Yet options do exist.

title: DRILLING RIGS ABOUND
description: Drilling contractors searched for oil and natural gas in the United States at a record rate in 1980, according to statistics compiled by the Hughes Tool Company and the Petroleum Information Corporation.

title: The Talking Car: A Conversation Piece
description: IF there is anything more disconcerting on a cold, quiet night than a car that suddenly talks to you, I don't want to know about it. The automobile in question was a blue Datsun 810 Maxima, a fourdoor sedan that had behaved itself nicely on the drive home. It had lavished me with luxury, to be sure. It had handled well and it had shown its six-cylinder spunk. But it had remained as taciturn as any other vehicle on the road.

title: MEDICAL COMMUNICATIONS
description: An increasingly common problem for doctors, nurses and other health professionals is the inability to communicate properly with patients of different ethnic and cultural backgrounds, and this can make effective treatment difficult.

title: REAGAN'S SHIFT TO CENTER BRINGS ATTACKS FROM RIGHT
description: In its first days in office, the Reagan Administration has found itself under attack from conservative legislators and activists who were among Ronald Reagan's earliest and most ardent supporters.

title: SOUTH KOREAN LEADER ENDS 456 DAYS OF MARTIAL LAW
description: President Chun Doo Hwan lifted martial law throughout South Korea today, ending 456 days of total or partial military authority.

title: PHILADELPHIA IN DISPUTE ON TAX ASSESSMENT FREEZE
description: The city agency that controls Philadelphia's property assessments is expected to ignore a new law freezing assessments at their present level for up to three years.

title: AFTER THE ANSCHLUSS
description: THE WATER CASTLE By Ingeborg Lauterstein. 408 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $12.95.

title: FOR SEEKERS OF SUN AND SEA, BARBADOS IS PARADISE ENOW
description: Friends of ours - a couple in their mid-50's - have been going to Barbados for years. Every February they spend a week there at Sandy Lane, a fashionable 20-year-old resort. This year they will pay about $310 a day for the two of them for their room, breakast and dinner, plus 18 percent for taxes and tips.

title: MISTAKES, DEFENSE, LIKELY KEY FACTORS 4)
description: In its early moments, through the first quarter at least, tomorrow's Super Bowl game between the Oakland Raiders and the Philadelphia Eagles is likely to resemble the beginning of a checkers or a chess match - minimal movement and a probing attitude.

title: Food; FINDING 'A BETTER WAY' IN THE KITCHEN
description: EAST HAMPTON WHY would anyone want to buy measuring cups with spouts at the bottom instead of the top, or an empty cookbook? Kenneth and Patricia Ferrin of East Hampton have discovered that thousands of people are delighted to have these items in the kitchen. The Ferrins' latest gadget, a five-inch disk with four holes in it, might prove to be even more popular.

title: Running to a Foot Doctor
description: Although your readers might not suspect it after reading Sally Ogle Davis's article ''The Battle of Wounded Knees'' (Dec. 7), the battle is over and the runners have won.

title: CONSERVATION'uf814Harold K. Hochschild, the former head of a large metals company and an active Adirondacks historian and conservationist, died Friday night at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after an eight-month illness. He was 88 years old and lived in Blue Mountain Lake, N.Y., and New York City.
description: Mr. Hochschild was for many years the executive head of the American Metal Company, which merged in 1957 and eventually became AMAX Inc. He retired after the merger, although he was serving as a director emeritus at the time of his death.

title: HOME INSPECTORS WEIGH CODE
description: Leaders of the newly established American Society of Home Inspectors have drawn up model legislation to regulate their industry.

title: WIDOW OF EX-TEXAS SPEAKER CHARGED WITH HIS MURDER
description: The widow of former Texas House Speaker Price Daniel Jr. was arrested tonight and charged with murder in the shooting of her husband, law-enforcement authorities said.

Now Mr. Danielian has come in from the road; he is a teacher at the New York Conservatory of Dance and, until last August, was the director of the American Ballet Theater School. But he can't seem to shake the aura of a traveler. His current kitchen, in a one-bedroom apartment near New York's Lincoln Center, is the Pullman type. Actually part of the living room, it is banked along one wall that also contains a stacked washer-dryer and storage space. (When not in use, all is concealed behind folding doors.) When he cooks for a crowd, he still hauls out a vinyl-topped ironing board to use as additional work space. And he continues to use an electric frying pan with a crumpled aluminum-foil division that allows one to cook two dishes at once.

title: 'PRINCESS DAISY' TO BE PUBLISHED IN A SPANISH PAPERBACK VERSION
description: ''Princess Daisy,'' the best-selling novel by Judith Krantz, which commanded a princely $3.2 million in paperback rights two years ago, will be published next spring in a Spanish-language edition aimed at America's growing Hispanic population. The Spanish title will be ''Princesa Daisy.''

title: The Libertarian Road
description: To most people, reaching 97 years of age is a distinction in itself. Roger Baldwin, however, had more than longevity to distinguish him on his 97th birthday last week.

title: Bill Bradley Among 12 To Get Thurman Awards
description: Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, will be one of 12 persons who will be presented Thurman Awards in honor of the late New York Yankees' captain, Thurman Munson, on Feb. 2 at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan.

title: WHY UNC WANTS AN AIRLINE
description: FALLS CHURCH, Va. W HEN he first heard the idea, Keith A. Cunningham found it a hard one to take seriously. After all, what business did his beleaguered uranium mining company have trying to enter the glamorous airline industry with a bid for a company whose sales were more than three times as large and that had already agreed to merge with another airline.

ALITTLE nook next to the cinema in a shopping center is an unlikely locale for pleasant Americanized French food, but the Joie de Vivre is just such a restaurant. It is situated in Chatham's Hickory Tree Mall and has been under new ownership since June.

title: New York Times Magazine January 25, 1981
description: William Safire 9 On Language Cheap Shots Russell Baker 12 Sunday Observer The Decline of Manners Marie Winn 14 What Became of Childhood Innocence? Peter Miller 18 Skiing the Steeps The current kick for ski purists is scaling and descending slopes with a 60-degree pitch. To the rest of us, this might resemble skiing down an elevator shaft.

title: EX-PLAYER GIVES ANOTHER SIDE TO TICKET-SCALPING ISSUE
description: ''We know that one of the chief sources of tickets has been the players.'' Tex Schramm President, general manager Dallas Cowboys By PAT TOOMAY

title: SHE PUTS 'PIRATES' ON ITS TOES
description: It sounds like a blueprint for disaster. A cast of rock stars, classically trained singers, film personalities and unknown repertory actors thrown together in a rigidly traditional 19th-century British operetta. But ''The Pirates of Penzance,'' the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta which opened Jan. 8 at the Uris and which stars Linda Ronstadt, Kevin Kline, George Rose, Rex Smith and Estelle Parsons, is the musical hit of the season. A major reason is the choreography. Graciela Daniele can take credit for making an ensemble of actors and singers, most of whom have never taken a dance class in their life, as satisfying to watch as a highly trained dance company.

title: TWO EXPEDITIONS FOR ECLIPSE CHASERS
description: Though summer may seem far ahead, July 31 is close enough for eclipse chasers to start making plans. That is when there will be a total eclipse of the sun, but, like the remaining 14 total eclipses due during this century, it will not be visible from the North American Continent. The portion of the July path of eclipse totality over land is entirely in the Soviet Union, but then it will sweep southeast across the northern Pacific and end about 300 miles north of Hawaii.

title: CASE OF UNSIGNED FISK GOES TO ARBITRATION
description: One day after they traded Fred Lynn to the California Angels to solve one problem, the Boston Red Sox wrestled yesterday with the twin problem of Carlton Fisk. But after a four-hour grievance hearing in Manhattan, the star catcher was neither signed nor traded, and his fight to become a free agent was placed before a labor arbitrator for a final decision.

title: Home Clinic; VENTILATION AND VAPOR BARRIERS HELP KEEP ATTICS DRY
description: MANY homeowners concerned with keeping out cold air have asked whether it is advisable to close or cover the vents in their attics and along the eaves on cold days.

title: CROWNING ACHIEVEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Cold Wave in India Kills 270
description: More than 270 people have died from a month-old cold wave in northern India, the United News of India said today. The news agency said roads leading to Srinagar, the capital of Kashmir, and Simla, the capital of neighboring Himachal Pradesh, were blocked by snow.

title: S. PHILIP COHEN
description: S. Philip Cohen, a retired lawyer who had been active as a representative of the Bronx Democratic organization when it was headed by Charles A. Buckley, died Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach. Mr. Cohen was 77 years old and a longtime resident of New York City.

title: Roman A. Rudenko, 73; Soviet Chief Prosecutor
description: Roman A. Rudenko, the Soviet Union's Prosecutor General and its chief prosecutor at the Nuremberg war crimes trials of 1945-46, died Friday after an illness, the official press agency Tass said today.

title: Jim Lee Howell's Beef
description: Jim Lee Howell, the former Giants coach, is retiring as the director of player personnel and will be going home to Arkansas.

title: Benjamin Book Honors 'Citizen's Citizen'; R. S. Benjamin Biography Honors 'Citizen's Citizen'
description: The United Nations Association of the United States has issued a biography, ''Robert S. Benjamin: A Citizen's Citizen,'' as a tribute to the late ambassador, motion-picture executive and chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. The description of Mr. Benjamin as a ''citizen's citizen'' comes from a statement by Adlai E. Stevenson, a close associate at the United Nations and in Democratic party affairs.

title: In the Fast Lane
description: John Bunting, a member of the well-disciplined Eagles, told of the time a few years ago when he and two teammates - Bill Bergey and Frank LeMaster - broke a club rule but did not have to pay for their indiscretions.

title: Suspected Caribbean Terrorists Blamed for Attack on Paris Train
description: The police said today that suspected Caribbean terrorists dropped a huge concrete block onto a speeding suburban train last night, killing the conductor.

title: ENERGY AIDE AT COOPERS
description: W. Bowman Cutter, 38 years old, an official of the Carter Administration and a major architect of the legislation that created the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, will become a partner of Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, on Feb. 1. He will be based in its Washington office as national energy partner and serve as chairman of its alternative energy development task force.

title: Think of July, Now
description: Those who think there's no drought in the New York area because they've seen no bleached bones on 42d Street have been looking in the wrong place. If they could see the city's low, low reservoirs, starved for rain or snow, they'd get the point. And if all considered their customary profligacy with water in bathrooms and kitchens, they'd realize how to fend off an emergency.

title: SOME HAVE ESCAPED BY AIR FROM PRISONS WHILE OTHERS FAILED
description: Some attempts to escape from prison by helicopter have succeeded. In one, a New York millionaire serving 28 years for murder in a Government prison in Mexico was flown to safety by a helicopter that had landed within the prison walls in 1971.

title: WARY ALGERIA EDGED INTO PIVOTAL ROLE
description: Algeria started out as ''a simple mailman,'' delivering messages between the United States and Iran, but in the end it played a decisive mediator's role in the negotiations for the release of the 52 American hostages and the return to Iran of assets frozen in the United States.

title: Union Leaders in Zambia Urge Strikers to Return
description: Mine union leaders held meetings throughout Zambia's copper region today to urge wildcat strikers to go back to work tomorrow.

title: KNOX AND BENNETT SAY PLUNKETT HAD TIME TO PASS ALMOST AT WILL
description: ''Complete dominance of the line of scrimmage on offense and defense.'' ''The peerless pass protection of Jim Plunkett so he could sit back or even scramble, do anything he wanted.'' Those were the important elements in Oakland's rout of Philadelphia in the Super Bowl game today, the first view coming from Leeman Bennett, head coach of the Atlanta Falcons, and the second from Coach Chuck Knox of the Buffalo Bills.

title: A Dream Come True: Playing the Mighty Wurlitzer
description: In the elite world of organists, one of the most elite and gifted is Leonard Raver, organist of the New York Philharmonic and teacher at the Juilliard School and Yale University. He has played with many classical musical groups, including the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, and had been organist at several churches, notably Holy Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Mexican-Canadian Pact
description: Mexico has signed two agreements with Canadian organizations to buy as much as $200 million (Canadian) worth of services and equipment for its urban transportation renewal program, Canadian Trade Minister Ed Lumley said.

title: CLONING MEANS THE END OF MAN
description: Those reports of the first successful cloning of mice set off another round of science-fiction speculation and doomsday warnings. Some fear science will duplicate champion racehorses and renowned geniuses. Others fear cloning catches society unprepared for awesome ethical and social issues.

title: Young & Rubicam Gets Xerox Retail Business
description: Did you know that Xerox has a retail operation? Well, it does and it has just gone to Young & Rubicam for advertising.

title: SHARE A SHORTAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting Math to Work In a Practical Example
description: There are 50 animals in a barn. Some are chickens and some are rabbits. Together they have 140 legs. Rabbits have four legs.

title: IN ERA OF PERMANENT CAMPAIGN, PARTIES LOOK TO 1982
description: Earlier this month the Republican Party sent out a fund-raising letter with a simple message: A switch of 26 seats would give the party control of the House of Representatives in 1982.

title: A VITAL FOCUS FOR THE ARTS ENDOWMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Can't Stop Kupchak, Lose to Bullets
description: Mitch Kupchak, an Olympic player in 1976 from Brentwood, L.I., had an outstanding game for the second Sunday in a row today, scoring 30 points and pulling down 11 rebounds in leading the Washington Bullets to a 118-100 victory over the New Jersey Nets at the Rutgers Athletic Center.

title: PAYOFFS ALLEGED IN F.B.I. INQUIRY OF CONSTRUCTION
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation, using a fictitious consulting company to infiltrate building contractors and union officials alleged to be corrupt, says it has uncovered evidence of bid-rigging by contractors, payoffs to buy labor peace, and organized-crime influence in the construction industry in the metropolitan New York area.

title: Two Reports On Economy
description: The nation's economic ills have been worsened by Federal spending that has grown faster than the economy's ability to cope with it and by an accompa@nying rapid growth in the money supply, a pair of Congressional studies said today.

title: Pregnant Woman Believes Prayers Obviated Caesarean
description: A pregnant woman believes that prayers moved the placenta blocking her birth canal and she can now deliver her baby naturally without any risk to her or the unborn child, a spokesman said today.

title: New Products' Scarcity Seen
description: The housewares industry, traditionally considered recession-proof, is feeling the effects of the nation's business woes.

title: A New Strategy to Help Keep New York Bright
description: Two New York City officials have hit on an unusual strategy to cut the amount of time it takes to get a burned-out street light back on the beam - increasing the amount of time contractors are given to make each repair.

title: Peter J. Salmon, Leader In Programs for the Blind
description: Peter J. Salmon, administrative vice president of the Industrial Home for the Blind in Brooklyn, died Friday in Long Island College Hospital. He was 85 years old and a resident of Brooklyn.

title: Index; International
description: Ontario issue complicates Cana- dian language dispute A2 Iraqis say they have taken 2 key passes on Iranian border A2 Druse sheik's son admits killing Bedouin Parliament member A3 Nicaraguan dissident urges U.S. aid A4 French Socialists open presiden- tial campaign A5 Around the World A6 Khalid urges Islamic heads not to ally with superpowers A8 Ghana seeks foreign investors to revive its gold industry A9 Gierek accepts some responsibil- ity for Poland's crisis A10 Polish writers, like workers, slip from Communist Party control A10 Algerian intermediaries played decisive role in U.S.-Iran talks A16 Government/Politics Reagan is expected to cut foreign aid bill A7 About Washington: How televi- sion influences news events A12 Low profile marks Reagan stance on former hostages A14 Israeli assails Justice Dept.'s decision on accused Nazi A19 Miss Claybrook issues car safety rules before leaving office A20 The 1982 Congressional campaign appears to have already begun A22 Two Congressional chairmen seek to put teeth in 1974 Budget Act A22 Percy gives strong support to Iran accord A23 Census dramatizes changes in Jersey life during 1970's B3 Industry/Labor Blacks are quitting Philadelphia Police Department A17 Movie industry faces strikes by writers and directors C23 Education/Welfare Pupils' fear of math still the big problem in teaching B1 Teaching program assailed B4 SportsMonday Super Bowl: Raiders beat Eagles, 27-10 victory C1

title: Art of the West In Princeton Show
description: ''American Masters in the West: Selections From the Anschutz Collection of Western Art'' will be on view at the Princeton University Art Museum in New Jersey, through March 15.

title: SHOSTAKOVICH 'KATERINA' FINALLY AT BOLSHOI
description: ''Katerina Ismailova,'' Dmitri Shostakovich's great opera, has finally reached the stage of Moscow's Bolshoi Theater, 47 years after its premiere in Leningrad and five years after the composer's death.

title: PLUNKETT CLIMBED STEEP HILL IN 2 YEARS
description: Two years ago, Jim Plunkett was considered washed up. He had been cut by the San Francisco 49ers and waived over by 27 other clubs. Today he stood on top of the pro football world - the Super Bowl's most valuable player in the Oakland Raiders victory over the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: TEXT OF REAGAN'S REMARKS TO FAMILIES AT RECEPTION
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's remarks to relatives of the freed hostages at a White House reception today:

title: Chrysler Raises Prices
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it was raising prices of its intermediate-sized cars by up to $199 and prices for full-sized cars by $63, but most small-car prices will remain unchanged.

title: TO REVIVE STALLED HOUSING STARTS
description: Ways to build housing at far less cost are greatly needed - and possible. Without them, the deteriorated areas across the nation, symbolized by the desolate void of the South Bronx, will continue to spread. Substandard housing will persist while the nation has enormous, untapped capacities and excessive unemployment.

title: THE LOSERS' LAMENT: 'COULDN'T GET GOING
description: The Philadelphia Eagles tried to think of what had gone wrong, and could not. They thought back to the preparation, they remembered how they felt just before their first Super Bowl today, and then they thought about the moments when it was time to put the foot to the floor and get going.

title: APPRAISING NEEDS AND LIMITS OF DEFENSE SPENDING
description: To the Editor:

title: GHANA SEEKS INVESTORS TO REVIVE ITS GOLD INDUSTRY
description: Ghana, the legendary Gold Coast of West Africa, is hoping for a new gold rush. With the economy in desperate straits after years of military misrule, the civilian Government of President Hilla Limann has appealed to foreign investors to revive Ghana's gold industry.

title: Gerard Weinstock, 61; President of Basic Foods
description: Gerard Weinstock, president of the Basic Foods Division of Mallinckrodt Inc. and chairman of the American Jewish Committee's board of trustees, died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan after a brief illness. He was 61 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Jillian Marjorie Barber Is Married to Harry J.Petchesky
description: Jillian Marjorie Barber and Harry J. Petchesky, a New York lawyer, were married yesterday at the New York home of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Sahlman. Rabbi Daniel Wolk of Congregation Emanuel of Westchester in Rye, N.Y., performed the ceremony.

title: Woman, a Murderer, Flees Bedford Prison
description: A 31-year-old woman serving a sentence for murder escaped from the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility yesterday apparently by scaling a fence, the state police said.

title: Bodies of Two Men Are Found in Park
description: Two men were found dead in Central Park yesterday morning, apparently the victims of separate attacks, the police said.

title: Sheryl Daniels Is Bride Of Michael Muscarella
description: Sheryl Daniels, daughter of Mrs. Joseph H. Daniels of Englewood, N.J., and the late Mr. Daniels, was married yesterday morning in Alpine, N.J., to Michael Muscarella Jr., son of Mr. Muscarella of Fair Lawn, N.J., and the late Mrs. Muscarella. Rabbi Israel Margolies performed the ceremony at the Tammy Brook Country Club.

title: Bomb Injures 7 in Spain
description: A bomb exploded early today at a restaurant in Berriz, a town near this Basque city in northern Spain. The police said seven people were injured, three severely. No group immediately claimed responsibility, the police said.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger are confronted with a dilemma that they have indicated they are not yet ready to resolve but that may come crowding in on them shortly.

title: German Soccer Fans Set Train on Fire
description: Fans of a West Berlin soccer club set five express-train coaches on fire, causing damage estimated at between $1.5 and $2 million, the police said today.

title: CITY'S TEACHER-TRAINING PROGRAM CRITICIZED IN 1977-'78 STATE AUDIT
description: A 1977-78 audit of the training program designed to improve the abilities of New York City teachers found that only 10 percent of the program's 303 courses were related to reading and mathematics, even though pupils in the public schools were scoring significantly lower in those areas than they should, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan reported yesterday.

title: Nkomo Supporters Accused Of Terror in Zimbabwe
description: Guerrillas loyal to the ousted Home Affairs Minister, Joshua Nkomo, were accused today of forcing more than 5,000 people to flee their homes by a reign of terror, including kidnapping, looting and rape.

title: Chile's Bishops Protest Government's Charge
description: Roman Catholic bishops assailed Chile's military rulers today for what they said were ''false and insolent'' charges that they were encouraging a wave of church sitins.

title: Sports World Specials By Jim Benagh; Barroom Talk
description: In the Pittsburgh area, Chiodo's was the place to go in the 1970's. At this workingman's bar in Homestead, six miles south of Pittsburgh, football fans congregated weekly during the season to honor one of the great dynasties of the National Football League.

title: Council Dismisses Peking Mayor; Move Is Tied to Lavish Spending
description: The Mayor of Peking, who has been criticized for lavish municipal spending, was dismissed by the city council today, the New China News Agency reported.

title: ON LADDER TO THE TOP, A MENTOR IS KEY STEP
description: In addition to a tailored suit, a briefcase and a masters degree in business administration, the young woman who aspires to get ahead in the corporation is now being advised to find herself a mentor.

title: MUSIC: CELLO AND PIANO DUO
description: A sprightly addition to the cello and piano repertory was given its premiere in Goodman Concert Hall on Wednesday night by the ClarkSchuldmann Duo. Composed last year by Seymour Barab (a cellist himself), the piece is blandly labeled Duo for Cello and Piano but the music has a quirky individuality about it that sticks in the memory.

title: ESCAPE BY COPTER FOILED AT U.S. JAIL IN MANHATTAN
description: An armed man and woman hijacked a sightseeing helicopter and flew to the Federal detention center in lower Manhattan yesterday morning in an unsuccessful attempt to pluck an inmate from a rooftop recreation area.

title: Virginia Beats Ohio State, 89-73
description: Ralph Sampson scored 14 of his career-high 40 points during a 24-6 burst in the first half today, and unbeaten Virginia extended its winning streak to 21 games with an 89-73 victory over Ohio State.

title: TV GUIDE LOOKS BACK ON 1980
description: ''TV GUIDE: 1980 - the Year in Television,'' which will be seen from 9 to 11 o'clock tonight on WNBC-TV, is a generally pleasant variety show. It is, however, more noteworthy for the questions it raises.

title: DRUSE SHEIK'S SON ADMITS KILLING BEDOUIN MEMBER OF PARLIAMENT
description: The son of a Druse Member of Parliament has confessed to the murder of a Bedouin sheik who was a Member of Parliament, the Israeli police said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''America has to be very proud of you.'' - President Reagan to the hostages' families. (A1:3.)

title: Rogers Relinquishes Heisman to School
description: George Rogers handed over his Heisman trophy yesterday to his school, the University of South Carolina, and jokingly said he was glad to get it off his hands.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 26, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Intergovernmental Committee on Science and Technology for Develop- ment - 10:30 A.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: BLACKS ARE QUITTING PHILADELPHIA POLICE
description: One year ago, Donald Gravatt was appointed a Deputy Police Commissioner, making him the highest-ranking black and one of the top three officials in the Philadelphia Police Department. He remarked that if he had not been elevated, ''I'd more than likely be in Atlantic City right now,'' working as a security official at a gambling casino.

title: Red Smith; Plunkett Throwing Strikes, Engineers Destruction of Eagles
description: THERE was a bomb scare in the Oakland Raiders' hotel here the other night but it was Oakland's retread quarterback, Jim Plunkett, who set off the explosives in Super Bowl XV. Firing projectiles of 80 yards to Kenny King for one touchdown, 29 yards to Cliff Branch for another and 2 yards to Branch for still another, Plunkett engineered the almost total destruction of the Eagles as he and his accomplices demolished Philadelphia in a postseason playoff that was nowhere near as competitive as suggested by the final score of 27-10.

title: Gore Vidal Ponders a Race for the Senate
description: He's been living in Rome for years and says he hasn't voted since 1964, but now, as a newly registered resident of Los Angeles, the novelist Gore Vidal says he is seriously considering running for the Senate from California in 1982.

title: FORMER CHINESE LEADERS GIVEN LONG PRISON TERMS
description: The principal surviving leaders of China's Cultural Revolution were spared today from execution but sentenced to long terms in prison by a special court for having persecuted political enemies and plotted to seize power in the chaotic decade before Chairman Mao Zedong's death in 1976.

title: ATLANTA DEATHS: FEAR FELT BY YOUNG
description: A 5-year-old girl, once independent and cheerful, now refuses to move around the house without her mother or father. She is afraid someone will snatch her away through a window. A group of young boys in a nearby South Side neighborhood used to play in a vacant lot on their street. Now, the boys spend more of their time inside their homes.

title: U.S. BACKS TRADING IN 'CREDITS' ALLOWING NEW PLANTS TO POLLUTE
description: The antipollution rules of the Clean Air Act have given rise to a novel brokerage business: introducing companies that propose to build factories and possibly add to air pollution to other concerns that are reducing their emissions.

title: ALOOF HOBART FIGHTS CP TAKEOVER BID
description: In its 83-year history, the Hobart Corporation has earned an enviable reputation for the high quality of its KitchenAid home appliances and its commercial food-processing equipment.

title: ADMIRAL WHO HEADED COAST GUARD ACADEMY
description: Rear Adm. Malcolm E. Clark, superintendent of the United States Coast Guard Academy, died yesterday afternoon of a heart attack. He was 57 years old.

title: ON HELPING WITH HOMEWORK: A PRIMER FOR PARENTS
description: Mary Kahn wanted to know how to keep her son from becoming overly upset when he forgot a book at school and was unable to do his homework. Mary Lynn Bianco asked about special courses in study skills. Carol Collins wondered when parents ought to start asking children about homework, and Jane Adato wanted to know how she could help her 6 year old son when her toddler daughter was clamoring for attention.

title: HUDSON VALLEY SOUNDS A HOMECOMING CHEER
description: At first, for most of America, the drama's penultimate chapter was like a silent movie filmed at a distance.

title: Pope Appeals for Aid to Lepers
description: Pope John Paul II marked World Leper's Day today by asking Roman Catholics to help leprosy victims with the ''greatest generosity.''

title: STAGE: BOB CARROLL'S ONE-MAN 'DIRT SHOW'
description: IN his previous one-man extravaganzas, Bob Carroll has proved himself to be a creature of many species. He has impersonated everything from a spawning salmon to primordial ooze. In his new monologue, ''Dirt Show,'' at the Economy Tires Theater in the American Theater Laboratory, he adds continental drift and Diana Ross to his repertory. One might say that Mr. Carroll does impressions of natural phenomena.

title: TOOL PALNTS BUSY AMID ORDER DROP
description: The nation's machine tool industry, now suffering a severe slump in orders, nevertheless completed the second best year in its history last year, thanks to the strong first half.

title: Salvadoran Troops Said to Pound Guerrilla Forces for Three Days
description: Government aircraft and light artillery pounded leftist guerrillas massed on the outskirts of four northern Salvadoran towns for three days in a row, military sources said today.

title: A Winning Experience
description: Burgess Owens has become somewhat of an expert on winning and losing. ''I've had enough experience with both,'' he said last week, ''so I'm qualified to talk about it.''

title: Fines Being Imposed To Curb Water Use
description: Customers of the Hackensack Water Company who have not heeded rationing orders will find unexpectedly high water bills in their mailboxes, company officials say.

title: British Soldier Shot by the I.R.A.  Dies of Wounds in Ulster Hospital
description: A British soldier, shot in the head yesterday by Irish Republican Army guerrillas, died in a Belfast hospital today.

title: YANKEE STAY PUT
description: To the Government's suggestion that migration from the North to the South be encouraged: thanks but no thanks. New Mexico has grown by 27 percent in the past decade, and look where it's gotten us. Albuquerque is the nation's 49th largest city; we are number 23 in major crimes. Today, I have a better chance of being murdered or raped than being killed in a freeway accident. Our air pollution is so bad that a friend who moved here from New York as a lifesaving measure took to wearing a mask outdoors.

title: Hallmark Cards Turning to PBS
description: Hallmark Cards, which has presented outstanding dramas on commercial television networks since 1952, is turning to the Public Broadcasting System this year.

title: Bridge: Swedes Victors in London, Defeating 2 American Pairs
description: Two American partnerships came close, but it was Sweden that was victorious in London yesterday in the world's most prestigious invitation event. Sixteen partnerships, mostly from Europe, competed in the Now! pairs championship, formerly sponsored by The Sunday Times.

title: FOUR LABOR EX-CABINET MINISTERS FORM GROUP TO FIGHT LEFT TREND
description: Four former Cabinet Ministers in the Labor Party, denouncing the sharp move to the left that the party took yesterday, formed a ''Council for Social Democracy'' today, and appealed to other party members to join them in it.

title: FRANCE'S SOCIALISTS KICK OFF CAMPAIGN
description: The French Socialist Party, invigorated by signs of increasing public support for itself and decreasing support for President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, has officially opened its presidential campaign.

title: EXCITEME
description: NT FOR OAKLAND WIVES MEANS A HOLIDAY INN IN FAT CITY BY MALCOLM MORAN

title: RELIGIOUS SCHOOL IS IN TAX BATTLE OVER POLICY OF RACIAL SEPARATISM
description: In a church-state confrontation that has lasted more than a decade, Bob Jones University, which operates on conservative Christian principles, has petitioned for a rehearing of a Federal Court decision threatening its tax-exempt status.

title: Egyptian Tomb Is Robbed
description: Grave robbers have stolen nine wall paintings from an ancient Egyptian tomb. The police said today that the paintings had been taken from the tomb of Hur-Min, a scribe of one of the kings of the New Kingdom (1570-1085 B.C.). The tomb is 350 miles south of Cairo.

title: CONTRACT COVERS NEW BUS FLAW, GRUMMAN SAYS
description: The Grumman Corporation confirmed yesterday that a recently discovered flaw in its Flxible buses was specifically covered in the company's repair agreement with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and the company said that the faulty component caused no new problem for New York City's Flxible fleet.

title: PRESIDENT KEEPS LOW PROFILE ON THE 52
description: No cameras were allowed, and the news media were forbidden to broadcast President Reagan's brief, but emotional prayer, delivered today at the White House to the families of the 52 Americans freed from captivity in Iran.

title: The Irish Dance of Death
description: The avowed aim of the Irish Republican Army is to end what it regards as a British military occupation of Northern Ireland. But its deeds make any reduction in security forces unthinkable.

title: CITICORP BIGGEST YEAR-END
description: Despite a decline in earnings during 1980, Citicorp became the nation's biggest banking organization during the year. It edged out the BankAmerica Corporation, which had long held the top position.

title: No Headline
description: AT STOP ON FLIGHT HOME, A WARM IRISH WELCOME

title: OUSTED POLISH CHIEF ACCEPTS SOME BLAME
description: Edward Gierek, the 68-year-old Communist leader who ruled for 10 years and was deposed during the strikes last September, accepts a modicum of responsibility for Poland's crisis but shifts much of the blame to people around him.

title: Stephen Supina, 68, War Veteran Dropped Dynamite on U.N. in '48
description: Stephen J. Supina, a decorated World War II serviceman who in 1948 dropped a stick of dynamite from an airplane above the headquarters of the United Nations, then in Lake Success, L.I., died Friday at Hartford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Ashford, Conn.

title: RESEARCH INSTITUTE RISES WITH REAGAN
description: After six years of keeping the ideological flame burning bright, the Institute of Contemporary Studies has come into its own with Ronald Reagan's assumption of the Presidency.

title: MISS CLAYBROOK INITIATES 2 RULES BEFORE LEAVING AUTO SAFETY POST
description: Joan Claybrook, by all odds the most active leader yet of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, issued two regulations on automobile safety in her last week in the job.

title: LEON M. LEVITT
description: Dr. Leon M. Levitt, a senior attending physician at Long Island College Hospital, died Saturday at Boca Raton (Fla.)

title: S.E.C. Reverses Ruling on Analyst
description: Ray L. Dirks, a securities analyst who exposed a huge fraud in 1973 and was subsequently prosecuted by the Securities and Exchange Commission for tipping off his clients about it, says he has won a reversal of the 60-day suspension that was imposed on him.

title: SHARP REDUCTION EXPECTED IN FOREIGN AID REQUEST
description: A foreign aid request sent to Congress by the Carter Administration with major increases for population control and food in developing countries is likely to be cut back sharply by President Reagan's budget managers.

title: JUSTICE FOR IRAN
description: The people who were wrong from the start about America's reaction to an act of war -who assured us that patience and restraint would uphold the nation's honor, and that a demonstration of American weakness would not encourage terrorists to escalate their demands and the Soviets to make an expansionary move - are back in business again.

title: International
description: Iran is being studied by West European and Japanese banks, which expect to assume the big financing role American banks once played when stability returns to Iran. But the country is now regarded as a poor credit risk; among the many problems that remain are payments for nationalized foreign banks. (D1.)

title: Chess: Strengths of a Passed Pawn Can Be Figured Objectively
description: The question of the value of an advanced passed pawn is primarily a tactical one: If it can be supported by pieces or can generate threats that throw the opponent on the defensive, it is a weapon, but if it can be engulfed and jeopardized by enemy pieces, it is a weakness. The answer is a matter of concrete calculation.

title: DISSIDENT ASKS AID FOR NICARAGUA
description: A leading opponent of the Sandinist revolutionary Government in Nicaragua, Alfonso Robelo Callejas, said today that the Sandinist Party is seeking to push Nicaragua ''toward a Communist, totalitarian regimen'' but urged the United States to continue sending financial aid to private groups in his country.

title: No Headline
description: Sporting Gear; Alarm Kit for Boats

title: PLUNKETT PASSES RAIDERS TO A 2D SUPER BOWL, 27-10
description: The Oakland Raiders completed their long, controversial season tonight by defeating the Philadelphia Eagles, 27-10, in Super Bowl XV.

title: Prix d'Amerique To Ideal du Gazeau
description: Ideal du Gazeau of France defeated the American champion mare, Classical Way, in the the $326,000 Prix d'Amerique today at suburban Vicenne.

title: Bossy's Last-Chance Goals a Dramatic Ending to 50-Game Quest
description: There were only 89 seconds left in the game at Nassau Coliseum Saturday night when Mike Bossy fired a quick shot from the left faceoff circle and saw the puck zip through the legs of the Quebec Nordiques' goalie for Bossy's 50th goal of the season.

title: KATHLEEN K. CAFFYN
description: Kathleen K. Caffyn, a former director of the Grand Jury Association of New York County and a longtime volunteer with the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, died Friday at St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital. Mrs. Caffyn, who lived in Manhattan, was 84 years old.

title: 200 Settlers Pitch Camp In a West Bank Protest
description: About 200 Jewish settlers set up camp last night on a hill near the West Bank settlement of Givon to protest what they said were the Government's delays in building permanent housing for them on the site. They remained through the day.

title: IRAQIS SAY THEY HAVE CAPTURED 2 KEY PASSES ON IRANIAN BORDER
description: Iraqi forces have seized control of two strategically important frontier mountain passes in Iran's rugged northwestern Kurdistan province, according to Iraqi officers at the front.

title: Utilities to Discuss Hudson Power Pact
description: New York's Public Service Commission said that terms of an agreement announced Dec. 19 under which four utilities could skip the construction of cooling towers at Hudson River power plants ''appear to raise potential cost and reliability problems,'' particularly in shutting down some units during peak spawning periods for fish. Under the agreement, the utilities would act to reduce the impact of the plants' heating of river water on fish.

title: THE DAY IS BITTERSWEET FOR KIN OF 8
description: On April 24 of last year, eight members of an ill-fated United States military rescue operation died in the darkness of an Iranian desert in an abortive attempt to free the Americans held hostage in Teheran.

title: PERCY SAYS IT WOULD BE 'DISHONORABLE'FOR REAGANTO RENEGE ON IRAN ACCORD
description: Senator Charles H. Percy, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, lent strong support today to the agreement for releasing the 52 hostages that was negotiated by the Carter Administration. He said it would be ''dishonorable'' for the Reagan Administration not to carry out its provisions.

title: Pravda Says Carter Used Crisis for Military Moves
description: The Soviet Union accused former President Jimmy Carter today of having used the hostage crisis as a pretext to send military forces to the Persian Gulf region.

title: MORE STATES SEEK TO TAX GLOBAL CORPORATE PROFITS
description: The latest skirmish in a quiet but widening confrontation over the right of states to tax the profits of big multinational companies is under way in California.

title: ONTARIO IS CAUGHT UP IN CANADA'S LANGUAGE TANGLE
description: Premier William Davis of Ontario had barely stepped off the plane in Toronto from a Florida vacation last week when he was confronted in the airport terminal by four Quebec members of the federal House of Commons.

title: ELAINE POWERS FOUNDER PLANS DIET FORMULA
description: Richard Proctor, a 49-year-old chiropractor who founded Elaine Powers Figure Salons Inc., has another business venture with which he is ready to go national this year: A high-nutrition meal-replacement formula called Sensible Eating Formula, to be sold through the Elaine Powers branches.

title: Census Data Show Rise In State and Local Taxes
description: United States citizens paid an average of $934 in taxes to state and local governments in the fiscal year 1979, an increase of $46 over the previous year, the Commerce Clearing House said in a newly released report on Census Bureau statistics.

title: How Not to Refine Oil Controls
description: The end of price controls on oil, perhaps any day now and in any case by October, will mean higher profits for those who find crude. But not every oil company is in the business of looking for oil. For the independent refiners who manufacture about 20 percent of America's oil products, decontrol will mean an end to regulations that guarantee them supplies of crude at bargain prices. So the independents are pressing Congress for new arrangements that would protect their benefits; they need a break, they argue, to survive in a market dominated by Big Oil.

title: POLICE SAY ISOLATED CHEATING HAS REPLACED CORRUPTION FOUND BY KNAPP
description: INQUIRY By BARBARA BASLER

title: Commodities; Slumping Soybean Futures
description: Consumers may be pouring more salad dressing these days, but this has not been much help to buyers of soybean futures in the past two months.

title: FLORIDA EXPERIENCES A SLUMP IN CONDOMINIUM SALES
description: The South Bay Club condominium project in Miami Beach had a pool, a health spa and its own marina - everything but buyers. After months of heavy advertising, only six purchasers had closed on 347 apartments.

title: IRAN'S LOAN STATUS SEEN RECOVERING
description: When the controversy stirred by the IranianAmerican agreement freeing the 52 hostages has finally died down, many European bankers privately predict, Iran may emerge with a good credit rating and a need to borrow, but a strong preference for doing business with European or Japanese banks instead of the American banks favored under the Shah.

title: FROM MAX MCGEE TO JOHN STALL WORTH, THE MEMORIES ARE SPECIAL
description: Bart Starr is a member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame. Franco Harris, Larry Csonka, and Willie Brown are likely Hall of Fame selections. Max McGee and Jim O'Brien were journeymen. Duane Thomas was as well known for his wall of silence as for his running.

title: CELLO RECITAL: YO-YO MA PERFORMS AT Y
description: YO MA has an enviable quality not often encountered among musicians. For as long as he is playing, it becomes very difficult for a listener to think that any cellist today could possibly surpass him. That is surely a prime indication of any performer's ability to communicate on the highest level of technical and interpretive excellence, and Mr. Ma demonstrated such a rare gift during his recital at the 92d Street Y on Saturday night.

title: Super Bowl Losers
description: Who lost the Super Bowl? Philadelphia and Oakland, in a way. The National Football League allots about $570,000 in expenses for the winning team and $435,000 for the loser, plus 80 first-class airfares for each team.

title: Making Connections
description: All Jimmy Carter wanted was a copy of the private White House telephone directory containing the unlisted numbers of Cabinet secretaries, heads of state and other officials he had dealt with during his four years in office.

title: Dantley Is Fit Again
description: Adrian Dantley of the Utah Jazz, the National Basketball Association's leading scorer, is expected to be back in action tomorrow night against Detroit after having missed two games because of the flu, a team spokesman said. Dantley, who has been averaging 31.7 points a game, missed a home game Friday against Golden State and a road trip to Houston yesterday. The Jazz lost both games and their record fell to 21-31.

title: ADELE ASTAIRE, DANCER-COMEDIAN, DIES
description: Adele Marie Astaire, the pixieish dancer who captivated audiences in New York and London in many musical comedies of the 1920's with her brother and dance partner, Fred, died yesterday in Phoenix at the age of 83. Members of the family said she had suffered a stroke on Jan. 6 and never recovered consciousness.

title: DONORS TO FUND FOR NEEDIEST SEE REASON TO HONOR YOUNG AND OLD
description: Occasions for rejoicing in celebration of new life as well as for honoring hearty old age often inspire contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: POLAND'S WRITERS, LIKE ITS WORKERS, SLIP FROM COMMUNIST CONTROL
description: A little over two years ago Jan Jozef Szczepanski, a Polish essayist and novelist, was forbidden to publish anything in his native land. Last month the sturdy, free-thinking 62-year-old author was elected chairman of the Union of Polish Writers, an organization of intellectuals subsidized by the state.

title: Israeli Opposition Leader Meets Chancellor of Austria in Vienna
description: The Israeli opposition leader, Shimon Peres, had private talks with Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria in Vienna yesterday, Dr. Kreisky said today.

title: Joe Kuharich Dies; Coached Eagles, Irish
description: Joe Kuharich, coach of the Philadelphia Eagles for five years in the late 1960's when the team was among the worst in the National Football League, died yesterday of a massive heart attack at Graduate Hospital in Philadelphia during the first half of the Super Bowl game. He was 63 years old.

title: ORCHESTRA AS METAPHOR
description: Two years ago Federico Fellini used the orchestra as a metaphor for a disintegrating Italian society in his extraordinary film ''Orchestra Rehearsal.'' More recently Andrzej Wajda used the same device to examine Poland's crisis in ''The Orchestra Conductor.''

title: A REAL OR MOVIE DRAMA: NEIGHBORS DIDN'T KNOW
description: ''You can't go down there,'' Officer David Krause was telling drivers and pedestrians as he turned traffic on Park Row away from Foley Square yesterday. ''There're cops running around with shotguns. It's like something out of the movies.''

title: Times Sq. Office Tower Is Sold to Swiss Investors
description: The 23-story office tower at 1 Times Square, formerly the Allied Chemical Building and originally the New York Times Building, has been purchased by a Swiss investment group for $8.2 million from Alex Parker, a real-estate manager. The price included a $7.45 million mortgage.

title: MUSIC: BEETHOVEN ALSO HEARD AS SCULPTOR
description: WHEN the Beethoven Society presented Otto-Werner Mueller conducting the Philharmonia Orchestra of Yale at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday afternoon, Beethoven was heard to be a sculptor as well as a composer.

title: Teaching Math One of an occasional series on how various; subjects are taught.
description: James Hopkins was at the front of the room drawing a parallelogram on the blackboard. He divided it in half along a diagonal, then smiled.

title: Kentucky Fire Kills 11 Thoroughbreds
description: A fire roared through a Stone Farm barn early today, killing 11 thoroughbred horses worth $250,000 and destroying the barn.

title: Krizaj of Yugoslavia Wins Men's Slalom
description: Bojan Krizaj of Yugoslavia, with the fastest run of the second heat, won the men's World Cup slalom race today. Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden finished third and took the lead in the World Cup standing.

title: COUNTDOWN TO A TROPHY
description: NEW ORLEANS WITH nearly nine minutes remaining in Super Bowl XV, the Oakland Raiders were in command, 24-10, as Al Davis peered down from his seat in the Superdome press box. Suddenly, from the row in front, a photographer angled his camera close to the clenched face of the Raiders' managing general partner.

title: Washington Watch; Jan. 20: A Study In Contrasts
description: WASHINGTON AS the sun rose over the Potomac last Tuesday, two dramas were running concurrently at the Treasury, presenting a study in contrasts. In the third floor ''hot room'' just down from the Secretary's office, a haggard group of officials and bankers, with open telephone lines to Algiers, London and New York, was stil trying to capture the magic financial formula that would free 52 Americans in Teheran.

title: Market Place; Chemical Field: Diversification
description: MANY industries keep changing their spots as component companies diversify, expand or even contract in today's fast-moving business world. The chemical industry is no exception. Wall Street analysts agree that classifying chemical stocks is, at best, somewhat arbitrary.

title: Clues Are Sought on Coast In Fatal Scaffolding Collapse
description: State safety inspectors returned to a Sierra Nevada construction site today to find out the cause of a scaffolding collapse that sent seven miners plunging more than 300 feet to their deaths Friday.

title: PRESIDENT LEADS NATION IN THANKS
description: Without ruffles or flourishes, the 52 Americans who were held hostage in Iran stepped onto American soil today and into the waiting arms of their families and their nation.

title: MAYOR KOLLEK IN MANHATTAN, STRESSES GOALS
description: Wearing the red robe of an Episcopal cleric, Mayor Teddy Kollek of Jerusalem addressed yesterday morning's service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, describing his Government's efforts to reconstruct his city and pleading that ''Jerusalem should never be divided again.''

title: AS THE WORLD TURNS-FOR TV
description: Viewed from a pedestrian's simple level, the inaugural ball, set across the Mall in one of the Smithsonian museums, had the distant, haunting quality of a party at Gatsby's mansion glinting across the water in the night.

title: Lay Teachers Reach Tentative Settlement
description: Lay teachers at 11 Roman Catholic high schools in the metropolitan area reached a tentative contract settlement last night with the Archdiocese of New York.

title: GAME CAN'T END SOON ENOUGH FOR FANS IN OAKLAND
description: Oakland Raiders fans, knowing they may lose their team but for the moment not caring, were overjoyed tonight after Oakland's convincing Super Bowl victory.

title: No Headline
description: EX-HOSTAGE SAY MILITANTS RAN '3-RING MENTAL CIRCUS'

title: ISRAELI ASSAILS JUSTICE DEPT. DECISION ON ACCUSED NAZI
description: Israel's chief investigator of Nazi war crimes has sharply criticized the Department of Justice for its decision not to retry a Chicago man accused of committing acts of persecution as a member of the Gestapo in World War II.

title: RAZING THE WRONG ROOF
description: To the Editor:

title: SHOOTING OF COLUMBIA STUDENT EVOKES FEAR UPTOWN
description: The neighbors of a 23-year-old graduate student at Columbia University who was badly wounded in a holdup gathered yesterday on the sidewalks, and in the lobbies of buildings on Morningside Drive to talk about their fears and ways to deal with crime in the neighborhood.

title: An Appraisal
description: The 50-story apartment tower of glass that Harry Helmsley, the developer, has proposed to erect beside the East River at 42d Street is more handsome than most new luxury apartment buildings in New York City, and it might seem, at first glance, to be almost a positive contribution to the city's riverfront. Yet it has aroused as much controversy as any building proposed for midtown Manhattan for some time, and with reason - for this plan is no ordinary real-estate project, but the result of a complex drama involving Mr. Helmsley, the City Planning Commission, the United Nations, a city playground and a pair of parks in the midst of the neighboring apartment complex, Tudor City.

title: Restrictions on Gas Heat Are Lifted in Massachusetts
description: Gov. Edward J. King today lifted an executive order limiting thermostat settings in gas-heated homes and buildings throughout Massachusetts.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt TOO OLD TO CRY. By Paul Hemphill. 249 pages. Viking. $11.95.

title: BRADSHAW'S MANDATE AT RCA
description: Thornton F. Bradshaw, the president of the Atlantic Richfield Company who was named this weekend to replace Edgar H. Griffiths as chairman of the RCA Corporation, will bring to the job an outspoken concern for social responsibility that has frequently cast him as a maverick among fellow oil executives. He will also carry a mandate from his fellow members on the RCA board to achieve something that Mr. Griffiths never did: the finding and nurturing of his eventual successor.

title: Magazine on Hostages
description: CBS Publications is rushing out today with a one-shot magazine that contains a photo essay on the former American hostages called Free! It is an extra from American Photography, carries advertising and is selling for $2.95.

title: Big Ten Basketball: Great for the Fans but Tough on the Coaches
description: In last season's 90 Big Ten games, the home team won 68 times. This season, after 30 games, the home teams have won only 16. Seemingly, the home-court advantage is no longer so sacred, and unpredictability has become the key word in the Big Ten. Indiana, Ohio State, Iowa and Illinois, all of whom were well regarded before the season, are experiencing the same problems as Purdue, Michigan State, Michigan and Minnesota, the predicted middle-of-the-pack finishers.

title: P.L.O. Paper Advocates Holy War To Regain Israeli-Occupied Lands
description: A Palestine Liberation Organization newspaper today urged leaders at the Islamic summit meeting in Saudi Arabia to declare a holy war to recover Israeli-occupied Arab lands.

title: Carol M. O'Connor Is Bride of Jon Groetzinger, Lawyer
description: Carol Marie O'Connor, daughter of John F. O'Connor of Winchester, Mass., and the late Mrs. O'Connor, was married yesterday to Jon Groetzinger Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Groetzinger of White Plains. Justice of the Peace Justin Wyner of Brookline, Mass., performed the ceremony in the Martha Mary Chapel in Sudbury, Mass.

title: 2 CONGRESSIONAL CHAIRMEN SEEKING TOUGHER RULES FOR SHAPING BUDGETS
description: The chairmen of the House and Senate budget committees have agreed to seek measures to put teeth into the Congressional Budget Act of 1974.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: When a player in the National Basketball Association is fouled in the act of shooting, and the ball misses the basket, is the attempt counted in calculating his field-goal shooting statistics?

title: FINANCIAL REPORTS SHOW THAT 10MEMBERS OF CABINET ARE WORTH $1 MILLION OR
description: MORE

title: Train Kills Motorist at Crossing
description: Dawn Dulock, a 19-year-old art student who stopped her automobile on a railroad crossing when other cars reportedly blocked her from both sides, was crushed to death by a freight train yesterday. Anthony Puerta, 26, of Pompano Beach, Fla., the driver of the car to the rear, was charged by police with vehicular manslaughter for allegedly refusing to move his auto.

title: SUCCESS AT WORK AND AS A WOMAN
description: A S more and more women achieve success in business, they are being forced to cope with a problem that many find shattering and demoralizing: How to accept their success without feeling that they are failures as women.

title: Iran Reports Killing 40 Iraqis
description: Iran reported killing 40 Iraqis in ''mopping-up operations'' around Nowsud. The official Pars press agency said five Iranian revolutionary guards were killed in the clashes.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JANUARY 26, 1981
description: International Mao's widow's death sentence could be commuted to life imprisonment. Jiang Qing and nine other former Chinese leaders were convicted by a special court of counterrevolutinary crimes during the Cultural Revolution. Eight of the others were given prison terms, Miss Jiang and Zhang Chunqiao were suspended for two years. (Page A3, Columns 1-2.) The Labor Party's turn to the left was denounced in Britain by four former Labor Party Cabinet Ministers, all in the party's right wing. They formed a ''Council for Social Democracy'' and asked other party members to join them. (A3:3-4.)

title: LON-TERM YIELDS MAY REMAIN HIGH
description: The credit markets expect to hear some good news soon from Washington, but many analysts say those announcements are not likely to cause a significant decline in long-term interest rates. High inflation and high short-term interest rates are powerful forces that deter investors and keep long-term bond yields high, they explain.

title: Super Opinions
description: Dr. Hunter S. Thompson is back in Woody Creek, Colo., after a hectic writing assignment in Hawaii. He had covered the Honolulu Marathon for Running magazine, producing an 87-page text, and had survived what he called ''the worst surf storm in the history of the Kona Coast,'' producing what he claims is a ''tape of a 17-foot wave.'' So he was glad to be recuperating at home last week. In past years, he would have been at the Super Bowl.

title: THE MAKING OF A UNITED STATES FOREIGN SERVICE OFFICER
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Nashel Is Married
description: Susan Ostro Nashel, a member of the social-work department of Lenox Hill Hospital, and Robert Neil Solomon, a partner in the law firm of Frankfurt, Garbus, Klein & Selz, were married yesterday afternoon.

title: No Headline
description: Miss Navratilova Takes First Step to Regain Top

title: New President Named At Telecom Entertainment
description: Michael Lepiner, who was senior vice president and director of programming at Benton & Bowles, has been named president of the newly formed Telecom Entertainment, a subsidiary of the agency that will produce programming not only for the three commercial networks but what the agency calls ''other broadcast entities.'' Does that include cable? Yes, said Mr. Lepiner, who added, ''and any technology that needs software.''

title: KING KHALID ENTREATS ISLAMIC LEADERS TO SHUN ALLIANCS WITH SUPERPOWERS
description: In a prepared speech read by Crown Prince Fahd in Mecca, King Khalid today urged Moslem countries to resist military alliances with the superpowers, and he appealed to Islamic leaders gathered for a summit conference to resolve disputes that have divided the Moslem world.

title: Indonesian Quake Toll Is Rising
description: An Indonesian official said today that about 250 people had probably died in an earthquake last week that destroyed 14 villages in Irian Jaya Province, 2,200 miles east of Jakarta on the island of New Guinea. The official death toll today stood at 67, but the provincial governor said that the figure may reach 250, the number of people still missing in the area.

title: J. EDGAR HOOVER'S PRESS-RELEASE POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: Paper Work
description: John Madden has a game plan as a sports commentator just as he did when he was a successful coach with the Oakland Raiders.

title: 2 Armories to End Shelter Operations
description: Two armories in the city providing shelter for people lacking heat in their own homes will no longer accept new applicants.

title: People
description: * Fred Gardner is now chairman and Patrick Fitzgerald president and chief executive of the Fred Gardner Company

title: TV: JONATHAN MILLER'S 'SHREW' ON PBS
description: year series that will encompass all 37 of the master dramatist's works for the stage. The first two years were overseen by Cedric Messina; the last two are scheduled to be produced by Shaun Sutton, head of drama for the British Broadcasting Corporation.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Broadcasting Company has reorganized its Owned Stations division and named Richard L. Beesemyer as vice president and general manager, operations, for the division and David Johnson as vice president and general manager, planning and development.

title: WEEK'S NEW ISSUE VOLUME UNCLEAR
description: Upwards of $800 million of corporate bonds are scheduled for public sale this week, but market participants cannot be certain of the volume because the vast majority of pending issues are to be negotiated with underwriters. Negotiated financings give the underwriters flexibility to bring new debt issues to market quickly if buyers are receptive or to withdraw them if buyers will not make commitments.

title: Southern Baptists Planning To Set Up a TV Network; Southern Baptists Plan To Set Up a TV Network
description: The Southern Baptist Church would join CBS, NBC, ABC and the Cable News Network in the network television business this year if a license application to the Federal Communications Commission is approved.

title: Hassall Captures Central Park Race
description: Tom Hassall of the Warren Street Social and Athletic Club captured the New York Road Runners Club Freedom Run, a 20-kilometer race, yesterday morning in Central Park in 1 hour 3 minutes 30 seconds.

title: DAY OF SUPERLATIVES AT THE SUPER BOWL
description: The first competitive sports event of Super Bowl Sunday was a 6.2-mile road race held here this morning over the streets of the French Quarter in which three former Super Bowl stars played a role.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FRENCH PICTURES

title: Braniff Pays $400,000 Fine
description: Braniff Airways has paid the Federal Aviation Administration $400,000 to settle a $1.5 million fine - the largest in F.A.A. history - imposed for maintenance and safety violations in 1978 and 1979. The settlement was made ''under protest'' and did not reflect an admission of guilt, Braniff said.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Robert H. Wellington, the 58-year-old president of Amsted Industries Inc., has been named to the added position of chief executive officer. He succeeds Goff Smith, 64, who continues as chairman of the Chicago-based company, where the usual retirement age is 65.

title: GRAHAM GETS 7 BIRDIES AND WINS BY A SHOT
description: David Graham shot seven birdies today, carded a 66 for 268 and won the Phoenix open by a stroke. He also proved to be something of a prophet.

title: BALANCHINE 'STARS AND STRIPES' HAILS EX-HOSTAGES The New York City Ballet celebrated the return from Iran of the former hostages at the end of last night's performance at the New York State Theater with the finale of George Balanchine's ballet ''Stars and Stripes.''
description: Announcing the surprise encore in a curtain speech, the principal dancer Jacques d'Amboise said that it was presented by the ''dancers, orchestra and stage crew to celebrate this event with you. Our American hostages are free at last.''

title: President Named At D.M.&M. Worldwide
description: Anthony J. Abrahams, 54-year-old chairman of D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius, Europe, has become president of the D.M.&M. Worldwide, James B. Orthwein, chairman and chief executive, announced from his St. Louis office. Mr. Abrahams replaces Charles F. Adams, who left to become Washington representative of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

title: SIRENS AND CHURCH BELLS PROCLAIM THE COUNTRY'S JOY
description: The private happiness of the hostages and their families at Stewart International Airport and at West Point was transformed into public joy in cities and hamlets around the country yesterday.

title: Hesburgh's Asteroid
description: He can't see it, but the Rev. Theodore Hesburgh, the president of the University of Notre Dame says, he feels ''great'' just knowing it's up there.

title: Church Formed by Split Welcomes Carter Family
description: Former President Jimmy Carter has switched his church membership to the Maranatha Baptist Church, which was created during a church division about the time he took office.

title: Widow Accused of Slaying Ex-Speaker of Texas House
description: The wife of former Price Daniel Jr., the former Speaker of the Texas House who was shot to death last Monday, has been charged with murdering her husband.

title: DORA SELVER
description: Dora Selver, retired president and chairman of Dutchess Lingerie and an early leader in the development of synthetic fabrics, died Friday at the Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. Mrs. Selver, who was a resident of New York City, was 90 years old.

title: TEHERAN PAPER ASSERTS ACCORD WAS NO VICTORY
description: A major Iranian newspaper today dismissed Government claims that the release of the American hostages was a victory for Iran and said that the United States had at best met Iran's demands only in part.

title: LEFTISTS' OFFENSIVE IN EL SALVADOR STALLS
description: Two weeks after launching their longawaited ''final offensive,'' El Salvador's leftist guerrillas have so far posed no serious threat to the country's civilian-military junta, although the Government is not yet claiming that the rebels have been defeated.

title: U.S. IS 'PROUD OF YOU,' RELATIVES ARE TOLD
description: President Reagan held an understated but emotional White House meeting today with the families of the former American hostages, telling them: ''America has to be very proud of you.''

title: Federal Study Advising Mail-Order Rule Reform
description: Mail order customers are being cheated significantly despite Federal regulations designed to protect them, Congressional investigators said today.

title: CENSUS DRAMATIZES CHANGES IN JERSEY LIFE DURING 1970's
description: The 1980 census has uncovered dramatic changes in New Jersey in the last decade caused by an erosion of the state's manufacturing base, the continued decline of its cities, the development of the Interstate Highway System and changes in family living patterns.

title: CENSUS MISSES 8.5% ON NEW YORK CITY WELFARE ROLL
description: A court-ordered report by the Census Bureau has disclosed that a preliminary sample of statistics indicated that the 1980 census apparently missed 8.5 percent of the welfare recipients in New York City.

title: Advertising; New Push By Allied Chemical
description: FOLLOWING the lead of many diversified companies that consider themselves not fully understood in the marketplace, the Allied Chemical Corporation has decided to explain itself through corporate advertising. And it has picked Doyle Dane Bernbach as its agency.

title: Reinforcing a Career
description: When the Young Concert Artists' Philip M. Faucett Prize was set up, Mr. Faucett, the Illinois economist who endowed it, intended it to have two purposes. They were to provide a struggling young artist with a recital in Alice Tully Hall and to start him on a recording career by means of a contract with the Musical Heritage Society.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE OLD PROS WHEN YOUNG

title: What the Cheers Are For
description: Watching the hostages return, a line from ''Hair,'' the rock musical, kept coming to mind: ''Crazy for the red, white, blue - and yellow ... fringe.'' In the late 60's, the fourth color signified bitter division over the draft and Vietnam.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard SOLOMON & SHEBA. By Faye Levine. 227 pages. Richard Marek. $10.95.

title: DANCE: ROBERT KOVICH DISPLAYS HIS CHOREOGRAPHIC WARES
description: DEFT and intensely alert, Robert Kovich is an unfailingly interesting dancer. He recently left the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, presumably to concentrate on his own choreography.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allied Chemical Corporation announced a 49 percent equity investment in Alkamex S.A., a supplier of aluminum sulfate for the Mexican market.

title: CARTER HIRES JOSEPHSON AS LITERARY AGENT
description: Former President Jimmy Carter appointed Marvin Josephson and Lynn Nesbit, literary agents, to handle the sale of rights to his memoirs, it was disclosed yesterday. If Mrs. Carter decides to write a book, she also will be represented by Mr. Josephson, chairman of Marvin Josephson Associates, and Miss Nesbit, senior vice president of International Creative Management, a talent agency and Josephson Associates' principal subsidiary.

title: Solo Debut in Boston
description: In her first public appearance following the announcement last week that her 22-year marriage to Senator Edward M. Kennedy would soon be ''terminated,'' Joan Kennedy appeared Sunday with the Boston Symphony Orchestra as narrator of Prokofiev's Russian fairy tale, ''Peter and the Wolf.''

title: MARTHA BETZ SHAPLEY
description: Martha Betz Shapley, widow of Dr. Harlow Shapley, the astronomer, died Saturday in Tucson, Ariz.

title: 8 Found Drilling Into Jewelry Outlet
description: Eight men were arrested while drilling into a jewelry exchange with the help of electric generators, two 75-pound drills, sledgehammers, crowbars and two sanitation trucks, the police said.

title: PHARMACIST TELLS OF PRESCRIPTIONS MRS. HARRIS GOT
description: A pharmacist testified today in Westchester County Court that Dr. Herman Tarnower was prescribing a variety of stimulants, depressants and painkillers to Jean S. Harris, who is accused of his murder, for two years prior to the shooting.

title: Suspect in Sniper Attack Killed by Police in Texas
description: The police said today that a suspected sniper was shot to death by officers yesterday after he had allegedly slain one youth and critically wounded another because they had been riding minibikes near his home.

title: Dr. W.F. Caveness, 72, Expert on Head Injuries
description: Dr. William F. Caveness, a neurologist and expert in head injuries, died Saturday at the U.S. Naval Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 72 years old and lived in Bethesda.

title: Officer Named For Ford Unit
description: Philip E. Benton Jr. has been appointed vice president for the North American car and truck group at the Ford Motor Company after less than three months as head of the Ford division, the company said today.

title: TENATIVE SCHEDULE FOR HOSTAGES
description: Following is the tentative schedule of events tomorrow for the former American hostages. All times are Eastern standard.

title: SPEEDED DECONTROL OF OIL IS INDICATED BY ADMINISTRATION
description: A decision by the Reagan Administration to lift remaining controls on the price and allocation of petroleum is ''fairly imminent,'' David A. Stockman, director-designate of the Office of Management and Budget, said today.

title: 3 More Ask Funds For Jersey Race
description: Three more candidates for Governor filed financial reports with the New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission, bringing to six the number of candidates who have applied for public funds.

title: Bank in St. Louis Cuts Prime to 19%
description: The Southwest Bank of St. Louis reduced its prime rate yesterday to 19 percent from 20 percent, the level that now prevails throughout the nation.

title: Parliament Will Debate New Murdoch Bid
description: Last week's announcement that Rupert Murdoch had reached a conditional agreement to buy The Times of London and affiliated publications stirred criticism that the sale would give too much editorial power to Mr. Murdoch, who already owns two London newspapers.

title: EAST IS EAST, REAGAN IS LEARNING
description: As soon as President Reagan took office, his staff hung color photographs of his beloved California ranch in a hallway near the Oval Office. But what was intended as a homey touch may have touched off a case of Presidential homesickness.

title: Boston Offering a Plan To Entice Bruins to Stay
description: Mayor Kevin H. White, trying to prevent the city from losing the Bruins to Salem, N.H., presented a plan today to build a new sports arena behind 50-year-old Boston Garden.

title: Toyota Closes California Plant
description: Toyota Motor Company's only United States manufacturing plant closed its doors for two weeks, idling 355 employees, because of a slowdown in truck sales, the company said.

title: Kush Lawyer Questions Motive in Suit
description: An attorney for Frank Kush told a jury today that a $2.2 million damage suit by a former player was filed in an effort to get Kush dismissed as Arizona State football coach.

title: China's Press Hails Trial As Victory for Legal System
description: China's press today called the judgments against 10 leaders of the Cultural Revolution a victory for the country's new legal system but said other ''hostile elements'' remained to be dealt with.

title: U.S. -SOVIET SCIENTIFIC FREEZE CUTS BOTH WAYS
description: WASHINGTON WHEN the Soviet Union sent a new science attache to its embassy here recently, President Carter's science adviser refused to receive him for the customary get-acquainted chat. The attache, Dr. Igor M. Makarov, ultimately met informally with the adviser, Dr. Frank Press, at private parties and he says, with a sly grin, that there are ''no bad feelings.''

title: MALAYSIA IS FIGHTING TIDE OF INDONERIANS
description: uf881 By PAMELA G. HOLLIE

title: GOLD SINKS ON REAGAN COMMENTS
description: Gold and silver prices plunged yesterday as traders reacted to comments by President Reagan and Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, indicating they would like to see gold prices move sharply lower.

title: TELEVISION BLOCKS THE VIEW
