description: AGOVERNMENT study commissioned by the White House recently concluded that there is a ''trend toward virtual scientific and technological illiteracy'' in this country -bad news for a society whose foundations are based on science and technology.

title: Weekly Steel Output Up
description: Steel production rose to 2.41 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, up 2.3 percent from the previous week's 2.35 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Super Premiere Plays For London Fans 5
description: Thanks to the wizardry of a communications satellite, Super Bowl madness hopped across the Atlantic last night, thrilling a high-paying audience of 2,000 fans at a movie theater in Leicester Square.

title: Fires in Atlantic City Checked for Arson
description: ATLANTIC CITY (AP) - Authorities were investigating whether youths from the Inlet neighborhood set a half-dozen fires that broke out there during a power failure Sunday.

title: BROADER ELIGIBILITY FOR RECIPIENTS IN U.S. CHARITY DRIVE WELCOMED
description: A Federal court has sharply criticized the Government for excluding two minority groups as recipients of funds from its charity drives. A critic of the Government's policy called the decision a ''major step'' in broadening the types of ''charity'' efforts that can benefit from fund raising among Government employes.

title: ARCO NAMES A NEW PRESIDENT
description: The board of the Atlantic Richfield Company yesterday named William F. Kieschnick president and chief operating officer amid indications that he might be just as unconventional as Thornton F. Bradshaw, his predecessor, who ignored industry dogma on issues such as the ''windfall'' profits tax.

title: Q. Why aren't meadows invaded by surrounding trees?
description: A. If meadows are not maintained by mowing, they will gradually revert back to forests. Without mowing, in three to five years there would be a woody invasion of the meadow consisting largely of shrubs. After about 10 years, small trees would have grown, and in about 30 years the former meadow would be well on its way to becoming a forest.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; French Deny Libyan Charge Of Troop Move Near Chad

title: Bridge: '57 Book on Bidding Offers Solid Theory in '81 Edition
description: The number of books in the literature of bridge that have represented a major advance in bidding is in single figures. One of them is ''The Theory of Bidding'' by Norman Squire, which was first published in 1957.

title: Rates Down Slightly at Auction; Six Month Bills Yield 14.12%
description: Treasury bill rates fell modestly at yesterday's auctions as the six-month issue averaged 14.12 percent, compared with 14.47 percent last week, and the three-month issue averaged 15.20 percent, compared with 15.60 percent.

title: CAPITAL GREETING FOR EX-HOSTAGES TO BE SUBDUED
description: The Reagan Administration reported today that ''a dozen or so'' of the 52 Americans freed from captivity in Iran still had ''severe'' mental problems and that the welcoming ceremony at the White House tomorrow would therefore be subdued in nature.

title: Is There a (Trained) Doctor in the House?
description: Few cries for help are more chilling than the urgent call for a doctor in the house. It evokes visions of the heroic physician, never off duty, interrupting his entertainment to rescue the victim of a heart attack. Unfortunately, a lot of doctors don't know what to do when they reach the victim's side. Worse, they don't seem to want to learn.

title: ARCO AND UNION OIL POST GAINS
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, the nation's seventh-largest oil company, and the smaller Union Oil Company of California yesterday reported earnings increases of 16.1 percent and 16.3 percent, respectively, for the fourth quarter of 1980.

title: No Headline
description: AMERICA'S VIETNAM ROLE USED TO TAUNT HOSTAGES

title: JERSEY UTILITY TO SHIP NUCLEAR RODS TO OHIO TO EXAMINE DAMAGE
description: Within the next few weeks, the Jersey Central Power and Light Company plans to truck damaged nuclear fuel rods with a state police escort from its Forked River power plant through Pennsylvania to a laboratory in Ohio.

title: Nehemiah Polishing His Form
description: Last Friday night, Renaldo (Skeets) Nehemiah made his 1981 indoor track debut and won the 60-yard high hurdles in 7.01 seconds at the Philadelphia Track Classic. Yesterday, he apologized for it.

title: Advertising; A 'Great Year' At SSC&B
description: TO some noncompetitive soul, being in the shoes of the president of SSC&B in the last year would have been torture. But said William J. Weithas Jr., who was wearing them for the first time, ''We've had a great year and it was one of the most interesting in my life.''

title: POLISH STUDENTS' SIT IN SPREADING
description: A spreading protest by 2,000 students at the University of Lodz demanding abolition of compulsory classes in Marxism-Leninism and other changes added new tensions today.

title: WOMEN FREED BY IRAN FIND RECEPTION AT WEST POINT IS LIKE A 'BATH IN LOVE'
description: Together through a harrowing captivity, Elizabeth Ann Swift and Kathryn Koob remained together today in joy and freedom.

title: NO LACK OF ADVICE FOR SCHOOLS
description: ABARRAGE of studies and reports on curriculum has hit the schools in recent months, including these: - A Presidential commission called the neglect of foreign languages and international studies a threat to American security.

title: JUST A DROP IN THE NEW YORK POLICE BUCKET
description: To the Editor:

title: The Boxer Who Won't Quit
description: The money, Bennie Briscoe said yesterday, ''of course it's the money.'' In 12 days, Briscoe will be 38 years old and will be in his 20th year as a professional boxer, one year after his hometown promoter wrote to every commission in the United States and asked that this ''deteriorated fighter'' be retired.

title: Yanks Reach Agreements With Brown and Werth
description: The Yankees said yesterday that they had signed Bobby Brown and Dennis Werth to one-year contracts at undisclosed salaries.

title: SINGER: MARILYN HORNE
description: MARILYN HORNE'S oft-postponed recital at Carnegie Hall finally came to pass Sunday afternoon. The singer, now restored to health, joined Martin Katz, her accompanist, in a program that touched almost every style and mood imaginable.

title: Ford's Advice to Carter
description: It may not be easy to give up the pressures and perquisites of power, but Jimmy Carter has received some advice on how to face his enforced retirement. It comes from someone who should know.

title: 3 White Girls in Louisiana Start Class at Private School
description: Three white girls who defied a Federal judge's desegregation order that would have bused them to a racially integrated public school started classes today at a private academy.

title: On Camera, Not In
description: The Supreme Court has sensibly rejected the view that photographic coverage inherently deprives a defendant of a fair trial. Its unanimous decision to let states continue experimental televising of trials is a victory for public justice.

title: STAGE: CANADIAN SIDE OF WORLD WAR II
description: REAL life is fine as far as it goes, but it doesn't necessarily make for good theater. That's the main lesson to be learned from ''Waiting for the Parade,'' a new Canadian play about five women in the provincial town of Calgary during the World War II years. According to a program note, John Murrell, the playwright, adapted his drama from the actual reminiscences of such home-front women, and no doubt everything that happens in ''Parade'' is true. But so what? Realistic details are the raw material of art, not art itself; they become compelling only when an artist has the talent to arrange them in an arresting pattern. If Mr. Murrell were a painter, I'm afraid he'd be Norman Rockwell, not Edward Hopper.

title: Theater in Park to Offer Film and Concert Series
description: The film series at Theater in the Park in Flushing Meadow-Corona Park continues on Feb. 6 with Rainer Werner Fassbinder's ''The Marriage of Maria Braun.'' On Feb. 13, Theater in the Park will show Ermanno Olmi's ''The Tree of Wooden Clogs.''

title: SEOUL LEADER HOPES TO ENHANCE U.S. TIES
description: President Chun Doo Hwan sees ''no differences of opinion or outlook'' between South Korea and the United States.

title: New Haven Students Improve in Math Test
description: While more than one-fourth of the ninth-grade students in public schools in Connecticut have failed a minimium-proficiency test in mathematics, the city with the lowest scores, New Haven, has shown a notable improvement, the State Commissioner of Education announced.

title: NEW-MUSIC SYMPOSIUM RAISES SOME HACKLES
description: Acrimony was perhaps pre-ordained at the 92d Street Y's Conference on Contemporary Music, which attracted several hundred composers, performers, critics, arts administrators and members of the public Sunday and yesterday. The Y has a noble history of support for musical modernism, but the history has not been sustained.

title: A DEAL IS A DEAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Packers and Raiders Deny Pastorini Trade Report
description: Bart Starr, the Green Bay Packer coach, scoffed today at a report of a trade that would send the ailing Oakland Raider quarterback, Dan Pastorini, to the Packers for James Lofton, a wide receiver.

title: A NEW FASHION EMPHASIS ON GRANDEUR LIVENS PARIS COUTURE SHOW
description: The couture shows for spring and summer opened quite literally with fireworks. Showers of sparkling lights illuminated the night as Gerard Pipart strode down the runway to meet his bride adrift in point d'esprit and flowers. The designer of the Nina Ricci collection then posed with the model in the bouffant wedding dress that is the traditional finale for French fashion shows and with all her bouffantgowned attendants in what looked like a family portrait.

title: NO SIGNS OF ANGUISH SHOWN BY HOSTAGES
description: Savoring their first full day of freedom on American soil, the former hostages emerged singly and in pairs today from the Hotel Thayer on the campus of the United States Military Academy here, some to jog or simply stroll about the snowcovered grounds, others to attend an ecumenical worship service in the academy's chapel or to take a short bus ride to the post exchange.

title: AID TO NEEDIEST HONORS HOSTAGES
description: ''We have been waiting for this day too long!'' wrote Nancy and John Kipping of Manhattan on Jan. 19. That was the message accompanying their $25 donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund at a time when the release of the American hostages in Iran was expected momentarily.

title: TV: 'BUNKER,' ON HITLER'S LAST DAYS
description: FOR three hours this evening, beginning at 8 o'clock, CBS-TV is offering ''The Bunker,'' a dramatization of the final days of Hitler and his Third Reich. John Gay's script is based on a book by James O'Donnell, who was on assignment for Newsweek in the Berlin of 1945. Mr. O'Donnell, played by James Naughton, is seen entering Hitler's abandoned underground hideout. He explains:

title: Redskins Hire Ex-Oiler
description: Joe Bugel, one of six Houston Oiler assistants freed from their contracts after Coach Bum Phillips was dismissed last month, was named offensive coordinator for the Washington Redskins today.

title: BENDIX CLIMBS 5.1%; CONTROL DATA SOARS
description: The Bendix Corporation, a diversified manufacturer with interests in the automotive, aerospace and industrial markets, reported yesterday that earnings in the first fiscal quarter of 1981 ended Dec. 31 increased 5.1 percent on a revenue increase of 26.4 percent.

title: News Analysis
description: Once again, the Polish Government and the independent trade unions are battling, but this time the issues are vaguer and the stakes are higher.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * E.I.L. Instruments filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an initial offering of 500,000 common shares in March. A maximum offering price of $15 a share is planned.

title: What Kind Of Tax Cut?
description: President Reagan has slipped far behind the optimistic timetable of his most impatient economic advisers, because vigorous debate continues within the Administration on the substance of his promised tax and budget reductions. Even some Democrats are managing to get a few words in edgewise.

title: MONGOLIAN HOT POTS
description: SOME years back, the dinner parties of the Western world were blitzed by fondue pots. As a result, many people seemed to go through a period in which they were sure they had had their fill of dipping this into that. But the time is appropriate enough now, I think, to revive talk about dipping rituals, in particular the one presented by the Mongolian hot pot.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JANUARY 27, 1981
description: International Primacy for the State Department in the formulation of foreign policy was sought urgently by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., according to Reagan Administration aides. They said Mr. Haig submitted a 20-page memorandum presenting ways to implement the request to President Reagan while he was still in his inaugural attire. Mr. Reagan, they said, deferred a response. (Page A1, Column 5.) Cool scientific contacts between Washington and Moscow have become the rule in the last year because of the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan and revulsion among American scientists over Moscow's treatment of Soviet dissidents. American scientists disagree over the effects of the change. (C1:6.)

title: Talking Business with Jones of G.E.; How to Improve Management
description: American management is undergoing a period of critical scrutiny within the board rooms and the classrooms. Its indictment contains the following elements: managers are obsessed with short-term profits, ignoring long-range investments; the entrepreneurial spirit seems scarce among executives; top positions are often filled with financial types, who have little hands-on experience with the businesses they oversee; managers have not focused enough on overseas markets, and business schools are a seedbed for these deficiencies.

title: No Headline
description: Hostage to: mind and heart of the solar wind blazing Hostage to: scrape of the coriolis force in the uplands Hostage to: fingers of the gravitational dance Hostage to: cosmos and chaos and ever in freedom Hostage to no man in no place in no time

title: EUROPE, IN THE WOODS
description: Few observers will seriously dispute that ''there has never been a time when the two halves of the Atlantic alliance were as divided as they are now,'' as The Economist said in an editorial recently. The ritual incantations of Atlantic solidarity will, of course, continue. The Reagan Administration will certainly stress the need for close cooperation with the allies. But it is not certain whether even a major world crisis (over Poland, for instance) will bring about a closing of ranks.

title: EX-REPRESENTIVE KELLY CONVICTED OF ABSCAM BRIBERY
description: Former Representative Richard Kelly of Florida was found guilty today of bribery and conspiracy, becoming the sixth member or former member of Congress to be convicted on charges arising from the Abscam investigation of political corruption.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: '' I have every confidence, knowing these men and women, that they are going to bounce back in spirit and strength.'' - L. Bruce Laingen, speaking of those held hostage with him. (B8:1.)

title: American Express Shows Profit Rise
description: The American Express Company, a diversified travel and financial company, reported yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings rose 12.2 percent, to $92 million, or $1.30 a share, from $82 million, or $1.15 a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Revenues rose to $1.5 billion from $1.2 billion.

title: Metals Found In Oil Shale
description: Oil shale beneath 2,700 square miles of central Montana contains significant amounts of zinc, nickel, molybdenum, vanadium and selenium as well as an estimated 180 billion barrels of synthetic crude oil, the Interior Department said today.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A 20-year-old Brooklyn man surrendered in the Jan. 19 robbery of a limousine parked on East 57th Street in which the chauffeur, an offduty policeman about to retire, shot and killed one robber. The suspect was identified as Richard Lugo and the dead man as Mark Diax, 19, both of the Fort Greene section, where Mr. Lugo surrendered at a Youth Patrol office.

title: TAIPEI HOPES REAGAN WILL ACT ON CAMPAIGN PLEDGES
description: Government officials here hope that the United States will take several modest steps to satisfy Taiwan's desire for better relations.

title: H.I. FELDMAN, HEAD OF ARCHITECTURE CONCERN, DIES
description: H. I. Feldman, an architect who designed 2,500 apartment houses in the New York metropolitan area, died yesterday at his home on Riverside Drive. He was 84 years old.

title: PUT THE GALA ON HOLD
description: To the Editor:

title: China Clarifies Trade Policy
description: Despite its current economic belt-tightening and cutback in capital investment, China is maintaining an ''open door'' policy in foreign trade and economic cooperation, Gu Mu, Deputy Prime Minister, said today.

title: Article 240776 -- No Title
description: The British Government today approved about $2.38 billion in emergency aid over the next two years for BL Ltd., the ailing state-owned auto company.

title: Builders Hope For Tax Credit
description: The National Association of Home Builders is hoping to benefit from consumer tax credit and savings bills already in Congress to pull the industry out of its worst slump since World War II.

title: Futures Prices Erratic In Technical Trading
description: Prices of a number of commodities moved sharply and erratically yesterday in what analysts said was largely technical trading - buying or selling on the basis of price trend charts or other such market analyses.

title: Columbia Student Shot by Robber Dies
description: Toby Strober, the 23-year-old Columbia University graduate student who was shot in the head Friday night after making a chance remark to the man who had just held him up, died yesterday morning at St. Luke's Hospital.

title: ASSOCIATED DRY GOODS TO BUY CALDOR
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, the operator of the Lord & Taylor stores and other leading department stores, will acquire Caldor Inc., the discount retailer based in Norwalk, Conn., for about $313 million in cash, stock and notes, the companies announced jointly yesterday.

title: Moscow Drops Charges Against U.S. on Captives
description: After four protests from the United States, Soviet news organizations have dropped accusations against the United States of brainwashing the 52 American hostages and preparing military action against Iran, a State Department spokesman said today.

title: Reynolds Returns to TV For New Pipe Tobacco
description: R.J. Reynolds Tobacco, which has not been able to use much television advertising lately, will be back in the medium next month to push Royal Comfort, a new pipe tobacco entry, and its first new brand in the $216 million category since 1973.

title: REACTION OF AMERICAN PUBLIC PROVES A PLEASENT SURPRISE FOR EX-HOSTAGES
description: For so long they had been lumped together simply as The Hostages that some of them apparently began to accept the phrase as their point of identification.

title: Jazz Waive Boone, Ending His Streak of 1,041 Games
description: Ron Boone, a guard who has played in a record 1,041 consecutive pro basketball games, had his streak ended today when he was waived by the Utah Jazz.

title: WINFIELD AND YANKS REACH AGREEMENT
description: Six weeks after they signed their first contract, George Steinbrenner and Dave Winfield agreed yesterday on an amended one. In one meeting and one telephone conversation, the Yankees' principal owner and his richest-ever free agent worked out a new cost-of-living provision to replace the one from the Dec. 15 contract that could have been worth $23.3 million over 10 years.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the meaning of a sentence was changed in Mirra Komarovsky's article ''College Women and Careers,'' on Friday's Op-Ed page. The sentence should have read: ''It is quite true that building bridges, writing books, and splitting the atom are no more essential to society than child-rearing.''

title: THEATER: 'VICTORY OVER THE SUN'
description: WASHINGTON IN ''Victory Over the Sun,'' an avant-garde Cubo-Futurist ''opera'' staged in Russia in 1913, a pair of ''Futurist Strongmen'' wear cardboard boxlike armor, step into the future and proclaim, ''All's well that begins well and has no end/ the world will perish but there is no end to us!''

title: No Headline
description: IRAQIS SAY KURDISH GUERRILLAS STRIKE AT IRANIAN TROOPS

title: Iran Opposes Bank on Funds
description: The Government of Iran asked a Federal judge today to abandon an order allowing the Bank of America to attach $91 million in Iranian assets involved in the freeing of the former United States hostages.

title: British Insurer Stock Sale
description: The Kuwait Investment Office said today that it had bought a further 2.4 million shares of stock in the Royal Insurance Company, Britain's largest insurance concern, raising its stake to 10.5 million shares, or 5.59 percent.

title: Sutter and Cards Agree
description: Bruce Sutter and the St. Louis Cardinals reached agreement today on terms of a four-year contract, the club president, August A. Busch Jr., said. Terms of the agreement were not released, but the star relief pitcher and 1979 Cy Young winner is certain to be getting more than the $700,000 he received from the Chicago Cubs last year.

title: The Economy
description: An Administration decision to speed up decontrol of petroleum prices is ''fairly imminent,'' David A. Stockman, director-designate of the Office of Management and Budget, said. Such a move could raise the price of gasoline and heating oil by as much as 5 to 10 cents a gallon within weeks. (Page A1.)

title: 6 Injured in Queens Fire; Ex-Employee Is Charged
description: Four firefighters and two other persons suffered minor injuries last night and at least 16 families were forced from their homes as a blaze swept a row of three-story buildings in Richmond Hill, Queens, a Fire Department spokesman said.

title: Strategic Air Command Begins A 20-Day Test of Preparedness
description: The Strategic Air Command began what it called its ''largest and most comprehensive exercise of strategic readiness ever undertaken'' without notice today at 7 A.M.

title: FLORES HINTS TEAM SHOULD STAY IN OAKLAND
description: In the afterglow of the Super Bowl victory, Coach Tom Flores indicated today that he wanted the Raiders to remain in Oakland and not move to Los Angeles.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 27, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on drafting an in- ternational convention against merce- naries - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Rockefeller Center Shift
description: Alton G. Marshall, 59, president of Rockefeller Center Inc. since 1971 and a key figure when Nelson A. Rockefeller was governor of New York, will leave the company this spring ''to pursue outside business interests,'' the company said. Mr. Marshall did not return telephone calls yesterday.

title: National Steel's Net Slides 28.2%
description: The National Steel Corporation reported today that net income fell 28.2 percent for the fourth quarter and 33.8 percent for the entire year of 1980, and attributed the declines to sharply lower demand for sheet steel products and ''inadequate prices in the marketplace.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, Pittsburgh, has elected George W. Tippins chairman and Richard P. Simmons president and chief executive officer.

title: General Tire Chief Relinquishing Post
description: Thomas F. O'Neil, chairman of the General Tire and Rubber Company, told the board of directors yesterday that he would not stand for reelection as chairman.

title: Stenmark Triumphs Easily To Dominate World Cup
description: Ingemar Stenmark beat his nearest challengers by a stunning margin of 1.7 seconds today to score his third giant slalom triumph this season and take a big stride toward his fourth overall World Cup title.

title: Simmer Scores 50th Goal
description: Charlie Simmer got his 50th goal of the season and Steve Jensen and Jim Fox scored two goals apiece last night as the Los Angeles Kings rallied for a 7-5 victory over the Nordiques in Quebec.

title: Pratt & Whitney Engines for Avianca
description: The United Technologies Corporation announced that its Pratt & Whitney unit would provide JT9D engines worth more than $45 million to power the new fleet of Boeing wide-body 767 twin jets of Avianca, the domestic and international airline of Colombia.

title: U.N. ASKS ISLAMIC AID TO END GULF WAR
description: Secretary General Kurt Waldheim today urged leaders of Islamic nations meeting here to help the United Nations more vigorously in its efforts to mediate the Iraqi-Iranian war.

title: METRO/SUB Court; City's Rent-Control Law Is Upheld by High Court
description: The United States Supreme Court let stand New York City's rentcontrol law yesterday, citing ''want of a substantial Federal question.''

title: Touche Ross Unit Merger
description: Touche Ross International, the accounting concern, announced a merger in Hong Kong between its Touche Ross & Company and Kwan Wong Tan & Fong, the British crown colony's largest Chinese firm of chartered accountants. The combined firm is expected to have 310 partners and three offices.

title: Sports of The Times; The Raiders Unlikely Season
description: IN his quiet moments, Tom Flores enjoys strumming a guitar. So he was asked yesterday what tune he'd play when he got home. '' 'Tie a Yellow Ribbon,' '' he said. The coach of the Super Bowl champion Oakland Raiders was referring to the yellow ribbons at the Superdome that symbolized the return to America of the freed hostages.

title: Defense Plant in Tennessee Vents Uranium Accidentally
description: A top-secret defense plant in the Tennessee mountains accidentally vented radioactive uranium twice in the last four months, Federal officials said today.

title: REMEMBER THE LIVES LOST
description: To the Editor:

title: Ferris Curbs Role at F.C.C.
description: Charles D. Ferris said today that he would remain as titular chairman of the Federal Communications Commission until April, fulfilling the required time to qualify for a $25,000-ayear pension. But he added that effective this week he would take no part in new commission matters. Mr. Ferris said that this procedure, worked out with the Reagan Administration, allows him to negotiate the terms of his next job - with a private law firm here - without compromising his status as a commission member. The procedure also allows the Administration to replace Mr. Ferris, a Democrat, with a chairman of its choice immediately.

title: ALMOST HALF OF SAMPLE IN A POLL REPORTS 'ADDICTION'
description: IF it were possible to get several hundred people together in a room for an hour and ask them a few hard questions about their drug and alcohol use, whether they gamble compulsively, overeat or overwork, most would understate or deny any addictive behavior.

title: LAW TO CURB RACKETEERS FACES REVIEW
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to define the scope of the Federal antiracketeering law, one of the most sweeping and controversial of all Federal criminal laws.

title: Key Rates
description: Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Japan's Record Vehicle Output
description: A record 11,042,884 vehicles rolled off Japanese assembly lines in 1980, surpassing the previous high of 9,635,546 in 1979, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

title: WARRENTS SEEK 2 IN COPTOR PLOT AT FEDERAL JAIL
description: Investigators said yesterday that they believed they knew the identities of two of the three persons sought in the unsuccessful attempt on Sunday to pluck an inmate by hijacked helicopter from the roof of a Federal jail in Manhattan.

title: REPORTS OF HOSTAGE ABUSE SURPRISE CLERICS
description: Some of the American ministers and professors who visited the 52 American hostages in Teheran last year and returned saying that the hostages seemed reasonably well-treated have been surprised and disturbed by recent reports to the contrary.

title: Risks of Tanning Booths
description: People who seek off-season or quick suntans in indoor tanning booths may be exposed to two times more cancer-inducing ultraviolet radiation than natural sunlight delivers, according to a report in the Jan. 23 issue of Science.

title: BLACK-HISPANIC COALITION PRESSING FOR 2 BOROUGH PRESIDENCIES IN CITY
description: A coalition of black and Puerto Rican politicians, formed in the maneuvering to pick Manhattan's Democratic at-large candidate in the City Council, will remain active in the November elections for Borough President in Manhattan and the Bronx, politicians said yesterday.

title: Texaco Finds Gas Off Trinidad Coast
description: Texaco Inc. said that tests of two wells drilled by a subsidiary off the coast of Trinidad had indicated the existence of a ''substantial'' deposit of natural gas.

title: CARBIDE SLIPS 7.2%; HERCULES UP BY 16%
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, the nation's third-largest chemical company, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980 fell 7.2 percent on an increase in sales of 11.7 percent.

title: Crane Co. Seeks Shares in Harsco
description: The Crane Company, a major building and plumbing products concern, said it intends to begin a cash tender today for up to 1.6 million shares of common stock of the Harsco Corporation at $38 net a share. Crane now owns 433,400 shares, or about 4.3 percent of the outstanding shares of Harsco, a producer of metals, plastic and other products.

title: POLICE IN CITY WILL USE NETS TO SUBDUE THE DERANGED
description: New York City police officers, who have been forced to handle a growing number of cases involving mentally disturbed people, will begin using fire extinguishers and huge nets this week when they answer such calls.

title: NEW JETS FOR TAIWAN: AN ISSUE SURROUNDED BY NETTLES
description: The Reagan Administration is quickly coming under pressure at home and from abroad to approve the sale of a new fighter plane to Taiwan. But the issue is full of potential diplomatic, political and economic problems, according to Government and industry officials.

title: CITY 'TICKER TAPE' PARADE FRIDAY
description: The city will hold a ''ticker tape'' parade Friday in honor of the 52 returned hostages, a spokesman for Mayor Koch said yesterday. The actual scheduling of the parade was decided upon after one of the 52, Barry M. Rosen of Brooklyn, accepted the city invitation to the celebration.

title: 12 People Injured in Ulster As Bombs Go Off in 6 Towns
description: Bombs placed in cars and buildings exploded tonight at nearly the same time in six towns, injuring 12 people and damaging 30 shops and other buildings.

title: Toyota-Ford Meeting Set
description: Officials of the Toyota Motor Company and Ford will meet on Feb. 5 at the Japanese company's headquarters to discuss a joint venture to manufacture autos, Toyota officials said today. The meeting will be attended by H.A. Poling, Ford vice president; Tatsuo Hasegawa, Toyota managing director, and other executives, Toyota said. The two auto makers have held a series of talks since the conclusion last June of a basic agreement on joint production of vehicles in the United States.

title: Wheaties Said to Be Changing Agencies
description: Wheaties is sprinting to a new agency, Needham, Harper & Steer, which already has a lot of business from General Mills, which makes the dry cereal, it has been learned.

title: Market Place; Stock Buying: P/E Approach
description: SOME money managers may remain enthusiastic about high-flying stocks that sell at 30 times annual earnings or more, but David N. Dreman is not part of that crowd. His approach to investing, in fact, is just the opposite.

title: Contracts Let For Iraqi Dam
description: A consortium of West German and Italian construction companies has been awarded contracts worth $1.5 billion to build a hydroelectric project on the Tigris River in Iraq, Hochtief A.G., the West German construction company that is leading the group, said today.

title: The Play for Time in Poland
description: The battle lines are drawn again in Poland. The workers are once more threatening massive strikes and the Soviet Army is staging new maneuvers. In Moscow's view, the very existence of the independent workers' union, Solidarity, endangers Communist Party rule throughout Eastern Europe. Each assertion of union strength evokes a demonstration of Soviet power.

title: Israeli Police Arrest 15 in Clash
description: The Israeli police said today that they had arrested 15 members of an Orthodox group last night. The police said members of Neturei Karta had clashed with other Jews in the Bukhariya section of Jerusalem over a community center that the group asserts would lead to ''degrading'' activities because of its use by both boys and girls.

title: EVANGELICALS DEBATE THEIR ROLE IN BATTLING SECULARISM
description: A large national gathering of Christian evangelicals, including hundreds of television and radio broadcasters, was urged today to bolster the campaign by evangelical political activists to combat secular humanism, which was described as ''the established religion of America.''

title: OPEC Output Up in Month
description: Oil production in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries rebounded slightly in November from a 10-month low as Iran and Iraq managed to export some oil despite their war, a trade newsletter said yesterday.

title: DEFEAT IS 3D STRAIGHT
description: The Knicks played poorly at the beginning and the end last night and dropped their third straight game, a 99-94 loss to the Phoenix Suns at Madison Square Garden.

title: Judge Urges a Refund Of Indian Point Charge
description: An administrative judge for the Public Service Commission recommended today that Consolidated Edison be ordered to refund nearly $43 million it charged its customers for replacement power after the Indian Point No. 2 nuclear plant was shut down.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES, T.W.A. AND WESTERN REPORT LOSSES
description: Three major airlines - American, Trans World and Western - reported large losses yesterday for the fourth quarter of 1980, mainly because of fuel price increases and a decline in traffic.

title: Lily P. Edelman, Writer And B'nai B'rith Official
description: Lily P. Edelman, a writer, translator and administrator of adult education programs for B'nai B'rith, died last Thursday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. She was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MOTHER OF VICTIM IN ATLANTA
description: Helen Pue being comforted by a police officer after she identified the body of her son, Terry. The boy, found strangled, was one of 16 children to disappear around Atlanta in 18 months.

title: Editor Named for Vietnam Series
description: Robert Manning, former editor in chief of The Atlantic Monthly and Assistant Secretary of State for public affairs under Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, will be editor of a 14-volume series on the Vietnam War for the Boston Publishing Company, a new independent house.

title: Scovill Names Baldrige's Successor
description: William F. Andrews, the 49-year-old president of Scovill Inc., has been elected to the additional posts of chairman and chief executive officer. He succeeds Malcolm Baldrige, 58, who was appointed Secretary of Commerce by President Reagan.

title: Two East German Soldiers Flee to West Germany
description: Two East German soldiers in full uniform and armed with Soviet pistols fled to West Germany yesterday by crossing a border area where there were no land mines, the West German border police said today.

title: The Kettering Tradition
description: After a yearlong search for a new president, trustees of the Charles F. Kettering Foundation of Dayton, Ohio, have awarded the job to one of their own - David Mathews, a former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, who served as a foundation trustee before joining the Ford Cabinet in 1975.

title: Sowetan, a Black Weekly Paper, To Publish Daily in South Africa
description: The black weekly Sowetan, companion journal of two newspapers banned by the South African Government, will publish as a daily, the Argus Publishing Company said today.

title: Hills Chain Picks New President
description: Stephen A. Goldberger, 38, has been named president of Hills Department Stores, a big discount-store chain and the largest unit of Scoa Industries Inc. He succeeds his father, Herbert H. Goldberger, 63, who continues as senior vice president, general merchandising, of the parent company, whose annual sales total more than $900 million.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times last Wednesday on inauguration activities incorrectly identified the college attended by the Rev. Donn Moomaw, the minister and former football player who gave the invocation and benediction at the Inaugural ceremony.

title: COURT GETS HOSPITAL COSTS CASE
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether private health insurers can be held liable for violating the antitrust laws if they limit the coverage they provide for care in hospital beds they believe should not exist. The case, which provoked a sharp internal dispute during the last months of the Carter Administration, involves an inherent conflict between two Federal policies: the effort to limit unnecessary hospital construction and the effort to protect competition and free choice in the marketplace.

title: No Headline
description: FLASH FLOODS HIT SOUTH AFRICA: Washed-out bridge on road to Laingsburg, about 160 miles northeast of Cape Town.

title: HIGH COURT DECIDES STATES CAN PERMIT TELEVISING OF TRIALS
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that states are free to permit the televising of criminal trials. In a decision likely to accelerate the trend toward cameras in the courtroom, the Justices ruled, 8 to 0, that television coverage does not automatically violate a defendant's constitutional right to a fair trial even when the defendant objects to the presence of the cameras.

title: SMALL BUSINESSES DUE FOR TAX CUT IN ASSEMBLY BILL
description: The New York State Assembly passed legislation today intended to help small business, including a package of bills that provide three new business-tax reductions.

title: REAGAN AIDES TO PROPOSE 'PERMANENT' BUDGET CUTS
description: David A. Stockman, the Reagan Administration's budget chief, said today that senior Government officials were compiling an array of proposals to Congress for permanent cuts in such benefits as Medicaid and dairy price supports.

title: MAGNETOMETER LEADS SEARCHERS TO ANCIENT BURIAL CAVE IN JORDAN
description: USING a magnetic contour map showing local highs and lows of magnetism, archeologists from the University of Pennsylvania have located an undisturbed, silt-filled burial cave in Jordan containing artifacts that may illuminate the apparently troubled times in the region between 1200 and 1050 B.C.

title: H. Sanders, Senior Partner In a Manhattan Accounting Firm
description: Albert H. Sanders, a senior partner in the accounting firm of Weinick, Sanders & Company of Manhattan, died Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MAN PLEADS GUILTY IN BEATING OF ACTRESS
description: A businessman pleaded guilty yesterday to assaulting Melonie Haller, an actress-model, during a weekend visit to a theater producer's mansion in Southampton.

title: HAIG MOVES FAST IN EFFORT TO WIN KEY POLICY ROLE
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. moved quickly on Inauguration Day to propose mechanisms to President Reagan for putting the State Department clearly in charge of developing foreign policy, Reagan aides reported today.

title: Grain Supplies Down
description: The Agriculture Department said today that grain supplies were down sharply from a year ago, reflecting last year's drought-shriveled harvests and a record demand abroad for United States commodities. With the exception of wheat, all major grains and oilseeds posted declines, the department's quarterly report showed. Last year's wheat crop set a record and was mostly harvested before the summer's drought and heat wave took a toll.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE AT A GLANCE
description: The space shuttle is a basically reusable vehicle, and is designed to make flight into Earth orbit more routine and somewhat less expensive. A fleet of at least four shuttles is expected to make up the nation's space transportation system for the rest of the century.

title: by florence fab
description: EVEN those who prefer smooth peanut butter are now faced with a crunch. In many supermarkets, independent groceries and small delicatessens in and around New York, the selection of peanut butter is limited. No stores are completely sold out, but certain brands, and especially the popular one pound 12 ounce size, are in short supply. And prices are higher, generally at least double what they were in September. Finding an 18-ounce jar for less than $2 is nearly impossible.

title: UNION PACIFIC, BURLINGTON AND N. & W. PROFITS RISE
description: Improved earnings were reported yesterday by three major railroads that either transport or produce energy-related products - the Union Pacific Corporation, Burlington Northern Inc. and the Norfolk & Western Railway.

title: WHERE BRITISH CENTRAL BANKERS WENT WRONG
description: To the Editor:

title: PHYSICIAN SUES SCIENCE MAGAZINE OVER ARTICLE ON CARE OF EX-SHAH
description: Dr. Benjamin H. Kean, the New York physician who urged the controversial admission of the late Shah of Iran to the United States for medical treatment in 1979 and who served as the deposed monarch's personal physician for part of that period, has filed a libel suit against Science magazine in Federal court here.

title: Don King Sues Ali Group, Mamby for Breach of Pact
description: The boxing promoter Don King filed a $21 million suit yesterday against Muhammad Ali Professional Sports and obtained a temporary restraining order against Madison Square Garden in an effort to prevent it from paying $600,000 to Maps for the promotion of a Feb. 23 boxing card.

title: Suntory of Japan Seeks TBS Britanica
description: Suntory Ltd., a Japanese whisky distiller and beer brewer, said it was negotiating with Encyclopaedia Britanica Inc. of Chicago and the Tokyo Broadcasting System to purchase the majority of the TBS Britanica Company, a joint venture.

title: EXCERPTS FROM CHIEF JUSTICE'S OPINION ALLOWING TELEVISED TRIALS
description: Following are excerpts from Chief Justice Warren E. Burger's majority opinion today in Chandler v. Florida, the Supreme Court decision that states are free to allow radio, television and still-photography coverage of criminal trials over defendants' objections:

title: RELATIVES AS 'OVERWHELMED' AS EX-HOSTAGES BY THE PUBLIC
description: Sgt. Rodney V. Sickmann is in good health, but he and the other former hostages have a lot to get used to, according to his father.

title: Joseph G. Martin, Won a Pulitzer In '59 for International Reporting
description: Joseph G. Martin, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter for The Daily News, died yesterday at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass.

title: Some Accept Pact At Canada Chrysler
description: Office and clerical workers at Chrysler Canada Ltd. voted to accept a revised contract, a spokesman for the United Automobile Workers union said.

title: 3 WEST BANK SETTLEMENT ENORSED IN ISRAEL
description: The Parliament's Foreign Affairs and Security Committee today approved an Israeli Cabinet decision to establish three additional Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank.

title: OAKLAND, A 'CITY OF CHAMPIONS,' FIGHTS CIVIC INFERIORITY COMPLEX
description: The story is told that Gertrude Stein, who spent her girlhood in Oakland, once said that the problem with Oakland was, ''When you get there, there isn't any THERE there.''

title: Islander Win Streak Snapped by Sabres
description: With the emotion of his scoring 50 goals in 50 games having subsided, Mike Bossy went out tonight and scored his 51st within 16 seconds of the opening whistle. But the Islanders succumbed to their pressure-packed week and dropped a 5-3 game to the Buffalo Sabres at Nassau Coliseum.

title: '80 Union Raises Averaged 9.5%
description: Workers covered by major union contracts in private business won average first-year pay rises of 9.5 percent in 1980, the largest gain since 1975, the Government reported today.

title: TIME OFF FOR CHILD CARE: PROGRAMS VARY
description: Nancy Jones wanted it both ways. ''I love corporate America,'' she said, ''but I love my family, too.'' When Mrs. Jones became pregnant in 1974, she wanted more than the usual six-to-eight-week disability leave given to women recuperating from childbirth. So Manufacturers Hanover Trust, her employer for the previous 10 years, gave her five months off and promised that she would get her job back when she returned.

title: SUBWAY RIDERS FRAZZLED BY DELAYS AND CROWDING
description: Angry and frustrated, apprehensive and sometimes frightened, many people who take New York City's subways to work and back are finding that getting there exacts a toll far in excess of the 60-cent fare.

title: I.B.M. PAYING GREYHOUND $17.7 MILLION TO END SUIT
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and the Greyhound Computer Corporation, acting on the day a retrial was to begin in Phoenix, have settled their 11-year-old antitrust case, the companies announced yesterday.

title: Former Executive Sues Bache Halsey
description: A former executive at Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, Inc. filed a lawsuit yesterday against the company, charging it with falsifying records involving sales of silver once owned by the Hunt brothers of Dallas. Irving J. Louis Jr., the executive, said the alleged misstatements allowed the Bache Group to overstate its income by $2.3 million, or 25.8 percent of its profits for the quarter ended April 30.

title: Indonesian Ship Catches Fire
description: An Indonesian passenger ship, the Tampomas-2, caught fire today 700 miles northeast of Jakarta, stranding 900 people on board. Television Republic Indonesia said that some of the 1,056 passengers had jumped into the sea and that 149 people had been rescued by a passing vessel.

title: Richard Newmark, 70; Won Medal of Science
description: Dr. Richard M. Newmark, professor emeritus of civil engineering at the University of Illinois and a consultant on the design of earthquake-resistance structures, died Sunday at Carle Hospital in Urbana, Ill. He was 70 years old and lived in Urbana.

title: Raiders' Line Play Strategy A Key to Triumph
description: Stopwatch clockings taken in the press box at yesterday's Super Bowl game here showed that Jim Plunkett, the Oakland Raiders' quarterback, had from 3.2 to 3.7 seconds to analyze the Philadelphia defense, choose a receiver and launch his passes. Ron Jaworski, the Eagle quarterback, was throwing his passes much more quickly, within 1.7 to 2.7 seconds after the snap of the ball.

title: 885 TAKE POLICE OATH AS 94 DECIDE AGAINST JOB
description: The New York City Police Department swore in 885 recruits yesterday. Ninety-four others who had been candidates declined appointment, mostly, they said, because of new thoughts they or their families had about the dangers of the job. Four policemen were shot this month and all of those who turned down appointments were asked this month whether they wanted to be police officers.

title: Index; International
description: Iraqis say Iranian Kurds harass Iranian troops A3 Polish students' sit-in is spreading A4 Around the World A5 Malaysia futilely fights the flow of illegal Indonesian immigrants A9 Iranian Prime Minister defends accord on release of hostages B10 Government/Politics Minority groups welcome wider eligibility for charity funds A12 Supreme Court Roundup A14 Reporter's Notebook: For Rea- gan, East is East A16 Analysis of costs may complicate Westway negotiations B2 Albany Assembly votes tax cuts for small business B2 Many members of minorities in- cluded as 885 join police force B3 Black-Hispanic coalition seeks two borough presidencies B4 Energy Jersey utility to truck damaged nuclear fuel rods to Ohio B3 General Around the Nation A12 Oakland, the ''city of champions,'' has number of problems A12 Reaction of public a pleasant sur- prise for freed hostages B8 'Ticker tape' parade planned Friday for hostages B8 Sickman family as 'overwhelmed' as the hostages B9 Iranian captors used the U.S. role in Vietnam to taunt hostages B9 Clergymen who visited hostages surprised by mistreatment B10 New York doctor sues magazine over article on Shah's care B10 Religion Christian Evangelicals debate their proper political role A12 Obituaries H. I. Feldman, architect who de- signed 2,500 apartment houses B19 Science Times A Voyage in Space - with the Shuttle Simulator C1 A Poll Reports Addiction of Half the Respondents C1 Education: Jesse Jackson's Ef- fort to Produce Motivation C1 Scientists on Television: Not a Good Image C2 Science Watch C2 Finding Ancient Man With a Magnetometer C3 Science Q&A C3 About Education C4 Arts/Entertainment Robert Kovich puts his choreogra- phy on display C6 ''Van Gogh and the Birth of Cloiso- nism'' opens in Toronto C7 Symposium on new music at Y raises some hackles C7 Faye Levine's novel ''Solomon & Sheba'' is reviewed C9 Robert Manning to edit 14-volume series on Vietnam War C9 ''The Bunker,'' about Hitler's last days, on CBS-TV tonight C19 ''Victory Over the Sun'' ''opera'' is staged in Washington C20 ''Waiting for the Parade,'' Cana- dian play at the Hudson Guild C20 Jimmy Carter names Marvin Jo- sephson his literary agent C20 Style A new emphasis on grandeur livens Paris couture opening B13 Fashion Notes B13 Sports Suns beat Knicks, 99-94 B15 Sabres down Islanders, 5-3 B15 Raider coach hints at opposition to moving team B15 2,000 football fans in London see a super premiere B15 Raiders' line play was decisive factor in domination of Eagles B16 Dave Anderson on Raiders' un- likely season B16 Yanks and Winfield agree on new contract terms B17 Nehemiah polishes his form and looks to new record B18 B4 Bennie Briscoe: The boxer who won't quit B18 Attorneys disagree on punch as Kush trial opens B18 Features/Notes Notes on People B7 Going Out Guide C6 News Analysis John Darnton on Poland's battle over a five-day workweek A4 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials A18

title: No Headline
description: POLLS FINDS BACKING FOR IRANIAN PACT

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: If you thought you'd heard the name ''Gloria Vanderbilt'' enough to last you a lifetime, prepare yourself. You're apparently going to be hearing it more.

title: STUDY MAY COMPLICATE WESTWAY TALKS
description: f814 By ARI L. GOLDMAN

title: FOR JACKSON, FAILURES AND SOME SUCCESS
description: CHICAGO FIVE years after he created his ''push for excellence'' program, the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson is still seeking the right formula to transform his personal charisma into a practical program to increase the academic performance of disadvantaged high school students.

title: MESSAGE FROM IRAN: AUG. 13, '79
description: Following are excerpts from a confidential cable sent Aug. 13, 1979, to Cyrus R. Vance, then the Secretary of State, and signed by L. Bruce Laingen, charge d'affaires at the United States Embassy in Teheran, which was seized by militants on Nov. 4, 1979. Mr. Laingen, the top American diplomat in Teheran after the exile of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, was at the Foreign Ministry when the embassy was overrun, and remained there until after last Christmas. The cable was made available to The New York Times on Jan. 26, 1980, by Dale Van Atta, a reporter with the syndicated columnist Jack Anderson, and was held by The Times for publication until the 52 hostages were freed.

title: BACK TO SCOOPERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Crystal Withdraws Issue
description: The Crystal Oil Company said today that it would withdraw its previously announced $35 million Eurodollar convertible debenture offering as a result of developments in the Arkana field in Louisiana. Because of the difficulty of evaluating the significance of an apparent field extension, Crystal Oil said it had decided to forgo the sale of convertible securities.

title: TIME NOW FOR THE DEFERRED U.S. DEBATE ON IRAN
description: To the Editor:

title: AS SHUTTLE SIMULATOR ROARS, ITS PERILS ARE ALMOST REAL
description: HOUSTON ANYONE with the right stuff, to borrow Tom Wolfe's apt expression, would ease into the cockpit, stroke the stick knowingly, and jauntily say something like, ''This'll be a piece of cake.''

title: MARKET POSTS 6TH STRAIGHT LOSS
description: The stock market registered its sixth consecutive decline yesterday in continued slow trading, with the precious metal issues posting the largest losses.

title: ART: 'VAN GOGH AND THE BIRTH OF CLOISONISM'
description: Few artists of the modern era have won a posthumous fame equal to that of the Dutch painter Vincent van Gogh (1853-90). His short, stormy career, ending in episodes of madness, have long been exploited by purveyors of popular entertainment. Certain of his paintings have acquired the status of visual cliches, instantly recognizable even to people who never set foot in an art museum. But fame of this sort is never an unalloyed blessing. By dwelling on, and even embellishing, the ordeals of the artist's life, it diverts attention from the grave artistic labor that formed the central focus of his existence. It buries the art under the debris of a sentimental myth.

title: WHAT THIS COUNTRY NEEDS IS A COLLEGE FOR MACHINISTS
description: To the Editor:

title: IRANIAN LEADERS CONTINUE BATTLE OVER HOSTAGE ACCORD
description: Prime Minister Mohammed Ali Rajai rose in Parliament today to defend the Iranian-American accord on releasing the hostages. President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr and other Iranians have criticized the agreement.

title: LEARNER'S LAMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: '80 DIP CALLED OF LITTLE HELP TO CONSUMERS
description: Prices are falling! Prices are falling! Cocoa beans are 33 percent less costly than a year ago. Choice Omaha steers are bringing 8 percent less. Cow hides are down 27 percent. Copper scrap is off 17 percent from a year ago. Lead scrap is off 31 percent. And burlap is down by 35 percent.

title: Doctors Approve Artificial Heart for Use in Human
description: An artificial heart that is the product of more than 20 years' research received approval today from the University of Utah's College of Medicine for its first use in a human.

title: TWO PATRIOTS
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: BIRGIT NILSSON SINGS ELEKTRA IN MET'S STAGING
description: TONIGHT'S ''Live From the Met,'' beginning at 8 o'clock on WNET-TV, was taped nearly a year ago at a matinee on Feb. 16. The viewer will be getting a ''live on tape'' recording of what is described as ''a historic performance.'' Semantics aside, the occasion was special primarily for one reason - Birgit Nilsson was returning to the Metropolitan Opera after an absence of nearly five years.

title: STATE TASK FORCE SEEKS NEW LAWS FOR FIRE SAFETY
description: The Governor's Special Fire Safety Task Force will immediately seek legislation that would require operators of public facilities to read an announcement pointing out exits and emergency procedures at all public gatherings of more than 20 persons.

title: MOSLEMS URGE SOVIET TO LEAVE AFGHANISTAN
description: The meeting here of Islamic leaders tonight approved a resolution based on a strongly worded draft that called for immediate withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan.

title: EXXON NET FELL 1.1% IN 4TH QUARTER
description: The Exxon Corporation reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings dropped 1.1 percent from the comparable period a year earlier, but said profits for all of last year surged 31.8 percent, to a record $5.66 billion.

title: Richard M. Bozorth, a Specialist In Magnetic Material and Crystals
description: Dr. Richard M. Bozorth, a research physicist who had been with Bell Laboratories for many years, died Saturday at his home in Short Hills, N.J. He was 84 years old.

title: Strength, Weakness and Patience
description: There were chants at the beginning: the zealots screaming ''Margh bar Carter, death to Carter'' on the streets of Teheran. Yesterday, as the hostages landed in Washington, there was an answering chant at the end: ''Wel-come home, wel-come home.'' And then they heard President Reagan express sentiments that have become another kind of chant: ''Let terrorists be aware that when the rules of international behavior are violated, our policy will be one of swift and effective retribution. We hear it said that we live in an era of limits to our power. Well, let it also be understood there are limits to our patience.''

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard A QUEST OF LOVE. By Jacquetta Hawkes. 220 pages. George Braziller. $10.95.

title: SIR ANDREW SHONFIELD, WRITER ON ECONOMICS, DIES IN LONDON AT 63
description: Sir Andrew Shonfield, the British economist, writer and editor, died on Friday in London, his friends have reported. He was 63 years old and had homes in London and Florence, where he was a professor of economics at the European University Institute.

title: PREPPIE SWEATERS AND A PARTY PLACE
description: 1. Fresh Handbag Ideas

title: CHAMBER CONCERT TO BE ON PBS
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will be presented on the 'Live from Lincoln Center' series next Monday at 8P.M. over the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: No Headline
description: BANI-SADAR, IN POWER FIGHT,CHARGES PLOT TO KILL HIM

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Scottish Inns of America filed 12.5 million shares of common with the Securities and Exchange Commission, to be offered through a group led by John Muir & Company.

title: Creative Promotions At Ted Bates
description: With the new promotions in Ted Bates & Company's creative high command, you really do need a score card. William Maynard Jr., 51, has been given a newly created title, managing director/creative services.

title: THE CAPITAL SHOUTS OUT A WELCOME
description: The battered American mission from Iran finally made it back to home base today, moving slowly by bus caravan through a gray canyon of cheering bureaucrats to a heroic welcome at the White House.

title: Macrolack
description: Ronald Reagan's boldest move so far to deal with the troubled economy has been to take no professional economist into his Cabinet. There are successful businessmen, of course, but only one person with the credentials of an economist.

title: Changes in Phone Rates Take Effect in New York
description: New telephone rates take effect today in New York State. A change in billing for local calls will increase the cost of longer conversations, but reduce it for some shorter ones.

title: SPERRY CLIMBS BY 16%; INGERSOLL-RAND UP 33.6%
description: The Sperry Corporation, a leading factor in the electronic dataprocessing industry, reported yesterday that earnings in the third fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31 increased 16.7 percent on an increase in revenues of 12.6 percent.

title: 9 P.M. Curfew Is Ordered For Children in Atlanta
description: Mayor Maynard Jackson today imposed a 9 P.M. curfew on Atlanta children up to 15 years old in the hope of preventing further deaths and disappearances. Fourteen black children 15 and under have been slain since July 1979 and three have vanished.

title: '81 WHEAT SUPPLY IS UP, BUT FEED STORAGE IS LOW
description: American farmers are expected to have in storage at least a year's domestic supply of wheat when the 1981 harvest begins in June, the Agriculture Department reported today. But it said carry-over stocks of feed grains would be the lowest since 1976.

title: Procter & Gamble Earnings Up 8.4%
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, a major manufacturer of packaged goods and household products, said today that earnings for the second quarter of its fiscal year rose 8.4 percent despite foreign exchange losses and a higher effective tax rate than in the same period a year earlier.

title: RATE RISE SKEWS BANK PROFITS
description: The sharp and largely unexpected rise in interest rates in last year's fourth quarter played havoc with bank earnings, causing a surge in profits at some institutions and dramatic declines at others.

title: How Hostage Pact Was Forged: Turning Point in September
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Iran appeared so eager to resolve the hostage crisis last September that it alerted Washington ahead of time to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's statement outlining for the first time Iran's four conditions for releasing the hostages.

title: MADRID SESSION ON EAST-WEST TIES RESUMES WITH NEW U.S.-SOVIET RANCOR
description: After a five-week holiday break, the conference on human rights and East-West cooperation in Europe resumed today in an acrimonious mood, with the United States accusing the Soviet Union of fresh rights violations and the Russians raising the possibility of scuttling the 1975 Helsinki accords, under review here, if this conference is not followed by one on disarmament.

title: BLUES GUITAR: OTIS RUSH
description: THERE has been renewed interest in the Chicago blues guitarist and singer Otis Rush lately because of the reissue of some recordings he made for the Cobra label in the late 1950's. His subsequent recordings have rarely captured him at his best, but he has continued to refine his talents, especially his extraordinary guitar playing.

title: The Ribbon Untied ... and Enough
description: What a peculiar symbol those yellow ribbons are. The inspiration for them was ''Tie a Yellow Ribbon Round the Ole Oak Tree,'' a popular song a few years ago. It told of a released convict who wrote his wife that if he saw no ribbon from the bus carrying him from prison, he'd simply keep going and start a new life.

title: BLONDIE RIDING HIGH
description: Manhattan punk circuit in the mid-1970's, is riding high. The country's number one single is Blondie's ''The Tide Is High,'' and their latest album, ''Autoamerican'' (Chrysalis) is in the top 10.

title: State Camp for Boys Told to Open to Girls
description: SYRACUSE (AP) - A 12-year-old girl has won her case against a state-operated summer camp for boys. Justice John Conway of State Supreme Court told the state to open its Rushford Environmental Education Camp for Boys in Allegany County to girls no later than 1982. The ruling was the result of a complaint made in a suit by a Syracuse girl, Lorca Sheppard.

title: Welch Pleads Not Guilty In Halberstam Shooting
description: Bernard C. Welch pleaded not guilty today to an 11-count indictment stemming from the fatal shooting of Dr. Michael Halberstam, the Washington cardiologist. Mr. Welch's lawyer, Sol Z. Rosen, entered the plea in Superior Court before Chief Judge Carl H. Moultrie.

title: Leader of Iran Militants Gained Political Power
description: A Moslem clergyman, Mousavi Khoeiny, singled out by a former American hostage today as a leader of the Iranian militants who took over the American Embassy in Teheran, rose to political prominence soon afterward.

title: GUNS AS PROPS IN OUR SCENARIOS OF VIOLENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 242147 -- No Title
description: The development concern that announced its intention last fall to build a residential and commercial complex on the site of the abandoned Penn Central Rail Yards on the West Side has outlined details of the proposal for 250 neighborhood residents.

title: 500 ARE MISSING, 620 SAFE AS SHIP SINKS IN JAVA SEA
description: An Indonesian passenger ship caught fire in a storm and sank in the Java Sea yesterday, and Indonesian officials said early today that more than 500 people were missing.

title: Borden's Profits Up 15.6%
description: Borden Inc. reported yesterday that fourth-quarter profits increased by 15.7 percent, to $33.9 million from $29.3 million in the same period a year ago.

title: GIFTS FOR NEEDIEST HONOR 2
description: The memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the civil rights leader who was assassinated on April 4, 1968, was honored with a donation of $500 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund from Nancy B. Lewis of Summit, N.J.

title: UNIO LOSES IN VOTE AT FACTORY IN SOUTH
description: Employees at the nation's largest nonunion General Motors Corporation plant today rejected a bid to be represented by the United Automobile Workers. The union's defeat, the third at the plant in seven months, dealt a blow to organized labor's efforts to broaden its appeal in rural, conservative Southern communities. The unofficial vote was 721 against representation to 659 for the union.

title: Cuba Diplomat Attends White House Reception
description: A Cuban Government representative attended President and Mrs. Reagan's first diplomatic reception tonight, but a top Reagan adviser insisted it had ''no special significance.''

title: Ward Head Puts Stress On Strategic Planning
description: Stephen L. Pistner, who was named president and chief operating officer of Montgomery Ward & Company on Monday, is an advocate of corporate strategic planning. His method, he said in a telephone interview from Chicago yesterday, consists of studying a company and its employees, conducting intensive demographic research, and then capitalizing on those two in ''heavy strategic planning sessions.''

title: CONFLICTS IN MENTAL REPORTS RAISE QUESTIONS ON CAPTIVES
description: Incomplete and contradictory reports about the condition of the 52 former hostages, issued since they were freed last week, have created confusion over the state of their mental health.

title: ROCK STAR WHO DISSECTS HUMAN RELATIONSHIPS
description: ELVIS COSTELLO has never tried to pass himself off as a nice fellow. He's a scrawny, bespectacled former computer programmer from England with a nasal voice some people take an immediate dislike to, and if there's a single image or theme that ties his work together, it's his vision of individual sexual relationships as fascist societies in miniature. He hasn't visited the United States in two years, despite the top 20 success of his ''Get Happy!!'' album early in 1980, and since he doesn't give interviews or even issue press handouts, it's difficult to tell whether he's had better things to do or simply doesn't like it here.

title: Nuggets 143, Pistons 123
description: The Nuggets, with four players scoring in double figures in the first half, ran up an 80-62 lead and coasted to victory over Detroit. Dan Issel of Denver (19-32) led all scorers with 29 points, David Thompson had 26, and Kiki Vandeweghe, the rookie, 22. The Pistons (13-41) got 24 points from Phil Hubbard.

title: Saints Hire Peppler
description: Pat Peppler, 58-year-old former assistant general manager for the Houston Oilers, was hired today as an administrative assistant for the New Orleans Saints.

title: News of the Theater; Renee Taylor and Joseph Bologna's 'Show'
description: THE new Renee Taylor-Joseph Bologna ''show'' is going to open the first week in May at the Golden Theater. Miss Taylor and Mr. Bologna, the husband-and-wife team best known as the authors and stars of ''Lovers and Other Strangers,'' which played on Broadway in 1968, are calling their new comedy simply a ''show'' because it has no title at the moment. The play was known as ''Blau and Pignoli'' when it had a workshop production at the Perry Street Theater in Greenwich Village in November, but new titles are being discussed.

title: BINNEY & SMITH SEES A NEED TO DIVERSIFY
description: Faced with a virtually stagnant market and rising costs for raw materials, Binney & Smith Inc., the 116-year-old maker of Crayola crayons, must diversify to grow.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TWANG TWANG, TAP TAP

title: INDUSTRY MUST CURB ITS BORROWING
description: To the Editor:

title: British Government Backs Sale of Times to Murdoch
description: The British Government gave its approval today to Rupert Murdoch, the Australian-born publisher of The New York Post, to buy The Times of London and its sister newspaper, The Sunday Times.

title: TOP OFFICIALS CLASH ON TAX CUT TIMING
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and senior economic officials of the Reagan Administration disagreed today over whether tax cuts should come before or after reductions are made in Federal spending.

title: Bernstein Is Big Box Office
description: Although Leonard Bernstein is now laureate conductor of the New York Philharmonic and hasn't appeared with it since June 1979, his name still hath charms, apparently, with Philharmonic fans.

title: FOOD COSTS ROSE BY 8 PERCENT IN 1980
description: IN 1980, the food bill of the typical family of four in New York City increased by more than 8 percent over 1979, according to the Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Tokyo String Quartet To Play a Premiere Feb. 23
description: The Tokyo String Quartet will give the world premiere of the String Quartet No. 1 by the Japanese composer Toru Takemitsu on Feb. 23 at 8 P.M. in Carnegie Hall.

title: The Four Seasons Reply
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I am devastated by the furor following my remark in The Times' Jan. 7 article (''A Problem in the Cloakroom: Finding Space for Down Coats'') in which I gave the impression that The Four Seasons is not concerned about the bulkiness of down coats because they are worn largely by secretaries. This unpardonable gaffe came as a flip afterthought during a hurried telephone conversation with your reporter at the peak of our busy and extremely hectic lunch hour. It is wholly inaccurate, and I am mortified at the ill feeling it may have caused, particularly among the many secretaries who do frequent The Four Seasons.

title: Advertising; A Growing Role for Consultants
description: ARE there more consultants in the advertising business these days? Harry Paster, executive vice president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, thinks so. He is sure he has more of their names on file than ever before.

title: JEAN HARRIS AS A WITNESS: SAD, HUMOROUS, CUTTING
description: This morning, on the 50th day of Jean S. Harris's trial for the murder of Dr. Herman Tarnower, an assistant defense attorney turned in his chair, looked at Mrs. Harris's younger son, who was sitting in the first row in his Marine Corps uniform, and crooked a finger toward the door.

title: Fordham Sets Back Columbia by 61-53
description: There was nothing artistic about Fordham's 61-53 triumph over Columbia last night at Levien Gymnasium. But there was something significant about it because it was the Rams' 12th victory of the season - Fordham had not won that many games in a season since 1974-75.

title: Blue Jays Sign Mayberry To Four-Year Contract
description: The Toronto Blue Jays signed John Mayberry yesterday to a fouryear, multimillion-dollar contract that could make him the highest paid athlete in Canada on an annual basis.

title: THE FIRST LADY'S HIGH FASHION IS TOO HIGH
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REMARKS BY PRESIDENT AND LAINGEN AT WHITE HOUSE
description: Following is a transcript of remarks yesterday by President Reagan and L. Bruce Laingen, former charge d'affaires at the United States Embassy in Teheran, at ceremonies at the White House, as recorded by The New York Times: Remarks by Reagan

title: CONSTANCE APPLEBEE
description: Constance Mary Katherine Applebee, who introduced the game of field hockey in the United States, died Monday at a nursing home in New Milton, Hampshire, England.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The professor enters Room 1512 where 20 seminar students enrolled in Public Affairs U9000y are seated. He goes to the head of the class, tidies his papers, takes a seat and says: ''I'm Javits, your Senator from New York for many years. Since I'm so contemporary, it's probably desirable to tap my experience.''

title: MERCK, CELANESE RISE; OLIN HAS LOSS IN QUARTER
description: Merck & Company, one of the world's leading ethical drug manufacturers and a leading chemicals producer, yesterday reported that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980 increased 15.8 percent on an increase in sales of 12.9 percent.

title: HOUSE VOTE SHOWS HOW POWER IS USED
description: In recent weeks the Speaker of the House, Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts, has been urging members of the Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee to support Representative Henry B. Gonzalez of Texas for the chairmanship of the panel's Subcommittee on Housing and Community Development.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES FALL SLIGHTLY
description: Short-term interest rates declined slightly yesterday, but that was not enough to help the long-term bond market, where yields rose slightly as underwriters concentrated on selling several new issues.

title: Cleaning House
description: The last Congress took less than a month to expel Representative Michael Myers after a jury found him guilty of selling his office for $50,000. Now another Philadelphia Congressman, Raymond Lederer, stands convicted of taking a similar Abscam bribe.

title: DeLorean Seeking More British Funds
description: The DeLorean Motor Company, already granted $161 million in British Government money to produce luxury sports cars in Northern Ireland, is urgently requesting another $2.3 million loan, the provincial commerce department said.

title: EVANGELICAL LEADERS HAIL ELECTION AND ASK CONTINUATION OF EFFORTS
description: Conservative religious leaders who headed a recent evangelical political campaign today cheered the sizable gains by conservatives in the November elections and exhorted their followers to continue the fight for moral values.

title: BRITAIN NOW HAS SOME 200 WINERIES, MOST OF THEM NEW; by Terry Robards; NEWENT, England
description: ALAN McKECHNIE and his colleagues are waging war against nature here in the vineyards of Gloucestershire, trying to demonstrate that good wines can be produced in the capricious climate of the west country of England. Driven partly by patriotism and partly by economics, they are making wines that are suddenly gaining popularity all over the British Isles. ''The tourists and everyone else treated English wine as a joke,'' Mr. McKechnie said, ''but now it's in demand.''

title: Ball President Adds Chief Executive Post
description: Richard M. Ringoen, the 54-year-old president of the Ball Corporation, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer. He succeeds John W. Fisher, 65, who continues as chairman of the Muncie, Ind., concern.

title: Low-Power TV Filing by ABC
description: The American Broadcasting Companies Inc. today became the first major television network to file applications for a series of so-called low-power television stations.

title: Colombian Guerrillas Repeat Threat to Execute Hostage
description: Guerrillas today repeated their threat to execute an American they are holding unless his employer, the Summer Institute of Linguistics, leaves the country by Feb. 19 and newspapers, including the The New York Times and The Washington Post, publish the group's manifesto.

title: Canada Dry Account
description: Only one of Canada Dry's 160 bottlers is company-owned - Canada Dry New England. And which bottler has decided to take its advertising out of Grey Advertising, which has the national account? Canada Dry New England, of course. It is giving its business - billing about $1 million - to Haughey Advertising in Boston, which has a lot of retail experience in that market and now has $6 million in billings.

title: Duke Thwarts Rutgers Rally to Win, 53-51
description: Duke, led by Gene Banks's 18 points, held off a late Rutgers rally to score a 53-51 victory tonight before a crowd of 8,373 in the Rutgers Athletic Center.

title: Oil Decontrol Set Today
description: The Reagan Administration, which had planned to remove the remaining controls on crude oil and refined products today, deferred its action until tomorrow because of preoccupation with its reception for the returned American hostages, according to a White House spokesman.

title: MOYNIHAN ATTACKS CARTER YEARS AT U.N.
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has charged that United States policy at the United Nations was a ''total and squalid failure'' that helped destroy President Carter and that hurt nations backing the United States in the Middle East.

title: Careers; Assessing Politics Overseas
description: CORPORATE listening posts abroad are in vogue and becoming ever more important, the result largely of crises in Iran, El Salvador and Nicaragua.

title: Western Airlines Spurns UNC Offer
description: Western Airlines, which reported a $29.6 million loss in 1980, says its directors have spurned a proposed takeover by UNC Resources Inc. and agreed to merge with Continental Air Lines.

title: 3 Islanders on AllStar Team
description: MONTREAL (AP) - Three members of the Islanders - Denis Potvin, a defenseman, Bryan Trottier, a center, and the high-scoring right wing Mike Bossy - head the first contingent selected to play for the Campbell Conference in the National Hockey League All-Star Game.

title: MURDER TRIAL WITNESS TELLS OF BLACKS' ATTACKS ON CAR IN MIAMI RIOT
description: Two of four blacks on trial for allegedly beating three whites to death in racial riots here last May were placed at the scene of the crime today by a key state witness.

title: Carter Praises Reagan For Stand on Hostages
description: Former President Jimmy Carter praised President Reagan today for his stiff warning to terrorists who might try to take Americans hostage.

title: FOR THE NATION, A RISK OF 'MORAL AMNESIA'
description: In responding to Iran's kidnapping and mistreatment of the 52 Americans, this nation is in danger of developing a severe case of moral amnesia that could well have fateful political consequences.

title: Truth in Advertising
description: The idea was to take a photograph of Governor Carey and the state's four legislative leaders, standing shoulder to shoulder, for an advertisement extolling New York State's business climate.

title: 2 Queens Lines Buy 60 Buses From G.M.
description: Operators of two privately owned bus lines in Queens announced yesterday that they had signed an agreement with the General Motors Corporation to purchase 60 new passenger buses of the model RTS-04. The companies, Queens Transit and Steinway Transit, serving northern Queens, will pay $8 million for the vehicles, which they are to receive in July.

title: Whitney Buys Coal Book
description: Whitney Communications, which has owned The Oil Daily for three years, has purchased Coal Industry News, a twice-monthly trade tabloid with a controlled circulation of 11,000. DeVan L.
