Shumway, editor and publisher of the oil publication, will also be publisher of the coal sheet, while its former publisher, Owen Kean, will be associate publisher. Would wood sell?

title: Woman Gets $3,250 On Sex Harassment
description: A researcher who lost her job after she refused to spend the night with her supervisor has won $3,250 from Polytechnic Institute of New York, the city's Commission on Human Rights announced.

title: MARCOS'S LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: Smith Won't Get Back Job As Astro General Manager
description: Tal Smith, dismissed as the Houston Astros' general manager last October, said today that he had been told by the minority owners that he would not be rehired.

title: F.B.I. SAYS IT CAN'T CONFIRM ALLEGATIONS ON DONOVAN
description: Officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation told the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee today that an ''exhaustive'' investigation had not corroborated allegations by underworld informers about purported illegal and improper activities by Raymond J. Donovan, President Reagan's nominee for Secretary of Labor.

title: MRS. HARRIS, ON THE WITNESS STAND, TELLS OF ROMANCE WITH TARNOWER
description: A pale and drawn Jean S. Harris took the stand today, describing to a jury in Westchester County Court the love she said she felt for Dr. Herman Tarnower, whom she is accused of murdering, and recounting how her personal life began to unravel in the year before the shooting.

title: State Power Agency May Revise Its Rates
description: As an energy conservation measure, the Power Authority of the State of New York said it was considering a revision in rate structures for the 47 municipal systems and rural cooperatives to which it sells electricity.

title: Kean in Jersey Race
description: TRENTON (AP) - Thomas H. Kean, a former Assembly Speaker, used a taped five-minute television commercial to announce formally his candidacy for the Republican gubernatorial nomination. The tape was to be shown on a station in New York and one in Philadelphia. Mayor Lawrence F. Kramer of Paterson is expected to make a similar announcement today of his candidacy for the nomination.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 28, 1981
description: International Indonesia's worst ship disaster was reported by officials who said that more than 500 people were missing after a passenger vessel caught fire in a storm and sank. The officials said that more than 500 people had been saved, but that rescue efforts were hampered by heavy seas and rain. (Page A1, Col. 1.) Strikes erupted throughout Poland amid signs that the leadership of the independent labor movement no longer controlled local union chapters. The most serious stoppage occurred at Bielsko-Biala, near the Czechoslovak border, where a general strike affecting 110 factories was called to force the ouster of local officials. (A1:2.)

title: Paper Makers Fined on Prices
description: A Federal judge today levied fines of $3 million on four companies in Wisconsin, New Jersey and Massachusetts on charges of fixing prices on specialty paper products between 1973 and 1976. Prison sentences or fines were set for five of the corporations' executives.

title: Celtics, 76ers Gird For Game of Power
description: The Boston Celtics' closed-door practice session yesterday at Hellenic College in Brookline, Mass., was loose, according to Coach Bill Fitch.

title: YOUNG CHEFS: A BIG-CITY SUCCESS STORY
description: CUSTOMERS invited into the kitchen after dinner at the Palace, Manhattan's most expensive luxury restaurant, are often astonished when they meet the chef. Instead of shaking hands with the sort of hulking fellow in his mid-40's that graces the jackets of popular cookbooks, they find a slender young man in a large toque blanche that perches just over his ears.

title: DURABLES ORDERS UP LAST MONTH
description: New orders for durable goods manufactured in the United States increased 1.9 percent last month, buoyed by an upswing in orders for military goods, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: REAGAN VOWS 'SWIFT RETRIBUTION' FOR ANY NEW ATTACK ON DIPLOMATS
description: In an emotion-charged ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House, President Reagan today welcomed home the 52 Americans formerly held hostage in Iran and promised ''swift and effective retribution'' for attacks on American Government employees in foreign lands.

title: Canadian Energy Talks
description: Talks will open tomorrow in Edmonton, Alberta's capital, between permanent officials of the respective energy departments of Alberta and the Canadian federal Government in the first major attempt in months to reach agreement on pricing and revenue sharing for oil and gas. The two sides not only disagree on policy but also cannot arrive at a common set of figures that would provide a basis for negotiation.

title:
RED SMITH;
Death of a Riverkeeper
description: THE best part of Super Bowl XV was that the flight to New Orleans and back allowed time to read Ernie Schwiebert's ''Death of a Riverkeeper,'' which is infinitely more enjoyable than the game was. Ernie Schwiebert, best known perhaps for his fly-fishing bible, ''Matching the Hatch,'' is author of the monumental and indispensable two-volume work ''Trout.''

title: SCHLESINGER ELECTED HEAD OF ARTS AND LETTERS GROUP
description: Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., historian and professor, was elected president yesterday of the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, the 250-member national society of men and women who form a pantheon of literature, music and the fine arts.

title: TO QUICKEN A BUS RIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 242155 -- No Title
description: A civil suit was filed yesterday seeking $260 million in damages from engineers, contractors and politicians involved in the construction of the nearly completed $1 billion Southwest Sewer District project in Suffolk County.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ALTHOUGH I have always taken a great deal of pleasure in foraging for food - hunting wild deer and pheasant and quail in season, fishing for trout and bass and tending my own garden - I have never had a great interest in hunting for wild mushrooms.

title: WRONG WATER FOR FIGHTING FIRES
description: To the Editor:

title: VIEWS AND REVIEWS OF A LOS ANGELES CHEF
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Colman Andrews is a freelance writer living on the West Coast. By COLMAN ANDREWS LOS ANGELES TWO sous-chefs chop and stir, pivot and scurry. Fish poaches in white wine, mushrooms sizzle in sweet butter, duck breasts are broiling. The kitchen is bus@tling at La Toque in Los Angeles -the youngest of that city's new ''California French'' restaurants.

title: THE SCREEN: 'LONG SHOT'
description: ''Long Shot'' was shown in last year's ''British Film Now'' series at the Paramount Theater. Following are excerpts from the review by Janet Maslin published in The New York Times on Sept. 22. The film is playing at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: HOW HOSTAGE PACT WAS FORGED: TURNING POINT WAS IN SEPTEMBER
description: Iran appeared so eager to resolve the hostage crisis last September that it alerted Washington ahead of time to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's statement outlining for the first time Iran's four conditions for releasing the hostages.

title: RAIDERS CHEERED IN PARADE
description: The Oakland Raiders, the new Super Bowl champions, were cheered today in a rainy parade through the streets of this city, which is fighting to keep them from moving to Los Angeles.

title: No. 3 Defense Dept. Job Is Expected to Go to Ikle
description: In a move apparently designed to mollify Senate conservatives, the Reagan Administration is expected to appoint Fred C. Ikle, who was director of the Arms Controls and Disarmament Agency under President Ford, to the post of Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, Administration officials said yesterday.

title: Budget $7.3 Billion In Red Last Month
description: The Government registered a $7.3 billion deficit last month, pushing the shortfall for the first quarter of the fiscal year 1981 past the total that had been estimated for the entire year, the Treasury Department reported today.

title: U.S. FILES FOR DELAY OF COURT CASES ABOUT IRAN PENDING REAGAN STUDY
description: The Justice Department today began filing papers in at least 388 court cases asking judges to delay proceedings over Iranian assets and private claims against Iran for 30 days to allow the Reagan Administration time to complete its review of President Carter's hostage agreement, a spokesman said today.

title: Colonel 'Shed a Tear'1.3- On Trip to West Point
description: Col. Leland J. Holland said today that he ''shed a tear'' when he saw 17 miles of well-wishers on his way from Stewart International Airport to the United States Military Academy after he and the other former hostages arrived Sunday.

title: BY ANGEL CASTILLO
description: Surrogate motherhood performed for a fee, which some of its advocates contend is legal in only one state, Kentucky, is illegal there also, Kentucky's Attorney General said yesterday.

title: Judge Will Not Bar Bid on Buffalo Forge
description: A Federal judge has refused to block an attempted takeover of Buffalo Forge Company by the Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation.

title: Not So Hot
description: I wasted little time on Us magazine's gallery of ''The 50 Hottest Couples in the World'' after scanning the pictures and noting that they included President and Mrs. Reagan, Senator John Warner and his wife Elizabeth Taylor, and Senator Edward Kennedy and his wife Joan who are divorcing.

title: GROUP OPPOSED TO KOCH DRAFTS PLATFORM
description: 4 By MAURICE CARROLL

title: A NEW AGENCY IS PROPOSED IN MANHATTAN LOFT RECYCLING
description: A controversial institution known as BRAC is struggling to be born in city government, with the Planning Commission of New York City as midwife. The future of loft recycling is at stake.

title: IRAN DENIES ABBUSE OF HOSTAGES AND SAYS TORTURE WOULD BE 'A GREAT SIN'
description: The Iranian Government today ''categorically denied'' American statements that the hostages were subjected to mental and physical abuse during their 444 days of captivity in Iran.

title: Mugabe Appoints Nkomo To New Post in Cabinet
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe named Joshua Nkomo a Minister Without Portfolio today in an apparent compromise of a 17-day Government crisis.

title: MILITARY JUDGE DISMISSES 3 CHARGES IN GARWOOD TRIAL
description: A military judge today dismissed desertion charges against Pfc. Robert R. Garwood of the Marines but will let a court-martial jury decide the Government's key charge of collaboration with the enemy.

title: JOBLESS: 35%? NO.
description: It is hard to discuss the economy or America's blacks without hearing that 35 to 40 percent of young blacks are unemployed. The statistic provokes outrage and demands for crash programs. But the statistic hides more than it reveals. Worse, it masks extraordinary changes among the 2.23 million blacks between 16 and 19 years of age.

title: Sale of Gold Bonds In Europe Planned
description: A 100,000-ounce issue of gold bonds is planned for sale to investors in Europe next month, according to investment bankers at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The bonds will not be available to Americans.

title: Economic Scene; Weidenbaum's Balancing Act
description: MURRAY L. WEIDENBAUM, President Reagan's choice to head the Council of Economic Advisers, sees his role as that of a balancer, struggling to achieve a ''grand reconciliation'' between the traditional conservatives who would delay big tax cuts until inflation is brought down and the more radical supply siders who would cut taxes deeply and promptly to cure both inflation and stagnation.

title: DANGERS OF INDOOR AIR POLLUTION
description: THE air you breathe in your home or office may be hazardous to your health - more dangerous, in fact, than the outdoor air in the most polluted of cities. This is especially so during the cold months, when windows and doors are kept tightly shut and homes, schools and office buildings are made as airtight as possible to conserve energy.

title: MERRILL LYNCH, HUTTON IMPROVE
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, parent corporation for the nation's biggest stockbroker, Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, reported yesterday that it had record earnings for the fourth quarter and all of 1980.

title: Walton Seeking $5 Million In Suit Over Broken Foot
description: Bill Walton, the National Basketball Association's most valuable player in 1977, is seeking more than $5 million in damages in a suit over the broken foot that interrupted his pro career.

title: TRANSPORTING DISABLED IS A COSTLY CHALLENGE FOR CITY AND STATE
description: After three years and millions of dollars, New York State and New York City have met many of the easier requirements of the tangle of Federal regulations barring discrimination against the handicapped. Now, officials say, comes the hard part.

title: 41 EX-CAPTIVES AVOID INQUIRIES ON HANDLING OF EVENTS IN TEHERAN
description: The freed American hostages, in their first full-dress news conference, gave new insights today into their 14 months of captivity in Iran but avoided substantial discussion of some aspects of their ordeal.

title: MARGIN RULES URGED FOR FOREIGNERS, TOO
description: Legislation intended to keep foreign investors from bypassing the Federal Reserve's margin requirements when they borrow abroad to buy shares of American companies was introduced today in both houses of Congress.

title: 25 EX-HOSTAGES SAY YES TO A TICKER-TAPE PARADE
description: Twenty-five of the men and women who spent 14 months in captivity in Iran have accepted New York City's invitation to participate in a traditional ticker-tape parade on Friday. The parade will begin at Battery Park, with the Statue of Liberty in the background, and proceed up Broadway to City Hall.

title: Bayard W. Read, 78, Ex-Banker Who Became a Conservationist
description: Bayard W. Read, a former New York banker who was also a conservationist and wildlife photographer, died last Thursday at the age of 78 at his home in Rye, N.Y.

title: U.S. STEEL GAINS; WHEELING DECLINES
description: The United States Steel Corporation yesterday reported earnings of $190 million, or $2.16 a share, for the fourth quarter, compared with a loss of $668.9 million in the fourth quarter of 1979 when the company was at one of its lowest points and made huge cutbacks by closing old plants.

title: Burger Rejects Dresser Request
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger rejected a Dresser Industries request to block delivery of information subpoenaed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Q. I recently dined in the home of a friend who served a salad made with lettuce, cucumber and carnation petals. Have you ever heard of carnations as a food?
description: A. I have never used carnations in my kitchen, but in her book ''The Forgotten Art of Flower Cookery,'' (Harper & Row, 1973), Leona Woodring Smith proposes several uses of carnations in edible creations.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Let terrorists be aware that when the rules of international behavior are violated, our policy will be one of swift and effective retribution.'' - President Ronald Reagan. (A14:1.)

title: A SNACKING TOUR OF THE NEIGHBORHOODS
description: AN ingredient essential to the New York nosh is the New York waiter. So when Lou Singer brought the six women from his Nosher's Tour of New York into Gertel's Kosher Bakery at 53 Hester Street the other day, there was little surprise when the waiter, with blond walrus mustache and several tattoos, asked somewhat brusquely, ''You gonna sit like that all facing each other?''

title: THE FIRST LADY'S HIFGH FASHION IS TOO HIGH
description: To the Editor:

title: A Longevity Secret
description: When he turned 106 yesterday, James Wylie Mahaffey wasn't able to say much because of the effects of a stroke he suffered some years ago, but his visiting daughter had a lot to say about his longevity. She said he's lived to be the nation's second oldest veteran because of his natural immunity to a number of diseases.

title: Accounts
description: * Norwegian-Swedish National Tourist Office to AC&R Advertising Inc.

title: 3 Reduce Loan Rates
description: Reductions to 20 percent in broker loan rates were announced yesterday by the Chase Manhattan Bank, the Chemical Bank and the Bank of New York. Chase's rate had been 21 percent; those at Chemical and the Bank of New York, 20 1/2 percent.

title: SANDOZ PLANS TO BUY A DIVISION OF CULBRO
description: Sandoz Ltd., the huge Swiss company with interests in drugs, chemicals and food, has agreed to purchase the proprietary medicine division of the Culbro Corporation, which manufactures, among other products, Ex-Lax.

title: Television And The Courts
description: The Supreme Court has ruled unanimously that the states are not prohibited by the Constitution from allowing television cameras in the courts, but it did not guarantee or advocate the televising of court proceedings.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Airco Inc. of St. Marys, Pa., has appointed Nicholas T. Kaiser president of the Airco Carbon division.

title: CORRECTION
description: Walter Laqueur's article, ''Europe, In the Woods,'' on Tuesday's Op-Ed page, was adapted by the author from a longer version in the February issue of Commentary magazine.

title: UNGARO'S PRESENT ECHOES PAST
description: ''That wasn't fashion - that was art.'' Irith Landeau, the young Israeli woman who is an attractive part of the social and fashion scene here, left Emanuel Ungaro's show at the Jacquemart Andre Museum glowing with good feeling about the designer's imaginative mixture of colors, fabrics and, of course, sense of luxury.

title: Relay Journalism in South Africa
description: South Africa has undeniably made gestures toward black economic progress, if not political equality. Black trade unions have been officially recognized, steps have been taken to require compulsory education for all black children and residence restrictions are to be eased.

title: TYNER: A JAZZ PIANIST WHO HAS ENRICHED ROCK
description: MCCOY TYNER, who is performing at the Bottom Line Friday and Saturday night with his quintet, has probably been the most influential jazz pianist of the last 20 years. His powerful left-hand repetition patterns and the swirling masses of sound he shapes as delicately and vividly as a sculptor working in clay have permeated jazz since he perfected them during his tenure with the John Coltrane quartet of the early and middle 60's. They have also enriched the vocabularies of rock and fusion keyboard players.

title: TALKS END ON EASTERN, BRANIFF LINK
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. and the Braniff International Corporation announced yesterday that they were halting talks on a possible merger, citing concern that an attempt to combine work forces would be ''too disruptive'' to the employees involved.

title: BELITTLING DIMINUTIVES
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Donovan Cleared
description: It is time for the Senate Labor Committee to affirm Raymond Donovan's appointment as Secretary of Labor. The nomination of the New Jersey construction executive was properly delayed by allegations that he was involved, some years ago, in some questionable dealings with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Player Tells Court Of Punch by Coach
description: A former kicker for Arizona State's s football team testified in court today that Coach Frank Kush grabbed him by the face mask, cursed him repeatedly and then punched him after a poor punt in a game two years ago.

title: Jersey Youth Shelter Is Ordered Closed
description: A Juvenile Court judge has ordered the Passaic County youth shelter closed.

title: Drug Fair Accepts Acquisition Offer
description: Directors of Drug Fair Inc., which operates 175 drugstores, accepted an acquisition offer from the Cleveland-based Gray Drug Stores Inc.

title: THE AMERICAN FILM INSTITUTE HAD TO FIND A NEW HOME-OR DIE
description: When the American Film Institute holds a thanksgiving banquet tomorrow night on the college campus it purchased for $4.9 million last summer to convert into its headquarters, it will announce a $1 million gift from the Louis B. Mayer Foundation to finance a library in the film pioneer's name.

title: COPY OF TAPE PLAYED AT BELMONTE HEARING
description: A copy of a 45-minute recording, challenged by the defense because the original tape had mysteriously disappeared, was played yesterday for members of the State Racing and Wagering Board in an effort to link the former jockey Eddie Belmonte to fixed horse races at Saratoga in 1974.

title: CHEF RECIPES
description: Smoked Salmon Terrine David Waltuck (Chanterelle) 1 3/4 pounds smoked Novia Scotia Salmon 1/4 pound melted unsalted butter Juice 1 lemon (or more to taste) 3 tablespoons chopped chives Freshly ground white pepper 1/4 pint whipped cream 4 ounces American black caviar

title: TRANSCRIPT OF NEWS CONFERENCE HELD BY FORMER HOSTAGES AT WEST POINT.
description: HOSTAGES' NEWS CONFERENCE: QUESTIONS ON TORTURE AND RELIGIOUS PREJUDICE

title: BILL SEKS TAX BREAK FOR EMPLOYERS' CHILD CARE CENTERS
description: Tax breaks would be given to employers who set up child-care centers at or near their plants and offices under a plan announced today by key legislators from the Assembly and the Senate.

title: Bridge: Kamil Posts Twin Triumph Although Partners Change
description: Regional pair championships in the New York area attract fields notable for the quality and quantity of the participants. To win two consecutive events with different partners is a rare feat, and to do so at the age of 20 is a record.

title: Key Rates
description: Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 3 JAZZ NIGHTS AT CARNEGIE
description: Three jazz programs will be presented at Carnegie Hall on Fridays in March as part of the hall's 90th anniversary celebration. The first, on March 6, will recreate a program of jazz, blues, ragtime, spirituals and semiclassical music presented in 1928 by W.C. Handy, the composer of ''St. Louis Blues.'' At the program, 24-year-old Fats Waller, the pianist, made his first ''downtown'' appearance as soloist on ''Yamekraw'' by James P. Johnson, his mentor.

title: TV: A SOLDIER'S ORDEAL IN 'THORNWELL'
description: THE strengths and weaknesses of the ''docudrama'' - the dramatization of actual events - are demonstrated in ''Thornwell,'' which will be seen from 9 to 11 o'clock tonight on CBS-TV.

title: Commissioner Upstaged
description: As Commissioner of the city's Department for the Aging, Janet S. Sainer routinely attends a lot of functions and serves as an expert panelist at conferences on the problems of the aging.

title: WILSCAT WALKOUTS ERUPTING IN POLAND IN SURGE OF UNREST
description: Spontaneous strikes erupted throughout Poland today amid signs that the national leadership of the independent labor movement was no longer in control of local union chapters.

title: DETAILS EMERGE ON TERROR IN CAPTIVITY
description: As the former hostages gradually meld back into American life, more details of their long ordeal are emerging, bringing into sharper focus a picture of deprivation, humiliation and terror, spiked with occasional physical attacks.

title: 2d Arrest Is Made In Queens Slaying
description: A second arrest was reported in the robbery-murder last November of Thomas Nielan, an investigator of the special state prosecutor's office. Ronnie Del Toro, 15 years old, was seized in front of his Queens Village home.

title: STOCK PRICES CLIMB BRISKLY
description: Stock prices, buoyed partly by prospects for early decontrol of domestic crude oil prices, moved ahead briskly yesterday to score their first advance since President Reagan took office.

title: Reagan Planning to Sell 108 Tanks to Morocco
description: The Reagan Administration plans to notify Congress this week of its intention to sell Morocco 108 American M-60 tanks that it requested last summer, a State Department official said today.

title: U.S. Advises Americans Travel to Iran Is Perilous
description: The State Department warned Americans today against traveling to Iran, saying there was a risk of being taken hostage.

title: Gains Are Forecast In Newspaper Revenues
description: Jack Kauffman, president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, has built up a reputation as a minor prophet, at least where newspaper advertising revenues are concerned.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary in The Times yesterday gave an incorrect first name for Dr. Nathan Newmark, emeritus professor of civil engineering at the University of Illinois and a consultant on the design of earthquake resistant structures. An article on Sept. 23 reported incorrectly that the Dow Chemical Company contributed to the pollution in Cubatao, Brazil. Dow does not have a plant in the town.

title: FLEET GROWS DESPITE A SLUMP
description: In the midst of a global shipping slump that has led the industry to idle or scrap millions of tons of tanker capacity, one shipowner based here has moved aggressively to expand his fleet and consolidate his influence on major routes.

title: Hundreds of School Officials Call in Sick in Detroit
description: Nearly 500 principals and assistant principals stayed away from the Detroit schools for a second day today, calling in sick in a contract dispute, district spokesmen said.

title: Belgium Says BL Will Close Plant
description: BL Ltd., the British state-owned motor company, has made an irreversible decision to close its car assembly plant at Seneffe, Belgium, with the loss of more than 2,000 jobs, a Belgian Government official said.

title: Market Place; What Price Technology?
description: SOME fear that shares of highly favored high-technology companies are headed for a sinking spell that could last for months. The leading science-based companies - Cray Research at a price/earnings ratio of 45, Computervision at 44 and Apple Computer at an astounding 100 -have reached price/earnings ratios as high as those reached during the glamour stock excesses of the early 1970's.

title: Companies
description: Exxon's final-quarter earnings fell but full-year profits soared. The world's largest oil company said fourth quarter earnings slipped 1.1 percent, while profits for all of last year advanced 31.8 percent, to a record $5.66 billion. Revenues for the year jumped 30 percent, to $110.47 billion, believed to be a the highest ever posted by an industrial company. (Page D1.)

title: BENDIX COMPLETES FOREST UNIT SALE
description: The Bendix Corporation said it had completed the sale of substantially all of its forest products operations to a company formed by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, an investment firm based in New York City. An agreement in principle for the sale was announced in September.

title: Chrysler de Mexico Had Record Year
description: The Chrysler Corporation, fighting for survival in the United States and Canada, enjoyed a record year in Mexico, the auto maker said today.

title: TEXT OF IRANIAN NOTE DENYING ABUSE OF HOSTAGES
description: Following is the text of an Iranian Foreign Ministry statement on reports that the American hostages were mistreated while they were in Iran. The statement was telexed here today, in English, by the official Iranian press agency Pars.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: BOSTON (AL) - Signed Carney Lans- f ord, third baseman, and Gary Allenson, c atcher. CLEVELAND (AL) - Signed Mike Pax- t on, pitcher.

title: An Inaugural Cake Saga
description: It sounded like a good idea at the time - a seven-foot, 3,000-pound inaugural cake decorated with blue frosting pictures of President Reagan and Vice President Bush.

title: VIOLIN: MARKOV PLAYS FINKO PREMIERE
description: THE wave of emigres from the Soviet Union in recent years has thrown up on our shores a great many talented musicians, among whom Albert Markov must be ranked with the most successful in making the public aware of his presence. Mr. Markov came to America five years ago and quickly established himself as a violinist and teacher. Last night's recital at Carnegie Hall by the 47-year-old musician and his pianist, Lev Natochenny, reaffirmed his reputation as a virtuoso fiddler. The quality of artistry that Mr. Markov demonstrated all evening allowed the listener to simply sit back and revel in the sheer pleasure of hearing the instrument played by a master. There was no need to lean forward in the seat, even during Mr. Markov's spectacular dash through Paganini's Caprice No. 7: the technique was spotless and gave absolutely no cause for anxiety.

title: TOWARD A HUNGRIER AMERICA?
description: To the Editor:

title: OPTIMISTIC AMERICAN DIPLOMAT
description: Throughout his 444 days of captivity in Iran, Lowell Bruce Laingen somehow always managed to remain optimistic about the eventual outcome of the hostage crisis, sending out a series of private messages to his family and State Department officials that were notable for their concern about duty to country and fellow man. Today Mr. Laingen, the charge d'affaires of the United States Embassy in Teheran when it was seized, publicly repeated those messages in a series of jubilant homecoming appearances, momentarily transfixing a national television audience with his plucky humor, grace, dramatic eloquence and, above all, his devotion to family and country.

title: No Headline
description: American Brands Inc.?$ 83,400,000 8.6 Borden Inc.33,900,000 + 15.7 Cabot Corp.27,900,000 + 1.5 Celanese Corp.39,000,000 + 44.4 Clark Equipment 16,700,000 28.6 Consolidated Edison 61,200,000 12.1 Consolidated Foods 33,900,000 + 14.9 Eastern Air Lines 17,400,000 + 13.7 Exxon Corp.1,350,000,000 1.1 Foremost-McKesson 21,200,000 + 16.5 Hammermill Paper 11,700,000 14.6 Hilton Hotels 26,300,000 + 10.5 Hutton (E. F.) 23,300,000 + 109.9 INA Corp.73,500,000 + 20.3 Ingersoll-Rand 58,000,000 + 33.6 Marathon Oil 55,300,000 + 1.8 Merck & Co.94,600,000 + 15.8 Merrill Lynch & Co.52,300,000 + 76.7 Missouri Pacific Corp.44,800,000 13.7 Murphy Oil 45,600,000 + 20.0 Paccar Inc.16,300,000 50.0 Procter & Gamble 159,000,000 + 8.4 Singer Co.12,900,000 + 98.5 Southern Ry.44,100,000 + 32.4 Sperry Corp.79,800,000 + 16.7 Tosco Corp.(9,800,000) U. S. Steel 190,000,000 Zale Corp.24,600,000 32.0 See notes below for special items(loss) * Loss in year-earlier quarter

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan chose a moment of enormous emotional fervor, a moment of national patriotic communion this afternoon to proclaim a resurgent and more assertive America willing to use force swiftly to protect its diplomats abroad.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 28, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Relations With the Host Country - 10:30 A.M.

title: 3 Are Killed in Head-On Collision Of a Car and a Truck in Queens
description: Three people were killed early yesterday in a head-on collision in Queens.

title: STAGE: MUSICAL 'FACADE'
description: ''FACADE,'' a musical-theatrical ''entertainment'' composed by Sir William Walton to a suite of poems by Edith Sitwell in the early 1920's, is a sort of work that lends itself to experimental theatrics. Originally a parlor entertainment, written when the composer, only 19, was a protege of the Sitwells, it was subsequently revised and expanded, and nowadays it is usually performed by one or two narrators and a six-piece chamber ensemble.

title: Index; The Hostages
description: Transcript of ex-hostages news conference at West Point A12 Transcipt of reamarks by President and Laingen A14 Cheering bureacrats welcomed the hostages to Washington A14 More tales of hostages' ordeal emerge A16 Iran denies abuse of hostages; says torture is a great sin A16 Text of Iranian reply to reports that hostages were mistreated A16 21 former hostages agree to ticker- tape parade A17 U.S. files for delay of court cases about Iran pending study A17 International Bani-Sadr, in power fight, charges plot to kill him A2 Guerrillas in Colombia repeated their threat to kill an American A3 Islamic leaders urge Soviet to leave Afghanistan A3 Around the World A4 Government/Politics Vote on House panel chairmanship reflects realities of power A24 Critics of Koch start move to oppose his election B3 Suit on Suffolk sewer project seeks $260 million in damages B3 General Around the Nation A6 Witness tells of blacks' attack on auto in Miami riots A10 Jean Harris as a witness B2 The City B3 The Region B7 Obituaries Sir Andrew Schonfield, British economist and author B5 Health/Science Satellite to help planes to avoid ozone B5 Living Section Food Young chefs: A big-city success story C1

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Products & Chemicals Inc. said its wholly owned French subsidiary, Prodair, would build a 320-ton-a-day industrial gas plant near Lyon, France.

title: FURNITURE TAKES CENTER STAGE
description: MAYBE it was because they were all starting out fresh. One couple had recently married and had just bought a duplex. Another had just divorced, and she got the art and a new apartment. And one executive, who had just begun a business, found a perfect, if small, studio right around the corner from her new shop.

title: Corona Foothill Purchase
description: The Daon Development Corporation of Vancouver, British Columbia, said yesterday that it had exercised an option to buy a majority interest in the Corona Foothill Lemon Company of southern California and was moving to acquire all the outstanding shares.

title: Peru and Ecuador Fight In Andes Border Area
description: A border conflict erupted today between Peru and Ecuador. Ecuador asserted that Peruvian aircraft attacked a frontier outpost this morning, and Peru said tonight that it was conducting a military operation to rout Ecuadorean troops from its territory.

title: Nippon K.K. in Pact To Aid Kaiser Steel
description: Nippon Kokan K.K., a leading Japanese steel producer, has agreed to provide technical assistance to the Kaiser Steel Corporation, a Nippon Kokan official said.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Analysts International is offering 300,000 shares of common at $8 7/8 a share.

title: Key Rates
description: Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 'IMPROVING' A BALLET CLASSIC IS TRICKY
description: SOMETIMES it seems that productions of the balletic classics can be needlessly fussy. Certain choreographers and balletmasters find what they regard as problems in these works and in their revivals they try to solve those problems. But, often, the problems are only pseudoproblems and the solutions, instead of illuminating the ballets, crowd them with extraneous details.

title: PRESIDENT TO REQUEST INCREASE OF $50 BILLION IN THE CEILING ON DEBT
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan announced today that the Administration was asking Congress to increase the national debt ceiling by nearly $50 billion.

title: Mobil Gets Gas Approval
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation has received Federal approval to drill four additional exploratory gas wells in lower Mobile Bay, the company announced today. A final approval from the State Oil and Gas Board must be given before drilling begins. In November 1979, tests of Mobil's first exploratory well in the bay showed natural gas, flowing at a rate of 10.4 million cubic feet of dry gas a day.

title: New President At W.R. Grace Home Centers
description: Frank W. Denny, 46, has been named president of the home centers unit of W.R. Grace & Company. He succeeds William F. Reilly, 42, a Grace employee since 1964 and a former New York City assistant finance administrator who left the division last month to become executive vice president of Macmillan Inc.

title: James Cross, the Stump Of Vaudeville Dance Act
description: James Cross, a vaudevillian best known as Stump in the long-lived act of Stump and Stumpy, died Sunday after a long illness. He was 61 years old.

title: HOW THE POLICE COULD HELP BOOST CAR SALES
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS ACCUSED OF 'POWER GRAB' IN VOTE ON PANEL SEATS
description: In a vote along straight party lines, Democrats in the House of Representatives today pushed through a set of rules that strengthens their influence over President Reagan's economic program.

title: '100,000 WELCOMES' GREET EX-HOSTAGES
description: ''And to you, Michael, in God's name, Cead Mile Failte, a hundred thousand welcomes home.'' The words were Gaelic, spoken by a Roman Catholic priest, the Rev. John Kelly, in a Byzantine Catholic Church. And indeed there seemed to be 100,000 welcomes here in the hometown of Michael J. Metrinko, one of the 52 freed hostages, who finally arrived at his birthplace today.

title: FINDING THE FRAMERS
description: The framers listed below are among those who are used frequently by professionals in the art field. Each uses strict conservation techniques and materials when framing original art works. They sell to the public as well as to the trade, but most caution that they will give time priorities and discounts to the trade. The estimated retail prices quoted are for a 24-by-30-inch framed piece, using allrag materials. Bark Frameworks, 85 Grand Street; 431-9080; by appointment only.

title: GOTTFRIED IS TOPPLED
description: Vitas Gerulaitis romped to a straight-set victory, but fifth-seeded Brian Gottfried was upset by Tim Gullikson in the second round of the $250,000 United States Pro Indoor tennis championship today.

title: THE JADE PLANT FLOWERS: BLOSSOMS LAST WEEKS
description: WHEN there are many house plants in a collection, they may all get short shrift because it takes so long to simply make the rounds and water. A dead leaf might be pulled off or a straggly stem pinched back, but for the most part the plants are on their own. Unless, of course, one of them does something special.

title: POLISH STUDENTS, TIRED OF LECTURES ON MARXISM, BRACE FOR LONG SIT-IN
description: In this grim manufacturing city, the Polish Manchester, as it is called, with its red-brick textile mills and tenements that spawned strikes a century ago, about 4,000 students are sitting in at the university.

title: LADISLAV GROSMAN
description: Ladislav Grosman, a Czechoslovak author whose book ''The Shop on Main Street'' was made into the Oscar Award-winning film of the same title, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Kiron, Israel, where he had been living since 1968. He was in his late 50's.

title: China Cancels Mitsubishi Deal
description: China is canceling a $420 million contract with Mitsubishi of Japan for the construction of a steel rolling mill, Mitsubishi said today.

title: Rise of a Hot Dog Vendor
description: When he was a student at Northwestern University Law School more than 20 years ago, Eddie Einhorn worked part time as a vendor of hot dogs and beer at Comiskey Park in Chicago during White Sox games. ''On some days, I wouldn't vend,'' he admits. ''I would just watch the ball game.''

title: PHILIP MORRIS ROSE 10.1% IN 4TH QUARTER
description: Philip Morris Inc., the nation's second-largest cigarette company behind R.J. Reynolds Industries, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter rose 10.1 percent on an increase in operating revenues of 12.2 percent.

title: NEW YORK EXPECTING 23 FORMER HOSTAGES
description: Preparations moved ahead yesterday for New York City's traditional Broadway ticker-tape parade and welcome at City Hall tomorrow for some of the former American hostages held in Iran.

title: Mentally Ill Mother Loses Custody Case
description: A judge's award of twin 7-year-old boys to the custody of their mentally ill mother was upset by an appeals court in Brooklyn. The youngsters were ordered turned over to their father, who had remarried after a divorce.

title: Texaco, U.S. Steel In Plastics Venture
description: Subsidiaries of Texaco Inc. and the United States Steel Corporation have formed a joint venture company to produce and market high-density polyetheylene, the companies said.

title: TV: THE TOYOTA, A SUCCESS STORY
description: J AY McMULLEN, a producer for CBS News, is something of a quiet man in television. Every year or so he goes off with a film crew to produce an essay on a single subject, usually something that is considered difficult for the electronic medium to tackle. Word has it that even his bosses don't know for certain what Mr. McMullen will bring back. Usually, though, the finished product is thorough, wellorganized and illuminating. It then goes on to collect numerous awards.

title: The Economy
description: President Reagan ended controls on domestic oil and gasoline production and distribution, effective immediately, in a move that is expected to lift gasoline prices. The Administration said, however, that gasoline prices at the end of the year would be no higher than they would have been if the controls had been allowed to expire as scheduled on Sept. 30. (Page A1.) The oil industry hailed the move, but small refiners and gasoline distributors said they feared deregulation could drive them out of business. (D6.)

title: Whalers 6, Rockies 3
description: Mike Rogers scored three goals in the second period to lead the Whalers over Colorado. The Rogers goals helped the Whalers snap a seven-game victoryless streak on their home ice.

title: REAGAN CONFERS WITH JAMAICAN AT WHITE HOUSE
description: President Reagan said today at a White House reception for Prime Minister Edward P.G. Seaga of Jamaica that he was concerned over ''instability being inflicted on some countries'' in the region by outside political forces.

title: A NORTHEAST CHANNEL TO CHEAPER ENERGY
description: To the Editor:

title: MASS-PRODUCED GOODS HELPED TO GIVE IMMIGRANTS A NEW IDENTITY; by Paula Deitz
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Paula Deitz, co-editor of The Hudson Review, is a guest columnist.

title: TUNICS SHARPEN UP A CLASSIC COLLECTION FROM SAINT LAURENT
description: Other fashion designers may try to find out what their competitors are doing so they can stimulate their own ideas. If Yves Saint Laurent cares at all - and there is no indication that he does - it is so he can do something different.

title: HAPPY FAMILIES SHOW GRATITUDE BY DONATING FUNDS FOR THE NEEDIEST
description: The gratitude felt by secure and happy families with children is often the source of inspiration for contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: JOINT CHIEFS' HEAD URGES NEW BOMBER
description: In a marked shift of position and tone, Gen. David C. Jones of the Air Force, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, vigorously urged Congress today to give top priority to building a new strategic bomber.

title: TWO FORMS OF TUITION ALLOWANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Sabres 4, Flyers 4
description: Buffalo's Randy McClanahan, John Van Boxmeer and Richie Dunn scored following a stick-swinging incident involving a teammate, Danny Gare, to gain a tie with Philadelphia. The tie extended the Flyers' unbeaten streak against Buffalo to 11 games - six victories and five ties.

title: Holy Cross 82, Manhattan 70
description: With Ernie Floyd scoring 19 points and grabbing seven rebounds, Holy Cross rolled to an 82-70 victory over Manhattan tonight.

title: Bridge: John Gerber Remembered For a Career of Distinction
description: The world of contract bridge lost one of its most celebrated personalities yesterday when John Gerber died in Houston. A million players around the world knew him as the inventor of the Gerber four-club convention, in general use to locate aces after partner has bid no-trump.

title: STAGE: NOSTALGIC 'FIVE O'CLOCK GIRL'
description: UNTIL it turned up at the Helen Hayes last night, ''The Five O'Clock Girl'' had not been seen on Broadway since its initial production in 1927. There may be a good reason for that. This amiably silly musical comedy, with its less-than-deathless Bert Kalmar-Harry Ruby score, was not built for the ages; indeed, it wasn't even the best musical of 1927, which was also the year of Rodgers and Hart's ''A Connecticut Yankee'' and Kern and Hammerstein's ''Showboat.'' Seeing this show now, in a merry but routine production that originated at Connecticut's Goodspeed Opera House, one wonders why it has returned to New York. ''The Five O'Clock Girl'' is not without passing interest as an arcane footnote to theatrical history, but as entertainment in 1981 it's a pretty slim affair.

title: Clippers Release Wicks 'For Good of the Team'
description: Sidney Wicks was released by the San Diego Clippers ''for the good of the team'' today in a move that he said surprised him.

title: STORMS EASE WATER SHORTAGE AND AID SKI AREAS IN WEST
description: A break in the West Coast's stagnant weather pattern brought tempestuous storms and much-needed water to California and snow to the mountains to the east yesterday and today, easing the threat of a drought and bracing the tottering ski industry.

title: IRELAND DUBBED 'SMALL POTATOES'
description: The Irish have been given a new picture of themselves by an American diplomat. He has called them a dull, dreary country that is ''small potatoes'' in world affairs.

title: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 28 (AP) -A Government spokesman said tonight that little hope remained of finding any more survivors of the passenger ship Tampomas II, which sank yesterday in a storm in the Java Sea.
description: With rough weather continuing to hamper rescue ships and aircraft, he said 287 people were still listed as missing. The spokesman said 87 had been confirmed dead.

title: CELEBRATING BREAKFAST IN UPHOLSTERED BEDS
description: ''BREAKFAST IN BED'' is the theme of W & J Sloane's new model rooms, but the store isn't taking the idea too literally. It might be breakfast served on a table in a corner of the bedroom, or even a champagne supper at midnight. But no matter. The point isn't the food but the beds - specifically, upholstered beds.

title: Red Wings 2, Nordiques 2
description: Dale McCourt scored his 16th goal of the season at 7:08 of the third period, giving Detroit a tie with the Nordiques. With Quebec leading, 2-1, McCourt raced into the slot untouched and snapped a low wrist shot between the legs of the goalie, Michel Plasse.

title: SOVIET ARMY PAPER SAYS NATO IS WOOING POLAND
description: The Soviet Union today added a new - and to some Western diplomats, an ominous - dimension to its commentary on the political crisis in Poland.

title: ASKS TRADE CAUTION
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that no military equipment or spare parts would be provided to Iran, and he urged American companies to exercise ''the most careful caution'' before resuming trade with Iran now that sanctions have been lifted.

title: Garwood's Defense Rejected In Plea on Certain Charges
description: Col. R.E. Switzer of the Marine Corps, presiding over the court-martial of Pfc. Robert R. Garwood, today refused a defense request to dismiss the remaining charges, saying a jury of Vietnam veterans should be allowed to consider his fate.

title: U.S WARNS JAPANESE ON AUTO SALES
description: The United States has warned Japan against curbing motor vehicle shipments to the European Common Market on the ground that they might be diverted to the United States and touch off a protectionist reaction.

title: IT PROVED A DIFFICULT DAY FOR THE SPECTATORS TOO
description: Today was a difficult day for Jean S. Harris, for the jurors and for those sitting in on Mrs. Harris's murder trial.

title: Ireland Raises Prices On Gas, Beer and Cigarettes
description: Finance Minister Gene Fitzgerald announced price increases today for gasoline, beer and cigarettes as part of an unexpectedly harsh budget designed to shore up Ireland's sagging economy.

title: Anthracite Demand Grows
description: Energy officials from the Northeast, where anthracite for home heating is in short supply this winter, say they expect demand for the hard coal to quadruple next year.

title: Technology
description: IN January 1979, after the price of cobalt had risen fivefold in a year, to $25 a pound among producers and up to $50 a pound on the free market, several engineers at Colt Industries Inc. set to work.

title: Socal and Shell Profits Advance; Sun, Phillips Post Declines
description: The Standard Oil Company of California, the country's fourthbiggest oil company, reported yesterday that it had a 17 percent rise in fourth-quarter earnings and a 35 percent gain for the full year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amcon Group Inc., the principal North American subsidiary of Consolidated Gold Fields of London, has elected David Lloyd-Jacob chairman and Robert Barbanell president.

title: AS AN ELEPHANT'S EYE; by Anthony Lewis
description: ''If you want to know how it's going here,'' a banker said, ''look at maize.'' Black politicians and white farmers made the same suggestion. Corn, as Americans call it, is as good a clue as any to what has happened in Zimbabwe since it became independent last April under black political control.

title: KHOMEINI REBUFFS IRAQ AND URGES WAR UNTIL 'VICTORY'
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini ignored a new conditional peace offer from Iraq today and ordered Iran's armed forces to fight until ''total victory.''

title: by Larry McCoy
description: Finally! A good idea whose time has come! Representative Barry Goldwater Jr., who may turn out to be as much fun as his dad, thinks we ought to put advertisements on our stamps, and, to that end, has introduced the Free Enterprise Postage Stamp Act. He says it's a way to stop the Postal Service from operating in the red -excuse the expression, Congressman.

title: IRAN CHALLENGES U.S. TO PROVE ABUSE
description: The leader of Iran's dominant clergy-led political party challenged the United States today to produce documentary evidence that the American hostages were mistreated during their captivity ''so we can discuss it.''

title: JOHN VERNON JR.
description: John Vernon Jr., manager of the Western Hemisphere operations of the Kuwait National Petroleum Company, died Saturday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 53 years old and lived in Mountain Lakes, N.J.

title: 2 FREED HOSTAGES ARE HOSPITALIZED AS VIRAL INFECTION HITS MANY OF 52
description: Two former hostages were being treated in hospitals yesterday as an outbreak of a viral respiratory infection struck about a fifth of the 52 Americans who were freed eight days ago in Iran, according to Dr. Jerome M. Korcak, the State Department's medical director.

title: OIL WIDENS TRADE GAP IN MONTH
description: A surge in oil imports aggravated the nation's trade deficit in December, but the overall deficit for last year narrowed from the 1979 figure, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Detroit 75, L.I.U. 74
description: Roy Simms sank a pair of free throws with 3 seconds to play, giving the University of Detroit a 75-74 victory over Long Island University tonight.

title: Seton Hall 58, Army 41
description: Matt Piccinich led Seton Hall on a 16-2 surge in less than five minutes early in the second half to break open a close game en route to a 58-41 victory tonight over Army.

title: PRICE INDEX TO DROP HOME-BUYING COSTS
description: The much-criticized home-purchase component of the Consumer Price Index will be deleted and will probably be replaced with an estimate for rents, Janet L. Norwood, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, announced today.

title: Hanoi Offers to Withdraw Some Troops in Cambodia
description: Vietnam said today that it was ready to withdraw some troops from Cambodia under certain conditions and proposed a regional conference involving the countries of Indochina and the non-Communist countries of Southeast Asia.

title: CARTER'S GOOD DEED; by William Safire
description: Time was, the top 7,000 Civil Service employees - the creme de la creme of the Federal bureaucracy - were locked into their jobs, unable to be moved or even influenced by an incoming Administration.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Clark Oil and Refining Corporation received a filing from the Securities and Exchange Commission indicating that the Apex Holding Company had purchased 5.5 percent of Clark's common stock.

title: Weyerhaeuser Declines
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company, the nation's leading forest-products concern, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980 dropped 36.6 percent as sales slipped nine-tenths of 1 percent.

title: North Carolina 61, Clemson 47
description: Sam Perkins hauled in 12 rebounds and scored 16 points to lead North Carolina to a 61-47 victory over Clemson in the Atlantic Coast Conference tonight.

title: FOCUS OF TV NETWORKS ON DRAMA OF THE HOSTAGES' RELEASE
description: ABC News devoted three and a half hours last Thursday evening to a special report about negotiations for the release of the 52 American hostages. CBS News interrupted its prime time schedule on Saturday evening for a one-hour special devoted to interviews with several of the freed hostages. Ted Turner's 24-hour Cable News Network focused its news coverage almost exclusively on the hostage story for most of last week.

title: Anaconda to Build Big Aluminum Plant
description: The Anaconda Company said that it planned to build a major aluminum processing complex, expected to cost about $400 million, in Kentucky.

title: Advertising; Attenzione Magazine Expanding
description: SPEAKING of her magazine, which has survived 19 issues in an area where others could not make it to six, Leda Giovannetti Sanford, editor in chief and publisher of Attenzione, said, ''What you have to have is patience and a lot of money.''

title: On Crime Prevention
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: We in the New York City Police Department read with great interest the article ''Neighborly Crime Prevention'' (Jan. 15). We have launched a major drive over the past few years to involve citizens in various crime-fighting programs.

title: PRANKS IN PEKING: WOMAN IMPERSONATES TIMES MAN
description: A 23-year-old female worker in a Peking phonograph needle factory has been arrested after she allegedly ordered banquets in 14 Peking restaurants by posing as a correspondent of The New York Times or as a Hong Kong businesswoman, a spokesman for the Public Security Bureau confirmed today.

title: Honegger's 'David' Feb. 15
description: Honegger's ''King David'' will be performed by the combined choirs of the Park Avenue Christian Church and Park Avenue Methodist Church at 1010 Park Avenue on Feb. 15 at 2 P.M. Based on a drama by Rene Morax, the popular choral work was termed a ''Sacred Psalm'' by its composer, and has often been staged.

title: THE REGION
description: TRENTON (UPI) - Governor Byrne signed a bill that would extend for another year the current moratorium on the taxation of mobile homes as real property.

title: FAST LEARNERS
description: To the Editor:

title: ARMY TO CHECK FORMER TOXIC DUMP
description: Chemical weapons and munitions dating from World War I are buried at the former Raritan Arsenal, now a major office and industrial park, according to the Army, which says it is restudying its records to see if six disposal sites at the park pose any threat to the public.

title: DECONTROL OF OIL MAY MAKE MOOT A NEW YORK SUIT
description: President Reagan's lifting of oil pricing controls could make moot a Federal lawsuit brought by oil companies against New York State's 2 percent tax on their gross receipts, Governor Carey and other state officials said today. Oil company officials disagreed.

title: EX-HOSTAGES ASSERT CLERGY MADE CAPTIVITY WORSE
description: A former hostage has complained that a note alleging mistreatment by Iranians, which he had given to a visiting American clergyman, had been turned over to his captors and had ''caused a lot of problems.''

title: WHOM SOLDIERS MUST OBEY
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Die in Avalanches in Norway
description: Avalanches killed three people and destroyed three houses in northern Norway, the police said today. At least three other people were missing.

title: Index; International
description: Salvadoran spreads word abroad: back the rebels A2 Poor Filipino farmers being killed after trying to improve life A3 Jamaican leader is Reagan's first foreign visitor A3 Females impersonates Times man in Peking A3 Lebanese leader urges Islamic na- tions' help against P.L.O. A5 Around the World A9 Excerpts from Haig's news con- ference A10 Indonesia has little hope of finding more ship survivors A11 Iranian calls on U.S. to produce proof hostages were abused B10 Government/Politics House Democrats are accused of 'power grab' A14 Reagan seeks an increase in the national debt limit A20 Army checking old Raritan Ar- senal dumping site for hazards B1 Revamped development unit on altered but ambitious course B1 City to shift traffic enforcement duties to police officers B3 Democrats vote to abolish Scheuer's subcommittee B3 Carey stumping to sell his $16.2 billion budget to public B11 General Leslie H. Gelb rejoining The Times A8 Around the Nation A14 A difficult day for Harris trial spectators B2 The Region B4 Freed hostage is greeted by '100,000' welcomes B8 Former hostages say visiting clergy made captivity worse B9 City prepares official welcomefor former hostages B10 Former hostage from New York City returns home B10 Television coverage of hostages' return was extensive B10 The Home Section Home Furniture takes center stage C1

title: Yes, Decontrol Oil; but Now What?
description: President Reagan is right to end the price controls on oil immediately, eight months ahead of schedule. The effect of that decision will be to raise the cost of fuel by an additional 5 to 10 cents a gallon. But price increases are a necessary if unpleasant part of the process of adjusting to energy scarcity.

title: LEBANESE PLEADS AT ISLAMIC TALKS FOR A P.L.O. CURB
description: The President of Lebanon told Islamic leaders today that Palestinian military activity in the southern part of his country was ''in violation'' of a commitment made by the guerrilla movement. He asked the Islamic leaders attending a conference in this mountain resort to use their influence in the problem.

title: China Medical Magazine Looking for Ads, Articles
description: After working for 15 years with corporations that supply the health-care field, Joel Martz decided to go out on his own and seek his fortune in underdeveloped China.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SEA LORE

title: OIL DECONTROL'S IMPACT ASSAILED IN JERSEY, NEW YORK AND CONNECTICUT
description: New Jersey's Energy Commissioner said yesterday that the order by President Reagan for immediate decontrol of petroleum prices would ''fan the fires of inflation.''

title: ST. JOHN'S, SPARKED BY PLAIR, WINS, 79-65
description: Ron Plair entered the game long before the outcome was determined, long before St. John's celebrated its 199th victory in Alumni Hall by beating Niagara, 79-65, last night. He came in with eight minutes left in the first half, when Niagara was leading, 14-13, on the Redmens' 20-year-old home court.

title: Pro-P.L.O. Newspaper Indicates Link to Guerrillas in El Salvador
description: The daily newspaper Al Liwa, which has close ties with the Palestine Liberation Organization, today indicated a link between Palestinian guerrillas and leftist guerrillas in El Salvador.

title: Wagner 51, St. Peter's 49
description: Wagner College, behind Jamie Ciampaglia's 3-point play with 2:03 remaining, rallied from a 43-36 second-half deficit to defeat St. Peter's College, 51-49, last night at Sutter Gymnasium.

title: Penguins 3, North Stars 1
description: Goals by Paul Gardner, Rod Schutt and Ron Stackhouse carried Pittsburgh over under-manned Minnesota.

title: TRAFFIC ENFORCEMENT SHIFT SCHEDULED IN CITY IN 1982
description: The force of 1,575 traffic enforcement agents who wear brown uniforms will be cut back next year to enable the city to hire additional police officers whose duties will include keeping an eye on traffic problems, Mayor Koch's office said yesterday.

title: First News Conference By President Set Today
description: President Reagan has scheduled his first news conference for 4 P.M. today in Washington. It will be televised live from the Executive Office Building, which is adjacent to the White House, and will be carried on the CBS, NBC, ABC and PBS networks, Channels 2, 4, 7 and 13 in New York.

title: HOMETOWNS GIVE FREED AMERICANS HERO'S WELCOME
description: The former American hostages fanned out across the nation yesterday to their homes in small towns and cities, and everywhere they were greeted as V.I.P.'s and heroes, with cheering crowds, brass bands, motorcades, champagne and red carpets.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN OPENS PARLIAMENT WITH CALL FOR ELECTION ON APRIL 29
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha called his first general election today, apparently in hopes of strengthening his hand within the dominant National Party.

title: Zero-Cost Loans Offered by Utility
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company won authorization today for a $650 million program that is believed to be the largest commitment ever made by a public utility to energy conservation incentives.

title: KENNECOTT AND CURTISS IN PACT
description: Ending their two-year feud, the Kennecott Corporation and the Curtiss-Wright Corporation announced jointly yesterday that they had signed an agreement providing that neither would attempt to take over the other for the next 10 years.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt AMERICA, LOST & FOUND. By Anthony Bailey. 152 pages. Illustrated. Random House. $9.95.

title: Back Rule on Breath Unit, Mine Safety Agency Told
description: The United States Mine Safety and Health Administration was ordered today by a Federal court to begin immediate enforcement of a requirement that all coal miners be equipped with 60-minute, oxygen-generating breathing devices.

title: DEVISED A CONVENTION USED IN BRIDGE GAMES
description: John Gerber, a notable figure in contract bridge, died yesterday in a Houston hospital following a heart attack. He was 74 years old and lived in Houston.

title: RICHARD LODGE
description: Prof. Richard Lodge, a member of the Adelphi University faculty who was on the board of directors of the American Civil Liberties Union, died Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital.

title: Tennessee 72, Georgia 67
description: Tennessee rallied twice from 8-point deficits in the first half, then played a slow-down game in the final four minutes tonight to beat Georgia, 72-67, in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: Former Jockey Is Sought After Missing Court Date
description: Jimmy Martin, a former jockey who secretly tape recorded a meeting with Eddie Belmonte, another former jockey, as part of a State Racing and Wagering Board corruption investigation, was being sought yesterday, after he failed to show up for a court appearance on a robbery charge.

title: NATHAN JACKSON
description: Nathan Jackson, a retired assistant general foreman of the composing room of The New York Times, died yesterday at a convalescent home in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 75 years old.

title: Bristol-Myers Net Up 15.7% in Period
description: The Bristol-Myers Company, a leading producer of drugs and toiletries, reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1980 increased 15.7 percent, to $71.4 million, or $1.08 a share, from $61.7 million, or 93 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1979.

title: WATER METERING FOR APARTMENTS IS BEING STUDIED
description: Mayor Koch directed the Buildings Commissioner and the Environmental Protection Commissioner yesterday to look into the possibility of requiring water meters in individual apartments in buildings under construction, yet to be built or undergoing largescale rehabilitation.

title: In Quest of Better Plays
description: As a top theatrical lawyer and an avid theatergoer for more than 50 years, L. Arnold Weissberger, has seen a lot of bad plays, too many, he says.

title: Three Mile Island Operator Is Cleared by Federal Unit
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today cleared the utility that operates the Three Mile Island atomic power plant in Pennsylvania of charges that it deliberately withheld information at the time of the accident there two years ago. But it said the operator had not provided the Federal agency with all the information that it should have at the time.

title: 1981 SHAPES UP AS BIG BERNSTEIN YEAR
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN was absent from the public eye during 1980, a year he devoted to composition, but this year he faces a hectic performing schedule that will see him conducting all over the globe. This week and next finds Mr. Bernstein at home with the New York Philharmonic, and tonight he leads the first of two programs devoted to American music, including the world premiere of Ned Rorem's ''Sunday Morning'' as well as Lukas Foss's ''Quintets,'' William Schuman's Third Symphony and several works by Aaron Copland.

title: WITH A BUDGET IN HAND, CAREY STUMPS TO CONQUER
description: Part comedian, part preacher, part politician, part statesman, part salesman, Governor Carey is here in Poughkeepsie, there in Rochester, last night in Syracuse, everywhere accessible, everywhere telling voters of the joys of his $16.2 billion budget and - between the lines of figures - about what a good job Hugh L. Carey is doing for New York.

title: Cleveland Suburb Wins A Stay on Desegregation
description: A Federal appeals judge has granted this Cleveland suburb a temporary stay of a housing desegregation order.

title: JURY HEARS MRS. HARRIS RECALL LOVE SHE CONTINUED TO FEEL FOR TARNOWER
description: Jean S. Harris wrote a bittersweet letter to Dr. Herman Tarnower a month before she was accused of murdering him. In it, she spoke of her deep affection for the cardiologist who had been her lover, while expressing contempt for Lynne Tryforos, who appeared to be taking her place.

title: EDUCATION SECRETARY PLANS CUTBACK IN STUDENT AID
description: Secretary of Education T.H. Bell declared today that the primary target in the Reagan Administration's efforts to reduce Federal spending in education would be loans and grants to college students.

title: 'DUBIOUS' REFORM IN EL SALVADOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Scholastic Putting Out An Electronics Magazine
description: Scholastic Inc., a big name among students and teachers alike, is no stick in the mud.

title: BOOTJACKS AND SCRAPERS; by Barbara L. Isenberg and Mary Smith
description: ABOOT scraper mounted near a door will help clean boots that are dirty from gardening or winter snow. They come in many styles and designs, from the very simple to fanciful animal motifs.

title: Treasury Sets Huge Borrowing;
description: The Treasury yesterday announced plans to sell $8 1/2 billion of new notes and bonds next week at auctions that promise to offer investors near-record yields.

title: Pan Am Service to China
description: A Pan American World Airways Boeing 747 left New York for Peking yesterday, the first scheduled New York-China service by a United States carrier since 1949.

title: Islanders Beat Toronto, 6-4; Islanders Win, 6-4, With Revised Lines
description: As promised, Coach Al Arbour mixed up his New York Islander lines tonight. As hoped, they produced six goals, three of them on their league-leading power play, and a 6-4 victory over Toronto at Maple Leaf Gardens.

title: Third Thoughts on Second Opinions
description: The idea was that a lot of patients could avoid the pain and expense of elective surgery if, when one doctor recommended an operation, they got a second opinion. Then came a study by Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York suggesting there may not be any savings at all. Some patients are dissuaded from surgery by a contradictory second opinion; but others, initially reluctant to go under the knife, find it harder to resist the urgings of two doctors. The net result may be more surgery, not less.

title: David Thomas, Character Actor; In 2,148 'Fair Lady' Performances
description: David Thomas, a character actor on the Broadway stage and a featured performer in the motion picture ''Roseland,'' died Tuesday in St. Clare's Hospital. Mr. Thomas, who was a resident of Manhattan, was 73 years old.

title: Sports of The Times; Joe Kuharich and His Extra Decade
description: FOR the last 15 years, Vince Lombardi has been credited by historians with proclaiming, ''Winning isn't everything; it's the only thing.'' But according to Morris Siegel of The Washington Star, that credo was uttered as long ago as 1954 by Joe Kuharich, then in his first season as the Washington Redskin coach.

title: by Claudia Wright
description: To those who have known the Saudi royal family well, the kingdom's foreign policies have scarcely changed from those of Abdel Aziz, the unifier of the state, who died in 1953. But to those indifferent to the personalities of the Riyadh court, who focus instead on issues such as oil production, economic development, weapons acquisition, and Israel, the Saudi stance has been decidedly less reticent and more aggressive in recent months.

title: Chrysler Says Talks Continue
description: The Chrysler Corporation, responding to a news report from Tokyo, said today that its 15 percent owned Japanese affiliate, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, had not rejected the idea of a joint venture.

title: HOUSE OF FRASER'S CHAIRMAN IS VOTED OUT
description: Sir Hugh Fraser today was voted out of his job as chairman of the House of Fraser, Britain's largest departmentstore chain, after heading the group for 16 years.

title: Rutledge's Testimony In Conflict
description: The former Arizona State football player who has accused Coach Frank Kush of harassing him made conflicting statements regarding one alleged incident with Kush, the coach's attorney pointed out in cross-examining the player today.

title: CONCERT: MUSICA SACRA PRESENTS HOVHANESS'S 'ST. PAUL' PREMIERE
description: ALAN HOVHANESS, it sometimes seems, wandered into our century by mistake. In a time when most composers of repute have been strenuously engaged in trying to write a few terse, immaculate pieces, Mr. Hovhaness has been churning out music as if his name were Telemann or Boccherini. A couple of years ago, his output of symphonies alone had reached 33, and perhaps the total has gone beyond that by now. Reference book editors have always been hardpressed to keep up with him.

title: John Keell Knights, 51; British Yachting Writer
description: John Keell Knights, one of the most widely-read and respected yachting writers, died Monday at his farm in Newport, Isle of Wight, England. Mr. Knights, who was 51 years old, suffered a massive heart attack.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: President of South Korea Starts 11-Day U.S. Visit
description: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea arrived here today for an 11-day visit to the United States during which he will meet President Reagan. He expressed the belief that the United States would continue to play ''a positive role'' in the defense of peace in the Pacific.

title: REAGAN SAYS TAX INCENTIVES MAY BE HURTING STATE
description: Tax incentives offered by New York State and promoted by Governor Carey to attract business may not be saving or creating jobs or bringing in new business, Comptroller Edward V. Regan reported today. He said the incentives could weaken rather than improve the state's economy.

title: Dorm Rates to Rise At State University
description: ALBANY (AP) - State University of New York students who live on campus will have to pay $150 more to stay in dormitories next fall, the State University's board of trustees has decided.

title: HORACE MANN TUTORS PUBLIC SCHOOL PUPILS
description: ON a Saturday morning, Robert d'Ambrosio, a red-haired, 15-year-old sophomore at the Horace Mann School in the Bronx, stood in front of his class. There were only two students.

title: Funeral Industry Reaches an Accord
description: Funeral industry representatives reached a contract settlement last night with pallbearers and hearse drivers, averting a strike threatened for midnight.

title: Firm Order for Liner By Holland America
description: Holland America Cruises said it had exercised an option to build a 32,000-gross-ton cruise liner, similar to one it ordered last October, for delivery in January 1984.

title: Market Place; Analyst Bullish On Rails, Coal
description: WHEN Wall Street discusses growth, it rarely mentions rails, though some in that transport group could post unusual gains in the years ahead. That, at least, is the thesis of Kenneth B. Smilen of Smilen & Safian, investment advisers and money managers in Wall Street.

title: No Headline
description: Strike activity in Britain in 1980 was at its lowest level in 39 years, the Government said yesterday. The Department of Employment said there were 1,262 work stoppages, the lowest total si [ TEXT OMITTED FROM SOURCE ] nce 1941 and less than half the 2,600 average for the past 10 years. The department's monthly Employment Gazette said about 12 million working days were lost, compared with 29 million in 1979.

title: No Headline
description: CHARLES J. DOLANSKY

title: Europeans Welcome Move
description: Trade tensions between the European Economic Community and the United States will be eased by President Reagan's decision to lift remaining price controls on domestically produced oil, sources on the Common Market's Commission said today.

title: Hero in Gas Leak Rescues Man in Fire
description: A police officer who capped a leaking propane truck on the George Washington Bridge last summer helped save a man from a burning Harlem apartment, the police said. A woman identified as Josephine Irazziri, 60 years old, leaped to her death from the same apartment.

title: GRAHAM WARNS ON ARMS AND 'DANGERS' IN TV EVANGELISM
description: The Rev. Billy Graham, in an appearance here before 2,500 evangelical Christians, spoke out tonight about the threat of a renewed arms race and warned about the ''dangers'' of television evangelism.

title: HAIG'S MISUNDERSTANDING OF POPULISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Rabbi Isidor Hoffman Dies at 82; Counselor to Columbia Students
description: Rabbi Isidor B. Hoffman, former counselor to Jewish students at Columbia University, died Tuesday at Waterbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Southbury, Conn.

title: SECRETARY LEWIS PLANS PANEL TO AID CAR MAKERS
description: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis said today that he would form and head a Government task force to help the ailing auto industry, but he pledged to support certain safety standards, such as the air bag requirement and restrictions on hazardous emissions.

title: Canada Oil Drop Foreseen
description: An industry organization said today that Canada's ability to search for oil and gas will drop sharply in the first half of 1981. It said the expected decline would result from the Canadian Government's energy policies and the existence of more attractive opportunities in the United States.

title: DEVELOPMENT UNIT TESTS AMBITIOUS NEW AGENDA
description: From the window of his 52d-floor office on Times Square, Richard A. Kahan can see bulldozers, toylike, bustling about the muddy Manhattan site of the new convention center. Farther south, through the haze, the top of a derrick shows above the sand of Battery Park City.

title: JUDGING HOW MUCH ADDED INSULATION YOUR HOME NEEDS
description: By installing insulation in areas of the house where there is none, or adding material in places where only a minimum amount was installed, homeowners can often substantially cut heat losses during cold weather. At the same time, they will lessen heat gains during the summer for homes where air-conditioning is used. In other words, adding insulation can save money on a year-round basis.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday about a forthcoming series of jazz concerts at Carnegie Hall gave an incorrect telephone number for Carnegie Credit Charge. The correct number is 247-7459.

title: REPUBLIC CLIMBS SHARPLY
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported a 44.6 percent rise in fourth-quarter earnings, to $55.8 million, or $1.28 a share, from $38.6 million, or 88 cents a share, for the similar quarter of 1979 .

title: Prime Off to 19 1/2% At Marine Midland
description: The Marine Midland Bank, the nation's 12th-largest commercial bank, cut its prime rate yesterday by one-half percentage point, to 19 1/2 percent.

title: Learning Firsthand
description: He hasn't even taken over yet, but the staff at the New York Public Library thinks it has the new board chairman all figured out. ''It's the journalist in him,'' said one staffer, explaining why Andrew Heiskell has been hanging around the library, looking over shoulders here and poking into corners there.

title: LETTER: ON PROVIDING JOBS
description: To the Editor:

title: Exxon Declares Dividend of $1.50
description: Directors of the Exxon Corporation declared a cash dividend of $1.50 per share of common stock for the first quarter and said they would ask shareholders to approve a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: WILDCAT WALKOUTS CONTINUE IN POLAND
description: Thousands of workers stayed away from jobs for a second day today in Poland's largest number of wildcat walkouts since last summer. The national leadership of the independent labor movement called an hour's work stoppage for Tuesday and threatened a nationwide strike to back its demands for a five-day workweek.

title: A 'No' From Buckley
description: In Switzerland primarily to write a book, but incidentally to escape British reporters trying to get him to comment on a certain persistent rumor, William F. Buckley Jr. yesterday had a few of his customarily well-chosen words that (1) seemed to lay the rumor to rest and (2) inserted a good-natured needle in an old ideological adversary.

title: SALVADORAN SPREADS WORD ABROAD: BACK THE REBELS
description: Guillermo Ungo's entire party, his detractors like to say, would fit into a Volkswagen and leave room for a chauffeur. And the Salvadoran Social Democrat himself, some admirers note sadly, is a well-intentioned man who is now being manipulated by Communists.

title: Oilers 9, Canadiens 1
description: Jari Kurri scored three goals and Ed Mio thwarted numerous Canadien shots as the Oilers routed Montreal, which dropped its fourth straight road game.

title: Trans Union Cites Merger Discussions
description: The Trans Union Corporation, whose shareholders are scheduled to vote Feb. 10 on a proposed merger with the Marmon Group Inc., disclosed in a special amendment to its proxy statement that it was pursuing merger discussions with an unidentified suitor.

title: Memorial Parks Increasing Ad Budgets
description: Television advertising has worked so well for Memorial Parks, which sells mausoleum space in New York and New Jersey, that the company is quadrupling its advertising budget.

title: Oil Decontrol Statement
description: Following is the text of the statement by President Reagan today ending price controls on crude oil, gasoline and propane and the allocation system for gasoline:
