title: TEXTRON IS TO SELL TALON, 2 OTHER UNITS
description: Textron Inc., one of the pioneer conglomerates, announced yesterday that it would jettison three operations that accounted for an estimated $260 million in revenues last year. The move will result in a $70 million after-tax writedown against 1980 earnings, the company said.

title: by Maggie Scarf
description: ABOUT six years ago, while gathering material for an article on sleep disorders, I learned how to self-induce body muscle relaxation with the aid of a biofeedback device. What this device ''feeds back'' to the sleep patient is ongoing information about the state of his or her own muscular tension.

title: RAY OYLER
description: Ray Oyler, the Detroit Tigers' shortstop in 1968, died Monday of a heart attack.

title: LITTON PLANS PUBLISHING GROUP SALE
description: Litton Industries, the giant diversified electronics company, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to sell its publishing division to the International Thomson Organization Ltd., the big Toronto-based publishing empire that has been aggressively increasing its American presence in recent years.

title: TREASURY WORKERS FILE CHALLENGE TO JOB FREEZE
description: The National Treasury Employees Union, in the first court challenge to President Reagan's freeze on Federal hiring, filed suit today to block the Reagan Administration's move to make the order retroactive.

title: VOLUME OFF
description: Stock prices fell yesterday after a rally attempt at midday failed to sustain any momentum. The Dow Jones industrial average, dropping 6.91 points, to 942.58, posted its seventh loss in the last eight sessions.

title: POOR FILIPINOS LOSE FARMS, THEN LIVES
description: In the Holy Week procession in the remote mountain village of Tanawan last year, Alexander Garsales, an impoverished farmer like nearly all the inabitants of the barrio 60 miles south of this provincial capital on Negros Island, had the part of Jesus. He bore the cross and acted out the stations that led to the passion.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: HOME SHOW ON L.I.
description: Long Island Home Show, Nassau Coli- seum, Uniondale, L.I.

title: Suit Over Bank Snub
description: A reputed ''pornography king'' who deals in books, magazines and films sued to block the Chemical Bank from canceling his accounts because of the nature of his business.

title: CELTICS BEAT 76ERS TO GAIN FIRST PLACE
description: The hoopla and anticipation of a big midseason match between the Boston Celtics and the Philadelphia 76ers culminated tonight when the Celtics registered their 13th straight victory and moved into first place.

title: Trunnion Troubles
description: The Flxible buses bought by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority have developed trunnion troubles to complicate their Aframe troubles. But Flxible and Grumman, its parent, are not the first to develop problem trunnions.

title: EXCERPTS FROM HAIG'S REMARKS AT FIRST NEWS CONFERENCE AS SECRETARY OF
description: STATE

title: Mrs. Humphrey to Wed
description: Muriel Humphrey announced in Minneapolis yesterday that she planned to marry Max Brown, a widowed businessman who was a classmate at Huron High School in South Dakota.

title: Virginia Turns Back Wake Forest, 83-73
description: Lee Raker scored 25 points, 5 on free thows in the last 45 seconds, and helped undefeated Virginia thwart a rally by Wake Forest for an 83-73 victory tonight.

title: Offers to Hostages
description: Tomorrow's ticker-tape parade for the freed hostages has meant a lot of extra work at New York's City Hall, but no one has been busier than Herbert J. Rickman, the mayoral aide who is in charge of approving gift offers for the city's guests.

title: O'Neils on the Move At General Tire
description: M. Gerald O'Neil, who turns 59 today, has been president and chief executive officer of the General Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's fifth-largest tire manufacturer, since 1960. His forthcoming assumption of the chairmanship from his 65-year-old brother, Thomas F., may have seemed anticlimactic to him, and he reflected that attitude in a telephone interview from his Akron headquaters.

title: WEST GEMANY EXPECTS SLUGGISH ECONOMY IN '81
description: West Germany's economy will shrink as much as 1 percent this year, the Government predicted today. It was the first official hint that a recession is likely.

title: Insider Reports for Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange. The report of changes follows: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: FRAMERS PUTTING MORE EMPHASIS ON PRESERVATION OF ART WORKS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Beverly Solochek is a freelance writer. By BEVERLY SOLOCHEK

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JANUARY 29, 1981
description: International Iran will not get military equipment or spare parts from the United States, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. declared. He urged American companies to exercise ''the most careful caution'' before resuming trade with Teheran now that sanctions have been lifted. Mr. Haig maintained a stern attitude toward both Iran and the Soviet Union at his first news conference since taking office. (Page A1, Column 6.) Iran spurned a new offer by Iraq to begin peace talks as Ayatollah Khomeini exhorted Iran's forces to press for ''total victory.'' (A4:3-5.)

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 29, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on drafting an in- ternational convention against the use of mercenaries - 10:30 A.M.

title: Kentucky 71, Mississippi St. 64
description: Sam Bowie, playing despite an injured hip, led a second-half rally that brought Kentucky to a 71-64 victory over Mississippi State in a Southeastern Conference game tonight.

title: S.E.C.'S FUTURE FOCUS IN DOUBT
description: In the fall of 1972, William J. Casey, then chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, followed the advice of an S.E.C. enforcement official, Stanley Sporkin, and rebuffed repeated pressures from the Nixon White House to slow a sensitive investigation into Robert L. Vesco, the financier.

title: PRESIDENT ABOLISHES LAST PRICE CONTROLS ON U.S.-PRODUCED OIL
description: President Reagan today abolished the remaining price and allocation controls on domestic oil and gasoline production and distribution, carrying out a pledge to end what the Administration regards as counterproductive Federal regulations of the oil industry.

title: CABARET:MIMI HINES AND LARRY KERT
description: THE producers Jerry Kravat and Harve Brosten have dug into one of the most delightful collections of Broadway songs for their latest songfest at the King Cole Room of the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel. It is called ''From Rodgers and Hart With Love,'' a group of 22 songs squeezed into less than 45 minutes, all of them so familiar and so warmly evocative that they almost sing themselves.

title: CITY BALLET: 'KAMMERMUSIK' AND 'OTHER DANCES'
description: THE New York City Ballet season continues apace, with more debuts and even more repertory staples reintroduced. George Balanchine's gasp-producing ''Kammermusik No. 2'' was seen for the first time this season Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, along with Jerome Robbins's ''Other Dances.'' Heather Watts made a debut as the lead ballerina in ''Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto No. 2.''

title: LILY TOMLIN:'SHRINKING WOMAN' STANDS TALL
description: AT this point in her movie career, Lily Tomlin is either standing tall or wasting away to nothing, probably both. Yes, Miss Tomlin's ''The Incredible Shrinking Woman'' is the film over which she has had the most control, and it may well follow her latest movie, ''Nine to Five,'' as a big box-office success. But in the new film, Miss Tomlin shrivels from her regular stature to three inches in height, and even suffers the indignity of being dropped into a garbage disposal, along with the kitchen scraps.

title: COLLEAGUES ABOLISH A BROOKLYN DEMOCRAT'S SUBCOMMITTEE
description: Representative James H. Scheuer, a Brooklyn Democrat, was deprived of a subcommittee chairmanship today when his Democratic colleagues abolished the panel.

title: O.M.B. Urges Drastic Cuts In American Foreign Aid
description: The Office of Management and Budget has proposed drastic reductions in United States foreign aid commitments, particularly affecting the poorer countries of Africa and Asia, according to a document circulated to the State and Treasury Departments.

title: South Carolina 90, Hofstra 72
description: Zam Fredrick scored 39 points to lead South Carolina to a 90-72 victory tonight over Hofstra here Wednesday night. Fredrick, a senior guard, scored 22 in the first half as South Carolina (12-7) took a 46-24 lead.

title: A 'TYPICAL' NEW YORK WELCOME FOR NATIVE SON AMONG HOSTAGES
description: Barry Rosen, the only freed hostage who calls New York City his home, returned yesterday for the first time in more than two years and pronounced that ''it's wonderful to be back home again.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The party line - students are fed up with it.'' - Krzysztof Przylinski, a student at Lodz University, on required courses on Marxism. (A7:1.)

title: Connecticut House Votes End of Grants
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill's proposal to close a state budget gap by canceling state grants of $23.8 million to Connecticut's cities and towns was approved 90 to 58 by the House of Representatives. The Senate is expected to approve the measure today.

title: Phillips Names Offense Coach
description: Coach Bum Phillips, who was dismissed by the Houston Oilers last month primarily because he had refused to hire an offensive coordinator, hired one today for his new team, the New Orleans Saints.

title: PROGRAMS TO DEVELOP SKILLS OF FATHERHOOD
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Barbara Lovenheim is a freelance writer. By BARBARA LOVENHEIM

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed Joe Nolan, c atcher, to a one-year contract; Nolan had f iled for arbitration. CHICAGO (NL) - Signed Gregory Trot- t er, pitcher, a second-round draft choice. CLEVELAND (AL) - Signed John D enny, pitcher, and Dave Rosello, infielder, t o one-year contracts and Ron Hassey, c atcher, to a three-year contract. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Signed John Wa- t han, catcher, and Jeff Twitty, pitcher. MINNESOTA (AL) - Signed Butch W ynegar, catcher, to a five-year contract. YANKEES (AL) - Signed Johnny Oates, c atcher, and Ed Darling, first baseman and o utfielder, to minor league contracts.

title: LESLIE GELB TO REJOIN THE TIMES
description: Leslie H. Gelb, a reporter and former executive with the State and Defense Departments, has been appointed national security correspondent in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, A.M. Rosenthal, the newspaper's executive editor, announced yesterday.

title: Widow of Ex-Texas Official Is Indicted in His Death
description: The widow of Price Daniel Jr., the former Speaker of the Texas House, was indicted tonight on firstdegree murder charges in his shooting death.

title: No Headline
description: Martina Navratilova gained the quarterfinal round of a $200,000 Avon tournament tonight with a 6-1, 6-4 victory over Wendy White.

title: Industry Welcomes Decontrol; Small Refiners, Dealers Worried
description: The oil industry yesterday hailed President Reagan's decision to immediately lift remaining controls from crude oil and gasoline, a step many industry leaders had been advocating for a decade.

title: REAGAN NAMES DIPLOMAT AND BUCKLEY TO KEY POST
description: President Reagan nominated Walter J. Stoessel Jr., the United States Ambassador to West Germany, and former Senator James L. Buckley to key posts in the State Department today and named 13 others to posts in his fledgling Administration.

title: KOCH OFFERS HOPE FOR RISE IN CITY SERVICES
description: Mayor Koch held out the hope yesterday that for the first time since the city's fiscal crisis began, New Yorkers could look forward to more rather than less service from city agencies.

title: BEST SKATING SPOTS FOR FIRST TIMERS OR DICK BUTTONS
description: ICE SKATING, the winter pastime that can transform any city dweller, young or old, into a country child, is in full glide. In New York City and its suburbs this time of year, there is good skating on ponds and lakes and on artificial rinks, indoors and out.

title: Massey Postpones Its Annual Meeting
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the debt-burdened Canadian farm machinery manufacturer, announced that its annual meeting, usually held in early March, had been rescheduled for April 28 to allow more time for completion of details on the lender-based portion of its proposed $720 million refinancing plan.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: Approved the s ale of two franchises: Chicago to a group h eaded by Jerry Reinsdorf and Eddie Ein- h orn for a reported $20 million and Seattle to a group headed by George Argyros for a re- p orted $12 million. CLEVELAND (AL) - Signed Rick Waits a nd Sid Monge, pitchers.

title: JOHN W. NIELDS
description: John W. Nields, a professor in the political science department of Sarah Lawrence College and a former partner of the New York Law firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel, died Tuesday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Huntington.

title: GALLERY HOPPING AROUND NEW YORK: A SATURDAY GUIDE FOR ART LOVERS
description: ''UPTOWN'' in the patois of the art world stands for the safe, the sure and the expensive. That isn't always true. Some uptown galleries have a downtown character: no velvet, no white marble, no clacking computer, no Ivy League trainees. Some downtown galleries are uptown in all but their location. But there's a general feeling that whatever is north of 57th Street must be big and solid. However, it is the charm of Madison Avenue that it contradicts itself at every turn, and that one and the same street turns out to harbor great masterpieces on the one hand, and things that would get the bum's rush in a thrift shop on the other.

title: Jazz 99, Rockets 97
description: Adrian Dantley scored 37 points and teammates Ben Poquette and Rickey Green sparked a fourth-quarter comeback that gave the Utah Jazz the victory over Houston. Houston led through most of the game and at one point in the second quarter was up by 15 points. The Jazz took their first lead, 89-88, when Dantley scored with 5:20 remaining and held the lead the rest of the way.

title: Dome Plans A Canadian Subsidiary; Move Aimed at Higher Subsidies
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. and the Canadian Government announced an agreement yesterday through which the company will establish a new Canadian subsidiary and gradually increase its own Canadian ownership.

title: 10 MUSEUMS BID FOR WIDER AUDIENCE
description: TEN of New York's leading cultural institutions yesterday paraded their wares in hopes of attracting customers from the more than threescore community groups that were represented at the gathering in the Synod House of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 110th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Reforming The Reforms
description: Senator Alan Cranston of California has proposed that no more than a third of the delegates to the next Democratic National Convention be elected in primaries and pledged to a particular candidate. That would move perhaps too far in the right direction.

title: Bendix Sets Offer To Buy Own Stock
description: The Bendix Corporation said yesterday that it would purchase up to 4 million of its common shares for cash at an average price of $64 a share and that it was negotiating to sell its geological survey subsidiary, the United Geophysical Cororation.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday erroneously described an interview by The Detroit Free Press with Charles Jones, a former hostage. Mr. Jones said one hostage had delivered a note to a visiting clergyman, but he did not identify the hostage.

title: Friday; CUBAN JAZZ ON 52D ST.
description: Paquito d'Rivera, the alto and soprano saxophonist formerly with Cuba's leading jazz group, Irakere, has recently arrived in this country with a style of jazz notable for its strong African flavor. He will present his own group, Havana/ New York, tonight at 9:30 at Soundscape, 500 West 52d Street. Havana/ New York features Ignacio Berroa, drummer, and Daniel Ponce, percussionist, also newcomers to New York; Russel Blake, bassist, and Hilton Ruiz, pianist. David Amram, composer and musician, will appear as a guest artist. Tickets are $5. Information: 581-7032. TIMES SQ. LUNCH FARE

title: ALLEGHENY LUDLUM BIDS $500 MILLION FOR BLUE BELL
description: Blue Bell Inc., the nation's second-largest jeans maker, said yesterday that it had received an offer from Allegheny Ludlum Industries Inc. to purchase Blue Bell for approximately $500 million in securities.

title: No Headline
description: Rhode Island 78, UConn 75

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JANUARY 30, 1981
description: International Poland's labor crisis grew more grave as the authorities issued their sternest warning in six months of recurrent turmoil. Asserting that the country was threatened by anarchy, the Government warned that it was ready to ''take the necessary steps'' to keep factories operating. The Government and the independent union agreed to hold talks today in an effort to end a wave of wildcat walkouts. (Page A1, Column 3.) President Reagan denounced Moscow for reserving ''the right to commit any crime, to lie, to cheat.'' Officials said that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. had sent a message to Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, warning that a Soviet invasion of Poland could mean dire consequences for East-West relations. (A1:4-5.)

title: GOLD BELOW $500 IN LONDON
description: The price of gold fell as low as $485 an ounce here today - its first move below $500 in more than nine months. In later New York trading, however, gold for February delivery rose $8.80 on the Commodity Exchange Inc. to $515.80 an ounce, and the Republic National Bank quoted it at $513 an ounce, up $8.

title: THE CITY
description: The Board of Estimate, avoiding a fight over a package of $76 million in spending increases this year promised by Mayor Koch in his Jan. 16 financial plan, approved part of the increases deemed most urgent and agreed to consider the remainder at a special meeting on Tuesday.

title: ANOTHER SCHAYES STARS IN SYRACUSE
description: Four years ago, when it was time for Dan Schayes to choose a college, he decided to stay home and play basketball in Syracuse, the city where his father, Dolph, had been a 12-time National Basketball Association all-star with the Syracuse Nationals.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All of us should remember that the Federal Government is not some mysterious institution comprised of buildings, files and paper.

title: The Economy
description: President Reagan, warning of ''wildly skyrocketing deficits and runaway government,'' ordered a freeze on pending Federal regulations and abolished the Council on Wage and Price Stability. Speaking at his first news conference since becoming President, Mr. Reagan did not identify the targets of his proposed spending cuts, but he said those cuts are probably ''going to be bigger than anyone has ever attempted.'' (Page A1.)

title: Philadelphia Rejects Bond Bids
description: Philadelphia rejected all bids yesterday for its $60 million of general obligation bonds. The best bid for the Baa/BBB+-rated bonds set an interest cost of 13.21 percent, the highest rate investment bankers could remember for investment grade general obligation bonds.

title: U.S. Seeks Delay in Bell Suit; Administration Not Yet Briefed
description: The Justice Department asked United States District Court Judge Harold H. Greene late today to put off, for one month, the Feb. 2 deadline he set for the Government and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to present the final terms of an out-of-court settlement of the Government's antitrust suit against A.T.&T.

title: REAGAN AGREES TO MEETING ON CHILD SLAYINGS IN ATLANTA
description: President Reagan said today that a meeting would be held soon with city officials here to discuss what role the Federal Government might play in helping the city solve the case of Atlanta's murdered and missing children.

title: Index; International
description: Murders bring fear to Protestants on Ulster border A2 Japan plans to double foreign aid over five years A2 Marcos plans presidential elec- tions this year A3 Around the World A6 Iranians show journalists films of hostage interviews B6 Government/Politics Cedar Rapids, Iowa, hopeful about Reagan Administration A8 Reagan agrees to arrange meet- ing on Atlanta slayings A8 Reporters subdued at first Rea- gan news conference A13 Senate committee approves Dono- van to be Secretary of Labor A14 Reagan names Ambassador and Buckley to State Dept. posts A17 D'Amato to fill up to four Federal judgeships immediately B3 Koch holds out hope for more rather than less city services B3 Carey urges restoration of old power plants in state park B3 General Around the Nation A9 The man who looked for seed in ad for ''grass'' B3 Seventeen ex-hostages are cap- tives on flight to New York B6 Weekend Weekender Guide C1

title: WATER FOR THE ASKING
description: To the Editor:

title: TEST FLIGHT FOR AIRLINE DECONTROL
description: A British Airways ticket from London to Rome costs $513. But passengers from London to New York -more than twice the distance - pay only $424 for the same airline's regular economy class. And if they reserve in advance or risk standby status, the London-New York fare can be as low as $175.

title: SHIFTING OF CARS FOR THE D LINE CALLED POLITICAL
description: f814 By JUDITH CUMMINGS

title: Jet Coaching Duties Juggled by Michaels
description: The Jets, whose 4-12 record tied for the second worst in the National Football League last season, juggled their coaching staff yesterday. They made Joe Gardi the defensive coordinator, hired Bill Baird, a starter in the 1969 Super Bowl for the Jets, and shuffled the assignments of four other assistants.

title: SOVIET REBUTS U.S. CHARGE ON HOSTAGES
description: Responding to American protests, the Soviet Union today defended its stand on the hostages released by Iran and accused the United States of keeping the issue alive as a pretext for a naval buildup in the Persian Gulf.

title: Garden Offers Bout to Duran
description: Roberto Duran, who announced his retirement Nov. 22 after losing the World Boxing Council welterweight title to Ray Leonard, is being wooed back to the ring by two promoters.

title: Warriors 117, Pistons 112
description: Bernard King, Lloyd Free and Joe Barry Carroll accounted for 88 points as Golden State rebounded from an 18-point deficit.

title: Teleprompter Sale Backed by F.C.C.
description: Federal authorities have approved a temporary waiver allowing the Westinghouse Electric Corporation to purchase 30 percent of the stock in the Teleprompter Corporation.

title:
Sports of the Times;
Belated Wishes
description: JOE CRONIN, the most valuable player in a league that didn't have a most valuable player, and Babe Herman, who brought off the master stroke of hitting .393 without winning a batting championship, will hear cheers Sunday night that they should have heard half a century ago. As special guests of the New York Baseball Writers at their annual midwinter hog killing, Cronin and Herman will receive ''You Could Look It Up'' Awards for achievements that never got their due.

title: HAIG WARNING ON POLAND DISCLOSED
description: President Reagan accused Soviet leaders today of reserving ''the right to commit any crime, to lie, to cheat,'' and his Administration disclosed a tough American message warning of dire consequences for East-West relations if Soviet troops invaded Poland.

title: PER SPOOK: A SPARE FRESHNESS
description: A Norwegian designer, Per Spook, gave a lift to the French couture showings this morning with a collection that was not meant for outer space or pre-revolutionary (any revolution) aristocratic balls. Let other designers toy with 18th-century hoop skirts or 19th-century bustles; Mr. Spook keeps his eye firmly on the present.

title: Jersey Senate Votes Gun Compromise
description: The New Jersey Senate voted 35 to 0 to impose mandatory sentences on persons convicted of using a gun in the commission of a crime.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: A N abacus would have been required to keep count, the courses were so numerous. To get a head start in celebrating the Chinese New Year 4679 - the year of the Rooster - which begins next Thursday, Sam Wong invited a dozen or so friends and relatives the other night to banquet at the Hunan Garden in Chinatown.

title: CAREY PROPOSES RESTORATION OF STATE PARK POWER PLANTS
description: Governor Carey today proposed using small, abandoned hydroelectric power plants within the Adirondack Park in upstate New York to help meet the state's electricity needs.

title: OFFER ISLAMIC PEACEKEEPING TROOPS
description: After a four-day conference that ended early today, leaders of 37 Islamic countries and the Palestine Liberation Organization called for an immediate cease-fire in the war between Iraq and Iran.

title: Crime on Subways Up 17% Last Year
description: The Transit Authority reported that major crimes in the New York City subway system increased by 17 percent last year to 13,675, compared with 11,678 in 1979.

title: STAGE: 'EMINENT DOMAIN,' STORY OF AN AMERICAN FAMILY
description: with the wry literary allusions and the craftily constructed defenses that are endemic to his nature. Alcohol fuels his colorful stream of conversation, and his personal life is as disarrayed as his rabbit warren of a study.

title: U.S. AGENCY DISAVOWS FORECAST OF QUAKES
description: The United States Geological Survey has repudiated predictions by two American Government scientists that three violent earthquakes would occur in Peru this year.

title: SENATE IN CONNECTICUT REJECTS O'NEILL'S PLAN FOR BALANCING BUDGET
description: The State Senate tonight rejected Gov. William A. O'Neill's proposal to erase a state budget deficit by eliminating $23.8 million in state grants to cities and towns. The vote was a stunning setback for the new Governor's first legislative test.

title: Celtics' Streak Ends At 13 as Bulls Win
description: Reggie Theus scored 22 points tonight as the Chicago Bulls ended Boston's 13-game winning streak by trouncing the Celtics, 108-85.

title: Short-Term Rates Edge Lower; Prices Recover On U.S. Issues
description: Short-term interest rates declined slightly yesterday, but analysts said that a drop in the rates over the last week had not caused any heavy flow of investor funds into the long-term bond market.

title: SHARP DECREASE IN U.S. REPORTED IN TOXIC SHOCK SYNDROME CASES
description: Toxic shock syndrome, the rare but sometimes fatal disease that strikes primarily at young women who use tampons, appears to have declined dramatically in the United States during the last months of 1980. Between the end of September and the end of the year, the number of new cases reported monthly and verified by the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta fell by more than 60 percent.

title: Dow Closes Up 6.31; Gold Issues Surge
description: Stock prices finished moderately higher yesterday as many investors anticipated positive economic news from President Reagan's late-afternoon news conference.

title: ABC and Hearst Set Up Women's Cable TV; ABC and Hearst Set Up Cable TV Unit for Women
description: ABC and the Hearst Corporation yesterday announced that they would set up a network for cable-television systems aimed at women. Subjects covered would be careers, money, fashion, health and ways of life.

title: No Headline
description: Relatives of Fawn Brodie Dispute Statement on Excommunication

title: KALMAN MOLNAR
description: Dr. Kalman Molnar, a Manhattan physician and a former president of the eastern district of the American-Hungarian Federation, died Sunday at the DeWitt Nursing Home.

title: Many Deaths Reported In Peru-Ecuador Conflict
description: Peruvian and Ecuadorean troops fought today at a remote border outpost in the Andes in the second day of their frontier conflict. Large numbers of dead were reported on both sides.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: The Kawasaki Motors Corporation will spend $3 million to $4 million to recall 16,500 snowmobiles and will also pay a $90,000 penalty to settle a case brought by the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title: STEREOTYPE STEREOTYPE
description: The dramatic Washington-Algiers-Teheran negotiations that climaxed in the release of the 52 hostages give rise to speculation about the tones and overtones of international, especially inter-regional, conflicts.

title: TRANSCIPT OF PRESIDENT'S FIRST NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC TOPICS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference yesterday in Washington, his first since becoming President, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Biosearch Medical Products registered 1.2 million common shares with the Securities and Exchange Commission, to be offered through underwriters headed by Fittin Cunningham & Lauzon Inc.

title: News Analysis; REAGAN PUTTING HIS STAMP ON U.S. POLICIES: AT HOME AND ABROAD, A CHANGE OF COURSE
description: In accents as well as actions, in his denunciation of Soviet behavior around the world as well as his demands for budget austerity at home, President Reagan has begun to signal a break from the more moderate style and substance of the Carter era.

title: No Headline
description: Winter has come back to Cedar Rapids after a January thaw. The ice is set again in the Cedar River. And the winds off the open prairies have an angry bite.

title: Track to Train Nonunion Help
description: Nonunion clerks will be recruited to operate the parimutuel machines at Roosevelt Raceway, the president of the track, William B. Hopkins, announced yesterday. ''Training for these positions will start immediately,'' he said.

title: Mrs. Schlafly Faulted for Her Religious Views
description: A four-day Bible conference organized by the television evangelist James Robison had hardly begun in Fort Worth when a prominent fundamentalist Baptist leader withdrew to avoid appearing with Phyllis Schlafly. But it was Mrs. Schlafly's religion, not her position as a leading opponent of the proposed equal rights amendment, that Dr. Curtis Hutson found at fault.

title: KERT SINGING RODGERS & HART QUIETLY
description: LARRY KERT has a close feeling for the songs of Stephen Sondheim. He made his Broadway debut as Tony in ''West Side Story'' in 1957 and played the role for three years, singing Mr. Sondheim's lyrics. A decade later, when he had his next success playing Bobby in ''Company,'' for which he received a Tony nomination, he was again singing Sondheim songs.

title: PEARL HARBOUR RETURNS
description: Pearl Harbour and the Explosions blew into New York from San Francisco in 1979 with a debut album on Warner Bros. Records, a popular single called ''Drivin','' a danceable pop-rock sound with astringent edges and a fast, furious stage show that focused on Miss Harbour. She sang winningly, danced fluidly and commanded large stages with insolent ease. Everyone expected to hear more from her, but the Explosions disbanded early last year because of musical differences, and Miss Harbour moved to London, where she set about rebuilding her career from the ground up.

title: SUAREZ REIGNS AS SPANISH PRIME MINISTER
description: Adolfo Suarez, who has led Spain toward democracy since 1976, announced his ''irrevocable'' resignation as Prime Minister today.

title: WOMEN BID SENATE ACT ON BIAS
description: A dozen leaders of the women's movement asked the Republican-controlled Senate yesterday to redeem the party's campaign pledge and enact legislation to end sex discrimination in the marketplace.

title: ST. PATRICK'S RESOUNDS TO CHEERS FOR EX-HOSTAGE
description: Barry Rosen, the former hostage, asked the Senate to investigate the decision to allow the Shah of Iran into the United States, and another returned hostage, Michael Metrinko, gave a graphic account of his ordeal. Page B6. By WILLIAM G. BLAIR

title: Advertising; A Starring Film Role For Ogilvy
description: DAVID OGILVY, his great ego undiminished by the fast approach of his 70th birthday, says, ''I'd like to be remembered as a copywriter who had some big ideas.''

title: 'Streetcar' in Russian
description: Tennessee Williams's ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' will be presented in Russian Sunday afternoon at 2 P.M. in the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Washington Heights and Inwood.

title: KNICKS CONQUER HAWKS, 114 TO 111
description: The New York Knicks almost ran away with the game in the first half, but they had to overcome a fourth-quarter letdown to beat the Atlanta Hawks, 114-111, tonight.

title: STAGE: MEMOIRS OF 'PILATE' BY BENTLEY AT 92ND ST. Y
description: ANEW perspective on the events leading to the Crucifixion constitutes the thesis of ''From the Memoirs of Pontius Pilate,'' a play by Eric Bentley now in its first production, by the American Jewish Theater at the 92d Street Y.

title: Steel Imports By U.S. Off 11%
description: United States imports of steel fell 11.6 percent last year, to 15.5 million tons from 17.5 million in 1979, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: EX-CAPTIVE TELLS OF LONG TIMES ALONE IN CRAMPED, FREEZING AND FILTHY CELLS
description: Michael J. Metrinko, one of the freed Americans apparently most abused by their Iranian captors, says he was kept in solitary confinement for long periods, part of the time in cramped, unheated prison cells while snow fell outside and the walls exuded a cold sweat.

title: Rep. Spellman to Get Therapy
description: Representative Gladys Noon Spellman, Democrat of Maryland, who has been semiconscious since a heart attack in October, has been transferred to Walter Reed Army Hospital in Washington for longterm care, therapy and new medical tests, aides say.

title: Chief Officer Is Named by R. Hoe & Co.
description: James A. Taylor, 62, a corporation executive and management consultant, has been named president and chief executive of R. Hoe & Company Inc. He succeeds Robert M. Corrao, 48, who resigned from the Scarsdale, N.Y., corporation ''for personal reasons.''

title: LILY TOMLIN, SHRINKING WOMAN
description: PAT KRAMER (Lily Tomlin) is an ordinary, upwardly mobile, southern California housewife, much like her brand-name-dropping neighbors in the suburban community of Tasty Meadows. She's happily married to Vance Kramer (Charles Grodin), a hot-shot advertising executive, has two bright children, one comic dog and one comic, non-Englishspeaking maid with national origins south of the border.

title: TOKYO TO DOUBLE ITS FOREIGN AID
description: Japan is planning to ''more than double'' its foreign aid in the period from 1981 to 1985 and will probably become the second largest donor, after the United States, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: POLISH REGIME SAYS 'CREEPING ANARCHY' THREATENS ECONOMY
description: Asserting that Poland was threatened by creeping anarchy, the Government said today that it was prepared to ''take the necessary steps'' to keep strike-bound plants going.

title: MARCOS PLANS TO HOLD PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS SEEKS 'FRESH MANDATE'
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, who ended eight years of martial law on Jan. 17, said today that he intends to run for President this year under a revised constitution, even if he is the only candidate.

title: Republic and Gulf Plan Coal Venture
description: The Republic Steel Corporation and the Gulf Oil Corporation announced an agreement to form a joint venture to own, operate and develop Republic's 83,000 acres of coal properties in Alabama.

title: THE PROPER MIX FOR A REVITALIZED SOUTH STREET SEAPORT
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkey Loan Extended
description: Western banks have told Turkey they will extend to 10 years from seven years the repayment term of more than $3.2 billion in loans that Ankara asked them to reschedule, banking sources said today. They said the 16 major banks, which met in London earlier this week, yesterday told Turkey's chief economic planner, Deputy Prime Minister Turgut Ozal, they would also extend the grace period to five years from three years.

title: Bridge: Visibility of All Four Hands Can Conceal Some Hazards
description: Some defensive plays that appear childishly simple with all four hands in view can be very difficult indeed at the table. In the diagramed deal, played recently in the Tristate Regional Championship in Port Chester, N.Y., the reader should cover the South and West hands and put himself in the East position.

title: Cheers for two after the return of 'Napoleon.'
description: THE two people who were most moved by the standing ovation that ''Napoleon'' received at its New York premiere last Friday were Abel Gance, the 91-year-old creator of the epic film, and Kevin Brownlow, the 42-year-old English film editor turned film historian who lovingly reconstructed the scattered fragments of Mr. Gance's 1927 silent film.

title: FROM WEST SIDE BARTENDING TO THE BAR IN 'INSIDE MOVES'
description: DAVID MORSE can be forgiven for being a bit tentative about success. There he was one ordinary evening, tending bar at a restaurant on the Upper West Side, and there he was the following morning at 7 being hustled over to a hotel to meet the director Richard Donner, and there he was, that afternoon being videotaped and tested and told absolutely not to cut his hair.

title: A SUNDAY FOR DR. KING
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada Group Bids For Abitibi Shares
description: Federal Commerce and Navigation Ltd., a Montreal-based shipping and energy group, said it planned to offer $27.50 a share for up to 2,250,000 common shares of Abitibi-Price Inc., a major pulp and paper producer.

title: DONATIONS TO NEEDIEST CONTINUE TO BE GIVEN IN MEMORY OF LENNON
description: The murder last Dec. 8 of John Lennon, the former Beatle, continues to evoke expressions of shock and grief that inspire contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: South African Blames U.N. Bias For Breakdown of Namibia Talks
description: Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said in Parliament today that a lack of impartiality by the United Nations was behind the breakdown of the conference on the independence of South-West Africa in Geneva this month.

title: DANCE: JOSE LIMON TROUPE OPEN 2-WEEK SEASON
description: DANCES created specifically for men and dances for women were in the spotlight Wednesday night when the Jose Limon Dance Company returned to the City Center for a two-week season that takes an unusual look at the modern-dance tradition of Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman, as reflected in the work of Mr. Limon.

title: No Headline
description: Mike Faulkner, the Giants' special-assignments coach, resigned yesterday after one season with the club.

title: 'Sugar Babies,' as Seen Through the Eyes of Joey Bishop
description: When Joey Bishop replaces Mickey Rooney on Monday night for a four-week engagement in Broadway's ''Sugar Babies,'' he won't just be taking the Rooney part in the nostalgic recreation of burlesque. The whole show is being reworked in the Bishop image.

title: Cavaliers 115, Suns 111
description: Mike Mitchell and Roger Phegley each scored 27 and Kenny Carr collected 26 points and 18 rebounds to lead Cleveland to victory over Phoenix.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Energy Department accused the Murphy Oil Corporation of $82.3 million in violations of Government price control regulations today - one day after President Reagan abolished the nine-year-old rules governing crude oil.

title: Jamaican Premier Reports Aid Accords With U.S.
description: Prime Minister Edward P.G. Seaga of Jamaica ended an official visit here today with the announcement of two agreements that he said were aimed at promoting economic cooperation and tourism for his Caribbean nation.

title: IRAN SHOWS VIDEOTAPE INTERVIEWS WITH 14 CAPTIVES AND ALL BUT 2 SAY
description: TREATMENT WAS GOOD

title: L.I. Project Manager Guilty of Extortion
description: The former site manager at a Long Island construction project was found guilty of charges of extortion and attempted extortion that could bring him up to 20 years in prison.

title: Strike Squeezes Small Stables
description: When Roosevelt Raceway is operating, Duke Mayo explains, he has to scrounge to make a living. When it is closed - as it has been for four nights this week by a strike of parimutuel clerks - he must sell some of his horses to survive.

title: Key Rates
description: Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday incorrectly stated the position of Janet L. Norwood, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, on proposed changes in the Consumer Price Index. A clarifying article appears on page A10.

title: REDUCE FUNDING; LET THEM COMPETE
description: For millions who struggle to ride commuter trains, it was startling to hear Secretary of Transportation Andrew L. Lewis Jr., during his confirmation hearings, call for a reduction in Federal assistance to mass transit. Commuters could more easily accept cuts in Federal aid if they didn't have to ride the train to work.

title: Josef Adler, 90, a Concert Pianist Who Accompanied Noted Artists
description: Josef Adler, a concert pianist and teacher who accompanied such artists as Mischa Elman, Rosa Ponselle, Lily Pons and Eugene Ysaye, in New York City and throughout the world, died Wednesday in Lenox Hill Hospital. Mr. Adler, who was a resident of Manhattan, was 90 years old.

title: HARLEM RECALLED AND A VISIT TO THE AFGHANS
description: FOR four consecutive nights, beginning Sunday at 10 o'clock, the ''Non Fiction Television'' series on WNET, Channel 13, will explore the history and personality of Harlem, perhaps the world's most famous black neighborhood. ''I Remember Harlem'' is a film by William Miles, the producer of an earlier documentary on the black 369th Infantry Unit that fought under the French flag in World War I. The script was written by Clayton Riley and is narrated by Adolph Caesar.

title: LOUIS CARDINALI DIES: RAN SOUTHERN REGION FOR AVIATION AGENCY
description: Louis J. Cardinali, a New Yorker who capped a 30-year career in the Federal Aviation Administration by becoming chief of the agency's Southern Region 16 months ago, died Wednesday at Georgetown Hospital in Washington after suffering a stroke on Jan. 15.

title: Training Camps Planned For Jewish Self-Defense
description: Secret training camps to teach Jews to protect themselves against anti-Semitic attacks will be established on the West Coast, New York and Michigan, a Jewish leader said today.

title: Market Place; Phone Terminal Suppliers Favored
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S decontrol of domestic oil production and distribution on Wednesday is part of his policy of reducing regulations on business. Generally speaking, deregulation is welcome, but some businesses will find themselves in increasingly competitive circumstances, at least in the beginning.

title: The Lost Picture Show
description: Napoleon's place in history resists easy judgment. But that is no longer the case with Abel Gance, his cinematic eulogist. It has taken 54 years for a general audience in America to see his legendary film ''Napoleon'' in something like its original form - and at Radio City Music Hall, a theater equal to the film's grandeur. At 91, the French director has been ''rediscovered'' and is finally getting his due as one of the most versatile and ambitious of film pioneers.

title: IRAN AND THE 'LARGER AMERICAN INTERESTS'
description: To the Editor:

title: FREE FESTIVAL OF MUSIC OPENS AT JUILLIARD TONIGHT
description: The Juilliard School's Festival of Contemporary Music, which begins tonight at Alice Tully Hall, bears no stern evangelical message, no startling revelation about music's future. Its six concerts will stroll in a leisurely, almost random way through a whole collection of ideas, styles and techniques that have occupied composers over the last several generations.

title: MRS. HARRIS GIVES JURY HER VERSION OF WHAT LED TO DEATH OF TARNOWER
description: Jean S. Harris gave her version today of the shooting of Dr. Herman Tarnower, describing his death as the tragic aftermath of what was to have been a ''a few quiet minutes with Hy, for me to feel safe again'' before she killed herself.

title: SENATOR D'AMATO WILL IMMEDIATELY FILL UP TO 4 FEDERAL JUDGESHIPS
description: New York State's new Republican Senator, Alfonse M. D'Amato, will fill up to four Federal judgeships immediately. This compares with seven Federal judges whom Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a New York Democrat, has recommended in the four years he has been in the Senate.

title: Carey Asks Haig to Seek Release Of New York Woman Held in Iran
description: Governor Carey has implored Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to devote ''full energies'' toward gaining the release of Cynthia Dwyer of Buffalo, held captive in an Iranian prison for nine months.

title: PARADE TODAY
description: A ticker-tape parade honoring the former American hostages in Iran will begin at 11:45 A.M. at the Promenade at the Battery, and move up Broadway to City Hall. The police advise motor- ists to avoid the Brooklyn Bridge and lower Manhattan. Streets along the pa- rade route will be closed between 11 A.M. and 2 P.M., and Chambers Street will be closed from 9 A.M. to 2 P.M. Additional streets may be closed as conditions warrant.

title: Addenda
description: TV Guide magazine increasing its advertising rates 9.5 percent effective with the April 4 issue.

title: Grand Jury Said to Open Inquiry on Point-Shaving
description: A Federal grand jury has been impaneled in the Eastern District of New York to hear testimony concerning alleged point-shaving at Boston College during the 1978-79 season, according to a source close to the investigation.

title: The Profit of Despair
description: In LaVerkin, Utah, $39,000 will get you a small underground apartment with blast-proof doors, eight inches of concrete overhead and a four-year food supply stuffed into the walls and ceiling. (What it can't get you, of course, is a room with a view.)

title: Munsingwear Sale Of Stock Opposed
description: Tweedy, Browne Inc., a New York investment adviser that owns 10.9 percent of Munsingwear Inc. on behalf of clients, said that it would wage a stockholder fight against the underwear and sportswear maker to block a company proposal to sell some 30 percent of its stock to three Japanese marketing companies.

title: Woman Wins Suit Over Short Uniform
description: A Federal judge ruled that a lobby attendant in a Manhattan building had been wrongfully dismissed for refusing to wear a Bicentennial uniform in 1976 that was ''short, revealing and sexually provocative.''

title: XEROX NET RISES 11.3% TO RECORD
description: The Xerox Corporation reported yesterday that profits for the fourth quarter rose 11.3 percent, to a record $142.2 million, or $1.68 a share, from $127.8 million, or $1.52 a share, for the last quarter of 1979. Revenues for the quarter increased 19.3 percent, to $2.23 billion from $1.87 billion.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, Pittsburgh, has named Vincent G. Gioia general counsel and secretary.

title: Gulf Net Off 16.9% In the 4th Quarter
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings fell 16.9 percent, to $304 million, or $1.56 a share, from $366 million, or $1.88 a share in the comparable period a year ago. It cited the impact on refining, marketing and chemical operations of its higher-than-average crude oil costs.

title: Real Estate; Apartment Data Firms Under Fire
description: IN what they hope is the last decisive campaign of a war against apartment referral agencies - now called apartment information vendors - lawyers in the New York State Attorney General's office say they are preparing for a courtroom battle against a carefully selected group of alleged offenders, accused of fraud.

title: Miller Leaving SSC&B; Marschalk Fills Two Posts
description: Harold Miller, 56, executive vice president in charge of media and network programing at SSC&B, is retiring next month.

title: Benin Art at Grey Gallery Of N.Y.U. Until Feb. 21
description: More than 65 works of art from the city-state of Benin, now in Nigeria, are on view at the Grey Art Gallery and Study Center of New York University, 33 Washington Place in Greenwich Village. The exhibition, ''Images of Power: The Royal Court of Benin,'' consists mostly of works on loan from private collections in New York that are not generally accessible to the public.

title: STATE'S BANKS WARNED ON MOVING OUT
description: Fearing that New York's role as a domestic and international money center is in jeopardy, Anthony B. Solomon, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, warned the state's bankers yesterday against moving too much of their business outside New York.

title: Interviews Set for 75 Jobs That Drew Crowd of 26,000
description: Interviews at the national Social Security headquarters for 75 low-level jobs that drew about 26,000 applicants here last September are scheduled to begin next week despite the Reagan Administration's freeze on hiring for Government jobs, a spokesman for the agency said today.

title: U.S. Keeping Curbs; on Iranians, Acting Chief of Immigration Says
description: David Crosland, Acting Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said today that restrictions on Iranian nationals would remain in effect until the Reagan Administration decided to change them.

title: Lakers 118, Kings 104
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 35 points and moved into second place on the N.B.A. career field-goal list as Los Angeles turned back Kansas City. Abdul-Jabbar passed John Havlicek, the former Boston Celtics' star, with 2:47 left in the third quarter when he made one of his patented hook shots. It was the 10,514th field goal of his career, leaving him second only to Wilt Chamberlain.

title: No Headline
description: FIN K HED; COMPANY NEWS; Western Electric Expands

title: Curtiss Stock Offer
description: RIDGE, N.J., Jan. 29 (Reuters) - The Curtiss-Wright Corporation said holders who tendered Curtiss stock under its offer for one million shares at $46 each will be permitted to withdraw the shares before Feb. 5. Curtiss-Wright said the move stemmed from its transaction involving the sale of its subsidiary Dorr-Oliver Inc. and all of its Kennecott Corporation shares to Kennecott.

title: Burns Account to Fearon
description: Fearon/O'Leary got a good account for the 1980's, a client in a growth industry. It is Burns International Seurity Services, which had been at Marsteller and is expected to bill more than $1 million. The 71-year-old client has 171 offices worldwide and had sales last year of $220 million.

title: Maintaining Serenity
description: The MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, N.H., provides a peaceful setting for writers, composers and visual artists, who work in 42 secluded studios and cabins scattered over the 400-acre site.

title: 'TURTLE ON ITS BACK,' DROLL COMEDY ABOUT WRITER'S BLOCK
description: ''ONLY by wasting time can a writer discover his own sense of time.'' That's an early line from ''Like a Turtle on Its Back,'' a droll, intricate comedy by Luc Beraud about, of all subjects for a movie, writer's block. Paul (Jean-Francois Stevenin), who has not published anything in six years, is being interviewed by an American journalist for an article entitled ''The Long Silence.'' ''What is the function of the creative person?'' the interviewer asks. Neither Paul nor his friend Pierre, another specialist in first drafts, seems to have any idea.

title: Leach to direct musical on orphans going west by rail.
description: FROM 1853 to 1929, nearly 100,000 impoverished orphans who had no place to live but the streets of New York were transported to new families and new lives by the Children's Aid Society. These children were taken to homes waiting to welcome them across the country on a caravan of railroad cars known as orphan trains. This is the story that Dorothea Petrie, the writer and television producer, stumbled across a few years ago, and she was instantly hooked on its dramatic possibilities. In 1979, Mrs. Petrie produced a three-hour television drama called ''Orphan Train'' for CBS. Now she is at work producing another show called ''Orphan Train,'' this time a Broadway musical.

title: PLAN AIMS TO FREE REFUGEES IN JAILS FOR CRIMES IN CUBA
description: Justice Department officials are developing a plan under which some of the 1,700 Cuban refugees held in Federal prisons because of crimes committed in Cuba will be moved to a refugee camp and then released in the United States.

title: E.E.C. Inflation Rises to 13.8%
description: The rate of inflation in the European Common Market rose to 13.8 percent last year from 9.9 percent in 1979, the group's statistics bureau said today.

title: THE AD SAID, 'QUALITY GRASS,' BUT ONLY A CALLER WAS GREEN
description: The jogger spotted it during a run around the reservoir in Central Park. There, fastened to a tree, was a small, white business card that read: ''Quality Grass Delivered, Money Back Guarantee, (212) 689-1183.''

title: Several Refiners Raise Fuel Prices
description: Several major refiners raised wholesale fuel prices yesterday, a day after President Reagan ended price controls in the oil industry eight months ahead of schedule.

title: ORIGINAL SAVANNAH BAND GLITTERS ANEW AT THE FRITZ
description: DR. BUZZARD'S Original Savannah Band doesn't get together very often these days, and that's too bad. Back in the mid-70's, the Savannah Band combined danceable rhythms, a firm grasp of Latin popular styles past and present, a fondness for Broadway glitter and a visual flair that mixed idioms and eras as wittily as the music. During the last year, August Darnell has kept the Savannah Band spirit alive by performing as Kid Creole, with another Savannah Band member, Andy Hernandez, in his group, the Coconuts. But Kid Creole and the Coconuts just aren't as compelling as the Savannah Band, which made a rare appearance at the Ritz on Wednesday night.

title: Cooper at Bosendorfer
description: The pianist Kenneth Cooper will play a recital in the auditorium of the New York Times building, 229 West 43d Street, tomorrow night at 8. Mr. Cooper will be joined by Josephine Mongiardo in Schumann's ''Papillons.''

title: A BROOKLYN MAN ARRESTED FOR BID TO FREE PRISONER
description: A 36-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday on charges that he hijacked a helicopter on Sunday in an attempt to pluck a prisoner from the roof of the Federal jail in lower Manhattan.

title: CAREY ASKS SUPERMARKET SALES OF LIQUOR AND WINE
description: Governor Carey said today that he would back the sale of liquor and wine, in addition to beer, in New York State's supermarkets. And he proposed that some bars be allowed to stay open 24 hours a day to cut into the business now done by illegal afterhours clubs.

title: DENOUNCES SOVIET INTENTIONS
description: President Reagan, warning against ''wildly skyrocketing deficits and runaway government,'' today ordered a 60-day freeze on pending Government regulations, including some proposed by the Carter Administration in its final days. He also abolished the Federal agency that for six years has monitored wage and price increases around the nation.

title: Murder Plot Brings 60-Day Jail Sentence
description: A 43-year-old Brooklyn man who faced up to seven years in prison on his conviction of soliciting the murder of two relatives was sentenced to 60 days in jail and five years on probation.

title: ARNETT COBB AND THOSE TEXAN SAXES
description: WHEN Texas-born saxophonists blow, they rattle the rafters. As long ago as the 1930's, Texas saxophonists like Arnett Cobb and Buddy Tate were already masters of the stomping rhythms and throaty growls that rock-and-roll saxophonists would popularize a decade later.

title: Inquiry Reported at Colorado
description: As many as six members of the University of Colorado's football coaching staff are under investigation by the university for alleged misuse of school funds, The Denver Post reported today.

title: Nuggets 131, Bucks 118
description: Kiki Vandeweghe scored 12 of his 22 points in the final period, helping Denver beat Milwaukee for the Nuggets' third straight victory.

title: Savings Up In December
description: Savers deposited $2.1 billion more in savings and loan institutions than they withdrew in December, taking advantage of record interest on six-month money market certificates, the Government reported today.

title: IRONIC SOVIET CONCERN
description: To the Editor:

title: Money Funds Up $2.2 Billion for Week
description: The recent strong growth of the nation's money market funds continued in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: ALLIED CHEMICAL UP: DISTILLERS PROFIT SLIPS
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation, a diversified chemical concern, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980 rose 20.8 percent on an increase in sales of 11.5 percent.

title: Man, Crippled in Crash, Awarded $1.6 Million for Faulty Auto Axle
description: A Federal jury has awarded $1.6 million to an Indiana man who was crippled in an accident that he said was caused by a faulty axle in his 1971 Ford Maverick.

title: A.R.F. Head Steps Down
description: Edgar A. Roll, 51, for six years president of the Advertising Research Foundation, has resigned. ''I've done my thing for six years,'' he said. Mr. Roll had been with Dow Jones & Company, where he was circulation sales director of Barons and The National Observer.

title: COMMITTEE APPROVES LABOR NOMINEE DESPITE FIVE SENATORS' DOUBTS
description: The Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee approved the nomination of Raymond J. Donovan as Secretary of Labor today even though some Democrats on the committee expressed doubt that allegations that he had links to organized crime had been fully resolved.

title: Pan Am Building Gets New Manager
description: The title of vice president in the real estate financing department of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company may not seem particularly imposing. But the man just given that title at the big New Yorkbased insurance company, 37-year-old Thomas J. Sheehan, will also be responsible for the newly established Metropolitan Realty Management Inc. That makes him the person in charge of running one of the world's most identifiable structures -the Pan Am Building in Manhattan.

title: REPORTERS ARE MORE SUBDUED AT NEWS CONFERENCE
description: Ronald Reagan's first news conference as President yesterday was appreciably more decorous than most similar sessions in the last decade, in large measure because of a White House request that reporters not jump up and call out ''Mr. President'' to be recognized for a question.

title: SUIT ENDED ON SUPPLIES OF URANIUM
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday that they had reached an out-of-court settlement of their tangled antitrust litigation over uranium supply contracts.

title: SATURDAY'S GUIDE TO GALLERY HOPPING
description: THE art galleries of no other city in the world now rival those of New York. We already have more of them, and more seem to be opening all the time. They show a broader range of art - both of the present and of the past - than can be found in other cities, either in this country or abroad. In the abundance of new art that they regularly bring us, they define the contemporary impulses of our culture more vividly and more comprehensively than other cultural institutions.

title: Statistics Official Denies Report About Changing the Price Index
description: Janet L. Norwood, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said today that she had made no final decision about deleting the house-purchase component of the Consumer Price Index and replacing it with an estimate for rents.

title: MURDERS BRING FEAR TO PROTESTANTS ON ULSTER BORDER
description: Last Sunday afternoon, when they buried Sir Norman Stronge, a prominent retired politician whom Irish Republican Army terrorists said they had killed, the British Cabinet Minister responsible for Northern Ireland pointedly stayed away from the service in the little gray stone church here.

title: Pratt Engine Kits Ordered by Eastern
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. has placed a $130 million order for engine-performance improvement kits made by the Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Group, according to officials of Pratt & Whitney, which is a subsidiary of the United Technologies Corporation.

title: Accounts
description: Datatrol and Instrumentation Laboratories Inc. to Ingalls Associates, Boston.

title: From haute cuisine to brasserie style.
description: FEW restaurants have ever earned so instant a success as Le Chantilly when it opened on East 57th Street early in 1978. Well deserving of three stars right from the start, it continued to maintain that level despite the sort of overwhelming popularity that often defeats less experienced hands. If Le Chantilly is now slightly below its original level of excellence, it still maintains an average far above many haute cuisine French restaurants in the city.

title: GOV. URUKAGINA'S MESSAGE FOR MR. REAGAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Crosby Golf Put Off by Rain
description: When a rainstorm lashed the Bing Crosby National Pro-Am some years ago, Bing Crosby asked the Rev. John Durkin, one of the amateur players, ''Can you do something about this weather?'' Father Durkin replied: ''Sorry, Bing, that's up to management. I'm in sales.''

title: California Man Is Accused Of Murdering Jews in Latvia
description: The Government moved today to revoke the citizenship of a 66-year-old California man for allegedly concealing his involvement in the persecution and murder of Jews in Latvia in World War II.

title: Great Basins Sale
description: The Great Basins Petroleum Company said it was negotiating to sell all of its oil and gas properties in the United States, mostly for cash, to an unidentified party. Great Basins said details of the agreement may be announced by this weekend. The company said the potential sale included neither its uranium, coal and construction properties not its holdings in Canada.

title: Books
description: Fierce Originality By Anatole Broyard ELLIS ISLAND AND OTHER STORIES. By Mark Helprin. Delacorte/Seymour Lawrence. 196 pages. $10.95.

title: Renaissance in Ridgewood
description: An evening of Renaissance music will be presented tonight at 8:30 by the Pro Arte Chamber Singers and Calliope: A Renaissance Band at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church in Ridgewood, N.J. The concert, the second in a Pro Arte series, will feature sacred and secular choral pieces, including dances, madrigals and motets by Machaut, Dufay, Isaac, Praetorius and other composers of the 13th and 14th centuries. Tickets are $6 and $7.50 at the box office; $4.50 and $5.50 for students and the elderly. For more information: (201) 447-1500, extension 457.

title: IRAN AND THE 'LARGER AMERICAN INTERESTS'
description: To the Editor:

title: energywatch
description: JAN. 23, 1981 Fewer imports and greater refinery utilization resulted in a 3.4 million barrel drop in crude oil supplies, to 360.3 million barrels.

title: Mets and Zachry Agree To Terms on 5-Year Pact
description: Pat Zachry agreed to a five-year, $2 million contract with the Mets yesterday and solved two problems at once: His salary dispute will not go to arbitration, and he will not become a free agent at the end of the season.

title: RUTLEDGE ADMITS 2D CONFLICT IN STATEMENTS
description: Kevin Rutledge, former Arizona State football player, admitted under cross-examination today that he had made conflicting statements about whether the chin strap on his helmet was fastened when Coach Frank Kush allegedly punched him.

title: December Ad Pages Off; Revenues Up 4 Percent
description: Member publications of the Publishers Information Bureau carried 9,779 ad pages in December, a drop of 2 percent from December, 1979. Revenues were up 4 percent, to $254.3 million.

title: EX-HOSTAGE ASSAILS SHAH'S ENTRY TO U.S.
description: Barry M. Rosen, one of the Americans taken hostage in Iran, said yesterday that he hoped there would be a Senate investigation into why the Carter Administration allowed the deposed Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi to enter the United States in 1979 for medical treatment.

title: CONGRESS'S 'STALEMATE SYSTEM'
description: The 96th Congress departed with a record that was less than brilliant. It was unable to vote appropriations for much of the Government, which will thus be funded by continuing resolution. One program (foreign assistance) is in its second straight year of such fiscal purgatory. Even these lackluster results required marathon end-of-session bargaining that left even those individuals most directly involved sorting through the debris for days to find out what finally did happen.

title: ISRAELIS URGED TO ACT OVER BLACK HEBREW CULT
description: A group of black Americans led by Bayard Rustin has urged Israel to move quickly to resolve the status of the black Hebrew cult and to eliminate discriminatory practices against black tourists.

title: STEVE GOODMAN A SOLO AT CLUB
description: based singer-songwriter who headlined at the Bottom Line last Friday and Saturday, has had a respectable career spinning wry, urban folk vignettes, and his nostalgic tribute to the railroad era, ''City of New Orleans,'' is deservedly a modern standard. But on his latest record, ''Hot Spot,'' Mr. Goodman has opted for a more impersonal pop-rock approach.

title: A NISSAN AUTO PLANT IN BRITAIN
description: The British Government announced in Parliament today that Nissan, Japan's No. 2 car maker after Toyota, was planning to build an advanced technology automobile plant in Britain that would be capable, by 1986, of turning out 200,000 cars a year.

title: Big Bird, in Person
description: The great-granddaughter of one President and her cousin, the grandson of another President, had their chance Wednesday to look in awe upon Big Bird and his friends in person.

title: Harry W. Gribble, 90, Actor and Playwright Who Staged 'Lucasta'
description: Harry Wagstaff Gribble, director of the 1944 hit play ''Anna Lucasta,'' died Wednesday night in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived at 349 East 49th Street.

title: A.L. Owners Approve 2 Sales
description: Acting quickly and unanimously, the American League's owners approved the sale of the Chicago White Sox and the Seattle Mariners today.

title: Western Electric Expands
description: Western Electric, the manufacturing arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, formally announced plans today for construction of a $400 million electronics components plant in the Orlando area.

title: PUBLISHING: BOOK CLUBS DISCOVER HAROLD ROBBINS
description: HAROLD ROBBINS'S 15 novels have sold some 200 million copies, nine have been produced as motion pictures, and his publisher estimates that more than 40,000 copies of his novels are sold each day. Yet for all their commercial success, none of his novels were ever selected by a major American book club - until No. 16, ''Goodbye, Janette,'' which is scheduled for publication in the spring.

title: Dow Jones Earnings Up
description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings rose 42.4 percent, to $19.3 million, or $1.24 a share, from $13.6 million, or 87 cents a share in the same period of 1979.

title: SCHWEIKER IS CRITICAL OF PROGRAMS ON SEX COUNSEL AND CONTRACEPTION
description: Richard S. Schweiker, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said today that he did not think his department should promote sex education and that doctors treating poor, unmarried teen-agers under Medicaid should not be permitted to prescribe contraceptives.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Commonwealth Natural Resources Inc.'s shareholders approved the acquisition of the company by Columbia Gas System Inc.

title: Amram Jazz at Museum
description: The David Amram Quintet will play jazz Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

title: Ohio Mayor Asks State Aid As City Workers Stay Home
description: Mayor William Crabbe appealed to Gov. James A. Rhodes for help today, saying that businessmen were arming themselves and looters had cleaned out two stores since police officers and other municipal workers began calling in sick a week ago ago because of a labor dispute.

title: Carey Selects 2 For County Posts
description: ALBANY (AP) - Governor Carey named Edward Meyer to the post of Orange County District Attorney and nominated Catherine England to serve as Family Court judge in Suffolk County.

title: Stouffer's Offers $50,000 Fire Reward
description: The Stouffer Corporation announced a $50,000 reward yesterday for information leading to the arrest and arson conviction of the ''person or persons'' responsible for the fire in Stouffer's Inn in Westchester County on Dec. 4 that killed 26 people and injured 40 others.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt BLACK MOUNTAIN BREAKDOWN. By Lee Smith. 228 pages. Putnam. $10.95.

title: Toyota Ends Export Of Trucks to U.S.
description: Toyota, Japan's biggest auto maker, said it had decided to stop export shipments of its assembled small trucks to the United States beginning this month.

title: Storms Compel Indonesians To Halt Hunt for Survivors
description: Monsoon storms forced the suspension today of the search for nearly 400 people missing from an Indonesian ship that sank in flames in the Java Sea, and officials said it was feared that there were no more survivors.

title: 17 FORMER HOSTAGES MADE PRISONERS OF A SORT AGAIN
description: Seventeen former hostages became captives again yesterday when journalists twice their number were also issued tickets aboard the DC-9 plane flying the group to New York City for a ticker-tape parade.

title: Chinese Jurist Defends Trial of 'Gang of Four'
description: A leading Chinese jurist said today that the ''Gang of Four'' trial heralded a new era of law and order.

title: REAGAN REJECTS REVENGE ON IRAN AS UNWORTHY OF U.S.
description: President Reagan rejected today as unworthy of the national character any revenge against Iran. He declined to say what actions he might take to enforce his promise of ''swift and effective retribution'' against future acts of terrorism against Americans.

title: Aide Spurned by Reagan Named to N.L.R.B. Post; The Washington Star
description: In a move that has surprised business and President Reagan's conservative supporters, the National Labor Relations Board has appointed a former board member, John C. Truesdale, as its executive secretary.

title: Taming the Inflation Monster
description: In his first news conference yesterday, President Reagan could hardly have been more emphatic about his determination to control the inflation monster. ''I do not intend to make wildly skyrocketing deficits and runaway Government simple facts of life in this Administration,'' he said. Instead, he will cut taxes and cut back Government spending; no caretaker Presidency for him. So much, then, for the back-room battling within his Cabinet over which to cut first, taxes or spending. The truth is that Mr. Reagan must do both. And the question is whether, even together, the cutbacks will do the job.

title: MUSICAL: 'JOAN CRAWFORD,' ONE MAN'S IMPRESSION
description: THERE'S no real reason a male actor should not play Joan Crawford; there's no real reason he should, either. "An Evening with Joan Crawford," a ramshackle musical at the Orpheum, is a kind of vanity production for its star, Lee Sparks. He is an accomplished female impersonator, and the show drapes itself around his shoulders. There is no more to it than that, and the musical is distinguished not so much by what is on stage as what is not: no book, no score, no acting. It is animated gossip column of the more trivial kind.

title: Shell, B.P. Seen Buying Iran Oil
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell group is to buy about 100,000 barrels a day of crude oil from Iran under an accord that puts the group back into the Iranian market after a nine-month absence, oil industry sources said today.

title: ASSESSMENTS IN CITY TAKE A RECORD LEAP
description: Real-estate assessments in New York City have shown the highest one-year increase ever, rising about 10 percent in the last year, according to the city's Department of Finance. The vast majority of the increases came from commercial properties in midtown Manhattan.

title: Economic Scene; Reagan's Plan Falls Into Place
description: TREASURY Secretary Donald T. Regan's testimony before the Senate Appropriations Committee this week delighted the supply-siders, who can now hail him as one of their own. Mr. Regan said tax cuts ''can't wait until budget outlays are reduced.'' The tax cuts were essential to stimulate economic growth, which would help increase Government revenues and reduce Federal borrowing.

title: MUSIC: BERSTEIN LEADS 3 WORKS BY COPLAND
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN returned to lead the New York Philharmonic last night after a sabbatical year devoted, we are told, to composition. The orchestra's Laureate Conductor was just about as you remember him, only more so, full of beans and leaping about in the patented Bernstein manner. Whatever else he does, Mr. Bernstein provides a lively show. On this occasion, his cavorting happened to get in the way of the music as often as not. It was rarely possible to ignore his charismatic presence - by rhythmic bobbing and jerking he even managed to steal the show from Stanley Drucker during the soloist's cadenza in Aaron Copland's Concerto for Clarinet. Mr. Bernstein knows better than that, but he obviously was keyed up for his return to the Philharmonic.

title: SAVING FUEL AT HOME-THE UNADVERTISED WAY
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Oregon State Defeats U.C.L.A.

title: Jewel Ends Service
description: The Jewel Companies announced it would discontine its Jewel home shopping service, which distributes groceries and general merchandise in 42 states, and transfer the assets to a cooperative organization to be formed by certain of its employees. Jewel said it expects to provide an after-tax reserve of about $7.5 million, or 66 cents a share, in its fiscal year ending Jan. 31 for write-off of the assets and other costs related to the transaction.

title: 'Tribute to Pavlova' at Theater of Riverside; 'Tribute to Pavlova' At Theater of Riverside
description: In celebration of tomorrow's 100th anniversary of the birth of the ballerina Anna Pavlova, ''Tribute to Pavlova,'' a portrait in dance produced and directed by George Daugherty, is being presented this weekend at the Theater of the Riverside Church. The production, revised since its debut last August at the Lincoln Center Festival, now incorporates spoken dialogue between dance sequences.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 30, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on Namibia - 11 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Mrs. Thatcher Detects No Sign Of Moscow's Interest in Detente
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said tonight that she detected no sign of genuine Soviet interest in detente.

title: AVCO: AN UNWORRIED SUPPLIER
description: While the Chrysler Corporation's bankers, suppliers and workers are hoping for the best in helping the company sell $400 million of Government-guaranteed notes, one supplier - the Avco Corporation - seems more sure of the future than most of the others.

title: IS SMOKING ON STAGE HAZARDOUS TO THE THEATER?
description: A FEW months ago an editor suggested that I make note of the cigarette smoking that goes on in our plays nowadays. Cigarette smoking has, of course, long been one of the theater's most powerful means of expression. Whenever an actor wanted to indicate nonchalance, nervousness, wisdom, ignorance, furtiveness, candor, depression or exhilaration, he elaborately lighted up. Similarly, if a director couldn't think of any other reason for having a character sit down, stand up, cross the stage or stand utterly still, he was again instructing the performer to fish out a pack, tap a cigarette out of it, insert it between his lips while continuing to talk, and then create additional dramatic excitement by waving the match in midair until it went out and by exhaling as spectacularly as possible.

title: AUCTIONS
description: SOTHEBY PARK BERNET'S series of American Heritage auctions continues today at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. and tomorrow at 2 P.M. at the house's York Avenue Galleries, at 72d Street. Up for sale in the auction, held in association with American Heritage magazine, are 670 lots of folk art and furniture. This morning's session includes quilts, hooked rugs, scrimshaw, watercolors, carvings and weather vanes. The most important of these are a weather vane of an Indian poised to shoot a bow (estimated to bring as much as $18,000), a carved and painted wooden sea bird (up to $12,000) and a painted wooden eagle with spread wings, grasping a furled American flag (up to $15,000). The stars of the sale are in tomorrow afternoon's furniture session, and the top lot is a superbly carved New York Chippendale mahogany tea table, its serpentine top fitted with a fret-carved gallery (up to $150,000). Notable, too, is a Philadelphia Chippendale highboy (up to $100,000), formerly in the collection of George Horace Lorimer, long-time editor of the Saturday Evening Post and a collector of American furniture. After Mr. Lorimer's death a decade ago, the highboy was donated to the North Museum of Franklin and Marshall College in Lancaster, Pa., which has consigned it to Sotheby's. Also of interest is a Connecticut secretary-bookcase carved in cherry in the Chippendale style, with a block-and-shell front. There are, in addition, 400 lots of furniture from the collection of Leon F.S. Stark, a retired Philadelphia antiques dealer.

title: TISSUE PAPER FASHION: IS IT AN ART?
description: An exhibition of fashion in an art gallery always seems to bring up the question whether fashion is really art. Often, the question is irrelevant - as it is in the Julio show now at the Institute for Art and Urban Resources.

title: CRISPNESS FAILS TEST
description: ''Bran Chex taste crispier'' is the message of a television commercial for a new breakfast cereal. At the risk of offending a highly paid copywriter, and probably a good segment of the eating public, it seems pertinent to point out that ''crisp'' is not a flavor and, therefore, it cannot be ''tasted.''
