This peculiarly American notion that crispness can be tasted is not new; at least eight years ago while touring the Gorton Group's fish-processing plant in Gloucester, Mass., I was given a sample of fried fish along with the question, ''Tastes crispy, doesn't it?''

title: CONAGRA POSITIONING FOR FUTURE
description: Charles M. Harper calls the food industry ''the one bright spot'' in the American economy. That view underscores Mr. Harper's outlook as president and chief executive officer of Conagra Inc., the food processor that he has helped guide onto a long-range growth path. The latest evidence of that emphasis on growth within the food industry was Conagra's announcement today of its purchase of the Singleton Packing Corporation, a Florida shrimp processing company, for an undisclosed sum, and its previous acquisition of Banquet Foods Inc., for about $50 million, from RCA in November. Singleton has annual sales of approximately $100 million.

title: Iran Reports Attacking Main Iraqi Oil Terminal
description: Iran said tonight that its planes had attacked Iraq's main oil-loading terminal, the Persian Gulf port of Fao.

title: NEHEMIAH TRIUMPHS TWICE, BREAKS MARK
description: Renaldo Nehemiah bettered his worldbest time in the 50-yard hurdles tonight and won the event in 6.01 seconds at the Sunkist invitation track and field meet. His previous best for the event was 6.04.

title: JINGLE OF CASH LETS TOWN GIVE JET ROAR A DEAF EAR
description: One hundred fifty times a day in this otherwise quiet town of 4,500 people, homes rattle and visitors pause nervously. Outside town, herds of cattle appear to stir knowingly. The reason is that an airline crew is practicingtakeoffs and landings in a Boeing 747.

title:
Patents;
4 Selected For Hall Of Fame
description: WASHINGTON FOUR new members will be inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame at ceremonies in the Patent and Trademark Office, Arlington, Va., on Feb. 8. They were selected by representatives of 27 scientific and engineering societies for important technological advances covered by United States patents.

title: Your Money; Measuring Cost Of Checking
description: SINCE commercial banks were permitted to pay interest on checking accounts at the start of the year, the forest of options facing consumers has considerably thickened. For one, the lifting of the 47-year-old restriction on commercial banks has blurred many of the differences between them and the savings and thrift institutions.

title: NORWEIGIAN PREMEIR QUITS AFTER 5 YEARS
description: Prime Minister Odvar Nordli, under political attack within his own Labor Party for agreeing to stockpile United States weapons in central Norway, resigned today after five years in office. He cited reasons of health.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 47. 1. Using a net and a fire extinguisher, the New York City policemen pictured above are practicing a new departmental procedure. Explain. 2. ''To paraphrase, I think never has so small a group owed so much to so many.'' Who made this remark and what were the circumstances? 3. At his first news conference since taking office, President Reagan announced the abolition of a Federal agency that was established six years ago. What agency is it?

title: DRIVER FOR SLAIN MOBSTER CONVICTED OF PERJURY
description: John Stanfa, the driver of the car in which Angelo Bruno, a reputed organized crime leader was slain last March, was convicted today of lying to a Federal grand jury investigating Mr. Bruno's death.

title: Increase Seen For Stockpiles
description: President Reagan's pledge to improve military preparedness will lead to increased purchases for the national defense stockpile of strategic metals and other materials, United States officials say.

title: 'Amadeus' Players Return, But Macbeth Is Out Sick
description: Jane Seymour and Ian McKellen returned Thursday to the cast of ''Amadeus,'' the Peter Shaffer play at the Broadhurst Theater, after missing several performances because of illness.

title: Educational Broadcasting Elects Piercy as Chairman
description: George T. Piercy has been elected chairman of the board of trustees of the Educational Broadcasting Corporation, parent company of WNETTV. Mr. Piercy has been a member of the station's board since 1967 and its vice chairman since 1973.

title: Tenneco to Expand Louisiana Refinery
description: Tenneco Inc. plans a $400 million expansion and modernization of its refinery at Chalmett, La., that will increase the plant's crude oil capacity by about 30 percent and raise gasoline production 50 percent.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report on Jan. 23 gave an incorrect site for the Ashokan reservoir. It is in Ulster County, N.Y.

title: A Year, at Most, for Arms Control
description: Eight years after President Nixon began negotiating for SALT II, five years after President Ford pinned down the essence of the deal and 18 months after President Carter signed the treaty, President Reagan is reviewing arms control all over again. A review, to be sure, is better than rejection. But at some point in diplomacy, delay becomes defeat.

title: Sports of The Times; Last Laugh for Lou Johnson
description: IN empty sun-drenched Dodger Stadium, a band of irregulars frolicked round the bases at the end of a joyous ritual, baseball in January.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's been said that Americans are much more comfortable with their feelings about their country - much more united. Well let me tell you, to the extent that we had something to do with that feeling, we are profoundly grateful, and it made everything we went through worthwhile.'' - Moorhead C. Kennedy Jr., a former hostage. (28:5.)

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Rival tribesmen fought each other with bows and arrows at a black-market trading post on the outskirts of the Ugandan capital, the authorities said today. Customers from the Acholi tribe in the north, one of President Milton Obote's strongholds, went to the trading post yesterday to buy corn, beans, melon, potatoes and peas, which are unavailable at official marketplaces. They were refused service by merchants who belong to the Baganda tribe.

title: OUTPUT OFF
description: The Government index intended to forecast future economic trends dropped by eight tenths of 1 percent in December after rising for six consecutive months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Silvio A. Mastrianni, 60, Is Dead; Legislative Leader in Connecticut
description: State Representative Silvio A. Mastrianni, the Derby Democrat who was the majority whip of the Connecticut House of Representatives, died yesterday at Griffin Hospital here. He was 60 years old.

title: Henderson Among 4 to Sign Met Contracts
description: The Mets swept the field clear of contract hassles yesterday when four players agreed to terms, including three who had filed notices that they intended to carry their salary disputes to arbitration.

title: WOMEN'S STUDIES COURSES
description: Women's studies may be a fairly new educational discipline, but this spring more than 200 courses on the subject will be offered in New York.

title: No Headline
description: CONNORS AND GERULAITIS OUSTED

title: U.S. MOVES TO EXPEL GROUP OF HAITIANS
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service moved today to expel 3,900 Haitians who have entered the United States since Oct. 11 last year.

title: A Bad Bet for Connecticut
description: Connecticut's tightening budget bind has officials searching for new ways to raise revenue. Some legislators, gratified by the state's moneymaking lotteries and other gaming enterprises, think it should now venture into casino gambling. State Representative John Murphy of Bridgeport, whose city has been mentioned as a new Las Vegas, wants casinos legalized immediately. State Representative Abraham Giles of Hartford, only a bit more cautious, has called for a one-year feasibility study.

title: THE FAST-FOOD RUSH BRAZIL
description: With a huge number of people under the age of 18, an informal style of living and a population already accustomed to stand-up lunch counter service, it was just a matter of time before this sunny land would fall under the shadows of the golden arches.

title: JERSEY VIOLATORS OF WATER LIMITS FINED $4 MILLION
description: Notices of fines totaling $4.2 million have been mailed in recent days to thousands of homes and industries in northern New Jersey in the first concerted campaign by water companies to stop violations of a four-month-old water rationing plan covering six counties.

title: FEAR OF RADIATION
description: In November 1979, the use of radioisotopes in nuclear medicine and medical investigation almost came to a halt when the only two burial sites used for disposal of the wastes generated by these uses were closed by orders of the governors of the two states in which they were situated, South Carolina and Washington. In doing so, they indicated that every region should be responsible for its own radioactive waste.

title: POLAND AND UNION REPORT AN ACCORD ON 2 MAJOR ISSUES
description: After 13 hours of talks, the Government and leaders of the Solidarity trade union movement reported agreement early this morning on two of the three major issues that had caused strikes throughout the country.

title: MOM-POP ECONOMICS
description: As an attorney and libertarian, I am besieged with the plaintive cries of average citizens who feel that some arm of the state is reducing their cherished freedom to bureaucratic dust. However, until recently, I never had the time or the inclination to perceive one particularly insidious form of repression that awaits the dutiful citizen of the 1980's: compulsory consumption.

title: CITY OPENS ITS HEART TO FREED HOSTAGES
description: With a rare fervor for a city accustomed to spectacle, New York lionized the freed American hostages yesterday in a torrent of ticker tape, cheers and patriotism.

title: THE REGION
description: New Jersey's Medicaid deficit vanished as Governor Byrne signed into law an appropriations bill to cover the $50 million shortfall. The measure approved by Mr. Byrne appropriates $5.7 million in general funds for the Department of Human Services and transfers as many unexpended funds as needed from other departments.

title: Canada to Guarantee De Havilland Loans
description: The Canadian Government announced that it would guarantee loans up to $450 million (Canadian) in connection with development and production of a short takeoff and landing aircraft by the Government-owned De Havilland Aircraft of Canada Ltd.

title: U.S. Honda Raises Prices
description: The American Honda Motor Company said today that it had raised prices for its cars an average of 4.2 percent, or $276, effective next Monday.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Ecuador denied today that Peru had recaptured positions held by Ecuadorean forces. A military communique said, ''Nothing new has happened.''

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 18. 1. To aid in restraining the deranged, a net is cast over a mentally disturbed person after a harmless mixture in the fire extinguisher has been sprayed on him to disorient him.

title: Falwell Wins Court Curb On Penthouse Distribution
description: Federal Judge James C. Turk today prohibited Penthouse magazine from distributing its March issue at the request of the Rev. Jerry Falwell, the founder of Moral Majority, who says a Penthouse interview with him was obtained by deceit.

title: PRESIDENT SELLS $740,000 IN ASSETS AND PUTS THE CASH IN A BLIND TRUST
description: The White House said today that President Reagan had liquidated many of his assets and placed the cash in a blind trust to avoid any appearance of a conflict of interest.

title: AIRBORNE
description: Peter Wirnsberger of Austria practicing yesterday for today's World Cup downhill in Anton, Austria.

title: STOCKHOLDERS BACK RAPID-KENTON LINK
description: Stockholders of the Rapid-American Corporation and the Kenton Corporation yesterday approved a merger that would make Rapid a privately held company with only two owners.

title: STOCKS CLOSE ON EVEN KEEL
description: An early rally in blue chips lost its momemtum yesterday afternoon, but strength in railroads, chemicals and selected issues kept the stock market on a relatively even keel.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: METS (NL) - Signed Pete Falcone, p itcher, to two-year contract; Bob Bailor, i nfielder-outfielder, to three-year contract; S teve Henderson, outfielder, to one-year c ontract, and Ed Glynn, relief pitcher, to o ne-year contract. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Signed 13 players: Ken O berkfell, Mike Calise and Mike Ramsey, i nfielders; Silvio Martinez, Larry Sorenson, B ob Shirley, George Frazier, John Fulgh- a m, John Stupor and John Sykes, pitchers; G lenn Brummer, catcher, and Dane Iorg a nd Gene Roof, outfielders.

title: Ermine, Skin And Bones
description: It is still unclear whether we are supposed to shout ''Whoopee!'' or ''Shame!'' about the new elegance the Reagans are bringing to Washington. I speak of the new elegance cautiously. Not having made an on-site inspection as yet of Washington's Reaganized salons, I am dependent on the Washington reporters for information about social conditions down there, and ''the new elegance'' runs through their copy like melted butter through popcorn.

title: Great Basins Sells Properties to ENEX
description: The Great Basins Petroleum Company announced the sale of its domestic oil and gas properties to the Houston-based ENEX Resources Corporation for about $37.1 million in cash and stock.

title: 250,000 Said to Be Faced With Famine in Uganda
description: A quarter of a million people in northwestern Uganda are threatened with famine because strife and drought have cut their harvest by two-thirds, a United Nations official said today.

title: BALLET: 'HISTORIC SOLDAT,' NEW WORK BY MARTINS
description: Peter Martins's new ballet for the New York City Ballet is called ''Suite From Histoire du Soldat,'' and it is just that - a suite of dances from the music Stravinsky composed for a well-known theater piece he produced in 1918.

title: FOX PLAN TO GO PRIVATE HAS SUDDENLY COLLAPSED
description: A $500 million deal to convert the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation into a private company collapsed yesterday without explanation.

title: KOTSOPOULOS OF RANGERS IN HOSPITAL FOR AILING ARM
description: Chris Kotsopoulos of the Rangers has been admitted to Lenox Hill Hospital for treatment of an infection in his right arm.

title: No Headline
description: Some dermatologists, who traditionally have been hostile to cosmetic products, are lending their names (and sometimes financial backing) to rouges and powders and potions, substances that they once dismissed as the root of many complexion ills.

title: GREENWICH VILLAGE DOESN'T NEED EXPENSIVE CO-OPS
description: To the Editor:

title: 'KAMIKAZE MISSION' WAS PLANNED TO KILL CAPTORS, MARINE DISCLOSES
description: Several of the Marine guards held hostage in Iran had plans to sacrifice their lives next month in a ''kamikaze mission'' intended to kill as many of their captors as possible, one of those involved in the plot said today.

title: AIDE TERMS REAGAN NOT EAGER TO HOLD BIG HOSTAGE INQUIRY
description: The Reagan Administration, eager to turn public attention back to the the President's economic program, is unenthusiastic about prolonged investigations of the Iranian hostage crisis, a senior White House official said today.

title: Extension Granted In A.T.& T. Suit
description: A Federal judge reluctantly agreed to extend to March 2 his deadline for the Reagan Administration to decide whether it will support a settlement of the huge antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: 1,223d Straight Performance for 'Compulsive' Actress
description: ''I don't mind saying it - I'm a compulsive person, have been all my life, always on time, never missing a day of school or work,'' Marian Seldes was saying yesterday at the Juilliard School, where she teaches acting. ''That's because time is all we have and it mustn't be wasted.''

title: Stoic in Greece
description: When officials at Craig Hill Elementary School, in Greece, N.Y., a Rochester suburb, set out to obtain the services of a guest expert on Greek, they were surprised to receive an acceptance from Robert Stuart Fitzgerald, the prize-winning translator of the ''Iliad'' and the ''Odyssey.''

title: Kaiser Steel Posts Earnings Gain
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation announced yesterday that an $84.1 million gain on the sale of 4.5 million shares of Kaiser Resources Ltd. lifted earnings for the fourth quarter of 1980 to $73.9 million, or $10.50 a share, from $5.8 million, or 80 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1979.

title: BOXING PROMOTER LINKED TO BANK EMBEZZLEMENT
description: Muhammad Ali Professional Sports, Inc., the co-promoter of a major boxing program scheduled for Feb. 23 in Madison Square Garden, is linked to a California bank embezzlement investigation, according to an article published yesterday in The Los Angeles Herald-Examiner.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: EYE IN THE SKY

title: Tesoro Retirement
description: James C. Phelps, president of the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation, the San Antonio-based oil and gas company, announced that he will retire April 1. Mr. Phelps, 58 years old, denied that his retirement was a surprise move. The company said that no decision had been made concerning his replacement.

title: MANUFACTURERS HANOVER'S L.I. GROWTH
description: In sharp contrast to a flurry of plans by major New York banks to move some of their operations outside New York State, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company announced yesterday that it was planning a major expansion of its consumer-credit operations on Long Island.

title: PROTECT OUR POLICE OFFICERS' LIVES
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Bombs Exploded in Somalia
description: Two bombs exploded in the embassy district of Mogadishu, the Somali capital, in the latest of a series of attacks for which an underground opposition group has claimed responsibility, Western diplomatic sources said today. There were no casualties and damage was said to be light.

title: MAN IS FOUND GUILTY OF KILLING AN OFFICER IN HARLEM LAST YEAR
description: After five days of deliberation, a State Supreme Court jury yesterday found Rodney Bailey guilty of the murder of an undercover police officer in a Harlem alley last year.

title:
ABOUT NEW YORK;
SOME WHO SERVED AND WERE NOT TREATED TO PARADES
description: Bobby Muller is spending a lot of time these days trying to soothe the tortured feelings of his fellow veterans of the Vietnam War even as he fights to keep a rein on his own bitterness.

title: REAGAN TO MEET PRESS INFORMALLY EACH WEEK
description: President Reagan intends to hold informal, weekly meetings with reporters beginning next week, his chief spokesman said today.

title: Petro-Canada Deal Rumored
description: Oil industry sources said today that PetroCanada, the Government-owned oil company, was negotiating to buy Petrofina Canada Ltd., the Canadian subsidiary of the Belgian oil company Petrofina S.A.

title: RABBI MORDECAI MAYER
description: Rabbi Mordecai Mayer, leader for 20 years of the First Roumanian American Congregation at 28 Rivington Street in Manhattan, died Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital at the age of 65.

title: Index; International
description: Norway's Prime Minister resigns after 5 years in office 3 Chinese Premier promises to support Thais against Vietnam 4 Around the World 6 Tass accuses Reagan of distorting Soviet policy 6 Government/Politics Interior Dept. orders de-emphasis of endangered species list 8 Despite a Reagan freeze order, some new rules may take effect 10 General Around the Nation 8 Pilot training brings noise and money to town in Montana 8 New Yorkers provide a diverse welcome for former hostages 25 A regular cast of characters views the Harris trial 26 Boy, 15, drives subway train from Penn Station down IND line 27 Jury convicts man of murdering undercover officer in Harlem 27 The City 27 The Region 27 Hostages planned a mission to kill captors, a Marine reveals 28 Health/Science California whales leap as if for joy at increase 8 Education/Welfare More than 2,200 elderly people attend meeting on aging 26 Arts/Entertainment Ad Reinhardt paintings at the Whitney Museum 13 New York City Ballet presents Peter Martins's ''Soldat'' 13 Revue at Perry Street Theater, ''Romance Is ...'' 13 ''Collected Stories of Elizabeth Bowen'' reviewed 16 Bernstein conducts 3 works by Copland 18 Limon Company dances ''Kitchen Table'' at City Center 18 Film ''Maniac'' opens at theaters around city 47 Style Consumer Saturday: A phone center for the disabled 17 The question of doctor-backed cosmetics 17 Tissue-paper fashion: Is it an art? 17 De Gustibus: Crispness fails test 17 Obituaries Cozy Cole, jazz drummer 11 Msgr. J. Jerome Reddy, once of Brooklyn diocese 11 Sports Walton accepts that his playing career is over 19 Mets sign Henderson and three others 19 George Vecsey on the rehabilitation of Lou Johnson 19 Chandler is a small boxer with large ambitions 19 Boxing promoter linked to bank embezzlement inquiry 20 Briscoe loses split decision to Ortiz at Felt Forum 20 Fibak upsets Connors to gain tennis semifinal 20 Pro Hockey Notebook 21 Crosby golf postponed again 21

title: Chiropractors Lose Suit Against Medical Groups
description: A Federal court jury today returned verdicts of not guilty in a civil antitrust suit against the American Medical Association, 15 other state and national medical groups and several individuals by five chiropractors.

title: THE AMERICANIZATION OF THE VEGETABLE GARDEN
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ PERCUSSIONIST
description: William R. Cole, the jazz drummer known professionally as Cozy Cole and who played with Cab Calloway, Louis Armstrong and Benny Goodman, died of cancer Thursday at Ohio State University Hospital in Columbus. Mr. Cole, who was 71 years old, had lived in Columbus since 1976, when he became artist in residence and student lecturer at Capital Universty.

title: A FAILED FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE?
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME SALES FELL BY 25% LAST YEAR
description: Sales of new one-family houses plummeted 25 percent last year, with the downward trend continuing through December, the Government reported today.

title: Sperry Lifts Prices On Some Computers
description: The Sperry Corporation, which manufactures and markets electronic data processing systems and services for commercial and other applications, raised prices from 5 to 15 percent on selected Sperry Univac computer systems, software support and maintenance services, effective April 1.

title: NEW RULES MAY TAKE EFFECT DESPITE DIRECTING BY REAGAN
description: Four days before President Reagan took office, the Federal Register, a daily bulletin of Government activities and announcements, was so filled with new regulations that two additional volumes were published. Among the regulations that came out Jan. 16 were new definitions of grades for frozen brussels sprouts and new rules aimed at protecting the hearing of workers at their workplaces.

title: AMERADA DECLINES, AS DOES MCDONNELL
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980 slipped 10.3 percent on an increase in sales of 6.1 percent.

title: Peru Says It Recaptures 2 Positions From Ecuador
description: Peru said today that its forces had recaptured two of three positions held by Ecuadorean troops in Peru's northern jungle region on the third day of their border conflict.

title: CHINA'S PREMIER REASSURES THAIS
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China pledged tonight that Peking would stand by the non-Communist countries of Southeast Asia against foreign aggression.

title: Youth, 14, Indicted In 'Roulette' Killing
description: A 14-year-old Brooklyn boy was indicted for murder in connection with the ''Russian roulette'' death of a 13-year-old girl last week.

title: ELIZABETH CORBETT
description: Elizabeth Corbett, a novelist, poet and short-story writer, died Jan. 24 at her home in Manhattan. She was 93 years old.

title: L.I. Pilot, 18, Survives Crash on First Solo
description: An 18-year-old student pilot making his first solo flight escaped serious injury when his single-engine plane crashed into a vacant house here.

title: CITIBANK CUTS PRIME TO 19 1 2%
description: Amid declining short-term interest rates and predictions that further declines are possible, Citibank and the United California Bank cut their prime lending rates yesterday to 19 1/2 percent from 20 percent.

title: Bass Brothers Buys Blue Bell Shares
description: Bass Brothers Enterprises Inc., which is engaged in the oil and gas business, said it had purchased in the open market about 6.8 percent of the 12.5 million common shares of Blue Bell Inc., a major manufacturer of jeans.

title: Nuclear Power Station in Jersey Is Closed by Problem in a Turbine
description: The Salem Nuclear Generating Station was taken out of service today when oil lubricating a generator turbine reached excessively high temperatures, a spokesman for Public Service Electric and Gas Company said.

title: BALDWIN-UNITED BUYING S. & H.
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation, a diversified financial services and musical instruments company, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Sperry & Hutchinson Company for $366 million.

title: Harvard Beats Columbia For 4th Straight, 61 to 58
description: Joe Carrabino scored 20 points, 14 in the second half, and helped lift Harvard to a 61-58 Ivy League triumph over Columbia tonight. It was the Crimson's fourth straight victory.

title: Nik Kleinberg Brooklyn Group to Monitor Courts City Councilman Abraham G. Gerges speaking to 80 Brooklyn community representatives. The group was formed yesterday to put area residents in the courts to follow cases and make sure that criminals are sentenced rather than put back on the streets. Judge Louis R.
description: Rosenthal of the Kings County Criminal Court, who adjourned a trial to attend the meeting at Brooklyn Technical College, told the group, ''One of the biggest contributions you can make is to make sure witnesses are available.'' The program was established by Mr. Gerges.

title: FARMERS' PRICES OFF IN JANUARY
description: Prices received by farmers for raw products dropped eight-tenths of 1 percent in January from December but still averaged 11 percent higher than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: SOVIET ACCUSES REAGAN OF DISTORTION
description: In the first Soviet response to President Reagan's assault yesterday on the morality of the Kremlin leadership, Tass, the official press agency, said tonight that the President had engaged in ''deliberate distortions of the aims and character'' of Soviet policy.

title: SHOULD REAGAN HONOR DEAL WITH IRAN?
description: As the national celebration over the safe return of the 52 Americans held hostage by Iran draws to a close, the debate over whether to revoke or honor the complex agreements that led to their release may only be beginning.

title: TO PROVE THE N.R.A. RIGHT--OR WRONG
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE* 19.50 20.00 15.25 DISCOUNT RATE** 13.00 13.00 12.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 17.29 16.98 13.44 3-MO. TREASURY BILLS 14.48 14.90 12.20 6-MO. TREASURY BILLS 13.58 13.94 12.06 TREASURY NOTES 12.65 12.77 11.33 TREASURY BONDS 12.21 12.34 11.17 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 13.35 13.40 12.30 MUNICIPAL BONDS 11.00 11.00 8.00 6-MONTH SAVINGS 14.371 CERTIFICATES * Split rate, 19.50-20.00 ** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BILL WALTON'S CAREER APPEARS TO BE OVER, HIS PHYSICIAN SAYS
description: Bill Walton, who was once the National Basketball Association's preeminent center, has accepted the fact that his career is over at the age of 28, Dr. Tony Daly, his orthopedic surgeon, said yesterday.

title: HARRIS TRIAL'S REGULAR CAST OF VIEWERS
description: For all its contentious drama and high profile, the trial of Jean S. Harris for the murder of Dr. Herman Tarnower has settled into patterns as predictable and familiar as a Westchester home's family room. And much of the time, its atmosphere is almost that congenial.

title: Pro Hockey Notebook;  N.H.L. Statistics Promise a Record Season
description: Paced by Mike Bossy's 50 goals in 50 games, the National Hockey League is midway through a record season for scoring, according to first-half statistics. The 3,194 goals scored and 25,141 shots taken work out to a 12.7 scoring percentage, highest for any half-season in the 24 seasons such statistics have been tabulated.

title: Progress Reported In the War on Rats
description: The number of rat-free blocks in the city has increased 41 percent as a result of the Bureau of Pest Control's rat-patrol program, according to the City Health Commissioner, Dr. Reinaldo A. Ferrer.

title: SATURDAY, JANUARY 31, 1981
description: International Agreement was reached in Poland between the Government and the striking Solidarity trade union on two of three key issues. The Government accepted the principle of a 40-hour workweek with three of every four Saturdays to be nonworking days. Solidarity also won a one hour weekly television show. The third issue - legal registration for an independent union for farmers - was not resolved. (Page 1, Column 1.) In the first major internal dispute of the new Administration, Secretary of State Alexander B. Haig assailed the proposal made by David A. Stockman, the President's budget director, for a $2.6 billion cut in the $8.6 billion foreign aid authoriztion requested by the Carter Administration for the 1982 fiscal year. Mr. Haig, backed by the Treasury Department, cited his concern for pledges made to Western allies. (1:2.)

title:
PATENTS;
Device Helps in Cloning Mammalian Cells in Lab
description: Laboratory apparatus for cloning mammalian cells has been developed at the National Center for Toxicological Research in Jefferson, Ark.

title: Bridge: If an Accidental Bid Works, Why Not Call It Intentional
description: There are a few eccentric bidding coups that happen more often by accident than design. But the true ratio is hard to determine, for the leading character always insists, quite loudly, that he knew exactly what he was doing.

title: IDEALOGICAL BLINDERS TO MURDER ABROAD?
description: To the Editor:

title: WATER USE IN CITY IN LAST 12 DAYS IS CUT BY 71 MILLION GALLONS DAILY
description: In the 12 days since Mayor Koch declared a drought emergency, water consumption in New York has dropped by an average of 71 million gallons a day. The figure cheers city officials and seems to indicate that appeals for water conservation are being taken seriously.

title: Williams Wins High Jump At 6-10 in P.S.A.L. Meet
description: Eldred Williams of the High School of Music and Art cleared 6 feet 10 inches and won the high jump last night at the Royal Business Schools meet for boys and girls teams of the Public Schools Athletic League.

title: Expulsion From Annapolis In Sex Case Is Upheld
description: Federal District Judge Joseph Young today upheld the expulsion of a senior at the United States Naval Academy who admitted participating in and filming a sexual encounter involving five midshipmen, including a woman, in an academy dormitory.

title: The Economy
description: The index of leading economic indicators fell 0.8 percent in December after rising for six straight months, the Commerce Department reported. Most economists regarded the single-month decline in the index, which is designed to forecast future economic trends, as inconclusive. Also, the Labor Department said that productivity - output per worker - fell at a sharp 1.9 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter. (Page 29.)

title: REASON FOR JOY AND NATIONAL PRIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: Site Panel Approves Power Plant on S.I.
description: A state siting board yesterday approved the building of a coaland garbage-fired power plant on the west side of Staten Island. The decision on the State Power Authority's proposed Arthur Kill plant, by a vote of 4 to 1, came after more than six years of controversy.

title: Court-Martial Judge Narrows Garwood Charges
description: The judge in the court-martial of Pfc. Robert R. Garwood of the Marines today deleted allegations that Private Garwood had extolled Communism and called fellow prisoners of war ''criminals of war'' while a captive of the North Vietnamese.

title: ORTIZ WINS ON A SPLIT DECISION
description: Before Bennie Briscoe fought Nick Ortiz at the Felt Forum last night, there had been some feeling that a victory would encourage Briscoe to continue his career at the age of 37.

title: MRS. HARRIS TELLS COURT SHE WANTED HER SUICIDE TO BE 'A PRIVATE DEATH'
description: Jean S. Harris, ending her fourth day on the witness stand today, denied that her intended suicide was meant to be ''a big last act.'' She said: ''I had led a private life and wanted to die a private death.''

title: Vermont Rail Oil Spill Contained
description: A railroad tank car ruptured early today, spilling about 8,000 gallons of diesel fuel between the tracks and over embankments near the junction of the White and Connecticut rivers. The rail bed prevented oil from reaching either river.

title: News Analysis
description: Proposals to break the suburban commuter railroads away from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority seem to be multiplying as quickly as the breakdowns on its various lines.

title: Renault Planning Layoffs in France
description: Renault, one of Europe's largest auto makers, announced that it was being forced to cut production and will lay off workers at four of its 12 plants in France for two days next month.

title: 305 Dead in Indonesian Quake
description: An earthquake in Irian Jaya has killed at least 305 people, a spokesman for the province said today. Rescue teams are still searching for about 1,000 missing villagers in the district of Kurina Areal, near the border of Papua New Guinea.

title: Korean Asks Americans For Firmer Business Ties
description: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea urged American business leaders yesterday to redouble their efforts to strengthen economic ties with his country.

title: SERVED IN BROOKLYN
description: Msgr. J. Jerome Reddy, the director of Catholic Charities for the Diocese of Brooklyn from 1930 until 1959, died Thursday at the rectory of St. Jude's Church in Tuquesta, Fla., where he had served as associate priest since 1966. He was 92 years old.

title: Jim Dale Marrying
description: The long-expected marriage of Jim Dale, star of ''Barnum'' on Broadway, and Julie Schafler, a Madison Avenue gallery owner, will take place March 23.

title: BRIEFS
description: * British Petroleum Corporation agreed in principle to buy the 75 percent interest it does not own in BOC Subocean Services Ltd., an underwater welding company, from BOC International Ltd.

title: Bombing Destroys Section Of a Courthouse in Paris
description: A bomb destroyed a section of the main Paris courthouse early today and two terrorist groups said they were responsible, the police said.

title: A PHONE CENTER FOR DISABLED
description: W ITH the aid of sign language from a licensed interpreter for the deaf and the traditional ribbon-cutting ceremony (yellow for the hostages), the New York Telephone Company Thursday officially opened its new Communications Center for Disabled Customers at 1095 Avenue of the Americas near 42d Street.

title: Crosby Pro-Am Is Put Off Again
description: For the first time in the 40-year history of the Bing Crosby National Pro-Am golf tournament, the opening round was canceled a second time because of unplayable conditions on the three courses on which play rotates. The Monterey Peninsula has been deluged with more than five inches of rain that has fallen intermittently since Tuesday.

title: CROWD'S CHEERS MINGLE WITH JUST A FEW GRUMBLES
description: In lower Manhattan, New Yorkers erupted in screams and cheers to welcome the former hostages on their procession through the paperclogged streets.

title: Handy's Daughter Predicts More Stormy Weather
description: An unusual weather prediction came the other day from an unusual source, Katharine Handy Lewis, the 78-year-old daughter of W.C. Handy, the legendary blues musician.

title: News Analysis
description: In ruling Monday that there is nothing inherently unconstitutional about televising criminal trials, the Supreme Court widened rather than ended the debate over whether television helps or hinders the administration of justice.

title: 'Music in Ancient Israel' Opening at Yeshiva U.
description: ''Music in Ancient Israel,'' an exhibition including copies of musical instruments such as rattles, sistra, cymbals, bells, flutes, conches and shofars, will open tomorrow at the Yeshiva University Museum, Amsterdam Avenue and 185th Street.

title: SOUTH BRONX IS A PLACE TO BUILD
description: To the Editor:

title: REV. MICHAEL F. M'PHELIN
description: The Rev. Michael F. McPhelin, a Jesuit who was a former dean of the Fordham University School of Business, died Jan. 21 in Manila. He was 70 years old.

title: KEY SPANISH PARTY PICKS NEXT PREMIER
description: Deputy Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo was designated by Spain's badly divided governing party today as the successor to Adolfo Suarez, who resigned yesterday as Prime Minister.

title: STUDY FINDS TNT WASTE MAY BE AT UPSTATE DUMP
description: A New York State Assembly study group has found indications of potentially dangerous TNT contamination on the property of a toxicwaste landfill near Niagara Falls and has called for further tests, according to sources familiar with an announcement scheduled for today.

title: Dance: 'Kitchen Table' at City Center
description: What can you do with a kitchen table? Lots of things. You can sit at it. You can prepare meals on it. You can dine at it. You can hide under it. You can gather around it and squabble.

title: Largest Trash Converter
description: UOP Inc., a subsidiary of the Signal Companies Inc., said it planned to build the country's largest trash-to-electricity conversion plant, in North Andover, Mass. The $74 million plant, to be operated by the New England Power Company, will generate up to 150 million kilowatt hours of electricity a year and consume up to 465,000 tons of solid waste from 50 communities daily.

title: RIDERS UNAWARE AS BOY, 15, OPERATES IND TRAIN
description: A 15-year-old Queens boy took over the controls of a subway train Thursday night and operated it as its passengers rode unaware for six stops from 34th Street to the World Trade Center, transit authorities reported.

title: PLACING SPECIES ON DANGER LIST DE-EMPHASIZED
description: The Interior Department, in a significant policy change, is de-emphasizing its efforts to place on its endangered species list animals and plants that are faced with extinction.

title: THE UNION CAME FIRST
description: ''All of us - all of us need to be reminded that the Federal Government did not create the states; the states created the Federal Government.''

title: REVUE: RELATIONS BETWEEN SEXES IN 'ROMANCE IS...'
description: Just in time for Valentine's Day comes ''Romance Is ...'' - a musical revue that tries to find fun in the fact that there happen to be two sexes. It is a show with a single point in mind -the relations between men and women, a subject that offers ample opportunity to develop practically anything in practically any way, as writers have been proving since they took up the challenge from the oral storytellers.

title: 5 Energy Board Resignations
description: President Reagan today accepted the resignations he requested from the five persons his predecessor appointed on an interim basis to the new United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation board.

title: Somalian Seeks to Stay in U.S.
description: Somalia's Ambassador to the United States has asked to become a permanent resident. The State Department said today that Ambassador Mohamed Warsame had requested a change in his status from that of a diplomat.

title: TRUDEAU PRESSES HIS PLAN DESPITE LONDON SETBACK
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau today rejected all efforts to alter his constitutional plans despite a major setback in the British Parliament.

title: News Analysis
description: When Manhattan Cable, which serves most of Manhattan below 86th Street with cable television, recently announced a $20 million program to add program services and make technological improvements in its system, it raised anew questions about the quality of local cable service.

title: Tapping the Hudson
description: Gathered at the salty mouth of the Hudson River, New Yorkers resemble the Ancient Mariner and his comrades: water everywhere, but maybe not enough to drink. Thus the City's Department of Environmental Conservation deserves credit for doing what it can to squeeze some potable water from a point 60 miles upriver.

title: Small Boxer Reachs Big Time
description: There are heavyweights twice his size, but Jeff Chandler, a former waterbed maker who became the first American-born bantamweight champion in 30 years, still has a right to think small is big. Cars are getting smaller, too.

title: John Artis Seeking Release on Illness
description: John Artis is suffering from a ''potentially life-threatening disease'' and should be released from prison so he can receive medical treatment, his attorney said in court papers.

title: PROCEEDS FROM STOCK SOURCE FOR DONATIONS TO FUND FOR NEEDIEST
description: Many supporters of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund donate the proceeds from the sale of common stock. Ruth M. Berlin of Southport, Conn., contributed $5,215.57 from the sale of 155 shares of Melville Corporation stock.

title: Books of The Times
description: Breakfast, Other Woes By ANATOLE BROYARD THE COLLECTED STORIES OF ELIZA- BETH BOWEN. 784 pages. Knopf. $17.95.

title: Bettelheim to Open Wise Lecture Series; Bettelheim to Open Wise Lecture Series
description: Dr. Bruno Bettelheim, the child psychologist, will give the first Patricia Wise Lecture at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington next Tuesday. The lectures, which are sponsored by the American Film Institute, will examine the importance of the moving image as an art form and as a force in people's lives.

title:
PATENTS;
'Smart Noise Generator' Confuses Enemy Radar
description: Daniel D. Mawhinney, a technical staff member at RCA Laboratories, Princeton, N.J., was granted a patent this week for a ''smart noise generator'' - a microwave circuit arrangement called ''smart'' because it may help friendly aircraft or surface vessels prevent hostile tracking radars from pinpointing their positions.

title: KOREAN MOLDED BY ARMY FIFE
description: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea, who was in New York today prior to his visit to Washington and talks with President Reagan on Monday, is a military man. A paratroop officer who served in Vietnam, he was an unknown army intelligence chief under President Park Chung Hee when Mr. Park was murdered by the head of his own secret service in October 1979.

title: DENMARK'S NAZI-INSPIRED CRIME WAVE OF 1944
description: To the Editor:

title: Oilfield Off California
description: the Shell Oil Company reported the start of oil production from the Beta field nine miles off the California coast from Huntington Beach.

title: HOLISTIC POLITICAL HEALTH
description: ''Man is by nature a political animal,'' observed Aristotle, and in no realm of culture do we betray our natures more than when we consciously withdraw from political activities because of ''alienation,'' ''a sense of futility,'' or lesser reasons of other commitments.

title: GRAY WHALES IN REVIVAL OFF CALIFORNIA
description: For so huge a creature, the California gray whale is ponderously graceful, erupting from the Pacific swells in easy arcs, so big the sea itself bulges as it lifts to the surface, breaking the blue-green water with an audible cascade.

title: Tradewinds
description: Governor Carey, who has said he wants the ''I Love New York'' song to remain high on Japan's hit parade, will leave today for Tokyo and Hong Kong on an 11-day journey to promote New York business.

title: Tentative Accord Set at Roosevelt
description: Negotiators in the Roosevelt Raceway dispute reached another tentative agreement today to end the 12-day strike at the harness track, which has been closed since last Monday.

title: HOMICIDAL MANIAC
description: Good sense, if not heaven, should protect anyone who thinks he likes horror films from wasting a price of admission on ''Maniac,'' a movie that shows how an aging, pot-bellied maniac slices up young women of no great intelligence.

title: HAIG FIGHTS PROPOSAL FOR DRASTIC REDUCTION IN FOREIGN ASSISTANCE
description: In the first major internal dispute of the new Administration, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., backed by the Treasury Department, began a counterattack today against a proposal for drastic reductions in the foreign aid program proposed by David A. Stockman, President Reagan's budget director.

title: Miller to Rejoin Federated Board
description: G. William Miller, Secretary of the Treasury in the Carter Administration, has been re-elected to the board of directors of Federated Department Stores Inc., the company announced today.

title: ART: WHITNEY SHOWING AD REINHARDT COLLAGES
description: Through Feb. 8, the Whitney Museum of American Art has on view, as part of its ''Concentrations'' series, a group of paintings and collages by Ad Reinhardt (1913-67). It fills the small ground-floor room that has been set aside since January of last year for the ''Concentrations,'' and it also spills over into the basement, where Reinhardt's satirical collages form, in effect, a small separate show of their own.

title: CITY'S ELDERLY URGE FEDERAL HELP FOR THEIR MOST CRITICAL PROBLEMS
description: Elderly people from every borough, meeting at the New York Citywide White House Conference on Aging yesterday, advocated Federal solutions to the problems that concern them most - economic security, adequate housing, transportation, medical care and crime prevention.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS ATTACK REBELS IN MOZAMBIQUE CAPITAL
description: South African forces raided Maputo, the capital of Mozambique, last night, hitting operational headquarters of the African National Congress, a banned movement that has been responsible for a series of sporadic sabotage and small-scale attacks on targets in this country that are symbolic of white power.

title: Amex Removes A.G. Becker
description: The American Stock Exchange said its market performance committee had removed A.G. Becker Inc. as specialist in the stock of PetroLewis Corporation because of the sharp price swings in the shares during the much-publicized Joseph Granville market slide on Jan. 7.
